KNOWN_AS: The White Lion, St. Thomas Street
MONUMENT_DESC: The White Lion Inn, located on the eastern side of St. Thomas Street. The building was a gabled, jettied house of three storeys and attic with a one-window range and a rusticated quoin against the house to the south. The main entrance was on the north side of the west-facing elevation and had a porch supported on bracket. There was a seventeenth-century style post; the figure of a lion above ground-floor bay. The fenestration of the upper floors consisted of bays containing sashes at the first- and second-floors levels, while there was a sash at third-floor.

KNOWN_AS: House on the west side of Pithay
MONUMENT_DESC: House located west side of Pithay, below All Saints Street. Two doors up from "The Bell" public house. The building was a jettied, gabled house of three storeys and attic and it was probably constructed in the seventeenth century. 1-window range; first and second floors jettied; gabled front. Ground-floor not visible; oriel to first-floor, large cross-window to front; full-height bay or oriel, transomed with 6 lights to front, 2 each to sides, second-floor; attic window. Lateral stack on north side near front.

KNOWN_AS: The Swan, Mary le Port Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Swan, located on the north side of Mary le Port Street. An inn named "le Swan" had been established on the site by 1463. It was leased to George Grey (who had leased the Three Cups in Wine Street from St. James Priory) by Nicholas Willyams, tailor, later a mayor of Bristol (in 1564) (Leech 1997, 102). Williams bequeathed the leases and interest of "the tenement called "the Swanne"" to his wife Joan in his will of 1 September 1565, and the building was then recorded still to be in the tenure of George Graye (Wadley 1886, 225). The property had been acquired by the foeffees of Trinity Hospital in Old Market by 1581. It remained an inn, however, throughout.
The form of the building before the seventeenth century is unknown. However, a lane ran through the site between Mary le Port Street and Wine Street by 1615. An inventory of the property of the tenant Thomas Collier made in October 1647 recorded that the inn had eleven bedrooms, as well as two halls, the "Upper Hawll" and the "Lower Hawll", kitchen and hayloft (George & George 2002, 159-162). By 1670 the inn was known as the "White Swan." The property was subsequently acquired by the Bristol Corporation which sold it in 1730. The building was then demolished to allow the construction of "a Market Place for corn in Wine Street" (Leech 1997, 103) and this later became the Cheese Market.

No.1, Bellevue. The building is the southernmost of a terrace of nineteen houses. The plot, formerly part of the grounds associated with Clifton Hill House, was leased from the Society of Merchant Venturers by Harry Elderton in 1792 for a term of forty years (Ison 1952, 234). Construction of the terrace began under the supervision of William Paty (Priest 2003, 101) but was abandoned in 1793 when the outbreak of war caused a slump in development. The buildings remained uncompleted for nearly two decades but the terrace had apparently been completed by 1815.
The building is a rendered three-storey house with attic and basement. It has a slate mansard roof. A raised walk on the east side of the building extends the full length of the terrace.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/6).

No.3, Bellevue. The building is the southernmost of a terrace of nineteen houses. The plot, formerly part of the grounds associated with Clifton Hill House, was leased from the Society of Merchant Venturers by Harry Elderton in 1792 for a term of forty years (Ison 1952, 234). Construction of the terrace began under the supervision of William Paty (Priest 2003, 101) but was abandoned in 1793 when the outbreak of war caused a slump in development. The buildings remained uncompleted for nearly two decades but the terrace had apparently been completed by 1815.
The building is a rendered three-storey house with attic and basement. It has a slate mansard roof. A raised walk on the east side of the building extends the full length of the terrace.
In 1882 the building was occupied by C. W. Price.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/6).

No.5, Bellevue. The building is the southernmost of a terrace of nineteen houses. The plot, formerly part of the grounds associated with Clifton Hill House, was leased from the Society of Merchant Venturers by Harry Elderton in 1792 for a term of forty years (Ison 1952, 234). Construction of the terrace began under the supervision of William Paty (Priest 2003, 101) but was abandoned in 1793 when the outbreak of war caused a slump in development. The buildings remained uncompleted for nearly two decades but the terrace had apparently been completed by 1815.
The building is a rendered three-storey house with attic and basement. It has a slate mansard roof. A raised walk on the east side of the building extends the full length of the terrace.
In 1882 the building was occupied by E. C. Sampson.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/6).

KNOWN_AS: Plume of Feathers Inn, Wine Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Plume of Feathers Inn, located on the north side of Wine Street. The inn stood was around 17 metres back from the street and was reached by a passage, later known as Grand Hotel Passage, on the east side of No.7 Wine Street (BUAD 1699M). The inn was extant by the early nineteenth century and was recorded by Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 plan of Bristol. It was demolished later in the century and by the early 1880s the site was occupied by part of the Grand Hotel (BUAD 1667M).

Transit Shed, Narrow Quay. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map in the early 1880s. The building is depicted as a long shed against the quayside, with open-sided roofing on the north and south sides.

No.5 Wine Street, located on the northern side of Wine Street. A house appears to have stood on the site by the late thirteenth century.
The building was drawn in 1826 as part of a view of this part of the north side of Wine Street by T. L. Rowbotham (BRSMG M2343). At that date the shop was the premises of "BOORD WOOLLEN DRAPER." By 1882 the building was occupied by Eliza Greenway, confectioner and dining rooms
The building survived into the first half of the twentieth century but was subsequently removed and the site redeveloped.

A pair of houses. Nos. 37 & 38, Narrow Wine Street. Attached. Twin front gables with a more shallow central gully (i.e. an M-shaped roof). 3 storeys and attics; first-floors and attics/eaves jettied; 1-window ranges. Shop windows to ground-floors. Bays to first and second floors. Attic windows. 
Now largely below the modern Newgate.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Former Graham's Timber Yard, Hotwell Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Old Mill House, Limekiln Dock. The building was located on the west side of Limekiln Dock of early to mid nineteenth-century date. The building, referred to as "Old Mill" on a plan of nineteenth-century date, measured 5.8 metres wide by at least 12.4 metres long and was aligned north-north-east to south-south-west. The building was of three storeys and had four bays with a pitched pantile roof. The building was constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble bonded in a grey-white lime mortar and the walls were all approximately 0.6 metres wide. The building had a flagstone floor. In the east wall of the building there were four cellar lights, all 1.3 metres wide. The south wall of the building was knocked through during between the 1850s and 1880s to create a single large warehouse in combination with the Engine House (BUAD 1379M). The building was excavated in 1998 (BUAD 3398).

The Queen's Hall, located on the north side of Peter Street. The Queen's Hall was Bristol's first purpose-built cinema and was built for British Electric Theatres, which also owned the Kings Hall in Old Market (BUAD 1558M) (Winstone, 1972, 8). The building was unique in Bristol in that part of its roof could be opened for ventilation. This sliding roof was operated by two winches that were attached to steel cables on the roof (Winstone, 1971, 63). Photographs of the building taken in 1925 show the front of the builing with an illuminated sign for the Queen's Picture House and a view of the internal area with the sliding roof open above an empty auditorium (Winstone, 1971 pl.169-170). It opened on 24th March 1910.
The Queen's Hall was re-named the Queen's Picture House in 1915 (Winstone, 1971 pl.169-170). It was demolished in 1933 and replaced by the News Theatre (BUAD 1557M).
The site of the bulding now lies within Castle Park.
No.1 King Street. The building was part of a terrace of five houses built in c.1665 and was destroyed by bombing on 11 April 1941. Timber-framed front; gabled front and rear.

No.19 Jacobs Wells Road. Mostly one and two storey buildings forming a complex at No.19, Jacob's Wells Road, also extending to the rear of No.17. A street elevation of central vehicle entrance with one doorway to each side; 3-light casement in centre af first-floor, 1-light casement to right. Has a warehouse-like interior, with brick piers supporting roofs, also two arches to right of main entrance. There is a small squarish three-storey building in the south-west corner of the site. The site is cut back into one side of Constitution Hill. Possibly part of an eighteenth-century brewery. Erroneously thought to be the eighteenth-century theatre (which was in fact located further down the hill, now beneath Brandon House flats).

38, King Street
Theatre Royal entrance. A house forming an "interesting" front to the Theatre Royal and had a 'Dutch' gable to its front elevation. The building was demolished in 1903 (Pritchard, 1906 130).

Lawrence, Fraser warehouse, located at the junction of Moon Street and Wilder Street. The main block roughly triangular in plan, with an addition to the south from the south-east corner. 3-storey; 10-window range in the curved Moon Street elevation; 1-window range at west end; 4-window range to Wilder Street; 2-window range to right return; 3-window range to east-west wall north of old yard. Mostly coursed Pennant Sandstone rubble, but some areas of ashlar. Brick north wall to old yard. Brick dressings. String course above ground-floor (not yard walls); segmental window openings, with keystones at ground-floor; parapet. Wide doorway, vermiculated voussoirs alternating with brick voussoirs, at junction of the streets, with vermiculated keystone at first-floor, grotesque head to keystone at second. Internally, cast-iron columns supporting beams. Brick and rubble 3-storey extensions to east and south-east of old yard. Entrance to the same yard through a Bath Stone ashlar gateway with four-centred arch and enlarged keystone, the jambs largely of brick.

No.12, Orchard Street, located on the north-western side of Orchard Street. The building is a three-storey house with a brick front. The lease for the plot was granted to Peter Wilkins on 20 February 1718 and the house was presumably built soon afterwards (Ison 1952, 152-156).
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by Captain William Reed.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/151).

No.8 King Street, located on the south side of King Street. The house was constructed in 1665 as one of a pair with No.7 King Street (BUAD 11M). The building is a single-bay, jettied house with a gabled pantile roof. The main entrance is on the east side of the building and is reached by a set of four stone steps shaerd with No.8. On the west side of the doorway there is a lagre bay window. A pantiled pentice roof, which runs the full width of Nos.7 and 8, divides the ground from the first floor. The building is likely to have had pentices on the upper floors but these have apparently been removed. The fenestration at both first and second floors consists of six over six pane sash windows. The attic is lit by a smaller six over six pane sash.
The building was refenestrated in the eighteenth- or nineteenth-century. Restoration between 1967 and 1976, when it and No.8 formed the offices of Moxley, Jenner and Partners, architects, revealed the reuse of ship's timbers as structural elements within the building. Some laths were also found to be reused barrel staves.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/16/599).

The gate house to the Royal Fort. The building was constructed in the mid-seventeenth century presumably as part of the Royal Fort in 1643. It was reported by Samuel Seyer to have been the governor of Bristol's residence. The piers and gates of the Royal Fort Gatehouse have a Grade II listing. These are of mid to late eighteenth-century date and are Limestone ashlar and wrought-iron. There are also large square rusticated piers, spear-headed railings and attached spear-headed 2-leaf gates and railings.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/01/237).

St. Mary-le-Port, a parish church located to on the south side of Mary-le-port Street.
Nave, chancel and north aisle. Church tower of C15. Limestone ashlar with coursed Pennant rubble. Perpendicular Gothic with a Somerset-type tower. 3 stages divided by drip moulds, with angle buttresses and an octagonal south-east stair tower. West door; 4-light window above, and a blind 2-light window in the second stage. Belfry with 2-light louvred windows, a crenellated parapet with  corner pinnacles and a south-east spirelet. Unclerestoreyed 5-bay nave had one, north, aisle and 4-centred arches with moulded capitals. Stepped buttresses on south side. Chancel of 3 bays, and a small north-east chapel with 13th.century undercroft. South chancel windows of 3 lights in a square head. 
Interior illustrated by Johnson in 1828 (M2791), showing the nave, looking east to the altar. Other artists drew the eagle lectern (M2794), a monument, monumental shields, and a coffin with well-preserved body found in 1814, (922A) (BRSMG M2793). 
The main body of the church was destroyed by bombing during the Second World War. The footprint of the church was archaeologically excavated in 1962-63 by Philip Rahtz (Watts & Rahtz 1985).

No.27, St. Augustine's Parade. C17, rebuilt C19 and late C20. Formerly timber-framed, render, and pantile roof, gabled to front and rear. Double-depth plan. 3 storeys and attic; 2-window range. C20 shop front; shallow jetty to second floor. 6/6-pane sashes in exposed frames, a single sash to the attic. Originally timber-framed, largely remodelled 1983. Nos 26-30 (qv) are now internally one building. 
Cellared. On the second-floor, in the framing between the front windows, was a reused wooden transom from a four-light window, probably 17th.century in date. In the front room of the third-floor was a plank and batten door, possibly of the 17th.century. This building was demolished and rebuilt in 1983.

No.28, St. Augustine's Parade. Late C18. Render with limestone dressings, brick party wall stack and hipped pantile roof. Double-depth plan. 3 storeys; 1-window range. C20 shop front, and a moulded parapet coping. 2 storey 3-window canted oriel with 6/6-pane sashes, and 10/10-pane third-floor sash, in exposed frames. Nos 26-30 (qv) are now one building.
Cellared. Demolished and rebuilt in 1983.

No.29, St. Augustine's Parade. Late C18, rebuilt late C20. Brick with limestone dressings, formerly timber-frame, and a pantile hipped roof. Double-depth plan. 3 storeys and attic; 2-window range. Ground-floor in 2 sections with panelled timber jambs, shop front to the left, 2-leaf door to the right. Tall windows have cambered heads with brick arches to 6/6-pane sashes; hipped dormer. The building was largely remodelled in 1983; a section of timber studwork survives in the lobby. Nos 26-30 (qv) now form internally a single building.
No cellar identified. Demolished and rebuilt in 1983. There was surviving a possible single-storey 'detached' kitchen block, with connecting link to the main building. There was a freestone fireplace.

KNOWN_AS: The Cockpit, No.42, Old Market Street
MONUMENT_DESC: The Cockpit, No.42 Old Market Street. The building was a rectangular building, orientated east-west, and located to the to the rear of Nos.42 & 43 Old Market Street. The enterance was from No.42.

A building occupying a site on the northern side of Alfred Parade which is recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol. The building stood within a garden plot and there was another, smaller, building in the north-west corner of the plot.

No.13, Orchard Street, located on the north-western side of Orchard Street. The building is a three-storey house with a brick front. The lease for the plot was granted to Peter Wilkins on 20 February 1718 and the house was presumably built soon afterwards (Ison 1952, 152-156).
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by a John Fannon.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/152).

No.14, Orchard Street, located on the north-western side of Orchard Street and on the southern side of its junction with Orchard Avenue. The building is a three-storey house with a brick front. The lease for the plot was granted to Peter Wilkins on 20 February 1718 and the house was presumably built soon afterwards (Ison 1952, 152-156).
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by a Michael Jackson.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/152).

No.16, Orchard Street, located on the north-western side of Orchard Street. The plot was leased to John Worsley on 22 July 1718 and the width of the building frontage was set at 50 feet (15.3 metres). The building was presumably constructed soon afterwards (Ison 1952, 152-156). The building is a three-storey house with a brick front.
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by Miss Ann Butcher, dress maker.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/153).

No.17, Orchard Street  The plot was leased to John Worsley on 22 July 1718 and the width of the building frontage was set at 50 feet (15.3 metres). The building was presumably constructed soon afterwards (Ison 1952, 152-156). The building is a three-storey house with a brick front. (Ison 1952, 152-156).
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by Richard Matthias and the Bristol Eye Hospital.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/153).

No.18, Orchard Street 1718 (Ison 1952, 152-156).
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by Samuel Martin, carpenter.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/153).

No.19, Orchard Street, located on the north-west side of Orchard Street. The building was constructed in 1718 (Ison 1952, 152-156).
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by a Mrs Bryant and also by a Mrs Pearce, a dressmaker, by 1882.
The building was converted into flats in 2003.
The works to convert the building in 2003 were monitored by John Bryant (BUAD 3892).
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/153).

No.20, Orchard Street 1722 (Pilkington 2002; Ison 1952, 152-156).
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by a Thomas Bland.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/156).

No.21, Orchard Street 1722 (Pilkington 2002; Ison 1952, 152-156).
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by a Thomas Cockram.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/156).

No.22, Orchard Street 1722 (Pilkington 2002; Ison 1952, 152-156).
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by George Hamments, tailor.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/156).

No.23, Orchard Street 1722 (Pilkington 2002; Ison 1952, 152-156).
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by a William Martin.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/156).

Warehouse, No.16 Narrow Quay. A three-storey; 2-bay warehouse, probably constucted of stone rubble; rendered on west and south elevations, other faces abutting adjacent buildings. Parapet to front. Double wooden doors to left at all storeys; doorway in centre of ground-floor; window to right at each storey, that on ground-floor with bars. A pulley mounting above the second-floor doorway. The roof not visible, but possibly flat. The building was subject to renovation and conversion to offices in 1996.

No.39 Old Market Street. The building was constructed in 1688 by the Bristol clay tobacco pipemaker Llewellyn Evans as the eastern of a pair of attached houses. It was originally a house of two storeys and attic with a double-depth plan.
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by John Nichols, butcher.
Nos.38 and 39 Old Market Street were converted to a single structure, apparently after 1896 since the Goad fire insurance plan of that year indicates that the property then comprised two shops. The main, south-facing, elevation has a slated ground-floor lean-to canopy on fluted fascia brackets to a flush twentieth century shop front with a glazed door to No.38. A half-hipped pantile roof was added to span the two properties.
The interior of the building was completely remodelled c1985.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/12/1643).
The powder magazine of the Royal Fort. It is recorded by Samuel Seyer in 1823 as having been in or near the south-east bastion of the Royal Fort which dates to the English Civil War.

KNOWN_AS: Pug Mill at Stibbs Hill, St George
MONUMENT_DESC:
Pug Mill depicted on the 1888 1:2500 Ordnance Survey Plan. The mill was possibly associated with the various quarries that are recorded in the area. The OS plan indicates that the mill was approached by a track from the corner of Stibbs Hill and Raglan Lane. The form of the building is not clear form the plan, although an adjoining earthwork is recorded that is likely to be as associated waste heap.
The mill and waste heap are not recorded by the 1904 OS plan..
A medieval tenement, identified as Tenement C, which was recorded during archaeological excavation at Nos.76-96 Victoria Street in 1996 (BUAD 88).
A medieval tenement, identified as Tenement D, which was identified during archaeological excavation at Nos.76-96 Victoria Street in 1996 (BUAD 88).
A medieval tenement, identified as Tenement E, which was identified during archaeological excavation at Nos.76-96 Victoria Street in 1996 (BUAD 88).

KNOWN_AS: Great Western Cabinet Works, Meadow Street
MONUMENT_DESC: The Great Western Cabinet Works, Meadow Street. The factory was extant in 1882 at the time of the OS 1st edition map.
The Great Western Saw Mills, Meadow Street. The factory was extant in 1882 at the time of the OS 1st edition map.

KNOWN_AS: Church of St. Thomas the Martyr
MONUMENT_DESC:
The church of St. Thomas the Martyr, located on the west side of St. Thomas Street. The foundation date of the church is uncertain but the dedication to St. Thomas a Beckett (who was murdered in 1170) implies a foundation date near the end of the twelfth century. The church was a chapel of ease to St. John in Bedminster. The churchyard (BUAD 526M) had been established on the north side of the church by the end of the thirteenth century.
The original internal plan of the church and its medieval development is poorly understood. Documentary evidence records several chapels within the church including chapels dedicated to the Virgin Mary and St. Nicholas by the late fourteenth century (Wadley 1886, 5; 18), as well as one to St. John the Baptist in the first half of the fifteenth century (Wadley 1886, 134). In 1547 there were four chantry chapels - Chepe's, Welle's, Burton's and Stooke's (Maclean 1883-84, 234-235). Welles Chauntry is known to have been founded the early 1330s under the terms of the will of Richard of Wells and was endowed with two halls, the the adjacent shops and other appurtenances (Scott Holmes 1896, 162-163).
The church was substantially rebuilt in the fifteenth century, including the tower and in 1543-44 stone reclaimed from the buildings of the Carmelite friary in St. Augustine's Place was used for further repairs (Skeeters 1993, 81). The main evidence for the internal organisation of the medieval and early modern church is James Stewart's 1749 drawing of the interior (BUAD 2748), made prior to the rebuilding. This shows the church consisting of a nave, chancel and two aisles, with a lantern above the fourth bay eastward of the nave, and transepts to either side. A new reredos was constructed in 1716. The west wall of the lantern was decorated with complex blank arcading. At the west end of the nave was an organ, behind a screen of classical design. The nave roof was vaulted, there was a pulpit with tester, and iron gates led to the sanctuary. An organ was built according to a specification by John Harris in 1728-1729. The church appears to have had similar proportions in plan to its replacement.
In 1789 structural weaknesses were identified and it was decided to rebuild the church. Work began that summer, following a design by James Allen, and had been completed by December 1793 (Ison 1952, 84-88). The fifteenth century tower was retained but much of the medieval detailing seems to have been salvaged for buildings elsewhere in the city. A window from the old church was sold to Mr.Charles Joseph Harford, who installed it in his Pleasure Grounds at Stapleton Grove, Stapleton. The font from the old church was acquired by a Mr. Parrington of the White Lion Inn, St. Thomas Street, but was unfortunately broken on later removal (G. W. Braikenridge notes, Bristol Museum and Art Gallery). The 1716 reredos was retained, however. The organ was repaired by John Smith senior of the Bristol organ builders John Smith and Sons in 1825.
In the nineteenth century the tower was altered, and later restored. Burial within the church and chancel was ended by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852. In 1896 the interior was reworked by the architect Hugh Roumieu Gough (1843-1904).
The church was declared redundant in 1956 and was vested in the Redundant Churches Fund in 1988. A fire in the 1990s destroyed the Harris organ and it was replaced with the organ from St. Werburgh's Church. Three short sections of pipe from the earlier organ are currently (23/10/2006) stored in a cupboard created in the northern entrance to the gallery from the tower. The tower retains a ring of eight bells, the earliest of which is reported to date to the fifteenth century.
Some parts of the late-medieval church have probably survived beneath the floor (BUAD 226) and within the fabric of the walls (BUAD 3273). When the wall of the south aisle of St. Thomas was replastered in 1881 C. J. Taylor, then the incumbent, noted the discovery of "the detached shaft of a pillar and a stone fixed by a [illegible] that seemed to be the drain pipe from a piscina" (BUAD 3273; BRO FCP/St.T/R/1b). Excavation in September 1916 is reported to have revealed the base for a respond, drawn by William Venn Gough, and the original fifteenth-century floor-level, 1.5 metres below the existing floor (BUAD 226; Pritchard 1920, 144).

The Wool Hall. Market hall. The original Wool Hall building, replaced by a larger version which was opened in 1830. On the corner of St. Thomas Street and St. Thomas Lane. Attached. Three storeys; 2 bays to St. Thomas Street. To the Street a large left-hand entrance, another entrance, then, centre, a large entrance with twin columns either side, then two hand-pumps with shared stone cistern or sink, and finally a smaller door on the right-hand end; a moulded string-course above the ground-floor. Large openings to both upper floors of left-hand bay; 2-window range at upper floors to right-hand bay, cross-windows to the lower; Royal arms, 'E.R.', on escutcheon between sills at first-floor; lamp on corner; cornice. Sign on Street frontage:"WOOL HALL. ALL sorts of Wool bought & sold".

No.37, King Street., located on the northern side of King Street. The land between the lane on the east side of the Old Library (BUAD 14M) and St. Nicholas Almshouses (BUAD 17M) was leased to Thomas Wickham, carpenter, by the Corporation in 1650 and Wickham was almost certainly responsible for the construction of the building.
No.37 King Street was a house of three storeys and attic with a timber-framed front and a gabled roof. The main, south-east facing, elevation had an entrance on the eastern side with associated boot-scraper. The ground floor window was a shuttered 12/12 sash. Between ground and first floor there were full width pentice roofs, extending across the adjacent properties. At first floor level there was a wide first-floor bay Ipswich window, with a similar, narrower window to second-floor. At the centre of the attic gable there was a six-light transomed window flush to the gable. There was a single purlin either side of the roof.
Internally the house had a an original seventeenth-century staircase with splat balusters, and a chimney-piece described as "Hepplewhite."
The building was demolished at end of 1904, but was visited in advance of its removal by John Pritchard who described some of the internal features (Pritchard 1906, 130-131).
2, St. James Barton

Kingsdown Brewery, located on the west side of Montague Place. The brewery was constructed in the late nineteenth century and was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale plan surveyed in 1881-82 (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.14). It seems to have consisted of two brick buildings, each with a three-window range and four-storeys.
The brewery was largely demolished in the 1970s, although part of the front wall survived at the northern end of the site to a height of one storey until the site was redeveloped for housing from 2000. Archaeological monitoring of groundworks was undertaken in September and October of that year and on the north side of the site cellars of the brewery building with walls of Pennant sandstone rubble bonded in a grey lime mortar were recorded (Pilkington 2001; Williams 2000, 143).
The horse repository in College Street, which survived into the early twentieth-century, but which had been reused as a Garage by the 1950s. The site is now beneath the car park in St. George's Road.

Nelson('s) Bridge. The crossing of the River Frome by Nelson Street. The bridge was painted by Hugh O'Neill in 1820 (M2900) and 1821 (M2879). These views show housing across both sides. The bridge was a single span arch of stone construction [87A]. The 1820 drawing, from the north, indicates a pointed arch. The bridge probably survives beneath the centre and southern side of the present street.

St. John's Bridge. The Corporation ordered the erection of the bridge across the Frome, from Christmas Street to Lewin's Mead on 5 September 1757. It was a single span arch of stone construction and had ramped parapets with coping. A string course roughly indicating the road level behind the parapet.
A number of buildings, now demolished, were constructed on the bridge and there are rentals for them in the Bristol Record Office. The bridge was presumably incorporated into the culvert when this section of the Frome was covered in the later nineteenth century. In other places the culvert was built to butt against the bridge and it is therefore possible that the arch of the bridge has been preserved.

KNOWN_AS: Queen Elizabeth's Hospital, Jacob's Wells Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Queen Elizabeth's Hospital, located on the eastern side of Jacobs Wells Road. The grammar school was founded by John Carr, soapmaker, who made provision in his will of 1586 for the establishment of a school. The school's charter was granted by Queen Elizabeth I (reigned 1558-1603) and it charged the school with the education of poor children and orphans. The children wore distinctive 'blue' coats. Initially located at College Green, the school transferred to the buildings of the former St. Bartholomew's Hospital in the eighteenth century. A site, at least partly covering the site of the early-medieval Jewish burial ground known as Jews Acre, was acquired at Jacob's Wells Road and a new school building, designed by Thomas Foster and Son was constructed between 1844 and 1847.

KNOWN_AS: Printer's Devil Public House, No.10 Broad Plain
MONUMENT_DESC:
Printer's Devil Public House, No.10 Broad Plain, located on the south side of Broad Plain. The house was constructed in the late eighteenth century and is of two-storeys and attic, with a pantile mansard roof. The main, north-facing, elevation is of rendered brick with a two-window range and a canted bay. The entrance door is at the west side. The fenestration consists of sashes.
By 1882 the building was a public house and has subsequently remained in that use. The interior of the building was reordered in the twentieth century
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/27).

KNOWN_AS: Mission chapel, John Street, Tower Hill
MONUMENT_DESC: Mission Chapel located on the western side of John Street, Tower Hill. The building measured 20.4 metres from east to west and was 5.4 metre wide. It was in existence by the early 1880s and the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town Plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.21) surveyed in 1882 records that it had seating for 150 worshippers. The building had been demolished by 1902.

The Master's House of the St. Mark's Hospital, also known as Gaunt's Hospital.
By 1913 the building was incorporated into the business premises of Messrs. John Harvey & Sons Ltd., whose family was reported by Pritchard to have been "in possession of those buildings since 1796" (Pritchard 1913, 128). Pritchard also reported that a small window had been discovered "quite recently" and had been opened up. The building had been destroyed by bombing by February 1941 (BUAD 4215).
The site is now part of the post-Second World War offices of Harvey's Wine Merchants.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Former Central Fire Station, Bridewell Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Weir at Bridwell. Rocque's 1742 map shows a line, probably a weir, across most of the river Frome to the rear of the west side of St. James's Back, and a short distance (south-west) upstream of Bridewell Bridge. The feature is at a wider stretch of the river, and extends for about 80 feet (24.5 metres) south-west from the right bank. The small gap before the left bank shown by Rocque may represent the position of a sluice, which would indicate that the water mill (BUAD 105A) was on the town side of the river. The foundations of this mill appear to have been observed during construction of the new police and fire station complex in 1926.

No.2 Ellbroad Street. The house, located on the southern side of Ellbroad Street, was the western of a pair of gabled houses (the other was No.4 Ellbroad Street (BUAD 1297M)) of late seventeenth century date with jettied fronts, and "lean-to shelters over the entrances" (i.e. a common pentice roof between the ground and first floors). The building had a single bay and was of three storeys plus attic and cellar. the ground-floor was occupied by shop windows, the front entrances being adjacent. The gable ends rested on brackets and the building may have been cross-gabled. The house was demolished in 1906, along with 'The Rising Sun' public house (BUAD 151M), in order to construct enlarged licensed premises (which, in turn, were removed in 1954).
The site of the building now lies under the footway on the west side of Lower Castle Street and is therefore likely to have been disturbed by services to some extent.

No.10, Small Street. The building was warehouse of nineteenth-century date, but elements of the fabric were of medieval date. The building was of four storeys plus cellars, and five bays in width. In the central bay was the main entrance. The roof comprised parallel gabled roofs supported by 19th.century timber trusses, supported by posts 6.25in. square. There were two barrel-vaulted cellars of medieval and later date. In the ground-floor wall alongside Leonard Lane was a blocked medieval doorway with four-centred head (978A). At first-floor level, in the party wall with No.11, was one jamb of a doorway with a four-centred head and decorated spandrel (979A). On the far side (i.e. at No.11) was an even flatter rear arch, also with decorated spandrel. Between the ground and first floors of the warehouse, and towards the street end, was a large freestone chimney-piece with associated relieving arch of Pennant Sandstone (980A). Towards the rear of the party wall at third-floor level was an old chimney stack, possibly medieval in date (981A). At the south-east end of the rear, or south-west, wall were the remains of a gable, which, at the modern floor level, was 4.70m wide. On the ground-floor were two St. Leonard's parish boundary markers, nos. 12 & 13 (982A), with another, assumed to be no.11, on the Small Street frontage, where it lay alongside another stone, eroded away but presumed to be an old St.Werburgh marker (983A). In the south-east wall at first-floor level was a stone carrying the initials HI and JG (984A).
During demolition of the property a further doorway with four-centred head (985A) was discovered.

No.1 Tailors Court, located on the north-western side of Tailors Court. The building is an attached house of c.1670. Rendered timber-frame, right-hand brick lateral stack and a pantile half-hipped roof. Single front and rear rooms with stair between to the left with a light well behind. 3 storeys, attic and basement. 2-window range. A truncated gable to the front has a jettied first floor. There is raised panelling around ground-floor front windows, a cantilevered beam projecting from the rear with moulded end, dogleg winder stair, and small attic cupboard with butterfly hinges. The south-west side wall is constructed of rubble at ground-floor level
The building was refenestrated in the eighteenth century.

No.62 Colston Street. Late C17 or early C18 house, now a shop and offices. Stuccoed timber-frame with a left-hand brick stack and pantile hipped mansard roof. Single rooms front and back with central left-hand stair. 3 storeys, attic and basement; 1 bay. C19 shop front.

The Theatre Royal, located on the north side of King Street. Interest in establishing a new theatre in Bristol emerged in 1764 and a group of 34 individuals including councillors and business people (notably Henry Cruger, George Daubney, Joseph Harford, Richard Champion and William Champion) each took a £50 share (Barker 1974, 6-7) and a further ten subscribers were admitted to the group on 30 May 1766 (BRO 8976 (15)). An executive committee was formed and a plot of land on the north side King Street and two houses on Rackhay to the east were purchased. One of these was demolished to provide a side access to the theatre. The committee was heavily influenced by the design of Wren's Theatre Royal in Drury Lane, London and commissioned James Saunderson, carpenter at the Drury Lane who had designed a theatre then being built at Richmond, to produce plans (Barker 1974, 8). The architect Thomas Paty was appointed to supervise the construction work (Priest 2003, 68). The foundation stone was laid on 30 November 1764 and the building appears to have been finished in the spring of 1766.
The theatre was named the New Theatre and opened on 30 May 1766 with a performance of Sir Richard Steele's play "The Conscious Lovers" by the contracted company led by William Powell. As constructed, the main body of the theatre was a rectangular structure of stone rubble with a hipped roof some 20 metres to the north of King Street and the main entrance appears to have been off King Street, through the seventeenth-century house, No.38 King Street (BUAD 232M). Attached to the front of this building was a square portico extending over the footway of King Street and supported at its south-west and south-east corners by Roman Doric columns. At the centre of the south side was a pediment. Internally it had a raked stage with the stage machinery accommodated beneath. The auditorium had nine dress boxes and two circles. At the rear of the stage there were dressing rooms, two at each corner (one above the other), while there were two further dressing rooms at the north end of the basement. The space above the auditorium was used as the scenery workshop, the scenery flats being changed using wooden rails or grooves (Southern in Booth 1975, 69-79; Cooke 2002). The Green Room was sited in an element projecting east into Rackhay. The interior decoration was by Michael Edkins, known as a Bristol ceramic artist. Little is known of the Edkins decorative scheme although "carving, painting and gilding, executed with much taste" was used throughout. There was a frieze of triglyphs above the boxes. The partitions between the boxes were marked by pilasters and their fronts were apparently painted in green and gold (Barker 1974, 12). Internally the boxes were reported to have been papered with flock wallpaper and  The lighting throughout was from tallow candles. Barker estimated that the eighteenth-century theatre had a house of approximtely 1000, with around 320 seats in the Pit, over 250 in the Gallery, 267 seats in the dress circle and 148 in the upper circle (Barker 1974, 13).
Edkins was employed to repaint parts of the interior in 1774 and in a lease of 1779 required the new lessee, John Palmer who also managed the Theatre Royal in Bath, to "make an entire alteration in the theatre, enlarge the lobby, [and] to build an elegant tea room and other accommodations." In 1788 a Royal licence was granted and the theatre was renamed the Theatre Royal. The theatre was the subject of another round of significant alteration around 1790 when the ceiling was raised and the whole interior redecorated and re-gilded. A new lease was granted in John Palmer in 1799 and Palmer undertook alterations which included the construction of the gallery and the associated sloping of the auditorium ceiling. At the same time the boxes were fitted in the Upper Circle. In 1820 William Edkins, Michael Edkins son, was commissioned by the lessee William M'Cready to redecorate the boxes. M'Cready had the proscenium arch rebuilt in March 1824 and then removed entirely in the autumn of 1826.
In 1853 under a new lessee, J. H. Chute, the stage was enlarged by extending the building into the yard on its north side and new stage machinery was installed. Beneath the stage were two post traps, a grave trap or Hamlet trap, and bridges (lightweight timber frames which could be raised to stage level). Fixed to the roof trusses were a metal pulley wheels and winch for the safety curtain. The theatre was refurnished and redecorated as part of the project. Another substantial refurbishment was undertaken in 1881 in accordance with plans by C. J. Phipps and T. Pope and this saw the reduction of the size of the stage by five feet [1.53 metres], the addition of new stage traps and the alteration of the proscenium arch. Another scheme of redecoration was also implemented and the present ceiling of the auditorium, much of the extant plasterwork on the cornices of the pillars and the fronts of the boxes survives from this work.
By 1891 the buildings which formed the entrance to the theatre had become structurally unstable and were demolished in 1903 to enable construction of a new entrance. This was designed by W. Skinner and was a two-storey, four-bay structure of brick. At ground-floor the western three bays formed an arcade of segmental-headed arches, the two western bays forming entrance doors for patrons. The eastern bay was a double-width entrance or haulingway. A glass pentice roof protected the public entrance from the elements and the fenestration at first-floor level comprised sash windows with segmental pediments. Over these was a string course and overhanging cornice with a parapet above.
By the early 1940s the theatre was suffering serious financial decline and a public campaign was launched to establish a trust and purchase the building. This was successful and a series of renovations were made under the direction of the architect J. Ralph Edwards. The theatre reopened on 11 May 1943 (Barker 1974, 204-205).
The theatre was subject to major alteration in 1970 in a scheme by the architect Peter Moro. The 1903 entrance was demolished and the next door Coopers' Hall (BUAD 16M), gutting the building, was incorporated into the theatre. Despite the status of the building as a Scheduled Ancient Monument the original stage was rebuilt and the Georgian dressing rooms at the back of the stage were demolished. A modernist studio theatre, designed by the project architect Michael Heard, was constructed at the western end of the site and a new foyer and first floor gallery were inserted into the Coopers' Hall. The basement was also lowered.
There have been major architectural surveys of the building, made in 1942 by J. Ralph Edwards (BUAD 919) and in 1969 by the Ministry of Works (BUAD 4112). The latter includes an extensive photographic survey of the 1850s stage equipment. The theatre is a rare survival of a Georgian town theatre and is the earliest with any surviving interior in the United Kingdom. It is also thought to be the oldest theatre in the country to have been in continuous theatrical use.
The building has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/16/624).

No.66 Colston Street. Late C17, refronted mid C19. Timber framed with brick front and limestone dressings, a left-hand brick stack and pantile hipped roof. Single rooms front and back with central left-hand stair. 3 storeys and basement; 1 bay. C20 shop front.

No.56 Colston Street. One of a pair of attached houses, now shops and offices. The Schedule of Listed Buildings dates them as early C19, restored late C20, but they appear to be older. Render with a pantile hipped roof. Single room front and back with central lateral staircase. Of 3 storeys, attic and basement. Two bays. A timber-framed rear wall and party wall with No.54, at least at first-floor level.

KNOWN_AS: House at the junction of Broad Weir and Narrow Weir
MONUMENT_DESC:
A house at the east end of Broad Weir. The house was one of a group of four and was apparently built as one of a pair, the other being the house to the west at the eastern end of Broad Weir [BUAD 1296M]. The house was of two storeys plus attic and was rendered with jettied fronts. The frontage had a single bay with shop windows to ground-floor. The building had a jettied north elevation and pantile roofs with clustered chimneys. The building was used by C. Fowler, china and glass dealer prior to its demolition in January 1901.
The site now lies mainly under the pavement and flower bed on the south side of Broad Weir but was in the highway between the late nineteenth century and the 1960s. Services are likely therefore to have disturbed the site.

The Lamb Inn. The inn stood in an alley on the north side of Broadmead, a short distance west of the Baptist meeting house. The exact location is not known, and the whole alley was later removed for construction of Lower Union Street.

KNOWN_AS: House at the junction of Lower Castle Street and Ellbroad Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
A house with one large front gable facing the north end of Lower Castle Street. The building was of three storeys plus attic and was possibly cellared. It was not jettied, but had a full-width pentice above the ground-floor frontage. There was a canted bay window to the right of an off-centre entrance. Rendered front;  The east wall is known to have been of stone rubble with one ground-floor opening; there was a rubble chimney stack at top of same wall, topped with tall brick extension stack. The pantile roof had two purlins to each side.
The building was removed after April 1875, revealing evidence of an earlier gable against the side of the surviving house to its west. The site now lies mainly under the pavement and flower bed on the south side of Broad Weir but was in the highway between the late nineteenth century and the 1960s. Services are likely therefore to have disturbed the site.

The 'Crown' or 'Old Crown' tavern, on Broad Weir, demolished in 1906. It was reported that the workmen found "portions of a carved chimney-piece in pulling down the principal room", but that all ancient decorations "had long since gone". Jettied front. Carved 17th.century post on ground-floor at west end. Bracket to second-floor jetty at west end; east end bracket gone by 1901. Large lamp below centre of second-floor jetty. Gabled roof running east-west, with stacks at ends; pair of gables with decorative bargeboards on front elevation, slightly extending beyond line of second-floor. Horizontal sliding sashes to both windows on first and second floors. Advertised as having a 'bowling saloon' on sign. Its replacement was removed in 1957.

No.35 Broad Street.
Attached. Possibly late C17, C18 fenestration, early C19 shop front. Possibly timber-framed, render, roof not visible. Double-depth plan. 
3 storeys and basement; 3-window range. Jettied first floor, and timber modillion eaves cornice. To the right is a good cast lead rainwater head with a winged cupid, the letters GGI/SI, dated 1711 (993A). Largely rebuilt internally. 
A medieval cellar, possibly 14th.century, with a 4-bay ribbed vault (1021A). Now connected with the cellars of Nos.36 & 37/38.

No.13, King Street, located on the southern side of King Street. The building is a warehouse dating to the nineteenth century date and was of four storeys and basement. It is constructed of Pennant sandstone ashlar and squared rubble, with red brick and limestone dressings. The main north-west facing, elevation has a three-window range. A full-width segmental-arch across the ground floor is supported by two cast-iron columns on two large granite blocks which span the central basement opening. A storey has been removed from the building.

A pair of houses, now one house and shop (cafeteria). Attached. No.20-21 Lower Park Row. Probably C16, now largely C19, restored 1992. Render, brick rear lateral stacks and pantile roof. 2 single-cell houses with rear central stacks and rear outer winder stairs. Each of 2 storeys, attic and basement; 1-window range. A central low basement doorway (to Griffen Court), door at each end and C19 shop windows between. The rear elevation has a left-hand raking dormer and a central dormer between the stacks. Diagonal-braced timber-framing noted internally. To the rear of No.20, a small single-cell block, fronting the Court, and historically part of it.

House in Griffen Court. The two-storey building appears to be of seventeenth-century date and has a single-cell plan. It is timber framed with rubble side walls and rubble and brick exterior stack, and a pantile roof. It is described as "timber-framed building" on a plan of Nos.20 & 21, Lower Park Row drawn by J. Oultram in 1991. The exterior dimensions of 4.35/3.90 metres (NW-SE) by 4.05 metres (SW-NE) according to that plan. It was considered for listing in 1995 but was rejected because of alteration. No other details are known.

Boot Factory on the west side of Beaconsfield Road, St George. A two-storey brick building with pitched roof single depth plan along street frontage and attached single storey structure to the rear.
The factory was first depicted on the 1904 Ordnance Survey plan and is extant.

A tree avenue at Broom Hill was in existance by the time of the Brislington Tithe survey in 1846 (BRO EP/A/32/9). The avenue led from the village of Rock to Birchwood Road then beside Birchwood Road for a short distance before following a straight route from the road to St Anne's Wood and the Brislington Brook valley.
The avenue probably formed part of the 'picturesque' landscaped circular walk from Wick House along the brook and fish pond and past the quarry at Rock which would have provided part of the rugged aspect to the picturesque design. The straight part of the avenue across Broom Hill affords distant views of Bristol to the west and provides an approach to a spectacular view down into the deep Brislington Brook valley.
The avenue has largely been lost to twentieth century development, although part of the north west end  survives and an existing foot path largely preserves the route from Birchwood Road to the valley.
Smithy, Narrow Quay. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map in the early 1880s.

KNOWN_AS: The Seamen's Church and Institute, Prince Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
Seamens' Church, located on the east side of Prince Street. The southern elevation of the building fronts on to the north side of Royal Oak Avenue. The building is coursed stone rubble building has a two-storey frontage, with a steep tiled roof and a bell cote and chimney stack containing two bells towards east end of frontage. Freestone plinth and plain string courses. Two-centred arches to doorway (left) and two large ground-floor windows; smaller doorway and square-headed window to eastern bay. Six lancet windows above in first three bays, then stack/bell cote; square-headed window between floors at right end, with trefoil-headed windows above. Stained glass in lancets. Flat tiles to roof; decorative ridge tiles.
The western bay of the building against Prince Street was seriously damaged by bombing in 1940 (Warne 1943, 21) and was rebuilt in 1943. The mission closed in December 1953. The brasses and eagle lectern were rehoused at St. Nicholas Church Museum in the early 1980s.

No.24, Orchard Street 1722 (Pilkington 2002; Ison 1952, 152-156).
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by L. Beard, straw bonnet maker.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/156).

No.25, Orchard Street (Burchill 2001; Ison 1952, 152-156).
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by Miss Tozer's ladies' school.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/158).

No.26, Orchard Street (Burchill 2001; Ison 1952, 152-156).
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by Smith & Co., upholstery warerooms.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/158).

No.27, Orchard Street (Burchill 2001; Ison 1952, 152-156).
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by Gibbs, Bright & Co., merchants.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/159).

No.28, Orchard Street (Burchill 2001; Ison 1952, 152-156).
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by R. B. Haynes, insurance agent.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/159).

No.29, Orchard Street (Burchill 2001; Ison 1952, 152-156).
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/159).

KNOWN_AS: J. S. Fry and Sons warehouse, Cumberland Road
MONUMENT_DESC: J. S. Fry and Sons warehouse, located on the northern side of Cumberland Road. The warehouse was constructed in 1890, reusing part of the perimeter wall of the New Gaol (BUAD 63M) as the external wall on the south-eastern side in which a number of new window openings were created. The north and west walls of the building were partly demolished and rebuilt in 1931 (BRO Building Plans Vol.112 fo.53) with a series of pitched roofs. In 1932 the building became Baldwin's Garage Ltd. and remained in use as a garage until the 1950s.

No.41 Old Market Street, located on the northern side of Old Market Street. The building was constructed in 1688 by the Bristol clay tobacco pipemaker Llewellyn Evans. It is a single-bay jettied, house of two storeys and attic. The building has a pantiled cross-gable roof. At ground-floor the main, south-facing, elevation comprises a shopfront with a central entrance. The second floor fenestration consists of a pair of sash windows at the centre of the elevation. There is a further sash window at the centre of the gable. Internally the original plan conformed to the common Bristol layout of a single room at the front and the back with a staircase at the centre.
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by Samuel Mountani, boot maker.
The interior has been substantially reconstructed.

Needless Bridge. The bridge was located a little downstream of the present bridge carrying Nelson Street over the river Frome. Jean Rocque's 1742 map shows one central cutwater at each side. It may have survived to carry the buildings on the north side of Nelson Street, as Nelson Bridge was lined with them on both sides. Elements of the bridge may survive beneath the south-east corner of the present Bridewell police station.
No.28 West Street. The building was a three-storey house of probable late seventeenth- or early eighteenth-century date located on the south side of West Street, Old Market.

KNOWN_AS: The Great Gate of St. James's Priory
MONUMENT_DESC: The Great Gate of St.James's Priory. The gate formed the western entrance to the precinct of the priory. The gate was located at the lower end of Whitson Court, now Lower Maudlin Street, immediately outside the 'White Hart' public house, which may have been associated with it. Jean Rocque's map of 1742 shows a vehicular entrance with a narrower pedestrian gate immediately on its east. The gate appears to have been demolished by the end of the eighteenth-century.

Bowling green located on the east side of Montague Street, opposite Little James Street. The green was apparently created in the early-eighteenth century and was recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 map. This indicates that the green was sub-rectangular in shape and lay immediately against Lower Montague Street. It had apparently been removed by the time of Benjamin Donne's 1773 map and the site redeveloped for housing.
The site now lies largely beneath the dual carriageway in Marlborough Street.

The Globe Inn. The inn is recorded by Jean Rocque's plan of Bristol of 1742 as being located in a yard off the west end of the southern side of West Street, Old Market. The modern Nos.8-10, West Street, a pair of early eighteenth-century houses (now converted to offices), may incorporate part of the fabric of the inn.

Lawford's Gate Bridewell. The prison was recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol as "Bridewell". It was a small rectangular building set back slightly from the south side of the road to Gloucester, later Gloucester Street (modern Lawfords Gate), and a short distance east of the end of Brick Street. It was presumably replaced by the House of Correction that was erected further along the street [BUAD 654M].
The site now lies underneath surface car park beside Somerset House.

The Quaker's Workhouse. The building was located between the north-western end of New Street and the lane alongside the left bank of the river Frome. Rocque's map indicates an H-shaped plan in 1742, with the entrance opposite the end of New Street.

A survey of the building (HER 24673) has confirmed that three of the four ranges occupied until recently as council flats formed the body of the workhouse built in 1698-1700 by the Society of Friends (Quakers).

Weaving was carried out here until 1721, after which the building continued to serve as residential accommodation. A mission and school were established here in the 1860s but the buildings were converted into flats in or about 1929. The basic structure survives but was heavily rebuilt in the 1860s and c.1929, with further refurbishment since World War Two. Few original internal features survive and the roof has been raised. However, this is an early survival of an urban purpose-built workhouse and possibly the oldest-surviving Quaker workhouse.

A narrow foot bridge shown by Rocque's (1742) map, which was located at about 400 feet upstream of 'Traitors Bridge' (Wades Bridge) on the river Frome, opposite the continuation of the line of Eugene Street.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Car Park, Philadelphia Court, Penn Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Footbridge north of Narrow Weir. The bridge crossed the northern course of the river Frome, slightly upstream of the watercourse running from Narrow Weir. The bridge was short and narrow. Elements of the structure may survive below ground.

KNOWN_AS: Causeway leading to bridge north of Narrow Weir
MONUMENT_DESC: A causeway leading from Water Street, close to its junction with Hanover Street, to the bridge across the northern course of the River Frome [BUAD 1011M]. Rocque's 1742 map shows it as following a slightly irregular route, and also depicts large dumps in the field on either side. The site is now beneath buildings on the east side of Penn Street, and under the car park in Philadelphia Court.

KNOWN_AS: Bridge leading to the Rope Walk
MONUMENT_DESC: A small bridge across the northern course of the River Frome, connecting the 'Rope Walk' with the walk leading up to 'The Pest House' on 'New-found-land Lane' (modern Newfoundland Street). Elements of the bridge may survive below ground. The site was later occupied No.14, Ropewalk, close to the south-west corner of Hill Street.

No.2 Christmas Street, located on the south-western side of Christmas Street, close to the junction with Quay Street. The house was of medieval date, although its form as built is unknown. It did, however, have a timber roof with semi-circular windbraces of late-medieval date supported on contemporary stone corbel heads. The building appears to have been subject to some alteration during the seventeenth century, including the installation of a strapwork-decorated chimney-piece.
The late-medieval roof was truncated and by c.1875 when it was identified only one bay at the rear of the property consisting two principal rafters and semi-circular windbraces remained. The roof was removed c.1899 and at about the same time the two fifteenth-century corbel heads were moved to another position in the building. In 1909 the corbels were removed from the building and presented to Bristol Museum (Pritchard 1911, 72-74).
The building was demolished in May 1910 to make way for an extension to Messrs. Fry's factory.

Nos.3-17, Bath Street, a terrace of houses located on the southern side of Bath Street. The terrace was designed by Thomas Paty in 1786 and carried a parish boundary marker of 1790. They properties were probably intended from the first as ground-floor shops with living accommodation above. Each house is of three bays, and three and a half storeys, mostly also with basements. They were largely altered in the late 19th./early 20th.century, and subsequently after the Second World War, so that few original features survive. About half of the remaining terrace was removed in 1985-86. There were originally some matching buildings on the north side of the street.
The buildings have a Grade II listing (Listed Building Number 901-1/42/1).

No.24 Broad Street. The house contains two chimney-pieces of seventeenth-century date (774A), on on the ground-floor and one at first floor. The ground-floor example is well-preserved, that at first-floor has been cut back flush with the breast.
No.25 Broad Street. Includes, at first-floor, in the party wall with No.27 Broad Street, a 3-light window, cinquefoil heads in an overall square frame (775A).

KNOWN_AS: Outer Line of the Civil War Defences at Brandon Hill
MONUMENT_DESC: The outer line of the Civil War Defences at Brandon Hill, the remains of the Civil War double defensive line running between the Brandon Hill and Water Forts. Seyer (1823, 302) records that the ditches were from 10 to 15 feet deep and the ramparts as many feet in height. The length between the forts was about 320 yards, with a bastion about midway. At that date the ramparts and ditches were still perfect for about 60 yards from Brandon Hill Fort, after which the line was somewhat levelled.

The Merchants or Merchant Seamen's Almshouse, located on the north side of King Street. An almshouse was established on, or close to, the site in the very late-fifteenth or early-sixteenth century by the Guild of Mariners, which also founded the adjacent Chapel of St. Clement in 1493. The form of the almshouse is currently unknown - whether a separate building or accommodation within the chapel - but a kitchen for the almshouse is referred to in a seventeenth-century document, suggesting that it may have been a separate structure close to the chapel building. The almshouse was presumably also served by the priest for the chapel and was funded by a levy on goods and a deduction from the wages of Bristol's mariners which continued to be levied until at least 1595. The Guild of Mariners was dissolved in the mid-sixteenth century and the chapel of St. Clement and the Mariner's Almshouse were taken over by the Society of Merchant Venturers. The almshouse then had twelve residents and subsequently the funds for its maintenance were provided out of the Society's own resources (McGrath 1975, 81).
The present almshouse building was established in 1696 by the Society of Merchant Venturers. The building enclosed a quadrangle, with full ranges on the north, east and west sides and the southern range split by a main entrance at the centre of that side. There was a uniform for those accepted into the almshouse consisting of a long dark blue overcoat with a blue-green lining and a hat (BRSMG M2502).
The almshouse was damaged by blast in an air raid on 2 December 1940. Another raid on 14 May 1941 badly damaged the western range, and south-western range and the western end of the north range.
The almshouse has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/16/595).

No.4, St. Augustine's Place. An 18th.century brick front on an older building. Quoins, stringcourses. Three storeys plus attic. One window, late C19 shop front, first-floor window sash with glazing bars, second-floor, C19 sash, both with architrave surrounds. Parapet, pantiled roof, hipped at front. A detached two-storey kitchen block at the rear, with a first-floor link. Evidence at first-floor for a possible former privy block. Formerly listed as Grade II.

No.5, St. Augustine's Place.
C18. Rendered. Four storeys, with a two-storey rear. Three windows. Sashes in flush frames, glazing bars remaining on top floor. Cornice. A pantiled roof, front hipped in pyramidal fashion, the rear ridged. The rear wall was 500mm thick, the southern half occupied by a chimney breast.
Formerly listed Grade II, .

No.38 Mary-le-Port Street. The building was constructed c1648 by Thomas Harris, brewer. It was a jettied house of four storeys and attic with a timber-framed front. The ground-floor contained a shopfront with a central entrance and at first, second and third floors there were bay windows. There was a small window to east of third-floor bay; and another window in the attic gable. The arms of the Brewers Company were beneath the second-floor window. There were brackets at the second and third floors and supporting the eaves. The building had a gabled pantile roof with a side gable on the east side. The rear of the building was built against St. Mary-le-Port church (BUAD 133M), making use of its north wall and parts of the church window could be seen. In 1905 John Pritchard visited the building during renovation work and observed the remains of fireplaces (BUAD 659; Pritchard 1906, 270). The house was destroyed by bombing in the early 1940s. The site was archaeologically excavated by Rahtz in 1962-63 (BUAD 358).

No. 202 Church Road, St George. Two storey attached building with painted render and pantile roof. Possibly the same building first depicted on William Maule's survey of the parish of St George dated 1803. Directory entries indicate that the ground floor has been in retail use since at least 1897 (Bruce, 2006, 5), although the shop front is later twentieth century in date.

No.40 Mary-le-Port Street. The building was constructed c1648 by Thomas Harris, brewer. It was a jettied house of four storeys and attic with a timber-framed double front.The ground-floor contained a shopfront. The entrance was on the eastern side while the entrance to St. Mary-le-Port church (BUAD 133M). at first, second and third floors there were bay windows. There was a small window to east of third-floor bay; and another window in the attic gable. The arms of the Brewers Company were beneath the second-floor window. There were brackets at the second and third floors and supporting the eaves. The building had a pantile roof with two front gables. The building was partially cellared. In 1905 John Pritchard visited the building during renovation work (BUAD 659; Pritchard, 1906 270). The house was destroyed by bombing in the early 1940s. The site was archaeologically excavated by Rahtz in 1962-63 (BUAD 358).

Nos.3 & 5, Old King Street. A pair of houses that appear to have been part of a larger group, being very similar to their neighbours to the north, Nos. 7 & 9. Each of two storeys and attics, there being a third gable, containing a third-floor and set back a little, between the two front gables. Slight jettying. Shop windows, with left-hand entrances, to ground-floor; bay windows to first and second floors, the latter retaining their casements. Pritchard (1906,270) describes the rooms as "very small and low", with no internal features of interest.

Nos.11 & 13, Old King Street. The buildings were two-storey jettied, gabled houses. Two storeys and attic, without jettying. Shopfronts to ground-floor; single sash to first-floor; casement window to attic. Side gable on north side of No.11 (cross-gabled?). Pantiled. The houses were demolished in 1908 (Pritchard 1908, 303).

Former stable block on the north-east end of the Full Moon, North Street (BUAD 178M). A 5-window range to the yard, with parapet and ridge stacks. Gabled roof; many dormers to rear (Moon Street) elevation. Possibly cellared.

St. Nicholas' Almshouses, located on the north side of King Street. The building was constructed in 1652-1656 to provide almshouses for the parish of St. Nicholas. The building apparently occupies a plot on the berm between the town wall known as the Marsh Wall and the ditch inferred to be associated with it. Jean Roque's map Bristol of 1742 shows the almshouses not extending as far east as Back Street at that time.
The building was restored in 1961 by Donald Insall, and the interior remodelled.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/16/596).

A pair of houses. Nos.4 & 5 Peter Street. Timber-framed, gabled fronts. Taken down in March 1904, to be replaced by new brick buildings. A combined frontage of about 30 feet. Until the early 1890s the dates 1664 and 1663 were still visible, carved upon the fronts. By 1904 there was nothing of interest left in the interiors.

The Merchants' Tolzey, located on the south side of Corn Street, against the north side of All Saints Church and extending to either side, in all about 90 feet (27.5 metres) in length, and perhaps 10 feet (3 metres) deep. Contiguous with All Saints Conduit (BUAD 682M) at the west end. 6 bays and 7 columns; pent roof. Erected in c.1616, removed in c.1782. Built to serve the purpose of an Exchange, this Tolzey was replaced by John Wood's Exchange, opened in September 1743. Millerd's 1673 map records a nail in each of the six bays.
14, St. James' Parade

KNOWN_AS: House north-east of All Saints Church
MONUMENT_DESC: House north-east of All Saints Church, immediately east of the tower of All Saints Church. At the rear of the eastern end of the Merchants' Tolzey. 2 storeys and attics; cross-gabled, 3 gables to the front; 3-window range. An ogee-headed entrance to right of centre. All windows recorded as mullioned by Millerd's 1673 map of Bristol.

Totterdown Lock Bridge. Crossing Totterdown Lock, connecting the roads now known as Feeder Road and Cattle Market Road. Replaced by a wider example at a more convenient angle. The piers may survive. Single span arch. Stone. Ramped parapets, possibly ashlar.

KNOWN_AS: Entrance Lock to Bathurst Basin from New Cut
MONUMENT_DESC: Entrance lock to Bathurst Basin from the New Cut. c.1809, by William Jessop. To the left of the entrance, a landing stage with steps down to river level; to the right of the entrance, a hand-crane. Crossing the lock, a bridge [BUAD 770M]. A small square single-storey building with pyramidal hipped roof at the north-east corner of the lock, beyond the bridge. Pairs of wooden lock gates.

KNOWN_AS: St Luke's Church, Queen Ann Road
POSTAL_ADDRESS: St Luke's Church, Queen Ann Road
MONUMENT_DESC: St Luke's Church, Queen Ann Road, Barton Hill. Built 1842-50 by S.T. Welch and altered 1930 by A.V. Gough (Listing description). Constructed of Pennant rubble with limestone dressings.

A ravelin, or angular redoubt, on the line of the Civil War defences on Brandon Hill. The redoubt was probably sited forward of the line. The monument apparently was still extant in the late eighteenth century (Seyer, 1823 303) but has now disappeared. Its precise position is now unknown although it was located in the area now occupied by Berkeley Square.

A conical mound, surrounded by a deep ditch, located to the rear of Brandon Hill Fort. It is shown on a plan by Seyer (1823, 302). The top was 45 feet in diameter, and as much as 20 feet above the ground immediately below. Its form was so regular that Seyer suspected "that it was artificially constructed as a barrow or beacon by the early inhabitants". The date and function of the monument are unclear but it may have been associated with the English Civil War defences of the Bristol.

No.30/31, St. Augustine's Parade. A late 19th.century three storey building. Large glazed shopfront on ground-floor. Two storeys of sash windows, four to each floor. Pair of gables and mock half-timbering added in the 20th.century, as may also have been the ridge roof running parallel to the front. No cellar identified. Heavily restored in 1983, including new upper storeys. Two freestone spandrels were noted, reused as partial supprots for an old brick chimney breast.

House with ground-floor shop. Nos.1 & 1a Chirstmas Steps. Largely of 1747 or early 1748. No.1, on the corner of Host Street, was the baker's house, with a shop occupying part of the ground floor. It was of three and a half storeys plus a small cellar. Three bays faced Host Street and one faced Christmas Steps. Incorporated at the southern end was an earlier dwelling of three storeys and ridge roof, one bay in width. To the west on the Steps lay No.1a, containing the bakery and oven on the ground floor, and three storeys of storage above. A small lock-up shop was later installed at the front of the property. The party wall between Nos.1a and 2 was partly medieval and included the remains of two arches.

Cellar. A small 15th.century cellar below the front of No.35, Corn Street. Recorded in 1984 & 1986, with further work in 1995, all by John Bryant. The vault was carried on ribs that were Y-shaped in plan, the prong of the Y at the street end of each rib. The web consisted of squared blocks of tufa, laid in courses across the vault.

No.35 Corn Street, a banking hall and contemporary banker's house, constructed c1791. Extensive cellarage including a small 15th.century ribbed and vaulted example (BUAD 109M). The single storey banking hall with a three bay frontage has a flat roof with a central domed lantern. Beyond what was originally a yard lies the house, facing south-west onto a side alley. A double-depth plan with a central stairwell. Three storeys, attic and basement, and five bays, with three bays facing to the south-east. There is a triple ridged mansard slate roof with hipped ends. A number of internal features survive in the house, including the ceiling of the principal first floor room.

No.40 Old Market Street, located on the northern side of Old Market Street.. The building was constructed in 1688 by the Bristol clay tobacco pipemaker Llewellyn Evans. It is a single-bay jettied, house of two storeys and attic. The building has a gabled pantile roof. At ground-floor the main, south-facing, elevation comprises a shopfront with a central entrance. The second floor fenestration consists of a pair of sash windows at the centre of the elevation. There is a smaller casement window at the centre of the gable. Internally the original plan consisted of front and rear rooms, with a staircase to one side of the rear room.
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by John Sprod & Son, outfitters.
The interior has been substantially reconstructed.

George's Brewery also known as The Bristol Brewery. A porter brewery in the late C18 - early C19, under Philip George and partners. Much extended during the C19 and C20, and still very much in use. Georges, Rickettses & Bristol Old Porter Brewery Company in, e.g.1826.

KNOWN_AS: Church of St. John the Baptist
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. John the Baptist (sometimes known as St. John on the Wall). The parish church (and town gate) was built on the line of the Norman town wall during the twelfth century. The church is thought to have been founded c.1192 and the advowson of the rectory was in the gift of Tewkesbury Abbey.
The rector of St. John in 1420 was John Mybbys, probably the former principal of Cuthbert Hall, Oxford who had participated in the Lollard rising led by Sir John Oldcastle in the spring of 1414. In August 1420 he acted as compurgator for William Taylor during the latter's trial on six charges of heresy (Thomson 1965, 25n).
C14 and C15; late sixteenth-century vestry; narthex and side gateways formed later 1820s. Rubble with limestone dressings and limestone ashlar tower and spire. 
Nave, chancel and east vestry. Tower over gateway (originally shared with St.Lawrence). Perpendicular Gothic style.
The north elevation includes at the east end St John's conduit, beneath a nineteenth-century four-centred arch; above is a fifteenth-century canted oriel window; to the west is an octagonal chimney on a corbel; a deep drip over the C14 crypt of 6 bays, refenestrated with low, C15 three-light Tudor-arched windows, the west one blocked, and a small Tudor-arched ribbed door; 2-bay late C15 chancel of 3-light windows with a shallow buttress in between; C14 four-bay nave of larger 3-light windows, and a short 4-light Tudor-arched clerestory window above the first bay, with a crenellated parapet. 
South elevation of the chancel is 3 bays, windows as the north side with 2 doorways at either end with chamfered Tudor arches; at the west end of the chancel the nave steps out and is linked by an angled wall on corbels; the south nave wall is similar to the north, without the crypt windows. 
At the west end is the gateway. The south side of the central gateway has flanking niches with painted statues of Brennus and Bellinus, the mythical founders of Bristol, each holding an orb and sceptre; shields and a Royal Arms to the parapet above; the east arch is paired with the entrance to the church. 
The main gateway has a ribbed fan vault with bell hole, also portcullis slot. The two-stage tower has an octagonal spire.
