At lower level there is a crypt or crowde [969A] in 2 sections: that to the east is 3 bays, a tierceron vault with bosses; west section is 2 bays, with a more complex tierceron ribbed vault with bosses but no shafts; 2 stoops, by door and in south-west corner with a projecting shield. The crowde was illustrated by Rowbotham in 1826, with views from both ends (M2425-M2426).
A two-bay chancel with relief crenellation across the middle of east wall, and 3 fine Tudor-arched studded doors with raised lozenges in panels; an arch and steps up behind the south chancel arch pier to the pulpit; 6-bay nave has splayed window reveals and attached shafts between the bays, with painted octagonal capitals; the raised east bay has clerestory windows to former rood loft and a C15 roof with tie beams and posts to angel corbels, while the rest has a timber cornice to a shallow C15 arch-braced collar beam roof; narthex with open-well stair of 1883 to the organ loft.
After the dissolution of St. James, the advowson of the rectory was acquired by Henry Brayne as part of his purchase of the St. James property in January 1544.
Fine Laudian fittings. A gated altar rail with twisted banisters, 2 lecterns, pews of 1621 with doors and a partially restored C17 west screen and organ loft with painted panels and fluted pilasters; brass 2-sided lectern c1690, and a C18 wrought-iron sword rest; a fine 1624 font. A rare hour-glass (held in the City Museum) from the time of the Commonwealth is attached beside the octagonal pulpit. Various memorials include a wall tablet, the Rowley Brass, to Thomas Rowley d.1478, with inscribed figures; table tomb to Walter Frampton d.1388 in an elliptical-arched recess in the chancel. 
Walter Frampton was chief benefactor for St John's until his death in 1388. The crypt or crowde provided space for guild or chantry chapels, another example standing in the Church of St Nicholas (BUAD 147M).
The interior was recorded by Rowbotham in 1826 (M.2396) and Johnson in 1828 (M2397). Both show the pulpit raised above the central gangway. Illustrations, also, of the font (O'Neill, M2402), communion table (Rowbotham M2406), hour-glass (O'Neill M.2411; M2411a), Frampton tomb (M2413-M2417), Rowley brass (M2420), other monuments and internal fittings, etc.
An organ was built in 1846 by John Smith junior of the Bristol organ builders John Smith and Sons (Felix Farley's Bristol Journal, 21 February 1846).
The church was declared redundant in 1984 and the congregation moved to the Chapel of the Three Kings of Cologne.
The church has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number ).

KNOWN_AS: Well to the rear of 117 Richmond Road

MONUMENT_DESC: Kater's Sugar house, located at No.6, Tucker Street, between the north bend of that thoroughfare and the River Avon (now Floating Harbour). Operated by John Reincke from at least 1770, then, after his death in c.1785, by his relative, John Herman Kater. Sugar refining ceased in the early 1820s, after which it was used as a dry saltery warehouse by Lediard, Jones & Mortimer, until a disastrous fire gutted the building in the early hours of 22nd.December 1826 (Braikenridge notes,I.20). Rowbotham's drawing of the fire shows a massive 6-storey building with 5-window ranges to north-west and north-east, and a smaller, 3-storey block to the west.
Manfield's Boat Yard, located at Canons Marsh. The site included several single-storey sheds with gabled and hipped roofs.

KNOWN_AS: Nova Scotia Yard or Scott's Yard
MONUMENT_DESC: Ship yard and timber yard. "Scott's Yard called Nova Scotia". On the former course of the River Avon, filled up on creation of the Floating Harbour. Immediately west of the Overfall Dam. Various single-storey buildings, some with open sides. William Scott is listed at Nova Scotia yard as a timber merchant in the 1826 directory.

Western Wapping Dock. A dry dock in the shipyard at the western end of Wapping. The dock was aligned north-west to south-east, off a small inlet on the southern side of the harbour and had a large pair of dock gates.
The dock was subsequently infilled, and its site is now partly beneath L Shed, part of Bristol Industrial Museum, and the area to its south beneath the adjacent road and the adjoining surface car park.

KNOWN_AS: Houses on St. Thomas Street, north of Long Row
MONUMENT_DESC: Three houses. Attached on north side. On the east side of St. Thomas Street, on the north-west corner of Long Row. 3 storeys and attics, each a 1-window range. Gabled fronts. All storeys jettied, including eaves ends. Cellar access opened between the northern pair. Ground-floor bays to same pair; first- and second-floor bays to all, that on the first-floor of the northernmost house retaining an Ipswich window. A bracket at ground-floor corner of the southernmost house.

No.19 King Street, located on the south side of King Street. The building was constructed in c.1665. It is a rendered timber frame building with brick stacks to the left and a pantile roof. There are gabled front and rear elevations to the building and a double depth plan with central stairs between the front and back rooms. It has an eighteenth-century ground floor and outer doorways with sashes. It is joined internally to No.20. The building was refenestrated in the eighteenth-century and restored in 1991. Modern buildings are attached to the rear. It is now part of a public house and restaurant.

Harwood and Blackwell's sugar house. Probably at least 5 storeys. The west elevation was an 8-window range with a tower to its south end. Hipped roof. Harwood and Blackwell's sugar house in 1824. Later Conrad Finzel's sugar refinery.

No.17 King Street, located on the southern side of King Street. The building was constructed in the mid-1660s apparently as the central building of a group of three, the lease for the plots of Nos.16-18 being granted by the Bristol Corporation to Francis Bayley, a shipwright, in 1663 (BRO 04335(5) fo.4). This lease set a limit of three years for construction, suggesting that the three buildings had probably been completed by 1666.
The house has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/16/602).

KNOWN_AS: Liverpool, London and Globe Assurance Offices
MONUMENT_DESC:
Liverpool, London and Globe Assurance Offices. The building was constructed to a design by W. B. Gingell between 1865 and 1867. Limestone ashlar with dressings. Open banking hall with double-depth plan offices. 3 storeys and attic; 5-window range. The sculpture on the façade is by T. Colley. An elaborate symmetrical front is articulated by paired giant order of columns on pedestals, Composite on ground floor and Corinthian across the upper 2 floors, single to the sides. An attic storey with a pedimented centre. The attic has paired caryatids beneath the entablature, octagonal urns to the ends, a small segmental pediment within the main pediment, half segmental pediments each side.
The building was reconstructed behind the facade in 1977.

KNOWN_AS: West of England Fire & Life Engine House
MONUMENT_DESC: Fire engine house. Belonging to the West of England Fire & Life, and situated on the north-eastern corner of St. John's Bridge. Noted by Braikenridge (Notes, 87 & 106). A building of a single-storey and a hipped roof. The elevation to St. John's Bridge of a left-hand entrance and right-hand window. Must have been larger, but no more is shown on O'Neill's drawing (BSMRG M2893).

Colston's Almshouse, located on the eastern side of St. Michael's Hill. The almshouse was founded by Edward Colston in 1691.
Limestone ashlar with ridge stacks, and pantile hipped roof. U-shaped plan with wings to sides of a courtyard. 2 storeys; 8-window range middle with 10-window wings. A symmetrical group with a pedimented central chapel broken forward, drip moulds to both floors and a stone eaves cornice. Large central doorway has an eared architrave and 6-panel oak door, with a deep segmental canopy on foliate brackets, with a relief broken pediment with a pedestal. Above is a moulded panel inscribed to EDWARD COLSTON with a broken pediment, oval keyed windows each side and a clock in the pediment tympanum. Doorways to the ends of the centre, and in the 3rd and 8th bays of the wings, with pitched canopies on brackets and 4-panel oak doors. Stone moulded cross windows with architraves to metal casements, with alternate pediments and segmental pediments along the string, and 2 segmental pediments to the end elevations.
The rear elevation has projecting chapel with rose window and lower flanking windows with stained glass, and a good plank door to a flagged basement, with cross boarding to the inside. Stacks are diagonally-set with linked cornices. Central bell cupola with an ogee roof. Square section lead downpipes. Associated C19 building to the rear, on Horfield Road (No.21).
The chapel has panelled timber pilasters flanking the entrance and in the corners of the E end, to a 3-bay barrel-vaulted timber roof, tall wainscotting rising behind the altar to a segmental pediment, with attached side benches and curved arm rests, and a single row of pews each side with desks.
The three-storey houses to the south of the almshouses, Nos.22-24 St. Michael's Hill, were also constructed by Colston to provide additional income.
The houses were extensively restored in the 1880s.
The almshouse has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/595).

The church of St. Nicholas, sited on the line of the earliest town wall, and part of the early medieval Town Wall is visible at the western end of the crowde. The date at which the church was founded is unknown as is the original form. It was in existence by the twelfth century. Early eighteenth-century illustrations exist of the church and gate, suggesting a fourteenth-century date. Much of the fine largely fourteenth-century crowde, or lower church (973A) survives. It has two aisles and four bays with tierceron vaulting and good animate and foliate bosses; at the east end of the south aisle is an arched panel with good figure stops and a hexafoil panel. There is evidence of a former fifth bay at the west end of the southern aisle. The remains of an earlier vault survive east of the northern aisle. Beyond is a small vaulted area, used as a charnel house (970A), with two charnel pits (971A), one at each end. Four phases of construction in the crowde - east end of north aisle, running into the charnel house; eastern two full bays of same; western two ditto; the south aisle. In the south wall is the matrix for a 16th. or 17th.century memorial brass. Beyond the south-east corner are the remains of a staircase that linked with the chancel above. John Attwood, Junior, churchwarden, created a vault for burial use in the void between the old and new south walls at the eastern end. He restored the original crypt entrance, there (now the bottom of the fire exit stairs) in 1822. In 1821 a stone coffin was found partly embedded in the north wall (1032A).
The mid 14th.century church was demolished in 1762. The church was completely rebuilt above the lower church or crypt 1769 by James Bridges, the steeple and interior being designed by Thomas Paty. Bridges' design, building off the old crypt, was an early and remarkably well-studied attempt at Gothic revival, and the windows have similarities with those of St. Peter's, Peter Street (qv). The interior had a very fine Rococo plaster ceiling by Thomas Stocking. The chancel of the medieval church lay above St. Nicholas Gate, being a number of steps above the nave level. The location of the present tower was formerly a public thoroughfare between St. Nicholas and Baldwin Streets.
Bath stone ashlar and Pennant rubble.
Nave and west tower. Georgian Gothic Revival style.
Windowless east end projecting to the centre; below a moulded string are rubble crypt walls with quatrefoil openings. 7-bay north elevation (matched on the south), a re-set 15th.century three-light mullion window in the east bay and an inserted 20th.century door to the west of that; tall 5-light Perpendicular windows separated by buttresses up to a blind arcaded parapet. 
The crypt, or crowde, wall, extended outwards in the 18th.century, is exposed on the south side through the falling ground, and has a gabled porch in the second bay from the west; parapeted vestry (now stairs connecting the two levels) in the south-westcorner has a 4-light south window. 
2-stage tower: the north door has an ogee hood, with 20th.century glazing and small entrance lobby; above is an 8-foil oculus; the belfry has paired windows with ogee hoods, the bottom half blind, the top louvred, and clasping pilaster buttresses, open arcaded parapet, with pinnacles; on the south face is a clock, with a rare second hand (Arch.El.No.972A). Octagonal 3-stage spire with oculi around the middle stage.
In crypt a 18th.century baluster-shaped font. A 16th.century wall memorial (John Whitson) with a panelled base, flanking buttresses with pinnacles, an arch over with panelled soffit and an effigy on one elbow (Arch.El.No.974A), at one time in the porch below the tower.
Burial in the crypt was ended by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852.
Bombing during the Second World War destroyed the eighteenth-century upper church. The interior was largely rebuilt and the pre-war double gabled roof was replaced by a flat roof. The brass eagle lectern of c1480, William Edney's gates, and the sword rest have all been removed to St. Stephen's Church (qv). The 1822 Whitson monument, sited below the tower, was badly damaged in the Blitz, but portions survive. The church was declared redundant and used as a museum from 1973 until 1993.

The second building of the Red Maids' School. Replaced by a purpose-built structure, in the Elizabethan style, in 1840 or 1842-43. The site was vacated in the autumn of 1911 upon the removal to Westbury-on-Trym.

The Old Library, King Street. Originally the library was housed in an older building, but this had fallen into disrepair by the 1730s. Consequently the Bristol Corporation took the decision to erect a new building which was built between 1738 and 1740, possibly to a design by James Paty. The total cost is recorded in the Audit Books as £1,3081 8s. 1d. James Paty provided the ornamental carving.
The library was housed in the two larger rooms at first floor level. The building remained the home for the City Library until 1907 when it moved to the present building in College Green. The interior has since been remodelled and is currently occupied by a restaurant. The coat of arms in the pediment and the panels above the first floor windows have been removed, and the carved wooden fireplace from the first floor room in the west range was taken to College Green as part of the library's move. Internally major features survive, including the oak staircase. The building remains in the freehold ownership of Bristol City Council but is under lease.
The Old Library has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building Number 901-1/16/604). The wall, railings and gateway were originally listed separately but are now included in the main listing for the building.

Prior House, located on the south side of Robin Hood Lane. The building was constructed c.1750 as a house for Richard Going, a Bristol pewterer, and is recorded in the Land Tax assessment for that year as "Mr. Going's new house" (Leech, 2001 9). The house was orientated north south and stood within a rectangular walled garden, being sited against the west wall. As built, it was of two storeys and basement and was constructed of white Lias limestone. The ground-floor plan was of two rooms with a brick-vaulted underground cistern at the south-east corner of the building (Leech, 2001). There was a brick chimneystack in the west wall. The building appears to have been extended between 1828 and the early 1880s. The house survived until 1949 but was subsequently demolished.
The remains of the building were recorded in 2001 by Dr. Roger Leech (BUAD 3811; Leech, 2001).

Merchant Navy Memorial, located on the east side of Welsh Back. The Merchant Navy Association (Bristol Branch) decided in 1996 to create a "War Memorial Garden in Bristol Docks in memory of the Merchant Seamen of Bristol who died for their country". A memorial committee was set up and an outline scheme drawn up for a central memorial surrounded by a small garden enclosed by dwarf walls. A site in the Centre was initially investigated but one at Welsh Back was agreed in the late summer of 1999. Funds were raised by a public campaign and the artist, David Backhouse (who also sculpted the Cloaked Horseman at Narrow Lewins Mead), selected in May 2000 after a competition.
The memorial is a polished Portuguese granite monolith set on a plinth and has a bronze collar. It was constructed by Hanson Bath and Portland Stone of Keynsham and the collar was cast by G. F. James of Southampton. It is surrounded by seating. The memorial carries two inscriptions. That on the monument is:
"This memorial is a tribute to/all merchant seafarers who have sailed/to and from Bristol/throughout the ages." At the base of the monument is a poem by Capt. J. Earl, a member of the Bristol Branch of the Merchant Navy Association:
"Merchant Seamen/In war and peace they plied their trade/Over the angry seas/Remember them as here you stand/Beneath these placid trees."
The memorial was unveiled by HRH The Princess Royal, Princess Anne, at a public ceremony on 21 May 2001.

Counterslip Baptist Chapel. The rebuilt Baptist chapel on the south side of the original route of Counterslip. The chapel was founded in 1810 and rebuilt in 1839. It was damaged by bombing during the second World War and dismantled after the war. The Classical-looking block on the corner with Temple Street and Philip Street possessed a hipped roof, whereas the roof of the main chapel, at least in later years, was hipped with a gablet. The site now lies beneath the Keg Store of Courage's Brewery.

No.23 St. Michael's Hill. The building is an early seventeenth-century jettied, gabled house of two storeys and attic. The ground floor has a single central sash window with the main entrance door on the northern side of the elevation. The first floor is jettied and at the centre of the elevation there is a projecting bay containing a sash. There is also a projecting bay in the centre of the attic gable.
It is not clear when the building was constructed but it was probably one of a pair with No.25 [1414M]. Nos.27-29 St. Michael's Hill [1415M & 1416M] were built c.1637 and this house is probably roughly contemporary. The building was occupied by Henry Berry in 1695 and by a sequence of other individuals through the eighteenth century (Leech 2000, 74-75).

No.27 St. Michael's Hill, located on the western side of St. Michael's Hill. The building is an early seventeenth-century jettied, gabled house of two storeys and attic. The ground floor has a single central sash window with the main entrance door on the northern side of the elevation. The first floor is jettied and at the centre of the elevation there is a projecting bay containing a sash. There is also a projecting bay in the centre of the attic gable.
The house was demised to Philip Bowcher the younger by his cousin Humphrey Andrewes in 1637 and during the 1660s it was apparently occupied by Richard Cox. In 1695 the house was occupied by Martha Jones, widow, and by a sequence of other individuals through the eighteenth century (Leech 2000, 74-75).

KNOWN_AS: Warehouse at the rear of No.16 King Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Warehouse, located at the rear of No.16 King Street (24M) and fronting on to Little King Street. The building was constructed in the late seventeenth- or early eighteenth-century and was of three storeys with hipped pantile roof. The structure was probably linked to the rear of No.16 King Street by a gallery at first-floor level. The walls of the building were re-constructed in brick in the twentieth-century, although three seventeenth-century cross beams at ground floor and the central cross beam at first-floor survive, as does much of the original roof.

Colston's School, located on the north-eastern side of Temple Street. The school had been established and was supported through voluntary contributions before 1711 when Edward Colston established a new school building and schoolhouse (Manchee 1831, 176). The churchwardens and vestrymen were given responsibility for the management of the school and were instructed to meet annually on the Wednesday of Easter week to agree the Master's salary for the coming year, appoint the boys and appoint a clergyman to teach the catechism. The school was also to be inspected four times a year by four visiting clergymen (Manchee 1831, 177). The building was set back slightly from Temple Street, the front area being enclosed by a low boundary wall. The school building was a single storey in height with a hipped pantile roof with two dormers with casement windows. The main, south-west facing elevation had a five-window range, with the main entrance on the northern side beneath a 12-pane window. Colston's arms and and a plaque were fixed to the main elevation above the central window. The plaque bore the legend: "This Charity School was erected & endowed by Edwd.Colston Esqr. Native of this Parish Anno Dom. 1711 For the education in Reading Writing Cyphering and perfecting in the Church Catechism as it is now Established by Law And also for the Cloathing Forty Poor Boys of this Parish for ever."
At the beginning of the 1830s 30 boys were being educated at the school (Manchee 1831, 176).

House. No.35 Temple Street. Attached. 3 storeys; gabled front; 1-window range; no attic storey evident. Left-hand entrance; shopfront, possibly of a butcher; date of 1593 on beam above ground-floor. Sashes to upper storeys.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza Hotel, Victoria Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Alderman Stevens Almshouse, located on the east side of Temple Street, on the south side of the junction with Cart Lane. The building was of two storeys; 5-bay; plinth; string courses; parapet; ridge roof parallel to street, stacks both ends. Blind elevation to lane. Central entrance, double doors, up two steps. Segmental pediment over doorway. Cross-windows to both storeys. Rainwater pipes with moulded decoration to heads, each end of elevation. Semi-circular porch-like structure at left end of ground-floor. North wall of rubble, rendered.

A small structure located on the south side of Broad Weir, built into the Castle Ditch. The structure had a hipped roof with a chimney stack on south side. It may have been the shelter for the ducking stool that was sited here. The upper storey was at street level, the lower storey or foundation at water level. The ducking stool was in use from probably at least the fifteenth century, and was still being maintained in 1754. It may have been removed in about 1785 (Arrowsmith, 1906 151).
Philadelphia Bridge, located near the southern end of Philadelphia Street, crossing the northern course of the River Frome. The bridge was a single span arch of stone construction with parapets.

Horseshoes Bridge, a foot bridge crossing that portion of the River Frome that led to Castle Ditch and the Castle Mill. Connected Ellbridge Passage, adjacent to the 'Three Horseshoes', on the south bank, with Ropewalk, opposite on the north side. Single span timber footbridge. No piers as such, but propped off the river walls. Bowed with timber post-and-rail sides.

Bridge. Frome Bridge, sometimes called Christmas Bridge. Lay on Christmas Street, otherwise known as Fromebridge or Knifesmith Street. A medieval crossing of the River Frome, and in fact the lowest bridging point until the Drawbridge was built in 1714. There were houses on both sides of the street here by at least 1673 (Millerd's map - which also shows 2 arches to the bridge). Stone construction. Also recorded as Arch.El.Nos.68A and, probably, 172A).

No.47 Redcliff Street. The building was probably constructed in the seventeenth century and was a jettied, gable house of three storeys and attic. First and third floors jettied. Entrance to left of centre, right of which is a large open window or shopfront. Bays with Ipswich windows to first and second floors; 3-light casement to attic; eaves jettied out. Sign says "NEWMAN Undertaker".
The site of the building now lies beneath modern No.46 Redcliff Street.

Nos.48-50 Redcliff Street. Gabled fronts. All jettied to first-floor, Nos.49 & 50 to second-floor. Upper storey of No.50 possibly slate-hung. Shopfronts to all; 8-light mullioned windows to first-floors of Nos.48 & 49; cross-window to upper storey of No.49. Now beneath the north side of the western end of Three Queens Lane.

No.57 Redcliff Hill, located on the west side of Redcliff Hill. Attached to north, with a tall boundary wall to south. Two storeys and attic. Entrance to left; shopfront above cellar access; arms (?) above doorway. Three cross-windows to first-floor, with moulded string-course above; two cross-windows to second-floor. The 'Ship Inn' by the 19th.century. The property of Owen's Charity in, e.g.1877.

No.18 King Street, located on the southern side of King Street. The building was constructed in the mid-1660s apparently as the western of a group of three, the lease for the plots of Nos.16-18 being granted by the Bristol Corporation to Francis Bayley, a shipwright, in 1663 (BRO 04335(5) fo.4). This lease set a limit of three years for construction, suggesting that the three buildings had probably been completed by 1666. The building was refenestrated in the eighteenth-century and restored in the late twentieth-century.
The house has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/16/603).

No.58, on the west side of Redcliff Hill. Attached on both sides. Two storeys and attic; gabled front. Left entrance, right-hand bowed shopfront, further doorway or window between; full-width pentice above. Bays to upper storeys.

No.59 Redcliff Hill. Attached on both sides. Three storeys, roof not visible. Entrance left or centre; window to right; two cross-windows each to upper storeys, with moulded string-course above first-floor.

No.60 Redcliff Hill. Attached at least to its south. In the house was born Francis Freeling Esq., sometime Secretary to the General Post Office. Two storeys and attic; gabled front. Ground-floor apparently below pavement level. Two doorways to left, window to right. Single sashes to both upper floors, the upper 18+12 panes.

Shot tower, located on the west side of Redcliff Hill. The shot tower was constructed as part of a conversion of a house of c.1700 by William Watts who invented the process. The tower was square or rectangular in plan and was possibly of brick construction. Two small additions, to north and east, at the top. The property of Owen's Charity in, e.g. 1877, when described as "Shot tower and portion of a warehouse".
The building was demolished in 1968 to allow widening of Redcliff Hill. The site of the monument now lies mainly beneath the western part of the highway.

Garden house at No.17 Marlborough Hill. The building was a lodge or summerhouse (ie. a merchant's second residence) of mid eighteenth-century date which was sited in the corner of a roughly square garden plot. It was probably of three storeys and survives within No.17 to first floor level (Leech 1998, 8).

Garden on the east side of Marlborough Hill, immediately adjacent to Marlborough House. The garden occupied a roughly square plot of ground. It was first recorded cartographically by the survey of the city by Plumley and Ashmead of 1828 but had disappeared by the time of the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883. The layout consisted of paths around the edges of the plot and a circular bed at the centre.

No.37 High Street, now beneath No.35-38 High Street. The building had five storeys, two bays and a hipped roof. The ground floor was used as a shop front, while the fenestration was entirely of sashes. The frontage was entirely vertical with no jettying.

The sugar refinery of Isaac Hort in Redcliff Backs. A tenement on Redcliff Backs was converted into a sugar refinery apparently by Isaac Hort in the latter part of the seventeenth century and was taken over by Stephen Clutterbuck in 1715. After Clutterbuck's death the refinery passed to Nicholas Bloom and remained in the hands of the Bloom family into the second half of the eighteenth century. The building became the slaughterhouse of the butcher Robert Bartlett in 1774 but was leased to Messrs. Morgan, Blake & Co. in 1776 who resumed sugar refining there. The building survived into the nineteenth century but at least half was destroyed for the creation of Ferry Street in the mid nineteenth-century.
Elements of the south wall of the building survive in the listed wall in Ferry Street.

No.103, Redcliff Street. The building was a house on the west side of Redcliff Street of probable seventeenth-century date. The building was the premises of William Brookman, confectioner, by 1825 and Brookman occupied the building for several decades until it was added to the premises of Richard Gibbs and Sons, linendrapers, in the latter part of the nineteenth century.

KNOWN_AS: House at the north-west end of Golden Lion Passage
MONUMENT_DESC: A house at the north-west end of Golden Lion Passage, a court off Redcliff Street and leading to Ferry Lane. The house was one of seven built by Thomas Powell in the late 1780s and seems to have comprised a single room on each floor. The building was of brick and the west wall appears to survive in the fabric of the former garage No.101 Redcliff Street. A description of the court in 1850 states that the floors of the ground-floor rooms of the dwellings were below the then ground level.

Redcliffe Poor House, located on the north side of Commercial Road. The almshouse was built in 1804 by the Bristol docks company as part of the construction of the New Cut "under the powers of their act, and at their own expense" (Manchee 1831, 57-58) and replaced the original poor house on the west side of Redcliff Hill (BUAD 983M). The almshouse appears to have been managed by the vestry of St. Mary Redcliffe and supported using parish funds.
The building was still extant during the First World War but was subsequently demolished.
Tobacco Manufactury, Redcliff Street

The Three Cups, lying to the rear of the Old Custom House, Welsh Back (41M). The form and construction date of the building is unknown. It is recorded on a plan of the Crow Lane burial ground in 1850 (BRO Plan Book C folio 98a, Brett 1995, 7, fig 4) that indicates that the building was accessed via a passage from Welsh Back between the Old Custom House, then a house occupied by Frederick Willis, and premises occupied by Timothy McDonell. Adjoining the Three Cups to the north were a shed, yards and a wash house.
The Three Cups had been replaced by warehousing (840M) by the time of the 1:500 Ordnance Survey of 1884 and now lies beneath part of the site of Favell House.

KNOWN_AS: Social Club to rear of King David Hotel, Upper Maudlin Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Former social club building, adjoining courtyard to the rear of the King David Hotel, Upper Maudlin Street.

Gate lodge on the north side of Park Row. One of a pair (with 3223M) of eighteenth century entrance lodges for Tyndall's Park first depicted on a survey of the Royal Fort and lands adjoing belonging to Thomas Tyndall dated 1785 (BRO DC/E/40/68/1, Bryant 1994, 9-11). Plumley and Ashmeads survey of 1828 depict these lodges, altough the eastern lodge is unshaded, each with a rectangular pond to the rear. The large scale survey of 1855 also shows these lodges, although they are absent on the 1883 1:500 Ordnance Survy plan.

A house described as newly built by John Jones in 1602 (Leech, 1999, 14) and later the second residence of George Lane (Leech, 2000, 15). The building is depicted on Rocque's plan of 1742 and in two drawings by James Stewart made in 1745-1746 (2762 - 2763). These views, of the dwelling house "on Washingtons Breach" suggest that the building was a gabled house of two storeys and attic, with a two-storey eastern extension (possibly a former inn or tavern) with mullioned windows. It is believed that the site of the house now lies largely beneath the north side of Park Row and its pavement. Part of the building may have been located during the archaeological watching brief as part of the foundation works for the University Gate office development in 1994 [578].

A house recorded in the rate books as belonging to John Garway in 1679. The house was first depicted on Millerd's revised map of c.1710. A drawing by James Stewart made in 1752 (Bodleian, MS.Gough, Somersetshire 2, fol.14) suggests that the house had three storeys with a projecting two storey porch (Leech, 2000, 59). 
The property is recorded on several plans of the area including Rocque's 1742 plan and estate plans of the later eighteenth century. By the time of the 1884 Ordnance Survey plan the house had become the Preventive Home for Girls. The 1951 1:1250 Ordnance Survey plan records the site as "Ruin" suggesting that the property was largely destroy by bombing in the war and the site had been cleared entirely by the time of the OS survey in 1956.

No.39 St. Michael's Hill, located on the western side of St. Michael's Hill. The building was rebuilt along with the adjoining no.41 between 1695 and 1703 as a three storey house attached house with attic dormers (Leech, 2000, 77). The ground floor appears to have consisted of two parlours and a kitchen towards the rear and a detached wash kitchen behind as depicted on an early nineteenth century outline plan (ibid.)(BRO 04479(3) fol.63a; 38041/BMC/12/PL4 fol.37). Both no.39 and 41 were completely rebuilt in the 1950s and only the exterior shell of the building is likely to be original fabric.
The house was in the ownership of Owen Williams in 1696 (Leech 2000, 77).

Somerset House, 42 Alfred Hill. Constructed c.1800 with a three storey building fronting Alfred Hill and a later (pre 1855) two storey extension to the rear. The earliest clear depiction of the building is on Plumley and Ashmead's plan of 1828, although Donne's plan of 1800 indicates development fronting Alfred Hill. The rear extension had been constructed by the time of Ashmead's survey of 1855.
The house was built as one of a pair of dwellings with the adjoining Dorset House to the northwest (demolished 1905-8).
Somerset house was converted into flats in c.1977.

Croft Dale, Hepburn Road, a two storey attached house of mid nineteenth century date to the rear of 100-102 Stokes Croft.
The building is rendered with limestone quoins and detailing including an arched doorway in the front/south elevation with incised name 'Croft Dale' on limestone and four pain fan light..
The building is first depicted on Ashmead's 1855 survey at which time it is shown as a semi detached pair of dwellings adjoining the Carriageworks (1466M) to the north and a north-south aligned building to the southwest. A similar arrangement is shown on later nineteenth century plans.
By the time of the 1950 Ordnance Survey the structure is depicted as a single dwelling attached only to the industrial building to the north.
When the site was visited in July 2008 the building was extant with the open area to the south laid to lawn. The door and fanlight over appeared to be original, although all windows have been replaced. Features associated with the former attached linear building depicted on the 1855 plan,  including door openings and brick stringer course, were visible in the west garden rubble stone boundary wall.

Ivy Cottage, located some 35 metres to the north of Royal Fort Road. A building stood within Joachim's Close, "an closse of pasture", and was extant, and apparently ruinous, by 1581 when it was mentioned in a lease of the close by the Dean and Chapter to Elizabeth Dee as the remains of a toft.. A survey of the lands of the Dean and Chapter in c1618 also recorded this structure, describing it as "an house 40 foote long built within a stump of an house without [h]is covering 7 yards long" (quoted in Leech, 2000 44). It Is not clear whether this was the building subsequently known as Ivy Cottage. The building was, however, certainly extant by 1683 when it was occupied by John Millard. By 1699 Thomas Hickes, who owned the building as part of his lease of Cromwell House (BUAD 1412M), was letting it to Margaret Gilbert, widow. The Hicks family contibued to hold the However, James Stewart's drawings of the area of 1752 (BUAD 2756 & 2757) indicate that it was by that date either ruinous once more or being rebuilt. At some time between 1828 and 1881 a bay window was added to the eastern wall of the building and it was known as Ivy Cottage by the latter date (Leech, 2000 46). The building survived into the twentieth century but was subsequently demolished. Its site now lies beneath an extension ot the rear of the former Hospital for Sick Children.
No.7 Pipe Lane, located on the southern side of Pipe Lane. Early 18th. century. Attached to both sides. A gabled roof, M-shaped.
No.8 Pipe Lane, located on the southern side of Pipe Lane.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Cathedral of the Holy and Undivided Trinity, College Green
MONUMENT_DESC: The Chapter House of St Augustine's Abbey, now part of Bristol Cathedral. The chapter house is located on the east side of the cloister and is a late Norman structure.
Cellar, 13 Small Street
Cellar, 14 Small Street
Cellar, 16-17 Small Street
Nos.16-17, Small Street. The 1877 schedule of property administered by the Municipal Charities lists both as belonging to Foster's Almshouse.

KNOWN_AS: Engineer Volunteer HQ and Drill Hall
MONUMENT_DESC: The Engineer Volunteer Headquarters and Drill Hall, Trinity Street. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map in the early 1880s.

The Merchants Arms, No.1 Prince Street, located on the corner of Prince Street and King Street. The building was of later seventeenth or early eighteenth-century date and was of four-storeys.
The main, north-facing, elevation in King Street was of six bays and was plainer. There was a jetty between first and second floor. The two western sashes at second floor level were missing. The west-facing, Prince Street, frontage was of five bays. There was a central doorway in the west frontage with a broken pediment above it. A large window occupied most of the north side of the ground floor while there was only a single window to the south of the doorway. The sashes at first and second floor were evenly spaced, and at the first floor the centre window was occupied by a plaque. The two gables at attic level each had a sash with drip moulds above. The roof was pantiled and had traceried barge boards. A string course divided the second and attic storeys.
By 1882 the building was a public house known as the Merchants Arms and the street directory of that year gives the licensee as Edward Price.
The inn was demolished to make way for the construction of the inner circuit road in 1936 the Prince Street roundabout (removed in 2006) was constructed over its site.

No.27 Victoria Street. The building is part of a terrace of four gabled houses on the west side of Victoria Street (having fronted on to St. Thomas Street until the 1870s when Victoria Street was cut through the existing street pattern). The plots were the property of St. Thomas's Church and four shops are known to have been present on the site by 1456 and a date plaque on the front of the building which gives a date of c.1456 is presumably a reference to the documentary evidence for the earlier tenements. The present building was constructed between 1673 and 1675 by Henry Gleson, linendraper (BRO P/StT/D/151). The building is a single-bay timber-framed structure of three storeys plus attic with a pantile gabled roof. The ground floor is occupied by a shopfront and the first and second floors are bay windows. The attic has an eight over eight pane sash window. There is a large brick chimney stack on the southern side of the building. The original plan form consisted of a front and rear room at each floor with a winder stair against the south wall between the two.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/325).

Nos. 114 & 115, Redcliff Street. A pair of jettied houses with timber-framed fronts, each of three storeys and attic; gabled fronts; 3 17th.century doors to ground-floor; heavy cornice above. Canted bays to both first and second floors, the lower storey with Ipswich windows; cross-windows either side of bays at No.115, to one side of lower bay at No.114; glazing either side of wide sash at third-floor of No.115. Brackets to first-floor (5no.), and to eaves.

Block of four houses with a further two added at the west end. On Pile Street. Attached both ends. Ridge roofs, with dormers (2no. & 1no.) to north side. Ground-floor of 6 no. doorways, each with a window to one side or the other, all shuttered. A possible plaque above the fourth doorway. This may have been an almshouse or similar.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: The Old Council House, Corn Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Ewen's Churchyard, located on the west side of Broad Street,on the north side of the parish Church of St. Ewen (BUAD 334M). It was enclosed by high walls in the medieval period. At that time it probably measured around 12.7 metres from north-east to south-west and was 5.5 metres wide. By the end of the eighteenth century the area of the churchyard had been reduced to a rectangle of land on the north side of the tower measuring 4 metres (the width of the tower) by 2.4 metres.
The churchyard was not used for interment after the eighteenth century and buildings had been constructed on much of it by 1795. The site was developed for the rear part of Robert Smirke's Council House (BUAD 342M) in the 1820s.

No.28, High Street or the "Druids Arms" public house. The building was a medieval house with an arch brace roof with windbraces.
It was demolished to allow for the widening of the end of St. Nicholas Street.

St. Werburgh's Churchyard located on the north side of St. Werburgh's Church (BUAD 3893M), against the west side of Small Street. The church was in existence by the twelfth century and the churchyard is presumably contemporary with the establishment of the church. Little is known about the form of the medieval churchyard. By the early nineteenth century the churchyard was approximately rectangular, measuring 19 metres from east to west and 17.9 metres north-south. The entrance was off Small Street along a short lane paved with Penant sandstone flags. Burial in the churchyard was ended by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852.
After St. Werburgh's church (BUAD 393M) was demolished in 1878 the two sites were subsequently redeveloped. Human remains, including eighteen crania, were from the churchyard and were subject to study by Dr. John Beddoe (BUAD 217; Beddoe 1878-79). The entrance lane to the churchyard is extant.

Waterloo House, located on the southern side of Waterloo Road, Old Market. The building is apparently recorded by James Millerd's map of Bristol of c.1715, suggesting that it was constructed in the late seventeenth- or early-eighteenth century. The building survived into the early 1880s but had been apparently been demolished by the beginning of the twentieth century to make way for a railway turntable (BUAD 1274M).

KNOWN_AS: Goat in Armour public house, No.81 Broad Quay
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Goat in Armour public house, No.81 Broad Quay (while the building was located in Narrow Quay, the street numbering for Broad Quay continued into Narrow Quay). The site was created by the infilling of Aldsworth's Dock in the mid-seventeenth century and a building is recorded on the site by Millerd's 1673 map of Bristol.
The building was a house of late seventeenth-century date and contained an elaborately carved stone chimneypiece dated 1682. The form of the building as constructed as known although it apears to have been a single-bay structure of at least three storeys. The plot measured 13.8 metres from east to west and 6.25 metres north-south. The building appears to have been refronted in the early nineteenth century (Winstone 1960, pl.66) and the Goad fire insurance plan indicates that it was of four storeys by 1887.
By the beginning of the 1870s the building had become a public house, the licensee then being Patrick Gorey. By 1882 the licensee was J. Guzio Srichia and the building was still in use as a public house in 1891, in the tenure of John Way. It was apparently demolished soon after the closure of Alderskey Lane in 1900 (Pritchard 1904, 128-129) and the chimneypiece was retrieved. This is now in the Bristol Savages Wigwam at Red Lodge.
The site was subsequently revedeloped for the Co-operative Wholesale building. The site of the rear part was archaeologically excavated in 1979 (BUAD 442) but any evidence for the building appears to have been removed by the basements of the CWS building.

KNOWN_AS: Sugar House north of Nelson Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
Sugar House, located on the south bank of the river Frome, some 25 metres to the north of Nelson Street. The building is recorded by the survey of the city made in 1828 by John Plumley and George Ashmead. The building was recorded as a parallelogram measuring 28 from east to west by 15 metres north-south.
The site is now beneath Nelson House on the south side of Rupert Street.

No.10, Bellevue. The building is the southernmost of a terrace of nineteen houses. The plot, formerly part of the grounds associated with Clifton Hill House, was leased from the Society of Merchant Venturers by Harry Elderton in 1792 for a term of forty years (Ison 1952, 234). Construction of the terrace began under the supervision of William Paty (Priest 2003, 101) but was abandoned in 1793 when the outbreak of war caused a slump in development. The buildings remained uncompleted for nearly two decades but the terrace had apparently been completed by 1815.
The building is a rendered three-storey house with attic and basement. It has a slate mansard roof. A raised walk on the east side of the building extends the full length of the terrace.
In 1882 the building was occupied by Mrs C. H. Massiah.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/6).

No.12, Bellevue. The building is the southernmost of a terrace of nineteen houses. The plot, formerly part of the grounds associated with Clifton Hill House, was leased from the Society of Merchant Venturers by Harry Elderton in 1792 for a term of forty years (Ison 1952, 234). Construction of the terrace began under the supervision of William Paty (Priest 2003, 101) but was abandoned in 1793 when the outbreak of war caused a slump in development. The buildings remained uncompleted for nearly two decades but the terrace had apparently been completed by 1815.
The building is a rendered three-storey house with attic and basement. It has a slate mansard roof. A raised walk on the east side of the building extends the full length of the terrace.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/6).

No.14, Bellevue. The building is the southernmost of a terrace of nineteen houses. The plot, formerly part of the grounds associated with Clifton Hill House, was leased from the Society of Merchant Venturers by Harry Elderton in 1792 for a term of forty years (Ison 1952, 234). Construction of the terrace began under the supervision of William Paty (Priest 2003, 101) but was abandoned in 1793 when the outbreak of war caused a slump in development. The buildings remained uncompleted for nearly two decades but the terrace had apparently been completed by 1815.
The building is a rendered three-storey house with attic and basement. It has a slate mansard roof. A raised walk on the east side of the building extends the full length of the terrace.
In 1882 the building was occupied by George Morley.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/6).

No.17, Bellevue. The building is the southernmost of a terrace of nineteen houses. The plot, formerly part of the grounds associated with Clifton Hill House, was leased from the Society of Merchant Venturers by Harry Elderton in 1792 for a term of forty years (Ison 1952, 234). Construction of the terrace began under the supervision of William Paty (Priest 2003, 101) but was abandoned in 1793 when the outbreak of war caused a slump in development. The buildings remained uncompleted for nearly two decades but the terrace had apparently been completed by 1815.
The building is a rendered three-storey house with attic and basement. It has a slate mansard roof. A raised walk on the east side of the building extends the full length of the terrace. A two-storey porch with a semi-circular arched front ground-floor window and cornices at ground and first floor level, was added to the entrance doorway in the late nineteenth century.
In 1882 the building was occupied by Rev. A. H. Ward.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/6).
George Hotel, Canon's Marsh. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map in the early 1880s.

No.19, Bellevue. The building is the southernmost of a terrace of nineteen houses. The plot, formerly part of the grounds associated with Clifton Hill House, was leased from the Society of Merchant Venturers by Harry Elderton in 1792 for a term of forty years (Ison 1952, 234). Construction of the terrace began under the supervision of William Paty (Priest 2003, 101) but was abandoned in 1793 when the outbreak of war caused a slump in development. The buildings remained uncompleted for nearly two decades but the terrace had apparently been completed by 1815.
The building is a rendered three-storey house with attic and basement. It has a slate mansard roof. A raised walk on the east side of the building extends the full length of the terrace.
In 1882 the building was occupied by Rev. T. Bowman.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/6).

Transit shed located at Narrow Quay, 12 metres to the south of the Bush Warehouse (BUAD 1186M). The shed appears to have been constructed by 1828. It was still in existence by the early 1880s and is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town Plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.9) surveyed in 1883. The structure was an open shed, with the roof supported on columns (six on each of the north and south sides; fourteen in total), measuring 16 metres from east to west by 7.5 metres wide.

No.21/22, Welsh Back. Attached to the south. The building was a warehouse of nineteenth-century date. 4 storeys; 4-window range. Rubble (?) with limestone dressings. A rusticated ground-floor with segmental-headed arches. Above a plat band, pilasters to each end and centre of facade, strings between storeys. A cornice and parapet. The windows appear to be segmental-headed. Now largely under surface car parking rather than Telephone House proper.

Nos.23 & 24, Welsh Back A pair of houses on Welsh Back, latterly a public house (No.23, right) and dining rooms (No.24, left). Attached. C18 fronts, but possibly earlier structures behind. 3 storeys and attics; hipped (?) roofs, with 1 hipped dormer each; a heavy string above the first-floor; cornice. Entrances at outer ends, shop windows at the inward. 2 sashes each to first and second floors. Lateral stack(s). Now mostly below Welsh Back, but some beneath the surface car parking associated with Telephone House.

Warehouse, No.25, Welsh Back. The building was a warehouse of nineteenth-century date. 4 storeys; 3-window range. A left-hand entrance and right-hand window, both with segmental heads. The first-floor with a sash either side of a taller central window, probably a former entrance. 3 sashes to the second-floor; the third-floor with a sash either side of a blank embrasure. A rendered facade with end pilasters. Now largely under a surface car park rather than Telephone House proper.

KNOWN_AS: Weigh bridge and house, Welsh Back
POSTAL_ADDRESS: Dock Labour Board Sports & Social Club
MONUMENT_DESC: Weighbridge and house, the latter immediately east of the former. On Welsh Back, between the street and the harbour. A single-storey weighbridge house of ashlar with banded rustication; square in plan; hipped roof; single square chimney-stack on east side, possibly in south-east corner. In 1930 the south elevation carried the legend 'CITY WEIGHBRIDGE'.

Warehouse. On Welsh Back. Attached. C19. 4 storeys; 4 bays; brick-fronted; hipped roof with end stacks. An arcade of tall Gothic arches, narrow, wide, wide and narrow, enclosing both first and second floor windows. At third-floor, the windows grouped into 2, 3, 3 & 2 lights, respectively, above which a parapet was carried on a corbel table. Details of the ground-floor are not clear. Designed for Messrs.Jefferies in 1885.

Warehouse, possibly originally a house or other structure. Attached. Abutting the east wall of the 'Windsor Castle' public house in Queen Charlotte Street; aligned east-west. Latterly a part of the Back Hall complex. 2 storeys; gabled roof. At least 4 trusses in the roof, tie-beam trusses but including at least 1 A-frame examples; some of the tie-beams slightly arched. Some collars. 2 rows of purlins each side, with some wind-braces. Gutted in an air-raid before June 1941 (Street's notes).

No.34, Prince Street, located on the west side of Prince Street. Known as No.34 when the street was consecutively numbered. C19. Attached warehouse. 4 storeys and 4 bays (but possibly 5 of either). Brick-fronted. The third-floor was higher than the others. Strings, above the second and third floors. A left-hand entrance. All windows with segmental heads.

Fountain in Somerset Square. Somerset Square was developed in 1756 and the fountain or conduit head was sited at its centre. It is constructed of limestone ashlar with a Pennant sandstone base and is octagonal in plan. In form it has a plinth with statuary niches with pedestals and trefoil heads and is topped by a circular band of acanthus. Above this there are plain columns to a cap and a large vase with a fir-cone. The fountain restored in 1962.
The fountain has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/1688).

KNOWN_AS: Alderman Jackson's House, Small Street Court
MONUMENT_DESC: Alderman Jackson's town house on the north side of Small Street Court. The building was interpreted, on the basis of observations during demolition, to have been originally a timber structure. It was remodelled in the second quarter of the seventeenth-century when the original hall was converted into two rooms by the insertion of a floor. The upper room had a moulded plaster ceiling and a Jacobean carved stone chimney piece. The ground floor room also had a moulded chimney piece, although the lower part of it had been damaged by the time of demolition. Originally the room had been panelled and had a moulded plaster ceiling. The building was demolished in March 1923. Oliver Cromwell was reputed to have stayed there.

No.5, St. James's Square.
The building was destroyed by bombing on 11 December 1940.

No.6, St. James's Square.
The building was destroyed by bombing on 24 November 1940.

No.7, St. James's Square.
The building was destroyed by bombing on 2 December 1940.

No.8, St. James's Square.
The building was destroyed by bombing on 24 November 1940.

No.9, St. James's Square.
The building was destroyed by bombing on 24 November 1940.

No.10, St. James's Square.
The building was destroyed by bombing on 2 December 1940.
First slip above Back Ferry Slip. The slipway was on Welsh Back, opposite the north-east corner of Mill Avenue.

Second slip above Back Ferry Slip. The slipway was on Welsh Back, almost opposite the south-east corner of Queen Square Avenue. On the south side of the lane between the C19/20 transit sheds, and now relating similarly to their modern replacements. Part should survive below the quay.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Welsh Back Squash & Health Centre, Welsh Back
MONUMENT_DESC: Third slip above Back Ferry Slip. The slipway was on Welsh Back, opposite the north-east corner of Queen Square Avenue.
The Water Gate of Bristol Castle, located in the south curtain wall of the castle. The gate gave access across the castle moat to the King's Orchard between the river Avon and Queen Street.

Brass Ware House, a brass works, located on the west side of Queen Street. The building is recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 map of the city which labels it as "Brass Ware House", showing a building about 115 feet (35 metres) by 50 feet (15 metres).

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Former railway wharf (Lower Midland Yard), Avon Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Lime kiln, located between Avon Street and the River Avon. The linekiln was recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 plan of Brisotl as lying close to the river, about 90 feet (28 metres) upstream of Cuckolds Pill and 100 feet (30 metres) from Avon Street. The kiln was circular in plan.

The Venus glasshouse. The glassworks was located on the south side of a yard on the west side of the southern end of Temple Street. On the opposite side of the yard was Perrott's glasshouse. Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol records the cone, as "Glass H[ouse].".

KNOWN_AS: St. Thomas's burial ground, Mitchell Lane
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Thomas burial ground, located on the north side of Mitchell Lane. The cemetery was an extension burial ground for the parish of St. Thomas. It measured approximately 18 metres from east to west by 11-12 metres north-south. The churchyard was closed to burials by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852.
The site now lies mainly beneath the rear of No.21, St. Thomas Street, which has a basement, but the southern part is under the widened Mitchell Lane.
Stores, Canon's Marsh. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map in the early 1880s.

Redcliff Caves. A system of caverns cut into the red sandstone (Mercia Mudstone) at the western end of the hill known as Redcliffe.The caves were probably cut for sand to supply the glassworks on Redcliff Wharf during the post-medieval period and extend for some 100 metres into the cliff. Brick columns support the roof of the caves to stabilise the foundations of houses on Redcliff Parade above.
The caves have been investigated on a number of occasions, excavations taking place during the first three years of the Second World War (BUAD 3404) and in the 1960s (BUAD 493). The caves were surveyed in the late 1980s by the Field Archaeology Section of the City of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery (BUAD 481) and have reportedly been further explored in the 1990s by Axbridge Caving Club, leading to the discovery of further chambers. Features have been found inside the caves including wells and graffiti.
The results of the investigations have not been analysed, indeed in most cases the location of the finds and site archives is unknown.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: The Old Council House, Corn Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
Council house, located on the north side of Corn Street. The building was constructed between 1701 and 1704, the site having been recorded as cleared in 1701. There was a date of 1704 on the west side of the south-west quoin.
Attached to west. 2-storey, with attic storey in hipped roof. 5 bays with central entrance up a few steps. Plinth, string course and cornice. Entrance between columns with segmental pediment. Triangular pediment to central first-floor window, segmental pediments to outer windows, decorative foliage over inners; niches with shell heads between first-floor windows. Architraves to all windows, all sashes. Rusticated quoins around the two Corn Street corners. Two dormers, 6/6 pane sashes, to south side of attic.

KNOWN_AS: A Bond Bonded Warehouse, Smeaton Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
A Bond Bonded Warehouse, located on the south side of Cumberland Basin, between the basin and the New Cut. The warehouse was built in 1905 to a design by the Docks Committee engineer. William Cowlin and Son Ltd. were responsible for the constructing the warehouse which has a steel frame at ground and first floor, while the upper floors are supported on cast iron columns (Buchanan & Cossons, 1969 64).
The building footprint measures 65 metres from north-west to south-east by 32 metres wide. It is of nine storeys, with the south-west facing having 18 bays and the side elevations 6 bays. The ground floor is in black brick forming a low plinth and has large, arched openings for loading on the south-west side. The four bays at the centre of this elevation project forward of the building and this accommodates a large arched entrance at ground floor. The upper floors are finished with red bricks, and blue engineering bricks. The building has a cornice of black moulded brick, and stone parapet. The roof is of Welsh slate. The building is still used as a bonded warehouse. Internally the building is open plan, and is divided into two equal parts by central spine wall. The steel and iron columns support RSJs on which the segmental-arched concrete floor slabs rest.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/1294).

The Bristol Royal Infirmary, located on the south side of Marlborough Street, between Lower Maudlin Street and Whitson Street. The infirmary was opened in 1737 in a former brewery building to which two extensions were added to form a rectangular court enclosed on three sides (Stevenson 2000, 137). This building was recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol on the corner of Maudlin Lane and Earl Street, but not reaching to Marlborough Street.
A replacement building was constructed in 1784-86. Main block of an 11-window range, the central 5 windows set forward under a pediment. Wings of 2-window range, with 1-window range links. All 3 storeys with attics, but basement storey(s) at west end of main elevation to Marlborought Street, and to sides and rear. Sash windows. Much altered and extended.
The Guildhall in Broad Street. The building was erected on the site of an earlier Guildhall in 1843.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Bristol Eye Hospital, Lower Maudlin Street
MONUMENT_DESC: The Blind Asylum, located on the south-west side of Lower Maudlin Street. The left and centre sections survive, altered, as a pair of attached houses in early-mid Georgian style. Double-depth plan; 3 storeys, attic and basement. An unequal pair. Hopper head on left of the right-hand house is dated 1753 with the initials IBS.

KNOWN_AS: House west of Sheppard's timber yard, Lewin's Mead
MONUMENT_DESC: House. On the south side of Lewins Mead, west of the timber yard entrance. Attached. 3 storeys and attic; gabled front; 2-window range; jettied. Central entrance, bay to right, bracket at left end. Bays at either end of first-floor, 6-light windows to front, 2-light to sides; intermediate cross-window. Central bay with 8-light front each to second-floor and attic. Studs to panels at all floors above ground-floor. Two purlins to each side of roof. Lateral stack(s) on right (west) wall.

KNOWN_AS: House east of Sheppard's timber yard, Lewin's Mead
MONUMENT_DESC: House east of Sheppard's timber yard, located on the south side of Lewins Mead. The building lay east of the timber yard entrance. Attached. 3 storeys and attic; gabled front; 1-window range; jettied. Left-hand entrance, shop window to right. Oriel to first-floor, 3 lights and no transom. Bay to second-floor. 6-light attic window. External collar above window.

Cemetery of Bristol Cathedral, located to the east of the chapter house. The burial ground is an inhumation cemetery established to serve St. Augustine's Abbey (BUAD 58M), presumably c1170. It is likely that the majority of the burials associated with the abbey took place in College Green, with this smaller cemetery being reserved for the more senior members of the religious community. After the dissolution of the abbey in 1534 the burial ground was taken over as the cemetery of Bristol Cathedral.
An Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852 imposed the restriction that no burials were to take place "within five yards of any house, and only one body [was] to be buried in each grave" in the cemetery.

St. Mary Redcliffe Churchyard. The churchyard lies on the south side of St. Mary Redcliffe church and is bounded to the west by Redcliff Hill, to the south by Colston Parade and to the east by Pump Lane. The churchyard was presumably established at the same time as the church.
The churchyard was closed to burials by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852.
The churchyard wall has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/1682).

House. Somewhere in Tower Lane. Possibly attached on its far side. Two storeys and attic; cross-gabled. Right-hand entrance; sash window with shutter(s). Full-width pentice roof. First-floor bay Ipswich window,  with small window to right. 6-light transomed window to attic. No openings in left return elevation, which has blank gable end. Pantile roof. Brick stack to the rear. Possibly only one room per storey.

Daubeny's Sugar House, located on the south side of Nelson Street. Originally Daubeny's sugar house, it was subsequently operated by Stanton & Biggs who occupied it at the period when it was destroyed by fire (Braikenridge Notes, E42). At the time of the fire it was worked by Messrs. Biggs & Savery (Braikenridge Notes, 86). The Diocesan Schools (BUAD 387M) were subsequently constructed on the site.

The Diocesan Schools, Nelson Street. 2 storeys with basement; 5-window range; entrance porch and part of building set back, left. Plinth, with 3 low segmental-arched cellar openings; raised ground-floor. 5 sashes each to ground and first floors, all 8/8 panes; large tablet between the storeys with the legend 'DIOCESAN SCHOOLS'. Cornice and parapet, with large central raised plaque bearing the date 'MDCCCXXI'. In front of the porch, a pair of gate piers, iron gates and railings.

The Hospital, or Lazar House, of St. Mary Magdalen located on the south corner of Redcliff Hill and Guinea Street. The institution was founded as a hospital for women suffering from leprosy. It was in existence by c.1226 when a grant was made by the Prebendary of Bedminster, Gilbert de Lacy, allowing the inmates a chantry and a chaplain (Hall Warren 1907, 205-206). William Worcestre states that the cross and chapel of the hospital were "300 gressus" from the west end of St. Mary Redcliffe Churchyard (Neale 2000, 94-97) and that the "capella scita est vltra viam ducentem ad molendinam vocatam tremyllys in altera parte cimiterij de Westmynster [sic]" (Neale 2000, 98).
The site is now presumably mainly beneath the road and footway in front of Nos.1-5 Waring House.

The Dove Tower. A turret or barbette immediately west of the outside of Blind Gate or St. John's Arch. The tower was built of Pennant Sandstone coursed rubble and Diameter about the same as the width of the arch of the gate, and projecting forward perhaps the same. In January 1821 it was cut back flush with the wall. Prior to removal it was virtually the same height as the walls of the houses on its south side.

Bridewell prison, located on the north-western side of Bridewell Lane. It measured 15 metres long by 10 metres wide. A two-storey building, possibly also with an attic storey. Hipped roof. 4-window range; entrance with porch in second bay from right. This was probably the building on the west side of Bridewell Lane. Gateways across the lane at either end of the building, the nearer (south?) with a segmental arch and enlarged keystone, with a plaque bearing the initals "C.B." above. A studded gate. The building and the gates at either end are recorded in a painting by Hugh O'Neill of 1823 (BRSMG M2446).

No.25 Small Street, a warehouse of three storeys and 3 bays. Shop window on left of ground-floor; entrance; window of 2 lights with semicircular or four-centred heads, in an overall square head, possibly early post-medieval; right-hand entrance with pedimented head, leading to Small Street Court. First and second floors similar to each other, with one window either side of a central full-height access. Roof not visible; coping to front wall and left return.
The building was demolished in the autumn of 1921 (Pritchard, 1922 94-97).

The Bell Inn, located on the east side of St. Thomas Street, but on a through-yard connecting with Temple Street. The site of the inn proper now lies largely beneath the roadway of Victoria Street but is also partly under Nos.16 & 18 (a building at the rear on Temple Street is recorded as BUAD 287M).

The Society of Friends meeting house, located in an alley off the west side of Temple Street. The meeting house was constructed in 1667 to serve the Rosemary Street meeting. It was converted to use as a cholera hospital in 1832 but this use ended c.1834. The building became a Wesleyan Methodist chapel in the later 1830s and in 1840 was bought by Bristol's Jewish community. It was reconstructed as a synagogue, with the addition of a cupola and a colonnade. A further renovation took place in 1857 (Samuel 1997, 70-71). The building was sold in 1868 to enable the construction of Victoria Street and subsequently demolished. Its site is now largely beneath Victoria Street.

Perrott's glasshouse. The glass house was located on the north side of a yard on the west side of the southern end of Temple Street. On the opposite side of the yard was the Venus glasshouse. Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol records the cone, as "Glass H[ouse].".
Overfall Dam Bridge. The bridge carried Cumberland Road across the top of the Overfall Dam [BUAD 750M], immediately west of the Cumberland Road toll gate.

House. On the west side of Temple Street. 3 storeys and attic; gabled rear; ground-floor removed and converted into rear entrance to the 'Bell Inn', St. Thomas Street. Rear wall of rubble construction. Above haulingway in rear elevation the remains of a wide relieving arch, similar to that over first-floor window. First-floor rear window transomed with 10 lights; second-floor 4-light window; attic window of 3-lights. All windows with drip mouldings. Two tall brick stacks on north side.

No.143, Temple Street. A house on the north corner of the eastern end of Long Row. Attached to north. 2 storeys and attic; gabled front; jettied to first and second floors on both elevations. Brackets to both elevations at ground-floor corner; bracket to south eaves. Propped from No.142 across Long Row. Entrance to right; large ground-floor window. Two sashes at first-floor; single window at second-floor.

No.144, Temple Street. Attached. 2 storeys and attic; gabled front;  first-floor flush with ground-floor; second-floor jettied. Arched doorway to right of ground-floor sash. At first-floor, on right, a small square projection, springing from front wall and supported by two columns with square bases; cross-windows to front and north side; timber-framing below windows; hipped roof. A 2-light casement to the attic.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: The Old Council House, Corn Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
No.51 Corn Street.
partly printing office. Probably C17 or earlier, refronted. 4-storey; 2/3-window range. Ground-floor front, extending forward of main elevation, partly extending into next building to west (No.50); bracket beside entrance at east end. 2 sashes to first-floor, large window between; 3 sashes to second-floor, 2 to third; string courses above first and second floors; cornice above third. 
Occupied by City Printing Office in 1824, with Taylor, brush maker, on ground-floor.

Lead Shot Tower, Cheese Lane. The tower was constructed in 1969 and was designed by E. N. Underwood and Partners (Structural Engineers) for the Sheldon Bush and Patent Shot Company. It was awarded a Civic Trust Design Award on completion.
The tower is of reinforced concrete with vertically set slit windows in the tower. The tower has three spines, one containing a lift, and a second a emergency stair. At the top of the building is a twelve-sided room with a central band of vertically set windows. There is a band of ventilation slits beneath the windows. This room house the equipment for pouring the shot which fell into the drop at the centre of the tower.
The Cheese Lane shot tower is one of only three shot towers of any period now surviving in England.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/10010).

J. & F. Savage's Sugar House, located on the north-west side of Wilder Street, between (Upper) York Street and Brunswick Street. The building was apparently in existence by 1772 (BRO 9685(8)). It was recorded in a watercolour drawing by T. L. Rowbotham of 1826 and was of at least five storeys with a hipped roof (BRSMG M3442). The north-east wall comprised a two-window range with no openings in the northern half of the elevation. There was a tall chimney to the rear of the building. The Plumley and Ashmead plan of Bristol of 1828 records its location and indicates that it measured approximately 19 metres from south-west to north-east on the Wilder Street frontage and was 13.5 metres wide. The building appears to have been extant in the early 1880s but had been incorporated into a mineral water works. The building appears subsequently to have been demolished.

KNOWN_AS: House on the north side of Waterloo Road
MONUMENT_DESC: House located in the south-eastern corner of a large formal garden on the northern side of Waterloo Road, Old Market. The building is first recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol and was probably constructed in the early eighteenth-century. It had, however, been demolished by the time of Plumley and Ashmead's map of 1828 to make way for Fear's Buildings.

No.43 West Street, Old Market. The building was a single-bay house apparently constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble in the seventeenth-century. The building was subsequently remodelled, possibly in the eighteenth-century or early nineteenth-century, when the walls above basement-level were reconstructed. A hipped roof may also have been added at this time. The building was substantially rebuilt in the late-nineteenth or early-twentieth century. In March and April 2003 a further programme of alterations was carried out.
Photographs of the interior of the building taken during the repair and alteration works in 2003 are held in the Sites and Monuments Record Collection of Ground-based Photographs.

No.26 Mary-le-Port Street, on the south corner with Dolphin Street. Attached to west and south. Facing north onto Mary-le-Port Street. Two gables there. 2 storeys and attics; jettied; 2-window range. One wide shop window across the ground-floor. Two first-floor oriels, possibly with 12-light transomed fronts. Canted bay or oriel to left at second-floor; to right, an oriel, possibly 10-light transomed front. Demolished, along with the 'Swan Hotel', in Jan-Feb 1936 (Street's notes).

No.28 Mary-le-Port Street. Attached. 3 storeys and attic; gabled front; jettied. Open shop front. Jettied first-floor, Pair of central 2-light windows, plus one small window to right. Second-floor jetty supported on 5 brackets. Window provision at second-floor and attic levels is unclear.

St. James's Parish School, located at the western end of St. James Barton, set back behind a railing. Attached to north and south. 3-bay elevation, with a 4th.bay set back slightly on the left, or south, side. Hipped roof to the main elevation. Tall 2-light pointed windows to all 4 bays, each divided below the centre by a band containing a quatrefoil decoration in each light. Entrance with two-centred arched head beneath the window in the far left-hand bay. George Weare Braikenridge records (Braikenridge Notes M10) that the ground-floor was for boys, the upper floor for girls.

Stone Bridge Floodgates. One pair of lock gates on the River Frome, at the northern end of the Floating Harbour, immediately upstream of the Stone Bridge. Arranged so as to keep water from escaping from the harbour up the Frome, but able to open to allow flood water to pass in the opposite direction if necessary. They remain in operation.

The Adam and Eve Public house, located on the south side of Lewins Mead. The building was a jettied, gabled house of three storeys and attic of seventeenth-century date. 1-window range. Right-hand entrance, bow window. Bracket at left-hand of first-floor jetty. Full-width first-floor oriel, of 9 or 10 lights. Full-width pentice above. Twin sashes to second-floor, which has rusticated 'quoins'. Brackets to eaves. Two purlins to each side of roof. A small attic window. Lateral stack(s).

KNOWN_AS: Cat and Wheel Public House, Castle Green
MONUMENT_DESC: The Cat and Wheel Public House, located at the corner of Castle Green and Little Peter Street. The building was a timber-framed, jettied building with a gabled roof and dated to the seventeenth century. Demolition of the building began on 5 April 1900 (Pritchard, 1900 270-271). A new public house, also known as the Cat and Wheel, was contructed. The rebuilt structure was demolished during the 1960s.
No.43 High Street.

KNOWN_AS: House to the east of the Adam & Eve public house
MONUMENT_DESC: House. Lewins Mead, on the south side. Attached. Gabled roof, running parallel to street. 2 storeys and attic; first-floor jettied; 2-window range. Right-hand entrance, then window, then another entrance, with 2 further windows (probably sashes) to the left-hand. 5 large brackets to the first-floor jetty. Bolection-moulded beam to base of first-floor front, with a string at sill level. 5-light mullioned window, left, and 3-light version, right. Above the left-hand window, a gabled dormer with small window. At the left-hand gable end, a large stone stack in 2 stages, with moulded string to the lower. The whole 'feel' of this structure is that it is early, no later than the sixteenth century, perhaps medieval.

No.12, Lower Park Row. The house was of probable mid-seventeenth century date and was constructed of Brandon Hill Grit. The building had been in a poor state of repair for a number of years before the roof collapsed in 1967. It was demolished that July.
A watching brief on site investigation in 1987 (BUAD 655) recorded part of the north-west corner of the ground floor, including part of an alcove and chimney-breast.
Glass Bottle Manufactory, Church Street, Temple. The factory lay on the east side of Church Street and was recorded by the first edition Ordnance Survey 1:500 Town Plan of the early 1880s.

Emmanuel Church, Clarke Street. The church was located on the northern side of Clarke Street and was constructed at a cost of £3000 in the early 1860s to a design by Pope and Bindon. The church was of stone with an apsaidal east end and had a porch on its southern side. It could accommodate 700 worshippers.(Ralph & Cobb 1991, 24). It was consecrated on 9 December 1862 by Bishop Thompson.
The church was united with SS Philip and Jacob in the mid-1930s and ceased to be used for worship. It had also developed significant structural problems and, according to the vicar, there was "a serious crack in the arch separating the chancel and the nave" (Anon 1938). Against some opposition from the parishioners, the authorisation to sell the site was given in July 1939. The church was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped.

KNOWN_AS: Hannah More Infants School, New Kingsley Road
POSTAL_ADDRESS: Hannah More Infants School, New Kingsley Road
