MONUMENT_DESC: Hannah More Infants School, New Kingsley Road. The school was built as a Board School c.1900 on part of the site of the Barleyfield Iron Works and was designed by W. V. Gough. It is extant, though altered, and was considered for listing but was rejected.

Iron Works, located on the western side of Horton Street. The works were apparently built after 1883. The buildings have been demolished and the site now lies beneath the southern part of the Gardiner Haskins car park. The quality of survival of the archaeology below ground in not known but is likely to be good.

Zoar Chapel, Unity Street. The chapel was built in the mid-nineteenth century on the southern side of Unity Street. It was a Particular Baptist chapel with seating for 200 and is recorded on the Ordnance Survey first edition Town plan of 1883. The chapel survived into the early twentieth century but has since been demolished.

KNOWN_AS: Cross-gabled house by the west transept of Bristol Cathedral
POSTAL_ADDRESS: Cathedral of the Holy and Undivided Trinity, College Green
MONUMENT_DESC:
A house of probable seventeenth century date which stood a few metres to the west of the transept of Bristol Cathedral, fronting on to the south side of College Green. The house was of two storeys plus attic with an entrance is on the west side of the facade. Each of the two bays had sash windows. The cross-gable roof was pantiled and there was a chimney stack on the end of the northern gable on College Green and another on the north side of the west gable. Attached to the west side of the building was a smaller, two-storey cross-gabled ?gazebo, also with a pantile roof.
The house is recorded in a painting of 1791 by J. M. W. Turner was extant still extant in 1828 but had been demolished by the time of Ashmead's map of the city of 1855.
The southern part of the building extends beneath the north aisle of the Victorian nave of Bristol Cathedral, but the northern part lies in the grassed area on the north side of the Cathedral. Although the area has been landscaped and disturbed by services, survival of the sub-surface deposits may be expected to be good.

Essex Work, sometimes called Essex Fort. The fort was constructed in 1642 and was located slightly inside the main defensive line running between Brandon Hill fort (BUAD 127M) and Windmill Hill Fort to command the road leading from Bristol to Clifton. No cannon were recorded at the fort by the survey made after the capture of Bristol by the Royalist armies in July 1643, suggesting that the fort was a musketry platform.
It was apparently found in 1994 during construction of the University Gate development on the north side of Park Row, west of the Woodland Road junction.

KNOWN_AS: Garden House in Upper Church Lane
MONUMENT_DESC: A garden house or summerhouse (ie. the second residence) in Upper Church Lane, Kingsdown. The building was constructed in a large block of land (which had formed an estate since the medieval period) in the seventeenth century by Richard and Mary Stubbs. The plot was later owned by the Earle family who subdivided the block into gardens, and these were developed for housing in the nineteenth century (R. Leech pers. comm.).
Iron Foundry, Temple Street

KNOWN_AS: Oil and Colour works, St. Thomas Street
MONUMENT_DESC: The Oil and Colour Works, St. Thomas Street. The works is recorded by the 1:500 Ordnance Survey plan surveyed in 1882

Signal box over the railway line at the eastern end of the bridge on the approach to Temple Meads station. The structure was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 scale plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.2) surveyed in 1883 but had been removed by the beginning of the twentieth century.

Panther Works, a leadworks located on the western side of Avon Street. The works was constructed after 1828 and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 scale plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.2) surveyed in 1883. By the beginning of the twentieth century the buildings had been removed and the site redeveloped for the Avonside Goods Warehouse.

KNOWN_AS: Garden on the north side of Waterloo Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Formal garden located on the northern side of Waterloo Road. The garden is of seventeenth cenutry date and was recorded by James Millerd's 1673 map. This shows a large square plot, with diagonal divisions, possibly paths, crossing it and beds around the edges. Jean Rocque's 1742 map indicates that the garden had diagonal cross-paths by that date and probably also paths around the edges. Rocque indicates that a small rectangular building (BUAD 1431M) had been constructed in the south-eastern corner of the plot. By 1828 the plot had been subdivided, the formal garden removed and part of the area of the garden occupied by Williams burial ground (BUAD 1264M). Buildings had been constructed across the site by 1880s.

KNOWN_AS: Henry Naish & Sons Ltd. Bacon Curers, Waterloo Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
Henry Naish & Sons Ltd. Bacon Curers, located on the northern side of Waterloo Road, Old Market. A building later occupied by the firm was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.17) but this does not give any indication of its use at that time. The Goad Fire Insurance plan of August 1896 indicates that Henry Naish & Sons Bacon Curers then occupied the building and an extension had been added to the southern end.
The buildings of the bacon curers have been demolished and a new structure at the centre of the site.

KNOWN_AS: Newtown Free Methodist Chapel, Trinity Place
MONUMENT_DESC: Newtown Free Methodist Chapel, located on the southern side of Trinity Place, off Trinity Road. The chapel was constructed after 1828 and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.17) surveyed in 1883 which noted that the chapel had seating for 420. The chapel survived into the twentieth century and was still extant in 1918. However, the building was subsequently demolished and the site had been redeveloped for housing by 1967.

The Common Slip, located on the south side of Lewins Mead, at the boundary between the parishes of St. James and St. Michael. The slip is recorded in the 1751 perambulation of St. James parish as "the slip, anciently calle'd the Common slip, which slip is now in the Coach Yard kept by Mrs.Clift" (BRO P/StJ/ChW/6). It later became the site of the northern approach to St. John's Bridge and its site now lies beneath the northbound carriageway of Rupert Street.

Royal Fort House. The house was built on the site of an earlier great house in the Royal Fort. The site had been leased by the Tyndall family since the early eighteenth-century and Thomas Tyndall bought the site outright in the early 1760s. Tyndall commissioned a new house from the architect James Bridges (who also designed Bristol Bridge (BUAD 305M)) apparently in the late 1750s. Ison suggests that the mason used was Robert Gay (Ison 1952, 192). Thomas Paty was reponsible for the internal decoration (Priest 2003, 51-60). The house seems to have been completed by 1760 (Ison 1952, 190-198).
The building has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/10/304).

No.7, Bellevue. The building is the southernmost of a terrace of nineteen houses. The plot, formerly part of the grounds associated with Clifton Hill House, was leased from the Society of Merchant Venturers by Harry Elderton in 1792 for a term of forty years (Ison 1952, 234). Construction of the terrace began under the supervision of William Paty (Priest 2003, 101) but was abandoned in 1793 when the outbreak of war caused a slump in development. The buildings remained uncompleted for nearly two decades but the terrace had apparently been completed by 1815.
The building is a rendered three-storey house with attic and basement. It has a slate mansard roof. A raised walk on the east side of the building extends the full length of the terrace.
In 1882 the building was occupied by a Mrs Haig..
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/6).

No.9, Bellevue. The building is the southernmost of a terrace of nineteen houses. The plot, formerly part of the grounds associated with Clifton Hill House, was leased from the Society of Merchant Venturers by Harry Elderton in 1792 for a term of forty years (Ison 1952, 234). Construction of the terrace began under the supervision of William Paty (Priest 2003, 101) but was abandoned in 1793 when the outbreak of war caused a slump in development. The buildings remained uncompleted for nearly two decades but the terrace had apparently been completed by 1815.
The building is a rendered three-storey house with attic and basement. It has a slate mansard roof. A raised walk on the east side of the building extends the full length of the terrace.
In 1882 the building was occupied by Henry Humphries.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/6).
Tobacco Manufactory, Avon Street

KNOWN_AS: Temple Back Day Industrial Council School
MONUMENT_DESC: Temple Back Day Industrial Council School

KNOWN_AS: Stay and Corset Manufactory, Temple Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Stay and Corset Manufactory, Temple Street

No.32 Stokes Croft, located on the eastern side of Stokes Croft. The building was probably constructed in the later seventeenth century as a single bay house of three storeys plus attic with a gabled pantile roof. The building was refronted in brick, probably in the early nineteenth-century. The upper part of the southern wall appears to have been reconstructed in brick at the same time and the rear part of the roof may have been converted to a half hip as part of the same works.
The building was in dilapidated condition by the late 1990s, with parts of the floor in poor condition. It was subsequently gutted and the roof removed.

No.93, Stokes Croft. The building is a late seventeenth-century or early eighteenth-century, single bay house of two storeys plus attic with a gabled roof.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building Number 901-1/6/2035).

Rankin's Sugar House, located on the south side of Guinea Street, towards Commercial Road. According to the local antiquarian G. W. Braikenridge the sugar house was "built on what was called the Neutral Yard, now used by Mr. Tho[ma]s. Rankin as a bonded Warehouse for West India Produce" (Braikenridge notes F46).
The building was of at least five storeys, and the north elevation had six bays. Three large roofs, hipped at east ends and half-hipped to west. Some dormer windows on north side. Many segmental-headed windows. The building was removed to allow the construction of extensions to the General Hospital.

Carriage works, in, e.g. 1826. 3-storey, attached. Tall 2-storey vehicle entrance to left; large key. To right, 2 doorways and 2 shop windows, alternating. At first-floor, 2 segmental-headed windows; 5 similar to second-floor. Behind the right ground-floor was the 'Old Hall'. The "lofty arched way" was inserted in the early 1820s "to afford room for Coaches & Waggons to drive into a large yard belonging to these Premises which are now occupied by Mr.Chas.Hayes, Coach & Gig Maker & called No.16 in the Bristol Directory" (Braikenridge notes).

KNOWN_AS: All Saint's Almshouse, All Saints' Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
All Saints' Almshouse, All Saints' Street. The almshouse was located on the east side of All Saints' Street with a burial ground located behind (BUAD 1190M). The almshouse had originally been sited in High Street and moved to a location adjacent to St. John's Almshouses, St. John's Steep in 1740-1741.
The almshouse at All Saints' Street was built c1814 (Lobel & Carus-Wilson 1975, 26) and the almshouse and burial ground are shown on Plumley and Ashmead's map of 1828 and Ashmead's map of 1850. However, the form of the building is not currently known. The building provided accommodation for "eight poor women selected and appointed by the vestry from the parish poor." Each had an apartment to themselves and the parish was reported in the late 1820s to keep the building in good repair (Manchee 1831, 308).
The almshouse had been closed by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan of the 1880s and the site taken over as an iron foundry. It is not clear whether this involved the complete demolition of the almshouse building, or whether parts were incorporated into the foundry. The burial ground, however, seems to have remained undeveloped for many years and to have been used as a yard for the foundry.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Merrick Court, Merchants Landing, Wapping Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Eastern Wapping Dry Dock. A shipbuilding dock created in the early eighteenth century which lay on the south side of the Avon, east of Wapping Road. It was aligned north-south with its gates opposite the Old Mud Dock.

A pair of slipways on the south bank of the Avon, part of the shipyard east of Wapping Road which faced the area between the Old and New Mud Docks on The Grove. Rowbotham records the barque 'Avon' on the stocks here in 1826.

Merchants' Dock. The dock was built as a wet or floating dock prior to the floating of the harbour by William Champion between 1762 and 1768. It was a rectangular basin, aligned north-south, with a southern entrance lock. Two other docks, a graving dock and another wet dock, were built on its east side. Champion lost money in the venture and the docks were sold privately in 1770 to a small group of members of the Society of Merchant Venturers from whom the Society corporately bought the docks complex. The Society renamed the complex Merchants' Dock and gained an Act of Parliament in 1776 requiring ships to unload flammable materials, pitch, tar etc., there. The dock was also enlarged to accommodate sixteen vessels (McGrath 1975, 155-156).
The docks were periodically let, including to the shipbuilder George Hilhouse at the beginning of the nineteenth century and at this time a Bonding Yard (BUAD 1356M) was created to the west of the dock. The entrance lock to Merchants' Dock was truncated when Junction Lock was cut between the harbour and Cumberland Basin. By 1883 Merchants Road had been created through the Bonding Yard and cattle pens stood on the west side of the dock. The western and northern sides of the dock were infilled by the Great Western Railway as part of the works to lay a line to Canons Marsh in the early twentieth century. The remainder was filled to allow development of housing at Rownham Mead in the 1970s.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Bristol and West Building, Broad Quay
MONUMENT_DESC: Warehouse located in Marsh Street.

St. Bartholomew's Hospital, located on the western side of Narrow Lewins Mead. The hospital was founded in the early-thirteenth century - probably between 1232 and 1234 (Price 1998, 53) - by Sir John de la Warr on the site of a Norman first-floor aisled hall (BUAD 1120M) he owned. The hospital occupied a narrow curving site between a cliff and the River Frome. The entrance gate stood on Host Street with the chapel and infirmary immediately behind. To the north-west of this was the master's lodging and to the north the kitchen and refectory, bakehouses and dormitories. The burial ground occupied the remainder of the parcel to the north-east, although inhumations were also excavated in a courtyard area at the southern end of the site between the chapel, master's lodging and Narrow Lewins Mead.
St. Bartholomew's Hospital was transferred in January 1531/2 from the de la Warre family to the ownership of John and Robert Thorne established a grammar school on the site. The existing almoners were allowed to live out their remaining lives there.
The site was archaeologically excavated in 1977 (BUAD 3286).

KNOWN_AS: Moravian Minister's House, Upper Maudlin Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
Moravian Minister's House, Upper Maudlin Street. The house was located on the south-eastern side of Upper Maudlin Street, four metres to the north east of the Moravian Chapel.
Part of the house was archaeologically excavated in 1976 (BUAD 316).

No.12 St. James' Churchyard. The building was a gabled, jettied house of two storeys and attic with a 1-window range. It was of probable seventeenth-century date. The footprint of the building measured by 7 metres from north-west to south-east by 5 metres wide. The main elevation faced west on to Haymarket and there was a central projecting bay which extended up to attic level. Between ground- and first-floor level there was a full-width pentice roof. The fenestration in the bay comprised sashes. The gabled roof was covered with clay tiles and a substantial chimney stack, apparently shared with the Carpenters Arms public house attached to the north (BUAD 821M), projected from the roof on the northern side of the building.
The building was demolished in 1953 or 1954 and its site now lies beneath the highway in The Haymarket.

KNOWN_AS: Smith and Gregory Blacklead and Blue Factory
MONUMENT_DESC: Smith and Gregory Blacklead and Blue Factory. The works, on the south side of River Street, was recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883. It had expanded to the east by 1896.

KNOWN_AS: James Rudman Oil and Colour Works
MONUMENT_DESC: James Rudman Oil and Colour Works, River Street. The works, located on the south side of River Street, was recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883.

KNOWN_AS: Oil and Colour Store, River Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Oil and Colour Store, River Street. The store was located on the south side of River Street and probably belonged to the James Rudman Oil and Colour Works to the west. The building was recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883 but had been demolished by 1896.

Naish and Sons Slaughterhouse, located on the southern side of Braggs Lane, Old Market. The abbatoir was located on the southern side of Braggs Lane. The building is recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883 but the eastern part had been demolished by 1896.
Bonds (Bristol) Brewery Ltd, Redcross Street. The brewery was located on the west side of the junction of Redcross Street and Lawford Street.

Summerhouse at No.15 Marlborough Hill. The building was a lodge or summerhouse (ie. a merchant's second residence) of mid eighteenth-century date which was sited in the corner of a roughly square garden plot. The building was of three storeys and built of stone. It is known to have been internally heated (Leech, 1998 6-7).

Garden house below No.4 Kingsdown Parade. The building was a lodge or summerhouse (ie. a merchant's second residence). The building is not recorded cartographically until the survey of the city by Ashmead in 1855 but may well be of the same date as the similar nearby buildings. The building was sited in the corner of a roughly square garden plot, itself created within a larger lodge garden of early eighteenth-century date.

KNOWN_AS: St. Nicholas Street, 6th house from St. Nicholas Steps
MONUMENT_DESC: House located on the south side of St. Nicholas Street, sixth property from St. Nicholas Steps. Attached at least to the east. Three storeys, no attic storey; gabled front; jettied; 1-window range. Left-hand entrance; open butcher's shop window to right, with boxed cellar access below. Decorative brackets either side of entrance, also to right of window. Bay windows to upper storeys, with glazing beyond. Decorative brackets to eaves.
Methodist Chapel, Redcross Street, Old Market.

KNOWN_AS: The Sugar Loaf Public House, St. Nicholas Street
MONUMENT_DESC: The "Sugar Loaf" public house, located on the north side of St. Nicholas Street. The building was a jettied, gabled house of three storeys. Right-hand entrance, arched head. 6-light transomed window; cellar flaps below window. Brackets to first-floor and second-floor jetties. Pair of sashes to first-floor; sugar loaf symbol at right end. Cross-window to second-floor. no attic window.

KNOWN_AS: House on east side of Queen Charlotte Street
MONUMENT_DESC: House located on the east side of Back Street (modern Queen Charlotte Street), on the north corner of Crow Lane. Attached to north. Three storeys and attic; gabled front; jettied; 1-window range. Central entrance, windows either side. Bays to first and second floors. Sash to attic. One lateral stack near to west end, two pots; far end of building not recorded.

The Oyster Market, otherwise described as the oyster-women's shed or the oyster stands. At the top of Welsh Back. One storey; detached. 7 bays, in an irregular line, 2+2+3, suggesting two extensions. 8 columns to front (i.e. facing St.Nicholas). Roof dropped towards rear. All sides open, arched to the front. Erected as a shelter for the oyster women, who used it exclusively. They also sold mackerel, herring and sprats here in season.

No.38 Old Market Street. The building was constructed in 1688 by the Bristol clay tobacco pipemaker Llewellyn Evans as the western of a pair of attached houses. It was originally a house of two storeys and attic with a double-depth plan.
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by W. Rogers, boot maker.
Nos.38 and 39 Old Market Street were converted to a single structure, apparently after 1896 since the Goad fire insurance plan of that year indicates that the property then comprised two shops. The main, south-facing, elevation has a slated ground-floor lean-to canopy on fluted fascia brackets to a flush twentieth century shop front with a glazed door to No.38. A half-hipped pantile roof was added to span the two properties. The interior of the building was completely remodelled c1985.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/12/1643).

KNOWN_AS: Possible Barn on the west side of College Square
MONUMENT_DESC: A possible barn of thirteenth- or fourteenth-century date, located on the western side of College Square. The structure was excavated in 2001 (BUAD 3772). It was orientated north-south, with its east wall apparently forming the west side of the square, and was constructed of Brandon Hill Grit. The footings to the external walls were approximately 1 metre thick and at the centre of the structure there were large square stone bases thought by the excavator to be bases for timber columns supporting the roof.

The Colston Hall, located on the western side of Colston Street. The concert hall was constructed between 1863 and 1867 on the site of the Great House (BUAD 420M) and opened in 1868 (Meller 1976, 57-58). The interior of the original auditorium was recorded in a series of drawings by Samuel Loxton (Bristol Reference Library D181-D186). The building suffered a serious fire on 1 September 1898 which destroyed the auditorium (Winstone 1983, Pls.89-90). The auditorium was subsequently reconstructed but the hall was damaged by incendiaries during the Second World War. It was again rebuilt and remains in use as a concert hall.

KNOWN_AS: Bridge over New Cut entrance lock
MONUMENT_DESC: Bridge crossing the entrance lock to Bathurst Basin from the New Cut. A 2-leaf swing bridge, forming a depressed single arch span when closed. Timber lattice-work railings. Also illustrated, in part, by Rev. John Eden in 1820 (BRSMG M3377). Replaced later by a larger swing bridge that still survives but is no longer capable of opening.

KNOWN_AS: Churchyard of the Church of St Andrew-the-Less
MONUMENT_DESC: The churchyard of St. Andrew-the-Less, Chapel Row, Dowry Parade. The churchyard is recorded by Plumley and Ashmead's survey of Bristol in 1828 and was still extant and the time of the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883. The site was subsequently part of the development of Carrick House but it is not known if the burial ground has been cleared.

The Bristol Institute, now Freemasons' Hall, on the east side of Park Street. The building was designed by S. R. Cockrell and constructed between 1821 and 1823. The limestone ashlar building has a classical design with a curved porch at the south-east corner. The building was gutted by bombing in 1940 (Warne 1943, 20).
Portwall Ditch. The ditch outside the town wall known as the Portwall.
Malthouse, East Street, St. Pauls. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map in the early 1880s.

Church of the Dominican friary, Quakers Friars. The church appears to have stood on the northern side of the friary precinct, close to Rosemary Lane and measured approximately 50 metres from south-west to north-east by 18 metres wide. The precise internal layout of the church is yet to be established but documentary evidence indicates that there were aisles on the north and south side of the nave. There was a also a choir which contained two organs by the early-sixteenth century (Weare 1893, 84-86). The south aisle was refenestrated in the fourteenth century (BUAD 2378). The cloister of the friary was attached to the south side of the church.
The church was partially demolished after dissolution in 1538 but elements of the fabric survived into the 1930s.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: The Inkerman Public House, Grosvenor Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Grammar School, located on the southern side of a lane to the north-east of Portland Square [modern Grosvenor Road]. The school was in existence by the time of the 1828 survey of Bristol by John Plumley and George Ashmead. It was extant in 1881 but had been demolished by the beginning of the twentieth century and The Inkerman Public House developed on the site.

No.12 Cherry Lane, located on the northern side of Cherry Lane. The building was a three-storey, single bay house and was in existence by 1722 when the first occupant, Sarah Wedmore, was assessed for Land Tax (Bryant 2003, 5). By 1896 the building housed a grocers shop. The house was still extant in 1913 but it had been demolished by 1949 when the site was vacant.

No.17 Charles Street, located on the southern side of Charles Street. The building was a three-storey, single bay house and was in existence by 1758 when the Land Tax assessment described the building as "New Ho[use]." (Bryant 2003, 6). The first occupier was a Captain Carpenter. The house was still extant in 1913 but it had been demolished by 1949.

KNOWN_AS: 1, Cave Street Cottages, No.87 Wilder Street
MONUMENT_DESC: No.1, Cave Street Cottages, No.87 Wilder Street, located on the northern side of Wilder Street. The building was in existence by 1828 and was constructed as the western of a pair with No.89 Wilder Street (BUAD 1496M). The building was a two-storey, single bay house. By 1883 it had been incorporated into a larger industrial building constructed to the rear. No.1 Cave Street Cottages appears to have survived as part of this structure until at least 1950 but was subsequently demolished.
Phoenix Glasshouse, located on the south side of Portwall Lane. The glass works was established in the late 1780s on the site of the Phoenix Inn.

Hornwork at Stokes Croft. The fortification was built in 1642 to control the road into Bristol from the north. The precise location and form of the defences here are currently (19/03/2004) unclear but in 1643 the Royalist engineer Sir Bernard de Gomme described it as "a great "Spurreworck in the Line, and a strong high Traverse, or Fore worck, watching & shutting up the highwaye, with a strong port of timber barres on the East side of it" (Firth 1925, 184). The survey of cannon captured by the Royalist armies in July 1643 recorded one minion in the fort (BUAD 4095; Roy 1975, 261). The position of the bastion was still evident in property divisions until the late-nineteenth century, notably the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 town plan surveyed in 1881 (Bristol sheet LXXI.16.10).

St. Philip's Bridge, spanning the Floating Harbour between Counterslip and Passage Street. An Act of Parliament to enable the construction of the bridge was obtained in the late 1830s (1 and 2 Vict. Cap.lxvi). The bridge was opened in 1841, replacing the Queen Street ferry. The bridge was a two-arch span of Pennant sandstone and was a toll bridge until May 1875 when the bridge was vested in the Mayor, Aldermen and Burgesses of Bristol (38 Vict. Ch.xxviii). The western arch, adjacent to the Tramway Generating Station at Counterslip, was destroyed by bombing in 1940 and was subsequently rebuilt.

The burial ground for the Bristol Royal Infirmary (BUAD 709M). The burial ground was located to the rear of Nos.22-32 Upper Maudlin Street and was bounded on the north-east and south-east by Johnny Ball Lane. In the Municipal Charities 1877 schedule of properties was identified as belonging to Bristol Grammar School, on a 900 year lease to the Bristol Royal infirmary. The burial ground was closed by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852.
The site remained undeveloped until the end of the twentieth century. A substantial number of human remains were removed by archaeologists in 2002 in advance of redevelopment (BUAD 3928; Samuel 2003).

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Former Dept. of Surveying, University of the West of England
MONUMENT_DESC: Merchant Venturers' Technical College, located on the east side of Unity Street. The building was designed by E. C. Robins (The Builder 29 April 1882)
Oil Stores, Charlotte Street, St. Pauls'. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map in the early 1880s.

Moravian School, located on the north-west side of the south-west part of Blackfriars, between the street and the Moravian burial ground (BUAD 511M). The building was of at least two storeys and was constructed of stone rubble with limestone dressings. Part of ground-floor elevation facing the street comprised an arcade of round brick arches with square stone piers with bevelled capitals. The building was demolished between late 1963 and early 1973.

KNOWN_AS: Footbridge over exit of Castle Mill leat
MONUMENT_DESC: Footbridge over exit of Castle Mill leat, located a short distance from its confluence with the River Frome. Timber construction. Flat, with timber posts and rails. No piers, but propped off the leat walls. Probably destroyed in 1824 along with the Castle Mill.

Narrow Weir. A weir on the watercourse connecting the channel leading to the Castle Ditch and Castle Mill with the northern course of the River Frome. At the northern edge of the leat. A sluice is shown here on James Millerd's 1673 plan of Bristol. The weir was drawn, from the north, by O'Neill in 1820 (BRSMG M2902).

KNOWN_AS: Park Street Art Gallery, No.43, Park Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
No.43 Park Street, located on the south-western side of Park Street. The building was constructed in the early 1760s. Around 1762 Mary More, the sister of Hannah More, moved her school from No.6 Trinity Street to occupy the building. There were then around sixty pupils, mainly girls but with some younger boys (Stott, 2003 10) and included Hannah More herself who was educated there from the age of thirteen and subsequently became one of the teachers. The school remained in the building for many years, still being listed there in 1775. In the nineteenth century the Bristol Society of Artists established the Park Street Art Gallery in the building.
Attached. 3 storeys, attic and basement; gabled ends with stacks; 5-window range. A central entrance up some steps with large shop windows either side, 3 plate-glass panes to each; cellar access down steps at the left-hand end of frontage. Pairs of pilasters at ends and beside entrance. Sashes to first and second floors, the right-hand pair with pediments, the others with corbelled flat heads. Cornice and parapet. 3 hipped dormers, sashes.

KNOWN_AS: Medieval building or Hall, north of Temple Church
MONUMENT_DESC:
A building, interpreted as a hall, which was archaeologically excavated on the north side of Temple Church in 1971 (BUAD 314). Only parts of the north and a fragment of the west wall were recorded but the building was at least 25 metres long  (and, the excavator suggested, 13 to 15 metres wide) and was constructed of Pennant sandstone, bonded in an orange-red sandy mortar. The excavator suggested that it was roofed with shingles, several of which were found in the associated deposits. A fire had occurred within the building at some point during its life.
The excavator believed that the structure was associated with the Knight's Templar preceptory or that of the Knight's Hospitaller who took over the Templar site in Bristol when the order was suppressed in 1382. No function could be ascribed to the building. The building was completely destroyed by the construciton of Norfolk House.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Cathedral of the Holy and Undivided Trinity, College Green
MONUMENT_DESC:
The church of St. Augustine's Abbey. The abbey church was apparently the second abbey church, and it has been suggested that it was a larger church than the original (which may have been located on the site of the church of St. Augustine the Less) and was built as part of a repositioning of the abbey in the mid-twelfth century. The church was dedicated in 1170.
Fragments of the church remain, in particular the transepts of the present cathedral are known to rest on the lower part of those of the 1170 church. The plan of the church is unknown but the area of the nave of the cathedral was cleared of old walls when it was rebuilt in the nineteenth-century and the recovery of the full plan of the 1170 church may therefore be difficult.
A twelfth-century tenement which was excavated at No.95-97 Redcliff Street in 1984.

KNOWN_AS: Late twelfth-century tenement at Nos.95-97 Redcliff Street
MONUMENT_DESC: A late twelfth-century tenement at excavated at Nos.95-97 Redcliff Street.

A late-Saxon timber building, the northern part of which was excavated on the south side of Mary-le-port Street, on the northern side of the church, in 1962-63 (BUAD 358; Watts & Rahtz 1985). Two phases of building were identified, and the building was constructed in timber. Evidence of timber posts and sills were recorded, as was an entrance on Mary-le-port Street. Within the building heat damaged stones were found, one with iron slag fused to it. Fragments of daub were also recovered within the building, suggesting it had a wattle superstructure.
The southern part of the building was found to have been destroyed by the various phases of  reconstruction of St. Mary-le-Port.

KNOWN_AS: Cholera burial ground, Cattle Market Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Cholera burial ground, Cattle Market Road. The burial ground for cholera victims was established in the late 1840s on the north side of Cattle Market Road.
Malt house, Stratton Street, St. Paul's. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map in the early 1880s.
Bent timber yard, Stratton Street, St. Paul's. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map in the early 1880s.
Saw mill, Meadow Street. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map in the early 1880s.
Mission Hall, West Street, St. Paul's. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale town plan surveyed in the early 1880s.

A medieval house excavated during development of the Crown Courts site in Small Street in 1990 (BUAD 313). The house was of Pennant sandstone rubble and had a vaulted cellar. An external covered entrance to the cellar was located on the north-eastern side of the building. The building was owned by the church of St. Werburgh and consisted, in 1533, of vault, cellar, two lofts and a stable. It was leased to Roger Barlow, merchant until 1559 when a new lease was made to Thomas Aldworth, merchant, who held it until after 1600. Ultimately, in 1902, the building was sold to the Bristol Waterworks Company.
The building was almost certainly completely destroyed after partial archaeological excavation in 1990 (BUAD 313) by the construction of the new Crown Courts building in Small Street.
Campbell Iron Foundry, located on the east side of St. Thomas Street.

Protheroe's Warehouse, Denmark Street. The building is a five-storey warehouse of Pennant sandstone rubble with a pantle roof. It was a replacement for a warehouse erected c.1720, probably on the site. The present building was erected by Thomas Protheroe who leased the site in 1812 (Burchill 1995, 6) and it is recorded by an undated plan (BRO 04479(3) fo.78). It is, however, argued to be of late nineteenth-century date according to Gomme, Jenner & Little (1979 359).
The site was originally owned by Queen Elizabeth's Hospital and consequently passed to Bristol Municipal Charities after 1831.The warehouse was subdivided into two lets in the later nineteenth century, in 1877 one part being leased by Ford & Canning and the other by Smith & Co. It was subsequently occupied by John Harvey and Sons before being sold and converted into flats in 1997-1998. Before the conversion work was undertaken the building was the subject of a photographic survey (BUAD 3314). The building has a Grade II listing.
Baptist Chapel, located on the west side of Victoria Street.

Broadmead Baptist Church, with its main entrance in Union Street (formerly Lower Union Street), but before construction of that Victorian thoroughfare, entered from off of Broadmead. Founded in the mid-17th.century. A new meeting house (40ft. by 50ft.) was built in 1695.
Altered and extended principally in 1764-5, 1871-2 and 1875, to leave a building of 92ft. by 50ft. (of which only part of the east wall may have survived from the original). Gabled south wall - large gable between smaller ones (to aisles?). The west wall was rebuilt in 1876-7 to the new street. A new organ was built John Smith junior of the Bristol organ builders John Smith and Sons in 1843. It was apparently removed in c.1960 and installed at Downend Baptist Church, Salisbury Road.
The building was demolished and a new church was constructed in 1969. However, but one small part of the original building is thought to survive.
Brass foundry, West Street. The foundry was built on part of the cemetery known as Francis Ground and was in existence by 1883.

KNOWN_AS: House on the north side of Allcock's Lane
MONUMENT_DESC:
A house of probable late seventeenth century date sited on the north side of Allcock's Lane, off Cheese Lane. The house was one of several built along the lane at the end of the seventeenth century and was perhaps in origin a cottage for workers at the limekilns on the south side of the lane. The buildings were still extant in 1807 when they were described in a deed as "Poor Houses" (Bryant & Brett, 1996).
The house was constructed of Pennant sandstone bonded in a buff mortar and was cellared. Probably at a later date a brick structure was added in the cellar, though its function was not clear. No other structural information is known about the building. The south-east corner of the building was exposed in 1998 during an archaeological evaluation of the leadworks site.

The church of St. Bartholomew, located on the north-eastern side of Little James Back. The church is reported to have been constructed in 1861 and had accommodation for 300 worshippers. It closed in 1890 and was demolished 1894.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Bristol and West Building, Broad Quay
MONUMENT_DESC:
Water gate, Broad Quay. The gate was a double-arched structure which lay at the southern end of Broad Quay, allowing passage through the town wall known as the Marsh Wall. The gate was excavated in 1979 (BUAD 407) and was found to have been built of Pennant sandstone in a rubble construction and was bonded in a soft, medium-brown sandy mortar. Each stone-paved passageway was roughly 2.5 metres wide, divided by a stone wall 1 metre wide. The remains of the arch survived a little above the level of the paving and investigation of its foundations found that they were 1.8 metres deep. There was no evidence of timber piles supporting this rubble (Price 1990/91).
It is not clear when the gate was demolished but it is not shown by James Millerd's 1673 map of the city, suggesting that it had been removed by that date.

Holy Trinity Church, Trinity Road. The site was donated by the Bristol Corporation and the church was designed by Thomas Rickman and built at a cost of £8231. The Parliamentary Commissioners gave a grant of £6031 towards this. It could accommodate 2000 worshippers and 1500 of the places were free. The church was consecrated in 1832 (Ralph & Cobb 1991, 25).
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-156/1562).

KNOWN_AS: Churchyard, Holy Trinity Church, Trinity Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Churchyard of Holy Trinity Church, Trinity Road.
School, Trinity Road. The school is recorded by an Ordnance Survey plan of 1902.

St. Philip's Station, Waterloo Road. The station lay on the southern side of Waterloo Road, adjacent to the St. Philip's Goods Shed. Bristol Temple Meads had reached capacity by the end of the 1860s and the station was built to act as a terminus for the Midland Railway's local services, accommodating the overflow. It was built of timber with a glass roof and was opened on 2 May 1870 (Maggs 1996, 108).
The construction of the Joint Station at Temple Meads removed the need for the station and it finally closed on 21 September 1953. The structure was demolished, and the site has been redeveloped. Little is likely to remain of the station.

Railway turntable, St. Philip's Station. The turntable was located roughly 50 metres to the north-east of the passenger station. The site has been redeveloped but the likely condition of the monument is unknown.

Midland Railway Goods Shed, Midland Road. The shed was built in the later nineteenth century and covered an area of over 9000 square metres. The goods yard closed on 1 April 1967. The site has been redeveloped and the likely survival of the monument below ground is unknown.

Castle Ditch, the moat surrounding Bristol Castle [1037M]. Ran from the River Avon (now the Floating Harbour) eastwards as far as Tower Hill, then north, parallel to that street and Lower Castle Street, then turned westwards along Broad Weir, before returning south to rejoin the river at a point about 75 metres west of the point where it left the Avon. Now virtually completely culverted, but thought to survive throughout. Part remains open to the west of Queen Street. [Some of the culvert is Mon. No. 734M].

The keep of Bristol Castle. The structure was a tower keep and was reputedly built by Robert of Gloucester from 1135. It was square in plan with towers at each corner and was constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble bonded in an off-white mortar. The mouldings of the window openings were of ashlar, apparently using Dundry stone.
The keep was demolished in 1657 along with the rest of Bristol Castle and the site redeveloped.
Excavation in 1989 (BUAD 459) found evidence that the walls had been quarried for building stone and presumably the stone was used in the construction of the housing which succeeded it on the site. The site of the keep was archaeologically excavated by Gettins in the late 1940s (BUAD 414; Marshall 1951) and by Williams in 1989 (Good 1996).
Parts of the foundations of the keep survive and have a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/483).

The second town circuit wall, which enclosed a narrow area of, presumably reclaimed, land between the Norman inner circuit town wall and the River Frome. The wall was constructed in the thirteenth century and ran from the Quay Head at Small Street to Newgate. There were a number of interval towers and two gates - Frome Gate (BUAD 1212M) and Nether Pithay Gate (BUAD 947M) - which controlled the access to the crossings over the river.

The Pillory located in the centre of Wine Street. It stood near the centre of the street, 80 metres to the east of the High Cross and close the junction with Pithay. The pillory was described by William Worcestre in 1480 as a circular ashlar limestone structure with cells and iron bars on the windows. On the roof there was a timber structure, presumably stocks (Neale 2000, 66-67). The building had been removed by the 1670s.

A garden house on the site of No.13 Kingsdown Parade. The house was in existence by the early 1740s and stood at the south-eastern corner of a walled garden extending from Kingsdown Parade to the road to the north. It was recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol and was probably a merchant's garden house or lodge (ie. second residence). The building measured 8.5 metres from south-east to north-west and was 7 metres wide.
It is not currently (30/03/2006) known whether any elements of the structure have survived within the fabric of the building currently occupying the site, No.13 Kingsdown Parade.

Building on the northern side of Kingsdown Parade. Rocque's 1742 map of the city records a garden plot extending from Kingsdown Parade toward the road to the north. The building, possibly a merchant's lodge or garden house (ie. second residence), was sited in the south-eastern corner. The site is currently within the grassed area on the north side of Kingsdown Parade.

KNOWN_AS: Building east of the Montague Tavern
MONUMENT_DESC:
Building on the northern side of Kingsdown Parade. Rocque's 1742 map of the city records a garden plot extending from Kingsdown Parade toward the road to the north. The building, possibly a merchant's lodge (ie. second residence), was sited in the south-eastern corner.
The site is currently (9/10/1998) part of the grassed area on the north side of Kingsdown Parade although the northern edge of the site lies beneath Montague Place.

Brunel's Dock, Temple Meads. The dock was built in the 1840s, apparently using an existing pill, and is likely to have functioned as a barge basin. It was probably infilled in the 1870s when the Second Goods Shed [BUAD 1255M] was constructed. The entrance to the dock still survived to be recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of the early 1880s. Parts of the east and west walls of the dock were recorded during a watching brief on the insertion of foul water drainage in 1998-1999 (BUAD 3365) and were found to be of a rubble stone construction faced with closely-jointed ashlar blocks (Parry, 1999).
The dock has been damaged by subsequent development and the insertion of services, but substantial parts are likely to survive.

First Goods Shed, Temple Meads. The shed was built in the 1840s, not long after the Old Station, and was demolished in the 1870s to allow the building of the Second Goods Shed (BUAD 1255M). Parts of the building may have been recorded during a watching brief on the insertion of foul water drainage in 1998-1999 (BUAD 3365; Parry 1999).

Second Goods Shed, Temple Meads. The shed replaced the First Goods Shed and was constructed in the 1870s. It was demolished c.1926 to make way for a covered goods yard. Parts of the wall of the building were recorded during a watching brief on the insertion of foul water drainage in 1998-1999 (BUAD 3365; Parry 1999).

KNOWN_AS: Bristol and Exeter Railway Offices, Temple Gate
MONUMENT_DESC:
Bristol and Exeter Railway Offices, Temple Gate. The building was constructed in 1852 to a design by S. C. Fripp.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building No.290).

No.10 Cherry Lane, located on the northern side of Cherry Lane. The building was a three-storey, single bay house and was in existence by 1722 when the first occupant, Mr Bundy, was assessed for Land Tax (Bryant 2003, 5). The house was still extant in 1913 but it had been demolished by 1949 when the site was vacant.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: The Old Council House, Corn Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
No.50 Corn Street. Attached. 3 storeys and attic; gabled front; full-width pentice roofs above fronts of first 3 storeys, extending to No.49 adjacent to west; 1-window range. Entrance to right of centre; 2-bay shop window, gothick windows, to left; at right-hand end, a shopfront that runs into No.51 adjacent. Bays with 12/12 pane and 2/2 pane sashes; glazing either side of first-floor bay, to left only at second-floor. Twin 10/10 pane sashes to attic. Single-purlin roof. Lateral stacks on west wall. 
The Crown Fire Office in 1823. Partly occupied also by Taylor, brush maker.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: The Bank of England, Wine Street
MONUMENT_DESC: The "Guard House", located in the yard behind the 'Crown' public house on the north side of Mary-le-Port Street. The structure was a single-storey lean-to building against the rear of the 'Crown', beside the passage from the yard to Mary-le-Port Street (Winstone 1962, pl.27). The antiquarian George Weare Braikenridge recorded that on the west side of the yard were the "lock up Rooms in which Deserters or Soldiers under punishment are placed" (Braikenridge Notes, C92).

Wine Street Pump. In the middle of Wine Street, a little distance west of the top of the Pithay. An ancient well. In 1823 the pump comprised an eighteenth or nineteenth century hand pump in a wooden case, with an outlet on its eastern side, to a fairly large, but low-sided, trough or cistern raised slightly above road surface. The whole assembly was protected by stone bollards. One of the stations used by the magistrates on their processions to mark War or Peace was located here (Braikenridge Notes, C33).

St. Leonard's Church. The church stood over the town gate at the junction of Corn Street and St. Stephen's Street. Barrett describes the interior (Barrett, 1789 506). A flight of thirteen steps led to the only door of the church, at the west end of the north aisle, which was 35 feet long. The south aisle was 55 feet in length and 30 feet to the ceiling, the width of both aisles being 30 feet. Above the Corn Street gate stood "a plain freestone tower, 65 feet high from the ground, and 18 feet in front from north to south and from east to west 10 feet, having four small freestone pinnacles at the top, surrounded with freestone battlements". There were two bells, one large and one small. Against the east window was an altar. The church had a small crypt (crowde?).

The drinking fountain in Colston Avenue. The fountain was erected in 1901 at a cost of £220 to  commemorate the Industrial and Fine Art Exhibition which was held from 28th August 1893 to 31st January 1894. The fountain is of grey granite with red granite bowls and Lion head taps, of which only one survives.

The Ropeing House, Temple Back. The ropewalk was in existence by 1673 and is shown by James Millerd's map of Bristol published in that year. It was a long structure, oriented east-west, with a pitched roof supported on thirty-four pillars (seventeen on each side). A garden or orchard is shown on the north side (at the east end).

Stallage Cross or Temple Cross. The cross stood at the junction of Counterslip, Temple Street and Tucker Street. It was erected in the medieval period and was presumably a market cross. The cross was apparently replaced in the post-medeival period and Blackamore's plan of the northern end of Temple Street of c.1786 shows the cross with an octagonal base. The new cross may have incorporated parts of the original Stallage Cross. The cross was removed during the night of the 13 August 1794 as part of the scheme to create Bath Street.
The Wool Market over which the Wool Hall was built in the eighteenth-century.

The Bowling Green in the Marsh (now Queen Square). The green was in existence by the early 1660s when it was observedby the visiting Dutch artist Willem Schellinks (Exwood & Lehmann 1993, 102). The green was surrounded by a low wall and seems to have had an entrance on the south side. There was a building in the south-west corner of the green.

The Gib also known as Gib tailor. A structure, probably a crane, which stood at the south-west corner of the Marsh, at the entrance to St. Augustine's Reach. A structure which is probably the Gib is shown on Smith's map of the 1560s and is also recorded by documentary evidence from the mid-sixteenth century. It was shown still to be extant by Millerd's map of c1715 but had apparently been removed by the time Jean Rocque made his survey of Bristol in the 1740s.

The Marsh Gate. The town gate at the east end of the town wall known as the Marsh Wall. The gate led from Welsh Back into the Marsh and stood originally on the west bank of the river Avon. The ground to the east of the gate was subsequently reclaimed. The gate was recorded by William Worcestre as measuring "2 yards in width of the gate-walls" (Neale 2000, 214-215) and he also notes that it had not been built above, probably meaning that there was no upper accommodation in contrast to the earlier gates. The gate was still apparently standing in 1673 but had been demolished by 1742 (probably c.1738 when the removal of the nearby Back Street Gate was ordered by the Corporation).

No.1, West Street, located on the north-west side of West Street, St .James. The building possibly dated to the very early eighteenth century and was of two-storeys and attic, possibly with a basement. The main elevation was gabled and it was consttructed of rendered stone rubble. The building was demolished in c.1936, to make way for the  garages, office and yards of B.T.C.C.

A pair of houses. Attached. On the north-west side of West Street, St.James, and part of a terrace. 2 storeys and attics, possibly with basements. Gabled fronts; rendered rubble fronts; 2-window ranges. Entrances, with a hood each, at the outer ends; 2 sashes to each floor, including the attic. Demolished c.1936, for garages, office and yards of B.T.C.C. Possibly very early C18.

A terrace of four houses. Attached. On the north-west side of West Street, St.James, being part of a longer terrace. 2 storeys and attics, Nos.6 & 7, at least, with basements. Gabled fronts; rendered rubble fronts; originally 1-window ranges. Right-hand entrances, except No.4, which was left-hand, all with flat hoods, some on brackets. No.5 with 2 windows to first-floor and attic, and external shutters at ground-floor; No.7 with 2 first-floor windows; all windows sashes. Demolished c.1936, for garages, office and yards of B.T.C.C. Possibly very early C18.

No.20 Rosemary Street. The building was a house of probable seventeenth-century date which lay on the north side of Rosemary Street. The building appears to have been built as a one of a terrace of four and was a one window range house of two storeys plus attic with a gabled roof. The entrance on the ground floor was on the east side of the frontage. The building shared a lateral rubble stack with No.18. The building was demolished for the development of the Broadmead shopping centre, probably in the winter of 1954-1955.
The remains of the building are likely to be fairly well-preserved below ground.

No.19 Broadmead, located on the north side of Broadmead. The building was a ssingle-bay gabled house of two storeys and attic with a cross-gabled roof. It was of probable seventeenth-century date. The main, south-west facing, elevation occupied a 4 metre wide frontage on Broadmead and the building extended back 8.9 metres from the street. The ground floor was occupied by a shopfront with a central entrance and shop windows on either side. The first floor was jettied and the fenestration consisted of an oriel window with twin sashes. The attic storey was separated from first-floor by a full-width pentice. There was a central bay at attic level containing a two-light casement window. There were lateral chimneystacks on the western wall. Cartographic evidence suggests that the building probably originally had a detached kitchen to the rear.
The building had been demolished by 1953 and its site now lies beneath the front part of No.84 Broadmead.
Sunday school. Part of Broadmead Baptist Church. Victorian Gothic. Pennant Sandstone rubble with limestone dressings. 2-storey brick left return. Gable end to the Horsefair.

KNOWN_AS: Ferry house of Trin Mills Ferry
MONUMENT_DESC: Ferry house associated with the adjacent Grove or Trin Mills Ferry, whose southern slip lay at the western side of this building. The ferry house was constructed in the eighteenth- or nineteenth-century. It was of two storeys with a hipped roof; and single-window west and south ranges. Right-hand entrance in south wall, window to left; first-floor window. One window each storey of west wall. The fenestration consisted entirely of sash windows. At the north end there was a extension of apparently a single-storey in height.

Totterdown Lock. A canal lock linking the junction of the Floating Harbour and the Feeder Canal with the River Avon. Stone. The lock had two pairs of gates at harbour (i.e. eastern) end. The lock was infilled during the Second World War as a precautionary measure to prevent severe loss of water in the harbour in the event of a direct hit.

Merchants Bridge. The Merchant Street crossing of the northern course of the River Frome. The bridge was a single span arch of stone construction with parapets. It was recorded by Millerd's 1673 map but may have been constructed in the medieval period. The bridge probably survives beneath the present street

No.7, The Pithay, with the rear on part of Wellington Street. C17. Attached. 3 storeys and roof to front, 2 storeys and attic to rear. Gabled front and rear. Front jettied to first and second floors; 2-window range; no apparent attic storey as such. A rendered rubble rear elevation. 1-window range to rear, comprising entrance, sash at first-floor, and small attic window; cellar access beside entrance. The front not recorded in detail. The building was demolished for one of Messrs. Fry's factories.

No.8, The Pithay, with the rear on part of Wellington Street. C17. Attached. 3 storeys and roof to front, 2 storeys and roof to rear. Gabled to both front and rear. Front jettied to first and second floors; 2-window range; no attic storey as such. A rendered rubble rear elevation. 1-window range to rear, comprising entrance to left of a sash, and a sash at first-floor; no attic window; cellar access below window. A stack added at the base of right-hand side of the rear gable. The front not recorded in detail. Demolished for one of the Messrs. Fry's factories.

Gloucester Hotel, Joy Hill. The hotel is recorded by Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 survey of Bristol but the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map indicates that by 1883 it was being used as an Army recruiting centre.

Church of St. Andrew-the-Less, Dowry Parade. The church stood on Chapel Row, Dowry Parade, and was recorded by Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 survey of Bristol which shows its churchyard to the rear, lying on South Green Street.
Vinegar works, Redcliff Street. The vinegar brewery wwas located on the east side of Redcliff Street and was recorded by the 1st edition Ordnance Survey map of the early 1880s.

KNOWN_AS: T. and J. Perry & Co. Carriageworks, No.104 Stokes Croft
MONUMENT_DESC:
T. and J. Perry & Co. Carriageworks, No.104 (originally No.61) Stokes Croft, located on the eastern side of Stokes Croft. The carriage works was established in 1844 and consisted of a building which occupied the area between the Stokes Croft frontage and a lane off Hepburn Road to the rear. The original showroom was a two-storey rendered structure with a nine-window range. The ground-floor had a number of large vehicle arches beneath an open-sided lean-to roof supported by columns, which extended over the footway. The fenestration consisted of sash windows with stepped voussoirs above. The pitched roof, behind a parapet, had a bell cote at its centre.
The original building was damaged by fire and a new two-storey showroom was constructed to a design by the architect E. W. Godwin in 1858-1859 at a cost of £1000. This was added to existing buildings and Godwin apparently did not supervise the construction project (V & A AAD Ledger 4/9-1980: 9-10; Soros 1999, 193n).
The site was sold to Anderson's Rubber Company in 1912 and remained in its ownership until 1960. The building became vacant in 1979 and remained unused for thirty years.
The showroom has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/36/2037).

No.76 Stokes Croft, located on the eastern side of Stokes Croft. The building was constructed in 1868 for Rev. R. W. Gotch to a design by E. W. Godwin (Godwin's original drawings for the buildings are held by the Kelmscott Gallery, Chicago). The building was one of a pair with No.74 Stokes Croft (BUAD 1467M). It is a house of two-storeys and attic, constructed of brick with a tiled roof and comprises a shop with residential accommodation above (Soros 1999, 151-153). As designed, the main, north-west facing, elevation had a large Gothic arch forming the ground floor and this contained the shopfront. A string course divided ground and first floor. The fenestration at first-floor consisted of two sashes within arched openings. The parapet had a brick dentil course with stone copings. Above there was a central dormer with a pitched tile roof and a finial at the apex of the gable, which projected out of the parapet. The building has a steep hipped roof with a tall chimneystack, serving both No.74 and No.76 Stokes Croft, on its south side. There is a finial at the north end of the ridge.
The building is extant although the arch has been removed and the shopfront replaced.

No.11, St. James's Square.
The building was destroyed by bombing on 2 December 1940.

No.12, St. James's Square.
The building was damaged by bombing on 24 November 1940. It was destroyed in a further raid on 11 December 1940.

No.6 King Street, a timber-framed building erected in c.1665, and refronted in red brick with limestone dressings c.1720. A double-pile roof with two front hipped ends and two rear gables.
The building was formerly a Scheduled Ancient Monument but has been descheduled.
Transit Shed, Welsh Back. The shed was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan of the early 1880s and stood on the waterfront, roughly opposite Mill Avenue.
Transit Shed, Welsh Back. The shed was recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of the early 1880s and stood on the waterfront side of Welsh Back, on the site now opposite the NCP car park.
Transit Shed, Welsh Back. A small transit shed recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of the early 1880s and located on the waterfront side of Welsh Back, opposite No.5 Welsh Back.

KNOWN_AS: Assize Courts Hotel, No.15 Small Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Assize Courts Hotel, No.15 Small Street, located on the north-east side of Small Street. The building was constructed in the seventeenth century and was the house of Humphrey Brown in 1630.

Sir Thomas Langton owned the property in the later seventeenth century and at his death, in 1673, it passed to his widow, Lady Elizabeth, who died in 1703. In 1704 the property belonged to Robert Langton and Ann his wife, Robert being the youngest son of Sir Thomas, who sold it to Richard Champneys in that year. A deed of 1761 refers to the whole of the property as belonging to Richard Champneys, together with "the new buildings now or recently in course of erection". These stood where the present Hotel stands. By the 1820s the premises were occupied by John Matthew Gutch, printer of Felix Farley's Bristol Journal. Hirst described the building in 1927 as follows: "it contains on the ground floor a large kitchen and other offices, one of which is a strong room; on the first floor is the state room or dining room in which stood the chimney piece; there is a strong room and another small room adjoining. This state room is of fine proportions, 27 feet by 20 feet and 13 feet high. On the second floor are a number of bedrooms now disused and in poor repair. underneath the kitchens and extending right out under the new buildings to Small Street is a large cellar referred to in the old deeds as 'the great vault'. An inscribed tablet, apparently removed from some disused burial ground, is built into the wall of the kitchen." The building contained the 'Five Senses' chimney-piece (1007A).

still with C17 ceiling but minus chimneypiece - it's a very posh detached parlour/kitchen block

28 metres north-east of Small Street.

and had an open forecourt or garden.

No.7 Temple Street. The building was an attached house, with a ground-floor shop on the east side of the northern end of Temple Street. 3 storeys, no attic storey as such; gabled front; jettied; 2-window range. A ground-floor shopfront with a right-hand entrance. 2 sashes to the first-floor, 1 to the second. The building was demolished in the early 1960s.

The former County Court offices. To the rear of the right-hand part of the 1908 General Post Office extension. Bounded to the south-east by further part of the same, to west by Leonard Lane, to north-west by No.10 Small Street. Basemented. Ground-floor lit largely by skylights. Entered through the right-hand end of the Post Office extension, with some rooms in the same at ground and mezzanine floor levels. Early 20th.century, but incorporated the remains of an earlier warehouse. Some classical details to the interior, especially the hall or large room. Demolished, along with the General Post Office buildings, in 1989-90, and now part of the Crown Courts complex.

KNOWN_AS: Church of SS. Philip and Jacob
MONUMENT_DESC:
Church of SS. Philip and Jacob (ie. St. James), located on the east side of Tower Hill. The church stands within a roughly square churchyard of approximately 4700 square metres on the south side of Jacob Street, and lay outside the area of the planned medieval suburb of Old Market. The church was first recorded in the late-twelfth century. The advowson belonged to Tewkesbury Abbey, which appears to have exercised its right to appoint through its cell St. James Priory (BUAD 1024M).
The church was built of Pennant sandstone in a random rubble construction with limestone ashlar detailing. Its original plan was cruciform, and the south transept now forms the base of the tower. However, little fabric from the twelfth-century church has been identified although the font, with a square scalloped basin, is Norman.
The church was extensively rebuilt in the early-thirteenth century and its plan altered, the tower being relocated at the south-east corner of the nave. The chancel, nave and the lower element of the tower are all extant components of this phase of construction (BUAD 84; Anon. 1862, 91).
The church underwent major alteration in the mid-fifteenth century. A north chancel aisle with an arch-braced roof was added and the upper part of the tower was rebuilt, presumably adding stages and giving the tower four stages in all. The south and east chancel aisles were refenestrated with Perpendicular Gothic tracery windows, and the nave was also reworked in a Perpendicular style. A waggon roof, with bosses, supported on carved corbels was added. A chapel dedicated to St. Nicholas had been established by 1473 (Wadley 1886, 148), and John Kemys and Robert fforthey also endowed chantries.
St. James priory was dissolved in January 1540 and the advowson of the rectory was acquired by Henry Brayne as part of his purchase of the St. James property in 1544. Kemy's Chantry and fforthey's chantry were dissolved in the late 1540s. Thomas Boode was then the incumbent of Kemy's chantry and Henrie Spendalle occupied fforthey's chantry (Maclean 1883-84, 235-236). As part of the liturgical reordering associated with the reformation, the stone altars and rood screen were removed. In February 1547 the parish had 514 parishioners (Maclean 1883-84, 235-236).
A new pulpit and sounding board were added in 1631 and a small Baroque porch was also built on the north side of the nave in the seventeenth century. Several commemorative monuments also date to the seventeenth century, including a large wall monument to Henry Merrett (d.1692). 
The Bristol Corporation had acquired the advowson of the parish by the early eighteenth century and the Rector of Winterbourne, Mr. William Cary, was vicar with Thomas Jones serving as curate. The parish was reported to have 263 houses in 1712, and 330 in 1735 (McGrath 1985, 45-46).
Thomas Bilbie of Chew Stoke, who later established a bell foundry at Cullompton in Devon, cast a new tenor bell weighing approximately 18 cwt 2 lb 0 oz in 1739.
Drawings of the interior of the church made by James Stewart in April 1748 indicate that there was then a gallery in the north aisle. The high altar was enclosed by a Baroque altar rail with spiral balusters and behind there was a late seventeenth or early eighteenth century reredos with Tuscan columns with Corinthian capitals. The ring was increased to eight bells in 1789.
By 1759 Carew Reynell was vicar by 1759, with Thomas Chapman as his curate, and was probably the initiator of alterations made to the nave in 1764. Reynell resigned when he  succeeded to the curacy of St. James and  James New became vicar in April 1772.
By 1822 William Day was vicar and was assisted by his son. Further alteration to the fabric took place in 1836. Projecting nave wings were built to house staircases to the galleries, new porches were built on the north side of the church and there was some refenestration. The church was restored in 1850 by the architect William Armstrong, of Brunswick Square, whose staff included E. W. Godwin. Godwin noted that the tower was then in a "neglected and damaged" state and was in use as "a place of deposit for lumber" (Anon. 1862, 91). The galleries were removed in 1876. The reredos was also replaced in the nineteenth-century.
In 1907 works were undertaken to allow the north aisle to be used for worship. This entailed the movement of the remaining fragment of a medieval stone effigy of a recumbent knight in armour in the Kemys, or chapel, aisle, from the eastern end of the south side to a site within the most easterly panelled arch on the same side (Pritchard 1907, 223-224). In 1914 The 1739 Bilbie tenor bell was used to provide metal for a new bell (weighing 19 cwt  0 lb 11 oz) cast by Llewellin and James of Castle Green. 
Later in the twentieth century a single-storey extension was added to the south-east corner of the church.
The church has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/40/298).

Teast's Dock, later known as Albert Dock. The dry dock (a shipbuilding dock) was built at the south-western corner of an inlet off of the western side of St. Augustine's Reach. The dock was sited on the position of a graving dock, shown on Rocque's 1742 map, which was apparently created in the early eighteenth century when the harbour was tidal. The dock was subsequently turned into a dry dock by the addition of a pair of lock gates and, Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 map suggests, the building of stone walls. Part of the dock wall was recorded during an archaeological evaluation in 1997 (BUAD 3300) which was constructed of Pennant sandstone bonded in a off-white mortar. A layer of yellow/brown silty clay was found which the excavator suggested may have been a working surface for the dock (Cox, 1998). The dock had a number of associated structures.
The Teast family took over running of the dock between about 1790 and 1832. It later passed into the hands of the Peters family, who renamed it Albert Dock. The dock was infilled soon after 1884.

No.7 Brunswick Square. In the early-twentieth century the building was The Hahnemann Hospital, a homeopathic hospital.
The building is listed as part of the terrace with Nos.7-12.

'Overfall' Dam. Now on the line of Cumberland Road. Dredged material from the harbour was dumped inside the dam, from where the flow was supposed to flush it out over the top and into the River Avon at low tide. This system failed to clear all the material, which built up against the inside of the dam, and it was replaced by the 'Underfall', which carried the flow beneath the dam instead. It is still performing that function.
No.126 St. Thomas Street. Attached. 2 storeys and attic; 1-window range; gabled front; jettied. Full-width glazing to first-floor; 8-light(?) window to attic.

No.127 St. Thomas Street. Attached. 3 storeys and attic; 1-window range; gabled front; first-floor only jettied. Full-width first-floor glazing of Ipswich window flanked by cross-windows. 6-light oriel to second-floor, flanked, right, by a cross-window. A possible sash to the attic.

Bengough's Almshouses, located on the south-western side of Horfield Road. The alsmhouses were built in 1878 to designs by a local architectural practice, Foster and Wood. The building has five single-depth plan blocks arranged around three sides of a courtyard.

Platform or fort at Lawford's Gate. The fort formed part of the defences of the eastern side of Bristol during the English Civil War of 1642-1646. The date of its construction is not currently clear but it may be the "platforme at Stapleton way" referred to in the survey of ordnance captured by the Royalist armies in 1643 (Roy 1975, 261), implying a construction date of 1642. The size and form of the fort is not currently clear but it was surrounded by a ditch around 5.25 metres wide and 2 metres deep. On 10 September 1645, during the Parliamentarian attack on the city, the fort was assaulted and captured (Sprigge 1854, 116).
The location of the monument was established by archaeological evaluation (BUAD 3723; Insole 2001) and the ditch at the north-west corner was subject to archaeological excavation in 2002 (BUAD 3923; King 2002).

No.1 Trinity Street, located at the north-west corner of Trinity Street. The building was constructed in 1733.
The entance hall and stair were surveyed in the early 1920s (BUAD 4102; Dening 1923, 108-113).

No.8 Temple Street, located at the northern end of Temple Street, on its east side. Attached. 3 storeys, no attic storey as such; gabled front; jettied; 2-window range. 2 sashes each to the upper floors.
Gasometer, Canon's Marsh.

No.16 Peter Street. The building was a four-storey gabled building with a single bay which was located on the north side of Peter Street. The entrance was centrally placed in the shopfront which formed the ground floor. The fenestration in the remaining floors was formed by casements. A tall chimney stack projected from the roof on its west side. It was apparently built as a part of the same development as the adjacent building, No.16 which stood on its east side. The building was demolished at the end of the first decade of the twentieth-century to make way for the Queen's Picture House, which opened in 1910.
No.20 Christmas Steps.
No.54 Colston Street.

No.68 Colston Street. The gabled building, on the east side of Colston Street, is of two storeys plus attic. The ground-floor has a shopfront of nineteenth-century date and there is a bay window at first floor level.
No.70 Colston Street. A single bay gabled building of two storeys plus an attic with a pantile roof. The ground floor is a shopfront, while the first floor has a bay window.

No.12 Little Ann Street. The house stands on the north side of Little Ann Street and was probably built as part of the development of Great Ann Street and Great George Street between 1700 and 1720, an estate, unusually in Bristol at that time, aimed at artisans and craftsmen (Leech "The Processional City" in Tarlow & West (eds.) 1999, 19-34). The house was surveyed by Roger Leech (BUAD 2046)

The Crown Inn in All Saints' Lane.
The surviving northern three cellars were probably the medieval undecrofts of the Guilders Inn in St. Nicholas Street which was demolished in c.1740.
The Church of St. Gabriel, Newfoundland Street.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Bristol Dental Hospital, Lower Maudlin Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
A structure dating to the 2nd to 4th-century AD which was excavated in 1973 as part of the archaeological work associated with the development of the Greyfriars office block in Lewin's Mead. The structure was located beneath the remains of the Moravian Church, Upper Maudlin Street.
The building was fragmentary but had stone foundations. Part of a large millstone was excavated, possibly indicating that the structure was a mill. It is possible that the structure excavated to the west in 1976 may be part of the same building.
The construction of the Bristol Dental Hospital probably destroyed all remains of the structure.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: City Road Baptist Chapel, City Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
City Road Baptist Chapel, located on the north-eastern side of the junction of City Road with Upper York Street. It was erected in 1861 and is a two storey structure of squared, coursed Pennant sandstone with limestone ashlar detailing.
The main entrance is set in a Romanesque arch with the legend "City Road Baptist Chapel 1881" above the door. Carved into the plat band is the Biblical text "Strive to enter in at the strait gate" (Luke Chapter 13, verse 24).
In 2003-2004 conservation works were undertaken to the chapel.

S Shed, Narrow Quay. The transit shed stood along Narrow Quay. The centre of the structure was a closed shed with the elements at the north and south ends being open-sided.
Elements of the shed survive in the cobbled surface of Narrow Quay.

KNOWN_AS: Guest house of the Franciscan friary
MONUMENT_DESC:
A medieval stone building was identified during archaeological excavation at Deep Street in 1989 (BUAD 444). The building was a ground floor hall which was built on a terrace cut into the south facing hillside of rubble construction and measured approximately 8.5 by 5.5 metres. A fourteenth-century open hearth with a stone surround was found in the centre of the building. The hearth was constructed of over 400 ceramic floor tiles pitched on their sides. A small stone drain was found running west to east through the middle of the building. The excavator interpreted the structure as the lodge of the warden or the guest house of the Franciscan friary in Lewin's Mead.
The building was demolished in the early modern period and a secular domestic building constructed on the rubble. The remains of the south wall of the building were destroyed by construction of the revetment wall bounding the site.
Redcliff Corn Mill. The mill stood on the west side of Redcliff Street and is recorded by the 1st edition Ordnance Survey map of the early 1880s.
The churchyard of St. Leonard on the northern side of Leonard Lane. The churchyard was medieval in origin and had gone out of use by 1567 when it was the garden of Edith Payne (Leech, 1997 142).

No.68, Old Market Street, located on the southern side of Old Market Street. The building is a single bay house of three storeys with a detached kitchen block and was probably constructed in the first half of the eighteenth century.
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by J. H. Bussell, carpenter and builder, and by Miss Elliott, milliner. The Goad fire insurance plan of August 1896 indicates that it was then occupied by a veterinary surgery.

No.7, King Square. The three-storey house, probably designed by Thomas Paty, was built c.1760 as part of the creation of King Square. The entrance is from Dove Street South and has a portico. To the rear of the building is a possible stable block with a classical, pedimented front.
No.3, King Square. The three-storey house, probably designed by Thomas Paty, was built c.1760 as part of the creation of King Square.

Dolman's or Allen's burial ground. The burial ground was in existence by 1828. Interment there was ended by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852.
Bristol Museum and Art Gallery holds some human skeletal material reported to be from the burial ground (no accession number is marked on the box), although the circumstances of its collection are unknown

The Circular Stables at the east end of Back Fields, St. Pauls. The stable building was in existence by the time of the Plumley and Ashmead survey of Bristol of 1828 which shows the building as a circular structure 22 metres in diameter with buildings arranged around an open yard.
