It was still extant in the early 1880s when it was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan surveyed in 1883 although by this date a building had been constructed in the central yard and some of the original enclosing structure had been demolished.
The stables had been demolished by the early twentieth century, although an arc of outbuildings to the north-west of the main building appears to have survived until at least the First World War.

Unity Chapel, Midland Road. The building was constructed as a Christian Brethren chapel in the mid- nineteenth century. It was constructed of Pennant sandstone with brick detailing.
The building was demolished in 2002-2003.

KNOWN_AS: House at the east end of Temple Churchyard
MONUMENT_DESC:
House located at the eastern end of Temple Churchyard. The building was a two-storey stone rubble building of probable seventeenth-century date (possibly No.6 Ash Lodge by 1906). There was a single three-light mullioned window to each storey and the ground floor was sunken. The building was roofed with clay pantiles.
The building may be identifiable on Millerd's 1673 map of Bristol and seems later to have been subdivided, with the southern end possibly being demolished. By 1906 the property was in the ownership of Bristol Municipal Charities (Costello & Burleigh 1997, 47). It had been demolished by 1959.
The foundations of the building are likely to survive beneath the footway and pavement of Church Street at the east end of Temple Gardens, and the boundary wall of the churchyard here may have reused part of its west wall. This wall had been repointed and appeared also to have been partly rebuilt. This possible remnant element was demolished at the end of the 1990s when the southern wall of Temple Churchyard was reconstructed.

Powder magazine at Tower Harratz. The magazine was built in 1722 outside the Portwall and on the north side of the possible lodge excavated in 1997. The magazine was erected at a cost of £143 18s. 5d. (Evans 1824) and contained eight individual storage areas, four on both sides of a central passageway. The entrance was on the north, river Avon, side but there was also a communicating doorway with the possible redoubt on the south (BRO 0566(33)y). The store was closed c.1816 when the Bristol Gas Light Company gasworks was built 50 metres to the north-west.

The vicarage of Temple Church. The vicarage was located on the north side of Colston Place, opposite the north-west corner of Temple Church. The vicarage was of  two and three storeys with gabled roofs. It was constructed in the medieval period and survived until the beginning of the 1970s. It was surveyed by the Royal Commission on the Historical Monuments of England in 1969 and part of its site was excavated in 1971.

The Back Street Gate. The gate was part of the Marsh Wall and was located at the south end of Back Street (Queen Charlotte Street). It is recorded by James Millerd's 1673 map of Bristol and survived into the early-eighteenth century. The Bristol Corporation ordered its removal in 1738.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Portwall Lane Car Park, Phippen Street
MONUMENT_DESC: The Angel Inn, on Redcliff Street. An old inn, originally outside Redcliff Gate. Attached. By the early C19 was refronted. 3 storeys; 5 bays, with a 6th. at the left-hand, beyond a downpipe or pilaster strip. Parapet. Hipped roof(s). Hooded porch to right of centre. Most windows sashes with raised voussoirs. The garden extended as far east as the Pile Street School, and there were extensive stables, etc.

Nos. 82 & 83, Redcliff Street, a pair of houses located on the north corner of Pile Street. Attached to the north. 3 storeys; gabled fronts; jettied. Each a 1-window range. Adjacent entrances, with shop windows to the outer edges. Probably one sash each to each upper storey. No attic windows. Left-hand and central eaves on brackets.

No.1 Broadmead, located at the corner of Broadmead and St. James Back. Attached to north and east. 2 storeys and attic; one gable each to both frontages, both jettied; 1-window ranges. South elevation. Central entrance between shop windows; large corner bracket. Bay to first-floor and attic, both with 6-light fronts and 2-light sides. West elevation. Central entrance; left-hand window (shuttered). First-floor bay, windows as south elevation. Blocked attic window. Gable not reaching as far down as that facing south, stopping at sill level.

No.91 Redcliff Street, located on the western side of Redcliff Street. The building was a terraced house of medieval date.
The south wall of was recorded during the excavations of 91 Redcliff Street by R. H. Jones in 1983 (BUAD 447). This section of wall aligned east-west with plain walling at the east end, beyond which was an arcade of three arches (1000A). At least the westernmost two were visible on both sides of the wall. The arches consisted of Pennant Sandstone voussoirs only - there was no decorative stonework. On the northern face, between the springings for the second and third arches, was a carved head, interpreted as a corbel. Excavation down the north side of the arcade was carried out, showing that the pier between the first two arches continued for more than a metre below the modern ground level.

The Church of St. Peter, located on the south side of Peter Street. The church is traditionally held to be the oldest church in Bristol and it was first recorded in 1107 when the advowson was granted to Tewkesbury Abbey (Johnson & Cronne 1956, 73-74). Tewkesbury Abbey appears to have exercised its right to appoint through its cell St. James Priory (BUAD 1024M). William Worcestre, writing in 1480, recorded that the church was 54 steps long, omitting the choir, and 30 steps wide (Neale 2000, 134-135).
The church has aisles on the north and south sides of an unclerestoryed nave, each aisle separated from the nave by a four-bay arcade of Perpendicular arches supported by clustered columns, possibly of marble or some other polished stone. The nave has a square three-stage tower at its west end. The building is constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble with limestone ashlar dressings. There has not yet been a detailed archaeological analysis and phasing of the structure. However, the majority of the fabric appears to date to the fifteenth century.
The north aisle is of seven bays, articulated by buttresses, with a deep plinth. The aisle is lit by five-light windows, though there is a large chamfered bullseye window in the central bay. The penultimate bay at the west end is windowless. An octagonal stair tower projects from the north wall of the aisle against the buttress of the second bay from the east. The south aisle is wider than the north aisle and is of six bays with wide five-light windows between the projecting buttresses. It has a five-light late-Perpendicular east window which is blind below the transom. The west ends of both aisles are gabled, and there is a narrow three-light window in the north side, and a five-light window in the south.
The tower is flush with the west ends of the aisles and has ashlar quoins. In the west wall there is a wide Perpendicular arched doorway. Above there is a three-light window with a small two-light window in the second stage. The belfry has a two-light louvred window, a cornice with gargoyles on the corners and a crenellated parapet with crocketed pinnacles. The fabric of the lower element of the tower is thought to be of twelfth-century (or possibly earlier) date.
Relatively little is currently known about the organisation of the interior of the church during the medieval period. The church appears to have had a number of chapels; in 1395 William Poynez instructed that he was to be buried in the "chapel of the blessed Mary, before the image of St. George" (Wadley 1886, 55). A survey of the chantries in the church in 1548 recorded that one John Williams had established an anniversary there "att the awlter of o[ur] ladie of Belhousse" (Maclean 1883-84, 240-241). Behind the Newton tomb was a piscina. There was a brass to Master Robert Lond, chaplain (d.1461) and other brasses are recorded. In 1845 a finely decorated canopied niche [1005A] was found at the west end of the north aisle and during repair works in 1901 a Gothic doorway on the north side of the chancel, a piscina [1004A], and a suspected credence niche were found (Pritchard 1904, 131-132).
After the dissolution of St. James, the advowson of the rectory was acquired by Henry Brayne as part of his purchase of the St. James property in 1544. By the mid- sixteenth century there were 400 parishioners (Maclean, 1883-84 240) and the early-modern period is known to have seen a number of alterations to the fabric. At the east end of the south aisle south wall a large monument to Lady Antholin Newton of Barr's Court was erected in the 1570s or 1580s; against much of the east wall of the same aisle was a large monument to Alderman Robert Aldworth (d.1634) and his wife Martha (d.1619) (BRSMG M2667; Stoddard, 2001 35). Between the Newton and Aldworth monuments was the effigy of a priest. A substantial and ornate oak reredos was constructed in 1697 (Dening 1923, 121-123) and in 1698 the pews in the church were replaced with box pews which were still in place in the early nineteenth century (BRSMG M2670; Stoddard 2001, 34). In 1729 the peal of eight bells in the tower was recast by Abraham Rudhall. In 1912 a highly decorative Gothic traceried choir screen was erected. In the late-nineteenth or early-twentieth century a memorial to the poet Richard Savage (c1697-1743) was fixed to the exterior wall of the south aisle. The memorial bears the legend "IN MEMORY OF RICHARD SAVAGE/POET BURIED NEAR THIS SPOT/ AUG 2nd 1743." A boiler house was created beneath the west end of the south aisle (now filled in).
St. Peter's was one of the city centre churches gutted by bombing on the night of 24/25 November 1940. After the war the structure was stabilised, the base of the tower and arcades being reinforced with concrete, and left as a shell without a roof or reglazing. The Newton and Aldworth monuments were left in situ, suffering damage from weathering. In 1958 the Aldworth tomb was removed and elements placed in the collections of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery. The Newton tomb was moved into St. Nicholas Church museum in 1969. The church was subsequently designated as a memorial to the Second World War by Bristol City Council. On the west wall of the church is an inscribed slate plaque bearing the legend: "IN/MEMORY OF THE/CITIZENS OF BRISTOL/AND/SURROUNDING AREAS/WHO DIED/IN THE BLITZ/DURING/THE 1939-1945 WAR".
The church has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/40/184).

The Court Sampson tavern, No.119 St. Thomas Street. The building was a house of three storeys and attic, with a slightly jettied frontage and a gabled roof. It was probably built in the seventeenth century.
In the front room over the bar was a moulded wood chimney-piece bearing the initials ' I. G.', with, over, the date 1669. The building was demolished in early 1914 and was visited by John Pritchard shortly before (BUAD 678). It then belonged to the Bristol Municipal Charities, and "would have been saved had it not been beyond repair" (Pritchard 1920, 139).

KNOWN_AS: Statue of John Cabot, Narrow Quay
MONUMENT_DESC: Statue of John Cabot, located at the south end of Narrow Quay. The statue is a bronze figure of Cabot seated on a projecting (bronze) timber and was sculpted by Stephen Joyce FRBS, a locally-based artist. The sculpture was erected in 1985 (Merritt 2002, 54-55).

No.5 King Street, located on the south side of King Street. The building was constructed c1665 as part of a terrace of five houses. Timber-framed front. Gabled to front and rear.
The building now forms part of the public house known as the Llandoger Trow.

KNOWN_AS: The Elton Mansion, No.7 Small Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Elton Mansion, No.7 Small Street. The street frontage was rendered, with a short plinth, the whole elevation one with that of No.8. The property was purchased by Sir Abraham Elton from Sir Thomas Cann in 1700, the house having been occupied previously by Richard Streamer. On the ground-floor, a central arched vehicle entrance with double doors; a large window to each side. Three tall first-floor windows; two second-floor windows, above the outer ones of the floor below; similar mouldings to the window openings on both storeys, with decorative keystones.
An ornate stone chimney-piece (BUAD 1006A), in a first-floor room, used as a board-room, was removed to the company's new building at Telephone Avenue, to be installed in the board-room there. Another example, carrying the arms of the city and the Merchant Venturers, was likewise relocated. The wood panelling and fine plaster ceiling and frieze of the principal room were acquired by Sir E. H. Elton, Bart., of Clevedon Court. 
The building was last occupied by the Bristol Waterworks Company. It was removed for the Post Office extension in 1908.

No.8 Small Street. The street frontage was rendered, with a short plinth, the whole elevation one with that of No.7. On the ground-floor, a large window on the left; a central entrance; on the right the arched entry to a corridor (leading to St.Werburgh's Chambers). Two tall first-floor windows, left and centre, an unidentified opening on the right. One central second-floor window, similar to those at No.7; similar mouldings to the window openings on both storeys, with decorative keystones, as at No.7. Two small features, possibly windows, at second-floor, either side of main window. Coping to top of elevation. The building was removed for the construction of an extension to the Post Office in 1908.

The Rope House. The structure stood against the south face of the town wall known as the Marsh Wall. There were buildings on the east and west sides of a central courtyard and a further building against the Marsh Wall. A wall on the south side of the courtyard, divided it from King Street, and this had a gateway in the centre. The Mayor's Audit of 1556-1557 records that the rope house had "an essemente in the highe wey to seyne Ropes a dore and a entry into a stable in the mershe with a esemente in the towne wall" (Livock (ed.), 1966, 4).

Drill Hall located approximately 50 metres to the north of Queen's Road. The drill hall was in existence by the early 1880s and was a retangular building measuring approximately 45 metres from north-west to south-east by 28 metres wide. It was demolished to make way for the Wills Memorial Building in the early 1920s.

The Marsh Street Gate, located at the southern end of Marsh Street. The gate was one of the gates through the town wall known as the Marsh Wall. According to William Worcestre, writing in the 1480s, the road narrowed to 4.8 metres beneath the gate but he gives no other details (Neale 2000, 204-205). The gate still stood in 1673 but it had been removed by the early 1740s.
The original St. Peter's Pump. The medieval well was sited at the west end of Peter Street, in the centre of the highway.

Conduit Head, All Saint's Conduit. The conduit head was built in front of the Tolzey on the south side of Corn Street. It is recorded in one of the vignettes in the border of Millerd's map of Bristol of 1673 as an elaborately decorated two-bay structure with what appears to be the royal arms above.

No.16, Welsh Back. An attached warehouse. C19. 5 storeys; rubble front with parapet; 3-window range; strings between storeys. A  right-hand wide entrance at ground-floor, 2 windows to left; other floors with a central entrance and one window either side.

No.17, Welsh Back. An atttached warehouse. C19. 5 storeys; possibly with a hipped roof; parapet; 3-window range. The first 4 floors with a central entrance and one window either side, the top floor all window. Possibly a rubble facade.
Malthouse located on the south side of Constitution Hill. The malthouse was in existence by 1883 and is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.22).
Smithy, located to the south of John Carrs Terrace. The smithy was in existence by 1883 and is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.22).

A clay pit, located on the site of Rosebery Terrace, on the eastern side of John Carrs Terrace. The clay pit was in existence by 1883 and is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.22) which names it as "Old Clay Pit".

Police station, located on the eastern side of Jacobs Wells Road. The police station was in existence by 1883 and is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.22). It is constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble with ashlar dressings.

No.15, King Street, located on the southern side of King Street. The building was a house constructed in the mid-seventeenth century. It was of three storeys and attic and probably had a common rafter roof.
No.14 (BUAD 170M) and No.15 King Street were amalgamated into a single warehouse during the nineteenth century and a new façade created. This is of Pennant sandstone ashlar and squared rubble, with red brick and limestone dressings and has a four-window range. The ground-floor windows are in segmental-arched openings while the upper floor is divided by four two-storey semicircular-arched recesses, with alternate brick and limestone dressings. Several of the internal walls of both buildings appear to have been removed at the same time to create open-plan spaces and cast-iron columns (with flanges to pillows and timber floor beams) seven bays deep support the first-floor. The seventeenth-century second and third floors were also removed and a new floor for the warehouse inserted at a level between them.
The northern part of the seventeenth century building is in part extant. The former west wall of No.15 survives and contains a seventeenth-century chimney breast. The roof against the street front is hipped with a gable at its south end.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/16/600).

Transit shed, Cumberland Basin. The transit shed stood on the south side of Cumberland Basin, at the western end by the southern entrance lock to the Basin. It was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 scale plan (Bristol Sheet (LXXV.4.6) and measured 37 metres from east to west and was around 15 metres wide.

KNOWN_AS: Dewpond, 50 metres south of Priory Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Dewpond, located 50 metres south of Priory Road. The dewpond is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 scale plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.13) and measured 11.9 metres long and 4 metres wide.
Resin Works, located at the eastern end of White Street, St. Jude's. It was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 scale plan (Bristol Sheet (LXII.13.12).
Earlsmead Tannery.

Warehouse. At the northern end of the western side of Colston Avenue. C19. Pickford & Co., also London & North Western Railway. Attached. 3 storeys, attic and basement; 2-bay facade. A right-hand wide entrance; a segmental-headed window to the left, above a segmental-headed cellar access with double doors. Entrances with double doors to right-hand at both first and second floors, served by a hand-crane or hoist to the right. A pair of sashes with stepped voussoirs to first and second floors. Behind a parapet, a hipped mansard roof with 3 dormers to the front. Burnt down in 1905 (Winstone,32,pl.92).

Printing works. At the northern end of the western side of Colston Avenue, immediately north of the warehouse of Messrs. Pickfords. C19. Occupied by John Wright (The Stonebridge Press). Attached. 3 storeys; 7-window range; hipped roof with clerestory. A rusticated ground-floor and quoins. A round-headed entrance either side of a wide 2-storey round-arched opening with simple tracery. A pair of round-arched windows either side at first-floor. 7 round-arched second-floor windows, arranged 2+3+2, the middle trio with enlarged keystones. Parapet. Burnt out in 1905, restored, and later Blitzed (Winstone,32,pl.92).

Baker Baker's Department Store. Late C19. Facing Wine Street, running westwards from the corner of Cheesemarket. Attached. 4 storeys; an unknown number of bays/windows. Curved around the corner into Cheesemarket. Large plate-glass shop windows, with several entrances including one on the corner. Square piers, with capitals, between the windows on all upper floors, windows square-headed. Balustrading beneath all third-floor windows. Parapet. At least the one chimney-stack.

The Water Lane pottery, located to the east of Temple Church, on the eastern side of Petticoat Lane. The pottery was founded around 1683 by Edward Ward and was handed through the Ward family until it was leased to Thomas Cantle in 1746. It was sold in March 1751 with Cantle as tenant and he remained in occupation until 1756. The pottery was then taken over by William Taylor until it seems to have been amalgamated with the next door Temple Back pottery by Richard Frank. As part of the Temple Back Pottery [BUAD 86M] it continued to work until 1886.

The Y.M.C.A. Hall, at the rear of No.4, St. James Square, with one end on the alley that connected with St. James Barton. A large hall with a stage and balconies. Side windows, and, at the end, above the stage, 3 large windows, the outers with segmental heads, the middle being round-headed. Probably internally a wagon roof or similar, gabled externally (Winstone 1983, pl.127). Reading rooms, class rooms and offices lay between the hall and the Square. Now beneath the very wide pavement beside Bond Street.

A terrace of four houses, all with ground-floor shops. Nos.10 to 13, on the north side of Broadmead. C17. Attached. Gabled fronts (in pairs, as 2 M-shaped roofs); jettied; each a 2-window range. Lateral stacks at ends/ centre, the front central stack being tall. Shopfronts to the ground-floors. Pairs of sashes to first and second floors; single sashes to attics. In front of Broadmead Baptist Church.

No.128 St. Thomas Street. Attached. Immediately on the south side of the Wool Hall. 3 storeys and attic; 1-window range; gabled front; ground and first floors jettied. Full-width pentice roofs over fronts of lower 2 storeys. lateral stack. Right-hand entrance; bay shop window. Bays at outer ends of first-floor, glazing between. At the second-floor, a central 6-light bay, flanked by cross-windows. 3-light oriel to the attic.

KNOWN_AS: South possible Banqueting House, St. James Barton
MONUMENT_DESC: South possible Banqueting House, St. James Barton. The building was recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 plan of Bristol which indicates it to have been a square structure at the south-east corner of a garden on the east side of St. James Barton (BUAD 1587M).

A pair of houses. Nos.107 & 108, Temple Street. Attached. 3 storeys and attics; 1-window ranges; gabled fronts; first-floors only jettied, but string-courses or moulded beams over the first and second floors. Shared pentice roof over front of ground-floor, on 6 brackets. Entrances at outer ends. Double-height bays to the first and second floors, all Ipswich windows except first-floor of No.107, where sash front and sides. Attic windows of 6 or 8 lights. Twin-purlin sides to each roof. Lateral stacks. Blinman at No.107 in 1828.

KNOWN_AS: Henry Brayne's Great House, Lower Maudlin Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Henry Brayne's Great House. According to the documentary record, the house was formed out of the cloister of the Benedictine priory of St. James which Brayne acquired from the Crown after the dissolution.

The western of a pair of houses on the north side of Lewins Mead. Attached. 2 storeys and attics, with attics joined under a flat-roofed section between the gables. Gabled front; jettied; a 1-window range. Entrance at outer end; ground-floor square bays with flanking windows. One semicircular bay to each at first and second floors, each bay with 3 curved cross-windows. Flanking first-floor windows of 6 lights each to full width. All windows on this floor reach to the jetty above. Small window at left-hand of attic of left-hand property. Extensive decorative plasterwork beneath the first-floor windows, and to a lesser degree at attic level.
There is some evidence for a detached kitchen block on the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883.

Langton Street Chapel, a Wesleyan Methodist chapel which was opened in 1828. The chapel and its associated burial ground now lie in open space around the site of Broughton House. The chapel survived until at least 1951 and its remains are likely to be well preserved below ground.

Burial ground of Langton Street Chapel. The burial ground seems to have opened in 1828 with the chapel. The burial ground was disused in 1951 and the site was subsequently developed for Broughton House. It is not clear if the cemetery was cleared before development but the block of flats occupies only the centre of the cemetery. There is consequently a strong likelihood that inhumations remain in situ on the site.

KNOWN_AS: Gabled building, south side of Thomas Lane
MONUMENT_DESC:
A gabled, jettied building on the south side of Thomas Lane and immediately adjoining the west side of the Seven Stars public house. The building was of late seventeenth century date with a frontage of fifteen feet. The house was demolished on 29 May 1900 and was this observed by John Pritchard (BUAD 199). The building had six rooms, the largest measuring 12 feet by 10 feet by 8 feet high. Pritchard remarked on two internal fittings, "a heavy moulded chimneypiece" and "upon the cupboard in a recess were ornamental wrought-iron hinges of two designs" (Pritchard 1900, 272).
The frontage of the building is beneath Thomas Lane and the rear beneath the extant brick building which replaced it. The likely state of preservation of associated deposits is unknown but foundations and possibly  stratification may survive beneath the lane.

KNOWN_AS: Gabled building, south side of Thomas Lane
MONUMENT_DESC:
A gabled, jettied building on the south side of Thomas Lane to the west of the Seven Stars public house (directly adjoining the west wall of another gabled building, 1232M). The building was of late seventeenth century date with a frontage of thirteen feet. The house was demolished on 29 May 1900 and was this observed by John Pritchard (BUAD 199).
The frontage of the building is beneath Thomas Lane and the rear beneath the extant brick building which replaced it. The likely state of preservation of associated deposits is unknown but foundations and possibly  stratification may survive beneath the lane.

The preceptory of the Knights Hospitaller, Temple Street. The preceptory was granted to the order at the beginning of the fourteenth century after the suppression of the Knights Templar, whose preceptory it had previously been.
The order was suppressed by Act of Parliament in 1540 and the site was bought by the Corporation in July 1544 for £789 17s 10d (Gairdner & Brodie, 626).

The Great House, Redcliff Street. The house stood on the bank of the river Avon at the west side of Bristol Bridge. A vignette in the border of Millerd's 1673 map records structure as a house of three storeys plus attic with a cross-gabled roof. A lantern is shown in the centre of the roof. There were large, apparently mullion, windows of between four- and fifteen-lights in the north face, and some of these appear from the vignette to have been oriel windows. A two-storey range ran north from the west side of the main block, forming the west side of a small courtyard on the north, riverward, side of the house. This had a covered gallery along its north side.
The Great House became a sugar refinery between 1689 and 1715, run by Isaac Hort until c.1700 and then taken over by his son Thomas (Hall 1965, 120n).
9, St. James Barton
10, St. James Barton

KNOWN_AS: Quarry enclosed by the Seven Sisters, Durdham Down
MONUMENT_DESC: An infilled quarry on Durdham Downs (Darvill & Grinsell, 1989 70). The quarry is surrounded by a group of trees known as the "seven sisters" from a group of firs (seven originally) planted on it. It is a low mound near the tip of a minor ridge of the Downs, just outside of the old quarry area. The mound now has a flat top, about 2 feet high, 60 feet in diameter and surrounded by a shallow ditch about three feet wide.
Goldenhill Farm. The farm was demolished and built over in 1934.

Redlandgreen Farm. The farm is recorded by the Westbury-on-Trym tithe survey of 1841, when the farm buildings comprised only the farmhouse. The farmhouse is extant and is located on the west side of the plot. The Ordnance Survey 1st edition map surveyed in 1880 records outbuildings to the east of the farmhouse, including a block of five pigsties or stables.

KNOWN_AS: Site of a dewpond (alleged pond barrow)
MONUMENT_DESC:
Tumulus at ST59287732. An earthen basin resembling a dewpond, 20m in diameter east-west, 0.7m deep at the centre. It can never have been a robbed barrow and there are no signs of a ditch, outer banks or spoil mounds.

Tumulus dug by Bingham (SMR 801) and located by him to an OS field on the OS25" 1881 has been identified by Jones (1946, 16n) with this basin because he used the OS25" 1904 on which the field had been renumbered. This mistake has been followed by O'Neill & Grinsell.

KNOWN_AS: Chapel of St. Werburgha, Henbury Hill
MONUMENT_DESC: Chapel of St. Werburgha, Henbury Hill. The chapel, an appurtenance of Westbury Church, is referred to in medieval documents as being on Henbury Hill. and a reference occurs in 1299 to land in Henbury Manor beneath St.Werburgha's Hill. It has been suggested that the building excavated by Bartlett at Blaise Castle in 1918 (SMR 20457) were those of St. Werburgha's Chapel and that the dedication had later been changed to the more popular Saint Blaise, whose festival fell on the same day. Bartlett disagreed and argued that St. Werburgha's lay on a portion of Henbury Hill towards Sea Mills and the valley of the Trym, over-looking lower ground and in the parish of Westbury. A possible site is the fragment of a building revealed in 1936 near Highland Grove, Henbury Hill.

KNOWN_AS: Cross in the churchyard of the Church of St. John, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC: Cross in the churchyard of St. John's Church, Bedminster. Charles Pooley reports that "preserved in the Piggot Collection is a sketch... of a fine 15th century cross that formerly stood opposite the south porch of the church. It has been demolished and when I last visited the spot the fragments were lying in the grass about the churchyard"(Pooley 1877, 144). Shortly after the First World War the fragments of the cross base were reassembled to form a three-stepped octagonal base. A new shaft was added, with a war memorial carved into it.
House or lodge (ie. a merchant's second residence) known to have been located to the north of Oldbury House (R. Leech pers. comm.). The site of the building now lies beneath a terrace of houses.

An iron foundry on the north side of Ellbroad Street which is recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883. The works occupied the block between Ellbroad Street and Narrow Weir. The site now lies beneath Castlemead and the highway in Lower Castle Street and is therefore likely to have been seriously disturbed by services and piling.

No.13, St. James's Square.
The building was damaged by bombing on 24 November 1940. It was destroyed in a further raid on 11 December 1940.

No.14, St. James's Square.
The building was burnt out during bombing raids in the early 1940s .

No.15, St. James's Square.
The building was destroyed by bombing on 11 December 1940.

No.16, St. James's Square.
The building was destroyed by bombing on 11 December 1940.

KNOWN_AS: House on East side of Crow Inn
POSTAL_ADDRESS: NCP Car Park, Queen Charlotte Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
A house located on the north side of Crow Lane, immediately west of a nineteenth-century warehouse which stood on the corner of Crow Lane and Welsh Back. The building was a four-storey, two-bay jettied and gabled building with a pantile roof. There were cellar lights on either side of what appears to be two doorways side by side and centrally-placed in frontage. This appears originally to have been two, single-bay, properties (possibly built as part of the same development) and later made into one. The string lines are continuous across the facade at all levels. The ground floor is a shopfront. The windows in the upper floors were sashes, while windows in each of the gable ends seem to have had drip moulds above them.
The buildings were demolished sometime during the first decade of the twentieth-century.

The church of St Mary Redcliffe. The church appears to have been constructed in the later twelfth century and served as a chapel of ease to St. John's Church, Bedminster.
The upper stages of the spire toppled into the nave during a storm in the fifteenth century, probably in the winter of 1446, and it remained truncated for several centuries.
In 1468 William Canynges created a perpetual chantry in the chapel of St. George and installed Thomas Hallkesock as the chaplain (Berkeley Muniments A2/17/38).
A heavy tenor bell of approximately 39 cwt was cast by Purdue in 1622 (it was removed in 1903).
The Canynges Society was founded in 1848 to raise funds for restoration works to the church. The spire was rebuilt in the 1870s with funding from a public subscription organised by the Canynges Society, and the reconstruction was completed in 1872. The Society was then dissolved but it was reconstituted in 1972.
In 1910 with Messrs. Harrison and Harrison, of Durham and London, rebuilt the organ. The new organ occupied the same position on each side of the chancel as the previous one but because of restricted space, the console was detached and sited just west of the chancel arch on the north side of the nave.
The church has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/1687) while the churchyard wall and the head of the Redcliff pipe is listed Grade II (Listed Building number 901-1/42/1682).

A pair of houses. On the south side of the Horsefair. Attached. Twin front gables that meet a short distance down their inner slopes (i.e. an M-shaped roof). 3 storeys and attics; jettied (?); 1-window range each. Entrances at the outer ends, shop windows, with blinds or awnings, adjacent. To the left-hand property, first and second floor windows of 6 lights but formerly wider, the outer lights being blocked up. The same floors of the right-hand property with 12-light windows. To each attic, a cross-window below an external collar. Lateral stacks to the inside.

KNOWN_AS: House at the eastern end of Horsefair
MONUMENT_DESC: A gabled two-bay house of seventeenth-century date located on the south side of the Horsefair, close to the junction with St. James Back. The house is of two storeys and attic. Twin sashes to first-floor. Smaller twin windows to attic. Studs visible at attic level. Pendant to gable apex.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Hilton Hotel and Techno House, Redcliffe Way
MONUMENT_DESC:
Samuel Taylor's garden, located between Pile Street and Red (now Redcliffe Mead) Lane. The garden was described in the 1820s (Braikenridge Notes, G.30) as having consisted of: 
"6 or 7 Acres of useful ornamental Garden Ground, Shrubberies, Terraces &c extending from Temple Gate nearly to Redcliff Church & adjoind the Residence of Saml. Taylor Esqr. in whose Possession it was & who had so ornamented it. It contained in his Time many leaden Statues with a Jet d'eau [1051A] & pond [1052A] for Gold & Silver fish. Mr. Taylor erected & worked a large Glass House (nearby the one which is now the Phoenix Glass House) in the angle of Pile Street & Red Lane ..."

Samuel Taylor's glasshouse. The glasshouse was built and worked by Samuel Taylor and was located "nearby the one which is now the Phoenix Glass House" in the corner of Pile Street and Red Lane. It had been converted to a colour warehouse by 1826 (Braikenridge Notes G.30). Nearly adjoining was Samuel Taylor's "very ancient" dwelling house.

House. No.19 Broad Weir. The structure was a four-storey, two-bay, jettied house with a front gable and pantiled roof. The ground floor was a shopfront and there were two doorways, one centrally-placed and the other at the west end of the frontage. There were two-bay windows at first and second floor levels and a central attic light beneath the gable. There are full width pentice roofs above the bay windows.
The building was destroyed by enemy action during a daylight raid in August 1942.

KNOWN_AS: House on site of the nave of Bristol Cathedral
MONUMENT_DESC:
House, possibly a prebendal house, built on the site of the demolished south nave aisle of St. Augustine's Abbey, one bay west of the south transept. The house was probable seventeenth century date and was of two storeys and attic, with an east-west ridge roof with central cross-gable to the north. There was a two-storey gabled porch in front of the gable, with a segmental-arched entrance with a carved west jamb. There was a chimney stack in the south-east corner of the roof.
Part of the building is recorded by a watercolour drawing by Hugh O'Neill of the cathedral cloister made in 1821 (BRSMG M1887). The building was demolished in the later-ninetenth century to make way for the reconstruction of the northern side of the cloister.

Cloister of St. Augustine's Abbey, now Bristol Cathedral. The cloister lay on the south side of the abbey church and was constructed c1170. An arcade of three Romanesque arches supported by piers with clustered columns and cushion capitals led off the eastern walk to a vaulted vestibule at the entrance to the chapter house.
The east walk is extant. The north walk was restored in the nineteenth century. Early nineteenth century drawings show that the windows to the north and east walks were of different designs, those of the north walk possessing fifteenth- or sixteenth-century tracery.
11, St. James Barton

The Jolly Sailor Inn, located at the north corner of Temple Back and Ash Lodge. The building was a two-storey, three-bay structure with a hipped (and apparently catslide) pantiled roof. The entrance, in Temple Back, marked the central bay and the windows, at each storey, were sashes. There were chimney stacks at either end of the roof. A sash window was also present at first floor level on the Ash Lodge frontage.
The site of the building is now beneath Temple Way.

The 1937 concrete culvert enclosing the River Frome. The stretch of the river from St. Augustine's Bridge to the present [25/10/96] position of the Neptune statue was culverted between 1937 and 1938 as part of the construction of the inner circuit road. A temporary dam was thrown across the Floating Harbour and the culvert built slightly to the east of the centre of the dock walls. The culvert was founded on narrow piles on either side of it which were driven into the river bed. It was 24 feet wide and the water level was intended to be 20.42 feet aOD (BRO Yellow Label Plan 38(3)). The harbour was then infilled with rubble and a road surface constructed over the whole.
No.36 Broad Street.
No.5 Christmas Steps.
No.6 Christmas Steps.
No.7 Christmas Steps.
No.8 Christmas Steps.
No.16 Christmas Steps.
No.18 Christmas Steps.
No.19 Christmas Steps.

KNOWN_AS: Bristol Industrial & Fine Art Exhibition Pavilion
MONUMENT_DESC:
Exhibition pavilion located at the north end of Colston Avenue which was erected to house the Bristol Industrial and Fine Art Exhibition of 1893. The pavilion was sited on the then newly-completed culvert over the River Frome. The pavilion was a large temporary timber structure, with its main entrance at the southern end, beneath a wide gable between square turrets. A round-arched porch of five bays wide by one deep. The turrets had pyramidal roofs topped by lanterns. The main hall appears to have been a wide single-span, single-storey structure, with two-storey ranges running down the outside. Internal lighting was electrical, power being supplied by the newly-constructed Central Electric Lighting Station at Temple Back.
The pavilion was removed after the exhibition ended and the site was ultimately redesigned for Magpie Park (BUAD 649M). A drinking fountain (BUAD 66M) on the centre commemorates the exhibition.

Cabmans shelter located on the west side of Colston Avenue. The shelter was of timber construction. Octagonal, with short angles across the corners and longer sides parallel to the harbour. Octagonal roof. Windows.
Bandstand located in Colston Avenue gardens, also known as "Magpie Park". The bandstand was an octagonal structure with a pagoda roof. It stood on the site of the present Cenotaph.

KNOWN_AS: House on the east side of St. James Barton
MONUMENT_DESC: House on the east side of St. James Barton

KNOWN_AS: Garden on the east side of St. James Barton
MONUMENT_DESC: Garden on the east side of St. James Barton

KNOWN_AS: North possible Banqueting House, St. James Barton
MONUMENT_DESC: North possible Banqueting House, St. James Barton.  The building was recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 plan of Bristol which indicates it to have been a square structure at the north-east corner of a garden on the east side of St. James Barton (BUAD 1587M).

No.45 Pilemarsh, St. George, located on the northern side of Pilemarsh. The building is a two-storey, two-bay cottage of Pennant sandstone rubble. The main, south-facing, elevation is rendered while the rear elevation is not. The building was constructed between 1803 and 1842. It was recorded by the St. George tithe survey (BRO EP/A/32/32) as Parcel 95, a house owned by William Arnold but not then occupied.

KNOWN_AS: Church of Christ the King, Filwood Broadway
MONUMENT_DESC: Church of Christ the King, located on the western side of Filwood Broadway, to the south of its junction with Hartcliffe Road. The church is a Roman Catholic parish church and was built in 1951-52. It is in a Modernist style and is constructed of Portland stone. The main entrance at the west end of the church is stepped and is covered by an open porch with a timber roof. It has an apsidal west end, a square campanile at the north-east corner and a baptistry at the south-east corner. Internally the church has aisles on the north and south sides of the nave and a clerestorey above. The roof is of copper. The presbytery is attached to the south side of the church and a sculpture of Christ the King is fixed to its west wall.
Clift House Tannery, located on the northern side of Clift House Road. The tannery was in existence by the early 1880s.
Ashton Gate Galvanized Iron Works, located on the western side of Coronation Road. The works was in existence by the early 1880s.

Limekilns, located to the north-east of North Street, Bedminster. The kilns were in existence by the early 1880s and were probably producing lime for the adjacent mortar mill (SMR 10400). The kilns had been demolished by the early twentieth century and the site redeveloped for housing.

Mortar Mill, located to the north-west of North Street, Bedminster. The mill was in existence by the early 1880s but had been demolished by the early twentieth century and the site redeveloped for housing.
Malthouse, located to the rear of the Rising Sun public house on the east sidfe of Ashton Road. The malthouse and public house are recorded by the 1st edition Ordnance Survey map of the 1880s.
Imperial Brewery. The brewery is recorded by the 1st edition 25" Ordnance Survey map but had been replaced by housing by 1902.

Strand's Buildings, Nos.156-170 Coronation Road, a terrace of fifteen houses. The buildings were probably constructed in 1822 and were certainly in existence by 1828 when they were recorded by Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 plan of Bristol as "Stroud's Buildings." The houses are in a late-Georgian style and are each of three-storeys and basement with a one-window range. They are constructed of rendered brick with Limestone ashlar dressings.
The terrace has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/1824).

Red Brick House at the eastern end of St. Augustine's Yard (now called Orchard Place), partly above the end of the lane leading from St. Augustine's Parade. Three storeys; 2-window range. Brick, flemish bond. Gabled roof. Sashes. One main room on ground-floor, with staircase to rear. Two rooms to other floors. First-floor partly above end of the alley connecting with St. Augustine's Parade.

Nos.63 and 65 St. Georges Road. A pair of shops of late eighteenth- or early nineteenth-century date, located on the north side of St. Georges Road, a short distance to the east of St. Georges Hall. The pair were probably built as houses and were of three storeys and attic. Rubble construction, with brick at the top; rendered. Attached on the east side. Parapets. Each a 1-window range with shopfront of twentieth-century date. Cellar flaps below the shop windows.
The buildings were demolished in the later twentieth century.

A lead works located on the south-eastern side of Easton Road. The building was recorded by John Plumley and George Ashmead's survey of Bristol of 1828. The works had been demolished by the early 1880s and the site redeveloped with terraced housing.

Kiln at Limekiln Dock. The kiln is recorded by a drawing of 1822 by Hugh O'Neill (BRSMG M2961) and was located a short distance to the west of the landward end of Limekiln Dock, close to Mardyke. It was a circular kiln around three storeys in height., and its function is currently (09/02/07) unknown.

KNOWN_AS: Ropewalk at Packhorse Hill, Barton Hill
MONUMENT_DESC: A ropewalk located on the western side of Packhorse Hill [modern Ducie Road] in Barton Hill. The ropewalk was in existence by the late 1820s and was recorded by the 1828 plan of Bristol surveyed by John Plumley and George Ashmead. The ropewalk was orientated from south-west to north and was 78 metres long by 8 metres wide. By th eearly 1880s the site had been

Hebron Chapel, a Primitive Methodist Chapel, located on the north-eastern side of Barrow Lane [modern Barrow Road]. The chapel was in existence by the early 1880s and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town Plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.23) surveyed in 1883 which recorded that the chapel could accommodate 400 worshippers. The chapel survived into the early twentieth century but was subsequently demolished.

KNOWN_AS: Baptist Chapel at Elmgrove Road, Redland
MONUMENT_DESC: Baptist chapel on the south-eastern side of Elmgrove Road, Redland. The chapel was a General Baptist chapel was constructed in the later nienteenth century. It was recorded by the first edition 1:500-scale Bristol Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.4) surveyed in 1881 and had seating for 500 worshippers. An extension to house a Sunday school had been built at the south-eastern end of the building by the beginning of the twentieth century. The chapel survived into the twentieth century but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped with housing.

KNOWN_AS: Pump by the Railway, Day's Road
Weighing Machine in Station Road Coal Yard

POSTAL_ADDRESS: North Quay and South Quay, Temple Back
MONUMENT_DESC: Warehouse, Commercial Road. On the river side of Temple Back, latterly occupied by Stotesbury Tubes and Fittings. 19th.century. Two storeys. Roof hipped at north-west end, gabled at opposite end against adjacent, taller building. Stone rubble construction. In plan, appears to be two buildings end-on, the south-eastern of six bays, the other of four bays and slightly less deep. One front elevation, with, on each floor, two windows, large double doors, four windows, large double doors, and two windows. Rusticated door frames and voussoirs to windows. Crane to upper left-hand doors. Some windows blocked. Lights at front of roof. One set of stairs only. Large doorway to rear of north-west block, small doorway at north-west end. Access through ground-floor party wall between the two parts of this building, also at first-floor, where the opening was arched. The roof was supported by king-post trusses.
No.4 King Street, forming part of the public house known as the Llandoger Trow. It was part of a terrace of five houses built in c.1665. Timber-framed front; front and rear gables.

No.1 High Street. A seventeenth-century timber-framed building known as the Dutch House and located at the corner of High Street and Wine Street (now beneath Wine Street). It was destroyed by enemy action 24-25 November 1940.

No.1, St. James's Square.
In 1883 the building was occupied by Jesse Knee, a deal furniture maker.
The building was destroyed by bombing on 11 December 1940.

No.2, St. James's Square.
In 1883 the building was occupied by James Lee, a cabinet maker.
The building was destroyed by bombing on 11 December 1940.

No.3, St. James's Square.
The building was destroyed by bombing on 11 December 1940.

No.4, St. James's Square.
The building was destroyed by bombing on 11 December 1940.

Transit shed, Cumberland Basin. The transit shed stood on the south side of Cumberland Basin, at the eastern end opposite Novia Scotia Place. It was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 scale plan (Bristol Sheet (LXXV.4.6) and measured 42.5 metres from east to west and was around 16.5 metres wide.

KNOWN_AS: Ell's Bridge or Ellbroad Street Bridge
MONUMENT_DESC: Ell's Bridge or Ellbroad Street Bridge. Jean Rocque's 1742 plan of Bristol records it as "Ells Bridge". The bridge carries the road at the junction of Broad Weir/ Ellbroad Street/ Philadelphia Street across the watercourse or old mill leat connecting the River Frome and Castle Ditch. The bridge was a single span arch of stone construction with parapets.

Tucker Street Meeting House. The meeting house was a Presbyterian chapel located at the southern end of the west side of the north-south leg of Tucker Street. The building was reputed to be a former theatre but was used as a chapel from the late-seventeenth century. The building was demolished in the late-eighteenth century to enable the creation of Bath Street. The congregation then moved to the chapel at Bridge Street (BUAD 226M).

KNOWN_AS: The Pelican Inn, St. Thomas Street
MONUMENT_DESC: The Pelican Inn, later known as the Talbot Inn, located on the east side of St. Thomas Street near to its northern end. Jean Rocque's 1742 plan shows a long yard, stretching about as far as the line of the Law Ditch. Beneath the modern No.8, Victoria Street and surrounding properties.

KNOWN_AS: Engine house associated with excavation of New Cut
MONUMENT_DESC: Engine house for a fire engine used during the excavation of the New Cut between the Ropewalk and Clift House. Presumably the engine pumped water from the excavations. Stone building, square or rectangular in plan. At lower level in the west wall, an opening with round-arched head, probably an entrance. The remains were drawn by Rev. John Eagles.

Ropewalk located on the south side of Wapping Wharf, against the cliff. Part of the ropewalk was contained within buildings with a row of elms providing shade for the remainder (Braikenridge notes C.37).

No.2 King Street. The building was part of a terrace of five houses built in c.1665 by Michael Deyos. It was a timber-framed gabled house with a pantile roof. Beneath the building there was a large cellar with an arched vault.
The house was destroyed by bombing on 11 April 1941 although its cellar survived

Hill's Bridge, spanning the New Cut at the northern end of Bath Road. The bridge was a single span iron bridge supported on stone piers of nineteenth-century date. It had iron railings and there were lamp standards at each corner and at the centre of each side. The bridge was demolished in 1855 after being hit by the steam barge "John".

KNOWN_AS: Forges on site of later New Gaol
MONUMENT_DESC: Forges used for the repair of tools and implements during the construction of the Floating Harbour. The forges were located behind the Ropewalk at Wapping, on the site of the later New Gaol (BUAD 63M). A drawing of 1806 shows a timber shed with hipped roof with several chimneys or vents, and, a short distance to the right, a kiln or kiln-like chimney. These were presumably temporary structures which were dismantled after work on the New Cut was complete.

KNOWN_AS: Entrance Lock to Bathurst Basin from Harbour
MONUMENT_DESC: Entrance lock between Bathurst Basin and the Floating Harbour. Two opposing pairs of gates towards the northern end. There were a further pair towards the south, opening against the harbour. The lock gates now disused and derelict.

No.18 Charles Street, located on the southern side of Charles Street. The building was a three-storey, single bay house and was in existence by 1758 when the Land Tax assessment described the building as "New Ho[use]." (Bryant 2003, 6). The first occupier was a Captain Gagen. The house was still extant in 1913 but it had been demolished by 1949.

No.19 Charles Street, located on the southern side of Charles Street. The building was a three-storey, single bay house and was in existence by 1758 when the Land Tax assessment described the building as "New Ho[use]." (Bryant 2003, 6). The first occupier was a Widow Barnes. By 1884 the house was occupied by William Truscott, a beer retailer of The Crown. The house was still extant in 1913 but it had been demolished by 1949.

No.20 Charles Street, located on the southern side of Charles Street. The building was a three-storey, single bay house and was apparently constructed in the first six months of 1780. The first occupier was a William Hayes (Bryant 2003, 6). The house was still extant in 1913 but it had been demolished by 1949.

Garage located on the eastern side of Winterstoke Road, on the south side of Ashton Road. The garage was built in the 1920s in a Modernist style, complete with wheel motifs on the pilasters. It was altered and extended in the late-twentieth century.
An archaeological desk-based assessment of the site (Meager, 2008) has suggested a later date for the garage based on the Ordnance Survey data that would indicate a construction date for the building post 1938.

KNOWN_AS: Pumping house adjacent to the Great Western Railway line, St. Annes
MONUMENT_DESC: A pumping house, located on the southern side of the Great Western Railway line some 40 metres to the south-east of the eastern entrance of the St. Anne's Tunnel. The building is recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500-scale plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXVI.02) published in 1904. The building is extant.

The Rex Cinema, located on the southern side of North Street, Bedminster. The cinema was in existence by 1950.
The building is extant.

East Street Baptist Church, located on the east side of East Street, Bedminster. The church was constructed in the late-nineteenth century and was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500-scale plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXV.04) published in 1903. The building is a a two-storey brick structure with a pitched roof.
The building is extant.

KNOWN_AS: St. Bartholomew's Church, Maurice Road, St. Andrews
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Bartholomew's Church, located on the south east side of the junction of Sommerville Road and Maurice Road, St. Andrews. The church was built in 1893 to serve the developing suburb at St. Andrews and is first recorded by the the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500-scale plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXVI.02) published in 1904. The church is a two-storey structure orientated from north-east to south-west, parallel with Maurice Road. It was designed in a Gothic style and is consertructed of coursed Pennant sandstone rubble with ashlar detailing.
The church is extant.
A malt house located on the north-western side of Easton Road.
A malt house on the south-western side of Hulbert Street.

No.7 Broad Street. The building was a jettied, gabled house of four storeys and was probably constructed in the seventeenth century.
No attic storey; gabled front; first-floor jettied. Bays to first, second and third floors, each with a cornice. Sashes to first-floor, 6-light fronts & 2-light sides to others.

No.8 Broad Street. The building was a jettied building of four storeys and was probably constructed in the seventeenth century.
Probable flat roof; first-floor jettied. 3-window range to first and second floors, sashes; single third-floor window.

Old Gate or Aldgate. The gate was constructed as part of the Norman inner circuit town wall and stood in Narrow Wine Street. William Worcestre, writing in the 1480s refers to it as the oldest gate of the town and locates it at or near the end of Church Lane (Neale 2000, 38-39), which ran towards St. Peter's Church. Its function appears to have become redundant with the creation of the second circuit town wall and was replaced by Newgate. The date at which the gate was removed is unknown although Worcestre notes that it had been demolished (Neale 2000, 38-39).

No.9 Broad Street. The building was a jettied, gabled house of four storeys and attic and was probably constructed in the seventeenth century.
Bays to first, second and third floors, each with a cornice, the uppermost cut away in centre. Ipswich windows to first and second floors; 8-light window to third-floor. Brackets to eaves.

No.10 Broad Street. The building was a jettied, gabled house of four storeys and attic. It was probably constructed in the seventeenth century.
Gabled front; first-floor jettied, otherwise flush first, second and third floors, each with a cornice, the uppermost cut away in centre. 2-window range to first, second and third floors; single window to attic.

No.19 Broadmead, located on the north side of Broadmead. The building was a gabled house of two storeys, attic and basement and was of probable seventeenth-century date. The main, south-west facing, elevation occupied a 4 metre wide frontage on Broadmead and the building extended back 8.9 metres from the street. The ground floor was occupied by a shopfront with an entrance on the western side and an adjacent shop window. The first floor and attic storeys were jettied and there was a central canted bay with a single 10 by 10 pane sash window. The attic storey was separated from first-floor by a full-width pentice. In the bay at attic level was a 6 by 6 pane sash. There were lateral chimneystacks on the eastern wall. There may also have originally been a detached kitchen to the rear of the building.
The building was demolished in January 1931 (Notes by P. E. Street) and its site now lies beneath the front part of No.84 Broadmead.

No.12 King Street, located on the southern side of King Street. The building was a jettied, gabled house of three storeys, attic and basement. It was constructed in the mid-seventeenth century as part of the development of King Street. The main, north-west facing elevation was two-window range and at ground-floor level there were twin entrances on the eastern side of the elevation. At the centre there was a bay; with a window to the west, with a cellar access beneath. The first-floor was jettied. The fenestration of the first and second floors comprised bays to the east and west, each with six lights, while the area between the bays consisted of an eight-light window. There were decorative panels beneath the windows. At attic level there was a single canted bay. The building had a steeply pitched pantiled roof, with a pendant in the apex of the front gable.

Factory. C19, but constructed in phases over a number of years. The main production base for Messrs. J. S. Fry. Consisting of a number of individually numbered 'factories' in the Union Street-Pithay area. Tall brick-built structures with tall brick chimneys. Replaced by the new factory at Somerdale, Keynsham. The last buildings were removed in the 1960s.

House. No.65, on the south side of Broadmead, west of Union Street. C17. Attached. The western half of a pair of houses with M-shaped roof. 3 storeys and attic; first and second floors jettied; 1-window range. Shopfront with a central entrance. A wide sash to first-floor; twin sashes to second-floor; single attic window. Removed for the construction of a factory for Messrs. Fry's.

A pair of houses. Nos.66 & 67, Broadmead, on the south side to the west of Union Street. C17. Attached. Shared an M-shaped gabled front. 3 storeys and attics; first-floor jettied, other storeys slightly jettied; 2-window ranges. Sashes to first and second floors; single attic windows. A single common lateral stack, forward of centre. Removed for the construction of one of Messrs. Fry's factories.

Tabernacle Bridge, on Penn Street (the original line). Single span. Stone. Parapets. When drawn in 1821 had a distressed arch, which had distorted some time before but was still sound. Named after the nearby Whitefield's Tabernacle.

KNOWN_AS: Chapel of the Three Kings of Cologne
MONUMENT_DESC:
Chapel of the Three Kings of Cologne, located on the south corner of the junction of Colston Street and Christmas Steps. The chapel was established in the late-medieval period to serve Foster's Almshouse (BUAD 423M). The chapel escaped confiscation of its property by the Crown in the 1540s because of its relationship with the almshouse (Maclean 1883-84, 248-249).
In the early nineteenth century there was a small flat-roofed building with two-centred arched openings at the top of Christmas Steps against part of the north end wall of the chapel. The south end before restoration consisted of a gable with square bellcote topped by a finial and weathervane. The entrance was by two-leaf door under a four-centred arch with panelled soffits, over which was a porch consisting of a pediment supported on brackets. Above was a six-light mullion and transom window with leaded panes, and, in the apex of the gable, a sundial.
The building was refaced and roofed in 1861 by Foster and Wood as part of the reconstruction of the almshouse. The chapel was restored in 1865 and the internal panelling and pews date from this time. The chapel is constructed of squared, coursed limestone and Pennant rubble, with limestone dressings and a pitched roof. In the west-facing elevation there is a 4-light window with panel tracery. In the north wall there is a single window with intersecting tracery, and the remnant of an arched doorway. The west gable has a doorway with double doors, an ogee hood with crockets and finial, carved tympanum, and carved head stops. Three statue niches above the doorway on carved bases, canted canopies with attached finials and pinnacles containing statues by Ernest Pascoe dating to the mid-twentieth century. On the gable there is a square bellcote with angle buttresses and a weathered ogee cap and finial. Inside are canopied niches either side at the east end, and a Royal Arms above the entrance. C19 half panelling and pews.  In 1939 the decorative parapet was replaced by one of a simpler design, the belfry also (Notes by Philip Street).
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/11/75).

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Cathedral of the Holy and Undivided Trinity, College Green
MONUMENT_DESC: The Elder Lady Chapel of St. Augustine's Abbey, now Bristol Cathedral. The chapel is located between the north choir aisle and the north transept. The east parapet is angled up against the choir aisle wall.

KNOWN_AS: Old Pelican, No.87 Old Market Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Old Pelican public house, No.87 Old Market Street. The building was located on the southern side of Old Market Street, on the east side of its junction with Church Lane. It was probably constructed in the seventeenth century was a three-storey, single-bay house with a pantiled gabled roof. It had a shopfront at ground floor, with the main entrance on the west side. It had a bay window at first floor level and a three-light attic window.
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being The Pelican, occupied by Edward Mance and by John Hitchcock, confectioner.
The building was demolished in the 1960s to make way for the Old Market underpass.

The Empire Theatre, located on the north side of Old Market Street, and with a frontage on Carey's Lane. A company was formed by Charles W. Poole to construct a new music hall. A site on Old Market Street was chosen. The building was designed by the architects Wylson and Long . Construction started in March 1892 and the theatre opened on 6 November 1893 (Sachs & Woodrow 1896, 46). In 1897 the Empire became one of the first theatres in Bristol to show moving pictures. These were limited runs of shows within the normal music hall nightly programme. Between 1931 and 1939 the building became the Empire Cinema (Anderson 1983, 8). The theatre later became the BBC Theatre. It was demolished in the 1963 to make way for the Old Market Underpass.

Warehouse, Commercial Road. On the river side of Temple Back, latterly occupied by Stotesbury Tubes and Fittings. 19th.century date. Two storeys, four bays. The building was wider at its south-east end. Large doorway in ground-floor at north-west end. Smaller doorways at south-east end of north-east wall on both storeys. Three windows to first-floor. Access to building to south (No.21) at south-east end of both floors. Three iron columns supported first-floor. Stairs in north corner. Ground-floor had stone floor containing setts, channells, flags and millstones. There was possibly a hatch in the west corner. Timber first-floor. Small posts up to roof trusses. Possibly former windows in north-west end wall at this level.

The 'Saracen's Head' inn at Temple Gate. The structure was of two-storeys, apparently of rendered stone rubble, and was one of the hostelries confirmed and authorised in 1606. The building was demolished about 1883 and large wrought-iron lamp bracket from the building [1009A] was saved, and presented to the city in c.1908.
The site had been redeveloped for Messrs. Mardon's factory by 1908.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: City Museum and Art Gallery, Queens Road
MONUMENT_DESC: The Museum lecture theatre, on University Road. Constructed to the rear of the then Museum on Queens Road, in 1874 to a design by Samuel Colman. An almost blank wall, ashlar with brick panels above, to the street, with very tall and narrow lancet windows. An entrance under a saddle-back roof. Cellars beneath. Gutted in c.1983 for conversion to carpenters' workshops and design studio, with a detailed photographic record made at the time.

The Meat Market, located on the eastern side of Union Street, and contemporary with it. The market opened on 1 May 1776. The roof was similar to a northlight roof, but probably with vents in the vertical faces. The market continued in use until 1913, when it was demolished and the site redeveloped for shops.
According to John Pritchard the canopy frontage "was removed by the purchaser to his residence on Durdham Down, and may now be seen in the garden there" (Pritchard 1920, 127).

No.58 Victoria Street Beside the lane leading to Temple Church. Late 19th.century. Brick with ashlar dressings. Slate roof behind a decorative gable. Double-depth plan. Two storeys. Triple window at first-floor over 20th.century shopfront. Four pairs of square-headed windows to ground-floor of side elevation; round-headed windows above (three pairs and a single). Three similar windows to first-floor rear; doorway to left at ground-floor. Two stacks on side elevation.

The King's Head. The King's Head. Mid-17th.century. Rendered with brick eaves stacks and a hipped pantile roof. Double-depth plan. 3 storeys and cellar; 1-window range. C19 public house front with left-hand door and sash windows. Period public house interior (late 19th.century) retained. A date of 1660 painted on the front.

No.62 Victoria Street. Early 19th.century, restored 1981. Brick with ashlar voussoirs and pantile hipped roof. Double-depth plan. Ran behind No.64. 3 storeys; 1-window range. 20th.century bowed shop front. Parapet. Rebuilt behind the facade in 1981. During restoration it was noted that one timber frame spanned both this and No.64. Tin-glazed earthenware fire-back tiles from the late 18th.century were found during restoration work.

No.64 Victoria Street. 17th.century, restored 1981. Three storeys; 1-bay range. Part of the rear of No.62 ran behind this building. Timber-framed with roughcast panels, brick eaves stack and pantile roof. Double-depth plan with gable to street. First-floor jettied. 20th.century shopfront. Completely rebuilt behind the frontage in 1981. During restoration it was noted that one timber frame spanned both this and No.62.
No.3 King Street, forming part of the public house known as the Llandoger Trow. It was part of a terrace of five houses built in c.1665. Timber-framed front; gabled front and rear.

No.66 Victoria Street. Early 19th.century. Brick fronts and Pennant rubble side, ashlar voussoirs and a pantile hipped roof. Double-depth plan. 3 storeys; 1-window range. 20th.century shop front. Parapet. Completely rebuilt behind the frontage in 1981.

Granary, located on Welsh Back. The building is a seven-storey granary and was constructed between 1869 and 1871 for Wait and James to a design by the Bristol architectural practice of Ponton and Gough. The building is in the "Bristol Byzantine" style with patterned brick elevations, using local Cattybrook bricks (Crick 1975, 40-41; Gomme et al 1979, 375-377; Lord & Southam 1983, 90-94). According to The Builder (3 June 1871) the lifts were incorporated into the corners of the building, the openings in internal niches, and the grain sacks were placed "into carts upon moveable skids, sliding out of the round holes under the first floor string course" (quoted in Crick 1975, 41).
The building was surveyed by the Royal Commission on Historical Monuments (England) in 1988 (BUAD 902; Anon. 1989 32).
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/16/341).

POSTAL_ADDRESS: The Old School House, Wilson Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Old School House, located off the north side of Wilson Street. The building was constructed c1830, but was altered and dated 1859 (1851?); converted 1992. Pennant Sandstone rubble with limestone dressings. L-shaped plan. Two storeys; 4-window range, with 2-storey left-hand projecting wing at south side, and similar, containing open-well staircase, at east end of north side.  Relieving arches to openings with ashlar surrounds. Most windows were removed or blocked, but some noted with 28+28 sashes. Ground-floor Venetian window in south wall of south-west wing; first-floor example at west end of main block. The right return has pediment lintels to outer doorways inscribed BOYS and GIRLS to the left and right, and a triple semicircular-arched window between dated 1851. The interior was completely rebuilt in 1992.
A shallow slate hipped roof to the main block and north-east wing; a gabled slate roof to the south-west wing.

No.8, Victoria Street. A shop built in the early 1870s. Red brick with yellow brick and limestone dressings. Double-depth plan. 4 storeys; 3-window range. Venetian Gothic style. 20th.century shop front; first- and second-floor arcade of pointed arches with patterned voussoirs; first-floor windows have shoulder arches and a moulded lintel, beneath a yellow brick patterned panel, second-floor windows are arched casements; an angled brick string below the third-floor arcade of 6 shoulder arches, with flanking pilasters and a worn ashlar parapet. Rear elevation of rubble, 4 storeys, 3 bays to right of centre. A gabled roof to the front part of the property, with a hipped rear block. Part of a group of Victorian commercial buildings developed after Victoria Street was constructed.

No.17 Peter Street. The structure was a three-storey jettied building on the north side of Peter Street. It had a hipped pantiled roof and a large chimney stack projected from its east side. The frontage had been replaced during the late eighteenth- or early nineteenth-century and the ground floor comprised a shopfront with an entrance on the west side. There was a bay window containing sashes at the first floor and a further sash at the second floor. The new facade appeared to form a parapet around the roof. It was apparently built as a part of the same development as the adjacent building, No.16 which stood on its east side.

The access manhole pillar at Quay Head. The cast iron pillar was erected during the culverting, in 1892-93, of the river Frome between Stone Bridge and St. Augustine's Bridge. A single door in the north side leads to the  Stone Bridge flood gates [496M] and the entrance to Mylne's Culvert [498M].

No.21 Narrow Wine Street. The building was a nineteenth-century warehouse at the east corner of Narrow Wine Street and Church Lane.
The building was a three-storey warehouse with three bays and a hipped pantile roof. There was a large entrance or haulingway at the east side of the building with a large arched window above. In the centre of the third storey of the Narrow Wine Street frontage was an arched doorway with a bar across, probably used for winching goods into the building.
The building was destroyed by bombing in 1940.

St. Augustine's Bridge. The fixed bridge replaced the Drawbridge. It was a single arch span, which was considerably wider than the bridges which preceded it. The stonework was rusticated like that of the dock walls and there were iron railings along the top of the bridge. The bridge has disappeared as a result of the culverting of the Frome, but probably remains largely intact, as the culverts seem to have abutted the bridge.

Franciscan Friary, also known as Greyfriars or the friary of the Friars Minors, sited on the northern side of Lewins Mead. The friary was founded in the thirteenth century on the north-west side of Lewins Mead.
Part of the church, cloister and chapter house were archaeologically excavated by M. W. Ponsford in 1973, and other parts recorded then or earlier.

Pithay Bridge, crossing the Frome outside the Pithay Gate. The bridge was in existence, known as Aylward's Bridge, in 1285 (Veale 1931, 164). It was noted by the antiquarian Samuel Seyer as having buildings each side in 1823, and shown as such by Millerd's 1673 map.
Baldwin's Cross, noted by Seyer as having stood close to the mill. Details and exact location not known.

Castle Mill. North of the bottom end of Castle Mill Street. The watermill was medieval in origin and drew its water supply from the Castle Ditch at Broad Weir. Samuel Seyer noted the "ancient" Castle Mill "which still remains" in 1821.

St. Stephen's Churchyard, located on the south side of St. Stephen's Church (BUAD 148M) and was probably established with the church in the fourteenth century. The original extent of the churchyard is uncertain but it may well have included the area to the north of the church.
The churchyard was closed to burials by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852.
Spicer's Almshouse, located on the west side of Temple Street, a little north of Portwall Lane. The site was archaeologically excavated by Bruce Williams in 1975 (BUAD 443; Williams 1988).

KNOWN_AS: House on the west side of Adams Court, Hepburn Road
MONUMENT_DESC: House on the west side of Adams Court, Hepburn Road, Stokes Croft. The date of construction of the building is not currently known but it was in existence by the early 1740s and was recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 plan of Bristol. It was orientated parallel to Stokes Croft and measured approximately 17 metres from north to south and was 11 metres wide. The building appears to have been demolished and the site redeveloped by the early nineteenth century.
No.39, King Street, locatedon the north side of the street.

Queen Street Bridge. The bridge was possibly medieval in date. It crossed the castle moat towards the area known as the 'King's Orchard'. It was a single span with a pointed arch. The bridge is extant.

KNOWN_AS: Warburton & Sons Confectionery Factory, Redcross Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Warburton & Sons Confectionery Factory, located on the south side of Redcross Street. The building was in existence by 1828 and was owned by the Baynton family. The building was of three storeys. C. Warburton & Sons confectionery factory occupied the building from 1886 and the Goad fire insurance plan of 1896 indicates that the site then comprised a "Coach House, Offices & Store House over." At the rear, against the western boundary of the land parcel was a bake house. Much of the building was demolished in 1909 to enable construction of a new warehouse (BUAD 1543M), although the party walls and the internal walls were incorporated into the new structure.

Warehouse, No.13 Redcross Street, located on the south side of Redcross Street. The building was constructed in 1909 to a design by the architects W. V. Gough and A. R. Gough. It is a three-storey structure with a double pile plan and pitched pantile roofs with a central valley. The main, north-facing, elevation is of brick and has five bays. The ground floor has arched entrance openings at either end, that at the eastern end being double width with entrance into the building. The fenestration of the upper floors comprised metal windows in large arched openings. The rear elevation is of similar design and construction although the side walls are of stone rubble bonded in a lime mortar, and appear to have been elements of earlier structures (BUAD 1542M) incorporated into the new warehouse.Internally the warehouse is a single space at each storey, with the wooden floors supported on moulded cast iron columns. The roof structure comprises two pairs of braced king post roof trusses.
By the mid-twentieth century the building was occupied by the Central Shopfitting Company Ltd. and was a saw mill and cabinet factory.
Almshouse, located on the south side of Redcross Street.
No.39 High Street. The building was constructed as a house in the medieval period and from 1467 appears, together with No.40 High Street, to have formed part of The Rose inn (Leech, 1997 80).

KNOWN_AS: Spirit of Bristol, St. James Barton
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Spirit of Bristol, located at the north-east corner of St. James Barton (Merritt 2002, 114). The sculpture was commissioned by Copthall Holdings as part of the development of York House. It was designed by the artist Paul Mount (1922-) who had trained at the Royal College of Art and worked in Lagos between 1955 and 1962. The sculpture was fabricated between 1968 and 1969 in his studio at Nancherrow, St. Just-in-Penwith near Penzance in Cornwall with the assistance of the local blacksmith, Jim Williams. No brief was given, only a plan of the site, and the finished work cost £6000. The sculpture is a stainless steel structure with a mild steel armature set on a large rectangular area of landscaping of black engineering bricks. The design comprises six triangular aerodynamic forms with straight and parabolic edges linked together. Mount said that the design was "derived from a combination of sail shapes and equestrian forms." A scale model was tested in a wind tunnel by Professor Joseph Black of the School of Engineering, University of Bath. Black had performed the wind tunnel tests on Concorde and Mount was guided on the finishing of the metal surfaces by Amos Underhill of Coventry who had polished the prototype turbine blades for the Concorde engines.
Mount erected the sculpture on the site in the summer of 1971 with the assistance from Christine Feiler. There was no unveiling ceremony.

KNOWN_AS: Houses on corner of Temple Street
MONUMENT_DESC: A pair of houses.
