On the south-east corner of [the original] Counterslip and Temple Street, facing the former. 3 storeys; gabled fronts to Counterslip, no attic storey; first and second floors jettied; 3 brackets below first-floor, 2 below second. Casement windows to first and second floors. One purlin to east side of each roof.

Queen Street Ferry slipway. The Temple Back slipway for the Queen Street Ferry. Paved slipway with stone side walls. Wooden barriers near top of incline. A single-storey building adjacent to south may have been associated.

House. On the west side of Temple Back, immediately south of a pottery manufactory for 'Ponty Pool ware'. Attached; 2 storeys and attic; gabled front. Round-headed doorway to right; sash window; pentice roof above ground-floor front. One bay each to first and second floors, each 8-light mullion and transom with 2-light ends. The stone stack on the north side may belong to this or the adjacent building.

KNOWN_AS: The Welsh Market, or Goose Market
MONUMENT_DESC: The "Welsh Market" or "Goose Market" located on Welsh Back between the street and the harbour, south of the line of King Street. The market was an open-sided building of three bays square, four rows of four columns each, with capitals. Hipped roof with flat top, surmounted by a hexagonal or octagonal turret, each side with an oculus, with cupola. Room partitioned off in south-west corner, served by brick chimney on roof.
No.42 Broad Street.

KNOWN_AS: Polygonal Tower south west of Traitor's Bridge
MONUMENT_DESC: A polygonal tower, located adjacent to the River Frome to the south west of Traitor's Bridge (in the area of modern Wellington Road). The building was of two-storeys, with a one-window range towards River Frome on the north-west. The roof was conical, or possibly polygonal. The date of construction is unclear but it is likely to have been built in the eighteenth century. It was recorded in a watercolour drawing by Hugh O'Neill in 1821 (BRSMG 2908) and is also shown by Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 plan of Bristol. The function of the structure is unclear but it may have been a dovecote.

Frome Bridge, also known as Wade's or Wade Street Bridge, or Traitors Bridge, which crossed the River Frome at the north-western end of Wade Street. The bridge was a single span arched bridge of stone, with parapets, and a plaque in the centre of the outside of the downstream parapet. Jean Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol shows a cutwater on each side. The vehicular surface of the bridge was cambered. There was a wall beside river to west, and pollarded trees on opposite bank.

Ames, Wright & Clayfield's Sugar House, located between Stone Bridge and Host Street.
The drawings [what drawings would those be John?] show a massive building of perhaps 7 storeys, of which 5 and an attic storey are depicted. The south-east elevation a 7 or 9-window range, the attic wall gabled at each end, but otherwise horizontal, hiding the gables behind. South-west elevation capped by a large chimney or hoist-housing, the main wall a 5-window(?) range with some blank bays.
The surgar house was occupied by Ames, Wright & Clayfield in 1824 (Braikenridge notes, D.41).

The High Dial, a sundial located near the southern end of Broad Quay. The Dial was set in a square head with a ball finial. This was set on a Tuscan column fixed on an octagonal base. The Dial had been erected by the beginning of the eighteenth century and is recorded on James Millerd's map of Bristol of c1715. It survived into the mid-nineteenth century. The Dial Slip, located to the south,. took its name from the sundial.
The Dial Slip, a slipway located on the east side of Broad Quay. Immediately south of the High Dial (BUAD 743M), after which it was named (Braikenridge Notes, D40). Parts may survive below ground.

KNOWN_AS: Quay Warden's Office and Engine House
MONUMENT_DESC: Engine house, office and watch house, housed in one building on Broad Quay, a short distance to the south of Dial Slip. An octagonal central structure with two small square flanking wings, the former of larger dimensions than the latter two. The central part was the engine house, a domed roof with small central chimney, entrance on east. To the right (north) the Quay Warden's office, flat-roofed, entrance again on the east; to the left, the watch house, flat-roofed with eastern entrance. All 3 entrances with round-arched heads. [The function of the engine house has yet to be established].

Green's Dock Bridge, crossing the entrance to Green's or Tombs's Dock (BUAD 747M) which was located on the western bank of St. Augustine's Reach. The dock was established by the early 1740s, and both it and a drawbridge are recorded by Jean Rocque's map of Bristol of 1742, the bridge carrying the street known as The Butts over the dock entrance. The form of the bridge at this date is unknown but by the 1820s it may have been a lifting or removeable bridge. A painting by T. L. Rowbotham made in 1825 (BUAD 1945; BRSMG M2923) records the entrance to the dock and the bridge over the gates which it shows as a wooden, slightly arched, structure wide enough to carry a single waggon. The rail on the west side of the bridge had a wooden screen approximately 2 metres high attached to its outside edge. The deck appears to have been approximately 2 metres to 3 metres wide but there is no indication of the lifting mechanism.
The dock survived until 1883 when it was bought by the City Corporation and filled in. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.4), however, indicates that the gates and footbridge survived for a short time after the infilling was complete and notes that it was then a swing bridge. The deck was just over 3 metres wide.
Rowe's leadworks [BUAD 1199M] was developed on the site of the dock in 1884.

No.7 Dolphin Street. Attached. 3 storeys and double attic storey; gabled front; jettied first-floor; 2-window range. Left-hand entrances, with post below corner of first-floor; shop windows to left and right of a central entrance. Sashes to first and second floors. String courses above first and second floors. Two 6-pane attic windows, with, in the centre and at higher level, a 6-light oriel. Two purlins to each side of the roof.

No.11 Broad Street. The building was a jettied house of four storeys and was probably constructed in the seventeenth century.
Flat roof; first-floor jettied. Bays to first, second and third floors, first two with a cornice, the uppermost with a cornice common to No.11. Ipswich window to third floor; 10/10 sashes to others, 2/2 at sides.

No.12 Broad Street. The building was a house of four storeys and was probably constructed in the seventeenth century.
Flat roof; first-floor possibly jettied. Bays to first, second and third floors, first two with a cornice, the uppermost with a cornice common to No.10. Pair of 6/6 sashes to first-floor; Ipswich windows to second and third floors. Occupied by Pointing in 1826.

No.13 Broad Street. The building was a jettied, gabled house of three storeys and attic. It was probably built in the seventeenth century.
Gabled front; first and second floors jettied. Bay to first-floor, 8-light front, 2-light sides. Similar to second-floor. Bay to attic, 6 lights to front. Occupied by Saunderson in 1826.

No.14 Broad Street. The building was a house of four storeys and was probably constructed in the seventeenth century.
Flat roof?; first-floor possibly jettied. Bays to first, second and third floors, all with a cornice. Sash to first-floor, 10/10 pane with 2/2 pane sides. Upper windows each 6-light front, 2-light sides.

Statue of John Wesley, located on the north side of Broadmead in a courtyard between Broadmead and the New Room (BUAD 256M). The work is an equestrian bronze statue of Wesley set on an ashlar stone plinth and was donated by Edmund Sykes Lamplough (1860-1940), deputy-chairman of Lloyd's of London. It was sculpted by Arthur George Walker R. A. and was cast by the A. B. Burton foundry at Thames Ditton in 1932. The statue was unveiled by a Dr. Wiseman (Merritt 2002, 42-43).
A copy of the statue was given to the Wesley Theological Seminary in Washington D.C. by Lord Arthur Rank.
The statue has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/40/480).

KNOWN_AS: School of Industry for the Blind
MONUMENT_DESC:
The School of Industry for the Blind (also known as the Blind Asylum), Queen's Road. The building was erected in 1839 and was built in a Gothic Revival style. The main building was of stone and had two storeys. The main range, parallel to Queen's Road had at least five bays and there was a square three-storey tower occupying the second bay from the north. There were crenellations around the top of this and along the  roof. At the north end was a wing projecting forward towards the road which may have contained the chapel. An organ was built for the School by John Smith junior of the Bristol organ builders John Smith and Sons in 1838 (Bristol Mirror, 17 August 1839). There was a large grassed area in front, with a driveway leading from a main gate in front of the chapel block.
The building was used at the end of its life as the Bishop's College and was demolished in the early-twentieth century to make way for the Bristol Art Gallery.

No.20 Peter Street. Attached. 3 storeys and roof (no attic storey?); gabled to front, with side gable, left, to front lateral stack; jettied; 1-window range. Ground-floor shop, possibly with bay window. Bays to first and second floors, 6-light fronts. No attic window shown by O'Neill; a small one shown by Cashin. A similar building was adjacent to the north-east (i.e.downhill).

The 'Bear and Ragged Staff' public house, located on the south-east side of Little Peter Street, adjacent to the 'Cat and Wheel'. 2 storeys and attic; gabled front; jettied; 1-window range. Right-hand entrance; 2 sashes. Sash to first-floor, also to attic.

Watering place. On the south side of that portion of the River Frome serving the Castle Mill. At the bottom of an incline leading from the end of Ellbroad Street. Animals were prevented from straying too far into the river by a post-and-rail fence. William Worcestre called it "le wateryng-place" or "le wateryng-place vocat le weer".

No.13 Peter Street. Attached. 3 storeys and attic; half-hipped roof to front; 2-window range; possibly jettied, otherwise carved beams between storeys; lateral stack(s). Right-hand entrance, shop window with cellar access below. Two sashes each to first and second floors. A single sash to the attic.

The Sty, a pigsty or piggery, located on the north-east side of Avon Street, immediately south-east of the Wain Brook, the stream leading to Cuckolds Pill. The building is recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 plan of Bristol as two long, parallel buildings either side of a yard and at right-angles to the street.

The Brick Yard, Old Bread Street. The brick yard is recorded on Jean Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol where it is shown as being transected by Old Bread Street. The boundary of the brick yard is not firmly defined and although the map indicates there were two structures on the southern side of the site, fronting on to Cheese Lane (now Avon Street), neither is definitely connected with the brick yard. Consequently the function of the site is not clear, and it may only have been used for drying bricks before firing.

Brick Yard Pool, a clay pit located to the north-east of Avon Street. The clay pit apparently dates to the late-seventeenth or early-eighteenth century. It is recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 map, where it is shown as about 200 metres in length. Its extent was defined by the western side of a lane (modern Barton Road), from the junction with a lane leading to Avon Street (the section later named Kilboar Street) as far north as the line of the later Louisa Street. The pit presumably provided the clay for the brickyard in Old Bread Street (BUAD 978M).
No.13 St. James Parade.

Bristol Bridge (1247). In 1247 a stone bridge was built across the river Avon between Redcliffe and the High Street/Balwin Street junction to replace an earlier - possibly wooden - bridge. The main structure of the bridge was apparently constructed of Pennant sandstone bonded in a red sandy mortar (BUAD 431; Price in Thomas 1979, 29-33) and had four arches supported by three piers. The central pair of arches, as recorded by a drawing of c.1760 from the downstream side of the bridge (Seyer MS, Bristol Reference Library), were higher and wider than the arches at the northern and southern ends. Buttresses extended the full height of each pier and each pier had a cutwater at either end, that on the upstream side of the central pier extended up river to carry the Chapel of the Assumption (BUAD 667M) which arched over the carriageway. In 1480 William Worcestre measured the bridge and reports that it was 75 yards long by 5 yards wide (Neale 2000, 2-3) and cartographic sources suggest that the abutment extended further towards St. Nicholas Church, on the north bank of the river Avon, than does the present bridge (BUAD 305M).
Houses lined both sides of the central carriageway of the bridge by the later fourteenth century (Veale 1938, 117-118) but the presence of domestic accommodation on the bridge may well date to its construction. The form of the medieval houses is not clear but they appear to have comprised a shop at ground floor with tenements above and William Worcestre gives a dimension of 10 yards for the buildings, presumably the width of the frontage (Neale 2000, 76-77). Some of the buildings were cellared (Veale 1938, 117-118), with the cellars presumably being cut into the piers. Worcestre records that there were five "very strong" stone arched cellars on each side of the bridge and a large vault beneath the Chapel of the Assumption. He also notes four cellars at either end of the bridge (Neale 2000, 12-13).
The evidence for the early-modern housing on the bridge is stronger and these houses were timber-framed, were of four storeys and attic, and many had full-width glazing. Most had gabled roofs, but a few were flat-roofed. The houses projected beyond the sides of the stone bridge, the overhang being supported by props. A vignette in the border of Millerd's 1673 map of Bristol appears to show windows in some of the cellars beneath the houses. The antiquarian Samuel Seyer reports that the form of some of the houses on Bristol Bridge comprised a shop with a small room behind at ground floor, the staircase behind the door. At first floor there was a parlour and usually the kitchen. The second and third floors had two bedchambers each and there were then two garrets above. Some had lead platforms (Seyer 1823, 33-43). The function of these platforms is at present (02/11/2001) unknown but contemporary illustrations suggest that their form is comparable to similar platforms on the roofs of Venetian houses. It is not, however, clear on what authority Seyer's description of the buildings rests. A fire on 17 February 1647 destroyed or damaged 24 of the houses on the bridge (Latimer 1900, 216; Toulmin-Smith 1872, 67) and two years later the Bristol Corporation ordered Walter Stephens, draper, to "either pull down or repair the arch hanging over the highway leading over the bridge, which is very dangerous to all people travelling that way" (Latimer 1900, 224). By the eighteenth century the bridge was extremely congested with vehicular traffic and the two outer sides of the bridge sloped towards the middle, adding to the problem (Marcy 1968, 152). When the bridge was replaced in the 1760s the medieval foundations were found to be sound enough to be re-used, and seem to have been encased within the replacement bridge (BUAD 350M). One of the foundations, itself apparently enclosing a timber pile, was noted by William Barrett (BUAD 2590) toward the end of the eighteenth century (Barrett 1789, 77). It is also likely that the remains of the pier bases of the medieval bridge survive in the bed of the Floating Harbour.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: The George Railway Hotel, Temple Gate
MONUMENT_DESC: The George Inn, on the east side of Temple Gate, on the road to Bath. The Inn appears to have been constructed in the later seventeenth century. Jean Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol shows several buildings fronting a yard. The eastern end of the site was redeveloped as The George Railway Hotel in the later nineteenth century and fragments of masonry from the George were incorporated into the western range of the building. This range of the building was demolished at the beginning of the twenty-first century after becoming structurally unstable.

The Pelican Inn, also known as the Phoenix Inn, to the west and south-west of Temple Gate. Rocque's map of 1742 shows the building fronting the street immediately outside Temple Gate, with a central entrance leading to a rear yard. The northern range ran along Portwall Lane for about 200 feet. The site was subsequently used for a paint factory. The site now lies mainly beneath the highway in Temple Gate and is likely to have been disrupted by services.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Waring House Car Park, Redcliff Hill
MONUMENT_DESC:
Redcliff Poor House, or William Canynges Almshouse, located on the west side of Redcliff Hill. Jean Rocque's 1742 plan of Bristol indicates that the almshouse stood parallel to, but was set back a little from, the highway on Redcliff Hill. The almshouse is reputed to have been founded in the early 1440s by William Canynges (Manchee 1831, 56). After the reformation the almshouse appears to have been managed by the vestry of St. Mary Redcliffe and supported using parish funds.
The building was demolished and rebuilt slightly to the west in 1804 by the Bristol docks company as part of the construction of the New Cut "under the powers of their act, and at their own expense" (Manchee 1831, 57-58).

Mill pond serving Trin Mills (BUAD 669M). The mill was constructed by St. Augustine's Abbey at the confluence of the river Avon and the Malago in the late-twelfth century. The pond lay to the south of the mill and was irregular in shape with a large central island. The pond was extant at the time of Jean Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol. It was enlarged at the beginning of the nineteenth century to create Bathurst Basin (BUAD 621M).
The Queens Head Inn. The inn was recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 map lying in an alley running between the east side of Redcliff Street and the south side of Thomas Lane.

No.124 Temple Street. The building was an attached house of three storeys and attic with a gabled, jettied, front. The main entrance was to right, with a winged porch, each side with a pair of trefoil-headed lancet openings beneath a square head, and projecting forward to provide support for the jetty above. Two sash windows with shutters, behind a wooden railing with pyramid-capped posts; bracket at left end. First-floor with much timber-framing evident, all except left-hand panel glazed, and with right return glazed below bracket to second-floor; another bracket at left end. Bay projecting beyond second-floor jetty, transomed, 8 lights to front, 2 to side; some glazing beside bay; bracket at right end. Attic flush with second-floor, but with blocked window. There were two purlins on the south side of roof. The porch is not unlike that of Spicer's Hall. The date of the building is unknown although the brackets of the portch suggest that it may have been of fifteenth-century date, and was refenestrated later.

KNOWN_AS: Twelfth-century House at Buchanan's Wharf, Redcliff Street
MONUMENT_DESC: A stone building, probably a house, constructed in the east side of Redcliff Street in the twelfth-century, associated with a clay floor. The building was recorded during at an excavation at Nos.110-112 Redcliff Street in 1985 (BUAD 540).

KNOWN_AS: College Square or Lower College Green
MONUMENT_DESC:
College Square, previously known as Lower College Green. Millerd's 1673 map shows the area already laid out, with some buildings on each of the four sides. The Green itself has a medieval origin as the lower cloister of St. Augustine's Abbey.
In the mid nineteenth century (BUAD 3790; BRSMG M4342) the space at the centre of College Square was a square grassed area, enclosed by iron railings and with a circular planting bed in the middle. There was a large tree towards the south-west corner of the space and other smaller trees elsewhere within the space. There was also a lamp post immediately outside the railings at the south-west corner.

St. Matthias Park. The park is located on the north side of Redcross Street. In the early 1880s a scheme for the creation of a new road, St. Matthias Park, between Redcross Street and the Broad Weir led the Corporation to compulsorily purchase the burial ground. The Open Spaces Act or 1881, which allowed for closed urban burial grounds to be converted to use as public parks, prompted the city council to consider it as a candidate for "an open space or Play-ground for the inhabitants of that poor and populous neighbourhood" (BRO Sanitary Committee Minutes 15 June 1882). Initially, c.1882, a recreation ground was created in the north-west corner of the existing park, the remaining area being purchased from the Streets Improvement Committee in 1884.
The new park was laid out by Messrs. Parker & Son, with the City's surveyor supervising the work, and was formally opened by the Lord Mayor on 24 June 1886.

Berkeley Square, communal garden laid out by Thomas Paty in 1787. The surrounding buildings were only completed in the early nineteenth century. It was designed to be open on its south east side, now occupied by modern buildings.
The upper stages of the Victorian replica High Cross are now sited at the south-eastern corner of the square (BUAD 40M).

KNOWN_AS: All Saints Almshouse, All Saints Lane
MONUMENT_DESC:
All Saints Almshouse, on the west side of All Saints Lane (BRO P/AS/PL6). The building measured 10.5 metres from east to west by 6.5 north-south.
The site was sold to the Bristol Corporation for £420 in 1740 to allow construction of the Exchange (BRO 00472; Manchee, 1831 308) and the almshouse was moved to a site at St. John's Steep.
Chester's Almshouse located on St. James Back.
St. Jordan's Chapel. The chapel is reported to have been located on College Green and was in existence by the medieval period. It was observed by the antiquary William Camden.
The Park. In the area between Brandon Hill and Park Row, and hence, presumably, Park Street. Shown on Milerd's 1673 map. May have been associated with the Bishops Park (BUAD 951M).

The Little Park. In the area above Park Row/ Upper Church Lane and bounded on the north-west by the later Tyndall's Park. Shown as "ye little Park" by Millerd's 1673 map. The name is preserved in the Park Hill and Park Place street names.
Bridge at Nether Gate. The bridge outside the Nether Gate, crossing the Castle Ditch. Shown on Millerd's 1673 map.

Deanery Road Viaduct. The viaduct was constructed in the late 1860s to carry the new Deanery Road over Brandon Street and College Street. The viaduct is a girder bridge with its eastern abutment against the bridge over Lamb Street and its western on an embankment within retaining walls. The viaduct was described in 1869 as consisting of two outside girders, each over 30 metre long, to which were riveted "transverse girders carrying Mallett's patent buckled plates, which support the roadway; the footways on either side are carried on cast-iron cantilevers fastened to the main girders, and finished with ornamental cornice and balustrade" (Anon. 1869, 941).

Ropewalk located on the north-west side of Back Avon Walk, on either side of the south-east end of Rose Street. Jean Rocque's map of Bristol of 1742 shows both plots to have been provided with rows of trees.

Ferry at St. Mary-le-Port. Jean Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol records a crossing of the River Avon "at St. Mary le Port", prior to construction of Bristol Bridge. Possibly connecting Sir John Hawkins Lane with Worship Street [although the latter is not in the parish of St.Mary-le-Port].

A gallows located at the northern end of St. Michael's Hill (at the western end of modern Cotham Road at the junction with St. Michael's Hill), within the finger of the County of Bristol that extended out into Westbury-on-Trym parish. The site seems to have been used as a place of execution from the medieval period and the gallows is mentioned by William Worcester in his Itinerary of 1480 (Neale 2000, 86-87). The form of the medieval gallows is not known but James Millerd's map of Bristol of c1670 records a twin-post structure with a crossbeam. Jean Rocque's 1742 map records the same structure with the crossbeam additionally supported by angled brackets. It is not clear when the gallows was removed.
15, St. James' Parade

House, with ground-floor shop. No.48 Corn Street. Attached. 3 storeys and attic; gabled front; full-width pentice roofs above fronts of first 3 storeys, and extending to No.49 adjacent; 1-window range. A right-hand entrance; shop window. Bays with 10/10 pane and 2/2 pane sashes. Sash to attic. Single-purlin roof. Lateral stacks on the west side.
Occupied by Lander, engraver & printer, in 1823.

No.7 Peter Street, located on the corner of Peter Street and Church Lane. Two dwellings appear to have stood on the site by 1409. The building was refronted (and possibly rebuilt) in mid-seventeenth-century. The site of the rear part of the building was excavated in 1975 [BUAD 319].

House, with ground-floor shop. No.49 Corn Street. Attached. 3 storeys and attic; gabled front; full-width pentice roofs above fronts of first 3 storeys, extending to Nos.48 & 50 either side; 1-window range. Left-hand entrance; shop window. Bays with 10/10 pane and 2/2 pane sashes; glazing either side of first-floor bay. Casement (?) to attic. Single-purlin roof. Lateral stacks on east wall.
Occupied by French, watch maker, in 1823.

Stokescroft Brewery, located on the south-eastern side of Stokes Croft, to the rear of Nos.40-48 Stokes Croft. The brewery was constructed in the mid-nineteenth century and in the 1860s belonged to Foll and Abbott. It comprised a main building on the southern side of the junction of Stokes Croft and City Road with a malthouse (BUAD 1611M) and store to the south-east on Upper York Street. It was acquired by Harvey and Co. in the 1870s and was still in their ownership in 1882. By 1896, however, the brewery belonged to R. W. Miller and Co. Limited but in 1911 it was taken over by George's and Co. Ltd. along with its forty-eight public houses.

KNOWN_AS: Sunday School, City Road Baptist Church
MONUMENT_DESC: Sunday School of the City Road Baptist Church, located on the south-eastern side of City Road. The Sunday School is attached to the north wall of the church.
Carriageworks, Nos.37-39, Jamaica Street.

No.66, Prince Street, located on the west side of Prince Street. The building was constructed in the early eighteenth century (traditionally c1725), apparently as one of a pair with a house to the north. Gomme et al. (1970, 128) attribute the classical design to James Strahan.
It is a three-bay, three-storey house constructed of rendered brick with rusticated quoins. The centre bay is set forward slightly and contains the six-panel main entrance door in a rusticated opening. Originally there appear to have been single sash windows on either side of the door. A plat band divided ground from the upper floors. All of the fenestration at first- and second-floor level consisted of sashes. On either side of the central bay there were giant fluted Ionic pilasters supporting a segmental pediment with a cartouche. The roof is hidden behind a parapet.
The northern ground-floor bay was removed and replaced with a vehicular entrance door. The building was in poor repair by the end of the 1960s and was restored at the beginning of the 1970s when the interior is reported to have been entirely reconstructed.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/188).

No.32 Prince Street, located on the west side of Prince Street. The plan is recorded in the Kingsweston Book of Drawings (Downes, 1967 28) and the building was constructed in the early eighteenth century in a form slightly different from the original design (R. Leech pers. comm.). By 1887 the building was in use as offices for the Board of Trade. The building was demolished in the 1930s.

No.22 St. Michael's Hill. The building is a house of later seventeenth-century date and is of three storeys and attic with a gabled pantile roof. The building is reported to have been built for William Colston 
The main, south-west facing, elevation is of two-bays with a central entrance doorway.
In the yard to the rear of the building, against the north-west boundary wall, there was a detached kitchen. This was also constructed of lias and bonded in white lime mortar and was orientated south-west to north-east. It measured approximately six metres long by three metres wide.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/11/248).

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Micawber's Ale House, No.24, St. Michael's Hill
MONUMENT_DESC:
No.24 St. Michael's Hill. The building is a house of later seventeenth-century date and is of three storeys and attic with a gabled pantile roof.
Probably in the nineteenth century, the ground floor elevation was replaced with a classical shopfront with fluted ashlar pilasters.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/11/248).
Malt house, New Street. The malt house was located on the east side of New Street and was recorded by the 1883 1st edition Ordnance Survey map. It was out of use, however, by 1896.

No.46, Wade Street, located on the north-eastern side of Wade Street. The building is a three-storey, single-bay house with a pitched pantile roof and was apparently constructed in the earlier-eighteenth century. The exterior is rendered. The main entrance door is on the southern side of the main, south-west facing, elevation. At first- and second-floor levels the fenestration consists of a single wide metal window of twentieth-century date. There is a large rendered chimney stack, probably constructed of stone rubble, projecting above the roof on the southern wall. At the rear of the building there is a smaller chimney stack, possibly serving a kitchen.

No.10, Orchard Street, located on the north-west side of Orchard Street. The building is a three-storey house with a brick front. The lease for the plot was granted in 1718 and the house was presumably built soon afterwards (Ison, 1952 152-156).
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by Alfred Marchant, accountant.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/149).

No.11, Orchard Street, located on the north-western side of Orchard Street. The building is a three-storey house with a brick front. The lease for the plot was granted to Peter Wilkins on 20 February 1718 and the house was presumably built soon afterwards (Ison, 1952 152-156).
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by John Burgess, tailor.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/150).

Chapel, located on the northern side of West Street, Old Market. The chapel was in existence by 1828 and was recorded by the Plumley and Ashmead plan of Bristol of that year and the building was apparently still extant in the mid-1850s. Ashmead's 1874 plan of Bristol, however, suggests that it had been substantially altered or demolished and the site redeveloped by that date.

Stables of the New Gaol, Cumberland Road. The building was constructed between c1855 and c1869 when it was recorded by a plan showing proposed new additions to the gaol (BRO Clerk of the Peace Deposited Plans). The stables is constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble with brick quoins and a pitched pantile roof. The main entrance, a large arched opening with brick facings, is in the south-east facing elevation and above this, in the gable, is a large arched window.

KNOWN_AS: Bristol Gas Company Offices, Colston House, Colston Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Bristol Gas Company Offices, located on the northern side of the junction of Colston Street and Pipe Lane. The building was constructed in 1904. In 1935 the company commissioned Whinney, Son and Hall to design a new showroom and offices and to refront the building in a Modernist style. The building was renamed Radiant House at this date.

No.17, Alfred Place. A bakery to the rear of No.17 Alfred Place and separated from it by a yard. The structure is a two-storey brick building of early nineteenth-century date, but with a south-east wall of stone rubble. A gabled pantile roof. There is evidence of a large oven in the west corner of the ground-floor (now removed), with access into it from the south-east, and a wide door in the street elevation at first-floor level. The upper floor has been lost at its south-west end, but was probably laid directly on to the oven roof. A tall brick chimney-stack served the oven flue on the street wall.

The Talbot Hotel, located on the southern side of the juncton of Bath Street and Victoria Street. Built in the early 1870s, top two floors lost in the Blitz, but restored 1992. Red brick with yellow brick and limestone dressings. Double-depth plan. Originally had a heavy cornice that included the top storey.
2 storeys; 12-window range. Top storeys missing, the lower ones are defined by strings with angled bricks and have yellow brick stripes; ground-floor arcade of arches within 2-centred arches defined by moulded bricks; similar larger doorways to the Bath Street corner and third bay from the right; first-floor windows in alternate groups of 2 and 3 with semicircular arches. 3 bay frontage of Victorian building to Bath Street, then two storeys of former No.3 and three of No.4.
Some original features including staircase and fireplaces; a panelled lift cage. 
Part of a group of commercial buildings developed after Victoria Street was created.

Quakers Bridge. On the lane leading north from Broad Weir to Quakers Friars, crossing the northern River Frome channel. George Weare Braikenridge (Braikenridge Notes 59) that it was rebuilt in stone in 1798, "having been previously of wood". The later bridge was a single span arch of stone construction with a parapet which was probably in brick. The bridge was narrow, and was possibly a footbridge. It appears to have been in use until the 1950s, and elements may still survive below ground.

No.40, Wade Street, located on the north-eastern side of Wade Street. The house was built as part of the development of Great Ann Street and Great George Street between 1700 and 1720. This large development, unusually in Bristol at that time, was intended to provide housing for artisans and craftsmen (R. H. Leech 'The processional city: some issues for historical archaeology' in Tarlow & West (eds.) 1999, 19-34).
The building was completed by 1707 and on 27 July that year was conveyed by Nathaniel Wade to a Mr C. Slade. It appears to have been a single bay, three-storey house, originally with a plan consisting of a single room to each floor, and was constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble (Young 2000).
By 1879 the England family, with a locally-established blacksmith's business, set up a smithy at No.40 Wade Street. The forge was "behind the house through a passage" (quoted in Erskine 2000) and in 1882 the business belonged to J. England. In 1921 the property was sold to a farrier named Roberts who retired in 1931. The Bristol Corporation acquired the site by Compulsory Purchase on 18 December 1936. The building was subsequently demolished, apparently demolished in the mid-1950s.
A school on the east side of Wade Street recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883.

No.21 Charles Street, located on the southern side of Charles Street. The building was a three-storey, single bay house and was in existence by 1780 when it was occupied by a George Hawker (Bryant 2003, 6). The house was still extant in 1913 but it had been demolished by 1949.

No.16 Cherry Lane, located on the northern side of Cherry Lane. The building was in existence by 1757 (Bryant 2003, 5) and is a three-storey, single bay rendered house with a hipped pantile roof. One of the first-floor rooms retains its original panelling (R. H. Leech pers comm.). A structure had been constructed to the rear of the property by the early 1880s.
The building was surveyed by Dr. Roger Leech and Dr. Bernard Herman in the mid-1990s (BUAD 4131).

POSTAL_ADDRESS: St. Michael on the Mount Primary School, Park Lane
MONUMENT_DESC: Rupert House, on the south side of Upper Church Lane, facing Lower Church Lane. This was a stone building of seventeenth-century date which had been terraced into the hillside. It was named, according to one source after Prince Rupert (Winstone 1987). It was apparently renovated in the mid eighteenth-century and again in the nineteenth-century. Perry Road, built in the 1870s is reported to have destroyed the view of the city from the house. The building and the Llan House was turned into a single property in the 1880s when the photographer , William Harvey Barton, resident at Llan House on the north side of Rupert House expanded his business. The buildings seem to have been demolished in the mid-1960s.

No.57 Castle Street. The building was a house of seventeenth century date and was of three storeys and attic. three bays, jettied with a timber-framed gabled front and a pantile roof. The ground floor frontage was a shop front, set forward of the first-floor jetty. At first-floor was a central canted bay, with glazing to the ends on either side of it. At the ends of the second-floor were canted bays, with glazing between. The central third-storey bay was blank by the 1870s. Latterly there was a small dormer window at the northern end of the eastern pitch of the roof. The building was demolished to make way for rebuilding during the second two decades of the twentieth-century.

The Prewett Street glass cone. The cone was demolished above the level of the tops of the annealing arches and incorporated into the Dragonara Hotel as a restaurant in the later 1960s. It currently (25/10/96) retains this function as part of the Hilton National

Fuller's Carriage Works in St. George's Road. The firm was founded in the 1840s and a new works was built on the western side of St. George's Road in 1891. This building was designed by Edward Gabriel in an Arts and Crafts style (Gomme et al 1979, 405-406). It was a four-storey, nine-bay structure with a hexagonal domed tower projecting from the fourth bay from the east. The main roof consisted of a series of parallel gabled roofs, end on to the street.
The building was demolished in the mid twentieth-century although part of the tower does survive.

The culvert over the River Frome which was erected in the 1840s. The arched culvert is built of stone and runs along Rupert Street. It is approximately 8-10 metres wide with a maximum height above water level of 3-4 metres. Parts of the culvert, between Bridewell Street and the multistorey car park, were replaced with reinforced concrete in the early 1970s.

House, with ground-floor shop. Attached. Immediately east of the Lower Arcade. 3 storeys; roof not visible; 1-window range. Refronted C17 gabled house, with remains of a full-width pentice roof above the first-floor. Slightly projecting ground-floor shopfront with left-hand entrance. Bay to first-floor. 2-light casement to second-floor, with string or drip moulding above. Mostly demolished by August 1949 (Street's notes).

Quakers Bridge or Traitor's Bridge. The bridge crossed the southern channel of the river Frome which fed the Castle Mill and Ditch, between the rope walk, to the north, and the lane leading to New Street, to the south. The bridge was built at the beginning of the eighteenth century as part of Nathaniel Wade and Abraham Hook's development at Wade Street. It was constructed of stone and was a single span arch with ramped parapets and short flanking walls. The bridge was rebuilt in 1798.

No.4, Bristol Back (modern Welsh Back). Attched. Three storeys and attic. Gabled front; jettied. Entrances at centre and right; shop windows to remainder. Fine decoration to the remainder of the front, figure brackets, decorative panels and bargeboards. At first-floor, Venetian window to centre, with small square full-storey bays to left and right. Central bay at second-floor, 6 lights to front, 2 each to sides. Similar at attic storey. Pulled down July 1818, when the wainscotting from the first-floor was recovered and offered for sale by Mr.Nash the cooper who resided next door, but there were no purchasers, and it was destroyed.

KNOWN_AS: House on the north side of Little King Street
MONUMENT_DESC: House located on the north side of Little King Street, third house from the Back. Attached. Three storeys and attic. Gabled front. First-floor and attic jettied. Twin sash windows, with shutters, left and centre; twin doorways to right. Full-width pentice roofs over ground and first floors. Single bay to first-floor, transomed, 6 lights to front, 2 to each side. Two bays to second-floor, each transomed, 4 lights to front, 2 to sides. 6-light mullion and transom window to attic, external collar above, joining the single purlins (Winstone 1962, pls.103-104).

No.29 High Street, located on the west side of High Street.  House, with ground-floor shop. Four storeys; 2-window range; roof not visible. Fully jettied. Two large open windows with central entrance, later two pairs of sashes. One column each end of ground-floor. Three sashes to first-floor. Pair of oriels to second-floor, with intermediate glazing. Two oriels to third-floor. Parapet - a line of washing beyond indicates a probable flat roof. Occupied by Llewellin and Simmons, woollen drapers, in 1810. By that time the shop, kept first by Llewellyn's father then himself, was "almost the only one remaining in Bristol of that description without any windows & open entirely to the Street the Goods being exposed on bulks as they are called" (Braikenridge notes, 44). By August 1825 it was let to Ringer, a snuff concern, after being a woollen draper's for nearly a century.

The wooden crane located on Welsh Back, slightly south of the Crow Lane burial ground. The crane is recorded by William Worcestre in 1480 (Neale 2000, 146-147). Its structural elemets were "wholly taken down to be all new made" in August 1634. It is shown as extant on Millerd's 1673 map, where it appears to have a small ridge roof.

No.31 High Street. Attached. Four storeys and attic; jettied; gabled front; 1-window range. Left-hand entrance; bow shopfront to right. Bays to first and second floors; pair of sashes to first-floor, transomed 20-light second-floor window. Oriel to third-floor, transomed, 8 lights. Attic window of 4 or 5 lights with 1 light each side; traceried heads to uper lights. Occupied by Hurley, boot & shoe maker, in 1810 and 1826.

Shops at the north-west corner of Bristol Bridge, adjacent the toll booth. Single storey; three [?] bays to north-east, or front; two bays to north-west elevation, four to south-west; semicircular-headed windows. North end occupied by Bishop, umbrellas and parasols, in 1820s, bridge end by Garratt, tea dealer.

Weighing machine house, located at the north-west corner of the shops adjacent to Bristol Bridge, at the end of Baldwin Street. Detached; single storey. Polygonal, probably octagonal, with conical roof. Semicircular-headed doorway facing end of Baldwin Street; small arch-headed windows in at least next two bays, anticlockwise. Drawn by Delamotte in 1824, Rowbotham in 1826. Noted by Braikenridge in 1824 as being erected "a very few years ago" (Braikenridge Notes, D89).

KNOWN_AS: Nether Pithay Gate or Aylward's Gate
MONUMENT_DESC: Nether Pithay Gate, or Aylward's Gate, was located at the bottom of the Pithay. The gate was built in the medieval period and was part of the second town wall It was 4 yards long according to William Worcestre, writing in the 1480s (Neale 2000, 206-207). The gate was still extant in the mid-eighteenth century and was recorded as a landmark by the church wardens during their perambulation of St. James parish in 1751 (BRO P/StJ/ChW/6). The gate was subsequently demolished.

Calvary cross and drinking fountain in the centre of the east half of St. James's Churchyard. The fountain is dated 1885 and has a Pennant Sandstone base, a limestone ashlar plinth and cross, with a red granite basin. It has an octagonal stepped base with a square plinth supporting an octagonal shaft. There is a curved basin in the south side set one step down from the top, with a bronze tap above. The top of the cross has been toppled.

Ropewalk located on the northern edge of Canons Marsh, and orientated approximately east-west. The ropewalk is recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 map which shows it planted with rows of trees. The ropewalk measured 1200 feet long by 120 feet wide at its maximum extent (365 metres by 36.5 metres), but it narrowed considerably towards its western end. Drainage ditches ran along most of its long sides.

KNOWN_AS: Dock at south end of St. Augustine's Reach
MONUMENT_DESC: A feature, probably a dock, located at the southern end of the western bank of the Frome at St. Augustine's Reach. The feature was roughly rectangular in shape, and lay at right-angles to the river. Jean Rocque's 1742 map shows it to have measured approximately 235 feet by 65 feet (70 metres by 20 metres).

KNOWN_AS: Scolis Judeorum or Synagogue, Wine Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Scolis Judeorum or synagogue, located on the northern side of Wine Street. The date at which the synagogue was established is unknown but it presumably dated to at least the period of the Ordinances of the Jews in 1194 when a number of urban centres, including Bristol, were designated as the places where business transactions by the Jewish community had be formally recorded. The site was owned by the Crown and when the synagogue went out of use after the expulsion of the Jews from England in 1290, the building was rented to the Bristol Corporation. The site was finally purchased by the Corporation only in 1462 (Leech 1999, 7).

The New Market, located on either side of an alley known as Newmarket Passage which ran off the east side of Broad Street, north-east towards Tower Lane. The market was founded in 1598 (as a provision of the will of alderman Robert Kitchen), as a shambles or meat market for the use of butchers from outside the city. Jean Rocque's 1742 plan of Bristol shows two buildings, one each side of the alley.
Nwemarket Passage was substantially widened when the Grand Hotel was constructed in the second half of the 1860s and any structures associated with the market were probably demolished at that time.
The Post House, a post office located on the east side of Small Street, occupying part of the complex known as 'Colston's House'. The post office was recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 plan of Bristol.

KNOWN_AS: St. Nicholas Church Yard, The Rackhay
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Nicholas Church Yard, Rackhay, located on the west side of Queen Charlotte Street. The cemetery was the second extension burial ground for St. Nicholas parish (that at Crow Lane (BUAD 43M) on the opposite side of Queen Charlotte Street was the first) and was located on the north side of The Rackhay. It was apparently established in the late seventeenth century and Jean Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol records the cemetery as D-shaped, measuring 50 feet (north-south) by 35 feet. It was later extended to the west and Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 map records it as measuring 94 feet east to west and 70 feet north-south. In his survey of the sanitary condition of Bristol, Clark noted that the surface of the burial-ground was several feet above the ambient ground-level (Clark 1850, 66). He also recorded that the surface area of the cemetery was 415 square yards and that it was, by then, full (Clark 1850, 158). The churchyard was closed to burials by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852. Subsequently St. Nicholas's School was built on the site.
In 1999 (BUAD 3522) the excavation of a gas main approximately 1 metre deep through the cemetery disturbed human remains, including one cranium with a large rectangular puncture wound suggesting that the individual died as the result of a violent attack.
Lucas Hall, Marsh Street
Merchant Venturer's Garden, Marsh Street
Pillbox, located on the northern side of the junction of Woodland Road with St. Michael's Park.

KNOWN_AS: Tower at the south end of Broad Quay
MONUMENT_DESC: Tower located at the south end of Broad Quay. The tower was an angle tower on the town wall known as the Marsh Wall and lay at the south end of Broad Quay. It is recorded by William Worcestre
Latrine located on the south-west side of Bristol Bridge. The latrine was mentioned by William Worcestre in 1480 and was apparently excavated in 1981 (BUAD 341).
A pillory in Temple Street. The pillory was in existence by the mid-thirteenth century (Chadwyck-Healey 1897, 239).
Lard Refinery, Lamb Street. The works was located on the north side of Lamb Street and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883. The works was out of use by 1896.

Bush Inn Stables, located on the west side of Dolphin Street. The stables served the 'Bush Inn' in Corn Street. Attached. 2 storeys, upper jettied; ridge roof parallel to street. Right-hand wide entrance, with brackets to jetty, loft access to right of centre on first-floor. Some windows. Were ruinous when drawn in 1820, and were "now nearly pulled down" in June 1821 (Braikenridge Notes 57).
Royal Tennis court at Newgate Prison. The court is mentioned by George Weare Braikenridge (Braikenridge Notes 79) in his notes on the 1821 drawing by O'Neill of the front of the governor's house.

No.36 Narrow Wine Street. Attached to west. 2 storeys and attic; gabled front; first-floor jettied; 1-window range. Ground and first floor windows to the left return, i.e.Church Lane. Right-hand entrance; open shopfront. 10-light first-floor window; sash to attic. 
O'Neill's 1820 drawing shows the building as occupied by one Stroud, who was listed at No.18 in the directories. The property is later listed as No.36. Now largely below the modern Newgate.
No.42 High Street. The present building has a hipped roof.

No.44 High Street. The house is of fifteenth- or sixteenth-century date. It was refronted in the eighteenth century and again in 1907. The cellar has a timber roof with the floor joists tenoned into the principal cross beams.
No.47 High Street. The present roof is gabled, the ridge parallel to the street.

The Redcliff Wharf glass house. The glass house was extant by 1700 when it was owned by Thomas Ewens who seems to have retained it until 1717. It is shown by Millerd's map of c.1715 which indicates that the glasshouse then consisted of two small rectangular buildings. It was then acquired by a Captain Wheeler, who ran it until 1723, and then by John Jones who held it until his death in 1740. His widow sold the works to Crosse and Berrow in 1750 and it was acquired by Little and Longman in 1761. Robert Vigor joined the business in 1767 and by 1775 it had become Vigor, Stevens and Hill. In 1802 the company amalgamated with Wadham Ricketts and Co. and documentary evidence indicates that in the early nineteenth century the works was producing glass bottles, some of which were being shipped to New York; a Braikenridge illustration of the 1820s shows the glass furnace with a wooden superstructure. The glasshouse appears to have closed down in the later 1820s.
A single archaeological evaluation trench dug in 1989 (BUAD 446) found possible evidence of the glass works, including several stone walls as well as a brick floor covered with a blue, glassy substance. Some disturbance to the deposits was noted. The extent of the monument is currently unknown.

The watch box at the corner of Milk Street and Old King Street. The box was square and had a doorway at the street intersection. There were large windows to each street elevation and the box had a flat roof behind a low parapet. The box was rendered.
In 1912 the watch box was demolished for road widening; its site is now beneath Horsefair at its junction with Merchant Street.

No.2 Broad Street. The building was a jettied, gabled house of three storeys and attic and was probably built in the seventeenth century. There were bays at first and second floors each containing sash windows. There was a two-light casement in the attic gable.

No.6 Broad Street. The building was a jettied, gabled house of four storeys and was probably constructed in the seventeenth century.
There was no attic storey; gabled front; first-floor jettied. Bays to first, second and third floors, each with cornice. Sashes to first-floor, 6-light fronts & 2-light sides to others.

No.25 Narrow Wine Street. On the corner of Narrow Wine Street and Little Peter Street. 3 storeys and attic; 1 bay to north, 2 to east; gabled to Narrow Wine Street, or north; jettied first-floors, with angled corner bracket; attached to the west and south; 2-window range on east side. Cellar flaps to Narrow Wine Street, beneath sill of ground-floor window. Decorative panels to the first-floor of both elevations (but not shown by every drawing), appearing to have been painted rather than timber-framed (see Rowbotham's 1826 illustration, M.2721). On the east side, 6-light window to left, sash to right; 2 windows to second-floor, the right-hand a 3-light. To the north elevation, a 6-light first-floor window, 1 window to the second-floor, another to attic storey. Central stack, broaching the ridge halfway down. The drawings show a sign on the corner, 'Hamilton Day & Evening School'.
Malthouse, Lamb Street. The malt house was located on the southern side of Lamb Street and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883. The building was out of use by 1896.

KNOWN_AS: Bastion behind the George Inn, Narrow Wine Street
MONUMENT_DESC: A bastion at the rear of The George Inn in Narrow Wine Street. The semi-circular bastion (BUAD 182A) was an element of the second town wall, projecting to the River Frome. The structure was still extant in the early-nineteenth century, and was noted to be "still almost perfect" by the antiquarian Samuel Seyer in 1821, who also commented that the "brass workshop of Mr W[asborough] is built upon it" (Seyer 1821, 269).

The Red Lion Inn, located on the southern side of a narrow lane off the east side of Redcliff Street, close to the junction with St. Thomas Street. 3 storeys, and (possibly) 5 bays. Roof appears hipped. A galleried elevation to the yard at first and second floor levels. Attached at least to the north-west and south-west. A small 2-storey block attached to the south-east end.

No.7, Redcliff Street. The building was a gabled house of seventeenth century date which was built across the entrance leading from Redcliff Street to the yard of the 'Red Lion Inn'. O'Neill's 1823 drawing of the inn shows this building in the background, where it appears to have 3 or 4 storeys and an attic storey, all above the haulingway. Lateral stack.

Nos.41 & 42, St. Thomas Street. A pair of houses. Nos.41 (left) and 42, St. Thomas Street. 2 storeys and attic (one with 2 storeys in attic). Attached; 1-window ranges; gabled fronts; jettied. Lateral stacks. Twin-purlin sides to each roof. Entrances at outer ends. To the left-hand house, a bay with 4 sashes to front, full-width pentice roof on 3 brackets. 3 sashes to right-hand house. 3-light first-floor windows, 6-light to attics. In the roofspace of the right-hand building, a 2-light window. Arms or shields either side of the first-floor window at No.41. A barber's pole outside No.41; No.42 in use as 'The George Inn'.
No.125 St. Thomas Street. Attached. 3 storeys and attic; 1-window range; gabled front; jettied. Ground-floor detail unknown. Sash each to first-floor and attic. 6-light window to second-floor.

KNOWN_AS: 2, Cave Street Cottages, No.89 Wilder Street
MONUMENT_DESC: No.2, Cave Street Cottages, No.89 Wilder Street, located on the northern side of Wilder Street. The building was in existence by 1828 and was constructed as the eastern of a pair with No.87 Wilder Street (BUAD 1495M). The building was a two-storey, single bay house. By 1883 it had been incorporated into a larger industrial building constructed to the rear. No.2 Cave Street Cottages appears to have survived as part of this structure until at least 1950 but was subsequently demolished.

Ropewalk located on the northern side of Wilder Street. The ropewalk was recorded by Jean Rocque's plan of Bristol of 1742 as an avenue of parallel trees. It was orientated from south-west to north-east and measured 385 metres long by 14 metres wide. There appears to have been a building at the south-west end. The ropewalk was out of use and parts had been developed for housing by 1828, although the enclosure was still largely identifiable.

Cut Nail Factory, occupying the block between Backfields and Wilder Street. The factory was constructed in the mid-nineteenth century and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan surveyed in 1883. The factory was still operating in the early-twentieth century but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped.

Bath House located on the southern side of Gorse Lane. The bath house was of eighteenth century date and was a cold bath associated with Clifton Hill House. It was of ashlar stone blocks with tongue and mortices. A lead drain hole in the centre of the north wall carried water away into the drainage system on Jacob's Wells Road.
The bath house was recorded during field evaluation of the site by Avon Archaeological Unit (BUAD 3707) and was subsequently archaeologically excavated (BUAD 3990).

Portwall Lane glasshouse, located on the northern side of Portwall Lane. The glassworks was in existence by 1715 when it was occupied by Benjamin Perrott. It subsequently passed into the ownership of Robert Vigor and Co and was occupied in the mid 1780s by Stevens and Co. It originally had only one glass cone, later the "Old" glasshouse, but by 1785 a second glass cone, the "New" glasshouse, had been built (Bryant 2001). The business went bankrupt in 1798.
The glasshouse was subject to archaeological field evaluation in 2002 (BUAD 3844; Townsend 2002) and was excavated in 2006 (BUAD 4371; Williams & Jackson 2006). The foundations of the new office building were designed to retain the glassworks in situ.

KNOWN_AS: Drill Hall, No.57 Old Market Street
POSTAL_ADDRESS: Drill Hall, No.57 Old Market Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
Drill Hall, located to the rear of No.57 Old Market Street.
The building was surveyed in 2006 (BUAD 4300; Morriss 2006).

Cellar. The so-called 'Crypt of St. Leonard'. Almost certainly a merchant's cellar, being, at the front, not dissimilar to that at the present No.35 Corn Street (BUAD 109M). Beneath the east corner of Corn Street and St. Nicholas Street, largely beneath the National Westminster Bank but partly under the western end of the latter street. In May 1827 lay below Lucas's china shop. 
The front portion consisted of a cellar of parallelogram plan with three Y-plan ribs, the top each Y towards Corn Street. In the north wall, at the apex of the eastern Y, was an opening from that street. In the opposite wall were three openings into the, larger, rear portion, each with segmental-arches. The limbs of the second Y met at a decorative boss. Beyond the west end was a rectangular extension.  The floor of the front cellar was raised almost to the springing by 1827. 
The rear cellar was much more plain, was twice the area of the front part, and the same width as it. There were shallow recesses in the east and west walls, also the north wall of the front cellar.

KNOWN_AS: House on the northern side of Baldwin Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
House located on the northern side of Baldwin Street. The building was a jettied, gabled house of three storeys and attic and was of probably constructed in the seventeenth century.
Two gables to front; fully jettied. Shops, the left-hand a chair maker and cane worker, S. Broome (sic). First and second floors each with two bays or oriels, 8-light fronts, 2-light sides. Both storeys with extensive pargetting. Sash to left gable; 6-light mullion and transom window to right gable. Another example of an unusual external roof drainage system. The 1828 directory lists Samuel Brown, chair maker and cane worker. The site of the house now probably lies in St. Stephens Street

No.22 West Street, Old Market. The building is a house of probable seventeenth-century date and is two storeys and attic. The shell walls are of Pennant sandstone in a random rubble construction and the building has a pantile roof. There is a large stone rubble chimneystack in the west wall. The house was refronted during the nineteenth century and the ground floor is occupied by a shop. The interior was largely gutted during the late-twentieth century.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/12/1662).

Tropic Club, No.84 Stokes Croft, located on the east side of Stokes Croft and lying some 20 metres back from the street. The building is a three-storey, three-bay rendered house with limestone ashlar dressings and probably dates to the early-eighteenth century. It measures 11 metres from north to south and is approximately 5 metres wide. It has a pitched pantile roof and a cellar. The building was apparently in existence by 1742 and originally stood at the rear of a large walled garden measuring approximately 20 metres from east to west by 11 metres wide. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.10) surveyed in 1883 shows the design of the formal garden.
In the early nineteenth century the building appears to have undergone significant alteration. Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 plan indicates that the structure had bow windows on the west-facing elevation by that date.  By 1903 the garden had been developed for the bank which now stands on Stokes Croft. Internally the central entrance hall and the front room to the north of this are fully panelled. The hall also has a semicircular hall arch and open-well stairs. The building has been significantly altered and extended and few original internal features now appear to survive. The roof timbers are also modern.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/6/2022).

No.89 Stokes Croft, located on the north-western side of Stoke Croft. The building was a house of two-storeys and attic with a gabled pantile roof. It was probably constructed in the late-seventeenth or early-eighteenth century.
The building was demolished in 1961 (Winstone 1972, pl.129) and the site redeveloped. The building line was set back from the original position, meaning that the eastern part of the house now lies beneath the footway.

Stokes Croft Chapel, located on the northern side of City Road. The chapel was a Christian Brethren meeting house which could accommodate 300 people. It was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.20) surveyed in 1883 and survived into the twentieth century. The building was still extant in 1920 but was subsequently demolished.

The 'Bush Inn', north side of Corn Street. With a ground-floor shop at No.47. 4 storeys; flat roof. At eastern end, cut back at an angle. First, second and third floors with 12/12 pane sashes, separated by square pillars, a continuous Classical frieze above each storey. Bow-fronted shop windows to ground-floor. 
H.Tripp, junior, linen draper & tailor, at No.47 in 1823.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: The Pump House, Cumberland Basin Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Accumulator Tower and Engine House, Junction Lock. The hydraulic engine house was built c.1870 to a design by Thomas Howard. Constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble and with a hipped roof, the two-stage accumulator tower is at the west end. The monument supplied hydraulic power to the machinery of the Floating Harbour. It has been converted into a public house.

KNOWN_AS: Air Raid Shelter, Upper Maudlin Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
A surface air raid shelter of Second World War date which was located on the eastern side of The Seahorse public house, in a small garden in the grounds of the Bristol Royal Infirmary, and was orientated roughly north-east to south-west. The site, part of the site of Nos.4-8 Terrell Street, was requisitioned from the Bristol Royal Infirmary and the Terrill & Foskett Trust on July 1940 for the construction of the air raid shelter. It was released on 30 October 1947 (BRO 37698).
The structure measured 11.4 metres long by 2.3 metres wide (standing 2 metres high) and appears to have been a standard double 50 person capacity shelter with traversed entrances at either end. It was constructed in brick (English Bond) with slightly overhanging flat concrete roof slabs. Small ventilation holes or lights were positioned at approximately 1.5 metre intervals along the longer sides of the shelter. The single width entrance doorway was at the eastern end and the partial demolition of the structure revealed that it was subdivided into (apparently three) modules internally, each with its own entrance doorway.
The development of a new children's hospital on the site led to the demolition of the two eastern bays of the shelter in the autumn of 1997. The remaining western module was demolished in late February 1998.
No plan or elevations of the building, internal or external, were made before demolition although photographs of the structure are held within the archive for an archaeological field evaluation of the site in 1998 (BUAD 3298; Longman, 1998).

KNOWN_AS: The Trout Inn, No.18, Cherry Lane
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Trout Inn, No.18 Cherry Lane, located on the northern side of Cherry Lane. The building was in existence by the 1740s when Israel Trout occupied it and established it as the Trout Tavern. The building was a two-storey, single bay house. The main, south-east facing elevation had a main entrance door with a egmental-arched fanlight above on the western side of the ground floor. The eastern half of the elevation consisted of a bay window which extnded up to the level of the parapet.
The building was still extant in November 1961 although it was vacant at that date. It was subsequently demolished.

No.4 Charles Street, located on the northern side of Charles Street. The building was constructed in the early eighteenth century and is a three-storey, two-bay brick house. Much of the original interior detailing is known to survive at ground floor level. The building was occupied by Charles Wesley between 1749 and 1771.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/5/2020).

No.5 Charles Street, located on the northern side of Charles Street. The building was constructed in the early eighteenth century and is a three-storey, two-bay brick house.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/5/2020).

KNOWN_AS: King Charles Public House, No.1 King Square Avenue
MONUMENT_DESC: King Charles Public House, No.1 King Square Avenue, located on the southern side of the junction of Charles Street and King Square Avenue.

Stables, located on the eastern side of the junction of Barton Street and Charles Street. The building appears to have been constructed in the mid-1760s as an enlargement of an earlier stable associated with No.2 Cherry Lane (BUAD 1474M). It was a two-storey structure and measured 14 metres from south-west to north-east on the Charles Street frontage by 15 metres from north-west to south-east on the Barton Street frontage. The building, described as a "Stable & Coach Houses", had been purchased by Henry Gwyer by 1851 and was then occupied by Isaac Niblett (BRO 04250(1)). By 1896 the building was used for the manufacture of cabinets. It appears to have been damaged by bombing during the Second World War and was combined with a building constructed on the site of the former Nos.2-6 Cherry Lane (Bryant 2003, 7).

No.14 Cherry Lane, located on the northern side of Cherry Lane. The building was a three-storey, single bay house. In 1896 the building was recorded as vacant. The house was still extant in November 1961, although it was again then recorded as vacant. The building was subsequently demolished.

KNOWN_AS: Shute, Arthur and Bush Confectionery Factory, No.85 Wilder Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Shute, Arthur and Bush Confectionery Factory, No.85 Wilder Street. The factory was located on the northern side of Wilder Street. It was established in the late 1870s, being first recorded in the street directory for 1878. The building measured 17.7 metres long on the Wilder Street frontage and 19 metres long on Brunswick Street. In 1895 it passed into the occupation of a "bent timber merchant." The building survived into the twentieth century but it was apparently damaged by bombing during the Second World War and had been demolished by 1950 (Burchill 2003).

KNOWN_AS: Sun Insurance Office Building, Colston Avenue
MONUMENT_DESC: Sun Insurance Office Building, Colston Avenue.
No.41 Broad Street. The building was reconstructed as premises for Elton and Lloyd's bank in the eighteenth-century date.

The Tabernacle Burial Ground, also known as Bunhill Fields, located on the north side of Redcross Street. An Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852 restricted interment to members of the Tabernacle congregation and prohibited burials "within yards of any house." It also ordered that "only one body [was] to be buried in each grave."
The cemetery was purchased by the Bristol Board of Health in 1884 for £250 and was incorporated into a new public park, St. Matthias Park (BUAD 1051M) which opened in 1886.

A stone building, probably a house, located on the west side of Redcliff Street. The building was constructed in the thirteenth-century date and was remodelled later in the Middle Ages, with the removal of one of the walls and the insertion of an internal partition. It was demolished in the post-medieval period and a new structure was built on its site. The building was recorded during at an excavation at Nos.110-112 Redcliff Street in 1985 (BUAD 540).

No.13 Baldwin Street, located on the south side of Baldwin Street, on the outside of the bend. The building was a jettied, gabled house of three storeys.
Front apparently much altered. Entrance to alley on left; window; two (?) doorways on right, with large bracket beyond. Glazing to full width of first-floor, with left end projecting and small window to its left return. All windows mullioned casements with no transoms. Oriel window, 5 lights, to second-floor, top of window flush with eaves. Decorative bargeboards, removed to ornament one gable of Braikenridge's 'Cottage Lodge'. Pantile roof. 
The rear view, from the courtyard, shows a building truncated, with remains of walls and a pile of building timbers. Arch-braced roof truss visible. Pair of rough doors to ground-floor, alley to street on right; large 4-light mullion and transom repositioned window at first-floor, the lights being wider than they are tall, doorway with 9-panel door to right; canted oriel window to second-floor, with 8 lights and transom, and 2 lights to each side. 
A 'water-spout' and 2 fragments of a chimney-piece were drawn by O'Neill (M2293).
Between Husenbeth's Provision Warehouse, to the west, and David Morris's porter cellars, to the east. A sign on the latter gives the number as 15, Baldwin Street, whereas directories give 13. Occupied by S. Bird, Turner in 1821, who is listed at No.13 by the directories.
The building was demolished on 31 July 1823.
Tobacco warehouse located on the western side of Back Street [modern Queen Charlotte Street]. It included a brick cone that was used for incinerating damaged tobacco.

KNOWN_AS: Part of the Back Hall complex
MONUMENT_DESC: A medieval house, part of the Back Hall complex. On the eastern side of the main yard, towards the southern end. East-west block, possibly with an associated wing running south from the western end. Two storeys and attic later in life: may have started off as a first-floor hall. Two-light lancet-headed window at first-floor of west end. Later (?) openings above to attic or roofspace. By early 19th.century had tall thin window in west end on ground-floor, with doorway to right. Rubble walls; pantile roof, with gable to west end, probably also east end.

No.27 Welsh Back, located to the north of the building at the junction with King Street.
Three storeys and attics. Full-width pentice roofs; possibly not jettied. Right-hand doorway, remainder of ground-floor much glazed. Bay windows to all other storeys. Ipswich windows to first-floor, otherwise mullion and transom examples, 8-light fronts at second-floor, 6-light to attic. Gables not full-depth in central gully (i.e. M-shaped roof). Large projecting stone chimneystack in the south wall of the building.

KNOWN_AS: House on the south-western side of Seville Court
MONUMENT_DESC: House on the south-western side of Seville Court. The house was a two-storey structure measuring 4 metres by 2.7 metres wide and was attached to a similar building on its north-west side. It is not clear when the house was constructed but it may be associated with the occupation of No.8 Charles Street by Daniel Sidnell in the mid-1770s, Sidnell Court being one of the earlier names for Seville Court. The building was in existence by 1828 and survived until at least 1957, but was subsequently demolished.

KNOWN_AS: House on the south-western side of Seville Court
MONUMENT_DESC: House on the south-western side of Seville Court. The house was a two-storey structure measuring 4 metres by 2.7 metres wide and was attached to a similar building on its south-east side. It is not clear when the house was constructed but it may be associated with the occupation of No.8 Charles Street by Daniel Sidnell in the mid-1770s, Sidnell Court being one of the earlier names for Seville Court. The building was in existence by 1828 and survived until at least 1957, but was subsequently demolished.

No.8, Charles Street, located on the northern side of Charles Street. It is not currently clear when the house was constructed but it was apparently in existence by the early 1770s and in 1775 the house was occupied by Daniel Sidnell.
No.8 Charles Street was last recorded in street directories in 1938 and it is not clear whether the building was destroyed by the bombing or had been demolished previously.
Iron Foundry, Temple Street.

No.9, Charles Street, located on the northern side of Charles Street. It is not currently clear when the house was constructed but it was apparently in existence by the early 1770s. In 1775 it was occupied by one Davis. In 1820 when Richard Webb and Co., Coach Masters, were based in the building. By 1865 No.9 was known as Caxton House and was occupied by R. & H. J. Stapells, bookbinders and printers. William Eades boot factory operated from Nos.9 and 10 Charles Street by the early 1880s. The building was demolished in c.1900 to make way for a new parish hall for St. James's parish (BUAD 1651M).

No.10, Charles Street, located on the northern side of Charles Street. It is not currently clear when the house was constructed but it was apparently in exstence by the early 1770s. William Eades boot factory operated from Nos.9 and 10 Charles Street by the early 1880s.
The building was demolished in c.1900 to make way for a new parish hall for St. James's parish (BUAD 1651M).

A semi-circular tower or bastion at Tower Lane. The tower was an element of the Norman inner circuit town wall. It was extant in the early-nineteenth century and was observed by the antiquarian Samuel Seyer in 1821. Seyer noted that the tower had been mutilated and incorporated into a house in Tower Lane. A boundary marker for the parishes of Christ Church and St John was attached to the wall of the tower.

No.3 Frog Lane, located on the north-west side of Frog Lane. Probably C17. 2 storeys and attic; gabled at least to rear; rubble construction. The north-east side lay above a passage through to Warren's Court. Removed in the 1930s.

Cabmans shelter located at the northern end of Canons Road. The shelter was of timber construction. Octagonal, with short angles across the corners and longer sides parallel to the harbour. Octagonal roof.

Swing bridge. The fourth and final 'Drawbridge', of 1868, weighing 130 tons. Pivoting at the outward end of the fixed approach from Broad Quay. On the same site as its predecessors, and its successor, St.Augustine's Bridge. Removed in 1892, concluding about 16th.June.

KNOWN_AS: Cross-gable house on the south side of Steep Street
POSTAL_ADDRESS: Bristol County Sports Club, 40 Colston Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
A three-storey cross gable house of probable seventeenth-century date, located on the south side of Steep Street. At ground floor the north-facing elevation contained a bay window, the second floor a sash and the gable end a four-light casement. A single-flue chimney stack projected from gable end. The cross-gable roof was pantiled.
The building was probably demolished during the removal of Steep Street at the end of the 1860s as part of the remodelling of the road pattern in this part of the city.
Ropeseld, an inn located on the north-eastern side of High Street. The inn was in existence by 1309.

Cross, located on the southern side of Old Market Street, just outside the east gate of Bristol Castle. The stone cross was recorded by William Worcestre in the 1480s. Its precise location is unknown.
No.251, Hotwell Road.

KNOWN_AS: T. Griffiths Frome Bridge Leather Works
MONUMENT_DESC: T. Griffiths Frome Bridge Leather Works on the north side of Little George Street.

KNOWN_AS: Francis F. Fox Oil and Colour Works
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Francis F. Fox Oil and Colour Works. The works occupied a site of 4000 square metres on the north side of Little George Street and bounded on its north and west sides by the river Frome and the T. Griffiths leather works.
The site has been redeveloped and the archaeological stratification associated with the monument has to some degree been disturbed. However, of the site are open and in some areas deposit survival may be good.

A smithy recorded on the western side of Lower Lamb Street by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map surveyed in 1883. The building had been demolished by 1953. The site was subsequently redeveloped and the associated archaeological stratification is likely to have suffered some attrition.

Pithay Pump. Beside an alley or passage, beneath the first-floor of a building. Of C18 or C19 date. Against wall; wooden case; handle to right, spout in front; large D-shaped, slightly elevated, stone trough or cistern below spout.

The Midland Inn, at the junction of Midland Road and Willway Street. The public house was a three-storey bull-nose brick building of nineteenth century date with elevations on Midland Road and Horton Street. The main entrance to the building was in the bull-nose. The interior contained Victorian details, including an unusual polished marble balcony and doorcase. The building was demolished without record in 1999.

Llewellin and James Brass Foundry, located on the south side of Castle Green.
