The works was the largest brass foundry in Bristol, employing 100 men, according to Mr. Lewellin, and produced "brass work of all common kinds, as well as for steam engine mountings, hydraulic engineering, bell founding, and copper work, such as making coppers for breweries, sugar boiling, &c" (Children's Employment Commission 1866, 61-62).
Currently little is known about internal organisation of the factory, but part was excavated in 1989 (BUAD 459) and the remains of a furnace, well, walls and floors were recorded. Archaeological stratification associated with other parts of the brass works are likely to survive beneath Castle Park.

Guppy's Sugar House. A sugar house, sited on the north side of Quaker's Friars from 1777. The sugar house was probably built over much of the site of the church of the Dominican friary (Leech & Bryant 2000). It was owned by the Guppy family and operated until 1840.

A stained glass workshop on the south side of Newfoundland Street, between Clark Street and Stratton Street which is recorded by the Goad fire insurance plan of August 1896. The works appears to have been located in a converted dwelling and to have expanded to take in the whole of its rear garden.

KNOWN_AS: Bath and Wash Houses, Clarence Road
POSTAL_ADDRESS: Mayor's Arms Public House, Clarence Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Public Baths and Wash House, Clarence Road. The building was located on the north side of Clarence Road, on the east side of the junction with Mayor Street. The baths are recorded by Ashmead's 1874 survey and the Ordnance Survey first edition plan, Sheet LXXV.4.15 surveyed in 1883. The building were still extant in the mid-1950s but the site had been redeveloped by the mid-1960s.

Bakers' Hall, Quakers Friars. The building was probably constructed as the infirmary of the Dominican Friary [BUAD 238M], c.1227. Pennant Sandstone rubble with limestone dressings and a pantile roof. A first-floor hall plan. Two storeys. In the south wall is half a 15th.century Perpendicular window reset from the north end of the west range of the great cloister. A 14th.century five and a half bay arch-braced collar beam crown-post roof, possibly the oldest roof in Bristol. The ground-floor passage was probably the south walk of the 'lower cloister', the east walk is now covered by the New Hall.
The building became a guild hall for the Bakers in c.1540, and was converted into a house in the eighteenth century, now restored. 
The building is a Scheduled Ancient Monument. (AV 102) and also has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/40/489).

Catholic Apostolic chapel, located on the eastern side of St. Augustine's Reach. The chapel was built between 1839 and 1843 to the design of R. S. Pope. Financial difficulties forced the sale to the Roman Catholic church before completion. Now known as the Church of St. Mary on the Quay. An ashlar front. A central portico of six Corinthian columns supporting a pediment.
The interior has an "elaborately detailed" sanctuary at the west end, north and south transepts, and a 5-bay nave with east gallery.

The Brunswick Chapel, a Congregational chapel located at the west end of the north side of Brunswick Square. The building was constructed in 1834-1835 for seceding members of the Castle Green congregation to a design by the architect William Armstrong, whose offices were at No.7 Brunswick Square.
The main, south-facing, elevation was of three bays with central portico with two pairs of giant Ionic columns. The exterior was rendered; two tiers of windows, the upper round-arched headed; moulded cornice and parapet. Front  Internally there were galleries around three sides, the pulpit being located against the centre of the rear, north, wall. A relativel small organ was installed in the chapel by John Smith junior of the Bristol organ builders John Smith and Sons in 1837.
The chapel was closed in c.1950, and subsequently the building was in commercial use for some time.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/6/1882).

The New Room, located on the southern side of The Horsefair. The building was the first Methodist chapel to be built.
George Whitefield (1714-1770), a recently-ordained Anglican minister who began to evangelise in Bristol in early 1739, had quickly established two meetings of followers based at St. Nicholas Street and Baldwin Street. The New Room was established to support these two groups and the foundation stone of the building was laid on 12 May 1739 (Stell 1986, 68).
The building is a two-storey structure with rendered stone walls, a basement and hipped, pantile roofs. The original entrance to the building was at the north-east corner via a narrow alley, later known as Wesley Court, from Horsefair (Stell 1986, 68). Internally, the ground floor is occupied by the meeting-room which has a roughly rectangular, though irregular, plan measuring approximately 19.3 metres from north to south by 12.9 metres wide. There are galleries on the east and west sides and the pulpit, which has two desks and is enclosed by mahogany rails, stands against the north wall. The seating at ground-level is believed to have consisted of movable wooden benches. A clock (of c.1670 which had been purchased by his father, Samuel, in 1710) was donated by John Wesley and is fixed to the gallery rail of the west gallery. The first floor is supported by six Tuscan columns, forming aisles on either side of the meeting room and the room is lit by a large semi-circular arched windows and in the north and south walls, and other smaller windows together with an octagonal lantern which passes through the first floor rooms. The sides of the lantern contain windows to provide light to those rooms. The largest room on the upper floor is the Conference Room, approximately 9.2 metres long, with the lantern located towards the northern end. There is a row of four rooms on each side of the Conference Room which were used by preachers. John Wesley had the two rooms at the south-west corner, usually visiting the New Room three times each year, while other preachers used the remainder.
In April 1739 Whitefield, planning his second trip to the American colonies, invited John Wesley to Bristol to take over responsibility for the Bristol awakening in his absence. There was a strong theological disagreement between the two men over predestination and election, Whitefield adopting a Calvinistic position while Wesley was inclined towards Arminianism. On his arrival Wesley preached in defence of free will and thereby began to create a split amongst Bristol's Methodists. Despite this Whitefield nevertheless persisted with his intention of entrusting affairs to Wesley and sailed for the Americas in August 1739. Local Calvinist Methodists appealed to the Welsh evangelist Howel Harris (1714-1739) to defend their position. Wesley assured Harris that his views were compatible with those of Whitefield. However, in June 1740 Wesley expelled the advocates of predestination and took control of the New Room and the Kingswood school (Jones 2003, 80-82).
The New Room was altered in 1748. An extension was added to the south end and a new main entrance was created off Broadmead. A single-storey lean-to structure, the Preachers Stable was constructed on the east side of the entrance. It is not currently (26/05/2006) known whether the courtyard to the south of the building was created as part of this work or whether it already existed, although a stone screen separating it from Broadmead was probably built at this time. This was of squared, coursed Lias stone with limestone ashlar dressings and at the centre was an elliptical arch with wrought-iron gates and an urn finial above. The original entrance appears to have been blocked off and a small vestry, the Conference Room, created in the north-east corner of the meeting-room. A small square limestone ashlar panel at first-floor level on the east side of the north elevation of the building which celebrates its foundation John Wesley in 1739 may also have been fixed at this time.
In 1792 the Portland Chapel (BUAD 257M) was opened in Portland Street, Cotham to serve the growing number of Methodists living on the north side of the city and reduced the numbers attending services in the New Room. Two years later the New Room congregation split over the question of ordination as a requirement for the administration of commmunion and a new chapel, the Ebenezer Chapel (BUAD 258M) was established on the western side of Old King Street by those who left the meeting. This further weakened the New Room and in 1808 it was sold to Welsh Calvinistic Methodists.
The Welsh Methodist congregation retained the building until the late 1920s, adding wooden pews. In 1929 the building was purchased by Edmund Sykes Lamplough (1860-1940), deputy-chairman of Lloyd's of London, who then gave it to the Methodist Conference. The building was restored under the supervision of the architect Sir George Oatley. Oatley designed new wooden pews and an organ made by John Snetzler of London in 1761 was purchased in c.1929 from Little Plumstead Church in Norfolk. After refurbishment the organ was installed in the gallery in 1930. An equestrian statue of John Wesley was erected in the Broadmead courtyard on the south side of the building in c.1932 (BUAD 1668M). In 1939 a statue of Charles Wesley (BUAD 1669M) was placed in The Horsefair courtyard on its north side.
The remains of Captain Thomas Webb (c.1720-1796), influential in the establishment of Methodism in North America, and his wife were reinterred in the Broadmead coutyard to the south of the building when the Portland Chapel was closed in 1972.
Investigation of the building has been limited. It was surveyed by A. Barbara Coates of the Royal Commission on the Historical Monuments of England (RCHME) in 1944 (BUAD 956; Stell 1986, 66-68) and was re-examined by Christopher Stell of RCHME in the 1980s (Stell 1986, 66-68).
The building has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/40/481). The screen wall on the Broadmead frontage is listed Grade II (Listed Building number 901-1/40/477). The statues of John Wesley (Listed Building number 901-1/40/480) and Samuel Wesley (Listed Building number 901-1/40/484) are also listed Grade II.

Ferry slipway. The Gaol Ferry. On the north, or right, bank of the New Cut. Two long inclines ran down to a short slipway proper. Replaced by Gaol Ferry Bridge in the mid-1930s. The inclines survive, beneath layers of mud, but the slipway was destroyed by the northern pier of the bridge. The NGR given is for the slipway.

Ebenezer Chapel, a Wesleyan Methodist chapel located on the western side of Old King Street. The chapel was established in 1794-95 by members of the New Room congregation who seceded after a dispute with the New Room trustees over the requirement for communion to be administered by an ordained minster.
The building was a two-storey structure with a half-hipped roof and measured 23.8 metres from east to west by 18.7 metres wide.
The main, east-facing, elevation of the building was of five bays with a pediment, shaped parapet, and two tiers of semi-circular arched windows. The central bay at ground floor level had a single-storey gabled porch with an arched doorway and on each side were two arched windows. The first floor held five identical arched windows and above these was a pediment with a central relief plaque. The chapel was separated from Old King Street by a low wall with iron railings along it (Bristol Reference Library E400). The gallery extended around all four sides of the interior.
The interior was partly refitted in 1859 (Stell 1986, 70) and the Ordnance Survey 1:500-scale town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.20) surveyed in 1882 and revised in 1894 records that the chapel could then accommodate 900 worshippers.
The chapel was closed in 1954 and demolished soon afterwards to make way for the redevelopment of Broadmead.

Starch Works, located on the eastern side of Redcliff Street. The works was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.5) surveyed in 1882. The works was set back from the street behind buildings on the Redcliff Street frontage. The building was roughly square in plan, measuring 35 metres in length on the south-east facing and north-west facing sides. The Goad fire insurance plan of January 1887 indiacates that the ground-floor plan of the building comprised a large main space on the south with a square room at the south-east corner. There were four rooms along the north side of the building. The roof contained a number of skylights.
The building was still extant at the time of the First World War but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped.

No.53 Redcliff Street, located on the east side of Redcliff Street. The building was constructed in the seventeenth century, apparently as one of a pair with No.52 Redcliff Street (BUAD 268M).
The land parcel, defined by Redcliff Street and the lawditch to the east, was leased to Thomas Oates in 1661 (BRO DC/E/40/37/52064) and to Rowalnd Collins by 1672 (BRO DC/E/40/37/52070). The building was recorded in a watercolour drawing by T. L. Rowbotham (BUAD 967; BRSMG M2042) in 1826 and this view shows the structure as a single-bay jettied, gabled house of three storeys and attic. The building was still apparently extant in the mid-1850s, but it had been demolished by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.5) surveyed in 1882 and the site redeveloped. The site of the building now lies partly beneath the highway in Redcliff Street, but the rear, eastern, part of the footprint is on the site of modern No.54 Redcliff Street.

The Manor House in Tyndall's Park, which was extant until the early twentieth-century, and was demolished to make way for the construction of the building which now forms part of the Physics Building.

Southey House, No.11 College Green. A three-storey, three-bay gabled building. There was an oriel window in the central bay of the west face of the building at first floor level and chimneystacks at either end. It was set back from the road and the yard in front was surrounded by a low wall. The building was demolished in the late-1920s to make way for the construction of the new Council House.

Whitson's House located on the north side of St. Nicholas Street. The building was a four storey house which was reputed to have been the house of Alderman John Whitson. Attached. Four storeys; probable flat roof. Full-width pentice roofs above first three storeys. Carved posts to ends of same floors, also on right side of left-hand entry and at centre of first-floor. On left, entry to the 'Queen Bess Tavern'; entrance adjacent; window; another entrance; window at right-hand end. At first and second floors, pairs of bays with Ipswich windows, with side glazing, and cross-window between each bay and the central post. Top floor originally full-width glazing, one panel blanked off at each end; Ipswich and cross-windows. Stack on right-hand end. To the left, building of about the same height; right, a building of one storey and attic. In 1826 the tavern was by Thomas Dunn. The main building was occupied by W. Plumley, furrier and poulterer, listed at No.8 in the directories.

KNOWN_AS: Possible Garden House at No.23 Horfield Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Possible Garden House located on the west side of Horfield Road. The house was in existence by 1766 (SRO DD/MC Maps 1766-1824) and stood at the north-western corner of a rectangular walled garden. The building appears to have been demolished and Colston Villa built on part of its site by 1828.
No.58, St. Michael's Hill.
No.60, St. Michael's Hill.
No.62, St. Michael's Hill, located on the north-eastern side of St. Michael's Hill.

KNOWN_AS: House in Currant Lane adjacent to No.47 Prince Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
House on the north side of Currant Lane, attached to No.47 Prince Street. The site was created by the infilling of Aldsworth's Dock in the mid-seventeenth century and a building is recorded on the site by Millerd's 1673 map of Bristol.
The building was apparently demolished soon after the closure of Alderskey Lane in 1900 and the site was subsequently redeveloped for the Co-operative Wholesale building.

KNOWN_AS: Fry's House of Mercy, Colston Parade
POSTAL_ADDRESS: Fry's House of Mercy, Colston Parade
MONUMENT_DESC:
Fry's House of Mercy, located on the south side of Colston Parade. The almshouse was established in 1778 by William Fry to provide accommodation for "the reception and habitation of eight poor women, in eight rooms" (Manchee, 1831 60). Fry specified that those nominated for residence "should always be single persons; to wit, widows, or such as had not been married, and that they should continue unmarried during their abode in the said hospital under the penalty of expulsion therefrom." Fry also emphasised that "none should be known to be vicious persons or drunkards, or of turbulent spirits" (Manchee, 1831 61).
The building was constructed of stone rubble and was two-storeys in height with the main, north-facing, elevation on Colston Parade being of three bays. It was in a Gothick style. An oval panel above the main entrance doorway reads FRY'S/HOUSE OF MERCY/1784.
The building was gutted as a result of bombing during the Second World War, and was rebuilt behind the façade after the war.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/1672).

KNOWN_AS: St. Michael's Hill, houses below that forming 429M
MONUMENT_DESC: A pair of houses. On the west side of St. Michael's Hill, Immediately downhill from Mon.No.429M. Attached. 2 storeys and attics; gabled fronts; jettied; 1-window ranges; full-width pentice roofs common to both fronts. Cellar access to left of left-hand house. Adjacent entrances, with three C17 posts. Bay with sashes to right-hand house, pair of sashes to left-hand. Bays to first-floor and attic of right-hand, 8-light and 6-light fronts respectively, 2-light sides. 6-light first-floor window to left-hand house, attic window probably similar. A slightly raised pavement outside the lower house.

House, the ground-floor now a fish & chip shop and restaurant. Attached to the north-east and rear. C17 house of 3 storeys and attic; 1-window range; gable to the street. Jettied first-floor with a slate pent, a small second-floor jetty and a moulded strip to the attic; a C19 shop front has an ovolo-moulded beam across the central doorway and plate glass windows, beneath a good 2-storey canted oriel with close studding beneath central Ipswich windows with flanking cross windows; a 4-light attic mullion window. 
The stone left-hand corner is curved out beneath the jetty, and the curve continues in the left return to an exterior stack, with a left-hand small first-floor opening with stone jambs and lintel, and a rear section with a Tudor-arched doorway with C20 door and a left-hand 6/6-pane sash. Above is a moulded 3-light mullion and transom window with 6 panes above and 4 panes beneath the transom, beneath an overhanging gable, against half of which the side of No.20 Christmas Steps butts. 
O'Neill's undated drawing (Mb.2968/172) shows all of the first-floor glazing with Gothick traceried lead cames. Flanking windows are also shown beside the second-floor bay.

St. Peter's Vicarage, located on the south side of Peter Street some 10 metres to the west of the western end of St. Peter's Church [BUAD 513M]. The building was a jettied, single-bay structure of two-storeys plus attic with a gabled pantile roof. There was an entrance on the east side of the main elevation at ground floor and a window to its west. A full-width carved beam separated ground and first floor and this carried the date "1613". There was a central six-light window at first-floor, and evidence for other possible windows. A full-width carved beam with brackets at either end supported the second-floor jetty and there was a central two-light window at second-floor. The building had carved bargeboards with brackets to the eaves and at the apex of the gable was a decorative finial. The side, north-east facing, elevation of the vicarage was blank but a two-storey side extension with a hipped pantile roof had been added. This had an entrance on the west side of the main elevation, adjacent to that of the vicarage itself, with a shop window. The single first-floor window was a sash.
The vicarage was of early seventeenth-century date and G. W. Braikenridge reports that the carved beam at first-floor also carried the initials of Robert Aldworth who was responsible for its construction. By 1825 the building was in use as a shop and was occupied by a basket-maker.

No.2 Peter Street. Attached. 3 storeys and attic; gabled front; jettied; 1-window range. First and second floor jettied, with left-hand bracket to latter. Oriel to first-floor, sash to front. Sash to second-floor. Attic window. Lateral stacks.

Iron Foundry, Commercial Road. The foundry was located on the southern side of Commercial Road (later Temple Back) and along the west side of Ash Lodge. It was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town Plan of the early 1880s.

Malthouse, Commercial Road. The malthouse lay on the southern side of Commercial Road (later Temple Back) and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of the early 1880s. The site now lies mainly beneath Temple Back.

KNOWN_AS: All Saints' Almshouse burial ground, All Saints' Street
MONUMENT_DESC: The burial ground of All Saints' Almshouse, All Saints' Street. The cemetery was located on the west side of Fairfax Street and behind the almshouse which faced on to All Saints' Street. The almshouse (BUAD 1189M) was originally sited in High Street and moved to a location adjacent to St. John's Almshouses, St. John's Steep in 1740 to 1741. It was moved again to All Saints' Street in 1813 (Lobel & Carus-Wilson 1975, 26). The almshouse and burial ground are shown on Plumley and Ashmead's map of 1828 and Ashmead's map of 1850. The almshouse had been closed by the early 1880s and the Ordnance Survey first edition map indicates that a foundry occupied the site. The burial ground, however, seems to have remained undeveloped for many years and to have been used as a yard for the foundry. The site of the cemetery was subsequently redeveloped as Nos.10-12 Fairfax Street but it is not known whether, or when, the cemetery was cleared before redevelopment of the site.
The Quay Pipe. The pipe carried water from the Boiling Wells to the Quay Head at the end of St. Stephen's Avenue.

KNOWN_AS: All Saints' or All Hallow's Pipe
MONUMENT_DESC: All Saints' or All Hallow's Pipe. The conduit carried water from a spring at Bedford Road across Upper Maudlin Street, through the Franciscan Friary and across the river Frome to Broad Street and a conduit head on the west side of All Saints' Church.

Great Western Dry Dock. The dock was designed by Isambard Kingdom Brunel and built in 1839 on the site of the western clay pit of a brickyard which had previously occupied the site. The SS. Great Britain was constructed in the dock and launched from there in 1843.
On 26 July 1845 the ship set sail on her maiden voyage to New York.
The dock has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building Number 1300).

Edwards Ringer & Co tobacco factory, No.60 Redcliff Street. It was built in 1883 to a design by the architects Henry Crisp and H. C. M. Hirst who submitted drawings on 9 July 1883 for " four shop premises and tobacco Manufactory". The front of the building is of local Pennant and Bath stone with Mansfield stone columns. The original building consists of a front range against Redcliff Street with a central atrium at right angles. The premises were subsequently extended to the east with the construction in 1900 of a building, No.30 St Thomas Street, at the eastern end of the site. Further infilling of the site took place, largely before 1931. The buildings are currently in a poor state of repair. It is uncertain whether the buildings contain evidence of the original tobacco manufacturing process. However, the buildings have been subsequently reused for other purposes which may have resulted in the clearance of original fixtures and fittings. It is known that the party wall between Nos.57 and 60 Redcliff Street reuses an earlier, probably medieval, wall.

Cross-gabled house of probable seventeenth-century date on the south side of Upper Wells Street. The building was of two storeys with an attic and a pantile roof. The building was probably a merchant's lodge or garden house given its similarity to other lodges in the area.
The building was demolished in 1961 and its site is now beneath the rear of the Entertainment Centre in Frogmore Street.

Rowe's Leadworks, located on the north side of Anchor Lane. The Leadworks was built in 1884.
The buildings stood empty during the 1990s until they were converted to form part of the Wildscreen centre.

No.7 Frog Lane. The building is a house of two-storeys plus attic and of probable seventeenth-century date. At the rear of the building is a gable and the visible elements are of Brandon Hill Grit rubble construction and there is a Pennant sandstone rubble stack on the west side, probably serving the rear room. A door has been inserted in the gable at attic level in the position which would have been occupied by the attic window. The 2-window three storey front is of brick, and the building was probably refronted during the eighteenth or nineteenth centuries. There is an entrance on the east end of the south side. The roof is hipped at the front. The plan suggests there may have been a detached kitchen block.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Castle Street Picture Theatre, Castle Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Castle Street Picture Theatre reportedly designed by W. H. Watkins for Cinema House Ltd. and opened in 1911 with 550 seats (Ewins 1984, 27). The cinema, also known as the Cinema House, closed in c1926 when the Regent in Castle Street was opened.

Clare Street Picture House on north side of Clare Street. Built by Provincial Cinematograph Theatres Ltd. Opened 1912 with 470 seats (Anderson 1983, 18). The cinema had a high arched stone entrance glazed at first floor level with small central fan light. The wide entrance was flanked by columns with illuminated sign above.
The cinema was demolished in 1928 (Winstone 1920's, pl 176).

KNOWN_AS: Boot and Shoe Manufactory, Castle Green

MONUMENT_DESC:
Dolphin Picture House on the east side of Dolphin Street opened as Pringle's Picture Palace in 1910 and was nicknamed Kosy Korner Kinema. The cinema was converted from the ground floor of a café and restaurant by R. Wilkins and Sons, Bristol to a design by W. H. Watkins and could seat 500 patrons (Ewins 1984, 26; Anderson 1983, 16). The cinema closed in the early 1920s.
The site of the building now lies within Castle Park.

Gem Cinema situated close to the junction of Broad Weir and Merchant Street. The cinema opened in 1909 with seating for 1200 people on three floors (Anderson 1983, 21). The cinema closed in 1932 and was demolished in 1957 (Winstone 1972, pl.227).

Magnet Cinema, located on the north west side of Newfoundland Street. The cinema was built in 1914 and had a large arched entrance and circular "port hole" windows at first floor level (Winstone 1971, pl.177). There was seating for 520 people. The cinema closed in 1937 (Anderson 1983, 21) and the building was subsequently converted. The building is extant though it is currently (15/11/2004) in use as offices.

The Tatler Cinema, located on the east side of Carey's Lane, Old Market. The cinema opened as the Olympia in 1910, and was reconstructed internally in 1947 by W. H. Watkins for Joseph Cohen of Jacey Cinemas Ltd and renamed The Tatler (Ewins 1984, 29). It was marked as the Picture Theatre on the 1913 Ordnance Survey plan (Gloucestershire sheet LXXII.13). The building was demolished in 1965.
The Redcliffe Hall, located on the east side of Redcliff Hill. The building opened in 1911 and was in use as a cinema by the 1920s. It was destroyed by bombing in 1940 (Winstone, 1971, pl.175).

Vestry Hall, located on the north west side of Pennywell Road. The building was constructed in 1880 as a segragated sports and activities gymnasium owned by Bristol Corporation Baths Department (Stephenson & Willmott 2005, 113). David Lloyd-George addressed a meting in the hall during the Second Boer War. 
Ralph Pringle leased the building and converted it into a 580-seat cinema. This opened on 19 October 1909 (Winstone 1972, 8) and Vestry Hall was Ralph Pringle's second cinema in Bristol after the Bedminster Town Hall Cinema (Anderson 1983, 16). A licence for cinematograph entertainment, music and dancing had been obtained by 1920. In 1921 the lease was taken over by Mr A. B. Atkinson who installed an RCA sound system. The hall remained in use as a cinema until 1954. The building was subsequently converted to industrial use.
The building is extant. A survey of the building was carried out by David Etheridge of Avon Archaeological Unit in 2007 (BHER 4428) (Etheridge, 2008).

Bristol Hippodrome located on the west side of St Augustine's Parade. Built in 1911 by Frank Matcham. Three storey building built in limestone ashlar.
Used as a cinema from 1932 until 1938 (Anderson 1983)

No.82 Broad Quay, located on the north side of the junction of Broad Quay and Currant Lane. The site was created by the infilling of Aldsworth's Dock in the mid-seventeenth century and a building is recorded on the site by Millerd's 1673 map of Bristol. This had been rebuilt by the mid-nineteenth century as a four-storey brick building with ashlar quoins and a hipped pantile roof. Its footprint measured 14.4 metres from east to west by 6.4 metres north-south.
The ground floor of the building was in use as offices by January 1887, according to the Goad fire insurance plan, while the upper floors were divided into tenements. The building was apparently demolished to make way for the development of the Co-operative Wholesale building, although the Ordnance Survey second edition Ordnance Survey plan published in 1903 indicates that the block of buildings between Alderskey Lane and Currant Lane which contained No.82 was demolished after that date. The site is now beneath Narrow Quay at the entrance to the car park of Broad Quay House.

Union Bridge, crossing the River Frome, almost at the top of Union Street. Single span. A single row of voussoirs; rubble construction; parapet with coping stones; possible string course at about street level. A recess in the northern underside of the span. There was a further, large, arch a short distance downhill from this bridge.

Tower or bastion on the line of the second town wall, projecting slightly into the River Frome, west of the later line of Union Street. In 1821 the antiquarian Samuel Seyer noted a tower about 12 feet square, being used as a [public?] house, known as the Compasses (Seyer 1821, 267-268). The lane from Union Street to the bottom of the Pithay then passed through its ground-floor. In the south wall was a large blocked-up pointed archway. Illustrations by O'Neill and Cashin in 1820 and 1823 show a timber-framed building propped off the base of the tower, on the river side. The building, most likely a house, was of two storeys plus a gabled roof, 1 bay wide.

Old Assembly Room, located on the northern side of the original line of Tower Lane, near to the junction with Pithay. Now partly below the widened lane, but also probably below the car park to the rear of 'The Pithay'. O'Neill's drawing of 1820 (BRSMG M2374) shows the stack of a demolished building, with fireplaces at first and second floors. Braikenridge's notes record that this or the adjacent house to the east had been "part of the old Assembly Room".

No.40 High Street. The building was in existence by 1261 and by 1306 was described as comprising a messuage and cellar (Leech, 1997 80). It formed part of Cooks' Row by the mid-fourteenth century and was acquired by Thomas Stamford in 1414. Stamford granted it to Agnes Knight in 1440, the cellar being described as newly rebuilt and annexed (ibid.). By the mid-fifteenth century it was owned by Agnes Fylor, who also held the lease of No.39 High Street. She bequeathed the property to her son Thomas, a London mercer, in her will of November 1467. Under the terms of her will the property passed to her daughter Joan at her son's death, and at Joan's death to the vicar and churchwardens of All Saints (Burgess, 2004 15-16). Nos.39 and 40 together appear to have formed The Rose inn from 1467 and the All Saints churchwardens leased No.40 to John Hooper, a vintner, in 1525. Hooper retained the property until 1564 when it was in the possession of John Banting. In 1577 it was granted in fee farm to Philipp Langle, grocer.
The building retained an arch-brace roof with plain windbraces in the 1820s (BRSMG M2388) which was still extant in 1850 (Pryce, 1850 221-222).

Conduit house for St. John's Conduit. The conduit house was located at the junction of Broad Street and Tower Lane, against the west end of the south side of St. John the Baptist Church. Half-gable at south-west end, conduit below. Two gables along Tower Lane, frieze beneath, then plain wall below. Ball finials and other decoration to gables.
A new conduit house (BUAD 375M) was created in Nelson Street in 1827, after a series of serious traffic accidents which involved women and children standing at the conduit. The stonework of the conduit house was destroyed at the time of removal, March 1827.

Conduit head, St John's Conduit. A conduit house created at the eastern end of the Nelson Street elevation to St. John the Baptist Church in 1827. 2 lion heads and a tap below a carved panel of beasts to a shield inscribed 1866, recessed beneath a four-centred arch of nineteenth-century date. The conduit head is extant.

The 'Globe Tavern', a public house located on the east side of Christmas Street, between Nelson Street and the River Frome. Possibly a former house. Attached. 4 storeys and attic; half-hipped; flush front; 1-window range. Right-hand entrance; large pub window. 8-light transomed first-floor window; cross-windows to second and third floors; 2-light casement to attic. Brackets to eaves.

Tomb of Hugh Brown, located against the south-east boundary wall of St. John's Churchyard (BUAD 377M). The tomb is of seventeenth-century date and has effigies of Hugh Brown, alderman, and his wife, within a vaulted structure of ashlar stone. There is an open semicircular arch on its north-west side and panels on the underside of the semicircular vault. The vault was recorded in a watercolour drawing by T. L. Rowbotham in 1825 (BRSMG M2430). George Weare Braikenridge, writing in the 1820s, notes that the monument had once had doors, but they had rotted off (Braikenridge Notes, E84).

Tailors' Hall, located on the north-western side of Tailors Court. The building was the meeting hall of the Company of Merchant Tailors. The building was constructed in 1740-41.
Rendered limestone ashlar, roof not visible. Single-depth Great Hall and right-hand stair block.
3 storey; 7-window range. A 2-window right-hand service block set forward, Great Hall to the left with raised basement; the right-hand entrance has a fine late C17 shell hood with painted Arms of the guild with flanking winged cupids and a head of John the Baptist, on acanthus brackets, double 6-panel doors. Plain surrounds to square basement windows, with entrances at each end, separated by angled spurs; to the right-hand section, 9/9-pane sashes and a small 6-pane window over the door, and alternate segmental and triangular pediments to tall 20/20-pane sashes to 2-storey windows on the Great Hall. In the re-entrant is a conical lead hopper and downpipe.
In the late-nineteenth century the building was used as a Temperance Hall.
Now connected internally with No.41 Broad Street. Converted c1950.
Malthouse, Pipe Lane. The malthouse was located on the west side of Pipe Lane.
Saw Mills, Commercial Road. The saw mills were located on the north side of Commercial Road, later Temple Back and were recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of the early 1880s.
Henbury Lodge. The Lodge was built in 1780 and is a three-storey, located at the west end of Thirty Acre Wood.

Pennywell House. The house lay on the northern side of Pennywell Road, immediately to the south of the E. Baily and Son malt house. It was recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883 and by the Goad fire insurance plan of August 1896. The building was still extant in the mid-1950s but has since been demolished. The site is not known to have been disturbed since demolition and the archaeological stratification associated with the monument is therefore likely to survive in good condition.

A smithy recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883 lying on the western side of Penywell Road. The smithy was still extantat the time of the Goad fire insurance plan of August 1896 which records some evidence of the internal organisation organisation of the structure, notably the existence of a chimney in the centre of its northern wall. The site of the smithy has been redeveloped and the western part of the building lies beneath the footprint of Universal House. It is likely therefore that, at least in this area, the archaeological stratification associated with the monument has been heavily disturbed.

KNOWN_AS: Church of St Nicholas of Tolentino
MONUMENT_DESC: The Church of St. Nicholas of Tolentino, located on the north side of Gloucester Road (modern Lawfords Gate). The building was constructed between 1848 and 1851 to a design by Charles Hansom (Gomme et al. 1979, 35) and is extant.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: The King's Hall, Old Market Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
The King's Hall on the north side of Old Market Street opened in July 1910 (Winstone 1972, 8) by British Electric Theatres who also owned the Queen's Hall (1556M) in Peter Street (Anderson 1983, 17). The cinema survived until 1976 when the site was redeveloped.
The building consisted of four storeys including dormers in the mansard roof.
The site is now occupied by Kings House office building.

KNOWN_AS: Bristol Distilling Company Ltd. Distillery, Avon Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Bristol Distilling Company Ltd. Distillery. The distillery was located on the south side of Cheese Lane [modern Avon Street]. The building is noted on the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Sheet LXXII.16.24) surveyed in 1883 and was still extant in August 1896 Goad fire insurance survey was made. The offices and machine shop were located on the Cheese Lane frontage and the spirit stores and boilers to the rear of the site. The distillery also had storehouses (BUAD 1386M) on the north side of Cheese Lane and a cooperage to the east of these according to the Goad plan.

A chapel in St. James Churchyard. The precise location of the chapel is unknown although it was described by the antiquary William Worcestre in 1480 as being "quasi versus fratres sancti francisci". The dedication is similarly uncertain. Worcestre reports the chapel as being 10 paces square, built of freestone with eight buttresses. The windows were also of freestone and the roof was tiled (Neale 2000, 194-195; 210-211). A tiled pavement discovered in 1894 during demolition of the White Lion public house (BUAD 104) was thought Robert Hall Warren to be the floor of this chapel, but this is very unlikely.
Totterdown Lock Tollgate. The gate stood across the bridge over Totterdown Lock bridge. It is recorded by the survey of the city in 1828 by John Plumley and George Ashmead.

A brickyard of probable seventeenth-century date located on the south side of Temple Back. The yard is recorded by a plan in the Corporation plan books but appears to have gone out of use by the time of Jean Rocque's 1742 plan of Bristol.

Bristol Baptist College, located on the east side of Stokes Croft. The theological college was founded in 1679. The Stokes Croft site was purchased between 1803 and 1812 and after substantial rebuilding the college moved to the site in 1812. The building was rectangular in plan and was of four storeys with a three-window range to Stokes Croft. Three sashes to ground-floor. Above there was a string or plat band, four two-storey pilasters to a cornice, with three square-headed first-floor windows and three segmental-headed second-floor windows. Third-floor of three small segmental-headed windows. The building had a shallow hipped roof.
The Baptist College moved to a new building Tyndall's Park (BUAD 47M) circa 1913. The building became a Christian Science Church but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped.

KNOWN_AS: House in Temple Street, south of Temple Church
MONUMENT_DESC: A house on the east side of Temple Street, to the south of Temple Church. The building was of seventeenth-century date. Attached. 2 storeys and attic; gabled front; jettied; 1-window range. Shops either side of a central entrance, with pair of columns with Corinthian (?) capitals supporting carved lintels to porch. A full-width pentice roof above the ground-floor. Casements to first-floor, the right-hand a 6-light. 2 two-light casements to attic. Probably with lateral stacks.

Redcliff Gate, located at the south end of Redcliff Street. The gate was constructed in the thirteenth cenutry as part of the town wall known as the Portwall (BUAD 1042M) and allowed access into Redcliff Street. There were two gates by the 1480s according to William Worcestre and an entry in The Great Red Book refers to premises between them. It was replaced by a single gate in the Classical style in 1730 or 1731, probably built on the site of the old outer gate.

Temple Gate, a town gate located at the south end of Temple Street. The gate was contemporary with the construction of the town wall known as the Portwall (BUAD 1042M) in the thirteenth century. The medieval gate was 9 yards long by 3 yards wide according to William Worcestre (Neale 2000, 10-11). The original gate was demolished in 1734 and a new gate built on the same site in a Classical style. This was drawn by James Stewart in 1751. It had banded rustication on its north face, banded columns at the ends and to either side of central arch, and alternately enlarged voussoirs above pedestrian entrances. There was a tall round-headed wide central gate for vehicular traffic, with smaller round-headed pedestrian gates on either side. Above the centre there was a gabled roof, the gable ends being decorated with the Royal Arms (facing north) and the City Arms (facing south). Temple Gate was removed in 1808-09.
One of the large urns is preserved in the collections of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery.

Lawford's Gate, a town gate standing at the eastern end of Old Market Street. A gate probably stood in this position from at least the twelfth century, and "Laffordesyate" is mentioned in the 1373 perambulation of the County of Bristol. The drawings of the gate show what appears to be a structure which is late-medieval in date, suggesting that it was rebuilt, or at least refronted, at that date.
A single wide entrance with a depressed moulded drop arch. Facing east (?), a mullion and transom window with two pointed lights in a square head, beneath a drip moulding, with, to either side, a niche containing the statue of a king, each niche decorated with crocketing. Above the first-floor was a string or cornice. In the gable there was a window or opening, below a pentice roof. It appears from a drawing of 1745 by James Stewart (the only known depiction) that the gate was set back slightly from the line of the town wall to either side.
The gate was removed in 1768 but the two statues have survived, and are now in the collections of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery.
The Market, High Street. The market on High Street is medieval in origin. It was rebuilt to a design by Samuel Glascodine between 1744 and 1745, following the completion of The Exchange.

KNOWN_AS: St. Giles's or King Edward's Gate
MONUMENT_DESC:
The town gate known as St. Giles's, or King Edward's, Gate, at the northern end of Small Street leading to the Quay Head. On the south side the gateway consisted of an ogee-headed arch with a carved head above its apex; the right-hand springing supported by some form of corbel. Above the gate was a two-storey building, the lower part possibly including a roofed gallery.
This tenement was rented out by the Corporation in the early modern period, a landgable rent being paid by John Griffith in c.1650 and a fee farm rent by Thomas Collins in 1741 (Leech 1997, 119). The gate was demolished c.1777.

KNOWN_AS: Flitch of Bacon public house, Host Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Flitch of Bacon public house on the north side of Host Street (possibly No.30 Host Street). The building was a three-storey, single-bay house with a front gable. It had a central entrance, reached by two steps, with a sash window on either side. There was a bay window at first floor level and a single sash in the gable end. A large lamp projected from the frontage immediately above the doorway.
The building was demolished in the later nineteenth-century.

Nos.31-34(?) Host Street. The row of four gabled houses stood on the north side of Host Street, No.34 being at the east corner of Host Street abd Steep Street. The buildings were all four-storey, single-bay jettied houses with front gables. They had bay windows at first and second floor level, and smaller sashes in the gable ends. The roofs were pantiled.
The buildings appear to have been erected contemporaneously as part of the same development. They were demolished in the later part of the nineteenth-century.

KNOWN_AS: House at the junction of Host Street and Steep Street
MONUMENT_DESC: House at the west corner of Host Street and Steep Street. The building was a four-storey, two-bay jettied building with a gabled front to Host Street. The ground floor was a shopfront. The first and second floors each contained two tall four-light casement windows. The gable end held a single smaller casement. The building was demolished in the later nineteenth-century, probably with the removal of Steep Street in the 1870s.

Orchard located on the north side of the River Frome, to the east of Quakers Friars. The orchard was recorded in 1751 as "a Place called the old Orchard" during the perambulation of St. James parish (BRO P/StJ/ChW/6). It is possible that this was originally the orchard of the Dominican Friary.
Swan Hotel, Nos.117-119 Stokes Croft, located on the north-western side of Stokes Croft.

The statue of Samuel Morley, now located in Lewins Mead. Morley (1809-1886) was an M.P. for Bristol for eighteen years between 1858 and 1885 and donated large sums of money to several causes in the city. Money was raised for a commemorative statue by public subscription. The statue was sculpted by J. Howard Thomas from Carrara marble and was "considered by his family to be an admirable likeness." It was erected on a red Aberdeen granite plinth at a site in the highway between Bristol Bridge and St. Nicholas Church.
The main face of the plinth carries the inscription:
"Samuel Morley/Member of Parliament for this city/From 1868 to 1885/To preserve for their children/The memory of the face and from/Of one who was an example/Of justice, generosity, and public spirit/This statue was given/By more than 5,000 citizens of Bristol."
Sir Joseph D. Weston performed the unveiling at a ceremony on 22 October 1887, attended by 25000 people.
The statue was moved to as site in the Haymarket in 1921 and was moved again to Lewin's Mead in 1997 to make way for the construction of a gateway structure in Broadmead (Merritt 2002, 24-25).
The statue has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/11/494).

No.55 Broad Street, located close to the corner of Newmarket Avenue and Broad Street. A building seems to have stood on the site from at least 1295 when William Scoche is recorded as the occupier and in 1384, when it was purchased by John Stanys the property comprised three shops with a cellar beneath. A document of 1437 records the property as a messuage, cellar, solar and garden held by Margaret Asscheley (Leech 1997, 46). By 1543 the property had been acquired by the feoffees of All Saints parish and a lease of that year to Lewes Robyns, skinner, mentions a stable at the end of the plot. In 1598 the feoffees sold the building to the executors of Robert Kitchen. It is not clear what works this entailed but some reconstruction of the building was certainly undertaken. The building appears to have been refronted in the seventeenth century and by the early 1860s was a four-storey, single-bay jettied building with a shopfront at ground floor level and bay sash windows at first and second floors. It had a smaller sash at third floor. It had a pantiled roof with a front gable (Winstone 1972, plates 17-18). The building was demolished in c.1864 to allow construction of The Grand Hotel.

No. 30 St. Augustine's Parade. The building was a four-storey, two-bay house with a front gable. The ground floor contained a shopfront and there were sash windows in the other floors. In the gable end (the fourth storey) there was a single sash. The gabled roof was pantiled and a chimney stack projected from it on the southern side. No.30 and No.31 appear to have been erected as a single development and what appeared to be part of the roof of a further gabled building, also part of the development, which would have stood on the site of No.32 St. Augustine's Parade can be seen on the north side of the roof of No.31.

No. 31 St. Augustine's Parade. The building was a four-storey, two-bay house with a front gable. The ground floor contained a shopfront and there were sash windows in the other floors. In the gable end (the fourth storey) there was a single sash. The gabled roof was pantiled and a chimney stack projected from it on the northern side. No.30 and No.31 appear to have been erected as a single development and what appeared to be part of the roof of a further gabled building, also part of the development, which would have stood on the site of No.32 St. Augustine's Parade can be seen on the north side of the roof of No.31.

No.10 Merchant Street on the north corner of the junction of Merchant Street and Quaker's Friars. This was a two-storey, single-bay building with a front gable. The ground floor was a shopfront with an entrance door on the south side. Above the shopfront the frontage was pargetted and the timberwork was exposed. There was a three light casement window in the centre of the frontage at first floor level. There were rusticated quoins at the south corner. The south-facing wall had three irregularly spaced windows at first floor. The roof was pantiled and a two-flue chimney stack projected from the ridge of the roof. In the centre of the gable end was the date "AD 1650".
The building was demolished in 1955 to make way for the redevelopment of Broadmead.

No.103 Redcliff Hill. The building stood on the east side of the hill and was a three-storey, single-bay jettied house with a gabled front. The ground floor had a bay window on the north side and the entrance door was on south. Above was a full width pentice and the first floor had a central bay window. The attic storey had a single sash in the gable end. The building appears to have had a two-flue chimney stack which projected from the north side of the roof.
The building was demolished in 1963 to make way for a new road system associated with Bedminster Bridge.

Two conical limekilns formerly on the site of 10-14 Cheese Lane. Millerd's map of 1673 indicates the presence of the structures which had been demolished by the end of the seventeenth-century to make way for a glass cone.
Mineral Water Works, located on the southern side of Ninetree Hill.
A smithy in Braggs Lane recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883. The smithy lay on the north side of the lane and was out of use by 1896.

Sir Abraham Elton's Glasshouse otherwise known as the "St. Philip's Glasshouse" or "Lower Glasshouse", Cheese Lane.
The glass cone, built in 1710, stood on the west side of Cheese Lane on the site of Nos.10-14 Cheese Lane. The glasshouse was built by Sir Abraham Elton and remained within the family until the bankruptcy of the third baronet in 1746. During renovation in 1736 the cone collapsed (General Advertiser 4 June 1736) and was rebuilt. The business was bought by Isaac Elton in 1746 and passed to his son. By the beginning of the nineteenth-century the glassworks was suffering from the more general decline which affected Bristol glass bottle manufacture. It was leased in 1804 and again in 1807 and finally sold in 1809 to a partnership which demolished the cone to set up a spelter, copper and wire manufacturing business.
A plan on deeds dating to 1807 suggests that the pot rooms for the glassworks were to the south of the cone and on the east side of Cheese Lane.

Four houses or other buildings shown by Millerd's map of 1673 on the west side of Cheese Lane, now the site of Nos.10-14 Cheese Lane.
Three of the buildings form a row oriented north-south parallel to Cheese Lane, with gabled fronts to the south. The fourth house is oriented east-west and aligns with the north walls of the three other houses. On the south side of the buildings were gardens. It is not clear whether these buildings were associated with the two limekilns shown to the west. Recording work inside Nos.10-14 Cheese Lane at the end of 1995 recognised plan elements of these buildings in the fabric of the existing buildings at the east side of the site, but could not determine to what extent the fabric of seventeenth-century houses survived.

Water Gate, located at the northern end of the town wall known as the Portwall (BUAD 1042M) close to Tower Harratz (BUAD 671M). The gate was recorded by William Worcestre in his 1480 survey of Bristol. The feature was archaeologically excavated in 2000 (BUAD 3643) and was found to be constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble (Cox 2000).
The structure was enclosed in a series of retaining walls and a viewing platform was constructed as part of a wider scheme of paving and lighting to mark the line of the wall designed by the Irish artist John Aiken.

KNOWN_AS: New Quay Iron Works, Hotwell Road
MONUMENT_DESC: New Quay Iron Works, located on the southern side of Hotwell Road. The iron works is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 scale plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.2) surveyed in 1883 and was still operating in 1903 when it had apparently been renamed as the Limekiln Works. However, by 1918 the works had been demolished and the site was in use as a timber yard.

Marble Works, located on the southern side of Hotwell Road. The works is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 scale plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.2) surveyed in 1883 and may still have been operating in 1903. However, by 1918 the works had been demolished and the site was in use as a timber yard.

Regent Cinema, located on the south side of Castle Street. The cinema was designed by W. H. Watkins for Provincial Cinematograph Theatres Ltd. and built by Frank Wilkins (Ewins 1984, 27). The cinema opened on 30 July 1927 with 2036 seats. It was taken over by the PCT circuit in February 1929 and by Gaumont-British in the early 1930s. The cinema was destroyed on 24 November 1940 by bombing and the site was cleared in 1963 (Elyes 1996, 201).

POSTAL_ADDRESS: U.B.H.T. Car Park, Upper Maudlin Street
MONUMENT_DESC: The Baptist Stable, located on the south-eastern side of Maudlin Lane (now Upper Maudlin Street), opposite to the mark that indicated the point from which both sides were in the parish of St.James. Recorded in 1751 as "a Stable calle'd Baptist Stable" during the perambulation of St. James parish (BRO P/StJ/ChW/6). It may date from the seventeenth- or the eighteenth-century. No other details are known.

Roaring Bridge, a bridge crossing the river Frome in the area of modern Wellington Road. The bridge may have had a medeival origin. It was recorded by James Millerd's 1673 map of Bristol and the version of c.1715 names it as "Roaring Bridg[e]", presumably due to the noise of the weir for the Castle Mill leat beneath it. The bridge is also mentioned in a document recording the prembulation of the parish of St. James in 1751 as "the Roaring bridge" (BRO P/StJ/ChW/6).

The Roperies, a ropewalk located in the section of the land parcel known as Earls Mead which lay between the River Frome and the Castle Mill leat, extending from the Narrow Weir to the Roaring Bridge. The ropewalk was apparently in existence by the and James Millerd's map of c1670 calls it "ye Roperie". The ropewalk is not shown on his 1673 map, but the revision of c1715 does show "Roperies". Jean Rocque's plan of the city of 1742 shows three rows of trees marked as "The Rope Walk" and it was also recorded in 1751 as "the Rope Y[ar]d" during the perambulation of St. James parish (BRO P/StJ/ChW/6). The ropwalk is not, however, recorded by the Plumley and Ashmead map of 1828, suggesting that it had gone out of use by that date.
Malthouse, located in Brooks Court off Pipe Lane, Temple.

Croft House, No.106, Stokes Croft, located on the south side of the original junction of Ashley Road with Stokes Croft (the junction was later moved north to its present position). The land on which the building stood was leased to John Brock, a carpenter, in 1729 by the Parish of St. James which owned it. In 1732 Brock transferred the lease to William Simkins. The building appears to have been in existence by 1742 and as built seems to have been a three-storey, four-bay house with a pitched roof.
In the nineteenth century, probably before 1850, a projecting bay was added at either end of the building. By 1883 it was occupied by Vincent Skinner, horticultural builder. It had been subdivided into two buildings by the early 1960s. The building was still extant in 1963 but had been demolished by 1966 (Winstone 1990, pl.17).
Imperial Saw Mills, Cumberland Road. The saw mill was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 scale plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.12).

Mission Hall, Hotwell Road. The mission hall is located on the southern side of Hotwell Road and is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 scale plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.1) as a Wesleyan Methodist hall with seating for 250 people.
The building is extant and was converted into a convenience store in the late 1990s.
Dry Dock, Poole's Wharf.
20, St. James Barton
22, St. James Barton
Iron Foundry, located on the north side of Cheese Lane. The foundry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.21) surveyed in 1882.
Brewery, located on the east side of Nelson Place, off Cheese Lane. The brewery is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.21) surveyed in 1882.
Malthouse, located on the west side of Goat Alley, off Cheese Lane. The malthouse is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.21) surveyed in 1882.

George Railway Hotel, Temple Gate.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/338).
Victoria Hotel, located on the south-western side of Temple Gate. The hotel is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 scale plan surveyed in 1882 (Bristol Sheet LXXI.1.6).

Brewery, located on the western side of Old Brick Yard, Temple Gate. The brewery is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 scale plan surveyed in 1882 (Bristol Sheet LXXI.1.6) and occupied the site between Old Brick Yard and Russell Street.
Temple Gate Corn Mill. The corn mill is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 scale plan surveyed in 1882 (Bristol Sheet LXXI.1.6).
Cathay Brewery, located on the eastern side of Bethall Place, Redcliffe.

Wycliffe Chapel, located on the northern side of Guinea Street. The chapel is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.10) surveyed in 1882 and had seating for 500 people.
Malthouse, located on the western side of Redcliff Backs. The malthouse is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 scale plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.10) surveyed in 1882.
Huller House, located on the west side of Redcliff Backs. The warehouse was constructed in the mid-nienteenth century.

KNOWN_AS: Great Western Railway Goods Shed, Canon's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC:
Great Western Railway Goods Shed, Canons's Marsh. The goods shed was designed between 1904 and 1906. Acording to the listing description the drawings are marked from the office of LG Mouchel and quote the Hennebique patent for ferro-concrete construction. The engineer responsible for new works on the GWR was W. Armstrong who played an important role in the introduction of reinforced concrete construction. The goods shed was built in 1906 by Robinson of Bristol. It was two storeys in height and was 10 bays long by four bays wide and was clad in brick, including blue engineering bricks.
The shed remained out of use onto the early 1990s and the eastern half was demolished c.1995. The eastern half was converted into a new science centre, @t-Explore, by the architects Wilkinson Eyre as part of the Harbourside redevelopment scheme for Canon's Marsh.

KNOWN_AS: Cross-gabled house on the north-east corner of Turn Again Lane
MONUMENT_DESC: Cross-gabled house, located on the north-east corner of Turn Again Lane at the north-eastern end of Bridewell Bridge. The building was a jettied house of two-storeys and attic with a cross-gabled pantile roof. The south-west facing elevation was of two bays while the side, south-east facing elevation was blank though with a chimney stack at the centre of the elevation. The building was drawn by Hugh O'Neill in 1823 and by that date the fenestration had been altered to sashes at ground and first floor.

KNOWN_AS: Cross-gabled house at the corner of Horsefair and St. James's Back
MONUMENT_DESC: A jettied cross-gabled house of two-storeys and attic located at the corner of Horsefair and St. James's Back. The house was of seventeenth-century date.

Castle Ditch Culvert which covered part of the Castle Ditch, the former moat of Bristol Castle. Round-arched openings to both ends. The ends were drawn by O'Neill (BRSMG M2740; M2901-M2903). Later extended in both directions. The culvert is extant.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Royal Fort Gatehouse, Royal Fort Road

KNOWN_AS: The Prince of Wales public house, No.29 Pithay
MONUMENT_DESC:
The 'Prince of Wales' public house, No.29 Pithay. The building was an attached three-storey house, probably with an attic, of seventeenth-century date. The main, west-facing, elevation had a two-window range. with an entrance to right of centre. The fenestration consisted of sashes at the first and second floors. String courses separated all of the floors.
John Pritchard monitored the demolition of the building in early September 1899, and argued that it was a eigtheenth-century building which was "very plain in character" (Pritchard 1900, 259).

KNOWN_AS: The Bell Public House, Duck Lane
MONUMENT_DESC: The Bell public house, located on the corner of Duck Lane and the Pithay. The building was a three-storey, jettied house with a one-window range, and probably a cross-gabled roof, and was of probable seventeenth-century date.

KNOWN_AS: House in Pithay, adjacent to The Bell
MONUMENT_DESC: House in Pithay, adjacent to The Bell in the Pithay. C17. Attached. 3 storeys and roof; gabled front; first and second floors jettied; 2-window range. A shuttered shopfront with a recessed central entrance. Two sashes to first-floor; cross-windows (?) to second-floor.
Temple Pottery, Commercial Road

Duffet's Redware Pottery, Temple Back. The pottery produced redware pottery during the nineteenth century, forms including jugs, and other domestic pottery. Flower pots and other garden wares were also produced. When the surrounding area of Temple Back was raised large quantities of the dumped material was ceramic waste from the factory.

KNOWN_AS: H. D. Pochin & Co. Ltd. Alum Works, Temple Back
MONUMENT_DESC:
H. D. Pochin & Co. Ltd. Alum works, Temple Back. The factory lay between the Floating Harbour and Commercial Road, later Temple Back.
It operated from the late nineteenth century into the twentieth century. A photograph of its stationary steam engine is held in the George Watkins collection at the National Monuments Record. The building was gutted by fire in the early 1990s and the shell demolished soon afterward.
A record of the building was made by Temple Local History Group in 1987. In 1998 the kilns of the works were located and excavated during an archaeological watching brief [BUAD 438].
Warehouse, located on the west side of Pipe Lane, Temple Back.
Malthouse, Pipe Lane. The malthouse was located on the west side of Pipe Lane.

The Jewish burial ground, Rose Street also known as Brooks's Court burial ground. It was designated as a private burial ground in 1811 and bought by the community from the estate of Isaac Jacobs in 1830 (Samuel 1997, 74). The burial ground was closed in the early part of the nineteenth-century. In 1850 the burial ground was described as "very small and narrow; house windows overlook it. The soil is marshy, and the whole in a very dirty and neglected state, being used as the back premises of the dwelling-house through which it is entered" (Clark 1850, 165). An Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852 imposed the restriction that "only one body [was] to be buried in each grave" in the burial ground and the cemetery was shown as disused on the 1st edition Ordnance Survey map of the early 1880s. The plot was compulsorily purchased by the Great Western Railway in May or June 1913 to allow for the construction of a new goods shed (built c.1926). The human remains and memorials were removed to a new burial ground in Fishponds in the early 1920s (Samuel 1997, 78).
Methodist Chapel. The chapel was located on the north side of Rose Street, Temple Back.

KNOWN_AS: Oil and Tallow Works, Avon Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Oil and Tallow Works, Avon Street, Temple Back.
Baptist Chapel, Tower Street, Temple Back. The chapel was located on the south side of Tower Street and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan of the early 1880s.

KNOWN_AS: Water Bailiff's Flag Staff and Signal Tower
MONUMENT_DESC:
The "Water Bailiff's Flag Staff". A signal tower on the west side of St. Augustine's Reach known as the Water Bailiff's Flag Staff (Braikenridge Notes, D.26). The tower was extant by the early nineteenth century and was apparently the location from where movement into St. Augustine's Reach was controlled. The signal tower was a circular tower approximately 2.5 metres in diameter and two storeys high, constructed of ashlar blocks. There was a door opening on the south side of the tower and the top was crenellated. There was a first floor platform, which was presumably reached by an internal circular stair. In the centre of the tower a tall flag staff was set. This was restrained by cables at mid-height and at the top which were anchored some metres to the east of the tower.
The tower survived until the 1890s when it seems to have been demolished to make way for the construction of E Shed in 1894.

House located at the north corner of Pipe Lane and St. Augustine's Place. The building was a single bay jettied, gabled house of three storeys and attic and was of probable late seventeenth-century or early eighteenth-century date. The main entrance was on the eastern side of the ground-floor and there were two sashes to the west. The fenestration at first- and second-floors comsisted of single eight by eight pane sashes. There was a single (possible sash) window in the attic gable.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Merchant Venturers Technical College, Unity Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Grammar school located between Unity Street and St. Mark's the Lord Mayor's Chapel. The school building was originally built c.1590 for Queen Elizabeth's Hospital, but the school premises were swapped with those of Bristol Grammar School in 1766. Four ranges around a quadrangle. The exterior of the south-western range of 2 storeys and 11 bays, string course between the storeys, cross-windows, niche at first-floor in the middle bay. To the south-west, between the building and the houses fronting College Green, an open area, entered from Unity Street through a boundary wall via double gates on square panelled piers topped by ball finials. Steps led up to the entrance from Unity Street (see drawing by Holmes, BRSMG M2543).

KNOWN_AS: Warehouse and sail loft, Nos.18-20, Narrow Quay
MONUMENT_DESC: Warehouse and sail loft, Nos.18-20 Narrow Quay. The buildings housed a warehouse and sail lofts. The facade of the building was an arhythmic collection of doorways and windows which apparently represented the incorporation of a number of earlier buildings into an eighteenth-century facade. The crowns of three hipped pantiled roofs are visible behind the facade. There was also a narrow passage leading to The Shakespeare public house in Prince Street which was incorporated into the frontage and ran between the properties. The site is now void.

Queen Victoria Statue, College Green. The statue was unveiled by H. R. H. Duke of Clarence (son of the future Edward VII) on 25th July 1888. It stood at the edge of College Green until the postwar landscaping exercise. In February 1951 it was removed to the Corporation depot on Redcliff Wharf prior to an intended resiting on the Prince Street roundabout (Winstone 1964). In the event, however, the statue was restored and placed in its present (11/11/96) position.

No.64 Castle Street. Attached to both sides, on the east to a single-storey extension to No.63. 4 storeys and attic; 1-window range; jettied. Central entrance between shop windows. First-floor possibly jettied; bay with sashes. Second-floor jettied, decorative moulding along the front and a short distance onto the east return; bay with sashes. Sash to third-floor. Hipped roof with dormer to front. Lateral stack(s) against No.65 to the west.

Dr. Estlin's House at St. Michael's Hill. The exact location of the house is unknown, but Edward Cashin's drawing (BRSMG Mb6433) indicates that it probably lay on the west side of St. Michael's Hill.
The house was of probable seventeenth-century dtae and appears to have comprised three square blocks, joined corner to corner. Each block was of three storeys and attic, cross-gabled, the gables with finials. Assorted windows, 6-light mullion and transom, cross-window, or sash. Cashin also records some blocked openings, some string courses. There was a garden at the rear of the house. The external walls were mostly rendered in the early nineteenth century, but one garden elevation was bare rubble.
Braikenridge's notes record that the house was pulled down in October 1823.

KNOWN_AS: The Ship public house, Griffin Lane
MONUMENT_DESC: The Ship public house, located on the north side of Griffin Lane. Gable to the Lane. 2 storeys and attic; 1-window range; timber-framed front. Attached to the west. Square 2-storey porch projecting from left-hand side, open to south and east at ground-floor, sash window to front above, lean-to roof. Main entrance through porch. Bay window. 3-light windows to first-floor and attic. First-floor right-hand set forward slightly. Lateral stack a short distance in on east return. There may have been another lateral stack on the opposite wall. On the west side of the main block, about halfway back, was a small projection to eaves level. To the rear was a small extension of slightly increased height, with stacks between the two parts. The building was demolished to enable the construction of Perry Road in the late 1860s.

No.10 Dighton Street, located on the southern side of Dighton Street. Dighton Street had been laid out by 1742 and the house was apparently built between 1742 and 1772. In 1883 the building was occupied by a photographer, Hector Aylesbury.
The building was demolished in c.1962.

No.11 Dighton Street, located on the southern side of Dighton Street. Dighton Street had been laid out by 1742 and the house was apparently built between 1742 and 1772 when it was occupied by a Widow Price. In 1883 the building was occupied by one William Gough and in 1882-83 a bakehouse was built on the site (BRO Building Plans Vol.19 fo.52b). By 1913 William Alfred Baker, trunk repairer was based in the building. Baker became a motor engineer in 1915.
The building was demolished in c.1962.

No.12 Dighton Street, located on the southern side of Dighton Street. Dighton Street had been laid out by 1742 and the house was apparently built between 1742 and 1772 when it was occupied by one Rosanna Halston. In 1883 the building was occupied by P. Collins, accountant.
The building was demolished in c.1962.

No.13 Dighton Street, located on the southern side of Dighton Street. Dighton Street had been laid out by 1742 and the house was apparently built between 1742 and 1772 when it was occupied by Joseph Glascodine, carpenter. In 1883 the building was occupied by George Haddrell, tailor and by 1913 William Alfred Baker, trunk repairer was based in the building. Baker became a motor engineer in 1915.
The building was demolished in c.1962.
Chapel of St George, Broad Street.

E. Baily and Son Malthouse. The malt house was located on a site bounded by the northern end of Pennywell Lane and Little Ann Street and Eugene Street. It was recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map surveyed in 1883 and by the Goad fire insurance plan of August 1896 which records some of the internal layout of the building.

St. Peter's Pump conduit house, located on the north-western end of Peter Street, at the junction with Dolphin Street. The structure formed part of the No.5 Dolphin Street. It was constructed c.1766 as part of the redevelopment of Bridge Street, Dolphin Street and Union Street to the designs of Thomas Paty. The conduit house replaced the medieval St. Peter's Pump (BUAD 39M) after the Trustees of Bristol Bridge ordered the removal of the original well head at the west end of Peter Street in 1766, and stood 10 metres north-north-west of the original site.
The conduit head was a limestone ashlar structure which was open to Dolphin Street and Peter  Street, via a single semicircular-headed arch in each elevation. The elevations comprised rusticated ashlar piers, quoins and voussoirs, with a plat band above.
The pump was taken out of use by the Health Authority in 1887.

No.63 Castle Street, located on the west corner of Queen Street. Attached to No.64, adjacent to the west, by a single-storey extension on Castle Street. 3 storeys and attic; 2-window range; half-hipped roof. Entrance to right of centre, between shop windows. Cellar access beneath right-hand window. A street lamp on the corner above the ground-floor storey. First-floor apparently jettied. Two sashes each to first and second floors; one sash to attic.

KNOWN_AS: House at the junction of Narrow Plain and Tower Hill
MONUMENT_DESC: House located immediately south of the south-west corner of the churchyard of SS.Philip and Jacob, on the corner of Tower Hill. The western end of a row of houses that ran along Narrow Plain. Gabled to south, west, and probably also north; pantiled. Stack on north side. 3 storeys and attic; 1-window range to west elevation. Small ground-floor extension on west end, with right-hand entrance and a left-hand 3-light window; hipped pentice roof. Bay at first and second floors, each with a 12 over 12 pane sash; pentice roof. 3-light attic window. Details of the south elevation are unknown. The guttering discharged away from the building and its neighbours via long chutes. A street lamp at the northern end of the main west wall.
The Queen Street Ferry. The ferry was located at the end of a passage from the southern end of Queen Street and was set back slightly from the main waterfront.

Glass furnace or cone. On the south-west side of Avon Street, to the west of the end of New Kingsley Road. Part of the Phoenix Bottle Works in 1828. The cone was archaeologically excavated in 1988-1989 [also recorded as BUAD 714A].

The Baptist College, located on the north-eastern side of Woodland Road. The college was founded in 1679 and was based in Stokes Croft until the early eighteenth century.
The Woodland Road building was built between 1913 and 1915 to a design in a Tudor Gothic Revival style by Sir George Oatley. The college is a three-storey building of brick with limestone dressings, lateral stacks and a hipped roof. The building has an axial plan with a chapel on the north, and three rear service wings.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/10/350).
Glass furnace or cone. On the south-west side of Avon Street, to the south of the end of New Kingsley Road. Part of the Phoenix Bottle Works in 1828. Not archaeologically excavated.
Cooksons Bottle Works, located on the south-west side of Avon Street, on the north-west corner of Free Tank. The glass kiln was archaeologically excavated in 1988-89 (BUAD 343).

Nos. 73 & 74, Old Market Street. Attached. Immediately east of the 'Stag and Hounds', and, similarly, carried across the pavement, the fronts supported on a total of 5 pillars with bracket tops. 1-window ranges. Hipped roofs; clustered stacks on the party wall. 3 storeys with a modillion cornice to the parapet. Ground-floor details unclear. Canted bay to each first-floor, with sashes. Twin 6/6 pane sashes to second-floors.

No.72 Old Market Street. The building was a two-bay gabled house of three storeys and attic which was probably constructed in the seventeenth century.
At ground-floor the main elevation, north-west comprised a shopfront and the main entrance door was to the west of centre. There was a full-width pentice roof over ground-floor front with two-storey bays above. There were Ipswich windows to the first-floor, 8-light windows to the second. moulded strings above first and second floors. Central bay at attic, 8-light window. Two purlins to each side of roof.
The building was demolished for the construction of David Street.

No.36 West Street, Old Market. An attached house, with two ground-floor shops located on the south side of West Street. 2 storeys and double attic storey; 2-window range; gabled front. Ground-floor shops set forward, with shared pentice roof; adjacent entrances in the centre; in 1828 a currier, west, and a butcher, east. Pair of bays to first-floor, 6 lights to front of each; a 6 or 8-light window linking the bays. Pair of 2-light oriels to lower attic; single 1-light window (casement?) to upper attic in apex of roof. Stone lateral stack on east wall. Immediately east was a building whose ridge roof ran parallel to the street, and which also had a ground-floor similarly set forward and used as a shop.

The meal market on the south side of Wine Street, opposite Pithay. The market was built in 1570 (along with the two buildings which flanked its entrance), according to Adams's Chronicle, and was still extant at the time of Millerd's survey in 1673. The extent of the market can possibly be seen on the Ordnance Survey 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol sheet LXXI.16.25) of the early 1880s.

Nos.51 & 52, Broad Street. Attached. 3 storeys and roofs; gabled fronts; jettied. Each with bay to first-floor, transomed, 10 lights/2 lights. 8-light transomed windows to second-floors. No.51 with tall bracket at first-floor north end.
