No.18 Broad Street. Adjacent to the old Guildhall, on the upper side. Attached. 3 storeys and attic; front and side gables; fully jettied to front. Right-hand entrance; windows centre and left, the latter set slightly forward; cellar access below central windows; bracket at right end. First-floor full-width windows with transom, left end set forward as an oriel, 10-light/2-light; brackets below sill level of remainder, with about 24 lights, 2 or 4 to end; panelling beneath windows for whole width. Pair of oriels to second-floor, 8 and 2 lights each, 2 brackets below each; 2-light mullioned window to right return. Front attic window of probably 2 lights; side window of 2 lights, the one sub-divided. Front gable with 2 purlins each side. Side half-gable forward of front wall of Guildhall. 
Occupied by T. Fry, carver and print seller, 1806. Had once been occupied by one Parsley, tooth-puller to much of Bristol and area. In July 1831 Braikenridge noted that the front had just been removed to be replaced by a modern one.
Other illustrations of the right return against the Guildhall include M.2335 and M.2336.

No.3 Small Street. Attached to the south. C18 brick facade. 3 storeys and basement, 5 bays. Left-hand semicircular-arched entrance, enlarged keystone and imposts, fanlight over door, bootscraper in recess to right. Sash window with raised voussoirs, above cellar access flap in wall/pavement. Main entrance with rusticated piers, segmental-arched head below a broken pediment on brackets; one step up; bootscraper recesses each side. Two further windows with raised voussoirs at right-hand end, the left over another wall/pavement cellar access. In the two left-hand bays, between ground and first floors, a sign for 'THE BRISTOL FIRE OFFICE'. First and second floors each with 5 sash windows and raised voussoirs, 6/6 panes and 3/6 panes. Cornice and parapet; roof not visible, but most likely hipped. A single-storey wall to the north to the Copper Warehouse.

The Copper Company's warehouse, located on the south-western side of Small Street. The building measured 12.5 metres long by 6 metres wide. To the left, a semicircular-arched entrance up a few steps, possibly Venetian, as side openings apparent. Building of 2 storeys and attic with half-hipped roof, left-hand entrance and window to ground-floor, single window to first-floor, double doors to attic with roof projecting beyond.
The building had a large yard to the rear measuring 26 metres from north-east to south-west and 13 metres wide. It was extant in 1828 but had been demolished by the early 1880s.

No.22 High Street. The stone cellar of the building had a vaulted, moulded roof, and was recorded by the architect Thomas S. Pope c.1887. It was ascribed a fifteenth-century date by Pope because of the style of the mouldings (Pope 1881-84, 172-174).

Mereweather's Warehouse. The warehouse in 1827 of Mr. Mereweather the fruiterer, immediately behind No.10 St.Nicholas Street.
An arcade and a window in a room on the second-floor, the floor "supported by upwards of 25 immense beams placed not more than 2 feet asunder" (Braikenridge notes H60). The arcade as drawn consisted of 3 semicircular arches, but was incomplete, there being room for two more. In Transitional style. The arcade was in the west wall (1042A). 
The window, in the same room, was in the east wall (1043A). Early English in style. Rowbotham's drawing (M2490) also shows another window to its right (i.e. in the south wall).
There was also an old door in the loft of the same premises (1044A).

A pair of houses. Nos.26 & 27, King Street. Attached. One common 'half-hipped' roof, possibly rather two gables with their apexes linked. 3 storeys and attics; first and second floors possibly jettied; 2-window range. Adjacent entrances, 3 or 4-light sash windows beyond. Bays with sashes to first and second floors. Small attic windows.

No.28 King Street. The house appears to have been constructed in the seventeenth century and was a jettied, gabled structure of three-storeys and attic with a one-window range. There were a pair of entrances on the west side of the main, north-facing, elevation and the western of these openings contained a seventeenth-century panelled door. The fenestration at ground-floor level originally consisted of a ten-light transomed bay window. At first- and second-floor levels there was glazing across the full-width of the elevation and outer bay windows which had six-light windows in the front and two-light windows in the sides. The panels beneath the windows were decorated. There was an eight-light bay window in the gable at attic level and a pendant below the apex of gable. The building was recorded in a drawing by T. L. Rowbotham made in 1825 (BRSMG M2504) by which time the ground-floor bay had largely been removed. It was demolished in the late 1930s to enable the construction of the inner circuit road.

KNOWN_AS: House on the west side of Marsh Street
MONUMENT_DESC: House on the west side of Marsh Street. Attached. 3 storeys and attic; double-gabled front; jettied. Central entrance; 2 sash windows each side. Canted bays either end of first and second floors, 6 lights to fronts, 2 each to sides; pair of cross-windows between bays. Panelling below windows. Pentice roofs between bays. Bracket to central eaves. In each gable, an oculus with a sunburst decoration; pendants in apexes, carrying the date 1660. Lateral stacks.
Bristol Royal Infirmary Chapel on the southwest side of Whitson Street. Built between 1858 and 1860 and constructed of Pennant sandstone with freestone dressings.

No.3, Pembroke Place, located on the northern side of Johnny Ball Lane. The building was a rendered three-storey, two-bay house of Pennant sandstone in a random rubble construction. It was part of a terrace of four occupying the site of a formal garden of seventeenth-century date, and was built as part of a pair with No.4. The main elevation faced south-west. The entrance door was on the south-east side of the elevation. The fenestration at all levels consisted of recessed sash windows with ashlar stone cills. Above there was a brick parapet wall and cornice. Internally the basement plan consisted of two rooms, the kitchen at the front (south-west) and a second at the rear (north-east). There was a chimneybreast on the northern wall of the kitchen. Access to the basement was probably by a stair in the northern corner of the rear room, against the rear wall of the property. had a flagstone floor. In front of the building, between the house and Johnny Ball Lane, was the garden.
The house was first occupied c.1764 according to the St. James parish ratebooks and in 1775 it was occupied by a Widow Smith. The original sash windows were replaced in the nineteenth century with new sashes with horns and margin panes and the window openings appear to have been altered at the same time. The house was demolished in 1973.
The building was archaeologically excavated in 1999 (BUAD 3399).

KNOWN_AS: Lodge at the northern end of White Friars
MONUMENT_DESC: A lodge at the northern end of White Friars. The lodge was described as "late newly built" by Richard Cole in 1581 (BRO 35722/1/1).

A pair of houses, with ground-floor shops. Attached. C17 gabled houses, refronted. 3 storeys; roof not clearly visible; each a 1-window range. Projecting shopfronts with entrances at the outer ends. Bays to first-floors; a 2-light casement to each second-floor. Both cleared away before July 1948 (Street's notes).

A pair of houses, with ground-floor shops. Attached. C17, with M-shaped roof, of which the left half had been replaced (by an unidentified form of roof). 3 storeys and attics; 1/2-window ranges; lateral stacks. No.26 with a right-hand entrance leading to Wesley Place Passage (The New Room), then the shop entrance, with the shop window left. No.27 with a left-hand entrance. Pair of sashes to first and second floors of No.26, one to all 3 upper floors of No.27. Single sash to attic of No.26. Demolished c.1935 (Street's notes).

POSTAL_ADDRESS: St Michael's Primary School, Park Lane
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Michael's Church Boys' School. The school opened in 1840 as an Infants School for boys and girls and a Junior Boys' School. It had an L-shaped plan, with a small block within the angle between the wings. The majority of the building was a single-storey in height with a gabled roof. There were at least two dormers in the roof; and at elast two chimneystacks. There was also a bell-cote on the roof ridge.
The school was largely rebuilt in the 1890s, although the original gateways for Infants and Boys survive. A  freestone sculpture ('The Reader') in the north elevation of the existing building is possibly a reclaimed architectural piece of Renaisance date (Mary Wright, pers com).
No.42, Mary-le-Port Street, with ground-floor shop. Attached to east. 4 storeys and attic; half-hipped roof; first, second and third floors jettied; 1-window range.

No.20, Mary-le-Port Street, with ground-floor shop. Attached. 4 storeys; first-floor jettied; roof not recorded; 3-window range. Right-hand entrance to shop; shop window. Above, a C18-style facade, 3 storeys of 3 bays each, all sashes, a string beneath each storey; rusticated pilasters at each end.
Great Western Tannery, Gasferry Road. The tannery subsequently moved to St. Philip's but walls which possibly belong to the structure appear to survive.

Malt house, located on the north-western side of Gasferry Road. The building was constructed in 1896 for Bristol United Brewery Ltd. to a design by William Bradford. A fire in 1938 destroyed the roof of the building.

KNOWN_AS: The Old Police Station, Bridewell Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Police station, located on the east side of Bridewell Street, over the (culverted) course of the Frome. C19. Main building facing the street, with a yard to the rear, with flanking blocks to either side. A street elevation of 3 storeys and a 7-window range. Coursed Pennant Sandstone rubble with limestone dressings. Plinth; plat band above ground-floor; rusticated quoins. A central entrance with a square opening with stepped voussoirs below an arch within a square frame with rusticated quoins and voussoirs. Segmental-headed windows with enlarged keystones and shouldered architraves, all sashes. Decorative frieze beneath the cornice. Some stacks.

Gibb Slip, a wide slipway located at the end of Prince Street, later built over by the approach to the north pier of Prince Street Bridge. Braikenridge (Notes, G.12) states that the slip was where the corpses of the drowned were brought out of the water of the Floating Harbour.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Fairbairn Crane, Wapping Wharf, City Docks
MONUMENT_DESC: Fairbairn Steam Crane, located at the eastern end of Wapping Wharf. The Docks Committee accepted a tender from the Bath firm Stothert and Pitt for a Fairbairn Steam Crane in 1875 and by August in the following year construction was underway (Large, 1984 128; 133). It was completed in 1878. The steam operated jib, or swan-neck, crane stands on a semi-circular plinth projecting into the harbour at the eastern end of Wapping Wharf and has a well beneath it. With its 35-ton capacity, the crane was the most powerful in the City Docks when it was brought into use. The crane is still operational. It is a Scheduled Ancient Monument (SAM No. AV7).

KNOWN_AS: Crane towards southern end of Narrow Quay
MONUMENT_DESC: Hydraulic crane. On Narrow Quay, near its southern end. Fixed. On an obelisk-shaped base. A small cabin situated in an elevated position, forward of the central pillar, with a curved roof and windows to all sides. A small circular counter-weight (?) on the opposite end of the crane to the jib.

Lee's Marble and Slate Works, located at Anchor Lane, Canons Marsh. The works was founded by William Lee, c1863, and continued until 1913, when it was known as Arthur Lee & Bros.
The works conprised open yards, with gantries, and a rail-mounted hand-operated crane, a linear two-storey stone rubble building with gable ends. The works was probably replaced by the G.W.R. goods shed and/or yards.

KNOWN_AS: Crane in the Amphitheatre, Canons Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: A crane located on the dockside on Canon's Marsh. The crane was built c.1890 and consisted of a circular base of Pennant sandstone ashlar supporting a steam crane. The circular base survives and has a Grade II listing.

Ye Ould Friendship public house, No.27 Castle Green, located at the corner of Castle Green and Tower Street. The building was a four storey house, double-gabled on the Castle Green elevation, with a cellar, and attics in the top storey.
By the late-nineteenth century the building was a public house called "Ye Ould Friendship." The building was demolished in 1901.

The Friendship, a beer shop, or beer retailer, located on the south side of St. George's Road, partly above some of the "Thatched House" public house. Occupied the first-floor of a building at right-angles to the road. Two storeys and attic, hipped roof, three dormers to the west, one to the east, all with hipped roofs. Probably eighteenth-century in date.

Wesleyan Methodist burial ground, located on the north side of the Methodist Chapel in Redcross Street.
An Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852 restricted burial to members of the congregation and ordered that "only one body [was] to be buried in each grave."
The burial ground was redeveloped in the twentieth century.

KNOWN_AS: Air Raid Shelter to the rear of Oldbury House, St. Michael's Hill
MONUMENT_DESC: Air Raid Shelter, located at the rear of Oldbury House, St. Michael's Hill. The shelter is of brick with a flat reinforced concrete roof. The entrance is at the south-eastern corner of the shelter and is reached by an open passage formed by an external blast wall.

Lunsford House, Lower Park Row. The building was erected in the seventeenth century and the rear part of this structure survives. The seventeenth century structure is of a stone rubble construction, the walls being approximately 0.5 metres thick (R. Leech pers. comm.), and was given a new brick facade in the eighteenth century (Leech 2000, 117-120).

Tower View, Cantock's Close. The building is a small garden with an attached prospect tower built of Brandon Hill Grit looking out over the the southern slopes of St. Michael's Hill to the city. The ground floor of the tower is open to the garden which formerly surrounded it. The structure may have been built for Samuel Whitchurch.
Most of the archaeology of the garden is thought to have been removed by building works in the 1970s and 1990s (Leech, 2000 117).
Bristol Refinery. The sugar refinery was established by the Rogers Family in 1684.

A mound on the north side of the line of Civil War defences, close to the junction of St. Michael's Hill and Cotham Road. A mound in the garden of the Homepathic Hospital is thought to have been the remains of the redoubt.

A stone culvert or drain located on the southern side of the Bristol Cathedral School site which was recorded during a watching brief  in 1987 (BUAD 3292). The feature lay beneath the site of the lesser cloister of St. Augustine's Abbey, and was provisionally dated to the later twelfth century. It is aligned on an east-north-east to west-south-west alignment and a length of roughly 30 metres survives. Internally it measured 0.75 metres wide and the height varies between c.0.8 metres and 1.1 metres high. The walls of the drain are constructed of Brandon Hill Grit, bonded in various mortars as a result of later repointing. The earliest bonding was found to be by a red sandy mortar. Three small channels fed into the culvert on its northern side, while on the southern were three major outlets. It is believed that the drain was continually flushed by running water.
Access is by a manhole inserted through the roof where one of the capstones has been removed (Boore 1989, 220-221).

No.6 Kingsdown Parade. An extant building standing within a square garden plot which is recorded by Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 map of Bristol. The building is probably of late eighteenth- or early nineteenth-century date and replaced an earlier lodge garden recorded by Rocque's map of 1742 (BUAD 1239M). There appear to be similar plots with surviving, though derelict, structures adjacent. The level of survival of the associated garden deposits is unknown but if relatively undisturbed, as seems likely, would enhance the importance of the site.
The monument was considered Not Listable in the 1995 relisting exercise.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Former Graham's Timber Yard, Hotwell Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Engine House, Limekiln Dock. The building, referred to as "Engine House" on a plan of nineteenth-century date, was located to the west of Limekiln Dock and was constructed in the early to mid nineteenth-century. It was attached to the south end of the Old Mill building (BUAD 1378M). The building, measured 5.8 metres wide by 13 metres long and was aligned north-north-east to south-south-west. The walls were all approximately 0.6 metres wide, were constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble bonded in a grey-white lime mortar. An internal dividing wall in the centre of the building, also of Pennant sandstone, was bonded in a beige sandy mortar with charcoal flecks. A fireplace and brick arch were constructed between the1850s and 1880s to support a vertical boiler. Later the north wall of the building was knocked through during between the 1850s and 1880s to create a single large warehouse in combination with the Old Mill. The building was excavated in 1998 (BUAD 3398).

St. Matthew's School, Montague Place. The school was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition plan surveyed in 1883. The two-storey building is of Pennant sandstone rubble with ashlar dressings. The building is extant and is currently (16/10/2000) extant.

Burial ground, located on the east side of Portland Chapel, Portland Street, Kingsdown. An Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852 ordered that burials were "to be discontinued within five yards of Portland-street Wesleyan Chapel, in the parish of Westbury-on-Trym."

Royal Swimming Baths, Cotham. The swimming baths were located on the east side of Oxford Street, to the rear of the villas on the south side of Cotham Road South. The baths are recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition plan surveyed in 1883.

Smithy, Old Bread Street. The smithy was located on the north side of Old Bread Street, close to the Broad Plain Soap Works, and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Sheet LXXII.16.24) surveyed in 1883. The Goad fire insurance plan of August 1896 indicates that the smithy was producing chain.

Malthouse, Old Bread Street. The malthouse was located on the north side of Old Bread Street, close to the Broad Plain Soap Works, and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Sheet LXXII.16.24) surveyed in 1883. It was still extant at the time of the Goad fire insurance plan in August 1896.

KNOWN_AS: Bristol Distilling Company Ltd. Storehouses, Old Bread Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Bristol Distilling Company Ltd. Storehouses, Old Bread Street. The store houses were located on the south side of Old Bread Street, close to the distillery itself which lay on the south side of Cheese Lane [modern Avon Street]. The building is noted on the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Sheet LXXII.16.24) surveyed in 1883 which records it only as "Bristol Distillery".

School, Old Bread Street. The school was located on the south side of Old Bread Street, on the west side of the junction with Providence Place. It was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Sheet LXXII.16.24) surveyed in 1883 which noted it was for "Boys & Girls". The school was still extant at the time of the Goad fire insurance plan of August 1896.

KNOWN_AS: House on the west side of Marsh Street
MONUMENT_DESC: House on the west side of Marsh Street. Attached. 2 storeys and attic; gabled front; jettied; 1-window range. Recorded by O'Neill during the removal of the timber-framed front, by which time the front part of the roof had gone. Ground-floor obscured. First-floor jettied; twin window; bracket at north end. The front of the attic was jettied. Collar visible inside roof. There appear to have been two purlins on the north side of the roof.

The replica of the High cross, made in 1851, by John Norton. The carving of the structure was by Harry Hems of Exeter. It was built of Limestone ashlar (Anon., 1851 816).
The cross consists of a plinth with 4 statues of seated monarchs under canted hoods with ogee finials, pinnacles between, and a square spirelet with crocketed ribs and a foliate finial.
The original cross was removed to College Green in 1733, and again to Stourhead in 1768, where it still stands.
The foundation stone of the replica was laid at College Green in 1850, and the cross stood there until it was replaced by the statue of Queen Victoria in 1888. The truncated cross came to Berkeley Square in 1950.

Arch, or, rather, a series of 3 arches, forming a passage beneath a building that possessed windows of  no later than C17 date. One arch each end of the relatively short passage, a third in the middle. The two outer arches both four-centred, with Pennant Sandstone voussoirs. In a passage between the middle of Marsh Street and the Quay, but fronting neither, the arch apparently not visible except from the passage itself.

KNOWN_AS: House on the west side of Marsh Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
House on the west side of Marsh Street, opposite the bonded sugar warehouse of Messrs. Robert Bush & Son. Attached. 3 storeys and attic; gabled front; first and second floors jettied; a 1-window range. Two entrances to right-hand; 2 sashes. Oriels to first-floor, 10 lights to front, 2 lights to sides. Bay to second-floor, 5 lights, no transom, 1 light to side. Small window high in attic. Two purlins to each roof slope. 
Pulled down in 1822 and replaced by a warehouse (Braikenridge Notes, 13).

The parish church of St. Augustine the Less. The church was a daughter church of the adjacent Abbey of St. Augustine. It was located on a bluff overlooking the River Frome, on the southern edge of the eastern end of College Green.
West tower, nave and aisles, chancel, north porch. The church had a perpendicular three-stage tower at its west end with stair-turret spirelet. Pointed windows, also some circular multi-lobed windows. Window at east end of north aisle, other gables blank. Pinnacles to parapets; crosses atop the three eastern gables. Late seventeenth-century plasterwork to the chancel vault. Manning recorded 27 heraldic shields from monuments inside the church (M2527-M2530). The chancel lengthened 1708. Church extensively altered in 1823 and 1840. The church was damaged by enemy action in 1940 and a survey was made . It was closed in 1956, and demolished in 1962.
The site of the church was archaeologically excavated in 1983-84 (BUAD 1686) and the full plan recorded. Important assemblages of post-medieval human remains and grave furniture were recovered.

KNOWN_AS: Building at corner of St. Augustine's Churchyard
MONUMENT_DESC: Building at corner of St. Augustine's Churchyard. Of unknown original fuction, but a coal merchant's office later. On the outside of the angled north-east corner of St.Augustine's Churchyard. Single-storey; flat roof. Entrance and windows. Distantly recorded by Pine's 1824 drawing (M2525). O'Neill's 1824 drawing shows the Park End Coal Mine in occupation, presumably as an office (M2917).

No.68, Victoria Street, located on the east side of Victoria Street. The building was a house with a ground-floor shop and was of probable seventeenth century date. Attached. Hipped roof to front. 3 storeys; first-floor possibly jettied; 1-window range. Left-hand entrance; shop window. Wide sashes to first and second floors. The building was refronted in the late-eighteenth or early-nineteenth century. It was demolished for construction of the end of Church Lane.

No.70, Victoria Street, located on the east side of Victoria Street. The building was a house, with a ground-floor shop and was of probable seventeenth century date. Attached. 3 storeys, no attic storey; gabled front; jettied; 1-window range. Sashes to first and second floors. It was demolished for construction of the end of Church Lane.

No.21 West Street, located on the north side of West Street, Old Market. The building was a single-bay, jettied house of probable seventeenth-century date, and was constructed as the eastern of a pair of properties. By the late-nineteenth century the pair was in use as a single property. The ground-floor contained a shopfront. The fenestration at first-floor consisted of a pair of sash windows with a string course above. The attic storey contained a single sash with a collar above. Lateral chimneystacks.
The building was demolished and the street line set back, leaving the front of the now lies beneath the modern street.

No.23 West Street, located on the northern side of West Street, Old Market. The building was a single-bay jettied house of three storeys with a gabled pantile roof. It was probably constructed in later seventeenth- or early eighteenth century. The ground-floor contained a shopfront and by the nineteenth century had a central entrance with a shop window on either side. The fenestration at first-floor consisted of a single sash window. At second-floor there was a slightly narrower sash with a collar above. The pantiled roof had one purlin on each side and there were two lateral chimneystacks on east wall.
The building was later demolished and the street line set back, leaving the front beneath the modern street.

Tramway generating station, Temple Back, north corner of St. Philip's Bridge. 1899. By W. Curtis Green. For Bristol Tramways and Carriage Company. Red brick with limestone ashlar dressings. Open plan. Baroque style. 5 storeys. Tall pedimented end has a large Venetian window with a splayed, coffered central arch and narrow flanking windows. Splayed left-hand corner, which contains a small doorway. The side elevations are a 5-window range of sunken panels between brick pilasters, containing 3-light ground-floor windows below first-floor lunettes with Venetian windows to the third floor, and keyed oculi above. An inserted interior of c.1980.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: N.C.P. Multi-storey car park, Rupert Street
MONUMENT_DESC: The Lewin's Mead Brewery, operated by the Bristol United Brewery Ltd. Elevations to Lewins Mead and Rupert Street. Brick front to the south-east side of Lewins Mead. 2 storeys and a number of bays. To the ground-floor, segmental-arched  vehicle entrances, round-arched and square-headed windows, all the round-headed windows below pediments. Segmental-headed windows and blind openings to the first-floor. At least 2 pediments along the facade. The Rupert Street frontage not recorded.

Old Rownham Ferry. The Rownham Ferry is said to have been established by St. Augustine's Abbey in Bristol for the purposes of communication with their estate at Abbots Leigh. The ferry was moved upstream in about 1873 to allow construction of a realigned and enlarged entrance lock to Cumberland Basin.

New Rownham Ferry was constructed as a replacement for the medieval ferry [BUAD 919M], which was further downstream but was displaced by construction of the realigned and enlarged entrance lock to Cumberland Basin, c.1873. In use until 1932. Stone slipways at both sides of the river. At low tide the water was crossed by a temporary pontoon bridge consisting of planks carried on small boats. Both slipways survive, although buried beneath thick deposits of river silt (Winstone 1977, pls.212-213; 215; Winstone 1983, pl.418).

The Hope Chapel, of the Methodist New Connexion. The chapel was located on the north side of Castle Green. Designed by H. Crisp, it opened in May 1855 with seating for 800. A schoolroom and vestries were attached (Major, 1872 100).
The building had a two-storey front in the Italian style, five-window range, with a wide central bay of  three windows breaking forward. Banded rustication to the ground-floor; string; cornice and short parapet. 3 round-arched openings to centre of ground-floor, the middle taller, leading into a porch; 1 round-arched window to either side. Five round-arched first-floor windows. The frontage was set back from street, with railings to the pavement. It may be presumed to have had a gallery.

The City Saw Mill, Canon's Marsh. The saw mill was built in the nineteenth century and was recorded by the 1st edition Ordnance Survey map of the early 1880s. The north-east corner of the monument was excavated in 1997 (BUAD 3276). It was found to have been built of Pennant sandstone and brick and had been the subject of frequent alteration and renewal; within the rooms the floors had been successively replaced on several occasions. There was also evidence for the insertion of bases for machinery.

Francis Burial Ground, located on the northern side of Waterloo Road, Old Market. A private burial ground located on the northern side of Waterloo Road, the cemetery was opened in the early nineteenth century and is recorded by Plumley and Ashmead's map of 1828. At this date it measured 62.5 metres from south-east to north west and was 12.5 metres wide. In 1850 the burial ground was reported to be full (Clark 1850, 159) and interment there was ended by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852.
By 1883 a brass foundry had been erected on the site. It is not known whether the burial ground was cleared before redevelopment but undisturbed inhumations are likely to survive within the site.

West Street Gate. A turnpike gate and associated toll house at the eastern end of West Street, Old Market which is recorded by Plumley and Ashmead's survey of the city in 1828. The gate lay to the south of the house.
The site of both now lies beneath the island at the east end of Clarence Road.

Nos. 56 and 57 Wine Street. The buildings were located on the south side of the street. They appear to have been built as part of a single development and there is were apparently continuous string lines across both frontages. The four-storey gabled buildings each had a single bay, although between them had three bays. The central bay was over Guardhouse Passage. The ground floor formed a shop front. There were casements at first floor level and bay windows with sashes at second floor. In each of the gables was a small sash window. The roofs were pantiled.
No.56 (NGR ST 58954 73078)
No.57 (NGR ST 58957 73077)

No.18 Wine Street. The building had three-storeys and two bays. The ground floor was a shopfront. The building was rebuilt or refronted in the eighteenth- or nineteenth-century. The windows at first and second floor were sashes. A sign over the door, in the centre of the facade showed a boar.

No.22 Merchant Street. This medieval building stood in the centre of the street known as Quaker's Friars (slightly north of, and on the opposite side to, the Merchant Taylor's Almshouse), leaving a narrow pavement and cobbled road surface on either side. It was a three-storey, gabled building with a single bay. The ground floor was a shopfront, the main entrance being on the north side of the frontage with a large window forming the remainder, and there were sash windows at first and second storey, the upper being an attic storey. The cross-gable roof was pantiled. The building had been demolished by the early 1880s.

The statue of Edward Colston, standing in Colston Avenue. The statue was erected by public subscription organised by J. W. Arrowsmith and was unveiled by the Lord Mayor of Bristol on 13 November 1895. It was sculpted by John Cassidy of Manchester (Merritt, 2002 30-31). The bronze statue stands on a stone plinth decorated with bronzes plaques. The south-facing plaque carries the inscription "Edward Colston. Born 1636. Died 1721." The statue was moved to the north of its original position in March 1958 when a new road layout was created in the Centre.
The statue has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/11/555).

KNOWN_AS: House at the corner of St. Michael's Hill and Church Lane
MONUMENT_DESC: House at the south-east corner of (Lower) Church Lane and St. Michael's Hill. The house of seventeenth-century date was attached to the south-east and was of two storeys and attic; gabled front; jettied; 1-window range; full-width pentice roofs to front. Left-hand entrance between two C17 posts; large window. 8/8 pane sash to first-floor; 6/6 pane sash to attic. Cellar access below ground-floor window. It was occupied by Robert Chidgey, mason, in 1826.

No.14 Peter Street. Attached. 3 storeys and roof, no apparent attic storey; first-floor jettied; gabled front. Shop windows with entrance right of centre. Full-width bays to first and second floors, 10 lights to the former, Ipswich window with flanking lights to the latter. There were large bargeboards with pendant, below which a painting of a chinaman with tea chests indicated the premises to be in use as a tea dealer and grocer.

No.15 Peter Street. Attached. 4 storeys; attic with no window; 2-window range; half-hipped front; jettied; lateral stacks on east wall. Shop windows with entrance to right of centre, cellar access below left window. Wide first-floor window, comprising 2 wider sashes and a central narrow sash, separated by mullions. 12-light transomed second-floor window. A pair of cross-windows to the third-floor.

No.1 Castle Street, located at the western end of Castle Street. The building was a gabled house of three storeys and attic with a 1-window range of likely late seventeenth-century date. By the early-nineteenth century the main, south-facing, elevation comprised a shopfront at ground-floor shop with a central entrance between the shop windows. There was an oriel window at first-floor, with the other windows being sashes. The fenestration at second-floor consisted of sashes. There was a dormer on the east side of roof.
In the notes accompanying a drawing of the building G. W. Braikenridge records that the building stood on the site of the old "Ella Gate" (Braikenridge Notes F24).

Nos.40-42 West Street, Old Market. An attached house, or possibly a pair of houses, located on the south side of West Street. 2 storeys and attic; twin gables to front, the gables stopping short of the full frontage; 2-window range; gabled west end constructed of coursed rubble, stone stack on gable. As with the adjacent buildings, the ground-floor was set forward with a pentice roof, a central entrance and shop windows either side. Sash window to left at first-floor, 6-light window to right. 2-light window to each front gable.

No.44 West Street, Old Market. A pair of attached houses located on the south side of West Street. 2 storeys and attics; each a 1-window range; gabled front. Ground-floors set forward with pentice roofs; pair of adjacent entrances, one window to each side. 6-light window to first-floors. Attic windows not clearly recorded.

The Black Horse,  located on the south side of West Street, now on the south-west side of the corner of West Street with Waterloo Street. The Black Horse is recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol.
The building was attached. 2 storeys and attics; double-gabled front; 2-window range. Ground-floor raised above what is probably a high cellar but could be a sunken ground-floor. Twin sashes to the raised storey. Full-width pentice roof over. First-floor segmental-headed sash windows. Cross-windows to attic, with some timber-framing visible to the front. Lateral stack on west wall, with twin pots. The building was rebuilt on the same site to form the present building.

St. Mary-le-port Churchyard, located on the south side of St. Mary-le-Port Church and the same length as church. The churchyard was bounded to east, west and south by alleys and by the nineteenth century was  by a tall rubble wall on the south side, with lower walls with railings at the east and west ends. The entrance was from the west via double gates between square rusticated piers.
The churchyard was closed to burials by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852. The churchyard was largely destroyed by the early 1960s construction of the Norwich Union offices.
The Welsh Independent Chapel, located on the west side of Lower Castle Street. The building appears to have been a converted house.
No.9 Broad Quay.

Stuart House, located on the north-east side of Royal Fort House.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/10/305).

St. Mark's Hospital, otherwise known as Gaunt's Hospital, located on the east side of College Green. The hospital was founded by Maurice de Gaunt sometime before his death in 1230, with a brief to feed one hundred poor people daily. The hospital was initially administered by St. Augustine's Abbey, but was made a separate foundation by Robert de Gurnay, Maurice de Gaunt's nephew and heir, in 1232 (Ross 1959, 5). The hospital was Benedictine and the charter of 1232 specified that the community comprised the master, four chaplains and eight clerks.
The precinct extended between College Green along the line of modern Unity Street, to Pipe Lane where the corner of the boundary was marked by two plaques bearing winged lions and a small niche (presumably for a figure of the Virgin or other statue) on the exterior walls of No.9 Pipe Lane. The hospital complex consisted of a church (BUAD 93M) with a cloister on its north side. The hospital was involved in a series of disputes with St. Augustine's Abbey from the early-thirteenth century. These involved use of College Green  on which the hospital had grazed its animals and buried some of its dead (Ross 1959, 7-10). In 1491 the Abbey of St. Augustine claimed that the hospital fell within its manorial jurisdiction, beginning another long dispute in which the Bristol authorities became involved.
In 1534 the hospital community had five members. Four brothers and the master, John Colman, were still present at the time of the hospital's dissolution on 9th December 1539. The church plate was sent to London in February 1540 and the Hospital and its lands were acquired by the Bristol Corporation in May 1541.

The open-air preaching pulpit on College Green. Use of the pulpit was particularly noteworthy in the 1520s and 1530s when it was frequently used by reformers. William Tyndale also preached there while he was acting as a private tutor at Old Sodbury.

KNOWN_AS: White Hart Inn, Jacobs Wells Road
POSTAL_ADDRESS: St Peter's House, Jacob's Wells Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
The White Hart Inn at the foot of Jacob's Wells Road. The structure was a three-storey, three-bay gabled building with large chimney stacks at the north and south ends and a pantile roof. In the centre of the east front of the building was the entrance, over which a gabled first floor room projected (Winstone 1987, pl.58). The building was cut into the hillside slightly at its northern end. It is possible that the fabric of the building was largely medieval and that this was concealed behind later alterations.
The building was demolished in 1877 to make way for the construction of St. Peter's Church (BUAD 513M).

KNOWN_AS: Church of St. Peter, Jacob's Wells Road
POSTAL_ADDRESS: St Peter's House, Jacob's Wells Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Peter's Church at the foot of Jacob's Wells Road, now beneath St. Peter's House. The church was built in 1882 on the site of the White Hart Inn.
The stone church was built in a Romanesque style and had an apse at its north-east end with seven tall, evenly-spaced lancet arches forming the fenestration. On the south-east side of the nave was a row of romanesque arches. The buttressed square bell tower stood at the south-east end of the nave. This had three-storeys with a round-headed arch in the north-east face at ground floor level and tall lancet arches above, one in the first floor and three in the second. The tower had a pyramidal hipped roof.
The church was demolished in January and February 1939.

The Water Fort, located at the foot of the south side of Brandon Hill. The fort was constructed in 1642 as part of the defensive line protecting the northern side of Bristol. In July 1643 there were two cannon, recorded as Minions (Roy 1975, 261), within the fort.

A possible Civil War redoubt in the King's Orchard, on the south side of the entrance to the moat of Bristol castle from the river Avon. A mound shown on Millerd's 1673 map of Bristol has been interpreted as the site of a redoubt noted by de Gomme, the Royalist engineer, "towards the south [of the castle] next the River...".

The garden of the Great House built by Sir John Young on the site of the Carmelite Friary. The garden, apparently walled and raised above the level of the courtyard of the main house, lay to the north of the house, its northern edge against Trenchard Lane. This original garden seems to have survived as long as the house itself, although the planting scheme is unknown.
After the construction of the house was complete Sir John Young began a piecemeal acquisition of plots on the north side of Trenchard Street to create a large garden on the hillside above the house (Roger Leech pers. comm.). Two lodges, the Red Lodge and the White Lodge marked the northern corners of this garden.
The gardens were developed for housing in the later eighteenth century. A small part survives as the garden of the Red Lodge, and a replica Elizabethan formal garden has been established there.
The Bank of England building at No.13/14, Broad Street. Designed by Cockerell. Superceded in its original purpose by the building on the corner of Wine and High Streets.

Somerset Square, off the southern side of Prewett Street. Four-sided but not rectangular. Laid out in the 18th. century. At its centre is a fountain (BUAD 849M). The buildings surrounding the square were badly damaged during the Second World War,. The remaining houses were subsequently removed.

No.55 Frogmore Street. The building, which stood on the north side of Frogmore Street, was a three-storey single-bay building with a pantiled roof and a front gable. The ground floor was a shopfront with an entrance door on the east side. There were sash windows toward the east side of the frontage. The windows in the upper storey was a bay.
The house was demolished in the mid-1960s to make way for the construction of the NCP Car Park and Bristol Entertainment Centre.

No.57 Frogmore Street. The building, which stood on the north side of Frogmore Street, was a three-storey single-bay building with a pantiled roof and a front gable. The ground floor was a shopfront with an entrance door on the east side. There were sash windows in the first and second floors.
The house was demolished in the mid-1960s to make way for the construction of the NCP Car Park and Bristol Entertainment Centre.

No.59 Frogmore Street. The building, which stood on the north side of Frogmore Street, was a three-storey single-bay building with a pantiled roof and a front gable. The ground floor was a shopfront with an entrance door on the west side. There was a sash window in the first floor and a casement in the upper floor. A small pentice spanned the width of the gable end.
The house was demolished in the mid-1960s to make way for the construction of the NCP Car Park and Bristol Entertainment Centre.

No.61 Frogmore Street. The building, which stood on the north side of Frogmore Street, was a three-storey single-bay building with a front gable and a pantiled roof. The ground floor was a shopfront with the jettied first floor above. There was a double sash window in the first floor at the west end of the frontage. The first floor extends beyond the east frontage of the building and had a pentice above it. There is a casement in the gable end of the upper floor.
The house was demolished in the mid-1960s to make way for the construction of the NCP Car Park and Bristol Entertainment Centre.

The Old Fox public house, No.70 Redcliff Street.  The building was a four-storey, single-bay jettied house with a pantile roof with a front gable. The ground floor had a three large 5x4 windows and the entrance doorway was on the north side. There was a full-width slate tiled pentice separating the ground and first floors, and the first and second floors contained bay windows, each with casements in the upper half. A full-width pantiled pentice separated the second from the attic storey. There was a small, two-light casement in the gable end. There was a cellar entrance in the pavement in the centre of the frontage of the building.
The Old Fox was demolished in the late nineteenth-century during the widening of Redcliff Street.

No.26 St. Thomas Street, located on the corner of St. Thomas Street and Long Row, was a four-storey, single-bay house with a pantile roof and a front gable. The ground floor was a shopfront with the entrance on the north side, and the building had bay windows at first and second floors. There was a small sash in the gable end.

No.27 St. Thomas Street, located on the east side of St. Thomas Street, was a four-storey, single-bay building with a front gable and a pantile roof. The ground floor was a shopfront. A full-width pentice separated the ground and first floors and there was a bay window at first floor level. There was a plain sash at second floor and another full-width pentice divided the second and attic floors. There was a small casement in the gable end.

Bristol General Hospital in Guinea Street and overlooking Bathurst Basin. The hospital was buit between 1853 and 1857 and was designed by the architects Gyngell and Lysaght. The ground floor was designed to form warehouses to enable the generation of revenue from shipping.
The Hospital, the Hospital Lodge and the piers and gates are listed separately (all Grade II).

No.9 Pithay. The building was located on the west side of Pithay at the corner of Pithay and All Saints Street. It was a three-storey, single-bay jettied house with a front gable and pantile roof. The entrance doorway was on the south side of the frontage and there was a two-window range at first floor. There was a sash at second floor level.
The building was demolished at the end of the nineteenth-century and a new house erected on the plot.

No.22 Pithay, "The Friendship" (preumably a beer shop, the licensee being listed as a beer retailer in the 1880 directory). The building was located on the east side of Pithay, opposite the junction of Pithay and All Saint's Street.
The building was a three-storey, two-bay house with front gables and pantile roof. The ground floor formed the front of the public house. A full-width pantiled pentice roof separated the ground and first floors. There was a bay window in the east bay and a further full-width pentice above this. Again the pentice was pantiled. In each of the gable ends was a sash window.
The building was demolished at the end of the nineteenth-century although it was extant in January 1887.

No.34 West Street, St. Philips, located on the south side of West Street. The building was a three-storey, two-bay house with a pantiled cross-gabled roof. The ground floor of the main, north-west facing, elevation comprised a shopfront, with two centrally-placed doorways (giving the impression that the ground floor was originally two shops which had been made into one). There were bay windows in each of the first floor bays and smaller bays in the gable end. A chimney stack projected from either end of the ridge of the roof. In the early twentieth century the ground floor was the Star Dining Rooms. The building had been demolished by the 1960s.

KNOWN_AS: Crown and Mill, 3 Castle Mill Street
MONUMENT_DESC: The Crown and Mill public house, No.3 Castle Mill Street. The building was located in the north side of the street and was a three-storey, single-bay building with a front gable. The ground floor had a shopfront type window, while the first and second floors contained sashes.

No.4 Castle Mill Street. The building, which stood on the north side of the street, was a four-storey, single-bay building with a front gable and pantiled roof. The ground floor was a shopfront and the first and second floors were a two-window range; the sashes were placed together in the centre of each storey. There was a small sash in the gable end.
The building was demolished at the end of the nineteenth-century.

No.5 Castle Mill Street. The building, which stood on the north side of the street, was a four-storey, single-bay jettied house with a front gable and pantiled roof. The ground floor was a shopfront. There was a two-window range at first and second floors. The windows in the second storey were casements. There was a small casement in the gable end.
The building was demolished at the end of the nineteenth-century.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Canon's Marsh Gas Works, Canon's Road
MONUMENT_DESC: A rope walk recorded on the east side of the Canon's Marsh Oil Gas Works by Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 map of Bristol. The rope walk was developed as part of the gas works in the mid-nineteenth century.

Abyndon's Inn, All Saints' Lane. The date of building is not known but a document of 1390 refers to "le Niewynne". It was known as Abyndon's Inn by the fifteenth century. It passed through several hands and was rebuilt in the eighteenth century (Leech, 1997 2). The medieval form of the building has been lost although the thickness of a wall in the Market Tavern suggests that a medieval, possibly even a Norman, wall survives.

KNOWN_AS: Archway and Gates to Temple Church
MONUMENT_DESC: Archway and gates to Temple Church. Adjacent to the north side of No.58, Victoria Street. Mid-C19. Portland Stone and wrought-iron, in Gothic Revival style. Screen with 3 pointed archways, the middle taller.

Gillows Inn. The inn occupied roughly the area of St. Nicholas Market with an entrance off St. Nicholas Street. It was in existence by 1468 when it was part of the estate of Sir Walter Rodney, and ownership subsequently passed through several hands. The site was extensive and there are references in sixteenth century to a stables and tenements. The site was cleared c.1740 to enable the building of the Exchange and the new market behind.
Cellars of the inn survive beneath the The Crown Inn in All Saints' Lane. Other elements of the inn and its associated buildings are likely to survive below ground.

KNOWN_AS: Tenement north of The Old Fox Public House
MONUMENT_DESC:
A tenement on the north side of The Old Fox, Redcliff Street. The tenement (Structure 1) was of late-twelfth or early thirteenth-century date and was archaeologically excavated in 1982 [BUAD 467]. It was a stone-founded and comprised two ranges, one fronting on to the east side of Redcliff Street and the other to the rear. Within the building was a hearth of pitched Pennant sandstone slabs [603A].
The building was probably destroyed by the development of No.70, Redcliff Street.

The open space known as College Green. The land belonged to St. Augustine's Abbey and was used as the cemetery for the abbey according to documents of the thirteenth-century. It was the subject of disputes between the abbey and the neighbouring Hospital of St. Mark in the thirteenth- and fifteenth-centuries which were over access and grazing. The disputes were only settled by the intervention of the Bishop of Worcester. An open-air pulpit (BUAD 510M) was located in the centre of the green and the chapel of St. Jordan (BUAD 1058M) was located towards the abbey.
The green was transferred to the ownership of the Dean and Chapter after the dissolution. The 1880s Ordnance Survey map shows avenues running away from the centre of the green. A replica of the High Cross was erected at the end of the nineteenth-century. Deanery Road was pushed in front of the cathedral in the late nineteenth-century, dividing it from the green. Part of the area on the northern sides were destroyed by the construction of the new Council House through the 1930s and during the Second World War two air-raid shelters were dug across its centre. In the 1950s the green was landscaped: the trees around its edge were removed and the level of the ground apparently lowered. A refurbishment scheme removed Deanery Road and landscaped the area around the Queen Victoria statue in the early 1990s.

The Sugar House, Lewin's Mead. The earliest record of sugar refining in Lewins Mead is from 1684 and the present sugar house appears to have been founded in 1728 when it was occupied by a Mr. Reed. The site is occupied by a complex of buildings including the former a sugar refinery and a warehouse. The group consists of a front range constructed in 1922 against Narrow Lewins Mead (in a mock early eighteenth-century style), while to its north is the former refinery building, constructed in the early nineteenth century. To the rear of this is the former boiler house and engine room with the chimey surviving. This range is separated by a courtyard from a warehouse which probably predates all the other buildings on the site and may have been constructed in the late eighteenth century. The refinery passed through several hands before sugar production ceased on this site in 1832. The buildings were subsequently used as a warehouse by W. O. Budd who manufactured snuff and tobacco.
There is apparently no surviving evidence above ground on the site for sugar refining of the seventeenth century. The buildings are currently (26/7/99) undergoing renovation for future use as a hotel.

The Canon's Marsh Gas Works, located on the southern side of Anchor Road in Canon's Marsh. The history of gas works was assessed by Manco (Manco "Historical Background" in Gilmore Hankey Kirke 1995) but this account was superceded by the results of a programme of work on the site by RemedX in 1998. This included a review of the documentary history of the site and full rectified photogrammetric survey of the surviving buildings (BUAD 3339). A watching brief was also undertaken in 1998 during groundworks on the site of the Governor House (Erskine 1998).
Six phases of development were identified the RemedX study (RemedX 1998). During the first phase, from 1824 to 1836, The gas works was created by the Bristol and Clifton Oil Gas Company to produce gas from oil, primarily whale oil. The Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 map of Bristol indicates that the gas works initially occupied only the plot against the east side of Gasferry Road. The production process was housed in a single retort house towards the north end of the site, with a single stone rubble gasholder with a domed roof to the south of this. The upper part of this structure is recorded in a painting of 1837 by W. J. Muller showing Bristol from Clifton Wood (Bristol Museum and Art Gallery K1542). There was also a range of outbuildings. During Phase 2, between 1836 and 1841, the gas works was converted from oil gas to coal gas production when the former became uneconomic. The retort house was modified with new equipment and the range of outbuildings converted into a purifier house. The only surviving fabric from the first two phases of activity is part of the boundary wall along Gasferry Road. During the third phase, 1841 to 1848, the plant was modernised and expanded. Amongst other changes, the site of the ropewalk (BUAD 1282M) on the east side of the gas works was acquired and a larger coal store built there. A new underground Tar and Liquor tank was constructed and new lime purifiers were installed in the purifier house. On the south side of the site, by the north side of Canon's Road, two new gasholders were constructed, as was a landing place for unloading coal was created. In Phase 4, 1848-1860, another acre of land was purchased on the east side of the works and new offices, the main elevation of which is extant in the boundary wall on Canons Road, were constructed overlooking the Floating Harbour. This five-bay building was only a single storey in height. A new gasholder was also built on the newly-acquired land and the Phase 3 coal store converted to a retort house. The Phase 1 gasometer house meanwhile was converted to a purifier house. In 1853 the company was amalgamated with the Bristol Gas Light Company (which operated the Avon Street gas works) to form the Bristol United Gas Company. Phase 5, 1860 to 1870, saw further expansion of the site. The plot on the west side of Gasferry Road was purchased in 1860 and a new purifier house and gasholder erected there. The Phase 1 retort house and gasometer house were demolished along with the Phase 3 gasometers by Canon's Road. The eastern of these was roofed with brick arches to form a new underground liquor tank. Phase 6, 1870-1949, saw the acquisition of more land to the east of the plant. Germaine's timber yard was purchased in 1870 and a second block of land to the east of this probably in the mid- to late-1940s. A new gasholder (No.3) and a new retort house were built, the latter in two phases but completed by 1886. During the twentieth century a carburetted water gas plant, a concentrated liquor plant and a benzole plant were installed. A new jetty for unloading coal from the Floating Harbour was also created. Gas production at the site continued into the post-war period but by 1970 the works were derelict and in 1972 a number of the buildings were demolished.
What remains above ground of the buildings of the first three phases of the gas works is represented in the boundary wall of the site. The buildings on the west side of Gasferry Road, the purifier (ST 57903 72530), the No.1 gas holder (ST 57935 72530) and engine house (ST 57937 72498), date to between 1848 and 1860 but the majority of the surviving structures, almost all to the east of Gasferry Road, date to the period after 1870. These include the purifier house and its 1886 extension (ST 57990 72521), the No.3 gasholder towards the east end of the site (ST 58102 72507), the retort house (ST 58072 72440) and coal store (ST 58085 72473) of 1870 and the engine and dynamo house of 1908 (ST 58033 72487).
The purifier houses, retort house and boundary wall have a Grade II listing (Listed Building numbers 501, 504, 508). The remaining elements of the office building are now considered not to be listable. The ground around the gas works was heavily contaminated and was remediated in 2005.
A medieval tenement, identified as Tenement B, which was recorded during archaeological excavation at Nos.76-96 Victoria Street in 1996 (BUAD 88).

The Bishop's College located on the north side of Queens Road. C19. Neo-Tudor style. Projecting middle block of 3 bays with central entrance beneath a 3-storey tower. Main elevation of 2 storeys, with attic storey with gabled dormers. Set back from the north side of Queens Road, with a left-hand range extending southwards. Anglican college (1839), later a volunteers' club, with a drill hall (Mon.No.67M) behind, then became in 1888 the Salisbury Club. Removed for the 1905 Art Gallery, although part of the site is now below the western side of the Wills Memorial Building of Bristol University.

No.29, Park Row. C19. A tall 4-storey warehouse with lower 3-storey flanking ranges. Pennant Sandstone with limestone dressings. A central block of 3 storeys and attic, 3-window range. Ground-floor of 3 linked round-arched openings, 2 windows and a central entrance, all with moulded architraves and enlarged keystones. 3 sashes each to the first and second floors. Cornice, above which a small gable with oculus window, flanked by short parapets. To the left, a much lower, but contemporary, range, with single segmental-headed ground-floor opening. Triple segmental-headed first-floor window, that above being a double; parapet above a simple cornice. The right-hand range similar, but with a round-headed entrance between its ground-floor window and the main range. A steam carpet beating company were here in 1893 and into the 1930s. Later occupied by Newbery & Spindler, house furnishers, and now (1996) by the audio-visual department of Bristol University.

The Penn Street School, on the south side of the Penn Street Tabernacle. It was single-storey pedimented building with three bays built in 1834. There was a large arched window in the central bay while there were two entrances (also with pediments), one marked "Boys" and the other "Girls." The date "1834" was inscribed in the centre of the pediment. The building later became a Welsh Congregational Church. It was demolished in October 1957 to make way for the post-war redevelopment of Broadmead.

Cotham House. The house stands on the south side of Cotham Hill. A building on the site is recorded by Rocque's 1742 map and this seems to have been rebuilt in the mid-nineteenth century. The Ordnance Survey 1st Edition map records an extensive and formally laid out garden extending to Tyndall's Park Road. The house was bought and refurbished by Sir George White at the beginning of the twentieth century and subsequently became part of the Homeopathic Hospital.
The two-storey house, of Limestone ashlar, has a double depth plan and cellar. The interior created by Sir George White apparently survives "fine and complete" according to the listing details.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building Number 1158).

KNOWN_AS: Medieval industrial building, St. Thomas Street
MONUMENT_DESC: An industrial building dating to the late fourteenth or early fifteenth century excavated at the corner of St. Thomas Street and Portwall Lane in 1989 (BUAD 451; 353A). The outer walls of the building lay beyond the excavated area but the recorded evidence proved that the building was divided into at least four rooms and rendered. The partition walls were of Pennant sandstone, bonded in orange mortar, and plaster render survived on the face of the northern wall. On the earthen floors within the building burnt material and fragments of fired clay moulds which had been used for casting bronze (or other copper alloy) artefacts (Good, 1989 20). The building was demolished in the sixteenth century.

Clifton Poor Law Union Workhouse, located on the eastern side of Church Lane, Clifton. The building was constructed c1835. The footprint of the building measured 25 metres east-west by 14 metres from north to south. The institution remained on the site until 1849 when it was moved to Eastville and the building was subsequently occupied by the Clifton Wood Certified Industrial Training School for Boys, also known as Clifton Industrial School. The building was a three-storey structure and the main, south-facing, elevation was of nine bays. The Mardyke School moved into the building around the beginning of the twentieth century and is survived into the 1920s but was subsequently demolished.

KNOWN_AS: Royal Observer Corps Control Centre, King Square Avenue
MONUMENT_DESC:
Royal Observer Corps Control Centre, located on the south-western side of King Square Avenue. The structure appears to have been constructed during the Second World War and was the headquarters for 12 Group Anti-Aircraft artillery. It was principally constructed of timber and comprised an entrance area, operations room, offices and lecture room. The operations room was two storeys high while the ermainder was all of one storey. There was also a small detached structure, perhaps a store.
The building was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped.

The Mansion House, located at the north-east corner of Queen Square. The building had apparently been constructed by the 1730s and was a five-bay three-storey building with a hipped roof. The main entrance door was in the central bay of the elevation. The fenestration consisted of sashes. On the east side of the centre bay there were pilasters at each storey and ashlar quions at its eastern corner. On the southern slope of the roof there were three small dormers. The side, east-facing, elevation was very plain, with an arched doorway at the north end and windows adjacent and at the south end. There were smaller windows at the centre of the elevation, between ground- and first-floor and between first- and second-floor, presumably lighting a stair. Above the coping at the top of the elevation there were two tall chimney stacks (BUAD 1346) (Greenacre & Stoddard 1986, 25).
The building was bought by the Bristol Corporation in 1786 to provide the official residence of the Mayor and was known as the Mansion House from then on. The building was apparently refitted for this purpose, apparently including a "large turtle tubb" in which to keep live imported turtles before their consumption (Hudson 1993). As a symbol of the Corporation the building was the target of demonstrations in Queen Square on several occasions. It was ultimately destroyed by fire during the riots of 29-31 October 1831 apparently leaving only parts of the shell.walls standing (BUAD 1347).

Western Counties Agricultural Co-operative Association Mill Offices, located on the eastern side of the junction of Freshford Lane and Redcliff Backs, Redcliff. The building is a cellared three-storey brick structure with a hipped slate roof. It was constructed to a design by W. V. Gough in 1897 and opened in 1898.

A pond at the south-west corner of the meadow known as Temple Meads. The site of the pond lies beneath the northern wall of Brunel's Old Station. Its function is unknown, but it was apparently connected to the drainage ditches surrounding the meadow and may therefore have been designed to water cattle or simply to collect excess water.

No.2 Cherry Lane, located on the eastern side of the junction of Cherry Lane and Barton Street. The building was a two-storey, single bay house and was in existence by c1757 when the first occupant was assessed for Land Tax. The building had an associated coach house, presumably to the north, and additional structures had apparently been constructed by the following year (Bryant 2003, 5). The accommodation appears to have been enlarged by the mid-1760s and this may represent the construction of the large stable building at the junction of Barton Street and Charles Street (BUAD 1490M). It had been purchased by Henry Gwyer by 1851 (BRO 04250(1)) and was in use as a shop by 1896 (Bryant 2003, 6). The house was still extant in 1913 but it had been demolished by 1923 and the site redeveloped as a mason's yard.

The Royal Western Hotel, St. George's Road. The building was constructed as a hotel between 1838 and 1840 by Isambard Kingdom Brunel, to a design by R. S. Pope. It was intended to provide accommodation to transatlantic travellers before embarking on the onward stage of their journey. It ceased to be a hotel in 1855 and was coverted to use as a turkish baths. It continued to be used as a baths, becoming the Hydro Hotel between the First and Second World Wars. Most of the building was demolished to make way for Brunel House in the late 1970s, although part of the façade was retained.
The building was a two-storey structure with a large gateway at either end of the frontage with a large lunette above each. The centre of the facade at ground floor level was formed by a colonnade (of Doric columns) with sashes above. There was a string line above the colonnade and at the level of the roof parapet. Photographs show a number of hipped roofs.
The surviving façade of the building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/241).

No.35 Old Market Street, located on the northern side of Old Market Street. The building is three-storey house, probably constructed in the seventeenth century.
The building was refronted in the eighteenth century.
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by Mrs C. E. Ferris, grocer.
The ground floor is currently occupied by a shopfront. A photograph taken in the 1960s shows the roof above the level of the second-storey window enclosed in corrugated iron, suggesting that the attic storey has been significantly altered.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/12/1641).

No.37 Old Market Street. The building was probably constructed in the seventeenth century. The roof appears to be gabled and parallel to the street at the front but hipped to the rear.
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by John Smith, baker.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/12/1642).

No.52 Old Market Street, located on the southern side of Old Market Street. The building was probably constructed in the seventeenth century.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building 901-1/12/1647).

Kingsley Hall, No.59 Old Market Street. The building is a three-storey, four-bay building of apparent eighteenth-century date. The upper storeys, which overhang the footway, are supported on a colonnade of five columns. The upper floors contain equally-spaced sash windows. The frontage has stone quoins.
No.60 Old Market Street. The building is a gabled brick structure which dates to the very late nineteenth or early twentieth century.
No.61 Old Market Street. There is a modern two-storey front and a flat roof.
No.62 Old Market Street.

KNOWN_AS: Three Horseshoes, No.70, Old Market Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
Three Horseshoes, No.70 Old Market Street, located on the southern side of Old Market Street. The building is a single-bay, three storey house with a detached kitchen and was built in the seventeenth century.
By 1875 the building had become a public house known as The Three Horseshoes and was occupied by James Pring.
No.5 Pipe Lane, located on the southern side of Pipe Lane.
No.6 Pipe Lane, located on the southern side of Pipe Lane.
Printing Works located on the west side of Temple Street. The works was built at the end of the nineteenth century, some time after 1883.

KNOWN_AS: Pump to the rear of Little Ann Street
Bristol City Mission, Great Ann Street
MONUMENT_DESC: The Bristol City Mission, No.12 Great Ann Street. The mission hall was located on the south side of Great Ann Stret and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883. The building was still extant at the end of the nineeteeth century

Cattle Sale Yard, West Street. The sale yard lay to the south of the Hide Market in West Street. The yard itself formed a central space to the cattle pens which lined it on all sides. The yard was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan surveyed in 1883 and still survived at the end of the nineteenth century.
Hide Market,  located the south side of West Street. The market was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan surveyed in 1883.

A pond close to the southern corner of the meadow known as Temple Meads. The site of the pond lies beneath the office building of the Bristol and Exeter railway. Its function is unknown, but it was apparently connected to the drainage ditches surrounding the meadow and may therefore have been designed to water cattle or simply to collect excess water.

Floorcloth Manufactory, Temple Meads. The factory, probably producing linoleum, was located on the east side of Temple Gate, at the junction with Cattle Market Road and was recorded by the survey of Bristol by John Plumley and George Ashmead in 1828. The factory was apparently demolished to make way for the development of the railway complex at Temple Meads and has since been redeveloped. The survival of the archaeological stratification is unknown.

Two limekilns recorded by the map of Bristol by James Millerd of c.1715. The kilns were apparently built at the end of the seventeenth century or the beginning of the eighteenth and lay at the south-west corner of a close, immediately outside the town wall known as the Portwall. They are not shown by Rocque's map of 1742 and had probably therefore been demolished by then. The site was developed for housing in the early nineteenth century and the archaeological stratification is likely therefore to have suffered some disruption.

Great Garden or Spring Garden. The garden is recorded by James Millerd's map of Bristol of c.1715 and is shown as a formal garden with tree-lined walks dividing the space into four quadrants. The garden was developed for housing from 1725 by Joseph Haskins.

No.23 Pithay. A single-bay gabled house of three storeys plus attic which was located on the eastern side of Pithay. The ground floor was occupied by a shopfront with the entrance at the centre. A pentice roof tiled in pantiles separated the ground from the first floor. At second floor was a bay window and above another pentice roof marked the division between the second floor and attic.
The building survived to the end of the nineteenth century. The archaeological stratification is likely to have been seriously disturbed by the later redevelopment of the site.

No.24 Pithay. A single-bay house of two storeys plus attic which was located on the eastern side of Pithay. The ground floor was occupied by a shopfront with the entrance at the centre. A full-width pentice roof tiled in pantiles separated the ground from the first floor. At second floor was a bay window and above another full-width pentice marked the division between the second floor and attic. There was a single casement light at attic level. The building had an M-shaped pantile roof.
The building survived to the end of the nineteenth century and was a dwelling in 1887. It was demolished in c.1900 and the site redeveloped.

No.26 Pithay. A single-bay gabled house of three storeys plus attic which was located on the eastern side of Pithay. The ground floor was occupied by a shopfront. A full-width pentice roof divided ground and first floor. At second floor was a bay window with a pentice roof, apparently not full-width, above. There was a casement window at second floor and possibly another casement beneath the eaves of the attic.
The building survived to the end of the nineteenth century and was a lodging house by 1887. It was demolished in c.1900 and the site redeveloped.

No.28 Pithay. A two-bay gabled house of two storeys plus attic which was located on the eastern side of Pithay. The ground floor was occupied by a shopfront with the entrance at the centre. A pentice roof tiled in pantiles separated the ground from the first floor. At second floor were two bay windows and above aonther pentice roof marked the division between the second floor and attic. There was a single casement light at attic level.
The building survived to the end of the nineteenth century and was a lodging house by 1887 and is recorded as belonging to John Finn by 1896. It was demolished in c.1900 and the site redeveloped.

Marlborough House, lying on the east side of Marlborough Hill. The house stood at the north end of a garden or close which was recorded by Rocque's map of Bristol of 1742. The house was not recorded at that time but was in existence by the time of Plumley and Ashmead's map of Bristol of 1828.

No.6 Wine Street, located on the northern side of Wine Street. The building was of four-storeys with a two-window range. The ground floor was occupied by a shopfront with a central entrance between tall shop windows. Cornices separated the floors and the fenestration consisted of six-over-six pane sash windows in moulded openings. There was substantial cornice at the top of the facade. The form of the roof is currently unknown.
By 1791 the building was in the tenure of Joseph Lloyd. The building was drawn in 1826 as part of a view of this part of the north side of Wine Street by T. L. Rowbotham (BRSMG M2343). At that date there was a large signboard fixed to the upper part of the shopfront advertising the shop as the premises of "SMITH & HACKETT." By 1882 the building was occupied by the Criterion Dining Rooms run by Edmund Thomas. It survived into the first half of the twentieth century but was subsequently removed and the site redeveloped.

KNOWN_AS: Garden of the Free School, St. Mary Redcliffe Churchyard
MONUMENT_DESC: The garden of the Free School, St. Mary Redcliffe Churchyard. The school took over the former Chapel of the Holy Spirit in the later sixteenth-century. The garden is recorded by a survey of the church and surrounding buildings by John Lyons in 1717 occupying the area between the south transept and the south porch of the church. It had a geometric layout with beds along the north and south sides and through its centre.

A tenement of twelfth-century date which was recorded during the archaeological excavation at Dundas Wharf in 1982 (BUAD 344). The tenement was built simultaneously with the tenement to the north (BUAD 1291M) and was built of Pennant sandstone. It apparently had a yard to the rear. The northern and southern boundaries of its plot remained essentially unchanged until the twentieth century but the building was extended westward as land was reclaimed from the river and at least three more rooms had been added by the fifteenth century via enclosure of the yard and new construction. These extensions were entirely independent of the tenement to the north and the plan of the building and its rate of expansion were different (Good 1990/91, 38).

No.20 Rosemary Street. The building was a house of probable seventeenth-century date which lay on the north side of Rosemary Street. The building appears to have been built as a one of a terrace of four and was a one window range house of two storeys plus attic with a gabled roof. The entrance on the ground floor was on the west side of the frontage. The building shared a lateral rubble stack with No.18. The building was demolished for the development of the Broadmead shopping centre, probably in the winter of 1954-1955.
The remains of the building are likely to be fairly well-preserved below ground.

No.22 Rosemary Street. The building was a house of probable seventeenth-century date which lay on the north side of Rosemary Street. The building appears to have been built as a one of a terrace of four and was a one window range house of two storeys plus attic with a gabled roof. The entrance on the ground floor was on the east side of the frontage. The building shared a lateral rubble stack with No.24. The building was demolished for the development of the Broadmead shopping centre, probably in the winter of 1954-1955.
The remains of the building are likely to be fairly well-preserved below ground.

KNOWN_AS: House at the east end of Broad Weir
MONUMENT_DESC:
A house at the east end of Broad Weir. The house formed the westernmost of a group of four and was apparently built as one of a pair, the other being the house to the east [162M]. The house was of two storeys plus attic and was rendered with jettied fronts. The frontage had a single bay with shop windows to ground-floor. The building had a jettied north elevation and pantile roofs with clustered chimneys. The second-floor window was of 8 lights The building was demolished in January 1901.
The site now lies mainly under the pavement and flower bed on the south side of Broad Weir but was in the highway between the late nineteenth century and the 1960s. Services are likely therefore to have disturbed the site.

KNOWN_AS: Densham and Sons Tannery, Redcross Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
Densham and Sons Tannery, Redcross Street. The tannery was located on the north side of Redcross Street, at the junction with Haberfield Street. The main entrance was from Redcross Street and the offices and warehouses were along the west side of the site. The tanning pits and drying lofts were located at the north end of the site, the tanning pits open to the elements in the courtyard according to the Ordnance Survey 1st Edition map of 1883.
