By 1896 the site of the saw mill [1299M] on Redcross Street had been acquired and, the fire insurance plans indicate, was in use for lime pits and a drying loft.
The site of the tannery now lies beneath Mercury House and the adjacent multi-storey carpark and the below ground archaeology is likely to have been disturbed by the construction of these buildings. Areas may however remain undisturbed.
Temple Gate Pottery. The site was Taylor's Glasshouse until it was taken over by the Powell family who opened Temple Gate Pottery in 1824. The pottery was demolished in 1906.

A saw mill on the north side of Redcross Street which was recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883. The building had been demolished by 1896 and its site incorporated into Densham and Sons tannery [BUAD 1298M].
The below ground remains of the building are likely to have been dsturbed by this and subsequent building.

KNOWN_AS: Kear Engineering Cycle Company Works, Redcross Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Kear Engineering Cycle Company Works, Redcross Street. The iron works was in existence by 1883. It was demolished in the twentieth century and the site is likely to have been disturbed to some degree by later construction.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Cathedral of the Holy and Undivided Trinity, College Green
MONUMENT_DESC: Minster House. The building, built of Brandon Hill Grit and of medieval origin, stood to the west of the west front of the Cathedral and was connected to it by a cloister. The building was demolished in 1884 when the west front of the cathedral was rebuilt. The site of the building was subject to archaeological excavation in 1992 (BUAD 1685).

The St. Michael's Hill toll gate. The structure stood on the west side of the junction of Cotham Hill and Hampton Road. It was a two-storey building with a hipped roof. A gate on its east side prevented access to Hampton Road. The building was demolished in 1867 and the site is now part of the garden of No.6 Cotham Hill.

The Old Deanery, which stood on the west side of the Norman gateway to the precincts of the abbey of St. Augustine. The stone building comprised a main block with two ranges projecting north towards College Green from this. All had two storeys. There were small dormer windows in the roof of the centre block and four tall single chimney stacks projected from the roof on its north side. The gable end of eastern range had a small entrance porch with a pitched tile roof with cusped barge boards. The upper storey contained a dormitory which was decorated with more than twenty murals drawn on to the walls. The gable end of the western range had a single bay with a centrally placed sash in each storey. There was an open area in front of the building which was demarkated from Deanery Road by iron railings. The building was demolished in 1902 to make way for the new City Reference Library. Several of the murals were removed to the Cathedral.

The Bristol Cenotaph, Colston Avenue. A desire to erect a monument to the fallen of World War I emerged in the early 1920s but nothing came of the first effort and in the meantime Bristol's Remembrance Day services were held around a temporary cenotaph approximately two metres high which was erected annually on St. Augustine's Bridge [BUAD 539M] in the Tramway Centre.
A second attempt to create a memorial was made in the mid-1920s by the newly-established Bristol branch of the British Legion. Opinion was divided over whether to create a reverential public monument or to establish a memorial with a more practical function, particularly to support disabled servicemen. A committee was established to campaign for funds and College Green, then occupied by the Replica High Cross [BUAD 40M] was proposed as a site but this was opposed by the Dean and Chapter, who owned College Green. An alternative site in the footway in front of the Church of St. Augustine-the-Less was also rejected. The council did, however, fund construction of a small housing estate at Bethune in northern France at this time as memorial.
A third attempt to create a memorial in the late 1920s proved successful. A site was allocated at the northern end of the Tramway Centre and the council provided £790 to prepare it in July 1931. The design for the memorial was selected by means of an architectural competition. Eighteen submitted designs were reduced to a shortlist of three by G. C. Lawrence FRIBA, an assessor selected by the President of the Royal Insititute of British Architects. The three shortlisted designs, by C. R. Beechcroft, Adrian E. Powell and the practice of H. Heathman and Miss E. Blacker, were published in the Bristol Evening Times and Echo for the public to vote on. The winning design was that by Heathman and Blacker, and this was built during the first half of 1932. The cenotaph was unveiled by Field-Marshal Sir William Birdwood, who commanded the ANZAC forces during the First World War, on Sunday 16th July 1932 at a ceremony involving the council, armed and civilian services, the Bishop of Bristol and representatives of other religious denominations.
The monument is a tepaering rectangular slab of Portland stone set on a stepped plinth with plain square blocks approximately 1.1 metres high at each corner. The top is moulded in the form of a fascine with scrolled consoles at either end and a sarcophagus on top. At the centre of both the north-east and south-west faces is a large wreath with a central sword. The dates "1914" and "1918" were carved below the wreath, on either side of the sword. The dates "1939" and "1945" were subsequently added. Below the dates are bronze plaques with a band of roundels containing service badges, including those of the Royal Navy, Royal Marines and Royal Air Force, running around the monument at the level of the plaques. The plaque on the north-east face of the monument carries the legend:
"O VALIANT HEARTS, WHO TO YOUR GLORY CAME
THROUGH DUST OF CONFLICT AND THROUGH BATTLE-FLAME:
TRANQUIL YOU LIE, YOUR KNIGHTLY VIRTUE PROVED
YOUR MEMORY HALLOWED IN THE LAND YOU LOVED
SPLENDID YOU PASSED, THE GREAT SURRENDER MADE
INTO THE LIGHT THAT NEVERMORE SHALL FADE
ALL YOU HAD HOPED FOR, ALL YOU HAD, YOU GAVE
TO SAVE MANKIND, YOUSELVES YOU SCORNED TO SAVE."
The plaque on the south-west face is inscribed:
"SACRED TO THE MEMORY
OF BRISTOL'S SONS AND
DAUGHTERS WHO MADE
THE ULTIMATE SACRIFICE"
The mention of "daughters" is unusual and possibly unique (Dr. C. Moriarty pers. comm.).
On the narrow, south-east and north-west facing, sides are the arms of the City of Bristol in bronze.
Some 10 metres from each of the square blocks at corners of the plinth there are four bronze openwork lamp standards with globe lamps each with a lion's head roundel on every side.
The cenotaph has a Grade II listing (Listed Building No. 901-1/11/551). The bronze lamp standards are listed separately (Listed Building No. 901-1/11/552) and are also Grade II. The monument is owned and maintained by Bristol City Council. The stonework is currently [14/06/2001] suffering erosion probably attributable to pollution. [Public Monument and Sculpture Association reference number BR61]

The Quay Pipe conduit head at the corner of St. Stephen's Street and Colston Avenue. The conduit head was a stone structure with two iron taps set in niches. These were at the foot of two stone steps.
The structure was removed in the late 1930s.

Watch box on the corner of Brunswick Square and York Street. The box was built of freestone blocks with a central wooden door. It was accidentally destroyed by a motor vehicle during the Second World War.

The tram signal box and tram shed and stables at Perry Road/Lower Park Row. The buildings were part of a horse-drawn tramway run by the Bristol Tramways Company. A spur ran off the line along Colston Street into the yard. The buildings were constructed c.1874 and are of Brandon Hill Grit. The building at the north-east side of the junction of Lower Park Row and Perry Road was a stables for the horse drawn trams. The roof of the stable was gabled, with a ridge-roof following the curve of the building. A wooden signal box projected from the retaining wall on the south-east side of Perry Road. This had a hipped roof.

The Harbour Master's House at Cumberland Basin. The house was erected in 1858. It was of stone, had two-storeys and a gabled pantile roof, and had a clock tower with a hipped roof at its north-east corner. The corners had freestone quoins. The entrance to the building was on the east side.
The building was demolished in July 1964 to make way for the construction of Plimsoll Swing Bridge.

The Bathurst Basin bascule bridge. The rail bridge was built in 1872 and was steam-operated with the western end being raised to open the bridge. It was removed in 1963. The footbridge which currently occupies the site was built in 1985.

No.23 Little Peter Street. The building was a four-storey, single-bay, jettied house with a pantiled roof with front gable which stood on the west side of Little Peter Street (opposite the Bear and Ragged Staff public house). The ground floor was a shopfront with an entrance doorway on the south side. The first floor projected out over the pavement and, like the second floor, contained a single sash window. There was a small sash window in the attic gable end.
The building was destroyed by bombing on 24th November 1940.

No.22 Little Peter Street. The four-storey, single bay, jettied and front-gabled building stood at the top of Little Peter Street. The ground floor was a shopfront with the entrance doorway on the south side. The first floor had a casement window while the second floor had a bay. There was a single casement window in the attic gable end. The roof was pantiled.
The building was destroyed by enemy action on 24th November 1940.

No.5 Silver Street. The building was a three-storey, two-bay, jettied house with a pantiled roof with front gable. The ground floor was a shopfront with a central entrance doorway. The upper storeys each had two sash windows. The frontage was rendered and stepped forward of the other buildings in the street.
The building was demolished in the early post-war period and the site on which it stood is currently void.

No.61 St. Thomas Street. The three-storey single-bay building was located on the east side of the street. The building had a pantile roof with a front gable. The entrance was on the north side of the facade and there was a window to the south of this. At first and second floor the building had bay windows. Adjacent on the south side of No.61 was a front-gabled structure erected over a haulingway. This had a double doorway.
The building was the Apple Tree Inn from the eighteenth-century. By 1870, however, the building was no longer an inn.
Bristol Grammar School.

The Drawbridge 1868-1892. The bridge, a bsacule bridge, replaced an earlier bridge and was the final drawbridge to occupy the site. It was determined to be too narrow and was removed during the culverting of the Frome from Stone Bridge. It was replaced with the fixed St. Augustine's Bridge.
The bridge appears to have been of iron or steel and pivoted on the east side. It had plain railings along both sides. There were two large gas lamp standards at the east end. On the south side of the bridge was a set of fixed steps which led down to water level and along a wooden footway to the base of the bridge.

The Hatchet Inn, sited on the north side of Frogmore Street. The building is a house of three storeys plus attic built of Brandon Hill Grit and dating to the seventeenth century. The cross-gabled pantile roof has a large chimney stack on the north-west side.
The building was substantially rebuilt in 1967.

Q Shed. A stone transit shed on the east side of  St. Augustine's Reach, immediately on the north side of the Drawbridge. The shed was erected in 1868 and removed during culverting of the River Frome in 1892.
The building had a central archway in its south frontage with a circular ventilator above. The pitched roof had a long rooflight on the west side. There appears to have been a later extension to the building on its north side although the roof of the extension was lower.

Bathurst Basin. The basin was constructed through enlargement of the mill pond for Trin Mill as part of the scheme to construct the Floating Harbour at the beginning of the nineteenth century. It had an entrance lock from the New Cut at the south-west corner, which is now blocked.

The Elephant Inn in St. Nicholas Street. The building was a four-bay building, comprising two two-bay houses with front gables which had been knocked together. The ground floor was a public house frontage containing three 24-light windows and an entrance in the second bay from the west. Above the entrance was the pub sign, a large statue of an elephant. The upper storeys contain sashes. There is a casement window in the west gable and a sash in the east.
The building was demolished in 1863 and rebuilt.

No.6 Castle Mill Street. The building, which stood on the north side of the street, was a four-storey jettied house with a front gable and pantiled roof. The ground floor was a shopfront and a full-width pentice roof divided the ground and first floors. There was a large bay window in the first floor and above this a full-width pantiled pentice marked the base of the second storey. This also contained a large bay window. The attic storey was jettied out and a large bay window had been inserted here too.
The building was demolished at the end of the nineteenth-century.

No.21 Peter Street. Located on the north side of Peter Street, the building was a four-storey, single-bay jettied building with a pantiled roof and a gabled front. The ground floor was a shop front and there was a bay window at first and second floor levels.

KNOWN_AS: Pump to the rear of Little Ann Street

MONUMENT_DESC: The Blue Bowl Inn at the north corner of Temple Back and Water Lane. The building was a two-storey, two-bay building with a ridged pantile roof parallel to the street and two small front gables with lower ridges. The main entrance, centrally placed in the Temple Back frontage, was reached down steps dug into the pavement. The door had a porch above and there were 7x4 lights on either side of the doorway, the northern having shutters. There were two small gables in the roof on either side of the doorway with casements in each. The sign for the house was between these.

No.47 St. Thomas Street. The building, located on the east side of St. Thomas Street, was a three-storey, two-bay jettied house with front gables and pantiled roofs. The northern bay had a shopfront at ground level and a bay window at first floor level. Above the bay window was a full-width pentice which extended across both bays. There was a 5 by 2-light window in the gable end. The southern bay was the entrance to a haulingway and above was an attic storey. This had a sash window in the gable end. The building gives the impression of having originally been two properties which were subsequently been made into one. It was apparently built as part of the same development as Nos.48-50 St. Thomas Street.
The building was the London and North Western Railway Company Receiving Office for Goods and Parcels in the later nineteenth-century.

No.49 St. Thomas Street. The building, which stood on the east side of the street, was a three-storey, single-bay house with a front gable and pantiled roof. There was a shopfront at ground floor and the entrance was on the north side. There were sashes at first and second floor (attic) level. It appears to have been erected with Nos.47, 48 and 50, as part of the same development. The building was empty by the end of nineteenth-century and was demolished soon after.

No.50 St. Thomas Street. The building, which stood on the east side of the street, was a three-storey, single-bay house with a front gable and pantiled roof. There was a shopfront at ground floor and the entrance was on the north side. There were sashes at first and second floor (attic) level. It appears to have been erected with Nos.47, 48 and 49, as part of the same developemnt. The building was empty by the end of nineteenth-century and was demolished soon after.

St. Nicholas Gate. The gate was built as part of the Norman inner circuit own wall and was joined to the west end of St. Nicholas Church (BUAD 147M). The gate was a two-storey structure which stepped forward (northward) of the nave of the church on the St. Nicholas Street side. It comprised a vehicular gate with an arched pedestrian gate on its east side. The north face of the upper part of the tower had three arched windows and the top was crenellated. The upper storey above the gate was accessible from the church via some "twenty-three steps of black and white marble" and is reported to have contained an altar. A clock had been added to the north-facing elevation of the gate by the eighteenth-century.
The gate was demolished in 1762.

The Market House in Wine Street. The market stood in the centre of Wine Street just to the west of the junction of Pithay and Wine Street and was in existence by the later-seventeenth century. James Millerd's 1673 map of Bristol indicates that the building was oriented east-west. An illustrative panel in the map border shows the structure with a pitched roof supported by columns on the north and south sides. There were stone or brick pillars at each corner and an arch in the centre each of the longer sides. In the centre of each side projecting above the roof was a plaque. The northern showed the Bristol City Arms, the southern the arms of the Society of Merchant Venturers and the eastern the arms of the Prince of Wales. That on the west may have been the Royal Arms. There were crenellations along the north and south sides of the roof and carved animals (lions?) at each corner. The building appears to have had a flagstone floor. The period of use of the structure is not known.

KNOWN_AS: St. Raphael's House of Charity, Cumberland Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Raphael's House of Charity, located on the north side of Cumberland Road. The building was in existence by the early 1880s and is recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map. By the First World War the building had become a mill.
The building was subsequently demolished and its site now lies beneath the eastern half of the housing development known as The Quays.

Sailors College, Cumberland Road. The Sailors' College was a row of almshouses and chapel [BUAD 522M] located on the north side of Cumberland Road. The complex was built at the expense of Rev. Robert H. Miles for retired sailors and their widows. Miles commissioned the architect Henry Woodyer, an Eton contemporary, to design the building (Elliott & Pritchard, 2002 78; 150) which appears to have been a range of individual single-storey dwellings 45 metres long (BRO 33041/BMC/12/Pl104; Elliott & Pritchard, 2002 150). Each had a narrow attic dormer window with three small gothic windows and cusped bargeboards. There was a decorative iron finial set slightly back from the apex of each dormer gable. The roofs of the almshouses projected forward to create a covered walkway.
The almshouses were demolished in 1970. The site of the almshouses now lies beneath Nos.1-30 Perretts Court.

KNOWN_AS: Pump to the rear of Little Ann Street

MONUMENT_DESC: No.1 Shed, otherwise known as Dublin Shed or A and B Sheds, which stood at the north end of Narrow Quay. The shed was erected in 1862. The building was a long, single storey transit shed with a hipped roof. It was constructed of a framework of girders with wooden panelling between and there were alternate double and single lights set in the roof. The roof was supported on columns, probably of cast iron, which were set in socketed granite blocks in the quayside. Some of these blocks can still be seen in the quayside at the northern end of Narrow Quay along with strips of iron probably positioned to allow sections of the wall on rollers to be opened. The shed was demolished c1937 at the same time that the section of the Floating Harbour south of St. Augustine's Bridge was culveretd to allow construction of the inner circuit road. During a watching brief on the redevelopment of the centre in 1999 further socketed granite blocks probably associated with the shed were exposed along with part of the quay wall (Burchill 1999).

KNOWN_AS: Friend's Workhouse Burial Ground, New Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
Burial ground of the Society of Friend's Workhouse, located at the north-western end of River Street. An Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852 placed the restriction that "only one body [was] to be buried in each grave" in the burial ground.
The stone grave markers were removed in 1932 and the graves were subject to clearance in 1961, being reinterred at Avon View cemetery in grave numbers 1453-1454 Purple AA (Stock 1996, 7-8).
The Vicarage, Redland Road.

Gotley Lodge. The house dates from c1820 and is of two-storeys, constructed of rendered Pennant rubble with brick dressings, limestone ashlar and pantile roof. Edward Ireland Clayfield is recorded as owner of both house and land in 1828. The Brislington Tithe survey of 1846 records Edward Ireland Clayfield as the owner of the property with David Burgess as the tenant.
The house has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/48/468).

KNOWN_AS: St. Gabriel's Church, St. Gabriel's Road, Easton
MONUMENT_DESC: St. Gabriel's Church, located on the western side of St. Gabriel's Road, Easton. The church was built in the mid-nineteenth century and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.13) published in 1884. The church survived into the twentieth century but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped.

Congregational Chapel, located on the north-western side Stapleton Road. The chapel was built in the mid-nineteenth century and was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.13) published in 1884. It is two-storey structure of Pennant sandstone rubble and has a Sunday School at the rear.

KNOWN_AS: Stable attached to The Grange, Park Road, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC: Stable located to the south of The Grange, on the western side of Park Road, Stapleton. The building is a one and a half storey structure constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble, covered with an ochre-coloured render, and with a hipped pantile roof. It was probably constructed in the seventeenth century. The west-facing elevation facing on to Park Road had been replaced, apparently in the early-eighteenth century. The new façade is of two-storey height and is in a classical style. There were three bays with ashlar mouldings forming segmental-headed arches. The central arch contained a doorway and those on either side small windows. At the shoulder of the arches is an impost-band and the arches have keystones. Above these is a plat band and above this there is a smaller segmental-headed arch and on either side a circular moulding. The parapet extends well above the level of the eaves and has a moulded coping.
St. Augustine's Church, located on the south side of Whitchurch Lane. The church was constructed in 1971-1972 to a design by the architect Michael Jenner.

KNOWN_AS: St. Mark's Church, St. Mark's Road, Easton
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Mark's Church, located on the eastern side of St. Mark's Road. The church was constructed in 1848 to a design by Charles Dyer. Dyer died in 1848 and the construction of the church was completed under the supervision of S. E. Gabriel. The building was constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble with ashlar dressings and was in a Norman style.
The church became redundant in 1984 and was converted to housing in 1988.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/37/1242).

Doveton Mills, a corn mill located on the northern side of Doveton Street, Bedminster. The mill was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.20) surveyed in 1883. The building survived into the 1920s but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped.

KNOWN_AS: Public House on Gloucester Road (now Stapleton Road)

MONUMENT_DESC: Cotham Chapel, Redland Road. The chapel was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheets LXXV.12.24 and LXXV.12.25) surveyed in 1883 which indicates that the building was Wesleyan Methodist chapel with accommodation for 800 people. The building is extant.

St. Nathanael's Church, located on the southern side of Redland Road. The church was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.12.24) surveyed in 1883 which indicates that the church had accommodation for 600 people. The building is extant.

Quarry, located some 70 metres to the north-west of Elmgrove Road. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.12.24) surveyed in 1883 as an "Old Quarry", indicating that it was out of use by that date. The quarry was subsequently infilled and the site now lies beneath the south-western corner of the Cotham Gardens Sports Centre.

KNOWN_AS: Eighteenth-century house at No.12 Passage Road, Westbury-on-Trym
MONUMENT_DESC: An eighteenth-century house located on the west side of Passage Road. The house was in existence by the late-eighteenth century and was first recorded by a plan of the estate of Isaac Hobhouse of 1792. It was apparently still extant in the second decade of the nineteenth century but seems to have been incorporated into the building which later became The Firs (SMR 22256) as the northern range by 1825. The Westbury-on-Trym tithe survey of 1841 (BRO EP/A/32/41) suggests that the building had been demolished by then.
No.5 Whitefield Road, located on the north side of Whitefield Road. The house was in existence by the time of the St. George tithe survey of 1842 (BRO EP/A/32/32).

KNOWN_AS: Chapel at No.163b Church Road, Redfield
MONUMENT_DESC: Chapel at No.163b Church Road, Redfield, located on the north side of Church Road. The chapel was built in the late-nineteenth century, between the early 1880s and 1903. It is constructed of squared, coursed Pennant sandstone blocks. The building had been converted into a Hindu Temple by 1981.

A limekiln at Headley Lane. The limekiln is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition County Series 1:2500-scale plan (Somerset Sheet VI.10) published in 1886 and there was an associated quarry some 31 metres to the north-west. The limekiln had been demolished and the quarry infilled by the early twentieth century.

KNOWN_AS: North Street Brick and Tile Works, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC: North Street Brick and Tile Works. The site was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition County Series 1:2500-scale plan (Somerset Sheet VI.06) published in 1894. The kiln building was at the centre and measured 6.9 metres wide by a maximum of 13.1 metres long. The kiln had been demolished by the early tweentieth century and terraced housing developed on the surrounding streets.

No.77 Sea Mills Lane was in existence by the early 1770s and was recorded by a plan of the Southwell estate of 1772.
It was also recorded in a painting by Joseph Walter of 1844 as a three-storey, three-bay house. There was a single-storey bay window at ground-floor on the western bay of the main, north-west facing, elevation.

No.33 Marling Road. The building is a two-storey rendered house and forms the eastern end of a terrace of four houses. The date at which the house was constructed is currently unclear but it was in existence by the time of the St. George tithe survey of 1842 (BRO EP/A/32/32).

No.22 Old Market Street. An office dating to c.1890. Brick with limestone dressings, tile-hung bay, and a pantile gabled roof. Double-depth plan. Queen Anne style. 3 storeys and attic; 1-bay range. A tall, narrow frontage with a coped gable has a late C20 shop front with 4-panel doors either side of a wide tripartite window, rendered side piers with cartouches at the top and a bracketed cornice between; first-floor brick piers to moulded second-floor capitals, beneath square panelled bases to octagonal ball finials either side of the attic gable; first- and second-floor shallow canted bay set flush with the front, has a plate-glass tripartite central window on the first floor, similar glazing with an Ipswich window on the second floor, with a low plaster pediment with side brackets and tile-hung backing in between; over the bay is a 2-centre moulded brick arch on curved brackets with a tile-hung tympanum after sprocketed eaves, and 2-light casement windows; the brick gable above has ashlar bands, a roll-top coping and a tall square ball finial. 
The building was renovated in 1988, when a shop fascia board  '22 A. C. Budden 22' , of c.1895, was revealed. The east wall of the building was in an orange-pink mortar. The main east side wall of the cellar was of stone rubble, also in an orange-pink mortar, and thought to be medieval in date. The outbuildings in the long rear yard have been demolished, but a surface of grooved Pennant Sandstone flags survived, laid square in late nineteenth-century fashion.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/12/1635).

The Avonside Ironworks, later the Avonside Engine Works, located between Avon Street and Barton Road in St. Philip's Marsh. In 1837, taking advantage of the proximity of the GWR terminus and the availability of coal, Henry Stothert bought part of the former brick yards on the east side of Avon Street to establish a works to construct engines, particularly railway locomotives for the Great Western Railway (Davies et al. in Harvey & Press 1988, 111). There were several discrete departments within the works, including an iron foundry, brass foundry, forge (which operated through the night as well as by day) and boiler-making, erecting and fitting shops. Clark reported in 1850 that the coke ovens of the works had become a local nuisance (Clark 1850, 82). By the mid-1860s the works employed over 700 men and 100 boys, although Edward Slaughter informed the agent of the Commissioners on the Employment of Children that the company only employed those over the age of 15 (Children's Employment Commission 1866, 62-63). The company had an important domestic market but was also exporting locomotives to railways across the world because of a willingness to supply the particular requirements of their customers. It suffered, like other locomotive builders across the country, from the consequences of the downturn in railway investment and went into liquidation in July 1881. The buildings were sold to John Mardon Ltd. and some put into use for papermaking while the Vulcan Ironworks moved into others. However, locomotive production continued until 1905 in a much reduced area of the site on the north side of Kilkenny Street leased by Edwin Walker after he acquired the Avonside machinery and patterns in 1882. The eastern part of the site had become the Midland Railway Lower Yard by August 1896 (Davies et al. in Harvey & Press 1988). The engine works removed to the suburbs in the 1900s, after which the buildings found other uses. All of the surviving buildings were recorded by the R.C.H.M.E in 1996 (BUAD 457), shortly before demolition (Cattell 1996; 1997).

Burton's Almshouse or Long Row Almshouse, located on the south side of Long Row. The almshouse is reputed to have been founded in 1292 by Simon Burton, mayor of Bristol, although Paterson argues that the attribution was more likely to have derived from a later mayor, John Burton who founded a chantry in St. Thomas Church which later funded repair works to the almshouse (Paterson 1939, 320-321).
The medieval form of the almshouse is uncertain but its plan appears to have been similar to the later building, though Marochan and Reed suggest it was larger than the later structure. There appear to have been a statue on either side of the main entrance, representing St. Thomas the Martyr and St. John the Baptist (Paterson 1939, 320). By 1550 there were twenty-four inmates, twelve men and twelve women.
The almshouse was rebuilt in 1606 and was rebuilt again in 1721. This structure is recorded by several nineteenth-century drawings and photographs and was a two storey building, probably of five bays. There was an entrance at the centre of the main, north-west facing, elevation above which a was large plaque under its own pediment. The legend was recorded by George Weare Braikenridge as reading: "This Almshouse was Erected in the year 1292 For Sixteen Persons By Simon Burton Esqr & Rebuilt Anno Domini 1721 He was Five times MAYOR of this City & the Original Founder of St. Mary Redcliff Church". The fenestration consisted of cross-windows. There was a raised area in front of the building, with access from either end through doorways and up steps. The front boundary wall was raised above these doorways and there were four arched cellar openings with grilles at the base of wall.
The almshouse was damaged by bombing during the Second World War and was demolished in the 1950s. The front wall plaque was removed to Bristol Museum, but is badly damaged. Keith Marochan and Keith Reed monitored groundworks associated with the redevelopment of the site in 1959 (BUAD 3079; Marochan and Reed 1959).
To the east of the house 2 ponds are marked, one to the west and 1 to the east of the track. {1} Two ponds marked, both to the west of the track on small stream of river Frome. {2}

KNOWN_AS: Tram Depot, Beaconsfield Road, St. George
MONUMENT_DESC: Tram depot, located on the eastern side of Beaconsfield Road, St. George. The depot was constructed in 1876 for the Bristol Tramway Co. and served the Old Market to St. George line (Harvey & Press 1988, 142). Originally the depot accommodated horse-drawn trams but in 1895 it was adapted for use by electric trams and had capacity for nineteen cars. The depot remained in use until the end of tramway operation in Bristol in 1941.

Railway viaduct, Royate Hill The viaduct was constructed for the Midland Railway to cross Rose Green Road and opened for traffic on 1 October 1874. The structure is a seven-arch double-track viaduct built of blue engineering brick, with some of the arches in red brick and a limestone ashlar stringcourse, which is situated on a curve and gradient. Passenger trains ceased to use it on 31 March 1941 and goods traffic ended on 14 June 1965.
Single track railway goods shed, believed built by Midland Railway.{1}

An Iron age fort may have been sited at ST598718, on the great bluff of Totterdown above the River Avon. Now built up - no trace of earthwork. The "way near Aldebury of Knowle" is mentioned in a Bristol charter of 1188, and Rocque's map of 1742 names the junction of the Bath Road and the Wells Road as Aldeburyham. The subsequent name of the same hill-top, Totterdown, may refer to its secondary use as a look-out hill, perhaps by the Saxons.

Clifton Suspension Bridge, crossing the Avon Gorge between Clifton and Leigh Woods. In his will of December 1753 Alderman William Vick, a Bristol wine merchant, bequeathed £1000 to the Society of Merchant Venturers to pay for a bridge across the Avon Gorge. Little was done for some decades but after pressure for action on the scheme from the Chamber of Commerce the Society formed a committee to oversee the project. By 1829 the funds available from Vick's legacy had reached £8000 and a trust was created in 1830. It was intended to raise the necessary additional money through loans and public donations and £22,007 was raised in this way, the great majority from loans (Portman 2002, 5). The committee obtained an Act of Parliament to allow the building of a toll bridge (11Geo.IV c69) in May 1830.
An architectural competition, judged by Thomas Telford, was held in 1829 and ended with Telford rejecting all 22 proposals (including one from I. K. Brunel). Consequently in late-1830 a second competition was held, the Trustees having invited Telford to submit his own design. The second competition was judged by Davies Gilbert, past president of the Royal Society who had worked on the Menai Bridge, and John Seaward, an iron founder, and was won by I. K. Brunel (Rolt 1957, 53-55). Brunel submitted four designs for a suspension bridge with detailing ranging from Gothic to Egyptian and employed the local artist Samuel Jackson to produce views of the proposed designs (Greenacre & Stoddard 1986, 48-55). The final design incorporated elements of Brunel's No.2 and No.3 designs combined with the Egyptian detailing which characterised his No.4 design. Gilbert raised a number of concerns based on his experience at Menai and I. K. Brunel and his father Marc Isambard Brunel made alterations to the scheme to take these on board. A shortfall in the available funds meant that the scheme was cut down to a cost of £45,000 and construction was to take four years.
Work began on the Somerset side of the Gorge and on 27 August 1836 the foundation stone for the Leigh Woods abutment was laid but the contractors building the Somerset abutment, Orton & Paxton, went bankrupt in 1837. Construction of the Clifton abutment was started in 1838. The pylons were substantially completed but construction halted in 1840 because funds were exhausted. The chains for the bridge, which had already been manufactured but not completely paid for, were sold on and used on Brunel's Royal Albert Bridge across the river Tamar in 1853 (Buchanan & Cossons 1969, 183).
In 1859 the engineer John Hawkshaw decided to complete the Clifton bridge. The piers were in sound condition and a new company was formed to which the original Trustees sold the assets in return for £2,000 in shares. The proposal was redesigned to enable the bridge to be built at minimum cost and the chains from Brunel's Hungerford Bridge in London were acquired (Porter Goff 1974). Sir Greville Smyth of Ashton Court supported the scheme but demanded a wider roadway and agreed to provide the £5000 needed. A new Act of Parliament was obtained for the completion of the bridge on 28 June 1861 and as one of its clauses this reserved an element of any operating profits to the Trustees. They would thereby be able to reduce the debt on the bridge by gradually purchasing the shares in the Company, ultimately wind up the trust and operate the bridge as a toll bridge. Construction resumed in November 1862 with Hawkshaw and W. H. Barlow acting as engineers to the project.
The bridge was opened on 8 December 1864 with a procession through Bristol to the bridge. An artillery salute by guns of the Volunteer Artillery sited in Leigh Woods was followed by an opening ceremony attended by the Directors of the Company, the Lords Lieutenants for Gloucestershire and Somerset, the Mayor of Bristol and the Bishop of Bristol at the bridge itself (Barnes 1928, 35-40).
The bridge consists of square red sandstone ashlar abutments with Pennant sandstone walls, and squared Pennant sandstone rubble pylons with limestone dressings. The pylons have battered fronts and backs, and are canted half-way up the sides to deep coved cornices. They are pierced by segmental-arched vehicle arches and these have parabolic arches above. The eastern pylon has narrow pointed-arched side openings and is constructed as a series of large arched vaults.
The Trust completed the purchase of the shares in 1952 and on 1 August 1952 an Act of Parliament was obtained to reincorporate the Trustees and allow the bridge to function as a toll bridge.
Clifton Suspension Bridge has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/7/750).

The Observatory, located at the centre of Clifton Down Camp. A wind-powered snuff mill was constructed on the site in 1766-1767 by James Waters with financial support from the Society of Merchant Venturers (Drummond 2003, 43). The mill was a circular rubble stone tower at least two storeys high. Felix Farley's Bristol Journal reports that it was damaged by fire on 23 October 1777 and the timbers forming the upper structure are reported to have been entirely destroyed (Drummond 2003, 44). The structure appears to have remained derelict for many years until it was rebuilt as observatory in 1828 by William West. A telescope supported on a timber frame was installed in the top stage and an overhanging walkway added around the tower. The telescope was replaced with a "camera obscura" in 1829. Access steps to Ghyston's Cave was later excavated through the cliff and opened to the public in 1837 (Spear & Arrowsmith 1884, 305).
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/7/749).

Bristol Port Railway & Pier Line opened in 1865 from Avonmouth to Clifton. Originally called Clifton but later renamed "Hotwells". Taken over by Clifton Extension Railway (GWR & MR) 1890, closed 1922 {1}The line includes two tunnels. The first tunnel (Clifton end of the line) 216ft long, 16 ft wide, 15 ft high. This tunnel is now used as a store for war archives. The second tunnel, 90 ft from the first, is 625 ft long, it was used as an air raid shelter during war.

KNOWN_AS: Scare Post, James Street (North side), St Werburgh's
MONUMENT_DESC: Cast iron scare post on the north side of James Street set against the south wall of Mary Seacole Court. The post is 'T' shaped, approximately 700mm high with the words 'Flood Level OCTR 1882' embossed across the top section. The lettering and embossed detailing are currently (March 2010) painted white. This is one of four surviving scare posts that record the floods in St Werburgh's in 1882.

KNOWN_AS: Pump to rear of Pennywell Road
Miles Arms Hotel, Avonmouth Road, Avonmouth
MONUMENT_DESC: The Miles Arms Hotel, located on the south-western side of Avonmouth Road, Avonmouth. The building is a two-storey brick structure with a pitched tiled roof and is in an Arts and Crafts style. The building was constructed in the first decades of the twentieth century and is recorded by the Ordnance Survey third edition 1:2500-scale County Series plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.01) published in 1916.

Quarries located in the area of Bracey Drive, on the south-west side of Frenchay Road, Stapleton. The quarries are ercorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500-scale County series plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.07) published in 1882 and cover a roughly square area measuring 65 metres from north-west to south-east by 68 metres from south-west to north-east. The quarries had gone out of use by the beginning of the twentieth century (being recorded as "Old Quarry" by the second edition County series plan published in 1903) and were apparently infilled at some time between 1918 and 1936. The site was subsequently developed with housing later in the twentieth century.

KNOWN_AS: Band Stand at Greville Smyth Park, Bedminister
MONUMENT_DESC: A Band Stand located near the centre of Greville Smyth Park, Bedminster. The date of the construction of the Band Stand is currently (04/12/06) unknown but it was in existence by 1904. A circular structure of 6.9 metres, the Ordnance Survey 1:2500-scale County series plan (Somerset sheet VI.06) indicates that it was enclosed by a circular feature of 13.9 metres in diameter, although the form of this enclosure is not clear. By 1954 the Band Stand was no longer recorded by the Ordnance Survey plan, implying that it had been demolished.

KNOWN_AS: Redgrave Theatre, No.2 Percival Road, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC: Redgrave Theatre, No.2 Percival Road, Clifton, located on the south-east side of Percival Road. The theatre was constructed in the mid-1960s and was named in honour of the actor Sir Michael Redgrave (1908-1985), who was born in Bristol and was a former pupil of Clifton College. Redgrave opened the theatre in 1966.

Large house first recorded on a late-eighteenth century plan of the manor of Bedminster (BRO AC/PL 92) a small part of which survives (09/11/2007) as the rear section of no.204 West Street and referred to as 'Beaufort House' on late nineteenth century documents. Where elements survive the building appears to be a two-storey lias rubble stone structure with a pitched roof pan-tiled roof.

The building was subdivided during the nineteenth century to form nos.200-206 West Street by 1870. By the mid 1950s nos.200, 202 and 206 had been demolished leaving only a small, much altered portion of the original bulding survivng as the rear of no.204 West Street (Townsend, 2007).

Part of the original building was recorded during an archaeological evaluation of nos. 200-202 West Street in 2007. This fieldwork identified part of the footings of a lias limestone structure dated through associated ceramic evidence to the late seventeenth century (Potter, 2007).

KNOWN_AS: Strangers' Burial Ground, Lower Clifton Hill, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Strangers' Burial Ground on the north side of Lower Clifton Hill, Clifton. The burial ground was opened in 1787. It covers an area of 2164 square metres and is enclosed by Pennant sandstone rubble walls with the main entrance gates off Lower Clifton Hill. The cemetery was where many visitors to the Hotwells who died during their visit were interred. The cemetery closed in 1871.
The boundary wall, gates and railings have a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/9/135).

T. W. Hill's Almshouses, on the west side of Jacob's Wells Road. The almshouses are dated 1867 and were designed by Charles Hansom. The two-storey building is of rubble construction, with limestone dressings and has a rear chapel.
The interior has been extensively remodelled and modernised. The arms of the Society of Merchant Venturer's is present inside the building.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/9/126).

KNOWN_AS: Churchyard of St. Andrew's Church, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC: The churchyard of the Church of St. Andrew, Clifton. Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 plan of Bristol indicates that the area of the churchyard used for burials was then limited to the area surrounding, and to the south of, the church. By the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan of the early 1880s the area of the churchyard had expanded to take in the whole of the land parcel bounded by The Fosseway and Clifton Road.

KNOWN_AS: Drinkning Fountain at St Clement's Church
Public House on Great George Street

MONUMENT_DESC: An acid works shown by the Second edition Ordnance Survey 15" plan of 1904 to lie on the west side of Albert Road, St. Philips Marsh.

KNOWN_AS: Avon works, Albert Road, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: Avon works, shown by the Second edition Ordnance Survey 15" map to have been located on the south side of Albert Road, St. Philip's Marsh (opposite the junction with Victoria Street). The factory was a chemical fertiliser plant.

Clifton Down. A large area of open land which has been used as common land for centuries. There are traces of eighteenth, nineteenth and twentieth century landscaping and the down is of considerable historical importance as a traditional area for open-air recreation. Clifton Down Camp is a Scheduled Ancient Monument and there is a prehistoric field system to the north of Bristol Zoo. The down is owned by the Society of Merchant Venturers and maintained by Bristol City Council.

KNOWN_AS: Holy Cross Church, Dean Lane, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC: Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church, located on the western side of Dean Lane, Bedminster. The church was built in 1930 to a design by J. Bevan (Harwood & Foster 1998, 106).

Arno's Castle Triumphal Arch, located between Bath Road and Junction Road. The triumphal arch was built c.1760 for the local brass founder William Reeve, possibly designed by James Bridges, and originally formed an entrance arch to Arno's Castle (HER 1899M). It was intended that the arch would house figures taken from Newgate. The arch forms a free-standing wall with tall central round archway flanked by plain arched doors. The central range is a third higher than the sides and broken forward slightly. The rear elevation is much simpler and there is a carving of the City's coat of arms above main arch (Ison, 1952 186-187).  The arch was moved to the entrance to Arno's Court Bath House in 1912 and has apparently been moved c.10 metres closer to the main Bath Road since, presumably when the Bath House was removed to Portmeirion.
The arch has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building Number 901-1/56/428). It was originally designated as a Scheduled Ancient Monument but was later descheduled.
A long low bank 650 metres long, running along water from 150 metres south-south-west of Stup Pill. It is probably remnant sea walling.

Rodbourn Farm, Hallen Marsh. The site was probably in existence by 1684 when it was recorded by the Commissioners of Sewers survey (Glos RO D272/10/1/1). The farm was owned by Queen Elizabeth's Hospital by the early nineteenth-century. The farm and its outbuildings are shown by the Ordnance Survey maps of 1881 and 1915. The farm is now demolished.
The site (Area 1; Site 10) was visited by R. G. Jackson during the course of a desk-based assessment (SMR 20081) of areas of Bristol City Council owned land north of Avonmouth in December 1996. The site of the farm was found to be the location of a sileage clamp. There were also several large piles of rubble which were assumed to be the remains of the farm buildings. Possible traces of the remnants of walls were seen within one of the rubble heaps.
Grass Marked ring ditch, possibly recent agricultural activity.

KNOWN_AS: Church of St. John the Divine, Lodge Causeway
MONUMENT_DESC:
Church of St. John the Divine, located on the south-western side of Lodge Causeway. The church was built as a parish church to replace a mission church (SMR 22408) on the adjacent site between 1910 and 1911, and was designed by the Hereford-based architect Edward. H. Lingen Barker (1838-1917) in a Gothic style. The church was consecrated on 25 May (Ascension Day) 1911.
The nave has north and south aisles with a slightly lower chancel at the east end. There is a bell cote at the apex of the gable of the west wall. The building is constructed of Pennant sandstone with limestone ashlar dressings.

KNOWN_AS: Summerhill Methodist Church, Summerhill Road, St. George
MONUMENT_DESC: Summerhill Methodist Church, Summerhill Road, St. George. The chapel was built in the mid-twentieth century.

KNOWN_AS: Waggon and Horses public house, No.83 Stapleton Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Waggon and Horses public house, No.83 Stapleton Road. The building appears to have been constructed is currently unknown but an inn called "The London Waggon" was recorded on Stapleton Road in 1800. If this were the same building a construction date in the late eighteenth century can be inferred. The "Waggon and Horses" was certainly in existence by the 1820s and the innkeeper was recorded in contemporary Bristol street directories as Ann Ferrar.

KNOWN_AS: Barton Regis Rural District Council sewage works, Sea Mills
MONUMENT_DESC: The Barton Regis Rural District Council sewage works. The pumping house was located on the south-east side of the site (NGR ST 55436 76157).

Victoria Pumping Station at Oakfield Road. The pumping station and the Victoria reservoir were built in the early years of the Bristol Waterworks Company, which was incorporated in July 1846. It pumps water from the reservoirs on the south side of the city to the water tower at Stoke Road (Buchanan & Cossons 1969, 161). The pumping house lies on its north side, by Oakfield Road (at ST 57669 73730). A large triple-expansion vertical steam engine survives in an adjacent building, as does the chimney, although the boilers have been scrapped. Modern electric pumping units were installed in 1953.

Malt house located on the south side of Stapleton Road, on the west side of its junction with Beaufort Street. The malt house was in apparently in existence by 1854 and was a rectangular building aligned from south-west to north-east, parallel with Stapleton Road. It measured 28.5 metres long by 7.6 metres wide.
The malt house building survived into the early twentieth century but was subsequently demolished.

KNOWN_AS: Devon House, No.168 East Street, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC: Devon House, also known as Pound House, Devon Cottage and Devon Villa, No.168 East Street, Bedminster. The building appears to have been constructed in the eighteenth century. A property known as Pound House was recorded as having been sold to Mr. Stokes in 1770 for £100 and a plan of Long Ashton of c.1786 (BRO AC/PL/92) records the building.

St. Alban's Church, Coldharbour Road. The building was constructed between 1903 and 1915 to a design by the local architect C. F. W. Dening and replaced the original, smaller church which stands immediately to the north-east and is now the church hall.
The nave dates to 1907 to 1909 while the transept and east end was constructed between 1913 and 1915. The church is constructed of squared, coursed Carboniferous limestone with limestone dressings and a Cornish slate roof.
The building is Listed Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/31/1701).

KNOWN_AS: Westbury Park School, Bayswater Avenue, Redland
MONUMENT_DESC: Westbury Park School, located on the south-west side of Bayswater Avenue. The church was built in 1893 and was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey Second edition 1:2500-scale County series plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.12) published in 1903. It was later extended with two ranges of buildings attached to its north-west side which were built on the site of a group of tennis courts.

A heavy anti-aircraft battery at Whitchurch. The battery was operational by February 1940 and is known to have been equipped with four 3.7-inch guns and GL radar by June 1941. The radar had been updated to a GL Mark II unit by the summer of 1942. There appear to have been five 3.7-inch guns by January 1943 (Dobinson 1996, 330; Richards 1981).
A windmill is marked here on Donn's Map of 1769.
Donn's map of 1769 shows a windmill here, apparently in connection with a watermill.
War memorial at Canford Cemetery.

KNOWN_AS: Roman cremation cemetery south-east of Cavendish Gardens, Sea Mills
MONUMENT_DESC:
A cremation cemetery identified in Area C (approximately centred on Nos.6-7 Cavendish Gardens) during the archaeological excavation at Nazareth House, Sea Mills in 1972 (SMR 20172). A tombstone and associated inhumation had been found in 1873 (SMR 20145) on the site. The cemetery was dated on the basis of ceramic evidence to 75-125AD. Cremation appears to have occurred elsewhere with a token volume of remains then collected and deposited in shallow pits in the rock together with pottery vessels. This burial practice appeared to have been consistently followed throughout the period of the cemetery's use.
The cemetery was discovered as a result of archaeological excavation in advance of development; its limits were not defined. The site has been built over for housing and it is likely that the archaeology has been destroyed or badly disturbed by foundations beneath the houses. Evidence may, however, survive in the gardens of the houses.

KNOWN_AS: Society of Friends' Burial Ground, Kingsweston Lane
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Society of Friends' (or Quaker) Burial Ground on the north-east side of the junction of Kingsweston Lane and Broadlands Drive. The burial ground is surrounded by a high rubble wall of probable eighteenth-century date. The entrance arch is on Kingsweston Lane and there is a stone above bearing the legend "FRIENDS BURIAL GROUND 1696" (datestones were placed on most Quaker burial grounds following advice issued in 1870, the date given normally being that of the earliest deed for the land parcel held). Brick arches (now blocked) of unknown purpose are set in the south-west and south-east facing boundary walls at the junction of Kingsweston Lane and Broadlands Drive.
The boundary wall of the cemetery has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/24/1567).

Buckingham Baptist Chapel, Queen's Road, Clifton. The chapel was built in 1842 to a design by R. S. Pope and is in a French Gothic Revival style (Stell, 1986 62). The chapel has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building Number 955)

Arley Chapel, Arley Hill. The chapel was built to a design by Foster and Wood in 1854-1855 as a Congregational Church (Stell 1986, 65). The chapel has been in use as a Polish Roman Catholic church, dedicated to Our Lady of Ostrabrama, since 1968.
The chapel has a Grade II listing (Listed Building Number 901-1/36/1155).

Holy Trinity Church, the parish church of Horfield, located on northern side of Wellington Hill. The church is of medieval date and the tower dates to the fifteenth century. The nave and chancel were rebuilt in the late 1840s to a design by the architect William Butterfield, who also designed the chapel of Horfield Barracks, Highbury Chapel and who worked on the Lord Mayor's Chapel. Alterations were also made to the fabric at the end of the nineteenth century and in the early-twentieth century. The church stands at the centre of an elliptical churchyard and the Horfield tithe map indicates that the churchyard has had that shape since at least 1843.
The church has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/53/1413).

St. Anne's Cottage, located on the northern side of Kellaway Avenue, Horfield. The cottage was in existence by the time of the Horfield tithe survey of 1843 (Parcel 112). The cottage survived into the twentieth century but was subsequently demolished. The site has been redeveloped for housing and the site of the cottage now lies largely beneath No.1 Abbots Way.

Horfield Lodge, located on the southern side of Kellaway Avenue, Horfield. The building was in existence by the time of the Horfield tithe survey of 1843 (BRO EP/A/32/23) which records the site (Parcel 84) as a "House Yard and Garden" occupied by James Marmont. The house appears to have been refronted in the second half of the nineteenth century. The building is extant.

School on the south-eastern side of Kellaway Avenue. The school was constructed in the late nineteenth century and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.08) published in 1903. The school building is still extant and is currently (08/10/2002) in use as the Manor Farm Boys Club.

Rose Cottage, located on the south-western side of Wellington Hill West, Horfield. The house was in existence by the time of the Horfield tithe survey of 1843 (Land Parcel 79). It is a two-storey, three-bay rendered structure with a pitched roof. There are chimneystacks at either end of the roof. The building is extant.

KNOWN_AS: St. John's Church, Apsley Road, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC: St. John's Church, located on the southern side of the junction of Apsley Road and Whiteladies Road, Clifton. The church was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.12.22) surveyed in 1881 records. The plan indicates that the church could accommodate 877 worshippers.

Broadway Cinema, located on the western side of Filwood Broadway. The cinema was built for Roy Chamberlain and is reported to have been in use between 1938 and 1961 (Anderson 1983, 56). The building is a three-storey brick structure with the main entrance in a lobby on the east side of the auditorium. Above the entrance canopy there are three tall windows with moulded facings. When it was in operation the cinema could seat an audience of 1000 (Anderson 1983, 56). In 1962 planning permission was granted for the redevelopment of the site with a retail store, but the building was not demolished and is currently (30/09/2005) extant, though in a poor state of repair.
Pre-medieval field system, Clifton Down.

A boatbuilding yard shown by the Second edition Ordnance Survey map of 1902 as being located on the north bank of the river Avon in St. Philip's Marsh. The yard is shown as consisting of three small structures spread across a plot. A slipway is indicated on the riverbank. The site currently (24/7/97) appears to lie beneath Pocket Park.

Castle Rope Works, located on the north side of Bath Road, Arno's Vale. The ropeworks extended north from the road, the main block being approximately 400 feet long, while a finger extended a further 600 feet from the north-east corner of the block towards the river Avon. The works belonged to Terrells and parts of the works survived into later twentieth-century.

KNOWN_AS: Avonside Varnish Works, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: Avonside Varnish Works, St. Philip's Marsh.

KNOWN_AS: St. Silas Pottery, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Silas Pottery, shown by the Second edition Ordnance Survey 15 inch map to lie on the north side of Albert Road, St. Philip's Marsh. The pottery was short-lived, coming into operation probably in the second half of the 1880s and surviving until the first decade of the twentieth-century when the railways in the area were expanded. The map shows a building with two kilns at its north end. To the west of this is a long building, presumably a drying shed, orientated north-south. West of the presumed drying shed, against Albert Road is a clay pit.
The site of the kilns probably lies beneath the embankment for the rail sidings and are therefore likely to be well preserved. Elements of the other buildings survived at least until 1938, but have since been demolished.

KNOWN_AS: Burial ground for Arno's Court Convent, Arno's Vale
MONUMENT_DESC: A burial ground, which the second edition Ordnance Survey 15 inch map of 1902 shows to the south-east of Arno's Court. The cemetery was apparently established for the convent and it is not known if it has been cleared.

Royal Edward Docks, Avonmouth. Royal Edward Docks were built to expand the capacity of the docks at Avonmouth between 1902 and 1908. The topsoil of the site was cleared and dumped beyond the then riverbank to create a new sea wall. The main excavation work was then carried out. The main dock and the associated graving dock largely destroyed Dumball, or Dungball Island, which lay at the entrance to the river Avon. A Bronze Age rapier was found during the excavation for the south wall of the new dock (SMR 733) while human remains (some of which probably originated from a gibbet on Dumball Island) were also recovered.
An extension was added to the north end of the docks in 1928.

Stapleton Bridge. The bridge carries Stapleton Road across the river Frome. A bridge is shown at approximately the site of the present bridge by the 1839 tithe survey, and it is presumably a historic crossing point.
Stapleton Baptist Church. The stone on the building gives the date 1833. It currently (17/4/98) remains in use for worship.

Hither Pothouse. A 1791 estate map names two fields on the south side of the river at St. Anne's as "Hither Pothouse" and "Further Pothouse". Pottery waste dating to the second half of the seventeenth-century has been found in the surrounding area (SMR 20215, 20216 & 20217). It is inferred that each field probably contained a pottery kiln. The grid reference given lies within the area of the fields, but the precise location of the kiln is not known.

Farther Pothouse. A 1791 estate map names two fields on the south side of the river at St. Anne's as "Hither Pothouse" and "Farther Pothouse". Pottery waste dating to the second half of the seventeenth-century has been found in the surrounding area (SMR 20215; 20216; 20217). It is inferred that each field probably contained a pottery kiln. The grid reference given lies within the area of the fields, but the precise location of the kiln is not known.

KNOWN_AS: St. Stephen's Church, Ullswater Road, Southmead
MONUMENT_DESC: St. Stephen's Church, located on the northern side of Ullswater Road. The church was constructed in 1958-1959. Above the high altar there is a sculpture of The Ascending Christ by Ernest Pascoe, and Pascoe was also responsible for a figure of St. Stephen on the porch.

KNOWN_AS: St. Vincent de Paul Roman Catholic church, Embleton Road, Southmead
MONUMENT_DESC: St. Vincent de Paul Roman Catholic church, located on the north side of Embleton Road. The church was constructed in 1955 and is a brick structure with a campanile at the south-west corner. There is also an apsaidal baptistry at the south-east corner.

KNOWN_AS: Former A. D. Collard butcher's shop, No.57 North Street, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC: Former A. D. Collard butcher's shop, No.57 North Street, located on the southern side of North Street on the western side of its junction with Braunton Road. The building was constructed in the late-nineteenth century and is a two-storey, two bay end of terrace brick house with a shop at ground floor. The shopfront has a low glazed plinth carrying the legend "A. D. COLLARD." There are stained glass panels in the upper lights of the shopfront. The interior of the shop is tiled with green tiles below a moulded dado and with white and green tiles forming a diamond pattern above. At the top there is a floral frieze. The interior of the shop was largely removed in 2005.

Clift Cottage, located on the eastern side of Coronation Road, Bedminster. The house was constructed between 1826 and 1843 at the southern end of a land parcel which had been in use as a nursery in the early twentieth century. The Bedminster tithe survey of 1843 (BRO EP/A/32/8) records the land parcel as a house and garden owned by St. Nicholas Church and occupied by Thomas Menlove. A stable was constructed on the property in 1889 (BRO Building Plans Vol.24 fo.80). The house survived into the early twentieth century but was apparently demolished when a motor garage was constructed in 1920.

KNOWN_AS: Victoria Cottage, No.2 British Road, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC: Victoria Cottage, No.2 British Road, located on the south-western side of the junction of British Road and Victoria Place. The house is a two-storey, three-bay rendered house.

KNOWN_AS: Albert Cottage, No.4 British Road, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC:
Albert Cottage, No.4 British Road, located on the northern side of British Road. The building is a three-bay rendered house of two-storeys and attic.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/45/371).

No.12 Victoria Place, located on the north-western side of Victoria Place. The building is a three-bay rendered house of three-storeys and appears to have been constructed between the early 1880s and the beginning of the twentieth century.

KNOWN_AS: Trinity Church Presbyterian chapel, Cranbrook Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Trinity Church Presbyterian chapel, located on the western side of Cranbrook Road. The chapel was constructed in the late-nineteenth or early-twentieth century.
St. Katherine's Church, located on the north-eastern side of Salisbury Road.
Immanuel Chapel, a Swedenborgian chapel, located on the eastern side of Cranbrook Road. The chapel was constructed in the late-nineteetth or early-twentieth century.

KNOWN_AS: School on the west side of East Street, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC: School, located on the west side of East Street, Bedminster. The school was in existence by the time of the tithe survey of Bedminster made in 1841 (BRO EP/A/32/7). The rectangular building was orientated north-south. It was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.24) surveyed in 1883 when it measured 42.5 metres from north to south and was 13.5 metres wide. The building survived into the twentieth century but was subsequently demolished.

KNOWN_AS: Roman timber building north of Glenavon Park, Sea Mills
MONUMENT_DESC: Postholes interpreted as a timber structure which was recorded (roughly the area centred on No.39 Glenavon Park) during an archaeological excavation at Nazareth House in 1972 (SMR 20172). No conclusion was reached about function of the building but it was believed by the excavator to lie outside the area of the main Roman settlement of Abona.

KNOWN_AS: Roman building at the junction of Roman Way and the Portway, Sea Mills
MONUMENT_DESC: A Roman building excavated in 1934 by Alfred Selley (SMR 20146). The site is on the southern side of the junction of Roman Way and the Portway, Sea Mills. The building has several rooms and has been left exposed.

KNOWN_AS: Netham Constructional Steel Works, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: Netham Constructional Steel Works, on the south side of Feeder Road. The works lay in the finger of land between Feeder Canal on the north side and the river Avon on the south. It is recorded on the 1904 Second edition Ordnance Survey map shows several ranges of buildings and there is a dock off the canal, the entrance to which appears to lie beneath Feeder Road.

KNOWN_AS: Limekilns on the north side of Feeder Canal
MONUMENT_DESC: Limekilns located on the north side of the Feeder Canal, St. Philip's Marsh (ST 61127 72447 approx.). The limekilns are shown on the 1904 Second edition Ordnance Survey map. and two circular kilns are identifiable.
Avonside Tannery (ST 61003 72597). The Ordnance Survey (Second edition) map of 1904 shows two large buildings off Feeder Road.

KNOWN_AS: Limekilns at Small Street, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: A group of three limekilns located in a plot on the east side of Small Street, St. Philip's Marsh. The limekilns were recorded by the 2nd edition Ordnance Survey map of 1902. The site has since been redeveloped.

KNOWN_AS: Avonside Glue Works, Feeder Road, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: Avonside Glue Factory, St. Philip's Marsh (ST 60629 72450 approx.). The site is recorded on the Second edition Ordnance Survey map of 1904 and is shown as a ranges of buildings around the fringes of the site.

KNOWN_AS: Saw mills, Feeder Road, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: Saw Mills, Feeder Road, St. Philip's Marsh (ST 60491 72410).

The eastern of a pair of houses on the north side of Lewins Mead. Attached. 2 storeys and attics, with attics joined under a flat-roofed section between the gables. Gabled front; jettied; a 1-window range. Entrance at outer end; ground-floor square bays with flanking windows. One semicircular bay to each at first and second floors, each bay with 3 curved cross-windows. Flanking first-floor windows of 6 lights each to full width. All windows on this floor reach to the jetty above. Small window at left-hand of attic of left-hand property. Extensive decorative plasterwork beneath the first-floor windows, and to a lesser degree at attic level.
There is some evidence for a detached kitchen block on the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883.

KNOWN_AS: House on west corner of Gravel Street
MONUMENT_DESC: House located on the west side of the junction of Gravel Street and Lewins Mead. A single wide gable to Lewins Mead. 2 storeys and attic; jettied; 2-window range to Mead. Central square ground-floor bay, with an entrance to its left, small window to left again. Pair of bays to outer ends of first-floor, with sashes. Intermediate glazing, with bracket in the centre. Central attic bay. Bracket to left-hand eaves. Two purlins to each side of roof. Finial to gable.

No.4 Broadmead, located on the north side of Broadmead. An attached house. A single wide front gable with exterior collar. 3 storeys and attic; jettied; 3-window range. Entrance at, or just left of, centre. Shop windows either side of entrance, those to the right apparently of single large sheets of plate glass. 3 sashes to first-floor. 2 sashes to second-floor. Single attic window. Lateral stack on west side.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: The Old Fire Station, Bridewell Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Central Fire Station, located in Bridewell Street, on the corner of Silver Street. A single-storey brick building with a yard to the rear, entered off Silver Street. Pedestrian entrance on the corner, with 3 windows to the left and 1 to the right. To the right again 3 bays with garage doors. Replaced by the enlarged fire station of 1928.

Clifton Down Camp, an Iron Age promontory fort at Clifton Down. The hillfort stood on the east side of the Avon Gorge and forms part of a cluster of three Iron Age hillforts, with Stokeleigh Camp and Burwalls on the western side of the Gorge. The ditches enclose an area of approximately three acres and Burrow (1981, 76; 235-236) argues that the "defences appear to have been bivallate with an entrance on the E[ast]." The entrance has been slightly affected by quarrying. It lies just north of present path into camp from the east and has an over-lapping counterscarp bank. In the north-west corner is a rectangular earthwork (SMR 3223). Sections cut by the Clifton Antiquarian Club through the south-east bank of this earthwork, and through the low bank leading from it towards the observatory, revealed no dating evidence, although the latter appeared almost certainly to be later than the inner vallum of the original camp. Roman coins (SMR 3224) and flints (SMR 3225) have also been found within and around the hillfort.
The hillfort was described by William Worcestre in 1480 (SMR 20588; Neale 2000, 34-35), by John Aubrey in the later seventeenth century (SMR 20659; Fowles 1980, 374-375) and a number of local antiquarians (eg. Seyer 1821, 60-61). Part of the outer earthworks of the camp are reported to have been levelled by Sir William Draper in the mid to late eighteenth century. There has been significant erosion by limestone quarrying on the west side and the construction of Suspension Bridge Road to the south also cut into the hillfort.
A windmill was built inside the hillfort in 1776 but was destroyed by fire soon after, and was rebuilt as the Observatory (SMR 1031) in 1828-29. A reservoir is also known to have been constructed inside the hillfort in the nineteenth-century. The hillfort is a Scheduled Ancient Monument (AV29).
Gas works, located on the north side of Marksbury Road.

KNOWN_AS: Pound at Two Mile Hill Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
A pound for straying livestock, located on theon the north side of Two Mile Hill Road, on the east side of its junction with Soundwell Road. The pound is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucester Sheet LXXII.15) published in 1882  as "Old Pound".
The site is now largely beneath No.325 Two Mile Hill Road.

KNOWN_AS: Chapel of the Holy Cross, Durdham Down
MONUMENT_DESC: Chapel of the Holy Cross, Durdham Down. The chapel was in existence in the 1480s when it was recorded by William Worcestre (SMR 5484) as being nine yards long by five yards wide (Neale 2000, 86-87). The location of the chapel is currently unknown.

Goldney Grotto, Clifton. The grotto was constructed by Thomas Goldney III at the south end of the garden of the family house between 1737 and 1764. It was part of a larger garden scheme (SMR 4202) for the house which included an orangery (built in 1714 by his father Thomas Goldney II), Great Terrace (1753) and a rotunda (1757).
The grotto and its associated tunnel system are not aligned exactly parallel to the axis of the house and it has been suggested that this may have been dictated by the limitations of the site (Savage 1989, 2; Stembridge 1998, 40-43).

Luck Well, located on the northern side of Luckwell Lane, Bedminster. The origin of the well is unknown but adjoining fields were known as Upper and Lower Luckwell as early as 1669 (Burchill 2000), suggesting that the well was already in existence by that date. The well is first recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition plan, Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.22 surveyed in 1883 which indicates that it lay immediately behind the stone wall on Luckwell Lane. It was then just over two metres square and apparently edged in stone. The well is reported to have been destroyed in 1900 (Jones 1946). The site of the well is now in the middle of the junction of Chessel Street, Luckwell Road and Smyth Road.

Atlas Villa, located on the north side of Deep Pit Road. The building was constructed at some time between the 1840s and the early 1880s. It was still extant during the First World War but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped.

Trinity Chapel, a Wesleyan Methodist chapel, on the southern side of North View, Westbury Park. The chapel was built in the late-nineteenth century and is recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 scale plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.12) published in 1903. The building is of Pennant sandstone rubble.

Methodist church located on the north side of Westbury Hill. The church is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500-scale plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.08) published in 1881. The building is extant.
Concert Hall located on the north side of East Hill. The hall is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500-scale plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.08) published in 1881.

Sea Mills Dock was the third wet dock (or floating harbour) in Britain. It was constructed in 1712 by John Padmore for Joshua Francklyn, a Bristol merchant. The dock was unpopular because of its distance from the city centre and fell into disuse after 1766. A plan of the Southwell estate of 1772 records the dock as essentially rectangular, with a long wall on the north side and north-west to south-east walls forming the entrance and eastern sides. There was apparently no dock wall on the southern side and the Trym flowed into the Dock at the eastern corner.
The upper part of the Dock was disturbed by the construction of the bridge carrying the Portway in the 1920s. The only structural elements now visible are the two piers at the entrance. That on the north is the best preserved, and contains remnants of two sluice gates (Buchanan & Cossons 1969, 37-38).

George Boon reports five cultivation terraces, much eroded, centred at ST54557697{1} ST538768; ST542769; ST544768: 3 areas of substantial ridge & furrow running up & down the slopes & across the flat top of the S spur of the golf  course. They survive in good condition, although in places overlain by golf course landscaping. V straight strips together with 3 more stones suggest a nineteenth century date. On the sides of the valley at ST544768 they survive as fairly substantial strip lynchets (there is a possibility that these latter are part of a celtic field system). The tithe surveys of Shirehampton & Henbury, 1840, record that the entire area was within Kings Weston Park and was either wood or pasture.

KNOWN_AS: Giant's or Ghyston's Cave, St. Vincent Rocks
MONUMENT_DESC: Giant's or Ghyston's Cave, St. Vincent Rocks. The cave is cut into the cliff face beneath Clifton Down Camp. An entrance from the observatory (SMR 1031) on Clifton Down was broken through in 1837, and an observation platform was constructed on the cliff face, possibly at the same time.

Bewy's Cross in the grounds of Kings Weston House. The cross is of limestone ashlar and appears to be of early  fifteenth-century date, with a square stepped base which is probably later in date (Pooley 1868, 59-60). It is reputed originally to have been the "sailor's cross" and stood near the Severn. It was moved to the grounds of the house in January 1954 to act as a garden feature (Winstone 1969, pl.4).
The cross has a Grade II listing (Listed Building No. 901-1/24/1753)

KNOWN_AS: Site of a chapel north of Kingsweston House
MONUMENT_DESC: Foundations of a chapel uncovered a few years before 1868 by workmen digging near Bewy's Cross (note that it stood at ST54247755 at that time).
A windmill on Kingsweston Hill (ST5473277701). The ruins of the windmill have been incorrectly described in the past as a Roman signal beacon.
Malthouse, Wilder Street. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale town plan surveyed in the early 1880s.
Saw Mill, York Street. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map in the early 1880s.
