Smithy, Moon Street. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale town plan surveyed in the early 1880s.
Saw mill, Wilder Street. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale town plan surveyed in the early 1880s.

Vinegar Stores, Houlton Street. The stores were part of the vinegar brewery on the opposite side of Houlton Street. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map in the early 1880s.
Vinegar brewery, Houlton Street. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map in the early 1880s.
School, Newfoundland Street. The site of the school is now beneath Newfoundland Street. The school building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map in the early 1880s.
The Gideon Chapel, Newfoundland Street. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map in the early 1880s.

No.95, Stokes Croft. The building is a late seventeenth-century or early eighteenth-century 2 storey (plus an attic), single bay house with a gabled roof.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building Number 901-1/6/2035).

Quarry located on the north side Cambridge Road, Horfield. The quarry was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.12) surveyed in 1880-81 as "Old Quarry", suggesting that the quarry was by that date out of use. The quarry measured some 72 metres from east to west by 55 metres north-south and had a working face on its western side. The site was subsequently developed for Horfield Prison.

KNOWN_AS: House on the southern side of Bridgwater Road, Bedminster Down
MONUMENT_DESC: House located on the southern side of Bridgwater Road, Bedminster Down. The building was in existence by the time of the Bedminster tithe survey of 1841 and was also recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.09) published in 1885.
Malago Vale Works. The factory was a colour works is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan as producing umber, barytes, ochre and oxides. It survived to the early 1950s.

St. John's Cemetery on the west side of St. John's Lane, Bedminster. A cemetery is marked in this position on the County Series map and post-dates the Bedminster tithe map of c.1844. It is presumably an extension burial ground of late 19th-century date.

KNOWN_AS: Air Raid Shelter at Manor House, St. Mark's Road, Easton
MONUMENT_DESC: An air raid shelter, located within the Manor House, St. Mark's Road, Easton (SMR 10505) The cellar of the building had been converted into an air raid shelter by the insertion of an internal framework of RSJs encased within concrete beams 0.3 metres square. The shelter was reached by an external flight of steps and a doorway pushed through its south wall, which was also reinforced by three small RSJs. None of the internal fixtures or fittings of the shelter survived with the sole exception of a sign painted on the wall of the entrance stairway (Brett et al. 1994).

KNOWN_AS: Possible searchlight battery, adjacent to Rockingham Farm
MONUMENT_DESC: Remains of a concrete and steel structure, possibly remains of a searchlight position associated with AA Battery (SMR 5972), within enclosure (SMR 5215) are noted in Lawler & Locock (1993).

Durdham Lodge, now known as The Old Halt, on the western side of Downleaze. The building is of mid eighteenth-century date but was altered in the ninteenth and twentieth centuries.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/31/1799).

A probable dewpond at the south-east corner of a field on the east side of Durdham Lodge (now known as The Old Halt) on the western side of Downleaze. The date of the feature is unknown but it is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition plan, Sheet LXXI.11.15 surveyed in 1880. The pond measures 8 metres long, was aligned from north-west to south-east, and was 4 metres wide. The north-western end was revetted in stone.

Redland Hall, located on the north side of Redland Hill. The building appears from documentary evidence to have been constructed in the mid eighteenth century (Bryant 2000) but it is first recorded cartographically by a map of the area produced by Sturges in 1817. In 1825 a Mrs Barnes was living at Redland Hall (BRO P/HTW/V2(a)). By the time of the Westbury tithe survey Redland Hall was owned by Hugh Vaughan.
Redland Bank and Redland House were listed Grade III but were removed in 1961 for the construction of new educational buildings.

KNOWN_AS: Chapel in the churchyard of the Church of St. John, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC: A chapel, apparently located in the churchyard of St. John's Church, Bedminster. The chapel is noted by a survey of chapels and chantries in Somerset made in 2 Ed.VI (1548-49) and was probably constructed in the medieval period. The exact location of the chapel is not known but it may have stood in the east corner of the churchyard - a kink in the churchyard wall recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1:500-scale Town plan surveyed in 1881 (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.24) may suggest this as a location. The chantry survey states that the chapel was held by the parishioners of Bedminster and produced xijd. per year (Green 1888, 273). The date of the demolition of the chapel is currently unknown.

No.8, Frog Lane. On the north side of Frog Lane. Attached. 3 storeys and attic; half-hipped roof; 2-window range (?); first-floor jettied. Probably with a ground-floor shop. The building was demolished ni mid-1937 (P. E. W. Street's notes).

The Park Street Viaduct, located at the south-eastern end of Park Street. The viaduct was constructed in 1871 to a design by R. S. Pope. The viaduct has abutments of Pennant Sandstone and the bridge is of wrought-iron and cast-iron.
The viaduct has s Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/183).

Rogers Jacob Street Brewery. The brewery was built c.1865 to a design by W. B. Gingell. The building is of four storeys with a five-window range. The structure is built of Pennant sandstone with semi-circular arches at ground-floor level. The brewery was refurbished and redesigned internally c.1975.

A parchment factory on the southern side of Redcliff Mead Lane. The factory apparently consisted of four long, narrow buildings on either side of a courtyard which is aligned north-north-west to south-south-east. The factory had been redeveloped for housing by 1855 and the site is now beneath the housing of Franklin Court. The extent of disruption to the remaining archaeological stratification is unknown.

KNOWN_AS: Floor Cloth Manufactory, Redcliff Mead Lane
MONUMENT_DESC: A floor cloth (probably linoleum) factory to the south of Redcliff Mead Lane. The factory was in existence by 1828 and continued in existence to the early twentieth century. The factory consisted of three buildings, running back in a line from Temple Gate. The site now lies beneath the Holiday Inn Express hotel and Franklin Court and the archaeological stratification is likely to have been seriously disrupted.

Malthouse on the northern side of Redcliff Mead Lane. A malthouse was in existence on the site by 1734 and established by John Jones as recorded in a conveyance (BRO 12529(1), Bryant 1999, 4). The building is cartagraphically recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883, although by this time the malthouse had gone out use. The building was subsequently converted for use as a Baptist chapel and had become a private garage by the mid 1930s. 
The site now lies beneath the buildings of Magdalena Court.
Cathay Works, Redcliff Mead Lane. The works was a fertiliser factory and the site is now occupied of the Hilton National Hotel.

Riding school, Portwall Lane. The riding school was located on the north side of Portwall Lane, on the east side of the junction with Canynges Street, and was recorded by Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 map of the city. By 1883 it had been converted to use as a malthouse. The site is now beneath the corner of 100, Temple Street. The survival of the archaeological stratification associated with the monument is unknown.

An earthwork on Purdown. The earthwork was first noted by Dr H. Taylor according to Tratman who describes the features as consisting of "half a circle with an outer ditch and an avenue" (Tratman 1946, 167). O'Neil and Grinsell observed the feature in the 1950s, reporting that it measured 340 feet from north-west to south-east, was 50 feet wide and survived to a height of 2 feet 6 inches. Grinsell and O'Neil argued that it was likely to be "some form of post-medieval landscape gardening" (O'Neil & Grinsell 1960, 68).
The monument is 80 feet in diameter, banded by a bank and outer ditch, adjoined by an enclosure or avenue about 115 yards long by 35 feet wide, enclosed by parallel banks and with traces of an outer ditch on the north-east side. The Ordnance Survey map of 1921 shows both the semi circular and the long enclosure, both planted with trees. The monument was surveyed by Dr. Mark Corney in December 2003 (Corney 2003). The survey demonstrated that it was of post-medieval date and was likely to have been created as a feature for the landscape garden of Heath House as Grinesll and O'Neil had suggested.
The monument was a Scheduled Ancient Monument (SAM No. AV 26) but was descheduled on 10 December 2004.
ST60697578, ancient well (supposed Roman) in grounds of Heath House {1}

KNOWN_AS: Strip lynchets south of Ashley Hill Station
MONUMENT_DESC: Strip lynchets south of Ashley Hill Station

KNOWN_AS: Holy Nativity Church, Wells Road, Knowle
MONUMENT_DESC:
Holy Nativity Church, located on the north-eastern side of Wells Road. The church was built in 1871-83 to a design by A. Ponton and W. V. Gough and was consructed of Bridgwater brick with limestone ashlar dressings. The church had an apsaidal end and a square tower on the south side of the nave. The tower was completed by Gough's son Arthur in 1931.
During the Second World War the body of the church was largely destroyed by bombing and the damaged building was painted by John Piper (BRSMG K1726).
The tower of the church is listed Grade II (901-1/47/1560).

KNOWN_AS: Fire Engine Turnpike Gate, Church Road, Redfield
MONUMENT_DESC: Fire Engine Turnpike Gate, Church Road, Redfield. The toll gate was established in the first decades of the nineteenth century with a toll house on the north side of Church Road. It was recorded by the tithe survey of St. George of 1842 (BRO EP/A/23/32) but went out of use in 1867.

KNOWN_AS: Toll house, Fire Engine Turnpike Gate, Church Road, Redfield
MONUMENT_DESC: Toll house, Fire Engine Turnpike Gate, Church Road, Redfield. The toll gate was established in the first decades of the nineteenth century and the toll house stood on the north side of Church Road. It appears to have been a typical toll house with a three-sided front and was recorded by the tithe survey of St. George of 1842 (BRO EP/A/23/32). The toll gate was removed in 1867. However, the building was still extant in the early 1880s but had been demolished by the beginning of the twentieth century to enable a widening of part of Church Road.

Smithy located on the north side of Church Road, Redfield. The smithy seems to have been built in the second half of the nineteenth century and was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.14.11) surveyed in 1881. The building survived into the early decades of the twentieth century but had been demolished by the late 1940s.

Grammar School located on the north side of Church Road, Redfield. The school was built at the end of the nineteenth century.
The building was converted into a gurdwara (Sikh temple) in the late-twentieth century.

School, located on the south side of Avonmouth Road. The school was built in the late-nineteenth century and was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500-scale County Series plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.01) published in 1903. The building subsequently became Avonmouth Library.

KNOWN_AS: Parish Boundary Marker at Summers Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
A parish boundary marker located at the southern end of Summers Road. The marker is of cast iron and stands approximately 0.5 metres high. It was erected by the Bristol Turnpike Trust to indicate the boundary between the (out) parishes of St. Paul and St. Philip and Jacob and is dated "1823".
The marker appears to have been moved from its original position, likely to have been on the bridge over the river Frome 20 metres to the south-east of the present position, when the M32 was constructed.
Parkway Methodist Chapel, located on the south side of Conduit Place.

Cock pit located on the north-western side of Fishponds Road. The cock pit may have been in existence by the mid-1780s but had certainly been established by the early-nineteenth century and was recorded by William Maule's survey of the parish of Stapleton of 1803 (BRO AC/PL 60a). It had certainly been demolished by the 1840s and the Stapleton tithe survey of 1839 (BRO EP/A/32/35) indicates that the site had been redeveloped for housing.

A two-storey, four window range house constructed of Pennant rubble walls with limestone dressings. Built in c.1834 as a new Turnpike House when the original Turnpike road was diverted to the present route of the Bath Road (see 1991M). The building remained in use as a toll gate until the abolition of the Turnpike roads in 1867 after which the building became a public house and is recorded as such on the Ordnance Survey plan of 1884.

The building is extant and continues in use as a public house. Many original features survive including a toll booth recess, now blocked, to one side of the entrance.

The building is Listed Grade II (Listed Building number 901-1/47/2038).

No.39 Marling Road. The building is a two-storey rendered house and forms the western end of a terrace of four houses. The date at which the house was constructed is currently unclear but it was in existence by the time of the St. George tithe survey of 1842 (BRO EP/A/32/32).

KNOWN_AS: Second World War Memorial, Arno's Vale Cemetery, Bath Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Second World War Memorial, located in the columbarium of Arno's Vale Cemetery, Bath Road. The memorial is a square column of Portland Stone approximately 2 metres high with an urn set on the top. The south-east face of the monument bears the inscription "1939+1945/IN MEMORY/OF THOSE/MEMBERS/OF HIS/MAJESTY'S/FORCES/WHO DIED/IN THE/SERVICE/OF THEIR/COUNTRY/AND WERE/CREMATED/HERE." The names of the fallen are inscribed on the remaining three faces.

KNOWN_AS: The Barn, Grove Road, Coombe Dingle
MONUMENT_DESC: The Barn located on the northern side of Grove Road, Coombe Dingle. The building is a stone rubble structure. It was in existence by the early 1880s.

KNOWN_AS: Drinking fountain at Clifton Road, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC:
Drinking fountain set in the north boundary wall of St. Andrew's Churchyard, adjacent to St. Andrew's Walk. The fountain is a freestone ashlar structure standing approximately 2.5 metres high. There is a semicircular-arched niche containing a small iron basin in the north face with rope moulding and a moulded archivolt with a moulded keystone and shell above. The fountain has a cornice and pedimented top. An impost band carries the inscribed legend "THE FEAR OF THE LORD IS A FOUNT OF LIFE PROV" within the niche.
The fountain has a Grade II Listing (Listed Building number 901-1/8/1043).

War memorial located on the northern side of Shirehampton Road, just to the west of the junction with Penpole Lane. The memorial comprises a bronze cross set on a stone plinth.
[Public Monument and Sculpture Association reference number BR123].

KNOWN_AS: Air Raid Shelter at Hillcrest Primary School, Knowle
MONUMENT_DESC: An air raid shelter at Hillcrest School, Knowle. The shelter is believed to be a trench shelter located in the lower playground to the west of the school buildings.

KNOWN_AS: Air Raid Shelter at No.459 Southmead Road, Southmead
MONUMENT_DESC: An air raid shelter located at the rear of No.459 Southmead Road. The shelter is a brick surface shelter measuring 2.5 metres by 2.2 metres with a reinforced concrete roof.

Withywood Methodist Church, located on the eastern side of Four Acres, Withywood. The Methodist church was built between 1957 and 1959 to designs by Miles and Mills Chartered Architects and is a two-storey building constructed of rendered brick and square Cotswold Dale reconstructed stone blocks. The building comprised the church at the south-west corner, a hall to the east and toilets, vestry and kitchen on the north side of the hall.

Vicarage located at Stackpool Road, Bedminster. The vicarage was contructed in the mid-nineteenth century and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Bristol town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.18) surveyed in 1883. The vicarage was set within a large rectangular garden enclosed by a stone wall with access off Greville Road.
The building survived into the twentieth century but it had been demolished by 1918, Stackpool Road created and the site redeveloped with housing.

KNOWN_AS: Children's Home at Snowdon Road, Fishponds
MONUMENT_DESC: Children's Home located on the southern side of Snowdon Road. The building is the western of three homes which were constructed in the late nineteenth century and were first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500-scale plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.01) published in 1903.

KNOWN_AS: Children's Home at Snowdon Road, Fishponds
MONUMENT_DESC: Children's Home located on the southern side of Snowdon Road. The building is the central of three homes which were constructed in the late nineteenth century and were first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500-scale plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.01) published in 1903.

KNOWN_AS: Children's Home at Snowdon Road, Fishponds
MONUMENT_DESC: Children's Home located on the southern side of Snowdon Road. The building is the eastern of three homes which were constructed in the late nineteenth century and were first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500-scale plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.01) published in 1903.

Norton Farm, located on the west side of Cribbs Causeway. The farm is recorded by the first edition Ordnance Survey plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXVII.15) surveyed in 1881.
The farm was subject to compulsory purchase by the Bristol Corporation in the late 1940s. The farm buildings were subsequently demolished and the site developed for housing.
Brentry Lodge, located on the east side of Brentry Hill. The building is recorded by the first edition Ordnance Survey plan surveyed in 1881. The building is extant but has been converted to flats.

KNOWN_AS: Parish boundary marker stone at No.1 Cotham Side
MONUMENT_DESC: A parish boundary marker stone set in the north-west facing rear boundary wall (Cotham Brow elevation) of No.1 Cotham Side. The stone was located at the foot of the wall, was of Pennant sandstone and had been cut to form a double-headed boundary marker. Any carved inscription on the stone would appear to have been lost.

The Exchange, Corn Street. Consideration of the need for a new gathering place for the city's merchants to replace the existing Tolzey began in 1717. An Act of Parliament was obtained in early 1722 permitting construction of the Exchange. William Halfpenny (the professional name used by Michael Hoare) submitted several designs for the building but John Wood the Elder was ultimately selected to produce the design. The foundation stone was laid by the Lord Mayor in March 1741 and the building completed in 1743. The decorative carving was undertaken by Thomas Paty. The opening on 21st September 1743 was attended by the Mayor (Sir Abraham Elton) and Aldermen.
The Corn Street elevation is of limestone ashlar, with lateral stacks, a hipped slate and leaded roof. It has a central square courtyard with rooms ranged around it. The principal elevation is symmetrical with a pedimented 3-window centre set forward, a rusticated ground floor, pedestal course to four Corinthian columns to the centre and pilasters to the sides. The main entrance in the Corn Street facade is a semi-circular arched doorway with rusticated reveals and heavy arched double doors with studs and cast-iron lion-head knockers. The ground-floor windows have incised voussoirs, and the first-floor windows Corinthian pilaster jambs with entablature and pediments. They are alternately triangular and segmental, with a central Venetian window, and square second-floor windows. Below the frieze is a band of well-detailed swag and festoon to human and animal heads symbolising trade, and a Royal Coat of Arms in the tympanum. The majority of the original fabric is Pennant sandstone rubble.
Wood's design included a coffee house and a tavern at the north-east and north-west corners of the building, respectively. Along the east and west sides of the building there were individual houses, each of which consisted of a single room on each floor with a cellar, a kitchen at semi-basement level and other accommodation above, including a counting house. Two of the kitchens on the eastern side of the building retain many of their fittings as does one of the counting houses on the west side.
There have been significant campaigns of alteration to the building throughout its life. The floors of the cellars in the centre of the building were lowered c.1811-1813 when the Exchange became the Corn Exchange. Another major scheme was carried through in 1872 by the architect E. M. Barry. The central courtyard was roofed and a new suite of offices was created on the first floor, above the colonnades around the court. There were further changes after the Second World War. The clock tower over the south range was removed and the four floors of the coffee house and the main entrance were rebuilt internally. The current roof over the central courtyard dates to 1949.
Wood published a short description of the building and an account of its building (Wood, 1745) and a study of its building was made by Priest in 1980. The most complete examination, however, has been a full measured survey and interpretation made in 1998 by Dr. Roger Leech (BUAD 3374) which identified the extent of the surviving original fabric and phased the various alterations (Leech, 1998). The original inner gates to The Exchange are currently located in the Industrial Museum.
The building has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/11/578).

The Old Post Office, No.48 Corn Street, at the corner of Corn Street and Exchange Avenue. The building was designed by Samuel Glascodine probably with the intention of complementing the Exchange [BUAD 337M] and forming a balancing pair with No.56 Corn Street [BUAD 336M]. It was constructed c.1746. The building is of three storeys plus attic and is constructed of limestone ashlar with lateral ashlar stacks and a hipped roof. The symmetrical front has a three-window range and has a pedimented centre set forward, plinth, rusticated quoins, cornice and parapet. The ground-floor windows are semicircular arches with glazing dating to the twentieth century and central glazed double doors. There are pediments to first-floor windows and a wide dormer. The left-hand return is a 11-window range: right-hand 3-window range as the front, with OLD POST OFFICE inscribed in the plat band; to the left 4:1:3 windows, with a raised entrance section set back containing a tall doorway with Gibbs surround, a pedimented first-floor window and a semicircular-arched second-floor window beneath a cartouche with festoon. Each side are windows as the front. The interior is open plan with a central stairwell, largely remodelled late twentieth century; the side doorway, in Exchange Avenue, leads to an open-well stair. At the beginning of the twentieth century the rear part of the Old Post office was rebuilt to designs by Sir George Oatley, extending the building south to take in the site of the northern two shops of a row of four probably designed by R. S. Pope c.1848 (BUAD 1394M). The building was part rebuilt as a facsimile in 1993. It is currently in use as offices.
The building has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/16/569).

KNOWN_AS: Napier Miles House, Napier Miles Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
Napier Miles House, built in 1763 to a design by Robert Mylne as a stable block for the Kings Weston Estate. The building was originally constructed as an 'H' plan limestone ashlar building with a slate roof. The building has a "tall central semicicular archway in a pedimented gatehouse with a clock" (Listing description).
The rear wings of the building were demolished in 1960 when the stables were converted for use as a police station. At this time the entire rear elevation either side of the central archway was rebuilt and now consists of random uncoursed Dolomitic Conglomerate rubble with limestone reveals and lintels.
At the time of entry the building remains in office use by the police.
The building is Listed Grade II* (Listed Building number 901-1/24/1752).

KNOWN_AS: 2 pillow mounds & other earthworks, north-east of Pale plantation
MONUMENT_DESC: ST61447704, a pillow mound, 300 yards north west of Duchess Pond is rectangular, aligned east to west and measures 40 yards by 5 yards. It is hog-backed, with a surrounding ditch about 5 feet wide, and the height from the bottom of the ditch to the top of the round is about 2.5 feet. A bank on the outer edge of the north ditch proceeds to the wood 20 yards to the west and may probably be found inside the wood. The same bank joins a north-south bank across the spur to the east of the pillow mound, and there is another ditch on the east of this bank. The south edge of the spur appears to be scarped, and a two feet high bank, about 15 feet wide, runs dows the tongue of the spur. {1}{2} As described in source {1}&{2}. The short north-south bank at the east end of the pillow mound is also surrounded by a ditch. Dec 1946 - CPE-UK-1869-3019; CPE-UK-1869-3020

KNOWN_AS: Possible site of a camp near Oldbury Court
MONUMENT_DESC: Near to Oldbury Court ".. is a small camp, which gave name to the place" Oldbury Court Camp - "on the hill above Oldbury Court in the parish of Stapleton ... there was a small camp which gave the name to the house. I have not been able to visit this locality, but the owner of the property informs me that he is unable now to trace any defensive works." In 1928 Davies noticed a mound about 2 feet high and 55 feet by 40 feet, surmounted by trees, about 200 yards east of the house just inside Oldbury Park, and bumps in the fields across the road east of the Training College.
A hermitage was in existence at Stapleton in 1382

Blackbird Gate, located at the junction of Stapleton Road and St. Mark's Road. The gate stood across Stapleton Road immediately to the south of the junction with St. Mark's Road. Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 map of Bristol records a second gate across Oxford Place.

The hospital of St Lawrence. According to William Worcester the hospital of St. Lawrence stood 1200 paces (approximately 650 metres) from Lawford's Gate (Neale 2000, 109). The exact position of the site is not known but plots on the east and west sides of the junction of Lawrence Hill and Barrow Lane are possible, although the triangular plot at the junction of Lawrence Hill and Easton Road has also been suggested.
The hospital was founded by John, the Earl of Mortain who, as king, confirmed the foundation in 1208. The Crown retained the right to appoint the master until the early-fifteenth century. Responsibility for the hospital was given to the Dean and Chapter of Westbury College, Westbury-on-Trym, in 1465. The College paid a salary of £2 for a priest to celebrate mass in the chapel and 16s. to support four almoners. The form of the hospital is uncertain. William Worcestre mentions "the church, and the house and hospital attached to the said church" (Neale 2000, 109), but gives few other details.
The hospital was surrendered as part of the property of Westbury College on 18 February 1544 (Graham 1907, 119). The site and all of the hospital's possessions were acquired by Sir Ralph Sadleir in March 1544 as part of his purchase of the lands of Westbury College (Gairdner & Brodie 1903, 175).

St. Anthony's Chapel. The chapel appears to have been in existence by 1476. It was still extant in the late eighteenth century when Samuel Rudder described it as standing "On a hill, within a few yards of the turnpike gate leading down to Crews hole there is a small dwelling house, which in former ages was a Romish chapel dedicated to St. Anthony: and it retains the name of St Anthony's chapel to this day" (Rudder 1779, 459).
The exact location of the chapel is currently unknown.

KNOWN_AS: Sun Dial in the grounds of Redland Lodge
MONUMENT_DESC: A sun dial located in the grounds of Redland Lodge (SMR 20320). The sun dial stood approximately 40 metres to the south of the house at the northern edge of the carriage drive. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500-scale plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.12) published in 1883 records the dial but it had been removed by the beginning of the twentieth century and No.2 Belvedere Road constructed across its site.

Limekilns located on the west side of Whiteladies Road. The kilns were in existence by the late 1820s and were recorded by the 1828 survey of Bristol by John Plumley and George Ashmead. The plan indicates that the kilns were housed in a rectangular building approximately 30 metres from the road. This building was orientated from north-west to south-east and measured 9 metres long by 5.6 metres wide.
The kilns had been demolished by the early 1880s and their site had become the gardens of Nos.5 and 6 Melrose Place.

A building known as Whiteladies, located on the west side of Whiteladies Road. The building was recorded by the 1828 survey of Bristol by John Plumley and George Ashmead. It was orientated from north-east to south-west and measured 24 metres long by approximately 5 metres wide. The building had been demolished by the early 1880s for the construction of South Parade.

A large pond depicted on a plan of the Southwell Estate dated 1772 (BRO 26570). It has been suggested that a bend in the lane ('Ballast Lane' as recorded on the 1840 Henbury Tithe Map) reflects the west end of this now infilled water feature. It has also been suggested that this feature formed part of the drainage management system in the eighteenth century (Goad, 2008).

A former pair of semi-detached two storey cottages constructed of Pennant sandstone and first depicted on the Stapleton Tithe map of 1839. The cottages contained a single room on each floor, the eastern of the two had a bay window, likely to be part of the original structure, to the front elevation. A survey of the buildings prior to demolition in 2006 recorded no evidence of an internal staircase within the western cottage. It is likely that there was an external staircase against the west elevation with access to the upper floor provided through an opening in the first floor elevation noted by the surveyor.
The two cottages were apparently combined into a single property in the early twentieth century.

Acraman's Iron Foundry, Bathurst Basin. The iron foundry was in existence by 1821 (Farr 1970, 5) and first depicted on Ashmead's 1828 plan of Bristol. A second iron works was opened by the company at Silverthorn Lane in 1829 (2703M). The Bedminster Tithe map records the iron foundry, although by 1842 bankruptcy preceedings had begun (Farr 1970, 5).
There is one quay bollard bearing the name "ACRAMANS BRISTOL" on the quayside at Bathurst Basin (Farr 1970, 4-5).

Cossham Memorial Hospital, founded in 1905 as a result of a bequest from Handel Cossham. The building consists of two storeys and an attic, with an ornate polygonal tower with four clock faces surmounted by a cupola and a weather vane. It is built of Pennant sandstone with Bath stone dressings.

Limekiln Lane pottery. There were two potteries that operated in the first half of the 18th century on the lower slopes of Brandon Hill. The earliest pottery was situated on the north side of Limekiln Lane, formerly Cow Lane and now called St George's Road. Both potteries produced tin-glazed earthenware. The first pottery, later referred to as the 'Lower Pottery' was operating between c.1706 and c.1746 and the second pottery between c.1734 and c.1740.

Searchlight cluster site called 'Bishopsworth' - (3 lights) (1941) at manned by 455 SL Bty of 68 SL Regt RA.
By 1943 this was a single light site CLG 9 (Bishopsworth) manned by 492 SL Bty of 76 SL Regt RA.
Searchlight CLI 16 at Charlton Road, Brentry. This was a single light site and was manned by 455 SL Bty of 68, SL Regt RA (David Hunt, pers comm).
Searchlight CLI 20 at Eastville Park. This was a single light site and was manned by 455 SL Bty of 68, SL Regt RA (David Hunt, pers comm).

1-27 The Horsefair. Formerly known as the John Lewis Building. The style of the building is modernist and is clad in Portland stone. The architect was Percy Thomas, and the building dates to the 1950s.
1792 mill on N bank of Avon. Seems set out over river 2 further buildings on the property behind. {1}

KNOWN_AS: Brick yard on the north bank of the River Avon, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: Brick yard, located on the north bank of the River Avon, St. Philip's Marsh. The brick yard is shown on a 1792 map as being located on the north bank of the river Avon. The map shows a large "pit" at the centre of the site, three buildings at its east end and one at its western.
Factory of the 19th Century Quaker industrialist Robert Chanton, whose house, Fulwood House, adjoins in Charlton Road. Part of the chapel & factory survive. {1}

Crew's Hole Pottery, located on the south side of Crew's Hole Road. The pottery was owned by Anthony Amatt and was in operation by c.1815 (Buchanan & Cossons, 1969 150). The pottery consisted of a single storey building containing a glazing kiln and main kiln and several ancillary structures. The yard lay on the west side of the kiln buildings. The pottery produced mocha ware items, examples of which are frequently recovered during excavation in and around Bristol. The pottery closed in 1819 and Amatt began to work at Powell's Temple Gate pottery (Marochan, 1962 189).
Much of the structure remained, though largely demolished, until 1960 when the site was excavated by Keith Marochan (SMR 20298; Marochan, 1962). The bases of the two kilns were subsequently removed for road widening.

KNOWN_AS: Drinking Fountain on Old King Street
Public House on Narrow Wine Street
Public House on Narrow Wine Street
Ashton Junction Signal Box, Ashton Gate
MONUMENT_DESC: Ashton Junction Signal Box. The box, built to a standard Great Western Railway design in use between the late 1890s and the 1920s, was opened on 20th May 1906. It is a surviving example, now rare in the Bristol area, of a GWR signal box. The equipment has been removed from the box and it is currently (29/4/98) boarded up.

KNOWN_AS: Pond on the east side of Lansdown Road, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC:
A pond on the west side of Lansdown Road. The pond is recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1881 (Ordnance Survey Glos. LXXI.16.16) and is shown as a rectangular pond measuring 10 metres long by 4 metres wide. It had a surrounding boundary wall and a stone revetted access which was the full width of the south end, and which sloped down to the water. This suggests that the pond may have been used for watering cattle.
The pond lay within a field against the line of Lansdown Road. The field, although not the pond itself, is shown by the Clifton tithe map but had been subdivided into blocks by 1881 and the blocks subsequently developed for housing. The pond falls entirely within the curtilage of No.43 Lansdown Road, being located partly beneath the front garden, but mainly beneath the front part of the house.

Two limekilns approximately 80 metres to the north-west of Hengrove Farm. The limekilns are recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan of 1883. The land was at that time owned by the Smyth family of Ashton Court.
The function of the limekilns, whether producing lime for agriculture or the construction industry, and it is also unclear if the kilns had any relationship to the quarry which lay in the same field, immediately to the north of Hengrove Farm (SMR 20306). The two limekilns are recorded on a map of 1917 concerned with the proposed sale of Herngrove Farm (BRO DD/QK C/2984 47).

A quarry located approximately 80 metres to the north of Hengrove Farm. The quarry was established by 1883 and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan of that year. It had apparently gone out of use by 1930 (BRO 40577/12-13). The purpose of the quarry is unknown, though it was presumably for stone. It is not clear whether the quarry had any relationship to the limekilns in the same field immediately to the north-west of Hengrove Farm (SMR 20305).  A tramway is marked on a map dated 1917 (BRO DD/QK C/2984 47) which is concerned with the sale of Hengrove Farm.

KNOWN_AS: Gunpowder magazine south of Shirehampton Park
MONUMENT_DESC: Gunpowder magazine south of Shirehampton Park. The magazine stored gunpowder deposited by shipping entering the port, which was unloaded at the surviving quay to the east (SMR 743). The building was demolished to make way for the development of housing at Riverside Close in the late twentieth century.

A limekiln to the west of Wells Road in Hengrove. The kiln is recorded on the Ordnance Survey plan of 1930 which indicates a possible quarry immediately to the south. This may indicate a similar working pattern to the limekilns at Hengrove Farm.

Greyhound Racing Track, located on the northern side of Petherton Road, Hengrove. The track was in existence in the 1930s The kennels lay to the north of the track while one stands was on the west sides and two were on the east.
The site has subsequently been redeveloped as housing.

KNOWN_AS: Group of three parish boundary marker stones at Stoke Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
A group of three stones marking the intersections of parish boundaries on the north side of Stoke Road, Durdham Down. The stones lie 100 metres to the north-west of the centre of the reservoir (SMR 20293).
All are of Pennant sandstone, standing roughly 0.4 metres high and 0.2 metres wide, and are very weathered. On the largest the inscription "WB 1818" is still legible.

KNOWN_AS: Group of two parish boundary marker stones at Stoke Road
MONUMENT_DESC: A group of two parish boundary marker stones located on a traffic island on the north side of Stoke Road, 110 metres to the south-east of the reservoir (SMR 20293). The stones are of Pennant sandstone, standing about 0.3 metres high by 0.2 metres wide, and are very weathered. No inscriptions appear to survive on either of the stones.

KNOWN_AS: Bedminster Poor House, West Street, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC: Bedminster Poor House, located on the south-eastern side of West Street. The building was in existence by 1827 (BRO AC/PL  107/2; BRO AC/E 21) and was also recorded by the Bedminster tithe survey of 1841 (Parcel 789; BRO EP/A/23/7). It was a large L-shaped structure on the West Street and Cromwell Street frontages. Much of the structure was apparently still extant in 1854  but it had been largely demolished by 1874 (Burchill 2003).

Pond located some 100 metres to the south of Church Road, Redfield. The large rectangular pond was established in the early nineteenth century, apparently as part of a scheme to supply water to private subscribers in Bristol. It was in existence by the early 1840s and was recorded by the St. George tithe survey of 1842 (BRO EP/A/32/32). At that time it lay within the grounds of Moorfields House. The pond was extant in 1883 and was recorded as a fishpond by the Ordnance Survey first edition Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.19), which indicates that the pond was orientated from east-north-east to west-south-west and was 52.5 metres long by 25 metres wide. The pond was set within a walled garden and surrounded by a row of trees on each side, and a double row of trees on the east.
The pond was apparently infilled when Victoria Avenue was developed in the 1890s.

Stratford Mill, Blaise Estate. Late C18. Red Pennant rubble, pantile roof with coped end gables. Single-depth plan. 2 storeys; 2-window range. 2 stable doors to the centre, and on first-floor door; paired casements have horizontal bars, and timber lintels. INTERIOR not inspected. SUBSIDIARY FEATURES: steel undershot wheel, ratchet and sluice to the left end.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/21/1367).

Inner Lodge, Blaise Estate Cottage. 1798. By Humphrey Repton, some mid C20 alteration. Rough-cast, brick ridge stack and round-ended tile roof. T-shaped plan. 1 storey and attic; 1-window range. Varied, mostly C20 fenestration, original ground-floor and dormer windows to the N have Gothic-headed glazing bars; altered verandah and slated porch; gable has barge-boards. INTERIOR not inspected. Part of Repton's landscape scheme for Blaise Castle House and described in the Red Book.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/21/1369).

KNOWN_AS: Oil and Colour Store, Victoria Road

MONUMENT_DESC:
Gate Lodge, Lodge and gateway. 1798-9. By Humphrey Repton. Pennant ashlar with limestone dressings, roof not visible. Single-depth plan, linked by an arch to a turret. Gothick style. 2 storeys; 1-window range. Left-hand lodge slightly forward of the entrance porch beside the 4-centred carriage archway, a tall octagonal turret on the right, with string courses to the ground and first floors and a crenellated parapet, machicolated above the archway. 3-light ground-floor and 2-light first-floor windows with Tudor-arched heads and labels; Tudor-arched door in porch below a shield and first-floor crossed arrow slit window. INTERIOR not inspected. Part of Repton's landscape design for Blaise Castle House
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/21/1365).

Model dairy Blaise Estate. 1802. By John Nash. Render, limestone dressings, rendered stack, pantiled verandah and thatched roof. Single-depth plan. Picturesque style. Single storey and attic; 3-window range. Apsidal end has a fitted bench beneath an overhanging verandah, porch to SW doorway, pantiled verandah to NE, diagonal lattice casement windows, 3 small eaves dormers and diagonally-set stacks. INTERIOR not inspected. Though styled as a Picturesque cottage, the dairy was used as a functional part of the house's economy.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/21/1371).

KNOWN_AS: The Mansion House, Canynge Road, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC: The Mansion House, located at the corner of Clifton Down and Canynge Road, Clifton (Hudson 1993).

Percy Hall, Parson Street, Bedminster. The date of construction of the building is currently unknown but it was in existence by the early 1840s and was recorded by the Bedminster tithe survey of 1841 (BRO EP/A/32/8). The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town Plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.8.8) surveyed in 1881 records the main house, outbuildings and a formal garden to the rear (north-east). The building had been demolished by the beginning of the twentieth century and Mansfield Street developed on its site.

KNOWN_AS: Church of St. Silas, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: The church of St. Silas, located between St. Silas Street and Arthur Street, off Feeder Road. The church was destroyed by bombing in 1940.
Albert Pottery, at the east end of Victoria Road (ST 60584 72354 approx.).

KNOWN_AS: Manure works, Victoria Road, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: Manure works, Victoria Road, St. Philip's. The fertiliser factory is recorded on the Second edition Ordnance Survey map of 1904 as a single block of buildings between Victoria Road and Albert Road (ST 60584 72354).
Colour works located on the inside of the bend of the river Avon to the south of Temple Meads (ST 59883 72236).
1792: Property containing 1 "Pitt", 1 large, l shaped and 1 other building at W end.
1792. Brickyard marked, H shaped building, and 1 other to the West. {1}
A map of 1792 shows a brickyard located on the north bank of the river Avon in St. Philip's Marsh. The building is shown as having a reverse L shape {1}.

Brislington Gate, a turnpike gate, across Bath Road. The toll gate was apparently established in the early eighteenth century by the Bristol turnpike trust. A renewal of the trustees powers by Parliament in February 1749 prompted local rioting, and in July 1749 Bedminster Gate was one of a number of turnpike gates destroyed by labourers with blackened faces who called themselves "Jack a Lents" (Latimer 1893, 274). The tollgate survived on this site until 1834 when the Turnpike road was diverted to the present route of the Bath Road because of the problems of frequent flooding and slippage. A new Turnpike House, the present Turnpike Inn, was created 100m east of the former gate.
The original Turnpike House survived as a cottage, then as part of the buildings for a boat repair yard until the site was cleared in c.1990. 
A Pennant rubble wall possibly a survving element of the toll house forms part of the northern boundary of this site (09/11/2007).
1792: Brickyard. 3 rectangular buildings running north-south along the north bank of the Avon. {1}

KNOWN_AS: Limekilns on the east bank of the River Avon, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: Limekilns, located on the east bank of the River Avon to the south of the Feeder Canal. The limekilns were extant by 1792 and are recorded by Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 plan of Bristol. By the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.7) surveyed in 1883 the kilns had been demolished and formed part of the site of a stone yard (SMR 21084).
1792: Map shows one cone of Lime Kiln, on bank of River below Giant's Hole, Vincent Rocks. {1}
New Hotwells, Walcombe Slade.

KNOWN_AS: Shot Castle Hill, above the parade from the Rownham Ferry
MONUMENT_DESC: 1792: Map shows rectangular building marked "Shot Castle, on top of hill parade from Hotwells pump room to Rownham ferry.

Vauxhall Yard on the northern side of Coronation Road. A shipbuilding yard known to have been in existence by 1845 and recorded by the Ordnance Survey 2nd edition 1:2500-scale County Series plan of 1902. The yard had a slip on its southern side into the New Cut.

Marsh Works, a soap and candle Works located on the southern side of Silverthorne Lane, St. Philip's Marsh. The works was located on the south side of Silverthorne Lane and had a frontage on the Feeder Canal.

KNOWN_AS: Woodman, Charles & Son Timber Yard, Feeder Road , St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: Timber yard, located at the west side of the junction of Feeder Road and Small Street, St. Philip's Marsh. The yard was owned by Woodman Charles & Son.

KNOWN_AS: Timber Yard, Silverthorne Lane, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: Timber yard, located at the east end of Silverthorne Lane, St. Philip's Marsh.

KNOWN_AS: Redcliffe Crown Oil Mills, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: The Redcliffe Crown Oil Mills, located on the south side of Chapel Lane, St. Philip's Marsh.

KNOWN_AS: Avonside charcoal mills, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: Avonside Mills, St. Philip's Marsh. The factory appears to have been a charcoal producing site.

KNOWN_AS: Bacon Curing House, Lower Castle Street
White Hart Inn, Old Market Street
Aerated Water Manufactory, Captain Carey's Lane
Public House on Great Ann Street
Quarry to the south of the River Frome, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry located on the south side of the River Frome at Stapleton. The quarry was recorded by the first edition Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882. At that date the quarry measured some 115 metres from east to west and some 60 metres from north to south.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry to the south of the River Frome, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC: A rectangular quarry, located on the east side of Broom Hill, Stapleton. The quarry was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882. At that date is measured 21 metres from east to west by 15 metres north-south and the working face was on its south side.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry to the south of the River Frome, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry located on the south side of the River Frome at Stapleton. The quarry was recorded by the first edition Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882 and at that date the quarry was roughly circular, measuring some 45 metres from east to west by 38 metres north-south. The entrance was on its north side. The lifespan of the quarry is not clear but it was recorded as "Old Quarry" by the first edition plan, suggesting that it was no longer in use by 1880.

Headley Farm, located some 300 metres to the east of Bishopsworth Road. The farm was in existence by the time of the Bedminster tithe survey of 1841 (BRO EP/A/23/7) and survived into the early twentieth century. It was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped for housing.
The site of the farm buildings now lies beneath the gardens to the rear of Nos.70-84 St. Peter's Rise.

KNOWN_AS: Limekiln at Bridgwater Road, Bedminster Down
MONUMENT_DESC: Limekiln on the southern side of Bridgwater Road, Bedminster Down. The limekiln was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.09) published in 1885 as an "Old Limekiln". Its site is now beneath the forecourt of the former Western Road service station.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry at Bridgwater Road, Bedminster Down
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry located on the southern side of Bridgwater Road, Bedminster Down. The quarry was probably associated with adjacent limekilns (SMR 21237 and 21245).

Emmanuel Church, located on the southern side of Guthrie Road, Clifton. The church was constructed in 1869 to a design by John Norton. It was of Pennant sandstone rubble with ashlar dressings. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.15.11) surveyed in 1881 records that it had seats for 800 people. The parish was joined to Christ Church, Clifton in 1963 and Emmanuel Church was subsequently declared redundant (Crossley-Evans 2000, 82).
The body of the church was demolished in 1976 to enable conversion of the building to sheltered housing but the tower is extant.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/2/871).

KNOWN_AS: Limekiln at Bridgwater Road, Bedminster Down
MONUMENT_DESC: Limekiln on the southern side of Bridgwater Road, Bedminster Down. The limekiln was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.09) published in 1885. Its site is now beneath the parking area to the rear of the Kings Head public house.

KNOWN_AS: Kings Head Public House, Bridgwater Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Kings Head Public House, located on the southern side of Bridgwater Road. The building was in existence by the time of the Bedminster tithe survey of 1841 and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.09) published in 1885 as the Kings Head Public House.

Oldmead Farm, located on the southern side of Bridgwater Road, to the north of its junction with Kings Head Lane. The building was in existence at the time of the Bedminster tithe survey of 1841 and was named by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.09) published in 1885 as Oldmead Farm.

Salem Chapel, located on the east side of Chapel Lane. The chapel was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.10) surveyed in 1881 as a Free Methodist chapel. It survived into the twentieth century but was subsequently demolished. The site of the chapel now lies beneath the entrance road to Fishponds Trading Estate.

Croftsend Farm, located on the southern side of Speedwell Road. The building was in existence by the time of the St. George tithe survey of 1842 (BRO EP/A/32/32). The farm survived into the twentieth century but the buildings were subsequently demolished. The site now lies beneath the houses and gardens of Nos.156-164 Speedwell Road.

KNOWN_AS: Coal Pit on the east side of Charlton Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Coal pit, located on the east side of Charlton Road. The pit is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.10) surveyed in 1881 as an "Old" pit. It measured roughly 23 metres from north to south by 17 metres from east to west. The pit has subsequently been infilled and the site redeveloped.
Barton Regis Union Workhouse. The workhouse was constructed in 1860. It was demolished in 1972 (Winstone 1977, pl.91).

KNOWN_AS: Disused railway bridge over the River Avon
MONUMENT_DESC: A disused section of the Bristol and North Somerset Railway of 1873, on a later metal bridge. (1) Structure at present sound, but as it is disused, may well be demolished.

KNOWN_AS: Private vehicle bridge over the River Avon
MONUMENT_DESC: Mid 20th-century light lattice-girder metal bridge formerly allowing private access from Whitby Road to premises on the far side of the Avon, and now disused.(1) Highly likely to be demolished in the near future.

Old Sneed Park Farm, located some 80 metres to the south of Mariner's Drive. The farm is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.11) published in 1889. The farmhouse appears to be extant but the sites of the farmyard and ancillary buildings have been redeveloped for housing.

The church of St. Mary Magdalene, located on the southern side of Mariner's Path. The church is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.11) published in 1889. The building is extant.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry below Circular Road, Clifton Down
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry located on the east side of the Avon Gorge below Circular Road. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.11) published in 1889.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry below Circular Road, Clifton Down
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry located on the east side of the Avon Gorge below Circular Road. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.11) published in 1889.

KNOWN_AS: Mr. Knight's house on the eastern side of Regent Street, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC:
A house located on the eastern side of Regent Street. The house was extant by the mid-eighteenth century and was recorded by the survey of the Manor of Clifton made by Jacob de Wilstar in 1746 for the Society of Merchant Venturers. The plot then comprised "One Tenement, Orchard, Garden and Paddock" which was in the freehold of Francis Freeman and was occupied by a Mr. Knight. The house measured approximately 15 metres from south-west to north-east by 8 metres wide.
The structure was still extant in 1828 but had been extended on the northern end. Also much of the paddock had been developed. The building may have been demolished as part of the works to create Merchant's Road in the late 1860s but had certainly gone by 1883 to make way for the construction of Nos.26-28 Regent Street.

KNOWN_AS: Mr. Peal's house on the eastern side of Regent Street, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC:
A house located on the eastern side of Regent Street. The house was extant by the mid-eighteenth century and was recorded by the survey of the Manor of Clifton made by Jacob de Wilstar in 1746 for the Society of Merchant Venturers. The plot then comprised a house and garden in the freehold of Mr. Peal, with the house in the southern corner of the garden on Regent Street. The building may still have been extant in 1828 but if so it had been altered by the addition of two bay windows on the main, south-west facing, elevation. The northern half of the garden had been divided off to provide the plot for a new building erected on the Regent Street frontage.
The house had been demolished by 1883 and the site redeveloped for the block which forms Nos.2-12 Regent Street.

KNOWN_AS: Mr. Cann's house on the eastern side of Regent Street, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC: A house located on the eastern side of Regent Street. The house was extant by the mid-eighteenth century and was recorded by the survey of the Manor of Clifton made by Jacob de Wilstar in 1746 for the Society of Merchant Venturers. The plot then comprised a mansion house and gardens in the freehold of William Cann, onetime Town Clerk of Bristol. Cann also leased or rented the house (SMR 20877) and land adjoining to the north The building was set a few metres back from Regents Street frontage, with gardens to the rear. The building was apparently demolished in the early 1770s to make way for the construction of Boyce's Buildings.

KNOWN_AS: Mrs. Parsons's house and close on the eastern side of Regent Street, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC: A house located on the eastern side of Regent Street. The house was extant by the mid-eighteenth century and was recorded by the survey of the Manor of Clifton made by Jacob de Wilstar in 1746 for the Society of Merchant Venturers. The house stood in the southern part of a plot in the possession of a Mrs. Parsons close to its Regent Street frontage. The building had been demolished by 1828 to make way for the construction of the houses and garden of Saville Place.

KNOWN_AS: Hotel on the south side of Princess Victoria Street, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC: A hotel on the south side of Princess Victoria Street, Clifton. The hotel was extant by 1828 and was presumably built in the late-eighteenth or early-nineteenth century. It was approximately 38 metres square and had a square central courtyard, reached by a haulingway off Princess Victoria Street. The building had been demolished and the site redeveloped by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.16) surveyed in 1883.

Surrey Lodge, located at the north-east corner of Brunswick Square. The building was the lodge to the Brunwick Square burial ground (BUAD 1022M). The date at which the building was constructed is currently unknown but it post-dates Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 plan of Bristol. It is a two-storey structure with a hipped slate roof. The main, south-facing, elevation is of limestone ashlar with an elliptical arch with rusticated voussoirs at the centre. There are blocks to either side with sash windows.
The interior of the building was completely remodelled in the 1980s or early 1990s and no historic internal fixtures or fittings now remain.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/6/1885).

No.90, West Street, Old Market. A building stood on the site in the seventeenth century and elements of seventeenth century fabric survives in the basement, which occupies the front part of the building's footprint. Subsequently the building was extensively rebuilt and the majority of the fabric now dates to the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. The building is a three-storey rendered structure with a pitched roof.

Domain, a seat located in Cathedral Walk, Canon's Marsh. The seat was designed by the artists Langlands & Bell, Ben Langlands (1955-) and Nikki Bell (1959-), in April 2005. It was commissioned by the developer of Harbourside, Crest Nicholson, at a quoted cost of £85,000.
The seat is circular and is 6 metres in diameter and stands 0.45 metres high. It is made of curved slabs of Portland stone 0.10 metres thick which are supported on uprights 0.15 metres wide. There is a lowered slab on the north-eastern side. Forty-five top-level domain codes, also known as "internet country codes", are carved into the upper surface. The whole structure rests on shallow concrete foundations. The fabrication, installation and stone carving was by Cathedral Works Organisation based in Chichester. Domain was installed on 24 March 2006.

Guinness Shed, located at Prince's Wharf, Wapping. The shed was built in 1957 to support the importation of Guinness stout into the Port of Bristol. It is a two-storey steel shed with a pitched roof. The building was originally used for the storage of bottles and crates and a cell, or cold store, was built against its western end in c.1960. The shed was converted into a canteen for Guinness workers on the wharf in 1969 (Leech 2005).

Guinness Cells, located at Prince's Wharf, Wapping. In the 1930s the Guiness stout supplied to the south-west of England was brewed in Dublin and shipped to Bristol, Glasgow, Liverpool and Manchester. In Bristol Broad Quay was the original site for unloading but in the 1930s this operation was moved to Prince's Wharf. The method of distribution was changed in the 1950s and the stout was shipped in 504 gallon aluminium casks. Two cells, or cold stores, were built at Prince's Wharf for bulk storage of the casks in 1954. Two further cells were later added, and a fifth was constructed against the Guinness shed in c.1960.
The cells are two-storey brick structures, the store element comprising the bulk of the building and having steel double doors in the north-facing elevation.
Comparison with Guinness installations in other major western ports has suggested that the Bristol cells are likely to be unique, representing a local storage solution. The cells may have been designed by the Port of Bristol, although the Guinness company was certainly involved in the design (Leech 2005, 16).

Aldworth's Dock, Narrow Quay. The dock was built in c.1625 for the merchant Robert Aldworth. It was apparently a rectangular dock with stone walls measuring approximately 1.8 metres wide (Good 1987). The overall size of the dock and its detailed form is not currently (31/10/2006) known. The dock was filled in c.1687 to enable development of housing and at least five vessels were in the dock at the time (BUAD 453).

A malthouse located on the south-west side of Anvil Street, off New Kingsley Road. The malthouse occupied the site between Anvil Street, Avon Lane (originally known as Hay Market) and Avon Square. The date of construction is currently (9/11/2006) unknown but a structure stood on the south-western half oof the site by 1742, and a building occupying the same footprint appears to have been in existence by 1828. It was a two-storey structure measuring approximately 20.2 metres from north-east to south-west and was 12.3 metres wide. The building survived into the early twentieth century but was subsequently demolished.

KNOWN_AS: Crane, Lower Midland Yard, Avon Street
MONUMENT_DESC: A crane located on the south side of the dock in Lower Midland Yard, Avon Street. The crane appears to have been constructed in the late-nineteenth century to serve shippingin the dock. The crane stood on a base approximately 2.9 metres square. The crane was extant at the beginning of the twentieth century. A large shed covering the dock had been constructed by 1916 and this covered the site of the crane. It is not clear whether the crane was removed at this point or retained within the shed.

KNOWN_AS: The Lodge, Stoke House, Stoke Park Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Lodge, located 30 metres to the south-east of Stoke House. The house is a four-bay house of two-streys and attic with a cross-gabled roof. The building was probably constructed in the mid-seventeenth century for Robert Cann, a Bristol merchant.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/31/2013).

KNOWN_AS: Mission Chapel on Great Ann Street
Public House on the Gloucester Road

MONUMENT_DESC: 'Tanyard' shown on 1828 Ashmead plan on site of modern tannery (1). Not clear from maps, but some 19th-century buildings may survive.

Lawrence Weston Farm, located on the east side of Lawrence Weston Road. The farm is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan published in 1881 (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.03). Its site now lies largely beneath the youth centre buildignon the east side of the junction of Lawrence Weston Road and Long Cross.

The grounds of Bristol Grammar School created in the nineteenth century out of the late eighteenth century landscape of Tyndall's Park. The grounds feature a landscaped terace, mature trees, rockery and shrubs.
The grounds of Clifton College created in the nineteenth century when the school was developed. Historic features within the grounds include a terrace, cherry avenue and boundary limes.

The garden of Clifton Hill House was created in 1747 at the same time as the house was built and was intended to form an integral design with the building.
Some planting has taken place in the nineteenth and twentieth century, but parts fo the original layout survive.

Nos 7-10 Bedford Row, four attached three-storey houses constructed in the mid-
1820s with considerable twentieth century extensions and alterations in association with their use as nurses accomodation for the Bristol Royal Infirmary. The row of houses incorporated a wedge-shaped portion at the Terrell Street end which appeared to have comprised a separate unit listed as no.11 in some street directories.
At some point in the twentieth century the cellars for the properties were knocked through to create a single room spanning the entire length of the terrace.
The terrace is Listed Grade II, although consent for their demolition was granted in 2005. The terrace was recorded in 2010 prior to demolition (BHER 24870).

The Bell Inn, Stapleton. Built in 1900 on the site of an earlier hostelry probably dating to the seventeenth century. The existing public house consists of a two-three storey brick and rubble-built structure with limestone dressings. Service rooms were placed within a Pennant sandstone with brick dressings two storey rear range that also included a coach house and stable. 
The building was surveyed in 2010 prior to conversion works to create residential accomadation.

KNOWN_AS: Carlton House Industrial School for Girls
Scare Post, Sanbed Road, St Werburgh's
MONUMENT_DESC: Cast iron scare post on the north side of Sandbed Road set against the south wall of no.46 Mina Road. The post is 'T' shaped, approximately 1m high with the words 'Flood Level OCTR 1882' embossed across the top section and 'Adlam, Bristol' embossed veritically on the stem. This is one of four surviving scare posts that record the floods in St Werburgh's in 1882.

KNOWN_AS: Dissused Paper Mill off Atchley Street
Well by The Cottage, City Farm
Colthurst and Harding's Oil and Colour Works, Temple Gate
MONUMENT_DESC: Colthurst and Harding's Oil and Colour works, Portwall Lane. The works lay between Portwall Lane and Pile Street. The Oil ad Colour works was in existence by 1874 and was leased by Colthurst and Harding from Whitson's Charity which owned the property. Two elements of the works were leased for a term of 99 years determinable on the life of George Thorne Ricketts, for which annual rents of £0/7/0 and £1/0/0 were paid. Of the other two elements, one was held on a 21 year absolute lease and "The reversion in a small part of the Freehold is sold to the Bristol Harbour Railway Company," for which an annual rent of £40/0/0 was paid. The other element, a "Piece or parcel of land whereon formerly stood part of the Temple Gate Hotel, fronting Temple Street and Portwall Lane," was held on a 12 year absolute lease from Great Western Railway Company and Bristol and Exeter Railway Company (Anon., 1877 20). The building was still extant during the First World War but were subsequently demolished. The site now lies partly beneath Redcliffe Way and partly beneath the grassed area on the south side of Portwall Lane.
Broadweir Public Baths. The public baths was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition map of 1883. The building was demolished in 1997.

No.16 Old Park Hill. The house is of seventeenth-century date and lies on the northern side of the street. It is of two storeys with a doorway in the centre of the Old Park Hill elevation. There is a three-light window on the west side of the door and a two-light window on the east, and stone drip moulds above the door and both windows. The roof is a hipped pantile roof aligned parallel with Old Park Hill which turns to a gable facing on to Old Park Hill at the west end of the roof. There is a brick chimney stack at the valley and another at the eastern corner of the house. The building was the garden house of Edward Tilley.

KNOWN_AS: Garden house and garden at Medical Avenue
MONUMENT_DESC: A garden house and associated garden on the southern side of Medical Avenue, within the University of Bristol precinct. The house was of late seventeenth- or early eighteenth-century date and was on the north side of a garden ground. Part of the north-western wall of the building survives, facing on to Medical Avenue, and its lower courses are of Pennant sandstone rubble (BUAD 3505).

No.14 Dighton Street, located on the southern side of Dighton Street.. Dighton Street had been laid out by 1742 and the house was apparently built between 1742 and the early nineteenth century. In 1883 the building was occupied by one Ernest H. Kethro.
The building was demolished in c.1962.

No.15 Dighton Street, located on the southern side of Dighton Street. Dighton Street had been laid out by 1742 and the house was apparently built between 1742 and the early nineteenth century. In 1883 the building was occupied by a Mrs Sharp.
The building was demolished in c.1962.

No.2 Charles Street, located on the northern side of Charles Street. The house was constructed in the mid-eighteenth century.
The building was demolished in c1964.

No.3 Charles Street, located on the northern side of Charles Street. The house was constructed in the mid-eighteenth century.
The building was demolished in c1964.

At ST54967787 is a univallate earthwork on Kings Weston Hill (Tratman 1946, 179). The rampart is up to 2 feet high,  and the outer ditch 3 feet wide, and 1 foot deep. The northern bank, marked by the hedge of Evergreen Wood, is 220 yards long and is best preserved at the east end near a small tumulus (SMR 784). The ditch apparently avoids this mound by crossing the crown of the hill obliquely. {1}The north bank of this earthwork does not run along the hedge line of Evergreen Wood, but along the edge of the very steep scarp about 12 metres further north. The ditch here is inside the bank and not outside as elsewhere. Within the wood at the west end there are signs of a retaining wall in the outer face of the bank which is 3 metres wide and 1.5 metres high above a ditch more than 2 metres wide. Traces of an outer defence along the north and south sides have been noted by Dr. Everton. There does not seem to be any entrance to the earthwork. In 1966 the earthwork was cut by a gas main trench.
ST54847890, an old bank goes across the hill at this point, reported by Boon in 1950. {1}

Congregational chapel located on the north-eastern side of Anvil Street, St. Philip's. The chapel appears to have been built in the mid-nineteenth century and was a two-storey structure, measuring 20.6 metres from south-west to north-east and was 12.6 metres wide. Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.2) surveyed in 1883 indicates that the chapel could accommodate 600 worshippers. The chapel survived into the twentieth century but had been demolished by the mid 1990s.

KNOWN_AS: Limekiln at No.45 West Street, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC:
Limekiln located at No.45 West Street. The limekiln seems to have been established in the mid-nineteenth century and was first recorded by Ashmead's 1855 survey of Bristol. It was a freestanding stone structure at the south-east corner of the site.
The limekiln was archaeologically excavated in 2005 by Avon Archaeological Unit (SMR 22226).

KNOWN_AS: Hartcliffe Methodist Church, No.51 Mowcroft Road, Hartcliffe
MONUMENT_DESC:
Hartcliffe Methodist Church located on the eastern side of Mowcroft Road, Hartcliffe. The church was built in the mid-twentieth century and is a two-storey Modernist building with a pitched copper roof, orientated east-west. There is a wide entrance with a shallow canopy above on the west-facing elevation. Projecting from the south-west corner is a square Italianate campanile with a tall, narrow light in the centre of the upper stage of each face.
A two-storey community hall is attached to the south wall of the church while at the south-western end of the hall is the minister's house.

KNOWN_AS: Well by South Wales Railway Tavern
Pumps by South Wales Railway Tavern
Pump to the rear of 60 Fairfield Road
Fountain to the rear of Caer Brito
Fountain in the garden of Cotham House
Statue in the grounds of Cotham House
Three Crows Public House, John Street
War memorial at St. John's Church, Apsley Road, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC:
War Memorial at St. John's Church, Apsley Road, Clifton. The memorial is located at the north-east corner of the churchyard and consists of an octagonal stepped stone plinth surmounted by a tall cross.
[Public Monument and Sculpture Association reference number BR341].

KNOWN_AS: Bristol Water Works Reservoir at Bishopsworth Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Bristol Water Works reservoir located on the east side of Bishopsworth Road. The reservoir was in existence by the mid-1880s and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500-scale plan (Somerset Sheet VI.10) published in 1886. The plan indicates that the reservoir was rectangular, measuring 44 metres from north to south by 29 metres wide and had ramped earthen sides.

KNOWN_AS: Limekiln in a quarry north of Kings Weston Road
MONUMENT_DESC: A limekiln located in a quarry (SMR 20836) some 250 metres to the north of Kings Weston Road. The kiln is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire sheet LXXI.07) published in 1885 and stood at the foot of the quarry face on the south side of the quarry. It measured 6 metres east-west by 4.5 metres.

KNOWN_AS: Old quarry north of Kings Weston Road
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry located some 250 metres to the north of Kings Weston Road. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire sheet LXXI.07) published in 1885 as "Old Quarry".

Coombe House, located on the north side of Canford Lane. The building is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.07) published in 1885. The house is extant.

Canford Farm, located on the south side of Canford Lane. The farm is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.07) published in 1885. The farmhouse stood against Canford Lane itself while to the south-west were a number of outbuildings. The farm was demolished to make way for Canford Cemetery.

A bridge, named as "Iron Bridge" by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.07) published in 1885. The bridge carried a running lane along the south side of Kingsweston Hill across Kings Weston Road.

Clack Farm located on the west side of the River Trym, immediately above the Trym valley. The farm is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.07) published in 1885. To the east of the farmhouse was a yard and U-shaped range of outbuildings to the east of the farmhouse.

A sewage tank, located in the south-east corner of Canford Cemetery. The feature was at the corner of a field at the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.07) published in 1885. It measured 12 metres by 10.5 metres and was fed by a sewage drain (SMR 20851) which emptied into it on the east side.

A sewage drain running from north-east to south-west and feeding into a sewage tank in the corner of a field, now the south-east corner of Canford Cemetery. The feature was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.07) published in 1885 which indicates that the drain was on a raised earth aqueduct and was approximately 250 metres long.

Redhouse Farm, located on the northern side of Coombe Lane. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.07) published in 1885 shows a yard and a range of outbuildings to the north-east of the farmhouse. The farmhouse appears to be extant but the site of the farmyard has been redeveloped and now lies beneath the plots of Nos.42 and 42a Coombe Lane.

A sewage tank located some 80 metres to the west of Canford Lane. The tank was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.08) published in 1881 and was an open tank measuring 14 metres by 10 metres. It was fed by a channel running into its west side.

A quarry located on the western side of Coombe Lane. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.07) published in 1885 as "Old Quarry". The site of the quarry now lies mainly beneath the house and garden at of No.19 Coombe Lane.

KNOWN_AS: Possible early Christian cemetery, Kingsweston Hill
MONUMENT_DESC: A gas pipeline excavated along Kingsweston Down in 1966 exposed at least ten extended inhumation burials between ST 5491 7782 and ST 5498 7785. The skeletons were buried in shallow graves, with heads to the west. In a number of cases the right arm was laid across the chest, with the left arm extended. No grave goods were recovered, but black pottery was found in the graves for Inhumations I, III and IIIi. It was inferred that the occupants of the graves were Christians buried between 400 and 700AD (Godman 1972).

KNOWN_AS: Don John's Cross, Church Road, St. George
MONUMENT_DESC:
Don John's Cross. The cross was probably of medieval date and is recorded by a map of Kingswood Forest in 1610 at the junction of Church Road, Clouds Hill Road and Summerhill Road. This plan suggests that the cross was set on a stepped base and Pooley also reports that the cross was a circular column of freestone, raised on an octagonal base (Pooley 1868, 75). The first edition Ordnance Survey 1:2500 scale plan (Gloucestershire sheet LXXII.14) surveyed in 1880-1881 suggests that the original position of the cross was on the southern side of Church Road, opposite what is now St. George's Park. However, a location nearer the junction would appear more probable. John Latimer, the Bristol City Librarian and historian, reports that the cross was demolished in July 1749 in rioting prompted by the renewal of the Bristol turnpike trustees powers by Parliament in February 1749 (Latimer 1893, 274).
Elements of the cross were removed to the garden of the vicarage to the east of the church (to ST 62490 73570) during the nineteenth century. The remnants of the cross were moved to the front of The Glebes (to ST 62376 73624 approx) during the twentieth century.

St. Anne's Mill. St. Anne's Mill was a water mill located at approximately ST 621728. The mill stood 40 yards from the chapel on the opposite side of Brislington Brook. A picture of 1812 shows it as a single-storey thatched building. It was L-shaped and stood on the north side of the northern of two channels leading from very large loaf shaped mill pond. The mill was been in existence for several centuries, certainly from the later medieval period, but its foundation date is not known. The earliest legible entry in the Brislington parish book is for 1696 when Edward Ward was the occupier. The mill pond and race were still extant at the time of W. J. Pountney's archaeological excavation of St. Anne's Chapel (to the north) in 1914 (SMR 20221).
