ST629728 - remains of colliery, opposite the junction of Trooper's Hill Road and Parfitt's Hill. The chimney and engine - house walls incorporate copper slag blocks in their construction.

St. Anne's Well was formerly a place of Pilgrimage visited by Henry VII. When it was cleared in 1878 many coins & tokens, offerings of the pilgrims were recovered from it, a further clearance in 1923 revealed it to be 20 feet deep, with well preserved stonework & a spring at the bottom.{1}{2} {3} The well was restored by Bristol Corporation in 1924 & a canopy erected over it {4} "the water of the well is believed by many uneducated people to have some healing virtue. Number of coins found in 1880 when cleaned - engraving- (1Edward I

KNOWN_AS: Preaching cross in the churchyard of St. Luke's, Brislington
MONUMENT_DESC:
A preaching cross of probable thirteenth-century date by the south porch of St. Luke's Church, Brislington. The cross was replaced in 1874, although the original shaft was retained. Pooley (1877, 82) noted that the shaft was the only remaining element of any antiquity when he examined the cross a few years later. He recorded the dimensions of the all of the elements of the cross, noting the shaft to be nine feet in height. Robinson (1914, 131) describes the cross as "a handsome old churchyard or preaching cross, raised on four steps, the shafts carrying the cross being about 8 feet in height."
The cross has a Grade II listing (Listed Building No. 901-1/49/456).

KNOWN_AS: Site of a coal mine to the south of Bath Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Mine shaft and head works located on the south side of Bath Road. The mound, known locally as The Tump, was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition map of the early 1880s and was still extant at the time of the provisional 1:10560 Ordnance Survey map published during the 1940s. It has been suggested that the mound is a barrow, but the feature was in fact formed from soil dumped from mining activity and marks the site of the mine shaft and head works of a coal mine.

ST64087464 Kingswood Lodge {1} Kingswood Lodge is an ancient house sometimes called "King
John's Hunting Lodge" from a tradition that it was built and owned by him. There is no proof of this,
but the house appears to have been standing nearly 300 years ago.

KNOWN_AS: Magazine store east of Washingpool Farm
MONUMENT_DESC: Armament Store depicted on 1920s Air photograph (CCC 11756/6238 ST 5279/1, Crowther and Dickson, 2008, 200, fig. 10.4). The store was linked to the complex of structures associated with the National Filling Factory at Chittening (2750M). It appears to have been connected to the factory by a light rail network, also visible in the air photo.

KNOWN_AS: Magazine store east of Washingpool Farm
MONUMENT_DESC: Armament Store depicted on 1920s Air photograph (CCC 11756/6238 ST 5279/1, Crowther and Dickson, 2008, 200, fig. 10.4). This is the third of three stores that lay to the north and east of Washingpool Farm and  linked to the complex of structures associated with the National Filling Factory at Chittening (2750M). It appears to have been connected to the factory by a light rail network, also visible in the air photo.

HM Henbury, Avonmounth. In December 1916, Nobel's Explosives Company at Ardeer, Scotland were invited by the Ministry of Munitions to establish a factory at Henbury following the success of their Ardeer plant. Work began at H.M. Henbury to create a plant for the manufacture of propellant nitrocellulose powders. Only part of the site was completed before the site was abandoned in May 1917 (Cocroft 2000, 166).
The precise location of this factory has been identified during study of pre-Second World War aerial photographs (CCC 11756/6225 ST 5281/1, CCC 11756/6226 ST 5281/1) undertaken as part of the Severn Estuary Rapid Coastal Zone Assessment (Crowther and Dickson 2008, 199).
The site was derelict before the Second World War and is now completely built over.

KNOWN_AS: Fountain in garden off Catherine Place
Weir on Cutlersmill Brook, to rear of 52 Banner Road
Pump to the rear of Vickrey's Buildings
Pump to rear of Pennywell Road
Footbridge across Mill Stream, Fox Lane
Quarry to the south of the River Frome, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry located on the south side of the River Frome at Stapleton. The quarry was recorded by the first edition Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882. At that date the quarry measured at least 30 metres from east to west by 28 metres north-south. Two working faces are recorded by the plan, on its east and south sides.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry on the north side of Blackberry Hill, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry located on the north side of Blackberry Hill, Stapleton. The quarry was recorded by the first edition Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882. At that date the quarry measured 38 metres from east to west by 37 metres north-south and there were working faces on its northern and eastern sides.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry on the east side of Small Lane, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry located on the west side of the junction of Blackberry Hill and Small Lane, Stapleton. The quarry, roughly triangular, occupied the corner of the defined by the roads. It was recorded by the first edition Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882. At that date the quarry measured 40 metres from east to west by 28 metres north-south and there were working faces on its northern, eastern and southern sides. The entrance was a via a short cutting at the north-west corner on to Blackberry Hill. The 1:2500 plan records a building of unknown function, presumably a shed or office, by the south face. This measured 6.7 metres from south-west to north-east by 8.1 metres north-west to south-east. The site of the quarry has been infilled.

Henbury. The manor of Henbury seems to have been in existence by the late-Seventh century AD when it was granted to the See of Worcester by the kings of Mercia. A charter of Alfred of c.883 AD indicates that the extent of manor was then similar to that within the later parish boundary. The settlement itself may have been in existence, although there is currently no archaeological evidence to confirm this. Smith (1964) suggested that the placename Henbury may derive from "heagh burgh" meaning "(at) the high or chief fortification." The Domesday survey of 1086 records that Henbury lay within the administrative hundred of Brentry ("Bernitrev").

KNOWN_AS: Quarry on the northern side of Manor Road, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry located on the northern side of Manor Road, close to the junction with Victoria Park. The quarry is recorded by a plan in the Smyth estate records dated between c.1779 and 1783 (BRO AC/PL59). The quarry had been infilled and built over by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882. The site is now beneath the houses and gardens of Nos.3-9 Manor Road.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry to the north of Manor Road, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry located some 280 metres to the north of Manor Road. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882 as "Old Quarry", suggesting that it had been out of use for some time. The quarry was later infilled and is now beneath the northern part of College Court.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry to the north of Manor Road, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry located some 260 metres to the north of Manor Road. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882 as "Old Quarry", suggesting that it had been out of use for some time. The quarry was later infilled and is now beneath the western part of College Court.

Clifton Rocks Railway. The railway was built between 1891 and 1893. A tunnel was excavated behind the cliff face from Clifton down to Hotwells. There were 4 tracks at a gradient of 1 : 2.5 using four cars on same the hydraulic counter-balancing system used by some other cliff railways. The railway was taken over by Bristol Tramways & Carriage Co. in 1912 and was closed in 1934. Both the top and bottom entrances survive in a dilapidated state. The upper station south-west of St. Vincent's Rock Hotel still exists but is fenced off. The lower station on the Portway still displays the name of the railway but has been obscured by concrete buttresses and is almost unrecognisable in consequence.
The site was reused during the Second World War as an emergency radio studio for the BBC (SMR 10569).

KNOWN_AS: Building on the west side of 6, Kingsdown Parade
MONUMENT_DESC: Building sited in the north-east corner of a plot on the south side of Kingsdown Parade, immediately west of No.6 Kingsdown Parade. The plot was created at some time between 1742 and 1828 and the building is almost certainly contemporary with it, possibly a later eighteenth-century merchant's lodge or summerhouse (ie. second residence). The structure was still extant in the early 1880s (Bristol Town Plan LXXI.16.14) but was later demolished.

Abbey Farm, located on the southern side of Parry's Lane. The farmhouse is a rendered stone rubble building with cross-gabled roof and is of probable seventeenth-century date. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.07) published in 1885 records the farmhouse and a number of ancillary buildings, including one which appears to be a barn. Several of these buildings are extant including former outbuildings within the adjacent dairy site.
The farmhouse has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/27/1996).
A quarry on the west side of Druid Hill. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.07) published in 1885.
A small C19 communal garden, with informal planting {1} A typical C19 communal town garden. {1}Well maintained. {1}

No.21 Castle Street, located on the north side of Castle Street. The building was a jettied, gabled house of three storeys and attic with a 1-window range. It was almost certainly constructed as part of the redevelopment of the site of Bristol Castle after its demolition in the late 1650s.
By the nineteenth century the ground floor was a shop. Shop windows with a central, flush, entrance, possibly with a 2-leaf door. One canted bay each to first and second floors, sashes. A single attic window with a pivotting pane. Fretted bargeboards. Lateral stack(s) on east side.
The building was destroyed by bombing on 24 November 1940.

No.22 Castle Street, located on the north side of Castle Street. The building was a jettied, gabled house of three storeys and attic with a 1-window range. It was almost certainly constructed as part of the redevelopment of the site of Bristol Castle after its demolition in the late 1650s.
The attic refronted. jettying to first and second floors only; 1-window range. Shopfront with a recessed central entrance. First-floor bay with twin sashes to the front; twin sashes to the second-floor. A single sash to the attic, which had been refronted with a squared facade.

KNOWN_AS: House at the top of Stile Lane
POSTAL_ADDRESS: The School of Chemistry, Cantock's Close
MONUMENT_DESC: House of seventeenth century date located at the north-west corner of Stile lane and Tyndall's Park. The house was aligned north-west to south-east, facing south-west, with its back to Stile Lane. Gabled to its ends, with cross-gables to the two stacks on the north-east elevation. 2 storeys and attic. A 1-window range to the north-west, a truncated ground-floor window where that storey cut into the hillside; no windows to the north-east; other elevations not recorded.

Prior's Slip. The slipway led to the Frome from the north end of Frome Bridge. It was extant by the time of William Worcestre's survey and is shown on Millerd's 1673 map. It had disappeared by Roque's map of 1742. The parish boundary of St. John runs along the west side of the slip.

Baber's Tower. The building stood on the west side of Midland Road, on the north side of the junction with Unity Street. It was apparently a house with a prospect tower or stair tower on the west side. It was leased by William Champion in the 1730s or early 1740s, who had erected a large "fire works" on the site (Buchanan 1995-96). The building had been demolished by 1743 (Latimer 1893, 244).

The Temple Back Glass Works. The cone of the glass works is shown by Millerd's map of c.1715. The works was owned by Robert Bradley and Co. until 1750. By 1795 James Jones was manufacturing black glass bottles on the site and it appears to have continued in work until 1805.

Redcliff Gate glassworks. The cone is recorded by James Millerd's map of c.1715. It was run by Richard Warren along with the St. Thomas Street glasshouse. The cone was demolished c.1718 to give improved access to Redcliff Backs from Redcliff Street.
Castle Green Dispensary.

The St. Thomas Street glasshouse. The glass works was in existence by 1712 and was owned by Richard Warren, who also owned the nearby Redcliff Gate glasshouse. When Richard Warren died in 1767 the business was taken over by Richard Cannington and his partners. The cone collapsed in 1773, the "ruinous" glass house changing hands the same year. In 1775 it was sold again, this time to Vigor and Stevens who owned the Redcliff Backs glass house. Ultimately, in 1802, the business was merged with Wadham Ricketts and Co.

KNOWN_AS: Motor Cab and Carriage Depot, Westbury Road, Westbury-on-Trym
MONUMENT_DESC:
Motor Cab and Carriage Depot, located on the eastern side of Westbury Road. The building, designed by the Bristol architect W. H. Watkins, was built on the site in 1909-1910 for the Bristol Tramways & Carriage Co. The building is a single-storey structure of rendered brick with hipped and gable roofs. At the north-west corner there is a circular turret with the arms of the Bristol Tramways company moulded on the exterior below the eaves of the roof. In 1911 a small structure was constructed on the south side of the garage building to provide a pavilion for tennis courts which occupied part of the remainder of the site. The building remained in the ownership of the Bristol Tramways company until the early 1950s when it became the premises of Welch & Co. Ltd., "motor car agents & d[ea]l[e]rs."
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/28/2094).

KNOWN_AS: Bear Pit at Bristol Zoological Gardens
MONUMENT_DESC: A Bear Pit created at Bristol Zoological Gardens in 1836 to a design by Richard Forrest . The design of the bear pit utilised the existing limekiln on the site to provide the depth and plan form for the pit. The bear pit survived until 1926 when it was roofed over and converted into an aquarium (Green-Armytage 1964, 61).

KNOWN_AS: The Concrete House, No.4 The Ridgeway
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Concrete House, No.4 The Ridgeway, located on the north side of the Ridgeway. The building was constructed in 1935 to a design by Aymas Connell and Basil Ward of the architectural practice Connell, Ward and Lucas using Le Corbusier's Dom-ino frame system (reportedly the first building in the United Kingdom to use the system). It is a two-storey structure of reinforced concrete with a flat roof and a penthouse. Internally the plan consists of a lateral passage, and many of the original fittings survive.
The house has a Grade II Listing (Listed Building number 901-1/22/2080).

Cotham Chapel, located on the southern side of Redland Road, Redland. The chapel was a Wesleyan Methodist chapel which was constructed in the later nineteenth century. It was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town Plan (Bristol Sheets LXXI.12.24 and LXXI.12.25) surveyed in 1881 and then had seating for 800 worshippers.
The building is extant.

KNOWN_AS: Yew Tree Cottage, No.5 Hollywood Road, Brislington
MONUMENT_DESC:
Yew Tree Cottage, No.5 Hollywood Road, located on the western side of Hollywood Road, Brislington. The building is the northern of a pair of cottages which were apparently constructed in the eighteenth century. It is a two-storey house with a pitched pantile roof and a catslide at the rear. The main, east-facing, elevation has a two-window range with a central door opening. The timber doorframe has a reeded architrave with corner roundels, and contains a six-panel door. The fenestration comprises six-over-six pane sashes without horns, although the southern ground-floor window has a smaller opening and a four-over-four pane horned sash. There is a blank window opening above the main entrance.
The house has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/48/463).

A nursery located on the eastern side of Cheltenham Road, on the northern side of its junction with Bath Buildings. The nursery was in existence by the 1880s and is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town Plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.5) surveyed in 1881. The street directory for 1883 record it as belonging to Jesse Prestidge, seedsman and florist. The nursery was a walled, essentially rectangular site with the main vehicular entrance on Bath Buildings. The site had a 42-metre frontage on Cheltenham Road and was 37 metres wide, covering an area of approximately 1490 square metres. A large building at the south-west corner of the site appears to have been residential, and there were ten greenhouses towards the centre of the site.
The western part of the site was removed to enable the widening of Cheltenham Road and the remainder of the site was subsequently redeveloped.
The Broad Weir engineering works on the north side of Broad Weir. The works is recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883.

A smithy located on the south-western side of Clayton Street, Avonmouth. The building was apaprently constructed in the late nineteenth century and is first recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500-scale County Series plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.01) published in 1890.

Congregational Chapel (SMR 22550) on the eastern side of Napier Road, Avonmouth. The chapel was constructed in the late nineteenth century and was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500-scale County Series plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.01) published in 1903. The building was still extant at the time of the First World War (1914-1918) but was subsequently demolished.

Home Farm, Horfield. The farm was in existence by the time of the Horfield tithe survey of 1843. It had been demolished by the time of the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.08) published in 1903 and the site redeveloped for housing.

Quabb Farm, Horfield. The farm was in existence by the time of the Horfield tithe survey of 1843 (Land Parcel 60). The farmhouse was a five-bay, two-storey building with a hipped pantile roof and was constructed of stone rubble. There were tall, two-flue chimney stacks at either end of the roof.
The farm was apparently still extant in 1935 (Winstone 1985, pl.174) but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped for housing.

Poplar Cottage, Horfield. The building was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.08) published in 1881. By 1903 the building had been renamed as Ardagh.

Elmtree Farm, located on the northern side of North Street, Bedminster. The farm was apparently in existence by the time of the Bedminster tithe survey of 1841. It was still extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.17) surveyed in 1883 had been demolished and the site cleared by 1903.

KNOWN_AS: St. Francis's Church, North Street, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Francis's Church, on the southern side of North Street, Bedminster. Holy Cross Church occupied the site in the 1880s, but appears to have been rebuilt at the end of the nineteenth century as St. Francis's Church. This was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXV.04) published in 1903. It is not clear whether this represented alteration or complete rebuilding of the earlier church.
The church was damaged by bombing in December 1940 and again in April 1941. It was rebuilt between 1951 and 1953 (Crossley-Evans 2000, 80). The church and the associated vicarage are extant.

Barrow Hill Farm, located on the northern side of Grove Leaze, Shirehampton, some 700 metres to the west of Shirehampton village. The farm was in existence by the time of the survey for the Tithing of Shirehampton in the parish of Westbury-on-Trym which records it as Parcel 226. The farmhouse was at the western side and a number of outbuildings extended to the east and north. The farm survived into the twentieth century but the outbuildings were demolished and housing developed on the site. The farmhouse, however, appears to survive.

KNOWN_AS: Miner's Arms, Bedminster Down Road, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Miner's Arms public house, located on the northern side of Bedminster Down Road. The building was constructed after 1841 and was recorded Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXV.08) published in 1890. It is a rendered two-storey, three bay house with a pitched pantile roof. The main entrance is at the centre of the main, south-east facing, elevation. The windows to either side of the door are casements while the fenestration at first floor comprises sashes. There are chimneystacks at either end of the roof and another at the centre of the ridge towards its south-western end.
There is a photograph of the building in the SMR Collection of Ground-based photographs, number 1860.

Sprods Farm, Bedminster. The farm was located some 20 metres to the north of Bedminster Down Road at its junction with Winsterstoke Road. The farm was in existence by the time of the Bedminster tithe survey of 1841 (BRO EP/A/32/8). The farmhouse was at the south-west corner of site and there were outbuildings to the north-east. The farm survived into the early twentieth century but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped for housing.

KNOWN_AS: Parish boundary marker stone at Hampton Road
MONUMENT_DESC: A parish boundary marker stone set in the footway on the eastern side of Hampton Road, Cotham, adjacent to the junction with Cotham Lawn Road. The stone is of Pennant sandstone and is approximately 0.3 metres high. An inscription on the west face of the stone appears to read "W P".

Tyning Farm, located some 900 metres to the west of Wells Road. The farm was recorded by the Whitchurch Tithe Survey of 1840 (BRO 24537/1 & 2) and was still extant in 1938. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.11) published in 1884 records the farm as a farmhouse surrounded by a number of outbuildings. An orchard lies on its west side. The land parcel was roughly 60 metres square and the parish boundary followed its north side.
The farm was demolished after the Second World War to make way for housing development and its site now lies largely beneath the gardens of Nos.88-92 Tarnock Avenue and Nos.29-31 Great Hayles Road.

KNOWN_AS: War Memorial at All Saints' Church, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC:
War memorial at All Saints Church, Pembroke Road. The memorial is located some 12 metres to the west of the church, close to the junction of Pembroke Road and Alma Vale Road. It was designed by F. C. Eden and was erected in 1928. The memorial takes the form of a wooden Calvary cross surrounded by stone figures set on a rounded arch on a polygonal stone base. It is flanked by obelisks.
The memorial has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/2/10090).

The Port Sanitary Hospital at Avonmouth Docks. The hospital was for infectious diseases and was presumably therefore an isolation hospital. It was apparently constructed at the end of the nineteenth century and is recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucester Sheet LXXI.01) published in 1903. The building measured 25 metres north-east to south-west, was 10 metres wide and stoods within a walled enclosure. There was also a group of outbuildings on the western boundary of the site. The hospital was demolished to make way for Royal Edward Dock and must therefore been removed c.1902.

KNOWN_AS: Parish boundary marker stone at No.1 Cotham Side
MONUMENT_DESC: Two parish boundary marker stones set in the north-west facing rear boundary wall (Cotham Brow elevation) of No.1 Cotham Side. The stones are located at the foot of the wall, and are of Pennant sandstone. Any carved inscription on the stone would appear to have been lost.

KNOWN_AS: Romano-British settlement at Crook's Marsh Farm
MONUMENT_DESC: Romano-British settlement at Crook's Marsh Farm. The settlement was discovered during clay extraction in the early 1980s. The form of the settlement is unclear but it consisted of several large ditches, approximately 2.5 metres wide and 1.2 metres deep, which were associated with small rectangular enclosures. The finds suggested that the site was occupied during the fourth-, and possibly the fifth-centuries A.D. There was also some evidence for silting and recutting of the ditches and also for industrial activity on the eastern side of the site (Everton & Everton 1981).

KNOWN_AS: Cartographic depiction of a quarry at Rock
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire sheet LXXVI.02) published in 1889 marks a quarry at Rock. The quarry is shown as a bowl shaped escarpment measuring approximately 50m across facing south towards the village. Structures, possibly associated with quarry activity are also shown in the vicinity. 
Several trees are shown in and around the quarry that might suggest it was in infrequent use or disused. Later plans do not show the quarry, although it is still visible to the rear of the modern Millbank Close properties.

Fir Tree Cottage at Rock near Brislington appears to have been in existance by the time of the Brislington Tithe survey in 1846 and was possibly associated with the quarry approximately 60m north east of the building (22080). The building is a two-storey symetrical cottage constructed of Pennant sandstone. The cottage is still extant although it has been extended to the west in the late nineteenth or early twentieth century.

Ferndale at Rock near Brislington was apparently in existance by the time of the Brislington Tithe survey in 1846 and was possibly associated with the quarry approximately 60m to the north east. The cottage has been extended to the west in the late nineteenth or early twentieth century. The building is a two-storey symetrical cottage constructed of Pennant sandstone and is apparently similar to Fir Tree Cottage to the west.. The cottage is still extant though much altered.

Terrace of four cottages at Rock that were in existance by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan published in 1886 (OS Somerset Sheet VI.08). Possibly constructed to house quarry workers the cottages are small two-storey structures with a single window on the frontage at first floor level. 
The cottages are extant.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Eagle House/ St.Stephens House, Colston Avenue
MONUMENT_DESC: Tontine warehouses located at the Quay Head, facing the harbour. Main block of five 5-storey units. Each unit with entrances to the left on each of the lower 4 storeys. The left-hand 4 units all 3-window ranges, the right-hand a 2-window range. All openings segmental-headed. There appears to have been a 3-storey portion at the southern end.
Mound, excavation c.1922 showed it to be an accumulation of soil over an old boundary wall. {1}{2}

No.107 Redcliff Street. The building was a four-storey, single-bay gabled, jettied house of seventeenth-century date. There was a doorway on the south side of the facade and two casement windows to the north of this. There were bay windows at first (three-light) and second floor (four-light) levels and a three-light casement in the attic storey. The facade was panelled and the legend "107" painted on the lower panelling of the first floor bay window. On the panelling of the second floor bay window was the date "AD 1640."
The building was destroyed by bombing on 24 November 1940.

The Grove Ferry, or Trim Mills Ferry. Slipway at the southern terminus. At the northern end of Lower Guinea Street/ western end of Midland Wharf (ex-Alfred Wharf). Ferry house adjacent to the east (BUAD 766M). The slipway survives, although the ferry is long-since stopped.
ST54957878, a group of large stones, possibly fragments of a megalithic monument reported by Boon {1}

KNOWN_AS: Lamplighters Hall, north of Shirehampton Railway Station
MONUMENT_DESC: Lamplighters Hall, a "hostel on the northern shore built by a supplier of oil lamps for the streets of Bristol". {1} 1792: Map shows Hall on north bank of river close to where the ferry from Pill crosses. An L shaped building {2} 1840s: Map shows Hall, group of buildings above a coal wharf.
ST514785-ST526775, Old Sea Bank. {1}

Mr. Weeks house, located on the south-eastern side of Fishponds Road. The building was in existence by the early 1780s and was recorded by a plan by J. Sturge of 1781 (BRO AC/PL 90). It was then owned by a William Weeks and was described as "An old inclosure." By 1803 the land and buildings were occupied by a Widow Tyler (BRO AC/PL60a) and at the time of the Stapleton tithe survey of 1839 (BRO EP/A/32/35) it was occupied by George Tyler. The plot (Parcel 742) was described as a house, outbuilding, garden and lane. The building had, however, been demolished by the early 1880s and part of it redeveloped for housing.

An Iron Age hillfort (SMR777) with evidence of Roman and Medieval remains (SMR 778, 779) and later an C18 folly with the rampart landscaped as part of a park scheme. Pictures in Blaise Castle House museum appear to show the site landscaped in the C17 but the major works seem to be connected with the construction of the Castle, a folly (SMR780), in 1766 to the design of Robert Mylne. In 1795 Humphry Repton did much work on the park. It is likely that much alteration of the earthworks took place then. An important example of Repton's 18th century landscaping works.

A gas main trench dug in 1966 along Kingsweston Down cut through a shallow ditch, aligned north-west to south-east, at ST 5532 7805. The ditch, not visible on the surface, was found some 15 metres east of the rampart (within the outwork of the hillfort). The trenching was observed by Godman (1972) but the fill of the ditch produced no finds. Godman suggested that it could be associated with the postulated Roman road from Gloucester to Sea Mills via Cribbs Causeway. There was no dating evidence to support this conjecture, however.

Garrison church, Horfield Barracks, located on the eastern side of Filton Road, immediately to the south of the site of Horfield Barracks (SMR 21130). The church was designed by the architect William Butterfield (who also worked on Horfield Church and designed Highbury Chapel) and was constructed in 1847. It is measures 26.6 metres from north-west to south east and is 12 metres wide. The church is constructed of coursed, ashlar Pennant sandstone with limestone dressings and a slate roof and is in a Gothic Revival style. The gable of the west front has a bellcote gable and a central projecting bay which contains the main entrance doorway.
The church has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/53/1411).
ST55287886, a crescentic earthwork on this hill, consisting of a bank and ditch outside, very indistinct, but visible on Air Ministry aerial photo.1948.
ST56997583, Parrys Well, filled in and obliterated. Pump preserved in the pavement.

Police Station located on the southern side Avonmouth Road, Avonmouth. The police statiom was built in the late nineteenth century and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500-scale County Series plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.01) published in 1903. It was still extant at the time of the First World War (1914-1918).
On River Trym. Some buildings survive. {1}

Public Library located on the south-western side of Clayton Street, Avonmouth. The library was built in the late nineteenth century and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500-scale County Series plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.01) published in 1903.

Avonmouth Park, located on the north-eastern side of Avonmouth Road, Avonmouth. The park was laid out in the first decades of the twentieth century as a roughly triangular site covering an area of approximately 9280 square metres. The Ordnance Survey third edition 1:2500-scale County Series plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.01) published in 1916 indicates that the park had lateral cross paths with connecting perimeter paths. At the centre of the site there was a circular bandstand (SMR 22558).

KNOWN_AS: Bandstand at Avonmouth Park, Avonmouth Road, Avonmouth
MONUMENT_DESC: A bandstand at the centre of Avonmouth Park (SMR 22556). The bandstand was built as part of the formal design of the park in the first decades of the twentieth century and was a circular structure approximately 5 metres in diameter.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry, Holmes Hill Road, St. George
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry located on the western side of Holmes Hill Road. The quarry occupied the site of a house and garden which had belonged to one Isaac Flay. It was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) published in 1904 and at that time measured 60 metres from north to south and 40 metres east-west. The entrance to the quarry was off Holmes Hill road at the south end of the quarry. A weighbridge and associated small building at the entrance is recorded by the second edition plan and this is currently (20/11/2001) extant. The quarry had a short operational life, apparently between the late 1880s and c.1900 since the second edition plan refers to it as an "Old Quarry". By the end of the First World War the quarry had been infilled and the site redeveloped as a storage yard.

KNOWN_AS: Crown Pottery, Hudds Vale Road, St. George
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Crown Pottery, located to the west of Hudd's Vale Road. The pottery is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500-scale County series plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) surveyed in 1880-81. Three large kilns stood at the east side of the site in a building measuring approximately 26 metres north-west to south-east and 10 metres north-east to south-west. There was a smaller kiln against its southern boundary. There were workshops in the centre of the site, although the precise function of each element is currently unknown. The site had become a soapworks (SMR 20969) by the early twentieth century, though many of its buildings appear to occupy a similar footprint to those of the pottery suggesting that they had been retained and converted. The small kiln at the south side of the site was still extant at this time.
The site has been redeveloped as the Soaphouse Industrial Estate.
1845: Map shows small coal works in field to west of (now) Greenway Bush Lane. Just north of the modern Walter Street. {1}

Dean Lane Colliery, Bedminster. The colliery was established in 1845 and had two shafts located towards the eastern part of the site (ST 58332 71686 and ST 58335 71678 approximately). These were sunk to 630 feet (193 metres) intially and the depth was later increased to 1290 feet (395 metres). The galleries extended into east Bristol (Southway 1976, 5-6). In 1886 eleven men were killed by an explosion in the mine (Ramsey 2003, 12).
The mine was run by the Bedminster, Easton, Kingswood and Parkfield Collieries Ltd. from the early twentieth century until the pit was closed in 1906 (Ramsey 2003, 20-21). Dame Emily Smyth Park has been developed on the site of the colliery.
1845: small tanyard marked just to the east of (the present) Bedminster Parade.
Brick works, located on the south-west side of Philip Street. A map of 1845 shows a brickyard just to the west of Whitehouse Lane. Terraced housing was later built on the site.

KNOWN_AS: Brick Yard south of Old Sneed Park
MONUMENT_DESC: 1840's map shows, brick yard with rows?. Kiln marked lies to the west of the property. {1}

KNOWN_AS: Bristol Union Workhouse, Manor Road, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC:
Bristol Union Workhouse, located on the northern side of Manor Road. The Bristol Guardians of the Poor leased the former French prison (SMR 10546) in c1831 and established the workhouse in its buildings. It was probably at this time that the outer walls were demolished. In 1837 the Guardians bought the site. The Stapleton tithe survey in 1839 records the workhouse buildings at that time and indicates that only the eastern of the two blocks built as part of the prison was providing living accommodation. A new accommodation building had, however, been constructed a short distance to the west of the western prison block. The latter was demolished between 1861 and 1865 to make way for new workhouse buildings. These included a large main building, a gatehouse range against Blackberry Hill and buildings to the north of the main block.
The building has a Grade II listing (901-1/30/1274).

School, located on the west side of Louisa Street, The Dings. The school was in existence by 1874. It was an L-shaped block measuring approximately 30 metres from north to south and 7 metres wide, with a range at the north end of the building extending 13 metres westwards. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town Plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.22) records the school as educating both boys and girls.
The school was still in existence in the mid-1950s but was subsequently demolished. The site later became part of the ground of the Hannah More Infants School.

KNOWN_AS: Barley Mow Public House, Barton Road
POSTAL_ADDRESS: Barley Mow Public House, Barton Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Barley Mow Public House, located on the east side of Barton Road in The Dings. The building appears to have originally been constructed in the late eighteenth century, and it is recorded by an early nineteenth century plan of the parish of St. Philip and Jacob (BRO 37959/31). The building is a two-storey rendered house with a pitched roof. The public house was known as the Duke of York by the mid-1870s and the 1883 street directory gives the licensee as John Westcott.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Barley Mow Public House, Barton Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
A smithy on the southern side of the junction of Barton Road and Barton Vale in The Dings. It is not currently clear when the building was constructed. It appears to have been in existence by 1828 and a very similar structure is recorded by the Plumley and Ashmead 1828 survey of Bristol. It is not, however, recorded by subsequent plans until the survey by George Ashmead of c.1874 which shows a building on the site. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town Plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.22) is the first to record the building as a smithy.
The building was a long, narrow structure fronting on to Barton Vale and was orientated from south-east to north-west along the street. It measured 17.8 metres long by 4 metres wide. The 1883 street directory suggests that the smithy was then operated by Uriah Hill, described as a blacksmith and wheelwright.
The building appears to have been demolished in the early twentieth century to enable the extension of the adjacent Barley Mow public house (BUAD 1714M).

Purifier House, Canon's Marsh Gasworks.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/503).

KNOWN_AS: Horse and Man, Brunel House, St. George's Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Horse and Man, located at the rear of Brunel House, St. George's Road. The statue is by the Bristol-based sculptor Stephen Joyce and consists of figures of a horse and a man in bronze and resin. The sculpture was unveiled by the Lord Mayor of Bristol on 21 August 1984 (Merritt 2002, 116).
Horse Bazaar, located at the rear of the Royal Western Hotel (BUAD 531M) in St. George's Road.

No.11 Guinea Street, located on the southern side of Guinea Street. The building was constructed for the merchant Captain Edmund Saunders and with No.10 (BUAD 1720M) and No.12 Guinea Street (BUAD 1722M) formed a single house which was later subdivided (Ison 1952, 156).
The house is a two-storey brick structure with limestone ashlar detailing and a hipped roof. The fenestration consist of sashes.
The building was surveyed in 1998 by Dr. Roger Leech of the Royal Commission on Historic Monuments (England) (BUAD 3419).
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/1675).

Congregational Chapel, located on the western side of Whiteladies Road, Clifton. The chapel is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.12.22) surveyed in 1881 which indicates that the chapel could accommodate 840 worshippers.

KNOWN_AS: St. Barnabas Church, Ashley Road, St. Pauls
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Barnabas Church, located on the southern side of Ashley Road, St. Paul's. The church was built at the beginning of the 1840s and was consecrated in 1843. The site was given by W. H. T. Brigstocke and the church was designed by S. T. Welch (Ralph & Cobb, 1991 26). The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.1) surveyed in 1881 indicates that the church could accommodate 600 worshippers.
The church is extant, although it has been extended, and is now the Malcolm X Centre.

KNOWN_AS: Congregational Church at Ashley Road, St. Paul's
MONUMENT_DESC: A Congregational Chapel on the northern side of Ashley Road, St. Paul's. The chapel was constructed in the mid-nineteenth century and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.1) surveyed in 1881. This plan indicated that the chapel could accommodate 400 worshippers. The chapel was still extant at the beginning of the twentieth century but had been demolished and the site redeveloped for housing by 1918. The sit eof the chapel now lies beneath Nos.83b and 83c Ashley Road and No.9 Norrisville Road.

KNOWN_AS: Ebenezer Chapel, Grosvenor Road, St. Paul's
MONUMENT_DESC: Ebenezer Chapel, located on the southern side of a lane to the north-east of Portland Square [modern Grosvenor Road]. The chapel was in existence by the time of the 1828 survey of Bristol by John Plumley and George Ashmead. It had been demolished and the site redeveloped for housing by 1881.

KNOWN_AS: Bachelors' Almshouse, Grosvenor Road, St. Paul's
MONUMENT_DESC: Bachelors' Almshouse, located on the southern side of a lane to the north-east of Portland Square [modern Grosvenor Road]. The almshouse was in existence by the time of the 1828 survey of Bristol by John Plumley and George Ashmead. It had been demolished and the site redeveloped for housing by 1881.

KNOWN_AS: Royal Observer Corps post at Avonmouth
MONUMENT_DESC: Royal Observer Corps post at Avonmouth. The post, No.23/K3, was constructed in May 1938 (Dobinson 2000, 220). Its precise location is currently unknown but the site appears to have been redeveloped for the industrial buildings on St. Brendan's Way.

KNOWN_AS: Bedminster Sub-control Centre, Banwell Close, Bedminster Down
MONUMENT_DESC:
Bedminster Sub-control Centre, located on the northern side of Banwell Close. The Sub-control centre is reported to have been built in 1938 as a civil defence control centre and operated as such through the Second World War. After the war the building was used by the Army but reverted to use as a civil defence control centre in the early 1950s, one of four around Bristol. This use continued into the 1960s but most sub-control centres around the UK appear to have downgraded to care and maintenance as the result of a policy review after the Cuban Missile Crisis in 1962. The Bedminster building was abandoned in 1968 and remained unused thereafter (McCamley, 2002 198-199).
The building is a single-storey concrete structure with a flat roof, which is orientated north-south, and there are slightly lower entrance lobbies at the middle of the north and south elevations. Internally the structure has a central corridor one metre wide running the length of the building, with rooms off it.
The structure was demolished in 2003 but was surveyed in advance of demolition (SMR 21778; Ross, 2003). There is a photograph of the building in the SMR Collection of Ground-based photographs, number 1851.

Clifton Wood House, located at the junction of Clifton Wood Road and Randall Road. The building is a three-storey house with two bow window bays of nineteenth-century date on the south frontage. The building is currently rendered with limestone dressings and has a pan tile hipped roof with brick ridge stacks. Adjoining the house is a small lawned area to the north and an open yard or driveway extends around the east and south sides of the property. Ruinous structures, possibly a former brewhouse adjoin the house to the northwest. A terraced walk approaches the house from the west alongside the south boundary wall of Goldney House garden.
The main building has apparently developed in four main phases from the later seventeenth- or early-eighteenth century (Leech, 2003). The earliest structural element of the house survives, though much altered, as the western third of the present house. This earliest structure is likely to have been a "lodge" or "summer house" (a merchant's second residence) constructed between 1690 and 1710 and measuring approximately 5 metres east-west and 11 metres north-south. This original house was subject to alteration and enlargement, possibly by the Quaker builder George Tully in 1723 (Mowl 1992, 23),  between 1722 and 1728 while in the ownership of Robert Smith to create a double-pile house with three bays. This enlarged building consisted of three storeys with a cellar below the north-east room, with a central hall and stairs extending the full depth of the house on the ground floor. The main stairs as built ascended only to the first floor, there being a separate servants stair (long since removed) to the east of the hall rising from the ground to the first and attic floors. This stair was one of the earliest such features in Bristol, the only other similar example being No.32 Prince Street (a plan of the latter is in the Kingsweston Book of Drawings (R. Leech pers. comm.). On the ground floor there were three reception rooms and a kitchen with projecting scullery wing to the north. There were four chambers on the first floor and five rooms in the attic, probably servants quarters. The ground floor entrance hall and reception rooms and the first floor front chambers were fully panelled with plaster cornices. The wide main stairs to the first floor were provided with marquetry inlays to the newel post, to the panelled wainscot, to the panels to the floor and underside of the upper quarter landing and to the soffit balustrade at the first floor. Most of the doors were of six panels raised and fielded in three heights, the two central panels roughly half the height of those above and below.
In 1748 the house and estate was sold to Thomas Goldney who leased the property to Selina Countess of Huntingdon, there in 1753 (Leech 2003). From 1757 the property was leased to Richard Farr a merchant and owner of ships engaged in the slave trade, who in 1769 agreed to an increased rent to pay for new work on the house that included a new laundry and enlargement of the brewhouse, possibly one of the outbuildings now ruinous on the site.
In the late eighteenth century and early nineteenth century the house was subject to several alterations and modernisation. New stairs were added from the first to second floor above the entrance hall and the servants' stairs were removed. In the south-east room on the second floor wall cloth placed above a panelled dado replaced earlier plaster and panelled finishes. The dado height panelling in other rooms was possibly fitted at a similar stage. The new stairs from the first to second floors differ from the earlier main stairs, having thinner turned column balusters than the original stairs and a moulded handrail characteristic of the later eighteenth century (Leech 2003). On the ground and first floors the space occupied by the servants' stairs became a closet, the corresponding space on the second floor became a cupboard and the location for new stairs onto the roof. 
At the beginning of the nineteenth century two bow windows were added to the south-east facing elevation their construction is described by Leech (2003) as 'economical', boarded panels below the windows providing the appearance of solid walls. 
In 1864 the property was sold to Lewis Fry. By the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.2) surveyed in 1883 the building was in use as a "Home for crippled children".
In 1924 a china pantry, scullery and an external WC were added to the ground floor. On the first floor a new room was added over the new scullery. Plans for these additions indicate that the ground floor south facing window in the south-west angle had been blocked by 1924 to become a cupboard.
To the west of the house are the ruins of a former necessary house with a stone slab covered earth closet and a former building with a wide fireplace now blocked. This is possibly the former back kitchen or brewhouse constructed in the 1760s. The original roofs of these structures have long since been removed. Further to the west at the end of the long terrace stood a summerhouse, now demolished.  Approximately 7m to the north of the main house an octagonal structure is shown on the plans of 1828 and 1885, possibly a summerhouse, in the area now laid to lawn.
Within the present garden the main historic feature is the terrace walk, now restored, that approaches the house from the west alongside the boundary wall with the Goldney House gardens to the north. This terrace walk and adjoining boundary walls are likely to date to c.1750 as does the low boundary wall at the west end of the garden. The wall towards the south side of the garden adjoinig Randall Road is not historically a boundary wall, it is the truncated part of a terrace wall within a former orchard shown on the nineteenth century plans. At the east end a wall of the 1880s (with a single door opening towards Randall Road) links this wall to the wall originally separating the inner courtyard in front of the main house from its formal garden (SMR 21731) to the south, separated before 1828 for a new house and garden. A feature of this wall is the projecting rectangular bastion. Since the Randall Road development of the 1880s there has been no boundary wall to the south side of the property. The north boundary wall is built in Brandon Hill Stone laid as random rubble. This wall is shown on the 1828 Ashmead plan and is probably built against the earlier north-south boundary wall against which the original house of 1690-1710 was constructed. The east boundary wall is of unknown date, although it is possibly that shown on the nineteenth century plans.
A stable block (also Grade II listed, Listed Building number 901-1/41/822) associated with Clifton Wood House lies ten metres north of the house. This is a single storey rendred structure with limestone dressings and a pantile hipped roof. The boundary walls and piers of Clifton Wood House are also Grade II listed (Listed Building number 901-1/41/823).
The building has been surveyed by Dr. Roger Leech of the Royal Commission on the Historical Monuments of England (SMR 21445). It has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/821).

St. Martin's Church, located on the western side of Wells Road. The church was built towards the end of the nineteenth-century to a design by the architect William Venn Gough. It was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXVI.05) published in 1904. At that date the church was a square structure, measuring approximately 19 metres from south-west to north-east and 17 metres wide. To the south-west, the site of the present nave, there were two smaller buildings, one of which was a Sunday School. By the end of the First World War these structures had been demolished and the church extended to the south-west.

Here Messrs Peckett were building steam locomotives till after World War 2. No equipment survives, but the large erecting shop and boiler shop survive and are used by another firm. {1}"Atlas Engine works" shown on map of 1895 to the E of Deep Pit one of the Kingswood Collieries.

North Almshouse, Westbury -on-Trym. The almshouse was located some 25 metres to the north of the church. The site was excavated between 1975 and 1978 by members of the Westbury-on-Trym Local History Group under the direction of James Russell (BSMR 4858; Russell 1988).
Grammar School at Henbury (ST563788) founded 1623. Close House, at ST563788, next to the graveyard at Henbury in the old Schoolhouse probably dating from the foundation in 1624 (Percival 1970, 117).

KNOWN_AS: Possible Roman earthwork within Clifton Down Camp
MONUMENT_DESC: A possible Roman earthwork, located in the north west corner of Clifton Down Camp (SMR 883). The feature is a low rectangular earthwork which local antiquarians conjectured was possibly of Roman date.

A pond located on the west side of West Town Grove. The pond was in existence by the time of the Brislington tithe survey of 1846 and the form of the field to the south suggests that the pond may originally have been considerably larger. The pond was still extant in the early 1880s and the first edition Ordnance Survey plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXVI.06) records it as a fishpond. At that date the feature measured 65 metres north-south by 42 metres east-west.
Dennison and Iles interpreted the features as a fishponds with a likely medieval origin (Dennison and Iles 1985, 43). However, cartographic evidence suggests that the pond itself formed part of a larger system of water management linked to Brislington Brook and records a building (SMR 4249) at the northern end of the pond in the 1840s. The function of this building is not clear. However, an alternative interpretation is that the pond may have been a mill pond.

Zion Primitive Methodist Chapel, located on the east side of Bishopsworth Road. The chapel was in existence by the mid-1880s and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500-scale plan (Somerset Sheet VI.10) published in 1886. The building measured 17.4 metres from east to west and was 6.95 metres wide. By the early twentieth century the chapel had become a Sunday School and a new chapel had been constructed just to the south. The building was extant in 1916 but was subsequently demolished.

KNOWN_AS: Zion Methodist Church, Bishopsworth Road, Bishopsworth
MONUMENT_DESC: Zion Methodist Church, located on the east side of Bishopsworth Road. The church was constructed in 1890 and was built to replace an earlier, smaller chapel (HER 3115M) just to the north. The building was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500-scale plan (Somerset Sheet VI.10) published in 1903.

St. Cuthbert's Church, located on the north side of Sandringham Road. The church was built in 1932-1933 to a design by the architect P. Hartland Thomas. The church is constructed of brick with limestone ashlar Gothic tracery windows. Internally the aisles on the north and south side of the nave are demarcated by an arcade of three bays with square piers.

KNOWN_AS: St. Cuthbert's Mission Church, Allison Road
MONUMENT_DESC: St. Cuthbert's Mission Church, located on the north side of Allison Road. The mission church was constructed in the early twentieth century, some time after 1904. It was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey third edition 1:2500-scale plan (Somerset Sheet VI.08) published in 1916. St. Cuthbert's Church (SMR22394) was built on Sandringham Road to replace it as as a parish church in 1931-32. The mission church was subsequently demolished and the site was redeveloped for housing.

KNOWN_AS: Flagpole at Balmoral Road, Ashley Hill
MONUMENT_DESC: Flagpole at Ashley Hill. The flagpole is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition County Series 1:2500-scale plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.09) surveyed in 1880-81. The flagpole had been removed by the early twentieth century.
Avonmouth Dock, located on the river Severn immediately above the saltmarsh. The station is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucester Sheet  LXXI.01) published in 1890.

KNOWN_AS: Coastal Battery at the confluence of the Rivers Avon and Severn
MONUMENT_DESC: A coastal battery of likely late-eighteenth or early-nineteenth century date located on the south side of the channel which passed to the north of Dumball Island, although its exact position is uncertain. The battery is recorded by an 1817 survey of the parish of Westbury-on-Trym by Y. and J. P. Sturge now in Northampton Record Office (NRO Plan 616) which shows a D-shaped structure, apparently immediately above high water, facing towards King Road. The tithe map of 1840 for the Tithing of Shirehampton, also by Y. and J. P. Sturge, also records the battery but marks it as "Old Battery", suggesting it had gone out of use by that date. It had been demolished by the early twentieth century.
1840's: Map shows coal wharf on the river edge slightly to the west of the hall. {1}

KNOWN_AS: Custom House, on the east bank of the confluence of Crockerne Pill and the River Avon
MONUMENT_DESC: 1840s: Map shows. "preventive station" on site of current customs houses.
1840s: Wharf on N. bank of Avon, just below Hung Row Cottages.

KNOWN_AS: Medieval field system south west of Moorgrove Wood
MONUMENT_DESC: Boon made the discovery of some Lynchets during observation of groundworks associated with the development of housing in the area, between 1945 and 1949.  He noted that the Lynchets were destroyed during building of the estate, but they are shown on O.S. LXXI.3 parcel 956 (3) (this needs checking).  They are thought to be medieval Strip Lynchets, but may be associated with the Roman building.

KNOWN_AS: Drinking fountain at Druid Hill, Sneyd Park
MONUMENT_DESC: Drinking fountain located on the southern side of Druid Hill, Sneyd Park. It is a circular timber structure with a polished granite drinking fountain at the centre and was constructed to commemmorate the Diamond Jubilee of Queen Victoria in 1897.
Clack Mill, also known as Combe Dale Mill, on the River Trym. The mill and watercourses are reported to have been obliterated during the creation of the public open space

St Blaise's Chapel. The foundation of the chapel of St. Blaise (patron saint of wool combers) on Henbury Hill. The hill was dug up in 1707, when "ancient Roman coins...(SMR 778), and in a vault 10 yards long and 6 yards broad...many human bodies were discovered." A chapel of St. Blaise on Blaise Castle Hill is marked on early maps (Saxton 1577; Speed 1610). It is also mentioned in local histories and traditions, though no medieval records of its existence have yet come to light. Possibly dedicated earlier to St Werburgha (SMR 817). J Bartlett's excavations in 1918 revealed the foundations of the chapel of St. Blasius about 15 feet east of Blaise Castle. Little more than the levelled and mortared surface remains, with a few stones in their original alignment, of a C14/15 buttressed building measuring 28 feet by 14 feet. Several skeletons were found in rock cut graves, all with their heads to the west and indicated a well-filled burial (SMR 778). Excavations in 1957 revealed Roman and medieval material.

KNOWN_AS: Iron Age enclosure south west of King's Weston Hill camp
MONUMENT_DESC: A roughly circular earthwork on Kingsweston Down. The earthwork is roughly 60 metres in diameter bounded by a slight bank which is more prominent on the south side - with a shallow outer ditch. Further west is a cross-ridge dyke which may be an outwork to the hillfort (SMR 781). Excavation by Rahtz (1956) across the east side of the circular earthwork revealed a rock cut ditch 2 feet deep and 2-3 feet wide. This can be tentatively identified as a palisade ditch with an exterior berm, enclosing farm buildings or huts. Pottery from the fort and circle show primary occupation in a late phase of the Iron Age "A" period, but 13 sling stones in the secondary fill of the circle's ditch suggest Iron Age "B" occupation. The finds from the excavation are held by Bristol Museum and Art Gallery.

Bank Hotel, located on Bridge Street near St Peter's Church. Originally a Bank of England building which was converted to a hotel following a new purpose-built branch office in Broad Street. In 1867 it was the Bank Family and Commercial Hotel, J.W Tapson, proprietor. Elizabeth Date took over later, but by 1899 the Mesdames Walter were the proprietors.  By 1923 W.R Margate was running the Bank Hotel, as was still the case in 1935.  It was destroyed in the bombing of the night of 24/25 November 1940.

Photographs of the building feature in two Reece Winstone publications: "Bristol As It Was 1845 - 1900" frame 40 and frame 141. "Bristol in the 1890's" frame 49

KNOWN_AS: Malthouse on the south-western side of Stillhouse Lane, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC: Malthouse located on the southern side of the junction of Stillhouse Lane and Willway Street, Bedminster. The malthouse was in existence by the late 1820s and is recorded by Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 survey of Bristol. It is a stone rubble building with brick detailing around the window openings.

Stoke Park. The park is a landscape park designed as the stting for the Dower House by Thomas Wright.
The park has a Grade II listing in the English Heritage Register of Historic Parks and Gardens (GD1025).

A brickworks located on the south-eastern side of Passage Road, Westbury-on-Trym, on the site of modern Grange Court and Nos.36-46 Passage Road. The brickworks was established after 1880 and was in existence by 1903 when it was recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500-scale plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.08). At that date the kiln was apparently positioned at the centre. Orientated from north-west to south east, the rectangular kiln building measured approximately 12 metres long by 4.5 metres wide. Three metres to the south-west there was a larger building of unknown function on a similar alignment (21 metres long by 8 metres wide). On the west side of this structure, and extending to the western boundary of the site there was a large pit, probably a clay pit, a maximum of 33 metres long and 18 metres wide. At the south end of the building was a 25-metre long, narrow, open-sided building, likely to have been a drying shed, which lay along the south boundary of the site. The brickworks buildings had been demolished and Nos.36-46 Passage Road built by 1916.

No.7 Back Stoke Lane, located on the eastern side of Back Stoke Lane. The house was in existence by the time of the Westbury-on-Trym tithe survey of 1841. It is the northern of a pair of semi-detached two-storey houses (the other being No.7 Back Stoke Lane). As built the main, west-facing elevation was of a single bay with a window slightly to the south of the centre at each floor, while the main entrance was on its north side. The house had a pitched pantile roof with a brick chimney stack at the apex of the north gable
A single-storey extension with a flat roof was added to the south side of the house in the twentieth century. The windows were also replaced.

Dyrham Lodge, No.16 Clifton Park, located on the eastern side of Clifton Park. It was built at some time between 1844, when the Clifton tithe survey recorded the land as "set out for building" (BRO EP/A/32/12) and 1849, by which time it had been completed. It was designed by Charles Underwood, who was also responsible for the lodges and chapels at Arno's Vale Cemetery. The building has a double-depth plan and is of two storeys with basement and attic. The building is in a Neo-Classical style.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/8/800).

KNOWN_AS: Building on the east side of Marlborough Hill
MONUMENT_DESC: House on the east side of the junction of Kingsdown Parade and Montague Hill. The building is recorded by Rocque's 1742 map of the city standing in the north-west corner of a large rectangular plot. It may have been a merchant's lodge (ie. second residence). The building appears to have survived into the 1880s but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped.

A garden house on the site of No.31 Kingsdown Parade. The house was in existence by the early 1740s and stood at the south-eastern corner of a walled garden extending from Kingsdown Parade to the road to the north. It was recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol and was probably a merchant's garden house or lodge (ie. second residence). The building measured 8.5 metres from south-east to north-west and was 7 metres wide.
The building had been apparently been extended by 1828. It is not currently (30/03/2006) known whether any elements of the earlier structure have survived within the fabric of the building currently occupying the site.

A garden house on the plot of No.25 Kingsdown Parade. The house was in existence by the early 1740s and stood at the south-eastern corner of a walled garden extending from Kingsdown Parade to the road to the north. It was recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol and was probably a merchant's garden house or lodge (ie. second residence). The building measured 8.5 metres from south-east to north-west and was 7 metres wide. It had been apparently been demolished by 1828.

A garden house on the plot of No.15 Kingsdown Parade. The house was in existence by the early 1740s and stood at the south-eastern corner of a walled garden extending from Kingsdown Parade to the road to the north. It was recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol and was probably a merchant's garden house or lodge (ie. second residence). The building measured 8.5 metres from south-east to north-west and was 7 metres wide.

KNOWN_AS: Oil and Colour Manufactory, Castle Green
MONUMENT_DESC: An Oil and Colour factory, located on the north side of Castle Green. The works is recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883.
A school on the north side of Castle Green. The school is recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition 1:500 plan of 1883 and lay to the north of the Hope Chapel.

KNOWN_AS: Hat, Cap and Felt Factory, Castle Green
MONUMENT_DESC: Hat, Cap and Felt Factory, Castle Green. The school is recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition 1:500 plan of 1883 and lay on the north side of Castle Green.

Pountney's pottery in Fishponds. The model factory was built in 1905 and was still working in the 1960s. "2 beehive kilns remain of the line that originally went across the width of the pottery: Fine decorative vases by Edward Raby preserved on premises". The pottery was demolished and the site redeveloped in the 1970s.

Kiln on the north side of Crew's Hole Road. The structure is first recorded by the St. George tithe survey of 1842 (BRO EP/A/32/32) and was a circular structure associated with an industrial complex on the north side of Crew's Hole Road. The kiln had a rectangular base measuring 13 metres from north to south and 9 metres wide. The cone was 8 metres in diameter. The site was recorded as a fireclay works by the Ordnance Survey second edition County series 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) published in 1904. The kiln was extant in 1918 but was subsequently demolished.

KNOWN_AS: Park Road House, Park Road, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC:
Park Road House, also known as Seabrook, located on the north side of Park Road, Stapleton. The building is a three-storey rendered building. The earliest element appears to be the rear half of the building, which has a pitched pantile roof. The front element is of nineteenth century date and is rendered, with limestone ashlar dressings, including rusticated quoins and stepped voussoirs above the window openings, and a hipped pantile roof. The fenestration consists of horned six-over-six sash windows at ground and first floor levels and six-over-three sashes at second floor.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/29/1950).

KNOWN_AS: Bristol South Pool, Dean Lane, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC:
Bristol South Pool, located on the north-western side of Dean Lane, Bedminster. The pool was built in 1929 to a design by the local architect C. F. W. Dening. The building is of brick with limestone ashlar detailing. Entrance is via a single-storey lobby at the north-east end of the building and above the door and the legend "BRISTOL SOUTH BATHS" is carved into the lintel with a relief of spread wings above. The building contains a 30-metre swimming pool. At the west end of the Pool there is a boiler house with a circular chimney with a coped top.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/45/377).

KNOWN_AS: Brewery at the rear of the Waggon and Horses public house, No.83 Stapleton Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Brewery, Waggon and Horses public house, No.83 Stapleton Road

KNOWN_AS: Sunday School for Horsefair Methodist Chapel

MONUMENT_DESC: Municipal park (c.1900) set in natural amphitheatre, with terrace gardens along top of slope dating to 1939-40.

Greville Smyth Park created on land donated by Greville and Lady Smyth and opened as a Municipal Park in 1883. Landscape features include a prospect mound, mature trees, shrubberies, rose beds, bowling green, tennis courts and a play area. The park was firsty depicted on the 1:2500 Ordnance Survey plan of 1903 which indicates that a bandstand was included in the original park design in the area now occupied by play facilities. This plan also indicates that some of the path layouts form part of the existing park landscape. Typical 19th century park.

Mostly open grass with some shrubberies and flower beds. There is a playground and a stream and an exotic cast-iron urinal and many mature trees.{1} Typical late 19th century municipal park. {1} Well maintained. {1}
Small municipal park {1} Of slight interest as a public park.{1} Well maintained by City Council. {1}

Fishponds Park, located on the north-western side of Fishponds Road. The land for the park was purchased for £300 by Stapleton Urban District Council in 1887 and a pleasure ground was laid out in 1888. At the entrance to the park from Fishponds Road there is a drinking fountain dated 1893. This consists of a Pennant sandstone arch with spigots issuing into marble basins, with an inscription commemorating J. Yalland, Chairman of the Local Board of Health, which was built to commemorate the opening of the park in 1888.  The park was taken over by Bristol Corporation in 1897.
At the centre of the park is a war memorial (SMR 20115), a bronze statue of a British infantry soldier on large granite plinth, which commemorates the dead of the Gloucestershire regiment during the First World War (1914-1918).

Canford Park was bought from the Rev. H.A. Daniel in 1874 for £6,157 by Clifton Urban Sanitary Authority. After Westbury became part of the city of Bristol in 1904, paths were laid out in 1905-9 and the park was opened to the public in 1909.
The sunken garden and pond were created in 1936-7.
The Drinking fountain near the east boundary of the park dates from 1897 and was originally erected in the centre of Westbury-on-Trym to commemorate the sixty years fo Victoria's reign.

A round barrow on Kingsweston Hill. The monument measured 40 feet in diameter, 2 feet high. It was excavated in 1924 by Tratman, and a cremation with parts of an Iron Age "A" carinated bowl was recorded. Finds included, the iron cheek piece of a bridle, two fragments of samian from under the turf, now in the University of Bristol Spelaeological Society Museum.
Tratman attributed the barrows on Kings Weston Hill (SMR 761, 784,785) to the Iron age. O'Neill and Grinsell (1960) imply that the Iron Age cremation may have been secondary. Though inconclusive, the excavations suggest a Late Bronze Age date for the barrow, with other material in secondary position. Three small round barrows excavated in about 1924 by Tratman seem to have contained primary cremations with Iron Age A pottery. Green briefly reviewed the dating evidence available for the barrows at Kingsweston Hill in considering a cairn he had excavated at Tickenham. On the basis of a re-examination of Tratman's pottery finds, which appeared to be from collared urns, Green concluded that "in the absence of any structural grounds for considering the Kings Weston Hill barrows to be of Iron Age date" the Kingsweston barrows were of Early Bronze Age origin (Green 1972-73, 43-44). Tratman replied to Green's reinterpretation, arguing that the interpretation of the pottery as Iron Age was questionable, the monuments had not necessarily been disturbed to any great extent in antiquity and that the argument that absence of structural grounds for an Iron Age date leads to the inference of a date in the Early Bronze Age was "highly specious". Tratman concluded that there was no good reason to redate the Kingsweston barrows until fresh evidence became available (Tratman 1975, 56-57).

KNOWN_AS: Hilltop enclosure at Coombe Hill, Henbury
MONUMENT_DESC:
A cliff-top enclosure at Coombe Hill, Henbury, overlooking the River Trym. The enclosure is sub-triangular in shape and covers about 5 acres of the north west corner of Coombe Hill. It is bounded on the north by the cliff edge of the gorge of the River Trym, and on the east side by a bank up to 1.5 metres high with an external ditch. On the south west side is a slight bank with only fragmentary remains of a ditch. At present the function of the enclosure is uncertain. Nor is there any dating evidence for the enclosure, although it is believed to be of likely Iron Age date. Burrow (1981 232-233) allocates the monument to his Group II.
The enclosure was first observed by E. K. Tratman (1946, 178). In February 1967 a survey of the monument was undertaken by J. W. Haldane, Mr. A. Waller and Ms. M. Robinson (Haldane in Anon. 1965-68, 249-251) (SMR 22010). Burrow visited the site in early February 1973 and noted that the earthworks were very eroded and had been lost entirely along the south side. He also noted possible entrances in both the east and west sides of the enclosure (Burrow 1981, 232-233).

An aquarium at Bristol Zoological Gardens, constructed in 1926 on the site of the former bear pit to a design by Dr Richard Clarke, the secretary of the Bristol, Clifton and West of England Zoological Society (Green-Armytage 1964, 61). The aquarium is extant.

Nos.9-11 Chantry Road, pair of attached houses formerly a single farm house constructed in c.1670. The first cartographic depiction of the building is on de Wilstar's survey of the Manor of Clifton, 1746. Plumley and Ashmead's plan of Bristol, 1828 shows the building by which time it was named Nursery Villa and was associated with the adjoining Durdham Down Nursery (SMR 22123) managed by John Miller. An advertisement dated 1827 for John Miller, Nurseryman, Seedsman and Florist, shows the square outer bays of the property (listing description). In the late 1830s Nursery Villa and Durdham Down Nursery was taken over by James Garaway who later divided the house into the present two properties formerly Nos.1 and 2 Nursery Villas now Nos.9 and 11 Chantry Road. In the late nineteenth century or very early twentieth century the nursery was relocated and the area developed for housing. Chantry Road was created at this time and was formed from the entrance drive to the nursery.
The building is extant and has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/34/10036).

KNOWN_AS: Entrance Lodges at Bristol Zoological Gardens
MONUMENT_DESC:
A pair of entrance lodges to the Bristol Zoological Gardens on the south side of Clifton Down were in existence by 1849 when they were surveyed by Ashmead for a plan of Clifton. The lodges were probably built in 1835-1836 or soon after the gardens opened in 1836 as they are shown on Richard Forrest's plan for the layout of the gardens probably drawn in 1835. Originally two lodges either side of the entrance to the gardens, since 1995 the lodges have been linked by a shop extension to the side and rear. The lodges are single storey limestone ashlar structures with a cruciform plan built in the neoclassical style. They have slate hipped and gabled roof with overhanging eaves.
The structures have a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/34/747).

The Clifton Pavillion on the north east side of College Road, Clifton, constructed on the west side of the Bristol Zoological Gardens in 1930 to a design by W. H. Watkins with a restaurant on the ground floor and a ballroom above. The building was constructed at a cost of £20,000 and was intended for private parties rather than public dances (Green-Armytage, 1964, 68). During the Second World War the building was taken over by the Bristol Aeroplane Company after the bombing of their premises at Filton (Green-Armytage 1964, 81).
Opened on 14.5.1917 as a wartime expedient for long trains that could not be accommodated at Hotwells. Closed 3.7.1922.

KNOWN_AS: Eighteenth-century house at Braemor Court, Passage Road, Westbury-on-Trym
MONUMENT_DESC: An eighteenth-century house located on the west side of Passage Road, Westbury-on-Trym. The house was in existence by the late-eighteenth century and was first recorded by a plan of the estate of Isaac Hobhouse of 1792. It was apparently still extant at the end of the 1940s but was subsequently demolished to allow the construction of Braemor Court.

KNOWN_AS: Pump to rear of Baptist Street
Pump to rear of Baptist Street
Pump to the rear of the Lion Public House
Lord Nelson Public House, Lower Ashley Road
Christian Brethren Gospel Hall, St Nicholas Road
Fountain to the rear of no. 13 Brunswick Square

MONUMENT_DESC:
A fishpond towards the southern end of St Anne's Wood was in existance by the time of the Brislington tithe survey in 1846 (EP/A/32/9). The fishpond was fed by Brislington Brook and controlled by a sluice at the northern end of the pond marked on the Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan (Somerset sheet VI.08) published in 1886. The pond measured approximately 120m north-south and 20m wide. It is likely to have been a feature of the designed 'picturesque' landscape for Wick House.
The pond was infilled prior to the First World War. Part of the sluice and associated stonework is still visible on both banks of the brook at NGR ST6200271496.
King's Mill, Oldbury Court. Site now derelict, though still possible to see some courses of the wall. Occupied by 1498 as a grist mill, 1771-c1842 used as a snuff mill. Small scale excavation.

Frenchay Mill. This building was cleared about 1958 as part of a River board scheme and although the weir remains, the only other visible vestiges of this mill are a rotting sluice gate 'in situ' and a millstone which marks the site of the old mill. {1}{2} Mill leased in 1733, ceased working in 1905, always used as a grist mill.{3} Mill originally grist mill, becoming snuff mill in 1753 - reverting to grinding corn for the final period of operation 1882-1905 {4}

KNOWN_AS: Smithy, Bower Ashton Terrace, Ashton Road, Ashton Gate
MONUMENT_DESC:
Smithy, located at the rear of No.1 Bower Ashton Terrace, Ashton Road. The smithy seems to have been established between 1882 and 1904.
It is not clear whether the building is extant.

Wytherlyes Mill, also known as Snuffy Jack's Mill, located on the northern bank of the river Frome. The mill was first recorded by a map of 1610 and is also shown by Isaac Taylor's map of 1777.
