By the late eighteenth century the mill was grinding snuff and the tobacconists Wilson and Thomas rented the mill in 1790. In 1792 W. S. Winstone leased it to Messrs. Lilly and Wills for a term of 21 years. H. O. Wills bought the freehold in 1805 and ground snuff there until 1843 when the mill was sold to W. S. Lawrence. It became a flock mill and was rented by Thomas Saint and from 1863 by Thomas Lusty. The mill buildings were of stone rubble construction and consisted of the mill building itself on the bank of the river, orientated north-west to south-east and measuring 19 metres by 8.5 metres, with a smaller structure - probably the house - attached on its north side.
The mill ceased to be used c.1877 (Ward 1978, 30) but the buildings remained standing for a period and were still in existence in the early 1880s when the site was described by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) as an "Old Mill." The mill buildings were subsequently demolished, although some elements are extant.
Lathbury Mill. The mill is known to have been in existence by 1620. It is referred to in 1842 as a grist mill. About 1859 Colston School used the weir to supply water to its swimming pool.

Ashleyvale Mill. The site lay on a tributary stream of Bristol Frome. The date of origin of the mill is not currently known but in 1842 the owner was J. Smythe and the occupier May Pickering. The mill is recorded by the 1st edition Ordnance Survey map, surveyed in 1881, as a flour mill. The railway was built in 1864 across the mill stream.
The mill buildings, including the house survive as Mill Cottage which was derelict in 1967 but which has now been restored. One surviving wall has a grille suggesting that there was a large high breast or overshot wheel about 4 feet wide.

KNOWN_AS: Upper Fishponds House or Beechwood, Fishponds
MONUMENT_DESC:
Upper Fishponds House, Beechwood, located some 170 metres to the south-east of Fishponds Road. The house was apparently in existence by the early nineteenth century and housed a school run by Joel Lean between 1816 and 1837, by George Joseph Bompas between 1844 to 1855, and by W. H. Paglor between 1855 and 1861. After the use as a school ended the house became a private residence and is thought to have been the home of William Edward Forster, who was responsible for guiding the Education Act of 1870 through the House of Commons.
The house is reported to have been demolished in 1935.

A pond located on the western side of Channel's Hill [modern Channon's Hill]. The pond may have originated as a quarry but was water-filled by the time of the Stapleton tithe survey of 1839. The pond had been infilled by the early 1880s and its site has been developed.

Avonbank Power Station. The power station was located on the south side of Feeder Road and is shown by the Ordnance Survey 2nd edition map of 1904 as Avonbank Electric Light Works in the ownership of the Bristol Corporation. Part of the site has been cleared, but some brick buildings survive.
The garden of The Holmes, Stoke Park Road. A late nineteenth century collector's garden in a suburban location, maintained by Bristol University.

Large formal garden and park laid out c.1690 by Robert Southwell, replaced by informal parkland 1720-1777. The park at Kingsweston was widely acknowledged to be one of the finest in the country in the C18. {1} An important C18 landscape park on the site of an important C17 formal garden. {1} Kingsweston Park is now greatly neglected. Much of the park is built over.{1}

Sparke Evans Park. City public park opened in 1902 on land presented to Bristol Corporation by P.F. Sparke Evans and Jonathan Evans. The features of the park consist of Boundary railings and gates (1922), decorative shelter (1925), mature planes, rose garden and footbridge over the Avon.
Fremantle Square. Single mature holm oak growing in the centre of a small square raised lawn.{1} Typical C19 communal garden. {1} Well maintained.

KNOWN_AS: St. Matthias College, Oldbury Court Road, Fishponds
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Matthias College, located on the western side of Oldbury Court Road. The college was constructed as the Gloucester and Bristol Diocesan Training Institution for School Mistresses in the early 1850s (the rainwater heads carry the date 1854). The college was designed by John Norton and Joseph Clarke and is a two-storey Gothic structure of Pennant sandstone rubble with ashlar detailing. The main block is on the College Road side of the site, with a range on its north side and chapel on its southern. These enclose a formal garden with some mature trees, including a judas tree, hollies, cherries and a row of limes, and a knot garden. A further range was added to the on the south side of the site between 1903 and the First World War.
The college has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/54/1275). The lodge on the south side of the Oldbury Court Road entrance and the boundary walls to the site have a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/54/1276).
Colston School Garden. An eighteenth-century park now used as grounds for school and much altered.

KNOWN_AS: Garden of Grove House, Cornwallis Cresent
MONUMENT_DESC: Garden of Grove House, Cornwallis Cresent. C18 Garden, with mature trees and lawns. No other notable features. C18th garden with some C19th planting.
Grounds of Heath House (SMR 5876).

Cumberland Basin. The main entrance to the Floating Harbour, from the River Avon a short distance upstream of the Avon Gorge. William Jessop. c.1809. Now the only access other than Netham Lock. Rowbotham's 1826 drawing (M2937) shows the inner gates of the two outer locks. Later, in 1870, they were rebuilt, the northernmost being replaced later in the century by a larger lock at a less severe angle to the river.

The Shakespeare public house, located on the western side of Victoria Street. The building was constructed in the seventeenth century in Temple Street and is a gabled house of three storeys and attic. Central entrance between bay windows; cellar access below right-hand window. A pair of bays each to the first and second floors, 6-light fronts, 2-light sides. Attic window of 3 lights, the central one divided by a transom. External collar. Two purlins  to each side of the roof. Full-width pentice roofs over the front of each of the 3 lower storeys. There are lateral chimneystacks on south wall.
The building was damaged by bombing during the Second World War and reconstructed after the war.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/331).

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Redcliff Hill, end of Colston Parade
MONUMENT_DESC: Stocks located on Redcliff Hill, at the end of Colston Parade. The stocks were recorded in a drawing by S. C. Jones (BRSMG M1925) made in the early nineteenth century and at that date they stood inside a circular enclosure of railings which was raised above the street. The stocks appear to have been capable of holding two persons.

Redcliff Mill, a water mill on the banks of the tidal harbour in the vicinity of the present eastern end of Redcliffe Bascule Bridge. The (presumed) main building of two storeys and two bays, with single-storey extensions. The wheel was in a building with a gabled roof, open at the river end, adjacent to the main building.

Ashton Gate Halt. The station was opened on 15 September 1906 for football crowds as Ashton Gate Platform. It was renamed Ashton Gate in August 1928, and became Ashton Gate Halt on 29 October 1962. It was staffed between November 1929 and October 1962. There was limited use for football specials after 1964, but the station is now closed.

KNOWN_AS: Ventilation tower for Clifton Rocks Railway
MONUMENT_DESC:
Ventilation tower for Clifton Rocks Railway, located on the western side of Clifton Down. The tower was built c.1875 to ventilate the tunnel of the Clifton Rocks Railway which was cut under the Downs and is 3.75 metres in diameter and approximately 6 metres high. The tower is constructed of squared, snecked Pennant sandstone and rests on a plinth approximately 1 metre high with a moulded limestone ashlar cornice. On the south-east face at a height of around 4 metres from the ground there is a small rectangular limestone plaque with a moulded edge. The stone at the centre of the plaque is badly delaminated and any inscription it may have carried is now lost.
The tower has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/34/757).

No.173 Crew's Hole Road, located on the north side of Crew's Hole Road. The building is a rendered two-storey, four bay house with a pitched pantile roof. A two-storey rear range runs north from the east-west block on the Crew's Hole Road fontage. The building is of probable eighteenth-century date but was refronted in the early-nineteenth century. It was first recorded by the St. George tithe survey of 1842 (BRO EP/A/32/32).

Shirehampton Golf Course, located on the southern side of Shirehampton Road. The golf club was founded in 1904 on land belonging to the Napier Miles family. It was conveyed with the rest of the estate to the National Trust in 1918. The western half of the course was taken over for Shirehampton camp (SMR 22152) in 1942-43 and the course reduced to nine holes. It reverted to eighteen holes after the end of the war.

A possible mine revealed beneath the garden of Bellevue, Grove Road during ground works at Malvern House. The 'mine' consisted of two interconnected chambers with smaller side chambers approached by an east-west aligned shaft. The original shaft entrance is likely to have been beneath the former Malvern House garden and later modern extension to Malvern House. The mine was only identified when ground reduction of the former garden area revealed an underground chamber 2 metres below the surface measuring 1.5 metres wide and 1m high. The chamber continued down at a slight incline for a further 3.5 metres to a depth approximately 3 metres below the garden to the rear of Bellevue. The chamber had been excavated into soft Dolomitic Conglomerate immediately to the west of an area of Carboniferous Limestone.  There are no known cartographic depictions or documentary references to the mine, dating the activity to a period before the first specific reference to the area on a sketch plan of 1801 (BRO 32226, Boxes 20-21, Redland bundle). It was speculated that the mine was excavated in the eighteenth century for Celestine or other rare minerals that can be found in the conglomerate.

KNOWN_AS: Drinking Fountain at Avonmouth Road, Avonmouth
MONUMENT_DESC: A drinking fountain in the highway at the junction of Avonmouth Road with St. Andrew's Road. The fountain was a rectangular structure constructed in the early decades of the twentieth century and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey third edition 1:2500-scale County Series plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.01) published in 1916.

KNOWN_AS: Bristol Tramways Company Depot, Avonmouth Road, Avonmouth
MONUMENT_DESC:
Bristol Tramways Company Depot located on the northern side of Avonmouth Road, Avonmouth. The building was constructed in 1915 and was probably designed by the Bristol architect W. H. Watkins. The building is a single-storey brick structure with pitched tiled roofs in an Arts and Crafts style. Much of the main, south-west facing elevation comprises a range of sliding timber doors to the garage and the garage entrance piers are rusticated render with alternate brick quoins. At the centre of the elevation and also in the office range there are two steep gables coontaining tympana decorated with plaster cartouches bearing the date 1915. At the south-west corner of the building there is a square corner turret containing the entrance, a semicircular-arched doorway, to the office range on the west side of the building with clock face above.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/52-357).

Mortuary located on the south-western side of Richmond Terrace, Avonmouth. The mortuary was built in the early decades of the twentieth century and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey third edition 1:2500-scale County Series plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.01) published in 1916.

The Avonmouth Hotel on the south-western side of Portview Road, Avonmouth. The building is a two-storey brick structure with a pitched tiled roof and is in an Arts and Crafts style. The building was constructed in the first decades of the twentieth century and is recorded by the Ordnance Survey third edition 1:2500-scale County Series plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.01) published in 1916. The upper floor of the building is rendered and it is currently (05/02/07) known as the Avonmouth Tavern.
Opened 18.4.1867.Unstaffed from 29.10.1962. Closed to passengers 7.9.1964 and entirely 5.7.1965.{1}

Montpelier Station, located on the north side of Station Road, Montpelier. The station is a single storey building of coursed Pennant sandstone blocks with ashlar dressings and a pitched roof. It was opened on 1 October 1874 as a stop on the Clifton Extension Railway. The station was closed to goods traffic from 29 November 1965 and was unstaffed from 17 July 1967. The building is extant.

Redland Station, located on the south side of South Road, Redland. The station is a single storey brick building with a pitched roof. It was opened on 12 April 1897 as a stop on the Clifton Extension Railway. The building is extant.

Clifton Down Station. The station opened on 1 October 1874. It was closed to goods traffic on 5 July 1965 and was unstaffed after 17 July 1967, but platform and line are still (2006) in use.
The station buildings have been converted into a public house.
Opened 7.1870. Closed to goods 1.6.1964.Unstaffed 23.9.1968.{1}

Parson Street Station, Bedminster. The station opened on 29 August 1927, when it was known as Parson Street Platform. The suffix was dropped in November 1933. The station has been unstaffed since 23 September 1968.
Ashley Hill Station.

Horfield Station. The station opened on 14 May 1927 when it was known as Horfield Platform. It was renamed as Horfield Station in November 1933. The station was closed as a result of the Beeching cuts on 23 November 1964.

Fishponds Station. The station opened on 1 April 1866 when it was called Stapleton. The name was changed to Fishponds on 1 July 1867. The station closed to goods traffic on 13 December 1965 and was closed entirely on 7 March 1966 (Oakley 1986).

Lawrence Hill Station, located on the northern side of Lawrence Hill. The station opened on 8 September 1863. A major extension was added in 1891 (partly as a result of the completion of the Clifton Extension Railway).
St. Anne's Park Station. Opened 23.5.1898. Unstaffed since 6.3.1967. Closed entirely 5.1.1970.
Brislington Station. Opened 3.9.1873. Closed to passengers 31.10.1959. Closed entirely 7.10.1963 (Oakley 1986).
Stapleton Road Station. Opened 8.9.1863. Closed to goods 29.11.1965. Partially unstaffed 16.6.1969.{1}
Small square enclosure on the north side of the field surrounded by ridge and furrow.

The 'British Restaurant', later called the 'Civic Restaurant'.  Located in Narrow Wine Street opposite the Car Park. Single storey, pitched roof, rectangular building.  The building features in two photographs in Reece Winstone's books: "Bristol in the 1940's" frame 90 and "Bristol As It Was 1953-1956" frame 32.

No.35 Marling Road. The building is a two-storey rendered house and forms part of a terrace of four houses. The date at which the house was constructed is currently unclear but it was in existence by the time of the St. George tithe survey of 1842 (BRO EP/A/32/32).

No.37 Marling Road. The building is a two-storey rendered house and forms part of a terrace of four houses. The date at which the house was constructed is currently unclear but it was in existence by the time of the St. George tithe survey of 1842 (BRO EP/A/32/32).

The Donkey Ramp, an inclined plane which  connected Alfred (later Midland) Wharf with Redcliffe Parade. The ramp was built against the sandstone cliff and was approximately 50 metres long and between 3 and 3.5 metres wide.

Wapping Railway yard, located on the west side of Wapping Road. The Docks Engineer, Thomas Howard, proposed a rail link between the docks and Temple Meads station in 1863 and the Docks Committee concluded the purchase of Western Wapping Dock (BUAD 757M) in 1865. The dock was then infilled to allow the development of the marshalling yard. The cell blocks of the New Gaol (BUAD 63M) were demolished in the mid-1890s to enable the yard to be enlarged on its south side.

Granary, at Princes Wharf. The granary was constructed in 1888 and was a seven-storey brick warehouse. It had the Bristol coat of arms at the centre of the elevation, on a raised element of the parapet. The building was destroyed by bombing on 3 January 1941.

M Shed, Princes Wharf. At the end of the Second World War the Port of Bristol Authority decided to develop a general cargo handling facility at Prince's Wharf. This was completed in 1951 and M Shed was constructed as part of the scheme. The building is a two-storey transit shed with a steel frame and is attached to L Shed (BUAD 1578M). M Shed was used by the Bristol Steam Navigation Company. From 1954 the company operated its Bristol-Dublin trade using M Shed and in 1965 a Scotch derrick crane was installed at the west end of the shed. This was removed in 1969 when BSNC moved its operations from Princes Wharf to Avonmouth. M Shed became a general cargo shed and remained so until the port use ended in the 1970s. The building was converted into an Industrial Museum for the city in 1977.

KNOWN_AS: House at south-west corner of St. James Churchyard
MONUMENT_DESC: House at south-west corner of St. James Churchyard. The ground-floor probably a shop. At the south-west corner of St.James Churchyard, on the Horsefair, the next but one property to the corner of Silver Street. Attached to west, probably also to north. 3 storeys and attic; gabled front; 3-window range (?). Entrance towards right-hand end of south elevation, shop window to left, cellar access beneath. Full-width pentice roof above. Possible further examples to next 2 storeys. First and second floors have 3 blocked windows each, the proportions being those of sashes. Attic window.

Bridewell Bridge, also known as Monkenbridge. The bridge crossed the River Frome between Bridewell and Turn Again Lane, now beneath Bridewell Street. Parts probably survive underground. The bridge was a single span arch with a string course immediately above the voussoirs. Tall ashlar parapets with rounded coping, the eastern parapet with a concave ramp down at its northern end. The road surface was slightly bowed.

KNOWN_AS: Pond south-west of Great house at Lower Knowle
MONUMENT_DESC:
A pond with a central island, which was filled in when the old people's home currently occupying the site was built. The date of the feature is not clear; it is recorded by a sketch map amongst the Smyth papers (BRO AC/PL18b) but not by the Bedminster tithe map of 1841 although later maps do show it. The date of creation and function of the pond are unknown and while its form may possibly suggest a medieval date there is currently no firm evidence to support this.
The land was sold to the City by the Smyth family in 1929 (BRO 4627/181a-c) and in the 1960s it was a nature conservation site.

KNOWN_AS: Pond south-east of Old Sneed Park
MONUMENT_DESC: Fishpond marked on tithe map (1836) within area of medieval park. It is considerably larger on modern OS 6" map. {1} Ponds & lock system on stream to left of the house.{3

Medieval deerpark, Pen Park. The park belonged to the Bishop of Worcester and dated from the 13th century. There is a detailed survey of the park for 1299 (Red Book of Worcester). Some park boundaries are marked on the tithe map. Much of the area was built up in the 1930's.
A park of the bishop of Worcester dating from the 13th century (1271?).{1}Kip engraving of the park. {3}

Avonmouth Dock Junction Signal Box. Former Midland Railway standard signal box dating from 1904. This location was known as Crown Brickyard crossing until 1911, when the present name was adopted. The lever frame which is also of Midland Railway design also dates from 1911. This is now the only operational ex-Midland Railway signal box south of Birmingham.

KNOWN_AS: Mill near Paye Bridge Road, Bishopsworth
MONUMENT_DESC: Mill probably located somewhere in the general area of Paye Bridge Road. On 9 May 1588 Jane Smythe threatened Will Woonye, miller with fine of 6s. 8d. if he did not turn the water near the Paye Bridge back into its accustomed course by St. Michael's day (Bantock 1982, 47).

KNOWN_AS: Quarry to the south of Lawrence Weston Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Quarry located some 25 metres to the south of Lawrence Weston Road, close to the junction with Quarry Lane. The quarry is recorded as "Old Quarry" by the Ordnance Survey first edition plan published in 1881 (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.03).

Knowle Picture House. The cinema was built for Frank Moore in 1913 to a design by W. H. Watkins. The building had a fireplace in the foyer and a billiard room upstairs (Anderson 1983, 22). The cinema could seat an audience of 700 and was run by F. G. W. Chamberlain from the early 1920s (Ewins 1984, 27). The cinema closed in 1961 and the building demolished soon after. The site is now occupied by a supermarket.

Brightbow Bridge, located at approximately the junction of East Street and Bedminster Parade. The bridge was constructed in the medieval period to carry the highway over the River Malago. In 1480 William Worcestre gave two measurements for the length of the bridge, 24 steps and 36 steps. He recorded it as 5 yards wide (SMR 20703; Neale 2000, 96-97). In 1665, the bridge was reported as being "in great decay and that several people have lost their lives and others been greatly hurt and damaged and that part of the bridge is already fallen and the rest is likely to fall speedily" (quoted in Bantock 1982, 163). The extent of the survival of the elements of the bridge is not known.

The medieval manor house of Bishopsworth probably stood on the site of its 16th-century and 18th-century successors there is a documentary reference to the site in 1726: "Ann Smyth moved to the manor here. The Old Elizabethan farmhouse was almost totally rebuilt for her in the Georgian style, (SMR 4697) reminiscent of Kings Weston..."

A heavy anti-aircraft battery, located on Bedminster Down to the north of Bridgwater Road. The battery appears to have been operational by February 1940 and at that date was equipped with four 3.7in guns. This armament appears to have remained the same through its life (Dobinson 1996, 330). The form of the battery is recorded by a vertical air photograph taken in 1946 (CPE/UK/1869 Frame 3091) which comprised six gun emplacements arranged in an ellipse around and to the south of a central command post. An access road ran from Bridgwater Road, along the current entrance road to the cemetery and then turned to the north-west to the central building. On the north-eastern and south-western sides of this road there were the ancillary buildings housing the unit which manned the battery.
The site is now part of the South Bristol Cemetery and grave-digging may have damaged the monument severely.

KNOWN_AS: Possible Mill on Pigeon House Stream
MONUMENT_DESC: Possible Mill on Pigeon House Stream. Tithe map has field name "Millmead" at ST584687. {1} Croxbottom Farm (ST 582686) sits astride  stream with weir and pond upstream of it and may be the site of a mill, but not recorded as such on maps. {2}{3}

KNOWN_AS: Avonbank Brick and Tile Works, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC:
Avonbank Brick and Tile Works, located to the south of Feeder Road. The works is recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition 1:500 plan (Sheet LXXVI.1.9) surveyed in 1883 which records the kiln, with large sheds to its east. A clay pit roughly 100 metres across is marked some 90 metres to the north-west of the kiln. The kiln, apparently a Hoffman kiln, was an elliptical building, orientated from north-east to south-west and measuring 45 metres long by 16 metres wide (Johnson, 2002).
The works had apparently gone out of use by the time of the second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXVI.01) published in 1904, which indicates that the majority of the sheds had been removed. Only the kiln, the largest shed and two groups of smaller buildings 40 metres north of the kiln survived. The southern part of the the Avonside Glue Works had also been built constructed in the northern end of the clay pit. By 1918 all of the structures associated with the brickworks had been demolished.

Sulphur Works, St. Philip's Marsh, located to the south of Feeder Road. The works is recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition 1:500 plan (Sheet LXXVI.1.9) surveyed in 1883. It had, however, been completely demolished by the time of the 2nd edition map in 1902. The site has been completely redeveloped.

Manure Works, St. Philip's Marsh, located to the south of Feeder Road. The works is recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition 1:500 plan (Sheet LXXVI.1.9) surveyed in 1883 but it had been demolished by the time of the 2nd edition map of 1902 and the site incorporated into the site of the Great Western Colliery, itself by then disused. The site has been completely redeveloped.

KNOWN_AS: St. Alban's Church, Coldharbour Lane, Redland
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Alban's Church, Coldharbour Road, Redland located on the southern side of the junction of Coldharbour Lane and Bayswater Avenue. The construction of the church was agreed in 1892-1893.
In c.1903 it was replaced by a larger church immediately to the south-west and the building became the church hall.

KNOWN_AS: Garden of Cote, Cote House Lane, Westbury-on-Trym
MONUMENT_DESC: Garden of Cote (SMR 3060), an eighteenth-century house located on the southern side of Cote House Lane. At the beginning of the nineteenth century Humphry Repton undertook a consultation on the garden. The existing formal garden was created in the early-nineteenth century by Mrs Jean Anderson and John Wedgewood. Its site has now been partly built over but several features of the garden are extant, including the drive, a stable block, the terrace walk and the orangery and a cast iron post and chain fence (Avon Gardens Trust 1991, 18).

KNOWN_AS: Possible barrow west of Croxbottom Farm
MONUMENT_DESC: Possible barrow west of Croxbottom Farm. Circular earthwork, almost level, 50 feet diameter, possibly a disc barrow. ST57896858 <1>. "...There is no trace of antiquity on the ground".

Chapel of St. Peter, Bishopsworth. The date of construction, form and location of the chapel are currently (13/02/2002) unknown, although it was preseumably on or near the site of the present church. The chapel was probably founded during the medieval period and Taylor (1888-93, 188; 200) dates it to c.1189.
The chapel was dissolved in the mid-sixteenth century but the site appears to have remained unsold into the early-seventeenth century. It was bringing an annual revenue of 1s. 8d. to the Crown in 1602 (Woodward 1982, 124).
The date of demolition of the chapel building is unknown.

A Roman building at Bedminster Down. Roman pottery, tile fragments and some plaster were found in the area in 1921-22 on the edge of a quarry, 150 yards south of Bridgwater Road. The site was then archaeologically excavated by the University of Bristol Spelaeological Society in 1925 (Prowse, 1923-25 89). The excavation recorded the foundations of walls, plaster, pottery, iron objects, samian pottery, sandstone roof tiles and coins (Tratman 1922, 298). The site extended as far as the Bridgwater Road on the north.
The site was subsequently built over and destroyed.
ST59486940, a ring earthwork 50 feet in diameter, 6" high. Other small mounds in the same field are probably from felled trees.

KNOWN_AS: Medieval Filton or Filwood Deer Park
MONUMENT_DESC: Filton or Filwood Deer Park or chase. The park was a medieval deer park which apparently belonged to Keynsham Abbey. The abbey had a grange, chapel and lands and tenements in the area. The ancient park of Filwood (also called a Chase) is recorded by Saxton in 1642 (Shirley 1867, 11).

A gibbet sited on Dunball Island, at the mouth of the River Avon. The gibbet was apparently still extant in the early nineteenth-century when is it shown by a survey of the area by Y. and J. Sturge 'A plan of the parish of Westbury-on-Trym', 1817 (Northampton Record Office plan 616).

A building known as the Tithe Barn, located on the southern side of High Street, Shirehampton, which is reputed to have been built c.1470. The building appears to have been constructed as a barn and has a ten bay roof, of collar beam type, with curved wind braces. It is reputed to be associated with a medieval priory but there is currently no historical evidence to support its connection with any monastic site.
The building was heavily altered in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. A two-storey cottage was added to the western end of the building and the rear (south) wall of the barn has been substantially rebuilt, with the insertion of modern windows. The fabric of the north wall, facing High Street, shows evidence of a large blocked entrance.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/18/1737).

A holy well, named Bucklewell, was pointed out to Davies by T. Hughes, under an overhanging rock north east of the allotment gardens west of Horseshoe Point (ST538766). {1}
On 30th September 1948 George Boon recorded in his diary that he discovered Bucklewell.  He notes that the supposed Bucklewell rock shelter and the holy well are one and the same (Boon, undated)

A probable Roman building lies along the line of the main road, 1800-1900 feet from King's Weston villa (SMR 744) and 400' from the junction with Kingsweston Lane. Pottery (mostly late, and a piece of mended samian, Dragendorf 31),  walling, roofing, ashes and a possible flagged floor were discovered. Part of the site probably underlies the grounds of the adjoining school. (Boon 1974) Some 100' along the road, towards the villa, is a possible lime kiln (a pit was found with much lime and pottery). ST53917779 an arch reported as Roman proved to be an C18-19 spring head. In 1947 several buildings were found during building and excavated in 1948 and 1949. Two buildings of different dates, and were farmhouses. Date probably late C3 and later (Boon Undated)

A rocket battery, or Z Battery, dating to the Second World War located at Brislington. The battery formed part of a group of batteries which fired unguided rockets to create a box defence (Roberts, 1981 65). It was in existence by 1941. The exact location of the battery is not currently known.
A pill box built into the wall of the former gasworks. {1} No trace of this survives in 1994. {2}
Ashtongate Camp or Bedminster Camp. The camp was a prisoner of war camp established during the Second World War (Thomas 2003, 30). Its precise location is currently (19/03/04) unknown.

Clifton Green, located at the heart of the medieval village of Clifton to the south of the parish church of St. Andrew. The green was a 1.15 hectare area of open ground. There was a pound (SMR 5809) on the south side of the green.

Ashton Gate Football Ground. Bristol City played their first game here in 1894 on land leased from the Ashton Court estate, although the first ground was constructed by 1904. The earliest depiction of the sports ground is on the 1:2500 Ordnance Survey plan published in 1903. This plan shows a pavillion building on the northeast side of the ground and an incomplete rectangular area surrounded by banks. The west corner of the sports pitch is not depicted presumeably because the ground was not completed until after the survey. The plan also indicates that the area was in use as a cricket and footbal ground. By the time of the Ordnance Survey plan published in 1918 the ground had been repositioned to be centred approximately 100m west of the original ground. On this plan the site of the original pitch was in use as a bowling green and the football ground appears to have southwest and northeast stands with open terraces possibly made from earth banks to the northwest and southeast. The stands have been considerably altered and rebuilt at various times during the twentieth century. Records held by the football club suggest that the northeast stand was rebuilt in 1970, the southeast in 1928, the southwest in 1958 and the northwest stand in 1994.

Upper Fishpond, located on the south-eastern side of Fishponds Road. The original function of the pond is not currently clear, and it may have been a fishpond or possibly a water-filled quarry. However, it was in existence by the beginning of the seventeenth century and was recorded on a plan of Kingswood Forest made in 1610 as one of "the newe pooles." A plan by J. Sturge of 1781 (BRO AC/PL 90) indicates that the pond measured approximately 200 metres from north-west to south-east and was 42 metres wide. It had apparently been infilled by the time of the Stapleton tithe survey of 1839.

KNOWN_AS: West End Brick and Tile Works
MONUMENT_DESC: West End Brick and tile Works, Bedminster. The works with clay pit at the north end is marked on the Ordnance Survey County Series map.
Hendre Brick and Tile Works. Marked at this location on the County Series map. {1}
A large rectangular building with apsidal North East end marked at this location on the county series map.
Constructed between 1886 and 1904. {1}{2}

KNOWN_AS: Bower Ashton Terrace, Ashton Road, Ashton Gate
MONUMENT_DESC:
Bower Ashton Terrace, located on the northern side of Ashton Road. The terrace of single-bay houses was constructed in the late-nineteenth century. Nos.2-4, 11-16 and 17-18 had been built by 1882 (Bristol 1:500-scale Town Plan Sheet LXXV.3.20) and between Nos.4 and 11 was an enclosed space known as Horesham Green. This had, however, been developed to construct Nos.5-10 Bower Ashton Terrace by the time of the Second edition 1:2500-scale plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXV.03) published in 1904.
The terrace is extant.

The Fishponds Cinema, located on the east side of Station Avenue near the junction of Fishponds Road. The cinema opened in 1911 and it closed 1922. The building is now Fishponds library (Winstone 1972, 8).

The Gaiety Cinema located at the junction of Crossway's Road and Wells Road, Knowle. The cinema opened in 1933 with 2000 seats (Anderson 1983, 50; 90). It was demolished in 2000 and is now the site of Anchor House.

KNOWN_AS: Granada Cinema, Church Road, St. George
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Granada Cinema, located on the north side of Church Road, St George. The cinema opened as the Electric Theatre in 1912 with 746 seats. It became St George's Picture House owned by Pugsley's in the 1920s and later became the Granada (Anderson 1983, 3). The building was converted in to a bingo hall in 1961 (Winstone 1972, pl.240).
The building is still extant.

The Eastville Hippodrome, located on south east side of Stapleton Road. The cinema built for George Allen of the Eastville Hippodrome Company to a design by W. H. Watkins (Ewins 1984, 27). The cinema, also known as the Picture Hippodrome (Ewins 1984, 26), opened in 1913 with 300 seats, and closed in 1959 (Anderson, 1983 22; 83).
The building is still extant, and is currently used as warehouse (17/11/2004).

KNOWN_AS: Kingsway Cinema, Two Mile Hill Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Kingsway Cinema on the north side of Two Mile Hill Road. The cinema opened in 1928 and had 800 seats. It was closed in 1959 (Anderson, 1983, 39).
Shirehampton Park. Possibly originally part of Kings Weston Park. {1}. The park is owned and managed by the National Trust.

KNOWN_AS: First World War Coastal Battery at the South Pier, Avonmouth Docks
MONUMENT_DESC: A coastal defence battery located on the south pier of Avonmouth Docks. The precise location of the battery is not clear but it was apparently operational from 1 December 1916 and was equipped with two 4.7 inch QF/Naval guns (Dobinson 2000, 287). QF Batteries were intended to provide defence against torpedo boats. They had an effective range of 1000 yards and were "always sited to command an intensively illuminated area of water" (Dobinson 2000, 37). An emplacement was typically approximately 60 metres long and the guns had a wide arc of fire. Subsurface magazines and crew shelters were immediately adjacent to the guns (Dobinson 2000, 38).

Knowle House, located on the north side of Knowle Lane (modern Talbot Road). The house was in existence by the time of the Bedminster tithe survey of 1841 and survived into the early-twentieth century. The house was subsequently demolished and the site lies partly beneath Talbot Road and the Nos.27-33 Talbot Road.
Wickham Bridge, located at the foot of Wickham Hill. The bridge is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882.

Oldbury Court Farm, located some 425 metres to the north of Manor Road on the eastern side of Oldbury Court Road. The farm was in existence by the time of the Stapleton tithe survey of 1839 and the tithe map indicates that the farmhouse was on the south side of the plot (at ST 65305 76410) while to the north was a yard with outbuildings on the north and south sides. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882 indicates that no new buildings had been added by that date but some outbuildings had been constructed to the east of the farmhouse by 1916. The farm survived into the mid-1930s but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped for housing.
The site of the farm now lies largely beneath the houses and gardens of Nos.86-98 Oldbury Court Road.
Mason's Arms public house, located on the eastern side of Park Road. The building is extant.
Frome Bridge, located at the southern end of Broom Hill.

No.36, King Street, located on the north side of King Street.. The land between the lane on the east side of the Old Library (BUAD 14M) and St. Nicholas Almshouses (BUAD 17M) was leased to Thomas Wickham, carpenter, by the Corporation in 1650 and Wickham was almost certainly responsible for the construction of the building. No.36 King Street was a house of three storeys and attic with a timber-framed front and a gabled roof.
The building was demolished at end of 1904, but was visited in advance of its removal by John Pritchard who described some of the internal features (Pritchard 1906, 130-131).

Ridleys Almshouse, also known as the Batchelors and Maids Almshouse, located on the western side of the junction of Milk Street and Old King Street. The almshouse was founded by Sarah Ridley through a bequest of £2,200 in her will of 10 November 1716 to provide for "the maintenance from time to time of five old poor decayed batchelors, and five old poor decayed maidens" (Manchee, 1831 192-193). Sarah Ridley died in 1726 and the site was purchased in 1735. Five small houses had previously ocupied the site but were then reported to be "decayed and in great part fallen down" (Manchee, 1831 195). Building commenced in 1738 and was completed August 1740, and a total £860 was spent to establish the almshouse (Manchee, 1831 195).
The almshouse measured 20.5 metres from east to west and was 13.5 metres north-south and was of two storeys with a hipped slate roof. The Milk Street elevation had a five-window range and at either end there were a pair of slightly projecting side wings, each with a one-window range.
At first-floor, a round-headed recess contained a plaque which, in accordance with the terms of Sarah Ridley's will, carried the legend: "In Memory of Mr Thomas Ridley and Sarah Ridley Being Brother and Sister Never Married Erected Anno Dom 1739." otherwise cross-windows, as at both storeys of wings, also in side elevations and insides of wings. The Old King Street elevation had a three-window range with a projecting centre bay.
The building was unusual in having casement windows at so late a date.
There were some additions of perhaps 1741.
The almshouse was damaged by bombing during the Second World War, was subsequently designated as a Scheduled Ancient Monument. It was, however, removed to make way for the development of the new Broadmead shopping centre. The building was recorded by the Ministry of Works prior to its demolition (BUAD 920; O'Neill, 1951). The plaque commemorating the founder and her brother was removed when the building was demolished and is now in the collections of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery.
A drinking fountain was located in an arched recess, in a larger gabled structure, in the boundary wall against Old King Street. Until early in the twentieth century there was a 'Charley Box' or watchman's box at the junction of the two streets.

A rope walk stretching from Whitehouse Street in north west direction almost to Bedminster Parade. Terraced housing (the buildings on the north-east side of Philip Street) was later erected on the site.

Locks Mill, located on the south-western side of Parson Street, Bedminster. The mill was in existence by 1834 and was recorded by the Bedminster tithe survey (BRO EP/A/32/8). At that date the mill building stood at the north-eastern end of a large millpond which measured approximately 120 metres from south-west to north-east and was 28 metres wide. There was an outbuilding some 10 metres to the north-west of the mill building. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan published in 1890 (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXV.08) indicates that the mill was then producing glue. The millpond, however, had apparently silted up to a large extent. The mill building survived into the twentieth century but was subsequently demolished. The western outbuilding may, however, survive.

Odeon (Ambassador) cinema on corner of Winterstoke Road and Luckwell Road. The cinema opened in 1936 with 1250 seats (Anderson, 1983, 56). The main entrance to the cinema was on the corner of Winterstoke Road and Luckwell Road with a circular white cement tower above. A large white cement canopy projected above the entrance and followed the curve of the tower above.
The building was converted to a bingo hall in 1961 and has more recently been the Alphabet Zoo.

The Orpheus Cinema, Henleaze located on the south west side of Northumbria Drive, Henleaze. The cinema opened in 1938 with 1400 seats. It remained in use for several decades, although the cinema closed for a time in the 1970s. The cinema remains in use although the building has now been partly incorporated into a supermarket (Anderson 1983, 56).
Malthouse, located on the northern side of Upper Maudliin Street. The structure is shown by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition 1:500-scale plan of the early 1880s.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Westgate House, Quay Head, Rupert Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Boot and Shoe Manufactory, located to the west of Quay Street. The factory is shown by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of the 1880s.

KNOWN_AS: Governor House, Canon's Marsh Gas Works
MONUMENT_DESC: The Governor House, Canon's Marsh Gas Works. The Governor House was built c1900. It was a single-storey brick building with a pitched pantile roof. Some of the internal features remained in situ after the building went out of use, including control valves. The building stood in a state of dereliction for many years. A photographic survey was made (BUAD 3285) before it was demolished at the end of 1997.

KNOWN_AS: W. D. & H. O. Wills Tobacco Factory, Redcliff Street
MONUMENT_DESC: W. D. & H. O. Wills Tobacco Factory, located on the western side of Redcliff Street. The factory was constructed in 1869 to designs by Foster and Wood. An extension designed by Frank Wills had been added by the early 1880s.
Malthouse, Redcliff Street. The factory stood on the east side of Redcliff Street and is recorded by the 1st Edition Ordnance Survey map of the 1880s.
Tobacco factory, Redcliff Street. The factory is recorded by the 1st edition Ordnance Survey map of the early 1880s.
Redcliff Brewery. The brewery, on the east side of Redcliff Street, was recorded by the 1st edition Ordnance Survey map of the early 1880s.

Hamilton Rooms, assembly rooms or public rooms located at the top of Hamilton Place Steps, Culver Street. The building was probably two storeys in height with five parallel gabled roofs, the gables facing south-east. Access from Park Street was via an alley between Nos.38 & 40. The site is now occupied by the Folk House building.

No.2 Pipe Lane, an attached house of three-storeys and attic; gabled front; 2-window range. A left-hand entrance with pedimented hood; 2 sashes, over cellar access door. 2 sashes each to first and second floors. A single attic window, possibly a horizontal sash. Much removed between September 1942 and July 1943, but facade still standing to two and a half storeys in 1952. 
The adjacent house to the east, No.1, with 3 storeys and an attic, a 2-window range, had at its right-hand the entrance to Princess Amelia Court (Nos.1-8 demolished c.1935); the house still possessed a shell hood in 1907.

Nos. 58 & 60 Colston Street. Attached. Early C18. Shared hipped roof, one front dormer to each side. 3 storeys, attics and basements; 2:1-window range, sashes. Single room front and back, with central lateral stair. 2 right-hand lateral stacks, 2 central stacks.

No.64 Colston Street. Attached. Late C17. Hipped roof with front dormer. 3 storeys, attic and basement; 2-window range. Single room front and back, with central stair. Sashes to first and second floors.

Brislington Hill House Lodge, Brislington. This was situated on the corner of the present Glenarm Road and Brislington Hill/Bath Road. It was built in the mid eighteenth century in a "Strawberry Hill Gothick" style. The Lodge was demolished in 1966 for road widening, and the building of flats and shops.

KNOWN_AS: White Horse Hotel, No.23 Barrs Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
The White Horse Hotel, No.23 Barrs Street, which was located at the corner of Barrs Street and Milk Street. The three-storey, eight-bay building had a double entrance in the corner bay and a second entrance in the second bay of the Milk Street frontage. The windows at first floor level were hood moulded, while those in the corner bay on both first and second floors were more elaborate. Each had three lights and more extensive moulding. There was a hipped roof. The hotel had a yard surrounded by a high wall on its east side.
The building was demolished in the late 1950s to make way for the redevelopment of Broadmead.

No.52 Colston Street. Attached. C18 style, stone front, stepped voussoirs. Hipped roof with front dormer. 3 storeys, attic and basement; 2-window range, sashes. Single room front and back, with central lateral stair. Lateral stacks to right.

Church of St. Peter, Bishopsworth, located on the west side of Church Road, Bishopsworth. The church was intended as a chapel-of-ease to St. John's, Bedminster. It was designed by S. C. Fripp in a Norman Revival style and was built between November 1841 and 1843 by the firm of T. Pratten. Finances for completion of the building ran short near the end of the project and a public appeal for £1000 was launched in 1843.
In 1853 St. Peter became an ecclesiastical parish in its own right.
The church has a short broad tower with pyramidal roof over the chancel (Pevsner 1958, 463).
The church has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/50/412).

Circa 1840 (probably contemporary with the Church) Tudor Revival style in limestone rubble. 3 bays 2:1, gabled to right. 2 storeys, 2 light lozenge lattice casement windows, 2 below, 3 above. Pantiled roof with stone stacks.

St. Paul's Church, Coronation Road. The church was built between 1829 and 1831 to a design by C. Dyer.
It was destroyed by bombing in 1940 and rebuilt in 1958. The building suffered a partial collapse in 1990 (Crossley-Evans, 2000 81).
The tower of the church has a Grade II listing (Listed Building Number 901-1/45/1826)

KNOWN_AS: All Saints' Church, Thingwall Park, Fishponds
MONUMENT_DESC: All Saints' Church on the north side of Thingwall Park. The church was constructed between 1903 and the First World War and was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.10) published in 1918. The church has a hall some 10 metres to the north.

The Priory, located some 175 metres to the east of Westbury Road, Westbury-on-Trym. The building was apparently constructed in the earlier nineteenth century and was recorded by the Westbury-on-Trym tithe survey of 1841 (BRO EP/A/32/41) as Parcel 1021. The apportionment described the property as then comprising a House, Offices & Gardens owned by James Gibbs and occupied by Thomas Griffiths. The building was still extant at the time of the First World War but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped for housing.

Burfield House, located some 175 metres to the east of Westbury Road, Westbury-on-Trym. The building was in existence by c1815 (Northampton Record Office plan 616). The Westbury-on-Trym tithe survey of 1841 (BRO EP/A/32/41) records the house (Parcel 1023) as Burfield House, Office, Gardens & Yards owned by Edward Bowles Fripp and occupied by Thomas Jones. The house survived into the twentieth century and by 1916 had become Red Maids School. It had also been substantially extended on its east side by that date, presumably as part of the conversion to use as a school. The building is extant.

Westmead House, located some 150 metres to the east of Westbury Road, Westbury-on-Trym. The building was in existence by 1817 (Northampton Record Office plan 613 2C). It subsequently became part of the Convent of Mercy (SMR 21728) and the Westbury-on-Trym tithe survey of 1841 (BRO EP/A/32/41) records the property (Parcel 1029) as Convent, Offices and Gardens, and front of Field at Westmead owned by Maria Theresa Weld which she occupied herself.

No.156 Westbury Road, located on the east side of Westbury Road. The building was in existence by c1815 (Northampton Record Office plan 623 (b) 2). The Westbury-on-Trym tithe survey of 1841 (BRO EP/A/32/41) records the property (Parcel 697) as a Dwelling House and Garden owned and occupied by James Joseph Whitchurch. By the 1880s the building was known as Southey House.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/28/2093).

KNOWN_AS: Quarry on the west side of Saville Road
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry on Durdham Down, to the west of the line of modern Saville Road. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition plan, Sheet LXXI.11.15 surveyed in 1880, which marks it as "Old Quarry".

KNOWN_AS: Adam and Eve public house, Hope Chapel Hill
MONUMENT_DESC:
Adam and Eve public house, located on the northern side of Hope Chapel Hill, on the west side of its junction with North Green Street. The building was in existence by 1746 and was recorded as a public house occupied by George Rivers, brewer, by Sketchley's directory of Bristol of 1775.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/13/1438).

KNOWN_AS: Limekiln at Blackberry Hill Hospital, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC:
Limekiln at Blackberry Hill Hospital, Stapleton. The limekiln was recorded during a watching brief maintained on groundworks associated with the construction of a new hospital building. The kiln was semi-circular in shape and measured approximately 5.5 metres from east to west and a maximum of 3.5 metres north-south. It was constructed of coursed Pennant sandstone bonded in a grey-white lime mortar containing occasional fragments of charcoal. On the south side was a substantial wall containing four openings with splays leading down into openings in the north face of the wall. On the north side of this wall was semi-circular enclosure.
The limekiln was not recorded by any maps of the area but was believed, on grounds of its style of construction, to date to the nineteenth century (Lankstead 2003).

Oldbury Court. The building was a stone rubble house of two-storeys and attic. It appears to have been of sixteenth- or seventeenth-century date. It survived into the 1930s when it was in poor condition and was apparently derelict by the 1960s. The remaining elements of the structure were subsequently demolished (Winstone, 1977 pl.93).

Bedminster Gate, East Street. The gate was created in the early eighteenth century by the Bristol turnpike trustees and crossed East Street just to the north-west of St. John's Church. A renewal of the trustees powers by Parliament in February 1749 prompted local rioting, and in July 1749 Bedminster Gate was one of a number of turnpike gates destroyed by labourers with blackened faces who called themselves "Jack a Lents" (Latimer 1893, 274). The 1828 survey of Bristol by John Plumley and George Ashmead depicts it as a single gate across the highway. A group of buildings stood to its east, although it is not clear if one of these was a toll house. The gate had apparently been removed by the early 1840s.

The western side of Bath Road at this point below the junction with Wells Road was for many years retained by a wall c.20 metres high. The removal of this wall in 1992 revealed that despite appearance, it was largely of early-mid 20th-century date, with a Pennant Sandstone coursed rubble front to a poured reinforced concrete main structure. (1) (2) Wall now destroyed during road widening. (2)

Totterdown Bridge, crossing the New Cut. The bridge was constructed in 1888 as a clear-span metal girder bridge between high masonry abutments, with a separate span crossing the towpath beside the river (1). This bridge was the first link to St. Philips Marsh from the south after the construction of the New Cut of 1809. The bridge is in excellent condition and is maintained as major highway bridge.

St. Anderw's Church, located on the eastern side of Richmond Terrace, Avonmouth. The church was built at the end of the nineteenth century to serve the new village at Avonmouth. A mission hall had been constructed at the north-west corner of the churchyard by the First World War.
The church was severely damaged by bombing during the Second World War and was rebuilt c1955 to designs by F. L. Hannam. Parts of the original church were incorporated into the new structure.
Probably constructed c.1930 {1}.
Fishponds Baptist Church, located on the northern side of Downend Road. The chapel was constructed for a schismatic group from the Downend congregation and the chapel opened in 1847.

KNOWN_AS: Salvation Army Chapel, Victoria Road, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC:
Salvation Army Chapel, located on the east side of Victoria Road, St. Philip's Marsh. The chapel is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.7) surveyed in 1883 as a Salvation Army chapel with seats for 100. The bears a date stone of 1887 which may mark its change to a Methodist Chapel, and is probably responsible for its being known as the Jubilee Room. It functions today as a warehouse. A photograph was published by Falconer (1991, 18).
The structure of the building is sound, but the interior fittings relating to its use as a chapel have not survived.

Village Pound, Brislington.  The entrance was from Brislington Hill and its rear wall backed on to Church Row.  It was situated adjacent to the The Shrubberies (SMR 20508).  Stray animals were kept here until claimed by their owners.  In earlier times the village stocks and whipping post stood in front of the pound. It was a built of stone and the front wall was significantly lower than the other walls.  A wooden gate was set in this front elevation.

Wesleyan Chapel, Brislington was situated on the corner of Church Lane and Brislington Square. The chapel was built on the site of two cottages that had belonged to Woodland House (SMR 20562) and where the coachman and gardener had resided. On the Brislington Tithe Survey of 1846, (entry 35) the site is recorded as a house and garden owned by John Tompkins. In 1985 the site was occupied by Kentucky Fried Chicken. The Chapel was built of stone in the Victorian Gothic style. The roof was pitched with alternate bands of ornamental tiles.

KNOWN_AS: Park Picture House, Church Road, Redfield
MONUMENT_DESC: The Park Picture House located on the north side of Church Road, St George. The cinema opened in 1911 and consisted of a rubble stone building with ashlar quoins. The entrance to the cinema was at the east end of the Church Road frontage. Photographic evidence suggests that the cinema was created out of existing terraced housing with two first floor windows above the entrance apparently having been truncated by the entrance façade and the roof appears to have been raised. A metal framed partially glazed entrance canopy projected above the entrance and continued at a lower level along the Church Road frontage presumably to provide shelter for patrons (Winstone 1972, pl.242). The building closed as a cinema in 1964 and was demolished in 1967.

The Premier Cinema, located on the east side of Gloucester Road. The cinema was built by W. Porter for S.H. Justin and designed by W. H. Watkins (Ewins 1984, 27). The cinema opened in 1914 with 600 seats downstairs and 100 seats on the balcony (Anderson 1983, 22). The building was altered in the 1930s to hold 962 seats and taken over by Jacey Cinemas Ltd in the 1940s (Ewins 1984, 27). The cinema closed in 1964.
The building is extant.

The Ritz cinema, located on the south side of Bristol Hill, Brislington. The cinema was commissioned by George Allen of Cornell Cinemas Ltd and built by Hyatt and Neate to a design by W. H. Watkins (Ewins 1984, 29). It opened on Saturday 8th October 1938 with 1400 seats (Ewins 1984, 22; Anderson 1983, 56). The building was a reinforced concrete structure filled with panels of bricks (Ewins 1984, 22). 
The cinema closed in 1964 and was demolished for retail use in 1969.
Ridgeway Cemetery, located at the north-western end of Oakdene Avenue, Eastville. The cemetery was established at the end of the nineteenth century.

KNOWN_AS: Milestone at No.341 Fishponds Road, Eastville
MONUMENT_DESC: Milestone located against the stone boundary wall of No.341 Fishponds Road, Eastville. The milestone is a single block of stone approximately 0.8 metres high and 0.17 metres thick, with a cast iron plate roughly 15 millimetres thick fixed to its face. The plate bears the legend "TO / BRISTOL / 2" [miles]. The milestone is currently (05/07/06) painted black.

KNOWN_AS: Lower Lodge, No.27 Mariners Drive, Sneyd Park
MONUMENT_DESC:
Lower Lodge, No.27 Mariners Drive. The building was built as the lower lodge to Old Sneed Park (SMR 5734) which lay approximately 280 metres to the south-west. The lodge, in the Cottage ornee style, was built in the early nineteenth century and is a square structure of Carboniferous limestone of a single storey and attic, with a single-depth plan. Each elevation has a two-window range and the entrance door is in the centre of the south-west facing elevation. The windows are pointed paired timber casement windows with Y mullions. The building has a thatched roof with a central brick stack. At the centre of each elevation there are narrow pointed lunette eyebrow dormers.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/53/1807).

Nursery located on the south-eastern side of Stapleton Road. The nursery was in existence by 1828. It occupied an irregularly-shaped parcel of land with a straight southern boundary formed by a lane which later became Twinnell Road. The nursery covered an area of 4355 square metres. The nursery had been developed for housing by the early 1880s.

KNOWN_AS: Gabled house on the west side of the George Inn, East Street, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC:
House of likely later seventeenth-century date, located on the west side of the George Inn, located on the southern side of East Street, Bedminster. The building was a single-bay, gabled structure with a pantile roof, which the similarities of form suggest was probably constructed as the eastern house of a terrace of three. By the early 1870s the ground-floor of the eastern of this group of three has been rebuilt, creating a square shopfront with a central doorway and shuttered windows on either side. A pantiled pentice roof divided ground- and first-floor and resting on this there was a central bay which continues up to second-floor level. There was a single sash window at both first- and second-floor and the bay had a sloping roof (Winstone 1966, pl.78).
The building was occupied by William Hutchings, greengrocer in 1871 but it had been demolished and the site redeveloped by 1883. The site of the building now lies entirely beneath No.135 East Street.

Durdham Down. A large area of open land which has been used as common land for centuries. There are traces of eighteenth, nineteenth and twentieth century landscaping and the down is of considerable historical importance as a traditional area for open-air recreation. The down is managed by Bristol City Council.

No.39, Broad Street. C19. Attached. 4 storeys and basement; attic(?). Ashlar, probably Bath stone. 4-window range. A right-hand entrance with 3 windows to the left, all with segmental heads with console-like keystones; below the windows a wide segmental arch to a basement light. First-floor arcade with round-headed windows. Round-headed windows to the 2 upper floors. Sashes throughout. A balustraded parapet.

No.8 Christmas Street located on the south side of Christmas Street. Attached. 3 storeys; tall hipped roof; probably jettied; 2-window range. Sashes to first and second floors. C18 or earlier. Removed before July 1931 (Street's notes).

No.9 Christmas Street located on south side of Christmas Street. Attached. 3 storeys and attic; wide half-hipped roof; jettied; 3-window range. Possible alley entrance on left-hand; double shop doors to right of centre, otherwise shop windows. Single attic window. All upper storeys with sashes.

30, Nelson Street. A warehouse. Attached. 3 storeys; 3-window range. Plinth, with plat band above ground-floor. Entrances in the centre of each storey. Round-headed ground-floor windows; sashes to first and second floors.

Court House, located at the north-eastern end of Tailors' Court. Dated 1692.
Roughcast, gable and rear lateral stacks and a slate hipped roof. Single-depth plan.
3 storeys; 6-window range. A regular front has a doorway 4 from the left with a good shell hood on brackets, over a narrow panel inscribed "IFM, 1692." The initials to James and Mary Freeman, who were listed at the building in 1696. Wide 2-panel door. Restored cross windows with C20 leaded casements; inserted doorway in the left-hand window. The left return has a 2-centred arched second-floor mullion and transom casement window; the rear elevation has a second-floor cross window and small mullion window below it, and the outline of a gabled house (The Cyder House BUAD 107M).

No.3, Tailors Court. Attached to south-west, and, probably, also north-west. Adjacent to the north-west side of the entrance to St. John's Churchyard. 2 storeys and attic; gabled front; jettied; 2-window range. Removed before 1950.

No.9 St. James' Churchyard. The building was a cross-gabled, possibly jettied, house of two storeys and attic with a 1-window range. It was of probable seventeenth-century date. The footprint of the building measured by 8.5 metres from north-west to south-east by 5 metres wide. The main elevation faced west on to Haymarket and in most photographs of the building the ground-floor is obscured by foliage and its form is therefore unknown at present. However, it was presumably occupied by a shop. The fenestration at first floor and attic level comprised a single sash and above the first-floor window there was a large painted signboard extending across the full-width of the building. The roof was pantiled. There was a passageway leading to a rear yard along the north side of the building.
The building was demolished in 1953 or 1954. Its site now lies mainly beneath the House of Fraser department store and partly beneath the footway on the north side of the building.

St. Giles Church. Located on the town wall against the town gate at the end of Small Street known as St. Giles's Gate, the church was in existence by c.1285. By c.1350, however, it had been subdivided into properties rented out by the Corporation and became known as the "Old Jury" (Leech 1997, 118-119). The northern half seems to have been used as a storehouse and dwelling into the sixteenth century, while the southern part had been formed into four tenements which survived at least the late seventeenth (ibid.).

KNOWN_AS: St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Chapel, Trenchard Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Chapel, located on the north-western side of Trenchard Street. The chapel was built between 1788 and 1790 and was the first Catholic church built in Bristol after the Reformation.
Interment within the building was ended by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852. The chapel had been gutted by 1973 and it was converted into flats at the beginning of the 1980s.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/11/301).

St. Leonard's Gate. The gate was part of the Norman inner circuit town wall and was an elaborate three-way gate with a T-shaped plan. One arch led into Corn Street, one to the northern end of the original line of Baldwin Street, and the third to the southern end of Fisher Lane (now the northern section of St. Stephen's Street). The church of St. Leonard (BUAD 668M) was above the gate. The gate was removed in 1771 to make way for the creation of Clare Street.

Late Victorian (1888-91) municipal park, also known as Windmill Hill. Much of the original network of paths survive as does the original park lodge at the Somerset Terrace entrance. The park also contains a water-maze designed by Peter Milner in 1984 (2195M).

A smithy located in the area of what is now Elton Road, Redland. The smithy appears to have been constructed between the 1840s and the early 1880s, being first recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.12). It had been demolished by the beginning of the twentieth century, apparently to enable the construction of Elton Road. The site of the smithy now lies beneath the highway.

Moor Lodge, located on the southern side of Avonvale Road, St. Philips. The building was in existence by the time of the St. George tithe survey of 1842 (BRO EP/A/32/32; Parcel 264) when it was owned by Ann Frost and occupied by Henry Clark. The parcel was described by the apportionment as a house and land. The house survived into the early twentieth century but had been demolished by the First World War and the site redeveloped for a Mission Hall.

KNOWN_AS: House at Avonvale Road, St. Philips
MONUMENT_DESC: House, located on the southern side of Avonvale Road, St. Philips. The building was in existence by the time of the St. George tithe survey of 1842 (BRO EP/A/32/32; Parcel 265) when it was owned by Ann Frost but unoccupied. The parcel was described by the apportionment as a house and garden. The house survived into the early twentieth century but had been demolished by the First World War and the site redeveloped for a Mission Hall.

KNOWN_AS: Mission Hall, Avonvale Road, St. Philips
MONUMENT_DESC:
Mission Hall, located on the south side of Avonvale Road, St. Philip's. The hall was constructed in the early twentieth century and was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey third edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.13) published in 1918.
The building is extant.

Coldharbour Farm, located on the eastern side of Coldharbour Road, Redland. The farm is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.12) surveyed in 1881. By 1912 the site of the farm had been redeveloped for housing.

St. Aidan's Church on the western side of Cassey Bottom Lane. The church was constructed at the end of the nineteenth century and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.14) published in 1903. The site of the church was subsequently redeveloped for housing and now lies beneath the plot of No.10 Cassey Bottom Lane.

Broadway Farm, located on the western side of Wellington Hill West, Horfield. The farm is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.08) published in 1881. The farm survived into the twentieth century but the site was subsequently redeveloped for housing. The site of the farmhouse is now occupied by a garage.

Mount Zion Chapel located on the southern side of Whitehall Road. In 1866 William Walland gained permission to establish a Primitive Methodist church at Rose Green. The chapel was constructed from 1870 and opened in 1871. An extension was added in 1873 (Townsend 2003). The chapel survived into the twentieth century but was subsequently demolished.

KNOWN_AS: Hospital for Infectious Diseases, Ham Lane
MONUMENT_DESC:
Hospital for Infectious Diseases, located to the south-west of Ham Lane, Stapleton. The hospital was constructed around the end of the nineteenth century and was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1903. The hospital comprised a single long building measuring approximately 22 metres long by 6 metres wide and orientated from north-west to south-east. It was set in formal grounds, apparently screened by planting of deciduous and coniferous trees.
The hospital was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped. The site of the hospital now lies largely beneath the house and garden of Glen View, Ham Lane.

KNOWN_AS: WWII air raid shelter at Two Mile Hill Primary School
MONUMENT_DESC: A Second World War air raid shelter located in the main, northern, playground of Two Mile Hill Primary School, Kingswood. The shelter is believed to be a trench shelter.

National Filling Factory No.23, also known as H.M. Factory Chittening, located on the western side of Chittening Road. The factory was established by the Ministry of Munitions in October 1917 to manufacture the blister agent mustard gas (sulphur mustard - 1,1-thiobis(2-chloroethane)) in response to German use of the weapon in the early stages of the Third Battle of Ypres (Passchendaele) and Nobel's Explosives were instructed to construct a plant at the site to manufacture thiodiglycol, a mustard gas precursor, in December 1917. Progress with construction of the factory appears to have been slow and site clearance was still in progress when a strike stopped work throughout most of March 1918 (Haber 1986, 164). Construction of the mustard gas facility was abandoned in April 1918 and production moved to a new factory at Avonmouth (SMR 21403; located on the south side of Kingsweston Lane) which was constructed in May and June (National Archives MUN 4/1696; Haber 1986, 165; Hartcup 1988, 109). The Chittening factory was re-equipped for filling artillery shells and began to operate on 8 July 1918. Initially part of the site was given over to production of chloropicrin, a vomiting and lachrymatory agent in its own right, which is commonly mixed with mustard gas to raise its freezing point and hence its battlefield dispersal (Sidell et al 1997, 201). Later in July the plant started to produce mustard gas shells. However, manufacturing problems at the Avonmouth factory meant that the site worked at well below its capacity until September (Haber 1986, 191). The filling of mustard gas shells at the plant was extremely hazardous and 1213 gas injuries were reported at Chittening between 21 June and 7 December 1918 (Haber 1986, 249). To counter the extremely high sickness and absenteeism rates which resulted, the hours of work were reduced and an entitlement to a week's holiday for every 20 days worked introduced (Haber 1986, 251-252). However, the Treasury was still agreeing compensation payments for injured workers in 1920 (National Archives T 1/12456).
According to a plan dated 27 November 1918 (National Archives MUN 4/1753) the factory was served by a platform on the railway line to the south-west of the site and a road led to what may have been be a pair of gatehouses with time clocks a short distance to the west. There was a large canteen building to the south-west and the dirty change house and clean change house (both with associated detached lavatories) to the north-west. The site itself was arranged on a grid pattern. Isolated on the north-west side was the laboratory with stores, the engine shop, repair shop, laundry and boiler house to the south-east. The railway ran from the north past these buildings and south of the canteen to pass north-east around the core of the site. Inside the railway were large receiving sheds with small charging sheds on their south-east side. A small hospital building stood in isolation at the centre of the site and to the south-east of this were the assembly sheds. To the south-east again, adjacent to the railway line, were the dispatching sheds and box store. Army Ordnance Department (A.O.D.) and other store buildings and magazines stood between Greensplot Farm (SMR 9230) and Washingpool Farm (SMR 9232) to the east of the site. The general offices, a larger hospital, inspection offices and a garage lay away from the main site, to the south of Greensplot Farm.
It is not currently clear what area of the site was used specifically for the production of mustard gas and how much for other munitions. The postwar use of the site is unknown but all of the factory buildings appear to have remained standing into the 1930s (SMR 21401; Neale 1976, 227) and most were still extant at the end of the Second World War. Two brick air raid shelters were constructed on the southern side of the dirty change house, probably in the late 1930s.  The group of structures close to Chittening Warth had been demolished by the beginning of December 1946 (CPE/UK/1869 Frame 4015; SMR 21402) with the exception of the laundry buildings and the chimney of the boiler house. The general offices and surrounding buildings, including the hospital, and most of the A.O.D. stores were also extant.
An archaeological desk-based assessment of the site of the changing sheds was carried out in 2004 (SMR 21992; Bryant 2004) and the surviving historic buildings in the core of the filling factory, including the dirty and clean change houses, a dispatch shed and an assembly shed were subsequently archaeologically recorded  in advance of their demolition (SMR 22114; Davis 2004).
There are photographs of buildings within the factory in the SMR Collection of Ground-based photographs.

Kings Arms, Bristol Hill, Brislington, situated on the corner of Bristol Hill and Hollywood Road. The earliest reference to the building is on a map of 1791 (SMR 20561) depicting the properties of William Gore-Langton. The Brislington tithe survey of 1846, records John London as the owner with Orlando Tipton and John Hemans as the occupiers. In 1900, Mr. Slater is recorded as the landlord.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building no. 901-1/48/2109).

Blagdon Lodge, Bristol Hill, Brislington.  The house was originally known as "Ivy Lodge" and was the lodge to Grove House. In 1830, Richard Ricketts (of the family residing at Grove House) is recorded as living there. In 1843, John Cox, a tanner from Bristol, came to live there, and in the Brislington Tithe Survey of 1846 he is recorded as being the occupier with Henry Ricketts as the owner. There were a succession of tenants, including from 1880 to 1885 John and Caroline Brookman who ran a school on the premises. A long drive ran northwards from an entrance in Bristol Hill to the house, stable and yard. In 1904 Harold Almond set up the "Derry Hand Laundry" which was taken over in 1908 by James Galley and continued to be used as a laundry, until at least 1948 (SMR 20571). In 1959, it was sold by the Galley family to Mr. R. Verrecchia who converted the building into flats.

Conham Ferry, Brislington. The ferry appears to have been worked as a tidal ferry, at low tide the boats were moored sideways on to each other with planks leading to the banks, thus forming a floating bridge across the River Avon over  which travellers could travel. At high tide a boat was used to take travellers across the river. Some references refer to it as Bees Ferry. A path from Ironmould Lane to the ferry led across a field called Popes Ground which lay to the south of Eastwood Farm (SMR 3136)  The ferry is marked on the 1791 map and also the Brislington Tithe Survey of 1846.

KNOWN_AS: Obelisk on the south side of Cotham Park
MONUMENT_DESC:
Obelisk located on the southern side of the junction of Cotham Park and Cotham Road. The obelisk dates to the eighteenth-century and marked one side of the entrance to Cotham Lodge. It is of coursed, squared lias stone with elements of Pennant sandstone and vermiculated ashlar blocks. A lias rubble boundary wall runs south-west from the obelisk.
The obelisk has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/35/1165).

KNOWN_AS: Obelisk on the north side of Cotham Park
MONUMENT_DESC:
Obelisk located on the northern side of the junction of Cotham Park and Cotham Road. The obelisk dates to the eighteenth-century and marked one side of the entrance to Cotham Lodge. It is of coursed, squared lias stone with elements of Pennant sandstone and vermiculated ashlar blocks. A lias rubble boundary wall ran north-east from the obelisk. The original wall collapsed and was rebuilt in the late 1990s.
The obelisk has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/35/1165).

Cotham's Lodge, located some 130 metres to the north of Cotham Brow. The date of construction of the lodge is unknown but it was in existence by 1742 when it was recorded by Jean Rocque's map of Bristol. The building was an "L-haped" structure orientated south-west to north-east, with a rectangular formal garden (SMR 21906) on its north-eastern side. On the north-west side of this was an orchard (SMR 21907). The lodge was reached via an avenue of trees from Cotham Brow, the entrance of which was flanked by two extant stone obelisks (SMR 21896 & SMR 21897).
The lodge had been demolished by 1828 and a new house (SMR 21910) constructed immediately to its north-east, on the edge of the formal garden.

KNOWN_AS: Octavius Hunt Ltd. Match Factory, Dove Lane, Redfield
MONUMENT_DESC:
Octavius Hunt Ltd. Match Factory, located on the east side of Dove Lane, Redfield. The factory was established in the 1870s and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.20) surveyed in 1882. The factory was subsequently extended to the south.
The company was apparently acquired by Bryant and May in the 1920s and remained in its ownership into the 1960s. Sparklers made on the site from the 1930s.
In the later twentieth century the company developed the windproof match for the United Kingdom Ministry of Defence. It also manufactures hexamine (also known as methenamine, a compound produced by the reaction of ammonia and formaldehyde and invented in Murrhardt in Germany in 1932) solid fuel tablets currently (30/09/2005) issued by the British Army. The company also produces a range of smoke and fungicidal and pesticide products. By the end of the twentieth century Octavius Hunt Ltd. was the only remaining manufacturer of matches in the United Kingdom.

KNOWN_AS: Gabled house on the southern side of East Street, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC:
Gabled house of likely later seventeenth-century date, located on the southern side of East Street, Bedminster.
