The building was a single-bay, gabled structure with a pantile roof, which the similarities of form suggest was probably constructed as the western house of a terrace of three. A photograph of the early 1870s (Winstone 1966, pl.78) indicates that the ground-floor had a bay window on the eastern side with a single doorway to its west. A pantiled pentice roof divided ground- and first-floor and resting on this there was a central bay which continued up to second-floor level. There was a single sash window at both first- and second-floor and a pentice roof divided the two levels. The bay had a sloping pantile roof.
The building was occupied by Thomas Smith, pork butcher in 1871 but it had been demolished and the site redeveloped by 1883. The site of the building now lies beneath Nos.137 and 139 East Street.

An irregularly-shaped pond, close to Luck Well, on the northern side of Luckwell Lane, Bedminster. The pond seems to have first been recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition plan, Sheet LXXV.4.22 surveyed in 1883, but although its presence is not indicated by earlier maps the pond may have an earlier origin.

KNOWN_AS: Jettied house on the western side of the Royal Oak, East Street, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC:
Jettied house located on the southern side of East Street, Bedminster. The building was a rendered, jettied house of a single storey plus attic and was probably of late-medieval or sixteenth-century date. A photograph of the early 1870s (Winstone 1966, pl.78) indicates that the ground-floor level probably contained a shopfront at that date. There was a single sash window at the centre of the upper storey. The pantiled roof was steeply pitched.
The building was occupied by William Guest, ironmonger in 1871 but it had been demolished and the site redeveloped by 1883. The site of the building now lies largely beneath No.141 East Street.

No.31 West Street, located on the southern side of West Street, Bedminster. The building is a two-storey house with a double-pile plan. The date of construction is currently unknown but is of likely seventeenth- or eighteenth-century date. It is built of stone rubble and the main, north-west facing, and side, north-east facing, elevations are rendered with a sand-cement render. The main elevation is of three bays with a central doorway. On either side there are bay windows with canted sides. The rear, south-east facing, elevation is not rendered and is also of three bays although the fenestration was replaced during the twentieth century. The twin pitched roofs are pantiled and there are chimney stacks at either end of the ridge, with the exception of the south-eastern gable end. The garden to the rear of the house is enclosed by a high wall.

No.49 North Street, located on the southern side of North Street, Bedminster. The building is a rendered stone rubble structure of two-storey and attic with a gabled pantile roof and dates to the seventeenth century.

KNOWN_AS: Pound at Brook Farm, Whitchurch Lane
MONUMENT_DESC:
Pound located to the west of Brook Farm (SMR 21199), on the northern side of Whitchurch Lane, Bishopsworth. The building seems to have been in existence by the late eighteenth century and measured roughly 14.5 metres east-west by 5.5 metres north-south. It appears to have been a two-storey stone rubble building with a pitched roof (Bantock, 1996) and may have been constructed as a barn. However, an Ordnance Survey plan published in the 1950s records the structure as a pound. The building survived into the 1950s but was subsequently demolished.
The site of the building now lies largely beneath the entrance road to a warehouse on the west side of Cater Road.

Dundridge Farm, located some 50 metres to the west of modern Poplar Road, St. George. The farm was in existence by the time of the St. George tithe survey of 1842 (BRO EP/A/32/32) and was also recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXVI.02) published in 1889. Between the farm and the road there was a water course with a narrow pond at its northern end. The farm survived into the 1920s but was subsequently demolished and the site used as a sports ground.

Kensington House, Bath Road, Brislington.  The house was built in 1822 by John Brown. In the late 1840s, Brown sold the house to Richard Jenkins Poole-King, a merchant from Bristol, who lived there until his death in 1874. In 1935 it was acquired by St. Christopher's Church who used it as a club house. During World War II the house was used by the Territorial Army. It was subsequently used as business premises and was demolished in 1973. The present PDSA building occupies the site. The coach house and stables are extant.

The Church of St. Mary, Manor Road Fishponds. The church was built in 1821 and the chancel and north aisle were extended c1860. The church is constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble with limestone dressings, ashlar spire, and tiled roof. The church was extended on its northern side between the beginning of twentieth century and the First World War. Pevsner notes that inside the church is a painting of Christ at Emmaus of probable seventeenth-century date (Pevsner 1958, 454).
The church has a Grade II listing (Listed Building no. 901-1/54/1272).

St. Nicholas Churchyard, Baldwin Street. A small burial ground, triangular in plan, which was attached to the south side of St. Nicholas Church. The churchyard is recorded by Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 map. The churchyard was closed to burials by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852.
The site now lies beneath the highway.

Pithay gate. The gate stood on the Norman inner circuit town wall, at the top of the Pithay. The gate provided an exit from the medieval town to the left bank of the river Frome. Its function was apparently replaced by the Nether Pithay gate, sited at the foot of Pithay, when the second, outer, circuit of walls was built. It is mentioned by William Worcestre in the 1480s (Neale 2000, 170-171) but is not shown on Millerd's 1673 map of Bristol, suggesting that it had by been removed by that date.

Barbican and gatehouse at the western end of Bristol Castle. The exact location is uncertain, but may be below what was later the western end of Peter Street, although M. W. Ponsford locates it slightly further south, at the south-west corner of the Castle. The barbican is mentioned in deeds of properties immediately outside the Castle.

Frome Gate, a gate on the second town wall circuit by Frome Bridge. Frome Gate was a double gate, probably with one gate structure at either end of the bridge. William Worcestre describes it as "two gates with an iron chain, built upon an arch and two piers" and measured the distance between the gates as approximately 12.8 metres (Neale 2000, 70-71). In the sixteenth century the Bristol Corporation ran a knitting school for poor children in the room over the gate. It formed part of the defences of the city during the civil war of 1642-1646 when two cannon, recorded as sakers in 1643 (Roy 1975, 261), were sited there. During the trial of the Parliamentarian governor of Bristol for surrendering the city after it had been stormed it was reported that a new portcullis had been installed in the gate, and that when Royalist troops had reached the western bank of St. Augustine's Reach, "Maides and Women, in the face of the Enemy, made a Barracado and Bulwark against it 15 or sixteen foot thick with earth and sacks of Wooll, to keep them from entring there" (Prynne & Walker 1644, 64).

KNOWN_AS: Friary of the Friars of the Sack
MONUMENT_TYPE: Friary of friars of the sack
NARROW_TERM: Friary of friars of the sack
MONUMENT_DESC:
The friary of the Friars of the Sack, or Friars of the Penance of Jesus Christ. The friary was founded in or before 1266, and the is church mentioned in 1322. The house did not survive to the Dissolution.
Its site not now certain, but is thought to be at the bottom of Redcliff Mead Lane, just outside Temple Gate.

A circular dovecote, located to the south of the eastern end of the Abbey church, in the corner between the modern Anchor Road and Trinity Steps. The dovecote was recorded during groundworks associated with construction of an extension to Bristol Cathedral School (Boore, 1979 198-200; Webster, 1980 236).

KNOWN_AS: Burial ground at St. James Priory
POSTAL_ADDRESS: St. James Court, St. James Parade
MONUMENT_DESC: The monastic burial ground associated with St. James Priory. The burial ground was located to the east of the conventual buildings and around the east end of the priory church. Archaeological excavations have taken place within the cemetery on several occasions, the main excavations being in 1995 (BUAD 3155 and BUAD 3156).

Viell's great Tower. The tower was constructed in the medieval period and was possibly a terminal tower at the northern end of the Marsh Wall. The location of the tower has not been firmly established.

KNOWN_AS: Crane at southern end of Narrow Quay
MONUMENT_DESC: Crane located at the southern end of Narrow Quay. The crane was a fixed hydraulic crane set on an obelisk-shaped base. With a long lattice-work jib. A small cabin situated at the equivalent of second-floor level, with curved roof, and windows to at least its front and sides.

No.55, Wine Street, located on the south side of Wine Street. The building was a gabled house of three-storeys and attic. The main, north-facing, elevation had a two-window range and the entrance door was at the centre of the elevation. The ground floor formed a shop. At first-floor level there were two bay windows and at second floor a single central bay. The gable of the attic storey contained an oriel window.
The building was drawn by James Stewart in 1746 and was then occupied by a Mr. Joseph Partridge.

Quarry located on the eastern side of Effingham Road, St. Andrews. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.9.11) as an "Old Quarry", indicating that it was out of use by that date. The quarry was crescentic, running southwards from Effingham Road and measured approximately 30 metres wide and was around 120 metres long. The site was purchased by the Bristol Corporation in 1890 to create St. Andrew's Park (SMR 4243) and the quarry was infilled with material produced by the development of the surrounding estate (Lambert 2000, 50).

KNOWN_AS: Boot and Shoe Factory, Two Mile Hill Road, Kingswood
MONUMENT_DESC: Boot and Shoe Factory, located on the southern side of Two Mile Hill Road, Kingswood. The factory was built in the late-nineteenth century and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.15). The main factory building fronting on to Two Mile Hill Road appears to be extant.

Hidridge Common, a roughly triangular common originally with narrow extensions on the corners, but only that on the north side is now discernible. It was flanked on the north east and south but not the east by a number of small closes, these do not appear to have contained dwellings but are probably small intakes from the common.

The 1840 tithe of the parish of St. George depicts a series of small fields on dispersed closes, the general layout of which is recognisable today, such layouts are a common type of Medieval (and perhaps earlier) settlement in the area now covered by the county of Avon.

Bishopsworth. The village was established in the Saxon period and is recorded in the Domesday survey of 1086 as the land of Bishop Geoffrey of Coutances. The form of the settlement in the medieval period has not been firmly established but a Chapel dedicated to St. Peter (SMR 650) was founded apparently c.1189. This was presumably a chapel-of-ease to St. John at Bedminster and is likely to have been the focus of the settlement. The chapel was dissolved in the mid-sixteenth century when it was recorded by a survey of 1548-49.
The Bedminster tithe survey of 1841 indicates a group of dwellings in the area of the junction of Church Road and Whitchurch Road, with additional development to the north, along Romn Road.

Henbury Manor, located on the south side of Henbury Road. The building was constructed in the later seventeenth century and is of stone rubble. It became a school for boys in the nineteenth century and was extended at that time.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/17/1396).

KNOWN_AS: Surface air raid shelter at No.51 Wingfield Road, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC: A domestic surface air raid shelter located in the garden at the rear of No.51 Wingfield Road, Bedminster, approximately 20 metres to the south-west of the house. The shelter was constructed of brick with a reinforced concrete roof slab (M. Ashmead pers. comm.).

A war memorial arch located in the south-eastern corner of Greenbank Cemetery. The arch is a plain brick structure with a semi-circular headed arch and a pitched stone-tiled capping. There is a freestone block with a coat of arms carved into it above the arch and inscribed tablets on the eastern and western sides. That on the west carries the inscription "To the memory of those civilians who lost their lives in this city through enemy action in the world war of 1939-1945."

KNOWN_AS: Clifton Hill House, Lower Clifton Hill
MONUMENT_DESC:
Clifton Hill House, located on the south-eastern side of Lower Clifton Hill. The house was constructed on the site of an earlier dwelling between 1746 and 1750 for Paul Fisher, a Bristol merchant with strong connections to the slave trade. It was designed by Isaac Ware (Ison 1952, 177).
The house has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/780).

Goldney House, located on the southern side of Lower Clifton Hill. The building was constructed c1720 as a lodge or sunmmerhouse (ie a second residence) for the Goldney family.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/782).

KNOWN_AS: House to the north of Manor Road, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC: A house located some 240 metres to the north of Manor Road. The house is recorded by a plan in the Smyth estate records dated between c.1779 and 1783 (BRO AC/PL59). It appears to have been extant, though extended to the west by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882. The site is now beneath the buildings of College Court.

KNOWN_AS: St. Matthew's Church, Church Road, Redfield
MONUMENT_DESC: St. Matthew's Church, located on the south side of Church Road, Redfield. The church was in existence by the early 1880s and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.20) surveyed in 1882. The church had accommodation for 500 worshippers and was a vicarage.

Arno's Vale Cemetery, located on the south side of Bath Road. The western part of the site formed part of the estate of William Reeves, who owned the copper foundry at Crew's Hole, from 1740. Reeves built Arno's Court House (SMR 8467), the Bath House (SMR 20124), Black Castle (SMR 3498) and the gateway (Ison 1952). Elements of the designed landscape park survive (including some mature trees, boundary walls and the remains of a prospect mounds).
In 1837 an Act of Parliament (1 Vict. Cap.cxxi) was obtained, enabling the creation of a cemetery company, the Bristol General Cemetery Company, and setting out the rules for its operation and for interment. It was to function as a private cemetery and was laid out following 1834 designs by James Loudon (Harding & Lambert 1994, 109). The entrance lodges, Church of England mortuary chapel (SMR 20122) and Nonconformist mortuary chapel (SMR 20123) were designed by Charles Underwood, a local architect. The cemetery opened in 1839 and in 1850 it was reported that the cemetery then covered a little over twenty-seven acres, of which more than eight acres was consecrated ground (Clark 1850, 220-224). Part of the cemetery was used for the interment of the remains of "several hundred" victims of the cholera epidemic of 1849 (Clark 1850, 220-224). A number of major figures were also interred at Arno's Vale in the nineteenth century. The remains of Raja Ram Mohum Roy Bahadoor (1772-1833), an Indian reform campaigner who died in Bristol, were interred in a tomb designed by the artist William Prinsep (1794-1874) in 1843. The educational reformer Mary Carpenter (1807-1877)  and the founder of the Muller orphanages, George Muller (1805-1898), were also buried there.The cemetery was enlarged by permission of Acts of Parliament in 1880 (43 and 44 Vict. Ch.lxxix) and 1891 (54 Vict. Ch.xi) which allowed the purchase of land adjoining the southern side of the cemetery, creating an area of approximately 45 acres in total. A further act in 1926 (16 and 17 Geo.5 Ch.vi) permitted the construction of a crematorium and an associated chapel. This was constructed in 1928 and was one of the earlier crematoriums in the country.
The cemetery was sold in the 1960s and again in the 1970s, and maintenance of the cemetery was not kept up. The cemetery and its management company was acquired by Mr. Tony Towner, a barrister, in 1987. Despite the change in ownership the level of investment in maintenance continued to be inadequate. The Company operated the cemetery until 31 March 1998 when it closed the site. The closure decision caused local people, through the Association for the Preservation of Arnos Vale Cemetery (which became the Friends of Arno's Vale Cemetery in 1998), to take direct action in order to maintain access to the cemetery. On Thursday 21 May 1998 the MP for the Bristol East constituency, Ms Jean Corston, secured an adjournment debate on the subject of the cemetery and in July 1988 a march and demonstration through Bristol City Centre was organised by the Friends of Arno's Vale. Bristol City Council resolved to acquire the cemetery in June 2000. A charitable trust, the Arno's Vale Cemetery Preservation Trust, was established by the Friends of Arno's Vale. The cemetery was subject to compulsory purchase by Bristol City Council in early August 2003 and was immediately leased to the Arno's Vale Cemetery Preservation Trust (Cloke & Jones 2004) for a period of 125 years. Funding of £4.82 million was granted to the Trust by the Heritage Lottery Fund in mid-December 2005 to support a long-term conservation programme.
The entrance gates, lodges, chapels, war memorial (SMR 20119) and several of the individual monuments are Listed Buildings, notably the tomb of the Indian reformer Raja Ram Mohun Roy Bahadoor (SMR 20120) which has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building No.901-1/47/438). The early Victorian landscaped element of the cemetery is included in the English Heritage Register of Gardens of Historic Interest (Grade II).
Oldbury Court Estate
A C19 town garden laid out in 3 rectangular sections. Informal planting. {1}West Mall has probably the best C19 communal garden in Bristol. {1}Well maintained, with much recent restoration work. {1}
A fine early C19 communal town garden, with mature informal planting {1} A fine early C19 town garden. {1}Well maintained.
A rectangular C19 communal town garden {1} A typical C19 communal town garden. {1}Reasonably maintained. {1}
An elongated strip of C19 garden, informally planted, altered in late C19.{1} A garden of considerable landscape importance, a good expression {1} Well maintained {1}

St. Andrew's Park. Land at Montpelier was purchased by the Bristol Corporation in 1890 from Derham Brothers, boot manufacturers, who developed the surrounding housing estate. A quarry (SMR 21410) on the west side of the park was infilled and the park itself laid out to a design by the Corporation''s Surveyor C. F. Ball. The upper, northern, end of the park was designed as a space "where young people will be able to amuse themselves to their hearts' content upon the green sward" (Lambert 2000, 52) while the lower, southern, end was an ornamental pleasure ground. The park was opened in May 1895 (Lambert 2000, 50-53).

Redland Court Park. The park formed the setting of the house at Redland Court. The date of origin of the park is currently (23/03/2004) unknown but it is likely to have been in existence by at least the seventeenth-century. Whether any planting or earthwork features survive from this period Is not clear. The present building (SMR 3973) was constructed between 1732 and 1735 for John Cossins and the park appears to have been at least partly relandscaped at that date. The major features were an axial avenue of trees (SMR 21899) running 600 metres south-east from the house to a crenellated stone gate (SMR 21902) close to Cotham Brow. The park survived into the late 1820s but most of its area was developed for housing in the later-nineteenth century. A section of the tree avenue survive in Redland Park and Redland Grove, however.
A large, enclosed C19 communal garden, divided into two sections by a public right of way. {1} One of the largest of Bristol's C19 communal gardens. {1}Well maintained {1}

Canynge Square was laid out in the first half of the nineteenth century. The square contains some mature trees, the remains of a rockery at the southern end of the garden and a shrubbery is likely to have once surrounded the central area.

Troopershill Farm, located some 75 metres to the south of Summerhill Road. The farm was in existence by the time of the tithe survey of St. George of the mid-nineteenth century. It is also recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) surveyed in 1880-81. The farm house and outbuildings appear to be extant.

The Old Police Station, Bedminster. The building is located on the western side of Bedminster Parade and was built in 1882 to a design by Henry Crisp. The building is constructed in Pennant sandstone rubble with freestone ashlar dressings. Internally the cells survive.
The building has a Grade II listing (901-1/45/369).

Chapel, located on the south side of York Road, Bedminster. The chapel is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition plan surveyed in 1883 which indicates that it had seating for 750. The site has been redeveloped for housing and the footprint of the chapel now lies beneath Nos.1-7, 2-8 and 9-15 York Buildings.

Malthouse, located on the west side of Gordon Road, Montpelier. The building is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition plan surveyed in 1883 (sheet LXXII.13.2). It has been demolished and the site now lies partly beneath the site of the parking for Mary Carpenter Place and the filling station on the north side of Lower Ashley Road.

Malthouse, located on the western side of Stillhouse Lane. The malthouse was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.4.15) surveyed in 1883. The building had been demolished by the early 1960s for road widening at Bedminster Bridge.

Brewery, located on the east side of Bedminster Parade. The building was constructed between 1828 and 1883 when it was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.15). The building was demolished in the early  twentieth century to make way for a glueworks constructed in 1904 (La Trobe-Bateman, 1999 30). The site of the building now lies mainly beneath the highway.

KNOWN_AS: Toll Gate at Luckwell Road, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC: A toll gate across the end of Luckwell Lane at its junction with North Street, Bedminster. The gate was in existence by 1827 (BRO AC/PL 107/1) and is also recorded by the 1828 survey of Bristol by John Plumley and George Ashmead. This shows the gate schematically and there was an irregularly-shaped building, perhaps a toll house, adjoining its east side. The gate had been removed by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition plan of 1883 (Sheet LXXV.4.22).

KNOWN_AS: Statue of King William III, Queen Square
MONUMENT_DESC:
An equestrian statue of King William III as Roman emperor in triumph by the Belgian sculptor Michael Rysbrack (1694-1770), located at the centre of Queen Square (BUAD 307M). The statue was commissioned by the Bristol Corporation in 1731, after the buildings around the side of the square had been completed, to form the focal point of a proposed scheme of cross and diagonal gravel paths in the central green space. The commissioning of the statue was facilitated by John Elbridge (founder of a charity school at St. Michael's Hill (BUAD 933M)) and the Corporation ordered a payment of £500 to him on 25 August 1733. The following year the Society of Merchant Venturers paid Elbridge £300 towards the statue (Eustace 1982, 31-32).
Rysbrack produced the sculpture in his studio in London. The clay model for the statue was begun on 1 May 1733 (a small gilded model was also produced), and the statue had been cast in plaster by 1 August of that year. The brass casting was also executed in Rysbrack's studio and the statue was brought to Bristol by sea in July 1735. Despite the apparent success of the work, this appears to have been Rysbrack's only work in metal. On 25 September 1736 the mayor Lionel Lyde reported that the statue had been erected in the Square. However, an outstanding balance of £709 10s 3d remained to be paid. The Corporation undertook to pay £500 and the Society of Merchant Venturers contributed another £200 to Lyde "towards finishing King Williams statue" (quoted in Eustace 1982, 32-32).
The statue was set on a large ashlar pedestal of Portland stone with a moulded plinth and cornice and faced north, towards the Custom House. The works to landscape the square and lay out the gravel paths were then implemented (Hughes et al. 1996, 23). By 1749 the statue had apparently started to show faults and the Town Clerk was instructed to write to the sculptor to advise him of this. The Corporation ultimately resolved to carry out works "to repair the Defects in the s[ai]d statue at the Expence of this House" (quoted in Hughes et al. 1996, 24). At sometime between the rioting in the square in 1831 and 1880 the statue was enclosed with iron railings.
In the late 1930s the inner circuit road was pushed through the centre of Queen Square from Redcliffe Way.
After restoration work the statue was placed on a small traffic island in the middle of the carriageway facing towards the Centre (Winstone 1987, pls.91-92) and it remained in this position until it was replaced on its original alignment as part of a scheme to restore the square implemented in 1999 (Merritt 2002, 16). The opportunity was taken to make a photogrammetric survey of the statue (BUAD 3498) and carry out conservation work. Samples of the metal were also analysed, which established its composition an alloy of copper and zinc, ie brass (Merritt 200216-17). Observation of the groundworks associated with the reconstruction of the plinth (BUAD 3515) noted a group of numerals carved on its north face. The inscription consisted of a group of three characters "173" and another, unfinished, character, apparently a "4", suggesting that the plinth may have been pre-fabricated and was assembled in the square (Etheridge 2000).
The statue has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/16/220).

KNOWN_AS: Pond on the west side of Stoke Park Road South
MONUMENT_DESC: A pond to the west of Stoke Park Road South. The pond is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.11.15) surveyed in 1880.

A circular icehouse to the north of Stoke House. The structure was located some 100 metres to the north-west of Stoke Park House and on its northern side was a rectangular projection, probably the entrance. It is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition plan, Sheet LXXI.11.10 surveyed in 1880, which marks the the structure as "disused". The site of the icehouse now lies within the garden of No.18 Stoke Park Road.

No.60, Wine Street, located on the south side of Wine Street. The building was a jettied house of three storeys and attic with a cross-gabled roof which was of seventeenth century date. The main, north-facing, elevation had a two-window range with the entrance door at the centre of the elevation. The ground floor contained a shop while there were two bays at both first- and second-floors. There was a single attic window in the gable end.
The building was drawn by James Stewart in 1746 and was then occupied by a Mr. Stretton.

Bewell's Cross. A cross located in the vicinity of the modern junction of Cotham Hill, Cotham Road, Hampton Road and St. Michael's Hill The cross is recorded, as "Bewellescrosse", in the 1373 perambulation of the new County of Bristol (Harding 1930, 156-157) and is also noted by William Worcestre in his Itinerary of 1480 (Neale 2000, 86-87).

KNOWN_AS: Churchyard of SS. Philip and Jacob
MONUMENT_DESC:
The churchyard of SS. Philip and Jacob. The churchyard is bounded on the north side by Jacob Street, to the east by Church Alley, to the south by Narrow Plain and to the west by Tower Hill (formerly St. Philip's Lane). The churchyard is medieval in origin and was recorded in the 1373 perambulation of the new County of Bristol (Harding 1930, 162-163).
A drawing of the churchyard made by James Stewart in April 1748 indicates a considerable number of chest tombs on the north side of the church.
The churchyard was closed to burials by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852.
The surviving ledger stones have now been relaid around the church as paving.

The King's Orchard, part of the precinct of Bristol Castle. The orchard was located to the south of the Castle Ditch, roughly in the area bounded by modern Passage Street, Tower Hill and the river Avon. It was recorded by the 1373 perambulation of the County of Bristol (Harding 1930, 162-163). The perambulation mentions an orchard ditch on the west side of "Seint Phelip is lane" (now Tower Hill). The site appears still to have been open land at the time of Millerd's 1673 map, although this does show a mound of unknown function close to the western end of the Castle Ditch.

The Nether Gate. A gate at the eastern end of the eastern bailey of Bristol Castle, against Old Market. The gate was recorded by the 1373 perambulation of the County of Bristol (Harding 1930, 162-163).

The motte of Bristol Castle. The motte was located at the western end of the castle precinct. The height of the mound, the form of the tower at its summit and of the bailey ditch are only partly known. The motte ditch seems to have been slightly elliptical and was approximately 35 metres across. As excavated, the motte ditch was 5.5 metres across but it is unclear whether it was originally wider and deeper.
The motte was removed and the surrounding ditch infilled to allow construction of the keep from 1135, although the infilling may have been intially only partial since the "Motdych" was recorded in 1373 by the perambulation of the County of Bristol (Harding 1930, 162-163).
The motte ditch was archaeologically excavated in 1948 (BUAD 414) and 1989 (BUAD 459).

The Fish Market. Jean Rocque's 1742 map records the "Fish Market" standing at what is now the north-western corner of St. Stephens Street and at the back of 'The Keys Head'. The map shows a rectangular building within a larger demarcated, possibly fenced, area. The fish market is presumably alluded to in the name of "Fish Lane" by which St. Stephen's Street is marked on Millerd's 1673 map, suggesting that the presence of the market on this site was well established by the later seventeenth-century.

A slipway located on the east bank of the River Frome, a little to the north of the Drawbridge and on the outside of an area projecting into the river. The slip is recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol, and apparently also by the Plumley and Ashmead survey in 1828. Parts may survive beneath Colston Avenue.

A slipway located about 90 feet (28 metres) north of the Dial on Broad Quay, almost opposite the end of Little Tower Court. Broad. The slipway is shown by Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol as the same width as Dial Slip and it is one of a set of four slips shown by Plumley and Ashmead's survey in 1828, being then the northernmost but one. Parts may survive beneath the present Broad Quay.

Crane located on the Quay, opposite the western end of Thunderbolt Street. The crane was recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 plan of Bristol. It is noted as Crane No.1 on Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 map. A travelling crane was later positioned at about this point (O.S. 1:1250 plan, 1952).

KNOWN_AS: Pound on the southern side of Manor Road, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC: A pound located on the south side of Manor Road. The pound is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry to the south of Manor Road, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry located some 50 metres to the south of Manor Road. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882 and measured at that date approximately 28 metres from north to south and 28 metres from east to west. The plan indicates two working faces, on the north and the west sides. The quarry has been infilled and the site now lies largely beneath Nos.17-20 Pound Drive.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry between Manor Road and Small Lane, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry located between Manor Road and Small Lane. The quarry was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) surveyed in 1881 and at that time measured 57 metres from north to south and roughly 20 metres east-west. The working faces were on the east and west sides of the quarry. It has been infilled and the site now lied beneath the houses and gardens of Nos.1-5 Manor Road.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry on the south side of Small Lane, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry located on the south side of Small Lane. The quarry was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheets LXXII.06 and LXXII.10) surveyed in 1881 and at that time measured 75 metres from east to west and 35 metres north-south. The working face was on the south side of the quarry. It has been infilled and the site now lied beneath the houses and gardens of Nos.13-49 Small Lane.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry on the west side of the River Frome, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry located on the west side of the River Frome. The quarry was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882 and measured at that date approximately 75 metres from north to south and 165 metres from east to west. The plan indicates only a small active area 150 metres to the east of the river but suggests that the entire area to the west of this had formerly been part of the quarry but by then had been infilled. All of the quarry appears now to have been infilled.

KNOWN_AS: Probable quarry at the junction of Manor Road and Snowdon Road, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC: A probable disused water-filled quarry, or possible pond, located on the eastern side of the junction of Snowdon Road and Manor Road. The feature is recorded by the Stapleton tithe survey of 1839 and a similar feature, measuring 23 metres east-west by 34 metres north-south, was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheets LXXII.06 and LXXII.10) surveyed in 1881. The plan does not indicate the function of this feature and it had apparently been infilled by the time of the second edition plan in 1916. The site of the feature now lies largely beneath the triangle of land defined by the two arms of Snowdon Road and under the eastern part of the road itself.

Nos.283-303 Dowry Parade, located on the east side of Hotwells Road. The houses were built in 1763 and 1764 to a design by Thomas Paty. They were originally double-fronted, but were divided in 1790. Each is of three storeys with basement and dormer. The houses are constructed of red brick, with moulded stone coping, rusticated end pilasters, and keyed flat arches. The sashes are in exposed frames. Coupled plain doorways with cornice,  semi-circular heads, impost block, plinth, later doors. Pantile roof with two later dormers. Walled areas. The centre windows are blank behind sashes. Nos.265-9 and Nos.305-23 are also listed.

A mainly 18th-century farmhouse of 4 rooms arranged round a central entrance, brickend stacks, pantile roof. Recessed panel with carved lettering B R M 1782. Kitchen extension to rear, 19th-century addition to left, some 18th-century details survive. In poor condition at time of survey. {1}
19th-century public house. (1)

Quarry located on the south side of modern Frenchay Close. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882. The quarry is indicated to be approximately 58 metres from north to south and 18 metres from east to west.
The site of the quarry now lies beneath Nos.33-39 Frenchay Close.

The Cyder House, located 43 metres north-east of Broad Street. The building was constructed in the twelfth-century and was house with first floor hall. It was orientated from north-west to south-east (parallel to Broad Street) and the footprint of the building measured 13.3 metres from north-west to south-east and it was 7.1 metres wide. The building was constructed of Brandon Hill Grit and the walls were 1 metre thick at foundation level.

At lower level there was a V-shaped window embrasure in the end wall.

The foundations and end walls were constructed of Brandon Hill Grit, and exceeded 1 metre in thickness.

It appears that the south-west side wall had been rebuilt later in the medieval period.

A view of the exterior from the north-east was drawn by O'Neill in 1820 (BRSMG M2375) shows Cyder House Passage running below the first-floor hall, with, above the passage, a 2-light window with cinquefoil heads under an overall square head with drip moulding, the bottom of the window blocked off. To the north of the passage, against the north-west end of the Norman building, lay a later structure, perhaps of seventeenth-century date. It comprised 2 storeys and attic, 1 gable to each external elevation, its north-west end built against the rear of the Court House in Tailors Court. Both elevations jettied. Entrance, with porch, in north-east wall at first-floor, cross-window to left of it 3-light window in gable; small window to attic storey at right-hand end. South-east elevation not clearly illustrated, but probably with first-floor cross-window, and 3-light window to gable. Structure leading to porch not drawn in detail, but arch shown below it. Some detail of the rear and end of Court House.

Recorded internally by Rowbotham in 1828, with a view apparently towards the north-western end of the first-floor room or hall. This was open to the roof, one of at least 4, or possibly 5, bays; arch-braced trusses springing off corbels about two-thirds of the way up the side wall, the two corbels visible decorated with faces. Two tiers of plain windbraces; long, moulded, purlin or similar, above uppermost tier. Between 2nd. & 3rd. bays from south, as drawn, a partition to wall plate height, with a full-width carved beam above doorway height; 2 adjacent doorways, left to stairs down, right to stairs up. In first bay of north-east wall, window of at least 2 lights, cinquefoil heads, bottom of lights blocked. in next bay, a small square window above corbels. Floorboards running along length of building; to left, bottom of staircase with twisted newels at bottom.

Later, the building was in use as a tavern. It appears to have been the Lord Raglan tavern, gutted by fire in the early hours of Tuesday 4 January 1859. The Bristol Mercury newspaper for 8 January 1859 reported "At about a quarter past three o'clock on Tuesday morning a fire was discovered to have broken out in the Lord Raglan tavern, Cider-house passage, Broad-street." and that "The building being very old, and composed for the most part of wood, the fire spread with rapidity, and the part of the house used as a singing-room, and known as the Lord Raglan Concert-hall, together with the brew-house underneath, was soon wrapped in flames..." Such concert halls or rooms were the forerunners of the music hall.

The south-east gable end remained intact, as did part of the south-west wall until 1990. The house was demolished in early 1990. The north-west gable end survives incorporated into the rear wall of the late-seventeenth century Court House, and was drawn in about 1992. The V-shaped window embrasure at lower level has survived.

KNOWN_AS: Pond on the site of Nos.11 & 12 The Glen
MONUMENT_DESC:
A pond on the site of Nos.11 and 12 The Glen. The pond is recorded by the Westbury-on-Trym tithe map and lies immediately adjacent to a group of outbuildings on its eastern side.
The pond is shown by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1880 (Glos. LXXI.12.7) and is recorded as a rectangular pond measuring 19 metres long by 10 metres wide. It had a stone revetted access which was the full width of the southern end, and which sloped down to the water suggesting that the pond may have originally been used for watering cattle. It had apparently been incorporated into the garden of Redland Lodge, and was crossed by a bridge; the adjacent outbuildings also survived at this time, forming the eastern end of the garden.
The pond falls within the curtilages of Nos.10, 11 and 12 The Glen, being located beneath the northern edge of the house occupying No.10, and immediately beneath the house at No.11.

Grove Farm, Stockwood. The farm was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.12) published in 1884. The farm survived into the mid-1930s but was subsequently demolished. Its site now lies largely beneath Nos.85-95 Lacey Road.

Upper Stockwood Farm on the south side of modern Lacey Road. The farm was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.16) published in 1884. It had been demolished by 1903 and part of the site redeveloped.

Glebe Cottage, located on the southern side of Pembroke Road, Shirehampton. The cottage was in existence by 1772 and is recorded by a plan of the Southwell Estate by Isaac Taylor. It lay within a narrow strips of land fronting on to Pembroke Road and belonged to St. Mary's Chapel (SMR 21569). It was a two storey stone rubble building with a pitched pantile roof and was orientated at right-angles to the street frontage. The building measured 15 metres from north-east to sotuh-west and was six metres wide. The tithe survey for Shirehampton of 1840 suggests that an extension had apparently been added to the rear of the cottage by that date. The apportionment records that the cottage was then owned by Rev. Richard Carrow and occupied by James England. Glebe Cottage survived into the early 1960s but was subsequently demolished (Davenport & Lewcun, 2003). The site of the cottage now forms part of the car park and grass verge to the north of the Shirehampton health centre.

St. Mary's Chapel, located on the southern side of High Street. The chapel was a chapel of ease and was in existence by 1579. It was rebuilt in 1772 and in 1827. The early nineteenth-century building was destroeyd in a fire in 1927 and a larger church on a different alignment was constructed.

Elizabethan Cottage, High Street, Shirehampton. The building is a gabled house of 1 1/2 storeys with a pantile roof which probably dates to the seventeenth century. It is constructed of random stone rubble.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/18/1731).

Shirehampton Methodist Church, located on the western side of the junction of High Street and Penpole Avenue, Shirehampton. The chapel appears to have been built after 1840 and is of coursed Pennant sandstone with limestone ashlar dressings.
Park House, located on the western side Penpole Place, Shirehampton, The building is a two storey house of two bays with a pitched roof. There are chimneystacks at either end of the ridge.

Boskenna, located on the eastern side of Penpole Place, Shirehampton. The building is a three-storey, three-bay rendered house with a hipped pantile roof.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/18/1772).

Bethel Chapel, located on the northern side of Clouds Hill Road. The chapel was constructed in the mid-nineteenth century and is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) surveyed in 1880-81 which indicates that it was a Free Methodist chapel. The chapel building is extant.

Wesleyan Methodist chapel, located on the eastern side of the junction of Hudds Hill Road and Whiteway Road. The chapel was in existence by the time of the tithe survey of St. George of the 1840s and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) of 1880-81 as a Wesleyan Methodist chapel. By the beginning of the twentieth century the chapel had been demolished and the site redeveloped. The site of the chapel now lies beneath No.2 Hudds Hill Road.

Territorial Army Centre, located on the western side of Whiteladies Road. The site was established in the later nineteenth century and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.12) surveyed in 1883 an artillery drill ground. At that date there was a drill hall (SMR 21943) on the south side of the site and other ancillary buildings on its northern edge. At the north-west corner (ST 57716 73726 approx.) there was a semi-circular gun emplacement. In the early 1940s a new brick building was constructed at the west side of the site.

KNOWN_AS: Drill Hall, Territorial Army Centre, Whiteladies Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Drill Hall, located on the south side of the Territorial Army Centre, Whiteladies Road (SMR 21942). The drill hall was in existence by 1883 and is a two-storey structure with a pitched roof constructed of coursed Pennant sandstone rubble.

KNOWN_AS: Church of St. Gerard Majella, Talbot Road, Knowle
MONUMENT_DESC: Church of St. Gerard Majella, located on the north side of Talbot Road, Knowle. The church was constructed in the early-twentieth century and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey third edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXVI.05) published in 1916. The church is constructed of stone rubble and is a rectangular structure with a two-storey nave and chancel and single-storey north and south aisles. A Presbytery was added at the east end later in the twentieth century.

Westbury Court Farm, located some 70 metres to the west of High Street, Westbury-on-Trym. The farm was in existence by the time of the Westbury-on-Trym survey of 1841. It was still extant in 1916 but the farm buildings had been demolished and the site laid out for new housing development by 1936. The site of the farmhouse now lies on the north side of Westbury Court Road, some 20 metres to the east of its junction with Fraley Road.
Crane. On the Quay, opposite the end of Currant Street. Recorded by Rocque in 1742. Crane No.2 on Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 map.

KNOWN_AS: Crane at the south end of Narrow Quay
MONUMENT_DESC: Crane located at the southern end of the Quay, close to the confluence of the Rivers Frome and Avon. The crane is recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 plan of Bristol. It is recorded as Crane No.9 on Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 map. A drawing of 1747 (reproduced in Buchanan and Cossons (1970 38a)) shows it to have been of the "hut" type typical on the Bristol docksides, with a jib at one end and a crank handle on the right-hand side, slewing movement presumably being effected by use of the projecting pole at the rear.

The Mud Dock, or Old Mud Dock. Also known as the Great Dock. The dock was created in the eighteenth century and is recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol. On the western side was the Great Crane [BUAD 965M]. Squared Pennant Sandstone and granite coping. The quay walls and bollards are listed Grade II.

Hen Roost Slip, located at the northern end of Welsh Back, opposite the original Nos.1 to 4 Welsh Back. The slip lay parallel to the river. It was in existence by the time of James Millerd's 1673 map. A plan of 1803 (BRO 04479(5), fo.50)  indicates that the slip was known as "Hen Roost Slip" at that date.

Conduit Slip, located near the northern end of Welsh Back, opposite Nos.4 to 10 Welsh Back. A plan of 1803 (BRO 04479(5), fo.50) indicates that the slip was known as "Conduit Slip" at that date and identified as a "section ... to be infilled".

Bridgwater Slip, located on Welsh Back, opposite Crow Lane. The slipway was in existence by the later seventeenth century and is shown, unnamed, by James Millerd's maps of Bristol of 1670 and 1673. Jean Rocque's 1742 plan of the city shows it descending southwards to the water. The slipway is first named on an undated plan of probable late eighteenth-century date (BRO 04479(1), fo.28-29) as "Bridgewater Slip", and as "Bridge Water Slip" on a plan of 1783 (BRO 04779(2), fo.87b).

Back Ferry Slip on Welsh Back. The slipway was western terminal of the Back Ferry and Jean Rocque's 1742 plan shows it with what appear to be steps at its landward end. It still survives, beneath the northern end of O Shed.
The slipway has a Grade II listing, as part of the whole quay wall.

United Free Methodist Chapel, located on the northern side of Milk Street. The chapel was apparently constructed in the mid-nineteenth century. It was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.15) surveyed in 1883 which indicates that it could accommodate 620 worshippers. The chapel survived into the early twentieth century.

KNOWN_AS: Scottish Presbyterian Chapel, St. James Parade
POSTAL_ADDRESS: St. James' Court, St. James' Parade
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Scottish Presbyterian Chapel, St. James Parade. The chapel was constructed in the 1850s on the site of eighteenth-century properties on St. James Parade. It was in an Early English Gothic style and was constructed of stone in a rubble construction. 
The building was gutted by fire in 1940 as a result of enemy action and the site was redeveloped in the early 1960s for the National Farmers Union Mutual Insurance Offices. The tower and facade of the chapel were retained.
Parts of the chapel were excavated in 1988-89 and in 1995. Subsequent development of the site again retained the tower and facade of the chapel.
Mission Hall, Cannon Street. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale town plan surveyed in the early 1880s.
Malt house, Barton Street. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale town plan surveyed in the early 1880s.

KNOWN_AS: Boot and Shoe Manufactory, Barton Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Boot and Shoe Manufactory, Barton Street. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale town plan surveyed in the early 1880s.

Redland Lodge. The building was a large dwelling constructed sometime after the tithe survey of the 1840s, apparently on the site of an earlier dwelling. It is recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition plan of 1880 (Ordnance Survey Glos. LXXI.12.7) which shows the house set in extensive gardens which incorporate an earlier pond (SMR 20318) and outbuildings [SMR 20319] at their eastern boundary.
The site of the building now lies beneath Nos.18 and 19 Belvedere Road.

Redland Knoll, a substantial dwelling now apparently standing on the north side of Blenheim Road. The Ordnance Survey 1st edition plan of 1880 (Glos. LXXI.12.7) records a substantial house with gardens.

Wood Lodge, Penpole Lane. The lodge was built c.1750 as part of the Kingsweston estate and was possibly designed by Thomas Wright. It is a single storey structure with a pantile roof which was added c.1820. The building was drawn by Samuel Grimm in 1788 (British Library, Kaye Collection) in its original form.
The building is now a domestic dwelling and has a Grade II listing (Listed Building No.1758)

Blue Maids Orphanage, Ashley Hill. The orphanage was located in Ashley Manor House until it moved to a site on the east side of Ashley Hill in 1829. There was a house at the north edge of the grounds (ST 59838 74682) of a similar architectural style to the main building, and probably therefore built at the same time. The orphanage was sold at auction in November 1927, the cottage and the orphanage building being disposed of in two separate lots (Bristol Reference Library 12750).

Old Crow, Henbury. The building was an inn on the road to the Severn crossing. It was a single-storey structure of stone rubble of probable seventeenth century date with a pantile roof. There was a stone entrance porch with a pitched roof and on either side were small sash windows. Above were attic gables with two-light casements (Winstone 1985, pl.52). The building was still extant at the beginning of the twentieth century but has since been demolished.

No.59-61 Lower High Street, Shirehampton. A cottage of possible late seventeenth or eighteenth century date on the western side of the street. It is of two-storeys, the upper being an attic storey. Only the external walls now remain, the interior having been reworked and the roof replaced apparently in the late ninteenth century.
[Photographs of the interior and exterior of the building are held in the SMR collection of Ground-based Photographs, 509-512]
Lower Knowle Farm, Berrow Walk.

Brentry Farm, located on the south side of Charlton Road. The date of origin of the farm is not known but it was originally known as Pen Park Farm. The farm was in existence by the early 1840s and was recorded by the 1841 tithe survey of Westbury-on-Trym. The farm appears to have consisted of the farmhouse to the east and a yard enclosed by outbuildings on the west. An additional cottage, Brenty Farm Cottage (SMR 22326), was built approximately 400 metres to the south at the end of the nineteenth century.
By 1927 the owner was a Mr. H. L. Hardwicke (BRO EP/A/22/StSSM/1) but the site was sold to the Bristol Corporation in April of that year and the farm subsequently demolished to enable housing development.

KNOWN_AS: Air raid shelter at Gaunts Ham Park
MONUMENT_DESC:
Air raid shelter locted at the western end of Gaunt's Ham Park. The shelter is an underground tunnel shelter approximately 9 metres square and constructed of precast reinforced concrete slabs with a concrete bracing framework. There are escape hatches at the north-east and north-west corners of the shelter.
The shelter now lies beneath the tennis courts on the north side of Peter's Terrace.

KNOWN_AS: Air raid shelter at No.6 Sunnyside, Sneyd Park
MONUMENT_DESC: Air raid shelter located in the rear garden of No.6 Sunnyside, Sneyd Park. The shelter was a domestic surface shelter constructed of brick with a concrete roof and stood 9 metres to the south-east of the rear of the house. It was demolished between the summer of 1999 and January 2004. The concrete base for the shelter is extant.

KNOWN_AS: Burial Ground of Barton Regis Union Workshouse
MONUMENT_DESC: Burial Ground of the Barton Regis Union Workhouse. The cemetery lay a short distance to the south of the workhouse, on the north side of modern Greenbank View. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.9.25) surveyed in 1881 records a formal layout with paths running south-east to north-west between the rows of grave plots. The cemetery is currently (25/04/2002) an open green space.

Quarry located on the south side of modern Frenchay Close. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882. The quarry is roughly circular and measures approximately 15 metres in diameter.
The site of the quarry now lies largely beneath the gardens to the rear of Nos.25-27 Frenchay Close.
A small accommodation bridge in the embankment of the North Somerset Railway of 1873, close to the junction of the line at Cole Road with the Great Western Railway. (1)

20th-century rebuild of earlier licensed premises. Photograph in (1). Remains of earlier buildings may survive at the site as archaeological deposits. The earlier Bull Inn recorded on the 1:2500 OS plan of 1888 approximately 50m south of teh existing public house.

KNOWN_AS: United Methodist Chapel, Crew's Hole Road
MONUMENT_DESC: United Methodist Chapel, located on the eastern side of Crew's Hole Road. The chapel was built in 1853 and is a single-storey structure of rubble stone with a pitched pantile roof. An associated Sunday school stands on the north side of the building.
A group of short terraces of typical two-storey cottages of late 19th-century date.(1)
An early 19th-century inn, surviving in this form until the 1930s, but now converted to business premises. (1)

This building was constructed as a Wesleyan Methodist Chapel in 1860. It now forms part of Technigraphic Ltd (1991) and is part of an industrial complex (1). The shell of the building only survives, in reasonable condition.
Railway offices at Days Road, are shown on Lavar's map of 1867 (Falconer 1991).
Former goods shed, appearing on a map of 1867. (1)

Lock-keeper's House, located on the north side of Feeder Lock at the eastern end of the Feeder Canal. The building was constructed in c.1809 and is a two-storey, two-bay house constructed of coursed, squared Pennant sandstone with ashlar facings around the window openings. The windows are sashes. The main entrance is at the centre of the west-facing elevation. The building has a pitched slate roof with carved bargeboards. There is a central brick chimneystack on the north side of the roof. A cast-iron plaque fixed to the exterior carries the legend "BUILDING 1 / BRISTOL DOCKS".
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/43/1625).

Bridge carrying Marsh Lane over the Feeder Canal, comprising two separate riveted metal girder bridges between Pennant Sandstone abutments with sandstone copings and caps. {1} The present structure replaces an 19th-century the abutments of which survive. {2} Road bridge in good condition, maintained as Highway.

Lower Fishpond, located on the north-western side of Fishponds Road. The original function of the pond is not currently clear, and it may have been a fishpond or possibly a water-fileld quarry. However, it was in existence by the beginning of the seventeenth century and was recorded on a plan of Kingswood Forest made in 1610 as one of "the newe pooles." A plan by J. Sturge of 1781 (BRO AC/PL 90) indicates that the pond then measured approximately 100 metres from north-east to south-west and was 28 metres wide. It had apparently been infilled by the time of the Stapleton tithe survey of 1839.

KNOWN_AS: Great Western Colliery, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: Great Western Colliery. The colliery opened in 1847. The shaft was sunk to 591 feet (291 metres) although the deepest coal was found at 582 feet (178 metres). The mine closed in 1860 (Southway, 1971 21).

KNOWN_AS: South Wales Railway Tavern, Mina Road
MONUMENT_DESC: The South Wales Railway Tavern. The public house was in existence by 1881 when there was a range of outbuildings to the south-west of the main house, possibly a stable block and a well in the garden. The main building is still extant, though the outbuildings have been demolished, and still operates as a public house.

Smithy, located on the northern side of Pembroke Road. The smith was constructed in the later 1880s or 1890s and was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet Sheet LXXI.06) published in 1904. The smithy and the associated building are of stone rubble.

Withywood Farm, located some 150 metres to the east of modern Queen's Road, Bishopsworth. The farm appears to have been built in the 1830s and was in existence by the time of the Bedminster tithe survey of 1841 (BRO EP/A/32/8). It was still extant in the early 1930s but was demolished in c.1968 and the site redeveloped for housing. The site of the farm now lies largely beneath Nos.30-34 Gatehouse Avenue.

KNOWN_AS: United Free Methodist Chapel, Lower Ashley Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Salem Chapel, located on the northern side of Lower Ashley Road. The chapel was a United Free Methodist Chapel and was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.3) surveyed in 1881. The chapel could accommodate 240 worshippers and was surrounded by a burial ground. The building was still extant in 1918 but was subsequently demolished. The site of the chapel is now open ground.

Frome Lodge, located on the north side of Lower Ashley Road. The house appears to have been constructed after 1828 on the site of an earlier octagonal building, and was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.2) surveyed in 1883. It had been demolished by the beginning of the twentieth century and a Sunday School associated with a Methodist Chapel (SMR 21606) constructed on the site.

Tannery located on the south side of Lower Ashley Road and to the east of Pennywell Road. The tannery was constructed after 1828 and was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.2) surveyed in 1883. It survived into the early twentieth century but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped.

Bridge Farm located on the northern side of Glenfrome Road. The farm buildings appear to have been constructed in the late-seventeenth or early-eighteenth century and are of Pennant sandstone rubble. There is evidence for some alterations to the buildings in the nineteenth cenury.
The farm has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/33/1936).

KNOWN_AS: Church of St. Thomas, Fishponds Road, Easton
MONUMENT_DESC: Church of St. Thomas, located on the western side of Fishponds Road. The church was constructed at the end of the nineteenth century and was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.09) published in 1903. The church was then a roughly square structure set some 20 metres back from the street frontage, but by the time of the third edition plan published in 1918 an extension, possibly a larger nave, had been added to its south-eastern end. The building is extant.
New Brislington Bridge, crossing the river Avon above Netham Dam. The bridge is a bowstring concrete bridge constructed c.1930 to replace an earlier light steel structure of c.1900.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry to the north of Crew's Hole Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Quarry located some  75 metres to the north of Crew's Hole Road. The quarry was recorded Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) surveyed in 1880-81 and at that time it measured 120 metres from south-east to north-west and is approximately 55 metres wide.

Gasworks, located on the north side of Day's Road, St. Phillips. The gas works is recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map surveyed 1883 and by the 2nd edition map of 1902. In 1883 there was a single gasometer at the north end of the site but a second had been constructed by 1902 in the remaining space at the south end.
Only the Folly Lane boundary wall now survives. This has an integral pillbox (SMR 9930) dating to the Second World War.

The remains of a footbridge crossing the Cuckold's Pill railway of 1836 (the footbridge possibly later 19th-century). (1) Few remains of the footbridge abutment next to the disused Cuckolds Pill Line.
Congregational Chapel. The building was originally a Congregational Chapel, but was in use as a store by the end of 1963. The structure was a roofless ruin in 1991 (1).
School, Francis Place Court. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey 1st edition first edition 1:500-scale town plan surveyed in the early 1880s.

KNOWN_AS: Boot and Shoe Manufactory, King Square
MONUMENT_DESC: Boot and Shoe manufactory, King Square. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale town plan surveyed in the early 1880s. The building, at the south-west corner of the square, is extant and is in use as a factory.
Smithy, Earl Street. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale town plan surveyed in the early 1880s.
St. Matthias-on-the-Weir Churchyard.

The Merchants Hall at the corner of King Street and Marsh Street. The Society of Merchant Venturers was established by an Ordinance of the Bristol Corporation in 1467 and was confirmed by subsequent Royal charters. The site was acquired by the Society in the mid-sixteenth century after the Guild of Mariners which had founded a chantry chapel dedicated to St. Clement (BUAD 1206M) there. The chapel building was converted into use as the Society's meeting hall. A vignette in the border of James Millerd's 1673 plan of Bristol shows the hall in its original form, with the Society's coat of arms fixed to the wall above the main entrance door. The internal plan of the hall during the seventeenth century is not clear, but an inventory of its contents in December 1631 refers to the hall and inner rooms (McGrath 1952, 68-70).
In 1718 the Society resolved to create new rooms and land on the north side of the existing hall was purchased for an extension. In 1719 a new "Great Room " and a "Withdrawing Room" were completed. The Society expended a further £1000 in works to the building between 1720 and 1722, including an improved entrance, probably refronting of the King Street elevation and an extension on the north side. The architect Thomas Paty was employed in 1787 to remodel the exterior of the building, a process which seems to have taken a number of years. After Paty's redesign was completed, the building had six bays and two storeys. The lower storey had six casement windows with architrave surrounds. The upper storey had six tall sash windows, with the date "1701" between the heads of the third and fourth windows, and the cornice had six sunken panels. The parapet had square corner pillars. The centre of the west elevation steps forward slightly and like the south elevation, had rusticated quoins at the corners. The entrance was at first floor level and was reached by steps with decorative railings. This had a column on either side and a porch, and above the entrance was an arched niche containing a bust on a plinth. A low wall with railings surrounded the precinct. In the nineteenth century a number of internal alterations were made to the building to improve its facilities, including refurnishing in 1838, installation of a heating system - the "warm air apparatus" designed by a Mr H. C. Price - in 1842-1843 and a new decorative scheme designed by the architect Owen Jones (McGrath 1975, 269-270).
The hall was used for entertaining and events by other local organisations and groups on a number of occasions, notably on 10 June 1921 when Edward Prince of Wales (later Edward VIII) was made a Freeman of the Society of Merchant Venturers at a ceremony there.
The building was extensively damaged by bombing on 2 December 1940 and as a result the Society's furniture, plate and records were removed to secure storage. Air raids struck the hall again on 16 March 1941 and then on 14 May (Warne 1943, 20), this time causing irrecoverable damage to the remaining elements of the structure (McGrath 1975, 459-461). It remained derelict for several years after the war while the Society considered whether to rebuild the hall. Finally, in 1955, the site was sold and it was subsequently redeveloped.

KNOWN_AS: Seven Stars public house, Thomas Lane
POSTAL_ADDRESS: Seven Stars public house, Thomas Lane
MONUMENT_DESC:
Seven Stars public house, located on the south side of Thomas Lane. An inn known as the "Starrs" or the "Seven Stars," on or close to the site of the present building, appears to have existed in Thomas Lane by the 1670s. In 1671 an annuity of 30 shillings was granted to the Feoffees of St. Thomas by Richard Pope on the issues of the house known by the sign of the "Starrs," adjacent to St. Thomas Church. Of the annuity, 10 shillings was to be used for an annual sermon on the Sunday after All Saints Day and 20 shillings was to be distributed on the same day among poor parishioners who did not receive weekly alms.
The present building is believed to have been constructed in the second half of the eighteenth century and is a rendered building of two-storeys, attic and cellar with a pantile mansard roof. The main, north-west facing, elevation has a three-window range with the main entrance at the centre. It is not clear whether any earlier fabric survives within the building from any earlier structure.
In 1787 the anti-slavery campaigner Thomas Clarkson (1760-1846), in Bristol to collect evidence on the slave trade for the London-based Committee for Effecting the Abolition of the Slave Trade, met the then landlord of the Seven Stars, a Mr Thompson, who put him in contact with several sailors with experience of slaving voyages.
The building continued in use as a public house through the nineteenth century and by 1882 the landlord was James Clements.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/297).

Feeder Farm, located some 45 metres to the south of Feeder Canal. The farm was in existence by the time of the St. George tithe survey of 1842 (BRO EP/A/32/32) and was also recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.1.5) surveyed in 1882. The farm had been demolished by the time of the second edition plan published in 1904 and the site redeveloped.

Canal at St. Philip's Marsh. The canal was in existence by the time of the St. George tithe survey of 1842 (BRO EP/A/32/32) which indicates that it was cut right across St. Philip's Marsh to connect the Feeder Canal at its northern end to the River Avon at its southern. It is believed to have been constructed to divert river traffic around Netham Dam. The canal was orientated from north-east to south-west and had an entrance lock from the River Avon approximately 60 metres long at its southern end. The dock itself measured some 160 metres long by 30 metres wide. By 1882 when the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.1.5) was surveyed the dock was out of use. This plan does not record any dock walls and suggests that the dock itself may have been in the process of silting up. By 1904 the dock had been infilled and the site redeveloped for the Netham Constructional Steel Works (Lord & Southam 1983, 48).

KNOWN_AS: Vitriol Works on the eastern side of Avon Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Vitriol Works, located on the eastern side of Avon Street. The building appears to have been in existence at the time of Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 survey of Bristol. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.2) surveyed in 1883 also records the works which appears to have survived into the early twentieth century.

Signal Box on the south side of the main railway line to the east of Temple Meads station. The signal box was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.2) surveyed in 1883. The structure was extant in the early-twentieth century but appears to have been removed as part of the expansion of the line to the south.

KNOWN_AS: School at Freestone Road, St Philips
MONUMENT_DESC: School, located on the southern side of Freestone Road, St. Philip's Marsh. The school was constructed after 1828 but was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.2) surveyed in 1883. This plan records that the school was for both boys and girls. The school survived into the early-twentieth century but had been demolished and the site redeveloped by the mid-1960s.

Railway engine shed located some 190 metres to the north of Silverthorne Lane. The engine shed was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.3) surveyed in 1883 but it had been removed by 1903.

The medieval village of Brislington. Place-name evidence suggests that Bedminster was founded in the Late-Saxon period. The approximate extent of the medieval settlement can be seen on the 1840 tithe map of Brislington parish.

Two separate spans one of which replaces the deck of the 1809 bridge the other a separate structure, of a type of temporary bridge designed by the Royal Engineers during the Second World War (1939-1945) as temporary structures and the bridges presumably date to this period or shortly after.

Engine House, Ashleyvale Mill. The engine house is recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1881 (Sheet LXXII.9.12) and lay to the south of the main mill buildings and the map suggests that it had its own supply of water taken from the mill pond. The site of the engine house now lies mainly beneath Boiling Wells Lane although the southern element appears to lie on the site on the south side of the road.

Conduit Head, Mina Road. The Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1881 (Sheet LXXII.9.12) records a conduit head in the grounds of the South Wales Railway Tavern. It is not clear with what this structure is associated but the source of the Quay Pipe was close by. The conduit head has been demolished and its site is in the garden of The Farm public house. The preservation of the stratification associated with the conduit head may be expected to be good.

Cotham Gate, located across the highway of Cotham Brow. The gate was recorded by the 1828 survey of Bristol by John Plumley and George Ashmead which also indicates a possible toll house on the south-east side of the gate. The gate had been removed and the toll huose demolished by the early 1880s.

Toll house at Cotham Gate, located on the south-eastern side of Cotham Brow. The toll house was recorded by the 1828 survey of Bristol by John Plumley and George Ashmead. The gate had been removed and the toll house demolished by the early 1880s. The site of the house now lies beneath the footway on the south-eastern side of Cotham Brow and the garden of No.86 Cotham Brow.
No.8 Ambra Vale, located on the east side of Ambra Vale. The building was constructed in 1722.

Cotham Lodge, located some 130 metres to the north of Cotham Brow. The building was a rectangular structure measuring some 22 metres long from south-east to north-west by 12 metres wide. The date of construction is unknown but it was probably built in the late-eighteenth or early-nineteenth century as a replacement to an earlier house (SMR 21904) and stood on the south-western edge of the formal garden (SMR 21906) associated with it. The building is reported to have been demolished in 1846. Its site is now in the front garden of No.16 Cotham Grove.
A malthouse located on the north side of Stapleton Road. The building is shown by the first edition 1:2500-scale County Series Ordnance Survey plan of 1881 (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.9.24).

KNOWN_AS: Formal garden on the north-east side of Cotham's Lodge
MONUMENT_DESC: Formal garden located on the north-east side of Cotham's Lodge. The garden was rectangular, measuring 70 metres from south-west to north-east and was 38 metres wide. It was in existence by 1742 and was recorded by Jean Rocque's plan of Bristol of that year as comprising two contiguous square plots, probably walled. There was an axial path running through the centre of both, connecting them together. The north-eastern of these had a perimeter path with cross-paths from the middle of each side. All of the paths were lined with trees. The garden parcel was still extant in 1828 but No.16 Cotham Grove was built within it in the later-nineteenth century.

An orchard located to the north of Cotham's Lodge. The orchard was in existence by 1742 when it was recorded by Jean Rocque's plan of Bristol. It was rectangular and was orientated from south-east to north-west, measuring 75 metres south-east to north-west by approximately 50 metres wide. The orchard parcel was still extant in 1828 but Nos.18-28 Cotham Grove were built within it in the later-nineteenth century.

Katyn memorial, located in Clifton Park, some 17.5 metres to the west of the west door of the Roman Catholic Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul (Merritt 2002, 51). The memorial was erected in 1985 by Bristol's Polish community to commemorate the murder of around 5000 officers and NCOs of the Polish army and other Poles by the N.K.V.D. in April and May 1940, who were buried in mass graves at three sites in the Kaytn Forest near Smolensk.
The memorial consists of a roughly-hewn boulder of Cornish granite with bronze relief panels by the London-based artist A. P. Klecki fixed to its south-east face. The monument is set on a plinth of brick paviours and concrete measuring approximately 3.5 metres from south-west to north-east by 1.5 metres wide. Overall the memorial is roughly 1.5 metres high. The bronze panels bear a depiction of the the figure of the crucified Christ on the western side and an inscription on the eastern. The inscription reads:
"OFIAROM KATYNIA/1940/IINNYCH/MIEJSC KAZNI W Z.S.S.R./niech spoczywaja w pokjov wiecznym/TO THE MEMORY OF THOSE/MASSACRED IN KATYN 1940/may they rest in peace."
[Public Monument and Sculpture Association BR303].

No.25 Seymour Road, located on the northern side of Seymour Road, Bishopston. The building is a two-storey rendered house with a pitched pantile roof. The building is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.9.1) surveyed in 1881.

No.26, St. Augustine's Parade. C17, rebuilt C19 and C20. Timber-frame, render with a cross-gabled pantile roof. Double-depth plan. 3 storeys and attic; 2-window range. Mid C19 shop front has Tudor arches to plate-glass windows and a central doorway, on slender columns, and a cornice; shallow jetties to each floor above, and paired gables. Paired 9/9-pane sashes below jetties, and a 3-light casement to the attic, in exposed frames. The left return has a stone mullion window to the attic with lattice leaded lights. A large hanging 3-sided clock with elaborate wrought-iron brackets and decoration. Little evidence of timber-framing; the roof extends back one gable, and is a C20 ridged roof behind. Nos 26-30 are now internally one building. 
Cellared. Gutted internally in 1983, at which time a number of extra features were identified. There was evidence that early floors were at different levels to those associated with the 17th.century facade.
Some relieving arches were noted in the exterior walls.

No.71, Old Market Street, located on the southern side of Old Market Street. The building is a rendered single bay house of two storeys and attic and appears to have had a detached kitchen. It was constructed in the early-seventeenth century. The building has a double-depth plan and a basement with access steps down from the footway.
The main, north-west facing, elevation has a left-hand entrance with a rectangular overlight, and a full-width lean-to canopy on two moulded, curved brackets with Tudor roses on the sides, over paired plate-glass sashes; canted first- and second-storey bays have sashes, below a gable with scalloped barge-boards pierced with quatrefoils, side finials and a central pendant. The right-hand return has a six-panel door and side- and overlights beneath paired lintels each with 3-stepped voussoirs. An area at the front of the building is enclosed by wrought-iron railings with a 2-leaf gate in the middle and is paved with Pennant sandstone flags. At the rear the gable to an earlier, adjoining property is cut off short above the current building.
