The building has a butt-purlin gabled roof, apparently original, but this is pantiled only on the east side.
Internally there is a central winder stair with stick balusters and column newels; rear niche cupboard with curved shelves; front second-floor bolection-moulded fireplace and a rear cast-iron range with pointed-arched panels. On the first-floor landing there is a seventeenth-century panelled cupboard door with butterfly hinges, and in the southern room is a spice cupboard, as well as evidence for a former three-quarter height fireplace. There is a separate stair to the attic storey.
 In the mid-nineteenth century the building was owned by a Mrs Godwin, the mother of the architect E. W. Godwin, who lived on the rental income from the building (L. Lambourne Edward William Godwin (1833-1886): aesthetic polymath. In Soros 1999, 20). In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by William Smith & Sons, decorators.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/12/1655).

The building known as the "Guest House", located some 50 metres to the west of East Street, Bedminster. It was a three-bay house of at least two storeys with a steeply pitched roof. It was probably constructed of stone rubble and was of late-medieval or early post-medieval date. Hudd (1884-88) believed that the structure was part of the Hospital of St. Katherine (SMR 905).
The building was demolished in February 1887 and the site redeveloped for the W. H. & H. O. Wills Tobacco Factory (SMR 5494).

No.7 King Street, located on the south side of King Street. The house was constructed in 1665 as one of a pair with No.8 King Street (BUAD 12M). The building is a single-bay, jettied house with a gabled pantile roof. The main entrance is on the west side of the building and is reached by a set of four stone steps shaerd with No.8. On the east side of the doorway there is a pair of five by four pane sash windows. A pantiled pentice roof which runs the full width of Nos.7 and 8 divides the ground from the first floor. The fenestration at first floor consists of a single, central canted bay. A similar pentice divides the first and second, and the second and attic storeys, again with a canted bay at second floor. Above the small attic window there is a pantiled pentice across its width. The building was partly refenestrated in the eighteenth-century.
Restoration between 1967 and 1976, when it and No.8 formed the offices of Moxley, Jenner and Partners, architects, revealed the reuse of ship's timbers as structural elements within the building. Some laths were also found to be reused barrel staves.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/16/599).

KNOWN_AS: Methodist Chapel at Lower Ashley Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Methodist Chapel located on the norther side of Lower Ashley Road. The chapel was constructed on the site of Frome Lodge between the early 1880s and the eginning of the twentieth century. The chapel was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet Sheet LXXII.13) published in 1902. The chapel had an associated Sunday school to the east. It survived into the 1930s but was subsequently demolished.

KNOWN_AS: Duke of York public house, Jubilee Road
MONUMENT_DESC: The Duke of York public house, located to the north of Lower Ashley Road. The building was in existence by the time of the survey of Bristol by John Plumley and George Ashmead in 1828. The building is still in use as a public house.

KNOWN_AS: Medieval wood at Daventry Road, Knowle
MONUMENT_DESC: A wood to the north of Daventry Road, Knowle. The wood was in existence by the late-twelfth century and was recorded by the grant of the Redcliffe conduit by Robert de Berkeley to the Church of St. Mary Redcliffe. The wood appears at that date to have been split into the ownership of Robert de Berkeley and Robert le Werre (Hirst, 1924 359; 361). The source of the Redcliffe Pipe lay on the boundary between the two areas. The medieval extent of the wood is not known but a small area of woodland was still extant at the time of the Bedminster tithe survey of 1841.

No.2, Bellevue. The building is the southernmost of a terrace of nineteen houses. The plot, formerly part of the grounds associated with Clifton Hill House, was leased from the Society of Merchant Venturers by Harry Elderton in 1792 for a term of forty years (Ison 1952, 234). Construction of the terrace began under the supervision of William Paty (Priest 2003, 101) but was abandoned in 1793 when the outbreak of war caused a slump in development. The buildings remained uncompleted for nearly two decades but the terrace had apparently been completed by 1815.
The building is a rendered three-storey house with attic and basement. It has a slate mansard roof. A raised walk on the east side of the building extends the full length of the terrace.
In 1882 the building was occupied by J. Tremayne Lane.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/6).

Great Headley House, located some 110 metres to the west of Headley Lane. The building was in exstence by the time of the Bedminster tithe survey of 1841 (BRO EP/A/23/7). It was still extant in the early twentieth century but had apparently been divided into two dwellings by the First World War.
The building was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped for housing. The site of the house now lies in the garden to the north of No.15 Maytree Avenue.

KNOWN_AS: Church of St. Michael and All Angels, Bishopston
MONUMENT_DESC:
Church of St. Michael and All Angels, Bishopston, located on the east side of Gloucester Road. The construction fo the church was funded by William Gibbs, a merchant involved in the Peruvian guano trade who was resident at Tyntesfield in North Somerset and was influenced by the Oxford movement. It was opened in 1858 as a chapel of ease to Horfield parish church. It was consecrated on 28 February 1862 and that year became the parish church of Bishopston (taking elements of Horfield, Stapleton and St. Paul's parishes). The church was constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble with ashlar dressings and there was a tower with a steep spire at the east end. A new south aisle was constructed in the mid-1860s.
The building was declared structurally unsound in 1990 and it was demolished in 1997. The site was subsequently redeveloped for housing.

Unnamed Farm located some 60 metres to the south of Park Place, Eastville. The complex is recorded by the Stapleton tithe survey of 1839 (BRO EP/A/32/35). It survived into the early twentieth century but was subsequently demolished.
The site now lies largely beneath the gardens to the rear of Nos.19-29 Stonebrideg Park.
The Manor House, located on the northern side of High Street, Shirehampton. The building was a large house of two-storeys and attic with a cross-gabled roof. It was constructed of stone rubble.

Emmaus House, located on the eastern side of Hensmans Hill, Clifton. The building was in existence by the late seventeenth century. An extension had been added to the east side of the building and the north-east facing elevation refaced by 1707. In the early-eighteenth century the building was owned by James Hollidge. A further extension was added to the south-west side of the seventeenth-century element in c1750 and a further extension to the south side of the early eighteenth-century phase at the end of the eighteenth century.
A survey of the building was carried out by Roger Leech of Cultural Heritage Services in 2002 (SMR 21648).
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/14/873).

KNOWN_AS: War memorial, Churchyard of St. Mary the Virgin, Henbury
MONUMENT_DESC: War memorial located in the churchyard of St. Mary the Virgin, Henbury, close to the entrance to the churchyard from Church Close. The memorial was erected in 1920 to commemorate the parishioners of Henbury who were killed during the First World War (1914-1918). The memorial has a circular base approximately 4.4 metres in diameter with four concentric octagonal steps, standing approximately 1.5 metres high, surmounted by a stone Celtic cross.

Nos.1 & 2 Church Close, located on the western side of Church Close. The building is a rendered three-storey, three-bay house with a pitched pantile roof.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/17/1322).

KNOWN_AS: BBC Emergency Radio Studio, Clifton Rocks Railway
MONUMENT_DESC:
BBC Emergency Radio Studio constructed inside the tunnel of the Clifton Rocks Railway. The BBC sought an emergency studio at the beginning of the Second World War and one of the tunnels of the Bristol to Avonmouth Railway was initially considered. This did not become available and the Corporation leased the tunnel of the former Clifton Rocks funicular railway. The tunnel was made water and gas-tight, and extractor fans and an ozoneator were installed. Four chambers were constructed along the tunnel. The highest, around the mid-point of the tunnel, housed transmitters. Immediately below this was the studio. The recording room was below this and the lowest chamber was a the control room. Smaller rooms housed a canteen, diesel generators and water tanks (Penny 2001, 9-10).
Use of the tunnel as a studio appears to have ended in 1946 but the BBC continued to lease it for use as a local radio repeater station. In the mid-1950s structural failures were noted and in January 1958 it was recommended that a series of concrete buttresses be constructed to support the face of the tunnel. The BBC ended its lease in 1960 and the tunnel has remained vacant since then.
The medieval village of Shirehampton. The approximate extent of the medieval village can be seen on the 1840 tithe map of the tithing of Shirehampton, part of the parish of Westbury-on-Trym.
Horfield Common.
The medieval village of Stapleton. The approximate area of medieval settlement is shown on the Stapleton tithe map.

The early-medieval settlement of Westbury-on-Trym. Excavation at Westbury College in 1968 (SMR 20249) found evidence for Saxon settlement of the area. The approximate area of the medieval settlement is indicated by the Westbury-on-Trym tithe map.

The medieval settlement of Clifton. Place-name evidence suggests that the settlement may have been founded in the Saxon period. The medieval settlement was centered on the church (SMR 893). From the later seventeenth-century the village greatly expanded, particularly during the late eighteenth- and early nineteenth-century. Little if any of the medieval street pattern survives.

KNOWN_AS: Prefabricated housing at Fortfield Road, Hengrove
MONUMENT_DESC: Prefabricated housing at Fortfield Road, Hengrove. Prefabricated houses were constructed on the site after the end of the Second World War. The houses were demolished in the late 1970s (Boore, 1995).

Holy Trinity Church, located on the north side of Hotwell Road. The church was constructed in 1829 to a design by C. R. Cockerell and consecrated in 1830. The site was purchased for £800 and construction cost £10000, with the funds necessary being raised though public subscription. The building is of Bath stone ashlar with a slate roof. The original interior was by T. Burrough. The church could accommodate 1654 worshippers. The seating plan is held by Bristol Record Office (BRO EP/A/45/2 pp315-317). The church was damaged by bombing in 1941, being gutted, and the interior was completely rebuilt in 1957.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/14/1461).

KNOWN_AS: War memorial, St. Andrew's Church, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC:
War memorial on the south side of the remains of St. Andrew's Church, Clifton (ST 57389 72902). The memorial is a plain cross (the Cross of Sacrifice also known as the Great War Cross designed for the Imperial War Graves Commission by Sir Reginald Blomfield), which stands approximately 3 metres high, and is set on a octagonal base with three tiers. The monument carries the inscription ""TO THE GLORIOUS DEAD 1914-19" on its south-west face. The date "1939-45" has been added underneath. The memorial is discoloured by lichen growth.
[Public Monument and Sculpture Association reference number BR335]

Lower Pen Park, Southmead. The building is of at least eighteenth century date. It is recorded by a plan of the parish of Westbury-on-Trym by Sturges in 1817 (Northampton Record Office Plan 616) and was still extant in the mid 1930s according to the 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXVII.16) published in 1835 where it is named as "Pen Park". The plan shows a house, outbuildings and a large pond. The site of the house is now beneath Nos.21-25 Matford Close.

KNOWN_AS: Stapleton House, former Bishop's Palace, Bell Hill, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC:
Stapleton House, located some 70 metres to the south of Bell Hill, Stapleton. The house was constructed c.1725. In 1840 it became the residence of the Bishop of Bristol and Gloucester after the Bishop's Palace to the south of Bristol Cathedral was gutted by fire during the Bristol riots of 1831.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/33/1915).

Quarry, located on the southern side of Seymour Road. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.9.1) surveyed in 1881 as an "Old Quarry". The quarry had been infilled by the early twentieth century and the site was subsequently developed for housing. The site of the quarry now lies beneath the gardens of Nos.31-45 Muller Avenue and Nos.40-52 Seymour Road.

KNOWN_AS: Pound on the western side of Lower High Street, Shirehampton
MONUMENT_DESC: Pound located on the western side of Lower High Street, Shirehampton. The pound was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.06) published in 1883. The pound was sited immediately adjacent to the road and appears to have had an entrance on its south-west side. It measured 7 metres along its north-west to south-east side and was 6 metres wide. The pound appears to have fallen into disrepair by middle of the First World War and was subsequently removed. Its site now lies partly beneath the front gardens of Nos.23 and 25 Lower High Street and partly below the adjacent footway.

Arlington Villas Garden, built in the mid nineteenth century. The garden is rectangular in plan and bounded on three sides by private gardens of the properties fronting St Pauls Road and Pembroke Road. The north west side of the garden is formed by the road Arlington Villas. The garden is surrounded by mature trees and shrubs.

KNOWN_AS: Building approximately 125 metres to the south-east of West Town Lane, Brislington
MONUMENT_DESC:
A building located approximately 125 metres to the south-east of the junction of West Town Lane and Ellesmere Road, Brislington. The construction date of the building is unknown but it was in existence by the time of the Brislington tithe survey of 1846. This indicates that it stood immediately to the north of a large pond (SMR 3319), on an island of land between two watercourses leading from the north-east and north-west corners of the pond. The building had been demolished by the early 1880s. The function of the structure is not clear but it may have originated as a water mill.
The site of the building now lies in the gardens to the rear of Nos.2-4 West Town Grove.

Good example of a mid C19 town garden. Informally planted with mixed trees and shrubs. Occupies the site of an earlier Georgian garden. {1} A good example of a C19 town garden, retaining much of its original planting.{1} Well maintained.{1}
Small triangular C19 town garden with informal layout. {1} A typical C19 town garden. {1}Well maintained. {1}

The garden at Saville Place, Clifton. The garden was created in the early nineteenth century as a communal garden for the houses of Saville Place, and is a raised lawn with a stone retaining wall. The garden had been established by the 1828 when the plan of Bristol produced by Plumley and Ashmead recorded the garden as a circular area, approximately 35 metres in diameter, with a number of trees planted informally across the space (Avon Gardens Trust, 1991 22). By the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.16) published in 1885 the garden had been extended to the west, giving it its current ovoid shape and at least some of the trees from the original garden scheme may have been extant.

Brick works on Stapleton Road. The brick works is recorded by the first edition Ordnance Survey 1:500 plan of 1881 (Bristol sheet. LXXI.9.24) when it consisted of clay pits on the western side of the site with two kilns to the east.

KNOWN_AS: Pond south-east of Southmead Manor House
MONUMENT_DESC: A pond to the south-east of Southmead Manor House. The pond is shown on the 1841 tithe map and appears to survive until the mid-1920s from cartographic evidence. The pond lay with its longest side along Wellington Hill, being served by a small brook flowing from east to west. The pond gradually broadens towards the manor house and sluices control the water flow into the watercourse beyond. The pond had been given a much more regular shape than that shown on the tithe map by the 1880s. The linear nature of the pond suggests that pond may originally have been a millpond. The site of the pond is now partly beneath Southmead Road and the remainder has been built over.

KNOWN_AS: The Maltings, No.142 St. Andrew's Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Maltings, St. Andrews Road, Montpelier. The malthouse was built between 1873 and 1881. It remained in use as a maltings until 1971 and was converted to residential use in the mid-1990s. The building is constructed of Pennant Sandstone and at the time of a survey by RCHME, in early 1995, comprised "a single growing-floor range with two growing floors and a barley storage floor over". At the time of recording, the steep and kiln furnace had been removed, but the tiled drying floor remained in situ and there was evidence for a couching frame.
The building has a Grade II listing.

Police station, located on the west side of High Street, Westbury-on-Trym. The police station was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.08) published in 1881. The use of the building as a police station continued into the mid-1930s. The building is extant.

KNOWN_AS: Coal yard at East Street, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC: Coal yard, located on the northern side of East Street, Bedminster. The coal yard was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.19) surveyed in 1883. The yard was a large open area with buildings, presumably offices, on the East Street frontage. There was a weighing machine slightly to the south of the centre of the site. The coal yard was still extant at the beginning of the twentieth century but the site was redeveloped in 1911 and the Hippodrome theatre (SMR 21365) constructed in the western half.

Philip Street Baptist Chapel, located on the southern side of Philip Street, Bedminster. The chapel was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.4.20) surveyed in 1883 and this plan indicates that the chapel had accommodation for 650 people. The chapel is extant.

Temperance Hall, located on the northern side of East Street, Bedminster. The hall was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.4.15) surveyed in 1883 and survived into the early twentieth century. However, by 1918 the building had been demolished and the site was subsequently redeveloped for the Bedminster Library.

Free Library, located on the northern side of East Street, Bedminster. The library was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.4.15) surveyed in 1883 and it survived into the early twentieth century. By 1918, however, the building had been demolished and the site was subsequently redeveloped.

A cinema located on the northern side of East Street, Bedminster. Opened as the Picturedrome, also known as the Penny Pops, in 1911 with seating for 450 (Anderson 1983, 21). The cinema is recorded by the Ordnance Survey third edition County Series 1:2500-scale plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXV.4) published in 1918. The cinema closed in c.1919 (Anderson 1983, 21).

Bethesda Chapel, located on the western side of Herbert Street, Bedminster. The chapel is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.19) surveyed in 1883 which indicates that the chapel was a Primitive Methodist chapel with accommodation for 300 people. A sunday school stood on the south side of the chapel. The building was extant in 1918 but it was subsequently demolished. The site of the chapel is now at the eastern edge of the car park to the rear of Nos.68-82 East Street.

No.15, Orchard Street, located on the north-western side of Orchard Street and on the northern side of its junction with Orchard Avenue. The plot was leased to John Worsley on 22 July 1718 and the width of the building frontage was set at 50 feet (15.3 metres). The building was presumably constructed soon afterwards (Ison 1952, 152-156). The building is a three-storey house with a brick front.
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by a John Nutt and by Walter Davis, surgeon dentist.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/153).

KNOWN_AS: The Whistry or Pest House, Newfoundland Lane
MONUMENT_DESC: The Whistry. The building, also known as Earl's Mead Lodge and Newfoundland, lay on the south side of Newfoundland Lane. It was constructed in the seventeenth century, and among the owners of the house was the Harris family, Bristol brewers (Leech & Bryant 2000). It was first recorded by Millerd's 1673 map of Bristol. Jean Rocque's survey of the city in 1742 records the building as an L-shaped building, end-on to the lane which is named as the Pest House. The antiquarian Samuel Seyer, writing in the early-nineteenth century, wrote that "within memory", the house had stood separate from the other houses "as usual" (Seyer 1823, 305).

KNOWN_AS: Victoria Iron Works, Victoria Road, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: Victoria Iron Works, located on the east side of Victoria Road, St. Philip's Marsh. The foundry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.7) surveyed in 1883.

Sexton Cottage, located on the west side of Church Close. The building is a two-storey, three-bay house of stone rubble with a pitched pantile roof. The main, east-facing, elevation is rendered.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/17/1330).

KNOWN_AS: Mortuary chapel, Churchyard of St. Mary the Virgin, Henbury
MONUMENT_DESC:
Mortuary chapel located in the churchyard of St. Mary the Virgin. The building is a single-storey ashlar chapel with a steeply pitched slate roof. The building appears originally to have been of stone rubble and the south and west facing elevation were building were refronted in the mid- to late-nineteenth century.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/17/1325).

Vine House, located on the west side of Henbury Road. The building is a two-storey, five-bay house of coursed stone rubble with a pitched slate roof.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/17/1392).

Whitchurch Airport. A flying club was established on the site in 1927 and in 1929 the Bristol Corporation bought the site and built an apron and hanger. The airport opened in 1930 and by 1936 several more airport buildings had been constructed. The Air Transport Auxiliary moved to Whitchurch from Croydon in August 1939 and became the base for No.2 Pool ATA. A concrete runway was built and air defences put in place. The site closed in 1957.

Royal Hotel, Gloucester Road, Avonmouth located on the north-west side of Gloucester Road. The hotel was built in the late nineteenth century and is first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500-scale County Series plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.01) published in 1903.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/52/358).

Katherine Farm. A complex of farm buildings were recorded on the 1830 OS 1st edition 1:63360 map at this location.  They form a group with the farmstead SMR 9011. The two form a group similar to other known medieval farm settlements on the Avon levels. Many buildings of the farm still survive in 1992 (1). Buildings of the post-medieval period survive at the site, but the potential for surviving medieval deposits and structures is high.

Poplar Farm. A farmstead was recorded at this site in 1830 (1). The origins of the site are unclear, but it is potentially medieval. Buildings survive at the site, the farmhouse being entered for Listing but rejected in 1991. The site certainly contains structures and deposits of post-medieval date, and may contain some of medieval date too. In the event of planning applications relating to this site, it should be archaeologically evaluated prior to determination.

Cowley Farm, Avonmouth. A farm was depicted at this site in 1830 (Ordnance Survey 1st edition 1:63360).
It was still intact in 1946 (CPE/UK 1869 3015).
However, by 1982 it had been demolished and the site partially redeveloped.

Campbell's Farm. The farmhouse is of mid nineteenth-century date. Rubble with red brick dressings. 2 storeys and attic. 3 windows, casements. Central door with gabled porch. Pantile roof with 3 gabled dormers with bargeboards. The farm is probably earlier than the nineteenth-century in origin. A 1931 Ordnance Survey map shows the farm with one range of outbuildings to the south-west and another to the north.

KNOWN_AS: War memorial, Avon View Cemetery, Beaufort Road
MONUMENT_DESC: War memorial, located in Avon View Cemetery, on the east side of the road leading the chapel.

Worthy Farm. A property named "La Wrthie" is recorded in the Feet of Fines for 1241. The property was recorded by the tithe survey in 1841. It is shown by the 1915 Ordnance Survey map (Gloucestershire sheet LXVII.10) as a farmhouse and complex of farm buildings. The farm remained in existence until the construction of the industrial unit which currently occupies the site. An entrance gate for the farm is still extant on the east side of the disused railway running north from Severn Road. Elements of the farm may still survive immediately to the north of the plant currently standing on the site.

The 1915 OS plan of this area (Glos Sheet LXVII.10) depicts a building in a narrow enclosure alongside the road. It now lies under an industrial complex (1) Structures and deposits relating to this building may survive.

KNOWN_AS: Site of a building, north-east of Stup Pill Gout
MONUMENT_DESC: A building (possibly two adjoining dwellings) was depicted at this NGR in 1830 (Ordnance Survey 1:63360) and 1915 (Glos Sheet LXVII.10) Archaeological deposits relating to these buildings almost certainly survive.

Purdown Camp, located immediately to the south-west of the Anti-Aircraft Gun Site (SMR 4804). The camp consisted of a number of rectangular buildings aligned south-west to north-east, including a group of six linked buildings. These probably included the sleeping quarters, canteen, sickbay etc. for the battery. The camp survived until the late 1950s, being recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1:1250 plan (Sheets ST 6076 and ST 6176) published in 1959, but seems to have been demolished and the site levelled in the early 1960s when the radio repeater station was constructed. Archaeological evaluation (SMR 20970; Stevens 2001) suggested that the foundations of the camp buildings survive beneath parts of the radio station. Two buildings lay on the southern side of Sir John's Lane and these are unlikely to have been disturbed since their demolition.

Vincent Lodge, located on the southern side of Redland Hill. The earliest cartographic evidence for the building is Jacob de Wilstar's 1746 map of the the Manor of Clifton. The house was extant at that time although the surrounding garden was part of the Downs. The site was leased by Jacob Ricketts from 1805 (BRO AC/E/15) and included a garden in which Ricketts erected an obelisk commemorating Princess Charlotte of Wales and Saxe-Coburg (SMR 22545) and a statue. The eighteenth-century house was named as Vincent Lodge by the Westbury-on-Trym tithe survey of 1841 and it survived to be recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1:500-scale Town plan of 1885. Vincent Lodge was demolished and Queen Victoria House (SMR 21032) built on its site c.1885 (Leech 2000).

KNOWN_AS: Coal pit on the west side of Alcove Road, Fishponds
MONUMENT_DESC:
Coal pit, located on the south side of Fishponds Road, to the west of modern Alcobe Road. The date of origin of the pit is not known. It is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.10) surveyed in 1881 as "Old Coal Pit". A small spoil or slag heap is shown.
The site of the coal pit is now beneath 508-512 Fishponds Road.

Brickyard, located to the south of modern Fromeside Park. The brickyard is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.10) published in 1882. This shows a pair of parallel rectangular buildings 2 metres apart, the southern measuring 13 metres from south-west to north-east and 5 metres from south-east to north-west while the northern measured 10 metres by 3 metres. The plan, however, gives no indication of the functions of the building.
The site of the brickyard buildings is now largey beneath the rear garden of No.4 Fromeside Park.

KNOWN_AS: Rectangular enclosure adjacent to Salt Rhine
MONUMENT_DESC: A small square enclosure in field immediately to the south of Salt Rhine, enclosure set back from rhine edge.
Enclosure in the field to the south of Salt Rhine, abutting on to the rhine, depicted on an aerial photograph of 1946. There appears to be plough damage to the earthworks.
Enclosure to the east of Smoke Lane (now just north of the railway) 3 sides of a square (small) survive with another possible smaller square enclosure to the west.
Rectangular enclosure, lying on line of ridge and furrow in field to the north of Mere Bank Rhyne.<1>
King's Head Inn, located on the northern side of Whitehall Road, St. George. The inn appears to have been in existence by the time of the St. George tithe survey of 1842 (BRO EP/A/32/32).
Crooks Marsh Farm. The site of the farm is within South Gloucestershire.

KNOWN_AS: Anti-Aircraft Battery on the north side of Eastfield Road, Henleaze
MONUMENT_DESC:
A heavy anti-aircraft battery located on the north side of Eastfield Road, Henleaze. The battery was operational by June 1941 and was equipped with four 3in guns at that date. By June 1942 the battery had been re-equipped with four 3.7 inch guns and had GL Mark II radar by January 1943 (Dobinson 1996, 330). The early form of the battery has not been established but its final form is recorded by an air photograph taken in 1946 (CPE/UK/1869 3024) which shows six gun emplacements forming an arc around a central rectangular command post. The eastern four of these were semi-circular and the western two square.
The site has subsequently been developed for housing and the site of the central building lies beneath Home Ground. Some of the gun positions may survive in the grassed areas surrounding Cote Bank House and in the gardens of houses to the north of Home Ground.

KNOWN_AS: Bridge over Stup Pill rhine at Washingpool Lane
MONUMENT_DESC: Bridge over Stup Pill Rhine at Washingpool Lane. The bridge caries Washingpool Lane across Stup Pill Rhine at Red Spoltt Gout. It is built of stone and has later brick reinforcing of the arches. Th e parapet is modern. The site was visited by R. G. Jackson during the course of a desk-based assessment (SMR 20081) of areas of Bristol City Council owned land north of Avonmouth in December 1996. It was suggested that the bridge was of post-medieval date, possibly eighteenth-century, but was on an old trackway and may be earlier in date.

KNOWN_AS: House and garden at Red Splot Gout
MONUMENT_DESC:
A building of unknown function at Red Splott (or Reed Splat) Gout. The building was located (ST 53433 81280 approx.) in a triangular plot of land and was extant by c.1810 when it is shown on a survey of the area. It apparently remained in existence until the early twentieth-century, being recorded by the 1841 tithe survey as a "House & garden". It is also shown by the 1881 and 1915 Ordnance Survey maps.
The site (Area 1; Site 4) was visited by R. G. Jackson during the course of a desk-based assessment (SMR 20081) of areas of Bristol City Council owned land north of Avonmouth in December 1996. The plot was extant but overgrown; the building no longer stands. No traces of its foundations could be observed on site.

KNOWN_AS: House on the southern side of Severn Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
House on the western side of Severn Road, Chittening (ST 54139 81307). The building is recorded by the 1841 tithe survey (but not by Taylor's 1773 map of the area BRO 29351) and is shown on the Ordnance Survey maps of 1881 and 1915. There is now nothing of the structure standing above ground.
The site (Area 1; Site 7) was visited by R. G. Jackson during the course of a desk-based assessment (SMR 20081) of areas of Bristol City Council owned land north of Avonmouth in December 1996. No traces of the house could be seen but there were stone structures, including a possible water trough, on its site. the plot was overgrown by trees and shrubs.

Quarry located on the south side of modern Frenchay Close. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882. It measures approximately 30 metres from east to west and 30 metres from north to south.
The site of the quarry now lies largely beneath the gardens to the rear of Nos.6 and 7 Frenchay Close.

Forge located on the west side of modern Frenchay Close. The forge is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882 records. The building was rectangular and measured 6 metres from north to south and 4 metres from east to west. It appears to have been associated with a quarry some 30 metrs to the east (SMR 21042).
The site of the quarry now lies largely beneath the garden to the rear of Nos.57 Frenchay Close.

Coal pit, located on the western side of Forest Road. The date of origin of the pit is not known. It is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.10) surveyed in 1881 as "Old Coal Pit". A small spoil or slag heap is shown but there is no indication of the location of the pit itself.
The site of the coal pit is now beneath Nos.154-156 Forest Road.

West Town Farm, located on the western side of West Town Lane. The farm is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.12) published in 1884. The plan records several buildings but it is not currently clear what the functions of each were.
The site of the farm now lies beneath the grounds of West Town Lane Primary School.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry to the north of Frenchay Close
MONUMENT_DESC: Quarry located to the north of Frenchay Close. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882. The quarry measured approximately 24 metres from east to west and 32 metres from north to south.

Whiteshill Farm. The farm is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) surveyed in 1880-81. The farm and its outbuildings were still extant in 1918.
The site of the farm buildings now lies beneath No.26-30 Northfield Road and the open ground to the north-west.

The George, a corner public house, constructed around the core of an 1829 house. It is a central 2.5 storey building, with replaced 20th-century fenestration, rendered rubble and brick with coped small parapet, hipped gable pantile roof with modern dormer. There is a multiple flued brick stack at rear. A right angle wing at left, in rendered brick 20th-century windows on ground, pseudo-Georgian 19th-century windows 1st floor, gabled pantile roof. At right end, corner pub in 19th-century style in rendered brick, canted corner with door, one ground floor 20th-century window in each face, and one 19th-century window in each face (first floor). Small parapet, coped with string course and pantiled roof.
A road bridge running under the railway at Kingland Road.
A tall single-storey brick building at the northern end of the inter-war development of council houses, may have been a local transformer station. (1)
A 19th-century road bridge with Pennant Sandstone parapets. (1) Bridge maintained as highway.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry at Quarry Lane, Lawrence Weston
MONUMENT_DESC: Quarry located on the south side of the junction of Lawrence Weston Road and Quarry Lane. The quarry was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition plan published in 1881 (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.03).

KNOWN_AS: Wesleyan Methodist Chapel, Chapel Lane, Lawrence Weston
MONUMENT_DESC: Weslyan Methodist Chapel, located on the northern side of Chapel Lane, Lawrence Weston. The chapel appears to have been built in the late nineteenth- or early twentieth-century and is first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan published in 1903 (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.03). The site has been redeveloped for housing and the footprint of the chapel now lies partly beneath Nos.81-93 Orlebar Gardens.

A complex building, an off-licence in 1991. The core of the building is possibly C18. It consists of a twin-gabled wing, with a long wing at rightangles. Rubble and brick, rendered, with rendered brick stacks and pantile roofs. All windows and doors 19th-century or 20th-century. Garden surrounded by coursed Pennant Sandstone wall (1) (2). Probably a 18th-century core to the buildings.

A freestanding 19th-century public house with Victorian detail, and a fireplace reputedly from the demolished Tillys Court (Dr Day's Mansion) nearby {1}. While the facade and most of the section fronting the street are certainly 19th-century the core of the building is almost certainly of 18th-century date. {2} A building in this position is marked on Ashmead's map of 1828. {3}

Christ Church congregational chapel, located at the junction of modern Julian Road and Rockleaze Avenue. The building was constructed in 1877 to a design in an eclectic but predominantly Early English Gothic style by the architect Stuart Colman. The Ordnance Survey first edition plan, Sheet LXXI.11.15 surveyed in 1880 recorded that the building had seating for 300 worshippers.
The building was demolished in 1961 and the site redeveloped for housing.

Bishop's Palace, located at the south-western end of the Pro-Cathedral in Park Place. The palace was designed by Charles Francis Hansom in c1876 and was constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble with limestone ashlar dressings.
The building is currently derelict.

KNOWN_AS: Parish boundary marker stone at Nos.183-185 Whiteladies Road
MONUMENT_DESC: A parish boundary marker stone fixed to the party wall of Nos.183-185 Whiteladies Road, Clifton. The marker is of freestone, and measures approximately 15 centimetres square and bears the legend "W P / 1848". The marker stone is approximately 1.2 metres above the ground.

Victoria Chapel, located on the western side of Queen's Road. The building was a Wesleyan Methodist chapel constructed in 1863 to a design in a French Gothic Revival Style by the architectural practice Foster and Wood. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.13) records that the chapel cuold accommodate 700 worshippers.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/9/1135).

Green Splott Cottages, located at Chittening Warth. The buildings appear to have been in existence by 1830 and the 1915 Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire sheet LXVII.10), indicates that there were by that date at least two dwellings, with a further building in an orchard to the south-east. The cottages were apparently demolished to enable the construction of National Filling Factory No.23 (SMR 21403) in 1917.

Hemplow House. The site was purchased in c1680 by Sir John Hawkins from Arthur Sanders and a house was built on the site. Around 1800, Joan Hawkins, widow of John Hawkins, is recorded as selling Hemplow House to a Mr. Prescott upon her purchase of Gotley Lodge. It was subsequently sold to Edward Rollo Clayfield who had also purchased the adjoining estate of Gotley Lodge. In 1828, Edward Ireland Clayfield was recorded as the owner of both Hemplow House and Gotley Lodge. The Brislington Tithe Award of 1846 records Edward Ireland Clayfield as the owner with Daniel Tripp as the tenant. Upon the death of Clayfield's widow in 1865, the property passed to Thomas Priaulx Clayfield Ireland who sold it to Charles Gardiner, a wealthy Bristol clothier. In 1899, the property was sold to James Wise and remained in the Wise family until 1936 when it was purchased by Bristol Corporation. In 1939, the house was requisitioned as a base for the civil defence of Brislington. After the war the house was used as an ambulance and fire station. It was demolished in the late 1960s.
The site of the house and gardens is now occupied by the houses of Hawburn Close and Beeches Grove.

KNOWN_AS: Parish boundary marker stone at No.94 Cotham Brow
MONUMENT_DESC: On 4th March 2001 Jonathan Brett of the Department of Environment, Transport and Leisure, Bristol City Council observed a parish boundary marker stone set in the footway immediately in front of the boundary wall of No.1 Cotham Side. The stone was of Pennant sandstone and stood to a height of approximately 25 centimetres. Any carved inscription on the stone would appear to have been lost.

A quarry at the junction of Charlton Road and Knole Lane. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.04) published in 1881. In the twentieth century Nos.192-194 Knole Lane were constructed on the site of the quarry.

A quarry on the south side of Charlton Road, close to the junction with Knole Lane. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.04) published in 1881. The site of the quarry is now part of a larger area of open ground.

A quarry on the south side of Charlton Road, close to the junction with Knole Lane. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.04) published in 1881. The site of the quarry is now largely beneath Nos.8-12 Standon Avenue.

A quarry on the west side of Brentry Hill, to the north of the junction with Charlton Road. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.04) published in 1881 and may have been in existence at the time of the Westbury-on-Trym tithe survey of 1841 since the apportionment records that the land parcel within which the quarry lay (Parcel 837a) was "Quarries and land adjoining" belonging to the Commissioners of Bristol Turnpike Roads.

A quarry on the west side of Brentry Hill, to the north of the junction with Charlton Road. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.04) published in 1881 and may have been in existence at the time of the Westbury-on-Trym tithe survey of 1841 since the apportionment records that the land parcel within which the quarry lay (Parcel 837a) was "Quarries and land adjoining" belonging to the Commissioners of Bristol Turnpike Roads.

A quarry on the west side of Brentry Hill, to the north of the junction with Charlton Road. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.04) published in 1881 and may have been in existence at the time of the Westbury-on-Trym tithe survey of 1841 since the apportionment records that the land parcel within which the quarry lay (837a) was "Quarries and land adjoining" belonging to the Commissioners of Bristol Turnpike Roads.

A quarry on the west side of Shetland Road, Southmead. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.04) published in 1881. The site of the quarry is now beneath Nos.33-35 Shetland Road.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry on the north side of Troopers Hill Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Quarry located on the north side of Troopers Hill Road. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) surveyed in 1880-81 where it is named "Old Quarry", suggesting that it was by then out of use. At that date the quarry measured approximately 30 metres from east to west.

KNOWN_AS: Rookery Farm or Manor Farm, West Town Lane, Brislington
MONUMENT_DESC: Rookery Farm, Brislington. The farm lay on the east side of West Town Lane and appears to have comprised a main farmhouse with outbuildings to the north. The date of origin of the farm is not currently known but it was recorded (as Parcel 685) by the Brislington tithe survey of 1846 (BRO EP/A/32/9). The owner of the site was John Hurle, linen merchant, of Clifton and on 16 November 1850 (BRO 37870(5)) Hurle leased the farm to Thomas Kelson Bush, yeoman, of Queen Charlton for £400 per annum. The farm was renamed Manor Farm at the end of the nineteenth century and was first recorded under its new name by the second edition Ordnance Survey County Series plan published in 1904. The farm was demolished in c.1933 and a number of sports pitches had been set out across the site by 1947 (Clark & Thomas 2007).

Court Farm. The farm lay to the south of the Whitchurch Lane and comprised a farmhouse with outbuildings to the east and north. There were orchards to the south. The farmhouse appears to have been constructed in the seventeenth century and was a gabled stone rubble building of two storeys (Winstone 1977, pl.202).
The site of the farmhouse appears to lie beneath the gardens of dwellings on the south side of Woodmarsh Close while the outbuildings to the east are beneath the grassed open space.

Hill Farm. The farm lies to the east of the end of Lampton Avenue, Hartcliffe. It is still in existence and comprises a farmhouse and outbuildings, many of which have been erected since the late 1930s.
Bridge Farm, located on the east side of East Dundry Road. The farmhouse is a two-storey stone rubble building with a double pile plan and a pitched pantile roof.

KNOWN_AS: Eastville Park Methodist Church, Fishponds Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Eastville Park Methodist Church, Fishponds Road.

KNOWN_AS: Meerstone at Westbury Road, Durdham Down
MONUMENT_DESC: Meerstone on the east side of Westbury Road, Henleaze. The stone stands approximately one metre high and is inscribed. The upper part of the surface of the stone has delaminated, removing part of the inscription but the word "parish" is legible. The stone also carries an Ordnance Survey benchmark.

KNOWN_AS: Little Horfylde or Hethe House, Purdown
MONUMENT_DESC:
Little Horfylde or Hethe House, located on the north-eastern side of Sir John's Lane, Purdown. The building was the manor house for the Little Horfylde or Heath House estate and was in existence by 1425 (Upton Way 1912, 19-22). The estate belonged to the Hospital of St. Bartholomew in Bristol and was leased out by the hospital. The house was sited some 22 metres to the north-east of Sir John's Lane and measured some 35 metres from north-west to south-east and was 8 metres wide. The form of the building is currently unknown.
The building survived into the later eighteenth century and its location was recorded by an estate plan of 1767 (BRO AC/PL 88). A new house, the present Heath House (SMR 5876) was constructed in 1784 and, although it appears to have survived for some years, the original house was later demolished. The site of the house is now an area of car parking to the north-west of Heath House.

KNOWN_AS: Clay pit at the Malago Vale Brickworks
MONUMENT_DESC: Clay pit at the Malago Vale Brickworks. The pit was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.08.03) surveyed in 1883. It had been partly infilled by the middle of the First World War.

Candle factory located on the western side of Albert Road [modern Sheene Road]. The factory was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.04.24) surveyed in 1883. It was still operating in the early twentieth century but was subsequently demolished.

KNOWN_AS: Malago Vale Brick and Tile Works, Albert Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Malago Vale Brick and Tile Works, located on the eastern side of Albert Road [modern Sheene Road]. The works was in existence at the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.04.24) surveyed in 1883 but the site had apparently been demolished by the beginning of the twentieth century.

Tarpaulin Factory located on the western side of Albert Road [modern Sheene Road]. The factory was in existence at the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.04.24) surveyed in 1883. The building was still extant in the early twentieth century but was subsequently demolished.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry on the west side of Crew's Hole Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
Quarry located on the west side of Crew's Hole Road. The quarry was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) surveyed in 1880-81 and then measured approximately 30 metres from north to south. The entrance was off Crew's Hole Road.
The quarry site is extant and the dwelling called Little Haven now stands within it.

KNOWN_AS: Chemical works on the west side of Crews Hole Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
Chemical works, located on the west side of Crew's Hole Road. The works was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) surveyed in 1880-81. This indicates that the buildings of the works were grouped together on the bank of the River Avon on the west side of the site but gives no detailed indication of their functions.
The site of the works now lies largely beneath the Butlers Walk development.

KNOWN_AS: Crown Works on the west side of Crews Hole Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
Crown Works, a brick and tile works located on the west side of Crew's Hole Road. The works is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) surveyed in 1880-81. At that date two buildings stood on the Crew's Hole Road frontage but most of the structures of the works occupied the western half of the site. There is no indication that brickearth was dug on the site itself.
Most of the site of the brickworks now lies beneath the Butler's Close.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry on the north side of Cassey Bottom Lane
MONUMENT_DESC:
A quarry located on the north side of Cassey Bottom Lane. The quarry was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) surveyed in 1880-81 as an "Old Quarry", indicating that it had gone out of use by that date. At that time the quarry measured approximately 75 metres from north-west to south-east and was 27 metres wide. The working face appears to have been at the south-western end and the entrance was off Troopers Hill Road.
The quarry has now been infilled and lies beneath Nos.1-9 Cassey Bottom Lane.

KNOWN_AS: Pond to the north west of the South Wales Railway Tavern, Mina Road
MONUMENT_DESC: A small pond to the north west of the South Wales Railway Tavern which was recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1881 (Sheet LXXII.9.12). The function and date of the pond is unknown.

The British School, located on the southern side of British Road, Bedminster was built in 1846 by the local Methodist congregation and was enlarged in 1855 by the addition of a first floor designed by Henry Crisp. In 1867 an infant school was added, occupying the site to the west. A new Board School was built in South Street in 1895 making the British School redundant. The building was sold to E. S. & A. Robinson in 1898 and passed through a number of commercial uses. It was listed Grade II but stood empty for several years before it was gutted by fire in 1997. The shell of the building was demolished in July 1998 as a dangerous structure without any record of the building being made (Insole 1998).

KNOWN_AS: Site of a building on the north side of Penpole Wood
MONUMENT_DESC: Building on the north side of Penpole Wood. The building is recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1:2500 map of 1949 (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.06) when it was marked as "ruin". The site of the L-shaped building, which measured roughly 15 metres by 6 metres, was approximately 100 metres south-east of No.10 Nigel Park. Its current condition is unknown.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry at the east end of Penpole Wood
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry at the western end of Penpole Wood and lies on the south side of Penpole Lane. The quarry, marked as "Old Quarry", was recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1:2500 map of 1949 (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.06) and is the eastern of a group of three. It measures roughly 50 metres in diameter.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry at the east end of Penpole Wood
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry at the western end of Penpole Wood. The quarry is at the centre of a group of three and lies on the south side of Penpole Lane. The Ordnance Survey 1:2500 map of 1949 (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.06) shows several buildings within the quarry but it is not known whether or not they are associated with its working.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry at the east end of Penpole Wood
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry at the western end of Penpole Wood. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1:2500 map of 1881 (Glucestershire Sheet LXXI.06). It lies at the western end of a group of three and lies on the south side of Penpole Lane.

Quarry located some 30 metres to the south of modern Doncaster Road. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet Sheet LXXI.04) published in 1881 which described it as an "Old Quarry". The quarry measured 13 metres from north-west to south-east by 7 metres wide and was still extant in the early twentieth century. The quarry was subsequently infilled.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry 130 metres south of Doncaster Road, Southmead
MONUMENT_DESC: Quarry located some 130 metres to the south of modern Doncaster Road. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet Sheet LXXI.04) published in 1881 which described it as an "Old Quarry". The quarry measured 29 metres from north to south by 25 metres wide and was still extant in the early twentieth century. The quarry was subsequently infilled.

KNOWN_AS: Engine Shed and Workshops on the west side of the River Avon
MONUMENT_DESC: Engine Shed and Workshops, located on the west side of the River Avon, to the south of Temple Meads station. The engine shed was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.12) surveyed in 1883 which shows a complex of large buildings including an engine shed and workshops on its southern side. The shed is attached to a smaller engine shed (SMR 21081) on its north-west facing side.

KNOWN_AS: Marsh Foundry, Victoria Road, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: Marsh Foundry, an iron foundry located on the eastern side of Victoria Road, St. Philip's Marsh. The foundry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.7) surveyed in 1883 which shows the foundry as a complex of buildings arranged around a yard. The entrance to the site was off Victoria Road.

Stone Yard, located on the south side of Feeder Road, St. Philip's Marsh. The stone yard is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.7) surveyed in 1883 as a walled enclosure with small buildings on the north and western sides. The entrance to the site was off Victoria Road and a second gateway on the south side gave access to the Fever and Smallpox Hospitals (SMR 21086 & SMR 21087).

Avonside Refinery, located on the south side of Feeder Road, St. Philip's Marsh. The works is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.7) surveyed in 1883 as a long rectangular building orientated north-south. The entrance to the site was off Feeder Road. The 1883 plan indicates that the refinery was disused at that time.

KNOWN_AS: Fever Hospital on the east side of the River Avon, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: Fever Hospital, located on the east bank of the River Avon in St. Philip's Marsh. The hospital is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.7) surveyed in 1883 which shows it on the north side of a roughly triangular walled enclosure also containing a Smallpox Hospital. The hospital building was orientated east-west and measured 80 feet on its long axis by 40 feet wide. The entrance to the enclosure seems to have been via a gate leading into the stone yard (SMR 21084) immediately to the north.

Marsh Mill, an oil mill located on the south side of Feeder Road, St. Philip's Marsh. The mill is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.7) surveyed in 1883 as a large building against Feeder Road with smaller buildings to the south and west forming an enclosed yard. The entrance to the site was off Feeder Road.

KNOWN_AS: Vulcan Iron Works, Albert Road, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: Vulcan Iron Works, located on the west side of Albert Road, St. Philip's Marsh. The foundry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.12) surveyed in 1883.

KNOWN_AS: Suspension footbridge over the River Avon
MONUMENT_DESC: Suspension footbridge over the river Avon, carrying the footpath into Sparke Evans Park. The bridge was constructed by John Lysaght Ltd. of Bristol in 1933 and is a lattice pylon and girder suspension bridge. Iron railings protect the ends of the suspension cables at either end of the bridge.
Terrace of late C19 housing in original condition. (1)

KNOWN_AS: Railway bridge across the river Avon
MONUMENT_DESC: Railway bridge across the river Avon at Albert Road.

Pound located on the south-eastern side of Bedminster Down Road. The pound was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.8.7) surveyed in 1882 and measured 11 metres from north to south and was 7.5 metres wide. It was enclosed by a masonry wall and the entrance was on the north-eastern side.

KNOWN_AS: Bedminster Gate Toll house, Bedminster Down Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Bedminster Gate tollhouse, located on the south-western side of the junction of Parson Street and Bedminster Down Road. The tollhouse was a two-storey building with a slate roof. The northern end took the form of an octagon with the southern part a rectangular block. The entrance door was in the northern side of the octagonal part of the building and there were probably casement windows in each of the other faces, except that for one in the upper floor which, by 1937, had been replaced by a sign for H. Phillips & Sons, Builders and Decorators. There was a weighbridge on the south side of the building. The building was demolished in 1965 (Jones & Chown 1977, pl45).
The Plough Inn, located on the south-eastern side of Bedminster Down Road. The building was in existence in the early 1840s.

Chapel located on the north side of Bell Hill Road. The chapel was constructed in the late-nineteenth century and was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) published in 1904. The building measured 8 metres from east to west and was 12.5 metres long. It was still extant in 1916 but was subsequently demolished.

KNOWN_AS: Methodist chapel at Church Road, Redfield
MONUMENT_DESC: Methodist chapel located on the north side of Church Road, Redfield. The chapel was constructed in the nineteenth century and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition County Series 1:2500-scale plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.13) published in 1884. The building measures 15 metres from east to west and is 13 metres wide.

Avonmouth Dock. The dock was built by the Bristol Port and Channel Dock Company. It was completed in 1877. A rectangular basin with wharves around the sides. An Act of Parliament of 28 June 1877 (40 and 41 Vict. Ch.lxv) allowed the company to construct a graving dock.
The Bristol Port and Channel Dock Company was taken over by Bristol Council in 1884.

Zion Chapel, located on the south side of Coronation Road, Bedminster on the west side of the junction with Bedminster Parade. The chapel was built in 1829-1830 by John Hare and is of Pennant sandstone rubble construction with limestone ashlar detailing (Stell 1986, 64). Stell notes that an organ gallery was added in 1878-1880 and the seating was also renewed at that date. The chapel is set within a walled plot.
An Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852 ordered that burials were "to be discontinued within five yards of Zion Independent Chapel, in the parish of St. Mary Redcliffe and only one body to be buried in each grave." The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan surveyed in 1883 (Bristol Sheet LXXII.4.15) indicates that there were two discrete areas of interment against the north and east boundaries.
The chapel has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/45/376).
The churchyard of Redland Chapel (SMR 9594), Redland. The perimeter walls, gate piers and gates to the churchyard have a Grade II* listing (Listed Building Number 1724).

A wreck lying to the west of Stup Pill, Chittening. The remaining element of the ship was 20.8 metres long and the part exposed above the mud appeared to be the eroded upper ends of floor timbers 0.2-0.25 metres above the sediments.
The vessel was estimated to be between approximately 5 and approximately 8 metres across. No evidence of a mast step was observed. The exposed planks were of oak and were cut rather than grown crook timbers. No artefacts were observed within the vessel.
It was concluded that the "unusual length to breadth ratio would seem to indicate a craft built for speed and not a large cargo carrying capacity - possibly a vessel such as a clipper or yacht," though alternatively the shape would be comparable to that of river colliers.(Buglass 1996).

A circular stone tower at the northern end of Belmont Street. The crenellated tower has two-storeys and includes a gothic window. The tower is recorded on the 1st edition Ordnance Survey map but its function is not stated. The tower may be a gazebo, possibly associated with Manor House to the south.

KNOWN_AS: Air Raid Shelter at the rear of No.176 Pen Park Road, Southmead
MONUMENT_DESC: A domestic surface air raid shelter located to the rear of No.176 Pen Park Road, Southmead. The shelter stands 11 metres to the north-east of the house and is of the traverse entry type, constructed of brick with a flat reinforced concrete roof. The entrance is at the southern end of the north-west facing elevation and has been bricked up.

Cattle pens located some 120 metres to the north of Silverthorne Lane. The pens were recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.3) surveyed in 1883 and were still extant at the beginning of the twentieth century. The area of the pens had, however, been reduced significantly by the end of the First World War, and the railway expanded across the northern part of its site.

Bristol Rolling Works, located on the south side of Silverthorne Road. The works was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.3) surveyed in 1883. The site included a railway timber yard to the west. The site appears to have become a yard for the Bristol Corporation by the end of the First World War but the buildings survived into the mid-1960s. The site was subsequently redeveloped.

KNOWN_AS: Parish Boundary Marker Stone at Ladies Mile, Durdham Down
MONUMENT_DESC: Parish Boundary Marker Stone at Ladies Mile, Durdham Down.

Bristol Vitriol Works, located on the western side of Avon Street. The works was in existence by the time of Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 plan of Bristol. The works was still extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.3) surveyed in 1883 but had been demolished by the beginning of the twentieth century.

Greensplot Farm, located on the southern side of Washingpool Lane. The farm was recorded by the 1830 Ordnance Survey plan. It was recorded as Green Splot Farm in 1839. The Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan of 1915 (Gloucestershire sheet LXVII.10) depicts a farmhouse and outbuildings to the north-east. The farm  appears to have been demolished sometime between 1955 and 1969 (Corcos, 2008, 3), possibly for the construction of large storage sheds that were granted planning permission in 1963.

Washingpool Farm. A farm was depicted on this site (ST 53414 81560) in 1830 (Ordnance Survey 1:63360). The range of buildings was recorded in 1915 (Ordnance Survey County Series 1:2500-scale plan, Gloucestershire Sheet LXVII.10). It was a farm with a number of outbuildings, probably of post-medieval date. Much of the post-medieval site now lies beneath the A403 and was destroyed by construction of a reservoir associated with the Sevalco Works. Walls and brick paved surfaces survive west of the A 403.
A small "island" shown by the maps to the south of the site was reached from the farm by a small footbridge, and may represent an earlier possible moated site (ST 53423 81511) (1). The area enclosed by the ditch measures 20 metres north-south by 27 metres east-west. The site of the farm is largely overgrown with trees, although not built over, and the "moat" is untouched. Substantial archaeological deposits and structures probably survive.
The site was visited by R. G. Jackson during the course of a desk-based assessment (SMR 20081) of areas of Bristol City Council owned land north of Avonmouth in December 1996. The ditch surrounding the site of the possible moated site was dry and was up to 1 metre deep in some places. The site was still overgrown by trees.

Rockingham Farm. The 1830 1:63360 map depicts two buildings in a yard and attached orchard at this NGR (1). By 1915, a range of buildings set around a yard had evolved, although construction of a bridge over the adjacent railway had intruded slightly (Glos LXVII.10).

This site was recorded on the 1830 1"/1:63360 map (1), although not named there. In 1915 (Glos sheet LXVII.10), a house and series of outbuildings, with a yard, was recorded, which was still there in 1946 (CPE UK 1869 3016). The site was waste ground in 1991. Archaeological deposits and structures relating to the farm almost certainly survive. Its date of origin cannot be established at present.

Kingroad Farm, located to the south-east of Kings Weston Rhine. The farm was in existence at the time of the Henbury tithe survey of 1840. It survived into the early twentieth century but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped.

A group of buildings was depicted at this site in 1830 (Ordnance Survey 1:63360), and was still in existence in 1946 (CPE-UK-1869 4030). The site had been built over by 1982. Archaeological evaluation of the site in 2001 (20683) identified the surviving remains of lime bonded rubble walls, interior floor surfaces and a cobbled yard and recovered artefactual material dating to the eighteenth century.

Crox Top Farm in Knowle. The farm comprised two main buildings just over 320 metres to the south-west of Inns Court, on either side of a lane leading to the farm from what is now Hartcliffe Way. Outbuildings lay to the east.
Horfield Baptist Church located on the east side of Gloucester Road.

KNOWN_AS: Parish boundary marker stones at the allotment site, Callington Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Two parish boundary marker stones, indicating the boundary between the parishes of Brislington and Bedminster in the southern part of the allotment site on the north side of Callington Road, Brislington. The stones (at ST 61052 70308 and ST 61128 70245) are recorded by Ordnance Survey maps from 1938 onwards. Only one, marked "CB 1897", was found by Burchill in March 2000 during a visit to the site as part of a desk-based assessment (Burchill 2000).

KNOWN_AS: Possible field system on Durdham Down
MONUMENT_DESC: A possible field system, on Durdham Down close to the west side of Westbury Road, is visible as a cropmark on a vertical air photograph taken on 5th April 1982 for the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (Run 83 Frame 24). The photograph indicates that the field system covers an area of roughly 23500 square metres centred on ST 5723 7515 It is currently undated but its form suggests a likely prehistoric or Romano-British date.

KNOWN_AS: Tennis Lawn to the rear of Down House
Burial ground of Ebenezer Chapel, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC: The burial ground of Ebenezer Chapel (SMR 20440), located on the north side of Victoria Road (now British Road). The burial ground comprised two parts, a small burial ground against British Road and the main burial ground to the north-west of the chapel. The site of the chapel has been redeveloped but the burial ground remains under grass.

KNOWN_AS: St. Mary Magdalene with St. Francis Church, Gainsborough Square, Lockleaze
MONUMENT_DESC: St. Mary Magdalene with St. Francis Church, located on the southern side of Gainsborough Square, Lockleaze. The church was built in 1960-1961 to a design by Thomas H. B. Burrough and F. L. Hannam (Harwood & Foster, 1998 108).

KNOWN_AS: Smithy on the southern side of New Wall Road, Totterdown
MONUMENT_DESC: Smithy, located on the southern side of New Wall Road, Totterdown. The smithy is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.17) surveyed in 1882 and the building survived into the early twentieth century. It was subsequently demolished and its site now lies partly beneath the gardens of Nos.80-82 and Nos.94-95 New Walls and partly beneath the adjacent access road off Angers Road.

KNOWN_AS: Primitive Methodist chapel on the southern side of Angers Road, Totterdown
MONUMENT_DESC: Primitive Methodist Chapel, located on the southern side of Angers Road, Totterdown. The chapel is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.17) surveyed in 1882. The building was orientated from north-west to south-east and measured 21 metres by 7.5 metres wide. The plan indicates that at that date the chapel had accommodation for 150. The building survived into the twentieth century but was subsequently demolished. Its site now lies beneath the open space at the eastern end of Angers Road, close to its junction with Bath Road.

KNOWN_AS: Fever hospital for women approximately 260 metres to the east of Novers Hill, Knowle
MONUMENT_DESC: Fever hospital for women, located approximately 260 metres to the east of Novers Hill, Knowle. The hospital is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.10) published in 1886. At that date the hospital comprised a narrow walled enclosure with a buildings at the north end and at the centre. Access was via a lane from the north-west corner which ran west to Novers Hill. The hospital was extant in 1916 but a new hospital, the Novers Hill Hospital for Infectious Diseases, had been constructed immediately to the north-east around the end of the nineteenth century. The hospital was subsequently demolished and its site is currently (04/07/2002) occupied by the Florence Brown Special School.

Prior's Hill Fort, located in the vicinity of the junction of Fremantle Road and Kingsdown Parade. The fort was constructed in 1642 as part of the new northern line of defences around Bristol to protect the city during the English Civil Wars. It was probably built of stone and was apparently square, the Royalist engineer Sir Bernard de Gomme describing it as "fower square, ech side 24 of my passes" [probably around 20 metres] (Firth 1925, 184). The structure seems to have consisted of a high level platform with gun embrasures and internal rooms below. A survey of the ordnance captured at the storming of Bristol made on 28 July 1643 records that there were three sakers and one "murderer" at the fort (Roy 1975, 261).
In 1643 fighting around Prior's Hill fort appears to have been relatively limited. There was some exchange of fire on the night of 24 July and the Royalist assault during the following morning included with small attacks on the defensive line to either side of the fort (Firth 1925, 187; 189). The Royalists presumably refortified the structure as part of other strengthening works to the line after their capture of the city but little is currently (17/06/2002) known about the nature of these works although Sprigge's account of the Parliamentarian assault of late-August and early-September 1645 refers to a sally-port near Prior's Hill fort, possibly to the east (Sprigge 1854, 104; 105-106).
The fort was a focus of fighting during the Parliamentarian assault on Bristol. The fort was subjected to a bombardment on 4 September. During the storming of the city in the early morning of the 10 September the Kingsdown section of the defensive line was heavily assaulted and was entered by the Parliamentarian regiments commanded by Colonel Rainsborough and Colonel Hammond. According to Sprigge Prior's Hill fort "very obstinately held out, playing fiercely with great and small shot upon our men for two hours after the line was entered" (Sprigge 1854, 117). The Parliamentarian forces eventually managed to reach the fort and get over the palisades protecting it using ladders. After hand-to-hand fighting they seized the colours and forced the defenders into the inner rooms where, according to Sprigge, "our soldiers were so little prepared for to show mercy, by the opposition that they met withal in the storm, and the refusal of quarter when it was offered, that they put to the sword the commander, . and almost all the officers, soldiers, and others in the fort, except a very few, which at the entreaty of some our officers, had their lives spared" (Sprigge 1854, 117).
Sprigge reports that following the Parliamentarian capture of the city Cromwell ordered that the forts along the line be left "in a safe condition", presumably by partial demolition (Sprigge 1854, 132). The fort had been entirely demolished by the early 1740s and its site is not indicated by Jean Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol which suggests that the area had returned to largely agricultural use by that date. Earthworks associated with the fort survived into the early nineteenth century when the antiquary Samuel Seyer reported that its site was "discernible from the uneveness of the ground, but its form cannot be traced" (Seyer 1823, 305). The precise location of the fort has not yet been established but may be beneath the Prior's Hill flats and the houses and gardens of Nos.13-19 Fremantle Road.

KNOWN_AS: Asphalt works, Chapel Street, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: Asphalt works, located on the north side of Chapel Street, St. Philip's Marsh. The works is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.7) surveyed in 1883. The works buildings were located on the south, Chapel Street, and west sides of the site, forming a central yard. The site entrance was off Chapel Street.

KNOWN_AS: Wesleyan Methodist Chapel, Victoria Road, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: Wesleyan Methodist Chapel, located on the east side of Victoria Road. The chapel is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.7) surveyed in 1883 which indicates that the chapel could accommodate 300 people.

Marsh Bridge, located at the south end of Avon Street, carrying Avon Street over the western end of the Feeder Canal to join Victoria Road. The bridge is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.7) surveyed in 1883.

Henleaze Park Gasometer. The gas holder is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.08) published in 1881 a short distance to the east of Henleaze Park (SMR 21106). The gas holder was circular, measuring approximately 3.5 metres in diameter. It was recorded as a tank on later editions of the plan and had been demolished by the mid-1930s. The site of the gas holder now lies on the east side of No.18a St. Margaret's Drive.

Henleaze Farm. The farm is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.08) published in 1881 which shows it a short distance to the west of the boundary between the parishes of Horfield and Westbury-on-Trym. The farm comprised two attached buildings on the north side of the farmyard. The farm seems to have been renamed as The Briars by the mid-1930s. The buildings were subsequently demolished and a new building named The Briars constructed.
1756: Gallows on St. Philips Plain. {1}
The formal garden of Stoke House, Stoke Hill. The garden lay immediately to the west of the main house, the southern part being the formal garden and the northern the kitchen garden.

Madgalen Chapel, Ashley Hill. The chapel may have been built to service the Blue Maids Orphanage which was housed in Ashley Manor House between 1795 and 1829. The chapel appears to be of late eighteenth-century date.

Hookes Mills. The corn mill was sited at the foot of Ashley Hill close to Ashley Manor House. The building was aligned north-south and is probably located beneath the yard of the former engineering works. A photograph published by Reece Winstone shows one of the elevations of the building which had two storeys, at least six bays and appears to be of a stone construction (Winstone 1985, pl.197). The fenestration of the upper storey is low in relation to the roofline. The building therefore seems to be an earlier structure (perhaps a barn) which was converted into a mill.
The millpond was to the east of the mill.

KNOWN_AS: Medieval church of St. Andrew, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC:
The medieval parish church of St. Andrew, Clifton, located on the north side of Clifton Green. The church was in existence by 1180. The body of the church was rebuilt in 1654, although the tower was retained.
The church was demolished in 1819-1822 because of a lack of accommodation space and a new church (SMR 893) built immediately to the north. Illustrations in the Braikenridge collection, Bristol Museum and Art Gallery record the church before and during its demolition.
Water tower at Stoke Road, Durdham Down.

KNOWN_AS: Water tower at Talbot Road, Knowle
MONUMENT_DESC:
Water tower at Talbot Road, Knowle. The tower, in a Gothic style, was built for Bristol Waterworks in 1905. A datestone on the structure reads "BWW 1906."
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building Number 901-1/48/1559).

Piggery, located some 180 metres to the north of Manor Road, Stapleton. The piggery was constructed at the end of the nineteenth century and is first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1903. It is a single-storey building, measuring approximately 5.5 metres from east to west and 8 metres north to south.
