The piggery is constructed of coursed Pennant sandstone rubble with ashlar quoins and details with a pitched roof. It was extended in the later twentieth century by the addition of pre-fabricated concrete structures on its east side and converted to changing rooms. The interior is reported to have been remodelled.

Begbrook, a house located on the west side of the river Frome near Stapleton. The house is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882 and it was still extant at the time of the First World War. The building has been demolished and the site redeveloped for the Begbrook House nursing home. The site of the house now lies beneath the east wing and to the north-east of the modern house.

Whiteladies Picture House, located on the west side of Whiteladies Road, to the north of the junction with Melrose Place. The building was designed by James Henry LaTrobe and Thomas Weston and was constructed in 1920-1921. It is of Limestone ashlar and render with a square tower over the foyer. The design originally included a restaurant and ballroom. When the cinema opened, the auditorium was 105 feet (32.1 metres) long by 68 feet (20.8 metres) wide and could accommodate 1298 patrons, 1016 at ground level and 282 in the balcony (Staples 2002, 7). The original interior design for the interior included elaborate plasterwork and this survives in many places.
The proscenium arch was removed in the early 1950s. The cinema was converted to three screens in 1978. The balcony became the main screen and the auditorium was split along its long axis to produce two screens. Use of the building as a cinema ceased on 15 December 2001.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building No.901-1/3/10069).
This farm was recorded on the 1830 OS map as Pag Gate Farm (Ordnance Survey 1:63360). It is still extant.

This farm was recorded in 1830 (Ordnance Survey 1:63360). At that date, there appear to have been two buildings between Moorhouse Lane and the bend in the track through the farmyard, although they now (1975) seem to be on the other side of the track. The site is potentially medieval in origin. Archaeological structures and deposits of the medieval period onwards can be expected to have survived here. The buildings recorded in the 1830 map may have been superceded by those at the site today.

KNOWN_AS: The Moor House or Moorhouse Farm
MONUMENT_DESC: This building was recorded in 1830 (1:63360). The area was almost certainly occupied in 1327 (2). Archaeological deposits relating to the medieval occupation of Moorhouse probably exist over an area wider than that of the farm.

Fishpond at Lower Pen Park, Southmead. The pond is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.06) published in 1881 and was roughly rectangular and measured approximately 50 metres long by 17 metres wide. The site has been developed for housing and is now beneath Nos.2-14 Tereslake Green.

Building at The Ridgeway, Brentry. The building is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.04), published in 1881, lying to west of a quarry at Brentry Hill (SMR 20376). The function of the building is not known, although it may perhaps be related to the working of the quarry, nor has it been established if it - or elements of it - are extant.

KNOWN_AS: Brislington Picture Palace, Sandy Park Road, Brislington
MONUMENT_DESC: Brislington Picture Palace. The cinema was located on the southern side of Sandy Park Road, Brislington on the east side of the junction with Belmont Road. The cinema seated 650 and was open from 1913 until 1955. For a short period it was called the Empress (Anderson, 1983, 22). The building is extant. It was converted to a bingo hall but is currently (10/04/01) vacant. The level of survival of the interior of the cinema is unknown.

KNOWN_AS: Pillbox at Brislington Depot, Sandy Park Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
A concrete pillbox in the upper car park of Brislington Depot, Sandy Park Road. The circular structure, which appears to be a Type 25 pillbox, is located very close to the boundary wall of the depot on the north side of Sandy Park Road. It is circular, stands 2.38 metres high and has three small slits in the walls. The entrance is on the southern side of the pillbox.
[There are photographs of the pillbox in the Sites and Monuments Record Collection of Ground-Based Photographs].

Kensington Cottage, located some 120 metres to the north of modern Wellington Hill West. The building is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.08) published in 1881. This plan names the building as Kensington Cottage but it is recorded by the 1936 edition of the plan as Kensington Farm. The site of the building is now largely beneath Nos.15-17 Kendon Drive.

Duckett Farm, located on the north side of modern Wellington Hill West. The building is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.08) published in 1881 and was still extant at the time of the 1936 edition of the plan. The site of the building is now largely beneath Nos.80-82 Duckett Farm.
A quarry lying some 100 metres to the south of Knole Lane, Brentry. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan published in 1881 (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.04).
Beacon on Dunball Island. The beacon is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan of 1890 (Gloucester Sheet LXXI.01).

Kingroad Farm. The farm was located a short distance inland from the Severn and it is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucester Sheet LXVII.13) published in 1881. The eastern arm of the extension to Royal Edward Dock cut through the western part of the farm.

The Marine Hotel. The hotel was located a short distance above mean high water on the river Severn. The hotel is recorded and it is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucester Sheet LXVI.01) published in 1890. The site of the hotel now lies to the east of Royal Edward Dock.

KNOWN_AS: United Free Methodist chapel on the eastern side of Oxford Street, Totterdown
MONUMENT_DESC:
United Free Methodist chapel, located on the eastern side of Oxford Street, Totterdown, on the north side of the junction with Bush Street. The chapel was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.17) surveyed in 1882. This plan indicated that the chapel had accommodation for 300. The building was orientated from east to west and measured 19.5 metres by 16.5 metres wide.
The chapel survived into the early-twentieth century but was subsequently demolished. Its site now lies partly beneath No.33 Oxford Street and partly beneath the adjacent footway.

KNOWN_AS: Bowling green of The Star Inn, North Street, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC: A bowling green of at least nineteenth-century date, at the rear of The Star Inn, North Street (SMR 20431). The bowling green lay to the north of the building and was recorded by John Ashmead's survey of 1849.

Novers Hill Isolation Hospital, located to approximately 300 metres to the east of Novers Hill. The hospital was constructed around the end fo the nineteenth century and was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.10) published in 1903. The hospital then comprised four substantial buildings set in formally designed grounds. The hospital has since been demolished and the site redeveloped as the Courtlands Special School. The sites of the former hospital buildings lie within the grounds of the school.

Montpelier Farm, located to the north side of Cromwell Road. The date of origin of the farm is unknown but traditionally it is reported to have served as Oliver Cromwell's headquarters during the storming of Bristol by the New Model Army in 1645. The farm is recorded by Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 survey of Bristol and was stil extant in the early 1880s. The farm had been demolished and the site redeveloped for housing by the beginning of the twentieth century. The site of the farm now lies beneath houses and gardens of Nos.128-136 Cromwell Road and No.87 Chesterfield Road.

KNOWN_AS: Limekilns at Windsor Road, St. Andrews
MONUMENT_DESC: A pair of limekilns, located to the north of modern Windsor Road. The limekilns are recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.09) surveyed in 1880-81 and were associated with a group of quarries (SMR 21339) to the north in the area of modern Leopold Road. The kilns had been demolished and the site redeveloped for housing by the beginning of the twentieth century. The site of the limekilns now lies beneath No.27 Windsor Road.

St. Luke's Church, Brislington. The date of foundation of the church is not clear but the fabric of the present building dates from the fifteenth century. The north aisle and arcade rebuilt 1819. The church was described by Sir Stephen Glynne in April 1850 (SMR 5745) as consisting of a "nave, and chancel, with aisles to the former and south aisles only to the latter, a west tower and south porch" with mainly Decorated Gothic features. Glynne also noted the shaft of the cross in the churchyard (McGarvie 1994, 49-50). A watercolour by John Buckler executed in 1828 in the Piggott collection records the church from the south-east. The church is constructed of coursed red and grey Pennant sandstone rubble with ashlar dressings and stone-coped slate roofs. The eastern end was rebuilt in 1874 by B. Ferrey.
The interior dates predominantly to the late-nineteenth century with a fifteenth-century archway.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building Number 901-1/49/452).

The Malago Vale Brickworks, located on the southern side of West Street, Bedminster. The works was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.08.03) surveyed in 1883 which indicates that the site contained two large clay pits, a row of kilns, and other structures.

A linear earthwork on the north side of the railway, Hallen Marsh (ST 5375 8045 approx.). The earthwork is approximately 12 metres wide and 0.5 metres deep, and is orientated south-west to north-east across a field.
The site (Area 1; Site 11) was identified and visited by R. G. Jackson during the course of a desk-based assessment (SMR 20081) of areas of Bristol City Council owned land north of Avonmouth in December 1996. Its function is unknown but it was suggested that the feature may represent the line of a rhine on a former field boundary.

KNOWN_AS: Ridge and furrow at Hallen Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC:
Ridge and furrow at Hallen Marsh (centred on ST 54273 80808). Two adjoining fields have very well preserved ridge and furrow.
The site (Area 1; Site 13) was identified and visited by R. G. Jackson during the course of a desk-based assessment (SMR 20081) of areas of Bristol City Council owned land north of Avonmouth in December 1996. It was concluded that the fields were "the best preserved examples of ridge and furrow within the four study areas".

Victoria Rooms, Queen's Road. The building was constructed between 1839 and 1841 to a design by the architect Charles Dyer. Dyer had exhibited the drawings for the building at the Royal Academy in London in 1831 (Crick, 1975 5-6). Sphinxes were set on the plinths on either side of the steps to the building. In 1883 the area of land on the north side of the building was in use as a "tennis ground."
The forecourt area was redesigned in 1912 when new fountains designed by Edwin Rickards and Henry Poole were constructed. The sphinxes flanking the entrance steps were removed as part of the work.
From 1920 until 1922 the building housed 'Clifton Super Cinema' (Anderson, 1983, 39).
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/9/959) and the fountains in front of the building have a separate Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/9/960).

KNOWN_AS: Avon View Cemetery, Beaufort Road, Crews Hole
MONUMENT_DESC:
Avon View Cemetery, located on the south side of Beaufort Road. The cemetery was established in the late-nineteenth century and was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.12) published in 1903. The cemetery has a war memorial close on the east side of the main entrance off Beaufort Road and a chapel, constructed at the same time as the cemetery was established.
The cemetery walls along Beaufort Road and the entrance gates have a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/56/1834).

Pembroke Chapel, located on the south side of Oakfield Road. The chapel was a Congregational chapel and was built in the mid-nineteenth century and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.12) surveyed in 1883 as having accommodation for 800 worshippers.

KNOWN_AS: Church of St. Paul, St. Paul's Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
Church of St. Paul, located on the northern side of St. Paul's Road. The church was constructed in the mid-nineteenth century and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.12) surveyed in 1883 as having accommodation for 900 worshippers.
The church has  Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/3/1053).

Reading room located on the south-west side of Southleigh Road. The reading room was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.12) surveyed in 1883. It was recorded as a hall by the beginning of the twentieth century and was still extant in 1916.

Oakleigh House on the south side of Oakfield Road. The house was constructed in 1850 to a design by the architect Charles Dyer who also designed the Victoria Rooms (SMR 21927). It was a two-storey building and the main, north-facing, elevation was of five storeys. A stable block was constructed at the north-west corner of the plot. In 1882 the house was occupied by a W. M. Webb.
The house has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/3/900) and the stables are also separately listed Grade II (Listed Building number 901-1/3/901).

No.17, St. Augustine's Parade. An attached late eighteenth-century house, now an office and shop, restored in 1991. Render with party wall brick stack and slate mansard roof. Double-depth plan. 3 storeys and attic; 2-window range. A C20 shop front, with a banded left-hand pilaster strip to a cornice and parapet; keyed architraves to 6/6-pane sashes. 
The interior (though not the ground-floor) was briefly inspected during renovation work, c.1991 by John Bryant. The first-floor contained  no significant features. There may have once been a staircase to the second-floor in the rear (i.e. south-west corner). The second-floor comprised two rooms and a closet. The fireplaces were tiled 20th.century examples. Front windows of 18th.century (?) sashes with shutters. Doors with L-hinges and fielded panels. Some panelling opposite the staircase to the top floor. The staircase was open-well with quarter landings, in eighteenth- or nineteenth-century style. The bottom was not cut, suggesting that it never reached the first-floor. The third, or top, floor was covered with a mansard roof front and rear, but a ridge roof in the centre over the stairwell. There was an internal gutter running along the west side, on the floor.
St. Augustine's Parade is a street developed in the medieval period. The party walls with adjacent properties may be of some age.

Berrylane Farm, located on the south side of modern Chedworth Road. The farm was created in the second half of the nineteenth century. It is not shown by the tithe survey of Horfield but is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.05) published in 1881. At that date the farm comprised an L-shaped range of buildings on the north and west sides of a square yard, with another building on its southern side. The farm survived into the twentieth century but it had been demolished by the mid 1930s and the site redeveloped for the existing housing on Chedworth Road.
The site of the farm now lies beneath Nos.12-14 Chedworth Lane and elements will probably be preserved in the gardens to the rear.

Horfield Court Farm, located on the east side of Gloucester Road. The farm was in existence by the time of the tithe survey of Horfield and at that date the farm comprised three substantial buildings, though none is indicated to be a dwelling. It was also recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.05) published in 1881 and this shows a similar arrangement of buildings. The farm survived into the twentieth century but it had been demolished by the mid 1930s and the site redeveloped.

Manor Farm, located on the western side of modern Kellaway Avenue. The buildings of the farm were in existence by the time of the tithe survey of Horfield, though none is indicated to be a dwelling. The farm was also recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.05) published in 1881 which shows a single building, presumably the farmhouse, at the south end of the plot. Some 90 metres to the north there was a yard roughly 25 metres square with buildings on its northern, eastern and southern sides. The site of the presumed farmhouse had been redeveloped by the early twentieth century according to the Ordnance Survey second edition plan published in 1903. The farm survived into the mid 1930s but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped for housing.
Its site now lies beneath Nos.5-10 Manor Court Drive.
A brewery on the north-western side of Cromwell Street. The brewery is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan surveyed in 1883 (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXV.4.23).

Court Farm, located on the eastern side of modern Filton Road. The farm was created in the early twentieth century, being first recorded by the Ordnance Survey third edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.05) published in 1916. This showed several buildings on the north, east and south sides of a plot measuring some 33 metres east-west by 27 metres north-south. A small group of buildings at the centre of the south side may have been animal stalls, possibly pigsties. The farm had been demolished and the site redeveloped by the mid-1930s.

Limekiln, located at the eastern end of a quarry (SMR 21143) some 75 metres to the west of Wells Road. The limekiln was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500-scale plan (Somerset Sheet VI.07) published in 1886.

Quarry, located some 75 metres to the west of Wells Road. The quarry was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.07) published in 1886. The quarry measures 113 metres from east to west by 68 metres north-south and the working face was at its western end. There was a limekiln (SMR 21141) at the eastern end. The quarry had apparently gone out of use by the beginning of the twentieth century and is recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition plan published in 1905 as "Old Quarry". The site has now been infilled and redeveloped for housing.

The Chestnuts, Brislington. In 1660 Rowland Lacy, the lord of the manor, granted the estate to Abraham Saunders and the house is believed to date from this date. In 1680 the estate was sold to John Hawkins and it remained in the Hawkins family until c1790 when it was sold to William Fry who exchanged the property for Gotley Lodge with James Ireland.  The house remained in the Clayfield-Ireland family until 1926 when Henry Williams bought the house from the Clayfield-Ireland Estate.

KNOWN_AS: The White Hart Hotel, Bristol Hill, Brislington
MONUMENT_DESC:
The White Hart Hotel, located on the north side of Bristol Hill. The date of construction of the building is currently unknown but it is first recorded as a coaching inn in 1738. An area at the back of the property was known as "The Green" in the eighteenth century (Winstone 1985). On the Brislington tithe survey it is recorded as the White Hart Inn, Stables, Yard and Gardens with Philip Marks given as the owner and occupier.
The hotel is a Grade II listed building (Listed Building number 901-1/49/449).

Malago Vale Engine Works. The works was located on the south side of what is now Malago Road and was, in the late nineteenth century, the leat for the corn mill at Mill Lane and the railway. The works is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan of Bristol (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXV.4.24) and was still extant at the time of the second edition 1:2500-scale County Series plan in 1902. The site has since been redeveloped.

Avonmouth Hotel. The hotel was located a short distance to the east of the north channel of the river Avon. The hotel is recorded and it is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucester Sheet LXVI.01) published in 1890. The site of the hotel now lies between the two arms of Royal Edward Dock.

Avonmouth Farm. The farm was located to the north of Avonmouth. The farm was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucester Sheet LXVI.01) published in 1890. The buildings of the farm were still extant in December 1946 (CPE/UK/1869 4030) but were subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped. The site of the farm now lies beneath a warehouse on the south side of Crowley Road.

Avonmouth Rifle Range on the saltmarsh above mean high water to the north of Avonmouth. The range is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucester Sheet LXVII.13) published in 1881.

Netham Dam. The dam diverts a flow of water along the Feeder canal. It was raised in height on the recommendation of I. K. Brunel, and has been subsequently modified. The weir marks the effective limits of normal tides on the River Avon (Buchanan & Buchanan 1980, 47-48).

Totterdown Lock gave direct entrance to the Feeder canal from the New Cut, at the basin outside the Floating Harbour, it was firmly sealed in WWII to prevent the drainage of the Harbour by a direct hit on the lock. It had a lock-keeper's cottage which also served as a toll house until it was demolished in 1966.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry at the eastern end of Coombe Hill, Henbury
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry at the eastern end of Henbury Golf Course recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1:2500 map of 1949. The quarry covered an area of approximately 5800 square metres.

The Feeder Canal. A vital element in the scheme for the Floating Harbour was a supply of fresh water. Some of this came from the River Frome, but this became seriously polluted by sewage so that the Corporation was compelled to divert the Frome in the 1820s through a culvert under the Harbour directly into the New Cut. The main source of fresh water was the River Avon, and to ensure a reliable supply from a point above high-tide level, the Feeder Canal was built from Netham to the head of the Floating Harbour at Totterdown, a distance of just over a mile.{1}
Vauxhall Footbridge, carrying pedestrian traffic across the New Cut (Buchanan & Buchanan 1980, 42).

Ashton Swing Bridge. A rail and road bridge constructed as part of the Portishead to Wapping Wharf railway in a joint initiative by the Bristol Corporation and the Great Western Railway. The bridge was opened on 4th October 1906 and was hydraulically-powered, using 182 gallons for each swing, drawn from the hydraulic power system of the Floating Harbour. The bridge was last swung in 1936 and is now fixed. The road deck and operator's cabin were removed in 1965 when the Cumberland Basin flyover was built (Buchanan & Buchanan 1980, 42: Lord & Southam 1983, 47-48; 64-65; 77-78).
The bridge has a Grade II listing (Listed Building No. 901-1/41/10087)
Old Sneed Park, located at NGR ST 55369 75649. The house survived into the 1950s but has since been built over. Kip engraving of c.1712.

Millpond, Cutler's Mill Brook, Montpelier. The pond lay to the south-east on Cutler's Mill (SMR 21848) and appears to have been originally at least 160 metres long. By 1828 it was largely silted up and the south-eastern end had been incorporated into Rennison's Bath.

No.22 Jefferies Hill Bottom, located on the west side of Gillingham Hill. The building is a two-storey house of coursed Pennant sandstone bonded in a white lime mortar, with a pitched pantile roof. The building was constructed between 1803 and 1842 when it was owned by Lewis Moss and occupied by Edward Fry.

Telecommunications tower, Purdown. The tower was constructed in 1970 as a radio repeater mast but also functioned as a microwave relay station in the network established by the Home Office. It replaced a slightly shorter steel pylon with a square base which was sited adjacent to the south-west. It is a concrete tower with eight projecting platforms to support antennae. The design for the tower was commended by the Royal Fine Art Commission.

Redhouse Farm. The site of the farm is located on the west side of Hareclive Road immediately to the north of the junction with Gatehouse Avenue. The farm was in existence from at least 1817 (Burchill 1993) and is recorded by the tithe survey for Bedminster (BRO EP/A/32/8). This indicates that at that time the farm comprised a farmhouse and two outbuildings, immediately to the west and north-west. In the 1930s or later the farm buildings were demolished. The site was partly excavated in the early 1990s (SMR 20049) and stone rubble foundations, dated to the eighteenth century by pottery finds, were recorded (Burchill n.d.). The site was subsequently re-developed.

Greenbank mortuary chapels, located in the centre of Greenbank Cemetery, Eastville (SMR 20111). The structures were designed by Henry Masters and were built in 1871.
The structure has a Grade II listing (Listed Building Number 901-1/38/1258).

War memorial cross immediately south of Greenbank Chapel, Greenbank Cemetery (ST 61638 74635 centre). The plain cross is a Cross of Sacrifice, also known as the Great War Cross, designed for the Imperial War Graves Commission by Sir Reginald Blomfield. It is set on a five-tier octagonal base and the whole is built of Portland stone. A bronze sword is attached to the south face of the cross. The inscription "THEIR NAME LIVETH FOR EVERMORE" runs around the fourth tier of the memorial, and the dates "1914-1918" on the south-east face and "1939-1945" on the south-west face of the fifth (upper) tier. There is no inscription on the north face of the memorial, facing Greenbank Chapel.

The Albert Works, located on the south-western side of West Street. The works was established in 1878 by Saville, Ewens & Co. Ltd. in a move from established premises at St. John's Lane. The works comprised a number of discrete structures for manufacturing isinglass (gelatin made from the swim bladders of the sturgeon), finings and a patented preservative for beer and porter.
The main building is a two-storey structure with a double pitched pantile roof and is of rendered stone rubble. The first floor is supported on cast-iron columns (Burchill 2003, 3).

No.7, Wine Street, located on the north side of Wine Street an on the west side of Grand Hotel Passage. The date of construction of the building is currently unknown but it was apparently refronted in the late-eighteenth or early-nineteenth century. By 1791 the building was in the tenure of George Papps. The building was drawn in 1826 as part of a view of this part of the north side of Wine Street by T. L. Rowbotham (BRSMG M2343). At that date the building was a three-storey structure with a two-window range and a hipped roof behind a parapet. The ground floor contained a shopfront. Above the main, south-east facing, elevation was rendered and the fenestration comprised six-over-six pane sash windows. An oval painted sign bearing the number "7" projected from the centre of the elevation above the first-floor windows.
By 1882 the building was occupied by Edwin Wheeler, homeopathic chemist. The building survived into the first half of the twentieth century but was subsequently removed and the site redeveloped.

No.28 Portland Square, located at the north-western corner of Portland Square. Portland Square was laid out in the late 1780s and building plots were advertised for sale from March 1790. Construction stalled, however, when the building boom collapsed in 1792 and was completed by the architect Daniel Hague in 1811 (Ison 1952, 221). No.28 is at the west end of the terrace on the northern side of the square, Nos.22-28 Portland Square. The main, south-east facing elevation is of limestone ashlar. Cellars extend beneath the house. By 1896 the building was in use as Parsons and Co. Boot and Shoe Factory.
The building has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/6/1904).

Host Street Warehouse, located on the north-west side of Host Street. Thought to have been part of a sugar refinery; was latterly a clothes warehouse. Mid 19th.century, partly demolished c.1979. Pennant rubble with limestone dressings and a pantile hipped roof. Rectangular open plan. 
4 storey; 10-window range (now 6). A regular front has plain sill courses to each floor and a parapet. Segmental-arched openings. Blind left return. 1-window right modern return. 
Internal frame of cast-iron columns to RSJs supporting a timber floor; queen post timber roof. Formerly a 10-window range, extending to the right, with a round chimney at the rear. Apparently part of the once significant Bristol sugar industry, along with the former refinery at Narrow Lewins Mead.

Holy Trinity Church, Stapleton, located on the south-east side of Bell Hill. The church is of medieval origin and the advowson of the rectory was in the gift of Tewkesbury Abbey, although it appears to have been exercised through its cell, St. James Priory. After the dissolution of St. James, the advowson of the rectory was acquired by Henry Brayne as part of his purchase of the St. James property in January 1544 (Gairdner & Brodie 1903, 37).
The church was rebuilt in 1857 to a design by John Norton in a Decorated Gothic Revival style. The building is of squared Pennant rubble with limestone dressings and a slate roof. There is a tower at the west end. The stained glass in the south chancel window was made by the London studio of Charles Eamer Kempe in 1887.
The church has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/33/1938).

KNOWN_AS: Disused railway bridge immediately north of Avon Bridge
MONUMENT_DESC: Girder bridge located on the north side of Avon Bridge. The bridge was constructed in the late-nineteenth century. The bridge is supported on cylindrical metal riveted piers.

Avon Bridge. The bridge was constructed by I. K. Brunel in 1839 for the Great Western Railway. It is a masonry structure with a small four-centred arch on either side of the main span. There are cutwaters at the base of the piers.
The bridge has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/43/470).

KNOWN_AS: Railway bridge south of Avon Bridge
MONUMENT_DESC: Metal girder bridge supporting a line parallel and south of the Avon bridge of 1839 (SMR 8536). Photographs show underside of the structure in (1). Currently in good condition, but while disused is likely to be demolished.

KNOWN_AS: The Star Inn, North Street, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC: The Star Inn, located on the north side of North Street, Bedminster. The inn was constructed on the site of Bull House (SMR 20433) in the mid 1730s. By 1818 the building was owned by the Smyth estate, and surveys and terriers produced by the estate indicate that it was surrounded by outbuildings including stables, workshops and a bowling green.

Bull House, located on the north side of North Street, Bedminster on the plot now occupied by The Star Inn. To the north of the building was an associated paddock known as Bull Close which probably later became the bowling green of The Star Inn (SMR 20435). The building is known to have been extant by 1712 (BRO AC/JS/60(4) a-i) and was rebuilt some time after 1736 to become The Star Inn (SMR 20431). The extent of fabric surviving from the building within The Star Inn is unknown.

The Bishop's Palace, located on the west side of Redland Court Road. Greville Edwards donated land at Redland Green for construction and the palace was constructed in 1899 to a design by the architect W. D. Caroe, his only work in Bristol (Gomme, Jenner & Little, 1979 431).
The building was gutted by fire after incendiary bombs were dropped on it in early December 1940 and remained in ruins for many years. The site was purchased Bristol City Council in 1953 and Bristol's Education Committee constructed the St. John Reade Hostel, occupying much the same area as the palace, in 1966 (O'Connor, 2000).
The southern and eastern parts of the building lie in undeveloped land outside the footprint of the hostel and are therefore likely to survive.

KNOWN_AS: Gibbet on the north side of the River Avon at Avonmouth
MONUMENT_DESC: A gibbet on the north side of the River Avon at Avonmouth which is recorded by a survey of the parish of Westbury-on-Trym made by Y. and J. P. Sturge in 1817, now in Northampton Record Office (NRO Plan 616). The gibbet was apparently located immediately below mean high water. It is not known when the gibbet was erected, nor when it was removed.

KNOWN_AS: Brislington Hill House, Bath Road, Brislington
MONUMENT_DESC:
Brislington Hill House. Aaron Ithell is recorded as purchasing land in 1660 from Rowland Lacy, lord of the manor,  part of which subsequently formed the estate of Brislington Hill House. A succession of owners are recorded in the C18, but in 1798 John Hurle, the prominent Quaker and Bristol merchant, purchased the estate and built a new house on the site of an older building. In 1828, his widow Elizabeth, is recorded as living in the property (Ireland manuscripts; BRO St.LB/HM/1a & 1b). After her death the property passed to her neice Susannah who had married Joseph Cooke of "West Town House" in 1805.  Their son, Joseph, took the name Cooke-Hurle and lived at Brislington Hill House. The Brislington tithe Award of 1846 records John Hurle as the owner and occupier. The Cooke-Hurle family continued to reside at Brislington Hill House until 1921 when the property was sold to George Gay and converted into flats.
The house was badly damaged during World War II and had to be demolished.  The "Gilton House" flats stand on the site of the house.

The Shrubberies, located on Brislington Hill, 100 metres south of St. Luke's Church.  The date at which the house as built is currently (14/08/2006) unknown, although tradition ascribes a sixteenth-century date.
The house was later known as "Seven Gables" and was by then a three-storey building with a steeply-pitched roof with dormer windows. The Brislington Tithe Award of 1846 records Mary Ann Brown as the owner and occupier. From 1890 a Mr. Biggs, a market gardener, is recorded as the owner. He built many greenhouses in which he grew flowers and vegetables for the Bristol market. The house was demolished in the 1960s.

KNOWN_AS: Wick House Lodge, Wick Road, Brislington
MONUMENT_DESC: Wick House Lodge, Brislington.  Built as the Lodge to Wick House. It was a three-bay, single-storey building of Gothic design constructed in the eighteenth century. The Brislington tithe map, 1846, (BRO EP/A/32/9) shows the lodge with a long drive leading past it to Wick House. The lodge was demolished in 1931.

Eagle House, Brislington.  Part of an estate called Templeman's that was originally purchased in 1660 by a Mr. Munday from Rowland Lacy, the Lord of the Manor. The land was purchased by John Tipton and he is recorded as the owner in 1751.  The estate remained in the Tipton family as Mary Tipton is recorded as living at Eagle House in 1828.  In 1830 the estate was purchased by Sir John Hare but was broken up soon after and William Plummer is recorded as purchasing the house,  and John Hurle and Richard Poole-King, both local landowners, purchasing the land lying to the north of the property.  The Tithe Award, 1846, records that William Plummer continued to be the owner and occupier of the property.

The house was built in 1769 and took its name from the stone eagle that surmounted the centre of the façade of the house. 

A ha-ha crossed by a wooden bridge gave access to the field which bordered Talbot Lane, the railway lines and Bristol Road. The house was demolished in 1934.

Flowers Hill Farm, Brislington. In 1774, James Ireland purchased land in the south of the parish of Brislington which included land in the area known as Flowers Hill. The Tithe Award map of 1846 does not record a farm on the present site of Flowers Hill Farm, but there are many field names shown with "Flowers" in them. The Sanders Map of 1862 does not record a farm at Flowers Hill. The farmhouse was demolished c1965 and the Hungerford Road Community Centre now stands on the site.

KNOWN_AS: Burial ground for the Methodist chapel at Church Road, Redfield
MONUMENT_DESC: Burial ground located on the north side of the Methodist chapel at Church Road, Redfield. At that date the cemetery was 55 metres from north-west to south-east and was 28 metres wide. It had been enlarged to include a strip of land against Gilbert Road on the eastern side by the beginning of the twentieth century.

KNOWN_AS: Master's House, Edmonds Trust School, Gloucester Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
Master's House of The Edmonds Trust School, Gloucester Road. The house was located on the south side of the school building and was built in 1868 by a Mr Hardy. It was orientated north-east to south-west with the main elevation facing south-east and a house of one-storey and attic with a pitched roof. There was a bay window at the northern end of the main elevation with small attic dormers above. The roof had a chimneystack at the north gable end.
The building was demolished in the 1960s.

KNOWN_AS: Clay pit at Church Road, Redfield
MONUMENT_DESC: A clay pit located on the south side of Church Road, St. George. The clay pit is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) surveyed in 1880-1881 as an "Old Clay Pit" when the western half it is shown as infilled. By the beginning of the twentieth century the pit had been entirely infilled and No.282 Church Road and Richmond Road constructed over it.

Stapleton Gas Works. The gas works was in existence by the early 1880s when it was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.09). At that date there was a single gas holder with a cistern to the south-west. By 1903 a second gas holder had been constructed along with associated buildings, including a smithy.

Rifle range, located to the south of Sir John's Lane, Bedminster. The range was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXV.08) published in 1890 and was approximately 730 metres long. The butts were in four groups located in the area of modern Haldon Close (at ST 58540 70268, ST 58597 70334, ST 58675 70447 and ST 58741 70528). There were a number of fixed firing positions at 800 yards (ST 58360 71005), 700 yards (ST 58385 70935), 600 yards (ST 58494 70865), 300 yards (ST 58588 70737), 200 yards (ST 58634 70673) and 100 yards (ST 58694 70592). These were 'classification' ranges of the
'gallery' type as opposed to iron  targets with mantlets (David Hunt, pers comm).
The range was still in existence during the First World War but was subsequently closed and much of the southern half of the site developed for housing.

A pond located to the west of Channel's Hill, Fishponds. The pond is recorded by the Stapleton tithe survey of 1839 (BRO EP/A/32/35) and was roughly circular. It was still extant at the beginning of the twentieth century when it measured 13 metres from north to south by 11 metres east-west. The pond had been infilled by 1918.

A pond to the north of Fishponds Road. The pond was in existence by the late 1830s and was recorded by the Stapleton tithe survey of 1839 (BRO EP/A/32/35). It lay at the eastern end of a stream. The pond had been infilled by the early 1880s.

Duchess Pond, located 450 metres to the south-west of Stoke Park. The pond was recorded by the Stapleton tithe survey of 1839 (BRO EP/A/32/35). In the early 1880s the pond measured 250 metres from north-west to south-east and was 70 metres wide. The pond was extant a the time of the First World War but was subsequently infilled.

KNOWN_AS: Garden of St. Matthias College, Oldbury Court Road, Fishponds
MONUMENT_DESC: Garden of St. Matthias College, located to the rear of the main college building. The garden was designed in the mid-nineteenth century as part of the development of the Gloucester and Bristol Diocesan Training Institution for School Mistresses. It comprises a sunken lawn, a knot garden with a central sundial and a number of specimen trees, including a judas tree (Avon Gardens Trust 1991, 22).

KNOWN_AS: Air raid shelter at No.18 Old Sneed Park
MONUMENT_DESC: A domestic surface air raid shelter located to the rear of No.18 Old Sneed Park. The shelter stands 11 metres to the north-east of the house and is constructed of brick with a flat reinforced concrete roof. The entrance is at the eastern end of the south-east facing elevation.
Rockfold, located on the northern side of Bell Hill, Stapleton. The building is a rendered two-storey house with a hipped pantile roof with a probable stair tower on its south-west facing elevation.

Kingshill House, located some 70 metres to the west of Wells Road. The house was in existence by the time of the Bedminster tithe survey of 1841. The house was reached from Wells Road by a short lane (the eastern end of modern Broadfield Road) and had a large rectangular garden of approximately 200 square metres to its rear. The house was still extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey third edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXVI.05) published in 1916 but was later demolished and the site redeveloped.
The site of the Kingshill House now lies largely beneath the front garden of No.12 Broadfield Road. Housing now occupies most of the area of the garden.

Reservoir, located on the southern side of Talbot Road. The covered reservoir, belonging to the Bristol Water Works company, was recorded by Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500-scale plan (Somerset Sheet VI.07) published in 1886 when it measured 60 metres from east to west by 35 metres north-south. The reservoir is extant.

KNOWN_AS: Pump in the Garden of Bedford House

MONUMENT_DESC:
Malago Vale Colliery, located on the southern side of West Street, Bedminster. The colliery is believed to have been established c1840 and at that date was operating with a single mine shaft. The colliery was controlled by Stuckey's Bank in 1854 but was being operated by Steedes and Pilditch by 1862. The site was operated by the Malago Vale Coal Company which in 1875 deepened the original Malago shaft to a depth of 1566 feet [479 metres] and sank a new shaft known as the Argus 1740 feet [532 metres] deep (Southway 1976, 6). The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.08.03) surveyed in 1883 records the internal layout of the site, and indicates that tram lines led to a loading platform on the adjacent main rail line. In 1891 ten men were killed by an explosion in the mine and two more died in a similar incident in 1895 (Ramsey 2003, 12). The shaft at the colliery had reached a depth of roughly 3000 feet [918 metres] below ground by 1891 (Ramsey 2003, 13).
The colliery closed in 1892 after a fifteen-month long strike over the introduction of safety lamps.
New Deep Pit. At the rear of 29/39 Gores Marsh Road, now a lorry park.
Starveall Colliery. The colliery was disused by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset sheet VI.06) published in 1894.

A pound, located on the north-west side of Barton Hill Road. The pound was in existence by the late 1820s and was recorded by Plumley and Ashmead's survey of Bristol of 1828 as a rectangular enclosure measuring 18.8 metres from south-west to north-east and 6.4 metres wide. It had been removed by the 1880s and the site redeveloped for housing.
Lebeck Gate. The gate was located at the north end of Lansdown Road at its junction with Stapleton Road. It was extant at the time of Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 map of Bristol.
Armoury located on the north-west side of Stapleton Road. The building was in existence by 1828. It consisted of one long rectangular and four smaller square buildings.

KNOWN_AS: Ropewalk at Grosvenor Road, St. Paul's
MONUMENT_DESC: A ropewalk on the southern side of a lane to the north-east of Portland Square [modern Grosvenor Road]. The ropewalk was in existence by the time of the 1828 survey of Bristol by John Plumley and George Ashmead when it comprised two long, narrow buildings, orientated from north-west to south-east, at the western end of the site and open ground at the eastern end. The site measured 195 metres long by approximately 15 metres wide, while the western of the two buildings was some 85 metres long. The site had been redeveloped for terraced housing by 1881.

Whiteladies Gate. The gate was a double gate, one across Whiteladies Road and the other across Cotham Hill. The 1828 plan of Bristol by Plumley and Ashmead records a house on the site of No.2 Cotham Hill, between the two gates, which appears from its form to have been a toll house.

Clifton toll gate, located at the eastern end of Bridge Valley Road. The gate was in existence by 1828 and appears to have controlled traffic between Bridge Valley Rad and the Downs. There was a toll house on the western side of the gate.

A tannery located on the east side of the junction of York Road and Stillhouse Lane. The tannery was recorded by Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 survey of Bristol and was still extant when the first edition Ordnance Survey plan (Sheet LXXV.4.15) was surveyed in 1883. The building had been demolished by the early 1960s.

KNOWN_AS: Convent of Mercy, Brecon Close, Westbury-on-Trym
MONUMENT_DESC:
Convent of Mercy, located on the western side of Brecon Close. The monastery was established in an early-nineteenth century house known as Westmead House by 1841, the site then being owned by Maria Theresa Weld (BRO EP/A/32/41). By the early 1880s the convent had been substantially extended at the south-east corner to create a cloister.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/28/1689).

Redcatch Farm, located some 550 metres to the west of Wells Road. The farm was in existence by the time of the Bedminster tithe survey of 1841. The form of the farm had apparently not altered substantially by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.11) published in 1884. The farm survived into the twentieth century and the third edition plan published in 1916 (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXVI.05) indicates that a range of buildings had been added to the north-eastern corner of the farmhouse. The farm was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped for housing. The site of the farm now lies beneath Nos.58-64 Ravenhill Road, the farmhouse being largely in the rear gardens of the houses.

St. Michael's Manor House. Probably late C17. Restored 1983. Roughcast with limestone dressings, brick lateral stacks and a pantile hipped roof. Double-depth plan. 
2 storeys and attic; 6-window range, single storey and attic; 2-window side wings. Regular fenestration, with a continuous string over the window heads, and moulded cornice eaves. A right-of-centre doorway under a good raised canopy with a shell hood on carved foliate brackets. Narrow cross windows have metal casements; 6 hipped dormers with casements. Left-hand wing has 2 cross windows, the right-hand one with a C20 door below the transom, left-hand wing has an inner doorway and 12/12-pane sash. Rear elevation has irregular fenestration, C20 dormers and oriel. Large stacks with small ridge links. 
The interior had original panelling and a staircase until the fire in the late 1970s. Panelling remained in one room of the main building only after the fire. The stair did not survive.
Attached rubble walls to the front garden, an ashlar side doorway with alternate rusticated quoins, and large voussoirs, and ashlar piers to the front. 
The staircase between the first and second floors was lit by a wooden cross-window, its mullion and transom recessed along their centre lines. Incorporated within the fabric of the main building were the remains of an earlier structure of probable medieval date.

Boucher's House, located on the south side of Christmas Street, adjoining Frome Bridge, and nearly opposite St. John's Bridge. The building was known as "Boucher's House," supposed to have been the residence of Mr.George Boucher, executed along with Robert Yeomans in 1643. A house with a courtyard [919A] in the middle, one side carried on two or three large freestone pillars [920A]. The entrance was by a narrow passage from the street. On the side opposite the entrance was "a large room looking into the river, lately used as a school room" in 1823 (Seyer 1823, 357-358).
G. W. Braikenridge (Braikenridge Notes A18) records that the house was being demolished in November 1821. It had consisted of a complete quadrangle. the part standing on pillars "was the offices". The building lay back from the street up a passage, the back part hanging over the Frome on brackets. About 50 years previous to 1822 it had been the residence of Thomas Evans, corn factor, owned by Mr.Pomfrey of Portishead.

Lodgeside Club, located on the western side of Lodge Road, Kingswood. The house was a two-storey structure. By the mid-1940s it was known as Guild House and formed part of Handel Cossham Hospital. By the 1990s it had become the Lodgeside Club. The house was demolished in 2003 and the site was redeveloped for housing. A survey of the building was carried out in advance of demolition by Jonathan Erskine for Avon Archaeological Unit (SMR 21750).

KNOWN_AS: Lodge Hill Reservoir, Lodge Road, Kingswood
MONUMENT_DESC: Lodge Hill Reservoir, located on the western side of Lodge Road, Kingswood. The reservoir was a structure measuring 45 metres from north-west to south-east by 40 metres wide and had earth banks. The reservoir was built for the Bristol Water Works Company in the early decades of the twentieth century and there was a single-storey pumping station (SMR 22437) and a water tower (SMR 22438) close to its south-east corner. The reservoir was apparently demolished in the early 1990s and the site redeveloped.

KNOWN_AS: Pumping station, Lodge Hill Reservoir, Lodge Road, Kingswood
MONUMENT_DESC:
Pumping station located on the west side of Lodge Road, Kingswood. The pumping station was built after 1916 as part of the Bristol Water Works Company Lodge Hill reservoir. It was a single-storey structure of squared, coursed Pennant sandstone with limestone ashlar dressings and a pitched roof.
The building was demolished in the early 1990s.

KNOWN_AS: Water tower, Lodge Hill Reservoir, Lodge Road, Kingswood
MONUMENT_DESC: Water tower located on the west side of Lodge Road, Kingswood. The water tower was built after 1916 as part of the Bristol Water Works Company Lodge Hill reservoir. It was a circular structure and was 8.2 metres in diameter. The water tower was apparently demolished in the early 1990s.

Shirehampton Farm, located on the northern side of Avonmouth Road. The farm was in existence by the time of the tithe survey of Shirehampton of 1840. It was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet Sheet LXXI.02) published in 1881. This indicates that the farmhouse was close to the road with outbuildings to the north and north-east. There was a large orchard on the south-eastern side of the farmyard. The farm survived into the twentieth century but was later demolished and the site redeveloped.

St. Anne's Farm. The farm was in existence by the time of the tithe survey of Brislington of the 1840s. The farmhouse was a three-storey rendered house with a hipped pantile roof (Winstone 1977, pl.107).
The farm survived into the twentieth century but was demolished in 1937 and the site redeveloped for housing.

This site was recorded in 1830 (Ordnance Survey 1:63360), when named Englands Farm (1). The settlement around the site was almost certainly already in existence in 1327 (2). Medieval structures and deposits probably survive at this site.

KNOWN_AS: Public House on Upper Maudlin Street

MONUMENT_DESC:
Edmonds Trust School, located on the western side of Gloucester Road. The school was established in 1860 by the Rev. H. Richards. The land was given by the Horfield Trustees and the Edmonds Trust gave a grant towards construction costs. The school was consequently known as The Edmonds Trust School and taught both boys and girls. The building was a single-storey structure with two parallel ranges in a Gothic style and was constructed of coursed squared Pennant sandstone rubble with ashlar mouldings. The ranges each had pitched roofs. There was a single-storey porch at the centre of the south-eastern elevation. After 1880 the school accepted only boys as students.
The Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan of c.1903 records the church building as a Mission Room. In 1905 the school building became the Church of St. Edmund, King and Martyr and a number of alterations to the fabric were subsequently made, including construction of two aisles and the conversion of the single-storey porch into a tower. Internally the building had a timber arch brace roof resting on timber beams supported by hexagonal brick columns. There was a rood screen in front of the high altar and the side aisles had small chapels at their west ends.
The church closed in 1978 and the building was subsequently used as commercial premises.

Bishop's House, located on the north side of Clifton Hill. The building was the Parsonage House and was constructed in 1711.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/14/776).

KNOWN_AS: Clifton Hill Cottage, Constitution Hill, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC:
Clifton Hill Cottage, located on the southern side of Constitution Hill, Clifton. The building was constructed in 1715 and is a two-storey rendered house.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/14/883).

No.3 Clifton Wood Road, located on the northern side of Clifton Wood Road. The building was constructed as one of a pair with No.4 Clifton Wood Road some time in the first half of the eighteenth century, and was in existence by the time of de Wilstar's survey of Clifton of 1746.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/817).

No.4 Clifton Wood Road, located on the northern side of Clifton Wood Road. The building was constructed as one of a pair with No.3 Clifton Wood Road some time in the first half of the eighteenth century, and was in existence by the time of de Wilstar's survey of Clifton of 1746.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/817).

Elm Farm, located on the north-western side of Bridgwater Road. The farm was in existence by the time of the Bedminster tithe survey and consisted of a farmhouse on Bridgwater road.  The farmhouse is of two storeys with a double-depth plan and is constructed of Lias limestone in a random rubble construction with ashlar detailing.
The farmhouse has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/57/399).

Icehouse, located on the northern side of Southmead Road. The quarry was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.08) published in 1881. The structure appears to have survived into the twentieth century but the later revisions of the Ordnance Survey plan do not mark the structure as an icehouse. The site was subsequently redeveloped.

Eastfield Quarry, located on the southern side of Southmead Road. The quarry was extant by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.08) published in 1881 and measured approximately 195 metres from north-east to south-west at that date. There was also a limekiln (SMR 3932) at its northern end.
The quarry was apparently no longer being worked by the end of the First World War and part at the southern end had been infilled by the end of the First World War. The remainder has since been infilled and the site now forms open space on the western side of Henleaze Road. Buildings associated with quarry on Southmead Road, together with the limekiln, are extant.
Reservoir at Durdham Down. The reservoir was created by the Bristol Water Works company and was in existence by 1884.

KNOWN_AS: Ropewalk at St. John's Lane, Lower Knowle
MONUMENT_DESC: Ropewalk located on the south side of St. John's Lane, Lower Knowle. The ropewalk was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.06) published in 1894 and measured 86 metres from north-west to south-east and was 22 metres wide. The ropewalk appears to have gone out of use by the beginning of the twentieth century and by the time of the Ordnance Survey third edition plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXV.08) published in 1916 it had been turned into a minature rifle range.

This farm was recorded in 1830 (Ordnance Survey 1:63360), but its position seems to be respected on the ground by blocks of ridge and furrow, so it may be of medieval origin. This site almost certainly retains archaeological deposits and structures relating to the occupation of the site from the medieval period onwards.

KNOWN_AS: Site of nineteenth-century buildings, Hallen Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC:
Site of nineteenth-century buildings, at Severn Road, Hallen Marsh. The site is recorded in 1769 (B. Donne Map of the country 11 miles around Bristol), although not by a 1773 survey of the area (BRO 29351). The 1841 tithe survey shows three enclosures containing two buildings. Only one building remained on the site by the time of the 1915 Ordnance Survey map, however. A square hedge enclosure was still in existence in 1975. 
The site was investigated by Wessex Archaeology during archaeological work associated with the construction of the Second Severn Crossing and found to date at the earliest to the late eighteenth-century (Barnes et al 1993, 22).
The site (Area 1; Site 17) was visited by R. G. Jackson during the course of a desk-based assessment (SMR 20081) of areas of Bristol City Council owned land north of Avonmouth in December 1996. It was found that no evidence of the buildings or enclosures remained. The site has probably been completely destroyed by works associated with the construction of the bridge carrying Severn Road across the M49 motorway (Jackson 1997).

KNOWN_AS: Site of a house at Hallen Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: The site of a house, Hallen Marsh. The house is recorded by Benjamin Donne's 1769 Map of the 11 miles around Bristol.

KNOWN_AS: Sea wall, south-south-west of Stup Pill
MONUMENT_DESC: A long low bank 650 metres long running along warth from 150 metres south of Stup Pill. Probably remnant sea walling.

KNOWN_AS: Pond to the south-east of Heath Farm, Brislington
MONUMENT_DESC: A pond lying to the south-east of Heath Farm (SMR20526). The pond is recorded by the Brislington tithe survey of 1846 as lying some 60 metres to the south-east of the farmhouse. The Ordnance Survey 1st edition plan of 1884 indicates that the western and southern sides of the pond had been screened by the planting of mixed coniferous and broad-leaved trees. The pond now appears to have been infilled.

Cherry Orchard Farm, the site of which is located on the south side of Stockwood Road. The farm was in existence by the time of the Brislington tithe survey in 1846 and is also recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition 1:2500 scale plan of Brislington made in 1884. This indicates that the farm consisted of a farmhouse and an outbuilding to its south. The farm was demolished in the 1950s. The site of the farmhouse now lies largely beneath the house and garden of No.507 Stockwood Road, although the northern end extends beyond the plot, under the footway on the southern side of the junction of Stockwood Road and Hungerford Road.
Earls Mead House, located on the north-western side of Pennywell Road. The building was in existence by 1828 but had apparently been demolished by the early 1880s.

Netham Works, located on the west side of the river Avon and the north side of the Feeder canal. The works was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.25) surveyed in 1882 when the works buildings were at the eastern end of the site while the western end was covered by tips. The site was owned by the United Alkali Company and manufactured ammonium nitrate during the First World War (Cocroft 2000, 278).
The part of the works to the west of Fireclay Road was sold by ICI to the City of Bristol for £40,000 on 31 December 1951. The site was subsequently landscaped to form the Netham Recreation Ground.

Netham Lodge, located on the west side of Netham Road. The lodge was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.25) surveyed in 1882. The building survived into the twentieth century but was ssubsequently demolished.

Netham Cooperage, located on the west side of Netham Road. The cooperage is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.25) surveyed in 1882. The cooperage survived into the twentieth century but was subsequently demolished.

KNOWN_AS: Parish boundary marker stone at Whiteladies Road
MONUMENT_DESC: A parish boundary marker stone located against the south wall of No.1 Cotham Hill, in the area in front of No.115 Whiteladies Road.

Hazelton Farm, located some 360 metres to the west of Gloucester Road, Horfield. The farm was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.12) published in 1880. It had been demolished and the site redeveloped for housing by the early twentieth century, however. The site of the farm now lies beneath Nos.22-26 Berkshire Road.

KNOWN_AS: Baptist Chapel, No.66 St. John's Lane, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC:
Baptist Chapel, No.66 St. John's Lane, Bedminster,. located on the north-western side of St. John's Lane. The chapel appears to have been constructed c1900 and is a rendered single-storey structure of brick. The building had a pair of parallel timber pitched pantile roofs. There were small lancet windows in the south-west and north-east walls of the building and a large lancet window in the north-west wall. There was a roughly contemporary two-storey element at the rear of the chapel, although the function of this was not clear. At first-floor the north-eastern end of the building had surviving dado-height panelling, suggesting that it may have been used as public space of some sort.
The chapel was subsequently altered internally and the main, south-east facing, elevation was rebuilt as a shopfront in the later twentieth century.
The chapel was demolished in c.2000 and the site redeveloped.

Field House, located some 400 metres to the south-west of Heath House. The house was in existence by the late eighteenth century when it appears to have been recorded by a plan of the Heath House estate. At the time of the Stapleton tithe survey of 1839 (BRO EP/A/32/35) the building was owned by William Hillier Bailey and occupied by James Lorymer. The building survived into the twentieth century but had been demolished by 1946 (CPE/UK/2157 Frame 5132) and the site was subsequently developed for housing. The site of the building now lies mainly in the rear garden of No.25 Rousham Road.
Upper Terrace, located on the south-western side of Lawrence Weston Road. The terrace is a row of cottages which were in existence by the time of the Henbury tithe survey of 1841 (BRO EP/A/32/22).

KNOWN_AS: Pound at Chapel Lane, Lawrence Weston
MONUMENT_DESC: A pound located on the south-eastern side of Chapel Lane, Lawrence Weston. The pound is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.03) published in 1881 but had been removed by the beginning of the twentieth century.

KNOWN_AS: Tollhouse at Blackbird Gate, Stapleton Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Tollhouse at Blackbird Gate, located on the north-western side of Stapleton Road. The building was in existence by the time of the Plumley and Ashmead plan of Bristol of 1828. The ground floor of the building has been extended and converted into a shop.

Kensington Baptist Chapel, located on the north-western side of Stapleton Road. The chapel is a structure of freestone ashlar and is designed in a classical style. It was constructed in the late-nineteenth century and is first recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.13) published in 1903.
The chapel has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/37/1250).

No.4 Cherry Lane, located on the northern side of Cherry Lane. The building was a three-storey, single bay house and was in existence by 1746 when the first occupant was assessed for Land Tax (Bryant 2003, 5). It had been purchased by Henry Gwyer by 1851 (BRO 04250(1); Bryant 2003, 6). The house was still extant in 1913 but it had been demolished by 1923 and the site redeveloped as a mason's yard.

No.6 Cherry Lane, located on the northern side of Cherry Lane. The building was a two-storey, single bay house and was in existence by 1722 when the first occupant, "Nevil [of] Bath", was assessed for Land Tax (Bryant 2003, 5). It had been purchased by Henry Gwyer by 1851 (BRO 04250(1); Bryant 2003, 6). The house was apparently still extant in the 1950s but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped. The house was still extant in 1913 but it had been demolished by 1923 and the site redeveloped as a mason's yard.

No.8 Cherry Lane, located on the northern side of Cherry Lane. The building was a three-storey, single bay house and was in existence by 1722 when the first occupant, Mrs Jackson, was assessed for Land Tax (Bryant 2003, 5). The house was apparently still extant in the 1950s but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped. The house was still extant in 1913 but it had been demolished by 1949 when the site was vacant.

No.10 Temple Street, located at the northern end of Temple Street, on its east side. Attached. 3 storeys and attic; gabled front; no jettying; 2-window range. The lower two storeys replaced by a large vehicle entrance, with a pedestrian entrance on the left. A pair of 6-light mullion and transom windows to the second-floor, with a 2-light attic window.

Scotland House Farm, located on the south side of Stockwood Lane, Brislington. The farm was in existence by the time of the Brislington tithe survey and is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.12) published in 1884. Most of the farm buildings appear still to be extant and have been converted to dwellings.

No.7 Temple Street, located on the south side of Narrow Plain. Attached. 3 storeys and attic; cross-gabled. Lateral stack on east wall. The front elevation not recorded. A rendered rear elevation, a stair projection with hipped roof on the right, otherwise a 2-window range. Sashes to first and second floors of the main rear wall; single 2-light casement in a reduced-size embrasure to the attic. The windows to the first and second floors of stair-turret also reduced in size. The ground-floor of the rear elevation is not recorded. Appears to be late C17, but possibly early C18. Still standing in April 1963, but removed for the widening of Temple Way.

No.16 Castle Street, located on the north side of Castle Street. The building was a jettied, gabled house of two storeys and attic with a 1-window range. It was almost certainly constructed as part of the redevelopment of the site of Bristol Castle after its demolition in the late 1650s.
By the nineteenth century the ground floor was a shop. Shop windows with a recessed central entrance. a canted first-floor bay with sashes. A sash to the attic. Both upper floors were jettied. Lateral stack(s).
The building was destroyed by bombing on 24 November 1940.

No.38 High Street, now beneath No.35-38 High Street. The building had four storeys and a single bay. The ground floor was used as a shop and the upper three had sash windows. The building appears to have been refronted during the eighteenth or early nineteenth-century. This may have concealed an earlier building behind.

No.23 Castle Street, located on the north side of Castle Street. The building was a jettied, gabled house of three storeys and attic with a 1-window range. It was almost certainly constructed as part of the redevelopment of the site of Bristol Castle after its demolition in the late 1650s.
By the nineteenth century the ground floor was a shop. One bay each to the first and second floors, sashes. Sash to attic. Decorative bargeboards. Lateral stack(s).
The building was destroyed by bombing on 24 November 1940.
No.7 Ellbridge Passage. House. Attached to the west. No.7, Ellbridge Passage, on the north-west corner of same. 2 storeys and attic; half-hipped roof; 1-window range. Removed c.1935 (Street's notes).

POSTAL_ADDRESS: N.C.P. Car Park, Lower Castle Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Nos.11 to 15 Ellbroad Street, located on the north side of Ellbroad Street. Attached. C17. 2 storeys and attics; gabled fronts; jettied; 1-window ranges. Incorporated into part of the works of George Adlam & Sons, engineers and ironfounders by the 1930s, and much altered as a result. The remains of a first-floor bay to No.13. Nearly all demolished by February 1938 (Notes by P. E. W. Street).

Rennison's Bath, Montpelier, located on the north-western side of Bath Buildings. The bath was established in the late 1740s. It was recorded by the 1828 survey of Bristol by John Plumley and George Ashmead which shows the bath forming the south-east end of a larger water feature on Cutler's Mill Brook (probably a partially silted millpond serving Cutler's Mills to the north-west) orientated from north-west to south-east. The bath was surrounded by buildings but it is not clear which were ancillary structures. However, the Old England public house is believed to have formed part of the complex by the early-nineteenth century and there was also an associated tea garden (Yorkston 1993). The bath was still operating in the early twentieth century and came into the ownership of Bristol Corporation in 1908. The baths closed in 1917 and the site was subsequently redeveloped.

Cutler's Mill, Montpelier, located at the northern end of Cheltenham Road. The mill was extant by 1828 but is likely to have an earlier origin. A large pond to the south-east on Cutler's Mill Brook appears to have been originally at least 160 metres long but was largely silted up by 1828. The mill itself consisted of a complex of buildings on the east side of Cutler's Mill Brook. The mill buildings had been demolished and the site redeveloped by the early 1880s.

Harts Farm, Bedminster. The farm was located on the western side of Parson Street. The farm was in existence by the time of the Bedminster tithe survey of 1841 (BRO EP/A/32/8) and in the second half of the nineteenth century was rented by Richard Withers, the son of John Beard Withers of Pigeonhouse Farm (BSMR 5165).
The farm survived into the early twentieth century but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped for housing.

KNOWN_AS: Surface air raid shelter at Nos.3a-4a St. Peter's Rise, Bishopsworth
MONUMENT_DESC:
A domestic surface air raid shelter of the traverse entry type located 11 metres to the south of No.3a St. Peter's Rise, Bishopsworth. The shelter measured 3.86 metres long by 2.33 metres wide and was 2.12 metres high. It was constructed of brick in English bond and had a flat reinforced concrete roof. Narrow metal vents below the roof in the east, south and west walls provided ventilation. The internal toilet with a soil vent pipe was located in the south-east corner of the shelter.
The shelter was been converted to a storage building after the Second World War by the removal of the internal blast wall of the traverse entry and the insertion of a window in the west facing elevation (Brett 2003).
Photographs of the shelter are held in the SMR Collection of Ground-based photographs, numbers 1865-1878.

KNOWN_AS: Base Fort, constructed for the entertainment of Elizabeth I, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC: Base Fort, located some 300 metres to the south of the river Avon. It was constructed in 1574 and was the smaller of two forts built for a three-day long mock assault by the Bristol militia, the centrepiece of the entertainments laid on for Elizabeth I during her visit to Bristol between 14 and 17 August that year (Fissel 2001, 62). The fort was sited on a mound of earth approximately 28 metres in diameter. Its form is not known, although the Great Audit records that it was covered with cloth. During the assaults was apparently attacked by pioneers and infantry and captured on the first night (J. Bettey (ed.) Two Tudor visits to Bristol. In McGrath 1985, 7). The earth mound was apparently still extant in 1828 but was subsequently levelled and most of its site had been developed for housing by the early 1880s.

Westmoreland Farm, located on the northern side of Crow Lane, at its junction with Henbury Road. The farmhouse was constructed in the eighteenth century and formed part of the estate of the local Sampson family which was built up from the late seventeenth century. The farm was let to William Taylor at the time of the Westbury-on-Trym tithe survey of 1841 (BRO EP/A/32/41). The stables were built in the nineteenth century.
The farm was subject to compulsory purchase in the late 1940s and the farmhouse and ancillary buildings were rented as a council house to the McEwen Smith family. The family purchased the farm buildings under the right-to-buy in the 1980s.
The farmhouse and the stables have Grade II listings (Listed Building numbers 901-1/21/1338 and 901-1/21/1339 respectively).

The Rookery, Brislington.  The property dated back to the 17th century when William Payne sold his estate that included a house which later became known as The Rooker to Tobias Daniel.  In 1689, the property passed to his daughter Joan on her marriage to Edward Lyne, a mercer and a Quaker.  A Quaker burial ground (SMR 20533) was created around this time on land adjacent to the property.  In 1812, James Ireland is recorded as purchasing the house and land from William Maberley.  In 1900, The Rookery was occupied by Mr. Stephens, Steward to the Fox family, and therefore the property must have been purchased by Dr. Edward Long Fox in the early part of the 19th century as he was buried in the adjoining private cemetery in 1835.  A castellated wall enclosed the burial ground. (SMR 20536)..
In the 1940s, Norman Reece set up the Brislington Engineering Co. Ltd. on the site, and the house known as The Rookery was demolished in the early 1970s.

KNOWN_AS: Bowling Green of The White Hart Inn, Bath Hill, Brislington
MONUMENT_DESC: A bowling green to the rear of the White Hart Inn, Brislington.
Parish Lock Up, Brislington.  This was situated on Church Hill and was recorded by the Brislington Tithe Survey of 1846.

Linton Farm, Brislington Hill, Brislington.  Referred in some documents as Linden Farm and was situated adjacent to the White Hart Inn on its eastern side. Although there is no documentary evidence regarding the property, the house is shown in a drawing made in 1826 by Rowbotham (SMR 20549) depicting a general view of Brislington Hill. The property was noted for supplying milk to Brislington village and to several companies in the city of Bristol in the late-nineteenth or early twentieth centuries. Francis Bishop lived at the farm and ran the dairy business from 1883-1903, and after his death the business was taken over by his son-in-law Thomas Fuller. The farm was owned by the Clayfield-Ireland family and when the estate was broken up in 1925, the Fullers left. The dairy business ended and the house was demolished in 1926. The dairy was in a wing of the farmhouse and was a large, whitewashed room with a stone floor. Cowsheds and pig sties lay to the south of the farm and formed two sides of the farmyard. A large ash tree stood near the entrance gate to the yard.

Knowle Gate, across Wells Road at the junction with St. John's Lane. The toll gate was apparently established in the early eighteenth century by the Bristol turnpike trust. A renewal of the trustees powers by Parliament in February 1749 prompted local rioting, and in July 1749 Bedminster Gate was one of a number of turnpike gates destroyed by labourers with blackened faces who called themselves "Jack a Lents" (Latimer 1893, 274). The tollgate was still extant in 1828 but was subsequently removed.

KNOWN_AS: Late Bronze Age possible saltmaking site at Kites Corner, Avonmouth
MONUMENT_DESC: A Late Bronze Age possible saltmaking site at Kites Corner, Avonmouth. The site was excavated in 1997 and comprised a surface of burnt stone and charcoal on the surface of a stabilisation horizon in the alluvial clay. Radiocarbon dating suggests a date c1200BC for the surface (Locock 2001).

Home Farm, Bishopsworth, located approximately 50 metres to the south of Kings Head Lane. In the mid-1890s the farm was worked by Edwin Wyatt and his diary for 1895 is held by Bristol Record Office (BRO 41450/X/3).

Ashton Cinema located on the south west side of North Street, Bedminster, on corner of Raleigh Road. The cinema opened in 1914 as the Ashton Cinema, but later became the Plaza. The building became a shop in 1961 (Winstone 1972, pl.230).

Tramway Depot, located on the eastern side of Sheene Road The depot was constructed in the late-nineteenth century, and was used during the first half of the twentieth century. The building was subsequently demolished.

Western Tannery. The tannery was recorded by Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 Survey of Bristol as lying on the current East Street frontage, between it and the Malago. The boundary of this tannery was fossilised in the boundaries of the buildings on East Street. The later area was east of the Malago, as seen on the 1950 Ordnance Survey plan.

No.1 Granary, the earliest of five reinforced concrete granaries in the Royal Edward Dock, was built at the same time as the dock in 1908 and formed part of the first bulk grain handling installation in the port. The building is 220 feet long, 71 feet wide, and approximately 85 feet high. The north end housed intake elevators and weighers, the middle is occupied by 65 rectangular storage silos, and at the south end there was floor storage on six floors, later given over to additional handling equipment. Designed to the Hennebique system by L. G. Mouchel. Out of use 1983. Builders John Aird & Co.

Wills Factory, located on the southern side of Hartcliffe Way. The factory and an associated office block were constructed between 1970 and 1975. The office block was designed by the American architectural practice Skidmore, Owings, Merrill.
The factory building was demolished in the 1990s.
The office building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/57/10063).

KNOWN_AS: Wills Factory office block, Hartcliffe Way
MONUMENT_DESC:
Wills office building, located on the southern side of Hartcliffe Way. The building was a two-storey podium standing over a lake designed by the American firm Skidmore, Owings and Merrill.
