It was constructed between 1970 and 1975 and has been noted as the most ambitious use of COR-TEN steel in England. It was the European Headquarters office building for Wills (Aldous 1979, 28).
In 1999 to 2000 the office building was stripped of asbestos, and the concrete partition walls, lift shafts and other elements of the structure were removed at the same time to leave only the COR-TEN steel frame and the floor slabs standing.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/57/10063).
Water-maze designed by Peter Milner in 1984. The design of the maze is based on a roof boss in St Mary Redcliffe Church.

Belgium Pit, located in the triangular plot of land formed by Speedwell Road, Whiteway Road and Duncombe Road. The pithead appears to have been at the centre of the site. Most of the site, including the pithead now lies beneath the gardens of Nos.2-16 Duncombe Road.

Constructed as a link for the Bristol Port & Pier Railway Company to the main network, includes the 1738 yard long tunnel under Clifton Down. Stations at Clifton Down, Redland and Montpelier, and still (1994) in use.
A battery was placed in this position in 1643 & 1645. {1}
Site of the main parliamentary camp and battery during the siege of 1645. {1}

Smithy located on the southern side of Bishop Road, Bishopston. It was constructed in the late-nineteenth century. The building is a two-storey brick structure with a pitched pantile roof. The forge was located at the eastern end of the building against the south wall.
The building was converted to a single house in 2004 and largely reconstructed as a result of structural failures.

A rocket battery, or Z Battery, dating to the Second World War located at Bishopsworth. The battery formed part of a group of batteries which fired unguided rockets to create a box defence (Roberts, 1981 65). It was in existence by the end of 1941, opened 11/1941 (David Hunt, pers com). The exact location of the battery is not currently known.

The Vandyke Cinema located on the south side of Fishponds Road. The cinema was designed by W. H.Watkins for the Vandyke Picture Theatre Company and built by Frank Wilkins (Ewins 1984, 27). The building was constructed in red brick with 742 seats in the stalls and 332 seats on the balcony (Anderson, 1983, 38). The cinema opened in 1926 and was taken over by Associated British Cinemas in the 1930s. The building became a Mecca Bingo Hall in 1973 (Ewins 1984, 27) and is currently a public house (18/11/2004).

No.1½ Prince Street. The building was a two-storey, single-bay structure with a hipped roof. The building was refronted in the early nineteenth-century. The ground floor was a shopfront with the entrance doorway on the north side. There was a single sash in the upper floor. It had a hipped pantiled roof.
It is not clear whether the building was a part of the Merchants Arms by the end of the nineteenth-century, although it appears to have been a separate structure. The street directory for 1882 indicates that it was then a grocer's shop run by Elizabeth Hawkins.
The building was demolished c.1937 to make way for the construction of the inner circuit road.

Holy Cross Roman Catholic chapel in Victoria Street, opposite the junction with Avon Street. A temporary chapel was erected on the site in 1872 as a replacement for the chapel in Nelson's Gardens in Bedminster. A subscription was raised in 1893 to build a new church although only the west front and nave were completed. The church was dedicated on 2 December 1894 by Bishop Brownlow.
The building was a later ninteenth-century stone chapel with a pitched tiled roof. There was a large arched window in the centre of the upper part of the facade which was flanked by two smaller lancet windows. On either side of the entrance were two buttresses, the upper parts of which turned into pinnacles which projected above the roofline. There were two skylights on the north side of the roof.
The building was later converted into a car showroom and was demolished c.1940 to make way for the construction of Temple Way.

KNOWN_AS: Preaching Cross, St. Mary Redcliffe Churchyard
MONUMENT_DESC: Preaching cross in St. Mary Redcliffe Churchyard. The cross stood in the churchyard by the south transept of the church and was erected in the medieval period. Its most famous use was when Roger Edgeworth delivered eight Lenten sermons in 1558 (). The cross survived into the early eighteenth century but was removed in 1763 on the instructions of a churchwarden.

KNOWN_AS: Possible guest house, St. Augustine's Abbey
POSTAL_ADDRESS: Cathedral of the Holy and Undivided Trinity, College Green
MONUMENT_DESC: A twelfth-century building was identified by excavation at the west end of Bristol Cathedral in 1992 (BUAD 1685). Only two walls, the northern and southern, were recorded and the structure was built of Brandon Hill Grit and measured only c. 2 to 3 metres wide. It was orientated east-west and appears to have originally continued under the south-west tower of the nave. The condition of the building remaining beneath the cathedral is unknown. The building was interpreted by the excavator as a possible guest house for St. Augustine's Abbey.
Temple Church Mission Hall. Part of the monument was identified during an archaeological evaluation between Temple Way and Temple Gardens in 1997.

A stone building dating to the late Norman period was excavated at the site of Nos.1-2 Tower Lane in 1979-80 (BUAD 320) in advance of re-development of the site. The building was constructed (on the evidence of a coin of Henry I set in the south wall and pottery sherds in the foundation trench for the wall facing on to Tower Lane) measured approximately 26 metres by approximately 9 metres wide and was interpreted as a first-floor hall. At the west end of the building was a small cellar. Outside the building, at its south-east corner, was a small and narrow structure with a drain set in its south side. This was interpreted as a garderobe.
The building was demolished towards the end of the twelfth century.

KNOWN_AS: Welsh Baptist Chapel, Upper Maudlin Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Welsh Particular Bapist Chapel, located on the southern side of Upper Maudlin Street. The plot was sold to the trustees of the chapel in 1839 and the chapel was built, of Pennant sandstone rubble in 1840-1841. It was recorded by the 1880s 1st edition Ordnance Survey map. The chapel was given new furniture in 1901 and continued in use until its closure in c.1970. It was demolished in 1978 to allow construction of an underpass to the Bristol Royal Infirmary beneath Upper Maudlin Street (Dawson, 1982 43). The entire plan of the building was recorded during an archaeological excavation in 1999 directed by R. Jackson (BUAD 3399).
Horfield Brewery, located on the eastern side of Horfield Road. The brewery is shown by the Ordnance Survey first edition map of the 1880s.

The gasometer between Upper Maudlin Street and Horfield Road.
Much of the site of the gasometer is currently in use as a car ark for the Bristol Royal Informary complex. The southern part of the gasometer base was built of stone and stood approximately three metres high and two metres wide. This was demolished in late August 1997 as part of the construction of the Bristol Children's Hospital.

Henbury Court, located some 300 metres to the north-east of Henbury village. The building appears to have been constructed in the seventeenth century. It was orientated north-east to south-west and stood in a large formal garden. The building survived into the early twentieth century but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped for apartments. The site of the building now lies largely to the north and west of the apartment blocks however.

Quarry, located some 70 metres to the west of Wells Road, Knowle. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.07) published in 1886 which indicates that the working face was on its western side. At this date the quarry measured 95 metres north-west to south-east by roughly 35 metres wide. However, by the time of the second edition plan published in 1905 the working face had moved westwards to the edge of the land parcel and the previously quarried area had been infilled, presumably with the quarry waste. The quarry has now been infilled and the houses of Newlyn Walk developed on top of it.

Langton Court. Langton Court was built by the Langton family and was at one time owned by Earl Temple. Although most of the house was demolished in 1900, a small part survives with features dating from the 16th century. The Langton Court Arms now stands on the site. Langton Court was once known as Brislington Farm but became Langton Court in 1783 upon the marriage of William Gore to Bridget Langton,  into whose ownership the Manor of Brislington passed. 
Langton Court was a seven bay, three storeyed building dating from around 1650. The windows of the four outer bays on the ground floor are floor length, while those either side of the front door are the same size as the seven windows of the first floor. The second floor comprises three Dutch gables characteristic of the period with curved sides and culminating in an apex. There is an extensive network of chimney stacks. Attached to the main building is an 'L-shaped' two storeyed building with crenellations.
A summer house in the grounds was still standing in 1853.
Small rectangular earthwork enclosure against the east side of drove 100 metres north x east of Redborn Gout.{1}{2}{3}

KNOWN_AS: Circular platform south-west of Seabank Power Station
MONUMENT_DESC:
Small circular platform, less than 20 metres in diameter, with a bank around outer lip. Possibly modern, ? WWII. This feature could well be a bomb crater.
The site (Area 1; Site 13) was identified and visited by R. G. Jackson during the course of a desk-based assessment (SMR 20081) of areas of Bristol City Council owned land north of Avonmouth in December 1996. The area was overgrown, but no trace of the feature could be found.

KNOWN_AS: Railway turntable to the south of Green Lane, Avonmouth
MONUMENT_DESC: Railway turntable located some 16 metres to the south of the southern end of Green Lane, Avonmouth. The turntable appears to have been removed but the turntable pit is extant.

KNOWN_AS: Site of crashed aircraft, on the north-east side of Mere Bank Rhyne
MONUMENT_DESC: Crashed twin-engine aircraft against the north-east side of Mere Bank Rhyne. The starboard engine and tailplane are missing.

KNOWN_AS: Deserted farm site, north of Poplar Farm
MONUMENT_DESC: Ruined building and derelict enclosures 400 metres north of Poplar Farm suggesting a deserted farm site. {1}{2}

KNOWN_AS: Possible enclosures in the playing fields of St. Bede's School, Lawrence Weston
MONUMENT_DESC: Marks in the grass of the playing fields of St. Bede's Roman Catholic School, Lawrence Weston Road indicate a limited area of small sub-rectangular enclosures with the possible junction of trackways {1}{2}.
Possible abortive coalmine. {1}

Holmwood House and its gardens, located on the south side of Holmwood Gardens. The house was constructed in the later nineteenth century, and was altered and extended in the early twentieth century by Sir George Oatley. A garden was created by Dr Stanley Badock between 1905-1910 (Harding & Lambert 1991, 20). The planting included specimen trees, a formal pool, a balustraded curved terrace backed by yews, a summer house and pergola in Arts and Crafts style, a rose garden and a cascade, now dry. A section of the garden was planted as wild (Harding & Lambert 1994, 87-88). Part of the garden has been built over and the kitchen gardens and water tower are now in separate ownership.

The Embassy Cinema located at the corner of Queen's Road and Queen's Avenue. The cinema was commissioned by Ewan Davies of the Avenue Cinema Company and was built by Frank Wilkins to a design by W. H. Watkins at a cost of £2,099.9s.0d (Ewins 1984, 28) It opened in 1933 as possibly Bristol's largest single screen cinema with 2100 seats including 700 on the balcony (Anderson, 1983 55; 76). The building was demolished in 1964 and the site is now occupied by Embassy House.

Bedminster Town Hall located on the west side of Cannon Street. The hall was built in 1891. It was converted to a cinema by Ralph Pringle in 1909 and continued in use as a cinema until 1954 (Anderson 1983, 16; Winstone 1971, pl.178). The façade was subsequently heavily altered.
The building is still extant and is currently (08/12/2004) in use as a furniture store.

The Bristol North Baths on west side of Gloucester Road. The building was constructed c1912 and is of red brick with limestone dressings and a slate hipped roof. Between 1922 and 1936 the building was used as a cinema in the winter months by putting a temporary floor over the pool (Winstone 1971, pl.173).
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/32/406).
Hotwells Cinema, located on the north side of Hotwell Road. The cinema opened 1915 and had 450 seats. It was closed c.1939  (Anderson 1983, 22). The building is extant.

The Globe Cinema, located on the north side of Church Road, Redfield, at the junction with Jane Street. The cinema opened in 1914 and had 1123 seats. It had a spherical front with an entrance on the corner of Jane Street and Church Road. The cinema closed in 1973 and was demolished in the mid-1970s (Anderson 1983, 22).

School, located on the east side of Beam Street, Redfield. The school was constructed at the end of the nineteenth century, between the early 180s and 1903 and is first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.13) published in 1903.
The building is extant.

Tramway depot, located on the south-eastern side of Stapleton Road. The depot was in existence by the early 1880s when it was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.09). It continued to operate into the twentieth century but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped.

A Primitive Methodist Chapel, located at the junction of Fishponds Road and Stapleton Road. The chapel was in existence by the early 1880s and survived into the early twentieth century. It was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped.

Eastville Stadium, located some 100 metres to the north-west of Stapleton Road. The sports ground was constructed at the end of the nineteenth century and was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 scale plan of 1903 with a stand on the southern side. By the middle of the First World War a larger stand had been constructed on the north side of the site and that on the southern had been considerably enlarged. During the 1980s the stadium was used for greyhound racing. It was demolished in the late 1990s and the site redeveloped.

KNOWN_AS: Arbour or root house at Wick House, Brislington
MONUMENT_DESC: An arbour or root-house located in the grounds of Wick House, Brislington. The arbour appears to have been set within a band of trees immediately to the east of Wick Cottage, on the crest of the valley overlooking Brislington Brook. It was in existence by the mid-1820s and was recorded by a drawing by T. L. Rowbotham of c.1826-1827. The arbour was a circular open-sided structure, approximately 3 metres in diameter, with a conical thatched roof resting on arches supported by columns with vegetation trained over them (Stoddard 1981, 24). The nature of its construction is therefore unclear. The structure survived into the early twentieth century but was subsequently demolished.

The Portwall, a town wall enclosing the suburb or Redcliff and the Temple Fee to the south-east of Temple Church. The wall was constructed in the thirteenth century and ran from a terminal tower, Tower Harratz (BUAD 671M), at Temple Back across Temple Meads and along Portwall Lane to Redcliff Back. There were a number of interval towers or bastions along the length of the wall, and there was a water gate (BUAD 1418M), close to Tower Harratz. The wall was also pierced by gates for vehicular traffic at the southern ends of Temple Street (Temple Gate - BUAD 927M) and Redcliff Street (Redcliff Gate - BUAD 1211M).
The wall has been recorded during archaeological excavation in several locations. It was constructed in Pennant sandstone bonded in a light-brown sandy mortar and measured 2 metres wide. Its foundations extended several metres into the underlying alluvial clay but none of the excavations has so far found any evidence for supporting piles. In front of the wall was a berm which was approximately 15 metres wide. Beyond this was a substantial ditch, known as Portwall ditch which was around 15 metres wide and up to 5 metres deep (BUAD 312; 408).
The wall was altered and reinforced during the English Civil Wars of the 1640s and the excavations of the Portwall ditch (BUAD 312; 408) also found evidence for recutting of the ditch, probably associated with the refortification of the wall during the 1640s. A survey of 1643 records cannon at Tower Harratz, Temple Gate and the adjacent tower and at Redcliff Gate (Roy 1975, 261-263). Assaults were made on the Portwall by Royalist forces in 1643 and by the New Model Army in 1645. The wall was not breached and after the wars appears to have remained largely extant - it was recorded by James Millerd's 1673 map of Bristol - and the reputation of its strength was a causal factor in encouraging the Monmouth rebels not to attack the south side of Bristol in the mid-1680s.
The Portwall appears to have remained standing into the post-medieval period and been gradually incorporated into other structures. No part of the wall now survives above ground but it is known to be extant for considerable stretches along its length. During excavation and evaluation in several places the wall has been located close to the ground surface. The eastern half of the Portwall was retained in situ in the Temple Quay development and a scheme of paving and lighting to mark its line was designed by the Irish artist John Aiken.

A limekiln of late eighteenth- or nineteenth-century date excavated at Water Lane in 1971 (BUAD 314). The kiln was a perpetual or draw-kiln roughly 5.7 metres square and was built of stone bonded in a white lime mortar with a brick lined furnace. In the base were four arched passages to allow the lime to be removed from the kiln, and two of these were found to be blocked with clay. The surviving base of the kiln stood 1 metre high (Good, 1987 66-69).

Magpie Park, laid out on the space created by the culverting of the Frome in 1892-93, between the two sides of Colston Avenue and between St. Augustine's Bridge and the end of Rupert Street. It succeeded the temporary Industrial and Fine Art Exhibition hall.
The park had square stone entrance pillars with tall lamp posts on top at either end. It was surrounded by railings, and shrubs lined the inside of these. Trees were planted along the sides of the park to form an avenue and seating was placed at intervals. There was a bandstand at the north end of the park. The statue of Edward Colston was in the centre and that of Edmund Burke was at the south end. On the west side opposite the end of Colston Street were single storey brick-built public toilets which survived into the 1970s.
Traditionally the name of the park was derived by Bristolians from the Magpie paper which was published nearby (the city authorities failing to choose a name). The layout of the park was steadily eroded by alterations to the road layout of the Centre during the twentieth century, particularly those associated with the creation of the inner circuit road of the 1930s and further reorganisation in the 1950s.
Elements of the park survive at present [19/11/96], however. Three of the original London Plane trees are in situ, two adjacent by the cenotaph and the other to the south. In the area of the Colston statue too it is possible that part of the original paving layout is extant. The Colston statue itself has been moved two metres north of its original position, and the Burke statue has also been repositioned. There were surface air raid shelters in the area of the park during the second world war, and a bomb exploded in the area opposite St. Mary-on-the-Quay, destroying part of the roof of the Frome culvert.

The Austin Friary, otherwise Augustinian Friary. The friary was founded in 1313 on a site close to Temple Gate, to the west of the George Railway Hotel. The precinct may have been defined by Temple Street and the later-named Pipe Lane, Rose Street and Prince Eugene Lane. Little is currently known about the arrangement and form of the monastic buildings on the site, but it appears that they may not have been particularly extensive. An inventory made for dissolution of the house refers to the vestry, hall and kitchen.
The friary was dissolved on 10 September 1538 (Gairdner 1893, 125). The site was purchased by Maurice Dennys for £536 14s. in March 1544 (Gairdner & Brodie 1903, 174-175). Dennys immediately sold the site on to John Perte (Gairdner & Brodie 1903, 178).

Magdalen's or Redcliffe Almshouses, located on the southern side of Temple Gate. The almshouse is reputed to have been founded by Roger Magdalen of Nunney in Somerset during the middle ages. The building was aligned parallel with the street and measured approximately 23 metres from north-west to south-east and was 5.5 metres wide, with a garden plot to the rear.
From the Reformation the vestry of St. Mary Redcliffe managed the almshouse. The building is reported to have been rebuilt by the vestry in 1675 at a cost of £113 (Manchee 1831, 58) and on October 1700 the vestry appears to have entered into an agreement with the newly-created Corporation of the Poor. An inspection by officers of the Corporation in April 1705 found that "it was inhabited by rude disorderly people" (Manchee 1831, 57). The vestry continued to nominate poor parishioners to reside in the almshouse and to maintain the building, while the Corporation of the Poor provided an annual sum of £16 to the residents. In 1831 there were fourteen residents (Manchee 1831, 57).

Tower Harratz was the terminal tower of the town wall known as the Portwall (BUAD 1042M) which defended the suburbs of Redcliff and Temple. The tower was in existence by the time of the perambulation of the county of Bristol in 1373 in which it is named as "Tourharatz." It was a circular tower built of Pennant sandstone bonded in a mid-brown mortar and measuring 13 metres in diameter at foundation level. The tower was constructed around a core of clay, 5.4 metres across, with six clay spines (each roughly 1.6 metres wide) radiating from the centre (Jackson 1995). This core appeared to have been formed by cutting of the natural clay rather than by dumping of material on the site. The form of the tower above ground level is not clear.
The tower was still standing at the time of the English Civil War, when three cannon - 1 Saker and 2 Minions - were positioned on the tower (Roy 1975, 262). By the time of James Millerd's map of 1673 small scale development was taking place to the north, between the tower and river; archaeological excavation exposed a path around the tower which led to a slipway to the inside the line of the town wall, and Millerd shows tenements abutting it. The tower was still standing in 1695, when it was referred to in the lease for an adjacent property (BRO ETD 00020) and is believed to have been demolished in the eighteenth century when the Portwall was incorporated piecemeal into new building (Cox 1998). Seyer reports that parts of the tower remained in the 1820s but that these were in use elements of other buildings (Seyer 1823, 52). Probably during the later nineteenth century the remains of the tower were demolished to foundation level and buried beneath several metres of made ground.
The clay core was damaged by the excavation of a geotechnical trial pit through the centre of it in the early 1980s. This trial pit was archaeologically observed but no stonework was visible and the position of the tower was not confirmed until an archaeological field evaluation in 1994 (BUAD 462). The area of the tower was subject to archaeological excavation (BUAD 463), exposing the full plan of the structure. The site was redeveloped in 1998-1999 as a new office building for Bristol and West Building Society but the remains of the tower were retained beneath a courtyard within the new building (Jackson, 1994; Williams 1994-95, 74). An interpretative scheme was created within the courtyard.

KNOWN_AS: The Carpenters Arms, 13 St. James' Churchyard
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Carpenters Arms public house, No.13 St. James' Churchyard. The building was a gabled, jettied house of two storeys and attic with a 1-window range. It was of probable seventeenth-century date. The footprint of the building measured by 7 metres from north-west to south-east by approximately 4.25 metres wide. The main elevation faced west on to Haymarket and there was a central projecting bay. The fenestration at first-floor and attic level comprised sashes. The gabled roof was covered with clay tiles and the upper part of the gable appears to have been cut back to form a small hip. A painted signboard which projected slightly beyond the eaves was fixed to to the roof at the base of the hip. A substantial chimney stack, apparently shared with No.12 St. James' Churchyard attached to the south (BUAD 820M ), projected from the roof on the southern side of the building.
The building was demolished in 1953 or 1954 and its site now lies beneath the highway in The Haymarket.

KNOWN_AS: Bristol Fireclay Company works, Crew's Hole Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Brickworks on the north side of Crew's Hole Road, Crew's Hole. The brickworks was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883, and was operated by the Bristol Fireclay Company until 1912. The brickworks still shown by the 1949 1:2500 map.

Castle Sugar Refinery, Queen Street. The refiner was located on the west side of Queen Street and had frontages on the Avon and the surviving uncovered stretch of the castle moat. The refinery was bought by Wills, Young, and Co. in July 1870 after the failure of the joint-stock company which had perviously owned it. The new owners invested in the business, installing additional boilers and charcoal filters.
The process by which the sugar was refined was described in an article published in the Bristol Times and Mirror and reprinted in 1883 (Anon, 1883). The entrance to the works was on Queen Street and the raw sugar was bought into the first floor melting room, on the north side of the works by Queen Street bridge, where it was dissolved in water and boiled in "blow up" pans. The syrup was then released through a pipe into the room below where it was cleaned and decoloured through charcoal filters. The syrup was then pumped into vacuum pans for further heating and then cooled and the various grades of sugar crystals produced by spinning in centrifuges at 800 rpm. The site is now occupied by an office block built in the 1980s which is semi-basemented in part. No elements of the refinery are known to survive above ground and the archaeological stratification of the site is likely to have suffered at least some disturbance during the construction of the office block.

The Custom House, located on the north side of Queen Square (at the east corner of King William Avenue). Construction commenced in 1709 and the original building was burnt down during the 1831 Bristol Riots. It was rebuilt in 1836 to a design by Sidney Smirke.
The original building was of three storeys with a full-width portico carried on six columns; rusticated quoins; sashes to all openings, with tall first-floor windows with 12/12 panes, otherwise 8/8 panes to windows; aprons below all windows.
Limestone ashlar, with ridge and party wall stacks.
Double-depth plan. Neoclassical style. 2 storeys, attic and basement; 5-window range; symmetrical front. A large doorway has paired pilasters to an entablature, with a plinth above with raised ends, and a carving of the Royal Coat of Arms; 9-pane overlight and 2-leaf 4-panel door; tall semicircular-arched first-floor windows. Left-hand return has 3-window range, with 3/3-pane attic sashes set below the cornice, and basement windows with grille to pavement lights. Rear has projecting right-hand section, and gabled left-hand with semicircular-arched windows. There are traces in basement of the early 18th.century house destroyed in the riots, with tooled Pennant walls and timbers, and security doors.

Three houses. On the inside of the bend on old Baldwin Street. Each three storeys and attic, jettied, with gabled fronts. Brackets to first and second floors; attic fronts flush with second-floor fronts. Beyond right-hand property was that occupied by Whiting (Whitting), plumber, etc., in 1823, given as No.53 in the directories. Right-hand entrances to left and centre houses; right-hand house had entrances at centre and right. Oriel at first-floor of left house, 10-light with transom. Projections at same storey of right house, with large muti-paned window. Mixed windows to second-floors, with cross-window to right house. Small attic windows. It was reputed that the right-hand house, No.46, contained the room where Henry II was educated as a child. This building is illustrated separately, M.2224. In 1827 it was owned by Mr.Terrel, flax dresser of the Back, and let out as a lodging house to "the low Irish". On carrying out alterations, the removal of a stack of chimneys revealed some wall painting depicting a 16th.century (?) man with some text (M.2225 & 2225a). Various fragments of panelling were also discovered and recorded (M.2226-2228). A sketch plan of the house is given (M.2229). It is assumed that the finds were made on the first-floor of the house. The house consisted of a full-width front room, with fireplace on the back wall, and, to the right, a doorway leading to the rear room via a lobby. The rear room was of reduced width, but backed onto the rear of the adjacent property to the west, with their fireplaces back-to-back on the party wall.

People's Palace cinema, located on the north side of Baldwin Street. The building opened as a music hall and was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.11) published in 1903. It became a full-time cinema in February 1912 and was taken over by the Biocolour circuit in 1920 (Eyles 1996, 201). The cinema became part of the Gaumont chain in March 1927 and was closed on 30 June 1927 for a reconstruction behind the faacde designed by the architect Frank Verity. It reopened on 14 February 1928 as the New Palace with 1574 seats. The cinema became the Gaumont c.1952 and was modernised c.1960, reducing the seating to 1245 in the process. The cinema closed on 15 March 1980 and is currently (22/04/2002) in use as nightclub.

KNOWN_AS: The Rising Sun, Lower Castle Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
'The Rising Sun' public house, at the corner of Ellbroad and Lower Castle Streets. The main building, on the corner of the south side of Ellbroad Street but facing Lower Castle Street, was of two storeys, the upper jettied, on brackets. Rendered. Four bays; main entrance in third bay from north, with pair of seventeenth-century posts to the porch; large lamp over entrance; four sashes to first-floor. Large steep pantiled roof, gable to north end. One-bay extension along Lower Castle Street; similar steep roof; one window only, to ?ground-floor; stack at south end. Further one-bay extension of two storeys and flat roof; doorway and window to ground-floor, window above. Whole length of building with clinker plinth to ground-floor, returning on north elevation. North end gabled; 2 bays; plain gable end with stack at apex, adjacent to Lower Castle Street; eastern bay with cellar access below ground-floor window. One common pentice roof between the ground and first floors of the eastern bay and Nos.2 & 4 Ellbroad Street.
Pritchard (1907, 160-162) describes the accommodation as small, the rooms very low. In the bar-parlour, on the right-hand on entering, was a stone chimney-piece depicting Adam and Eve on a central panel, with a smaller panel of an eagle. Moulded plaster ceiling, divided by a large moulded beam; moulded plaster cornice above panelling; leaded panes to window; an "unusually wide" window sill. In the back kitchen, a three-quarter height chimney-piece with flat four-centred arch; decorated frieze above fireplace, with scroll work, two roses and a central shield bearing the date 1606 and the initials ' T M A'.
A front bedroom at the corner on the first-floor was largely panelled in oak, with a "handsome moulded plaster cornice, representing griffin-like monsters, divided by mask-head brackets". Below was a decorated oak frieze including several shields bearing the same initials as in the kitchen.
The building was demolished in August and September 1906, along with two other historic buildings in Ellbroad Street (BUAD 152M). and rebuilt to a design by Paull and James. The new public house was to incorporate features recovered from the old, but their fate when the Edwardian building was demolished in 1954 is unknown.

Transit Shed, The Grove. The shed was recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of the early 1880s and lay along the eastern side of Wesh Back and The Grove.
Built c.1883 as the New Scotch Shed (also known as the Glasgow Shed) with three sections forming a continuous range of buildings; an open shed at the north end, a central square section with higher pitched roof and three sliding doors on each side and a longer southern section with curved east wall respecting the harbour wall alignment and three sliding doors to the river and road frontages.
Between 1918 and 1923, probably in 1922, the northern open section was demolished following a fire at the premises (Leach, 2004, 12-13, fig 17-18). Temporary buildings were erected on the site followign the fire and these were replaced by the structure known as O Shed in 1937.
Between 1937 and 1940 the southern section of the original transit shed was demolished to enable the construction of the New Western Road or inner circuit road.
A photograph the site of the transit shed taken on 14th November 1940 shows the remaining central section of the Scotch or Glasgow Shed, now known as M Shed,  with its roof removed. On the 24th November the site was heavily bombed and the only elements of the original transit shed still extant (06/10/2008) are the north and south walls of the central square section. Based on photographic and cartographic evidence, the side walls and roof were replaced at sometime between 1949 and 1969 (Leach, 2004, 14).

The General Post Office. The first block was opened in 1868. By W J Williams. Now bays 8 to 15, from the left, but originally consisting of 7 bays including 3-bay entrance with 1 bay set back at each end, at least the left-hand being a vehicular entrance. Limestone ashlar, roof not recorded. Italianate style. Three storey main facade. Enlarged 1889 and 1925, on the former occasion by the addition of 7 bays to the left, in an elevation of similar style. Upper storeys along the front were burnt out in the Blitz, but leaving the ground-floor intact. Mostly basemented. Various numbers of storeys and types of roof.
Work commenced in 1908 on a large extension to the right, of 17 bays and 4 storeys plus mezzanine and basement. The facade changes angle at mid-point. Three main storeys and massive cornice, above which is the final storey. Construction of this block involved the loss of the right-hand recessed bay of the 1860s building. At the right-hand end included the entrance to the old Crown Courts building behind (Mon.No.196M). To the rear of the left-hand was the sorting office. Various numbers of storeys and roof types to the rear of the block fronting Small Street. Until the Blitz the buildings housed two chimney-pieces relocated from elsewhere on the site.
The site was redeveloped in 1990-91 for new County Courts. The facade of the 1900s block was retained, and the other facades were heavily restored. The building was formerly listed Grade II.

The former Nos. 1 & 2 Tower Lane, which were also known as Nos.3 & 4, Tailors Court, having frontages to both. Two nineteenth-century two-storey properties, largely of Pennant Sandstone rubble, but with brick details and additions. Latterly offices and warehousing. Both with gabled roofs. No.1 of two bays to Tower Lane, the right-hand bay projecting, entrance in left bay. No.2 with left-hand entrance, windows to centre and right; large window to first-floor. No.3 of two bays to Tailors Court, large door to centre, window to right; two windows to first-floor;rendered. No.4 with part of gable to Court (remainder against end of Court House), door at ground-floor, small window above; rendered. The north-west side of No.1/3 shared a wall with St. John's churchyard, with windows overlooking it.
The site was archaeologically excavated from later in 1979, the work directed by Eric Boore (BRSMG 87/1979).

The Royal Hotel, located on the south side of College Green. The hotel was built between 1863 and 1868 to a design by W. H. Hawtin. Limestone ashlar with ridge stacks and a slate hipped roof. Double-depth plan. Italianate style. 4 storeys and attic; 11-window range. A heavily decorated symmetrical front, 3:1:3:1:3, has projecting wings; a bracketed moulded cornice to the balustrade. Rustication to the ground floor. A Venetian doorway to the main entrance. Ground- and first-floor semicircular-arched windows; 2-storey canted bays to the wings; segmental pediments to the wings and centre, plain pediments to the outer middle windows. Tripartite middle windows. Second-floor windows have raised surrounds and rounded corners, third-floor windows with rounded corners, and semicircular-arched windows to the attic. Hipped dormers. The left return is a matching symmetrical 3-window range.
The building was restored and the interior largely remodelled in 1991; includes a Palm Court with glazed roof.

KNOWN_AS: Bristol Museum and Library, Queen's Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
Bristol Museum and library, located on the east side of the junction of University Road with Queen's Road. The building was constructed between 1867 and 1871 to a design by Foster and Ponton.
Yellow brick with red brick decoration and limestone dressings, pantile hipped roof. Rectangular open plan. Venetian Gothic Revival style. 2 storeys; 7-window range. A symmetrical front has steps up to a ground-floor loggia with an arcade of 2-centre arches on columns, the outer pair of arches now blocked and rendered. First-floor band of shields, below an arcade of alternate large 2-centre arches, glazed, with trefoil heads, and narrow, pointed blind statue niches. Band below a coved cornice and parapet. Left return has 9 ground-floor arches containing triple lancets and round windows above, and 7 first-floor arches. Interior largely rebuilt c.1950. Later attached front area walls and stone railings. 
The library moved to Deanery Road, c.1909 and the building then housed the geological and natural history collections of the Bristol Museum until theearly 1940s. Much of the decorative detail including pinnacles and parapet has been lost as a result of damage to the building by bombing during the Second World War. Restored for use as the refectory of Bristol University, became Brown's Restaurant, c.1990.

The Jewish burial Ground at Barton Road in St. Philip's Marsh. The burial ground is not shown by the 1750 edition of John Rocque's map of Bristol but was in existence by March 1759 when an advertisement referred to it (Felix Farley's Bristol Journal 31 March 1759). It was located within the brickyard in St. Philip and Jacob and was leased from the owner (in contravention of Jewish law which holds that a cemetery must be held in perpetuity). The Plumley and Ashmead plan of Bristol of 1828 indicates that the cemetery initially only consisted of the western half of the present site, a land parcel measuring 20 metres from north to south by approximately 20 metres wide (an area of 440 square metres) which lat 26 metres west of Barton Road. The land fronting on to Barton Road was added between 1828 and the early 1880s.
An Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852 imposed the restriction that "only one body [was] to be buried in each grave" in the burial ground. The freehold of the cemetery was not acquired until August 1859. A fire at Mardon's, next door, in 1901 made the wall around the burial ground unsafe and the firemen entering the burial ground to tackle the fire caused damage to the tombstones. After repairs were complete the cemetery was reconsecrated on 26th July 1903 (Samuel 1997, 74-77). The last known burial within the site was in 1944.
The burial ground survives and is surrounded by a stone rubble wall approximately 3 metres high. The entrance gate is on Barton Road. The site is owned by the Bristol Jewish Burial Society (Chevrah Chadisha).
The boundary wall has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/359).

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Church of the Holy Cross (Temple Church), Temple Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
A round-nave church built by the Knight's Templar, probably in the mid twelfth century. The history of the church is unknown but it was presumably demolished to make way for the construction of the later parish church.
The monument was first observed during works to the floor within Temple Church in the 1870s and was archaeologically excavated in 1960 by Andrew Saunders (BUAD 485). Saunders's excavation established that the church was fragmentary, but enough remained for a reconstruction of the plan of the church which consisted of a round nave enclosed within an ambulatory, while Saunders indicated it had an apsidal chancel. It probably formed part of one of the larger preceptories in southern England but the plan of its precinct is unknown. The location of archive for the excavation is unknown and the extent of attrition caused to the archaeological deposits associated with the church is therefore unknown.

No.35 Mary-le-Port Street, located on the south side of Mary-le-port Street opposite the junction with Cheese Market. The building was a house of seventeenth-century date and was of four storeys plus attic. The Mary-le-port Street frontage was 9.5 metres wide and the plot extended 10 metres back from the street.
The main, north-west facing, elevation on Mary-le-port Street was timber-framed and was of three storeys plus attic with two bays. The ground-floor was a shopfront with a central entrance and there was a large shop window on either side of this. At the eastern and western ends of the elevation there were passages, presumably leading to the rear of the building. Above the shopfront there was a large painted signboard advertising "BARNARD & CO." The first second and third floors each comprised two canted bays with central round-headed windows in each at first and second floors. There were windows between, and to either side of, the bays giving full-width glazing. There were pentice roofs across the full width of property above first, second and third floors. The building had a double gabled roof, the gables being hung with slate, and there was a window in the centre of the western gable. To either side of the gables, on the eastern and western ends of the building, the roof was apparently flat. Above the third-floor pentice in the 1890s, in front of the gables, there was a railing across the full width of the building. Pritchard reports (BUAD 658) that there were large arched cellars beneath the building which "extended a long way back" (Pritchard 1906, 129).
Abuttals from No.36 Mary-le-port Street indicate that in 1649 the building was the house of a Mr. Yates and by the second half of the 1660s had passed into the hands of John Symons, smith (Leech 1997, 108). The building was occupied by Barnard & Co., tobacco, snuff & cigar warehouse in the 1890s and Pritchard noted that latterly the building had been a shell, "there being but two rooms on each floor with no backlet" (Pritchard 1906, 129). Demolition of the building to make way for a warehouse began on 9 February 1904 (Pritchard 1906, 129) and some of the brackets on the front of the building were given to the City Museum by the builders Messrs. Wilkins and Sons (BUAD 996A). The building was painted by T. L. Rowbotham in 1825 (BRSMG M2800) and there is also a photograph of it dating to the 1890s (Winstone 1960, pl.53).

The House of the Kalendaries, located on the south-eastern side of Corn Street. The guild was an association of secular clergy and laity constituted with the purpose of meeting on the first day of the month to celebrate mass and intercede on behalf of the living and for the souls of the dead. The Bristol Kalendars were one of only a handful of similar guilds in the country, the others being at Exeter and Winchester. Its origins are obscure (Neale 2000, 210-211), but it had apparently been established by the early-thirteenth century (Orme 1978, 35).
The house at All Saints seems to have been built in the fourteenth century and oversailed the north aisle of All Saint's Church. Little is currently known in detail about its medieval form. The guild was wealthy enough to maintain a prior and three chantry priests in the building, and in the mid-fifteenth century created a public theological library there. The initiative seems to have come from the Bishop of Worcester with the aim of creating a centre of religious orthodoxy to counter the influence of Lollardy, and the library was open for private study for four hours each weekday (Orme 1978, 40-43). A deed of 1548 suggests that the library was housed in an extension to the main building, recording that the building had "a chamber annexed ... vulgarly called the Librarye" (Leech 1997, 66).
The Guild of Kalendars was dissolved at Easter 1548 and unlike many other medieval guilds it did not reconstitute itself but instead ceased to exist and the Crown sold off its property (Orme 1978, 45). The house seems to have been bought by Miles Partridge and Hugh Partridge and was immediately leased by them to Robert Wudwarde (Leech 1997, 66). The site had passed into the ownership of All Saints parish by 1616 when a faculty was granted for the creation of a doorway through the north wall of the church (Leech 1997, 66-67).
James Millerd's 1673 prospect of Bristol includes a vignette which shows All Saint's Church, and this records the building as a sixteenth- or seventeenth-century house of three storeys and attics with a cross-gabled roof, presenting two gables to Corn Street. There was a possible stair turret at the east end of the north elevation. There were mullioned windows on all floors. All Saints Conduit (BUAD 682M) was built into the ground-floor. By the early eighteenth century the building had apparently become the coffee house of George Cooke and on the basis of the property records Leech suggests that the house may have been rebuilt in c.1740 by John Worrall, though how extensive the rebuilding was is unknown. Extensive rebuilding did, however, take place when the present No.56 Corn Street (BUAD 336M) was constructed in 1782, but elements of earlier fabric appear to have survived in the cellar and the south wall of the property.

A building occupying roughly the site of No.4 Kingsdown Parade which is recorded on Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol. The building was probably a merchant's lodge (ie. second residence) and was associated with two parterre gardens which lay immediately to the south-west of it. These had been subdivided into smaller roughly square plots by 1828, the size of which seem to have been determined by the quadrants of the parterres. The building appears to have survived into the early 1880s the building appears to have survived into the early 1880s but was subsequently demolished.

Colston's Fort or Colston's Mount, located on the north-west side of the road now known as Montague Place. The fort was constructed in 1642 as part of the new northern line of defences around Bristol to protect the city during the English Civil Wars. It stood between Royal Fort (BUAD 928M), to the south-west, and Priors Hill Fort (BUAD 121M), to the north-east.
It was probably built of stone and was "some 18 foote square" according to the Royalist engineer Sir Bernard de Gomme (Firth 1925, 184). A survey of the ordnance captured at the storming of Bristol made on 28 July 1643 records that there was one minion and one falcon at the fort (Roy 1975, 261). Although the fort was involved in the fighting during both major assaults on the Bristol, attacks were concentrated elsewhere on the line, particularly towards Prior's Hill Fort (BUAD 121M).
Sprigge reports that following the Parliamentarian capture of the city Cromwell ordered that the forts along the line be left "in a safe condition", presumably by partial demolition (Sprigge 1854, 132). Jean Rocque's 1742 'A Plan of the City of Bristol' records the remains of the fort, a D-shaped mound on the north-west side of the road, suggesting that the south-eastern part of the fort had been cut away by the road. The remains of the fort were also noted to be extant in 1751 (BRO P/StJ/ChW/6). The antiquary Samuel Seyer observed the remains of the fort in the early-nineteenth century, noting that much had been cut away by the road, while the remainder survived in a garden (Seyer 1823, 305). The site of the fort was subsequently developed and no elements survive above ground. An archaeological watching brief during the redevelopment of the former Montague Brewery immediately to the south recorded no evidence for the fort (BUAD 3644).

No.20 King Street, located on the south side of King Street. The building was constructed in c.1665. It is a rendered timber frame house with brick stacks to the right, gabled front and rear elevations to the main building and a pantile roof. The building has three storeys, an attic and basement. It has a double-depth plan with central stairs between the front and back rooms. The building also has a single-storey wing linked to a seventeenth-century, two-storey back block. It has an eighteenth-century shop frontage with a seventeenth-century door frame to the left with moulded stops and a Tudor arch, with a studded 9-panel door with decorative panels to the top and a 10+10 pane sash abve a segmental-arched cellar opening. The building was refenestrated in the eighteenth-century and was restored in 1991. Inside, against the side wall is a seventeenth-century stone fire surround with architrave, panels abve and brackets to a cornice. The building is joined with No.19 internally. It now forms part of a public house and restaurant.

The culvert of the river Frome between Rupert Street and St. Augustine's Bridge in 1892-93.
The culvert was built after a debate on the replacement of the swing bridge at St. Augustine's Reach with a fixed bridge. The decision in 1890 to erect a fixed bridge meant that the upper part of the Floating Harbour between Stone Bridge and the new St. Augustine's Bridge would be impassable to shipping. It was therefore decided to enclose that part of the Frome.
A dam was put across the harbour at Thunderbolt Street in February 1892 and the water pumped out. A temporary bridge was erected on the site of the Drawbridge in April or May 1892. A flat-bottomed channel was built roughly centrally between the walls of the Floating Harbour. The walls of this appear to have been of stone and were 1.5 metres thick and stood approximately 5 metres high. On the outside of the walls were low arches placed approximately 1 metre apart. The area between the harbour walls and the culvert was infilled with rubble and then the arch (apparently of brick) was built. At the north end the culvert abutted Stone Bridge which is extant beneath the road, while at the south end it is built against St Augustine's Bridge.

Cabot Tower, Brandon Hill. The tower was built between 1897 and 1898 to a design by W. V. Gough, and was to commemorate the quatrcentenary of John Cabot's voyage to Newfoundland.
The first stone was laid by the Marquis of Dufferin and Ava in 1897. The foundations were dug into the underlying Brandon Hill Grit, disturbing inhumations and other archaeological features. The tower stands 105 feet [32.1 metres] high is of red sandstone rubble with limestone dressings and is in a Tudor Gothic Revival style. It is a square two-stage tower with diagonal buttresses. The lower band comprises square panels, the middle band of pointed panels, and it has a machicolated cornice with a pierced balustrade. The doorway in the north side has a moulded surround and plain door, below a two-centred arched panel with a gabled label, crockets and finial, containing the city arms. There is an ashlar octagonal spirelet on top, and a ball finial with a carved figure above.
The Marquis of Dufferin opened the monument on 6th September 1898. Originally there was a cannon on each side of the projecting base of the tower. The gardens which now surround the base are a later addition.
The tower has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/18).

Cumberland Road Gate, a toll house and gate. The gate was situated at the eastern end of the bridge across the Overfall Dam (at ST 57248 72092), and was removed with the cessation of tolls. The toll house (at ST 57250 72100) survived until destroyed by enemy action during the Second World War. The house was 2-storey with a porch on its south end, against the north side of Cumberland Road. The south wall was 3-sided, each side a 1-window range. The main east wall was a 2 or 3-window range. Hipped roof, probably slated.

Ebenezer Chapel, 683 Fishponds Road. A Nonconformist chapel constructed c.1880. An inscription at the front of the building reportedly read 'Methodist Free Church 1880 Opened 1881'. The chapel is constructed in the Gothic style and consists of Pennant sandstone with ashlar dressings and Roman tiles covering the pitched roof. Internally the building contains a mock vaulted ceiling with ornate iron chandelier mounts. At the time of a survey of the building in 2008 (Corcos, 2008) an internal wooden gallery supported by two ornamental pillars survived. Access to this gallery was provided by two spiral stone staircases flankning the main front entrance.
The chapel was known locally as the 'Clock Chapel' because of the clock on the front elevation below a bellcote.
The chapel first appears in the street directories in 1899 when it is listed as the 'Methodist Free Church'. Other directory records name the chapel; 'United Methodist Church' (1909), 'United Methodist Chapel' (1914) and 'Ebenezer Methodist Chapel' (1934).
Religious worship ceased at the chapel in the 1960s when it was amalgamated with the Trinity Weslyan Church at 800 Fishponds Road. A combined service to mark the closure of the chapel was held in February 1964.
Following the closure of the chapel the building came into the possession of M.W.M. Motors who converted the building to a car-tyre and exhaust centre. (Townsend, 2004).

Nos.7 and 9 Old King Street, a pair of houses lcoated on the west side of Old King Street (now part of Merchant Street). Occupied by a shoeing forge and veterinary infirmary by the late C19 and into the C20. Attached, originally to similar buildings either side. 2 storeys and attics; 1 front gable each; both upper storeys jettied; 1-window ranges. A large haulingway entrance occupying most of the right-hand ground and first floors; a right-hand entrance to the left-hand house, bay window. Bay first-floor window, with sashes. 2-light casements to both attics; gutter box across front of both at base of attic storey. Demolished 1953-54 (Street's notes).

Pair of two storey gate lodges at 140-142 Frenchay Park Road. Constructed in c.1879 as two detached lodge houses flanking the entrance to the Beaufort Nursery that was in existence from 1879 to 1931.
Both buildings are constructed of mortared pennant sandstone blocks and slabs, roughly squared and with a fair face, laid in uneven courses, with the occasional random squared block.  Quoins are in bath stone ashlar or similar, as are the sills of the windows.  There are four windows front and back, paired two up two down, each face.  The windows are single sash wooden frames, each divided from its twin by a moulded bath stone pillar, forming the central springer for a rough pennant double arch, one arch for each window of the pair.  Springers for the outside edges of each arch are in moulded bath stone, as are the arch keystones.  
Despite use of the Beaufort name, no records indicate any direct connection with the Beaufort estates.  Rather, the lands on which the nursery was established were agricultural fields in private hands from at least 1754, while the nursery itself was owned by Parker and Sons throughout its entire period of operation (1879 to 1931).  
Between 1916 and 1935 a western extension in the form of an early 20th century house was added to No. 140, with a detached garage to the rear of the property.  Minor changes and extensions were made to No. 140 in the early 1980s, but in 1988 and 1989 planning permission was granted for the conversion of the property into a private residential care home, with the addition of a two storey extension to the rear.

Brandon Hill Fort, located at the summit of Brandon Hill. The fort was constructed in 1642 as part of the line of defences protecting the northern side of Bristol during the civil war of 1642-1646. The Royalist engineer Sir Bernard de Gomme noted in 1643 that the fort was "some 18 foote square, & as many high; its Graff or mote but shallow & narrowe, by reason of the rockynesse of the grownd" (Firth 1925, 184). The survey of cannon captured by the Royalist armies in July 1643 recorded three minions and one Robinet in the fort (BUAD 4094; Roy 1975, 261). The fort may have been reconstructed as part of the Royalist refortification of the defences in 1643-1644. It is constructed following the principles of trace italienne and is of Brandon Hill Grit. Overall it appears originally to have measured approximately 45 metres by 30 metres.
The fort, along with the other surviving civil war defences on Brandon Hill, is a Scheduled Ancient Monument (AV 118).

St. Peter's Almshouses, Peter Street. The buildings were probably of twelfth- or thirteenth-century date from archaeological evidence and were in use as dwellings until the late fifteenth-century. By the early sixteenth-century the buildings were two parts, one in use as an almshouse and the other as a group of five tenements. It was later incorporated into the group of buildings known as St. Peter's Hospital but the group of medieval buildings survived well into the twentieth-century although they were refenestrated at some point. The monument was destroyed by enemy action on the night of the 24-25 November 1940.

King Square. The square is located on the north side of Jamaica Street. According to Ison (1952, 173-177) the process of construction was underway by 1737. Jean Rocque's map of 1742 shows the square laid out, with a double row of trees around all sides, but only the one building adjacent, on the corner of Dighton Street, although he does show the various streets, delineated by broken lines, and the whole area as "TO BE BUILT". At the centre there are communal gardens.
The square was subject to restoration works in the summer of 1993 after the construction of a large access chamber for the Northern Foul Water Interceptor sewer. Cross paving and seating was added and the railings and arched lampholders were reinstated, with a new hedge planted behind.

St. Philip's Poor House, located on the western side of Pennywell Road. The building was constructed c.1698-1700 according to Winstone (1971, pls.89-92) and was a two-storey structure of Pennant sandstone rubble with classical mouldings of ashlar stone around the door and window openings. 
An Indenture for the poorhouse dated 1803 (BRO P.StP&J/OP/2) refers to a lease of 1730 for a "good raparious and substantial workhouse".
Jean Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol indicates that the building had a C-shaped plan, the central range set back with the side ranges reaching to Pennywell Road. The building measured 180 feet (55 metres) by 80 feet (25 metres).
Plumley & Ashmead's 1828 survey depicts the northwestern side of the poorhouse as a single rectangular block that was wider in the centre separate from the two wings on the north-east and south-west side of a yard area.
The south-western half of the building and the northern range appear to have been demolished by the late-nineteenth century and the site redeveloped. The north-eastern half of the building survived into the twentieth century and was photographed when in a dilapidated condition in the early 1920s (Winstone 1971, pls.89-92). This remaining element building was demolished on 28 December 1925 (Winstone 1971).

No.16 St. James' Parade, located on the northern side of St. James' Parade. The building was a two-bay rendered house of two storeys and attic with a pitched pantile roof. It was constructed in the medieval period on the site of part of the parochial burial ground (BUAD 491M) associated with St. James Church.
The house is reported to have been demolished in the early 1950s and the site was part of a garden in front of St. James Church for many years. The site of the building was investigated as part of an archaeological field evaluation in 1993 (BUAD 413). The site was redeveloped in the mid-1990s.
A quarry some 65 metres to the north of Coombe Farm. The Ordnance Survey first edition plan published in 1881 (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.03) records the feature as "Old Quarry".

No.1 Christmas Street, later known as the 'Ship' public house. The building stood on the south-west corner of the junction of Christmas Street and Quay Street. The house was apparently of late-medieval date, although its original form as built is unclear. It may have had a first-floor hall and this was beneath an arch-brace collar-beam roof with chamfered windbraces which was of late fourteenth- or early fifteenth-century date. Pritchard thought that the room may originally have measured 24 feet [7.3 metres] long by 12 feet [3.7 metres] wide. He records that the "original half-timber work at the east end clearly showed the pitch of the roof, the position of the three windows, and the general character of the building" (Pritchard 1911, 70-72). The building may originally have presented a gabled front to Christmas Street.
The medieval roof was hidden by a plaster ceiling in the post-medieval period. The construction of an adjacent warehouse in around 1878 resulted the size of the first-floor room to 17 feet [5.2 metres] long by 16 feet [7.3 metres] wide in the removal of all but the rear two bays of the late-medieval roof.
The building was demolished on 21st November 1910 to make way for an extension to Fry's factory.
The majority of the evidence for the construction of the building was recorded by John Pritchard at the time of its demolition (BUAD 3207). One photograph of the roof seen from Christmas Street was published in Pritchard's report on the building (Pritchard 1911, 70-72).

A house at the western end of Blackfriars. The building is of probable seventeenth-century date, and was constructed as a merchant's summerhouse or garden house (R. H. Leech pers. comm.).
An attached, gabled, house of three and a half storeys plus a cellar. It was of a stone rubble construction with a rendered exterior; There was a 1-window range to north-east, 2-window range to south-east and large doors to the street; 6-light transomed first-floor window; cross-window to second-floor; oculus to attic. Lateral stack in centre of south-east wall, windows to either side (blocked by the 1950s).
Street's album (BRSMG Ex libris No.9104/13 A & C) includes two photographs of a staircase, probably in the small gabled projection on the north-west side of the main house. It is a seventeenth-century open-well version with square newels with ball finials and pendants, and turned balusters.
The building was surveyed in 1989 (BUAD 361). Subsequent archaeological excavation in 1989 (BUAD 444) recorded evidence of since demolished parts of the building on its north side as well as the associated garden. The house was substantially altered after recording and excavation was complete.

KNOWN_AS: Church of the Holy Cross or Temple Church
MONUMENT_DESC:
The parish church known as Temple Church or Holy Cross, located on the eastern side of Temple Street. The present church is built on the site of an earlier, circular, church built by the Knights Templar in the twelfth-century. The church was built by the Knights Hospitallers, beginning c.1400 with the nave being completed by 1500. The land to the south and east of the church became the churchyard.
The church was constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble with Bath stone ashlar dressings and is in a Perpendicular Gothic style. It has an aisled nave (without a clerestorey), and a chancel with five bays containing chapels. At the west end of the south aisle there is a five-stage Somerset-type tower at the south corner of the west end which stands 34.75 metres high. The tower was begun in 1441 and was completed in 1460. Subsidence caused the lower two stages of the tower to lean to the west before the third stage was added. The upper stages were built on an angle to try to correct the structural forces, but the tower then moved again. The pinnacles were consequently never added to the tower.
Internally with chapels of four (smaller) bays to north and south. The chapels included St. Katherine's Chapel, founded by the Weavers' Fraternity in the late-fourteenth century, as well as altars dedicated to the Holy Trinity, SS Andrew and Nicholas and St. James (Wadley 1886, passim). There was also a chapel dedicated to the Blessed Virgin Mary outside the church (Wadley 1886, 29; 55).
The Knights Hospitallers were suppressed in 1540 and the church was acquired by the Bristol Corporation in July of that year as part of its purchase of Temple Fee from the Crown (Gairdner & Brodie 1903, 626). The chapel of the Blessed Virgin Mary was demolished in the sixteenth-century.
A porch with Corinthian pilasters to a segmental pediment with a cartouche inside and an urn on the top was added to the nave in the mid-eighteenth century. The interior was also refitted in the eighteenth-century. In June 1788 the vicar, Rev. Joseph Easterbrook, along with six other ministers, performed a controversial exorcism in the vestry on George Lukins, a tailor from Yatton who claimed to be possessed by demons (Anon., 1788; Easterbrook, 1788). Restoration works were undertaken in 1872, 1907 and 1911.
An organ was built by Harris in 1701 (although it is not clear whether this was Renatus Harris or John Harris). It was refurbished by John Smith junior of the Bristol organ builders John Smith and Sons in 1847.
The churchyard was closed to burials in the 1850s and was converted into a public park between 1878 and 1880.
The church was gutted as a result of bombing on the night of the 24th and 25 November 1940 and only the shell walls now remain.
A survey of the building was undertaken by Wessex Archaeology in 1999 (BUAD 3775; Taylor 2000).
The church is a Scheduled Ancient Monument (SAM No. AV28841) and is an English Heritage Guardianship Monument. The building has Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/337). The archway and gates leading to the church are separately listed Grade II (Listed Building number 901-1/42/336).

Bristol Old Station, located on the north-western side of Temple Gate. A railway terminus built between 1839 and 1841, to a design by Isambard Kingdom Brunel, for the Great Western Railway Company. Limestone ashlar, squared Pennant Sandstone rubble with a hipped slate roof. 
Axially-planned with offices across the end facing the road, the engine shed behind and the passenger shed beyond again (now linked with Temple Meads Station). In Tudor Revival style. 
The offices (1010A) are three storeys; 7-window range. A symmetrical front missing the balancing right-hand Departures gateway. Tudor windows and a Tudor-arched doorway, with later shop fronts. To left, the 2-storey Arrivals gateway (1011A) with flanking turrets and a wide Tudor arch; a lower connecting block has a smaller gateway. The Pennant Sandstone rubble engine shed (1012A) behind has a tunnel crossing beneath it at the end. The passenger shed, or train shed (1013A), has a central projecting Arrivals entrance facing north.
The offices include a large open-well staircase. The sheds are built above a semicircular-vaulted undercroft: the engine shed has cast-iron stanchions; the aisled passenger shed has a cantilevered timber roof with false hammer beams above an arcade of Tudor arches on cast-iron columns. 
The GWR line to London was completed in 1841, at which time the Bristol terminus opened. Arrivals and Departures were on opposite sides, passengers passing through the undercroft, which held the waiting rooms. The engines were turned on turntables and moved from line to line in the engine shed. The functional space of the station as designed by Brunel is almost entirely intact. The building is the earliest surviving large railway terminus in the world.

Lawford's Gate House of Correction. A decision was taken by the Gloucestershire Commissioners to develop a new prison close to the site of the old bridewell in October 1783. The prison, on the south side of Lawford's Gate, was built in the late 1780s to a design by William Blackburn. Blackburn was replaced as architect during the course of construction by William Hobson.
The prisoners were transferred to the new building on 1 June 1791. In its finished form the house of correction was of two storeys and was constructed of rubble stone with a slate roof. A central, octagonal element contained the chapel at ground floor with the infirmary and dark (punishment) cells on either side at first-floor level. There twenty cells on each floor and these were arranged in two wings off the octagonal core. Each floor of each wing had a central corridor with five cells on either side of it. The cells all measured 7 feet 4 inches (2.24 metres) by 6 feet 7 inches (2.01 metres). Within the prison there was also a petty sessions room approximately 6 metres square and a two room keeper's house (each room of which was 3.6 metres square), plus a wash-house (Whiting 1975, 138-141). According to a late eighteenth-century report quoted by Whiting (1975, 141) there were on average between ten and twelve prisoners who were emploed cutting logs, making shoemakers pegs or making shoes. By 1832 the work given to the prisoners was picking oakum. The prisoners used the one yard and one day-room where they could fraternise and receive visitors.
In the nineteenth century an extension was added to the south-east side of the prison.
The building remained in use until 1860 but stood empty after that date until its demolition in 1907.

A quarry on the north side of Crew's Hole Road, Crew's Hole. The 1949 1:2500 Ordnance Survey map of the area marks the site as an "Old Quarry". The function of the quarry is not known but may have been for clay for the nearby Bristol Fireclay Company brickworks [SMR 20239].

KNOWN_AS: James Stewart's House, Upper Maudlin Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
James Stewart's House, Upper Maudlin Street. The house, probably built as a lodge or merchant's second residence, was located on the southern side of Upper Maudlin Street, just to the north of the junction with Johnny Ball Lane. The cross-gabled house was of three storeys and attic, was two rooms wide and one deep, with two gables to the front, and a two-window range. There was two-storey porch in centre, the lower storey open. The fenetration comprised two-storey continuous bays to first and second floors on each side, mostly Ipswich windows, with two-light casements in the attic. There were chimney stacks at the end of the gables. It also had a garden extending downhill in the direction of Lewin's Mead.
The artist James Stewart lived in the building and drew it as part of a view towards Lower Maudlin Street. Its site now lies beneath the southern part of the carriageway in Upper Maudlin Street. Elements of the house may survive below ground but the monument is likely to have been seriously disturbed by the insertion of services in the highway.

KNOWN_AS: The Great Ditch of the Town of Bristol
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Great Ditch of the town of Bristol. The ditch probably dates to the early post-Conquest or perhaps even late pre-Conquest period. A large ditch protecting the Old Market area of the town ran from the River Frome firstly east-south-east, then south-south-east through and beyond Lawford's Gate. It then turned to the south-west. It is not clear where the ditch terminated, but it should have extended to either the River Avon or the ditch of the King's Orchard. The ditch was recorded as the "magni fossati ville Bristollie" in the 1373 perambulation of the new County of Bristol (Harding 1930, 160; 163).
Jean Rocque's 1742 map shows a section of a wide ditch, about 150 feet (45 metres) in length, running south-eastwards from the southern bank of the Frome, immediately inside the 1373 County boundary (BUAD 2990; ST 59580 73363). The line of the ditch appears to have been fossilised in a continuous line of gardens to the rear of properties on the south-west side of New Street. It appears again on the west side of what is now Midland Road, between Trinity Hospital and the corner of Unity Street, as a 160 foot (49 metre) stretch of garden. The line lies on the north-east side of St. Matthias Park, crossing beneath it at its south-eastern end, then running on the west side of Lawford Street and Midland Road, before turning to run along the northern side of Unity Street.
Part of the ditch may have been located during a watching brief carried out by John Bryant in 1986 (BUAD 381) at the rear of No.49 Old Market Street (BUAD 901A), and possibly also earlier, in 1982, on Unity Street near the corner with Midland Road (BUAD 200A).

KNOWN_AS: St. Mark's Chapel or The Lord Mayor's Chapel
MONUMENT_DESC:
Lord Mayor's Chapel, formerly the church of St. Mark's Hospital (BUAD 509M), located on the north-easterns side of College Green. The church is the only part of the hospital which is known to survive above ground. The building was erected in 1230, the south aisle added in 1270, the tower in 1487, and the chancel and south aisle chapel in 1500. The Poyntz chapel was built in 1523. The roof of nave is early sixteenth-century. After the dissolution (in 1539) the precincts of the hospital and its properties were acquired by the Corporation in May 1541. In the early nineteenth-century oil paintings on stone which formed part of a squint were recorded in part of a building next door to the chapel (Gill & Howard, in Keen 1997, 97-106).
In 1822 the west window of the Chapel was removed [This window is currently located in the garden of No.5 The Ridgeway, Westbury-on-Trym and is listed Grade II*].
A new organ was built for the chapel in 1825 by John Smith senior of the Bristol organ builders John Smith & Sons. The organ was refurbished by W. G. Vowles in 1878. The chapel was the subject of a programme of restoration by J. L. Pearson in 1889, during which the north transept and the west front were rebuilt.
The church has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/66).

The Star, No.34 High Street, located on the western side of High Street. A building stood on the site from at least the mid-fifteenth century and in 1463 it was the tenement of John Viell. By 1544 it had become "the Starre" and was part of the lands of Lord Lisle. It had been acquired by the Corporation by 1556/7 and was leased out (Leech, 1997 78-79).
The building occupied a 4.4 metre wide frontage on High Street. The main, north-east facing, elevation was four storeys and two bays. The ground floor was a shop front and the fenestration above comprised sash windows. There was a flat element on the east side of the roof with a rail or balustrade along the eaves on the eastern side. The function of this is not clear, although it may have been a small viewing platform [1124A]. The frontage appeared to be of late eighteenth- or early nineteenth-century date, although it is likely to represent a refronting of an earlier building.
The building survived into the twentieth century but was totally destroyed by bombing during the raid on 24 November 1940. The site was subsequently redeveloped and is now beneath No.35-38 High Street.

KNOWN_AS: Three Sugar Loaves Public House, Back Street
POSTAL_ADDRESS: NCP Car Park, Queen Charlotte Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
Public house, probably once a house. The 'Three Sugar Loaves and Devonshire House'. On the east side of Back Street. Attached. Three storeys and attic. Gabled front; side gable on north elevation; first-floor jettied to front. Entrance to left, 3 sash windows, cellar entrance below windows. Bays to first and second floors, glazed to fronts and sides, transomed. At attic, 3-light window; external collar above window. Lateral stack on south side near west end. 
Back Street did a dogleg around north end of the building. Taken down in 1826, replaced by a shallower building (with mansard roof) due to road being widened. At the time of rebuilding a 'font' (possibly a mortar or stoop) was found (Braikenridge drawing, M.2277, no dimensions). 'By' William Bowden in 1826, according to drawing.

A quarry on the northern side of Crew's Hole Road, Crew's Hole. The 1949 1:2500 Ordnance Survey map of the area marks the site as an "Old Quarry". The function of the quarry is not known but may have been for clay for the nearby Bristol Fireclay Company brickworks [SMR 20239].

KNOWN_AS: Possible dovecote east of Partition Street
POSTAL_ADDRESS: Former Bryan Brothers site, Deanery Road
MONUMENT_DESC: A possible dovecote of medieval date, located some 40 metres to the east of Partition Street. The structure was recorded during archaeological excavation in 2000 (BUAD 3822). The dating evidence recovered was not sufficient to establish a close date for the structure but it was constructed in the medieval period. It was a circular building of Brandon Hill Grit and measured approximately 8 metres in diameter. It had stone buttress 1 metre wide on the southern side. Beneath the centre of the floor there was a stone drain which discharged into an area with a flagstone floor on the southern side of the structure, between the buttresses. The building was demolished and the stone quarried for reuse. Again the evidence could give a date for demolition but the structure was overlain by demolition rubble containing eighteenth-century pottery.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: King David Residence, No.1 St. Michael's Hill
MONUMENT_DESC:
The King David Inn, built at the foot of St. Michael's Hill during the seventeenth-century. The inn was built on part of the site of the of the St. Mary Magdalen Nunnery. It consisted of two adjacent buildings knocked together. That fronting Upper Maudlin Street had three storeys and three bays, the central bay comprising the very broad flue of a chimney. At first floor level in the west bay was a bay window projecting over the pavament. The west, St. Michael's Hill frontage of this building was blank except for a window at ground floor level. The roof was hipped. The building appears to have been refronted in the early nineteenth-century.
