The building making up the rear of the inn also had three-storeys and at least three bays, but had a gabled roof. Chimney stacks were located at the east and west ends of the building, there being two adjacent stacks at the east end. There was an entrance at ground floor level on the St. Michael's Hill frontage and a large window adjacent. At the rear of the building, facing on to the yard and adjacent to its entrance, was a bay window apparently with three lancet arches within it which seems to have been of medieval date. A doorway divided this from another bay window of late eighteenth- or early nineteenth-century date. East of this bay window was a doorway by which was a three-step mounting block. On the top of this was an apparently damaged stone feature which may be the remains of the font of St. Mary Magdalen Nunnery reputed to be located in the yard. Behind the mounting block was a niche of unknown function. Inside at least one of the rooms had wooden panelling and a moulded ceiling of seventeenth-century date.
On the north side of the yard was a stone building with a hipped roof which was used as a stable. The building was demolished in 1893 to be be replaced with the building currently standing.

No.2 Trenchard Street. The main house is a two-bay, three-storey rendered building with a hipped roof. The main entrance is at the centre of the ground-floor facade. To the rear is what appears to be a two-storey detached kitchen block, with a hipped roof. The side and rear walls of the building are of brick and date to the nineteenth century. The front wall is constructed of stone rubble with brick details and within it are the remains of a large freestone window of late-medieval date (BUAD 961A). The rubble surrounding the window was bonded in an orange-pink mortar The window was about 1800 millimetres high internally. The north-east end has been destroyed, but a jamb with plain chamfer survives at the other. This window may have been part of one of the buildings of the Carmelite friary (BUAD 609M).

Temple Meads Joint Railway Station. The building, designed by Sir Matthew Digby Wyatt, was erected between 1865 and 1878 in a joint venture by the Great Western Railway and Midland Railway. It was originally called Bristol Joint Station and had a steep French Empire roof to the tower, which was destroyed in the Second World War, and crockets to the turret tops. The listing argues that "the later Temple Meads station uniquely shows, with the Bristol Old Station at Temple Meads, the growth of a major terminus over more than a century". Additional platforms, designed by P. E. Culverhouse, were put in between 1930 and 1935 and the original footbridge linking the platforms replaced with an underpass.
The fabric of the building is rusticated conglomerate with limestone dressings. 
The Booking office has forward projecting screens to the train sheds. It is in a Tudor Revival style. 
The station has two-storeys, and 3-window range, with single storey. There is a nineteen-window range to right and 17-window range to left. The Booking office has a symmetrical crenellated front with lower angled side blocks and a central two-stage tower, and octagonal turrets to the corners; the ground-floor four-centred arches have banded Purbeck marble shafts, a label mould with quatrefoil spandrels, and twentieth-century doors. The first floor has six-light square-headed windows with transoms and cinquefoil heads, stilted labels over panels with quatrefoils over the middle window; there is a half-quatrefoil arcade below the parapet, with blind lancets to the merlons; the turrets have two crenellated courses below pyramidal tops. 
The tower has an arcade of engaged shafts which pass through the drip to pointed arches, under a large square panel and clock with a trefoil-headed blind arcade above. The shed screens have mullion and transom windows separated by octagonal buttresses, with a glazed cast-iron canopy all around the frontage. The main train shed has a two-centred trussed roof with traceried arch braces on octagonal corbel shafts and black diaper work under the eaves.
The building has a Grade I listing. Brunel's station has a separate Grade I listing.

The Coliseum, located on the western side of the junction of Park Row and Woodland Road. The building was erected in 1910 as a skating rink and cinema, the cinema being the single-storey bull-nose building at the junction while the rink was a larger element on its west side. The building was of rusticated ashlar with the entrance to the cinema in the corner by Woodland Road. The windows were a sequence formed by paired tall arched windows. Internally much of the building seems to have been a single space with the roof supported on a framework of steel girders. The cinema had a 450 seat capacity and continued in use until c.1924 (Anderson 1983, 22). In early 1915 the west part of building was taken over by Parnall & Sons of Broadmead (a subsidiary company of W. & T. Avery) as an aircraft factory (Barnes 1972, 6). The building served as the erection shop and produced mainly seaplanes for the Royal Naval Air Service until 1918 when the majority of production changed to Avro biplanes for the newly-formed Royal Air Force (Stone & Wells 1920, 250-251). After 1918 the building appears to have become an ice rink and it continued in that use until it was gutted as a result of bombing in the early 1940s (Warne 1943, 26). After the Second World War the site became part of the precinct of the University of Bristol and the Engineering department occupied the site by the late 1980s. Part of the facade was retained in the building of a new university Engineering building in 1994-1995.

A quarry on the north side of Crew's Hole Road, Crew's Hole. The 1949 1:2500 Ordnance Survey map of the area marks the site as an "Old Quarry". The function of the quarry is not known but may have been for clay for the nearby Bristol Fireclay Company brickworks (SMR 20239).

KNOWN_AS: Statue of Edmund Burke, Colston Avenue
MONUMENT_DESC:
Statue of Edmund Burke, Colston Avenue. Burke was one of Bristol's members of Parliament during the eighteenth century. Funds for the bronze figure, a copy of the statue in St. Stephen's Hall in London, were donated by Sir W. H. Wills and it was unveiled by the then Prime Minister, Lord Rosebery, on 30th October 1894 (Merritt 2002, 28-29). The statue was set at the southern end of Magpie Park later in the 1890s (at ST 58590 72944) and was moved, apparently during the creation of the Centre gardens in the 1950s, to a new position closer to Colston Avenue (st ST 58599 72947).
The figure of Burke is set on a large red granite plinth with a moulded top which carries two bronze inscriptions. That on the front of the plinth reads "Burke 1774-1780. "I wish to be a member of parliament to have my share of doing good and resisting evil." Speech at Bristol 1780". The rear inscription reads "To his fellow citizens. From Sir Henry Wills Bart. MP 1894."
The statue was moved to its current position in May 2003 as part of a scheme to repave the northern part of the Centre Promenade.
The statue has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/16/2138).

KNOWN_AS: Sugar House north of Lewin's Mead
MONUMENT_DESC: Sugar House, located some 25 metres to the north of Nelson Street. The building is recorded by the survey of the city made in 1828 by John Plumley and George Ashmead. The building was recorded lying 32 metres to the north of the Lewin's Mead street frontage. The site is now beneath the rear part of the Greyfriars office building.

No.12 West Street, Old Market. The building is a timber-framed single-bay house of three storeys and attic with a rendered façade. It is of late seventeenth-or early eighteenth-century date and appears to have been built as the western of a pair with No.14 West Street. The building was probably constructed with a gabled roof. A surviving passage, paved with Pennant Sandstone flags, served both buildings leading from West Street to the rear of the property. The entrance door to the upper floors was off this passage.
The building was constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble bonded in a red sandy mortar with white lime inclusions. These walls are extant in the rear two thirds of the structure. The rear elevation, however, has seen a number of phases of alteration.
The upper floors oversail the passage, supported by several large oak beams and structural beams survive at all levels within the building. The internal plan has been significantly altered over time and the original organisation of the internal spaces has not yet been established. However, particularly at ground-floor the beams show evidence of mortices where internal timber partitions are likely to have been removed.
Both buildings were refronted in the nineteenth century. The ground-floor is currently occupied by a shopfront with a central entrance doorway. There are three doors in the eastern wall of No.12 West Street and the main entrance to the property is the first, northern, of these. This opens into a narrow stairwell with a moulded timber jamb on its western side. This was inserted into the building in the eighteenth- or early nineteenth-century and was an octagonal brick structure. Above the ground floor the party wall with No.14 West Street appears to have been reconstructed at a similar date. Timbers were nailed to the knees of the cross timbers to extend across the shared passage and is the timber framed party wall above rests on these extensions.
Internally no original fittings or features are known to survive, apart from a possible alcove for a cupboard in the western party wall at second floor. A number of historic timbers are extant in the ceilings, however. The roof and part of the parapet was replaced in the late-nineteenth or early-twentieth century.
At the rear, southern, end of the passage there was probably a detached kitchen constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble. Much of the shell of this appears to survive but part of the eastern and northern wall have been removed, and the original roof replaced with a lean-to pantile roof at a lower level.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/12/1661).

KNOWN_AS: B Bond Bonded Warehouse, Smeaton Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
B Bond Bonded Warehouse, located on the south side of Cumberland Basin, between the basin and the New Cut. The warehouse was built in 1908 to a design by the Docks Committee engineer. William Cowlin and Son Ltd. were responsible for the constructing the warehouse and used the reinforced concrete system invented by he French engineer Edmond Coignet (1851-1916) - the first major structure in England to do so (Buchanan & Cossons 1969, 64).
The building footprint measures 65 metres from north-west to south-east by 32 metres wide. It is of nine storeys, with the south-west facing having 18 bays and the side elevations 6 bays. The ground floor is in black brick forming a low plinth and has large, arched openings for loading on the south-west side. The four bays at the centre of this elevation project forward of the building and this accommodates a large arched entrance at ground floor. The upper floors are finished with red bricks, and blue engineering bricks. The building has a cornice of black moulded brick, and stone parapet. The roof is of Welsh slate. Internally the building was open plan, and was divided into equal parts by a central spine wall.
The building was used as a bonded warehouse until the mid-1990s. It was subject to a major refurbishment and conversion to office accommodation for Bristol City Council in the late 1990s which saw some alterations to the fabric.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/1307).

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Bristol Dental Hospital, Lower Maudlin Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
Penitentiary or prison, located on the south side of Upper Maudlin Street. A seventeenth-century house of L-shaped plan with a later addition to the south-east. Garden, or south-east, elevations. Main house of 3-window range with a right-hand return of 1-window. 3 storeys and attics. 2 gables to main elevation, 1 to return, and 1 to south-east end of same. Entrance to right end of main wall, 2 wide sashes to left. Similar sashes to first-floor, but narrower example above entrance. 3 normal-size sashes to second-floor. 1 shorter sash to each gable. Right-hand return with possible ground-floor casement window, otherwise wider sashes to the next 2 floors, normal sash to attic. Extension block along part of north-east side of garden, 2 storeys and 3-window range, rubble foundations below a plinth, rendered main walls, left-hand entrance below segmental arch, small round-arched window above, 2 full-length round-arched sash windows with gothic tracery. At first-floor, 3 sashes. Roof not recorded. 
Pump and cistern/sink at south corner of the seventeenth-century return. Level area in the angle between the two ranges, then the garden slopes down to a lower area. A south-west garden wall of rubble construction, with ashlar gateposts with ball finials near to its north-west end.
Partly later the site for the church of St. James-the-Less, consecrated in 1867.
Map of 1792 shows Tile House on N bank of Avon. {1}

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Bristol Dental Hospital, Upper Maudlin Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
A Romano-British structure, interpreted as a barn, which was recorded during an archaeological excavation on the site of the Moravian Church in Upper Maudlin Street in 1976. The structure recorded was an earth-bonded stone wall with evidence of post pads for structural timbers, typical of other Romano-British rural buildings in the area. Thus it was likely to have had stone foundations with the upper part and roof of timber. The building is likely to have been one element of a small farmstead. It is possible that this structure is part of the same building excavated immediately to the north-east in 1973, and part of a large millstone found then may suggest that it is a mill.
The construction of the Bristol Dental Hospital probably destroyed all remains of the sites excavated in 1973 and 1976 at the eastern end of the site. There is likely to be much better preservation to the west, where there is currently a car park if the site extends that far.

The Great Crane, located on the west wall of the Mud Dock. The crane was constructed c1735 and was designed by John Padmore. It was of two storeys, with much of the eastern long side recessed and spanned by a wide arch, revealing, behind, a first-floor gallery. The ground-floor was open and had fourteen columns, possibly of cast-iron, supporting the timber first-floor. The structure included three individual cranes, worked by treadmills, with one at each end of a large arch on the eastern side and the third crane at the south western corner of the building. The ridge roof was gabled at the south end, but was partially hipped, topped by a gablet, at the opposite end. There were two dormers on the east side of the roof. A drawing of 1747 (reproduced in Buchanan and Cossons (1970 38a) shows large treadmills at first-floor level, with, at the base of each crane, a feature looking something like a ship's wheel. Beneath the first-floor balcony were two large sets of scales.

KNOWN_AS: Part of the Back Hall complex
MONUMENT_DESC:
Warehouse. Part of the complex of buildings known collectively as Back Hall. At one time the entry point for strangers' goods, later in use as the leather market. This part lay to the west, north and east of the main yard, which was entered from Baldwin Street. At the north end of the yard was the street entrance, with large double doors. Above the inner arch was a large sign or notice board, with, immediately above it, a 2-light window. At second-floor level was a clock, within a pedimented frame. The western range lay between the yard and the original line of the north end of Back Street. Four tall arches are illustrated by O'Neill (BRSMG M2234), the northernmost blocked in. Two storeys of windows and openings at various levels, mostly of 2 or 3 lights, lay above the arcade. The roof was not visible. Above the southernmost arch, which had a decorative keystone, were the City Arms, with the initials 'C.B.' and the date 1716, surmounted by a plaque bearing crossed swords, a crown, and the initial 'G.R.'. These last may refer to a rebuilding of the range, as the windows appear earlier in date. 
Parts of the buildings were archaeologically excavated in 1958.

KNOWN_AS: Cardiff Boat Public House, Welsh Back
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Cardiff Boat Public House, located on Welsh Back. The building occupied the south-east corner of the St. Nicholas Parish extension burial ground in Crow Lane [BUAD 43M]. A dwelling stood on the site from 1422 when a rent for it is known to have been paid to the merchant Richard Trenode. By 1579 it was occupied by Welthian Betts, a widow, when it was on the north side of a lane leading to Baste Street [modern Queen Charlotte Street] (Leech, 1997 168-169). The building is recorded by early-nineteenth century watercolours in the Braikenridge Collection of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery, notably that by T. L. S. Rowbotham made in 1825 (BRSMG M2238) which shows the east-facing elevation on Welsh Back and part of the north-facing elevation, and another by Hugh O'Neill of 1823 (BRSMG M2279) also showing the north-facing and the west-facing elevation.
These show a gabled two-bay house of two storeys plus attic with a pantile roof. It was of sixteenth- or seventeenth-century date. Its footprint measured 6.25 metres north-south and 13.3 metres from east to west. The main, east-facing, elevation fronted on to Welsh Back and the ground floor was a shopfront with the main doorway at the north end of the elevation. The fenestration to the south of the doorway consisted of a pair of three-by-four light with a stall riser beneath. There were signboards above both the door and the windows. The first and attic storeys were divided by a moulded string course and the fenestration of both storeys consisted of cross-windows. There was a small window near the apex of the gable. A tall chimney stack projected around a further storey above the eaves from the south wall of the building. At the centre of the north elevation there was a single window at ground, and at first-floor one at the centre of the elevation and one at the western end, the latter beneath a gablet. There were small two-light mullioned windows at the centre of the rear, west-facing, elevation and, immediately to the north, a projecting single-flue chimney stack. In the north side of the roof there was a skylight.
In 1850 the building was occupied by Frederick Willis when it was known as The Cardiff Boat (BRO Plan Book C fo.98a). It appears to have survived until the end of the nineteenth century and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 scale plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.5) surveyed in 1882. The Goad Fire Insurance plan of January 1887 indicates that by then the building formed part of the Tanner Brothers stationery factory (along with the Old Custom House [BUAD 41M] to the south). It was presumably demolished at the same time as the redevelopment of St. Nicholas Burial Ground after 1902.
The site of the building now lies beneath the eastern side of Telephone House.

No.53 St. Michael's Hill, located on the south west side of the hill. The building is a three storey house with a basement and has a hipped pantiled roof. The plot of land on which the building stands was leased from Eusebius Brookes by William Rufford in 1683. The house was built between 1683 and 1689 (Leech 2000, 64) The building is constructed of limestone ashlar and stone rubble, and is rendered. The building has a double-depth plan.
The main north east facing elevation has three bays. On the south side of the elevation there is a recessed door, set within a plain opening, which leads directly on to the terrace deck in front of the building. This door may lead to a basement. On the north side of the elevation steps lead up to the porch enclosing the main entrance door at first-floor level. These steps project forward from the line of the main elevation. The main entrance door is enclosed by a square twentieth century trellis porch with a flat roof. All the windows in the elevation are sashes with moulded voussoirs above the opening. A parapet with flat coping stones surrounds the roof. A rendered chimney projects from the south side of the roof.
Leech reports that internally original ceiling beams survive, as well as seventeenth century stairs (Leech 2000, 64). 
The ratebooks indicate that the house had been finished by 1689 but no occupant is recorded at this time. In 1695 Samuel Payne is the first recorded occupant. The ratebooks record occupancy during the eighteenth century (Leech 2000, 64-65).
The building has a grade II listing (listed building No. 901-1/10/261).

No.11, Small Street. The building was probably designed as a house with ground-floor shop and was constructed in the late-eighteenth century. It has an early- to mid-nineteenth century shop front. The building is of four storeys and attic, and has a hipped pantile roof. The main, north-east facing, elevation is of rendered brick with limestone dressings, and has a two-window range. The building has a double-depth plan. The upper floors of the north-western half of the building are carried over Leonard Lane and the access into the lane is formed by a segmental-arched carriage archway with a keystone of freestone carved into a head. The return has a clinker plinth. The vaulted basement of the building may be of medieval date.

Range of late C19 industrial buildings, the main block of which is 3 storeys high & 8 bays long. Gates have Geo Adlam Engineers shaped into metalwork, Adlam specialised in the manufacture of brewery equipment. One of their steam engines is extant at Northgate Brewery, of Wadworth at Devizes.{1}

No.86 Castle Street. The building was a jettied, gabled house of three storeys, dating to the mid-seventeenth century. It was almost certainly constructed as part of the redevelopment of the site of Bristol Castle after its demolition in the late 1650s.
By the beginning of the nineteenth century a shop had been created at ground-floor. During the later-nineteenth century he building was occupied by T. Goldesbrough, tobacconist. The building was almost entirely destroyed by a fire that began late on the evening of Saturday, May 18th 1907 and burned well into the following day (Whit-Sunday). As a result of the fire damage, The building was very extensively rebuilt as an architecturally plain brick structure.

Nos. 5-8 High Street. Four jettied, gabled houses located on the east side of High Street.
Four jettied houses, each with a front gable, all rather narrow, the central two matching in detail above first-floor level. Shop fronts at ground-floor; pairs of sashes at first-floor; single sashes at second-floor; no windows to roof spaces. Much of the interior had been altered, but it was still possible to see that each gable did not necessarily represent an individual property. The solar or principal room extended over Nos.6 & 7at first-floor level, with a small apartment adjoining in No.5. It "was also clear" that No.4 was a part of the original premises.
Only fragments of oak panelling survived in the solar, but there was a finely carved overmantel of sixteenth century date, bearing the name Wyllem Young, also the initials "WY" and "IY" (BUAD 989A). A small medieval relic found on the ground-floor, about six feet in, was a bracket post of the entrance porch, pierced by a narrow light with pointed trefoil head, the post 9ft.3in. high to the top of the spring.
The cellars were of massive construction. A flight of eight steps led down to that below No.6 (BUAD .990A), which was 19 feet long and 11 feet wide, beyond which was an arched passage that led to a pair of parallel cellars (each 37 feet long by 15 feet wide) that communicated at the far end. These must have run under the adjacent properties. From the northern section fourteen steps led up again, with a small chamber (BUAD 991A) leading off the sixth step.
The buildings were demolished in order to erect new premises for Messrs. Jones but were recorded by John Pritchard during demolition, commencing in January 1914.

No.11, Bellevue. The building is the southernmost of a terrace of nineteen houses. The plot, formerly part of the grounds associated with Clifton Hill House, was leased from the Society of Merchant Venturers by Harry Elderton in 1792 for a term of forty years (Ison 1952, 234). Construction of the terrace began under the supervision of William Paty (Priest 2003, 101) but was abandoned in 1793 when the outbreak of war caused a slump in development. The buildings remained uncompleted for nearly two decades but the terrace had apparently been completed by 1815.
The building is a rendered three-storey house with attic and basement. It has a slate mansard roof. A raised walk on the east side of the building extends the full length of the terrace.
In 1882 the building was occupied by Mrs Rudd Lucas..
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/6).

No.13, Bellevue. The building is the southernmost of a terrace of nineteen houses. The plot, formerly part of the grounds associated with Clifton Hill House, was leased from the Society of Merchant Venturers by Harry Elderton in 1792 for a term of forty years (Ison 1952, 234). Construction of the terrace began under the supervision of William Paty (Priest 2003, 101) but was abandoned in 1793 when the outbreak of war caused a slump in development. The buildings remained uncompleted for nearly two decades but the terrace had apparently been completed by 1815.
The building is a rendered three-storey house with attic and basement. It has a slate mansard roof. A raised walk on the east side of the building extends the full length of the terrace.
In 1882 the building was occupied by R. S. Clough.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/6).

No.15, Bellevue. The building is the southernmost of a terrace of nineteen houses. The plot, formerly part of the grounds associated with Clifton Hill House, was leased from the Society of Merchant Venturers by Harry Elderton in 1792 for a term of forty years (Ison 1952, 234). Construction of the terrace began under the supervision of William Paty (Priest 2003, 101) but was abandoned in 1793 when the outbreak of war caused a slump in development. The buildings remained uncompleted for nearly two decades but the terrace had apparently been completed by 1815.
The building is a rendered three-storey house with attic and basement. It has a slate mansard roof. A raised walk on the east side of the building extends the full length of the terrace.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/6).

No.16, Bellevue. The building is the southernmost of a terrace of nineteen houses. The plot, formerly part of the grounds associated with Clifton Hill House, was leased from the Society of Merchant Venturers by Harry Elderton in 1792 for a term of forty years (Ison 1952, 234). Construction of the terrace began under the supervision of William Paty (Priest 2003, 101) but was abandoned in 1793 when the outbreak of war caused a slump in development. The buildings remained uncompleted for nearly two decades but the terrace had apparently been completed by 1815.
The building is a rendered three-storey house with attic and basement. It has a slate mansard roof. A raised walk on the east side of the building extends the full length of the terrace.
In 1882 the building was occupied by George Harris.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/6).
Lies on the north bank of the Avon, between the bank and the road in 1792. {1}

No.18, Bellevue. The building is the southernmost of a terrace of nineteen houses. The plot, formerly part of the grounds associated with Clifton Hill House, was leased from the Society of Merchant Venturers by Harry Elderton in 1792 for a term of forty years (Ison 1952, 234). Construction of the terrace began under the supervision of William Paty (Priest 2003, 101) but was abandoned in 1793 when the outbreak of war caused a slump in development. The buildings remained uncompleted for nearly two decades but the terrace had apparently been completed by 1815.
The building is a rendered three-storey house with attic and basement. It has a slate mansard roof. A raised walk on the east side of the building extends the full length of the terrace.
In 1882 the building was occupied by a Mrs Williamson.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/6).

KNOWN_AS: Parish boundary marker stone, St. Michael's Hill
MONUMENT_DESC: Parish boundary marker stone, located at the back of the footway on the south-western side of St. Michael's Hill, immediately to the north of its junction with Tyndall's Park Road. Only the top element of the stone projects above the footway (BUAD 4317) and no lettering is therefore visible on the face of the stone. However, the stone marks the boundary of the parish of St. Michael.

KNOWN_AS: Unitarian Almshouse and School, Stokes Croft
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Unitarian Almshouse in Stokes Croft. The building also housed Stokes Croft Endowed School. The charity was founded in 1722 by public subscription. In 1726 Joseph Houlton and Abraham Hook conveyed to the charity's trustees "and to Richard Hort, since deceased, a certain piece of building, with the appurtenances, then used as to some parts thereof, as a charity school, and as to others parts thereof as an almshouse" (Manchee 1831, 202). The intention was apparently to provide financial support and education for thirty boys.
The building consisted of a range of two- to three-storeys at the eastern side of the site with two wings, each of three storeys, running along the northern and southern sides towards Stokes Croft to create a central courtyard. The central range had a central entrance above a double curved stairway (forming a horseshoe), with large pedimented sashes on either side. The three sashes above these were plain. There were also cellar lights on either side of the entrance steps. The wings constituted the almshouse while the school occupied the ground floor of the central range. The upper floor was the master's house. The wings were divided into individual almshouses, three on each floor. There was one continuous roof, hipped at its ends to Stokes Croft.
Latterly the school and almshouse were run by the Lewin's Mead Unitarian Church. By the late 1820s the financial resources of the school had reduced to a level sufficient to support only one boy, and at that date there were eleven women and one man resident in the almshouse (Manchee 1831, 203-204). The building appears to have been rebuilt, or refaced, in the late eighteenth- or early nineteenth-century. It survived into the twentieth century but was destroyed by bombing on 24 November 1940.

No.34 King Street, located on the north side of King Street. The land between the lane on the east side of the Old Library (BUAD 14M) and St. Nicholas Almshouses (BUAD 17M) was leased to Thomas Wickham, carpenter, by the Corporation in 1650 on condition that he built six messuages within ten years. No.34 King Street seems to have been constructed as a warehouse for No.33 King Street (BUAD 111M) and its footprint extended originally some 4.6 metres north from the street frontage. The warehouse was presumably part of the property associated with No.33 King Street until the later nineteenth century. No.33 King Street had been constructed by 1658. In 1673 the buildings on Wickham's plot were leased to Robert Dowding, ropemaker. No.33, and "a sellar adjoining", was at that time occupied by Robert Cary, grocer. A new lease was issued to John Freke, gentleman, in 1688 and the house was apparently then in the possession of Jacob Beel, merchant (BRO 04335(7) fo.82). By 1700 it was occupied by John Templeman, mariner. Freke's lease reverted to the Corporation in 1716 and in the following year it was leased to Thomas Seed, hooper. From 1739 Seed leased the property on a yearly basis and occupied it himself.
By January 1887 a building had been constructed at the rear of the plot, leaving an open courtyard between this building and the warehouse on the street frontage. This courtyard was not developed before the later 1950s. Leech noted that plans of the building made in 1985 recorded a chimney stack against the north wall of the site, although this is now the location of a lift (Leech 1997).
The ground floor of the building was surveyed by John Bryant in 1986 (BUAD 375). A full survey was made by Dr. Roger Leech of the Royal Commission on the Historical Monuments of England in 1993 (BUAD 2045; Leech 1997).
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/16/608). There is a photograph of the exterior of the building in the SMR Collection of Ground-based photographs, No.1341.

The Guildhall, located on the west side of Broad Street.
A frontage of 69 feet. Holmes' drawing of unknown date (1813?), M2436, shows the old front just as scaffolding was erecting to new front the building. Ground-floor in left and right sections, divided by a vertical line. On the left of the left-hand, a two-centred arch doorway with lamp bracket above, then 2 arched openings that are largely obscured by the planking of the fence. On the right, an arched doorway to left, another shorter one at the right, and in the centre a plaque or window. String course above the left-hand ground-floor. A decorative frieze above the right-hand area, with, immediately above, a large traceried window reaching two storeys in height, almost to the top of the wall. In the centre of the left half of the upper wall, twin two-centred arch windows, sharing a central jamb; at the left end, arms in a square frame; at the right end, a similar but larger feature below a niche containing the figure of Charles II (M2440). At second-floor, twin arched windows in a shared square head. One parapet common to both halves of the facade. The wall was equal in height to the late C18 or early C19 buildings immediately to the north. 
Rowbotham shows the building after the refronting (M2437). The whole front in stucco or ashlar, with a moulded cornice-parapet. The ground-floor a symmetrical arrangement of openings with two-centred arches and deep mouldings: 3 doorways, the central possibly false, and 2 lower openings, perhaps only niches. Above a string course, 2 large traceried windows with two-centred heads, the northernmost perhaps the original surviving from the earlier facade. Each window of 8 lights in 2 groups of 4, rising to 2 arches within the uppermost tracery. Arms at each end of the elevation, with, between the windows, a statue within an ogee-headed niche; above, a quatrefoil. 
The interior of the court illustrated by O'Neill and Johnson (M2438-M2439). Arch-braced roof of at least 7 bays, at right angles to the street, with at its end, one of the large traceried windows, presumably the northernmost. Trusses springing off of corbel heads. In the side wall to the right of the window, an arcade of 2 arches. 
The General Gaol Delivery, Court of Nisi Prius, Quarter Sessions, the Sheriffs Courts, Court of Conscience & Request, and Elections for members were held at the Guildhall (Braikenridge Notes, A.74x).
Replaced by the 1843 Guildhall, which occupies a longer frontage.

KNOWN_AS: St James' Ragged School, Marlborough Hill
MONUMENT_DESC: School building on the south corner of Afred Parade and Marlborough Hill. The school was in existence by 1870 and is first depicted on the 1880s Ordnace Survey plan of the area. It was originally known as the St James' Ragged School and was apparently established for boys, girls and infants and had a capacity of 225 places (Jackson, 2002). The building is extant (March 2010) and constructed of Pennant sandstone with freestone mouldings to the windows and doors. It has a pitched roof of Roman tiles with gable facades to Alfred Parade and Marlborough Hill. The main entrance is on Marlborough Hill. The building is currently in use by the hospital.

The Angel Tavern, No.30 High Street. The building was a jettied, gabled house of four storeys and was of probable fifteenth-century date. Column to left of left-hand entrance; bow shopfront to right. Three storeys of almost full-width bay Ipswich windows with glazing to sides. No attic storey proper.
The house was apparently constructed in the fifteenth century. Watercolour drawings executed in 1820 by Hugh O'Neill show the remains of a large fifteenth-century chimney-piece decorated with 8 trefoil-headed panels (BRSMG M2247). It appears to have been on the ground-floor, probably at the rear, as the drawing shows a flagstone floor, and a window that does not match any in the front elevation. In 1821 O'Neill drew part of the medieval roof of the inn, and this had at least three arch-braced trusses (BRSMG M2248).
By the late eighteenth century the building had become a public house, "The Bull Tavern" and between 1810 and 1826 it was known as "The Angel Tavern".

The High Cross located at the junction of High Street, Wine Street, Corn Street and Broad Street. The cross was erected in 1373, according to local tradition, (apparently as a replacement for an earlier cross) to celebrate the acquisition of county status and, according to Adams's Chronicle, was repainted and gilded in 1490 and again in 1573. In May 1633 the cross was remodelled, work finishing in December 1634. The Common Council was petitioned in 1733 by people living in the area who demanded its removal, arguing that:
"It hath been insinuated by some that this Cross, on account of its antiquity ought to be lookt upon as something sacred; But when we consider that we are protestants, and that popery ought effectually to be garded against in this Nation, we make this our request to you to consider. If the opening of a passage to four of the principal streets in this City ought not to outweigh anything that can be said for the keeping up a ruinous and superstitious Relick, which is at present a public nuisance" (quoted in Liversidge 1978 2).
The removal of the cross was ordered, though the stones were stored by the Corporation. In 1736, after the intervention of Alderman Price the cross was re-erected on College Green (at NGR ST 58349 72772).
A proposal to remove the cross from College Green was made in 1757 by a contractor working on the improvement of the paths on College Green, but the monument was not dismantled until August 1762. After a period in storage in the Cathedral it was given to Henry Hoare by the Dean and removed, in August 1766, to Stourhead where it now stands. Hoare considered that "the legs are not worth fetching" (Pryce 1861 559) andduring its re-erection the original base was replaced with a solid structure.
On the base rests a second stage on which four monarchs are depicted. Originally King John faced north (into Broad Street), Henry II faced east (into Wine Street), Edward III, a later addition according to Ponting, faced south (into High Street). The upper stages were added in 1633, and included four Tudor and Stuart monarchs, Henry VIII, Elizabeth I, James I and Charles I. At the top, was a spirelet which supported a copper cross. The whole structure stood 48 feet high according to Ponting who measured the cross at Stourhead. The stone used was an oolitic limestone, probably from Dundry or Bath. Liversidge argues that the lower tiers are of early fifteenth-century date (Liversidge 1978 11).
A replica of the cross (BUAD 40M), made in 1851 by John Norton, is located in Berkeley Square.

KNOWN_AS: Ring's Ohio Tobacco-Pipe Manufactory, Commercial Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
Ring's clay tobacco pipe factory, located on the northern side of Temple Back. The business was founded by John Ring in partnership with Frederick Cookworthy in 1802 (Price et al., 1984 264) and a factory established "opposite George's Deal Yard" on Temple Back. The factory was gutted by a fire so that, according to the Bristol Mirror of 27th July 1811, "in little more than an hour nothing more than bare walls were left standing" but was soon operating again. In 1817 Ring's partnership with Cookworthy was dissolved and Ring took over the running of the factory alone until his death in August 1818. The business and premises were auctioned and may have been bought by a William Bissix (Price et al., 1984 267). The business was taken on by John Ring's elder brother Richard Frank Ring who built a factory - the Ohio Tobacco-Pipe Manufactory - on the north side of Commercial Road at Temple Back which exported pipes to the Caribbean, the east coast of the United States, Canada and Ireland. By 1861 the business had become Richard Charles Ring & Co. although its interests diversified considerably and by 1884 the factory had apparently been sold to Hawley & Co. The factory was vacant at the time of a fire insurance survey in August 1896 and the second edition Ordnance Survey map of 1902 indicates that the factory had, by then, been demolished.
Some archaeological work has taken place on the site since the 1980s. Part of a muffle kiln from the factory was recovered during excavation of a service pipe in the mid 1980s [BUAD 3313] by Reg Jackson (Egan, 1984 318-319; Peacey, 1996 33-34). Part of the site was excavated in 1995 [BUAD 517] by Rod Burchill (Burchill, 1995; Williams, 1996 86). Large-scale office development at Temple Quay in the late 1990s destroyed most of the monument and only small elements, if anything, will remain.

KNOWN_AS: St. Nicholas of Tolentino Church School, Pennywell Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Nicholas of Tolentino Church School on the northern side of Lawfords Gate and lying immediately to the east of St. Nicholas of Tolentino Church. The school was built between 1848 and 1851 to a design by Charles Hansom and expanded in 1873. New school buildings designed by Scoles and Raymond were built in 1910 (Gomme et al. 1979, 35).
The later buildings have been demolished and the southern part of the site has been redeveloped for St. Nicholas House.

No.7, Castle Street. The building was a gabled of three storeys and attic with a pantile roof lying on the north side of Castle Street. It was almost certainly constructed as part of the redevelopment of the site of Bristol Castle after its demolition in the late 1650s, probably in 1664.
The building was painted by T. L. S. Rowbotham in 1829 (BUAD 1832; BRSMG Mb6398) when the occupier was "I. Walsh & Co Irish Linen Warehouse." The ground floor of the main elevation was a shopfront with the main door slightly to the west of the centre of the elevation. The first- and second-floor fenestration comprised a canted bay, with a large central sash and small sashes on each side. On either side of the bay there was pargetting or moulded plasterwork. The pargetting on either side of the bay at first floor had central elliptical panels, the western containing the letters "SD" and the eastern the date "1664". The plasterwork was very similar in style to that of No.8, suggesting that the work on the two buildings was executed at the same time and for the same owners. The divisions between first and second-floor and between second-floor and attic level were marked by moulded string courses, each extending the full-width of the elevation. The attic was lit by a three-light casement at the centre of the gable and there was a chimney stack on the east side of the roof.
The building survived into the early twentieth century. Its site now lies in Castle Park on the east side of the path from Broad Weir past the end of St. Peter's Church.

KNOWN_AS: Church of St. James-the-Less, Upper Maudlin Street
POSTAL_ADDRESS: Bristol Dental Hospital, Upper Maudlin Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. James-the-Less, Upper Maudlin Street. The church was built in 1867 by a committee of the Bristol Female Penitentiary to serve the penitentiary (Ralph & Cobb 1991, 27). Arrowsmith's Dictionary of Bristol reports that the church was consecrated by the Bishop of Bristol on 30th December 1867 (Spear & Arrowsmith 1884 56). It was designed by Pope and Bindon and built of Pennant Sandstone with freestone dressings. The entrance from Upper Maudlin Street was at the west end with a stair turret in the centre of the north wall giving access to an upper gallery and suggesting that the church was aisled at least on its north side. A transept crossed the apsaidal east end.
The history of the building is at present unclear, but it seems to have been built for the penitentiary and later become a chapel-at-ease to St. James, possibly after 1873 when it was consecrated, and the gallery appears to have been reserved for the exclusive use of the inmates of the penitentiary next door.
A "Religious Census" carried out by the Western Daily Press on 30 October 1881 recorded 167 worshippers at Morning Service and 158 at Evening Service.
In late summer 1932 the building was purchased by the Christian Lads' Brigade, founded in 1893, as a new headquarters and converted for their use. The architect was W. H. Watkins and the scheme involved the insertion of a reinforced concrete mezzanine floor. This floor was used for the gymnasium and lectures and concerts while the ground floor was subdivided with folding partitions to provide classrooms and an office. The building works were undertaken by Messrs W. Cowlin.
The opening ceremony was held on Saturday 22 October 1932 and was presided over by the Bishop of Malmesbury. A Guard of Honour in Upper Maudlin Street was inspected by Field Marshal Sir Claud Jacob (1863-1948), Commandant of the Church Lads' Brigade (Colonel of the Worcestershire Regiment and until recently Military Secretary at the India Office) and the building was formally opened by Mrs Yda Roberts, who had donated £1000 towards the conversion works.
The church survived into the early 1960s but was subsequently demolished.

The Volunteer Tavern, located on the southern side of New Street, Old Market. The building is a three-storey, four bay structure with a pitched pantile roof and is constructed of Pennant sandstone in a random rubble construction. The building was probably constructed in the eighteenth-century, and the Goad fire insurance plan suggests that it may originally have been two terraced houses which have been converted to a single unit by the creation of doorways through the party wall.
The main entrance is just to the south-east of the centre of the elevation. On its south-east side is a bay window with a tiled roof. The fenestration consists of sash windows at all floors, although there are two small casements at second-floor level at the north-western end of the main elevation. There are Pennant sandstone chimneystacks at either end of the roof although the south-eastern of these has been raised using brick. At the centre of the roof a smaller brick stack has apparently been added.
There are photographs of the building in the SMR Collection of Ground-based photographs [Nos 1713-1714].

No.33, King Street, located on the north side of King Street. The building is the earliest surviving house in King Street. The land between the lane on the east side of the Old Library (BUAD 14M) and St. Nicholas Almshouses (BUAD 17M) was leased to Thomas Wickham, carpenter, by the Corporation in 1650 on condition that he built six messuages within ten years. No.33 King Street had been constructed by 1658. In 1673 the buildings on Wickham's plot were leased to Robert Dowding, ropemaker. No.33, and "a sellar adjoining", was at that time occupied by Robert Cary, grocer. A new lease was issued to John Freke, gentleman, in 1688 and the house was apparently then in the possession of Jacob Beel, merchant (BRO 04335(7) fo.82). By 1700 it was occupied by John Templeman, mariner. Freke's lease reverted to the Corporation in 1716 and in the following year it was leased to Thomas Seed, hooper. From 1739 Seed leased the property on a yearly basis and occupied it himself.
The building is a jettied, gabled house of three storeys, attic and basement. The side and rear walls are of stone rubble and the rear wall of the house is likely to be founded on the remains of the town wall known as the Marsh Wall.
The main, south-facing, elevation is timber-framed. The ground-floor has three windows and a doorway, the first-floor has a bay window, the second a pair of windows, with a single window at attic level. On the ground floor is a probably contemporary chimney-piece. The ceiling of the front first-floor room has good plaster decoration in two sections separated by a chamfered beam, with pointed central quatrefoils and pomegranites, winged cherubs and corner decoration. Around the upper part of the walls is a frieze of adorsal hounds and fruit.
Plans of the house associated with alterations were made in 1956 and 1985 and the cellar was surveyed by John Bryant in 1980 (BUAD 374). A further survey was made by Dr. Roger Leech of the Royal Commission on the Historical Monuments of England in 1993 (BUAD 2044; Leech 1997).
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/16/607). There is a photograph of the exterior of the building in the SMR Collection of Ground-based photographs, No.1341.

KNOWN_AS: Everard Printing Works, Nos.37-38 Broad Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
Everard Building, a printing works, located on the east side of Broad Street. The building was constructed in 1900-1901 to a design by Henry Williams. The facade was by W. J. Neatby, Chief Designer for Doulton and Co. 
Polychromatic 'Carrara' marble-ware faience. Pre-Raphaelite style. 3 storeys; 4-window range. 
A wide semicircular-arched doorway with flanking elliptical-arched windows. A pair of semicircular-arched first-floor windows, EDWARD EVERARD in Art Nouveau lettering, spandrel panels featuring Gutenburg (L) and Morris (R). A second-floor arcade of 4 semicircular arches. In the gable is a semicircular-arched panel. Interior completely rebuilt behind the facade. Forrmerly part of a larger printing works extending to John Street. 
Beneath is a fragment of medieval cellar (1022A), possibly 14th.century, ribbed, and part of a 5-bay vault. Now combined with the cellars of Nos.35 & 36, as part of a public house. The works was demolished behind the façade c.1970
An important early use of glazed coloured external ware to propagate Arts and Crafts ideas of the reconciliation of art and industry, in the largest decorative facade of its kind in Britain.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/11/527).

No.16 King Street, located on the southern side of King Street. The building was constructed in the mid-1660s apparently as the eastern of a group of three, the lease for the plots of Nos.16-18 being granted by the Bristol Corporation to Francis Bayley, a shipwright, in 1663 (BRO 04335(5) fo.4). This lease set a limit of three years for construction, suggesting that the three buildings had probably been completed by 1666.
The building is a single-bay, three-storey timber-framed house with a gabled roof. In its original form the plan of the building at ground-floor consisted of two principal rooms which were separated by a half-turn stair placed between them. The stair had square newel posts with ball finials, turned pendants and balusters and a moulded handrail, all of pine. The stair is extant at first-floor level and above. Access to the rear part of the building was through the passage on the eastern side and the architectural evidence suggests that the rear room probably occupied the fill-width of the building. This has a large chimneybreast in the west wall, suggesting that the room was originally the kitchen. The plan of the upper floors was similarly arranged, with two principal rooms, front and rear separated by the stair and landing on the east side and a closet on the west. Both principal rooms occupied the full width of the building. The roof is of principal rafter and butt purlin construction using pine and was originally of five bays.
At the south end of the plot, fronting on to Little King Street, a warehouse building (BUAD 1437M) was constructed in the late seventeenth or early eighteenth-century. This was of three storeys with hipped pantile roof. The structure was probably linked to the rear of the main house by a gallery at first-floor level.
By 1676 the house was leased by Thomas Barns of Landavenny, Monmouthshire. In 1703 it was in the hands of Thomas Branch, and had passed to John Aust, hooper, by 1724 (Leech 2001).
The main house was subject to some internal reorganisation in the early-eighteenth century when the half-turn stair at ground floor level was replaced with a straight stair to allow the two principal ground-floor rooms to be used as a single space. A partition was inserted to extend the side passage to the rear of the building at the same time and a window was inserted in the west wall of the stair at second floor to light the adjacent closet. By 1784 the building had been leased to John Rawson.
The building appears to have been significantly altered once more in the mid twentieth century, reportedly as the result of bomb damage. The King Street elevation was rebuilt and the northern bay of the roof was replaced with a flat roof during the twentieth century. The rear elevation of the building, including the rear gable of the roof, also seems to have been reconstructed at this time. The walls of the warehouse were re-constructed in brick at this time, although three seventeenth-century cross beams at ground floor and the central cross beam at first-floor were retained, as was the roof the timber of which are of late seventeenth- or early eighteenth-century date.
The building was surveyed by Dr. Roger Leech in 2001 (BUAD 3812; Leech 2001) and the report on this work also summarised the documentary history of the building. The original core of the main building appears to survive largely intact and several mid seventeenth-century features survive within the building, including the joists and boards of the cellar and a samson post located towards King Street, ovolo-moulded cross beams and doorcases at all floors, as well as several surviving elements of moulded plaster cornices. Much of the fabric of the roof also dates to the original construction of the house.
The house has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/16/601).

Howland's Burial Ground, on the north side of Newfoundland Street. The burial ground was created in 1804 and was named in the 1805 Land Tax returns for St. Paul's parish as "Weetch & Ward's Buring G[roun]d." A lease of 1808 refers to Weetch but also names Thomas Howland of Stapleton, a house carpenter who later lived at No.10 Wilson Street as the second party (Bryant 1999). The burial ground was measured around 35.5 metres from north to south and was 10 metres wide. It was described in 1850 as "in a dirty state. It is surrounded, on two sides, by houses, is crossed by a path, and is a common receptacle for filth and rubbish" (Clark 1850, 164). The burial register and other documentation relating to the cemetery is held in Bristol Record Office (BRO 11930(1-3)). A total of 1339 individuals were interred there, arranged in ten rows, A-E and AA-EE, with up to twenty plots to a row. Numbers buried in an individual plot varied between one and seventeen. Interment in the burial ground was ended by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852.
By the time of the first edition 1:500-scale Ordnance Survey Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.11) the burial ground had been turned into gardens. Archaeological evaluation in 1999 (BUAD 3528) established that the burial ground survived intact and it was subsequently incorporated into new development without disturbance.

Ebenezer Chapel, located on the southern side of Midland Road (formerly Orchard Street). The chapel was a Primitive Methodist chapel and was built in the mid nineteenth-century. It is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.22) surveyed in 1883 which indicates that the chapel had accommodation for 250. It is built of coursed Pennant sandstone rubble in a Norman-revival style with ashlar windows and doorway.
Internally the wooden galleries and pulpit survive, the galleries being supported on cast iron columns. A wooden stair on the south side of the main entrance leads up to the galleries. Steps to the north of the main entrance give access into the basement. In the basement the timber floor of the ground floor rests on cast iron columns. Each of the three sets of columns has a pair of broad columns flanking the central aisle with a more slender column to the north and the south. At the south-west corner of the basement an opening has been created through the external wall to allow goods to be brought down a sloping concrete ramp.
The roof is of slate and currently in a poor state of repair. The building is currently (09/10/2002) in use as an antique and architectural reclamation shop.

St. James Church House. Dated 1666 on a front plaque, altered C19, when southern half of house removed for construction of enlarged north aisle to St.James Church. Rendered Pennant rubble with limestone dressings, timber-framed right-hand wall, rubble lateral and axial stacks and slate cross gabled roof. 
Single front and rear rooms divided by a stack with fireplaces each side, and right-hand C19 stair. 2 storeys, attic and basement; 2-window range. Originally 2 gables to front, with, between, a gabled 2-storey porch, open at lower level, a small first-floor room with 6-light transomed window. The right-hand ground-floor window was square-headed with drip-moulding, 3 trefoil-headed lights, with a cellar access forward and below of it. Above was an 8-light transomed window, also with drip-moulding. Late C17 keyed oculus in the top of each gable. 2 small shields over the present doorway inscribed ETA and 1666, originally in the porch. [Thomas and Ann Ellis, 1666].
Inside, a fine late C17 ground-floor full-width front room with full panelling to a cornice, a panelled overmantel to left-hand fire surround, a fine carved overmantel to the rear with a central cartouche and side sections set back with carved classical allegorical figures holding shields. A fine plaster ceiling in 2 sections with detailed panels, pomegranates and moulded bosses, separated by a panelled Jacobean-style beam with strapwork, and a frieze above the cornice with adorsal griffins; panelling flanking fireplace and overmantel in the rear ground-floor room, behind which a C17 chimney-piece, again ETA and 1666; the first-floor front room has a small Tudor-arched doorway, now to a cupboard moulded and stopped beam; diagonal-braced timber-framed wall to north side of St.James with re-used timbers. 
A rebuild of part of the western claustral range of the Benedictine Priory of St. James. Incorporates the second and third (from the south) arches of the western cloister walk, infilled in the 18th/19th.centuries (967A). The infill of the northern arch encased the last remaining portion of the original tracery, in the Decorated style. The two arches are segmental pointed examples, probably from the 14th.century, and therefore presumably replacing earlier versions. 
Some details were recorded by Rowbotham (BRSMG M2849). Also, the fireplace at the rear of the surviving ground-floor room (BRSMG M2850).

KNOWN_AS: Society of Friends burial ground, Redcliff Pit
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Society of Friends or Quaker burial ground at Redcliff Pit. During the middle ages the site belonged to the Hospital of St. John the Baptist and was known as Redrock Garden. A hermitage was established at the south end of the garden (BUAD 627M). The hospital was dissolved in March 1544 and its lands were surrendered to the Crown. The site, and much of the associated property, was sold to Dr. George Owen, physician to Henry VIII and a Fellow of Merton College, Oxford. In 1665 the freehold of the site was acquired by the Society of Friends and a burial ground was established. By the nineteenth century the burial ground was set out in rows with stone markers for each. An Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852 imposed the restriction that "only one body [was] to be buried in each grave" on the burial ground.
In the later-nineteenth or early-twentieth century a uniform series of markers was created, each of sawn slate approximately 100 millimetres thick with a name carved into the face. The burial ground continued to be used until 1923. In 1927 the "gravestones were removed and placed behind a fence in front of the Hermit's Cell" (WRO 1699(28A) quoted in Stock 1996, 6).
The north end of the burial ground, including the entrance gate at that end, was lost when the inner circuit road was created in the late 1930s. A large water main was also laid across the site which uncovered lead coffins of probable late eighteenth- or early nineteenth-century date (BRO 40804(1)). These were left in situ. The site was given to the City of Bristol in 1950 and the graves were subject to clearance in 1956, the human remains being reinterred at Avon View Cemetery in grave numbers 1357-1358 and 1449-1450 Purple AA (Stock 1996, 7).

A stone culvert of ninetenth-century date running parallel to the northern side of Wellington Road, which is entered via manhole cover in the garden of The Phoenix public house.
The culvert runs from the public house west, beneath the site of the Broadweir Baths (now demolished). The only section so far archaeologically inspected is approximately 75 metres long and is built of Pennant Sandstone bonded in a black mortar containing fragments of clay tobacco pipe and rare brick fragments. The culvert is 3 metres wide and a maximum of 2.5 metres high (estimated). The arch of the culvert springs from different levels, with the base of the arch being approximately 0.3 metres lower on the south side than on the north. The floor of the culvert is concave and appears to be constructed of Pennant Sandstone at the edges and brick in the centre, although this is not confirmed as the floor of the culvert is covered with several centimetres of sediment. Overall the section of culvert available for inspection follows a sinuous course, curving slightly north and then turning southward again.
At the east end of the culvert excavation work, probably undertaken in the 1970s and associated with the construction of the car park, had broken through the arch of the culvert. It has been infilled with soil, completely blocking it, but no attempt has been made to repair the arch. Part of the floor of the culvert at the east end has been grouted with concrete. A manhole has been inserted in the centre of the length, and below this again is another manhole serving a further drain beneath the culvert. To the west of the manhole the roof has been replaced, at some time during the twentieth-century, with the insertion of reinforced concrete sections. At the far western end the culvert has been cut off by a brick wall with a concrete pipe through it at ground level. There is no direct water flow through the culvert.
The culvert is clearly not the main channel of the river Frome, which is further to the south, but its function is unknown. The two channels are shown on Millerd's 1673 map but may originally be earlier in date.

The Playhouse in Wine Street. The playhouse was owned by Nicholas Wolfe, cutler and was at a location which is uncertain, probably a tenement on the north side of the street (backing on to the south wall of Christ Church (BUAD 33M)), probably No.6 1/2, which was in the possession of Wolfe by the late sixteenth-century. Wolfe occupied this property in 1589 and carried out alterations to it including "the rearinge up higher" (BRO 04421(a) quoted in Leech 1997, 172). He renewed his lease in 1598 and this allowed him "to Newe buylde the said Tenemente and everye parte thereof with thappurtenances within fowre yearees nexte ensuinge the date hereof..." (quoted in Pilkington 1983, 14). The records of lawsuits in the Public Record Office (Pilkinton 1988) suggest that the theatre was in use by late 1604 or early 1605 and remained a playhouse until 1625, despite Wolfe's death in 1614. It appears that part of the building remained in domestic use, with some players staying there while performing in the city. The rooms were also let to "comedyantes". Under the terms of Wolfe's will annuities were granted to six Bristol charities out of the profits of the venture "for longe only as the same house shall continewe a playe house..." (quoted in Pilkinton 1988, 73). Jones (1988, 207) quotes an entry in the Treasurer's Book of Queen Elizabeth's Hospital which records receipt of £1 10s 0d for one year's rent "out of the Playhouse in Wyne Street, which was given by Nicholas Woolfe, cutler, to remain to the Hospital for ever."
The building passed into the possession of Anthony Bassett, tailor, and then through a number of hands including, successively, pewterers, a surgeon, and an upholsterer. By the mid eighteenth-century part of the property was in use as a dwelling while the another part was a shop.
The building would seem to been extant until c.1782 when the lease was assigned to the feoffees of Christ Church to facilitate the rebuilding of the church. Illustrations of Wine Street in the Braikenridge Collection suggest that the buildings against the church were rebuilt, or at least refronted, during the late eighteenth- or early nineteenth-century.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: The Old Rectory, Lower Church Lane
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Old Rectory, Lower Church Lane. James Millerd's map of Bristol of 1673, shows a building on the site, but the existing structure is a house of c.1740. This was the rectory to St. Michael's Church, which was partially refronted c.1770 and then largely rebuilt by Thomas Paty in 1775. The listing description suggests that Paty may have introduced the ogee fenestration to the building.
Render and brick with limestone dressings, rubble plinth, brick gable stacks and pantile hipped roof. Double-depth plan including right-hand rear wings. 2 storeys and attic; 5-window range. In 2 sections, 2:3 windows stepped up to the left-hand brickwork, render to the right, with a band above the plinth, a ground-floor drip to the right, differently moulded cornices, stepped up, and a continuous coped parapet. 
c.1770 right-hand section has raised, coved surrounds and ogee heads, a left-hand doorway with interlacing overlight and 6-panel door with the upper 4 raised, and 6/6-pane sashes, with interlacing heads, and 3 sunken panels to the parapet. 
The nineteenth-century south-west section has keyed architraves to horned 6/6-pane ground-floor sashes, and 4/8-pane first-floor sashes. The drip and cornice extend into the right-hand return as far as the external gable stack, windows as the front to each side, no right-hand ground-floor window, with a rear single-storey block. A continuous roof with 2 hipped dormers to the rear and 3 hips to the front. (Schedule of Listed Buildings).
Fine late sixteenth-century panelling (which may have originally come from the White Lodge) was removed to the Red Lodge, and is now in the ground floor Oak Room there. In 1980 included mullioned windows in the north-west elevation of the main block. The interior has several fireplaces of eighteenth- or nineteenth-century date.

No.10 Lower Park Row. Early C17, altered c1722, datestone over doorways, altered early C19, restored c1980. Rubble, limestone dressings and ashlar gable stacks, and pantile cross-gabled roof. Double-depth plan with gable fronting the street. 
3 storeys, attic and basement; 1-window range. Gabled front (facing west) with 2 cross gables each side, strings to upper floors. Right-hand brick segmental-arched blocked doorway, central C19 shop window, and right-hand C20 sash. 8/8-pane first-floor sash under a relieving arch, and C20 attic casement. Left return has stacks to both gables, a central C20 casement and second-floor C16 mullion window, with good small semicircular-arched leaded windows in ashlar panels to extreme sides of upper floors. Right return a 5-window range, blind to the left of paired central semicircular-arched early C19 doorways with imposts, and restored cross windows with leaded metal casements. 
The interior included a rebuilt framed dogleg stair from the entrance with moulded C17 door frames and panelled doors on each landing. There were formerly a number of mid C17 features particularly 6 excellent panelled doors and a number of fine Tudor-arched fireplaces, one in the basement with a bread oven, also moulded cornices, panelling and some small freestone arched windows. The Schedule of Listed Buildings notes it as an exceptional survival.
Possibly mid-17th.century. Once known as the White Lodge (but not the 'White Lodge' that was sister to the Red Lodge). Some of the 17th.century doors were stolen before renovation of the building. Three of the original six chimney pieces survived. A well was found during renovation work. Remains of painted plasterwork were also found in the front ground-floor fireplace at that time.

KNOWN_AS: The Corn Market or Cheese Market
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Corn Market or Cheese Market, A pair of market halls, either side of the street sometimes called Cheesemarket. Both facades appear to have been similar. Rowbotham recorded the western building in 1825 (BRSMG M2800). Attached. 2 storeys; 4-window range. Pilasters between the bays. Round-arched openings to both storeys, projecting and linked imposts. Probably all ground-floor openings were entrances. Moulded string below first-floor window sills. Heavy projecting cornice. In the style of the architect Samuel Glascodine.
The markets were used as the Corn Market in 1742 (according to Rocque's map of that date), but Braikenridge records that it was no longer used as such by 1825 (Braikenridge Notes D132).

The Greyhound Hotel, Broadmead, formerly a coaching inn. Attached. Front of 3 storeys and 5 bays. The building extended some distance to the rear, with a C19-20 brick-built bedroom block beyond function rooms. The yard reached to within 30m of the River Frome. 
Broadmead, or front, elevation in 2 parts. On the left, and still largely surviving, a 3-storey, 3-window range. In the centre, a tall archway with segmental head, reaching well into the first-floor. Either side on the ground-floor, wide, low windows. First-floor jettied. Above, either side of the centre, a 2-storey bay with sashes. Between, at second-floor, a 6/6pane sash. Cornice and parapet; 2 wide hipped roofs. 
Right-hand part of elevation of 3 storeys, a 2-window range. Left-hand tall haulingway entrance with segmental head, occupying 2 storeys. Post office in right-hand of ground-floor, left-hand entrance and high windows. First-floor apparently jettied. Right-hand wide oriel window. Second-floor jettied, with 2 wide bay windows, 12/12 pane fronts. A cornice, above which 2 partial parapets, behind which 2 hipped or half-hipped roofs. 
The right-hand block, of 2 bays, containing the post office, was badly damaged by enemy action, and was removed before 1953. Most of the remainder was demolished in 1988.

No.43 Broad Street. A medieval house of three and a half storeys plus cellar. Built out over the entrance to Tailors Court. Stone rubble was used for party walls with adjacent properties, also for a cross-wall and the rear ground floor wall. The remainder was of timber-frame construction, including some of the forward party wall with No.44. One roof of medieval timberwork had survived in addition to timbers elsewhere. The rear first floor room had originally possessed an oriel window overlooking what is now Tailors Court, but this had later been removed. The first and second floors retained their rear jetties and accompanying brackets, but the ornately carved and jettied front had been replaced in brick in 1825. A medieval chimney stack survived until the 1979 rebuilding. The rear ground floor wall incorporated two doorways and a window, and on the northern side were two small figures, apparently removed from elsewhere. One doorway, with a two-centred arch, was probably 14th.century in date. The second doorway and the window were more difficult to date, but could also be medieval. Demolition of the single-storey rear extension, formerly the cafeteria kitchen, in April-May, 1993 revealed evidence of a medieval structure, possibly a detached kitchen block, in that corner of Tailors Court. 
Drawn by O'Neill in 1821, when known as the 'Guildhall Tavern', kept by Samuel Porch the pugilist. It was refronted in 1825 (Braikenridge Notes, a.5), occupied by Mr.John Willis as a grocer's shop. Some curious old carvings (rosettes) were found in pulling down the entrance doorway. In 1821 the front was of 2 bays, jettied at first-floor, the eaves also jettied. There was the access to Tailors Court on the left, with an entrance in the centre of the remainder, between windows, under the left of which was the cellar entry. To the left of the Court entry was a bracket, and above a frieze of quatrefoil decoration. At the first-floor a full-width oriel window, 14 lights wide, 1 light at the ends; pentice roof above. Two oriels at second-floor, each 4 lights to front, 1 to sides. Two gables to the front, each with single-purlin roofs.

KNOWN_AS: Civil War Defensive Wall to the north of Bristol
MONUMENT_DESC:
Civil War Defensive Wall to the north of Bristol. A line of defences around the north side of Bristol was constructed in 1642 to defend the city when it declared its support for Parliament. The form of the original line is certain but it probably comprised a stone wall with a ditch in front. The precise line of the defences is largely still to be established. However, it ran from a Water Fort (BUAD 1043M) close to the River Avon at the foot of Brandon Hill, north across Brandon Hill to a fort at the summit of the hill. The line then passed north-west to the Windmill Fort in the area of modern Tyndall Avenue. From there it ran to Colston's Fort (BUAD 943M) on the north-west side of modern Montague Place, then to Prior's Hill Fort (BUAD 121M) near Fremantle Square (with Back of Kingsdown Parade likely to follow the line of the ditch). The line then turned downhill to Stokes Croft which was barricaded by a wooden gate (still extant in the 1740s). On the east side of the gate there was a small bastion or hornwork. The line then ran south-east toward the river Frome, passing though the area of Portland Square to a cannon position on Newfoundland Road.
After Bristol was captured by Royalist forces in 1643 the line was subject to significant works to enhance its strength. The Windmill Fort was rebuilt and renamed The Royal Fort and there also appears to have been some movement of the line of the defences on Brandon Hill.
After the Civil War the line appears to have been removed relatively quickly. Some features were still extant in the mid-eighteenth century and were recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 map of the city. The antiquarian Samuel Seyer also noted the remains of Colston Fort and earthworks on Brandon Hill in the 1820s.
The surviving fort and earthworks on Brandon Hill are a Scheduled Ancient Monument (AV 118).

The Church St. Paul, located on the eastern side of Portland Square. The parish of St. Paul was created out of the parish of St. James in 1787 and building began on the church, designed by Daniel Hague, in April 1789. The foundation stone was laid on 23 April 1789 and the first service was held on 29 June 1794 (Ison 1952, 76-81).
The church is of Bath stone ashlar and has an aisled nave, sanctuary and flanking vestries, north and south porches. The west front has a central three-stage tower. The second stage of the tower has a clock commemorating the First World War set in a gable hood. The belfry has ogee windows with Y-tracery. At the top of the tower two further square stages are sharply set back to form the spire and on the top is an octagonal spirelet. Internally ogee-panelled transoms in the aisle windows mark the position of the original side galleries. The church has an octagonal marble pulpit, an octagonal font with tracery panels. There are various late eighteenth- and nineteenth-century wall tablets, and a memorial on the north side of the sacristy to Colonel Thomas Vassal (d.1807) by Flaxman (illustrated by Manning, BRSMG M2871). Part of the altar piece was also drawn by Manning in 1828 (BRSMG M2874).
The church has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/6/1906) while the railings and gates in front of the church are Grade II* (Listed Building number 901-1/6/2154).

Portland Square. The square was laid out between 1788 and 1790 as a speculative housing development. The architect and developer, Daniel Hague, advertised for builders to take up the plots, in a newspaper advertisement of 24 March 1790 (Ison 1952, 220).  The parish of St. James's was divided to create the new parish of St. Paul and the church was built between 1789-1794 to a design by Hague. Construction of the houses stopped in 1793 as a result of the crash caused by the outbreak of the French Revolutionary Wars. The houses were completed gradually during the second decade of the nineteenth century.
Lambert suggests it is likely that the central garden was an integral part of Hague's design. An obelisk was erected in the centre in 1810 to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of George III's reign. This was replaced in the following year by a Coade Stone statue of the monarch, which was itself pulled down and damaged beyond repair by republicans on the night of the 23 March 1817 (Ison 1952, 223).
Cartographic evidence records varying layouts within the garden. Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 plan shows a perimeter walk divided from the railings by shrubs, with a central small bed and two elliptical, roughly symmetrical beds north and south.
The Ordnance Survey 1:500 plan surveyed in 1883 (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.11) also shows a perimeter walk with shrubs and trees outside it, the central bed. The two ellipses had become less compact but are still identifiable; in addition several single trees stand in the open lawn.
The garden was conveyed to the Corporation on 12 September 1952, and in the following year bushes and undergrowth were cleared, trees removed and five floral beds constructed. In 1954 soil was brought in and grass re-seeded, with the "restoration" completed in 1956.
The planting of the space is very similar to that of 1918. The best trees survive in a scatter in the northern half (two Horse Chestnuts, a Lime, and a London Plane). To the south there are a Lime and a Sycamore.  Flowering cherries, presumably dating from the works of 1956, are planted round the perimeter. There are flower beds across the lawns, including a central raised bed. The path runs around the perimeter.
The railings and gates around the central garden are listed Grade II (Listed Building number 901-1/6/1908).

Isolation Hospital, located to the north of Blackberry Hill, Stapleton. The hospital was constructed at the end of the nineteenth century and was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1903. The building is extant and is currently the Orchard Day Hospital.

Crabb's Well, No.105 Temple Street, located on the western side of Temple Street.
