The building was a rendered, jettied timber-framed house of a single bay which probably dated to the later-seventeenth or early-eighteenth century, presumably originally with a gabled roof. The Temple Street frontage measured 15 feet 6 inches [4.7 metres] wide and the plot extended around 50 feet [15 metres] backwards. The front and rear walls of the building were at least 2 feet 6 inches [0.75 metres] thick and the party walls were 4 feet [1.2 metres] thick..
The main, east-facing, elevation had an entrance door on the southern side of the ground-floor with a canted bay window to its north. The first and second floors were jettied over the ground-floor and the first floor fenestration comprised a square bay window containing a 12 over 12 pane sash. At second-floor there was a three-light window, the wider central light with a horizontal 9 over 9 pane sash.
The original internal plan is not currently clear and the interior had been significantly altered by the time of demolition. There were apparently three rooms on both the first and second floors. The tap-room, parlour and kitchens were more than a foot below pavement level. By the late-nineteenth century the building had a "square-head" attic with a flat roof, probably formed by raising the original gable roof. Part of the top of the gable appears still to have been extant in 1907.
There was a yard to the rear of the house, and a large skittle alley.
In the late-eighteenth and early-nineteenth centuries a number of carriers worked from the property. It belonged to Owen's Charity and was described in 1877 a "Dwelling houses, yard and premises" in the tenure of George Neate (Anon. 1877, 26).
When Victoria Street was created in the later-nineteenth century the building was renumbered as No.117, Victoria Street. It closed as a licensed house in the late 1880s and its condition subsequently deteriorated. The building was demolished in 1907 and was observed by John Pritchard shortly beforehand (BUAD 697). He reports that traces of original window frames were found in the main elevation during demolition, as well as moulded beams in the ceiling of the first-floor room. Pritchard believed that the inn yard was then occupied by the warehouses of Messrs. Joseph Fish & Son.

The town gate known as St. John's Gate, which forms the west end of the Church of St. John Baptist in Broad Street. The tower of the church stands over the gate. The gate stands as part of the earliest circuit of the town wall and is the only survivor of the gates of the town. The structure was renovated in the nineteenth-century when two smaller arches were inserted on either side of the main gateway.
The north elevation of the gateway has a tall moulded arch of fourteenth-century date with a crenellated parapet. On either side are two arches, the east one under the end of the nave, the west beneath a parapeted wall. 
The south side of the central gateway has flanking niches with restored hoods and painted statues of Brennus and Bellinus, the mythical founders of Bristol, each holding an orb and sceptre; There are shields and a Royal Arms on the parapet above. 
The main gateway has a ribbed fan vault with bell hole, the side gateways a ridge rib and drips each side.
The gateway has a Grade I listing and is listed together with the Church of St. John the Baptist.

KNOWN_AS: Society of Friends' Burial Ground, Quaker's Friars
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Society of Friend's Burial Ground, Quaker's Friars, also known as the Priors' burial ground. The plot on which the burial ground was sited was bought by the meeting in February 1669 (Old style) but it is not clear when interment began. An Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852 imposed the restriction that "only one body [was] to be buried in each grave" in the burial ground.
The meeting house and burial ground were sold in 1956 and the burials reportedly exhumed (being reburied in Avon View cemetery) (Stock 1996, 6). The grave markers were removed to Bedminster Meeting House.
The site of the burial ground was used for car parking and was re-landscaped in 1998 along with the rest of the area surrounding Quakers Friars but, beyond the insertion of shallow service runs, the stratification was not disturbed. Further archaeological investigation on the south and east sides of the burial ground in 2002 (BUAD 3849) and 2006 recorded in situ post-medieval inhumations.

Ridgeway House some 130 metres to the north of Fishponds Road, Eastville. The building was in existence by the early seventeenth century and was recorded by a map of the forest of Kingswood of 1610. It was still extant in the early 1880s and was indicated as a site of antiquity by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.01) published in 1881. It survived into the early twentieth century but is reported to have been demolished in 1937 to allow the development of the housing on Redhill Drive.
The site now lies beneath Nos1-3 Redhill Drive.

KNOWN_AS: Jewish Burial Ground, Oakdene Avenue, Eastville
MONUMENT_DESC:
Jewish Cemetery located on the western side of Oakdene Road (formerly Cemetery Road). The cemetery was established in 1898 in a triangular plot of land covering an area of 860 square metres. There was a cemetery chapel, measuring 5.35 metres from south-west to north-east by 4 metres wide, at the centre of the site (ST 6197175231), and was enclosed by a 1.5 metre high Pennant sandstone rubble boundary wall. Human remains and headstones from the burial ground at Rose Street, Temple Meads were reinterred at the cemetery in the 1920s when the Rose Street burial ground was cleared.
An adjacent rectangular parcel of land of 800 square metres on the north side of the cemetery was acquired and was incorporated into it in 1933. The original cemetery chapel was demolished and a new chapel was built between January and May 1933. This is a single-storey rendered building with a clay tile hipped roof. There are double timber panelled doors in the north-east and south-west faces of the chapel. Foundation stones were laid at the north and south corners of the north-east facing elevation by Lewis Aaron Melcher and Abel Mass. A stone plaque on the south side of the western doors commemorates the opening of the chapel and the extension to the cemetery on 28th May 1933:
"THIS MEMORIAL HALL AND / CEMETERY EXTENSION WAS OPENED BY / JOSEPH STEINBERG ESQ PRESID[EN]T / OF THE BRISTOL JEWISH BURIAL SOCIETY / AND CONSECRATED BY / RABBI HARRIS SWIFT / MINISTER OF THE BRISTOL HEBREW CONGREG[ATIO]N / 28TH MAY1933 - 3RD SIVEN 5693." Above the entrance there is a plaque bearing an extract from Chapter 1 Verse 21 of the Old Testament Book of Job ("THE LORD HATH GIVEN AND THE / LORD HATH TAKEN AWAY: BLESSED / BE THE NAME OF THE LORD") in Hebrew and in English.
A new entrance was established to the north of the original entrance and wrought iron gates were donated in memory of Gita Miel by her husband and children.
The cemetery has a section reseerved for Cohanim (a direct male descendant of Aaron, brother of Moses, with a distinct personal status within Judaism) and another for suicides. Inside the chapel there is a memorial plaque for Jewish soldiers who were killed during the First and Second World Wars. The cemetery is owned by the Bristol Jewish Burial Society (Chevrah Chadisha).

Stone Bridge, or St.Giles's Bridge, which bridged the River Frome at the Quayhead. The first stone for the bridge was laid on 16 April 1753 (Evans, 1824 274). The bridge, of rusticated stonework, consisted of a single span arch with parapets and was only approximately 6 feet wide. Rowbotham's 1825 drawing from the south-east shows an additional, angled, partial arch at the south-west corner.
The Frome culvert was extended up to this point in the mid nineteenth century, but was extended further downstream in 1891-1892. The end of the culvert was built against the bridge, and the parapets removed to  create the pavement for the road. The bridge is known to survive beneath the end of Rupert Street.

Mylne's Culvert. The culvert was constructed as part of the water management system of the Floating Harbour at the beginning of the nineteenth century to carry the flow of the river Frome away from the lock gates at the Quay Head and into the New Cut. It runs from Stone Bridge, at the northern end of Colston Avenue, down the eastern side of that thoroughfare, below Broad and Narrow Quays, under Prince Street Bridge, and down the line of Wapping Road to the New Cut. Rowbotham's 1828 view (M.2825) shows the entrance to the culvert, built by the Bristol Dock Company for the purpose of carrying the flow of the River Frome directly to the New Cut. Immediately upstream of Stone Bridge and the floodgates. Protected by bars, which had to be cleared from time to time to ensure free flow of the water, and for which purpose a stage or boat was provided at the location. The culvert is still in use.

St. Peter's Churchyard, located on the south side of St. Peter's Church (BUAD 187M), but with a strip running up beside the west end of the church, as far as the street. The churchyard was bounded to the south by St. Peter's Hospital (BUAD 9M) and St. Peter's Almshouse (BUAD 10M). The churchyard was in use from at least the thirteenth century. The churchyard was closed to burials by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852.
The main area of the churchyard was planted as herb garden in the late twentieth century. The burials are believed to remained undisturbed within the site.

Steevens' Almshouse, located on the north side of Old Market Street. The almshouses were founded by Thomas Stevens, a former mayor of Bristol, under the terms of his will of 6 April 1679 which required a group of his "very good friends" to purchase a parcel of land in the parish of St. Philip and Jacob and then construct an almshouse "fit and convenient for twelve poor men and women" (Manchee 1831, 167). The trustees bought a parcel of land which consisted of a "tenement . converted into three small houses or tenements, and a stable and garden ground" from Robert Yate, this "being the only place they could find in the said parish of St. Philip" (Manchee 1831, 168). The form of the seventeenth century almshouses is not known, but the references in Manchee suggest that they may initially have been converted tenements.
The almshouses were rebuilt in 1725. The 1725 structures consisted of two ranges of buildings parallel to one another on either side of a yard, and were behind a narrow row of shops. The entrance to the almshouses was in the centre of this row. The two almshouses were two-storey, four-bay buildings with pitched roofs. An account published in 1831 described the almshouse as "containing sixteen rooms, one room being assigned to each poor person, with a fire-place in it" (Manchee 1831, 174).
The building was badly damaged by bombing in 1940 and restoration work was begun in 1957.

No.21 High Street.. The property was bequeathed to the Bristol Guardians of the Poor by John Knight, of St. Andrew, Holborn, Esquire, by will dated 19 April 1706, when it was described as "The George" (but not a licensed house), in the occupation of William Bush, Linen Draper. At the beginning of the nineteenth century it was occupied by Messrs. Barry & Son, Booksellers.
The building was inspected in 1914 by John Pritchard (Pritchard 1920, 134-135). No description of the front. Behind the then-modern shop was a low ceilinged room of irregular shape, about 27 feet 6 inches. by 16 feet 6 inches., "a relic of Jacobean days, if not earlier", with panelled walls and a "typical" mantel-piece. On the frieze were the initials T.A.D., but no date. The room led to a "lofty apartment", 25 feet by 16 feet, with a carved wood mantel-piece "of a century later". At the extreme rear was a small store room with a trace of seventeenth century moulded plasterwork.

Ashton Gate Brewery, located on the south side North Street, Ashton Gate. The brewery was founded in the late 1820s and was recorded by a street directory of 1829 as "Baynton, Thomas, Charles & John, Brewers, Somerset Brewery, near Ashton gate, Bedminster." Thomas Baynton alone was listed as the operator from 1834. By the mid-nineteenth century the brewery consisted of a large main building on North Street with a narrower range of buildings to the rear. Immediately to the souh-west of this range there was a trapezoidal pond measuring approximately 35 metres long by 18 metres wide.
The brewery was sold to a new registered company, the "Ashton Gate Brewery Co. Ltd." in 1865 and a number of new buildings were constructed. The company changed its name to "Hardwick & Co." between 1868 and 1883 but subsequently reverted to Ashton Gate Brewery. More expansion projects were undertaken including the construction of a new fermenting house in 1903 by George Adlams and Sons, local brewery engineers. In 1909 plans were produced for a new single-storey cellar brick cellar which was built alongside the fermenting house. This had a queen post roof with a lantern running along the centre. The Ashton Gate Brewery was purchased by George's and Co. in 1932 and closed down.

KNOWN_AS: The Glebe House, All Saints Church
POSTAL_ADDRESS: The Glebe House, All Saints Court
MONUMENT_DESC:
Glebe House. Priest's house, now offices. Mid-late 15th.century. Pennant rubble and limestone dressings and stone gable-end stack. Single-depth plan, the rear overhanging the south aisle of All Saints, Corn Street. 
3-storeys and basement; 3-window range. The corners are chamfered at street level and the upper parts corbelled out; a central Tudor-arched doorway to All Saints Court, and a studded door; cross windows with metal casements, a 3-light window to the right on the second floor, and a single-light window over the door. First-floor room has a Tudor-arched stone fireplace; chamfered beams, with 15 WH 85 painted on one, and a covered window with trefoil head looking on to the church below; second-floor room has a similar fire place, and a 3-bay roof rebuilt c.1980 with cambered collars and ties, clasped purlins, ceiled above the collars; a small window with splayed reveals and trefoil head to the right of the fireplace. 
The house is traditionally said to have been built on to the south-west corner of the church in 1422 as a parsonage. Probably remodelled in the 16th.century. Heavily restored by Oatley in 1905-6, making it difficult to fully discern the original plan.

Church of All Saints, located slightly to the south-west of the junction of Corn Street and High Street. The church was presumably established around the time of the foundation of Bristol c1000AD but the earliest documentary reference to the church is in a charter of William, Earl of Gloucester dating before c1160 which grants the advowson of the church to the Abbey of St. Augustine (BUAD 3873; Walker, 1998 21). The earliest form of the building is not currently clear (02/07/2002) but two pairs of round Norman piers with scalloped capitals survive at western end of the nave, suggesting that the building was substantially remodelled in the late eleventh- or early twelfth-century.
The churchwardens' accounts record several alterations and repairs to the structure in the fifteenth-century including the reconstruction of a chapel of Our Lady on the north side of the church in c1450 by Richard Haddon (Burgess 1995, 9). The eastern end of the nave and the aisles of the extant building are of fifteenth-century date and fragments of a fifteenth-century wall painting survive within the church.
The Glebe House or priest's house (BUAD 246M) was constructed in the mid- to late-fifteenth century at the south-west corner of the church and the building, which is extant, oversails part of the south aisle. The House of the Kalendaries (BUAD 990M) was constructed over the north aisle.
There was some modification to the church during the seventeenth century and two wide semi-circular-headed windows (BUAD 1019A), probably dating to the early seventeenth-century, survive in the south chancel wall. Between 1712 and 1717 the tower was reconstructed and in 1724 Edward Colston is reported to have bequeathed £250 to the church for the rebuilding of the tower and chancel in 1724 (Manchee 1831, 317). In c.1770 a new organ was built by Brice Seede. The House of the Kalendaries was reconstructed as a coffee house, No.56 Corn Street (BUAD 336M) in 1782.. The lantern of the tower was rebuilt by Luke Henwood in 1807. The chancel was extended on its south side in the mid nineteenth-century and the ridge of the roof was also raised.
The church in the 1820s is recorded by a number of watercolour drawings in the Braikenridge Collection, Bristol Museum and Art Gallery which show the east end of the church (BRSMG M2380-M2382) and, in a  series by Johnson in 1828, the interior (BRSMG M2377-M2379).
Burial within the church was ended by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852. The Brice Seede organ was rebuilt by John Smith junior of John Smith and Sons, Bristol organ builders, in 1844. The church was declared redundant in 1984.
The church has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/11/575).

KNOWN_AS: Factory, later the Corporation Electricity Department
MONUMENT_DESC: A factory, later the Corporation Electricity Department depot. At the very northern end of the western side of Colston Avenue, immediately north of John Wright's. C19. Attached. 4 storeys and basement. Hipped roofs to front and rear blocks. 5-window range to street. Left-hand entrance under a round-headed arch, next a canted bay, then 3 segmental-headed windows. Segmental-headed openings to basement.  5 round-headed windows each to first and second floors. Strings above first 3 storeys. Smaller round-headed windows to third-floor, arranged 2+3+3+3+2. Parapet. Stacks either end of ridge of hipped front roof. Blitzed.

KNOWN_AS: Pair of Houses in front of the Mulberry Tree Tavern
MONUMENT_DESC:
A pair of houses. Fronting the 'Mulberry Tree' tavern. Attached. On the west side of Broad Street, opposite John Street. 3 storeys and attics; gabled fronts; fully jettied. Entrance to right of right-hand ground-floor; bay windows to each ground-floor, cellar access below right-hand example. Large bracket at right end. Bays to both first-floors, each with Ipswich window; glazing beside both bays, giving almost full-width fenestration across combined frontage. Brackets to second-floor. On the second-floor, to left a bay with Ipswich window, glazing to either side; to right, an oriel with 6-light window without transom. Brackets to eaves of left gable. Small window to each attic. Decorated bargeboards. Panelling to various parts of both buildings. 
In front of the 'Mulberry Tree Tavern' and taken down in 1819. The tavern lay at the back of the houses, up a passage that ran under the far right-hand end. Turpin the bookbinder occupied one of the rooms in the buildings, his sign being on the second-floor of the left-hand house. Parry's boot and shoe warehouse had a sign between the first-floor bays. G.Franklin's name is under the left ground-floor bay. All the aforementioned listed at No.23 by the street directories.

A bastion or semi-circular tower on the outer or second town wall, located some 35 metres to the south-east of the Bridewell. The bastion is recorded by a plan of 1739 (BRO Corporation Plan Book A fo.24-25) which indicates that it was a semi-circular structure at that date. There was an entrance on the north side of the bastion which was reached via a walled passageway. The bastion was recorded in two watercolour drawings of 1820 by Hugh O'Neill in the Braikenridge Collection of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery (BRSMG M2447 and BRSMG M2448) and was also visited by Samuel Seyer in 1821. By this time the bastion had been converted to a three-storey circular tower with a pantile roof. Seyer (1821 270-271) described the tower as being 22 feet in external diameter while the wall at ground floor level was 8 or 9 feet thick. A stone staircase at the back of the small, square, ground floor room led to the first storey. The ceiling of the ground floor room was arched and groined without ribs. The roof when Seyer observed it was of tile with common eaves. The drawings show a shallow polygonal or pyramidal roof. The fabric of the tower was of rubble stone and evidence of a change in construction roughly in the middle of the tower is visible, indicating where the tower had been extended. There were doors at the centre of the structure at ground- and first-floor levels, and at second floor there was a small window opening.. The tower is recorded by the plan of the city produced by Plumley and Ashmead in 1828 and Stone (1909) records that the tower was demolished in 1879. The site of the bastion is now partly beneath a corner of the rear part of the Crown Court building but the medieval element mainly lies within yard of the Central Police Station. The line of the town wall to the north of the bastion also runs beneath the yard. The state of preservation of the bastion and wall is currently unknown.

Back Hall or Spicer's Hall, located at the northern end of Welsh Back.
Hall, aligned north-south. Rectangular plan. Arch-braced trusses to roof, some supported on corbels with carved human faces. Two tiers of cusped windbraces; two purlins to each side. Of oak. Two small windows above blind arch in north end wall. In 1826, an arched doorway at south end of west wall and square doorway at east end of south wall, this area interpreted as a former gallery. In the south-west corner near the arched doorway was a pulpit, destroyed in Mr.Attwood's absence. 
The hall was a ground-floor structure. There was the surviving end of a blind arch in the north end wall. Tall traceried window with two-centred arch at north end of west wall, bricked up. Two-centred arch to doorway on ground-floor; similar but slightly wider example above, bricked up, with small opening in wall adjacent to south (with a trefoil head), blocked with stone. A large arched opening further south, with, beyond it, a chimney breast in a later rubble. Most of the west wall was in angular random rubble, all shapes and sizes from small to medium. Quoins in ashlar. Types of stone and colours of mortar are unrecorded. The outside of the wall was much altered. Areas of plaster were recorded on both faces of the wall.
At its base the south wall of the hall was noted as being of angular random rubble. Later fireplaces and flues were noted higher up. It was partly plastered over.
The south end wall of the structure immediately adjacent on the west side of the hall survived largely intact. At ground-floor level was a blind arch, with, apparently, Pennant Sandstone voussoirs. The walls either side were thick, stepping back at first-floor level, where the main room was situated. The bottom of a possible doorway was noted, blocked with rubble, slightly left of centre, with, above and to the right, a window with two-centred arch, similarly blocked. The end wall was plastered at least at this level.
The building was gutted by fire during a bombimg raid on Bristol during the Second World War. The shell of the building was recorded by B. H. St.John O'Neill in 1941, but the final drawings dated 1944. He recorded both sides of the west wall of the hall, also the western end of the north end wall. In addition he drew the south end wall of the adjacent structure, which was part of the same complex.

The Playhouse or Jacob's Wells Theatre located on the west side of Woodwells Lane (modern Jacobs Wells Road). and lying just outside the boundary of the city. The theatre was purpose-built for its first owner, the actor John Hippisley, on a site immediately outside the Bristol county boundary. The building had a 12.5 metre wide frontage on Jacob's Wells Road and extended backwards to the south-west. The form of the building is currently unclear but it was rectangular, measuring 42 metres from north-east to south-west, and narrowed to 8.5 metres in width to the rear of the element on the street front. The theatre opened on 3 July 1729 (Barker 1974, 4) and aimed to draw much of its audience from those visiting the spa at Hotwells. It staged a summer season of plays performed by actors established on the London stage.
Hippisley still owned the theatre at his death in c.1748 and it was inherited by his wife who appears to have sold the lease to a consortium but continued to act as Box-Book Keeper (Barker 1974, 5). The seasons included some performances with a strong political resonance in the Bristol context; notably Southerne's stage adaptation of Oroonoko which was staged three times in the summer of 1763. The fortunes of the theatre declined as the spa waned in importance and competition emerged with the opening of the New Theatre in 1766 (BUAD 15M; later renamed Theatre Royal). The leading actor of one of the final seasons,.William Powell, was invited to lead the New Theatre company and the Jacob's Wells Theatre appears have closed after the 1765 season.
The playhouse was subsequently demolished and replaced by cottages, which were in turn removed for "industrial housing," and is now the site of post-Second World War flats.

KNOWN_AS: Possible Bet tohorah or mikveh, Jacobs Wells Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
Possible bet tohorah (for washing the dead before burial) or mikveh (Jewish ritual bath or washing place), located on the north side of Constitution Hill, at its junction with Jacob's Well Road. The monument was discovered in 1987 (BUAD 282) and appears to comprise at least two chambers cut into the hillside which collect water from springs on the hillside. A large stone lintel above an opening into the northern of the chambers appears to carry part of an inscription in Hebrew. The interpretation of the inscription is currently uncertain but Emanuel and Ponsford (1994) suggest that is "zochalim" ("flowing"). After its re-examination Blair et al (2001-02; Hillaby & Sermon 2004) suggest that "mayim tehorim" ("pure waters") or "mayim chayim" ("living waters") are possible alternative readings.
The monument was initially interpreted as a mikveh but Blair et al. note that the "mayim chayim" reading of the inscription "refers to the type of water required to cleanse a person after touching a corpse" (Blair et al. 2001-02, 18-20). The monument is also close to the Jewish cemetery known as Jew's Acre which was located on the site of the Queen Elizabeth's Hospital building and it was therefore argued that the monument was more likely to be a bet tohorah or cleansing house where the ceremony of washing the dead was carried out before burial.
The monument went out of use with the expulsion of the Jews from England in 1290 and it was then incorporated into the conduit (BUAD 934M) supplying water to St. Augustine's Abbey and St. Mark's Hospital.
Medieval mikva'ot are rare in Europe and the only other examples known from the British Isles, are those found in London in 1986 at Guildhall House, Gresham Street and in 2001 at Nos.1-6 Milk Street (Blair et al., 2001; Hillaby & Sermon 2004). If the interpretation as a bet tohorah is correct this is the only surviving example of this class of monument currently known in the United Kingdom.
The bet tohorah is a Scheduled Ancient Monument (SAM number AV 28881).

The Bishop's Park, located on the south-east side of modern St. George's Road. Elements of the park may be medieval in origin, since this was part of the estate of the adjacent Abbey of St. Augustine. At the creation of the diocese of Bristol in 1542 the lands of the former abbey were divided between the Bishop and the Dean and Chapter. The Abbot's Lodging and the Abbot's Park were granted to the Bishop. The park is recorded by James Millerd's 1673 map while Jean Rocque's 1742 'A Plan of the City of Bristol' shows the "BISHOP'S PARK" bounded by Cow or Limekiln Lane, the Rope Walk at Canons Marsh, and the rears of buildings fronting College Green and Lower College Green. Towards the south-western end of the park the plan shows three ponds (BUAD 1060A-1062A), the northern (a fishpond?) being the largest, triangular in shape, perhaps dammed at its southern end, while the others were irregular, one of them connected with the large drainage ditch that ran along the northern edge of Canons Marsh. No evidence of the largest pond was found during archaeological excavation on its putative site on the south side of Deanery Road.
In March 1770 the then Bishop of Bristol, Thomas Gooch, leased the Park to Samuel Worrall who was to develop it with housing: "The said close of ground should be improved by buildings to be erected theron and whereas the said Samuel Worrall hath formed a plan for covering the said close of ground with buildings to which plan there is a street called College Street of the breadth of forty feet from front to front of the second story of the intended houses out of which is taken three feet for areas or bow windows on the first story or ground floor and five feet for a paved foot-way which leaves twenty four feet carriage. " (BRO DC/E./40/28/2). The main sewer to serve the housing was reported to have been completed in September 1770 (Ison 1952, 210) and 1775 eight houses in College Street were occupied according to Sketchley's directory of Bristol. The leases on the individual properties reverted to the Bishop and in 1853 he issued a new lease to William Tanner, a property speculator (BRO 21054(2)). The Bishop sold his interest in the Park to Tanner in May 1871 (BRO 21054(7)). The land remained in a single ownership until June 1950 when the individual plots composing the estate were sold at auction (BRO 21054 (17)).

Headford House, located on the north side of Jacob Street, about 135 feet below David Street. Faced the old malthouse, and almost adjoined the back premises of the 'Stag and Hounds'. Had a frontage of 32 feet, with a long depth. Known as Headford or Headfort House, and described as such in a will of 1804. In September of that year it was sold, the lessee at that time being a Robert Headford. One document refers to "two lead soft-water pumps in the Brew-House". It had a gable on each of its four sides. The front windows were "somewhat small", and the ground-floor was six inches below the pavement. The large room on entering was almost devoid of interest, the only original work being the "moulded oak breast of the open fireplace - a timber 7 feet long by 10 inches in depth. The oak staircase at the back of this room possessed a good newel, and light from the rear of the property to the staircase came through an old leaded casement". The latter, with the moulded 'head-piece', was presented to the City Museum (995A). In the principal apartment on the first-floor was a carved fireplace or chimney-piece (994A), also later given to the Museum. On a shield in the centre were the letters
"C. / N.   B." [i.e. denoting the initials N. C. and B. C.] with the date 1664 divided on the left and right cartouches. There was a "handsome" moulded ceiling in the same room, in the same manner as the chimney-piece. Above was another floor, but with no features of note.

A freestanding chimney situated on the highest point of Trooper's Hill, St. George. The date of construction of the chimney is unknown but it has been argued to date from the eighteenth century. It is constructed of coursed Pennant sandstone with later brick dressings around the main arch. It measures 3.5 metres in diameter at the base and stands approximately 15 metres high, on a plinth which contains a semi-circular brick arch.
The chimney was incorporated into William Butler's Tar Distillery founded in 1843 (Buchanan & Cossons 1969, 154-155), and was connected to the works by a long flue (now largely collapsed).
The chimney has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/56/1236).

Cooper's Hall, located on the north side of King Street. The livery hall known as The Coopers' Hall was built between 1743 and 1744 to a design by William Halfpenny (the professional name used by Michael Hoare). The structure was erected on plot with a frontage of 65 feet 9 inches, which was bought from the Corporation for £900. Ison (1952, 105) notes that this hall replaced an earlier hall in Cock Lane (modern Exchange Avenue) which was demolished in clearing the site for The Exchange.
The building has a single storey with an attic and basement. It has a five window range. In the centre of the King Street (south) frontage is a pediment containing the Coopers' arms.
After the ending of its use as a livery hall, it became in turn an assembly-room, a sale-room, an exhibition hall and a Methodist chapel, finally being used as a warehouse. The interior of the building was rebuilt in 1971 to act as the foyer of the Theatre Royal.
The building has a Grade I listing (Listed Building Number 901-1/16/624).

No.14, King Street, located on the southern side of King Street. The building was a house constructed in the mid-seventeenth century. It was of three storeys and attic and probably had a common rafter roof.
No.14 and No.15 King Street [BUAD 1465M] were amalgamated into a single warehouse during the nineteenth century and a new façade created. This is of Pennant sandstone ashlar and squared rubble, with red brick and limestone dressings and has a four-window range. The ground-floor windows are in segmental-arched openings while rhe upper floor is divided by four two-storey semicircular-arched recesses, with alternate brick and limestone dressings. Several of the internal walls of both buildings appear to have been removed at the same time to create open-plan spaces and cast-iron columns (with flanges to pillows and timber floor beams) seven bays deep support the first-floor. The seventeenth-century second and third floors were also removed and a new floor for the warehouse inserted at a level between them.
The northern part of the seventeenth century building is in part extant. The former east wall of No.14 survives and contains a seventeenth-century chimney breast. The roof against the street front is hipped with a gable at its south end.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/16/600).

Prince William House on the south side of Colston Street constructed by 1898 for John Totterdill carriage builders. A two storey building with two basement floors fronting Colston Street with an attached two storey building to the rear fronting Host Street. The Colston Street frontage comprises a brick-built arcade of six full-height, semicircular arched bays with moulded surrounds and a parapet above, single pitched roof with hipped ends on the Colston Street side and a half mansard to the rear. On 20th May 1913 the building was gutted by fire and repaired in 1916 (King 2008).
The building was given Grade II Listed status in 1977 (Listed Building No. 901-1/11/77).

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Canons Marsh Gas Works, Gasferry Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
Child's or Limekiln Glasshouse. The glasshouse was located to the south of the junction of the modern Anchor and Jacobs Wells Roads. It was established in the late-seventeenth century and there was an associated limekiln. In the late-eighteenth century it was advertised as a bottle works and appears to have continued in operation into the 1820s. It is recorded by the Plumley and Ashmead plan of 1828, and in 1838 the timber merchants who occupied the site were granted permission to demolish the cone.
Waste from the glasshouse, dated on stylistic grounds to the late-seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, which was recovered during monitoring (BUAD 4071) on the adjacent Canon's Marsh gasworks (BUAD 698M) was analysed. The material was all high-lime low-alkali (HLLA) glass and exhibited the general trend of English glass during the nineteenth century for an increase in alumina and iron oxide and a decrease in phosphorus oxide and manganese oxide (Dungworth 2005).

School. Attached to the north and east. On the north corner of Narrow Quay/ Assembly Rooms Lane, at the rear of the Assembly Rooms. Street records it as "formerly a school" in 1930, by which time it was gutted and roofless, and surviving as ground-floor only by September 1942. 2 storey elevations, 4-window range to Narrow Quay, and to the Lane at least a 2-window range. Rubble walls with stucco rendering, as banded rustication to the ground-floor; plinth; pilaster at the end of each elevation. An entrance on the Quay, second from left. All windows and the door frame with alternate enlarged blocks to their jambs, also with stepped voussoirs.  Cellar access below the left-hand window in the Lane, with pavement grilles before most windows. Between the first and second ground-floor windows to the Lane, was a stretched octagonal feature, possbily a blocked window. Known as No.89, the Quay. Recorded as a public house or inn on Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 plan of the city.

Bishop's Palace, Henbury, located in the vicinity of the church of St. Mary the Virgin. The palace was established by Bishopric of Worcester to administer its estates in Bristol (including the manor of Henbury) and the Cotswolds (Emery 2000, 463). The precise date that the palace was founded is currently unknown but Ralph Bigland reports it to have been in existence soon after the Norman Conquest of 1066 (Frith 1990, 717). It was certainly in existence by the later fourteenth century and the Book of Margery Kempe describes her visit to the palace (SMR 9649), probably in the summer of 1417 (Windeatt 1994, 146).
The site of the palace is unknown but it appears to have been very close to the church of St. Mary the Virgin (SMR 5737) (Windeatt 1994, 146). It is likely therefore to have stood to the east of the church, either in the grounds of Henbury Manor or of the vicarage. However, Bigland, writing in the eighteenth century, noted that "ruinous Buildings near the Church seem to mark the Site of the Palace" (Frith 1990, 717).

No.35 Prince Street, located on the west side of Prince Street. The building was a three-storey, five-bay house constructed in 1740 by altering and extending the earlier "Great House" belonging to John Day. This was purchased by Richard Bayly in 1740 who obtained a new lease from the Bristol Corporation in June 1741. Ison suggested that the house may have been designed by the architect William Halfpenny (the professional name used by Michael Hoare) (Ison, 1952 172; Gomme et al., 1979 141). The main, east-facing, elevation was classical in style. The ground floor was rusticated with a central entrance doorway with a segmental pediment supported by semi-circular pilasters with bands of vermiculation. On either side of the doorway there were two segmental-headed window openings which contained four by six pane sashes. A plat band divided ground- from first-floor, and above were five tall sashes under alternate segmental and pediments. The window openings at second floor level were surrounded by moulded stonework and contained four by three pane sashes. Above there was a cornice, and a tall stone parapet with five panels. There were chimneystacks at the centre of the north and south ends of the roof.
Bayly died soon after completion of the building and it was sold in July 1742 when it was described as a "Great House - with a Freestone Front, Marble Chimneypieces, wainscotted and very handsomly furnished, with convenient Cellarage, Coach House, both sorts of Water, &c." (quoted in Ison, 1952 172).
The original internal organisation of space is not currently certain but by the early 1920s there were two linked reception rooms occupying the full width of the front of the building, overlooking Prince Street. Parts of the original panelling and chimneypieces also survived (Winstone, 1983 pl.173).
The building had been renumbered to No.40 Prince Street and was occupied by the Port of Bristol Sanitary Office by the early 1920s (Dening, 1923 pl.31). It was recorded by Dening in the early 1920s (BUAD 4105; Dening, 1923 99-101).
The building was destroyed by bombing in 1940.

Old King Street Baptist Church, located on the western side of Old King Street (now the northern half of Merchant Street). The footprint of the building measured 23.25 metres from south-east to north-west and was 17 metres wide. The main, south-west facing, elevation was of ashlar and had three bays. The ground-floor was rusticated with segmental-headed arched windows in the northern and southern bays on either side of a porch over the main entrance in the central bay. This had a wide frieze supported by twinned Roman Doric columns at the north-western and south-western corners. The first floor was plain and there had three arched windows and above these there was a pediment with the date "1815" at the centre. On either side of the main element of the facade there was a narrow recessed strip with identical incised decoration at ground- and first-floor. Behind the parapet the building had a hipped roof and there was also a gable at the eastern end. On the northern and southern ends of the elevation there were square two-storey structures, slightly set back from the main elevation, but apparently part of the original design. Each had a central door at ground floor and a single arched window above. An organ was built for the church by John Smith of the Bristol organ builders John Smith and Sons (although it is not clear whether this was John Smith senior or John Smith junior) in 1836. It was enlarged by John Smith junior in 1845.
The building was demolished in 1957 to make way for the development of the Broadmead shopping centre. The congregation moved to Cairns Road, and retained the "Old King Street" name.

Parish church of St. Stephen. It originally stood beside the quays by the River Frome, excavated 1240-1247.
Built in the fourteenth-century, rebuilt c1470. The tower and east window were paid for by John Shipward, Mayor of Bristol in the 1480s. 
The clerestory repaired after a storm in 1703, aisle and east windows restored 1873. Bath stone ashlar and Pennant rubble south aisle. 
In plan, aisled, clerestoreyed nave and chancel, south-west tower, south porch and south-east vestry. Perpendicular Gothic with a Somerset-type tower. 
A tall five-light transomed east window. A  five-bay north aisle of three-light windows, with a crenellated parapet; the south aisle similar; clerestorey of four-light Tudor-arched windows, again with a crenellated parapet. The south porch has a Tudor arch hung with open cusps. Inside, it has a fan vault with pendants. Nineteenth-century south-east crenellated octagonal vestry with 3-light mullion windows with cinquefoil heads. 
Large west nave window has a flat Tudor arch and six-light transomed lights. There is a four-stage tower with north-west octagonal stair tower and an open traceried castellated parapet.
Inside, a panelled reredos by Hansom. A  seven-bay nave, the chancel not structurally differentiated but the two east bays have raised floor; door in north aisle to a rood loft stair. Fifteenth-century arch-braced tie beam roof with gilded bosses. View of nave, looking east, by Johnson, 1828 (BRSMG M2492), showing the old pulpit with tester.
An ornate large marble pulpit; panelled choir stalls and pews with carved bench ends; wrought-iron sword rest by William or Simon Edney, early eighteenth century, with considerable foliage; ornate font of 1882, a square base with an octagonal basin. Royal Arms of Charles II over south door. North aisle: 3 ogee-arched chest tombs, to the west that to Edmund Blanket d.1371, a crocketed ogee arch with open cusps, containing recumbent figures of a man and wife praying, transferred from the previous church on this site. Dresser tomb to Martin Pringe d.1626, bearing a cartouche and two recumbent statues. 
In south aisle a dresser tomb to Sir George Snygge d.1617 with recumbent figure resting on his elbow; probably relocated to east end of aisle in the nineteenth century (BRSMG M2493-M2494). Wall tablet to Robert Kitchin d.1594, with a kneeling couple inscribed on a brass plate (BRSMG M2495). Various late eighteenth and nineteenth-century marble wall tablets. 
A new organ was built by John Smith junior of the Bristol organ builders John Smith and Sons in 1836 (the first organ he built).
Wrought-iron gates and piers, early eighteenth century by William Edney, removed from the Church of St. Nicholas after the Second World War.
Now the parish church of Bristol

Work behind the Snygge monument in 1992 revealed the blocked south aisle east window and some wall painting.

Nos.12 & 14, Victoria Street. Two shops constructed in the early 1870s. Limestone ashlar and brick stacks; roof to No.12 not visible, slate mansard to No.14. Each of 3 storeys; 4-window range (No.12), 3-window range (No.14). Double-depth plans.
Rusticated ground floor of No.12 has 2 large semicircular arches with radial voussoirs, the left forming a vehicle entrance with Pennant spurs or wheel stops and 19th.century doors, the right with a 20th.century shop front; smooth-faced upper storeys below a cornice and parapet with sunken panels, small rectangular windows to the first floor, and semicircular-arched windows to the second. Rear half of the south wall is medieval or post-medieval at ground and first floor level. No.12 contains some possible Georgian wooden window frames. To the rear of the main building was a yard, roofed over to form a garage or store.
No.14 has rendered ground floor and 20th.century shop front; upper windows set in recessed bays,  cornice with worn brackets and a balustrade with turned balusters, before 2 small dormers. The south wall contains much re-used freestone. There are some interesting timbers in the same wall. To the rear of the main building at No.14 was a 3-storey rubble-walled building; cast-iron columns supporting the upper floors; hipped roof on wooden king-post trusses; 2-bay rear wall; demolished September/October 1985. Beyond was a yard, then more buildings, with lean-to roofs, and, at the very back, a lateral building with hipped and tiled roof.
Part of a group of Victorian commercial buildings built when Victoria Street was constructed.

The Demerera House, Quay Head. The building was a three-storey, two-bay building with its entrance off Quay Street. The ground floor was a shopfront with the main entrance off Quay Street, centrally-placed between two bay windows. The upper floors had sash windows, and on the west side of the Quay Head frontage these had four lights while on the east they had two. On this frontage there were bay windows at all levels. The building has a hipped pantile roof from the south side of which a three-flue chimney stack projects. There was a cellar entrance in the pavement on the Quay Head frontage. In the centre of the south (Quay Head) frontage at first floor level was a niche which held a wooden ship's figurehead. This was rescued from the S.S. Demerera which was wrecked on its maiden voyage out of the Floating Harbour in 1850. The figurehead was placed on the building soon after.
The building was demolished in the early 1930s and the figurehead destroyed during attempts to remove it.

A malt house located on the north side of Redcross Street. The building is recorded by the 1st edition Ordnance Survey map of 1883 but had ceased to function by 1896. The site has subsequently been built over but the level of disturbance to the remains of the monument is unknown.

KNOWN_AS: The Coopers' Arms, No.101, Redcliff Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Cooper's Arms, No.101, Redcliff Street. A house of probable seventeenth century date on the west side of Redcliff Street. The tenement plot was laid out in the medieval period as part of the general development of Redcliffe. During the late-medieval period a Pennant sandstone rubble building occupied the site and part of its south wall has survived. The building appears to have been at least partially reconstructed during the seventeenth or early-eighteenth century. A plan of 1894 suggests that the ground floor comprised a room on the street front with a parlour behind. A yard separated the main building from a detached kitchen and a passage ran along the south side of the building. The building was of three storeys according to the Goad Fire Insurance plan of January 1887.
In 1687 the tenement was leased by Benjamin Adams and the rate books indicate that the building was known as The Coopers' Arms by 1695 when Christopher Legg was assessed for the property. Henry Bevan, glazier, seems to have been in possession of the building between 1707 and the late 1740s, though there appear to have been a series of occupants. It was owned by the Society of Hoopers in the 1740s according to a plan by De Wilstar (BRO 04479(1) fo.26-27). Abuttals from deeds relating to The Golden Lion record the property as "a house formerly of David Harris" (BRO 35447 Box 2 Bdl.VII) and by 1775 James Emery, victualler, was the occupier as tenant to Maria Sheard. The rate books indicate that there was also a stable on the site at that date. In the nineteenth century the building was housed J. & M. B. Warry, watchmakers, and later became the premises of Thomas Hall, a metalworker. The building had apparently been demolished by 1934 (Winstone 1957, pl.51) and the site redeveloped as a motor body repair works by 1966.
As part of a programme of archaeological work associated with development the site was partially excavated (BUAD 3629), and the extant south wall of the late-medieval building recorded, in 2000 (BUAD 3552; Lowe 2001) The surviving fabric of the wall was found to include part of an arch. The wall was retained in the subsequent redevelopment of the site.

Chapel of St. Martin, located in the outer ward of Bristol Castle. The precise location and founding date of the chapel are unclear, though it has been suggested that it may have originated as one of the churches of the Saxon town (Leech 1997, 23). The chapel was noted by William Worcestre in the 1480s who records that while it was dedicated to St. Martin, it was then in the service ("deuocione") of St. John the Baptist. A monk from St. James Priory (BUAD 1024M) was meant to be present daily, but Worcestre comments that a service was only performed on Sunday, Wednesday and Friday (Neale 2000, 240-241). The chapel was apparently still extant in 1540 when a "praty churche" was mentioned by John Leland (Toulmin-Smith 1910, 87).

KNOWN_AS: Bristol Gas Light Company Gas Works, Temple Back
MONUMENT_DESC:
Bristol Gas Light Company Gas Works, Temple Back. The Bristol Gas Light Company was formed in 1815, the Company offices being in Castle Street, and the Temple Back gas works was built between 1816 and 1818. The contract for its construction required the building of "ten retorts, one tarr well with a condensor, one purifier, the necessary and proper hydraulic mains with two inch pipes and semicircular bends and other necessary appendages, one wrought iron gasometer of sufficient dimensions to hold fifteen thousand cubic feet." (BRO 28777/G/L/4/1). Another gasometer with a capacity of 36,500 cubic feet, christened Aladdin (BUAD 1563M), was constructed in 1818.
The gas works was proving unable to meet demand by 1820 and the company acquired a site at Avon Street in October 1820. A new gas works was built there to consolidate the company's operations on one site and the Temple Back gas works was closed in 1821.
The site was leased from 1822 and it was sold in 1824 to Tothill & Co. which built an Alum Works on the site. The gas holder Aladdin and possibly some of the other gas works buildings were still at least extant in the 1850s.

Gate lodge on the north side of Park Row. One of a pair (with 3222M) of eighteenth century entrance lodges for Tyndall's Park first depicted on a survey of the Royal Fort and lands adjoing belonging to Thomas Tyndall dated 1785 (BRO DC/E/40/68/1, Bryant 1994, 9-11). Plumley and Ashmeads survey of 1828 depict these lodges, altough the eastern lodge is unshaded, each with a rectangular pond to the rear. The large scale survey of 1855 also shows these lodges, although they are absent on the 1883 1:500 Ordnance Survy plan.

Llan House, formerly no.9 St Michael's Church Lane. The house was in existence by 1662 when it was recorded in the rate books as the garden house or lodge belonging to Elizabeth, widow of Hugh Browne (Leech, 2000, 84). Archaeological evaluation of the site in 1992 identified medieval footings in part of the structure (1132). In the eighteenth century the main part of the house was of three storeys with a centrally placed pedimented entrance with a lower two storey range attached to the west as depicted in an early twentieth century drawing in Latimer's Annals, vol.1 (ibid.).

A house and garden recorded in ratebook entries as belonging to Elizabeth Cugley in 1662. A plan of c.1790 depicts the property as a single large garden with a small single room house in the south east corner labelled "Chicken Alehouse" (Leech, 2000, 76)(BRO 04479(2) fol.98c). The plot was redeveloped in c.1813 for ten houses and Park Place, later 31-37 St Michael's Hill.

KNOWN_AS: Pen Park Hole, Pen Park Road, Southmead
MONUMENT_DESC:
Pen Park Hole, located on the north-eastern side of Pen Park Road in an area of open space. The cave is believed to have been formed by hydrothermal action in a buried Carboniferous limestone ridge around 160 million years ago and a fault or bedding plane controlled the upward flow of water from the cave. It is currently (07/12/2006) the only known fossil hydrothermal cave in the United Kingdom. The main cave is approximately 100 metres long and 60 metres deep and has extensive deposits of the mineral calcite (Calcium carbonate) on the cave walls. There is also a series of galleries to the south-east of the main chamber, also part of the hydrothermal system which formed the cave, which were identified in the eighteenth century. Their precise location and extent is now unknown.
The cave is reported to have been discovered in 1669 by lead miners (Southwell 1683), apparently working a possible small quarry which appears to lie immediately north-east of the current entrance to the cave. On 2nd July 1669 Captain Samuel Sturmy (1633-1669) made a descent by rope into the cave. Sturmy was a local mariner who lived in St. George. When he retired from the sea he became a customs officer at the Port of Bristol. After leaving this post Sturmy made a series of observations of the tides in the Severn which were communicated to the Royal Society, produced a plan of Bristol (which is now lost), and published the Mariner's Mirror (1669). Sturmy is reported to have caught a chill after his exploration of the cave and died as a result (Southwell 1683; Kenney 1947). Several individuals and groups have subsequently explored the cave and several measured surveys have been made, including one by Captain Greenville Collins in 1682, one by William White in 1775-1776 [this survey is in the collections of Bristol Reference Library B10158], and another by the University of Bristol Spelaeological Society (UBSS) in 1992 (SMR 20138). An extensive investigation was undertaken by the Cave Research Group of Great Britain in 1962 (SMR 24512; Tratman 1963). Geophysical surveys to establish the extent of the cave took place in 2006, including a Ground Penetrating Radar survey (SMR 5087; Thomas 2006) and a radio location survey (SMR 24511).
Historically the cave has frequently been misinterpreted as a lead mine and there are signs of prospection within it. A proposal to work it was made in 1843, although this does not seem to have been executed. The evidence for prospection probably relates to this episode (Mullan 1993).
Pen Park Hole was sealed in 1962 following the Cave Research Group Survey. It was reopened in 1992 for the survey by the University of Bristol Spelaeological Society (UBSS) survey and a permanent, lockable entrance was created at that time.
The cave is owned by Bristol City Council. Access is administered by UBSS, the Bristol Exploration Club and the Wessex Caving Club.

KNOWN_AS: House on Horsefair, at corner of old Silver Street
MONUMENT_DESC: House on Horsefair, at corner of old Silver Street. The ground-floor used as a shop. On the corner of Horsefair and (old) Silver Street. Attached to north and east. One gable to Horsefair, at least one to Silver Street. 3 storeys and attic; 1-window range to south. On south side, a left-hand entrance; shop window. Full-width pentice roof above. First and second floors with rusticated 'quoins', and common canted bay with sashes. flat roof to bay. Attic window (sash?). Lateral stack(s) on east side. Occupied in 1824 by George Cox, brown stone potter, according to Cashin's illustration.

KNOWN_AS: Bristol Royal Hospital for Sick Children
POSTAL_ADDRESS: Bristol Royal Hospital for Sick Children, St. Michaels Hill
MONUMENT_DESC:
Bristol Royal Hospital for Sick Children, located on the western side of St. Michael's Hill. The building was constructed in 1885 to a design by Robert Carwen. It is a two-storey, five-bay structure of Brandon Hill Grit with limestone ashlar dressings. The structure is in a Tudor Gothic Revival style with perpendicular window and door openings. The central bay comprises a large, full-height, ashlar porch with octagonal buttresses. The main entrance is an arched double doorway and there is a three-light oriel window with a moulded base and a crenellated parapet above. The bays at either end of the building are gables and have projecting bay windows with canted sides at ground floor. The roof is covered with clay tiles and there is a large chimneystack to the northern ans southern ends of the roof. The original design included an ornate bellcote with crocketed finials at the centre of the roof, but this has been removed. Internally the building has a decorated entrance hall.
New wards designed by the architectural practice Oatley and Lawrence (BRO Building Plan Book 48 fo.12) were added to the rear of the building in 1905.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/10/284).

Bristol Castle. The castle replaced a motte and bailey castle (BUAD 940M) which was constructed after the Norman conquest in 1066. The motte and bailey was removed and the castle largely reconstructed in the early-twelfth century. The bailey ditch appears to have been realigned on the western side of the site and a barbican gate created. The castle was enclosed by a tall curtain wall constructed of Pennant sandstone with ashlar detailing to the openings. Internally the castle was divided into two wards, the outer ward on the western side in which the keep, the Constable's quarters and the Chapel of St. Martin were located, while the Great Hall, another chapel and the kitchens stood in the eastern, inner, ward (Neale 2000, 240-241). To the south, in the area between Queen Street and the River Avon was the Kings Orchard.
During the Anarchy, the fighting for the Crown which followed the death of Henry I in 1135, Bristol castle was the centre of power of the Angevin party supporting Henry's daughter Matilda (Fleming 2004, 4-5). In the mid-twelfth century Henry II took control of the castle and made it a Royal fortress. The maintenance of the Castle seems to have been a drain on Royal resources and the accounts of the Constables of the Castle record numerous repairs in the thirteenth and fourteenth century. Particularly in the later middle ages, a level of disrepair seems to have been tolerated.
The castle was sold to the Bristol Corporation by the Crown in the 1630s. It was reinforced during the First Civil War (1642-1646) and acted as the headquarters for the parliamentarian governor of Bristol, Nathaniel Fiennes. A total of 33 cannon were sited at different locations in the Castle at the time of its capture in July 1643 (Roy 1975, 262-263).
The castle was demolished relatively rapidly in the late 1650s to make way for the development of housing on the site, and the stone was apparently recovered for use in the construction of the houses. However, some elements seem to have escaped immediate removal. James Millerd's 1673 map of Bristol suggests that the west curtain wall was still standing at that date. Part of the south curtain wall also survived, as did the building known as the Vaulted Chambers - thought to be part of the entrance to the Great Hall.
Archaeological investigation of the site has been relatively limited but there have been two campaigns of excavation, one in the late 1940s and early 1950s and one in he late 1960s which was directed by M. W. Ponsford of the Department of Archaeology of the City of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery (Ponsford 1979).
The only elements now visible above ground are the Vaulted Chambers, a rock-cut sally port and a section of the south curtain wall.

No.1-3, St. Augustine's Place. c1892; refurbished 1925. Render with limestone dressings, cast-iron frame, roof not visible. Double-depth plan. 4 storeys and attic; 3-window range. C20 shop front, upper floors divided by pilaster strips and moulded strings, cornice, coped parapet swept up to a central raised segmental pediment with a ball finial. Right-hand doorway has 3/4 Doric columns to a semicircular arch with a key dated 1923. Windows have exposed steel lintels with slim central cast-iron fluted columns, and moulded cills; central attic window, plate-glass casements. Interior remodelled 1983. An early iron-framed building.
Before refurbishment the roof was gabled (front) and hipped (rear), with Double Roman tiles, some of which bore Bridgwater stamps. The rear elevation consisted of 5/6 bays, with the wall of No.1 St.Augustine's Place set back from the general line. Cellared. Those cellars to Nos.2 & 3 were extended beyond the building, and later used as a communal air raid shelter (Arch.El.No.960A).

Nos.24-27 Castle Green, a terrace of four houses located on the west side of Tower Street, immediately south of the 'Olde Friendship' public house. The buildings were of three storeys, and attic, each with a basement. Gabled fronts, 1 gable to each; each a 2-window range; all cellared. Not jettied, but with continuous strings between all storeys. Lateral stacks at ends and in the centre. Pairs of adjacent entrances. A pair of sashes to the 2 middle houses, a shop window to the southernmost, and a single window, shuttered, to the northernmost. Pairs of windows to all first and second floors, single windows to attics, a mixture of casements, cross-windows and sashes. A gable to second house from the south had been replaced by a flat roof, a wider window inserted at the front.

No.106, Temple Street, located on the western side of Temple Street. The building was a three-storey, single-bay jettied house with a gabled pantile roof. It does not appear to have had an attic storey.
The main, east-facing, elevation was timber-framed and rendered. The ground-floor contained a shopfront with the main entrance door on the north side of the elevation. The door head was supported by two carved wooden brackets (BUAD 1014A), that on the south side a grotesque mask head and scroll work at the sides while the other had leaf and scroll decoration and bore the date 1587 on the front. The first and second floors were jettied.
The original internal plan of the building is not currently clear and the interior had been significantly altered by the time of demolition.
When Victoria Street was created in the later-nineteenth century the building was renumbered as No.115, Victoria Street. The building was demolished in 1907 and was observed by John Pritchard shortly beforehand (BUAD 697). The carved brackets from the main entrance were recovered and both were donated to the City Museum.

No.12 Welsh Back, known as 'Langton's House'. The site now lies largely below an open area on the west side of the Back, immediately south of the 'Brygstowe' office block, and north-east of another at No.15-21 Queen Charlotte Street. In 1905 it was learned that many of the architectural details were to be removed to a new residence in Hampshire, designed by Edwin Lutyens. 
The building was recorded internally by Philip E. W. Street in 1931, with annotated sketch plans made on March 18th. and internal photographs taken the following day. He noted that the first-floor room facing the Back had been the "Drawing-room", with, apparently, a fireplace on the north wall; behind was another, unidentified, room; behind again, a modern office with skylight; to the rear, to the north the main staircase, to the south the "South Room". This last had an "Elizabethan" window in its east wall (i.e.against the modern office), with a fireplace of similar attribution at an angle in the south-east corner. Immediately west was the "West Room", with, on its west side, a passage which turned west at its north end to reach Queen Charlotte Street. In the west wall of the room were (south) "jambs of Elizabethan window" and (north end) "Elizab. panelled door", the latter above a similar feature on the ground-floor. A fireplace had formerly been located along the north wall of the west room. In the south wall of the adjacent property to the north, No.11 Welsh Back, and against the second room of Langton's House, were several blocked-up "Elizabethan" windows. 
The front was recorded by Robert Harman in 1732, when Arthur Taylor, mayor, occupied the house. His drawing was copied by H. O'Neill in 1821. As late as 1810 the left-hand entrance and two columns were still standing. In that year there was a fire in the building.
O'Neill shows a house of two bays, a 3-window range. Three storeys and attics. Entrances with semicircular heads to left and right, between single columns; low pairs of gates before the single panelled doors; wider central arched opening. Full-width parapet at first-floor, above the columns, with urns, etc., as decoration. Large central 15-light window with double transom; to either side, canted bays of 9-lights to front, 3 to each side, parapets. Second-floor possibly flush with first. Oriel to centre, single transom, 6 lights, 4 each to sides, parapet; either side 6-light windows. Balustraded parapet at attic level, with access door below central valley. A cross-window in either gable. Twin gables to front; cross gable, with stacks either end. Observatory platform in centre of roof, balustraded. Gables possibly slated. 
Inside was a fine staircase, drawn by O'Neill in 1821 (M2266), carved balusters, and square newel posts surmounted by beasts. The fine full-height chimney-piece was drawn by Johnson in 1823 (M2268); Rowbotham recorded the doorway and panelling in 1826 (M2269-2271).

A pair of houses. Attached. One front gable each. 3 storeys and attics; jettied; 1-window ranges. Haulingway entrance at left-hand of left property, cross-window to right. Right-hand entrance to right-hand property, sash to left, cross-window at left-hand end. Total of 8 brackets to the first-floor jetty across the pair, most with posts beneath, but 1 bracket removed by haulingway entry. One bay at all upper storeys of each property, 8-light fronts to first-floor left and attics, 10-light to second-floors. Sashes to first-floor right. Gabled mini-roofs to attic bays. Brackets to all eaves; pendants to gable apexes. Posts to ends and centre at the first-floor, possibly representing removed brackets. In 1821 the left-hand premises were occupied by John Hemming, wharfinger. 
By the 1930s the haulingway was 2 storeys in height, though no wider. Only 1 bay survived, at the first-floor of the right-hand house. On the ground-floor of the same building there survived on the right a 16-panel C17 door in a frame decorated with carved jambs, with brackets above; to the left was a 8/8 pane sash. The entire ground-floor was fronted in brick. P. E. W. Street's photograph of the rear shows that the roofs were connected by a cross-roof. The first and second floors were jettied. A pair of sashes had replaced the left-hand (i.e.eastern) first-floor window; upper storeys had retained their earlier fenestration, viz. 10-light to each at second-floor, 6-light to the right-hand attic, 3-light to the left-hand. Street notes that the buildings were destroyed by bombing on 24 November 1940.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: The Old Council House, Corn Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Tolzey, located on the north side of Corn Street, near its junction with Broad Street. The Tolzey was a court and was probably where market dues were collected or enforced and was in existence by 1331 (Bickley 1900, 41). The medieval form of the building is not, however, clear as the building was rebuilt in 1550. This may perhaps have been a reworking of the earlier structure rather than total reconstruction. However, in 1617 it was reconstructed again, the height increased to admit five tall windows. By 1657 the Corporation had purchased the adjacent house, on the corner with Broad Street, in order to increase the accommodation.
The building was damaged by a fire of unknown severity soon after the Restoration. A vignette in the border of James Millerd's 1673 map of Bristol records the repaired structure. This shows a building of two storeys with a five-window range. There was a central entrance between pairs of arched cross-windows. A colonnade (BUAD 1063A) with either a flat or lean-to roof protected the area in front of the ground floor and above the bay leading to the Tolzey entrance was a statue of a monarch (probably that of Charles II later at the Guildhall (BUAD 53M). Three nails were sited in this area, apparently between the columns. At first floor there were five windows, each of six lights, mullion and transom. Above each window was a shield or plaque, with the Royal Arms in the centre. The bays of the Corn Street elevation were divided by a series of pilasters or buttresses, each capped by either an heraldic animal or a crocketted finial, and were of unequal width. The form of the roof is not indicated by Millerd and is therefore unknown.
The Tolzey was removed to make way for construction of a Council House (BUAD 341M) in 1701-1704. The colonnade was given to the parishioners of St. Nicholas and apparently removed from the site.

No.6, Bellevue. The building is the southernmost of a terrace of nineteen houses. The plot, formerly part of the grounds associated with Clifton Hill House, was leased from the Society of Merchant Venturers by Harry Elderton in 1792 for a term of forty years (Ison 1952, 234). Construction of the terrace began under the supervision of William Paty (Priest 2003, 101) but was abandoned in 1793 when the outbreak of war caused a slump in development. The buildings remained uncompleted for nearly two decades but the terrace had apparently been completed by 1815.
The building is a rendered three-storey house with attic and basement. It has a slate mansard roof. A raised walk on the east side of the building extends the full length of the terrace.
In 1882 the building was occupied by Rev. J. W. T. Hart.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/6).

KNOWN_AS: The Stag and Hounds, No.74 Old Market Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Stag and Hounds, No.74 Old Market Street, located on the south side of Old Market Street. The building is a public house of three storeys and attic with a four-window range. It was built in the late-seventeenth or early-eighteenth century, and is of rendered stone rubble, with limestone detailing and a pantile roof. It has a stone vaulted basement with a barrel skid. The Pie-Poudre Court of the Market was held in the building from the medieval period, reputedly in the first-floor room. The extant building stands on the site of an earlier structure and the cellar retains some medieval fabric.
The building has a wide gabled front with the first floor projecting forward and overhanging four closely-chamfered timber Doric columns to a moulded entablature beam, moulded strings to each floor, and bracketed eaves. Central doorway with twentieth-century double doors, flanking nineteenth-century two-light left-hand and four-light right-hand windows; windows above in bolection-moulded exposed frames, with 6/6-pane sashes. 1-window right-hand return; the rest of the side is 1986. The rear has a narrow projecting left-hand section, and a projecting second-floor section to the right. Delamotte's 1824 drawing shows 4 cross-windows to the second-floor, 2 to the attic, with a truncated gable, flat-roofed at the front. Behind appear to have been a pair of parallel ridge roofs, with, towards the rear, a slate-hung small square turret with pyramidal roof rising above them. This last may have been a form of belvedere or observatory.
Internally some early eighteenth-century panelling and a cornice survives in the ground-floor front room with a stone right-hand fire surround with pulvinated frieze and cornice (removed from an upstairs room). There is a left-hand front open-well stair with uncut string, barleysugar balusters, square newels with pyramidal finials, and a moulded rail; fully-panelled first-floor room with 6-panel door and twentieth-century fire surround.
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as No.75 Old Market Street and was occupied by Henry Slade.
The building was subject to archaeological recording on several occasions during the twentieth century.
The right-hand return was rebuilt after the demolition of the neighbouring building to make way for the Inner Circuit Road. The building was partly reconstructed in the 1960s when the truncated gable was reinstated. It was refurbished and the interior extensively altered in 1986.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/12/1656).

Harford's Bridge or Bedminster Bridge, located at the south end of Redcliff Hill. The bridge was opened in 1807 to carry the main road from Bristol to Bedminster and the South West across the New Cut. The bridge was of iron with a single-span arch. At each corner there were stone piers, with lamp pillars and there was also a lamp at the centre of each side. The bridge was removed in 1882 and replaced by the western of the present pair of bridges.

Bathurst Basin Footbridge, located opposite the end of Guinea Street. The bridge was a swing footbridge over the southern end of the entrance to Bathurst Basin from the Floating Harbour. Two leaves, meeting in the centre. Shallow arch, with lattice-work sides to walkway. The bridge was replaced by Bristol Harbour Railway bascule bridge in the 1860s.

Lewin's Mead Meeting House, a Unitarian chapel, located on the north side of Lewins Mead. The building replaced an earlier meeting-house, built in 1693-94, which was demolished in 1787. The present structure built in the late 1780s or very early 1790s to a design by William Blackburn of London and was registered in 1791.
The meeting house is constructed of rendered stone rubble with ashlar dressings; ashlar facing to the front wall above a rusticated lower stage; main roof hipped and slated, with extension to south gable/pediment. In plan the main building is a broad rectangle with projecting pedimented centrepiece on the south with open semi-circular porch. Large tripartite window with arched head above porch, also one each end of building and three in north wall. Interior of 45ft. by 70ft.; galleries to east, west and south, with semi-circular staircases. Pulpit on north wall. Ceiling divided into panels. Later additions of ancillary buildings.
The front walls, gates and railings are also listed Grade II*. The Sunday school and Tower House are listed, together, as Grade II.

KNOWN_AS: House on the west of the junction of Pile Street and Pump Lane
MONUMENT_DESC:
House located on the western side of the junction of Pile Street and Pump Lane. The house was of seventeenth-century date and was of two-storeys and attic. A dwelling which belonged to the parish of St. Mary Redcliff stood on the site by 1623 and by 1693 the building was leased by the Foeffees of St. Mary Redcliff to William Townly, loader, and John Townly, tailor. In 1722 John Townly assigned the lease to George Alexander, a wheelright, in 1722.
Stuccoed upper storeys. Doorway to left of single cross-window, which has one shutter; two similar windows to first-floor, one to attic.
It is not clear when the building was demolished but it is likely to have been in in 1843 when the other buildings immediately to the north of St. Mary Redcliff churchyard. The site is now beneath the north-east corner of the churchyard and the adjacent footway on the west side of Pump Lane.

St. James Church. The church is the former church of the Benedictine priory of St. James, founded in 1129 as a cell of Tewkesbury Abbey.
Late C12 five-bay nave of stout columns with 4 half-round minor shafts; wide, scalloped capitals, and square-section semicircular arches and lozenge hoodmoulding which runs on into the east wall; ornamented string course below deeply splayed clerestory windows
C12 west end has clasping buttresses to the lower rubble section and a much restored segmental-arched doorway within a round arch; above is a sill band to the ashlar upper part, which contains a fine arcade of interlacing arches pierced by 3 round-arched windows matching those at the east end, the middle one wider; between the tops of the buttresses is a string, and a c.1160 wheel window of plate tracery forming 8 circles around a central one within a zigzag ring, but the interlacing moulding has mostly disappeared; above is an upper string and an arrow slit; wide, gabled north aisle with a semicircular-arched window to the south gable.
A wall tomb reputedly of Robert Earl of Gloucester, a wide moulded arch containing a C12 recumbent effigy in robes
tower c.1374
The priory nave became a parish church in 1374. Tewkesbury Abbey had the advowson of the rectory. The choir is virtually completely gone, except for part of its south wall against the north side of the tower.
South aisle widened in C14
late C14 arch-braced collar roof on corbels
The advowson of the church (worth xiijs. iiijd per annum) was acquired by Henry Brayne, a London merchant-tailor, as part of his purchase of the Priory lands in 1544 (Latimer 1897-99).

a wall memorial to Sir Charles Somerset d.1598
The late C17 south aisle of 5 bays has 4-light windows with square heads, separated by buttresses. South aisle rebuilt 1698
mid Georgian porch late C18 porch at the west end with side windows as the south aisle.
south porch early C19; north aisle rebuilt 1864.
mid C19 double north aisle.
Blank east end with 3 C19 round-arched windows at higher level, and an oval light in the apex. 4-stage unbuttressed tower with a small doorway on the east side, and a square south-west stair tower, flush with the west side, with an octagonal spirelet; on the south side is a small flat-headed window to the lower stage, a small lancet to the second stage, and a clock; 2-light belfry windows, a string with corner gargoyles and a crenellated parapet. 
C19 north aisle of 5 gables with 2-light plate tracery windows, and semicircular-arched clerestory windows. s; there is an arched doorway below the east window; clerestory windows set in a band of blank arcading, 2-storey
After the dissolution of St. James, the advowson of the rectory was acquired by Henry Brayne as part of his purchase of the St. James property in 1544.
The 5-bay C19 north aisle is 2 bays wide: an arcade of red granite columns, probably following the line of the old aisle, and respond shafts in the north wall, wide capitals with undercut foliage, with shallow pointed arches, and half-arches to the nave. 
The south aisle has fine painted corbels to a timber pitched roof. Restored west window.
