Large late C19 pulpit; C19 Norman-style font with zigzag moulded column base; wrought-iron altar railing, choir stalls with poppy heads, plain pews with doors.
Various memorials, including
Above the west door is a Royal Arms. Various wall tablets. 
O'Neill's 1821 drawing (M2805) shows a single-storey porch of square plan at the eastern end of the south aisle. Two-centred arch to outer door; 2-light west window with square head and drip-mould; flat roof. Drawings of the interior looking east (Johnson, M2808), details of monuments, the brass, the Somerset monument (M2817-M2818), and the possible Robert Earl of Gloucester tomb (M2819-M2821).
The church was declared redundant as an Anglican church in 1984. It was leased to the Little Brothers of Nazareth in 1992.

KNOWN_AS: West of England and South Wales Bank, Corn Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
West of England and South Wales Bank. The bank was founded in 1834 with the head office at Bristol. The bank commissioned and built new offices between 1854 and 1858. The building was designed by W. B. Gingell and T. R. Lysaght who drew their inspiration from Sansovino's Library in St. Mark's Square, Venice.
The structure is of Bath and Portland ashlar, roof not visible. Italian Palazzo style. 2 storeys; now a 6-window range (originally 5). A regular, richly decorated front with relief carving to spandrels and friezes. Portland left-hand C20 entrance bay (added later). A banded, vermiculated plinth, deep ground-floor sill band, attached ground-floor Tuscan columns to an entablature with frieze and modillion cornice, first-floor plinths to attached Ionic columns, paired over the entrance, to a larger entablature and a blocking course. 
Large left-hand doorway set back between pilaster jambs with a plate-glass overlight in a semicircular arch; urns on pedestals above. Semicircular-arched ground-floor windows. First-floor Venetian windows with cast-iron railings on the sills. Blocking course has large square urns at the ends and doorway. It was extended in the early twentieth century and was cleaned and restored 1974. The building is currently (16/6/98) occupied by Lloyd's Bank.

The Lamb Inn, on the north side of West Street, Old Market. The inn was established in 1651, according to a statement on the central bay and occupied three tenement-widths, with a frontage of 45 feet.
Ground-floor. To the left, a canted bay with railings either side. In the centre, a vehicle entrance with large wooden gates "carrying shell-pattern carving in the upper panels". Spurs to either side of access. To the right, two bays with central doorway, with twin lamps above. Across the whole width above the ground-floor a pentice roof, with full-width fascia board. Above left side of the haulingway, the inn 'sign', the figure of a lamb couchant. Painted sign bearing the legend "LAMB INN BY W. H. SYMES".
First and second floors. First-floor possibly jettied. Two-storey canted bays to left and right; two-storey square bay to centre. Sashes (8/8 pane) to first-floor, narrow (2/2) to bay sides. Six-light mullioned and transomed windows to left and right at second-floor; Ipswich-type window to centre, with keystone bearing an ornamental shield. Rowbotham's illustration shows a mullion dividing the centre panel of the Ipswich window, also oculus-type openings for the upper lights either side.
Three front gables, without windows, all linked at lower level to run across fronts of the bays.
A massive staircase was the principal interior feature, carrying the date 1651 [1017A] and with a carved ground-floor newel post and carved balusters, both typically mid-seventeenth century. John Pritchard, also noted an "excellent" chimney-piece inside the building.
The inn was demolished in 1905 for road widening. It was visited beforehand by John Pritchard (BUAD 903), who photographed several of the internal features (Pritchard 1906). Pritchard reports that the staircase, large wooden doors, sign and chimneypiece were all salvaged from the building. The staircase was retained locally; but the large wooden doors, the Lamb sign and the chimney-piece all left the city.

Nos.4 and 6 Victoria Street. The sturcures are a pair of shops constructed in the early 1870s. Red brick with yellow brick and limestone dressings. Top missing as a result of enemy action; present roof not visible but probably flat. Double-depth plan. 3 storeys; 6-window range. 20th.century shop fronts, below an arcade of narrow 2-centred arches between the first and second floors; bricked-up second-floor. Rear elevation of 3 storeys and 6 bays, all rendered. Part of a group of Victorian commercial buildings developed after Victoria Street was created.

No.10 Victoria Street. Early 1870s. Limestone ashlar, roof not visible. Double-depth plan. 3 storeys; 3-window range. 20th.century shop front; first-floor windows have set-back jambs and small moulded corners and inscribed keys; second-floors window separated by pilasters; PLATNAUER BROTHERS inscribed on the parapet. An unusual interior layout. No cellar. The outside of the rear wall has a brick facing to a possible 18th.century wall at the north end, with, at the very end, the remains of a medieval wall that once ran eastwards into the area later occupied by the brewery stables. Part of a group of Victorian commercial buildings developed after Victoria Street was constructed.

Church of St. Werburgh. The church stood on the south-west corner of Small Street and Corn Street. The date of foundation of the church is unknown; the dedication to St. Werburgh has traditionally been taken to imply a Saxon origin. However, the cult of St. Werburga apparently underwent a revival after the translation of the saint's remains to Ely in 1095 (Ridyard 1988, 186n) and the dedication may therefore post-date the Norman Conquest. The church is first directly recorded in a charter of 1148-1183.
The four-stage tower (with stair turret in north-west corner) was on the south, or Corn Street, side. On the west side at second-stage level was one two-light arched window. Upper half with two-light traceried panels or blind arches, three to each stage, the central ones with some openings.
The east end was taken down, and the church truncated, in 1759 to improve access into Small Street (Evans, 1824 278). At this time some of the monuments were removed to William Reeves house at Arnos Court.
When the church re-opened in 1762, the north elevation comprised five bays, with a short sixth bay at the east end. Large windows with geometrical tracery; no window in eastern bay. Porch in second bay from west, ogee-headed arch over entrance, possible room above porch; walls with cinquefoil-headed panels. 3-stage buttresses to church. A small plain single-storey building against east end of the elevation. 
Arcades of two-centred arches marked the division of the two aisles, which were either side of nave. 4-light window high in west end of nave.
The interior, looking west, was recorded by Johnson in 1828 (M2458) when there were box pews in nave. Other details, including the Barker monument (recorded by Cashin and Manning (M2461)). Part of a monument of Elizabethan or Jacobean date was drawn by O'Neill, 1820 (M3450) A blank end wall to Small Street, at least at its northern end where one gable end is recorded.
The church was demolished in 1878 to enable Small Street to be widened. A public meeting chaired by the Lord Mayor in March 1876 argued to retain at least the tower (Anon. 1876, 250) but the Bristol Corporation resolved by 30 votes to 23 to demolish the entire structure in December 1876 (Anon. 1876, 1270). The site was sold to South Western Bank for £15130 and subsequently redeveloped as a bank. Elements of the building were re-used in a new church at Mina Road (Listed Grade II*). The medieval font, which had been stored in the tower was reported, at the end of the nineteenth century, to have been removed to the garden of a house on the Bath Road.

No.8, Bellevue. The building is the southernmost of a terrace of nineteen houses. The plot, formerly part of the grounds associated with Clifton Hill House, was leased from the Society of Merchant Venturers by Harry Elderton in 1792 for a term of forty years (Ison 1952, 234). Construction of the terrace began under the supervision of William Paty (Priest 2003, 101) but was abandoned in 1793 when the outbreak of war caused a slump in development. The buildings remained uncompleted for nearly two decades but the terrace had apparently been completed by 1815.
The building is a rendered three-storey house with attic and basement. It has a slate mansard roof. A raised walk on the east side of the building extends the full length of the terrace.
In 1882 the building was occupied by a Mrs Webber.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/6).

POSTAL_ADDRESS: The Bank of England, Wine Street
MONUMENT_DESC: The 'Crown', located on the north side of Mary-le-Port Street, partly over the southern end of Guard House Passage. 3 storeys and attic; two gables to rear elevation. 6-light transomed windows, 1 to left of second-floor rear, one to left rear gable. Blocked window to right gable. The rear of the haulingway under the building is supported by a beam carrying the date 1612. There is a flat four-centred arch beneath the beam, and another at the southern end of the passage. At the rear of the eastern wall of the haulingway is a column with a Tuscan capital. A T-post was inserted into the centre of the passage, near the yard end. Part of the Guard House was built onto the rear of this building. The haulingway was drawn by T. L. Rowbotham in 1827 (M2361).

Dr. White's Almshouse, also known as the Temple Hospital, located on the western side of Temple Street, on the north side of its junction with Bear Lane. The almshouse was founded by Thomas White D.D. in 1613 and consisted of ten individual residences (Manchee 1831, 518). White set down regulations for the management of the almshouse in the same year (Manchee 1831, 518-521).
The original range of almshouse was a jettied structure of three-storeys. Bays to ground-floor with entrance between, all boarded below; Gothic arch to right, heavily-moulded, capitals to jambs. Bays to first-floor, 6-light mullion & transom, large arms between; full-width pentice roof over. Two cross-windows to second-floor; cornice and boxed exterior gully; brackets to eaves. Stack at southern end. Rear elevation of 2 storeys with one large gable. To left, end of passage from gothic arch at front; in centre, wide corbelled canted bay window, mullions and transom, 14-light, 2-light to sides; individual hipped roof. At first-floor two 2-light windows. Right-hand end of rear elevation obscured by range along north side of yard. 
The range on the north side of the yard was of 2 storeys with series of gables, a covered walkway with pentice roof running along the front of the ground-floor.
The almshouse is reported to have been "damaged and part blown down" in 1703 and subsequently rebuilt, probably in 1705 (Manchee 1831, 117). A further fourteen apartments were later added. These were described in the early-nineteenth century as "ranging with the old ones. This more recent part of the structure has been erected at various times, as the finances of the establishment have enabled the governors to build them" (Manchee 1831, 119).
The building fronting Temple Street (NGR ST 59250 72828), drawn by Hugh O'Neill in 1821, was removed in August 1824. A replacement building as constructed in 1824-1825. This was a two-storey; three-bay building in a Tudor style with a crenellated parapet and castellated miniature turrets at the ends. There was a central two-centred arched doorway in a square head with decorated spandrels, and drip moulding. Above, this there was a corbelled bay window.
The rear blocks were rebuilt in 1882 to increase the accomodation to 32 persons and depicted in a drawing by Loxton in c.1900 (Bryant, 2008, 8, figs, 16-18).

Bristol Sailors Home, located on the northern side of The Grove, to the rear of No.29 Queen Square. The Bristol Sailors Home was constructed by the Sailors Home Committee from 1851 (Pilkington, 2000) and was a conversion of the stable/warehouse, counting house and kitchen of No.29 Queen Square (BUAD 1463M) together with the western of a row of four houses constructed c1778 on The Grove. The works included reconstruction of the elevation to The Grove (BRO 40311/B/1 fol.17), the creation of an entrance hall towards the east side of the building at ground-floor and the insertion of a chimney stack against the west wall (Leech, 2002). The shell walls of the c1778 house formed the eastern rooms of the structure.
The building was recorded in a photograph of the 1870s, and as completed was a three-storey, four-bay structure with four hipped pantile roofs, three retained from the stable/warehouse to the west of the main entrance door and the other the roof of the c1778 house to the east. The main, south-facing elevation was of rendered rubble stone. The ground-floor level was of rusticated ashlar with moulded voussoirs above the window openings. The main entrance door is located towards the eastern side of the building, between the third and fourth ground-floor window and  its opening is surrounded by a moulding. The upper floors of the elevation were plain except for a pilaster which extended to the base of the parapet and divided the western bay from the rest. The fenestration appears to have comprised large sashes in all of the windows although the window opening at the east end of the second floor was blocked. The legend "SAILOR'S HOME" was painted between the first- and second-floor windows.
The original internal organisation of the building is not currently clear. At the front of the building, to the west of the entrance hall there was a single large room at each floor. The ceiling of the ground-floor room was supported on cast iron columns and may have been an association area. The upper floors are likely to have been dormitory space. At first floor in the east range (the former counting house) a metal safe for the inmates valuables was constructed against the party wall. During the twentieth century a number of alterations were made to the interior, including the insertion of partitions to create individual bedrooms in the large first and second-floor rooms and suspended ceilings on the ground floor. These alterations were removed in 2002. The site remained in use as a sailors home until the 1990s. It was converted to offices in 2003.
The building was surveyed by Jayne Pilkington in 2000 (BUAD 3627; Pilkington 2000) and by Dr. Roger Leech in 2002 (BUAD 3913; Leech 2002; 2003). There are photographs of the interior of the building before its conversion to offices within the Sites and Monuments Collection of Ground-based Photographs.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/204).

St. Philip's Mills, a hemp and flax mill located between Stephen Street, Russ Street and Upper Cheese Lane (now New Kingsley Road). The mill was in extstence by the early 1870s (Winstone 1966, pls.62-63) and its form remained very similar until 1883 when the mill was surveyed for the Ordnance Survey first edition Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.22). There were entrances to the site off Stephen Street and New Kingsley Road which led into an open metalled yard. On the north side of this yard, adjacent to the gateway on to New Kingsley Road, there was a two-storey stone rubble building with a hipped pantile roof. This had a steep flight of steps, apparently wooden, leading up to first-floor level. To the west of this was a detached square building and to the west again, a four storey building constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble, possibly a warehouse. This had at least nine bays and each bay contained small arched windows. Along the north side of the yard, on the south side of these buildings, there was a surface of large setts forming a vehicular route.
On the south side of the yard was a single-storey L-shaped shed (at ST 59772 72932) measuring 55 metres from east to west and 22 metres wide. The main element of the shed was aligned roughly east-west and had at least fifteen bays while the shorter, north-south, arm of the building had only three bays. The northern wall of the building stood on the Stephen Street frontage of the site close to the gateway off Stephen Street. The building was constructed of coursed Pennant sandstone rubble and had a pitched clay tiled roof. Each bay contained a single large casement window with a flat relieving arch above the opening. In the yard immediately to the north of this building and parallel to it there were six rows of drying racks for the flax, each formed by timber posts standing approximately 1.5 metres high which were connected by horizontal rails 2-3 metres long. Attached to the eastern end of the L-shaped building, and slightly set back from it, was a taller three-bay building of three storeys with a pitched tiled roof. The side, north-west facing, elevation contained three arched casement windows at second-floor level.
A rectangular building of two-storeys and attic stood on the New Kingsley Road frontage of the site (at ST 59812 72953), immediately to the north of these buildings and adjacent to the arched gateway opening on to New Kingsley Road. This measured 9.5 metres from east to west and 5.5 metres across and was constructed of rubble stone. The main, north-east facing, elevation was apparently of three bays, with sash windows at first floor. A dormer window with a pitched roof projected from the eaves at attic level and at either end of the roof there was a group of three tall chimney stacks. The side, north-west facing, wall was a single bay and has a projecting stone rubble porch with a flat roof at ground floor level. There was a single window, apparently with ashlar dressings, at first floor and another small window in the gable end. At the apex of the gable there was a bellcote. The functions of each of the buildings within the site is not currently (26/02/2002) clear.
Much of the yard had been developed for an extension to the northern side of the L-shaped building by the time of the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.13) published in 1903. The mill buildings and, it is reported (Winstone 1966, pl.62), some of the associated machinery survived into the late 1950s. The buildings were subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped, although part of the boundary wall to the site appears to survive and some of the fabric of the late nineteenth-century extension to the L-shaped shed seems to have been incorporated into the new warehouse on the site.

The chapel of St. Brandon, on Brandon Hill. The date of foundation of the chapel is not known but it was in existence by c.1193 when the Bishop of Worcester granted it to the Priory of St. James and other churches (Hall Warren 1907, 203). A hermitage was attached to the chapel, apparently by 1351 when Lucy de Newchirche asked to retreat there (Hall Warren 1907, 203). In 1480 William Worcestre visited the chapel in 1480 and recorded that::
"Capelle longitudo sancti Brandane continet .8. Virgas cum dimidio
latitudo eius .5. virgas, continet
Circitus muri capelle sancti Brandani continet .180. gressus" (Neale 2000, 182-183).
Leland visited the site in 1542 and described it as "now defacyd" and the building was apparently removed by the Corporation for the construction of a windmill in 1565 (Hall Warren 1907, 203). Part of the structure may have been found during excavation of foundations for Cabot Tower in 1898 (BUAD 2457) and certainly human remains representing at least three individuals were discovered, including a grave aligned east-west and lined with masonry (Fryer 1989). Most of the chapel seems likely to have been destroyed by later building.

KNOWN_AS: House on north side of Anchor Lane
POSTAL_ADDRESS: Former Railway Goods Shed, Anchor Lane
MONUMENT_DESC: A house located on the north side of Anchor Lane (86 metres directly south of the south-west corner of the Great Cloister of St. Augustine's Abbey). The house was of seventeenth century date. The main elevation of the building faced south, set back from the lane, but was linked to the adjacent building by a low right-hand two-storey range. 2 storeys and attic; cross-gabled; 4-window range. The main house is aligned east-west, with end gables and 2 front gables. Stacks on the ends. Ground-floor with 1 window either side of a central entrance, a wide drip mould above each window. First-floor of 4 sashes; full-width string above. One cross-window to each attic gable. A low front wall with railings and a central gate.

The Alhambra music hall, located on the northern side of Broadmead. The building was first used as a concert hall and between 1874 and 1888 became the Alhambra Music Hall. It became the New Star between 1889 and 1895 and then The Tivoli Music Hall between 1896 and 1900 (Winstone, 1983 pls.129 & 131). The Tivoli was the first venue in Bristol to show moving pictures in 1896 when a series of short films were booked for a fortnight run from June 8th Anderson, 1983, 8). The building became a cinema owned by Frank Ogden Smith known as the Welligton Palace from 1912 until 1916 then the Broadmead for a short time in 1916, although the cinema closed soon after (Anderson, 1983, 20). C19 facade, heavily decorated. Ground-floor of 3 arches, all different widths but each a pointed segmental arch. First-floor of 7 windows with pointed arches, arranged 3+1+3. Similar arrangement for second-floor, but the heads with shouldered lintels. A pointed window to the middle of the third-floor, which was the base of the tower, with a dormer in the steeply-sloping roof to either side. A further storey in the tower, with, possibly, a clock face against the street, then a spire. The building was demolished in 1952 to make way for the redevelopment of Broadmead.

KNOWN_AS: Church of St. Michael on the Mount, St. Michael's Hill
MONUMENT_DESC:
Parish church of St. Michael on the Mount Without, located at the foot of St. Michael's Hill. The date of origin of the church is currently unknown and it has been suggested that it may have originated as a chapel to an adjacent manor house in the area of Park Lane. However, the church was in existence by 1148 when William, Earl of Gloucester confirmed the grant of the advowson to Tewkesbury Abbey. The abbey appears to have exercised its right to appoint through its cell, St. James Priory (BUAD 1024M).
The form of the medieval church is known only in outline. The tower, dated to the mid-fifteenth century, and had a four-stage tower. The nave and chancel are only known from visual sources; Jean Rocque's 1742 'A Plan of the City of Bristol' shows the church in outline plan while a drawing by James Stewart records the south-east side. There were both north and south porches, and the south aisle terminated at the eastern side of the tower.
St. James Priory was dissolved in January 1540. The advowson of the rectory was acquired by Henry Brayne in 1544 as part of his purchase of the property of the Priory in 1544.
Rumney Penrose became rector on 25 June 1743 and he was succeeded by John Culliford in Octotober 1749. In 1763 the south wall of the church was reported to be bulging outwards as a result of the weight and spreading of the roof. On 6 1764 February, after Culliford had died, Samuel Seyer, master of the Grammar School and a local antiquarian, became rector.
To expand the accommodation and presumably also in response to identified structural weakness, the church was rebuilt between 1775 and 1777 to designs by Thomas Paty, although the late-medieval tower was retained. A new organ was built and was first recorded in the church in 1793. This was rebuilt by John Smith senior of the Bristol organ builders John Smith and Sons between 1819 and 1821. There are two illustrations in the Braikenridge collection in Bristol Museum and Art Gallery of the stained glass (M2580-M2581) and of the monumental shields (M2582-2583).
During road-widening at the lower end of St. Michael's Hill the eastern part of the churchyard was removed and this is reported to have "involved the transportation of a great quantity of human remains" (Latimer 1902, 45).
The church was declared redundant in 1999.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/11/279).
1792 Evan's Brick kiln named on map - no building shown. {1}

No.92 St,. Thomas Street, located on the west side of St. Thomas Street, to the south of Three Queens Lane. The building was a timber-framed, jettied and gabled house of probable later seventeenth- or early eighteenth-century date. It was of two storeys and attic and had a single bay. The building appears to have had a pantiled cross-gable roof. By the end of the nineteenth century at ground-floor level the main, east-facing, elevation on St. Thomas Street had a main entrance door on its northern side and a small window at the centre of the elevation. There was a timber stall riser with painted lettering fixed to the exterior. The first-floor was jettied and had a single small four by three pane sash window at the centre. There was another sash at the centre of the attic gable and the eaves were protected by plain wooden barge boards. The main entrance door off St. Thomas Street gave access to the passageway which led to a rear yard. A rainwater downpipe ran from the north side of the roof across the main elevation immediately below the attic sash and into another downpipe on the south side of the projecting element of the jetty. The elevation was rendered.
Internally the plan consisted of three adjacent rooms with a narrow passageway against the north party wall with No.93 St. Thomas Stret (BUAD 851M). There was a single room against St. Thomas Street. Another room to the west was connected by a single doorway and the rear, western, room had a connecting doorway and a doorway in its north wall to the passageway and yard.
The exact date of construction of the building has not yet been established. The 1800 Land Tax assessment records that the property was owned by William Hopkins (Jackson 2001, 5). At the end of the nineteenth century the building was occupied by Mary Francis, manufacturer, who was producing textile sheeting for awnings, tarpaulins etc. Along with the three properties to the north, No.92 St. Thomas Street was bought by Samuel Hannam for use as a timber yard (Jackson 2001, 5).
According to notes by Philip E. W. Street the building was demolished in about 1934, although the Ordnance Survey 1:1250 plan indicates that a building stood on the same footprint until the early 1950s. The site was cleared for road widening in the late 1950s and much of the site of No.92 St. Thomas Street now lies beneath the highway.

Statue of King Charles II. The statue is believed to have been sculpted by John Harvy, a stonecutter, who presented it to the Corporation in return for becoming a freeman. The statue was erected on the pentice roof on the front of the Tolsey (see Millerd's 1673 map of Bristol) and in 1674 "was removed on the leads nearer the Councill-house, by the perswasion of the Duchess of Cleveland [the King's mistress], being then in Bristol; it being (as she said) as a porter or a watchman" (quoted in Evans 1824, 226). It was placed in a niche in the front of the Guildhall when the building was refronted in the nineteenth-century (BRSMG M2440; BRSMG M2436). When the new Guildhall was built in 1843 the statue was placed in Law Courts Yard where it was drawn by Samuel Loxton in the early twentieth century (Bristol Reference Library Q1050). It remained in Law Courts Yard until February 1960 when it was removed during restoration work to th building (Anon. 1960). On inspection it was considered in too poor a condition to be saved and was disposed of.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Former Police and Fire Brigade H. Q., Bridewell Street
MONUMENT_DESC: Mill at Bridewell. On the left, or southern, bank of the River Frome, a little upstream of the location of Bridewell Bridge. Served by the weir that Rocque depicted on his 1742 map, which also may show a sluice at the mill end of the same feature. The foundations of the mill are thought to have been found in 1926 during construction of the new Police and Fire Brigade headquarters buildings. It is assumed that the mill is medieval, but it could be of later date.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Brunswick Square Burial Ground, Brunswick Square
MONUMENT_DESC:
Brunswick Square Burial Ground. The cemetery is sited on the north side of Brunswick Square and associated with the Congregational chapel adjacent to the west. The cemetery had been established by the time of Donne's map of Bristol of 1773, which records it as a "Presbyterian Burying Ground", although at this time its extent was limited to an area on the frontage with Brunswick Square.
The cemetery had expanded to approximately its modern extent by 1828, although Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 plan of Bristol suggests that an area at the north-east corner, measuring 32 metres north south by 22 metres wide, was not then in use for burials. A small mortuary chapel had by then been built at the centre of the burial ground (at ST 59264 73721). Surrey Lodge (BUAD 1700M) was built subsequently. The cemetery was one of those closed under the 1854 Act.
Interments are known to have taken place across the site, with the greatest density in the western half (BRO 39461/P/1(a)(b)). The majority of the headstones were removed in the early 1980s.
Surrey Lodge has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/6/1885). Two groups of chest tombs have a Grade II listing (Listed Building numbers 901-1/6/1883 and 901-1/6/1884).

KNOWN_AS: The Fourteen Stars public house, Counterslip
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Fourteen Stars public house. The building was located at the corner of Counterslip and the east side of Hawkins Lane. It was an attached building of three storeys and attic with a gabled front to Counterslip and dated to the seventeenth century. Jettied; timber-framed. Figure bracket or caryatid on decorated post at corner; bracket and decorated post at eastern end. Entrance on left; to right, sash window with shutters, set in possible brick ground-floor wall. First and second floors similar, with central bays with Ipswich windows and glazed sides, and 6-light transomed windows to each side of bays. Bay to attic storey, transomed, 6-lights to front. Tall brick stacks against east side.
The building presented a side elevation of three gables to Hawkins Lane. There were doors and windows to ground-floor, with some brick infilling below the latter. The cellar entrance was on this side. The first-floor was the only storey jettied and there was a bracket at the north end. In the upper storeys there were windows in the left and centre bays only. 
The inn is reported to have been once much frequented by persons in the 'Guinea Trade' and John Hodges was licensee in 1821. The house next door (east), which had a "very curious old front," was pulled down c.1800 (Braikenridge Notes). By the 1820s was a warehouse used by the Kennet and Avon Canal Company. The building survived into the 1850s and was photographed by Hugh Owen (Winstone, 1970 pls.48-49).

KNOWN_AS: Nonconformist mortuary chapel, Arno's Vale Cemetery
MONUMENT_DESC:
Nonconformist mortuary chapel, Arno's Vale Cemetery. The chapel dates to c.1840 and was designed by Charles Underwood. The chapel has a Pennant rubble basement, but is built of limestone with slate roof. It is an open plan design and has a single storey above the vault.
The chapel has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building No. 901-1/47/431).

No.74 Stokes Croft, located on the eastern side of Stokes Croft. The building was constructed in 1868 for Rev. R. W. Gotch of the Stokes Croft Chapel (BUAD 1451M) to a design by E. W. Godwin (Godwin's original drawings for the buildings are held by the Kelmscott Gallery, Chicago). The building was one of a pair with No.76 Stokes Croft (BUAD 1468M). It is a house of two-storeys and attic, constructed of brick with a tiled roof and comprises a shop with residential accommodation above (Soros 1999, 151-153). As designed, the main, north-west facing, elevation had a large Gothic arch forming the ground floor and this contained the shopfront. A string course divided ground and first floor. The fenestration at first-floor consisted of two sashes within arched openings. The parapet had a brick dentil course with stone copings. Above there was a central dormer with a pitched tile roof and a finial at the apex of the gable, which projected out of the parapet. The building has a pitched roof with a tall chimneystack, serving both No.74 and No.76 Stokes Croft, on its north side.
The building is extant although the arch has been removed and the shopfront replaced.

Cutlers' Hall, Quakers Friars. The building was constructed as the dorter or dormitory of the Dominican Friary. Between the great cloister, to the north, and the lesser cloister, to the south. A thirteenth-century first-floor hall over a ground-floor. An original north wall with a range of lancet windows and a west wall with a traceried window. East window of trefoil lancets. First-floor open to fourteenth-century roof of 6 double 'bays'; roof pantiled.
After dissolution the building became the Cutlers' guild hall.
The building is a Scheduled Ancient Monument. (AV 102) and also has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/40/490).

Friends Meeting House, located in Quaker's Friars. The first Quaker meetings in Bristol were held in an orchard of the former Dominican friary in the mid-1650s. A meeting house was soon built and Millerd's map of 1673 depicts this as a two-storey building apparently with a lantern in the roof. The meeting house was rebuilt in 1747-49 to a design by George Tully. Detailing was added by Thomas Paty and by the building contractor, according to the listing description.
The building is of two-storeys and has a flat lead roof with hipped slate roofs surrounding a central lantern. There is a moulded stone parapet, swept up at the corners. The main interior space is a rectangular room measuring 46 feet by 60.5 feet with galleries supported by stone Doric columns on the north, south and east sides). The fittings have mostly now been removed, but some seating remains in the galleries.
The building has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/40/492).

No.41 St. Michael's Hill, located on the western side of St. Michael's Hill. The building was rebuilt along with the adjoining no.39 between 1695 and 1703 as a three storey house attached house with attic dormers (Leech, 2000, 77). The ground floor appears to have consisted of two parlours and a kitchen towards the rear and a detached wash kitchen behind as depicted on an early nineteenth century outline plan (ibid.)(BRO 04479(3) fol.63a; 38041/BMC/12/PL4 fol.37). Both no.39 and 41 were completely rebuilt in the 1950s and only the exterior shell of the building is likely to be original fabric.
The house was in the ownership of Ezra Prigg in 1696 (Leech 2000, 77).

Chatterton House Museum, located on the northern side of Pile Street. The house was constructed for the use of the master of Pile Street School in the mid-eighteenth century, and the building carries a date of 1749. The building is of two storeys and cellar with a hipped pantile roof and is constructed of rendered Pennant sandstone rubble. It has a three-window range and the main doorway has a flat canopy supported by scrolled brackets. A plaque above the door reads "THIS HOUSE WAS CREATED BY GILES MALPAS... AD 1749".
The building had a double-depth plan with connecting rooms behind a central staircase. The interior has, however, been significantly altered. There was a yard in front of the building enclosed by a screen wall of limestone ashlar with a doorway on the western side and two segmental-headed windows with architraves.
The father of the poet Thomas Chatterton was schoolmaster and Chatterton was born in the building in 1752. Chatterton was also educated at the school.
The screen wall was repositioned in 1937-1939 when Redcliffe Way was created. The house was opened as a museum, part of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery, in 1958 and was latterly used for staff accommodation. A porch was added to the building in the twentieth century and in 1983 the cellar was filled in. A plaque on the building commemmorates Thomas Chatterton and bears the legend "THE BIRTHPLACE OF THOMAS CHATTERTON" and the statue of Chatterton (BUAD 50M), which originally stood on a tall plinth outside St. Mary Redcliffe Church (BUAD 6M), is stored in the garden shed. The building was photographed in the 1880s (Winstone 1962, pl.63) and was drawn by Samuel Loxton in early twentieth century (Bristol Reference Library V1218 and V1219. It was surveyed in 1980 (BUAD 930).
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/235).

No.4 Christmas Steps, located on the south side of Christmas Steps. The building dates to the late-eighteenth or early-nineteenth century and is a three-storey, single bay house with a cellar and a hipped roof. The ground and upper floors are of brick bonded in a white lime mortar. The cellar is of Pennant sandstone rubble with a barrel vault and a flagstone floor. The side walls are bonded in a white lime mortar with a cross wall at the southern end of the cellar in a greyish pink lime mortar and incorporating occasional bricks within its fabric. Internally the building was two rooms deep on each floor, with a one room overlooking Christmas Steps and one at the rear of the building. All of the rooms had a chimneybreast at the centre of the east wall.
In the later twentieth century the interior of the building was substantially altered with the removal of the cellar vault, the replacement of the floors at all levels of the building, the removal of the internal walls and the insertion of a spiral stair on the west side of the building.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/11/44).

The Assembly Room, located on the west side of Prince Street, to the north the junction of Prince Street with Assembly Rooms Lane. The Corporation made a grant of land for the erection of the building in 1753, subject to the right to occupy the hall for up to six days per year. Funds were raised for construction by a tontine subscription with 120 members each taking a £30 share in 1754. The building was erected to a design probably by the architect William Halfpenny (the professional name used by Michael Hoare) and was completed in 1755 (Ison, 1952 109).

The main elevation faced Prince Street. Attached to the north and west. Approached by steps which led into the ground-floor, which was rusticated to the Prince Street frontage. Central bay set forward; one segmental-headed window to each side of entrance. Pediment supported by two pairs of Corinthian columns above the rusticated storey. Central Venetian window, with, above, an entablature bearing the inscription "Curas Cithara tollit" ("Music dispels care"). To the each side a tall sash window with pediment. The ball-room was lofty, 90 feet long by 45 wide, with plaster decorations; two doorways led to the retiring rooms; lit by rows of segmental-headed windows on each side, with rusticated jambs and voussoirs. Carved and panelled ceiling to ball-room, with cornice; gallery at east end. Interior illustrated in TBGAS,29,opp.p.24. Jackson's 1825 illustration (M2508) shows a canopy over the front steps.
Elevation to the lane of a 7-window range. Right-hand entrance with pediment; 4 windows, entrance, and window, all with semicircular heads with rusticated voussoirs. Similar windows to first-floor, with 7 recessed panels above. Plain parapet.

In 1811 the building was converted to theatrical use by its owner William Jenkins, becoming the Regency Theatre. The proprietors of the Theatre Royal took action to close the theatre, arguing that the performances there were "extremely injurious to their Interests" (Barker, 1974 75-76). The building was demolished in 1956 (Gomme et al., 1979 155).

KNOWN_AS: Conduit of St. Mark's Hospital or Gaunt's Pipe
MONUMENT_DESC:
The conduit of St. Mark's Hospital, also known as Gaunt's Pipe. The conduit was constructed in the thirteenth century to supply water to St. Mark's Hospital and to St. Augustine's Abbey. A charter of c1205-35 made by Roger, Lord of Clifton granted the springs and watercourses arising in the croft, now the Gorse Lane area, to the Abbey of St. Augustine. The property containing a spring close to present Constitution Hill was granted to Henry de Gaunt master of St. Mark's Hospital at College Green in c.1235-45, thereby giving the right to the water to the Hospital of St. Mark and St. Augustine's Abbey. The conduit was also recorded by the 1373 perambulation of the new County of Bristol (Harding 1930, 154-155).
The conduit collected water from several springs on the hill below Bellevue and elsewhere above Jacobs Wells Road into a series of underground chambers. These include the possible "bet tohorah" (BUAD 949M), which is a Scheduled Ancient Monument, at the foot of Constitution Hill (ST 57689 72864), a late-medieval chamber, accessed via a moveable slab at the junction of Gorse Lane and Jacob's Wells Road (ST 5770 7293), and a further medieval chamber on the south side of the junction of Constitution Hill and Jacob's Well Road (ST 57692 72843)(BUAD 1191M). A plan by William Halfpenny of 1742 shows the chambers along Jacobs Wells Road connected by conduits and these combined to a single watercourse beneath the centre of the road south-east of the junction of Constitution Hill and Jacobs Wells Road. According to a plan of mid-nineteenth century date in the Corporation Plan Books the conduit then ran down Jacobs Wells Road and along St. George's Road to a conduit head at Unity Street. There was a feather close to the junction of York Place and St. George's Road to serve St. Augustine's Abbey. This ran south-east to the St Augustine's conduit head in the lower cloister, now College Square, and the water was then presumably carried to the north-east to serve the refectory of the abbey. The course of this conduit may have been diverted away from an original route along Frog Lane when the Park Street viaduct was built.

No.42 Old Market Street. The building is of early eighteenth-century date and is a three storey, three-bay redered house with limestone dressings. It has a hipped pantile roof. The building has a double-depth plan and has a cellar which is rectangular in plan, with stairs from the rear of the shop and a chute from the pavement. There is a possible former window in the rear wall.
The shop front is of eighteenth-century date, with rusticated pilasters to a deep modillion eaves cornice which returns at the ends. The early nineteenth-century shop front has two eight-pane bow windows either side of a two-leaf door, with fluted timber pilasters to a dentil cornice which bows out above the doorway, narrow first-floor 6 over 6-pane sashes beneath raised pediments, segmental to the centre, and shorter, keyed second-floor 6 over 6-pane sashes, all in flush boxes.
Internally the rear ground-floor fireplace is set in an ashlar niche, beside a cast-iron safe with fluted stone sides, and two-leaf doors above.
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by Samuel Butler, druggist.
The building had been truncated to two storeys by 1974, and it was restored c1980. The interior was largely remodelled at that time. Some of the fittings of the chemist's shop were obtained by Bristol Museum.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/12/1645).

No.93 St. Thomas Street, located on the west side of St. Thomas Street, to the south of Three Queens Lane. The building was a rendered timber-framed, single-bay house of two storeys and attic and probably dated to the later seventeenth- or early eighteenth-century. The design of No.94 St. Thomas Street was very similar (see the late nineteenth- or early twentieth-century photograph in the Ghey Collection), suggesting that the two were constructed as a pair, and possibly as a part of a terrace of three with the larger No.95 St. Thomas Street.
By the end of the nineteenth century at ground-floor level the main, east-facing, elevation on St. Thomas Street consisted of a shopfront. It had two adjacent entrance doors on its north side and the northern of these had a small light or signboard above it. The original narrow ground-floor window had been replaced with a six by three pane shop window which occupied much of the remainder of the elevation. The first-floor was jettied and had a single small two by four pane sash window at the centre. A projecting feature which extended across the full width of the frontages of Nos.93-95 divided second from attic storey. There was another, slightly smaller two by four pane sash at the centre of the attic gable.
The building had a pantiled roof which was half-hipped to the front. There was a large chimney stack, apparently of stone rubble, rising from the south wall. The Goad Fire Insurance plan of January 1887 suggests that in plan the ground floor had a single large room with a yard to the rear.
The exact date of construction of the building has not yet been established. The 1800 Land Tax assessment records that the property was owned by William Hopkins (Jackson 2001, 5). Along with No.92 St. Thomas Street (BUAD 850M) and the two properties to the north, No.93 St. Thomas Street was bought by Samuel Hannam for use as a timber yard (Jackson, 2001). According to notes by Philip E. W. Street the building was demolished in about 1934. The site was used as a timber yard by the early 1950s but the eastern part was was taken for widening of St. Thomas Street in the late 1950s.
Much of the site of No.93 St. Thomas Street now lies beneath the highway. Part of the rear of No.93 and the associated yard was examined during archaeological evaluation in 2001 (BUAD 3798). A live foul water sewer prevented investigation of the trench but beyond the trench for this extant archaeological features and stratification were noted.

KNOWN_AS: House on the west side of Pithay
MONUMENT_DESC: House located on the west side of Pithay, on the north corner of the junction with All Saints Street. Three doors up from "The Bell" public house. The building was a jettied, gabled house of three storeys and attic and was probably built in the seventeenth century. 1-window range; first and second floors jettied; gabled to the Pithay. Ground-floor not visible in detail; oriel to first-floor; full-height bay or oriel, 2 lights to front, 1 each to sides, second-floor; attic window.

The inner circuit town wall, defending the medieval town of Bristol. The circuit was constructed in the Norman period and documentary evidence indicates that it was in existence by the mid-1140s. The wall comprised a tall rubble wall of Brandon Hill grit which was approximately 2 metres thick and there appear to have been a number of semi-circular bastions or interval towers, although only two have so far been identified. Inside the wall were narrow intra-mural lanes - St. Nicholas Street, Leonard Lane, Bell Lane and Tower Lane - which followed its line. A series of town gates, St. Nicholas Gate (BUAD 283M), St. Leonard's Gate (BUAD 1207M), St. Giles's Gate (BUAD 930M), Blind Gate (BUAD 389M), Pithay Gate (BUAD 1209M) and Old Gate (BUAD 34M), controlled movement on the roads leading into the town. There were also several wall churches - St. Nicholas, St. Leonard's, St. Giles, St. Lawrence, and St. John - which were presumably contemporary with the wall. These were either above or were attached to the gates. Of the wall churches, St. Nicholas Church (BUAD 147M) and St. John's Church (BUAD 145M) are extant.
The wall has been archaeologically investigated on several occasions. The antiquarian Samuel Seyer noted elements of the wall in a number of loactions in the 1820s and a long section in Tower Lane was observed by John Pritchard during the construction of the Fry's Factory in Pithay and reported in the Transactions of the Bristol and Gloucestershire Archaeological Society between 1900 an 1910. A standing section of the wall to the rear of Nos.41-43 Baldwin Street was surveyed by Philip Rahtz for the Ministry of Public Building and Works in 1957 (BUAD 484) and an area excavation (BUAD 1503) was simultaneously undertaken in front of it (Rahtz 1960). A further section of the wall was excavated (BUAD 523) to the north-east at No.65 Baldwin Street by Roger Price for the city of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery in 1974 (Thomas 1979, 15-27).
The extant section of the wall to the rear of Nos.41-43 Baldwin Street is a Scheduled Ancient Monument (AV 117). St. Nicholas Church has a Grade II* Listing (Listed Building number 901-1/16/662) and St. John's Church has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/11/536).

KNOWN_AS: Barilla Mill in the former Crypt of St. Lawrence Church
MONUMENT_DESC:
A barilla mill located in the crypt of the former church of St. Lawrence [BUAD 7M]. The mill was installed in 1827 and  consisted of a large timber post set in the centre of a large horizontal circular stone base, with a large vertical stone wheel, and was similar in structure to a cider mill. It was presumably used to crush either burnt barilla, a plant from the Mediterranean region, or burnt kelp to produce an alkali used in soapmaking.
The crypt and mill are depicted in an illustration by Thomas L Rowbotham, 1827 (BRSMG M2455, Stoddard 2001, 24, pl.18).
It is not known when the mill was removed but the fabric of the church was not finally demolished until 1963 and whether or not the crypt of the church survives is not clear.

KNOWN_AS: Blind Gate or St. John's Arch
MONUMENT_DESC:
Blind Gate or St. John's Arch, also known as Tower Gate. A town gate which stood at the top of St. John's Steep. A minor gate, it was possibly a later addition to the defensive line. The gate itself consisted of a plain segmental arch to the outer, or north, side and was accompanied, west, by a small turret or barbette, the Dove Tower [390M]. The arch was constructed of stone rubble, with the segmental arch on the southern, inside, face of moulded freestone while on the outside removal of the render revealed a plain stone arch with voussoirs, apparently of Pennand sandstone above. By the early nineteenth century there was a 2-storey house with mansard roof built above the arch. O'Neill's drawings show the gate to be about twice the width of the 6/6 pane sashes in the house above. 
Seyer (1821, 266-267) noted that the town wall was about 10 feet thick at this point. In 1888 it was noted that the gate was "so nearly covered with modern buildings that only a fragment of the gate itself is visible." The gate and house were removed in March 1911. The demolition was photographed at successive stages by the local photographer Fred Little and observed by John Pritchard; a number of finds were recovered.

St. John's Almshouse, located on the south-east side of St. John's Steep. The almshouse is reputed to have been at the end of the fifteenth century (possibly in 1491). The form of the medieval building is unknown but the original building had fallen into a "ruinous" state by 1721 (Manchee, 1831 3). This was demolished and a new building constructed on the same site. There were thirteen poor female parishioners in the building at that date and the replacement building seems to have been designed with the same accommodation (Manchee, 1831 3-4).
The new building was sited along the south-east side of St. John's Steep, and measured 23 metres from south-west to north-east and was 4.6 metres wide. The building was set back slightly from St. John's Steep and was surrounded by a wall with a central gateway. It was of two storeys with a hipped roof. String course between storeys. Cross-windows to first-floor. Arched entrance at extreme right-hand end, rusticted quoins above it. Entrance with flat porch to its left. Tall brick stacks. Front boundary wall with ball-finial decoration. The almshouse was recorded in a drawing by Samuel Loxton in the early twentieth-century (Bristol Reference Library X1704).
The eighteenth-century building was demolished to allow construction of a new factory building for Fry's in 1910.

The Bonding Yard, to the west of Merchants Dock. The yard lay in the area between Charles Place and Oldfield Place. It was established in the early nineteenth century as a store for timber, pitch and tar, an Act of Parliament in 1776 having made it compulsory for ships to unload flammable materials at Merchants Dock. The yard covered an area of 1.8 hectares in 1828. It was essentially an open-air storage area surrounded by a wall, but Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 map records a large building, probably a warehouse, in the eastern part [the site of which is now partly beneath Merchants Road and partly beneath the Rownham Mead development]. The size of the yard had been reduced by the time of the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map in 1883, Merchants Road having been pushed through the eastern part of the yard. This formed the new eastern boundary of the yard. The area was developed for housing after 1883.

No.23 Lower Park Row. Attached. Probably C16, much rebuilt mid C20. Timber-framed, render and pantile hipped roof. Single depth plan. 2 storeys; 1-window range. Set diagonally to the street with a right-hand doorway at right angles to 3-panel plate-glass shop front, beneath a jettied first floor, with a plate-glass sash in exposed frames, and fascia board; single first-floor window in the left return. Rear elevation C20 stud work. Interior largely rebuilt c1950. Little of the C16 fabric survives, much of the framing rebuilt after extensive wartime damage.

St. Augustine's Hall. A warehouse occupying the whole of the north-west side of St. Augustine's Yard and extending back as far as the rears of Nos.20 to 24a Orchard Street. Large 18th/19th.century warehouse, constructed in three or four phases. Four storeys; seven bays. Rubble contruction, mostly Pennant Sandstone, with brick details. Grey, white and whitish mortars identified. Seven parallel hipped pantile roofs, one above each bay. Cellars to four left-hand bays, each similar and interconnected, with rubble walls, brick barrel vaults and Pennant flagstone floors. In some areas the ground and first floors were knocked together. The earliest part comprised the two left-hand bays, with curved east corner; these bays were set forward of the remaining five; original north-east external wall partly survived. Possibly contemporary was the fourth bay, also with a curved corner, but whose facade was set back from that of the left pair of bays. It also had a former external wall surviving, the south-west. The third bay of the warehouse was formed by roofing over the yard between the earlier buildings and inserting floors. The three right-hand bays appeared to be the latest build, and were of reduced depth. They had concrete floors, whereas the other bays were floored with Pennant flagstones. There were an assortment of doors and windows at all storeys of the seven-bay facade. At the north-east end of bay 2 was a lead rainwater-head, bearing the initials ' R S ' above the date 1774. The various storeys were linked by vehicle ramps. This had been Bristol's first multi-storey car park. Much of the building was supported internally by walls between the bays, some with pierced by arches, but there were also steel stanchions in places. Cast-iron columns supported the roof between the first and second and third and fourth bays. Timber roofs, mostly carried on collared trusses, but the third bay with braced collars. Top floor lit additionally by skylights. Some hoists at the front of the building. 
The Bristol SMR (BSMR 6159) notes that a building (possibly this one), consisting of two houses and land on which was a warehouse and brass foundry with entrances to Denmark Street and Orchard Street, advertised for sale in the Bristol Journal, 30 March 1771.

No.9 Pipe Lane, demolished for road widening at the end of 1937 and now beneath the Pipe Lane/ Frogmore Street junction.
The house had six bays and three storeys, two on the east side beneath the first dormer gable. A chimney stack projected from the roof behind the second, central dormer. Beneath this central dormer gable was a doorway with a broken pediment above. The remaining three bays were to the west of this. There were, however, only two windows in the ground floor and these did not align with the three above. A prominent string line divided the lower floors from the attic level. The roof was pantiled, gabled to east and west, with 3 small gables with lower ridges on the north elevation, and two large chimney stacks projected from either end of it. A cellar entrance was located in the west wall of the building. There was also a small square window at ground floor level. On the same side of the building at attic level was a larger blocked square window. The windows at first and second floor in the north frontage were sashes; the remainder were casements.
The ground sloped sharply downhill from the front to the rear of the property.
A niche, approximately 1 metre high, in the north-west corner of the Pipe Lane frontage may have been for a statue or, it has been suggested, a figure of the Virgin Mary during the medieval period. It is also reported that there was a winged lion near the niche, suggesting a link with St.Mark's Hospital. The niche was removed to the City Museum when the building was demolished.

Limekiln Dock. The dock lay at the bottom of Jacobs Wells Road. It was built into a pill at the bottom of Woodwell Lane (modern Jacobs Wells Road) reputedly in 1626. A document of October 1710 records the lease from the Society of Merchant Venturers of "a house lately built by . John Evans . and also all that piece of void ground on part whereof a dock lately made by him.." (quoted in Insole 1998) but it is not clear whether this was a mud dock operating in the pill or a dry dock. However, Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol records the dock as a dry dock though indicates no ancillary buildings. The dock passed to Edward Blandy in 1712 and the lease was assigned to Captain Joseph Osborne in 1721. The Osborne family sold the lease to John Roach in 1794 but by 1809 the dock was in the hands of Hilhouse and Company. Paintings of the dock from the opposite side of the Floating Harbour (BSRMG M2961; BRMSG M2942) indicate that substantial buildings had been erected to the west of the dock by 1822. By the 1850s the dock was leased to Charles Hill. The dock was too small to accommodate most ships of the period and as a result the dock gates ceased to function. Consequently the dock was out of use for ten years in the 1870s. It was extended to landward in the early 1880s and a new steel caisson inserted. It was extended again in 1893. The dock and its buildings were sold to the Great Western Railway for £5000 at the end of the nineteenth century to allow the extension of the Harbour railway (McGrath 1975, 345).
The western wall of the dock and part of the buildings to its west were archaeologically excavated in 1998 (BUAD 3398) (Cox 1999). Sections of the eastern dock wall was located by trial pits dug by the groundworks contractor during the redevelopment of the site in the same year in order to incorporate the upper parts of the walls into the development.

Spencer's Almshouse. On south side of Lewins Mead, between there and the River Frome. A long narrow range at right-angles to the street and on the eastern side of a courtyard, separated from the Mead by another building, under which was an access passage. There was a like building at the river end, also. The main range was single-storey, attached, with a large pent roof against the east side, with a catslide corbelled out beyond the fronts of each of the 5 units. Pantiled roof. Stacks at the rear of the range. Each unit with an entrance to the right of a small window or windows. Below each window, a stone platform or seat. 
The range fronting Lewins Mead, which may not have been part of the almshouse, was of 2 storeys and an attic. A main roof parallel to the street, with a raised gable at the western end of its south side. The north elevation is not recorded. The south elevation a 2-window range. Left-hand passage to the street, with a small window to its right. Right-hand half aginst the north-south almshouse range. 2 first-floor windows. 1 window in the gable; a dormer window to the right. Stack at right gable end. Pantiled roof. 
At the southern end of the courtyard, a 2-storey, 2-window range, the roof again at right angles to the almshouse range. At the right-hand end, a passage to the river, with square opening to the yard, but a two-centred arch at the far end. Immediately left of the passage, another arched entrance, with a four-centred head and 'stable' doors. Above, a small tiled pentice roof (protecting a bell?). 2 small first-floor windows. A stack at each end of the pantiled roof.

KNOWN_AS: Air raid shelter at No.7 Horseshoe Drive, Sea Mills
MONUMENT_DESC: Air raid shelter at located at the rear of No.7 Horseshoe Drive, Sea Mills. The shelter is a domestic brick shelter and measures approximately 5.5 metres from east to west and is approximately 2.5 metres wide (K. Cottrell pers. comm.).

Redcliff Pipe. The pipe or conduit supplied water to St. Mary Redcliffe Church. Rights over "Rugewell" were granted to the church by Robert Berkeley at the end of the twelfth century (Hirst 1924, 359-360) and the conduit pipe was presumably created after this grant. The source of the water supply is on the north side of Daventry Road, Knowle (at NGR ST 59667 70404) and is enclosed in a sunken chamber.
Beneath the northern end of the eighteenth century raised walkway at the western end of the churchyard was a conduit head. The recess containing the conduit was of one build with the balustrading above. The structure was of limestone ashlar jambs with a shallow arched head with projecting keystone. The conduit head was removed to near the south-west corner of the churchyard in 1832. A feather from the Redcliffe pipe, which ran across Redcliff Hill, supplied water to the Hospital of St. John the Baptist (BUAD 1055M) (Hobhouse 1887, 145).
During the Second World War bombing destroyed a stone chamber some 100 metres from the source of the spring in the Daventry Road area. An inspection chamber 156 metres to the north of this chamber through which the pipe ran was also destroyed by a bomb. A section of the pipe at the southern end of Redcliff Hill was also destroyed by bombing.

The Bishops Palace, located to the south of Bristol Cathedral. A late-medieval building which formed part of St. Augustine's Abbey (BUAD 58M) was converted to use as the palace for the Bishop of Bristol in 1542 or later. The building was irregular in plan and was mostly of two storeys. A Norman undercroft of 3 by 2 bays formed part of the building, the vaulting being carried on two pillars with cushion capitals. This structure is extant. In one wall of the east side there was a tall pointed three-light window, known as Bishop Butler's window. During the Commonwealth the episcopacy was abolished and the Dean and Chapter lands sold. The Bishop's Palace is reported to have been converted to use as a malthouse and the lead to have been stripped from the roof. It was returned to use as a palace after the restoration in 1660.
The building was gutted by fire in October 1831 during the rioting associated with passage of the Reform Act through Parliament. The roofless shell of the building survived until 1963.

KNOWN_AS: House on site of east end of Abbey south nave aisle
MONUMENT_DESC: House, possibly a prebendal house. Built on the site of the east end of the south nave aisle of the medieval St. Augustine's Abbey, against the southern transept and the remains of the south nave arcade. Attached on 3 sides. 3 storeys. Roof may have been of the pentice variety. Plan of 2 rooms wide and 1 room (?) deep. No windows to the ground-floor visible. Left-hand side of first-floor obscured by gabled roof to first-floor of north cloister walk. 2-light window to right. Ipswich right-hand second-floor window, 3-light mullioned window to left. No windows in attic/roofspace. A possible chimney against the nave arcade.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: NCP Car Park, Queen Charlotte Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Crow Inn in Crow Lane. The building was a three-storey, three-bay jettied structure. The narrow eastern bay, however, only had two storeys. The windows in the upper floors were sashes. There was a panelled wooden door in the centre of the western two bays and windows on either side. Beneath the western of these windows was a cellar entrance. The string lines were continuous across the frontage at ground floor level. There was a break between first and second floor, however. Above the second floor of the eastern bay was a sloping pantiled roof. This bay had its own doorway with very narrow window to the west. In the upper storey of the bay was a window immediately beneath the roof line. It appears the property consisted of three properties which had been amalgamated. The western two were gabled while the eastern seems to may have been a medieval house incorporated into the other two sometime later.
The Ordnance Survey 1:500 scale map of the 1882 marks the building as a public house. The building was demolished in the first decade of the twentieth-century.
There is a door in this bay and another placed slightly off-centre between the other two bays.

No.25, Kingsdown Parade. The house is located on the southern side of Back of Kingsdown Parade. The building appears to have been constructed by 1742. While the phasing of the development of the building has not been established through investigation, it seems originally to have been of two-storeys. In plan it is likely to have had a central entrance hall with room on either side at both ground and first floor levels, perhaps with an archway for a coach at the northern end and a small servant's room with a window facing on to St. Matthew's Road. Internally, cupboards built into the recesses adjacent to the chimney breasts survive at both ground and first floors. On the north wall of the western first-floor room there is a surviving fragment of wall painting probably dating to the eighteenth century, although it is not clear whether it dates to the original or second phase of construction. This painting is a single leaf and dart motif in black, white and grey on a liver-grey ground with a narrow white border. The painting was originally more extensive but the majority has been lost.
The building appears to have been altered during a programme of remodelling around the end of the eighteenth century. These works involved the replacement of the stairs and alteration of the position of several of the doors leading on to the landings as well as the addition of a storey and replacement of the roof. Extensions to the garden (south-east facing) elevation of the house were probably added at a slightly later date.
The building is now a structure of three storeys and attic, with a single-depth plan, which is aligned south-west to north-east along the street. The building has a pitched roof with a hip at the northern end.
The majority of the garden originally belonged to a garden house on Kingsdown Parade (BUAD 1246M). However, by 1828 this house had been demolished and most of its garden incorporated into the curtilage of No.25 Kingsdown Parade. A small plot had, however, also been carved out of the south-west corner to accommodate the present No.23 Kingsdown Parade by that date.

Severn Shed, also known as Hide Shed, located on the southern side of The Grove. The building is a transit shed constructed in 1864 to increase the accommodation for goods on the dockside. It is a single-storey structure and was built as an open-sided structure, with the roof supported on iron columns. Timber panels and sliding doors were later added between the columns. Severn Shed is the oldest surviving transit shed in the Floating Harbour.
The shed has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/296).

The Full Moon, North Street, Stokes Croft. The building is a late-seventeenth century coaching inn, constructed in 1690 (R. H. Leech pers comm.). The building is three-storeys and attic and is constructed of stone rubble with a roughcast render and limestone dressings. Double-depth plan. The south-western half of the building is cellared. Inside the building seventeenth-century beams with moulded chamfers to roll stops, and a framed newel stair with square newels and barley sugar balusters survive. The building was refenestrated in the eighteenth century. The nineteenth century frontage has pilasters and a cornice and semicircular-arched ground-floor windows. The gate to the yard on the south side of the building has an eighteenth-century wrought-iron overthrow arch with a lamp.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/6/2028).

The Pithay Chapel, a Baptist chapel. The chapel replaced an earlier meeting house and the Rev. John Tommas preached the last sermon in the old building in 1791. The chapel was a three-storey building with hipped roof; three bays; sash windows; entrance on right-hand through double doors, above which is the plaque. The square rainwater head bearing the date 1700, formerly on the west side of the chapel, was re-erected at "the south top corner of the east wall of the new buildings close by" (Pritchard 1908, 304). The new Bristol Guide for 1794 refers to the chapel as "lately rebuilt". Heath's Guide of 1797 describes the chapel as having "Galleries on three sides supported by small pillars of Mahogany; and two stout pillars of Freestone, which support the cross Arch of the Roof; the whole spacious and beautiful".
The building was visited by John Pritchard in 1907 shortly before its demolition and he described it as "a simple brick erection with a name-stone inset over the entrance". The stone read "BAPTIST MEETING 1653"
His report is accompanied by a photograph of the front. The building was demolished early in 1907, although it had by then been occupied for some time by Messrs. J. S. Fry & Sons.

Colston's House. A large late medieval house complex, on the east side of Small Street. Including a hall, and a chapel or second hall. Main ranges running parallel to the east side of street.  Incorporated a late Norman arcade, destroyed in 1961. At present the layout of the complex is not fully understood. 
Front of 5 bays, all gabled to street, 2 storeys and attics. Left bay with window and right-hand entrance; 2nd.bay with left semicircular-headed entrance and right window; middle bay with central entrance, 2 leaf door, 12-pane shop windows to either side, Babers sale room in 1826; 4th.bay a square-headed haulingway entrance, leading to Withers's cooperage in 1826; right bay with left-hand entrance and segmental-arched window. At first-floors and attics, the left-hand 4 bays are all consistent. One 8-light transomed window to each first-floor; one 4-light window or opening to each attic. Right-hand bay has a 4-light first-floor window, at lower level than those adjacent, and a sash at attic level. 
Rear elevation to courtyard of 2 storeys and 4 bays, Perpendicular, late C15 or early C16. Left-hand bay with square-headed entrance to haulingway to street, sash window above, cutting the string-course. Other 3 bays each of 8-light windows to ground-floor, separated by thin columns reaching full height of both storeys. Single tier of trefoil-headed panels, 4 per bay, with string course above at upper sill level. 8-light windows to first-floors, each light with trefoil head (1039A). Parapet for full 4-bay width, 2 panels to each bay.
Hall of 5 bays, exact location uncertain (1037A). Braikenridge notes (128) that most probably this was Colston's great hall, in 1821 a warehouse attached to a grocer's shop kept by Messrs.Pinnell & Co. (listed at No.21 Small Street in the directories). 
Chapel or hall of at least 4 bays (1038A). Hammerbeam roof (Find Record No.903); floor possibly inserted. In use as the Mirror Printing Office in 1821. The roof is preserved in the collection of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery.
In the first-floor room lit by the windows in the rear elevation, on the opposite wall, was a 5-sided full-height chimney-piece (1040A). The room was provided with a moulded and decorated plaster ceiling. 
Elaborate Classical-style chimney-piece (BUAD 1041A) in a room described as the 'Drawing Room' where Joanna Southcott's congregation assembled "for some time".

KNOWN_AS: Norman church on the site of St. Augustine the Less
MONUMENT_DESC:
A Norman building, interpreted as a church, was identified by archaeological excavation in advance of redevelopment of the site of the church of St. Augustine the Less in 1982. The elements recorded were fragmentary but it was possible to estimate the size of the building which measured approximately 22 metres east to west by 8 metres north to south and that it was had two-bays. The line of the walls was represented by stone-robbing trenches but the door jambs survived to a height of 0.6 metres above the level of the foundations. The building was constructed of Brandon Hill Grit with stones forming the edges of the walls and a rubble construction in the core. The remains of ceramic jars were found inside the church and these were interpreted as acoustic jars set in the floor. The building was later incorporated into the new structure when the church was substantially rebuilt in the late medieval period and the remaining elements were badly damaged by rebuilding of the later church and by the insertion of burial vaults.
Dickinson (1976) in his reinterpretation of the documentary history of the foundation of St. Augustine's Abbey c.1140 suggested that a small church was sited at St. Augustine the Less to house the regular clergy of the monastery until the larger church had been built.
The monument was completely destroyed by the construction of the extension to the Swallow Royal Hotel in the late 1980s.

A Norman first-floor aisled hall with an undercroft which was archaeologically excavated at the site of St. Bartholomew's Hospital in Lewin's Mead in 1974. The hall was built of stone (mainly Brandon Hill Grit although also with limestone, freestone) and was divided by two arcades which ran the whole length of the building. The steps leading to the undercroft were also excavated. Part of one of the arcades survived to a height of roughly 3 metres, although the arches had been rebuilt, as did other elements of the exterior walls. The kitchens and other discrete associated structures were not located.
It was noted by the excavator that the siting of the building respected the cliff to the rear of the property rather than the course of the river Frome at the front, although a slipway (leading to a postulated creek on the north bank of the river) was recorded. The excavator felt that the building was amongst the best preserved of the Norman structures of Bristol. Most of the structural remains recorded during the excavation were retained during the later redevelopment of the site.

The London Inn, located on the western side of East Street, Bedminster, at its junction with Cannon Street. The inn was in existence by 1730 and is recorded by a terrier of land forming part of the estate of the Smyth family of Ashton Court (BRO AC/M11/32) as the "London Inn and Barton." The earliest known cartographic depiction is apparently a plan of the parish of Bedminster made before c.1786 (BRO AC/PL92) and at that date the inn comprised two ranges of buildings, the main range orientated from north-west to south-east along the East Street frontage and a side range running roughly east-west from the south-eastern corner of the main building. The undeveloped land parcel to the north was ancillary to the inn, but had apparently been sold by the early-nineteenth century.
The inn was extant in the 1880s and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town Plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.24). However, it had been demolished by the beginning of the twentieth century to enable the widening of East Street and the creation of Victoria Street.

KNOWN_AS: Statue of Charles Wesley, The Horsefair
MONUMENT_DESC:
Statue of Charles Wesley, located on the south side of The Horsefair in a courtyard between The Horsefair and the New Room (BUAD 256M). The work is a standing figure of Samuel Wesley on a square ashlar pedestal of Hornton stone and was donated by Sir Arthur Sunderland, a Newcastle shipping magnate and then the owner of Aston Martin. It was sculpted by F. Brook Hitch in 1939. Carved into the north face of the plinth is the legend "CHARLES WESLEY / 1707 - 1787 / O LET ME COMMEND / MY SAVIOUR TO YOU" taken from Charles Wesley's hymn Thy Faithfulness, Lord, Each Moment We Find. The statue was unveiled by Sutherland's daughter on 3 June 1939 (Merritt 2002, 45).
The statue has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/40/484).

The 'Bear Inn'. Probably the source of the alternative name of Bear Lane for Little Peter Street. Braikenridge states (Braikenridge Notes 33) "between that house [No.1 Castle Street] & the Bear & Ragged Staff Public House is a Warehouse now used by Mr.Nott as an Iron Warehouse which a few years ago was the London Waggon Warehouse of James & Co. & prior to that period the Bear Inn".

Statue of Neptune, located in the Centre. The statue comprises the figure of Neptune holding a trident in its right hand and the tail of a large fish or dolphin in its left, the fish curving down to the base of the statue where the left foot of Neptune rests on its head. The figure is of cast lead, originally with an iron armature, and stands on a granite plinth. The bronze plaque on the front of the plinth bears the following legend: "Neptune a god of the sea according to ancient mythology this lead-covered statue was produced by John Randall founder Bristol 1723 and erected on the site of the old reservoir  of Temple Conduit in Temple Street, re-erected in Bear Lane Temple 1787 - Removed to the junction of Temple Street and Victoria Street in 1872. Erected on this site Latitude 51 27' 06" north Longitude 2 35' 47" west 10th May 1949." The sculptor is unknown, although a bronze plaque on the pedestal states that the it was produced by a John Randall in 1723. Merritt quotes the accounts for St. Paul's Fair of 1722 record a payment of £32 10s. to John Randall for "the Figureof Neptune & Peddistoll" (Merritt, 2002 69).
The statue originally stood on the head of the Temple conduit but has been moved on several occasions. It was first moved to the east side of Temple Street, at the end of Bear Lane, in 1821. A drawing of 1825 by Delamotte in Bristol Museum and Art Gallery (BRSMG M2170) shows the statue in Church Lane and in 1872 it was moved to the centre of the newly-created Victoria Street (ST 5927672696). The statue was moved to a site at St. Augustine's Reach (ST 5856972774) in the 1940s after a new space was created by the culverting of the section of the Floating Harbour south of St. Augustine's Bridge in 1937.  It was moved again as part of the creation of the Centre Promenade in 1999 and the opportunity was taken to conserve the statue.
