The leadwork was cleaned and repaired and the iron armature, badly corroded and failing adequately to support the weight of the lead, was replaced with a new armature of stainless steel by Eura Conservation. The statue was erected in its current position (ST 58597289) in November 1999.
The statue is listed Grade II* (Listed Building number 901-1/16/650).

Eastern Wapping Dock. A shipbuilding dock created in the early eighteenth century which was sometimes used as a wet dock. The dock lay on the south side of the Avon, to the east of the dry dock [BUAD 773M]. It was aligned NNW-SSE, with the entrance facing the Old Mud Dock.

Hilhouse's Shipyard, located on the south side of the harbour, opposite Mardyke. The shipyard was establised by Alderman George Hilhouse covered an area between the Floating Harbour and Cumberland Road. It was recorded in a watercolour drawing by T. L. Rowbotham in 1826 (BUAD 1970) and by the Plumley and Ashmead plan of Bristol of 1828. The site included a dry dock [1049A] on the east side, with three slips (BUAD 1050A), then a (?) fitting-out or timber storage dock. Various buildings to the west and south of the slips, single-storey, some with lofts, roofs mainly gabled. Removeable footbridges across the mouths of the dry dock and slips. Later known as the Albion Dockyard, run by Charles Hill & Son, and various escort ships (corvettes and frigates) were built here during the Second World War. The dry dock, slips and some buildings survive, altered. The area of the slips is now (1996) the site of a boatbuilding yard and marina.

House, ground-floor used as shop. Attached to east. Facing Horsefair but partly built out across the entrance to Whippington Court. Demolished before 1935. 
Front elevation. 3 storeys; hipped roof; 3-window range. On the right-hand, the Court entrance, with a narrow gap between the upper storeys and the Sunday School to the west. Shop entrance next the alley, shop window to left-hand. 2 first-floor sashes, no window at right-hand; 3 second-floor sashes. 
Rear elevation. Gabled, with small gabled left-hand rearward extension at first and second floor, largely over the alley; 2 small windows. Detail of main elevation not recorded for first 2 storeys; 3-light mullioned second-floor window.

Temple Churchyard, sometimes also known as Temple Gardens. The churchyard lies on the south side of Temple Church off Victoria Street, now bounded to the south and west by Church Lane. The churchyard has a medieval origin. It is not clear whether the site acted as a parochial churchyard during the Knights Templar ownership of the site, before 1312. The Templar church subsequently became the parish church, however, and the use of the site for interment must therefore date to at least the fourteenth century.
The vicar was reprimanded by the vestry for keeping horses, sheep and cattle in the churchyard in 1743. By the time of Donne's map of Bristol of 1773 two tree-lined walks had been created. The churchyard was closed to burials by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852.
Between 1878 and 1880 the churchyard was converted into a public park by the Corporation and the new park was opened by the mayor in July 1880. After the destruction of Temple Church during the Second World War, both the church and the churchyard were taken over by the Ministry of Works. In 1958, however, the Ministry conveyed all but a 15 foot strip of border of the churchyard to the City.

The church of St. Lawrence. The church shared its tower with St. John the Baptist and was located on the west side of it.
The church was sold to Henry Brayne during the Dissolution and was later sold again for building land. The parish was amalgamated with that of St. John in 1580. The church building survived until 1963 when it was demolished without record to make way for the construction of No.11 Quay Street. A note relating to drawing BRSMG M2455 in the Braikenridge Collection gives the internal width of the church as 24 feet. The height was given as about 30 feet and the length "from Present wall to wall" 54 feet. The walls were noted to be 2 feet 6 inches thick. Braikenridge also noted that the "old Oak roof" of the church survived. Various images in the Braikenridge Collection illustrate these features. In 1850, when the building seems to have been used at least in part as a stable, the west wall of the church was extant and contained a blocked doorway, the west window of the church and a stoup.

KNOWN_AS: Black Horse public house, College Square
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Black Hourse public house, facing on to the south side of College Square. The Dean and Chapter leased a plot at the south-east corner of the square to James Greene in 1611 (BRO DC/E/40/28/1) and the building was constructed on this plot in the seventeenth century. It was a single-bay jettied, gabled house of three storeys and the front (north-facing) and side (west-facing) elevations of the building were rendered. The ground floor contained a central entrance doorway and the jetty above was supported on four equally-spaced columns. The ground floor was divided from first floor by a narrow full-width pentice. The fenestration at first floor comprised a single five- by three-pane timber casement window. On the east side of the building there was a projecting element with a hipped pantile roof which extended only up to second floor. This was apparently square and was in front of the façade of the two-storey building attached to the east side. The function of this projecting element is unclear and it was divided from the rest of the façade by a timber pilaster, although it would appear to have been part of the original design of the building. The pediment dividing first- from second-floor did not extend across the full-width of the main elevation at this level, terminating at the eaves of the hipped element of the roof. The second floor fenestration was a wide five- by two-pane casement. There was no window in the attic gable. The roof was pantiled with a three-flue brick stack in the ridge of the roof at the rear of the building. On the west side of the building there was a gateway of coursed squared rubble stone, the main, north-facing,elevation was rendered with what appear to have been ashlar facings. This led to a path around the east and south sides of a walled garden belonging to the building to the west.
By 1825 the building had become the Black Horse public house. The building was demolished not long after 1890 along with the other structures on the south side of College Square. The site of the building now lies mainly beneath Anchor Road.

KNOWN_AS: Prebendal House on the south side of College Square
MONUMENT_DESC:
Prebendal house, located on the south side of College Square. The building was constructed in 1753 by Rev. John Castelman. The building was of two storeys, basement and attic and had a footprint measuring 13 metres from east to west and 10 metres north-south. The main, north-facing, elevation had five bays, each with a single arched sash window in a moulded opening at ground and first floor. The sills were supported by brackets. The main entrance door was in the centre bay. The division between ground- and first-floor level was marked by a plat band and there were ashlar quoins at either end of the elevation. The plat bands marking the division between basement and ground floor and ground and first floor continued around the west side of the building. The form and fenestration of the west-facing elevation were similar to that of the main elevation, with similar sash windows at ground and first floor level. Above the cornice and parapet there were three attic dormers and the roof was apparently a mansard. When recorded by a watercolour in the mid-nineteenth century (BUAD 3790) the building was rendered and painted black or dark grey. There was a large "T-shaped" garden (800 metres square), with a formal layout of paths and a number of mature trees, to the rear of the building and this was reached by steps leading down from the back of the house.
The house appears to have been demolished c.1890 along with the rest of the buildings on the south side of College Square to enable the construction of Anchor Road. The site of the building now lies mainly beneath Anchor Road.

Ship building yards, located at the south end of Narrow Quay. The date at which the yards were established is not currently (11/08/2006) clear but it is likely to have been in the last quarter of the seventeenth century. James Millerd's 1673 plan of Bristol shows an anchor on the site, implying the use was established by then. The yards are first recorded by subsequent editions of Millerd's plan. The 1715 edition indicates that the yards were enclosed by a wall along Prince Street and across Narrow Quay. There were two gates in the Narrow Quay frontage and two in the Prince Street frontage. The plan also indicates a building standing hard against Prince Street in the centre of the frontage.
The yard had gone out of use by the early 1740s and Jean Rocque's 1742 plan of Bristol records that a terrace of houses had been built on its site.

Bishopsworth Manor House, located on the western side of Roman Road. The house was constructed in the early eighteenth century and is of coursed stone rubble with freestone dressings. It has a hipped and mansarded pantile roof.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/50/411).

The Red Lodge, located on the southern side of Park Row. The building was constructed c.1588 as one of two lodges to the gardens of the Sir John Yonge's Great House (BUAD 420M) in St. Augustine's Back which extended from Trenchard Street across Stony Hill.

Brandon Hill Grit with freestone dressings, ashlar lateral stacks and a pantile hipped roof. 16th.century house remodelled in 18th.century as double-depth plan.

3 storeys and basement; 3-window range. Raised ground floor to garden front has an arcade of 3 semicircular arches, formerly an open verandah with a porch at the north-eastern end. Shallow side projections.

Interior with very fine late 16th.century joinery, plasterwork and fireplaces. Great Oak Room almost completely original; fine fireplace with paired fluted columns to a cornice; strapwork plaster ceiling with pendents.

There are attached rubble walls around the rear garden.

Altered c1730. 18th.century left-hand single-storey porch.
large 18th.century open-well stair, replacing an earlier small stair turret. 
18th.century reception rooms, formed by enclosing the garden verandah, panelled with good fireplaces. Stone stair flight to street entrance. the garden verandah was enclosed and mullion windows replaced.and early 18th.century joinery.

Mary Carpenter (1807-1877) founded a reformatory for girls in the building in 1854 (Saywell 1964). The Red Lodge Reformatory gained an international reputation. Three cells from this phase of the building's use still survive in the basement (R. H. Leech pers comm). The reformatory closed in 1917.
The building was purchased and presented to the City of Bristol in 1920 and the architect C. F. W. Dening was commissioned to undertake a programme of restoration. The building was then leased to the Bristol Savages art club. The New Oak Room has panelling and fireplaces from the Museum's collection, the panelling from the Old Rectory at Lower Church Lane (possibly originally from the White Lodge, sister to this building). In the walled garden at the rear a knot garden was created in the 
An annexe contains the 'Wigwam', home of the Bristol Savages club, where a number of items from the Museum's architectural collections are housed.

Foster's Almshouse, located on the eastern side of Colston Street. The almshouse was founded in 1483 by John Foster to provide residential accommodation for a number of poor people. The original form of the building is not currently known but it may have been similar in form and siting to the subsequent building. Foster's will of 6 August 1492 suggests that the residential accommodation consisted of thirteen rooms (Manchee 1831, 80). The Chapel of the Three Kings of Cologne (BUAD 424M) was an integral part of the foundation and Foster established a chantry for a priest to sing daily in the chapel under the terms of his will. As part of a secular establishment the chapel escaped confiscation of its property by the Crown in the 1540s.
The original building was reconstructed in the post-medieval period, probably in the late-seventeenth or early-eighteenth century. The replacement building was recorded in a watercolour drawing of the early nineteenth century by G. Hill (BRSMG M2557) which indicates it was of L-shaped plan, with the Chapel of the Three Kings of Cologne at the west end. The main range, abutting the east side of the chapel, ran parallel to Christmas Steps, with a return to the south at the eastern end. It was of two storeys with a hipped roof and chimneystacks in the ridge of the roof. In an inspection of the building, in relation to an investigation of the charities supporting it, of the early-nineteenth century the building was described as "a substantial stone building, plaistered, comprizing fourteen apartments, seven on the ground-floor, and seven over them. Annexed to this building, at the entrance, is a small chapel for the old people. There is a piece of ground before the building, affording to each of the poor people a small slip of garden; and each of the almspeople has an apartment with a fire-place in it, and a bed in the room" (Manchee 1831, 89).
The almshouse was reconstructed again between 1861 and 1883 to designs by Foster and Wood influenced by the Hotel Dieu, Beaune. The west wing was constructed in 1861, the north wing in 1872, and the south and east wings between 1880 and 1883 to form a courtyard on three sides. The building is of two storeys with hipped roofs and is constructed of brick with black diaper work and limestone dressings.
The almshouse has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/11/85).

No.86 Old Market Street. The building was a three-storey, single-bay house with a gabled pantile roof. There was a shopfront at ground floor level, the entrance being on the east side. It had a bay window at first floor level and a three-light attic window. There were fretted barge boards on the eaves of the gable.
The building was demolished in the 1960s to make way for the Old Market underpass.

Abbey House, also known as The Registrar's House or Headmaster's House, located on the east side of Lower College Square. The building is a two-storey, rendered structure with a cross-gables pantile roof and the main element of the structure is of seventeenth-century date. At ground floor level there is a Norman arched gateway, similar to the former gateway to St. Augustine's Abbey adjacent to the City Library.
The building was to be demolished in the early twentieth-century, but a campaign organised by the antiquarian John E. Pritchard saved the building (Pritchard, 1893-96). During the Second World War the building was heavily damaged by bombing and the interior has since been remodelled and little of antiquity is reported to remain.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/64).

The Rose and Crown public house, No.38 Broadmead, located on the west side of the junction of Broadmead and Merchant Street. The building was of probable seventeenth century date and its footprint measured 13.9m from north-east to south-west and 5.5 metres east-west.
The building was of three storeys and attic and was of probable seventeenth-century date. The north-facing elevation was of three storeys and attic with a two-window range. By the early twentieth century the ground-floor had a central entrance with public house windows, all forward of the main elevation (perhaps reflecting a hidden jetty behind). The fenestration at first and second floors comprised pairs of sashes. 
Parapet, behind which a roof turning from a gable end against the next building (west) to the ridge roof above the east elevation; single dormer window. The east-facing elevation was of three storeys and the first-floor was jettied. The fenestration of the northern and the adjacent bay comprised a single sash at both first and second floors.
The elevation had three gables, the right-hand joining a short return of the parapet on the north-facing elevation. There were no attic windows. There was a chimney stack at the southern end of the building.
The building had been demolished by 1935. The site of the building is now beneath the south-western quadrant of The Podium.

A fountain located 45 metres to the north-east of Henbury Court, Station Road. The fountain was constructed at the centre of a formally-designed set of paths in the first two decades of the twentieth century and was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey third edition 1:2500-scale plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.03) published in 1915. It was a circular structure 11 metres in diameter.
The fountain was demolished in the second half of the twentieth century.

KNOWN_AS: The Cock in the Hoop, 35 High Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Cock in the Hoop, No.35 High Street, located on the western side of High Street. A building stood on the site from at least the mid-fifteenth century and in 1461 comprised two shops with a share of an inn. In 1473 the inn was named "le Cok in the Hope" and at this date it was leased to Clement Wiltshire, merchant, by John Shipward. In 1566 "inner" part (presumably the rear) of the inn was conveyed by Hugh Smyth to Walter Standfast and by 1607 this element had been acquired by John Pepwall. In 1648 the property was sold to Jeremy Holwey and by 1695 the inn had been renamed the Golden Cock (Leech, 1997 79).
In the late 1930s the building occupied a 3.7 metre wide frontage on High Street and the main, north-east facing, elevation was of four-storeys and two bays with a gabled roof. The ground floor was occupied by a shop front with large plate-glass windows. The fenestration at first and second floor levels comprised evenly spaced sash windows The second and third storeys were jettied out from the lower storeys and from one another. The windows of the fourth storey, however, formed a continuous band across the frontages of Nos.35 and 36, beginning two-thirds of the way along the frontage of No.35 and running to the north side of the frontage of No.36. The ends of the two parallel gables had plain bargeboards and there were now windows in the attic gables. A double chimney stack projected from the roof on the south side of the building.
The building survived into the 1940s but was totally destroyed by bombing during the raid on 24 November 1940. The site was subsequently redeveloped and is now beneath No.35-38 High Street.

Grenville Chapel, Oldfield Road. The chapel was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883 which records it as a Wesleyan Methodist chapel with one hundred seats. The building is extant, although the crypt has been converted into a car park and an entrance inserted off Little Caroline Place.

Montague Tavern or the Duke of Montague, located at the junction of Montague Place and Kingsdown Parade. The building was in existence by the mid-1770s and Sketchley's directory of Bristol published in 1775 records that the tavern was in the hands of Blanch Brock. It may in fact be shown by Rocque's 1742 survey, although it is not marked by name. The tavern was subsequently recorded by Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 map of the city, and survived into the 1880s. The area in front of the tavern was where bonfire crowds assembled between 1831 and c.1850 and confrontations with the police were an annual event (Poole in Dresser & Ollerenshaw 1996, 88).
After the building was demolished Montague Place was realigned. The northern part of the building lies beneath the road. The southern part is beneath an area of green space on the north side of Kingsdown Parade.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: The Old Council House, Corn Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
House, partly fire office. No.52 Corn Street. Attached. Four storeys and attic. Cross-gabled. Central entrance between shop windows. Jettied bays, or oriels, at first-floor, with window between. Full-width glazing to second-floor, bay in centre. 2 cross-windows to third-floor; string-course above. Single cross-window to attic, front of gable apparently slate-hung. Small attic window in west cross-gable end. Brackets to eaves.
Occupied by the County Fire Office in 1824. The building was, in 1764 and later, Forster's Coffee House (Braikenridge Notes, B.1).

No.44 Broad Street. 
Render with limestone dressings, roof not visible. Single rooms front and rear with a central right-hand light well, and stair to the rear of the well. A fairly complete C19 shop front with left-hand door to the flat, right-hand to the shop, with a central plate-glass window. Pilasters above to a cornice and parapet; first-floor casements and second-floor 6/6-pane sashes. extensively altered and re-roofed. At the rear incorporates elements from the medieval period and later, also in the party wall with No.43 adjacent to the north. 
In the early C19 was of 3 storeys and attic, with a gabled front. Central entrance between 2 shop windows; first-floor oriel, sash windows; single sashes to upper floors. Single-purlin roof. Above ground-floor, a timber-framed party wall to north, revealed by the removal of part of the next building. At the front of the first-floor party wall a bracket or the eastern half of an arched doorway.

No.4, Bellevue. The building is the southernmost of a terrace of nineteen houses. The plot, formerly part of the grounds associated with Clifton Hill House, was leased from the Society of Merchant Venturers by Harry Elderton in 1792 for a term of forty years (Ison 1952, 234). Construction of the terrace began under the supervision of William Paty (Priest 2003, 101) but was abandoned in 1793 when the outbreak of war caused a slump in development. The buildings remained uncompleted for nearly two decades but the terrace had apparently been completed by 1815.
The building is a rendered three-storey house with attic and basement. It has a slate mansard roof. A raised walk on the east side of the building extends the full length of the terrace.
In 1882 the building was occupied by William Russell.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/41/6).

No.24 Rosemary Street. The building was a house of probable seventeenth-century date which lay on the north side of Rosemary Street. The building appears to have been built as a one of a terrace of four and was a one window range house of two storeys plus attic with a gabled roof. The entrance on the ground floor was on the west side of the frontage. The building shared a lateral rubble stack with No.22. The building was gutted as a result of enemy action in June 1941 and the shell was demolished for the development of the Broadmead shopping centre, probably in the winter of 1954-1955.
The remains of the building are likely to be fairly well-preserved below ground.

No.10 Wine Street, located on the northern side of Wine Street. The building was constructed as the western of a pair of houses with No.9 Wine Street (BUAD 470M) and was a jettied, gabled house of three-storeys and attic, of which the main, south-east facing, elevation and roof, at least, dated to the seventeenth century. The building had a one-window range with the ground floor comprising a shopfront. Above the fenestration consisted of a single canted bay window containing six-over-six pane sashes. A pentice over this extended across the entire width of the elevation. There was a similar bay at second-floor level, again with a full-width pentice roof which had balustrading fixed to it. The attic window in the centre of the gable contained a pair of casements apparently set in moulded openings. There was an exterior collar above lintel level in the gable. A tall brick chimneystack was sited on the west wall.
By 1791 the property belonged to Robert Southey, the father of the poet laureate. The building was drawn in 1826 as part of a view of this part of the north side of Wine Street by T. L. Rowbotham (BRSMG M2343). At that date there was a large signboard fixed to the upper part of the shopfront advertising the shop as the premises of "W. THOMAS HOSIER."
Doorways through the party wall had been created between Nos.9 and 10 by the late 1880s. The building survived into the first half of the twentieth century but was subsequently removed and the site redeveloped.

The New Gaol in Cumberland Road. The New Gaol was designed by Henry Hake Seward who was selected as the architect after an architectural competition (BRO Clerk of the Peace Deposited Plans). Construction of the gaol began in 1816 and it opened in 1820. The original plan of the gaol was recorded by Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 plan of Bristol and consisted of a gatehouse on Cumberland Road with the main elliptical area of the prison enclosed by attached stone walls to its north. The entrance gateway stood on Cumberland Road on the south side of the prison at the mid-point of the high perimeter wall. The gateway had drum towers on either corner and to the north of this, across the yard, was the Governor's House. This had five bays and three storeys and there was a large arched gateway in the centre of the ground floor on the south front. The cell blocks radiated from the Governor's House to the east, west, north-east and north-west and were connected to it by walkways at third-floor level. The cell blocks on the east and west sides each had fourteen bays and three storeys. Chimney stacks projected from the hipped roofs of both of these blocks. The water supply was drawn from a well by a treadmill pump and distributed to cisterns around the prison by a system of pipes but the well became contaminated with water from the Floating Harbour in the summer months, blocking the pipes and requiring that drinking water be bought in. The plan form of the New Gaol suggests that Seward was influenced by Bentham's panopticon principle. Certainly, management of the prison conformed to the emphases on surveillance and separation which characterised early- to mid-Victorian penal theory.
During the Bristol riots of 1831 the prison was attacked by the rioters. The prisoners were released and the buildings, including the Governor's house were burned. The gaol was subsequently rebuilt by R. S. Pope but how extensive Pope's rebuilding of the gaol was, and how far it altered Seward's original design, has yet to be defined. The separate system was introduced into the prison at the beginning of the 1840s (Wood et al. n.d.) and it influenced subsequent alterations to the building, including the creation of stalls within the chapel to ensure prisoners could only view the chaplain (see Winston 1965 pl.70). Overcrowding had also become a problem at the gaol by the 1840s and the day rooms were converted into ten extra cells. By the 1860s the chapel was located between the two cell blocks to the west of the Governor's House. The treadmill was sited in a building adjacent to the north-eastern cell block. Another round of alterations was proposed in 1869.
The New Gaol was closed in 1883. The site was purchased by the Great Western Railway Company in 1895 and the majority of the structure was demolished in 1898 to allow development of Wapping Wharf but the gateway and parts of the perimeter wall are still extant. These have a Grade II listing (Listed Building numbers 901-1/42/1295 (Entrance gate) and 901-1/42/1296 (Perimeter wall)). The National Monuments Record has a file on the New Gaol (NMR File No. 90988).

Smithy, No.36 Jacobs Wells Road, located on the eastern side of jacobs Wells Road. The smithy was constructed at the end of the nineteenth century and was certianly in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey second edition plan published in 1903. The building was initially occupied by, and may well have been built for, a farrier named Jack Mackrell who operated from the site until 1913 when it was taken over by another farrier, Albert Lansdowne (Longman 2002).
Subsequently the site was bought by W. H. Martin & Co., motor engineers, who operated the Brandon Garage from 1926 and a garage continued to operate on the site until the late 1980s. The building was altered to accommodate its use as a garage and while the shell walls survive no original features or equipment belonging to the smithy remains.

The Marsh Wall. A town wall of thirteenth century date which enclosed development outside the core of the medieval town. The wall ran from the Back (modern Welsh Back) westwards along the northern side of King Street, almost to the Key (modern Broad Quay), then turned northwards for an unknown distance, probably terminating at Viell's Great Tower near the western end of modern Baldwin Street. The wall was pierced by gates at the Back, Back Street and Marsh Street. Smith's map of Bristol, 1568, suggests that there was a ditch in front of the wall for at least the east-west section. Documentary evidence from the sixteenth and seventeenth century evidence suggests that houses and other structures were built in front of the wall, and Millerd's 1673 map tends to confirm this.
A bastion was excavated by K. J. Barton in 1960 (BUAD 441) at the rear of St. Nicholas with Burton's Almshouses (Barton 1964) which was left, and remains, exposed after the excavation and which is a Scheduled Ancient Monument. The wall was identified in a small excavation inside Nos.1-2 Broad Quay in 1972 (BUAD 3234) and a further section of the wall was excavated in 1995 during redevelopment of Olivetti House, Marsh Street (Burchill 1995) (BUAD 2456).
The wall was built of of Brandon Hill Grit with occasional pennant sandstone bonded in a red sandy, lime-flecked, mortar. A section cut through the wall in 1995 to determine how it was founded failed to identify any evidence for wooden piles beneath it (Burchill 1995, 4). The wall is not known to survive above ground but may have been at least partially incorporated into the rear walls of the properties on the north side of King Street. The line of the ditch should lie beneath King Street, and although the insertion of services is likely to have disrupted the stratification associated with its infilling.

St. James Square. The square was constructed in the early eighteenth-century. Roofs mostly gabled, parallel to the frontage, but there were some hipped examples. The south and west sides of the square were destroyed by bombing in 1940. Nos. 6, 8 and 9 were destroyed on 24th November 1940. Nos. 7, 10, 11, 12 and 13 were destroyed on 2nd December 1940 and Nos. 1, 2 , 3, 4, 5, 15, 16 and 17 on 11th December 1940. The surviving north and east sides were demolished c.1965 to make way for the new circuit road, Bond Street.

No.94 St. Thomas Street, located on the west side of St. Thomas Street, to the south of Three Queens Lane. The building was a rendered timber-framed, single-bay house of two storeys and attic and probably dated to the later seventeenth- or early eighteenth-century. The design of No.93 St. Thomas Street was very similar (see the late nineteenth- or early twentieth-century photograph in the Ghey Collection), suggesting that the two were constructed as a pair, and possibly as a part of a terrace of three with the larger No.95 St. Thomas Street (BUAD 1440M).
By the end of the nineteenth century at ground-floor level the main, east-facing, elevation on St. Thomas Street comprised part of the frontage of the White Hart public house. However, it retained its original narrow ground-floor window. The first-floor was jettied and had a window opening at the centre. A projecting feature which extended across the full width of the frontages of Nos.93-95 divided second from attic storey. The opening in the attic gable was a slightly smaller and contained a central casement window. The building had a pantiled roof which was half-hipped to the front. There was a large chimney stack, apparently of stone rubble, rising from the north wall. The Goad Fire Insurance plan of January 1887 suggests that in plan the ground floor had a single large room with a yard to the rear. An opening had been created in the centre of the party wall with No.95, although it is not clear whether this alteration was associated with the use of No.95 as a public house or its earlier use as a pottery.
The exact date of construction of the building has not yet been established. The 1800 Land Tax assessment records that the property was owned by William Hopkins (Jackson 2001, 5). By the late nineteenth century the house had been incorporated into the White Hart public house. Along with No.95 St. Thomas Street (BUAD 850M) and the two properties to the south, No.94 St. Thomas Street was bought by Samuel Hannam for use as a timber yard and No.94 was subsequently demolished to make way for a new brick warehouse (Jackson 2001). The site was still being used as a timber yard by the early 1950s but the eastern part was was taken for widening of St. Thomas Street in the late 1950s. Much of the site of No.94 St. Thomas Street now lies beneath the highway.

St. Peter's Hospital, lying on the south side of St. Peter's Churchyard. The property belonged to the Norton family from 1402, and its frontage was measured at 75 paces by William Worcestre in 1478. The medieval form of the building is unclear but the seventeenth-century ranges abutted an earlier, medieval, two-storey range with at least three bays. The arch-braced roof with wind braces over the room later known as the Court Room was also of medieval date (Simpson 1926, pl.9).
The building was acquired by the merchant Robert Aldworth in 1607 as his residence and was refronted by him in 1612-1613. The building was at that date a four-bay jettied structure with gabled pantile roofs. The north-west facing elevation had a timber frontage with elaborate decoration, including carved jettying and carved bargeboards. The porch on the south side of the structure was internally decorated with carved wooden friezes. These were drawn by Samuel Loxton in the early twentieth century (Bristol Reference Library A34) and also photographed in the 1920s. Internally the Court Room had a decorative plasterwork ceiling and frieze, both apparently of seventeenth-century date. It also had a full height chimney-piece with a frieze beneath the mantel and a decorated overmantel with what appear to have been the Royal Arms flanked by two female figures in the central panel. It had carved phoenixes on either side of the fireplace.
After Aldsworth's death in 1634 the building was used as a sugarhouse, believed to be the first in Bristol and to have been refining Madeira cane. During the Commonwealth the building became a mint.
In 1696 a union of the parish poor relief functions, the Corporation of the Poor, was formed after the passage of an Act of Parliament (Butcher 1932, 179-187). This was managed by a committee and housing both adults and orphaned or abandoned children, who were taught knitting, spinning and sack-making - products being sold to provide income for the Corporation. The four western bays of Aldsworth's house were taken over and became known as St. Peter's Hospital (also known as the Mint Workhouse). The building was the administrative centre for the Corporation of the Poor and its records were held there. It also provided accommodation "to the Number of three or fourscore Persons, young and old, chiefly Children" (Anon., 1732) for some of those in the care of the Corporation. However, the majority were either in receipt of outdoor relief (distributed weekly at the hospital) or were accommodated at other sites around Bristol.
The hospital continued to operate until it was destroyed by bombing on 24-25 November 1940 when both the fabric of the building and the hospital's records were lost. The site has not since been redeveloped and the rear wall of the range of buildings survives.
John Pritchard monitored the construction of a new Board Room in 1900 which involved the removal of some seventeenth-century fabric (BUAD 204; Pritchard 1900, 271-272) and a survey was made by Simpson two decades later (BUAD 531; Simpson 1926). However, there has been little archaeological work on the site since the destruction of the building, although a watching brief on landscaping works was carried out by Dr. Roger Price in 1972 (BUAD 63).
Medieval settlement at Bower Ashton (Rahtz 1969).

KNOWN_AS: The White Hart Public House, No.95 St. Thomas Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
The White Hart public house, No.95 St. Thomas Street, located on the west side of St. Thomas Street. The building was a rendered timber-framed, two-bay house of two storeys and attic and probably dated to the later seventeenth- or early eighteenth-century.
The main, east-facing, elevation on St. Thomas Street had a main entrance on is south side with an original narrow window immediately adjacent to it. On the north side of the building was a pair of large wooden gates and this gave access to a haulingway which led to a rear yard. The first floor was jettied and contained two six over six pane sash windows. A projecting feature which extended across the full width of the frontages of Nos.93-95 divided second from attic storey. The first-floor was jettied and had a window opening at the centre. The opening in the attic gable was a slightly smaller and contained a central casement window. The building had a pantiled roof which was half-hipped to the front.
The exact date of construction of the building has not yet been established. The Land Tax assessment of 1800 records that the property was owned by William Hopkins. By 1807 the stoneware pottery of Morgan, Walker and Company had been established at No.95 according to Mathew's Bristol Directory for 1807. The company became W. W. Walker and Company between 1808 and 1815 but it was taken over by William and Thomas Powell in 1816. Powells continued to occupy the site until the operation was moved to the company's site at Temple Gate (BUAD 660M) in 1830 (Jackson, 2001 5). By 1870 the building had become the White Hart public house and an opening had been created at the centre of the party wall to connect the building with No.94 (BUAD 1439M) by 1887, although it is not clear whether this alteration was associated with the use as a public house or as a pottery. Along with the three properties to the south, the White Hart was bought by Samuel Hannam for use as a timber yard and, along with No.94, was subsequently demolished to make way for a new brick warehouse (Jackson, 2001). The site was still being used as a timber yard by the early 1950s but the eastern part was was taken for widening of St. Thomas Street in the late 1950s. Much of the site of No.95 St. Thomas Street now lies beneath the highway.

Trin Mill, located at the confluence of the river Avon and the Malago on the south bank of the Avon opposite The Marsh (modern Queen Square). The mill was granted to St. Augustine's Abbey between 1154 and 1170 by Henry II and had apparently been constructed by 1170-1183 (Walker, 1998 6; 12). The 1373 perambulation of the boundary of the county of Bristol recorded the mill as "Trenlemulle". James Millerd's map of 1673 shows the site at the end of Guinea Street and indicated that it was a watermill at the end of two leats which ran north from a large mill pond in the area of Bathurst Basin. Trin Mills survived into at least the mid-eighteenth century and was recorded by Jean Roque's map of 1742. It was presumably removed to make way for the lock of Bathurst Basin (BUAD 621M) at the beginning of the nineteenth century and the mill pond converted into the basin itself.

The Preceptory of the Knights Templar, Temple Fee. The preceptory was founded c.1129 after a gift to the order by Robert, Earl of Gloucester of the eastern part of the marsh south of the Avon. The site appears initially to have been the centre for the administration of the Templar order in the south-west but later lost this function.
The extent of the preceptory is unknown but a ditch and rubble wall observed alongside Water Lane during laying of services in 1972 (BUAD 98) may indicate that the lane marks the north side and Temple Street the western. The southern and eastern boundaries are unknown.
Little of the internal layout of the precinct has so far been determined. A round-nave church, 18.5 metres in diameter (the same size as their church of St. Mary the Virgin in the City of London), was built and its site lies within Temple Church and excavation recorded evidence for a hall to the north of the church which, although not dated to the twelfth century, was believed by the excavator to be attributable to the Templar occupation of the site. This arrangement suggests a plan similar to that of preceptories elsewhere, the buildings being arranged informally around a central space.
The Templars also built dwellings, probably on Temple Street, which were rented out; by 1185 there were twenty-eight messuages producing, together with their other property in the area, an annual rental of just over £2 9s (Lees 1935, cxxi; 58). With the suppression of the order in 1312 the preceptory was given to the Knights Hospitaller.

Ellbridge's Charity School, located on the northern side of the junction of Fort Lane [modern Royal Fort Road] and St. Michael's Hill. The girls' school was founded by John Elbridge, and he had apparently overseen the construction of a house and schoolroom, with an associated garden, before his death in February 1739. In his will he left £3,000 in trust "for the better establishment" of the school (Manchee 1831, 225-226). Elbridge leased the land parcel within which the school was constructed, Joachim's Close, from the Dean and Chapter of Bristol Cathedral until his death, and the land was presumably part of the endowment he bequeathed for the purpose of founding the school (Leech 2000, 47).
The school had certainly been constructed by 1747 when it was recorded in a drawing by James Stewart (BUAD 2766). The building was orientated from north-east to south-west, parallel with Fort Lane, and measured approximately 56 feet (17.1 metres) along the Fort Lane frontage by 15 feet (4.6 metres) wide. It was a single-storey six-bay building with a hipped roof. The fenestration of the south-east facing elevation comprised six large sashes and the side, south-west facing, elevation had a single sash at its centre. A low parapet surrounded the roof. The garden was to the north of the building. In the early-nineteenth century the school was described as consisting of "a dwelling, with several convenient apartments, now occupied by the mistress of the school, with a school-room adjoining, though not under the same roof, and is capable of accommodating one hundred children" (Manchee 1831, 226). It was managed by the vicar of St. Michael's and the 24 girls educated were taught "reading, writing, summing, and plain needle-work, and they are otherwise employed so as to fit them for the business of servants. They are also instructed in the elements of christian [sic] duty and belief" (Manchee 1831, 226).
The use of the building as a school continued through the nineteenth century and between 1816 and 1830 around £70 was spent on repairs to the building (Manchee 1831, 226). By the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.14) surveyed in 1881-82 an extension had been added to the northern half of the north-east end of the building. The building was extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan published in 1903 (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.16). However by the time of the third edition plan published in 1918 it had been demolished.
Royal Fort Road was subsequently widened and the site of the school now lies partly beneath the northern side of the road and partly within the site of the Children's Hospital.

KNOWN_AS: The Dove House, No.9, Dowry Square
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Dove House, No.9, Dowry Square. The structure is a three-storey, rendered house with a double-pile plan and a pitched pantile roof. It was apparently constructed in the mid-1740s since a lease of April 1745 concerning No.10 Dowry Square describes the house as "new built" (Ison 1952, 159).
The main, south-west facing, elevation is of five bays and the main doorway occupies the centre bay at ground floor.
The original panelling and stair in the entrance hall survives. The stair has an irregular arrangement of balusters, with roughly every third baluster being a turned baluster. All of the balusters have small unturned blocks close to the base.
The cellars have flagstone floors and on the eastern wall of the east cellar parts of an original stone chimneypiece survive together with an adjacent copper.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/14/1426). Photographs of the interior of the building taken on 7 May 2003 are held in the Sites and Monuments Record Collection of Ground-based Photographs.

A tenement of twelfth-century date which was recorded during the archaeological excavation at Dundas Wharf in 1982 (BUAD 344). The tenement lay on the west side of Redcliff Street and was built of Pennant sandstone. It appeared in plan to have had a single room at ground floor and had a yard to the rear. Later construction of cellars had, however, removed considerable evidence and relatively little could therefore be determined about the building. The northern and southern boundaries of its plot remained essentially unchanged until the twentieth century, the southern boundary being the common slip leading to the river. The building was extended westward as land was reclaimed from the river, and an access to the slip from the rear of the property had been added by the fifteenth century (Good 1990/91, 38).

POSTAL_ADDRESS: St. George's Church, Great George Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
Church of St. George, Brandon Hill, located on the hillside between Great George Street and Charlotte Street. The site was purchased for £2400 using the church rate. The church was built in the early nineteenth century, to a design by Sir Robert Smirke, as a chapel at ease to St. Augustine-the-Less. It cost of £10042, met by the Parliamentary Commissioners, and was consecrated in 1823. It could accommodate 1416 worshippers, with 496 of the sittings rented and 920 free (Ralph & Cobb 1991, 27).
The church is constructed of ashlar and Pennant sandstone rubble, with limestone dressings. It has a flat roof with hipped edges.
The original organ was built by John Smith senior of the Bristol organ builders John Smith and Sons. It was replaced with a new organ by John Smith junior in 1854.
An Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852 imposed the restriction that burials were "to be discontinued within five yards of the church, or any housewall [sic] in the churchyard." In addition a restriction that only one body could be buried in a grave was imposed.
The church was declared redundant in 1984 but not deconsecrated. It was subsequently converted to act as a music venue.
The church has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/10/34).

No.11 Portland Square, located on the south side of Portland Square. Portland Square was laid out in the late 1780s and building plots were advertised for sale from March 1790. The plots of Nos.11 and 12 Portland Square were acquired for development by James Lockier but Lockier's went into bankruptcy when the building boom collapsed in 1792. The building was completed by the architect Daniel Hague in 1811. The sale advertisement of 1812 stated that the buildings comprised "three arched underground cellars, a servants hall, housekeeper's room, back-kitchen, larder, brew-house, and other offices, on the area floor; an entrance hall, front parlour twenty feet by twenty-two feet, two back parlours, and a garden on the ground floor; a drawing room twenty one feet by twenty seven, and two other rooms on the first storey; four rooms and a water closet on the attic storey; and four rooms on the upper storey" (quoted in Ison 1952, 221).
The building forms part of terrace, Nos.7-13 Portland Square and is a house with a double-depth plan of three storeys plus attic with a slate mansard roof. The main, north-west facing elevation is of limestone ashlar and has three bays. The ground floor is rusticated and the upper two floors plain. The fenestration consists of sashes. There is a parapet in front of two attic dormers. At either end of the mansard, projecting from the party walls, there is a brick chimney stack. The other walls are of rendered Pennant sandstone rubble. Cellars extend beneath the house and there is a basement lightwell at the front of the house and on the northern side of this smaller cellars extend under the road. The building seems to have gone out of domestic use by the later nineteenth century and was part of the Young & Melrow Stay and Corset factory by 1877.
The building has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/6/1901).

No.12 Portland Square, located on the south side of Portland Square. The building forms part of terrace, Nos.7-13 Portland Square and was a house of three storeys plus attic with a mansard roof. The main, north-west facing elevation is of limestone ashlar and has three bays. The ground floor is rusticated and the upper two floors plain. The interior of the building collapsed in the 1980s and only the façade survives from the original building. At either end of the mansard, projecting from the party walls, there is a brick chimney stack. The other walls are of Pennant sandstone rubble. Cellars extended beneath the house and there is a basement lightwell at the front of the house. On the northern side of this smaller cellars extend under the road.
Portland Square was laid out in the late 1780s and building plots were advertised for sale from March 1790. The plots of Nos.11 and 12 Portland Square were acquired for development by James Lockier but Lockier's went into bankruptcy when the building boom collapsed in 1792. The building was completed by the architect Daniel Hague in 1811. The sale advertisement of 1812 stated that the buildings comprised "three arched underground cellars, a servants hall, housekeeper's room, back-kitchen, larder, brew-house, and other offices, on the area floor; an entrance hall, front parlour twenty feet by twenty-two feet, two back parlours, and a garden on the ground floor; a drawing room twenty one feet by twenty seven, and two other rooms on the first storey; four rooms and a water closet on the attic storey; and four rooms on the upper storey" (quoted in Ison, 1952 221). Ashmead's plan of the 1850s indicates that the building had apparently only half the length of the adjoining buildings in the terrace. The rear part may therefore have been demolished by that date or the building may never have been of the same size. The building had gone out of domestic use by the later nineteenth century and was part of the Young & Melrow Stay and Corset factory by 1877.
The building has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/6/1901).

No.8, Castle Street. The building was a gabled of three storeys with a pantile roof and lay on the north side of Castle Street. It was almost certainly constructed as part of the redevelopment of the site of Bristol Castle after its demolition in the late 1650s, probably in 1663.
The building was painted by T. L. S. Rowbotham in 1829 (BUAD 1832; BRSMG Mb6398) when it was occupied by a druggist. The ground floor of the main elevation was a shopfront with a central doorway. The first-floor fenestration comprised a canted bay, with a large central sash and small sashes on each side. On either side of the bay there was pargetting or moulded plasterwork. The pargetting on either side of the bay at first floor had central elliptical panels, the western containing the letters "ID" and the eastern the date "1663". The plasterwork was very similar in style to that of No.7, suggesting that the work on the two buildings was executed at the same time and for the same owners. The second floor extends into the roof space and has a central twin sash window in the same plane as the rest of the gable end. The decorative plasterwork did not extend above first-floor. There was a chimney stack on the east side of the roof.
The building survived into the early twentieth century. Its site now lies in Castle Park on the east side of the path from Broad Weir past the end of St. Peter's Church.

War memorial, Fishponds Park. The memorial was erected in 1920 at a cost of £600 by the residents of Fishponds. It consists of a bronze statue of a British/Dominions infantry soldier of the First World War set on a granite plinth. The statue faces south-east and immediately below its feet on this face is a bronze scroll bearing the inscription "1914 VICTORY 1918". On each of the four sides of the plinth are bronze plaques recording the names of those killed during the First World War. That on the south-west face records the names of members of the Gloucestershire Regiment. The plinth rests on a three-tier octagonal stone base. There is a signature on the base of the statue on the north-west face. The figure was cast by Oakes and Humphries, founders.
[Public Monument and Sculpture Association reference number BR121].

KNOWN_AS: Holy Soul's Roman Catholic cemetery, Arno's Vale Cemetery
MONUMENT_DESC: Holy Souls' Roman Catholic Cemetery, Arno's Vale. The cemetery is located on the north side of Arno's Vale Cemetery, against Bath Road. In the north-west corner of the cemetery is a small chapel.

KNOWN_AS: Church of England mortuary chapel, Arno's Vale Cemetery
MONUMENT_DESC:
Church of England mortuary chapel, Arno's Vale Cemetery. The chapel dates to c.1840 and was designed by Charles Underwood. The building has a Pennant sandstone plinth, with limestone ashlar and dressings, and a slate roof. It is cruciform in plan and is built in a neoclassical style.
The chapel has a Grade listing II* (Listed Building No. 901-1/47/430).

St. Andrew's Road Station. A 26 chain length of branch line was constructed between Avonmouth Dock Joint Station and St. Andrew's Junction and opened on 9 May 1910. During the First World War it was used to service the munitions factory built a little way to the east of St. Andrew's Junction (SMR 21389). A Ministry of Munitions regulation required that workers at the factory should be carried to a point adjacent to it and the branch line was therefore converted to passenger use, and the St. Andrew's Road station was constructed. It opened on 1 May 1917 (Vincent 1979, 79-80). The station comprised northbound and southbound platforms with a single-storey timber shelter on the eastern, southbound, platform. The two platforms were connected by a footbridge.

Avonmouth Docks Station. The station was opened on 2 February 1877 to serve the new Avonmouth Dock. In 1885 the station was substantially expanded and was operated by the Great Western Railway and the Midland Light Railway. There was major rebuilding of the station in 1926 (Oakley 1986).

Cumberland Buildings, Cumberland Basin. A development of 20 three-storey houses on the south side of the entrance lock to Cumberland Basin. The housing had been constructed by c1822 and are shown in a watercolour drawing of Granby Hill by Lt. Col. William Booth of that date. The houses are recorded in more detail by a watercolour drawing by Samuel Jackson (BRSMG M970). The development comprised two adjoining terraces, one aligned parallel with the lock and the other running south-south-west from the east corner of the first, the angle of the two arms enclosing what appears to have been a cultivated space. The majority of the houses each had a small garden to the rear.
By the time of the first edition Ordnance Survey 1:500 plan surveyed in 1882 all of the houses had been demolished with the sole exception of that at the north-east corner of the development.
The site now lies largely beneath the elevated section of Brunel Lock Road.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Former Bristol Spastics Centre, Wellington Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Church of St. Matthias-on-the-Weir, located on the north side of Rope Walk, Broadweir. The church was constructed in 1851 to a design by John Norton and had accommodation for 830 worshippers (Ralph & Cobb 1991, 30).
The church was in a Gothic style and consisted of a nave with a gabled roof and aisles beneath pentice roofs. The nave was 80 feet 9 inches (24.71 metres) long from east to west and 49 feet (15 metres) wide internally. The octagonal font was sited toward the western end of the south aisle (at ST 59486 73381), just off the . There was a square tower at the west end of the church with angle buttresses. This was not completed, but finished with a pyramidal roof. The design intended that tower would contain moveable benches for children's seating.
In 1888 a new organ was built for the church by the Bristol-based organ builders W. G. Vowles. This was moved to the church of St. Jude the Apostle (BUAD 916M) in Lamb Street, presumably in the 1940s (it is now in St. George's Anglican Church on Orleana Square in Gawler, a town north of the Australian city of Adelaide).
The church was closed in June 1940 and was demolished in 1949.

No.1 Peter Street, located on the north side of Peter Street. The building was a jettied house of seventeenth-century date. It was of three storeys plus attic with a gabled roof. 2-window range. First and second floors jettied. Second-floor and attic slate-hung. 2 windows to second-floor, 1 sash to attic. Lateral stacks.
The plot was owned by the Corporation and in 1532 it was occupied by Henry Cooper. The occupiers of the property through the sixteenth and into the mid-seventeenth-century can be traced from property records (Leech 1997, 110). A new lease was granted to Francis Atwood in 1653 (BRO 04041 fo.19) who was presumably responsible for rebuilding (or possibly simply refronting) the house. By 1738 it had been leased to Jeremiah Ames, a grocer. The building survived into the early twentieth century and appears to have demolished as part of the clearance of the area after the Second World War.

St. Paul's Brewery located on Victoria Street [later Little Bishop Street]. The brewery was operated by Bristol United Breweries. The brewery comprised a mixture of buildings of two, three and four storeys, the southernmost being the most recent.
At the northern end of the site was a 2-storey building, the ground-floor occupied by a haulingway entrance, a first-floor window, then a cornice and a parapet with central pediment. Then a 4-storey building, probably stone ground-floor with rendering above. Banded rustication to the ground-floor, with 2 openings. 2 windows each at first and second floors, then heavy string, above which a third-floor, possibly in brick, with 4 openings, probably vents, before a cornice and parapet. The a longer and lower building, stone and render again, with rusticated ground-floor without openings. To first and second floors each 3 widely-spaced windows with segmental heads, then a cornice, above which a parapet with 3 small gables and some balustrading. At the left end, a 4-storey structure, brick above a stone ground-floor, with pilasters either end of the 2 middle storeys. Lowest storey with 2 arched loading bays, either side of a segmental-headed entrance, the wall and arches rusticated. No first-floor openings; 2 blind segmental-arched windows to second-floor. A cornice, above which 2 segmental-headed windows, set closer together than the blind examples below, then a lighter cornice and parapet
The brewery was later converted to an invert sugar factory operated by the Brewers Invert Company. This use continued into the 1950s but the brewery buildings were subsequently demolished.

The church of St. Jude the Apostle, located between Braggs Lane (to the south) and Lamb Street in Old Market. The church occupies the site of Poyntzpool. It was constructed in 1849 to fill a perceived need to expand the ministry to the growing working-class population of St. Philip's Marsh, and much of the funding was provided by the Special Fund created by Bishop Monk (Ralph & Cobb, 1991 28). The church was designed by S. B. Gabriel and is of squared Pennant Sandstone rubble with limestone dressings and a tiled roof. Chancel and south-east chapel, aisled nave and south-west tower. Decorated Gothic Revival style. 2-bay chancel with a late nineteenth century south vestry and an early twentieth century south-east chapel. 4-bay north aisle. Similar south aisle. 3-stage tower with diagonal buttresses and a square-sided south-east stair tower to the second stage.
The organ from St. Matthias-on-the-Weir in Broadweir (BUAD 912M), built by the Bristol-based organ builders W. G. Vowles, was moved to the church, presumably in the 1940s after St. Matthias closed. It was refurbished by the firm of Rushworth & Dreaper in 1970, but was subsequently removed and installed in St. George's Anglican Church on Orleana Square in Gawler, a town north of the Australian city of Adelaide.
The church was unoccupied for around three years around the end of the twentieth century and the interior suffered substantial damage from vandalism in that period. The church was converted to flats in 2003.
The church has a Grade II listing (Listed Building Number 901-1/12/1626).

Nos.4-7 College Green. A terrace of 4 houses, now offices. Left-hand house c.1759, right-hand threesome c.1760, possibly by George Tully; converted 1989. Brick with limestone dressings. Pantile hipped roof to left-hand two, slate mansard to No.6, and hipped at the end. Double-depth plan. Mid Georgian style. Each of 3 storeys, attic and basement. All with raised ground-floors, the left-hand three entered off College Green, the last off Trinity Street. No.4 is 3-window range with right-hand entrance; the next two are both 2-window ranges, arranged off-centre, probably originally with left-hand entrances; No.7 is a two-window range, with a symmetrical 3-window range to the return. Rusticated quoins and strings to the left-hand house, and lesenes to the right-hand three. Attached front area walls and spear-headed railings.
Investigation of the stripped walls in 1989 showed that No.4 had a front wall entirely of brick, with all windows remodelled in the 19th.century. The remainder, also the return to Trinity Street, had rubble walls at basement, ground, first and second floors, with brick for the third-floor. At No.5 the ground-floor had been rebuilt, the windows at first and second floor levels remodelled in the 19th.century. The front ground-floor of No.6 had been altered. Many of the walls, including some containing brick, were bonded in pinky mortars. It is possible that Nos.5, 6 & 7 incorporated the remains of the 'The Masonry', a building known to have previously been on the site.
Nos. 4 & 5 were formerly annexed to the Royal Hotel. All were gutted in 1989, leaving only the external and main party walls standing. The property adjacent to Trinity Street is now known as No.1 of that thoroughfare.

Bristol Grammar School. Incorporating some of the buildings of St. Bartholomew's Hospital, reputedly founded 1240 by Sir John le Warre. Bristol Grammar School here 1532-1767, Queen Elizabeth Hospital School 1767-1847. 
By the 1820s the school comprised 4 main buildings. Entering through the archway beneath No.18, Christmas Street, there was a passage leading to the playground in a courtyard at the rear, against Johnny Ball Lane. On the left of the passage, immediately behind No.17 Christmas Street, was a 3-storey range of possible C17 date, with a number of mullion and transom windows in the south-west side, overlooking a narrow yard cut into the hillside; there were 4 trefoil-headed windows, possibly re-used medieval ones. Continuing the line of this range, and reaching towards the north-west corner of the site, was one of the hospital blocks, 2-storey, largely refenestrated, but including in its north-east elevation a first-floor window with Y-tracery. At right-angles to these ranges was a 3 storey 5-window late C17 range with a cornice and parapet, a central elliptical-arched doorway, cross windows with label moulds, the right-hand range separated by a pilaster strip, with a right-hand open elliptical arch, 2-centred arched first-floor window with Y tracery, and second-floor quatrefoil window. There was a 1-window right-hand return between the 2 ranges previously described, the ground-floor with an arched doorway and 2 small windows. At the north-east end of this range was a further building, running northwards to the corner of Johnny Ball Lane, built in the 1810s, a 3-storeys and 4-window range, an open arcade of four-centred arches facing the playground, cross-windows above. 
The range on the south-east side of the playground largely survives; that to its north was demolished in c.1981. The south-west elevation of the range behind No.17 Christmas Street has also been preserved in the modern office development. The medieval range was rebuilt in the C19, and parts also survive.

KNOWN_AS: Romano-British farm at Lawrence Weston Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
A Romano-British farm in the playing fields of St. Bede's School, Lawrence Weston, which was partially archaeologically excavated in 1982 [SMR 20234]. On the basis of the excavated material, the farm was probably in existence by the end of the 1st century AD and survived until the 4th century AD. A flue, an earth-bonded stone wall and ditches were recorded. Sampling produced evidence for arable cultivation and grassland.
Parts of the site are known to be preserved beneath landscaping in the playing fields (Parker 1984).

Robert Adams's house on Castle Mill Street. Immediately downhill of Newgate Prison. 2 storeys and an attic to Castle Mill Street, but possibly more storeys cut into the hill below. Gabled front; jettied; 2-window range. Left-hand entrance; central entrance to shop, window right. On the left, a 6-panel door in a frame with a depressed four-centred arch, the spandrels with the initials 'R A'. Bracket at far left-hand. At first-floor a wide central oriel with 2 sash  windows, small left-hand (3-light?) window. 6-pane attic window. Carved bargeboards, carrying the date 1547 (or 1543) and the initials 'R A'; pendant at apex; eaves supported on brackets. Pantile roof. Lateral stacks. There was a C17 style full-height chimney-piece in one of the ground-floor rooms, the upper part decorated with the city arms between two panels each with rosettes or compositae at their centre. Rowbotham's 1825 drawing shows some openings in the west party wall with the gaol, but it is not clear to which building they belong, as there was clearly formerly another structure, probably a house, between there and the Prison. O'Neill shows a pair of C16 or C17 chimney-pieces on the outside of the second-floor wall.

KNOWN_AS: Price's Pottery, Nos.39-46 St. Thomas Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
Price's Pottery, No.39-46 St. Thomas Street, located on the east side of St. Thomas Street. The factory was in existence by the early 1820s. At that date the factory building was a three-storey structure, apparently constructed of brick.
The elevation of the building was recorded in a drawing by T. L. Rowbotham in 1826 (BRSMG M2092) and at that date the main, east-facing, elevation on St. Thomas Street had a three-window range. At ground floor level there was a large entrance with double doors on its south side and a pair of sashes to the north. At first-floor level there was a similar arrangement with a further large opening with double doors on the south side and two windows (possibly two-light casements) to the north. The second floor had three windows (possibly two-light casements). There was a sign on front of the building reading "CHARLES PRICE & SONS / STONE WARE & PATENT WATER PIPE / MANUFACTORY."
By 1887 there were six kilns, two against the northern boundary of the site, three just to the south of its centre and the last against the southern boundary. The factory continued to operate into the early twentieth century and part of the interior was photographed in 1925 (Winstone 1971, pl.164).

POSTAL_ADDRESS: St. Michael's Hospital, St. Michael's Hill
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Michael's Hill House, located on the north-eastern side of St. Michael's Hill. A house stood on the site by the early 1670s. The site had been acquired by Richard Going, a Bristol pewterer, by 1729 and he had presumably demolished the earlier house by that date since the site was described as void in the ratebooks for that year. St. Michael's Hill House was constructed for Going and was "in building" in 1732 (Leech 2001, 17). Dening suggests that it may have been designed by John Strahan (Dening 1923, 113).
The building was a three-storey house of brick with a hipped roof with a square lantern. Internally the main stair was located to one side of the entrance hall and was 3 feet 6 inches [1.07 metres] wide and, according to Dening, had "carved spandrel brackets with Doric columns as balusters, every third column being twisted" (Dening 1923, 114). It did not continue above the first floor. There was a large walled garden to the rear of the house.
The house was occupied by Charles Biggs in 1739 and 1740 but was once more in the hands of Going by 1749. In 1765-1766 the site was leased by Valentine Watkins but was occupied by William Nicholls by 1770 and Thomas Whitehead by 1773. Between 1883 and the beginning of the nineteenth century the house became a military training establishment where the 6th Battalion of the Gloucestershire Regiment was based. The garden became a drill ground.
The house was severely damaged by bombing in 1940-41 (Warne 1943, 21). It was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped for the St. Michael's Maternity Hospital.

KNOWN_AS: Clay pit to the north of Two Mile Hill Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
A clay pit associated with a brickworks (SMR 2269) some 120 metres to the north of Two Mile Hill Road, St. George. The works was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucester Sheet LXXII.15) published in 1882 and comprised a single "L-shaped" building some 20 metres long and orientated north-south at the centre of the site with a large clay pit immediately to the south-west. By the time the second edition plan was published in 1903 the brickworks had fallen into disuse, although the buildings were extant.
The site of the clay pit is now beneath Nos.82-84 Victoria Park and the gardens to the rear of the terrace.
Built to accommodate GWR trains from Bristol via Henbury. Opened 9/5/1910. Closed 28/04/1919. The position but no remains of the wooden station is still visible (1994).
Station opened 6/3/1865. Closed to goods 29/11/1965. Unstaffed since 1967.
Opened on 6.3.1865.

Fire Engine Farm. The farm is recorded by a survey of the parish of St. George of 1803, suggesting that it dates to at least the late-eighteenth century. The farm itself occupied a rectangular site some 20 metres to the north of Church Road. The farm was demolished to make way for the entrance to St. George's Park in 1894.
The churchyard of St. Paul's Church, Coronation Road.

The E. S. and A. Robinson building, located at the corner of Victoria Street and Redcliff Street. The was constructed in 1876 to a design by W. B. Gingell (Gomme et al. 1979, 336-337). It was of five storeys plus attic on the Victoria Street elevation and had a semi-basement. The ground floor was in a Byzantine style which was echoed in the upper floors and there was a distinctive domed tower with a lantern above the junction of Redcliff Street and Victoria Street.
The western half of the building was damaged by bombing during the Second World War (1939-1945) (Warne 1943, 13) and it was demolished to make way for the office block which currently occupies the site, No.1 Redcliff Street, in the 1960s. The decorative frieze from around the tower has been preserved, and is in the City Museum's collections.

The Holmes, located on the eastern side of Stoke Park Road. The site lay within the Manor of Stoke Bishop and the estate remained in the hands of the descendants of the Cann family until 1800. In 1869 the estate was sold at auction in lots. The parcel on which The Holmes was built was Lot 12. The bulk of the estate was purchased by the Birmingham Financial Company and resold as smaller lots. The Holmes was bought by Herbert Meade-King in 1870 and sold to William Edwards George in July 1876. It is not clear whether Meade-King or George built The Holmes but the house was complete by 1879 and was leased out. The building is a two-storey structure constructed of rubble stone (apparently an Old Red sandstone) with ashlar detailing.
From 1884 the lessee was W. Mills Baker, the father of the plant collector Hiatt C. Baker. Hiatt Baker is likely to have been responsible for the design of the formal garden created around the house which comprised a series of sinuous walks, a rockery and an area known as The Dell (Hicks 2004, 13). The Baker family let the property to Alfred Capper Pass, owner of a smelting works in Bedminster and later Professor emeritus of Chemistry at the University of Bristol, but retained ownership of the building until 1943 when it was acquired by the University of Bristol. The University extended the building by constructing east and west wings.
In 1944 The Holmes was requisitioned as the headquarters of General Omar N. Bradley, commander of the United States First Army, and his subordinate commanders (Generals Jacob Devers (1887-1979) of the 6th Army Group, Courtney Hodges (1887-1966) of the U.S. First Army, and George S. Patton Jr. (1885-1945) of U.S. Third Army). It served as the base for the planning of Operation OVERLORD, the invasion of Normandy, in June of that year. A note from Dwight D. Eisenhower (1890-1969), Supreme Allied Commander of the Allied Expeditionary Force (SHAEF) from 1944, and other memorabilia in the hall of the building commemorate the US Army's use of the building.
For many years the building was in use as a hall of residence.

KNOWN_AS: Wreck north of Stup Pill, possibly the "William"
MONUMENT_DESC:
A wreck identified at Stup Pill. The wreck is believed, on the basis of local tradition to be the "William" (wrecked in 1939).
In 1995 the ship was buried by between 0.5 and 0.8 metres of sediment. Most of the keel of the ship and some floor timbers and planking were found to be extant, although the stern had been removed, possibly by storm action. The rudder lay some 10-15 metres to the north of the main body of the wreck. Within and around the hull were artefacts and displaced structural elements.
"The wreck lies in very fine particulate sediment which is highly mobile and of marine origin, it is possible that the keel sits on a gravel layer beneath this. The site is exposed at every low tide" (Buglass 1996).

Ashley Manor House. The manor house was of seventeenth-century date, and was constructed of rendered random stone rubble with ranges of two storeys with an attic and three storeys with an attic and cross-gable roofs. The building was cellared.
During the medieval period the site was part of St. James's Priory lands and was bought by Robert Hooke, a brewer, in the 1650s (R. H. Leech The garden house: merchant culture and identity in the early modern city. In Lawrence 2003, 82). The house was constructed soon afterwards and a sundial originally sited over the main entrance door carried the date 1656 (Pritchard 1908, 304-308). The fenestration consisted of casements with leaded lights and stone drip moulds above, while the window frames were of oak. Internally, the entrance door opened on to a hall with two rooms on the west side and a winder stair with splat balusters on the east. Within the building there were a number of carved stone chimneypieces including one with bearing the arms of the Brewers' Company and the date 1669 (ibid.).
The building passed into the hands of Andrew Hook in 1733 and accommodated the Blue Maids orphanage from 1795 until 1829 (Pritchard 1908, 304-308).
The building was demolished in 1911 but was surveyed shortly before demolition by John Pritchard (Pritchard 1908, 34-308). A door and three chimney pieces probably from the building are in the collections of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery.

Savoy Cinema, located on the western side of Station Road, Shirehampton. The cinema was designed by the practice of William H. Watkins who was a Bristol architect responsible for many cinemas in Bristol and the south-west. It was commissioned by E. Harris of the Shirehampton Cinema Company Ltd. at a cost of £300 (Ewins 1984, 28). The cinema was built by Frank Wilkins and was opened in 1933 (Ewins 1984, 28). It gained the nickname 'The Cabbage' early in its history (Anderson 1983, 55). The building is a two-storey structure of brick in a Modernist style, with a central entrance at ground floor which is protected by an overhanging canopy. Above the canopy are three large centrally-placed windows. The cinema had seating for 1000, with 300 seats in the balcony. The building was still in use as a cinema after the Second World War but was converted to a Bingo Hall in 1961.

Newgate Gaol or Prison, located at the corner of Castle Mill Street and Narrow Wine Street, with frontages to both. Presumably partly built into the former gate. Attached to the west.
Hugh O'Neill's 1820 drawing (BRSMG Mb13) of the Castle Mill Street elevation shows an austere 3-storey building with at least 2 bays. Diagonal buttress left, to full height; central buttress, again full height; right-hand bay at an angle with a right-hand end buttress with battered base. In the left bay, a right-hand entrance with two-centred head arch, otherwise no openings. At ground-floor of the right bay, only a slit where donations for the prisoners (who were debtors) could be deposited. At first-floor, right, a cross-window, to its left a trefoil-headed window under a gable top, the window jambs comprising clasped shafts. Sash window to the second-floor. Also illustrated by him in 1821 (BRSMG M2711), from the south-east.
The elevation drawn also by O'Neill in 1820 (BRSMG M2708) depicts the Narrow Wine Street facade. On the corner, an L-shaped three-storey building, with an entrance in the eastern side of the south wing, a porch above, and a small first-floor window. On the south end of the same wing, a single ground-floor window; at first-floor, one window either side of a plaque above which a scrolled pediment; 2-light second-floor window. Hipped roof behind a parapet. Next to the west, a three-storey facade, in C18 military style, consisting of three elements, all with a common parapet, with hipped roof behind. A pilaster, then a bay with one window segmental-arched each to first and second floors. Next a bay standing slightly forward of its neighbours, a 1-window range with a semicircular-arched doorway with projecting keystone and capitals; above, a plat band running to the far western end of the facade; a segmental-arched window to the first and second floors. The left-hand element a 3-window range with plinth, one right-hand ground-floor segmental-arched window; to first and second floors, each with 3 segmental-arched openings, only the right-hand open as windows. Pilaster at left-hand end; lamp-iron above plat band near same end. Brick chimney stacks. 
Braikenridge notes (19) that in January 1821 contractors began to take down the prison.
