O'Neill made several drawings during the demolition,  showing exteriors and interiors, including the governor's house, the chapel (1047A), etc. He mentions the 'Tennis Court', also "the Bath" (1046A). There were a number of semicircular or segmental-arched openings containing cross-windows or narrow windows with one light top and bottom. All windows were heavily barred. In the yard in front of the governor's house were two pumps, originally separated by a tall wall, and probably using the one well. Off one yard was a 'room for Refractory debtors'. The chapel was galleried on 3 sides; during demolition an unsuspected cell was discovered behind the pulpit and reading desk. 
On the end of the prison facing east, O'Neill's view from the north (BRSMG M2718) shows what appear to be further remains of the medieval gatehouse, with a round tower against the road, and the base of a similar structure at the rear.
The National Monuments Record holds a file on the Newgate Prison (NMR File No. 90991).

KNOWN_AS: Large magazine south of Washingpool Farm
MONUMENT_DESC:
Large magazine located approximately 120 metres to the south of Washingpool Farm. The magazine was built in 1918 to serve National Filling Factory No.23 and is recorded by a plan in the National Archives (MUN 4/1753) dated 27 November 1918. The building measured approximately 38 metres from east to west and was 10 metres wide.
The shell of the building was extant in 1946 but the roof had been removed by that date. The remainder of the structure was subsequently demolished.

No.26 Small Street, located on the east side of Small Street. The building appears to have had a medieval origin, with a house recorded on the site from 1350. It was rebuilt in the fifteenth century as a timber-framed two-bay structure with a hall. In 1499 the building was granted to Matilda Baker, widow, by Thomas Hardyng. It subsequently became part of the endowment of Forthey's chantry and was recorded as belonging to St. Philip's parish in 1540. From 1607 until 1623 Elizabeth Warden resided in the house and in 1649 it was purchased by Alderman Jackson and remained in the possession of the family for some years. Significant alterations to the building, apparently in the second quarter of the seventeenth century, including refronting and the insertion of a floor into the hall to create a new room. The decorative scheme for this upper room included a moulded plaster ceiling and a carved stone chimney piece. The ground floor room also had a stone chimney piece, moulded plaster ceiling and panelled walls. Externally the building was a three-storey jettied house with a gabled pantile roof. The first and second floors were jettied.
The building was demolished in the autumn of 1921. W. F. Read visited the building before demolition (BUAD 3040) but found that "it had been repaired so many times externally that probably no part of the original structure remained" (Pritchard 1922, 94). The chimney pieces were extant at the time of demolition, though that in the ground floor room was damaged, as were the plaster ceilings (Pritchard 1922, 94-97).

St. John's Churchyard, located at the Tailor's Court. The plot, with a frontage on Tower Lane, was a garden known as Hasardysgarden which belonged to John Hasard, who lived in Broad Street in the mid-fourteenth century. The house in Broad Street was acquired by Edmund and Isabella Arthur in the later 1380s (Veale 1933, 204) and in 1390 Arthur granted the garden to John Knyghton and William Castell (BRO P/StJB/D/2/75) to be used as the churchyard for St. John the Baptist (BUAD 145M). Parishioners of St. John's had previously been buried in St. James Churchyard.
The grant included a right of access for the church to reach the churchyard through the gate of the tenement and the entrance to the churchyard remains in Tailor's Court. The use of the plot as a churchyard was confirmed by the Bishop of Worcester on 2nd July 1409 and it was consecrated on 12th June. The right of access appears to have been disputed by the Fraternity of St. John (the Merchant Tailors' Guild) which acquired Hasard's Broad Street tenement. On Sunday 22nd March 1489 members of the Fraternity armed themselves with daggers, swords and clubs to obstruct a procession on the path from Broad Street through Hasard's tenement to St. John's Cemetery, and closed the gates there in the face of the rector, William Thomas and others. The dispute was not resolved until 1499 when arbitrators brought the two sides to agreement. The Fraternity was to allow the parson of St. John to pass without interruption and allow the dead to be brought through the tenement. The parish received an annual rent of 13s. 4d. for Hasard's tenement, and the Fraternity was to retain 12d. of this each year towards the repair of the timber, lock and ironwork of two gates between Broad Street and the cemetery. A set of keys for these gates was to be kept by each party.
The churchyard measures 28.5 metres from south-west to north-east and is 18 metres wide, and its area has remained essentially the same, with only small changes, since the end of the fourteenth century. Archaeological excavation in 1979 (BUAD 320) recorded a strip containing graves adjacent to the existing south-east boundary of the cemetery, indicating that there was an encroachment on the cemetery during the early post-medieval period. The north-west corner of the churchyard was also removed in the third quarter of the eighteenth century to allow the creation of John Street. The burials do not appear to have been cleared from this area, and in the 1960s a grave was discovered there (BUAD 567). The Pennant sandstone rubble boundary walls and the limestone ashlar gate piers are of eighteenth-century date. Within the churchyard there are a number of post-medieval monuments and gravestones, notably the tomb of Hugh Brown (BUAD 378M) which is of seventeenth-century date and is sited against the south-east boundary wall of the churchyard.
The burial ground was reported to be full in 1850 with an average of thirteen interments each year (Clark 1850, 158). The churchyard was closed to burials by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852.
The walls, piers, gates and railings of the churchyard are listed Grade II (Listed Building number 901-1/11/680).

KNOWN_AS: St. James Parish Hall, Charles Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. James Church Hall, located on the northern side of Charles Street. The hall was constructed on the sites of Nos.9 and 10 Charles Street (BUAD 1655M and BUAD 1656M) and was designed by the local architect William Venn Gough (the plans in the BRO Building Plans Book 36 are dated 11 May 1899). The building was a two-storey brick building with a pitched roof supported on corbels. The Charles Street façade was apparently of freestone ashlar. There was a central entrance consisting of a pair of semi-circular arches with rusticated voussoirs and a smaller semi-circular arched window on the north-east side, all of which broke through a projecting moulded cornice. At first-floor level there were four smaller semi-circular arched window openings with rusticated keystones of which the central two were blind. Above a string course were seven smaller lancet windows, also with semi-circular arched heads, occupying the two central bays. The gable above was stepped with pyramidal finials (Winstone 1972, pl.53). The side elevations had six bays, each with a large semi-circular arched tracery window, and a clerestorey above with three lancet windows in each bay. Against the north-western wall of the building there was a further two-thirds height rear bay with a lean-to roof. The entrance steps projected from the south-western side of the building, off the alley leading to Seville Court.
Internally the ground floor plan comprised a hall occupying most of the centre of the building, an entrance lobby, kitchen and gallery above at the south-eastern, Charles Street, end. At the north-western end were the ladies and gentlemen's retiring rooms. The basement was reached by steps on the western side of the building and included a classroom and a smaller room on the eastern side accommodating the heating equipment.
The parish hall remained in use until the Second World War but was damaged by bombing. It remained a shell into the early 1950s but by 1954 the building appears to have been re-roofed and was in use as a warehouse for electrical goods. The original elevation of the building was removed after 1957 to create a larger entrance off Charles Street. Street directories record that the parish hall building was occupied by Midland Electrical Engineering between 1960 and 1969.

KNOWN_AS: Arno's Castle, or the Black Castle
MONUMENT_DESC:
Arno's Castle or the Black Castle, dated 1764. The structure was built as the stables, coach house, brew-house and laundry for Arno's Court (SMR 8467) for William Reeve (a local brassmaker) and was probably designed by James Bridges. Traditionally the building is said to include features salvaged from the medieval St. Werburgh's Church which was rebuilt by James Bridges between 1758 and 1761 (Ison, 1952 187-189). The building has a courtyard, entered through an archway beneath a tower. The buildings ranged around this courtyard have pointed tracery windows and doorways. Opposite the entrance is a larger tower with diagonal abutment. The outer angles are formed by tall circular turrets. A feature is the use of "copper slag" blocks from Reeve's works to construct the walling. The entrance front is symmetrical, 2-bay wings flanked by turrets flank with a central tower over the entrance. Originally the surviving entrance arch stood in front of this building but was moved in 1912 to stand in front of the bath-house (SMR 6327).
The building has a Grade I listing (Listed Building 901-1/56/466).
Gibbet stood at N end of Gallows Acre Lane, now Pembroke Rd..." {1}

West Almshouse, Westbury-on-Trym was established by John Carpenter, bishop of Worcester (1443-1476) and provided accommodation for six women. The Great Red Book of Bristol indicates that the building was adjacent to Holy Trinity Church (SMR 5739).
After the dissolution of Westbury College the maintenance of the almshouse passed to the parish and it remained in use until 1800 when new almshouse was built at Waters Lane. The almshouse was demolished in 1852-1853.
Lock-up named "the Cooler"

Redland Manor house, located at the west corner of Manor Park and Redland Road. The manor house is known to have had internal features dating to the seventeenth century. These included a full-height chimney-piece dated "1658" which carried the initials of Francis Gleed and a ceiling with ornate strapwork. The house was demolished in 1890.
Poor House, Eastfield Road, Westbury-on-Trym.

Barton Regis Workhouse, Southmead. In 877 two fields of the Southmead estate, Marland Grove and Little Marland Grove, were sold to the Guardians of the Poor of the Barton Regis Union in 1898. A new workhouse was constructed on the site in 1902 to a design by A. P. I. Cotterell and W. H. Thorpe (Morrison 1999, 204).
The entrance to the site was off Southmead Road and adjacent to the road were two groups of buildings, offices on the north-east side of the entrance and the casual and receiving wards on the south-west side. This included the disinfecting house and a stone yard to the south side. A drive led between these buildings, along an avenue of pollarded elms with cultivation beds on its northern and southern sides, to the Master's House. This was the central of three ranges of buildings with the men's block to its north-east and the women's block to the south-west. The kitchen and laundry were to the rear of these ranges and to the north was the married couple's quarters. The earliest buildings were typically constructed of squared Pennant sandstone blocks with limestone ashlar detailing.
No longer extant {1}
No longer extant {1}
2 kilns survive

Two limekilns at Eastfield Quarry. The kilns are recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.08) published in 1881 and lay at the northern end of the quarry close to Southmead Road. The kilns have been partially buried but were noted to be extant in 2002 (Smith pers. comm.).
1 limekiln, no longer extant.
Limekiln, probably still extant {1}

KNOWN_AS: North gazebo at Clifton Hill House
MONUMENT_DESC: Gazebo located at the north-east corner of the formal garden of Clifton Hill House. The building is a single-storey rubble stone structure of Brandon Hill Grit with a pitched roof.

The Dominican Friary, or Blackfriars. The friary was founded in 1227/8 by Maurice de Gaunt (R. Graham The religious houses. In Page 1907). Its layout has not yet been confirmed but the friary church (BUAD 1359M) appears to have been located on the north side of the site close to Rosemary Lane. On its south side was the cloister, with the church lying along its northern edge, the frater to its west, and the chapter house, sacristy, etc., on the eastern side. Cutler's Hall, is likely to have been the dorter and to the south of this was the lesser cloister. The building now known as Bakers Hall may have been the infirmary.
The house was surrendered on 10th September 1538. The site was purchased by the former mayor William Chester in June 1540 for £37 10s and was apparently used as a private dwelling with many of the buildings of the friary apparently being put to new use with the minimum of new building. The church would appear to have been incorporated into other buildings, although some of the stone was used to rebuild an altar and Easter sepulchre in St. Werburgh's church in 1552-53 (Skeeters 1993, 82). In 1933 tracery windows dating to the fourteenth century was discovered within one of the walls of a garage (BUAD 2378). The larger of these was damaged but survived to its full height, suggesting that demolition of the friary church after the dissolution was partial and at least some of its fabric was incorporated into other buildings. The site was acquired by the wealthy grocer Dennis Hollister in the mid seventeenth century for his residence and when he joined the fledgling Quaker movement in the city in 1654 open air meetings were held there. The Society of Friends meeting house (BUAD 241M) was later added to the rear of the linking block, New Hall.
Two of the conventual buildings, later known as the Bakers Hall (BUAD 239M) and Cutlers Hall (BUAD 240M), are extant along with part of a linking block. The surviving buildings are of Pennant sandstone rubble with limestone dressings, and pantile roof. The present New Hall is an 1869 rebuilding of a thirteenth-century hall, and was restored in 1970. Bakers Hall and Cutlers Hall are Scheduled Ancient Monuments (AV 102) and also have Grade II* listings (Baker's Hall is Listed Building number 901-1/40/489 and Cutler's Hall  is Listed Building number 901-1/40/490). New Hall has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/40/493).

The Tabernacle, also known as Penn Street Tabernacle or Whitefield Tabernacle, located on the east side of Penn Street. The chapel was built in 1753 for a Methodist society. The building measured 24 metres from east to west and was 15.5 metres wide and was a two-storey structure of rendered stone rubble.
The main, west-facing, elevation was of three bays. The primary entrance was in the central bay, and was formed by a large arch with a double doorway set within it. Above this was a large, two-light window while close to the head of the gable there was a circular window with an elaborate sill. The fenestration in the two adjacent bays was formed by small segmental arched windows and there were similar lights in the south wall of the building. A circular chimney stack projected from the south side of the roof. The roof itself had a gable at the west end and the rear and was hipped towards the lantern. The side aisles had separate roofs.
The interior of the building seems to have formed a assembly single space five bays long, which was divided by stone Tuscan columns into nave and aisles. The nave ceiling was coved with a central octagonal lantern and there were galleries around the north, west and south sides. The pulpit was sited against the east wall of the building and had a square base, pedimented back panel and was accessed via two staircases, one on its north and one on its south side (Stell 1986, 63). The organ in the Tabernacle was built by John Smith senior of the Bristol organ builders John Smith and Sons, in 1815 to 1828 (Whaley 1977).
The crypt of the Tabernacle was a single space apparently extending beneath the entire footprint of the building, with a vaulted roof supported on parallel rows of square columns. A number of brick burial vaults were sited within it the floor and there was also a vault for W. D. Wills (Winstone 1987, pl.54).
The chapel later became a Congregational chapel. The interior was partly refitted in the nineteenth century.
Immediately to the south of the chapel was the 1834 Sunday school (BUAD 90M), with Whitefield's house (later used as a vestry) behind it.
The building was demolished to the level of the base of the crypt in the second half of 1958 to make way for the development of Broadmead shopping centre. The Smith organ is reported to have been installed in the United Reform Church , Gloucester Road, Horfield in 1960. In 2006 the site of the Tabernacle was archaeologically excavated by Jon Webster for Cotswold Archaeology, recovering an assemblage of human remains from interments in brick vaults within the crypt.

KNOWN_AS: Small magazine south of Washingpool Farm
MONUMENT_DESC:
Small magazine located approximately 170 metres south-west of Washingpool Farm. The magazine was built in 1918 to serve National Filling Factory No.23 and is recorded by a plan in the National Archives (MUN 4/1753) dated 27 November 1918. The building measured approximately 13 metres from east to west and was 7 metres wide.
The shell of the building was extant in 1946 but the roof had been removed by that date. The remainder of the structure was subsequently demolished.

The well known as St. Peter's Pump (or St. Edith's Well), which was located at the end of Peter Street in the centre of the street. The dedication to St. Edith points to a Saxon date (Boucher 1939, 95) though the earliest reference to the well is apparently in 1391. A cross was added to the top of the well's superstructure in the mid fifteenth-century and this was renovated in the summer of 1633 according to Adams's Chronicle. It was painted for the visit of Charles II  in September 1663.
The Trustees of Bristol Bridge resolved that the structure should be removed on 7 July 1766, and they were then approached by Henry Hoare who removed the stones of the superstructure to his estate in Stourhead at his own expense.
A new shaft was excavated and a new superstructure erected. This was taken out of use at the order of the Health Authority in 1887.
Boucher gives the following description of the pump at Stourhead:
"It is hexagonal in form and consists of two storeys, surmounted by a shaft raised above a six-sided pedestal. The shaft, which is broken at the top, is said to have terminated in an actual cross, but this seems to be open to question.
The lower part of the structure consists of six depressed four-centred arches, the apex of each being ornamented with a cherub's head. The capitals of the columns have a simple moulding on the outer sides and a large wedge-shaped stone on the inner. They have a set-off about a third of the way up from the bottom.
Separating the upper from the lower storey runs a simple moulded cornice. The upper storey is made up of six round-headed arches, each of which contains a statue ... but the figures are so badly weathered that it is almost impossible to identify them. However, there is little doubt that they represented kings and queens with Bristol or local connexions.
The jambs are panelled and moulded. Over each of them there is a large carved fleur-de-lys and at the intersection of each pair or [sic] arches is a little pedestal supporting the carved figure of an animal, either a lion or a bear bearing a shield, but they are badly weathered.
The large pedestal carrying the crowning shaft has six carved panels. Three of them are so worn that the details of the carving which was on them are no longer recognizable. Of the others that to the south bears the merchant-mark of Robert Aldworth ... and that to the northeast the outlines of a ship" (ibid. pp104-105).

The large house or mansion known as 'Creswicke's House' which stood on the west side of Small Street, immediately north of St. Werburgh's churchyard. The site is now believed to be beneath both the Crown Courts complex and No.2 Small Street adjacent. Evans (1824,310) reports that a fire on March 3rd.1818 unaccountably consumed this, the former mansion of the Codrington family, and that it had previously been occupied by Dean, Whitehead & Co., bankers. Having been established on the site in 1769, they removed to 8, Corn Street in 1799 (Cave, A History of Banking in Bristol, for which see further information). 
A chimney-piece from what Evans calls the "state-room" was removed to Broomwell House, Brislington upon demolition of the remains (Braikenridge notes, D.56; illustration by Woodroffe,1825, M.2481).

No.28 King Street. The house appears to have been constructed in the seventeenth century and was a jettied, gabled structure of three-storeys and attic with a one-window range. The entrance was on the western side of the main, north-facing, elevation and the door opening contained a seventeenth-century panelled door. The fenestration at ground-floor level consisted of a pair of sash windows with shutters, while there were bay windows at both first and second floor, each with a six-light front and two-light side casements. There was a six-light window in the gable at attic level and a pendant below the apex of gable. The building was recorded in a drawing by T. L. Rowbotham made in 1825 (BRSMG M2504). It was demolished in the late 1930s to enable the construction of the inner circuit road.

No.4 Ellbroad Street. The house, located on the southern side of Ellbroad Street, was the eastern of a pair of gabled houses (the other was No.2 Ellbroad Street (BUAD 152M) of late seventeenth century date with jettied fronts, and "lean-to shelters over the entrances" (i.e. a common pentice roof between the ground and first floors). The building had a single bay and was of three storeys plus attic and cellar. the ground-floor was occupied by shop windows, the front entrances being adjacent. The gable ends rested on brackets and the building may have been cross-gabled. The house was demolished in 1906, along with 'The Rising Sun' public house [BUAD 151M], in order to construct enlarged licensed premises (which, in turn, were removed in 1954).
The site of the building now lies under the highway on the west side of Lower Castle Street and is therefore likely to have been significantly disturbed by highway works and services.

The Great House, or Colston's Great House located on the west side of St. Augustine's Place (modern Colston Street). The building was constructed c.1568, possibly reusing elements of the Carmelite friary (BUAD 609M). The house was a large mansion with a courtyard enclosed by two wings running west-north-west away from St. Augustine's Place. The entire complex was of two storeys plus attic, with a street-level cellar on the eastern (St. Augustine's Place) side. The building presented an elevation of five gabled bays with alternate canted bays to St. Augustine's Place, and at least three gabled bays on the northern and southern sides. James Millerd's 1673 vignette show that the wings were one bay wide, with two gables on their inner sides, and the rear of the street range also possessed two gables. All of main windows were of eight lights.
The arrangment of the interior has not been researched although seventeenth-century inventories record a great hall, "little studdie" and outhouses, a coach house and stables as well as a water cistern to control supply to the main house (Hall 1949, 122-123).
The initial plan included a garden, apparently walled and raised above the level of the courtyard, on the north side of the house. Its northern boundary was Trenchard Street. Later Sir John Yonge began to acquire plots on the hillside on the opposite side of Trenchard Street to create a larger garden for the house (Roger Leech pers. comm.). The White Lodge and the Red Lodge marked the edges of this garden.
The house provided the accommodation for Queen Elizabeth during her visit to Bristol in 1574. The building became a sugar house in 1653. Water for its three pans was drawn from St. John's Conduit (apparently without permission and causing a reduction in supply elsewhere) and cottages were built in the grounds of the house to provide dwellings for the refinery workers. Inventories record not only the utensils required for sugar making but also the equipment, the vats and coolers, installed in the various rooms (Hall, 1949 141). Refining continued on the site until 1708 when a school was founded in the building by Edward Colston. By 1742 it not only occupied the main house, but also a smaller building adjacent on Host Street to the east, and others fronting Trenchard Street. The building was occupied by the school into the early nineteenth century but later became an assembly rooms and art gallery. It was demolished in 1863 in order to enable construction of the Colston Hall (BUAD 69M).

The Carmelite friary in St. Augustine's Place. The friary was founded in 1256 and was a walled precinct with a rectangular plot on the north side of St. Augustine's Place (now Colston Street), probably defined by Pipe Lane, Host Street and Steep Street. 
In the absence of archaeological excavation, the internal arrangement of the site remains uncertain but the church and burial ground seem to have been at the south-western end and may have been orientated parallel with Pipe Lane. Evidence for the form of the church itself is equally limited. William Worcestre, writing in 1480, gives two, slightly different, sets of measurements for the nave, 24 and nearly 29 metres long by 13.4 or 14.5 metres wide (Neale 2000, 50-51; 278-279). The choir was 24 metres long (Neale 2000, 50-51). By the early sixteenth century there was "a chapell and an yle off the Church" (Weare 1893, 74). The chapel may have been that dedicated to St. George, known to have stood in the church by 1412 (Wadley 1886, 89), although there was also a chapel dedicated to St. Mary by 1393 (Wadley 1886, 51). The tower of the church was just under 2.7 metres wide and, with the spire, Worcestre says, was 200 feet high (Neale 2000, 100-101). There were three large tracery windows at first-floor level on the Colston Street frontage (BRSMG M2531; BRSMG M2532).One architectural feature of the church to have survived the 1530s may be the screen bequeathed by Thomas White in 1542 to Bristol Cathedral. Warren identified the remnants of this as the heavily-restored late-medieval screen now set in the fourth bay of the south choir aisle (Warren 1904-08; Warren 1904).
The spatial organisation of the precinct is also uncertain. Worcestre recorded the cloister as 21.4 metres square (Neale 2000, 50-51) although its position within the precinct is unclear. The north-eastern end presumably consisted of ancillary buildings and orchard and gardens. The friary obtained its water supply from the St. John's conduit which ran along Pipe Lane and then Host Street. Worcestre also mentions a statue of St. Mary in a shrine in the precinct wall near the corner of Host Street and Steep Street (Neale 2000, 18-19). The friary appears to have had gardens extending westward towards Park Row.
The friary was surrendered on 28 July 1538 and the site was bought by the Corporation. The buildings were demolished and provided stone for rebuilding altars in several churches. A Great House (BUAD 420M) was subsequently built on the site by Sir John Young.
There have been numerous discoveries of human remains around Pipe Lane, the earliest in April 1788 (BUAD 3666; Gentleman's Magazine 1788, 455). In August and September 1904 John Pritchard recorded (BUAD 46) several sections of what he believed were medieval walls as well as a number of burials (Beddoe 1906; Pritchard 1906, 133-141). In November 1932 several more skeletons and a pavement of medieval floor tiles were found during excavation in Trenchard Street (BUAD 3308) and disarticulated human remains were discovered inside No.2 Trenchard Street in 1999 (BUAD 3464). In 1989 John Bryant recorded a window of late-medieval date about 1800 millimetres high internally in the front wall of No.2 Trenchard Street (BUAD 622).

KNOWN_AS: Rank of four shops on the west side of Exchange Avenue
MONUMENT_DESC:
A rank of four shops on the west side of the Exchange Avenue. The rank was probably designed in c.1848 by R. S. Pope as part of his reworking of St. Nicholas Market (Leech, 2001) and is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.25) and the Goad Fire Insurance plan of 1887.
The main, east-facing, elevation on Exchange Avenue was an ashlar façade of four bays with moulded segmental-headed arches, each framing a shop. At the shoulder of the arches was a deep impost-band and the arches had keystones. Above these was a plat band and parapet. Each of the shops had a frontage 2.6 metres wide on Exchange Avenue and was 3.7 metres long and had a first floor level which was hidden behind the parapet. At the south end of the elevation was a doorway leading to a small rear yard and now the entrance to the toilets. In the footway of Exchange Avenue, in front of the rank is an iron plate covering the entrance to a cellar beneath the structure. The condition of this cellar is unknown.
The northern two of the rank were demolished in the early twentieth century when the rear of the Old Post Office was rebuilt and extended to the south. The southern two shops are extant and were subject to archaeological survey by Dr. Roger Leech in October 1999 [BUAD 3518] (Leech, 1999) and some stripping of plaster on selected internal walls to determine the development of the structure in early 2001 [BUAD 3761] (Leech, 2001). The rear wall of the building was found to pre-date construction of the shops. The shops have been altered internally, a scar in the rubble wall forming the north wall of the building suggesting that the roof had been altered. A partition of late eighteenth- or early nineteenth-century date had been inserted to sub-divide the first floor. Nothing of the original interior of the shops survives.

KNOWN_AS: Brandy Cask Hotel, No.79, Broad Quay
MONUMENT_DESC:
Brandy Cask Hotel, No.79 Broad Quay, located on the north side of the junction of Broad Quay and Alderskey Lane. The site was created by the infilling of Aldsworth's Dock in the mid-seventeenth century and a building is recorded on the site by Millerd's 1673 map of Bristol.
As built, the structure was a double-gabled house of two storeys plus attic with a pantile roof. The west-facing, Broad Quay, elevation measured 11.4 metres from north to south while the south-facing, Alderskey Lane, elevation measured 9.2 metres east-west.
The building was apparently refronted in the late-eighteenth or early-nineteenth century (Winstone 1960, pl.63) and the roof altered to a hip. In the west-facing elevation it had an entrance door at the south end with an adjacent shop window, while to the north of this were two sash windows, one against the party wall with No.77 and between them a plain door opening. Adjacent to the north of the door was an arched cellar access with a cellar drop in the footway in front of the building. A string course separated ground and first floor and the first-floor fenestration comprised sashes, the two on the north side of the elevation being slightly larger than the rest. At the south corner of the building there was a large ornate lamp supported on brackets and projecting over the footway. There were four six over six pane sash windows at second floor and these were separated from the third floor by a string course. At third floor level the fenestration consisted of four three over three pane sashes. The dentils beneath the eaves continued from No.77, suggesting that the two buildings were refronted at the same time.
The street directory for 1882 records the building as a public house, The Bell, and the licensee was then James Blake. The name had been changed by the 1980s to the Brandy Cask Hotel.
The building was apparently demolished soon after the closure of Alderskey Lane in 1900 (Pritchard 1904, 128-129) and the site was subsequently redeveloped for the Co-operative Wholesale building.

The Chapel of the Holy Spirit (sometimes called St. Sprite's), in St. Mary Redcliffe Churchyard. The chapel stood close to the south-west corner of St. Mary Redcliffe church and was in existence by 1363. The building measured 17 metres from east to west and was 8 metres wide.
The chapel appears initially to have had a two-cell plan with the entrance, protected by a porch, on the north side of the building. Documentary evidence suggests that the during the medieval period the chapel included an annexe for lepers, tended by the religious from the hospital of St. John the Baptist. A plan of 1717 by Lyons indicates suggests that a room, possibly this annexe, ran the full length of the wall between the porch and the western corner had subsequently been added to the north side of the building.
The chapel was suppressed in 1537 and a grammar school, Queen Elizabeth's Free Grammar and Writing School, was established by letters patent and appears to have occupied the building. The school was to have a master and one under-master and was managed by a board of Governors established by the same letters patent (Manchee 1831, 45). The interior was drawn by James Stewart in 1748 (Bodleian MS.Gough, Somersetshire 2 & 8). Stewart's drawing records two (blocked) pointed arches in north wall; another at east end of south wall, with an ogee-headed opening towards the west, with, in between, a statue (possibly that of Queen Elizabeth now in the church) in an ogee-headed niche. In the east end wall was an eight-light mullion and transom window with, at the north end of the same wall, a fireplace. It had a three-part ceiling with angled sides and flat centre. The visible walls were panelled to height of arch springing.
In the early 1760s the churchwardens seem to have decided that the "beauty and magnificence" of the church were "greatly impaired and diminished by the situation of the said schoolhouse" and the decision was taken to remove it. The Governors resolved to move the school into the Lady chapel at the east end of the church on 31 December 1762 (Manchee 1831, 49). The Lady chapel was fitted out as a schoolroom and the Chapel of the Holy Spirit was demolished in 1763 (Dawson 1981, 23).

KNOWN_AS: Cathedral of the Holy and Undivided Trinity
POSTAL_ADDRESS: Cathedral of the Holy and Undivided Trinity, College Green
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Cathedral of the Holy and Undivided Trinity came into being as the centre of the new diocese of Bristol, which was created on 4 June 1542. The old abbey church was taken over as the cathedral and an existing late-medieval building to the south of the Cathedral church was converted into palace (BUAD 789M) for the Bishop. Clergy were accommodated in a number of houses within the precinct of the former abbey.
At the time of the dissolution Abbot Newland's reconstruction of the nave of the abbey church was unfinished and, the diocese lacking the funds to complete the work, the nave of the cathedral remained truncated until the nineteenth century. Blocking was inserted between the transept walls to form a continuous frontage. The north and south bays of this frontage contained tall arched tracery windows at the extreme ends. The central bay beneath the tower had buttresses which projected west from the frontage. Other alterations were also made to the fabric of the church in the 1540s. The choir screen of the Franciscan friary in Lewin's Mead was purchased and erected in the cathedral. This was later removed. The statutes which established the cathedral required a choir of six minor canons, six lay clerks and six choristers and there was presumably also an organ within the building. By the 1640s the church had an organ by Thomas Dallam, although it is not clear whether this survived the Commonwealth (Spink 1995, 193). However, between 1683 and 1685 the cathedral organist, Thomas Deane, who had been reinstated at the restoration in 1660, was responsible for the installation of a three-manual organ designed by Renatus Harris and constructed by the local organ builder Robert Taunton at a cost of £950 (Spink 1995, 193).
By the mid-nineteenth century the cathedral was separated from Deanery Road by a low stone wall with iron railings along the top. Works to construct Deanery Road in 1866 also increased access to the north side of the Cathedral by lowering the level of the ground by several feet.
The nave was reconstructed in the mid nineteenth-century. Designs by G. E. Street were submitted to a public meeting in June 1867. This proposed a nave 117 feet long by 80 feet wide and with twin towers at the west end. The corner stone of the new nave was laid on 17 April 1868 by Lord Limerick, the Provincial Grand Master of the Freemasons "with grand Masonic ceremony" according to The Builder (Anon. 1868, 297). The towers of the west end of the new nave were initially roofed above the level of the second stage but the fourth stage was added by the architect John Loughborough Pearson, who designed Truro Cathedral and was also architect to Lincoln Cathedral.

Harford House, No.2 Dighton Street. The building is a large town house built c.1760 for Joseph Harford. According to the listing  it is one of a number of houses modelled on Clifton Hill House, 1750 and was probably designed by Thomas Paty. The three-storey building is of limestone ashlar and squared, coursed Pennant rubble, with rendered gable stacks and a slate mansard roof. It has a double-depth plan. It is built on a slope with the front set back from the basement. The rusticated ground floor has incised voussoirs and a plat band, pilasters from there to a cornice and parapet, raised on the taller centre to the height of the pediment, with ball finials.
The building became the Convent of Our Lady of Mercy in 1846 and a chapel was built on the west side of frontage. This had a single-bay frontage with an arcade of five romanesque arched windows above a rusticated band. Above a string course was a three-light lunette window above which the pitched roof had a broken pediment. The chapel had rusticated quoins. The chapel has been demolished, although the rusticated courses of the frontage survive in the boundary wall surrounding Harford House.
Harford House has been converted into flats.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed building number 901-1/5/1477).

Woodcroft House, Wick Road was in existence by 1826-1827 when it was depicted in an illustration by T. L. Rowbotham (Stoddard 1981, pl.23). The building is reported to have been the farm for Broomwell House (Longman 2003, 4) and built in the late eighteenth century. Woodcroft is a two storey, three-window range building constructed of limestone ashlar blocks. Two single storey narrow former farm outbuildings lie immediately to the south of Woodcroft constucted of Pennant rubble.

Gate at the northern end of Stokes Croft, blocking the highway. The date at which the gate was established is unknown but it was in existence by the early 1640s. At that date it formed part of the northern line of defences protecting Bristol during the English Civil War of 1642-1646 and had a hornwork (BUAD 1536M) on its west side. In 1643 it was described by the Royalist engineer Sir Bernard de Gomme as "a strong port of timber barres" (BUAD 3168; Firth 1925, 184). The gate was still present in the early 1740s and was recorded by Jean Rocque's plan of Bristol of 1742 (BUAD 4106).
In the late eighteenth or early nineteenth century the west end of Ashley Road and its junction with Stokes Croft was moved to the north. The gate was also relocated to a position at the south end of Cheltenham Road and was recorded in its new position (ST 59137409) by Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 plan of Bristol.

The Chatterton Monument, located in the north-western corner of the grassed area on the north side of the churchyard. The idea of erecting a statue had originally been put forward in the 1790s but the proposal was not implemented for many years because of local opposition.
In 1838 a statue designed by S. C. Fripp, the City Surveyor, was erected at a cost of £100. It consisted of a Bath stone statue of a Bluecoat boy, a student at Queen Elizabeth's Hospital, holding a scroll inscribed "Ella." set on a pentagonal stone column standing 9.45 metres high. The statue originally stood between tower and the north porch of St. Mary Redcliffe. The vicar argued that the statue had been erected on consecrated ground without his consent and it was removed in and stored in the crypt. It was re-erected to the north-west of the church and remained in that position until its removal. The monument was damaged by vandalism in the 1950s and was also suffering from weathering and chemical erosion. The monument was removed in 1967 and the surviving elements are currently stored in the shed at Chatterton House.

KNOWN_AS: Moravian burial ground, Upper Maudlin Street
POSTAL_ADDRESS: Bristol Dental Hospital, Upper Maudlin Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Moravian Burial Ground at the rear of the Moravian Church in Upper Maudlin Street. The cemetery was located on the south side of the Moravian Church and was enclosed by buildings belonging to the brethren. On the north side was the chapel and on the west, stabling. On Lower Maudlin Street were the Old Sisters houses, Minister's house and the school, while on Blackfriars was the Old Brethren's house. A path ran around the edge of the burial ground and another ran across it from the church to the Old Brethren's house. The burial ground was commended as a model of good practice in G. T. Clark's report to the General Board of Health (Clark 1850, 214). The graves were indicated by stone markers arranged in rows. There were a number of deep brick burial shafts and one vault running roughly across the centre of the plot, which were revealed during a watching brief in 1993.
The burial ground was partly cleared in the early 1970s, although the number of burials removed seems to have been small. The majority of the burial ground was finally cleared and destroyed during groundworks for an extension to the Dental Hospital in August 1993. A watching brief maintained during the work recorded approximately 220 interments dating between the eighteenth and the late nineteenth or early twentieth centuries (BUAD 471). Further work was undertaken on the western side of the cemetery in 1999 (BUAD 3586; Pilkington 2000).

KNOWN_AS: Sheldon, Bush and Patent Shot Co. Ltd. Leadworks, Cheese Lane
MONUMENT_DESC: The Sheldon, Bush and Patent Shot Co. Ltd lead works on the west side of Cheese Lane. The site became a lead works in 1846 when it was bought by James Williams and Patent Lead Shot Co. who produced sheet and pipe lead. In July 1862 the works was bought by Sheldon, Bush and Patent Shot Co. which had a rolling mill on the site for the production of sheet and pipe lead. In 1968 the company's shot works on Redcliff Hill was demolished for road widening and a new shot tower, designed by E. N. Underwood and Partners (Structural Engineers), was built. The tower was awarded a Civic Trust Design Award. It was given a Grade II listing in November 1995.

KNOWN_AS: Building in Greyfriars, at the bottom of the steps
MONUMENT_DESC:
Building located on the east side of the north-west leg of Greyfriars, at the bottom of the steps leading up into Blackfriars. The building was probably one of the conventual buildings of the Franciscan Friary. It appears to have been located amongst the buildings on the north side of the cloister and was likely to have been close to the eastern end of the refectory. The function of the building is unclear but a survey by T. S. Pope in 1892 recorded that the building measured 31 feet 6 inches from north to south and 11 feet 6 inches from east to west and the height from ground floor to the ridge of the roof was 29 feet. The elements of the shell walls, including a buttress at first-floor level were of medieval date and at the rear there was an "outer hall or lobby" which gave access "from the ground floor to the land on the higher level" via a flight of steps (Weare 1893, 33-34). Internally the building appeared originally to have comprised a hall at both ground and first floor. Parts of two Gothic round trefoil windows were extant in the west-facing, Greyfriars, elevation until c.1921. Pope's drawings of these windows were published in Weare (1893).
By the early twentieth century the building had been converted into two dwellings. The building was of two storeys and two bays and a pitched pantile roof. In the south facing elevation there were central sashes at first-floor and attic level. The dwellings had adjacent entrances in the west-facing elevation. A tall square brick chimney stack projected from the centre of the eaves above the western elevation. Immediately to the north of this there was a low single-light dormer window.
By 1931 (BUAD 2265) the building was ruined. Its site now lies beneath the northern part of the western range of the Whitefriars office block.

Redcliff Gate, located at the south end of Redcliff Street. The original medieval structure was replaced by a single gate in the Classical style in 1730 or 1731, probably built on the site of the old outer gate. This was a Classical design with banded rustication on the south face and a tall round-headed central gate with twin studded doors for vehicular traffic. There was a smaller square-headed pedestrian gate to either side. Above the outside of either side gate there was a coved niche, and a smaller niche at the top of the structure, above the main entry. The gate was removed in 1771 to improve traffic flow.

KNOWN_AS: Arno's Court Bath house, Arno's Vale
MONUMENT_DESC: Bath house for Arno's Court (SMR 8467). The building was located on the north side of the Bath Road (now beneath the east side of Junction Road), opposite the main house and was apparently connected to it by a tunnel. It was built for William Reeve, a Bristol brassmaker, and was octagonal in plan with a long thirteen-bay colonnade, orientated east-west, on the south side. The room containing the great bath was decorated with Bristol scenes. The estate was sold after Reeve's bankruptcy. By 1912 the bath house was in use as an antiques showroom. It later came into the possession of the Bristol tramways Company and was allowed to decay. Walter Ison visited and described the building in the late 1940s or early 1950s (SMR 20209; Ison 1952, 185-186), but no repair work was undertaken. Ultimately, in 1965, it was demolished, and the colonnade removed to Portmeirion in Wales.

KNOWN_AS: St. Mary Redcliffe extension cemetery, Arno's Vale
MONUMENT_DESC: St. Mary Redcliff cemetery, Bath Road. The cemetery, located on the north side of Bath Road opposite Arno's Vale cemetery, was opened in 1866.

KNOWN_AS: Monument to William Pitt, Earl of Chatham, Clifton Down
MONUMENT_DESC:
Monument to William Pitt, Earl of Chatham. The memorial to William Pitt (the elder) is an obelisk on a plinth and is built of limestone ashlar. It was erected by Lieutenant-General Sir William Draper in 1766 in the garden of his home, Manilla Hall (Dreaper 1998, 1). The Latin inscription was drafted by Christopher Anstey (Dreaper 1998, 11).
The obelisk was moved to its present site in 1882, after the intervention of Dr. John Beddoe (a local antiquary) when the construction of Manilla Road threatened its destruction (Parker 1914, 8).
The memorial has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building No. 901-1/7/756).
Aust Farmhouse (NGR ST 54709 78505). A stone-built farm, apparently of seventeenth-century date.
The Old Signal Station on the east bank of the river Avon at Sea Mills. This nineteenth-century signal station was replaced by another building a short distance upstream some time after 1950.

KNOWN_AS: Oakenhill Cottages, to the south of Oakenhill Farm
MONUMENT_DESC:
Oakenhill Cottages. Three cottages of possible late-eighteenth-century date and are recorded by the Brislington tithe survey of 1846. The cottages are currently (11/7/97) rendered, so the construction technique is unknown, but they are presumably stone-built.
With Oakenhill Farm the cottages became part of the Clayfield-Ireland estate in 1790. At this time the farm and cottages were often referred to as "Oakenhills".

Downend Park Farm. A seventeenth-century (possibly c.1630) farmhouse of two storeys, possibly originally with large dormer gables. According to a survey by Linda Hall (SMR 20152) the central front door opens on to a lobby, behind which is a dairy. One side of the lobby is the kitchen and on the other a parlour. There is a 2 1/2 storey porch which contains the stair, which rises to the attic.
Inside the building is a kitchen dresser of late seventeenth-century date, while panelling and fireplace surrounds in the parlour date to the mid eighteenth-century. An outbuilding to the east of the house has remnants of tie-beam roof trusses and may also date to the early seventeenth-century. The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building No.1410). It was restored c.1989.

Elmgrove Farm, located on the north side of Stuppill Rhine. The farm is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucester Sheet LXVII.15) published in 1881 and was still extant in the mid 1930s.

Limekiln at Avonmouth Dock. The date of construction of the limekiln is not currently known. However, the limekiln was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500-scale County series plan (Gloucester Sheet LXXI.01) published in 1890 as "Old Limekiln", implying that it was no longer in use by that date.

Toll house, Whiteladies Gate. The toll house was sited between gates across Whiteladies Road and Cotham Hill, on the site of No.2 Cotham Hill. The 1828 plan of Bristol by Plumley and Ashmead indicates that the northern end of the house was formed of three sides in the classic form of a toll house.

Three sub-circular enclosures to the north of Bedminster Down Road. These enclosures are first recorded on the Tithe Map for the Parish of Berdminster dated 1841 (BRO EP/A/32/8) when they are recorded as plantations in the ownership of Sir John Smythe. A similar enclosure survives at Ashton Court and were possibly intended for bird rearing in the nineteenth century. The plantations are enclosed by hedges and planted with coniferous and deciduous trees. The monuments are still extant.

Williams Ground, located on the southern side of West Street, Old Market. The site was bought by William Dingley Williams, a Wesleyan Methodist minister, in 1793 and he subsquently opened a private burial ground there. Williams' son, William Rogers Williams, inherited the cemetery at his death (James Morgan pers. comm.). It was recorded by Plumley and Ashmead's map of 1828. In 1850 the cemetery was reported to as full (Clark 1850, 159) and interment there was ended by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852.
The plot appears to have been rented out and was reported to have had pigs kept on it in 1858. By 1883 two narrow buildings (BUAD 1434M) had been erected the east side of its site. In 1932 the burial ground was rented by the Garden Guild apparently as allotments "for the benefit of tenement dwellers nearby" (Anon. 1932). Archaeological evaluation of the site in 2005 (BUAD 4235) established that the graves within the burial ground were apparently undisturbed.

Prince Street Bridge, located at the south end of Prince Street and carrying the highway across the Floating Harbour to Wapping. The bridge was constructed in the later eighteenth century and was a wooden structure with a slightly arched deck which was supported on ribs and had handrails and posts along each side. It was originally a toll bridge with a pair of toll houses on either side of the southern approach. These buildings were square in plan with shallow pyramidal roofs with overhanging eaves and central, decorative chimneys. There was an entrance with a round-headed arch towards road and two windows within round-headed frames to the south. There were pedestrian gates either side of the central vehicle gate (BRSMG M2926).
The bridge was replaced in the nineteenth century.

St. Stephen's Churchyard, located at the south end of Prince Street. The site was apparently an extension burial ground for St. Stephen's which occupied virtually the full width of The Grove. It is first recorded by Rocque's 1742 plan of Bristol, suggesting a date of establishment between 1715 and the beginning of the 1740s. George Weare Braikenridge records that it was where the bodies of the drowned recovered from the Floating Harbour were interred (Braikenridge Notes, G.12). A watercolour of 1826 by Rowbotham (BRSMG M2506) shows the cemetery which was then surrounded by a stone rubble wall approximately three metres in height. The map surveyed by Plumley and Ashmead in 1828 shows the plot but it had apparently gone out of active use by that date. The burial ground had been incorporated into the highway by the early 1880s.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Church of St. Thomas the Martyr, St. Thomas Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Thomas burial ground, located on the north side of St. Thomas Church (BUAD 275M), St. Thomas Street. The church was probably founded towards the end of the twelfth-century. The date at which the churchyard was established is unknown. Thomas de Berkeley granted two messuages on the north side of the church to be used as a burial ground in c.1289 (Walker 1998, 263), but whether this represented an expansion of an existing churchyard or its foundation is uncertain.
The churchyard was closed to burials by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852.
The Becket Hall has been built on part of the site, possibly the "new parish room" opened in 1890 (BRO P/StT/PM/17). It is not known if the burials were cleared from this part of the site before the construction of the hall.
A faculty was subsequently granted for a scheme by the architect William Venn Gough to remove the graveslabs and vaults, level the graveyard and set out paths. It is not clear whether burials were removed during the work.
Archaeological evaluation (BUAD 1728; Burchill 1994) in the churchyard in 1994 noted quantities of disarticulated human remains but no articulated inhumations. Part of a brick burial shaft and a burial vault were exposed, however, the vault containing a lead coffin.

KNOWN_AS: House west of the watering place
MONUMENT_DESC:
House on the west corner of the watering place opposite the west end of Narrow Weir. The house was of two storeys with a double gable in the jettied north elevation. The ground-floor of the north elevation had, from the east, a window, entrance, and two windows. The first-floor window beneath the end of the central valley. Jettying cut back at very east end. The east elevation had a left-hand entrance with a two-light window beneath relieving arch. There was a blocked window to left of centre at first-floor; the chimney stack was near northern end, with a possible dormer behind it. There was a small terrace-like feature outside northern ground-floor. 
The site now lies mainly under the pavement on the south side of Broad Weir but was in the highway between the late nineteenth century and the 1960s. Services are likely therefore to have disturbed the site.

A summerhouse within the garden of Wick House was in existance by the time of the publication of the Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXVI.02) published in 1889 and possibly by the time of the Tithe map survey of 1846. The square building is shown with garden paths leading up to the building and was probably part of the formal garden of Wick House that lay above the valley of the 'Pictureseque' pleasure grounds to the east. The structure appears to be extant, with later extensions, within the garden of No.209 Wick Road (Rowe & Williams 1986, 44).
A glassworks here was opened for production of bottles in 1745, closed in 1787. {1}
Opened 1702 for flint glass. Owned by Little Family. Closed 1790. In the area of St Katherine's Hospital (pers comm Emily La Trobe Bateman 1996).

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Cathedral of the Holy and Undivided Trinity, College Green
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Gatehouse of St. Augustine's Abbey, located on the south side of College Green and to the west of the abbey church (now Bristol Cathedral). The gatehouse was built between 1140 and 1170, and formed the main entrance to the abbey precinct.
The gatehouse is a three-storey structure of oolitic limestone ashlar with a basement. The semi-circular arched gateway at ground-floor is of Norman date and is supported on twisted columns. It has complex incised geometric decoration of beaded chevrons on the stonework of the arches and vaulting (including contemporary carved bosses). The form of the upper part of the gatehouse as built in the twelfth century is not currently known. The major part of the gatehouse structure was reconstructed in the fifteenth century and is in a Perpendicular Gothic style, with an oriel window on the main, north-facing, elevation. There are niches on either side of the elevation at first- and second-floor level containing statues. Those at first floor represent abbots while the statues at second-floor are possibly of kings. All of the statues appear to date to the fourteenth- or fifteenth-century. The present roof was constructed in the late fifteenth- to early sixteenth-century (Arnold et al. 2003; Anon 2004, 90). Internally there is a winder stair at the south-east corner of the building. The blind arcade at ground floor was painted with a red and yellow colour scheme during the late-middle ages, as was the statuary on the exterior of the building. There are also masons' marks on the stone of the arcade (L. Bainbridge pers. comm.).
The upper part of the structure was restored and altered in the early 1880s under the supervision of the architect John Loughborough Pearson, who designed Truro Cathedral and was also architect to Lincoln Cathedral. This work involved repairs to the stonework of the building, including repositioning and reuse of some carved medieval stonework.
A photogrammetric survey of the exterior of the building was made by Warwick Rodwell in 2003-2004 (BUAD 4151).
The gateway has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/73).

Brunswick Square. Work to develop the Square began in 1766 with the construction of the buildings on the west side and progressed over the following twenty years. Felix Farley's Bristol Journal for 19 April 1766 reported that "the plan for building a handsom [sic] street from just below the Full Moon was put into execution Wednesday last by beginning the first house. The street is to run back through the gardens and at the further end of it will be built a most handsom square" (quoted in Ison 1951, 204). The site occupied part of the garden of Sir Abraham Elton's town house in St James Barton, but was mostly on garden ground belonging to Joseph Loscombe of Wilder Street. The Square was a private amenity space for the housing which was intended to surround the space. An abstract of title of 1776 records the covenant attached to the sale of land forming part of the east side of the square "to build enough houses to fill the whole of said Ground towards Brunswick Square & for repairing same - for pitching Street and for keeping quarter of said Square rails walks and trees thereof in good condition" (BRO 2215(22)). The buildings of the south side of the Square were built from c.1770 and the east side from 1784. Only half of the west side was actually completed and the north side was only enclosed in 1834 with the construction of the Congregational Chapel designed by William Armstrong.
The Square was laid out with diagonal cross paths and elm trees planted around the perimeter, although these were felled in 1856. The first edition Ordnance Survey 1:500 Town plan (Bristol sheets LXXI.16.15 and LXXII.13.11) surveyed in 1883 map records open gates at each corner, marked by bollards. At that date the Square was enclosed by railings and there was also a central lamp post. The railings were removed during World War Two.
The square was vested in Bristol City Council in 1952 and between 1953 and 1954 the Council spent £669 on restoring the lawns and planting of twelve flower beds. In the later twentieth century car-parking bays were set out on each of the four sides of the Square.

KNOWN_AS: Medieval chamber beneath 31, Jacob's Well Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
A medieval chamber beneath 31, Jacob's Well Road and adjoining footway at the junction of Constitution Hill and Jacob's Well Road. This chamber is associated with the water supply to St Mark's Hospital known as St Mark's conduit or Gaunt's Pipe (934M). This is a large underground rectagular chamber measuring approximately 3.5m in length and 1.4m wide constructed of rubble of possible medieval date with a stone vault above. The feature is accessed from a steel road plate on the Jacob's Well Road frontage. 
This chamber possibly relates to the grant of the property containing a spring, refered to as Garden Springs in 1742 on a plan by William Halfpenny (the professional name used by Michael Hoare), to St Mark's Hospital in c.1235-45. Prior to this the associated water supply may have related to the possible Bet tohorah or mikveh (949M SAM number AV 28881) at 33 Jacob's Well Road. 
From the mid-thirteenth century the chamber is likely to have formed part of the complicated network of chambers and conduits collecting water from springs above Jacob's Well Road to supply water to St Augustine's Abbey and St. Mark's Hospital via Gaunt's Pipe. 
The chamber was surveyed by Mark Horton of the University of Bristol in 1999 (BUAD 3520).

POSTAL_ADDRESS: The Old Council House, Corn Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Ewen's church, located on the south-western side of Broad Street. The church was in existence by c1138-1147 when Robert, earl of Gloucester granted it to Turstin as priest (BRO P/St.E/A 1). Latterly the advowson for the rectory belonged to Tewkesbury Abbey which appears to have exercised its right to appoint through its cell St. James Priory (BUAD 1024M). The development of the form of the church is not currently clear but by the late middle ages the church measured 20 metres from north-east to south-west and was 8.5 metres wide. On the north side of the church a tower was attached to the building. The churchyard (BUAD 799M) lay on the north side of the church.
In October 1399 John Thorp and John Sherp, burgesses of Bristol, gained the agreement of the Crown to establish a chapel dedicated to St. John the Baptist in the church and this occupied the south aisle. The same charter also gave them permission to incorporate a fraternity (which later became the Company of Merchant Tailors). The fraternity's book includes an inventory of 1401-02 recording the ornaments of the altar of the chapel, which comprised hangings, vestments of green, gold and ruby and an altar frontal depicting the life of St. John the Baptist (Fox 1880, 13).
At the dissolution the advowson was acquired by Henry Brayne as part of his purchase of the properties of St. James Priory. The chapel of St. John the Baptist was dissolved in 1547 (Maclean 1883-84, 245) and in 1551 the parish rented the chapel site to the Bristol Corporation to allow the reconstruction and enlargement of the Tolzey (Masters & Ralph, 1967 xiv). In 1637 the tower was rebuilt. The new tower was of two stages with diagonal buttresses and a flat roof. There was a two-centred arch window in north wall of the lower stage. A string course separated the stages.
In 1657 the Corporation obtained an Act of Parliament to allow it to use the building as a library. The building survived as a parish church, however. The incumbent in the 1730s was Thomas Taylor, described in Bishop Secker's Diocese Book as "whig, regular, sensible, good" (McGrath 1985, 36). In 1787 when a further Act of Parliament (28 Geo.III cap. 67) was obtained to merge the parish with Christ Church and to allow demolition of the building. The church was finally demolished in 1820 to enable the construction of Robert Smirke's design for the enlarged Council House (BUAD 342M).
Drawings by Hugh O'Neill made in the 1820s provide some record of the church. He drew the bottom two stages of the tower were drawn in 1820, when it was in use by the Chamberlain for storage of old documents. O'Neill also recorded the demolition of the 1704 Council House (BUAD 341M) and his drawings (Mb2968; Mb2947-Mb2949) show the removal of various parts of the former church, including pointed arches and round-headed and trefoil-headed windows. Architectural fragments were also recovered from the building when it was demolished and O'Neill drew various corbel heads and a boss, in the possession of the antiquarian G. W. Braikenridge or Mr. Garrard the City Chamberlain, in 1822 (M2309-M2312). O'Neill also recorded three fragments of carving, said to be from the old altarpiece in 1823 (Mb14-Mb16).

Christ Church, located on the north-east side of Broad Street.
The advowson belonged to Tewkesbury Abbey which appears to have exercised its right to appoint through its cell St. James Priory (BUAD 1024M). After the dissolution of St. James, the advowson of the rectory was acquired by Henry Brayne as part of his purchase of the St. James property in 1544.
By the late-seventeenth century the church had a tower and spire at, or towards, its eastern end. Nave and two aisles. There was a covered walkway along the Broad Street frontage with a shop on north-west side; arched west doorway with twisted columns. Large traceried west window of 8 lights, one light containing a door at its base, leading to the roof over the pavement. 4-light traceried window to north aisle. Nave and north aisles gabled, crosses to apex of gables. At west end of south aisle a 5-light window with shallow segmental arch, quatrefoil in centre of tracery, above and to the right, in a decorative frame, a large clockface. At the south-west corner of the church, and reaching above the south aisle, a tall thin pillar was topped by a flaming urn. Dragon weathervane atop the spire.
A new organ was built for the church by Renatus Harris in 1708.
The church was demolished in the late eighteenth century and was rebuilt 1786-1791 to a design by William Paty. The construction work was undertaken by Thomas Paty and Sons.
The entrance was reconstructed and the interior refurbished by Henry Williams in 1883, restored 1973. Bath stone ashlar; roof not visible. 
West tower and nave. Baroque style. South wall has four 3-light round-arched windows, 1883. Tower is of four stages: first stage balcony beneath a pair of Roman Quarter Jacks striking bells, and a large clockface, below a cornice and segmental pediment; above this the tower is free-standing, and all 4 faces identical. 3-stage octagonal spire on a short plinth.
The original reredos, an elliptical pediment on Corinthian pilasters with gilded plaster decoration, is now the rood screen. Four-bay nave has elliptical arches on slender Corinthian columns; aisles the same height; Adam-style ceiling decoration.
Restored 1791 octagonal timber pulpit with painted plaster cherub heads, back and and inlaid tester; the original font is now the lectern base. At the rear is the 1708 organ loft by Renatus Harris, above a balcony on 2 Corinthian columns. In the north-west corner is a segmental arch to a bay containing a small octagonal font. The Quarter Jacks came from the earlier church, 1728, by James Paty, and many of the memorials from St. Ewen's (demolished). The dragon weathervane was on the top of the spire of the old church. The Quarter Jacks were drawn by Johnson, etc. (BRSMG M2345-M2347).
Burial in the crypt of the church was ended by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852.
The Renatus Harris organ was rebuilt in 1837 by John Smith and Sons, Bristol-based organ builders, and was refurbished later in the nineteenth century by another Bristol firm, W. G. Vowles.

KNOWN_AS: Oak and Elm Cottages, St Anne's Terrace
MONUMENT_DESC:
Two cottages at St Anne's Terrace possibly originally a single square structure depicted on the Brislington Tithe survey of 1846 (BRO EP/A/32/9) and the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.04) published in 1890.
The building is still extant though now subdivided.

No.3 St Anne's Terrace appears to have been in existance by the time of the Brislington Tithe survey of 1846 (BRO EP/A/32/9) as part a row of possible farm buildings. The Ordnance Survey 1:2500-scale first edition County Series plan (Somerset Sheet VI.04) shows that this structure stood on the southern corner of a square of farm buildings around a central yard. By the First World War the majority of the buildings on the north and east sides of the square had been demolished, but the structures along the southern side survived until later in the twentieth century. 
The property that is now No.3 St Anne's Terrace is the last surviving element of this nineteenth century farm. The remains of the chimney breast and part of the side walls of the former building to the west are still evident on the west elevation of the present building.

No.142 Temple Street. Attached to south. On the west side of Temple Street, on the south corner of the eastern end of Long Row. 3 storeys, 1 bay; gabled front; jettied to both elevations. Large corner bracket and post; brackets to south end and west end; corbelling outside north wall for first-floor fireplace. Bow shopfront, cellar access below; doorway to right, up two steps. Brickwork at east end of north wall, with beyond some openings. First-floor jettied on both elevations. Full-width pentice roof, above which is canted front bay, with sash, at first-floor. No windows to north elevation at first or second floors. Brackets to second-floor at each end, the northern decorative; second-floor jettied at front only; canted bay; decorative bracket to north eaves; small 2-light window to roofspace above bay window. Lateral stack, probably of brick. Propped from No.143 across Long Row. In 1821 occupied by "MITCHELL Cabinet & Chair Maker".

The Giant's Castle Public house, located at the northern end of the east side of Temple Street. Contained the remains of a chapel or hall. Had been the home of a shoemaker named Bevan, who, at every Temple Fair, let out rooms above stairs to Patrick O'Brien, the Irish Giant. Bevan converted the building to a public house, naming it after his annual guest. In a wall (probably the south) of a yard was a large arch (BUAD 1029A). Inside part of the building was an arcade (BUAD 1030A).

House. A large medieval hall, noted by Braikenridge in particular for its north-west to south-east alignment. Trusses springing off corbels set well below wall tops. Three tiers of windbraces each side. Numerous redundant corbels around the walls, possibly brought from elsewhere. Flagstone floor. 
At the north-west end, a 6-light window at higher level, two-centred heads within an overall square headed frame. Above, another window, shallow segmental two-centred head, 2 lights with some tracery. Door at north-west end of south-west wall led to a cellar. First-floor access in end of north-east wall leading to the adjacent dwelling house above stairs, a doorway below to a passage leading from the dwelling house to the street. 
High in the south-east end wall, a 3-light window, two-arched heads in a square frame. Panelling around all three walls at that end. 
Said to have been the residence of the younger Sir John Knight, who was Mayor in 1670. The house contained a full-height chimney-piece (Arch.El.No.1031A).

Tyndall's Park, St. Michael's Hill. The park extended from Park Row and Whiteladies Road on the west to St. Michael's Hill on the east and the lease had been acquired from the Dean and Chapter of Bristol Cathedral by John Tyndall in the first half of the eighteenth-century. The freehold had subsequently been purchased by Thomas Tyndall who commissioned the construction of Royal Fort House (BUAD 1034M). In 1792 a group of speculative builders headed by T. G. Vaughan persuaded Tyndall to sell part of the surrounding grounds for housing development. Construction work began but the scheme was a casualty of the crash in the property market caused by the outbreak of the French Revolutionary Wars, leaving the park disfigured by foundation trenches (Bettey, 1997 14-15).
The park subsequently reverted to Tyndall and in February 1799 he engaged Humphry Repton to landscape the site. Repton found Royal Fort House "surrounded by large chasms in the ground" and "immense heaps of earth & broken rock..." (quoted in Daniels, 1999 238). He proposed retaining the mounds and planting them with trees to screen the house, together with further excavation of the sides of the trenches to lower their edges and create hollows for lawns. Repton's scheme screened nearby housing but preserved views of the more distant city. A watercolour drawing of 1824 showing the western half of the park from Park Place suggests that the park was used for livestock (BUAD 3917; Greenacre and Stoddard, 1988 31).
Much of the park was developed for housing in the second half of the nineteenth century and the early twentieth century. The gardens in the immediate vicinity of Royal Fort House are now the only part of Repton's scheme to survive.

Highbury Chapel, located on the eastern side of the junction of Cotham Road and St. Michael's Hill. The chapel was a Congregational chapel. The chapel was constructed between 1842-1843 to a design by William Butterfield and is believed to be his earliest work (Stell 1986, 64). The chapel is constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble with limestone dressings and is in the Perpendicular Gothic style. It has an aisled nave of five bays with a polygonal chancel.
By 1862 accommodation within the chapel had become very limited because of housing development in Cotham, but also because of the popularity of the ministry of Rev. David Thomas. E. W. Godwin was commissioned to expand the chapel. Godwin's scheme followed Butterfield's the style of original design closely but used a mix of Pennant sandstone rubble and freestone for the fabric of the walls. His additions included an apse, a cloister and a freestone tower. Godwin also altered the interior, designing a polygonal oak pulpit on a freestone base, an oak screen across the apse to conceal the organ. He also designed a stained glass memorial window for the west end of the chapel, which was made by Joseph Bell (Soros 1999, 138). On the wall of the north-east nave respond there is a monument to Arnold Thomas by Eric Gill. This was executed in 1924 and takes the form of a shepherd and sheep.
The chapel was bought by the Church of England c1975 and is now Cotham Parish Church. The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/4/1195). The listing notes the building to be "an exceptionally early and unusual example of the application of the Gothic Revival style to nonconformist chapel architecture."

Nos.3 and 4 Pipe Lane. A pair of houses. Early C18 style fronts, but the whole possibly late C17. Rusticated quoins and wide eaves. Attached. 3 storeys, probably with attics. Each a 3-window range. No.3 with left-hand bow shop window, entrance with pedimented hood, and, on the right-hand, the round-headed entrance to Pipe Court, already closed by the time of the 1930 photograph taken by Street. No.4 with a left-hand sash, pedimented hood to entrance, then 2 further sashes. First and second floors each very slightly jettied, or with strings. Sashes to all upper windows, which for both storeys are arranged 2, 1, 1, 2. No.4 was mostly demolished in the autumn of 1952 (Street's notes).

KNOWN_AS: Richmond House or Abbot's House, Stoney Hill
MONUMENT_DESC:
Richmond House or Abbot's House, located on the east side of Stoney Hill. Research by Dr. Roger Leech indicates that the plot was leased from the Dean and Chapter of Bristol Cathedral in 1631 by Thomas Hobson, and a lodge already stood on the site at this time (BRO DC/E/40/57/51706). The lodge was replaced by two banqueting houses which were in the possession of Thomas Wells by 1649. Wells gained a new lease in 1661 (BRO DC/E/40/57/51706) and Richmond House was constructed c.1664.
The building was of rubble construction (in Brandon Hill grit), three storeys with an attic, cellar and cross-gable pantile roof. It appears to have had a substantial chimney stack on the south side with at least three flues. A further stack was positioned at the end of the gable on the north side of the building. There were two principal rooms on each floor, known to have been panelled inside with decorative plasterwork on the ceilings. The principal room on the first-floor was drawn by Samuel Loxton in the early twentieth century and contained a large chimneypiece and the walls had panelling to dado height. The ceiling had decorative platerwork with a large figure of abundance at the centre. Within the building there were also decorated chimneypieces, one with the initials "WTE" and the date 1664 (R. H. Leech pers. comm.; Leech in Lawrence, 2003 79-82). Frederick Jones reports a subterranean passage within the building but this is more likely to be the remains of the cellar (Jones 1946 182).
The building was gutted, apparently as a result of bombing during the Second World War, and was demolished in the 1940s. The Trenchard Street multistorey car park was built over the site in the 1960s.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Bristol and West Building, Temple Quay
MONUMENT_DESC:
Aladdin Gas Holder, located on the north side of Temple Back. The gas holder was part of a gasworks constructed at Temple Back by John Gostling for the Bristol Gas Light Company between August 1816 and 1818 (BRO 28777/G/L/4/1). It was sub-rectagular in shape, a plan of July 1818 indicating its maximum internal measurements were 59 feet (18 metres) from south-west to north-east by 34 feet (10.4 metres) wide. The walls were of Pennant sandstone bonded in a grey-yellow mortar with charcoal and ash inclusions and were approximately 1 metre thick with a batter towards the base. A test in March 1817 identified a leakage problem and the base of the gas holder was puddled. The required capacity also seems to have been increased to 36,500 in 1818 (BRO 28777/G/L/4/3), making it the largest gas holder in the country at the time. The gasworks closed in 1821 when the Bristol Gas Light Company moved its operations to a new site in Avon Street. The site was leased for two years, then sold in 1824 to Tothill & Co., cement manufacturers. Cartographic evidence suggests that the gas holder was incorporated into another building but survived into the 1850s before being demolished.
The foundations of the western half of the gas holder was recorded during an archaeological watching brief on the site in 2004 (BUAD 4133; Longman 2005).
