KNOWN_AS: House in Alderskey Lane attached to the east side of No.79 Broad Quay
MONUMENT_DESC:
A house located on the north side of Alderskey Lane, attached to the east side of No.79 Broad Quay (BUAD 1395M). The site was created by the infilling of Aldsworth's Dock in the mid-seventeenth century and a building is recorded on the site by Millerd's 1673 map of Bristol. The house was constructed in the later seventeenth- or early eighteenth century date and was of two storeys, and had two bays and a gabled pantile roof. The main entrance was on the west side of the elevation. It appears from cartographic evidence that the house was constructed with a detached kitchen block to the north. In total the plot measured 14 metres from north to south and was 6 metres wide.
The building was still in use as a dwelling in January 1887 according to the Goad fire insurance plan and was apparently demolished soon after the closure of Alderskey Lane in 1900 (Pritchard 1904, 128-129). The site of the rear part was excavated in 1979 (BUAD 442) but any evidence for the building appears to have been removed by the basements of the CWS building.

No.1, Pembroke Place, located on the northern side of Johnny Ball Lane. The building was a rendered three-storey, two-bay house of Pennant sandstone in a random rubble construction. It was the north-western of a terrace of four occupying the site of a formal garden of seventeenth-century date, and was built as part of a pair with No.2. The main elevation faced south-west. The main entrance was on the south-east side of the elevation. The fenestration at all levels consisted of recessed sash windows with ashlar stone cills. Above there was a parapet wall and cornice. Internally the basement plan consisted of two rooms, the kitchen at the front (south-west) and a second at the rear (north-east). There was a chimneybreast on the northern wall of the kitchen and the basement had a flagstone floor. In front of the building, between the house and Johnny Ball Lane, was the garden.
The house was first occupied c.1764 according to the St. James parish ratebooks and was originally known as Pembroke Court. In 1775 it was occupied by John Davis, school-master. The house was demolished in 1973.
The building was archaeologically excavated in 1999 (BUAD 3399).

Central Library, located on the south side of Deanery Road. In 1899 Vincent Stuckey Lean bequeathed the Bristol Corporation £50,000 for the construction of a new reference library for the city, along with his extensive personal library (Beeson 2006, 7). The site of the Old Deanery (BUAD 520M) and the Prebendal House (BUAD 521M) in Deanery Road was selected as the site for the new building.
The library was constructed to a design by the architect Charles Holden and opened in 1906 (Beeson 1986).
The building has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/70).
No longer extant {1}

A house located on the eastern side of Greyfriars, lying on the south side of the south-west to north-east section of the street. The building appears to have been constructed at the north edge of the interior of the Fransiscan friary and was probably therefore constructed after the Dissolution, either in the second half of the sixteenth or the seventeenth century. Its footprint measured 10.9 metres from east to west and 6 metres north-south. The building was of one (possibly two) storeys plus attic. The north-west facing elevation of was of rendered rubble.
The north-west corner of the building was cut back at ground-floor, and corbelled out above. The building had a pitched pantile roof and a gable covering a projecting tower, possibly a stair tower. This had a small square single light in its gable end and a similar square window in the main body of the wall to the west. There was a gable at the south-west end, and another, facing north-west, at the north-east end.
The building was in use as a store for Butcher & Co., builders, of Rupert Street in the 1930s. It was probably demolished in early 1973. Its site lies mainly to the west of the Whitefriars office block beneath an access road and landscaping.

KNOWN_AS: The Coffee House, No.56 Corn Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
No.56 Corn Street. The building was constructed in 1782 to a design by Thomas Paty. It is in a Classical style and is a three-storey structure of limestone ashlar with, rusticated quoins, cornice, parapet and a hipped roof. The upper floors project over the north aisle of All Saints Church (BUAD 247M).
The main, north-west facing, elevation to Corn Street has a three window range with the pedimented centre set forward. At ground-floor there is an arcade of keyed semicircular arches. There are pediments over the first floor window openings which contain six-over-six pane timber sash windows. The south-west facing elevation to All Saints Lane matches the style of the main elevation and has a doorway at its northern end and a blind arch at the southern end.
Internally the building has a single-depth plan with the upper floors projecting south over the north aisle of All Saint's Church. Eighteenth-century fixtures remain, including the stair above first floor and other joinery in the basement and window fittings on the upper floors. The building had previously been let to Sarah Sawyer and subsequently to John Avery, a distiller and by 1832 the building had "lately" been used as a Stamp Office. It was then leased to Frederick Sway (Leech 1997, 67). Norwich Union were still in occupation in 1883, apparently with an architect, W. H. Price, and a solicitor operating from the upper floors.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/11/573).

No.91 Stokes Croft, located on the north-western side of Stoke Croft. The building was a house of two-storeys and attic with a gabled pantile roof. It was probably constructed in the late-seventeenth or early-eighteenth century.
The building was demolished in 1961 (Winstone 1972, pl.129) and the site redeveloped. The building line was set back from the original position, meaning that the eastern part of the house now lies beneath the footway.

KNOWN_AS: Limekilns, west of the railway in Sea Mills
MONUMENT_DESC:
Two limekilns at Sea Mills, located at the edge of the river Avon to the west of the bridge carrying the Portway over the railway by Horseshoe Drive.
The kilns are constructed of random Dolomitic Conglomerate rubble bonded with off-white lime mortar. Both kilns have brick vaulted roofs and a square recess in each side wall.
The flues for the kilns are no longer visible due to stone slabs braced with railway tracks set into the back wall of the kilns from floor to vault.
Natural bedrock is visible at the base of the western kiln, although the eastern kiln contains a lot of post use debris (10/01/2011).
The kilns are not indicated on mapping until the 1903 Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan, although they are suggested by two indents on the earlier 1880s OS plan.
Typologically it is assumed that these kilns are late eighteenth century in date and relate to the Sneyd Park Estate and possibly the creation of the estates surrounding ornamental landscape that consists of terraces and summer houses within the woodland to the east - southeast upslope of these kilns.
The limekilns are extant.
Sea Mill or Say Mill. No longer extant.
Mill extant in 1660, no longer exists. Location unknown. {1}
1 pipe kiln definitely and 1 kiln perhaps used to lie in Chock Lane. Now destroyed.
No longer extant.
Pound, located at High Street, Westbury-on-Trym.

Pound, located on the east side of the junction of Southmead Road and Wellington Hill West. The pound is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.08) published in 1881.
Pound, no longer extant. {1}

KNOWN_AS: Earthworks at the west end of Deering Close, Lawrence Weston
MONUMENT_DESC: Earthworks of medieval date located on open ground at the west end of Deering Close, Lawrence Weston. The site was observed by Nick Greenberry in 1984, although it is not clear what the nature of the fieldwork was. The earthworks include a house platform which survives to a height of 1 metre and a hollow way. Pottery of thirteenth-century date, a medieval pilgrim badge and lace bobbin of seventeenth-century date were found on the site (Iles & White 1985, 61).

KNOWN_AS: Enclosures approximately 80 metres north of the junction of Fourth Way and Avonmouth Way, Avonmouth
MONUMENT_DESC:
Earthworks located approximately 80 metres to the north of the junction of Fourth Way and Avonmouth Way. The earthworks are recorded by air photographs taken on 4th December 1946 (CPE/UK/1869 Frame 4029) and comprised four or five small rectangular enclosures on the southern side of what appear to be a relict drainage feature. Adjoining, on the southern side of Ballast Lane (ST 52907859) was a small enclosure with buildings on its southern side.
The land is currently undeveloped and the earthwork features may be expected to be extant.

KNOWN_AS: Holy Cross Church, Inns Court Drive
MONUMENT_DESC: Holy Cross Church, Inns Court Drive. The church was constructed in early 1999 to a design by Fergusson Mann architects to replace an earlier church at Inns Court Green (SMR 3212).

Clifton College. The college was founded in 1860-1862. A company was created to manage the school and finance was raised by issuing shares in it (Christie, 1935 18). The core buildings of the school were constructed between 1860 and 1863 and were designed by Charles Francis Hansom and included the hall, boarding house and dwelling houses for the masters. The Guthrie Memorial chapel, again designed by Hansom, was added in 1866 and the library and additional classrooms were constructed in 1869. The Wilson Tower, by Hansom and Bond, was built in 1889, followed by a science lecture theatre around 1898. A memorial commemorating the South African War by the sculptor Alfred Drury was added in 1904 and a First World War memorial in the form of a gatehouse, designed by Charles Holden, in 1922. A statue of Earl Haig by W. McMillan was unveiled by Field-Marshal Sir William Birdwood, commander of the Anzac forces during the First World War and a Clifton College old boy, on Saturday 15th July 1932.
Several of the college buildings are listed Grade II. The Guthrie Memorial Chapel (Listed Building No. 901-1/2/830) and the memorial to the South African War (Listed Building No. 901-1/2/831) are Grade II*.

Portland Chapel, located on the south side of Portland Street, Cotham. The chapel was built in 1791-1792 to serve the growing Wesleyan Methodist congregation living on the north side of Bristol and one of the principal movers behind the establishment was Captain Thomas Webb (c.1726-1796), who had been a significant figure in the establishment of Methodism in the Americas. As a Loyalist, Webb had returned to live in England in 1778.
The chapel had five bays, with a slightly projecting centre comprising three bays with a pediment above. The external walls were rendered and the fenestration consisted of a semi-circular arched window with freestone dressings in each bay. The chapel had a pitched roof with louvred hexagonal lantern at the west end.
The interior originally measured 17 metres from east to west and was 11.9 metres wide, with a small apse at the east end. At the west end there was a gallery supported on Tuscan columns.
The seating was altered in 1864 and the chapel was extended to the west in 1871-1872, when a polygonal organ chamber was added to north wall (Stell 1986, 68). The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale town plan surveyed in 1881 (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.9) records that the chapel then had seating for 630 worshippers and also indicates that there was a burial ground on the western side of the chapel.
The chapel closed in 1970-1971, and was demolished in the same decade. The remains of Thomas Webb and his wife were removed from the burial ground and reinterred in the courtyard of the New Room (BUAD 256M) off Broadmead. The site was subsequently redeveloped for housing.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Bristol Dental Hospital, Upper Maudlin Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
Moravian Church, located on the south-east side of Upper Maudlin Street. The Moravian Society in Bristol was formed in 1748, the original chapel being located in Avon Street, St. Philips. It was relocated to Maudlin Lane, the land being bought in 1756; the chapel opened the next year. Various alterations were made, with substantial rebuilding in 1896 to provide a street-level chapel with hall beneath. This consisted of rendered walls with a brick superstructure and tiled roof. The original building had rusticated quoins and tall segmental-arched windows, with four bays on each side. There was an Upper chapel of 16.7 metres by 9.18 metres, with, at the south end, a re-used gallery of c.1757 with bowed centre supported by two Tuscan columns. The organ was built in 1827 by John Smith senior of John Smith and Sons, Bristol organ builders. The pulpit was added in 1854.
The chapel stood on the north side of the burial ground and had a large arched gateway leading to it. The four sides of the burial ground were lined by buildings associated with the brethren. The minister's house stood to the east of the church. On Lower Maudlin Street were the Old Sister's Houses, while on the south side fronting Blackfriars was the day and Sunday school. West of this building was the Old Brethren's House while the west side of the burial ground was open until a stable block was built (by the late 1880s). The site, including the burial ground and other buildings, was sold for redevelopment, 1971 and the chapel was removed before Easter 1973. The site was subject to archaeological excavation in 1973 and 1976.

The Royal Fort, located at the summit of St. Michael's Hill. A fort, known as Windmill Hill fort, was built on the site in 1643 and after the fall of Bristol to the Royalists in that year it was substantially reworked. A Royal order for the work was issued in the summer of 1644 (Cal. S. P. Dom. 1644-1645 235) and it was apparently completed in December of that year. Renamed the Royal Fort, the fort was the most powerful of the city's defensive fortifications during the English Civil Wars (1642-1648).
There has been some speculation about the exact footprint of the fort but geophysical survey by the University of Southampton in 1999 (BUAD 3479) together with documentary research by Dr. Roger Leech (Leech 2000, 20-21) have suggested a more precise position. The fort occupied the area defined by Royal Fort Road, University Walk, St. Michael's Hill and Tyndall Avenue. It was pentangular in form and the surrounding ditch was approximately 5 metres wide. Both the fortifications and the internal buildings appear to have been of Brandon Hill grit. Little is currently known about the internal organisation of the fort, although a gatehouse (BUAD 131M) in the eastern wall survives at the western end of Royal Fort Road.
The Royal Fort played a major part in the siege and storming of Bristol by the New Model Army in 1645.
The site was developed for housing from 1655 (Bettey 1997, 7) and the process of the removal of the fabric of the fort appears to have been gradual. Elements were still extant in the mid-eighteenth century and many of these were recorded in drawings by James Stewart in the 1750s. The Ordnance Survey first edition plan surveyed in 1883 clearly shows part of the north bastion in the garden of Cromwell House. Currently the gatehouse and a length of walling survive.
The Royal Fort gatehouse has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/10/237).

No.17 Wade Street. The house stands on the west side of Wade Street and was built as part of the development of Great Ann Street and Great George Street between 1700 and 1720. This large development, unusually in Bristol at that time, was intended to provide housing for artisans and craftsmen (R. H. Leech 'The processional city: some issues for historical archaeology' in Tarlow & West (eds.) 1999, 19-34).
The house was surveyed by Roger Leech of RCHME (BUAD 2102). As a result of this work it was concluded that the building originally comprised a single room on each floor with a stair winder next to the chimney stack (Leech 1981, 17).

No.2, Pembroke Place, located on the northern side of Johnny Ball Lane. The building was a rendered three-storey, two-bay house of Pennant sandstone in a random rubble construction. It was part of a terrace of four occupying the site of a formal garden of seventeenth-century date, and was built as part of a pair with No.1. The main elevation faced south-west. The entrance door was on the north-west side of the elevation. The fenestration at all levels consisted of recessed sash windows with ashlar stone cills. Above there was a parapet wall and cornice. Internally the basement plan consisted of two rooms, the kitchen at the front (south-west) and a second at the rear (north-east). There was a chimneybreast on the southern wall of the kitchen. Access to the basement was by a stair in the northern corner of the rear room, against the rear wall of the property. had a flagstone floor. In front of the building, between the house and Johnny Ball Lane, was the garden.
The house was first occupied c.1764 according to the St. James parish ratebooks and in 1775 it was occupied by Thomas Pruett Popple, gentleman. The original sash windows were replaced in the nineteenth century with new sashes with horns and margin panes. The house was demolished in 1973.
The building was archaeologically excavated in 1999 (BUAD 3399).

No.4, Pembroke Place, located on the northern side of Johnny Ball Lane. The building was a rendered three-storey, two-bay house of Pennant sandstone in a random rubble construction. It was part of a terrace of four occupying the site of a formal garden of seventeenth-century date, and was built as part of a pair with No.3. The main elevation faced south-west. The entrance door was on the north-west side of the elevation. The fenestration at all levels consisted of recessed sash windows with ashlar stone cills. Above there was a brick parapet wall and cornice. Internally the basement plan consisted of two rooms, the kitchen at the front (south-west) and a second at the rear (north-east). There was a chimneybreast on the northern wall of the kitchen. Access to the basement was probably by a stair in the northern corner of the rear room, against the rear wall of the property. had a flagstone floor. In front of the building, between the house and Johnny Ball Lane, was the garden.
The house was first occupied c.1764 according to the St. James parish ratebooks and in 1775 it was occupied by William Bayton, nurse and organist. The original sash windows were replaced in the nineteenth century with new sashes with horns and margin panes and the window opnings appear to have been altered at the same time. The house was demolished in 1973.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Great Western Dry Dock, Gasferry Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
A brickyard on the south bank of the River Avon, west of Wapping. The yard had a large clay pit at both the west and east ends and operated in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth century. Vitrified bricks from the site were recovered from the river bed in 1998, indicating that waste from the kilns was dumped directly into the river. The clay pits had been filled in by the 1820s. Brunel chose the western clay pit as the site of the Great Western Dry Dock where the SS. Great Britain.
No structures from the brickyard are known to survive above ground but subsurface survival of features is likely.

KNOWN_AS: Warehouse at Central Trading Estate, Bath Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Built as three attached warehouses of one to two and a half storeys on the north-east side of Lightbox Lane. The buildings are constructed of brick with large crittal windows, concrete lintels and pitched roofs. The warehouses are first depicted on the 1948 1:1250 Ordnance Survey plan and form part of an extensive area of light industrial warehousing on the south side of the Avon.

KNOWN_AS: Great Western Railway Boundary Marker, St Werburgh's Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Cast iron circular boundary marker mounted on a fragment of iron track (possibly a broud gauge rail fragment). Embossed on the top of the marker is recorded 'Great Western Railway Co. Boundary 1883'. The marker is situated on the south side of Boiling Wells Stream at the northern end of St Werburgh's Road. The adjacent railway embankment was built for the Port and Pier Railway in 1870 by the Great Western and Midland Railways.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Albion Dry Dock, Chatham Wharf, Cumberland Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
Albion Dry Dock, Gasferry Road. The dock was in existence by the early nineteenth century and is shown as a graving dock on the Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of 1883. It was part of Hilhouse's Shipyard but the yard was bought by Charles Hill & Sons in the latter part of the nineteenth century and was renamed the Albion Dockyard. The dock was extended in the twentieth century.
The dock is approximately 165 metres long and 7.5 metres deep and appears to have cut into the rockhead at least at its southern end. A cast iron caisson closes the northern end of the dock. The walls are constructed of blocks of sandstone as is the floor of the northern part of the dock. The walls on the east and west sides are constructed in a series of five ledges or galleries which vary in size but are roughly 0.5 metres wide by 1.5 metres high.
The dock was the subject of a photographic survey in 1998 [BUAD 3344] in advance of the infilling of its southern end. It was noted that a cannon of probable late eighteenth or early nineteenth century date had been set into the ground at the east side of the dock (NGR ST 5775 7239 approx) to act as a mooring post.

The Bristol Nails. Four bronze pillars set in the footway in front of The Exchange on the southern side of Corn Street (at ST 58858 73022, ST 58848 73017, ST 58841 73012 and ST 58834 73007) which were used for trading: according to Pryce (Anon., 1859 275) "upon them our merchants of a former day paid for their purchases . Hence, I believe, originated the phrase, 'pay down upon the nail'. Vignettes in the border Millerd's 1673 map of Bristol indicate that at that date there were nine Nails, three between the columns supporting the pentice of the Tolzey on the north side of Corn Street, and the remainder beneath a similar structure in front of All Saint's Church on the opposite side of the street. The four surviving pillars are reported to have been moved to their present position in 1782 (Anon., 1859 276).
There appears to have been very little archaeological study of the Nails, the only known detailed record being the drawings by Lepard made in the late 1850s (BUAD 3716; Anon., 1858 340-341). The surviving pillars date to the late-sixteenth and early-seventeenth century and three bear inscriptions commemorating their donors. The earliest, at the north-east end of the group, is undated but has been dated on stylistic grounds to the late-Elizabethan period. The remainder date to between 1625 and 1631.
The Nails have a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/11/580).

Chapel of St. Clement, located at the south end of Marsh Street. The site, immediately outside the Marsh Wall (BUAD 1041M) on the east side of the Marsh Gate (BUAD 677M), was leased by the Corporation to John Drewe on 14 March 1493 so that the Guild of Mariners could found a chantry chapel dedicated to St. Clement, the patron saint of mariners (Manchee 1831, 237). Once built, the chapel appears to have been managed by proctors appointed by the Guild and had a one priest who presumably also served the Mariners Almshouse. In addition, as part of the annual rent to the Bristol Corporation for the site the proctors were responsible for managing and maintaining the slip at Hungroad (McGrath 1975, 70).
The chapel was a rectangular two-storey structure, orientated east-west, with projecting buttresses at the south-west and south-east corners and a pitched roof. The main entrance, a doorway with a four-centred arched opening, was at the centre of the south wall. To the west of the doorway were a pair of tall four-light lancet windows. The fenestration at first-floor level consisted of a two-light lancet window towards the western end of the elevation. There was a second similar window above the entrance. In the eastern half of the elevation there was a pair of four-light mullion and transom windows - possibly inserted during the use of the building as the Merchant Venturers Hall. The organisation of internal space is not currently clear but the internal dimensions were recorded as 67 feet 6 inches [20.66 metres] from east to west by 23 feet [7.04 metres] north-south, the walls being about 2 feet 6 inches [0.77 metres] to 3 feet [0.92 metres] in thickness (Pritchard 1907, 226-227).
The chapel was presumably dissolved in 1547-1548 along with the Guild of Mariners. The site was granted to Sir Ralph Sadleir and Lawrence Winnyngton by the Crown on 15 December 1550, and Sadleir and Winnyngton subsequently sold the site to Edward Prynne. His heir, Erasmus Prynne, sold the site to Thomas Aldworthe and Thomas Symonds (Manchee 1831, 237) who were apparently acting for the Society of Merchant Venturers. The Society used the chapel as its hall and also took over responsibility for the Mariner's Almshouse. The building appears essentially to have been retained by the Society and, despite remodelling of the exterior, the core of the building seems to have survived as the southern element of the Merchant Venturers Hall until the early-twentieth century. The remains of the chapel were recorded in 1907 in the lower storey of the hall (Pritchard 1907, 226-227). Air raids struck the hall on 2 December 1940, causing extensive damage. It was bombed again on 16 March 1941 and then on 14 May, this time causing irrevocable damage to the remaining elements of the structure (McGrath 1975, 459-461). It remained derelict for several years after the war while the Society considered whether to rebuild the hall. Finally, in 1955, the site was sold and it was subsequently redeveloped.

The Lamb Inn, No.50 Wine Street, located on the southern side of Wine Street roughly opposite the junction with Pithay. The Lamb Inn had been established on the site by 1586 (BRO 00347(5)) and was then or lately in the tenure of John Austine, saddler. In 1626 the foeffees of the Whitson Lands granted a lease to John Bradway with a convenant to allow rebuilding. In 1670 the inn was held by Thomas Biggs and probate inventories made at the time of his death in 1677 and his wife's death in 1687 record the rooms and their contents. The inventory for Biggs mentions fifteen rooms for accommodation, kitchen and buttery, and brewhouse (George & George 2005, 80-85). Ten years later the arrangement of the rooms was essentially the same, with additionally a cellar, stables and turret recorded (George & George 2005, 156-160). In 1698 the inn was leased to Onesiphorous Tyndall with the requirement to spend £200 on the building. In 1700 two stables and the rooms over them were purchased from Bradway by Tyndall (Leech 1997, 197).
When it was drawn in 1823 (BRSMG M2357; M2358), the building was a gabled, jettied house of three storeys and attic with a three-window range. It was of probable seventeenth-century date, and the façade presumably dated mainly to the rebuilding by Tyndall. The ground floor was largely occupied by a shopfront with a central entrance and windows on its east and west sides. At the west end of the façade at ground floor there was a gabled porch with carving below gable covering an entrance with fretwork gates. At first-floor level there was a wide canted bay with ten lights, and one light to each end. The jettied second floor was supported by a bracket at its eastern end. The fenestration comprised three six by six pane sash windows. The gable end was hung with slates or tiles and at the centre there was a six-light transomed window under a drip-moulding. The gabled roof was pantiled. Evidence for the interior of the building comes from a drawing made by Hugh O'Neill in 1823 during demolition of the building. The eastern wall of the building is all that remains and this is supported by long timber props. Seventeenth-century, or earlier, fireplaces are recorded in the western wall of the building (towards its northern end) at ground-, first- and second-floor levels. A number of doors and sections of panelling are shown propped against the wall.
The porch is likely to have led to the stables and rooms to the rear of the main building. Latterly it appears to have served a building at the rear, probably No.51 Wine Street. In notes accompanying a painting by O'Neill made before demolition (BRSMG M2357) G. W. Braikenridge records that "under the Porch late the Warehouse of Messrs. Holland Jackson & Schimmelpenning Dry Salters was formerly the Lamb Inn .... & the House has from the arrangement of the Rooms all the appearance of having been built for an Inn" (Notes, B7). The warehouse was listed at No.51 Wine Street in the 1819 Bristol directory.
Old Limekiln" Gloucestershire LXXI.4 (1915).

KNOWN_AS: Iron Foundry in Boars Head Yard

MONUMENT_DESC: A Buried land surface recorded during evaluation and subsequent excavation at Katherine Farm, Avonmouth (21420 and 21421). The deposit was identified at approximately 5m aOD and was radiocarbon dated to 5879 +/- 70 BP (NZA-12478) and 6866 +/- 50 BP (NZA-12495) (4910-4550 cal BC and 5790-5590 cal BC) from samples taken from the top and bottom of the deposit. Analysis of the deposit suggested that it had formed in a semi-terrestrial environment and that reed like vegetation had been present. Charcoal fragments within the deposit might suggest burning of this vegetation as a result of human acticvitiy, although no direct anthropogenic evidence was recovered.

Two medieval ditches recorded during evaluation and excavation at Katherine Farm in 1998. Artefact recovered from the fills of these ditches suggest a 13th-14th century date and are likely to be associated with agricultural enclosure and drainage of the levels. Other finds frm the fills including fired clay suggest that the nearby Katherine Farm has a medieval date of origin.

KNOWN_AS: Army Ordnance Department (A.O.D.) store north of Washingpool Farm
MONUMENT_DESC:
Army Ordnance Department (A.O.D.) store located appro9ximately 110 metres to the north of Washingpool Farm. The store was built in 1918 to serve National Filling Factory No.23 and is recorded by a plan in the National Archives (MUN 4/1753) dated 27 November 1918. The building measured approximately 60 metres from east to west and was 10 metres wide.
The shell of the building was extant in 1946 but the roof had been removed by that date. The remainder of the structure was subsequently demolished.

KNOWN_AS: Southern hospital at National Filling Factory No.23, Chittening
MONUMENT_DESC:
Southern of two hospital serving National Filling Factory No.23, Chittening. The hospital was located on the southern side of Smoke Lane and was built in 1918. It is recorded by a plan in the National Archives (MUN 4/1753) dated 27 November 1918 and had a cruciform plan.
The building was extant in 1946 but was subsequently demolished. Part of the south wall survives.

KNOWN_AS: Inspection offices at National Filling Factory No.23, Chittening
MONUMENT_DESC:
Inspection offices for the National Filling Factory No.23, Chittening, located on the northern side of Smoke Lane. The building was constructed in 1918 and is recorded by a plan in the National Archives (MUN 4/1753) dated 27 November 1918. The building measured approximately 40 metres from east to west and was 10 metres wide.
The building was extant in 1946 but was subsequently demolished.

No.9 Wine Street, located on the northern side of Wine Street. The building was constructed as the western of a pair of houses with No.10 Wine Street (BUAD 1696M) and was a jettied, gabled house of three-storeys and attic, of which the main, south-east facing, elevation and roof, at least, dated to the seventeenth century. The building had a one-window range with the ground floor comprising a shopfront. Above the fenestration consisted of a single canted bay window containing six-over-six pane sashes. A pentice over this extended across the entire width of the elevation. Theere was a similar bay at second-floor level, again with a full-width pentice roof. The attic window in the centre of the gable contained a pair of casements apparently set in moulded openings. There was an exterior collar above lintel level in the gable. A tall brick chimneystack was sited on the west wall. The building was drawn in 1826 as part of a view of this part of the north side of Wine Street by T. L. Rowbotham (BRSMG M2343). At that date there were large signboards fixed to the pentice roofs and the upper part of the shopfront advertising the building as "NOTTINGHAM HOUSE" and the shop as the premises of "GOSS & FOWLER."
Doorways through the party wall had been created between Nos.9 and 10 by the late 1880s. The building survived into the first half of the twentieth century but was subsequently removed and the site redeveloped.

The Merchant Tailor's Almshouse, located on the east side of Merchant Street. The Society of Merchant Tailors' had established its almshouse in four tenements it owned on the western side of Merchant Street by 1630 (Fox, 1880 25). Its role seems to have been to provide accommodation for members of the Company in reduced circumstances, in accordance with the responsibility placed on the wardens by the charters which established the Company at the end of the fourteenth century.
The present building was erected as a replacement for the earlier almshouse in 1701, largely using the Company's own funds. The building is of two storeys with ranges arranged on three sides of a central courtyard to give a U-shaped plan. It is a rendered brick structure (one of the earliest brick buildings in Bristol) with ashlar dressings. The main entrance doorway has a bracketed shell hood and above is a large, painted panel bearing the arms of the Merchant Tailor's Guild, and flanking it the inscription "ANNODM/1701." The almshouse was designed to provide accommodation for nine people, with each range of the building having three individual dwellings.
By the late 1820s the Company of Merchant Tailors' was effectively defunct, having only one surviving member, a Mr. Isaac Amos (Manchee, 1831 205). The almshouse was inspected around the same time and was described as "a handsome and capacious building, well adapted for the accommodation and comfort of the description of persons for whom it was designed; but in its present state, and under the circumstances to which the company . is reduced, it must be considered as producing very little benefit as a charity, and as depending for its continuance on a very precarious support" (Manchee, 1831 222).
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/40/485).

No.21 Wine Street. The building was located on the north side of the street, the third to the east of Pithay. It was a four-storey, two-bay jettied house, although it appears to have originally been two properties, built as a single development, which were later made into one. The ground floor was a shopfront with entrances at either end. The first floor fenestration was formed by two bays containing sashes, while both the second and third floors contained three-light sashes. The building had a double hipped roof and there was a chimney stack on the west side.
The building, occupied in the later nineteenth-century by E. John's Hat Shop, was demolished in the 1880s for road widening.

No.36 Old Market Street, located on the nrothern side of Old Market Street. The building was probably constructed in the seventeenth century. The roof appears to be gabled and parallel to the street at the front but is hipped to the rear.
In 1875 the building was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by Frederick White, pork butcher.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/12/1642).

KNOWN_AS: Parish boundary marker stones at Fremantle Lane
MONUMENT_DESC: Two parish boundary marker stones set, side by side, in a boundary wall on the south side of Fremantle Lane, Cotham. Both stones are of Pennant sandstone and stand to a height of approximately 0.75 metres. The stone was observed in May 2001 and part of an inscription was noted to survive on the western of the two stones. Most of this was illegible but the first letter was "P". It was also noted that the surfaces of both were suffering from delamination.

Upper Arcade, a covered shopping arcade on the north side of The Horsefair. The arcade, one of the earliest in the country, was constructed in 1824 to a design by James Foster jun. (Ison, 1952 34) and ran from south-east to north-west between The Horsefair and Bond Street. It was the northern half of a long arcade divided by The Horsefair. The design was in a Greek Revival style and clearly drew on that of the Burlington Arcade in London of 1818 (Morrison, 2003 101). It consisted of a central footway 92 metres long with shops on its eastern and western sides. The divisions between the thirty-seven shops were marked by fluted classical pilasters. The arcade had a pitched glass-panelled roof supported on what appear to have been moulded cast iron roof trusses. There were iron gratings to provide ventilation between the roofline and the shops.
The arcade was destroyed by bombing during the Second World War (Warne, 1943 15) and the site redeveloped in the mid 1950s for a department store.

Lower Arcade, a covered shopping arcade located on the northern side of Broadmead. The arcade, one of the earliest in the country, was constructed in 1824 to a design by James Foster jun. (Ison, 1952 34) and runs from south-east to north-west between Broadmead and The Horsefair. It was the southern half of a long arcade divided by The Horsefair, the northern half, the Upper Arcade (BUAD 616M), being destroyed by bombing during the Second World War.
The design clearly drew on that of the Burlington Arcade in London of 1818 (Morrison, 2003 101) and was in a Greek Revival style. The external, south-facing, elevation on Broadmead front has a Pennant sandstone ashlar plinth supporting a freestone ashlar façade and fluted Ionic columns on either side of the entrance. On either side of these are plate-glass shopfronts flanked by pilasters. Above is an entablature bearing the legend "THE ARCADE" with a frieze of palmettes above and a tall parapet.
Internally the arcade consists of a central footway 82 metres long with shops on its eastern and western sides. Large two-storey Ionic pilasters between pairs of shops support architraves on either of the arcade. Above is a frieze containing decorative iron grilles for a ventilation system. The cornice over the frieze supports wide, triangular-section cast-iron cross-members, panelled on the lower side and with moulded lion's heads on the faces. Between these large skylights provide the light for the central walkway. The individual shops are single-bay units of three storeys and attic with a basement and are constructed of brick bonded in a grey-white lime mortar with charcoal inclusions. They originally appear to have conformed to a similar plan, each pair of shops having a mirrored plan. The ground floor originally consisted of a single-bay shop with a recessed entrance doorway on the northern or southern side. In the northern or southern corner at the rear of the shop there was a spiral stair which served all floors of the building. A partition wall separated off a small rectangular storeroom from the main area of the shop. The ground-floor storeroom and the landings for the stair on the upper floors were accommodated in a projecting rear block. At first- and second-floor the stair opened on to a small landing with a short rail, the balusters having a plain, square cross-section. This gave on to a single main room with a chimneybreast on either the northern or southern wall. The attic storey consisted of a single L-shaped space with the stair and landing enclosed by a partition wall.
The roof on each row of shops is a mansard with projecting eight-flue stacks on the line of the party wall between each pair of shops. The roof was recovered with concrete tiles in the late-twentieth century.
An arched alley, accessed by a door from the cellar of each shop, runs the full length of the arcade beneath the central footway.
The arcade has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/40/479).

The Myrtle Tree public house, No.48 St. Thomas Street. The building, which stood on the east side of the street, was a three-storey, single-bay house with a front gable and pantiled roof. There was a shopfront at ground floor and the entrance was on the north side. There were sashes at first and second floor (attic) level. A chimney stack projected from the roof on the south side. The building appears to have been erected at the same time as Nos.47, 49 and 50, as part of the same development.
The public house went out of use between 1883 and 1888 and appears to have reverted to use as a private dwelling. It was empty by the end of nineteenth-century and was demolished soon after.

Temple Back pottery, located to the east of Temple Church, on the far side of Petticoat Lane. Richard Frank left his pottery in Redcliff for this new location and seems to have amalgamated his business with the next door Water Lane pottery [BUAD 87M]. Joseph Ring took over the business in after marrying Frank's daughter Elizabeth and, with the help of Anthony Hassells, the pottery began to produce "Queen's Ware," a cream -coloured earthenware, in 1786. Ring died in April 1788 and the business was taken over by his brother Robert Ring and Henry Carter. Joseph Ring II and John Decimus Pountney came into the partnership in 1813 and the firm traded as Pountney and Carter until Pountney's death in 1852. In 1822 the pottery consisted of ranges of buildings arranged around four kilns, two adjacent gloss kilns and two biscuit kilns. This arrangement was retained into the early 1880s when it was recorded by the 1:500 Ordnance Survey first edition plan. The throwing room was on the west side of the kilns while the Dripping and Placing Room, the Hot House and the Enamel kiln were on their north side. A yard separated these buildings from the Plate Makers, Dish Makers shops and the Gig Room. The Mill Houses and steam engine were along the south-east boundary of the site. The pottery closed in 1886 and the centre of the site had been redeveloped by August 1896 as a Day Industrial School. The site is now occupied by The Crescent Centre.

KNOWN_AS: Chapel of St. John, Baldwin Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
Chapel, or possibly a house known as the 'Chapel of St. John'. The building was located on the north side of Baldwin Street. Taken down 1819, when some drawings made by Mr.Henry Smith, later copied by Hugh O'Neill. The ground on which the chapel stood was, by 1822, covered by a warehouse in the occupation of a Leather Factor, then the third house from St.Nicholas Steps. 
O'Neill illustrated the inside of the east gable end and top of the wall. in the gable was a medieval-style window with two-centred arch; two cinquefoil-headed lights below a quatrefoil. A little distance below the inner sill were two plain corbels, with, slightly further out, two brackets. Beneath the window was a small opening, possibly a piscina, with cinquefoil head within a square top. Found in the building were the keystone from a fireplace (M2250), and portions of a chimney-piece or frieze (M2251-2255). Six corbels, all with human heads, were purchased by Mr.Attwood, drawn by O'Neill (M2287-2289), some used at Back Hall, one used as a keystone to an arch leading to Coronation Court, off Back Street.

The hermitage, Redcliff Hill, located at the south end of the Redcliff Pit burial ground. The hermitage was associated with the hospital of St. John the Baptist (BUAD 1055M) and was in existence by the fourteenth century. It was recorded, in passing, by William Worcestre in 1480 as lying to the west [sic] of the hospital's church (Neale 2000, 248-249) and was located in a garden, known as Redrock Garden (Leech 2001) which became a burial for the Society of Friends in the seventeenth century.
The hermitage is a small chamber cut into the sandstone cliff and appears never to have been the subject of archaeological recording. Taylor, visiting the monument in 1878 (BUAD 2465), noted that it was "entire and unaltered" with the original arch over the entrance. It had two seats cut out of the rock (Maclean 1878-79, 7-8). Of these only one is now evident and the rear part of the hermitage was cut away to create the foundations for the Coliseum public house in Redcliffe Parade East. A seventeenth-century freestone memorial is fixed to the north wall of the monument.
The hermitage is a Scheduled Ancient Monument (AV103).
Up and down lynchets at right angles to contours  December 1946 (CPE-UK-1869-4174?).

KNOWN_AS: Lynchets and possible pillow mound, north of Pond Field Farm
MONUMENT_DESC: Confirmed lynchets, but one mound between ST61557682 and ST61587696 may be along pillow mound without side ditches.

The White Lodge, located some 17 metres to the south-east of Upper Maudlin Street. The building was constructed c.1588 as one of two lodges to the gardens of the Sir John Yonge's Great House (BUAD 420M) in St. Augustine's Back which extended from Trenchard Street across Stony Hill. The building was of three-storeys with a cross-gabled roof and a turret on the west side. In plan it measured 8 metres from south-west to north-east and was 6.8 metres wide. The south-east facing elevation had a two-window range with two gables. At ground floor the fenestration consisted of a four-light window. There was a three-light window at first-floor level and a two-light window in the attics. All of the windows had stone hood moulds above. The south-west facing elevation had a single gable, small windows lighting the attic and a single-flue chimneystack at the apex of the gable. The turret at the north--west corner of the building was octagonal with crenellations around the top and contained a spiral stair. There was another chimneystack at the centre of the roof. The main entrance to the building appears to have been at the western end of the north-west facing elevation. This led to into a lobby which gave on to the stair in the turret and the three ground-floor rooms, two on the south side of the building and the third at the north-east corner. In the corner of one of the rooms there was a stone chimney-piece bearing the date 1588. Above was a pair of compasses surmounted by a dove carrying an olive branch in its beak (Braikenridge Notes A32).
The antiquarian G. W. Braikenridge records that in the 1820s the building was occupied by a Mr. Willcocks, who had lived there for twenty years. The chimneypiece was extant in June 1823 although the tower had been subject to "much" alteration in the period of Willcock's residence (Braikenridge Notes A32). The building was still standing in the later 1860s (Winstone 1971, pl.27) but had been demolished by the early 1880s. No record appears to have been made of the building before its demolition although there are watercolour drawings of the 1820s by T. L. Rowbotham (BRSMG M2562) and Samuel Jackson (BRSMG M2577). It is also visible in some early photographs of this part of Bristol.

KNOWN_AS: Canteen at National Filling Factory No.23, Chittening
MONUMENT_DESC:
Canteen at National Filling Factory No.23, Chittening, located on the southern side of Smoke Lane. The building was constructed in 1918 and is recorded by a plan in the National Archives (MUN 4/1753) dated 27 November 1918. The building measured approximately 53 metres from east to west, was 43 metres wide and had a series of northlight roofs.
The building was extant in 1946 but was subsequently demolished.

KNOWN_AS: House on the north side of Brewer's Place, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC: House located on the north side of Brewer's Place. The building formed the north side of Brewer's Place, and was a small single-bay, two-storey building with a hipped pantile roof. The ground floor elevation has a large four by three pane window while in the first floor was a single sash. The entrance door was at the western end of the south side of the building in Brewer's Place. The façade of the building appears to be of early nineteenth-century date but may in fact have been a refronting of a much earlier structure, possibly of post-medieval or earlier date.

The White Hart public house, located on the eastern side of Bedminster Parade. The two-bay building was of three storeys with a rendered elevation to Bedminster Parade. The ground floor had a double door at the north of the elevation and another towards the south end. There was a single storey extension to the south end of the building. There was also a projecting chimney stack in the middle of the south wall which appears to have been set within the extension at ground floor.

KNOWN_AS: Hollybrook Brick Works, Clarence Road, St. George
MONUMENT_DESC: Brick works located 170 metres to the north of Clarence Road. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucester Sheet LXXII.10) surveyed in 1881 records three kilns and there was a clay pit 30 metres to the north of the main building (at ST 63740 74588). The site has been redeveloped.

KNOWN_AS: Bourne Chapel, Two Mile Hill Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Bourne Chapel, located on the south side of Two Mile Hill Road. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucester Sheet LXXII.15) published in 1882 records the chapel as a Primitive Methodist chapel.

The Chequers public house, located on the west side of Lodge Road. The building is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucester Sheet LXXII.15) published in 1882 but it would appear to have been demolished by the time the second edition plan was published in 1903.

KNOWN_AS: Boot and Shoe Factory, Lodge Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Boot and shoe factory located on the west side of Lodge Road. The factory was constructed in the late-nineteenth or very early-twentieth century.

KNOWN_AS: Cemetery at Church Street, St. Philips
MONUMENT_DESC:
Cemetery, located on the north side of Church Street, St. Philips. The cemetery was probably private and was not recorded by the 1828 survey of Bristol by Plumley and Ashmead, suggesting that it was established after this date. It was however recorded by Ashmead's survey of 1854 and the plot measured approximately 40 metres (along the Church Street frontage) by 37 metres. The entrance appears to have been off Clarence Place. The cemetery was one of those closed under the 1854 Act and therefore was in use for interment for only around twenty-five years at most. By the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.17) surveyed in 1883 the site had been partly redeveloped, with housing on Church Street, smaller buildings (possibly also housing) along its northern edge and a large building project towards the middle of the cemetery from its east side.
The site was redeveloped again in the second half of the twentieth century and now lies mainly beneath Nos.2-24 Hassell Drive and Hassell Drive itself.
Lynchets, visible from M32 {1} {2}

KNOWN_AS: Gloucestershire Regiment South African War memorial, Queen's Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Gloucestershire Regiment memorial, commemorating the South African War or Boer War (1899-1902). The memorial is located in the centre of Queen's Road and is a bronze figure of a soldier with a rifle by the sculptor Onslow Whiting, who also designed three of the bronze panels on the Boer War memorial at Plymouth Hoe, set on a granite plinth. The statue was unveiled by Field Marshal the Right Honourable Frederick Sleigh, Earl Roberts VC, KG, KP, GCB, GCSI, GCIE (1832-1914), last Commander-in-Chief of the British Army, on 4th March 1905 (Merritt 2002, 34-35).
The memorial has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/9/956).

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Cotham Grammar School, Cotham Lawn Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
Cotham Tower, a windmill later converted to a prospect tower, now beneath the grounds of Cotham Grammar School. The windmill was constructed c1670 and late-nineteenth and twentieth century photographs and cartography indicate it was a circular tower of coursed rubble, approximately 5.2 metres in diameter. Millerd's 1670 map of Bristol and Jean Rocque's 1742 map depict it as a tower mill with four sails. Millerd's prospect of the city of 1673 and that by the Bucks in 1734, on the other hand, seem to suggest that it was a post mill (Bryant, 2000).
According to Latimer the windmill was leased by William Hulme of Mary-le-port Street and converted into a snuff mill in 1754. Hulme went bankrupt in 1757 and the site, by then part of the Cotham Lodge estate, was bought by Sydenham Teast in 1772 (BRO 40376 Bundle 1). Teast sold the land to Charles Partridge the same year, the legal documents describing the property as "all that Windmill situate in a Close of Meadow or Pasture Ground called Windmill Close together with all other Buildings standing near thereto. And also All that the said Close of ground called Windmill Close now in the Occupation of Thomas Evans and Company."
Latimer states that the mill was rebuilt as a prospect tower in the base of the windmill in 1779 (Latimer, 1887 296) although the degree of reconstruction is unknown. There was an arched entrance at ground level and ogee-headed sash windows evenly spaced around the top of the tower. The structure also had mock arrowloop openings and crenellations around the top. The window openings were edged in brick and "loopholes" at the foot of the tower were edged in slag blocks, suggesting that all of these features dated to the conversion of the mill to a prospect tower. It was associated with Cotham Lodge to the east until that building was demolished in 1846. After this it formed part of the grounds of Tower House, occupied by Francis Fry.
The tower fell into disrepair in the twentieth century, and it and Hartfield House were acquired for the extension of the playing fields of Cotham Grammar School in the early 1950s by which time the tower had been listed (Grade III). This did not prevent demolition however, and the tower was removed during the summer of 1953 (Bryant, 2000).

POSTAL_ADDRESS: King David Residence, St. Michael's Hill
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Nunnery of St. Mary Magdalen. The house was located at the foot of St. Michael's Hill, on the eastern side of St. Michael's Hill. It was founded by Eva, wife of Robert, FitzHarding in 1173 (Graham in Page 1907, 93) and endowed with land in Southmead (apparently the manor of Southmead).
The layout and extent of the nunnery has not been established. The precinct appears to have been defined on the eastern and southern sides by Upper Maudlin Street and St. Michael's Hill, although its northern and western boundaries are less clear.
The church consisted of a nave and three aisles with four arches and William Worcestre, writing in 1480, gives the (probably internal) length of the church as approximately 15 metres (Neale 2000, 228-229). The church seems to have stood on Upper Maudlin Street and Dr. Roger Leech suggests that the tower of the church, which is mentioned in the post-dissolution sale documents, may have been located at the junction of St. Michael's Hill and Upper Maudlin Street (Longman 2001, 6-7). The burial ground for the nunnery probably lay immediately to the north-west of the church but the spatial organisation of the ancillary buildings is currently unknown. In the mid-fourteenth century St. Augustine's Abbey granted the nunnery four adjacent houses (Fry 1910, 368) although it is not clear whether this represented an enlargement of the precinct.
The house was dissolved in late-June or early-August 1536. The site was sold by the Crown to the London merchant Henry Brayne, who had also acquired St. James Priory (BUAD 1024M), and the priory buildings appear then to have been used as a residence (Longman 2001, 4-5). The manor of Southmead, including the wood known as Magdalene Wood, were sold to Richard Andrews of Hayles (Gairdner & Brodie 1880, 76).
Part of one of the buildings of the nunnery on Upper Maudlin Street seems to have still been extant in the latter part of the nineteenth-century and was by then the King David Inn. Internal and external photographs (published by Winstone) and drawings by James Stewart in 1751, T. L. Rowbotham in 1828 (BRSMG M2562) and Samuel Loxton in the early twentieth century (Bristol Reference Library M948 and M950) of these buildings exist.
The King David Inn was demolished in the early twentieth century and the present building erected. Part of the site was archaeologically investigated in 2000 and 2001 (BUAD 3591; BUAD 3617; BUAD 3934) when structural elements of the medieval nunnery and inhumations probably associated with the burial ground were recorded.

KNOWN_AS: Broad Plain Soap and Candle Works
MONUMENT_DESC:
Broad Plain Soap and Candle Works. The Broad Plain factory was established in 1783 by the Fripp family and it was run by Samuel Fripp & Co. in the early nineteenth century. The 1828 map of Bristol surveyed by Plumley and Ashmead records the factory lying to the south of Straight Street and reached by an (extant) hauling way off Broad Plain. In 1841 the business merged with the soapmakers T. Thomas & C. J. Thomas (established in 1824 in Red Lion Yard, off Redcliff Street (Sommerville, 1991 31)) to become Thomas, Fripp & Thomas.
The business expanded and laid emphasis on research into improvements in the quality of the products and of production methods, including the taking out of a patent on a process to recover glycerine in 1878 (Diaper, 1987 226). There was also considerable rebuilding in the early 1880s. The old pan building was seriously damaged by fire in March 1902. The works was taken over by Lever Brothers in 1914 and continued to operate as a soap factory until its closure in 1954.
Many of the buildings are listed including the warehouse (Grade II) and factory on either side of Straight Street (Grade II). The former was built in 1865 to a design by W. B. Gingell and refronted in 1884 with its current facade while the latter dated to 1841-43, with its upper floors being rebuilt in 1882. The majority of the old pan building survives as does a shed adjoining the southern wall of that building and accessible from the car park on Old Bread Street. These are, however, in a poor state of repair.

The Central Electric Lighting Station, Temple Back, built in 1893 as the first electrical power station in Bristol. The building originally had two chimneys "each 180 f[ee]t high and 9 f[ee]t across the inside of the base" (Buchanan & Cossons, 1969 168-169). At the eastern end was the engine room and the hoist still survives (Boore, 1994 3). The building was in use as a store for South Western Electricity Board into the 1980s. Only the west part of the station (fronting Temple Back) now survives, however, the block adjacent to the Floating Harbour having been demolished in 1991.
The building has a single storey and nineteen bays. The facade is of red brick with window mouldings of Bath stone and Pennant Sandstone while the decorative lower facings are of Granite.

Nos.14-16 Christmas Street A group of four houses located on the south and south-east side of Christmas Street, opposite the end of Narrow Lewins Mead. The 3 westerly examples survived until c.1970. All appear to have been refronted. The rears, to the Frome, were recorded by O'Neill in 1823 (M2913). Westernmost (later No.16) of 2 storeys with hipped roof, 1-window range, ground-floor not visible, 3-light first-floor window. Next (No.15) of 4 storeys with hipped (?) roof, 2-window range, sashes except right-hand ground-floor, which 2-light or double sash; strings between first/second and second/third floors; 2 top storeys slate-hung; small left-hand ground-floor extension. This and the next (No.14) above river arches of unknown exact function. No.14 of 4 storeys and attic, gable and part-gable to rear; 2-window range; second-floor jettied, strings over first to third floors; top 3 storeys slate-hung; lateral stack(s) on west side; 1 window to attic; all sashes; window boxes to first-floor. The rear of the next building to the east jettied out over the river; 4 storeys and attic, gable visible; 1-window range, mostly sashes, but small second window at far left-hand of ground-floor; strings between all floors, possibly representing small jetties; whole wall slate-hung.

The Drawbridge, a bascule or lifting bridge connecting St. Augustine's Back or St. Augustine's Parade with the Quay. The first bridge at this location, originally built in 1714, was rebuilt in 1755 and widened in 1796. A two-leaf bascule bridge at its western end, the remainder of the crossing being a stone causeway or approach projecting from the Quay, carried on 3 piers and 2 pointed arches, with a cutwater between the arches on the northern side (both sides?). Post and rail railings on the approach, post and chain on the lifting portions. Two small structures, one either side of the eastern approach, may have been toll houses. The northern example octagonal (?) with pyramidal roof, the other apparently circular, and with domed roof, both roofs capped by finials.

Green's, or Tomb's, Dock, located on the western bank of St. Augustine's Reach. The dock was established by the early 1740s and is recorded by Jean Rocque's map of Bristol of 1742 as a dry dock and a drawbridge (BUAD 748M) across the entrance to the dock is also recorded. The dock was operated by Richard Tombs in 1744 and was apparently used for shipbuilding. It was around 130 metres from east to west, 17 metres wide and included a launching slip. Cartographic evidence, notably Plumley and Ashmead's survey of Bristol in 1828 and Ashmead's mid-nineteenth century 1:600 plans, indicate that there were also a number of ancillary buildings within the shipyard.
It was taken over by John Green in 1815 and a painting by T. L. Rowbotham made in 1825 (BUAD 1945; BRSMG M2923) records the entrance to the dock and the drawbridge over the gates. The dock survived until 1883 when it was bought by the City Corporation and filled in. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.4), however, indicates that the gates and footbridge survived for a short time after the infilling was complete.
Rowe's leadworks (BUAD 1199M) was developed on the site of the dock in 1884.

No. 55 St. Michael's Hill was located on the south west side of the hill. The plot of land on which the building stood was leased from Eusebius Brookes by William Rufford in 1683. The building was constructed between 1683 and 1689 (Leech 2000 65), probably as one of a pair with No.57 St. Michael's Hill (BUAD 1453M), and was a three-storey, single bay house of rendered stone rubble with a hipped pantile roof. The original form of the building is uncertain, athough it probably had a gabled roof. There was a chimney stack on the south side of the roof.
The façade was probably altered in the eighteenth or early nineteenth century, when the windows were altered to sashes. The door and parapet were probably also added at this date. The main entrance door was on the north side of the elevation and was surrounded by an arch, possibly made of ashlar limestone. The door itself was panelled and had a fan light above it. There was a single sash window on each floor, although the opening for the second storey window was smaller that the others.
The first occupant of the house to be recorded by the ratebooks was William Ruffet (probably William Rufford) in 1695 (Leech 2000, 65). The ratebooks record occupancy throughout the eighteenth century.
The building was demolished in the 1950's and its site is now open ground.

No. 57 St. Michael's Hill, located on the south west side of the hill and on the south side of Tankards Close. The plot of land on which the building stood was leased from Eusebius Brookes by William Rufford in 1683. The building was constructed between 1683 and 1689 (Leech 2000, 65), probably as one of a pair with No.55 St. Michael's Hill [BUAD 1452M]. The building was a three-store, single-bay rendered house was probably constructed of stone rubble. The original form of the building is uncertain, although it was probably gabled. There was a chimney stack on the north side of the roof.
The façade was probably altered in the eighteenth or early nineteenth century, when the windows were altered to sashes. The door and parapet may have been added at the same time. The façade was symmetrical to that of No.55 St. Michael's Hill next door. The main entrance door was on the south side of the elevation and was contained within an arch, possibly of ashlar limestone. The door itself was wooden and had a fan light above it. There was a single sash window on each floor, although the opening for the second storey window was smaller that the others.
The first occupant of the house to be recorded by the ratebooks was Daniel Pill in 1705, although the entry in the ratebook comments that "a house yt is building" (Leech 2000, 65). The ratebooks record occupancy throughout the eighteenth century.
The building was demolished in the 1950s and the site is now open ground.

Malthouse, No.16 Charles Street, located on the southern side of Charles Street. The building appears to have been extant by 1828 and the Ashmead 1:600 plan of 1854 suggests that it was then in commercial use. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.15) records the building as a malthouse. It was still extant in the early twentieth century but had apparently been demolished by 1949 and a new building constructed on the site.

Cote, located on the southern side of Cote House Lane. The building was constructed in the early eighteenth century and is a stone rubble house of two storeys. The building was reached by a carriage drive from the Downs past an entrance lodge. A designed formal garden (SMR 300) was created to the west of the house in the early nineteenth century by Mrs Jean Anderson and John Wedgewood.
The main house has a Grade II* listing (901-1/28/1982) while the lodge (901-1/31/1987) and the Orangery (901-1/28/1984) have Grade II listings. The gate piers of the Orangery have a separate Grade II listing (901-1/28/1983).

KNOWN_AS: South Liberty Brick and Tile Works
MONUMENT_DESC: Brick and Tile Works Somerset Sheet VI.10 (1931).

The White Hart inn on the east side of Broad Street. The inn occupied the site of two buildings during the Middle Ages. The northern of these was a dwelling first recorded in 1295. An inn called "le Hart" had been established there by 1442 and it was then occupied by Martin Whyte. The southern tenement may have been incorporated into the inn by 1438.
The fifteenth and sixteenth century form of the inn is currently unknown. The buildings appear to have been refronted in the seventeenth century but remained architecturally legible as two structures. The southern building was a four-storey, two-bay jettied house. The ground floor was occupied by a shop front. The jettied first floor was supported by a large pillar at the south end of the frontage and that part of the frontage was recessed to form an entrance porch. The first floor had two bay windows with sash on the south side of the southern of these. There was a two-light large casement in the south face of the building where it projected forward of the next door property. The second floor was also jettied and had a similar arrangement of windows except that the narrow sash window in the south face of the building had only a single light. The third floor was similar although there was no casement in the south face of the building. Full width pentices divided the first and second, and second and third, floors. The roof contained small attic dormers. The northern building was a four-storey, three-bay jettied building. The building had a classical frontage with tall sashes. The jettied first floor overhung the footway and contains twelve over twelve-pane sash windows, while those of the second and third floors had eight over eight-pane sashes. Above each of the first-floor windows there were segmental-arched pediments, while above the second floor sashes there were standard pediments. The eaves of the roof projected well forward of the frontage of the building. The inn sign, a recumbent white hart, was located on the southern house set on a curved support projecting from the centre of the frontage above the ground floor.
Something of the internal form of the inn was recorded in a probate inventory of 1650. This records ten guest rooms, as well as the parlour, a hall which also contained the "little Buttery", the kitchen and a room for the maid (George & George 2002, 166-182). The inn was then leased by George Pearce.
The Quaker James Naylor stopped at the inn after riding into Bristol on a donkey on Palm Sunday in 1656 (Thomas 1971, 257).
The building was demolished in the mid-1860s to allow the construction of the Grand Hotel (BUAD 1667M).

KNOWN_AS: Quarry north of Kings Weston Road
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry located some 250 metres to the north of Kings Weston Road. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire sheet LXXI.07) published in 1885. There was a limekiln (SMR 20838) at the foot of the quarry face on the south side of the quarry.

KNOWN_AS: J. Watts Memorial Drinking Fountain, Wellington Hill West
MONUMENT_DESC:
J. Watts Memorial Drinking Fountain, located on the north-eastern side of the junction of Kellaway Avenue and Wellington Hill West. The structure is a cast iron fountain set on a circular Pennant sandstone plinth and bears a plinth commemorating J. Watts with the date 1900.
The drinking fountain has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/53/1415).

Manor House, located on the west side of Wells Road. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.15) published in 1885 records the building as being set some 22 metres back from the road within a large garden with a carriage drive from the road and a formal garden to the rear. It had a roughly rectangular plan, measuring 20 metres north-south by 12 metres east-west. There were two greenhouses against the north side of the wall around the garden. The building was still extant in the early 1930s.

Eastfield Dairy Farm, located on the east side of Henleaze Road. A farm had been established on the site by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.08) published in 1881. This was occupied by a W. J. Roper and was subsequently taken over by T. J. Roper, presumably his son. In 1906 the farm was converted to a dairy farm (BRO Building Plans Vol.56 fo.31) and a pasteurising plant was added in 1944 (BRO Building Plans 190/51). Roper sold the farm to Unigate dairies in July 1966 and it continued to be operated as a dairy by them until the late twentieth century.

A pair of cottages, located on the east side of Henleaze Road. The cottages were extant by the time of the survey of the parish of Westbury-on-Trym made by Y. and J. P. Sturge in 1825. They were recorded in 1841 by the tithe survey for the parish as houses and gardens occupied by Widow Tolemy and William John Wilkins. The cottages were demolished and rebuilt in June 1922 for Bristol Corporation (BRO Building Plans 190/51).

A quarry to the west of Brentry Road. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.04) published in 1881. The site of the quarry is now beneath Northover Road.

Brook Cottage at Bedminster Down, located some 300 metres to the south of the railway. The building is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.09) published in 1885 and has a roughly rectangular plan, measuring 4 metres east-west by 9 metres north-south. The building has subsequently been demolished.

Yew Tree Farm, located some 200 metres to the north of Bridgwater Road. The farm is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.09) published in 1885. The farmyard is shown 25 metres to the north-east of the farmhouse. The farm is extant.

Ropewalk, located to the west of Frayne's Colliery (SMR 5773) The ropewalk is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.06) published in 1894 and measured approximately 90 metres north-west to south-east by 10 metres wide. The site has been redeveloped as the Cala Trading estate.

Brentry House The house was built 1802 for William Payne and was designed by John Adey Repton. It is a two-storey structure of limestone rubble and Pennant ashlar with a five-window range. The house has a slate hipped roof. The grounds were landscaped by Repton's father Humphry at the same time (SMR 2403).
The house had been acquired by John Cave of the Bristol banking family by the 1820s and he expanded the house, the grounds and diverted Charlton Road to the south in 1825. Cave lived at Brentry House until his death in the early 1840s and, according to the Westbury-on-Trym tithe survey of 1841, he then owned much of the land surrounding the house. Cave's son William inherited the property but by 1859 an Edward Clark was listed as the resident in the local directory and George Miller after 1868. The house and grounds were purchased in 1898 to provide an extension to a Royal Victoria Homes retreat for alcoholics in Horfield. Two villages were created, one, for women, was to the east of Brentry House and the other, for men, was to the north. The house itself housed the superintendent and officers. In 1922 the house became the Brentry Certified Institution (Jancar 1972, 24) and this use continued until the mid-1990s, the institution being absorbed into the National Health Service.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building Number 901-1/22/2044).

KNOWN_AS: The Hospital of St. John the Baptist
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Hospital of St. John the Baptist, sited on the western side of Redcliff Pit. The hospital was founded in the later-twelfth century and is known to have been in existence by 1186. There is some uncertainty over the precise location and extent of the hospital. Dr. Roger Leech argues, from post-medieval documentary and cartographic evidence, that the hospital precinct was defined by Jones Lane on the south and west sides and Redcliff Pit on the east. The land parcels of Nos.71-74 represent a post-medieval subdivision of the precinct (Leech pers comm.). Jones Lane itself may have originated as a slipway to the river for the hospital.
The community appears to have contained both sexes. Some of the early documents relating to the hospital refer to "brethren and sisters" and in 1317 Bishop Drokensford of Bath and Wells asked the master to accept the niece of Edmund de Wyntereshall as a secular sister (Scott Holmes, T. Religious Houses in Page 1969, 160).
The form of the hospital is uncertain but William Worcestre indicates that it had a church and cloister. His measurements suggest that both were of a relatively modest size (Neale 2000, 248-249). The water supply of the hospital was delivered via a feather from the Redcliffe pipe which ran across Redcliff Hill (Hobhouse 1887, 145) to discharge into a square pool or cistern at the centre of the cloister (Neale 2000, 248-249). A hermitage (BUAD 627M) was established in Redrock Garden to the west of the church in the fourteenth century. The hospital also took over responsibility for the Chapel of the Holy Spirit (BUAD 925M) in the churchyard of St. Mary Redcliff in the thirteenth century. In addition it owned the advowson of the rectory of Butcome and the vicarage of Backwell (Gairdner & Brodie 1903, 286).
The hospital was at the centre of some controversy at the beginning of the fifteenth-century because of allegations of Lollardy in the Hospital and mismanagement by the then prior, John Seyntpoull. A commission was appointed in 1404 to investigate the charges (Hudson 1988, 122n) and in 1411 the goods and estates of the hospital were sequestered by the Crown (Scott Holmes 1914, lx-lxi; 80; 83-84). By 1442 there was apparently only one brother in residence (Scott Holmes, T. Religious Houses in Page 1969, 160).
The hospital was surrendered to the Crown by the master, Richard Bromefield, in early March 1544 and the site, and much of the associated property, was sold in two lots to Dr. George Owen, physician to Henry VIII and a Fellow of Merton College, Oxford, in April of that year on condition that he funded the salary and accommodation of a resident priest to preach in the city on eight occasions each year (Gairdner & Brodie 1903, 93; 286). The buildings were apparently demolished soon after Owen's acquisition of the site (Latimer 1901, 176-177).

Canynges House, (also known as Canynges Chapel), located on the western side of Redcliff Street. The building was a substantial house belonging to the merchant William Canynges (1402-1474). It stood on a plot of land approximately 70 metres in length between Redcliff Street and the River Avon which was first developed in the twelfth century (Jones 1986, 7-8). It is not clear how much of the house was built for Canynges in the mid-fifteenth century and how much was an existing building.
The form of the house as a whole is uncertain but at the east end, close to Redcliff Street, there was a hall with cusped arch-brace roof trusses supported on carved corbels (although "Many of the Corbels in the Chapel were purchased by the late Mr. Birtill of Mr. Steele the Mason in St. Thomas Street & came originally from the Old Church of St. Thomas Bristol" (Braikenridge notes)). This part of the building was constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble and was 0.58 metres thick. At the west end of the wall were two blind segmental-headed arches with freestone mouldings. The western arch was 5 metres wide, while the eastern was narrower, spanning 3.60 metres and contained an ogee-headed piscina or stoup (BUAD 999A; BRSMG M2045). The hall had panelling to head height and galleries at first-floor level along the south and east sides. Mr. Lazarus Birtill discovered a fresco on the west wall after he had purchased the building in the early-nineteenth century, and this was retouched in 1805 by a Mr.Young, one of Birtill's relations. A small gothic doorway led into a room, possibly a parlour, on the west side of the hall. This had a floor of encaustic or slip over stamp tiles of probable mid-fifteenth century date.
Above the hall there was a tower described by William Worcestre, writing in 1480, as measuring 60 feet (18.4 metres) by 48 feet (14.7 metres) with four highly decorated bay windows. Worcestre also indicates that the internal decoration was rich (Neale 2000, 214-215) and the roof of the hall is known to have had a painted and gilded decorative scheme. The house also contained a private chapel after 1454 (Sherbourne 1985, 15).
Canynge's House appears to have been subdivided into three properties in the post-medieval period. The hall appears had carved benches fixed to the south and west walls in the second half of the seventeenth century. The building was considerably altered in the 1820s. The hall was "dismantled" in 1821-1822, when the altarpiece in the chapel was removed, and converted to a warehouse which was occupied in 1822 by Mr. Thomas Chamberlain, a brush- and mop-maker.
