In 1826 the property was owned by Richard Badham of the Champion of Wales public house on Broad Quay, and in the tenure of William Naish, straw bonnet maker as recorded by Sun Fire Insurance Policy 1046624. The policy also records that bleaching was carried out within the property (BUAD 1146).
The medieval roof of the hall survived until 1937, when the front of the building was removed for road widening. The pavement of medieval tiles was removed to the British Museum. The medieval arches in the north wall survive in situ as part of the freestanding boundary wall of Nos.1-6 Guild Court, Redcliff Backs. Recording of the surviving medieval elements of the building began in the 1820s when several watercolour drawings of the interior were made. Part of the medieval roof of the hall was drawn by Dollman in the 1850s (Dollman & Jobbins 1863) and the main body of the hall was photographed c1910 (Winstone 1957, pl.105) and by Philip Street in 1933 (BUAD 2346-2349). The site of the house was archaeologically excavated in 1983-85 (BUAD 447; Jones 1986) and the standing north wall of the ground-floor hall was recorded by Roger Pryce in 1972 (BUAD 667) and by R. H. Jones in 1985 (BUAD 668).

47 & 48, Wine Street. A pair of houses, the ground-floors used as shops. Nos.47/48 Wine Street. Each of 3 storeys and an attic, 1-window range, gabled front; common full-width pentice roofs over first and second floor fronts. Both cellared. Shopfronts to ground-floors. Oriels to first-floors, 6 lights & 2 lights; 8-light bays to second-floors; similar to attics, with cornices above. Extra glazing beside first-floor bay at No.48. Both with roofs consisting of 2 purlins each side. Lateral stacks on west side of No.48. The front of the ground-floor return to Cheese Market consisting of a pair of 6/6 pane sashes under a shallow segmental arch with a keystone. 
Samuel Morgan & Co., linen drapers, at No.47 in 1824, Bourne, Rowland & Co., cheap cloth establishment, at No.48. Refronted and 'thrown back' in about 1824 (Braikenridge Notes).

KNOWN_AS: The Hartshorn Inn, later the Swan Inn, Nos.26 and 27 Mary le Port Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Hartshorn Inn, later known as the Swan Inn, Nos.26 and 27 Mary le Port Street, located on the south side of Mary le Port Street, close to the corner with Dolphin Street. The building was erected in 1434 
By 1423 these belonged to Bernard Brewer (Leech 1997, 105). In 1451 John Wylly, a brewer, occupied the southern house and by 1475 it was occupied by William Bruer. These names imply that brewing was probably taking place. A document of 1495 confirms that a brewhouse was present of the site and that an inn or tavern known as the "herteshorne" had been established (Leech 1997, 106).
The building was refronted (and possibly rebuilt) in the seventeenth-century. It possessed a gabled front to Mary-le-Port Street.  Richard Robins was being taxed for the Swan by 1745 and continued there well into the 1750's (Land Tax returns; McGraph & Williams 1947, 47). Widow Preston was at the Swan by about 1760. Sketchley's directory indicates that in 1775 the Swan Inn  was run by Henry Selden. Edward and then Amelia Cuddeford succeeded Seldon.  By 1786 the property consisted of Nos.26 & 27 Mary-le-port Street.  Sarah Applin was the occupant of the "Swan Inn & Tavern" in 1823 (First Rate). William Gray was at the "Swan Inn and Spirit Vault" in 1839, also in 1849 (ibid). Charles Osborne was running the Swan in the 1870's, bu which time it was now being described as a hotel. It was demolished (along with the property adjacent on the east, on the corner of Mary le Port Street and Dolphin Street) in January 1936. It was replaced by a modern concrete, brick and glass structure with metal-framed windows. This new building was dstoyed in the evening of  November 24th, 1940 by bombing.

The "Spunging House", located on the west side of Pithay, on the north side of the junction with Tower Lane. The building was a three-storey, two-bay house of probable mid seventeenth-century date and occupied a plot measuring 14.25 metres east-west by 5 metres north to south. The main elevation faced south-east on to Pithay. The ground floor was apparently a shopfront with a central entrance doorway. A full-width pentice roof, apparently covered with slates, divided ground from first-floor. The upper floors of the east end of the building extended over Tower Lane, forming a frontage 7.5 metres wide at first-floor level on Pithay. The fenestration at first and second floors consisted of continuous twin bays with panelling in the base and Ipswich windows above. The bays were apparently roofed with lead. The divison between the floors was marked by a moulded string course and between the second-floor windows is the arms of the Brewers' Company moulded in plasterwork. Immediately above there was a sunburst decoration. At attic level in the centre of the elevation there was a smaller bay which rested on the corners of the second-floor bays and contained an Ipswich window. Above the bay, immediately beneath the apex of the eaves there was a sunburst decoration. The side, south-west facing, elevation on Tower Lane had a window opening on Tower Lane and there was a rainwater downpipe immediately to the east of this. The building has a gabled pantile roof with a cross-gable on the southern part of the roof only. There was apparently only a single purlin on each side of the main roof.
The early history of the building is currently unknown but presumably during the late eighteenth- and early-nineteenth centuries the building was used as a Spunging House. In 1829 G. W. Braikenridge noted that the building was "formerly used to lock up Persons when first arrested for Debt & [was] called the Spunging House" (Notes, M82). A watercolour painting of that year in the Braikenridge Collection of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery executed by T. L. Rowbotham (BRSMG M2373) records the building and shows a painted signboard bearing the legend "CUMMINS/UPHOLSTERER" over the entry to Tower Lane. Cummins is listed as an upholsterer at No.1 Pithay in contemporary street directories. The painting also shows many trunks and coats displayed outside the building, suggesting that the ground-floor shop may have been used for the trade in ready-made or second-hand clothes.
The building was demolished in March 1898 according to John Pritchard (Pritchard 1900-03, 259) but a photograph by T. Protheroe at the end of the 1890s (BUAD 2651) shows the remains of the northern party wall. The site of the building now lies beneath the entrance to the car park at the rear of The Pithay office building.

KNOWN_AS: The Thatched House Public House and Brewery
MONUMENT_DESC: The Thatched House Public House and brewery. The main elevation of the building was that facing south on to Thatched House Lane, but it also had an access from St. George's Road. The building had a gabled front, with a hipped extension to the north and was probably of two storeys. The date of construction is uncertain but the building may have dated to the seventeenth century.

Eastwood Farm. A late seventeenth-century farmhouse. In 1660, Rowland Lacy as Lord of the Manor enfranchised all copyhold lands in exchange for small fee farm rents.  As part of this enfranchisement process, a Mr. Pope received land adjoining the River Avon, lying to the west of a wood called Eastwood. Elizabeth Master is recorded as the owner of Eastwood in 1751, and an Elizabeth Master is given as the owner in 1821.
The building has a Grade II listing.

Icehouse at Colston Boys School, Stapleton. The icehouse is a circular structure with a domed vault and is constructed of brick bonded in a lime mortar. The chamber is 14 feet (4.28 metres) in diameter and this was entered by a short tunnel which was at least 9 feet (2.8 metres) long, 8 feet (2.5 metres) and 38 inches (1 metre) wide. The icehouse was surveyed by G. G. Locke in 1974 (SMR 20942) (Beamon & Roaf 1990, 191).

No.52 Wine Street, located in the southern side of Wine Street slightly to the east of the junction with Pithay. A building stood on the site from at least the mid sixteenth century when it was the tenement of Richard Mallett (Leech 1997, 197). The building as recorded in 1823 was a gabled, jettied house of three storeys and attic which was of seventeenth-century date. The main, north-east facing, elevation of the building was almost entirely panelled. The ground floor consisted of a shopfront with a central entrance doorway and a bay window on either side, and the door of a cellar access shute was located below the western window. The first floor had full-width transomed glazing with bay windows at the eastern and western ends of the elevation. The second floor had a decorative strip at the base and there was transomed glazing across the full-width. At the centre of the elevation there was an oriel window, with six lights to the front, and two to the ends. There were five decorative brackets below the sills, including one in the oriel. There was also an oriel at attic level, containing four lights to the front and two to the ends. There was a bracket carved into a figure supporting the sill. The eaves were supported by decorative brackets and had carved bargeboards. The glazing to the first and second floors extended on to both returns by a light. There was a tall chimneystack in the western wall of the building.
The section of the side, west facing, elevation exposed where the building projected forward of those on either side was rendered and had no windows or other openings. The north-east facing elevation had panelling at ground-, first- and second-floor. To the rear of the building there was a tall, five-storey, structure. This had a lean-to pantile roof with a doorway at the eastern end and above there were small leaded casement windows. At the east end there was a stair tower leading on to a flat roof with a rail or balustrade on its northern side. The function of this is not clear, although it may have been a small viewing platform. Adoining the south side of this structure there was a small tower-like structure with a pitched roof. Beneath the eaves of this on the east side there was a small window, possibly a casement.
In 1823 the building was occupied by Crisps Boot and Shoe Manufactory but George Weare Braikenridge's notes accompanying a drawing made that year record that the building was "now taking down to rebuild" (Braikenridge Notes, C103). Braikenridge obtained the carved bargeboards for use at his Cottage Lodge.

The Lodge Street Chapel at the south-west corner of the junction of Lodge Street and Trenchard Street.
The Countess of Huntingdon's Connexion built the chapel in 1830 when it left the Salem chapel in St. Augustine's Parade. The structure had five bays and the Trenchard Street frontage contained five tall, three-light windows with four-centred arch heads and hood-moulds above. The windows held stained or painted glass. The central three bays were within a three-sided apse projecting towards Trenchard Street, which had crenellations along the roof line. A string line ran across the full width of the building at the height of the top of the apse. Two crenellated pillars projected from string line at the ends of the facade. In the centre of the pediment was a small single light with a four-centred arch and a hood-mould above. There was a finial at the crown of the pediment.
An organ was built for the chapel by John Smith senior of the Bristol organ builders John Smith and Sons in 1832.
The building became a printing works before its demolition in 1967. A petrol filling station was later built on part of the site. The organ was removed and was reinstalled in the United Reform Church at Rayleigh in Essex.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Church of Christ Church, Broad Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
The churchyard of Christ Church (BUAD 335M), located on the north side of the church. The church was in existence by the mid-twelfth century and the churchyard is presumably contemporary with the building. The southern side was built over when the the church was rebuilt and extended at the end of the eighteenth-century.
Burial in the churchyard was ended by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852. The ledgerstones have been laid to form a continuous hard surface for the churchyard and access is via the church but the Grand Hotel also has access via a fire escape.

KNOWN_AS: Bristol Turnpike Trust Quarry, St. George
MONUMENT_DESC: Bristol Turnpike trust quarry located on the western side of Holmes Hill Road, near its junction with Cecil Avenue. The quarry was in existence by the time of the St. George tithe survey of 1842 (BRO EP/A/32/32) and is shown by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) surveyed in 1880-81 as measuring approximately 110 metres from north-west to south-east. The entrance was off Holmes Hill Road at the north-west. The quarry has now been infilled and the site developed for housing.
Brick & Tile Works" Gloucs LXXII.14 (1918)

Goldney House Gardens. The gardens to the family house at Clifton Hill was created by Thomas Goldney III between 1736-1768. It contains many exceptional features, notably a grotto (SMR 901), orangery, canal, statuary, Great Terrace, and a bastion.
Goldney House has a Grade II listing while the grotto, tower, bastion, canal and several other garden features are individually listed, the grotto as Grade I. The house and gardens are owned and maintained by the University of Bristol.
The garden at Goldney House is listed Grade II* in the English Heritage Register of Historic Parks and Gardens.

Gardens of Blaise Hamlet. Blaise Hamlet (SMR 774) was designed by John Nash and George Stanley Repton from 1807-1811 and comprises nine cottages built around a gently sloping green. At the centre is a large sundial erected by J. S. Harford junior in 1815 (Avon Gardens Trust 1991, 16).
The gardens of Blaise Hamlet have a Grade II* listing in the English Heritage Register of Historic Parks and Gardens. The sundial at the centre of the gardens has a Grade I listing (901-1/20/1349).

Blaise Castle Estate. The estate is a large designed landscape laid out in the eighteenth century around a folly built in 1767 (SMR 780). The grounds were landscaped by Humphry Repton in the 1790s. John Nash designed some of the garden buildings.
Farm on N side of Green. Area since developed 4/12/1946 CPE-UK-1869 {1}

KNOWN_AS: St. Nicholas Market or The Shambles
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Nicholas' Market or The Shambles, located to the south and east of The Exchange. The markets were created in the 1740s as part of the development of The Exchange, moving The Shambles from their historic  position on the eastern side of High Street.
The markets had several discrete elements and their original spatial organisation and form is recorded in plans and drawings dating between c.1782 (BUAD 3805) and c.1813. The Somersetshire Market was located on the site of the Market Chambers building on the west side of Exchange Avenue. The Gloucestershire Market was on the south arcade of The Exchange. The main area of the market between All Saints' Lane, Exchange Avenue and St. Nicholas Street, recorded by O'Neill in 1823, consisted of eight parallel rows of stalls, running roughly north-south and containing 150 stalls. Each row was sheltered by a long hipped roof with slate. G. W. Braikenridge (Braikenridge Notes, C100) records that gates were erected at the ends of the standings. Removal of the old market 'houses' commenced on 4 January 1813.
The present structure dates to the nineteenth century open plan aisled extension to an earlier market, and faces St. Nicholas Street. Single storey; 7-window range. Trapezium-shaped with curved corners. The St. Nicholas Street front has a tall central entrance with iron gates, windows each side, and 2 lunettes at each end. Matching 7-window right return and 4-window left return. Inside, square piers support a 20th.century steel-trussed roof; wooden stalls.
St. Nicholas Market has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/16/591) while the Market Chambers has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/16/666).

Great Hall of Bristol Castle, located within the inner ward of Bristol Castle, at the eastern end of Castle Park.. The building was constructed in the thirteenth century with additions in the fourteenth century. Relatively little is currently known about the form of the Great Hall as a whole. The surviving Vaulted Chambers, probably part of the entrance to the building, is constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble with limestone ashlar detailing and consists of two adjoining rectangular chambers with quadripartite ribbed vaults, though the ribs of the two cells have different profiles, indicating that they do not belong to the same phase of construction. The structure appears to have been described by William Worcester in the early 1480s who notes it was 10 yards long, "with an arched vault above the entrance of the great hall" (Neale 2000, 238-239).
The building was one of the elements of Bristol Castle which survived its demolition in 1657-1658. It was incorporated into a new large house on the east side of Tower Street which is recorded by James Millerd's 1673 plan of Bristol. By the 1820s the building was owned by the Feoffees of the Baptist Society and let to a Mr. Gould (Braikenridge Notes A.29+ and A.29++). Samuel Seyer published a plan and view of the interior (Seyer 1821, 384-386) when the surviving medieval elements were largely the same as the currently existing plan. The interior of the building was recorded in three watercolour drawings by Hugh O'Neill in 1821 (BRSMG M2731 to M2733) and a seventeenth-century stair with carved newels and balusters and pendant newels at first floor survived beyond the north end of the building, a stair which is likely to have dated to the original conversion of the building into a house in the late 1650s or early 1660s. A drawing of the following year by Samuel Jackson (BRSMG M2734) recorded the Tower Street elevation, including a four-centred arched entrance containing a panelled door dating to the seventeenth-century and a pair of stepped buttresses. Gould removed the stepped buttresses on 21 October 1822 and the work was drawn in progress by Jackson (BRSMG M2735). By the late-nineteenth century the northern half of the building had been subdivided by the insertion of a stud partition. The seventeenth century stair was also extant at this date but was subsequently removed. By 1920 the building formed of No.21 Tower Street, then Sealey Brothers confectionery shop. Sealey Brothers inserted a new suspended floor in the southern half of the building, possibly after removal of a vaulted undercroft. The shop was let to Boots the Chemist in the 1930s which rebuilt the façade, and also appears to have been responsible for breaking through the eastern bays. The vaults were scheduled in 1936-37. The shop was bombed in November 1940 (Warne 1943, 7) and the building gutted. The medieval vaulted arches survived largely intact, though the limestone apparently suffered some heat damage from the associated fire. Some emergency repairs were made to stabilise the structure. The building was subject to Compulsory Purchase by the Bristol Corporation in 1951 but seems to have remained empty until the building was restored in 1974 by the architect Alan Rome (who made an initial measured survey of the building in 1970 (BUAD 3187)). As part of the work the floor was removed and relaid in concrete with an underfloor heating system. An extension was built at the north end of the building in the early 1980s, its site being archaeologically excavated in advance (BUAD 3096), and remedial works were also undertaken in 1993-1994 by the architect John Winstone.
The building is a Scheduled Ancient Monument (Monument no. AV116) and has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/40/222).

The Baptist Burial Ground, located at the east end of Redcross Street and lying between Redcross Street and Old Market Street. The burial ground was apparently founded in the later seventeenth century after the congregations of the Broadmead and Pithay chapels agreed on the purchase of a plot for a joint cemetery in 1681. An Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852 restricted burial to members of the congregation and ordered that "only one body [was] to be buried in each grave."
The final clearance work in the burial ground was undertaken in 1926 and the human remains reburied in Greenbank cemetery. However a watching brief in 1982 (BUAD 3037), undertaken when the site was redeveloped, recorded burials across much of the site, particularly along its east edge. The burial ground was probably completely destroyed by this development.

Prior's Cottage, No.27 Horfield Road. The building is a two-storey rendered stone house set in the north-west corner of a rectangular walled garden. It was constructed as summerhouse (ie. a second residence) for Richard Going, a Bristol pewterer and was built c.1750, being recorded in the Land Tax assessment for that year as a "garden and summerhouse" belonging to Going (Leech 2001, 9).
As built, the house was a narrow rectangular structure, orientated from east to west with its longest side along Robin Hood Lane, and measured 11 metres long by 2.7 metres wide. A second building, orientated north-south, had been constructed at the south-west corner of the garden by 1828. This appears to have been incorporated into the earlier building to form a larger range along the western boundary by the early 1880s. A bay window had also been added to the eastern end of the south-facing elevation by that date.

KNOWN_AS: Medieval manor house, Upper Church Lane
MONUMENT_DESC:
A probable medieval house at the west end of Upper Church Lane which was the capital messuage at the centre of an estate at the foot of St. Michael's Hill. The edges of the estate can be identified until the later post-medieval period and probably included St. Michael's Church, forming an association of great house and church which can be seen in many rural locations.
The land was owned by the Cheddre family and later passed into the ownership of the Lisle's. It was bought by the city and then into the Stubbs family who built a lodge or summerhouse [BUAD 1143M] (ie. a second residence) there in the seventeenth century. The land passed into the hands of the Earle family who began to divide it into gardens (R. Leech pers. comm.).

Broad Plain Confectionery Works, located on the south side of Broad Plain. The building occupied the site of Nos.8-9 Broad Plain and was in existence by 1882 when it was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.16.24). It was then occupied by Walter Long. By the time of the Goad fire insurance plan of August 1896 the works had become the George E. Spear and Brothers Bacon Factory.

The Fortune of War public house. A pair of houses, the right-hand in use as a public house. On the west side of Marsh Street, opposite the bonded sugar warehouse of Messrs. Robert Bush & Son. Attached. 3 storeys and attics; gabled fronts; first-floors only jettied; both a 1-window range. Left-hand entrance to left house, 3 sashes; 4 sashes to right house, cellar access below right-hand pair. Oriels to first and second floors, 10 lights at first-floors, 8 lights at second-floors, all with 2-light sides. Single windows to attics. Two purlins to each roof slope. 
The right-hand property was used as a public house, the 'Fortune of War', the sign of a sailor being removed immediately after O'Neill's drawing was made, the licence having been withdrawn.

No.120 St. Thomas Street. The building, on the west side of the street, was a wide three-storey, single-bay jettied house with a front gable and pantiled roof. The ground floor was a shopfront with a central doorway which had large lights adjacent. The first floor contained a large bay window as did the second storey. There were windows in the north wall of the building at first and second floors. These were at the extreme east end of the building. There also appears to have been a small gable on this side of the house.
The building was occupied in the 1890s by H. R. Clarke "Dealer in rags, rope, iron etc.".

KNOWN_AS: Chapel of St John the Evangelist
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Chapel of St. John the Evangelist, otherwise known as Knape's Chapel. It was a Chantry chapel founded by Thomas Knape, a former mayor of Bristol who died in 1404. Two priests were to be maintained in perpetuity to perform daily service and pray for the souls of Knape and his wife Agnes. In his will Knape directed that he should be buried in the chancel of the chapel (Wadley 1886, 68), suggesting that the building may have been complete, or at least close to completion, at the time of his death. The chapel occupied a plot between Welsh Back and Queen Charlotte Street. The north side was defined by Crow Lane and a plan of 1850 (BRO Plan Book C fo.98a) suggests that there may also have been a lane between Queen Charlotte Street and Welsh Back on the south side of the chapel. The form of the building and its position within the plot is currently unknown.
A survey of the Chantries of Bristol of February 1547/8 (BUAD 2591) found that there was then only one incumbent David Thomas who was then 51 years of age, had "noe other livinge or p[ro]mocion" and received £6 per annum. The property of the chapel brought in an annual income of £21 15 shillings. There was no plate but the Ornamentation was valued at 26 shillings 5 pence (Maclean 1883-84, 238-239). The chapel was probably dissolved in 1548 since a deed of that year refers to the site as the cemetery of St. Nicholas parish (Leech 1997, 168), the parish acquiring the site as an extension churchyard. The chapel building is likely to have been demolished then or soon afterwards.

Castle Green Congregational Chapel. The chapel was a three bay, two-storey structure with a central entrance and a pediment above the central bay and was of late eighteenth or early nineteenth-century date. Drawings by Samuel Loxton made in the early-twentieth century record both the exterior and interior of the chapel (Bristol Reference Library E353 and E354).

No.16 High Street. In use in 1821 as paper warehouse with ground-floor shop. South corner of High and Mary-le-Port Streets. Attached to south and east. Roof not recorded, but a building of 4 storeys otherwise, with a 1-window range to High Street. Jetties to both first-floor elevations, supported by pair of figure brackets at corner and a scroll bracket halfway along Mary-le-Port Street. Main elevation to High Street, where a left-hand entrance and shop window. Rear entrance at far eastern end of north return wall, which was of 4 storeys. At first-floor, central canted bay with flanking windows, all sashes; full-width moulded string above. Second-floor canted bay an extension on that below, 8-light front and 2-light sides; another string. 8-light third-floor window; eaves above on brackets. At various places the return propped against the opposite property across street. 
It appears that this building probably had a gable to High Street. It is shown by O'Neill in 1820 (M2797) as having a transverse gable at the eastern end of the northern return along Mary-le-Port Street. After this, there was a short eastern return wall of 1-window width, with a sash on each of the uppermost 3 floors, and a tiny window high in the ground-floor.

No.8, Narrow Plain, a house of possible late seventeenth- or early eighteenth-century date located on the south side of Narrow Plain. Attached. 3 storeys and attic; gable to rear, with cross-ridge connecting to No.7 to the east. Lateral stack on west wall. The front elevation not recorded. Ground and first floors extended rearwards later in brick. Second-floor and attic of rear elevation rendered, 1 window each, both sashes. The building was still standing in April 1963, but was removed for the widening of Temple Way.

No.17 Castle Street, located on the north side of Castle Street. The building was a jettied, gabled house of two storeys and attic with a 1-window range. It was almost certainly constructed as part of the redevelopment of the site of Bristol Castle after its demolition in the late 1650s.
By the nineteenth century the ground floor was a shop. Shop windows with a recessed central entrance. One sash each to the first-floor and attic. Both upper floors jettied. Lateral stack(s). The east end of the eastern half of the front gable had been removed by the 1930s.
The building was destroyed by bombing on 24 November 1940.

KNOWN_AS: Tenement south of The Old Fox Public House
MONUMENT_DESC:
A tenement to the south of The Old Fox Public House, Redcliff Street, excavated in 1982. The tenement lay on the east side of  Redcliff Street (Structure 3 & 4) and was built in the fourteenth century, an earlier structure being incorporated into the building and additional rooms added. The building had at least three rooms running back from Redcliff Street and there was a hearth in each of the front two rooms.
The remains of the building were probably destroyed by the development of No.70 Redcliff Street.

KNOWN_AS: Possible redoubt and lodge, Temple Quay
MONUMENT_DESC: A possible redoubt and lodge to the south--east of Tower Harratz in Temple Meads. The structure was identified by archaeological evaluation in 1997 and was subsequently excavated (BUAD 3158). The building was interpreted as a possible redoubt associated with the refortification of the city during the civil war in the mid-seventeenth century and three phases of building were identified (Cox 1997). The northern wall of the structure was apparently medieval in date and reused an earlier structure. Documentary evidence suggests that the structure was a private lodge in the eighteenth century (R. H. Leech pers comm).

Weavers Hall, probably located on the eastern side of Temple Street. The Weavers' Hall, the guild hall for the Weavers, was in existence by 1299. If the identifications of the structure by J. F. Nicholls in 1869 (BUAD 3670) and by G. L. Good in 1974 are correct, it appears to have been a substantial  structure of squared stone blocks. The master's house stood immediately adjacent.

A building known as The Priory, located on the west side of Priory Gardens, Shirehampton. A domestic building which is reputedly has a fifteenth-century origin with sixteenth-, seventeenth- and eighteenth-century alterations. It is mainly of eighteenth-century appearance externally. The hall roof is intact, and is an arch-braced with cusped wind-braces in three tiers. The building is reputed to be associated with a medieval priory but there is no historical evidence to support its connection with any monastic site.
The building was much altered in the mid-twentieth century and this has marred its appearance and affected its character.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/52/1759).
Coombe Farm, located some 170 metres to the north of Canford Lane. The farm is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan published in 1881 (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.03).

KNOWN_AS: Army Ordnance Department (A.O.D.) store north of Greensplot Farm
MONUMENT_DESC:
Army Ordnance Department (A.O.D.) store located approximately 180 metres to the north of Greensplot Farm. The store was built in 1918 to serve National Filling Factory No.23 and is recorded by a plan in the National Archives (MUN 4/1753) dated 27 November 1918. The building measured approximately 32 metres from north to south and was 26 metres wide with a double-pile plan.
The shell of the building was extant in 1946 but the roof had been removed by that date. The remainder of the structure was subsequently demolished.

Store located approximately 110 metres to the north of Greensplot Farm. The store was built in 1918 to serve National Filling Factory No.23 and is recorded by a plan in the National Archives (MUN 4/1753) dated 27 November 1918. The building measured approximately 32 metres from north to south and was 26 metres wide with a double-pile plan.
The shell of the western half of the building was extant in 1946 but had lost its roof. The eastern half had been demolished by that date. The remainder of the structure was subsequently demolished.

KNOWN_AS: Northern hospital at National Filling Factory No.23, Chittening
MONUMENT_DESC:
Northern of two hospitals serving National Filling Factory No.23, Chittening. The hospital was located at the centre of the site was built in 1918. It is recorded by a plan in the National Archives (MUN 4/1753) dated 27 November 1918 and was a rectangular building measuring approximately 20 metres from north to south and was 10 metres wide, with a pitched roof.
The building was extant in 1946 but was subsequently demolished.

KNOWN_AS: Bristol Union Workhouse Cemetery, Manor Road, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC: Bristol Union Workhouse Cemetery, Manor Road, Stapleton. The cemetery was located on the north side of Manor Road, on the east side of the workhouse complex. Acts of consecration were passed in 1852, 1866 and 1882 (A. Townsend pers. comm.) and the cemetery covered an area of approximately 8500 square metres. The cemetery had been closed by 1898.

KNOWN_AS: Church of the Sacred Heart, Grange Court Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Church of the Sacred Heart located in the south-east side of Grange Court Road. The church was built in 1939 and consecrated on 20 June 1950. The church is a two-storey red brick structure in a modern Romanesque style. Two stained glass windows were fixed into the windows of the west transept in 2006.

KNOWN_AS: Church of St. Bernadette, Wells Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Roman Catholic church of St. Bernadette, located on the western side of Wells Road. The church is a single-storey structure built in the second half of the twentieth century.
A stone stile located on the north side of Henbury Road.

KNOWN_AS: The Lodge, Charlton Mead Drive, Southmead
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Lodge, located on the western side of Charlton Mead Drive, Southmead. The building was the lodge for Pen Park and was sited approximately 150 metres to the north of the main group of buildings. It appears to have been built in the nineteenth century. The building is a two-storey structure with a T-shaped plan which is built of squared, coursed lias limestone, part rendered, with a cross-gable roof.
The original roof covering was replaced with concrete tiles in the second half of the twentieth century.

KNOWN_AS: Private Chapel at the Bristol Maternty Hospital, Southwell Street
MONUMENT_DESC: A private chapel associated with the Bristol Maternity Hospital and located in a separate building to the rear of no.100 St Michael's Hill. The chapel was apparently constructed when the Carlton Industrial School for Girls (5454M) was converted for use as the maternity hospital in 1912. The bulding was apparently demolished in the 1990s and partly arcaheologically recorded during excavations to the rear of 78-100 St Michael's Hill in 1994 (404).

KNOWN_AS: Barstaple's Almshouse or Trinity Hospital North
MONUMENT_DESC:
Barstaple's Almshouse, or Trinity Hospital North located on the north side of Old Market Street, on the east corner of Redcross Lane. The almshouse was founded in the late-medieval period and was apparently rebuilt in the seventeenth century. The hospital was U-shaped in plan with ranges down both sides and across the northern end of a courtyard running up from the street. Entrance into the courtyard via double gates between a pair of rusticated piers with ball finials. At the southern end of either side range, a 3-bay, 2-storey block with gabled end, a single 2-light window in the end of each storey, with, between storeys, a blank arcade of 6 semicircular arches; stacks at the rears of each block. An entrance to the ground-floor of each range immediately inside the gate. At parapet level, on the south-west corner of the western range, a sundial. 
At the northern end of the yard, a C-shaped block, with plinth, cornice and rusticated quoins. The left wing of 1 bay facing south, cross-window at first-floor, 4-window range facing east, entrance second from the south, all other openings with cross-windows; the right-hand range probably the mirror opposite. A single-storey extension at the south end of the left-hand range, 2 cross-windows with a central entrance; parapet. In the connecting 3-window range, at ground-floor outer semicircular-arched doorways with rusticated voussoirs, and a central blank window with semicircular head and projecting keystone and imposts. At first-floor level of the range, a semicircular-headed niche containing a statue of John Barstaple, with flanking sash windows. Pantile roof. Stacks at the rears.
Manchee describes the building as consisting of twenty-four apartments, each with a fireplace and furnished by the residents themselves.The building also had a communal kitchen (Manchee 1821, 79).
The almshouse was rebuilt in the mid nineteenth century, in Pennant Sandstone and limestone dressings, by Foster and Wood and extended again in 1881.

KNOWN_AS: Mason's Arms Public House, No.53, Old Market Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
Mason's Arms Public House, No.53 Old Market Street, located on the south side of the street. The building is a timber-framed, single-bay house of two-storeys and attic and was constructed with a detached kitchen to the rear. It was built in the late-seventeenth or early-eighteenth century. The main, north-west, facing elevation on Old Market Street is rendered and at ground-floor level it comprises a shopfront of ninteenth-century date. The main entrance door is on the northern side of the elevation and at the centre is a large window with panelled jambs. A leaded pentice roof divides ground- from first-floor. There is a single sash at the centre of the elevation at first-floor and another, similar window at second-floor. At the apex of the gable there is a small four-light casement window. The building has a cross-gabled pantile roof with a rendered chimney stack on the western side of the roof.
Internally the plan of the building appears to have consisted of a single room at the front and at the rear, with a winder stair between the rooms, on the western side of the building. The stair served all floor of the building, including the cellar. By 1875 the building had become a public house known as The Mason's Arms and was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by William Ward.
The building has been surveyed by Dr. Roger Leech for the Royal Commission on the Historical Monuments of England (BUAD 2068). One timber crossbeam with a stop survives at ground-floor by the main entrance door and the chimneybreast and stack for the detached kitchen is also extant. Another is extant in the rear room at first-floor level. The winder stair survives at first and second floor.
It has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/12/1648).

No.71 Redcliff Street, the Redcliff Dining Rooms. The building was located on the east side of Redcliff Street and was of probable seventeenth-century date. The building was a jettied and gabled house of three storeys plus attic. The ground floor was occupied by a shop front with the entrance on the north side. The first floor had at least one casement but there were no windows in the second storey and attic by the end of the nineteenth century. The original windows were presumably bays similar to those in The Old Fox next door.
The building was demolished in the early twentieth century and the site redeveloped. It was archaeologically excavated in 1982 (BUAD 467). The archaeological stratification is likely therefore to have been completely destroyed.

No.25 Pithay. A single-bay gabled house of three storeys plus attic which was located on the eastern side of Pithay. The ground floor was occupied by a shopfront. At first floor was a bay window with a pentice roof, apparently not full-width, above. There were three casement windows at second floor, the central one at a slightly lower level to the other two.
The building survived to the end of the nineteenth century and was a lodging house by 1887. It was demolished in c.1900 and the site redeveloped.

No.27 Pithay. A single-bay gabled house of three storeys plus attic which was located on the eastern side of Pithay. The ground floor was occupied by a shopfront with the entrance at the centre. On the north side of the door was a 3x3 shop window, but the window on the south side was apparently smaller. At second floor was a bay window with a pentice roof, apparently full-width, above which marked the division between first and second floor. There was a casement window at second floor and the attic was slightly jettied.
The building survived to the end of the nineteenth century and was a lodging house by January 1887. It was demolished in c.1900 and the site redeveloped.

KNOWN_AS: Chapel of the Assumption, Bristol Bridge
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Chapel of the Assumption also known as the Chapel of St. Mary, located slightly to the north of the centre of the medieval Bristol Bridge. The chapel, a chapel at ease of St Nicholas, was apparently founded using the gifts of several members of the Fraternity of the Assumption of Our Lady (Maclean 1883-84, 239-240) including the burgess Elias Spelly (Neale 2002, 142-143) and lay within the parish of St. Nicholas. William Worcestre gives the dedication date of the chapel as 4th February (Neale 2002, 166-167) and, in addition to funding clerics to perform masses on Saturdays and distributing alms to the poor, revenue from the endowments were to be used to fund the maintenance and repair of Bristol Bridge (Maclean 1883-84, 239-240).
The chapel was constructed of stone and appears to have been orientated from south-west to north-east across the width of the bridge. There was a large vehicular arch to allow traffic to pass beneath the building. The main description of the structure comes from William Worcestre, who visited it in the early 1480s (BUAD 3601; 3602). He noted that it was 25 yards long and 7 wide (Neale 2000, 2-3) with a square, four-stage stone bell tower "on the left [in sinistra]" of the chapel which was reputed to have been built c1460 (Neale 2000, 142-143; 150-151). Worcestre gives the height of the tower as 15 fathoms from ground-level to the bell-chamber "measured by the bell ropes" (Neale 2000, 142-143) and the bells were still present in the 1540s (Maclean 1883-84, 239-240). The fenestration comprised four large windows on each side and a "high" window above the main altar. One or more of the chapel windows contained stained glass depicting the founders from the Fraternity of the Assumption and their wives (Neale 2000, 142-143). Beneath the building there was a "beautiful" large crypt which, Worcestre notes, accommodated the councillors and officers of the town and was used for public meetings about the town's business (Neale, 2000 12-13). Half of the roof was leaded according to the survey made in 1547 (Maclean 1883-84, 239-240).
The internal organisation of the building is less clear, but in addition to the crypt Worcestre mentions the chapel, a hall with offices and an upper room and highest room (Neale 2002, 166-167) - the latter two presumably being spaces in the tower. There was also a smaller chapel with an altar to the east of the main altar and Worcestre states that this was three yards long (Neale 2000, 166-167).
The chapel was dissolved in 1547 and was purchased by the Corporation in 1548 for £40 which then rented it out as a warehouse. In 1649 Walter Stephens, draper, was ordered to repair the arch of the former building over the highway which was in a dangerous state (Latimer, 1900 224). The building survived into the mid-eighteenth century, although the tower is not visible in a view of the bridge of c1760 (BUAD 3321) perhaps suggesting that this element had already been removed. The chapel seems to have been demolished in the 1760s, at the same time that the rest of the medieval bridge was removed.

KNOWN_AS: Bowling Green by St. John's Almshouses
MONUMENT_DESC: The Bowling Green to the south of St. John's Almshouses. The bowling green was extant by the time of Millerd's map in 1673 and the entrance appears to have been from Tower Lane. A part of the site of the green was bought to enable the rebuilding of the almshouses in the eighteenth-century. Behind buildings fronting The Pithay and Tower Lane. Shown on Millerd's 1673 map. Recorded by Rocque as "OLD BOWLING GREEN".

No.16, Victoria Street. Early 1870s. Brick and terracotta dressings, brick stacks and slate mansard roof. Double-depth plan. Two storeys and attic; one-window range. 20th.century shop front, with haulingway entrance on right; haulingway ran much of the plot depth. Deep cornice and parapet; a large 2-light window in a semicircular arch and a tympanum with a lion head and COURAGE above it; semicircular-arched dormer, 2 lights and a round light above. Rear elevation of 3 bays. Behind the main building, a link to a 2-storey brick building, then a single-storey gabled block. Lift (1-ton capacity) to cellar.  Part of a group of Victorian commercial buildings developed after Victoria Street was cut. Latterly a bar, but earlier a wine merchant's premises.

The Prebendal House, on the north side of College Square, to the west of the Old Deanery. The south front showed it to be a complex structure, probably medieval in basis. Two storeys and an attic, at least a 6-window range. Cellared. From the left, a 2-window range, sashes to cellar, ground and first floors. Then a strip of quoins, beyond which was a 2-storey canted bay with sashes, after which was a possible cut-back buttress. There was an entrance with an open pediemnt over, with a first-floor sash, then a further sash each to both storeys. On the right-hand was a tall ground-floor sash (9 + 9 panes), above which was a small blocked late medieval window. The roof was gabled and was clearly two roofs end to end, with stacks at both ends of each roof. The building was removed for construction of the Central Library at the beginning of the twentieth century.

The White Lion Inn, located on the north side of Broad Street. The site of the inn appears to have covered the sites of two medieval properties. The "Whyt Lyon" had been established by 1517 in the southern of these and was then leased by Lord Lisle to John Ware and his wife Emott. After his imprisonment in the Tower of London, Lord Lisle's properties were confiscated by Henry VIII. In 1544 the Bristol property, including the White Lion, was purchased from the Crown by the Bristol Corporation and was then occupied by John Spryng. In 1598 the inn was occupied by Edmund Hereford and had passed to Margaret Hereford by 1627-28. The second medieval property had apparently been incorporated into the White Lion by this date.
The sixteenth-century form of the building is currently unclear, but it was apparently refronted in the seventeenth century. It was a four-storey jettied building with a six-window range and a pitched roof. The ground floor had a plain frontage with a band of casement windows at around shoulder height. The first floor was jettied over the footway. The first and second floors contained sash windows at the north side of each bay. Above the windows were pediments which were segmental in the second and fifth bays. The sashes at third floor did not have pediments. The frontage had pargetting forming a brick pattern. Beneath each of the first floor sashes was a small square of raised plasterwork with a circle in the centre and a quartered background.
By 1740 the inn was leased by James Bowyer, innholder, and Joseph Sheppard, saddler. In the 1760s and 1770s the White Lion was owned by Thomas Lawrence, father of the portrait painter Sir Thomas Lawrence R.A. (1769-1830). The White Lion Club, active in support of the Tory party in elections in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth century, took its name from the inn where it met.
The building was demolished in the mid-1860s to allow the construction of the Grand Hotel (BUAD 1667M).

No.54 Broad Street, located at the corner of Newmarket Avenue and Broad Street. A building seems to have stood on the site from at least 1295 when William Scoche is recorded as the occupier and in 1384, when it was purchased by John Stanys the property comprised three shops with a cellar beneath. A document of 1437 records the property as a messuage, cellar, solar and garden held by Margaret Asscheley (Leech 1997, 46). By 1543 the property had been acquired by the feoffees of All Saints parish and a lease of that year to Lewes Robyns, skinner, mentions a stable at the end of the plot. In 1598 the feoffees sold the building to the executors of Robert Kitchen who created a shambles known as Newmarket Passage. It is not clear what works this entailed but some reconstruction of the building was certainly undertaken. The building seems to have oversailed the south-western end of Newmarket Passage and a timber beam spanning the centre of the Passage had a carved inscription along the whole length of its south-west face reading "THIS BUILDING IS AT THE CHARGE OF ROBART KITCH[EN] / ALDERMAN OF BRISTOL FOR THE RELIEFE OF THE POOR." At the centre of the beam is a shield bearing a monogram , probably "RK", with the date 1598 below (BUAD 4265; BRSMG Mb6934).
The building appears to have been refronted in the seventeenth century and by the early 1860s was a four-storey, single-bay jettied building with a shopfront at ground floor level and bay sash windows at first and second floors. It had a smaller sash at third floor (Winstone 1972, plates 17-18). The building was demolished in c.1864 to allow construction of The Grand Hotel.

St. James Churchyard. The churchyard was the burial ground for the parish of St. James and was in use from the medieval period until the 1850s. It also served several other parishes during its lifetime, including St. John until the late fifteenth-century. The churchyard was located on the south side of the parish church, (the nave of the priory church). It was bounded on the north by the priory (although it extended in front of part of the west end of the church, aligned with the original south-west corner, slightly to the north of what is now the western part of St. James Parade) and on the east by a street known as St. James Churchyard (whose line survives as the passage along the east end of the John Lewis department store). The southern boundary was the Horsefair, and the western approximately Lower Maudlin Street. Excavation at the west front of St. James's Church in 1994-1995 (BUAD 3156) found that the northern edge of the churchyard had been moved southward, probably when the south aisle was added (perhaps c.1374), and houses (Nos.14-18) built on the site. The churchyard was not enclosed until 1813.
The internal arrangement of the churchyard is less well understood. William Worcestre describes a small, square freestone chapel in the churchyard. A path, shown on Millerd's 1673 map of Bristol, ran diagonally across the churchyard. The inhumations in the churchyard have been shown by archaeological excavation in three locations to have been laid in north-south rows with individual burials orientated east-west. No brick burial shafts or vaults have been recorded in the churchyard to date (14/11/98).
The churchyard was the site of the annual St. James Fair (illustrated by Miss Bird in 1825 (BRSMG Mb2)). The churchyard was subdivided to create a Hay and Coal Market in the south-east part in 1838 and part of the south-western corner was removed for street improvements during the century.
By the 1850s was found to be full and was closed to burials by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852. In 1880 the parochial authorities converted the churchyard into a public park and laid it out with seats, shrubberies and winding paths, which are shown by the Ordnance Survey 1:500 maps of the early 1880s. The surviving two parts of the churchyard are still in use as a public park, the easternmost containing the remains of a calvary cross (BUAD 94M). 
The boundary walls, railings, piers and gates are listed Grade II (No.955), with the walls, gates and railings around the small area of churchyard to the north of the Parade listed Grade II (No.954). The churchyard and the area around the church of St. James have been designated as a conservation area.

A group of three terraced houses on the west side of St Michael's Hill at the corner of Tyndall Avenue. Originally part of a group of eigth houses with 79-87 on the north side of Tyndall Avenue built c.1901. The houses were constructed with squared Pennant Sandstone rubble with limestone dressings on the St Michael's Hill façade. Side and rear elevations were of rendered brick. The front elevation had two storey canted bays and the main roof was hipped and tiled or slated. The buildings were recorded prior to their demolition in 2010 by John Bryant of Bristol and Region Archaeological Services.

The garden of Bishopsworth Manor originally a formal garden of early eighteenth century date contemporary with the Listed Grade II* Manor House. The original terrace in front of the house is extant and the garden retains several mature trees.

Bellevue, communal garden, was begun with the adjoining residential properties in 1789, but remained unfinished as a result of the property crash in 1793 until the early nineteenth century.
The gardens are in two halfs either side of the Bellevue properties. The area to the west is bounded by the garden of Clifton Hill House. In the southern part of the eastern half are the remains of an old rockery.

KNOWN_AS: Tennis Ground to the rear of the Victoria Rooms

MONUMENT_DESC:
All Saints' Churchyard. The churchyard was located on the southern side of All Saint's Court, opposite the church. It was apparently expanded slightly sometime after 1470. The boundary line between Nos.42 and 43 High Street provided one corner in 1470 but subsequent evidence shows that a strip (the width of No.43 High Street) was added. There is also reference to an entrance stile in 1531. The churchyard was still extant in the early eighteenth-century (Leech 1997, 1) but the site was subsequently developed with housing. The churchyard and All Saints Court was formally closed to interment by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852.
The site of the cemetery lies beneath Nos.2 and 3 All Saints' Court and beneath the northern half of No.6 All Saints' Lane. No.2 All Saints Court is cellared, though only beneath the core of the building. It is a reasonable assumption, therefore, that surviving undisturbed inhumations of medieval and later date may be anticipated in the area of the former cemetery.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Park Row Service Station, Park Row
MONUMENT_DESC:
Princes Theatre, sometimes known as the New Theatre Royal, located on the south side of Park Row. The theatre was built in 1867 to a design by C. J. Phipps. The building was of four storeys and the main elevation was of ashlar. Externally, the ground floor comprised an arcade and the main entrance was at the centre between shops. There was a public house near the western end, beyond which was a side access to the theatre. The stage was 107 feet (32.7 metres) wide and the proscenium arch 30 feet (9.18 metres) by 25 feet 6 inches (7.8 metres). The line of the gallery and the proscenium formed a perfect circle (Carleton 1983, 2). The theatre could accommodate an audience of 2800.
The theatre opened on 14 October 1867 with a performance of The Tempest. The theatre was the scene of a serious accident on Boxing Day 1869, when eighteen of the audience were trampled to death.
In 1902 there were extensive alterations to the theatre by Frank Matcham. Externally these included the creation of a glazed entrance porch with a cast iron frame to enclose the main entrance and the addition of four statues (Tragedy, Comedy, Music and Dance) were added to the parapet. Inside the theatre the floors were angled to make the seating raked, the boxes were remodelled, foyers, smoking rooms and lounges added and the decorative scheme altered to cream and gold. Electric lighting was also added throughout the building (Carleton 1983, 16). The theatre was refurbished again in 1931 when the architect A. E. Oaten oversaw the installation of new lighting and heating as well as structural alterations.
The theatre was destroyed by bombing in 1940. Fire gutted the building, leaving only the shell standing (Warne 1943, 17).

No.31 Victoria Street. The building is the southern of a terrace of four gabled houses on the west side of Victoria Street (having fronted on to St. Thomas Street until the 1870s when Victoria Street was cut through the existing street pattern). The plots were the property of St. Thomas's Church and four shops are known to have been present on the site by 1456 and a date plaque on the front of the building which gives a date of c.1456 is presumably a reference to the documentary evidence for the earlier tenements. The present building was constructed between 1673 and 1675 by Henry Gleson, linendraper (BRO P/StT/D/151). The building is a single-bay timber-framed structure of three storeys plus attic with a pantile gabled roof. The ground floor is occupied by a shopfront and the windows are all sashes. There is a small chimney stack on the southern side of the building. The original plan form consisted of a front and rear room at each floor with a winder stair against the south wall between the two.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/325).

Malthouse, located on the south-western side of Upper York Street. The building was constructed in the mid-nineteenth century and formed part of the Stokescroft Brewery (BUAD 1610M). It is a brick structure with limestone ashlar quoins and parapet, and is of two storeys and basement with a pitched roof. The main, north-east facing elevation is rendered and has a nine-window range, the fenestration consisting of brick arched windows with ashlar keystones. There are three arched double doorways at ground floor.
After the Stokescroft Brewery closed in the twentieth century the malthouse became a bottling plant for Franklin and Co. Ltd. This closed in the 1960s and the building was converted into a printing works in 1972. In 1983 it became a nightclub known as the Lakota Club.
The building is extant.

The Shakespeare, No.68 Prince Street, located on the west side of Prince Street. The building was constructed in the early eighteenth century (traditionally c1725), as one of a pair with No.70 Prince Street (BUAD 1505M). Gomme et al. (1970 128) attribute the classical design to James Strahan.
The building is a three-storey, four-bay house and is of limestone ashlar with rusticated pilasters on the north and south sides of the building and on the north and south sides of the central bays. The ground floor is rusticated and the main entrance is in the north bay. The central bays are set forward and at ground-floor the window openings have semicircular arches with keys and incised voussoirs. The fenestration in the rest of the elevation consists of openings with keyed segmental heads and architraves. The roof is hidden behind a parapet.
The building was recorded as a hotel by the Goad fire insurance plan of 1887.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/189).

No.70 Prince Street, located on the west side of Prince Street. The building was constructed in the early eighteenth century (traditionally c1725), as one of a pair with No.68 Prince Street (BUAD 1504M). Gomme et al. (1970 128) attribute the classical design to James Strahan.
The building is a three-storey, four-bay house and is of limestone ashlar with rusticated pilasters on the north and south sides of the building and on the north and south sides of the central bays. The ground floor is rusticated and the main entrance is in the south bay. The central bays are set forward and at ground-floor the window openings have semicircular arches with keys and incised voussoirs. The fenestration in the rest of the elevation consists of openings with keyed segmental heads and architraves. The roof is hidden behind a parapet.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/189).

Newgate, located at the western end of Broad Weir. The town gate was constructed as part of the second circuit of the town wall (BUAD 1040M) in the thirteenth century and stood in Broad Weir, at its junction with Peter Street and Wine Street. It appears to have directly replaced the earlier Aldgate or Old Gate (BUAD 34M), which was 82 metres to the south-west along Wine Street.
The form of the gate in medieval period is currently unclear. William Worcestre, writing in the 1480s, records the gate as 9 yards long by 4 yards wide (Neale 2000, 250-251) and notes that there was a large cellar beneath it (Neale 2000, 12-13). It appears to have had a drum towers on at least the eastern sides (BRSMG M2718) and was likely to have been of two storeys, with a room above the gate. At first-floor on the north-east facing elevation there was a cross-window at the north-western side with a trefoil-headed window under a gable top towards the centre of the elevation. The jambs of this window comprised clasped shafts.
From c1426 until the middle of the century a grammar school was held in the room over the gate. The master was Robert Londe and the curriculum of the school, indicated by a manuscript of teaching materials copied "at Bristol, above the New Gate" by Thomas Short (Oxford, Lincoln College MS lat.129) who may have been a senior pupil, derived from Oxford (Orme 1976, 38-40). Londe died in February 1462 but it is not clear whether the school continued to be held after his death. However, it had disappeared by 1480 (Neale 2000, 28-29).
The gate was still extant seventeenth century and formed part of Bristol's defences in the civil war of 1642-1646 when a falcon, a cannon which fired a shot weighing 2 pounds, was sited on it (Roy 1975, 261). Subsequently the gate appears to have been incorporated into the structure of Newgate prison (BUAD 439M) and a second storey was added, possibly around the time of the construction of the prison. Elements of the two round towers on the north, or River Frome, side of the gate survived into the early nineteenth century.
George Weare Braikenridge notes that contractors began to demolish Newgate and the prison in January 1821 and Hugh O'Neill made several drawings during the demolition (BRSMG M2713-M2717).

No.45 High Street, located on the western side of High Street. A tenement belonging to the Guild of Kalendars stood on the site by 1470 and at that date it was occupied by John Lemster, cook, and was part of the group of buildings known as "Cokyn Rewe". The building was leased to Walter Phylyp, mercer, in 1520. Phylyp bought the property from Sir Miles Partridge in 1542 after the Dissolution of the Chantries. Dr. White, Phylyp's grandson, made the tenement part of the endowment of his almshouse in Temple Street (BUAD 283M) and it was subsequently leased to a number of individuals. The building was recorded as new built in 1700 and was known as the "Hen and Chickens," the "Seven Stars" by 1760, "The Globe" in 1775 and "The Wheatsheaf" in 1778 (Leech, 1997 82).
The building was surveyed by Dr. Roger Leech in 2000 (Leech, 2001) and much of the fabric of the building was of late-medieval in date, including the shell walls, the timber beams supporting the floors at ground-, first- and second- floor. The medieval features of the cellar are particularly well-preserved. The original form of the building appears to have been a one-unit house with a gallery linking it to a detached kitchen at the rear. At a cellar level the area between the front and rear walls was probably an open lightwell. The building was refronted in 1907.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/11/586).

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Crow Lane/Telephone House, Queen Charlotte Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
Crow Lane burial ground, located on the west side of Welsh Back. The inhumation cemetery was an extension burial ground belonging to St. Nicholas Parish. The plot was formerly the site of the Chapel of St. John the Evangelist (BUAD 42M) and the parish seems to have acquired it in 1548 after the dissolution of the chapel, since a deed of that year refers to the site as the cemetery of St. Nicholas parish (Leech 1997, 168). The earliest cartographic record of the cemetery is James Millerd's map of 1673. It is also recorded by watercolour paintings dating to the early 1820s in Bristol Museum and Art Gallery (BRMSG M2238 (BUAD 1360) & BRSMG M2279 (BUAD 1378)).
The cemetery was enclosed by a stone wall, and entrance was from Welsh Back via a set of steps at the south end of the wall fronting the Back. The entrance had a semi-circular arched head with a ball finial above and panelled jambs. Roque's map of 1742 shows an open-fronted, roofed structure on the outside, along the entire length of the Welsh Back frontage. A structure, possibly a form of lych gate, stood immediately inside the entrance in the nineteenth-century. This was essentially a pyramidal pantiled roof, with a ball finial in the centre, which was open on its west side. Its western corners were supported by columns and its eastern corners probably by the perimeter wall. Use of the burial ground appears from the painting of 1823 (BRSMG 2279) to have been dense. The burial ground was closed for interment by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852.
The site was subsequently used as a children's play area until this was closed in 1902 (Latimer 1970, 4). The site was then built over. The site of the cemetery now lies mainly under Crow Lane but also extends beneath the Telephone House site. Crow Lane was widened (apparently in two stages) and the northern two-thirds of the burial ground lie beneath it. It is not known whether the inhumations have been removed from the site, but the Home Office has no record of any licence for the removal of human remains being granted (J. R. Brett pers. comm.). Articulated human remains were found in Crow Lane during observation of the excavation of telecommunications trenches in the 1980s (BUAD 293) and it is therefore likely that undisturbed burials remain on the northern part of the Telephone House site, and possibly also in Crow Lane.

KNOWN_AS: Extension to the Young & Melrow Stay and Corset Factory, No.12 Portland Square
MONUMENT_DESC:
Extension to the Young & Melrow Stay and Corset Factory, No.12 Portland Square, located at the rear of No.12 Portland Square and fronting on to Norfolk Avenue. The structure was built some time after 1877 to a design by the architect Joseph Parker. It was a two-storey, L-shaped building of Pennant sandstone rubble with openings edged in brick.
In the Norfolk Avenue, south-east facing, elevation there were three windows at semi-basement level (on the east side of the elevation). At the west end of the elevation was an arch which had formed the main vehicular access to into the factory. The arch was flanked on each side by Pennant sandstone pilasters and the voussoirs were of ashlar freestone. On the eastern side of this another, smaller, access was created. There were four windows at first-floor only one had not been altered. A string course of dentilated brick divided the first and second storey and above there were six second-storey windows. In the north-west facing elevation narrow lancet windows provided illumination to the semi-basement.
The basement contained a toilets in the western arm of the building, a "Grip floor" at the western corner and a dining hall at the northern end. At ground-floor there were separate but adjacent entrances in the east side of the arched haulingway. To the north of these was the fitting floor. The first floor against Nofolk Avenue was the ironing room.
By 2000 the building was derelict and only the shell walls remained (Morton & Oakey 2000, 20).

KNOWN_AS: Gun Emplacement at the Territorial Army Centre

MONUMENT_DESC:
Clifton National School, located on the east side of Church Lane, Clifton. The school was constructed in 1835 and is recorded by the tithe survey of Clifton made in 1844 (BRO EP/A/32/12). It was a large two-storey structure with a hipped roof and occupied a footprint measuring 29 metres east-west by 13 metres north to south on an apparently specially constructed terrace. The main, south-facing, elevation was of nine bays and had tall, narrow windows to both floors, those of the first-floor having segmental-headed arches. The side east-facing, elevation had three bays. Plans in Bristol Record Office (BRO 229389(6 & 7)) indicate that the ground-floor was largely occupied by a single teaching space. At the western end of the building were two smaller rooms and a lodge projected from the building at ground floor. The stairs to the first-floor were at the south-eastern corner of the building. The first-floor was largely occupied by the girls school with a smaller teaching area divided off by partitions at the head of the stair.
By 1883 an extension had been added to the eastern end of the building. This was intended as an Infants School and the Girls school was later also moved into the building. It measured 20 metres from east to west by 10 metres north-south and was a single-storey structure with a pitched roof and basement. The side, south-facing, elevation was of five bays with tall windows with segmental-headed arches and ashlar dressings. Immediately beneath the windows there was a projecting moulded freestone ashlar string course, with a second around 0.5 metres below this. The parapets at the east and west ends of the roof also had ashlar dressings. A single-storey block linking the two school buildings contained the latrines.
The school building survived into the twentieth-century and were damaged by bombing in the early 1940s. The structure remained in ruins throughout the 1950s and the site was subsequently redeveloped. However, the gymnasium, apparently dating to the first two decades of the twentieth century, survives as do elements of the main school building in the succeeding structure (Parry, 2001).

Excise Office, located at the north--west corner of Queen Square. No.55 Queen Square seems to have been constructed in the early-eighteenth century as a house. The 1828 survey of Bristol by John Plumley and George Ashmead indicates that the building was occupied by an Excise office by that date. It was still an Inland revenue office in 1887. The building seems to have been destroyed by bombing during the Second World War and the site was subsequently redeveloped.

Mission Chapel, No.51a West Street, Old Market. The building is located to the north of Nos.49-53 West Street. The origin of the building is not currently known but it appears to have been in existence by 1828. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan surveyed in 1883 records the building as a mission chapel with accommodation for 70 people. The building was still in use as a mission chapel in August 1896. It is a rectangular single-storey building, measuring 10.5 metres from south-west to north-east by 6 metres wide and has a pitched pantile roof. It is constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble bonded in a white lime mortar and the main, north-west facing, and the side, north-east facing, elevations are rendered. There are brick chimney stacks of eighteenth- or early nineteenth-century date projecting from the gables at either end of the roof. The interior was refurbished in the later twentieth century and no evidence of the earlier uses of the building are visible.

No.9 Temple Street, located at the northern end of Temple Street, on its east side. Attached. 3 storeys, no attic storey as such; gabled front; jettied; 2-window range. A right-hand entrance; 3-light window with enlarged centre light. 2 sashes each to the upper floors. Quoins attached at either end of the first-floor of the facade.

A farm was depicted at this site in 1830 (Ordnance Survey 1st edition 1:63360). It forms a group with SMR 9008 and may well be medieval in origin. The farm survived as late as 1946 (CPE-UK-1869 4028), but has been largely built over today. This site is now covered by the sewage works, but elements of post medieval structures and deposits (or possibly medieval) may survive at the site. In the event of planning application for this site, it should be archaeologically evaluated before determination.

Bank Farm. Lying on the north side of Severn Road, the site of the farm is shown by Taylor's map of the area in 1773 as an open field. Bank Farm had been built in the western part of the field by the time of the 1841 Henbury tithe map, and the apportionment indicates that the farm was owned by Edward Sampson and occupied by William Gregory. Orchards lay to the north of the farm (BRO EP/A/32/22). The Ordnance Survey map of 1915 (Glos sheet LXVII.10) recorded the farm as a single range with associated outbuildings, the remainder being orchard. The farm was demolished in 1960 and fuel storage tanks built. These have since been removed.
The site was visited by R. G. Jackson during the course of a desk-based assessment (SMR 20081) of areas of Bristol City Council owned land north of Avonmouth in December 1996. The site was found to be derelict and the ground had been disturbed by heavy vehicles.

KNOWN_AS: Dwelling or farmstead on the bank of the River Severn at Chittening Warth
MONUMENT_DESC: A dwelling or farmstead, located on the bank of the River Severn at Chittening Warth. Human activity began on the site in the eleventh century when the surrounding area was still saltmarsh and occupation continued into the twentieth century (Insole 1997). The ditches around the site surrounding the site had been repeatedly recut during the medieval and post-medieval periods and contained both food remains and pottery. The food material included wheat, barley and oats from the eleventh-century and Celtic beans from the twelfth. The most of the medieval pottery was local, including wares from Ham Green and other potteries in south Gloucestershire. The only evidence for medieval structures recovered were fragments of daub suggesting the presence of timber structures, presumably roofed with thatch. Some lias limestone was, however, noted across the site and this may have been imported as a building material for an early post-medieval stone building. The most substantial building was an "L-shaped" building recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXVII.06) published in 1881. This measured 13 metres north-west to south east and 8 metres south-west to north-east and lay at the northern end of a rectangular enclosure, apparently a garden, which measured 40 metres south-west to north-east by 25 metres. The building was extant in 1920 but had been demolished by 1955.

Nos.18-22 Victoria Street. Shops built in the early 1870s. Trio of buildings with one front. 4-storeys; 6-bay front. Arched ground-floor. Arched openings to first,second and third floors of Nos.18 & 20; square windows set back at first and second floors, round-headed windows at third-floor. Arched openings to first and second floors only for No.22, with square and round-headed windows respectively. Two-light windows to third-floor. Parapets. The roofs to Nos.18-24 were as one, with No.18 hipped to the north, Nos.20 & 22 gabled, and No.24 hipped to the south. No.20 is burnt out, now very derelict. No.22, damaged in the Blitz, was rebuilt behind its facade (but not the third-floor). The twin to No.22 was demolished for the end of the present Counterslip street. Rear elevations of 2 bays. To rear of Nos.18 & 20, tall single-storey structures with clerestory roofs on queen-post roofs, arch-braced collars between the said posts; brick floors. Extensive cellarage to all, stone walls and double brick barrel vaults; brick floors; all linked at one time, but subsequently blocked off from each other. Lift (5-ton capacity) in rear of cellar at No.22.

Bridge Street Chapel, located on the northern side of Bridge Street. The chapel was a Presbyterian chapel constructed in the late-eighteenth century to accommodate the congregation from the Tucker Street meeting house (BUAD 986M) which had been demolished to allow the construction of Bath Street. According to John Pritchard the chapel was architecturally plain, possessing "no features of interest" (Pritchard 1920, 138-139). The chapel closed as a place of worship in 1868, and was subsequently let for business purposes. It was demolished in 1913.

KNOWN_AS: Tratman Brothers Canvas & Rope Merchants, No.77-78, Broad Quay
MONUMENT_DESC:
No.77-78 Broad Quay, located at the west corner of Broad Quay and Thunderbolt Street. The site was created by the infilling of Aldsworth's Dock in the mid-seventeenth century and a building is recorded on the site by Millerd's 1673 map of Bristol.
The original form of the building is unknown but it appears to have been refronted in the late-eighteenth or early-nineteenth century. It was by then a three-storey rendered building of four bays with rusticated ashlar quoins and a hipped pantile roof. The main, north-facing, elevation in Thunderbolt Street consisted of a shopfront with the entrance towards the eastern side. There were three large shop windows on either side of the entrance at ground-floor level, with a third at the west end. A string course divided the ground from the first floor and the fenestration above comprised four tall six over nine pane sash window. The third floor was also marked by a string course with four smaller six over six pane sashes. The side, west-facing, elevation in Broad Quay had three entrance doorways, one blocked at the north end of the elevation with a pedimented canopy, another with a recessed door set in an opening with a plain segmental-arch at the centre. There was a similar doorway at the south end of the elevation and immediately to its north there was a small cellar light. Between these doorways, on both the north and south side of the central door, there was a large shop window. A string course divided the ground from the first floor and at first-floor level the fenestration consisted of tall nine over nine pane sash windows, with two in the south half of the elevation and a single sash in the north half. There was a smaller window between the large sashes, within its head well above the others, possibly lighting a stair. At first floor there were two smaller single nine over nine pane sashes. The eaves of the roof were marked by dentils which continued around the façade of No.79 Broad Quay (BUAD 1395M). There was a small brick chimneystack in the north elevation and a larger stack, the base of which was of stone rubble and the upper part brick, projecting from the party wall with No.79 Broad Quay.
The Goad fire insurance plan of January 1887 records the building as a chandlers dealing in ships stores with a sail loft. By the 1890s it was owned by Tratman Brothers who advertised themselves as canvas and rope merchants, a general ship stores and sail lofts on the front of the building (Winstone, 1960 pls.62-63). The building was apparently demolished soon after the closure of Alderskey Lane in 1900 (Pritchard, 1904 128-129) and the site was subsequently redeveloped for the Co-operative Wholesale building.

KNOWN_AS: Overhanging house, west side of Steep Street
