MONUMENT_DESC: House. In the sharp angle between the west side of Steep Street and the steps leading up to Trenchard Street. Attached to the north-west. Gabled to south-east: no gables to either main elevation. 3 storeys and roof, no attic storey; jettied to Steep Street. Ground and first floors to a near-triangular plan, second-floor corbelled out at southern end to form a sub-rectangular shape. Dated 1540 in plasterwork in centre of upper storeys on Steep Street. To the Street, a left-hand entrance and two 6/6 pane sashes. Central first-floor oriel window, small window to right, corbelling to left. Two 2-light windows to second-floor. Plain elevation to the steps; stacks. Small 2-light windows in the downslope elevation at first and second floors; this wall was timber-framed. There was a small structure adjacent in the extreme angle of the junction, below which was a cistern (O'Neill, 1821, BRSMG M2573).

The Green Lattice, No.41 High Street, located on the south-western side of High Street. The site is known to have been bequeathed by Alice Hailes to All Saints' Church in 1261. The feoffees borrowed money to build an inn or tavern known as the "Grene Lates" between 1439 and 1442 and the building was still known as the Green Lattice in 1653 (Leech, 1997). The tavern was one of the row of houses at the northern end of High Street known during the medieval period as Cooks Row, which sold take-away food to those without the means to cook for themselves. Entries in the accounts of the churchwardens of All Saints for 1475 and 1488 record construction work to the building, particularly to the kitchen (Burgess, 2000 84-85; 120). The form of the medieval building has not been completely established but it consisted of a cellared single-bay house with a detached kitchen separated by an open yard to the rear. Part of the medieval arch windbrace roof of the kitchen (drawn by George Pryce in 1850 (BUAD 3044; Pryce, 1850)) survives, as do two cellars of medieval date beneath the site. The roof of the front, east, cellar is of 5 inch square joists supported on 11 inch square transverse oak joists. The rear, west, cellar has a vaulted stone roof, with an original opening lined with freestone blocks. The walls of the cellar are of coursed rubble bonded in a red mortar with lime inclusions. In the south-west corner is a shute again lined with freestone blocks which, it was thought, might have been part of a garderobe for the floor above (Leech, 1999).
The facade of the house was replaced in the seventeenth century and this was painted by Hugh O'Neill in 1823 (BUAD 1419: Braikenridge Collection, BRSMG M2387). The view shows that the new front was jettied and the roof was gabled. There were shop windows either side of central entrance, a light above the doorway and cellar access under the south window. The glazing at first-floor was full-width and included a central bay with an Ipswich window. There was a roofed oriel or bay at second-floor, with 16/24 pane sash to the front and 6/9 to the side. The four-light attic window had no transom. The bargeboards had carved decoration. George Weare Braikenridge notes that in 1823 the building was known as The Sign of the Three Blackbirds, although a Mr. Stockdale and his son had carried on their woollen drapery business there for many years and it was then occupied by John, Joseph and Benjamin Davies, woollen warehouse.
In June 1825 the building was again re-fronted, the new facade being of limestone ashlar in a late-Georgian Greek Revival style having been taken to afford access to the Rummer Tavern in All Saints Lane (Braikenridge Notes, C.30). The building is of two storeys and attic with a two-window range and a hipped mansard roof. The shop front dates to the twentieth century and has right-hand doorway and plate-glass window.
No.41 High Street was surveyed by Dr. Roger Leech and the Royal Commission on the Historical Monuments of England in 1997 (BUAD 3413) when a plan of the cellars of the building and a cross-section of the rear part of the building and the medieval roof were made (Leech, 1999). The party walls are of stone rubble and may also contain medieval fabric and features. Medieval and early modern timberwork could also remain within the floors of the building. The roof at the rear of the property is a unique survival of a medieval domestic roof in Bristol
[Photographs of the interior of the building, including the medieval roof, are held in the Sites and Monuments Record collection of ground-based photographs, Nos.646-676]

The Corn market, located on Narrow Quay. The building was constructed in 1684 according to a revision of James Millerd's map of Bristol, and therefore pre-dates the construction of Queen Square. The building stood at the south-west corner of Currant Lane, facing Narrow Quay. The first-floor extended over an open colonnade consisting of seven columns of various shapes. At each end, was a square column with the corners chamfered, running out to plain bases and capitals. In the centre was a Tuscan column; the remaining columns had various turned shafts, all with square bases and capitals. There were more columns at the rear of the open area. The left-hand half of the first-floor had a central entrance, with one window either side; the right half, a window left and a double window at the centre. On the left return there was a brick chimney breast, corbelled out above ground-floor level, with external stairs to the first-floor.
The corn market was recorded in a watercolour drawing by Hugh O'Neil in 1823 (BRSMG M2518) and was photographed by Hugh Owen in the 1840s (Winstone, 1970 pls.59-60). The building was demolished in 1849.

Queen Victoria House, located on the southern side of Redland Hill. Queen Victoria House was built c.1885 by Rev. John Henry Wilkinson to house the Wayneflete Private School for Boys. The building was bought by E. P. Wills in 1899 for a committee to establish the first convalescent home in Bristol. The Queen Victoria Jubilee Convalescent Home was opened by Queen Victoria herself during her visit to Bristol on 15 November 1899 (Stone 1909).

Churchyard of the church of St. Augustine-the-Less, at the east end of the south side of College Green. Excavation suggests that the churchyard had been established by the twelfth century.
The north and east walls of the cemetery were set back in the nineteenth century. The north wall of rubble with coping. Piers with ball finials to gateways in north wall (leading to north porch), in east wall, and near to north end of west side. The churchyard was closed to burials by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852.
The churchyard was reported to have been cleared in 1962, but many burials were recovered during archaeological excavation of the church and part of the churchyard in 1983-1984 (BUAD 1686).

KNOWN_AS: Drill Hall, Clouds Hill Road, St. George
MONUMENT_DESC: Drill Hall, located on the southern side of Clouds Hill Road, St. George. The Drill Hall was in existence by the early twentieth-century and was first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500-scale County series plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) published in 1904.

Whitehall Colliery. The Whitehall shaft was sunk by the Easton Coal Company in 1860. The shaft was 1140 feet (348.8 metres) deep and was served by a twin cylinder horizontal winding engine was erected by Gregory of Kingswood (Southway 1971, 20). The site also included a small brickworks.
The depth of the shaft had been increased to 1920 feet (587.5 metres) by 1911 and the colliery was then working the Red Ash, Kingswood Great, Kingswood Little and Gillers Inn coal seams. In 1911 the owner, The Bedminster, Easton, Kingswood and Parkfield Collieries Ltd., closed the colliery, paying the miners off on 20 June 1911. Buildings associated with the colliery survived for some time, and the engine house was extant at the end of the 1960s (Buchanan & Cossons 1969, 242). The site has subsequently been redeveloped.

Crews Hole Copper Works. The copper works was established c.1710 by the Bristol Brass Company. The works is reported to have had 24 furnaces in operation by 1724, and 49 were counted by Angerstein in late June 1754 (Berg & Berg 2001, 142).
Bristol Brass Company abandoned the premises about 1781, and it was then leased to a copper company. Later the site was used as a tar distillery.

Blackswarth Lane Works. Works of Brass and Lead. {1}A large number of copper slag blocks in the walls between the road and river in this area indicate the site of what was primarily a leadworks. But the St George Tithe Map of 1845 refers to a section of these premises as an old brassworks belonging to Joseph Mosely, which by this time was no longer in use. {1} 1792 lead works, Lunell and Co., shown on map.
The existence of this works is mentioned in {1}, there are no structural remains on the site as of 1995.

Brislington Tramway Depot, Bath Road. The structure was designed in 1899 by W. Curtis Green. The two buildings formed one of the seven tram depots owned by the Bristol Tram Company which began trading in 1875.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/56/442).

Gasworks lying on the south side of Glenfrome Road. The gasworks was developed after 1879 and was the largest and best equipped coke gas works in the region until the changes to the gas industry by oil-based processes and North Sea Gas made most of plant redundant (Buchanan & Cossons 1969, 36).
Celtic fields (?) in Shirehampton Park ST539769. Also ridge and furrow at ST538768, ST542769, ST544768) {1}V slight traces of rectangular 'celtic fields' partly overlain by ridge and furrow. {3}

South Liberty Colliery. The colliery appears to have been established in the mid-eighteenth century. In 1748 an engine shaft 765 feet (234 metres) deep was excavated for drainage and in 1750 a Newcomen atmospheric engine (which was still operating in 1895) was installed. A walled shaft was subsequently sunk 800 feet (245 metres) to the Bedminster Great Seam.  This was later increased to 1400 feet (428 metres) to work the Ashton Great Seam. By the late-nineteenth century the colliery was owned by the Ashton Vale Iron Company Ltd. and blast furnaces were installed on the site to make use of iron ore and fireclay encountered during the mining. These furnaces ceased working in 1887, but the associated forge and rolling mills continued to operate into the twentieth century (Southway 1976, 4). South Liberty Colliery was the last surviving Bedminster colliery and was closed in 1925 (Buchanan & Cossons 1969, 95). The site was subsequently redeveloped.

KNOWN_AS: Grounds of Glenside Hospital and Manor Park Hospital
MONUMENT_DESC: Grounds of Glenside Hospital and Manor Park Hospital, located on the north side of Blackberry Hill. The grounds were developed to serve the hospital and include a lime avenue dating to 1870s and walks in the Frome valley on the north side of the site (Avon Gardens Trust 1991, 19).

Brislington Hall. James Ireland, a wealthy merchant from Bristol, bought an estate in Brislington which included the sites of Flowers Hill Farm and Eastwood Farm and built Brislington Hall. The house was a three-storey six-bay building (Winstone 1985, pl337). There was a lodge at the entrance to the drive, five acres of gardens and thirteen acres of parkland. Ireland added to his estate by buying land from William Reeve, the owner of Arno's Court. In 1828, the property was owned by the Ireland Trustees and let to a succession of tenants including  Jacob Ricketts who was listed as the occupier in the Brisington Tithe Award of 1846. Upon his death in 1846 his widow moved into The Elms. In 1856, James Clayfield-Ireland moved into Brislington Hall, having sold Hemplow House (Ireland 1870: BRO St.LB/HM/1a & 1b). The Clayfield family lived in the house until 1923 when the estate passed to a distant cousin who sold it. Brislington Hall was acquired by the haulage contractors, Henry Russett & Sons. The house was then briefly operated as "The Lido Spa Hotel" but the venture did not pay and the property was demolished in 1933 (Rowe & Williams 1985).
The site was redeveloped for Gallagher's Warehouse, itself demolished in 1984. The majority of the grounds were developed for the housing now occupying the area around Hungerford Road.

A house on the east side of the northward part of Wellington Street in Pithay. The house lay at the corner and faced on to the street. The building was a three-storey, three-bay structure with a pitched pantile roof. The windows were sashes. There was also a cellar light in the northern bay.
The building is called "Scully's House" by Reece Winstone after the last inhabitant (Winstone 1983, pl.159). It was demolished in the 1890s to make way for J. S. Fry's factory.

The Barber-Surgeons' Hall, an eighteenth-century livery hall located on the western side of Exchange Avenue. The building was of two storeys and basement. The main, north-east facing, elevation which fronted on to Exchange Avenue was a simple Classical design, of two storeys with three bays. A central entrance between two tall windows, a segmental pediment above the doorway, and blind balustrading below the windows. At the first-floor were 3 windows with eared and shouldered architraves, a above which was a cornice and shallow parapet. The hall occupied the principal storey, with offices below and an anatomical-theatre above. From about 1745 the building was leased as a coffee-house, later becoming "The Grapes" tavern. It was gutted during the Blitz and the front was removed soon afterwards. Ison (1952 92; fig.7) reproduces a drawing of the main elevation.

KNOWN_AS: Jews' Acre, Jewish Cemetery, Jacob's Wells Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
The medieval Jewish Cemetery, located on the eastern side of Jacob's Wells Road, on the site of Queen Elizabeth's Hospital. A plot on the north-west side of Brandon Hill was rented from St. Augustine's Abbey by the local Jewish community, and became their cemetery sometime after 1172, when these were allowed in the provinces. The area now occupied by Queen Elizabeth's Hospital School was traditionally called 'Jews Acre' and Pryce reports that headstones with Hebrew inscriptions were discovered during the excavation of the foundations for Queen Elizabeth's Hospital in the early 1840s (Pryce 1861, 23).
The site of the cemetery was rented out after the Jews were expelled from England in 1290. The accounts of the constables of Bristol Castle record the rent for the site in the subsequent decade - 3s. 4.d in 1295-96 (Sharp 1982, 40) - and Josce of Reigny paid 6s. 8d. to the Crown for it after 1304 (Veale 1933, 74).

KNOWN_AS: House on corner of Trenchard Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
A pair of attached four-storey gabled houses of probable mid seventeenth-century date, located on the western side of Steep Street, close to the junction with, and extending back to, Trenchard Lane. All of the storeys of the main, east-facing, elevations on Steep Street were jettied with the exception of the attic. The main doorway to the southern of the pair was at the south end of the ground floor. A second entrance is shown on the north side of the northern house, although it isnot clear whether this is part of the northern of the pair or of a two-storey gabled structure, apparently of stone rubble with a pantile roof and with a tall square-section brick chimney stack, which is attached to its north side. In both houses the fenestration at first-, second- and third-floor level comprises canted bays containing mullioned windows. The roofs of both houses are pantiled and there is a chimney stack, apparently of brick,.in the valley between the two buildings. At the centre of the north side of the northern house is a stair turret, which is gabled off the main roof. This has two small casement windows at the centre, one at third- floor and the other at attic level. Above each there appear to be drip-moulds.
The buildings survived into the mid-nineteenth century but appear to have been demolished at the end of the 1860s to make way for the realignment of the roads in this part of the city.

House of C17 above the gateway to St. Bartholomew's Hospital, traditionally founded 1240 by Sir John le Warre. Attached. Limestone ashlar, rendered timber-frame, and pantile roof. 2 storeys and attic; 1-window range; gable to the street. 2-light mullioned window to first-floor, similar to attic. 
C13 arched gateway with a deeply-moulded arch, with timber arched braces above on corbels to a jettied first floor with a C20 timber beam. The inside of the arch has attached columns with stiff leaf capitals, moulded as the front; a flagged passage has a blind left-hand arcade of 2 trefoil arches on columns with moulded capitals and hoodmould, facing a fine carved figure of the Madonna and Child with folded drapes (formerly exhibited on the left of the entrance).

Barstaple's Almshouse or Trinity Hospital, on the south side of Old Market Street, on the east corner of Jacob Street. The almshouse appears to have been founded by John Barstaple (died 1411) in the early-fifteenth century during the reign of Henry IV and was confirmed by a grant of Henry V in February 1417 (Manchee 1831, 499-500). It appears to have occupied sites on both sides of Old Market Street from its foundation. The fraternity of the Holy Trinity and St. George ran the almshouse and William Worcestre, writing in 1480, notes that John Barstable had appointed Nicholas Barstable as "master of the priests of the chapel of the Holy Trinity" (Neale 2000, 82-83).
The original form of the almshouse is uncertain and the main evidence comes from watercolour drawings (BRSMG M2764, BRSMG M2772 and M2773) dating to 1822 and 1825 in the Braikenridge Collection, Bristol Museum and Art Gallery. The buildings appear to have been arranged around a courtyard. The accommodation buildings were of two-storeys with traceried windows of late-medieval date. At first-floor there was gallery or corridor which projected from the main range and was supported on corbels. The entrance doors seem to have been set within ashlar mouldings with four-centred arched heads.
The chapel is reported to have been rebuilt in 1716, the work being funded by the Bristol Corporation at a cost of £463 4s. 3d (Manchee 1831, 80). It was apparently reworked again in the early 1790s in a Gothick style (Leighton 1933) and some of the rooms in the almshouse were rebuilt in 1814 at an expense of £140 (Manchee 1831, 79).
The entire almshouse was rebuilt between the mid-1850s and the early 1880s to designs in a Tudor Revival style by Foster and Wood (who also designed the rebuilt Foster's Almshouses in Colston Street ). All of the almshouse buildings are in squared Pennant sandstone rubble with ashlar detailing. The north-east block dates to 1857-1858, while the chapel and the north-west and south-west blocks were reconstructed in 1867. The south-east block dates to 1881-1883. These later blocks show a Burgundian Gothic influence.
The chapel is a single-storey building. The main entrance to the chapel is off Jacob Street, and consists of a doorway with an ogee hood in the centre of the elevation. The three-light east window has Perpendicular tracery and an ogee hood, with crocketed niches on either side and also above it. The Old Market Street elevation has a three-window range, with two-light arched windows. The roof is gabled on the eastern side and hipped on the western, with small square bell tower on the northern side of the ridge.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/12/1633).

KNOWN_AS: Lady Huntingdon's Chapel, St. Augustine's Place
MONUMENT_DESC:
Lady Huntingdon's Chapel, also known as Salem Chapel, located on the north-west side of St. Augustine's Place. The frontage was a continuation of a facade that included No.7 St. Augustine's Place and was of three storeys with a three-window range. String courses divided the storeys and the upper part of the elevation had a cornice and parapet. The southern end of the elevation was angled to begin to turn the corner into Pipe Lane. At ground-floor there was a segmental arch double-width entrance with steps. The fenestration at first-floor consisted of three Gothic arched windows, the central window being a four-centred arch with four lights and intersecting tracery. The two outer windows were narrower two-light windows. At second-floor there were three six-over-six pane sashes.
From c1726 building was occupied by a theatre which was the base for Charles Williams's Company. Thomas Lewis and his company also exhibited plays there around the end of the 1720s. The buildings remained in use as a place of entertainment until their purchase by the Countess of Huntingdon's Connexion.in c.1775 by the Countess of Huntingon's Connexion to act as a chapel. The congregation moved to a chapel at the bottom corner of Lodge Street in 1830.

The Custom House located on Welsh Back. Two tenements stood on the site by 1583, one being used as the Custom House at that date (Leech 1997, 169). A new building was constructed on the site of these in 1666 and acted as the Custom House through the later seveneteenth century, although it is not clear whether the structure was purpose-built as a Custom House. This was a square three-bay building of four storeys and attic with a hipped pantile roof. At the time of its construction the building had a cellar measuring 23 1/2 feet wide and extending 32 feet west from Welsh Back. The main, east-facing, elevation fronted on to Welsh Back. By 1825 (BRSMG M2238; BUAD 1360) the ground floor was a shopfront with entrance doorways at the north end and centre. The northern doorway served a narrow property which was in the occupation of Timothy McDonell in 1850 (BRO Corporation Plan Book C fo.98a). The middle doorway led into a passage to the "Three Cups" public house, built in 1820 at the rear of the building. On either side of this middle doorway were large shop windows with stall risers beneath. The first-floor fenestration consisted of three large sash windows while at second floor there was a large pedimented coat of arms in the place of the central window. On either side there were smaller cross-windows and the fenestration at third-floor consisted of three cross-windows. At the centre of the east face of the roof there was a small dormer with a cross window. A brick "turret" on the rear, west side, of the roof my have given access to a flat roof in the centre. On the north side of building there are a number of tall chimney stacks and towards the centre of the elevation at third-storey level, apparently built into one of the flues, is a feature which may have been a window. A nest of stairs was attached to the north side, some serving an adjacent building. There was also a chimney stack on the south wall. Much of the rear, west-facing, wall had been built against by the early nineteenth century but the elevation had at least two mullion and transom windows, and a three-storey square block with a pyramidal pantile roof had by then been added to its north end. This had single windows at each floor in its west-facing elevation.
In 1666 the building appears to have been owned by John Goninge and his mother Elizabeth who leased it to John Bowen and Richard Thrupp. A new Custom House was built in Queen Square in 1710, and the cellar beneath the building subsequently passed into the ownership of the Corporation which leased it to Francis Brown in 1719 and to Thomas Lewis in 1786 (Leech 1997, 169).
The structure seems to have survived into the mid-nineteenth century. The site of the building is now beneath the eastern part of the site of Telephone House.

St. Raphael's Church, located on the north side of Cumberland Road. The church was built at the expense of Rev. Robert H. Miles as a chapel to the adjacent almshouses for retired sailors and their widows [BUAD 524M]. Miles commissioned the architect Henry Woodyer, an Eton contemporary of his, to design the building (Elliott & Pritchard, 2002 78; 150). The church had thirteen-bays with buttressed aisles on the north and south sides and was constructed of coursed Pennant sandstone rubble with ashlar dressings. Buttresses projected from either side of the west front, which contained a large tracery window. The east window was also of tracery and contained stained glass by John Hardman & Co. of Birmingham. The roof was pitched and there was an elaborate timber fleche containing four bells slightly to the east of the centre of the ridge of the roof, marking the division between the chancel and the nave. The chapel was 100 feet from east to west and 51 feet wide and could accommodate 350 people (BRO P/StR/1/2; Elliott & Pritchard, 2002 150).
Internally there was a reredos of Derbyshire alabaster with a cross in the centre panel and an oak rood screen with carved trefoil-headed tracery. The pulpit was also of Derbyshire alabaster (Elliott & Pritchard, 2002 150).
Construction cost £10000 (Ralph & Cobb, 1991 30).
The church opened in 1859. It developed a reputation for ritualism and the Bishop of Bristol revoked the chaplain's licence to preach in 1879. It was re-consecrated and re-opened in 1893 (Ralph & Cobb, 1991).
The church was damaged by bombing in 1940 and was declared redundant in 1946. It was converted to use as a granary during the late 1940s and early 1950s. The church was demolished in 1954 and its site now lies beneath the western half of the housing development known as The Quays.

KNOWN_AS: Fountain in the Gardens of St Michaels Hill House
Landing stage for the gunpowder magazine south of Shirehampton Park
MONUMENT_DESC:
Landing stage for the gunpowder magazine south of Shirehampton Park. The gunpowder magazine was used to store gunpowder from ships coming up the Avon which unloaded it at the quay on arrival and collected it as they sailed away from the port.
The structures on the site consist of a loading bay, hand crane on the edge of the cliff and a building known as the "powder house." The landing place is built out into the river and the stone retaining wall survives. The date of the structures is unknown. The powder magazine (SMR 20307) was located approximately 40 metres to the west and was demolished without record in the late twentieth century.

Zion Chapel, a Primitive Methodist chapel, located on the south-east side of Fishponds Road. The site was purchased for £150 and the chapel was designed by Rev. T. T. Shields. The foundation stone was laid by Mark Whitwell on 1 September 1874 and the building was constructed by the Bristol firm of Eastabrook & Sons. The opening ceremony was held on 28 March 1875.
The chapel was a two-storey structure constructed of Pennant sandstone blocks with freestone ashlar facings in a romanesque style. A Sunday school had been built to the rear of the chapel by 1904.
On 16 March 1941 a 50 kilogramme bomb landed in Wharf Road, killing eight people, destroying three houses and severely damaging both the chapel and Sunday school. The latter was demolished and the chapel re-roofed with asbestos sheets. Its public function ended and the building was sold to a local haberdashery firm, Deighton Brothers, in the early 1950s. The company shared the buildign with Ranarf Press and J. M; Smith Ltd., linen converters, by 1956. By 1972 Hilti, an art transfer company, occupied the building and it was subsequently acquired by the Governmental Community Industries scheme before being sold to Tollgate Hire Ltd. The chapel building was demolished in 1996.

KNOWN_AS: Clowe's Chapel, Summerhill Road, St. George
MONUMENT_DESC: Clowe's Chapel, a Primitive Methodist chapel, located on the northern side of Summerhill Road. The chapel was recorded by the 1:2500-scale plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) published in 1880-81 and was still extant during the First World War. It was subsequently demolished and the new Summerhill Methodist Church (SMR 22546) was constructed.

Downs Haven Shelter, located on the north side of St. John's Parochial School, Blackboy Hill. The shelter was erected by Mr. S. J. King for the use of convalescent service personnel at the nearby Queen Victoria Convalescent Home (Nichols 2005, 36).

KNOWN_AS: St. John's Parochial School, Blackboy Hill
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. John's Parochial School, Blackboy Hill. The school was constructed in 1850 and is a single-storey building of squared Brandon Hill Grit rubble with bands of Pennant sandstone and limestone dressings in a Gothic Revival style. The roof is pitched and has a diaper pattern of black tiles with red and brown tiles between.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/34/1134).

White Tree Shelter, Westbury Road. The shelter was constructed in 1929 by Bristol Tramways and Carriage Company and is a hexagonal timber structure. It was in operation from September 1929. In 1937 the triangular spandrels were replaced with wood panels. The White Tree roundabout was constructed after the Second World War and the shelter was moved to its present location in January 1951. Extensive maintenance work was carried out to the shelter in 2002 (Nichols 2005, 31).

KNOWN_AS: Air raid shelter at Clifton Hill House
MONUMENT_DESC: Air raid shelter, located in the garden to the south of Clifton Hill House. The shelter is a reinforced concrete tunnel shelter and parallel with the house and covered with turf to form part of the bank at the western side of the garden. The shelter is approximately 20 metres long with open entrances at the northern and southern ends. There are no surviving internal features.

KNOWN_AS: South gazebo at Clifton Hill House
MONUMENT_DESC: Gazebo located at the south-east corner of the formal garden of Clifton Hill House. The building is a single-storey rubble stone structure of Brandon Hill Grit with a pitched roof. The entrance door is set in a semi-circular arched door opening faced with narrow bricks, but with an ashlar limestone keystone and springers for the arch. There is a window in the north wall.

Cook's Folly on the southwest side of Cook's Folly Road. Reportedly built as a prospect tower by John Cook in 1696 and described by Rudder (1779) as an octagonal tower with "three good rooms, with an observatory at top.The rooms are fitted up, and the tower is made use of as a Belvidere to Sneed Park House." The first cartographic depiction of the folly is on the Westbury-upon-Trym Tithe Map, 1841 when the owner was James John Martin Esquire as part of his Sneed Park House estate, the occupier was John Sykes Bramhall. The Folly is likely to have been incorporated within the structure of Cook's Folly House (built 1858), although the Listing description describes the folly as having been demolished in 1892.

KNOWN_AS: Crown and Anchor public house, New Kingsley Road
POSTAL_ADDRESS: Crown and Anchor Public House, New Kingsley Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
Crown and Anchor Public House, located on the corner of New Kingsley Road and Kilkenney Street. The building comprised two houses, made into one. The northern half, against Kilkenny Street, was a three-storey rendered, gabled structure of a single depth plan and with a pitched pantile roof. It was formerly the end of a terrace of housing on Kilkenny Street which was demolished in the mid-1930s as part of a slum clearance programme. The ground floor frontage on New Kingsley Road contained a single large window, which appears to be an enlargement of the original opening for the front door. There was one central sash at second floor and in the gable. On the north-east facing ground floor elevation there was a central large casement window and a smaller casement to the east. Above this the wall was blank. The rear elevation was also blank and rendered. However, there was a stack at the centre of the rear gable and the north side of the elevation had a wide projecting block of fabric, probably relating to the connection of the building to the terrace. The southern part of the building has a two-room depth and was of two storeys with a pitched pantiled roof. The New Kingsley Road elevation was rendered and forms a continuous façade with the northern element. The front door for the public house is in the northern part of the building and there was another large window at the centre. There was a single sash at the centre of the first floor. The gable was hidden behind a parapet. Both elements of the public house appeared to be post-medieval in date.
The building was demolished in the summer of 2004.

The News Theatre, located on the north side of Peter Street. The cinema was built on the site of the former Queen's Hall to a design by Curno Cooke of W. H. Watkins' firm of architects. It was commissioned by Joseph Cohen of Jacey Cinemas Ltd. and built by Frank Wilkins at a cost of £451.1s and took just four months to build (Ewins 1984, 19; 28; Anderson 1983, 55). The News Theatre opened on 26th December 1933 as the first specially designed provincial news theatre (Ewins 1984, 19). The building was very modern in design with a black and green alabaster glass frontage with stainles steel bands and a black tower above the main entrance. The Bristol Evening Post reported on 22nd December 1933 that "This news theatre is unique in the city, notably in the treatment of its main façade, the whole of which is faced with black and green alabaster glass, having stainless steel bands. The tower which rises above the main entrance is faced in black, and the flanking walls are treated with horizontal bands of green and black glass on a black granite base. Further striking features of this elevation are the neon lighting, which has been arranged to harmonise with the architectural design, and the flashing 'world' sign which depicts a rotating sphere with the continents depicted in red neon. The tones of green, silver, and black have been continued in the decorative scheme of the entrance vestibule, which is in every way strinkingly modern. The decoration has been carried out in tints of peach colour, pale green, and silver to the walls and ceilings, with walnut doors, pale green architraves, and black skirting," (Ewins 1984, 19-20). There were approximately 400 seats in the cinema and 50 more than the former Queen's Picture House due to the enlargement of the site (Ewins 1984, 19).
The cinema remained open until 1956 and was demolished in 1959. A photograph of the auditorium taken during the demolition of the building shows that the original late art deco ornamentation around the stage was then still extant (Winstone 1972, pl.231).
The site of The News Theatre now lies within Castle Park.

The house known as "The Marshalsea", located on the north side of Wine Street. The site is now beneath Aylward House, on the west side of the junction of Wine Street and Union Street. The construction date of the building is not known but in 1632 it was, together with the house to the west, the home of Robert Blunt, ironmonger. The house seems subsequently to have been divided into two, the western of the two being owned by Joyce Tyson, widow, in 1712. The plot is described as extending back to the town wall (Leech 1997, 183). A drawing by James Stewart dated 18th April 1751 entitled "The HOUSE formerly the MARSHALSY, from the Garden" (BUAD 3674) records the rear, north-facing, elevation of the building, outbuildings to the north and the garden. The building was of four storeys plus attic and appears to have had three bays, although only the western and half of the central bay can be seen in the drawing. The roof seems to have been hipped with a stack on its west side. The fenestration is recorded as comprising 3 by 6 pane sashes and there was a door at the centre of the ground floor. Attached to the west side of the north-facing elevation is a small 2 1/2 storey structure with sash windows and a pantile roof. The entire west wall of the structure appears to comprise a large chimney stack, freestanding for at least a storey above the roof. To the north of this, on the west side of the plot was a single storey outbuilding with a lean-to roof. On the east side of the plot, apparently a short distance from the house is a narrow four-storey building, possibly a square garden house. This has a single sash window in the third and fourth storeys, these storeys being divided by a string course, perhaps a cornice. There appears to be a tall free-standing stack projecting from roughly the centre of the roof and there were decorative urns on the north-east and north-west corners of the parapet. The rear yard was enclosed by a low wall with a gate at the centre. A path ran through the centre of the garden, with a rectangular planted bed on either side.

No.12 Broad Plain, located on the east side of the junction of Goat Alley with Broad Plain. The building was a three-storey gabled house with an attic, constructed in the seventeenth century. The main, north-facing, elevation was on Broad Plain and the original form of the building comprised a three-window range with the main entrance on the western side of the main elevation. The elevation was of ashlar limestone or incised stucco. The fenestration appears to have consisted entirely of cross-windows, each having a single mullion and a single transom. There was a pentice roof across the full width of the ground-floor, which was supported at either end by a single Tuscan column on a square plinth, decorated on each side with a lozenge within a rectangular panel. There was a pediment above the central first-floor window. A moulded beam extended across the entire second-floor, with a central pediment above a scrolled bracket or console. There was a further console at the apex of the gable.
The building was drawn by T. L. Rowbotham in 1826 (BRSMG M2782), and by that date an external staircase had been erected across the ground and first floors, some of the openings had been altered, and parts of some windows had been blocked. In his notes accompanying the drawing the antiquarian George Weare Braikenridge (F.54) records that the house was reputed to have been the birthplace of the Alderman, the elder Mr. Fripp.
The ground floor of the building was occupied by a shop in 1896 and the building was extant at the beginning of the twentieth century. It appears to have been demolished in the following decade and the site redeveloped.

Warehouse, possibly a former house. No.24 Small Street. At the right-hand, an entrance with rusticated left jamb; adjacent to its left, a doorway with two-centred arch. Above the arch, a transomed window of 12 lights; to the right, above the entrance, a canted oriel with sashes and flat roof. Main roof not visible.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Cathedral of the Holy and Undivided Trinity, College Green
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Augustine's Abbey, College Green. The abbey may stand upon land with an earlier religious use, the late-Saxon Harrowing of Hell carving having been found (reused as a grave slab) in the vestibule of the Chapter House in the early nineteenth-century.
The abbey was founded by Robert Fitzharding in 1140. The house was Augustinian, part of the Victorine section of the order, and the first abbot came from the abbey of St. Victor in Paris after which the section was named. The Romanesque abbey gateway, the gateway in the Registrar's House and the Chapter House are the surviving elements which date to the inital phase of building.
The precinct appears to have occupied the area between College Green and Canon's Marsh. The area to the south and west of the cloister appears to have had a more agricultural function, with a possible barn (BUAD 1456M) and dovecote (BUAD 1457M) lying to the western side of College Square and another dovecote (BUAD 1215M) close to modern Trinity Steps.
The abbey was dissolved on 9 December 1539 when the abbot and eleven canons were present. There were also forty-six paid servants. The abbey church was taken over as the Cathedral for the city and the administrative centre of the new diocese of Bristol which was created on 4 June 1542.

Bethesda Chapel, located on the west corner of Great George Street and Charlotte Street South. The chapel was constructed by the Independent meeting established by Rev. Thomas Connolly Cowan (1776-1868), who had been a curate of St. Andrew's, Clifton but who had seceded from the Church of England. The building was in a Classical style, dated to the late eighteenth- or early nineteenth-century and was of two-storeys and three bays. The main, south-west facing, elevation had a central, pedimented entrance and two other symmetrical entrances at either end of the ground floor, the north-western of these had a broken pediment above. This part of the facade was rusticated. Between the doorways at ground level were arched windows. The central and northern entrances were reached by a flight of steps. There were arched windows at first floor level. That above the central entrance was a three-light window with an enlarged central light. The roof comprised several hipped roofs.
George Müller, founder of the orphanage at Ashley Down, was a joint pastor of the chapel in the 1830s.The chapel was demolished in the mid-twentieth century.

A tenement of twelfth-century date which was recorded during the archaeological excavation at Dundas Wharf in 1982 (BUAD 344). The tenement lay on the west side of Redcliff Street and appeared to have been built simultaneously with the tenement to the south (BUAD 1290M). It was built of Pennant sandstone. It appeared in plan to have had a single room at ground floor and had a yard to the rear in which two wooden tubs were found set into the ground. These were believed to be possible evidence for tanning. The northern and southern boundaries of its plot remained essentially unchanged until the twentieth century, the northern boundary being the common slip leading to the river, but the building was extended westward as land was reclaimed from the river, with at least four more rooms having been added by the fifteenth century via enclosure of the yard and new construction. These extensions were entirely independent of the tenement to the north and the plan of the building and its rate of expansion were different (Good 1990/91, 38).

Baptist Mills brass mill. The mill was established by the Bristol Brass Wire Company in 1702. The company included Nehemiah Champion, Abraham Darby, John Coster and Thomas Coster and rapidly expanded to include a number of other works on the river Avon, including a site at Keynsham (Buchanan & Cossons 1969, 117-118). The works was visited in 1754 by R. R. Angerstein who counted 48 brass furnaces producing two kinds of brass, "Arco and Brass" and recorded something of the process of production (Berg & Berg 2001, 144-145). Gough notes that a House of Commons report called the brass works "perhaps the most considerable brass house in Europe" (Gough 1930, 216).

KNOWN_AS: Wesleyan Methodist Chapel, Lower Ashley Road, Baptist Mills
MONUMENT_DESC:
Wesleyan Methodist Chapel, located on the northern side of Lower Ashley Road. The chapel was founded in 1837. A group of Methodist merchants acquired part of the former Baptist Mills brass works in January 1837 and the chapel opened on 22 November of that year. The building was a two-storey building in a classical style with transepts and an apsaidal eastern end. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.3) surveyed in 1881 indicates that the chapel could accommodate 2000 worshippers.
The associated burial ground surrounded the chapel building, and was enclosed by a low stone wall surmounted by railings, but there was also a separate part to the north-east of the building. The register for the burial ground lists 1062 interments there between 1837 and 1899 (BRO 35123/W/P/1-2).
The Bristol Corporation the Compulsory Purchase of property within the study area in the early 1960s. The Wesley Chapel was subject to Compulsory Purchase by the Bristol Corporation in 1970 and had been demolished by 1973.

KNOWN_AS: Great Western Cotton Works, Feeder Canal
MONUMENT_DESC:
Great Western Cotton Factory, located on the northern side of the Feeder Canal in St. Philips. The factory was constructed in 1838 and was one of the largest in the country at that time, employing over 1000 people.
The main block was demolished in 1968. However, the mechanics block and the weaving sheds are still extant (Falconer 1991).

The Brislington Roman villa, Winchester Road. The villa was discovered in 1899, during the construction of a new road to the east of "Lynwood" (ST 616710) in the garden of which Romano-British pottery had earlier been found. Barker  (1899, 291) states the remains were situated in a field on the northern side of the present Bath Road, about half a mile beyond Arnos Vale Cemetery. The front elevation of the villa was estimated as being fifty yards back from the current position of the main road. Wick Lane was about fifty yards to the east, while to the west was the garden of "Lynwood".   
The site was excavated in advance of development by the Clifton Antiquarian Club and the Bristol Museum Committee, who uncovered a probable villa dating to the late 3rd-century AD (Barker 1900; 1901). The level of the whole site had been covered with a large amount of rubble. Aaccording to Barker, its deposition was "comparatively recent" (Barker 1900, 291) and the rubble may therefore have arrived on the site as a result of alterations to the nearby Bath Road. The construction of the new roadway divided the villa into two portions which made it difficult for the excavators to prepare a complete plan.
The foundations of the villa measured approximately 120 feet [37 metres] from east to west and were 70 feet [21.4 metres] wide, and excavation revealed a group of rectangular chambers of various sizes. Evidence of hypocausts and tessellated pavements was recorded. The villa was a winged corridor type, which was south-facing with at least ten rooms and a small bath area. Branigan (1969, 18) suggests that the building began as a suite of five rooms, possibly with no interconnecting corridor. He then suggests the villa acquired, in the following sequence, its projecting wing rooms and front corridor, a rear corridor and two rooms projecting north, a small bath suite and finally an extended suite of baths. It was destroyed c.370A.D (Russell and Williams 1984, 23).
Quantities of iron and glass slag were recovered, implying that small-scale manufacturing was taking place within the site. Barker lists the finds made during the excavation, and these include coins, pottery, glassware, bronze artefacts and animal remains. Two of the mosaics were recovered; one is exhibited at Bristol Museum and Art Gallery and the other is at Kings Weston Villa
An archaeological watching brief in 1996 (SMR 20031) at No.631 Bath Road to the south of the excavated area recorded no evidence of the villa (Bryant 1996), although field evaluation immediately to the east of the villa in 2005 (SMR 22174) did record in situ Roman features (Cullen 2005).

Grand Hotel, located on the northern side of Broad Street. The hotel was constructed between 1865 and 1869 on the site of the White Hart inn (BUAD 628M) and the White Lion Inn (BUAD 629M) and Nos.54 (BUAD 630M) and 55 (BUAD 631M) Broad Street. It was designed in an Italianate Renaissance style by the architectural practice of Foster and Wood and the building is of five-storeys and attic with a double basement. It is faced with limestone ashlar
As designed the Broad Street frontage at ground-floor was occupied by shops with rectangular rooflights, and the area behind accommodated the service functions of the hotel with substantial brick vaulted arches supporting the upper floors. Carriage access was from the south-eastern return to stables at the rear, which included a carriage turntable.
The public entrance was at the centre of the façade and visitors walked up a flight of steps to the first-floor lobby. On the north-western side of the stair at the front of the building was a conference hall and an office on its south-east side. The lobby extended along the centre of the building and there was a large sale room at its northern end. On the north-west sideof the lobby was a bar and restaurant, and on its south-east side a club room with a large bay overlooking the Christ Church churchyard on the south side of the building and another bar.
The entrance was relocated slightly to the north-west in the early twentieth century and the interior was also extensively altered later in the century. While the front element of the building dates to the 1860s, some of the fabric towards the rear may be reused from earlier structures. A fourteenth-century well survives in the basement towards the rear of the building.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/11/537).

KNOWN_AS: North Street Wesleyan Day School, Backfields
MONUMENT_DESC:
North Street Wesleyan Day School, also known as North Street Junior School, located on the northern side of Backfields. The building was designed by the the local architects Foster and Wood in May 1856 (BRO 22938(2)). The school was constructed over the following couple of years. The Master's house, attached to the south-west end of the building, formed an integral part of the design.
The school is a two-storey Pennant sandstone structure with limestone details in a Gothic Revival style. It has a single-depth plan with a hall in the core south-west to north-east two-storey element, with gabled north-west to south-east wings at either end. The fenestration consists of limestone ashlar mullioned and transomed Perpendicular Gothic tracery windows. The Master's House is a lower two-storey element of the strucure with with a hipped roof and low chimneystack at the south-western end of the ridge. There is a porch with a French Empire-style pyramidal roof on the south-east facing elevation.
An extension, again designed by Foster and Wood, was added to the girls' school, on the north-western side of the building, in 1871 (BRO 22938(16)).
A memorial to former pupils killed during the First World War (1914-1918) was fixed at the landing of the main stairwell after the war. The primary school closed in 1959 and planning permission was granted in the following year to convert the building into a Coroner's Court and mortuary. The works were apparently carried out in 1961, with the mortuary being located on the ground floor and the Coroner's Court occupying the first floor. The interior was modernised for the Coroner's Court and the building remained in that use until 2003 when it closed.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/6/2019).

St. Clement's Dock, Narrow Quay. The dock was an ellipsoidal pit measuring 19 metres long by 4 metres wide and cut into the alluvial clay. Excavation in 1978-1979 (BUAD 442) identified the remains of  contemporary structures at the eastern end of the dock which was interpreted as likely to have served a function relating to the dock or dock-side. The dock was filled in soon after the launch, in 1581, of the "Minion",. the last ship to be built there.

KNOWN_AS: Dock, Lower Midland Yard, Avon Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
A dock within the Lower Midland Yard railyard on the south-west side of Avon Street. The dock was a brick structure constructed in Cuckold's Pill, a pill formed at the confluence of the Wain Brook with the river Avon, in the mid-nineteenth century. The dock measured 48 metres from north-east to south-west and was 6 metres wide. A shed was constructed over the centre of the dock in the early twentieth century.
A section was dug across the south-western end of the dock in 1995 (BUAD 1578; Brett 1995).

Pigeonhouse Farm. The farm was in existence by 1730 and was also known as Arthurs Court (after the Arthur family who had owned the manor in the later-medieval period) or Woory's Farm. It was bought by the Smyth family of Ashton Court in 1569-70. The farm was inherited by Edward Gore in 1760 and remained in the ownership of the Gore-Langton family for another century and a half. The Bedminster tithe survey of 1841 (BRO EP/A/32/7) records that Colonel William Gore Langton then owned the farm and it was rented to James Poole. The farm (Land Parcel 1689) was described as a "House, Garden, Yard & Buildings." By 1851 the farm was rented by Benjamin Poole. The tenancy was taken over by John Beard Withers in the late-nineteenth century and latterly by his son William.
The farmhouse was a three-storey building with a steeply pitched roof (Winstone 1977, pl.203).
In July 1924 Algernon William Stephen Gore-Langton sold the farm. It was purchased by William White of Church Farm, Clutton for £6912. The 1924 sale documents describe the farm as follows:
"The Farmhouse is stone built and tiles and is well placed for the working of the Holding. It contains Entrance Hall, Drawing-room, Dining-room, Office or Cloak-room, Kitchen with range, spacious Dairy and Scullery with two Boilers on the Ground Floor. Upstairs are six Bedrooms (one partitioned by Tenant) and Bathroom.
The Farm Buildings, which are mostly constructed of stone and tiled, are of a substantial character and well arranged and include - Tie-up accommodation for 57 head of cattle, capital 5-stall stable with Loose-box and Loft over, Meal or Calves-house, Trap and Motor-house, Lean-to Wagon-house, set of 4 Cattle or Calves-house, Barn with Granary, Implements-shed, wooden Refrigerator-house, Fowl-house, &c. There are good Cattle Bartons, with large cemented drinking-trough for cattle.
note.- There is an excellent supply of water to the Farmhouse, Buildings and Land obtained by gravitation through pipes from a Spring upon the Farm" (BRO 9492(77) quoted in Bryant 1993).
White owned the farm until it was subject to Compulsory Purchase by Bristol City Council in 1949, along with his other property, Pottery Farm (BSMR 3135). The farm buildings were subsequently demolished to allow development of housing estates at Hartcliffe after the Second World War. The date of the demolition of the buildings is not known but buildings associated with the development of the Hartcliffe estate had been erected by 1957.
The site was archaeologically evaluated in 1994 (SMR 20007) and subsequently a watching brief was carried out.

114, St Michael's Hill, also known as Cogent House and formerly Rupert House. Situated on the east side of St Michael's Hill and south side of Myrtle Road. Built in the late eighteenth century, the building is extant and comprises a three-storey three window range constructed of rendered limestone rubble with limestone dressings and a pantile single-pile roof.
Originally a two storey structure the third floor was added in the late nineteenth century as evidenced by surviving stone copping along the north side of the building above first-floor window level.
Internally, very few pre-twentieth century features survive. The eighteenth century staircase survives, though much altered and the original newel post has been removed. In the hall is a metal fanlight with later coloured glass, an eighteenth century arch with reeded pilasters, a further three-centered arch and a reeded cornice to the rear hall and a late Georgian (now) half-glazed door to the rear. 
The building was first depicted on Donne's map of Bristol, printed in 1826. The 1:500 Ordnance Survey plan of 1885 shows that the building had been extended to the rear and a square bay added to the rear of the original building..
After the Second World War the building became a Nurses' Home and was subdivided into flats.
The building is Listed Grade II (Listed Building number 901-1/4/274).

Inns Court, Knowle. The site was the location of a property belonging to a John Onewyn in 1353 and was owned by John Inyn (d.1439) in the late-medieval period (Collinson, 1791). The architectural style of the surviving stair tower dates to the sixteenth-century and suggests that the house may have been rebuilt then. By the nineteenth-century the building had become a farm and remained in agricultural use until 1937 when the land was acquired by Bristol City Council to build a housing estate (O'Connor 1996). The Bristol Diocese demolished the farmhouse to build a church. The stair tower was, however, retained and restored by the church and is still extant. The housing estate was built in the late 1940s. In 1949 a new church was created from a barn to the west of the house. This was demolished in 1962. The site of Inns Court is apparently now occupied by the vicarage.
The surviving stair tower has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/57/1557).

KNOWN_AS: Mother Pugsley's Well, Nugent Hill, Kingsdown
MONUMENT_DESC: Mother Pugsley's Well, also known by the variant name of Mother Pugler's Well, Nugent Hill. The well may have originated as a spring, but when it was first used is unknown. Its location is recorded by Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 plan of Bristol and the well itself was recorded in drawings of 1788 (BL Add MS 15540 f166) by the Swiss artist Samuel Hieronymus Grimm (1733-1794) and of 1823 by Samuel Jackson (in the Braikenridge Collection, Bristol Museum and Art Gallery BRSMG M964). By 1788 the spring had been converted to a well. The head was apparently about 1 metre square, lined with stone and in 1788 was protected on three sides by a post and rail fence. On the other side was a series of steps leading down to two basins in which the water collected. These basins were carved into a single stone block and both had overflow channels on the same side. A memorandum on the well by a local resident written in 1850 (SMR 21305) noted of the water collected in the basins that one contained "the best drinking water on the hill, and the other water beneficial to persons suffering from inflamed, or otherwise diseased eyes" (Clark 1850, 85). This document also stated that the well had by then been enclosed for his own use by a Mr. Hucker, who was responsible for the development of much of the housing in the field containing the well. By the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.5) surveyed in 1881 the well had apparently been infilled and this plan locates its site between Nos.10 and 12 Nugent Hill.

Shirehampton Remount Depot, Barrow Hill, Shirehampton. The depot acted as a temporary stables for horses and mules arriving at Avonmouth Docks for military service. It was part of the establishment of the Army's Remount Department and was opened in September 1914 as part of an expansion of the Department (Singleton 1993, 188). It was initially staffed by 1380 civilian staff under the control of Army officers.
Animals were bought from Ireland, the traditional source of horses for the British Army, but the majority were shipped across the Atlantic in specially converted ships from the United States of America and Canada (Singleton 1993, 187). The first consignment arrived on 24 October. Most animals arrived from Avonmouth Docks, but around 35000 were also brought by rail (Stone & Wells 1920, 97; 238). The depot could accommodate 5000 animals and held them in quarantine for between a fortnight and twenty-one days. It was divided into ten squadrons and had a veterinary hospital capable of treating 500 animals which included an isolation ward for up to 100. Some animals were shipped out through the Port of Bristol but the majority seem to have been moved inland, many to other depots around Somerset, by rail.
In 1915 the depot became a fully military establishment. It was visited by King George V and Queen Mary on 7 September 1915 and was inspected by Viscount French, Commander of Home Forces, on 23 February 1916 (Stone & Wells 1920, 345).
The last major shipment of animals was on 25 November 1918 and Shirehampton Remount Depot was closed in October 1919, having handled 347045 animals (Neale 1976, 118) including 13811 which were returned from France after the Armistice (Stone & Wells, 1920 97). After the closure of the depot the Bristol Corporation acquired several of the huts as temporary housing (Stone & Wells 1920, 98).
The precise location and extent of the depot has not yet been established.

KNOWN_AS: St. Simon's Church, Lower Ashley Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Simon's Church, located on the southern side of Lower Ashley Road. Construction of the new church was approved in 1845 and £400 was contributed to the cost by the Incorporated Society for promoting the Enlargement, Building and Repairing Churches and Chapels. It was constructed in 1847 to a design by Hicks and Gabriel of Corn Street, Bristol. It was designed to accommodate 700 worshippers and, as a condition of the grant, 500 of the seats were to be free. The first incumbent was John Thomas Barclay. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.3) surveyed in 1881 recorded the church and indicated that it could accommodate 730 worshippers. The church was surrounded by a burial ground.
The church is extant and is now the Greek Orthodox church of SS. Peter and Paul.

Blaise Manor, originally known as Henburyhill House, located on the east side of Henbury Road. The building dates to the late-eighteenth or early-nineteenth century and is a roughly square, three-storey structure with a double-depth plan and a hipped slate roof. The building is rendered with limestone ashlar dressings. The main, north-facing, elevation has a four-window range with a central four-storey stair tower with rusticated pilasters. The main entrance door is set in the ground floor of the stair tower, beneath a porch has a pair of square columns and entablature with a shallow pediment. On either side there are projecting single-storey D-shaped bay windows.
The north-, west- and south-facing elevations are all of three storeys with four-window ranges and a plat band beneath the first-floor windows, cornice and parapet. There are two-storey ranges on the eastern side of the building. The fenestration throughout consists of six-over-six pane sash windows.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/21/2071).

The Elms, Brislington, located on the south side of a lane leading north-east from Bath Hill. The date of construction of the house is unknown, although it probably dates from the 18th century, but it is recorded by the Brislington Tithe Survey of 1843. A photograph taken around 1903 (Winstone 1985, pl.331) indicates that the house was double-fronted with a central doorway with an open-bed pediment, and semi-circular bay windows on either side. A gravel drive led around the house to the south east entrance, but there do not appear to have been formal gardens. A number of outbuildings, of unknown function, lay to the west of the house. The house was demolished in 1939, and the site had been redeveloped by 1960. The extent of surviving archaeological deposits associated with the house and its outbuildings is unknown.
Rebuilt on site of earlier house (Rowe 1985, 13) dating from the seventeenth century when part of an estate granted to Thomas Daniel. In 1660, Rowland Lacy, Lord of the Manor, enfranchised copyhold lands in exchange for small fee farm rents and so Daniel received enfranchisement.  The site included the subsequent properties of "The Elms"which was formerly called "Upper Oakenhill", and a second property formerly known as "Lower Oakenhill".  The estate remained in the Daniel family until 1775 when it was sold to William Hall.  (Ireland Manuscripts). Rowe (1985, 13) states the house was rebuilt in the eighteenth century.  In 1780 the estate was sold to Nehemiah Bartley, distiller from Bristol, and as one of the nouveau riche merchants may well have been responsible for the rebuilding of the house.  There were several owners in rapid succession until 1796 when the house became part of the Clayfield-Ireland estate.  In the early 19th century, the house was let to the Rev. Thomas Browne Simpson, Vicar of Keynsham, from 1804-1818.  Mrs Susanna Ricketts rented the property in 1846 after leaving Brislington Hall following the death of her husband, Jacob Ricketts. After her death in 1870 there followed a number of tenants with Egbert Spear being the last occupier in 1912.  After his death in 1936, the house remained unoccupied and was badly damaged by fire in 1938, and was demolished a year later.  A Scots Fir tree, one of several which grew on the edge of the lawn, was recorded as surviving still in 1985.

Keepers Cottage, Brislington, located on the northern side of Brislington Hill. It is not clear when the cottage was constructed, although it is likely to date to at least the seventeenth century. The building is a two-storey structure constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble bonded in a white lime mortar and has a pitched pantile roof. Several blocked openings are visible in the external walls, indicating a history of alteration, and it may have been divided into two cottages at one stage. Surviving internal details include stop-moulded chamfered beams, of likely late sixteenth- or early seventeenth-century date (SMR 20484). The original form of the cottage is currently uncertain but may have originally had a cross-passage plan form with a chimney on the south gable wall. To the south of the house the site of the infilled well, with the head of the iron pump still extant, was noted. In 1852, a Mr. Smart who was the gamekeeper on the Clayfield-Ireland estate is recorded as living in the cottage and it was subsequently occupied by various estate workers. By 1890 the cottage was occupied by Henry Knight and was known as Bath Hill Cottage. In 1924 the cottage was purchased by Blanche Sherwell who lived there until 1939 when there was a succession of tenants until 1953 when the house was purchased from the Sherwell family by Maitland Mitchell.
The building is extant and has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/49/448).

Probable summerhouse located to the west of Clifton Wood House. It was located on the south side of the wall retaining the terrace on the nerthern side of the garden and was in existence by 1828. The building measured 17 feet (5.3 metres) square and was apparently constructed of stone rubble. It had an arched doorway to the garden of Goldney House at the north-east corner and a fireplace at the north-western. Other details of construction are currently (20/09/2003) unknown.
The building had been demolished by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 town plan surveyed in 1883. Elements of the brick flue of the chimney and the blocking of the entrance doorway to Goldney garden survive in the terrace wall.

KNOWN_AS: Society of Friends Burial Ground to the south of Bath Road, Brislington
MONUMENT_DESC:
Society of Friends' burial ground, Brislington. The burial ground was sited on the south side of Bath Road, to the east of the junction with Stockwood Road. It was founded c.1691, the land being held on a one thousand year lease, and was originally surrounded by a wall. It was sold to Dr. Francis Fox in 1836 with the condition that "it shall be kept in good order and repair as a Private Burial Ground, and that Dr. Fox shall enter into a covenant to allow Burial there to Members of the Society of Friends should further occasion arise" (quoted in Stock 1997, 2). The boundary wall of the burial ground was crenellated. In the early 1970s, the area was paved over with the gravestones remaining in situ.
The inhumations apparently remain undisturbed within the burial ground, although neither grave markers nor the boundary wall survive (ibid.). A watching brief in 1998 during development of the adjacent car showroom (SMR 20373) noted what may have been part of the boundary wall of the cemetery. This was of limestone rubble construction and was exposed in a trial pit at a depth of 1.1 metres below the ground surface (Pilkington 1998).

Blaise Castle House, Henbury Road. The building replaced an earlier, a house was constructed between 1796 and 1799 for John Scandrett Harford, a Bristol banker to a design by the local architect William Paty (1757-1800).

(Priest 2003, 117-121).

Limestone ashlar and render with a slate roof. Double-depth plan around a central hall. Neoclassical style. 2 storeys; 5-window range. 1:3:1 fenestration with a pedimented and slightly projecting centre. 
A central semicircular Ionic portico on a low platform, banded square-cut rustication to the ground floor, first-floor plat band, modillion cornice and balustrade. An exedra behind the portico has 2 niches and a swag frieze with bucrania, a half-glazed door with a fanlight; six-over-six pane sashes with thick glazing bars, with moulded architraves below sunken panels on the first floor.

John Nash (1752-1835) added the Conservatory in 1804.
Extended 1831-1832 by Charles R. Cockerell (1788-1863) for John Harford junior. Garden front remodelled c1832

Interior, a complete Neoclassical decorative scheme by Charles Cockerell, with statuary collected by John Harford junior on his 1832 Italian tour.

The house is set in a landscape planned designed in c.1796 by Humphry Repton (1752-1818). Repton visited the site in August and October 1795. The Red Book is preserved in the House.

The Harford family left the house in 1926, selling the estate to Bristol Corporation.
The first visits by the public to the estate took place on 22 to 25 May 1926. The park was then closed until the purchase was finalised in June 1926. Blaise Castle House became a branch of the Bristol City Museum and Art Gallery in 1949.

The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/17/1370).

Rustic Lodge, Blaise Estate Cottage. Early C19. Clad in strips of bark; brick stack and thatch roof. Single-depth plan. Cottage ornee style. Single storey and attic; 1-window range. Openings formed with curved timbers: pointed-arched doorway in right-hand porch, windows with pointed arches, leaded ground-floor casements and lattice attic windows. INTERIOR not inspected. 
Though not mentioned in Repton's Red Book of the Blaise Castle House landscape scheme, and therefore possibly contemporary with the 1766 castle (qv), it is much more in character with the Nash/Repton improvements of 1798. A finely detailed and uncommon design, exemplifying the rustic simplicity of construction advanced by contemporaries such as Rousseau.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/21/1368).

KNOWN_AS: Barton Hill Pottery, Queen Ann Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
Barton Hill Pottery, located on the southern side of Barton Hill [modern Queen Ann Road]. The pottery was established on the site in the late 1850s or early 1860s, apparently having originated on the site of Tilly's Court (2293M) to the north in c.1810 (King 2008) and depicted on a plan of St Philip & Jacob outparish dated 1827 as Duffet's Pottery. 
 The pottery is listed in Matthew's and Slater's Street Directories as Thomas Church crucible maker and earthenware manufacturer from 1852 until 1874, although the 1866 Kelly's Directory lists Alfred Niblett manufacturer of brown ware at Barton Hill continuing as a potter then stoneware manufacturer and dealer until 1886.
The pottery is first depicted as The Barton Hill Pottery on the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.4) surveyed in 1883.
In 1887 Stephen Hollister was listed as a potter at the Barton Hill Pottery after which the property passed to the Noakes & Co paint keg and oil drum manufacturer.
The pottery buildings appear to have been demolished by the time of the First Worlsd War.

KNOWN_AS: Royal West of England Academy, Queen's Road, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC:
Royal West of England Academy, located on the north-eastern side of Queen's Road, Clifton. On 21 December 1844 the inaugural meeting of the Committee of the Bristol Academy for the Promotion of the Fine Arts, chaired by the banker John Scandrett Harford, was held at the Bristol Literary and Philosophical Institution [now the Masonic Hall] in Park Street. Mrs Ellen Sharples had given £2000 for the use of the Academy and a number of prominent local artists, among them Charles Branwhite, Samuel Jackson and William West. Harford became the first President with the banker Philip Miles as Vice-President. The first exhibition organised by the Academy was held in a building at St. Augustine's Parade between March and July 1845. At her death in 1849 Ellen Sharples bequeathed much of her estate to the Academy and the decision was taken to construct an art gallery. A design was produced by the architect John Henry Hirst in 1855 and the building was completed in 1857. The interiors were designed by Charles Underwood. The building as constructed was a two-storey structure. The main, west-south-west facing, elevation was constructed of ashlar stone and was of six bays. The ground-floor was rusticated with a doorway at either end. The main entrance was at first-floor level with the doorways set behind an arcade and was reached by a stone stair with balustrade on the frotn of the building.
In 1908 Henry Dare Bryan and George Oatley produced a scheme for a new domed two-storey entrance hall which involved the demolition of the staircase on the front of the building. Dare Bryan died in 1909 and S. S. Reay of the practice Silcock & Reay was appointed to oversee completion of the scheme and produced a slightly modified version. A competition was held in 1913 to produce murals in the lunettes in the hall. The competition was won by Walter Crane with a scheme for four paintings representing Painting, Craftsmanship, Sculpture and Architecture. The Academy was granted a Royal charter in the same year and King George V opened the refurbished building on 7 October.
During the Second World War the building was requisitioned for use by the Bristol Aeroplane Company, by the Ministry of Works and later in the war by US forces.
A major restoration programme was carried out in 2002 which included conservation work on the Crane murals.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/9/957).

West House Farm. The site of the farm (ST 53389 80905) is shown as an enclosure on Taylor's map of 1773 (BRO 29351) and was recorded by the 1822 enclosure map (GRO Q/RI 154), the 1841 Henbury tithe map, as well as the 1881 and 1915 Ordnance Survey maps. The tithe map records that the farm was owned by Celia Dickenson and occupied by Henry Hall. On the north side of the enclosure containing the farmhouse were three small enclosure identified as barn and orchard (BRO EP/A/32/22).
Most of the site is beneath a warehouse and silage clamps and yard of an adjoining farm. Two buildings of the farm remain, a stone barn with a tiled roof to the west of the original farm complex and a stone building of unknown function to the east. Historic maps show a ditched enclosure to the south-east of the farm (ST 53448 80874) which may be a medieval moated enclosure and possibly the original site of the farm. This feature is extant.
The site (Area 1; Site 5) was visited by R. G. Jackson, during the course of a desk-based assessment (SMR 20081) of areas of Bristol City Council owned land north of Avonmouth, in December 1996. The enclosure containing the farmhouse was found to be overgrown by trees and undergrowth.

KNOWN_AS: Memorial to Princess Charlotte, Queen Victoria House, Redland Hill
MONUMENT_DESC:
Memorial to Princess Charlotte Augusta of Wales (1796-1817), Queen Victoria House, Redland Hill. Princess Charlotte was the only child of George, Prince of Wales (later Prince Regent and George IV) by his wife Caroline of Brunswick (Merritt 2002, 20-21). In 1816 she was married to Prince Leopold of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha (1790-1865), later King Leopold I of Belgium. She died from complications during pregnancy on 6 November 1817.
The memorial was erected in the grounds of Vincent Lodge (SMR 21031) after Charlotte's death in 1817 by Jacob Wilcox Ricketts who leased the building from 1806. It is a limestone obelisk comprising a tall shaft with a pyramidal top and a  moulded base, set on a square plinth. There are fielded panels on each face and carved wreaths on the sides. A bronze tablet on the front panel carries the inscription:
"This Obelisk was erected by / JACOB WILCOX RICKETTS / to perpetuate the Memory of / HER ROYAL HIGHNESS / The much lamented and beloved / PRINCESS CHARLOTTE / of WALES and SAXE COBURG; Daughter of / HIS ROYAL HIGHNESS THE PRINCE REGENT, / and Consort to his Serene Highness PRINCE LEOPOLD. / This most illustrious Princess, the brightness of whose / Character surpasses all transcript, / was BORN Jan[uar]y. 6th 1796. Was MARRIED May 2nd 1816. AND DIED Novr. 6th 1817. / Thus were the Vine and Branch of true Whiggism and / Britannia's most blooming expectation, by one / irresistible stroke, together cut off."
The memorial has a Grade II listing.

KNOWN_AS: Imperial Soap and Candle works at Hudds Vale Road, St. George
MONUMENT_DESC: Soap works, located to the west of Hudd's Vale Road. The factory was constructed on the site of the Crown Pottery (SMR 20967) in the late nineteenth century and is recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500-scale County series plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) published in 1904. It was operated by James. L. Thomas & Company of Bristol and Exeter. Many of its buildings appear to occupy a similar footprint to those of the Crown Pottery suggesting that they had been retained and converted. The factory was still extant at the end of the First World War but the site has been redeveloped as the Soaphouse Industrial Estate.

Bedminster Tannery, located on the western side of East Street. A map of 1845 shows a large tanyard. Large range of buildings around yard, opening on to road now called Bedminster Parade. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan surveyed in 1883 (Sheet LXXV.4.19) records the tannery. The site was later developed for a new factory for W. D. and H. O. Wills.

KNOWN_AS: Lighthouse at the Swash Channel, Avonmouth
MONUMENT_DESC:
A lighthouse located on north bank of the river Avon, located 150 metres to the north of the north corner of Avonmouth Dock. The lighthouse was probably constructed in the mid-nineteenth century and consisted of a hexagonal central tower with connected blocks on its north and south sides) set within a semi-circular enclosure.
The lighthouse tower stood approximately five storeys high and the top had a machicolation approximately 1.5 metres high with a walkway around the lantern. The lantern had a circular sloping roof with a ball finial at its apex. Single-storey blocks with pitched roofs connected the tower to identical two-storey structures to the north and south. The two-storey blocks appear to have had an identical, mirror-image, form. The west-facing elevations had bay windows at the centre  and a smaller sash window above. There was a moulded stone hood mould over each. The side, outward-facing, elevations had wide projecting three-flue chimney stacks at either end. These projected above the eaves and had three tall individual brick flues with clay chimneypots on top of each stack. Between the stacks, apparently mid-way between ground and first floor level there were small casement windows with a hood mould, possibly indicating the position of internal stairs. The roofs were pitched and there were low parapets at either end. The inward-facing elevations had a large window at ground floor with a hood mould above at its western end. The enclosure was surrounded by a tall curving wall.
