The Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.01) published in 1903 records that the lighthouse was had an occulting white light (giving out longer phases of darkness than illumination) with a red sector (a vertical red strip of light in the centre of the beam which was only visible within a certain arc and could therefore be used to set a course). The lighthouse survived into the early nineteenth century but was demolished between mid-1902 and 1908 to allow the construction of Royal Edward Dock. The site is now at the edge of the channel leading from Avonmouth Dock to Royal Edward Dock. All traces of the lighthouse tower will have been removed by the construction of a small dock c.1916 but the at least part of the buildings to either side may well survive.

The Clifton Pump Room, located on the west side of Sion Hill, Clifton. The building is a single-storey limestone ashlar building built in 1894 by Philip Monro along with the adjoining Grand Spa Hotel (now Avon Gorge Hotel) to the south. It formed an integral part of the Clifton Spa complex along with the Clifton Rocks Railway for which Monro was co-engineer. The Pump Room originally drew water from a borehole to the Hotwells. Between 1920 and c.1921 the building was used as Clifton Spa or Grand Spa Picture Theatre (Anderson 1983, 39). It subsequently became a ballroom.

KNOWN_AS: Former Coach House to the rear of no.16 Vyvyan Terrace
MONUMENT_DESC:
Two storey coach house to the rear of no.16 Vyvyan Terrace, Clifton fronting Vyvyan Road. The structure, consists of roughly coarsed, roughly hewn or unhewn stone, bonded with lime mortar. The majority of the stonework is Dolomitic Conglomerate with occasional pennant sandstone, some Bath stone ashlars and Bath stone quoins at first floor level in the south, elevation. 
The south elevation has two ground floor openings; an eastern segmented arched wooden doorway opening out on wrought iron hinges and a western folding double door beneath a reinforced steel joist and a centrally located, low, single wooden door at first floor.
On the northern elevation facing the house and garden is a single ground floor opening in pointed gothic arch style, four blind pointed arches, two on each floor, a single wooden door at first floor level above the ground floor entrance and a single six pane sash window to the east.
Machine made bricks forming the gables in the east and west elevations indicate twentieth century alterations to the roof structure.
Internally the ground floor is divided into two rooms; the western room flagged with pennant slabs, the eastern room a mixture of flagstones and cobbles. In the southern half of the west wall were the remains of a single blocked fireplace. Metal fixings in wooden shelving in the western room possibly for hanging bridles and saddles. The partial remains of wooden stalling for a horse were recorded in the east room.

No.119 West Street, Bedminster. The building was constructed in the seventeenth century. It was constructed of Lias limestone bonded in a white lime mortar and had limestone ashlar windows. The original plan of the building is currently unknown but it appears to have been a two-storey house with an attic and basement. It had a central entrance and hall with a stair tower at the rear of the building. Ovolo-moulded stone windows from this earliest phase of construction survive at basement level in the main, north-west facing, elevation and a similar, smaller window survives at first-floor level in the rear, south-east facing, elevation to the east of the stair tower.
In the early eighteenth century the building was refronted. The majority of the fenestration was replaced with sashes and the internal fittings appear to have been comprehensively replaced. The stair dates to this phase.
In the second half of the twentieth century the building was heavily altered. By the early 1950s the building was apparently in use as a pipe fabrication workshop and a lean-to extension, roofing over the area at the rear of the building, was added in the late-1960s. The southern wall of the original stair tower was probably removed as part of this work. In the mid-1970s a new two-storey building was constructed on the north-east side of the building and door openings were created into the new structure at several levels through the side wall of the existing building.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/45/390).

KNOWN_AS: St. Aldhelm's Church, Bedminster Down Road, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Aldhelm's Church, located on the southern side of Bedminster Down Road. The churchwas in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXV.08) published in 1890 and it then measured 16 metres from east to west by 7 metres wide. The church remained similar in size into the early twentieth century but was subsequently enlarged.
There is a photograph of the west elevation of building in the SMR Collection of Ground-based photographs, number 1861.

KNOWN_AS: Earthwork feature to the north-east of Purdown Anti-Aircraft gun site
MONUMENT_DESC:
An earthwork feature located 60 metres to the north-east of the Purdown Anti-Aircraft Gun Battery site. It is sited on the eastern side of the Down, some 40 metres below the ridge. It is a low earth mound approximately 24.5 metres in diameter and survives to a height of roughly 0.25 metres. The character of the monument is at present unclear. It may be a barrow. However, O'Neil and Grinsell argue that it is not a long barrow and suggest that it "more probably a seventeenth-century mound connected with landscape gardening (O'Neil & Grinsell 1960, 68).
The feature and the surrounding area is currently under grass.

KNOWN_AS: Bristol Lunatic Asylum, Blackberry Hill, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC:
Bristol Lunatic Asylum, located on the north side of Blackberry Hill. The asylum, designed by Henry Crisp, was constructed in 1861 a short distance to the north-west of the Bristol Union workhouse. An isolation wing (now Orchard Day Hospital) was constructed c1898 to designs by H. Crisp and G. H.Oatley. The main asylum building was extended, the hospital chapel and the Lower Lodge constructed between 1885 and 1916 when the second edition Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan was published. In 1948 the buildings became Stapleton Hospital (later Glenside Hospital) and there have been alterations to the building while it has been in National Health Service ownership (Leech 2001).
The main hospital building (901-1/30/1260), the Upper (901-1/30/1259) and Lower (901-1/30/1262) Lodges, the hospital chapel (901-1/30/1261) and the Isolation Block (901-1/30/1263) all have a Grade II listing.

KNOWN_AS: War Memorial at Eagle Road, Brislington
MONUMENT_DESC:
War memorial located on the north-eastern side of Bath Road, Brislington, opposite its junction with Kensington Park Road. The memorial is a rusticated Celtic cross of Portland stone. The base is an octagonal base with three steps. On this is a chamfered square plinth on to which the cross is set. The shaft of the cross has a moulded sword on the south-west face with a laurel wreath beneath it. The plinth carries an inlaid legend, the lettering apparently being of lead. The legend reads:
"1914 1918/IN PROUD/AND GRATEFUL MEMORY/OF THOSE FROM THE/PARISH OF BRISLINGTON/WHO GAVE THEIR LIVES/IN THE GREAT WARS/1939 1945."
The stone mason responsible for carving the monument is believed to have been William Christopher Welsford.
[There are photographs of the memorial in the Sites and Monuments Record of Ground-Based Photographs. Public Monument and Sculpture Association reference number BR159].

Filwood Farm or Philwood Farm, located some 400 metres to the south-east of Inns Court. The farm was probably established in the mid-seventeenth century. By 1730 it formed part of the estate of the Smyth family of Ashton Court and was rented to James Forest. At that date it comprised 201 acres (BRO BRO AC/M11/32). By the time of the Whitchurch tithe survey of the earlier nineteenth century the farm was owned by Edward Gore Langton and let to Benjamin Hall (Burchill 1997). The Hall family apparently continued to work the farm until the end of the Second World War, buying the freehold in 1924 (Bantock et al 1996, 32; 117).
The farmhouse was of probable seventeenth century date. It was of two-storeys and attics and measured approximately 14.5 metres from north-west to south-east by 12.5 metres wide. It was constructed of coursed stone rubble  The south-east and north-west facing elevations were gabled and there were freestone copings on each of the gable ends with a ball finial at the apexes of the gables at the south-western end of the building. The roofs were pantiled and there was a chimneystack at the centre of the ridge of the southern range. The northern range had a smaller stack apparently at the centre of the ridge and a single flue chimneystack at the south-eastern end of the north-east facing elevation.
By the early twentieth century the original windows of the south-east and south-west facing elevations had been replaced with timber casement windows. A one-and-a-half storey extension was added to the north-west facing elevation of the farmhouse and a linked building was attached to its south-east corner. A coursed stone rubble wall enclosed the area on the western side of this building and the southern side of the farmhouse, presumably forming a garden. The farmyard was to the west of this wall and there were a number of outbuildings on the south and west sides of it. Both the extensions and the outbuildings were constructed of stone rubble.
The farm survived into the twentieth century and is reported to have been extant in 1945 (Bantock et al. 1996, 117). It was purchased by Bristol City Council and the buildings subsequently demolished.
An archaeological watching brief during development of the site in 1998 (SMR 20460) recorded two limestone rubble walls, both bonded in an off-white lime mortar and 0.43 metres wide, which formed part of one of the outbuildings to the north-west of the farmhouse (Insole 1998). The site of Filwood Farm now lies beneath South Bristol Business Park on the northern side of Hengrove Way.

KNOWN_AS: Obelisk commemorating Lady Elizabeth Somerset at Star Hill, Stoke Park
MONUMENT_DESC:
Obelisk in Stoke Park, located some 420 metres to the west of Stoke House itself on the southern slopes of Star Hill, within the grounds of Stoke House. The obelisk was built in 1761-1762 to commemorate Lady Elizabeth Somerset, daughter of the 4th Duke of Beaufort and also the niece of Sir Norborne Berkeley who had inherited Stoke House in 1738, who had been killed in a riding accident nearby on 7 May 1760. It is likely to have been designed by Thomas Wright, who was responsible for the landscape design at Stoke Park. As built, the obelisk stood around 16 metres high and was a rectangular structure surmounted by a solar disk or "star" of gilded mahogany. The structure had a core of random Lias rubble stone and was faced with limestone ashlar blocks. There was a latin inscription on the .
The obelisk was struck by lightning in 1940 and subsequently collapsed, ultimately leaving only a remnant consisting of the rubble core and some of the facing stone. This seems to have eroded rapidly during the 1990s, standing 5.7 metres high in 1989 but only approximately three metres high by 1999. In 1999 the obelisk was archaeologically recorded by Wessex Archaeology (Matthews et al 1999) and was then the subject of conservation works by St. Blaise Ltd. (D. Haigh pers comm.).
The obelisk has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/54/1972).

Madam Farm. The farm is recorded by the 1772 Southwell estate plan (BRO 26570) where it is named as Watson Farm, but the date of its creation is unknown. The farm lies somewhat askew to Lawrence Weston Road, suggesting that it may predate the laying out of this road. Desk-based assessment suggested that the farm name derives from the adjacent common meadows of Madam or Mead Hamm (Lawler, 1995 6) underwent many structural changes during its lifetime but nonetheless represented a rare survival of what would probably have been a typical farmhouse in the area.
The building consisted of two long ranges in a double-pile plan with a further range at right angles towards the rear (North) end of the property. An external inspection of the building showed that the western long range of the building was a later addition. It has a flatter roof pitch and its roof abutted that of the range at the rear. It was, however, probably no later than the late eighteenth century. The rear range was constructed of lias limestone, in marked contrast to the western long range and most of the eastern long range. It would appear, therefore, to have been of a separate build from the rest of the property, although it is uncertain whether it was earlier or later in date than the eastern long range. The eastern long range had been partially rendered, but there were traces of similar lias limestone in the upper courses of the east wall near the eaves, perhaps suggesting that the roof had been replaced at some time in the past. At the northern end of the property was a single storey range which necessitated the bricking up of the original fireplace in the north wall of the earlier building. The bricks used were handmade and probably no later than the mid nineteenth century, suggesting that the extension was built some time in the first half of the nineteenth century.
Internal inspection revealed a long through passage extending the full width of the building through both of the long ranges. In the room to the north of the passage in the eastern long range, there was a plain chamfered ceiling beam with a plain stop and a small cupboard in the east wall with H hinges. There was a similar plain chamfered beam in the room opposite, to the south of the through passage. A door leading to the rear range from the through passage had strap hinges with spearhead ends, while a door on the upper floor had strap hinges with expanded ends. The internal fittings are likely to be original to the building and would suggest an initial date for construction in the late seventeenth or possibly the early eighteenth. The building displayed a conservatism of style which might be expected in an isolated area such as the North Avon Levels.
Madam Farm was inspected by the City Archaeologist for Bristol City Council, Bob Jones on 10th May 1997. The inspection was brief and no measured survey was carried out, although some photographs were taken showing the exterior and interior of the farm and its outbuildings which are held in the SMR collection of ground-based photographs. The farm was demolished in May 1998 without record.

KNOWN_AS: Phoenix Pottery, Millpond Street, Baptist Mills
MONUMENT_DESC: Phoenix Pottery, located at the junction of Mina Road and Millpond Street. The buildings may have been part of the former Baptist Mills Brass Works (SMR 1379). The pottery was established in 1840 by Joseph White and his brother James (Pountney 1920, 268) and manufactured Egyptian black pottery, Rockingham teapot and also clay tobacco pipes. By 1851 the White's were employing 95 people (Price, Jackson & Jackson 1979). Joseph White emigrated to Canada in the 1860s but the pottery seems to have continued to be operated by his brother or by other members of the White family since the 1883 street directory records I. & J. White there. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.3) of the early 1880s indicates that the pottery then consisted of three discrete elements. The first was a building on the southern side of Fox Lane, the second was a building on the western side of Mina Road, built over Mill Stream, and the third was a triangular open yard with a kiln at the south-west corner between Mill Stream and Fox Lane. The pottery buildings had been removed by the beginning of the twentieth century and the sites redeveloped.

Felix Cottage located on the southern side of Back Lane (modern British Road). The building is recorded by the tithe survey of Bedminster made in 1841 (BRO EP/A/32/7) as a house and gardens. Felix Cottage itself, Parcel 616, was orientated from north-west to south-east and its northern wall stood on the Back Lane frontage of the plot. A narrow garden extended to the east some 60 metres along Back Street towards Diamond Street with a further small area to the west of the cottage. At the far eastern end of the garden there was a small rectangular outbuilding. There was access from the smaller, western, part of the garden to another associated plot, Parcel 624, on the south side of the cottage which measured 49 metres from north-west to south-east by 44 metres. The cottage was still extant at the time of the Ashmead survey of Bristol in 1855 but had been demolished and its site redeveloped by 1883 when the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.23) were surveyed. The eastern garden had been subdivided by that date and the houses of Westbourne Grove constructed while the southern component had also been developed, probably as a haulier's yard. The site of Felix Cottage now lies beneath the northern end of Westbourne Grove, at its junction with British Road.

Victoria reservoir located on the south side of Oakfield Road. The Victoria Reservoir and the associated pumping station (SMR 20294) were built in the early years of the Bristol Waterworks Company, which was incorporated in July 1846. The reservoir is a rectangular enclosure formed with mounded earth and measures 100 metres from north-west to south-east and is 86 metres wide.

Arno's Court. The house was built for William Reeve, a Bristol brassfounder, in 1764, to a design possibly by James Bridges. Apparently the house was originally called Mount Pleasant but had acquired the name Arno's Court by 1832. Arno's Court consisted of four elements: the house itself; the stables, brewhouse etc known as Arno's, or Black, Castle (SMR 3498); the bath house and the triumphal arch. The three-storey house was built of Bath stone and is often credited with influencing the early Gothic revival. Some of the original plasterwork by Thomas Stocking remains in situ in the building (Ison 1952, 181-189).
The house was bought the Sisters of the Asylum of the Good Shepherd in 1850 and developed as a reformatory for girls. Wings were added to the original house and there was a chapel on the north side of the building. A burial ground associated with the convent was also apparently created to the south-east of the house. The Triumphal Arch in front of the house was moved to its present position in 1912.
The gothic elements of the building (the original house) in the east corner have a Grade II* listing (Listed Building Number 901-1/56/426) while the remainder of the structure (related to the convent) is Grade II (Listed Building Number 901-1/56/427).

KNOWN_AS: Gas works, Avon Street, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC:
Avon Street gas works, located on the south side of Gas Lane, St. Philip's. The works was created by the Bristol Gas Light Company, formed in 1815, which had opened its gas works at Temple Back.in 1818. The company's offices were at Castle Street. The Temple Back site had proved inadequate by 1820 and the site at Avon Street was bought in October 1820 for £2100 (Nabb 1987, 14). A gas works centralising the offices, retort houses and gasholders was built between March and April 1821 and the site appears to have opened later that year. Initially iron retorts were used to carbonise the coal but clay retorts were adopted in the 1840s.
The works is recorded by Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 map of Bristol which indicates that the retort house was on the east side of the site and the offices stood on the western boundary. There was also a row of what appear to be five gasholders on the southern side of the site. By the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition map surveyed in 1883 these had been replaced by three large gasholders against Gas Lane. The Avon Street elevation of the works, including the office buildings were drawn by Samuel Loxton in 1919. The offices survived into the late 1960s but have since been demolished. The retort house against Silverthorne Lane is extant as are two of the three gasometers of the later nineteenth century.

KNOWN_AS: Mr. Cann's tenement and garden on the eastern side of Regent Street, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC: A house located on the eastern side of Regent Street. The house was extant by the mid-eighteenth century and was recorded by the survey of the Manor of Clifton made by Jacob de Wilstar in 1746 for the Society of Merchant Venturers. The plot then comprised "One tenement, Orchard, Garden field of pasture" in the freehold Francis Freeman by rented or leased by William Cann, onetime Town Clerk of Bristol. Cann also owned the house (SMR 20879) and gardens adjoining to the south. The building was set a few metres back from Regent Street frontage, with an area of land to the rear and the large pasture to the north of the house. The building was apparently demolished in the early 1770s to make way for the construction of Boyce's Buildings.

KNOWN_AS: House at the south-west end of Golden Lion Passage
MONUMENT_DESC: A house at the south-west end of Golden Lion Passage, a court off Redcliff Street and leading to Ferry Lane. The house was one of seven built by Thomas Powell in the late 1780s and seems to have comprised a single room on each floor. The building was of brick and the west wall appears to survive in the fabric of the former garage No.101 Redcliff Street. A description of the court in 1850 states that the floors of the ground-floor rooms of the dwellings were below the then ground level.

Redlandhill House, located on the southern side of Redland Hill. The house was constructed as a pair of semi-detached villas in the eighteenth century. The listing gives James Bridges as the architect of the houses and 1761 as the date of construction. This has been disputed by Evans (2000) who suggests that the house was in fact constructed by a Bristol mason, Philip West, in late 1767 or 1768.
The buildings were of three-storeys. Photographs in Bristol Reference Library of the Redland Hill (north-west facing) elevation of the southern of the two buildings (B21205) and the entire south-west facing elevation (B21205) records that the structure was rendered with a three-sided bay at the south end. Immediately to the north of this was a projecting entrance porch of classical design. Above the central doorway was a segmental arch supported by pilasters with windows between them. In the parapet above the arch there was a pediment.. A string course dividing the ground from the first floor extended around the whole building. All of the windows were 3 by 4 pane sashes, those in the second floor being slightly smaller. The window openings on the north-east facing elevation were surrounded by mouldings while those in the rear, south-west facing elevation were had ashlar rustication. A tall parapet surrounded, and obscured the roof but there was a large chimney stack at its centre.
The buildings were extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.12.17), surveyed in 1881. The southern of the houses was demolished in 1933 while the northern is extant, having been purchased by Bristol City Council in 1964 to provide accommodation for Redland College. The building subsequently became part of Bristol Polytechnic. It appears from the Ordnance Survey Landline plan of 2000 that part of the rear wall of the southern building may survive on the site, having perhaps been reused as a retaining wall.
The surviving half of the building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/34/1725).

KNOWN_AS: Engine Shed on the west side of the River Avon
MONUMENT_DESC: Engine Shed, located on the west side of the River Avon, to the south of Temple Meads station. The shed is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.12) surveyed in 1883 and is indicated to be  attached to a larger complex comprising an engine shed and workshop (SMR 21082) on its south-west facing side.

Chittening Farm (located at NGR ST 53546 81945 approx.). Taylor's 1773 map of the area shows the site of Chittening Farm as open fields. The tithe survey of 1841 first records the farm, noting that it was owned by Sir John Smyth and occupied by a tenant farmer. When sold in 1911 the farm was described in the sale deeds as "An excellent stone-built and slate residence ... containing two sitting rooms, five bedrooms, kitchen, dairy, pantry, wash-house and office, walled garden and orchard. The farm buildings are substantial and include ... cow stalls for twelve cows, large barn, open hovel, cart shed, three calf-pens, poultry house, stable for five horses, gig house" (Glos. Record Office SL 420). The 1915 Ordnance Survey map (Gloucestershire Sheet LXVII.10) depicts this farm as consisting of a farmhouse, some outbuildings and three small adjacent orchards. The site lies under the present Chittening brickworks.
The site was visited by R. G. Jackson during the course of a desk-based assessment (SMR 20081) of areas of Bristol City Council owned land north of Avonmouth in December 1996. It was noted that the modern development has probably destroyed the remains of the farm.

KNOWN_AS: Zion Chapel, Two Mile Hill Road, St. George
MONUMENT_DESC:
Zion Chapel, located on the north side of Two Mile Hill Road. The Free Methodist chapel was extant by 1882 when it was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucester Sheet LXXII.15). There was a Sunday School attached to the north end of the chapel.
The chapel is extant.

KNOWN_AS: W.D. & H.O. Wills tobacco factory, East Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
Tobacco factory of W. D. & H. O. Wills, located on the north side of East Street, Bedminster. The factory was designed by Sir Frank Wills and opened on the 27 March 1886 (Alford 1973, 135-136). It was designed to allow production to flow through the site from the leaf warehouse to the despatch sheds. Some machinery was brought from the existing factories but most was new. Bedminster No 1 factory was equipped with Belliss and Morcam high-speed steam engines providing power and exhausting into process and steam heating systems (Buchanan & Buchanan 1980, 32). The use of process steam made these engines very economical. A new block was opened at the centre of the site in 1895, constructed at a cost of £7000.
The buildings on Lombard Street survive as well as those at the west end East Street, although both have been converted to shops on the ground floor. The other factory buildings were demolished in the mid-1980s.
North of the junction of Church Road and Gloucester Road, until recently(1969) a garage, now empty, sheds and fan of tracks intact. {1} Recently converted to a shopping centre. {2}

The Lord Rodney Public House situated on the north side of Two Mile Hill Road at the junction with Brockhurst Road. The buildling consists of a two sorey double depth plan with pan tiled pitched roofs. The side walls are constructed of rubble pennant stone, the south elevation is currently (o6/05/2011) rendered.  The earliest depiction of a structure on the site is on the William Maule 1803 map of St George and an Inn called the Lord Rodney was in existence by the time of the St George tithe apportionment of 1842. Numerous alterations have been carried out to the building, which is predominantly 19th-century but may have a late 18th-century core.

The Churchyard of St. Paul's Church, Portland Square. The churchyard is located to the rear, east, of the church and extends around its northern and southern sides. The railings and gates date to 1789-94 and were designed by Daniel Hague, who also designed the church and are wrought-iron with Gothick details.
The area surrounding the church is largely occupied by grave shafts which was confirmed by geophysical survey in 2000 (BUAD 4205). The density and location of interments in the rest of the churchyard is unknown but they appear to have been placed primarily in the southern half.
An Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852 ended interment in the churchyard "except of members of the families of those already interred there."
The churchyard was conveyed to Bristol City Council for use as a park in June 1936 and an inscription on the south-east corner of the church records this:
"ST. PAULS / GREATER CHURCHYARD / WAS CONVEYED TO / THE BRISTOL CITY COUNCIL / AND CONVERTED INTO / ST. PAULS PARK / ON JUNE 11TH, 1936. / W. WARD B. A. VICAR / JENEFRED M. ADAMS / W. J. D. WOODS / CHURCH WARDENS."
The deed of conveyance indicates that in the late 1930s and early 1940s the vicarage was using the northern half of the site as allotments (BRO P/StP/D/9).
The railings and gates to the park have a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/6/2154).

KNOWN_AS: Smallpox Hospital on the east bank of the River Avon, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC: Smallpox Hospital, located on the east bank of the River Avon in St. Philip's Marsh. The hospital is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.7) surveyed in 1883 which shows it on the east side of a roughly triangular walled enclosure also containing a Fever Hospital. The hospital building was orientated north-south and measured 100 feet on its long axis by 20 feet wide. The entrance to the enclosure seems to have been via a gate leading into the stone yard (SMR 21084) immediately to the north.

KNOWN_AS: Civil Defence headquarters building, Netham Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Civil Defence Headquarters Building, located on the eastern side of Netham Road. The building was in existence by 1948. It was orientated north-south and measured 34 metres from north to south and 12 metres east-west. It was still extant in 1965 when it was recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1:1250 plan published in 1965 but had apparently been demolished by 1971 (HSL UK 71 121 - 63 Frame 5458).

An extant section of the Roman road between Bath (Aquae Sulis) and Sea Mills (Abona) (Margary 541) on Durdham Down, located on the south side of Stoke Road between Ladies Mile and Rockleaze. The road appears to have been first noted by the antiquary William Barrett who commented "that some rose-up ground, like an old Roman road, crosses Durdham Down, (where a coin of Constantine was lately dug up)" (Barrett 1789, 10). Seyer, writing a few decades later, described "a stony track on the open down having much the appearance of an old causeway, ten or twelve yards wide. It quits the turnpike road obliquely, and passes in a strait line across the Down due west, which is the direction of Sea mills" (Seyer 1821, 150). Seyer's description suggests that a significant length of the road may have been destroyed since the early nineteenth century. A section was excavated across the south-eastern end of the road in 1899 (SMR 20441) under the direction of Alfred Trice-Martin, John Pritchard and other members of the Bristol and Gloucestershire Archaeological Society and the Clifton Antiquarian Club (Trice-Martin 1899; 1900-03). This found a layer of sand overlying rock above which was a "reddish-looking earth." Stones forming the agger of the road were set on this layer. Investigation of the ditches on either side of the road found them to be highly eroded.

KNOWN_AS: Oracle, Temple Way House, Narrow Plain
MONUMENT_DESC: Oracle, located at the entrance to Temple Way House, Narrow Plain. The statue was commissioned as part of the development of the Temple Way House office building and is by the Czech sculptor Franta Blský (1921-2000) who was given a brief to create "a temple guardian" (Merritt 2002, 115). The sculpture was installed in 1975 and is an abstract form in aluminium and polyester resin, set on a cast concrete column. The sculpture was awarded the Sir Otto Beit Medal for Sculpture by the Royal Society of British Sculptors in 1976 (Merritt 2002, 115).

KNOWN_AS: Roman settlement of Abona, Sea Mills
MONUMENT_DESC: The Roman settlement of Abona, located in the area of present day Sea Mills. Peter Ellis (1987) reviewed the available evidence for the settlement as part of the published report on the archaeological excavations at Abon House in the mid 1960s and argues that the initial activity on the site was military. He rejects the case made by G. C. Boon (1949) for a Claudian origin for the settlement, and suggests that the military presence may have been established as early as c.55AD. A fort was presumably built alongside the road between Sea Mills and Bath, although no military site has yet been excavated. This may have been a stores or supply depot serving a naval detachment operating in the Bristol Channel area. The fort is argued to have remained until 85AD at the latest and the ceramic evidence suggests a break in occupation from then until the founding of a civilian settlement at the beginning of the 2nd century AD.
Tilly's Court, located on the northern side of Barton Hill [modern Queen Ann Road], St. Philip's Marsh (ST 60728 72777) otherwise known as Queen Anne's House or Dr. Day's Mansion.

No.10 Guinea Street, located on the southern side of Guinea Street. The building was constructed for the merchant Captain Edmund Saunders and with No.11 (BUAD 1721M) and No.12 Guinea Street (BUAD 1722M) formed a single house which was later subdivided (Ison 1952, 156).
The house is a two-storey brick structure with limestone ashlar detailing and a gabled roof. The fenestration consist of sashes with carved keystones above the window openings. Internally, the house was described in a sale document of 1746 as containing "four Vault Cellars, two Kitchens, a large handsom Hall, Dining-Room, and Withdrawing-Room, each neatly Wainscotted and Painted, with a Marble Chimney-Piece in Each; three parlours, two of them with Marble Chimney-Pieces, all neatly Wainscotted, one of them with Cedar and Mahogany, and highly finished; a very neat Mahogany Staircase, handsomly Painted, three Chambers Wainscotted, and a Marble Chimney-Piece in Each; with convenient Presses for Clothes, and three Closets. And six Upper Lodging-Rooms and two Closets, &c" (quoted in Ison 1952, 157). Much of the original internal detailing is extant.
The building was surveyed in 1998 by Dr. Roger Leech of the Royal Commission on Historic Monuments (England) (BUAD 3419).
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/1674).

No.12 Guinea Street, located on the southern side of Guinea Street. The building was constructed for the merchant Captain Edmund Saunders and with No.10 (BUAD 1720M) and No.11 Guinea Street (BUAD 1721M) formed a single house which was later subdivided (Ison 1952, 156).
The house is a two-storey brick structure with limestone ashlar detailing and a hipped roof. The fenestration consist of sashes.
The building was surveyed in 1998 by Dr. Roger Leech of the Royal Commission on Historic Monuments (England) (BUAD 3419).
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/1675).

Ebenezer Chapel. The Wesleyan Methodist chapel was located on the north side of Back Lane (modern British Road), Bedminster. It was in existence by the time of the tithe survey of Bedminster of 1841 (BRO EP/A/32/7) and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan surveyed in 1883 (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.23). This notes that the chapel had seating for 400. Attached to the rear of the chapel was a Sunday School. There was a small burial ground at the southern end of the plot but the main part of the burial ground (SMR 20429) was to the north of the Sunday School. It was bounded on its eastern side by the back lane of Albert Place. The chapel survived into the early twentieth century but was subsequently demolished. The site of the chapel has been redeveloped but the burial ground remains under grass.

Brush and Bellows Factory, located on Peter Street near St Peter's Church. Depicted on Ordnance Survey 1:500 plan 1882. On Ordnance Survey map referred to as Brush and Bellows Manufactory.  E. Brison & Co, wholesale brush and bellows makers,  moved to 24 and 25 Peter Street in 1878 and remained there until 1910.  The company was previously located on Redcliff Street. According to the 1820 Mathews Directory (the earliest Directory available to the author), John Hunt, Brusthmaker, was located at 56 Redclif Street until 1835.  In 1835, the business was under Elizabeth Hunt's name, and a year later, moved to 60 Redclif Street.  Robert Hunt took over the business in 1852. From 1854 to 1857, the company was owned by Hunt, Walter and Brison.  Hunt left in 1858, and Walter and Brison owned the company until 1862.  The business was referred to under the name of E. Brison and Co from 1863 until 1910.  There is no mention of the brush and bellows makers in the Directories after 1910.  

The brush and bellows manufactory shared its premises on Peter Street with William Randall, clothier and outfitter, until 1892.  Four years later, Garlick and Sons, hatters and hosiers, was established at 24 Peter Street in 1896.  The hatters remained on location until the 1940's.  Edward Stuart milliner was located at 25 Peter Street from 1910 and is last mentioned in the kelly's 1940 Directory. From 1916 a billiard saloon owned by Edward Albert Lewis; a woolen merchants called Langdon, Phillips and Co, and E Broderick & Co. clothing manufacturers were also found at the same address. All these companies were clossed by the late 1920's.

The buildings of 24 and 25 Peter Street were destroyed by World War II bombing.

KNOWN_AS: Church Hill House, Church Hill, Brislington
MONUMENT_DESC: Church Hill House, Church Hill, Brislington.  Situated at the end of Church Hill  Has also been called St. Luke's Vicarage. The house was built in the Palladian style by Charles Vaughan, and in 1704, his widow sold the property to Jeremiah Paerce. By 1751 the property had been purchased by John Newman, who had also purchased Hill Cottage (SMR 20575. By 1828, it was part of the Clayfield-Ireland estate. The Brislington Tithe Survey of 1846 (BRO EP/A/32/9) records Isaac Cooke as the owner, trustee under the will of James Ireland. In the early nineteenth century, the house was a boarding school known as Church Hill House Academy. It remained a school until 1856 when Major Robert Bush became the occupier.  In 1896, James Clayfield-Ireland presented the house to the parish as a vicarage. It remained the vicarage until 1981 when the house was sold to be converted into flats and a new vicarage was built. Pevsner describes the house as the vicarage and writies "a specially pretty early Georgian house rendered, five bays, two storeys, slightly projecting centre bay with pediment, and oval window in the pediment. The middle window on the first floor is of the venetian type" (Pevsner 1958, 465). This Venetian window belonged to a first floor room but was moved during alterations to the property in the 1930s. Other alterations included the moving of the staircase.

KNOWN_AS: St. Vincent's Iron Works, Silverthorne Lane
MONUMENT_DESC: St. Vincent's Iron Works, located on the south side of Silverthorne Lane. The Bristol Iron Works was founded by Acraman, Morgan and Co. in the early years of the nineteenth century and the extent of the original factory is recorded by the Plumley and Ashmead 1828 plan of Bristol. In 1860 John Lysaght took over the works and expanded it to establish an iron galvanizing plant which produced roofing sheets, and wire netting mainly for export. Sheet iron was brought by water from the companys Birmingham works for finishing.

The Scala cinema, located on the north-east side of Cromwell Road. The cinema was built by R. Wilkins and Sons, Bristol for Ralph Pringle to a design by W. H. Watkins and opened as Pringles Picture House in 1910 (Ewins 1984, 26). Pringle's Picture House was Bristols second purpose built cinema. The cinema was constructed on the site of three shops and two houses towards the bottom of Cromwell Road. It had a furnished lounge and grand circle reached by a marble staircase and could seat 1400 patrons. Pringle sold the cinema to Cheltenham and Zetlan Halls Ltd in 1914 when it became the Zetland Picture House (Ewins 1984, 26) The cinema was later run by Atkinson's Pictures Ltd and was known as the Scala from the 1930s (Ewins 1984, 26). The building was demolished in 1974 (Anderson 1983, 17).

In 1835 Dr Henry Riley, a physician to St Peters Hospital and Bristol Royal Infirmary and a leading member of the Bristol Institution founded, with fellow members of the Institution, the Bristol, Clifton and West of England Zoological Society (Green-Armytage 1964, 7). The Bristol Institution based at 17-31 Park Street, Bristol, now the Masonic Hall (BUAD 1357M), started as the Bristol Philosophical and Literary Society, but became the Bristol Institution in 1823 (Warin & Warin 1985, 9). Lectures and demonstrations given to the members of the Institution covered all areas of science and it was groups of individuals from this society that developed various science based establishments in Bristol such as the City Museum and the Zoological Gardens (Warin & Warin 1985, 9).

KNOWN_AS: Offer's clay tobacco pipe factory, Norfolk Place, East Street Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC: Offer's clay tobacco pipe factory, located on the east side of Norfolk Place, Bedminster. The pipe maker Richard Offer moved from Great George Street, St. Philips to George's Barton [modern Norfolk Place] in Bedminster in 1858. He was listed in the street directories there as a pipe maker from 1859 to 1866 and in the 1861 Census he was noted as employing 2 men and 5 women at his premises. Offer was still at Georges Barton according to the 1871 census but had died by 1888. It seems likely that the business was then carried on by Charles Tovey who was listed in the street directories as a pipe maker at No.143 East Street and Nos.1-3 Norfolk Place, Bedminster from 1889 to 1891 (Price et al 1979).

The grounds of Brislington House. Brislington House (SMR 1408) was built by Dr. Fox in 1804 as a pioneering institution for the treatment of the insane. The grounds covered some 200 acres and were designed to be an integral part of the treatment regime. The original design for the grounds is recorded in two plans, one of c1806 (Huntington Library, Stowe Papers Box 10, item 4) and another of 1843 (SRO Q/RLU/c/42/8). The design included a model farm and kitchen gardens (Harding & Lambert 1994, 103-104) while the area adjacent to the house, on its east side, was laid out as six airing courts. There were also separate houses in the grounds for wealthier patients where, according to an advertisement of 1809, they were "allowed to pursue any style of living and expense as to carriages, horses etc. most suitable to their former habits and not inconsistent with their present situation" (SRO T/PH/Fx 2). These buildings were relatively substantial and included Swiss Cottage, recorded by T. L. Rowbotham in 1827 (Stoddard 1981, 50-51). The house was originally of two storeys with drip moulds over the windows and a pitched roof with elaborate cusped bargeboards and large chimneystacks. The design of the grounds influenced the design of Victorian institutional landscapes.
The grounds appear to have been re-landscaped after 1846 (BRO EP/A/32/9) and the arrangement of the new planting is recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan of 1884. A sale prospectus for Brislington House, written around 1900, describes the House as "standing in extensive grounds of 80 acres of parkland and gardens. The latter comprise 36 acres of shrubbery, pleasure grounds, fruit and vegetable gardens, with greenhouses, peach house and vineries." These gardens were surrounded on three sides by "a farm of 220 acres which provided dairy, poultry and farm produce" (quoted in Rowe & Williams 1985, 18).
The grounds are entered in the English Heritage register of Parks and Gardens of Special Historic Interest with a Grade II* listing (GD3397).

No.27 Portland Square, located at the north-western corner of Portland Square. Portland Square was laid out in the late 1780s and building plots were advertised for sale from March 1790. Construction stalled, however, when the building boom collapsed in 1792 and was completed by the architect Daniel Hague in 1811 (Ison 1952, 221). No.27 is part of the terrace on the northern side of the square, Nos.22-28 Portland Square. The main, south-east facing elevation is of limestone ashlar. The fenestration consists of sashes. Cellars extend beneath the house and there is a basement lightwell at the front of the house and on the northern side of this smaller cellars extend under the road. By 1896 the building was in use as Pearce Brothers Hat and Cap Warehouse.
The building has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/6/1904).

The Carlton Cinema, located on north side of Canford Lane. The cinema was designed for George Allen of the Eastville Hippodrome Company by W. H. Watkins' architects firm and probably by E. Curno Cooke who worked for Watkins during the 1930s (Ewins 1984, 21). The cinema was built by Hyatt and Neale of Bristol (Ewins 1984, 28) and opened in 1933 with seating for 820 (Anderson, 1983, 55). The building was constructed of brick with white cement on the façade (Winstone, 1972, pl.245) and was described by the Bristol Evening Post (12/09/33) as having "the austere fineness of sheer straight lines and balanced harmony in its proportions. Flanking the geometric simplicity of a central tower of 'Snowcrete' white cement, the front elevation is finished with warm multicoloured facing bricks," (Ewins 1984, 21).

Baldwin's Cross Mill, located at the junction of Queen Charlotte Street with Baldwin Street. The mill was apparently a medieval structure. Its form is not currently (02/11/2006) understood in any detail. The building apparently survived into the eigheenth century but had been largely demolished by mid-century. Parts of the mill race survived in the cellar of the replacement building in the second half of the 1780s, however, and these were described by the local antiquarians William Barrett and Samuel Seyer. Seyer described the "thoroughs" of the mill in c.1785. He noted that the mill was "standing within memory" and was sited "nearly opposite to Blind-steps at the corner between Baldwin Street and Back Street, projecting into the street beyond the present corner house." William Barrett recorded that there were "some traces remaining still in a cellar at the corner of Baldwin-street; where are three old strong arches on each side of it now to be seen, being the thoroughs through which the water of the Froom then flowed, that drove the wheels, the mill-house being erected over them" (Barrett 1789, 52).

KNOWN_AS: Withey House, No.26 Withey Close West, Stoke Bishop
MONUMENT_DESC: Withey House, No.26 Withey Close West, located on the north-western side of Withey Close West. The building was constructed in 1935 for the Bristol Branch of the Electrical Association for Women in an otherwise vacant part of the Cote Grange Estate, then being developed by its owner, the builder Wyndham Rossiter, and Messrs. Lalonde Brothers and Parham. It was intended to be demonstration house for the use of electrical fittings as a standard in domestic housing.

KNOWN_AS: Statue of Isambard Kingdom Brunel, Temple Back East
MONUMENT_DESC: Statue of Isambard Kingdom Brunel (1806-1859), located outside No.2 Temple Back East. Brunel trained in France and began to work for his father Marc Isambard Brunels engineering practice in 1823. He worked for Marc for five years, mostly as resident engineer on the Thames Tunnel, and was badly injured when the tunnel flooded in 1828. He was sent to convalesce in Bristol where he entered the competition to design the bridge across the Avon Gorge. Eventually declared the winner, Brunel began work on construction of the Clifton Suspension Bridge and in 1833 he was also appointed chief engineer to the Great Western Railway. Brunel also designed the SS Great Western, a wooden paddle steamer, which was built in Bristol and was launched in 1837. He also designed the SS Great Britain, the first iron ship with a screw propeller, which was built in a purpose-built dock at Wapping and was launched in 1843. Brunel became seriously ill in the late 1850s. He died on 15 September 1859.

KNOWN_AS: Monkey Temple at Bristol Zoological Gardens
MONUMENT_DESC: Monkey Temple at Bristol Zoological Gardens built in 1928 after proposals by Dr Richard Clarke, then secretary to the Bristol, Clifton and West of England Zoological Society to increase and modernise the zoo attractions (Green-Armytage 1964, 61-63). The structure was designed to imitate the Indian Temple Cold Lairs inhabited by the Bandar-log in Kiplings Jungle Book with an exotically decorated domed tower in the centre of a circular open-air pit enclosure populated by Rhesus Monkeys (Shapland 2004, 4-6). The design was also influenced by the early twentieth century Hagenbeckian naturalism style of zoo enclosure. This style, as introduced by Carl Hagenbeck at Tierpark, Stellingen, near Hamburg in 1906 and imitated at zoos in Paris, Cologne, Antwerp and London (Guillery 1993, 14), provided visitors with uninhibited views of the animals in an open-air setting rather than through the bars of a cage (Shapland 2004, 5).

Frayne's Colliery. This pit apparently worked both Bedminster and Ashton Group of seams.... New Land Pit which could have been a second shaft for Fraynes. The colliery was disused by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition plan (Somerset sheet VI.06) published in 1894.

British School, located on the southern side of Redcross Street, Old Market. A school appears to have opened on the site in 1819. This was run by The Society for Promoting the Lancasterian System for the Education of the Poor according to the principles set out by Joseph Lancaster. Lancaster was a member of the Society of Friends who sought to create a network of schools for the children of what he called the "industrious classes" (Lancaster 1803). Lancaster's system employed monitors, a select group of older pupils who were taught by the master, who, in turn, taught the remaining children. In 1814 the Society was renamed the British and Foreign School Society (BFSS) and the school had become known as the British School by the 1840s. The school initially accepted only boys but a girls school was established in 1813. At 31 December 1841 there were 170 boys and 105 girls on the school roll (Anon 1841).
The building was built as a three-storey structure of Pennant sandstone rubble bonded in a lime mortar and with a pitched roof. The phasing of construction has not been established but minor alterations including a new playground, had been made by 1846 and in 1850 William Armstrong, an architect based in Brunswick Square, designed a new classroom extension with raked seating at the southern end.
The school was closed in 1889 because it did not meet the Board School standards and was converted to industrial use. The building was subsequently largely gutted during the twentieth century and the roof removed and a flat roof created. It was occupied by a wrestling club by 2003.

KNOWN_AS: Blaise Hamlet, north of Blaise Castle
MONUMENT_DESC: Blaise Hamlet, a group of nine cottages, including one double, built to house pensioners from Blaise Estate. John Scandrett Harford, the Bristol banker who owned the Blaise estate, commissioned the architect John Nash to design the site, a picturesque group of detached cottages round a village green (T. Burrough in Anon. 1977, 326), in 1811. It was completed in 1812. No two cottages are alike. The village pump is incorporated into a stone column with a lantern head and sundial, erected 1815. The hamlet is owned by the National Trust.

St. Anne's Ferry. The ferry, mentioned by Leland, formerly carried pilgrims across the river Avon to the chapel (SMR 1396) and well of St Anne. St. Anne's ferry formed part of the manor of Blackswarth and, like the manor was owned by the monastery of St Augustine, Bristol. At the dissolution the ferry passed to the Crown and was let at a rent of 1/- per annum. Before 1809 the ferry was worked as a tidal ferry; at low tide the boat was turned into a kind of floating bridge with planks to the banks on either side.

St. Anne's Chapel, also known as St. Anne's in the Wood (located at approximately ST62097278). The chapel was founded between 1170 and 1392, when a legacy was bequeathed to the chapel (Richardson 1898, 190). William Worcestre states that the chapel was founded by "Quidam Dominus de le Warr", presumably the same family responsible for the foundation of St. Bartholomew's Hospital in Bristol. He gives measurements for the chapel and lists the plate (Neale 2000, 56-59). St. Anne's Well (SMR 1400), which W. J. Pountney suggests was a reservoir to collect water from a spring rather than a well, also lay to the north.
At the time of the Dissolution, St. Anne's was held by the Abbey of Keynsham. In a deed dated 30 June 1538, the Abbot of Keynsham, granted the Chapel and ground of St. Anne's on a lease to a yeoman of "Bristelten" named Robert Stafford.  The chapel appears to have been at least partially demolished not long after the dissolution. It had been dismantled by 1592, when it was sold by Robert Bridges.
Between 1867 and 1873 the tenant farmer at St. Anne's Farm discovered human remains near the site of the chapel. Archaeological excavation of Brislington Pottery (SMR 20221) by Pountney in 1914 (SMR 20221) revealed the foundations of the chapel and two vaults, in one of which were remains of window masonry, the rood screen and the shrine of St. Anne (Pountney 1914). Other finds included a silver coin, possibly of Edward III and English and foreign Abbey tokens. The finds were presented to Bristol Museum and Art Gallery.
Today metal studs mark the position of the chapel on the ground, and a plaque on the wall of the modern Board Mill building records the site.

H.M.S. Flying Fox, located on the south side of Winterstoke Road. The building was constructed in 1940 as a Territorial Army Centre for the Gloucestershire Regiment and the building remained largely unaltered after its construction. It is a three-storey brick structure designed in a Neo-Georgian style. The main, south-facing, elevation has a central entrance porch with pilasters topped by the head of a sphinx (in reference to the badge of the Gloucestershire Regiment) extending up to mid second-floor level set on either side. Between the first and and second floor windows is the date "1940".

Henleaze Park, located some 450 metres to the east of Henleaze Lane (modern Henleaze Road). The building was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.08) published in 1881. The main building was reached by a sinuous drive leading from Henleaze Lane and the main, west-facing, elevation gave on to a large formal garden. There was also an east-west range of buildings on the north side of the land parcel. The building survived into the mid -1930s but was subsequently redeveloped. The site of the main building now lies largely beneath Kenton Mews and Longleat Close and the front gardens of the houses to the south of the roads.

KNOWN_AS: Possible farm outbuildings on the site of Nos.11 & 12 The Glen
MONUMENT_DESC:
Possible farm outbuildings on the site of Nos.11 and 12 The Glen. The buildings are recorded by the Westbury-on-Trym tithe map and lie immediately adjacent to a pond on their western side. The buildings had been incorporated into the garden of Redland Lodge by 1880 (Ordnance Survey Glos. Sheet LXXI.12.7) and formed the eastern end of the garden.
The buildings fall within the curtilages of Nos.10, 11 and 12 The Glen, being located gardens to the rear of the dwellings.

Muller orphanage, Ashley Down Road. In 1832 George Müller (1805-1898), joint pastor of Bethesda Chapel in Great George Street raised £1,000 to furnish their own home at No.6 Wilson Street, St. Paul's to accommodate thirty orphaned girls. Subsequently another three rented houses in Wilson Street were acquired, caring for a total of 130 children. Rented houses were not a long-term solution and by 1845 the number of children had risen even further without additional accommodation. Müller decided on the building of a purpose built home to accommodate 300 children. In 1845 he entered into a contract for the purchase of the 7 acres of ground at £120 per acre. The funding for purchase of the site and construction of the buildings came entirely from donations, including a gift from the Bristol sugar refiner Conrad Finzel. On June 18 1849 300 orphans transferred to the new site.
The plan of the orphanage developed without an overall design. The earliest building is Allen House (listed Grade II: Listed Building number 901-1/32/10038) which was constructed in 1847-49 to a design by the architects John Foster & Son. The same architects also designed Brunel House in 1857 (listed Grade II; Listed Building number 901-1/32/10058), Muller House in 1862 (listed Grade II: Listed Building number 901-1/32/10059), Davy House in 1868 (901-1/32/10061) and Cabot House (listed Grade II: Listed Building number 901-1/32/10060). All of the buildings are of Pennant sandstone rubble and all, except Davy House, have ashlar freestone dressings. The swimming baths, dating to the late-nineteenth century, also have a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/32/10062). Internally the buildings were characterised by an austere scheme of decoration, the main feature of which appears to have been biblical texts and improving legends painted on the walls. Part of the grounds was cultivated to provide .
By 1870 there were five houses at Ashley Down housing more than 2000 children and the site continued to operate into the twentieth century. The site subsequently became City of Bristol College and a number of alterations to the existing buildings were made and new structures built within the site as part of this use.

KNOWN_AS: St. George's Church, Summerhill Road, St. George
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. George's Church, located on the south side of Summerhill Road, St. George. The church was designed by Samuel Glascodine in 1751, with modifications to the original design of the roof made by Isaac Ware. Construction started in 1752, with a ceremony attended by the Mayor of Bristol on 3 May, and was completed in 1756 (Gomme et al 1979, 149; Rudder 1779, 461). It was consecrated by Bishop Hume on 6 September 1756. It was a stone building with freestone ashlar facings.
The church was rebuilt in 1846 to a design in a Gothic style by J. Hicks. The new building was of Pennant sandstone rubble with ashlar facings. It had a nave with clerestorey and aisles on the north and south sides. At the west end there was a buttressed, square three-stage tower. Internally the nave was of five bays with pointed arches supported by clustered columns. It is not clear how much, if any, of the fabric earlier church was retained within the new church.
St. George's was badly damaged by fire on 22 December 1878 and while the shell of the church appears to have survived, the building was gutted. P. E. Masey was appointed as the architect for the rebuilding works and in 1879 he produced plans including the construction of a new vestry and organ chamber, rebuilding of the nave arcades and the construction of new roofs, reseating and general repairs.
The building became structurally unsound and was demolished in 1976. The site was subsequently redeveloped for housing.

Queens Dale Farm, located some 240 metres to the west of Wells Road. The farm was in existence by the time of the Bedminster tithe survey of 1841 which indicated that the farmhouse was on the east side of the farm (at ST 60662 70245) with outbuildings on its west side. By the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.11) published in 1884 further buildings had been added to the west and north-west. The farm survived into the twentieth century, though no further buildings seem to have been constructed before the First World War (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXVI.05, published in 1916). The farm was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped for housing.
The site of the farm now lies largely beneath Nos.62-68 on the north side of Kingshill Road and Nos.61-71 on its south side.

KNOWN_AS: Malthouse at St. John's Lane, Lower Knowle
MONUMENT_DESC: Malthouse located on the south side of St. John's Lane, Lower Knowle. The malthouse is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.06) published in 1894 and at this date the building measured approximately 28 metres from north-west to south-east by 9 metres wide. The building was still extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey third edition plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXV.08) published in 1916 but was subsequently demolished. The site now lies beneath the western side of the car park of the Engineers Arms.

Gough Farm, located some 240 metres to the west of Wells Road. The farm was in existence by the time of the Bedminster tithe survey of 1841 which indicates that the farmhouse was on the east side of the site with rectangular outbuildings on its south side. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.11) published in 1884 indicates that no further buildings had been constructed at that time. There was a formal garden on the west side of the farmhouse and a plantation, possibly an orchard, to its north. By the time of the second edition plan published in 1902 (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXVI.05) the farm had been demolished and the site redeveloped for housing. The site of the farmhouse now lies largely beneath Nos.34-37 Beaconsfield Road.

Lanesborough House. The house was extant by the time of the Brislington tithe survey of 1846 and was also recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1st edition 1:2500 scale plan of Brislington of 1884. The latter indicates that Lanesborough House lay on the east side of a lane which largely follows the line of modern Broomhill Road. The house was located towards the southern edge of the plot and had a driveway leading off the lane around its east and west sides. The house was still in existence in 1961 according to the Ordnance Survey 1:1250 plan, although the front, west-facing elevation, had apparently by then been remodelled. The house has since been demolished and its site now lies towards the southern side of a block of open land on the east side of Broomhill Road.

Located on the Castle Precincts, the site of The George was a 24m wide plot of land located at the western end of Castle Street.  The site extended backwards from the street to the river.  The plot of land was laid by the Corporation, who had bought the land in 1656.  The site of the inn was originally a house in the Castle.  Latimer quotes the resolution of the Council:  "Whereas the Castle is demolished, and a common street and highway made therein. And whereas there was formally a house in the Castle called the George inn.  A new house having been built on part of the old site, and it being very commodious for entertaining men and horses, Ordered that the said house be used as a common inn and hostelry."  The Merchant Venturers became the owners of The George in 1686.  At this time there were three tenants:  Walter Lucas, innholder; Edward Hutton, distiller and William Davis, tobacconist.

George Woolham was the tenant from 1716.  John Whittock was the occupant from 1722 to 1731.  John Dibble and his widow, followed by John Russell and his widow, and then Nathaniel Ridley were successive tenants from 1731 to 1743. Charles Atkinson occuped the premises from 1731 until at least 1749.  John Wolf was the occupant in 1753 and was succeeded by his widow.  S. Wolf is recorded as the tenant in 1775, followed by George Cooper a few years later.  Richard Cox was occupant to Mary Hilsonte, proprietor, in early 1800.  In 1806, the premises were occupied by Davis and Company.  Ball Davis and Co were the occupiers in 1810.

By 1820, Richard and Charles Vaughen were the proprietors/occupants, with the premises described as a Wool Warehouse.  The Coalbrookdale Company used the buildings as an iron warehouse from 1829, the premises being described as "shop and warehouse" in the 1850's and 1860's.  The 1883 OS survey at 1:500 scale showed most of the site as a warehouse but with only half of the 24m street frontage.  The remainder was occupied by two smaller premises (nos. 83 & 84).  Later OS plans (1:2500 scale) show the building with a long covered haulingway running virtually the length of site.  By this time Lindrea and Company, leather makers and importers were at this address, remaining here until the construction of the Regent Cinema in the later 1920's.

No.6 Back Stoke Lane, located on the eastern side of Back Stoke Lane. The house was in existence by the time of the Westbury-on-Trym tithe survey of 1841. It is the southern of a pair of semi-detached two-storey houses (the other being No.7 Back Stoke Lane). As built the main, west-facing elevation was of a single bay with a window slightly to the south of the centre at each floor, while the main entrance was on its north side. The house had a pitched pantile roof with a brick chimney stack at the apex of the south gable
A small lean-to extension was added to the south side of the house in the twentieth century and the building rendered at the same time. The windows were also replaced.

No.5 Back Stoke Lane, located on the eastern side of Back Stoke Lane. The house was in existence by the time of the Westbury-on-Trym tithe survey of 1841. It is the northern of a pair of semi-detached two-storey houses (the other being No.7 Back Stoke Lane). As built the main, west-facing elevation was of a single bay with a window slightly to the south of the centre at each floor, while the main entrance was on its north side. The house had a hipped pantile roof with a brick chimney stack at the apex of the north gable.
A two-storey extension with a flat roof was added to the rear elevation of the house in the twentieth century. The windows were also replaced.

The Firs, located on the west side of Passage Road, Westbury-on-Trym. A building is recorded on this site by a survey of the estate of Isaac Hobhouse of 1792, and this was a three-storey house with a single-depth plan with a pitched roof. The building had been extended at the north end by 1825 (possibly through incorporation of a detached house or outbuilding (SMR 22257)). It was then owned by Sir Benjamin Hobhouse and was leased or rented by Philip Crowther. The house had been inherited by the baronet Sir John Cam Hobhouse by 1838 and the occupier was one Hannah Fisher, but the Westbury-on-Trym tithe survey of 1841 (BRO EP/A/32/41) records the occupier as the late Thomas Butterworth. This plan also suggests that the northern range had been demolished by this time. The house was named as "The Firs" by the Ordnance Survey first edition County Series 1:2500-scale plan published in 1881 (Gloucestershire sheet LXXI.08). It was still in existence by the late 1940s but was subsequently demolished to alow the construction of No.12 Passage Road.

KNOWN_AS: Burial ground of Hebron Chapel, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC:
Burial ground of Hebron Chapel, located on the western side of Hebron Road, on the north side of the Hebron Chapel (SMR 21344). The burial ground appears to have been created in 1853, at the same time that the Hebron Chapel was built. It was established within a land parcel which had previously been in agricultural use. The cemetery is first recorded by Ashmead's survey of Bristol of 1855 and later by Ashmead's 1870 map, although neither records the burial ground as such. The cemetery plot measures approximately 42 metres from north-west to south-east by 33.5 metres wide. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.23) surveyed in 1883 indicated that the burial ground was by that date enclosed by a stone wall and many randomly positioned small trees or shrubs were established across the site. The entrance was at the south-east corner and there was a small structure at the north-west corner.
The burial ground is extant.

Bedminster Smelting Works on the western side of Clarke Street, Bedminster. The works is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.4.19) surveyed in 1883. The works survived into the 1920s but was subsequently cleared and redeveloped.

Hippodrome, located on the northern side of East Street, Bedminster. The building was constructed by Walter de Freece to seat 3000 as a theatre in 1911 (Anderson 1983, 20) and was a four-storey, eleven-bay brick building with square towers at its south-west and south-east corners. These projected a storey above the level of the parapet and had a pediment on each of the four faces. The main entrance was at the centre of the ground floor and was reached by a flight of five steps. It was converted into a cinema known as Stoll Picture Theatre. This use continued until 1940 when the building was damaged by bombing. The remains of the structure were demolished in 1954 and the site redeveloped (Winstone 1978, pl.78).

KNOWN_AS: Heath House, Sir John's Lane, Purdown
MONUMENT_DESC:
Heath House, located to the north of Sir John's Lane, Purdown. The Heath House estate belonged to the Smyth family of Ashton Court by the later-eighteenth century and in 1784 Thomas Smyth commissioned the Bath-based architect John Hensley, to design a new house to replace the original manor house. As well as the main house the proposed scheme included the proposed scheme included a brewhouse, gardener's house, weighing room, and a laundry and washhouse.
Heath House is a two-storey, bow-fronted building, originally constructed with a single range. The long range on the north side was added after the tithe survey had taken place in 1839. The Stapleton tithe map of 1839 shows eight outbuildings further to the west of the house, of which the Lodge and a narrow stone rubble building against Sir John's Lane, as well as the building known as Heath Cottages survive. There is a formal garden immediately to the west and south of the original part of the house. The building was vacant for several years and was refurbished in 1992 to accommodate a psychiatric hospital.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building Number 901-1/33/1571).

Brislington Pottery, on the south side of the Avon at St. Anne's. The products of the pottery have received attention since the existence of the pottery was brought to a wider audience by Hugh Owen (1873), and its history has since been addressed by others, notably W. J. Pountney (1920) and Oliver Kent (1996).
The pottery was founded by John Bissicke, who had connections to the Southwark potteries, and Ralph Bennett in the 1650s. By the 1680s Edward Ward had taken over the pottery. It was advertised for sale in the Oracle Country Advertiser on 26 October 1745 when it was described as "consisting of a Messuage, Pot-house and sundery Close of Ground, the whole now lett at 55l. 12s. per annum...."
Archaeological excavations by W. J. Pountney in 1914 (SMR 20221) revealed the foundations of kilns on the south and north sides of the chapel and the stables and other outbuildings extending to the north.
Kent argues that three phases of development can be discerned in both the documentary record and the products of the pottery. The first phase, the founding and operation of the pottery by Bissicke and Bennett when pieces bearing simple geometric or brush decoration were produced, was followed by a second from 1679. Pieces bearing the simple geometric designs continued to be produced but there was a shift to figurative and political designs. The third phase began in the late 1740s, after the pottery had been sold, when with new investment in technology it began to produce red wares (Kent 1996, 80-81).

In 1799 Dr. E. L. Fox purchased part of the then recently enclosed Brislington Common for £4000 and built Brislington House in 1804 as a private hospital for the treatment of the insane (Pevsner 1958, 465). The building has been noted as an early example of the use of cast iron structural elements for fire protection (Richardson 1998, 156-157) and was composed of a series of linked houses where patients were accommodated according to their social rank and means. There was also care to segregate the sexes, each in "a distinct house, detached from the others by a considerable interval" (Fox & Fox 1836, 4). This segregation resulted in two identical wings being built with the dividing wall running through the central part of the main building, the baths and the airing ground. The door on the main façade was the only entrance to the asylum where a porter was constantly on duty. These six houses were joined together and remodelled in the Italian Renaissance style with a nine-bay centre and a lower nine-bay wing on each side (Pevsner 1959, 465; Stoddard 1981, 50-51). The chapel, reportedly the first in an asylum, was added in 1851, and a ballroom and concert room were built in 1866. There were also separate houses in the grounds (SMR 1229) for wealthier patients where according to an advertisement of 1809 they were "allowed to pursue any style of living and expense as to carriages, horses etc. most suitable to their former habits and not inconsistent with their present situation" (SRO T/PH/Fx 2).
Dr. Fox retired in 1829 and went to live at Heath House. He died in 1835 and was buried in burial ground of the Society of Friends on the south side of Bath Road (SMR 10187). After his death the management of the asylum was taken over by two of his sons, Dr. Francis Ker Fox and Dr. Charles Henry Fox. Succeeding generations of the Fox family managed the asylum with Dr. Francis Elliot Fox being the last postholder until his death in 1947. The patients were then moved to other institutions. The house was purchased by the former Bristol United Hospital Authority for £40,000 and was used as a Nurses' Home until 1983 when it was sold, to be re-opened as a private nursing home in November 1984.
The grounds appear to have been re-landscaped after 1846 (BRO EP/A/32/9) and the arrangment of the new planting is recorded by the Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan of 1884.
The building received a Grade II listing in March 1984 (Listed Building number 901-1/49/440).

A limekiln is reported on the site of the aquarium at Bristol Zoo. In 1836 the Bristol, Clifton and West of England Zoological Society purchased 12 acres of land including a cottage and limekiln at Summer Trenmoor, Clifton for the purpose of founding a zoological gardens (Green-Armitage 1964, 7-8). Richard Forrest designed the layout of the gardens utilising the circular bowl of the limekiln as the basis for a bear pit (SMR 22125) that stood at the east end of a terrace walkway until the bear pit was converted into an aquarium in 1926. It is likely that the circular and semi subterranean form of the present aquarium reflects the original form of the limekiln and subsequent bear pit.

No.3 Hollywood Road, located on the western side of Hollywood Road, Brislington. The building is the southern of a pair of cottages which were apparently constructed in the eighteenth century. It is a two-storey house with a pitched pantile roof and a catslide at the rear. The main, east-facing, elevation has a two-window range with a central door. The fenestration comprises six-over-six pane sashes without horns. There is a blank window opening above the main entrance.
The house has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/48/463).

KNOWN_AS: The Old England public house, Bath Buildings, Montpelier
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Old England public house, located off Bath Buildings, Montpelier. The building was constructed in the eighteenth or early nineteenth century and was in existence by 1828. The building is a three-storey rendered structure with a three-window range and a pitched roof. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town Plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.5) surveyed in 1881 names the public house as the "Old England."
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/36/1576).

Redland Chapel, Redland Green. The chapel was commissioned in 1740 as a private chapel by John Cossins of Redland Court. Dening (1923 85) suggests John Strahan as the architect, but Ison (1952, 54-55) establishes that William Halfpenny (the professional name used by Michael Hoare) oversaw the construction work and may therefore have provided the design. The chapel was drawn by Halfpenny in 1742 (Eustace, 1982 fig.22). Stone carving on the west front and the interior was by Thomas Paty, as was some of the plasterwork. Cossins nominated William Ray, then vicar of Westbury-on-Trym, as minister. An indenture dated 10th June 1749 records that an "Orchard and a piece of void ground on which a mansion house formerly stood" were used as endowment to maintain the chapel and pay a stipend to the minister.
The chapel has a Grade I listing (Listed Building No.901-1/34/1723). the perimeter wall, gate piers and gates to the churchyard (SMR 20266) are listed separately and are Grade II* (Listed Building No.901-1/34/1724).

Brislington National School, located on the east side of School Road, Brislington. The school was built was built in 1859. The plans for the school (SMR 20539) are deposited with the Somerset Record Office (SRO DD/EDS C/1404 S.B.D. Plans 5228) and are signed by N. Williams, Moses Webley, Thomas James and John Gray. The building was in a Victorian Gothic style of and was constructed of stone with a grey slate roof. The sides of the windows were edged in plain yellow brick, while over the top there were alternate red and yellow bricks. The doors were of wood. On the roof there was a weather-vane and a bell which was enclosed in ornate framework. The masters' and a mistresses' houses were sited at opposite ends of the building.
In the front of the building, and fronting on to School Road, there was a yard with a water pump. There was also an upper sloping playground. The school was built on the site of an older school and the additional land required for the new school was donated by James Ireland in November 1858. The school suffered bomb damage in 1941 and was demolished.

Village smithy, Brislington. This was situated on the corner of Grove Road and Bristol Hill and lay between the Kings Arms Inn and the bridge over Brislington Brook. The smithy comprised a two-storey building with a single-storey extension to the front of the building facing on to Grove Road. The roof was steeply pitched with a chimney at each end. An iron gate led from Bristol Hill to a yard overlooking the brook where a large ash tree grew. A round platform for retyring carriage and cart wheels was situated in this yard. Messrs Hellier, Snell and Wood were named as the three smiths in 1920.
The Brislington Tithe Award of 1846 records that the site was occupied by two houses, both owned by Thomas Rennolds, lessee to William Gore Langton with the occupiers recorded as Thomas Hibby and Samuel Hillier. The smithy is marked on the Ordnance Survey map of 1916 (but not on the 1882 edition). The smithy had possibly been closed down by 1928.

KNOWN_AS: Statue of Alfred Fagon, Ashley Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
Statue of Alfred Fagon, located in the grassed area at the junction of Ashley Road and Grosvenor Road.
