Fagon (1937-1986) was a Jamaican-born playwright, poet and actor and was one of the major Black British playwrights of the 1970s and 1980s. Fagon's notebooks and scripts were deposited with the V & A Theatre Museum in 2000 (accession number RF2000/690). The statue was commissioned by the Friends of Fagon Committee and is a bronze bust sculpted by David G. Mutasa. The work stands on a plinth, made of polished granite slabs, which is approximately 1.2 metres high and 0.5 metres square. The north-east face of the plinth bears the legend:
"ALFRED FAGON/1937-1986/POET PLAYWRIGHT ACTOR/"THROUGH GRIEF TO HAPPINESS/ERECTED/ON THE FIRST ANNIVERSARY/OF HIS DEATH,/29 AUGUST 1987,/BY THE FRIENDS OF FAGON"
The work was unveiled on 29 August 1987.
[Public Monument and Sculpture Association reference number BR52].

The Triangle Cinema located on west side of the Triangle West. The cinema was converted from the Triangle Hall skating rink by Frank Wilkins for Emmanuel Harris to a design by W. H. Watkins (Ewins 1984, 27). The cinema opened in 1914 with two storeys and a spherically fronted pillared entrance on its north east corner. Harris later added a balcony and an open café from which the screen could be viewed (Anderson 1983, 32-33; 61). The cinema was run in the 1930s in conjunction with the Whiteladies Picture House by Triangle and Whiteladies Picture Houses Ltd. (Ewins 1984, 27).
The cinema was destroyed by bombing in 1940.

KNOWN_AS: House on the west side of Allen Court, East Street, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC:
House on the west side of Allen Court, located on the southern side of East Street, Bedminster. The date at which the building was construction is unknown but its form at the end of the nineteenth century suggests that it may have been constructed in the seventeenth century. The building was extant by the time of the survey of Bristol by John Plumley and George Ashmead of 1828. In 1871 the building was occupied by E. Smale, stationer, and a photograph of roughly that date (Winstone 1966, pl.77) indicates that the building was probably refronted in the early nineteenth century. The building was then a rendered three-storey house with a pitched pantile roof. The main, north-west facing, elevation was of three bays. At ground-floor level the centre bay contained the main entrance doorway and this had a single stone step up from the footway of East Street with a footscraper on its western side. There were bay windows on either side of the entrance, and the eastern of these was square while the western was canted. The western bay window contained a central 4 by 4 pane sash and 2 by 4 pane sashes in the side. The ground floor was divided from the first floor by a flat canopy which rested on the top of the bay windows and extended across the full width of the elevation, also sheltering the main entrance. The fenestration at first-floor level consisted of single 3 by 4 pane sash windows in each of the three bays. The three second-floor windows, again with in each bay, were smaller and appear to be casements. Above the tops of these windows, at the west end of the elevation, there was a gout (serving a gutter behind the parapet) which emptied into a downpipe. The parapet itself has an ashlar coping and projected above the eaves of the roof, obscuring the lower part. The ridge was aligned parallel to East Street and a three-flue chimneystack projected from its eastern end. There was a narrower stack at the western end of the roof. Smaller structures to the rear of the main house may have included a detached kitchen.
The building appears to have survived into the twentieth century but was subsequently demolished. The extent of demolition is not clear. The front component of No.145 East Street is now only two storeys in height but parts of the structure may have been retained inside the main building and the surviving structures at the rear of the building may be contemporary with the early-modern building.

Easton Colliery. The colliery was opened in 1828 and by the mid-nineteenth century it was owned by Davidson and Walters. The company was combined with Leonard, Betts and Boult, which owned another colliery in Easton, to form the Easton Coal Company. The Leonard, Betts and Boult colliery was then closed (Ramsey 2003, 24). By the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.8) surveyed in 1883 the colliery included brick kilns to the north-west and the south-east of the shaft and engine house. In 1886 eight men were killed by an explosion in the mine (Ramsey 2003, 12).
The mine was run by the Bedminster, Easton, Kingswood and Parkfield Collieries Ltd. from the early twentieth century until the pit was closed in 1911 (Ramsey 2003, 20-21). Buildings were subsequently erected on the site in the 1930s and these were cleared in 1991 and the site was redeveloped. Parts of shafts and galleries were photographed by John Cornwell.

Brook Farm, located on the northern side of Whitchurch Lane, Bishopsworth. The farm was in existence by the eighteenth century and was owned in 1827 by William Gore-Langton (BRO AC/PL 107/1 & 2). The Bedminster tithe survey of 1841 indicated that the farm consisted of a farmhouse, yard and garden with outbuildings. The tithe map indicates that the farmhouse was a long building aligned north-east to south-west positioned at the centre of the farm site with outbuildings to either side. Some 5 metres to the east of the farmhouse was a pound (SMR 21199), which was also in existence by the late eighteenth century. The farm was then owned, along with much other land in the immediate area, by William Gore-Langton and was rented by John Smith and Elizabeth Sellett.. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.14) published in 1885 names the farm as Brook Farm and indicates that while most of the buildings recorded by the tithe map were still extant, an extension at the south-east corner of the farmhouse had been demolished. The plan also records a well just to the south of the farmhouse (at ST 57391 68587). Several of the farm outbuildings survived into the 1950s but most were demolished in the 1960s when a garage was constructed to the north-west of the farmhouse.
The farmhouse itself is extant and is now a two-storey rectangular building, measuring 9.5 metres from north-east to south-west by 8 metres wide, with a single-storey extension on the eastern side. The building is constructed of coursed stone rubble. The main, south-west facing elevation is of three bays with a main entrance door at the centre of the elevation. All of the openings have plain ashlar mouldings. Originally there were chimneystacks at the eastern and western ends of the building. These were apparently extant in the 1970s (Bantock, 1996) but have subsequently been removed. The pantile roof is hipped. The single-storey extension is also of coursed stone rubble and has a pitched pantile roof. There is an entrance door at the western end of its south-west facing elevation (Winstone, 1977 pl.201).

KNOWN_AS: Poor House at Hudds Vale Road, St. George
MONUMENT_DESC:
Poor House or workhouse, located to the west of modern Hudds Vale Road. The building opened in 1801. As a result of the Poor Law Amendment Act of 1834 the poor house became part of the Clifton Poor Law Union. The building was recorded by the St. George tithe survey of 1842 (BRO EP/A/32/32) which indicated that the residential component of the poor house was on the south side of the structure while the northern element consisted of a range of buildings around the sides of a central yard.
A larger poor house was developed at Fishponds Road, Eastville in 1847 and this subsequently expanded, making the Hudd's Vale Road site redundant. By the early 1870s John Ellis was operating an earthenware pottery (SMR 20967) in the buildings and this was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) surveyed in 1880-81. The buildings of the poor house seem to have been extant at that date but were subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped as a soapworks (SMR 20969).

Wickham Court, located on the south side of Wickham Hill. The building is a gabled house of seventeenth-century date constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble (Pevsner 1958, 473). Internally the building is reported to have a central dog-leg winder stair with splat balusters which leads to an observation platform at the top of the rear stair tower. The house has been sub-divided into smaller dwellings.
The listing description notes that it is believed Cromwell and Fairfax held council of war in the house before the march on Bristol in 1645.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/29/1975).

KNOWN_AS: Enclosure known as Old House Ground
MONUMENT_DESC:
Enclosure in a field to the south of the Salt Rhine and to the west of Moorend Farm. The land was part of Rockingham Farm until the mid eighteenth-century when it was acquired by the Southwell Estate. A 1772 plan of the Southwell Estate records the field in which the enclosure is sited as "Old House Ground", although the map shows no building (BRO 26570).
The irregular subrectangular enclosure consists of a ditch and platform, the base of the ditch being 0.7 metres lower than the platform. The enclosure was in good condition in 1946 when it was recorded by the RAF air photographic survey but has since been ploughed. The feature was surveyed in 1997 by Glamorgan-Gwent Archaeological Trust as part of an archaeological evaluation (HER 20226) of fields on the opposite side of the Salt Rhine.

The Wyck, otherwise known as The Wick, Wick Farm or Week Farm. The placename "The Wyck" was first recorded in the Pipe Rolls in 1195 and re-occurs in subsequent medieval property records (Smith 1964, 133). In 1794  "all that messuage tenement or dwelling house called or known by the name of Week House otherwise Wick House with the barns, stables offices, yards, gardens, orchards and paddock ground there belonging", then rented by William Yeoman, passed into the ownership of Sarah Beausoy of Stokes Croft in Bristol (BRO 28048 P92). The farm was inherited by her daughters Sarah Hood and Susannah Southall at her death in 1799 (BRO 28048 P92) and by the time of the Henbury Tithe Survey in 1840 was owned by Ann Hood, presumably the daughter of Sarah Hood, and Thomas Hayne. It was then rented by William Lambert (BRO EP/A/32/22). The Wick is recorded by the first edition Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire sheet LXVII.16 published in 1881). In the early twentieth century the Avonmouth and Filton Railway, which opened on 9th May 1910, bisected the fields to the north of the farmhouse.
The farm buildings were still extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey Provisional Edition map of 1938. The farm and farmhouse site has since been developed for housing and the majority of the buildings associated with the farmhouse lie beneath Nos.276-288 Passage Road.

A fishpond on the lower slopes of Ashley Hill. The pond is recorded on the 1st edition Ordnance Survey plan of 1881 (Bristol Sheet LXXII.9.12) as a fishpond and is similar in form of a duck decoy pond, though smaller in size than is usual for such a pond. Its surface area in 1881 was just over 820 square metres and the two southern limbs extended south towards a channel carrying water away from Ashleyvale Mill, 150 metres to the north-east, perhaps to create a flow into and out of the pond. There was a small island, presumably for waterfowl, in the centre which was reached by a bridge on the north-west side.
The pond has been infilled and now lies at the northern end of St. Werburghs City Farm.

Redland Court, located on the south-western side of Redland Court Road. An existing post-medieval house standng on the site was demolished and a new house was constructed (although some of the panelling was apparently reused in the new house) between 1732 and 1735 to designs by John Strahan for John Cossins, a retired London grocer (Ison 1952, 164). The house is a two-storey ashlar building with a hipped roof and cellar. In plan the building had an entrance hall on the north side with stairwells on either side. The eastern stairwell contains a winder stair while the western has a spiral stair. The hall led into the dining room and this connected on its west side with a parlour and on the east with another dining room (Ison 1952, 164-170). All of the rooms have a marble chimneypiece on the west wall and are panelled. The house appears to have had extensive landscaped grounds to the south-east, including a tree avenue approximately 600 metres long (SMR 21899) running north-west from a rusticated stone arch (SMR 21902) with crenellations at modern Cotham Grove towards the house. The newly-completed house and its grounds were surveyed in 1732, the plan surviving in the plans of the British Library. The arch was drawn by James Stewart in 1746 and was still extant in 1828. In 1747 Thomas Paty was commissioned design two pavilions, linked to the north-east and north-west corners of the house by corridors (Charlton & Milton 1951, 61-62).
John Cossins died in 1759 and bequeathed the Redland Court estate to his wife Martha (neé Innys). The couple had no children and at her death Martha left the estate to her brother Jeremy Innys who had been living at Redland Court since 1755. At his death in 1765 it passed to another of the Innys siblings, John Innys, and when he died in 1778 to Jeremy Baker (Martha Cossin's nephew). Baker died in 1798 and the estate was auctioned to pay his debts. Much of the land appears to have been bought by Sir John Smyth who subsequently leased it to Stephen Cave, while Henry Seymour purchased the house for £9200. Seymour's son Henry sold the house to Sir Richard Vaughan in 1811. Vaughan was declared bankrupt in December 1828 and the house was purchased in the following December by James Evan Baillie who initially lived there and continued to own it until his death in 1863. George Oldham bought Redland Court in 1864 and on his death in 1883 the house was acquired by Redland High School for Girls. The school moved into the buildings in 1885 (Little 1983, 4). The associated landscape park was developed for housing in the later-nineteenth century. The school commissioned the architectural practice Oatley and Lawrence to convert the stables to classrooms and refront the building in 1911-1912 (Little 1983, 7).
There has been little archaeological work at Redland Court but the stairs of the building were surveyed by C. D. Ruding Bryan, probably in the early 1920s (Dening 1923, 80).
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/35/1719).

KNOWN_AS: Hannah More Building, Nos.11-15 Manor Road, Fishponds
MONUMENT_DESC:
Hannah More Building, Nos.11-15 Manor Road, Fishponds, located on the south-western side of Manor Road. Under the will of Mary Webb of 1729 a trust was created to establish a free school at Fishponds. This was intended to teach "Twenty poor Boys and Ten poor Girls of the parish of Stapleton" and also to provide accommodation for three "poor old Women" (quoted in Stott 2003, 4). The building was constructed c1729 and is a two-storey structure with an H-shaped plan and is constructed of coursed Pennant sandstone bonded in an orange-red mortar with white lime inclusions. The central element of the building consists of a single room with a porch enclosing the entrance on the south-east facing elevation. Inside there was a stone chimneypiece of eighteenth-century date on the north-eastern wall. The northern and southern elements of the building are two houses, orientated from north-west to south-east, with the entrance to each on the north-east and south-west facing elevations. There are stone chimney stacks at either end of the roof which is covered in Roman clay tiles.
The first master, William Scutts, was dismissed in 1734 for "very obscene practices" towards some of the female students. The master replacing Scutts died in 1743 and Jacob More was appointed as master of the school in October of that year and appears to have remained in post until his death in 1783. More's fourth daughter, Hannah, who became a playwright, educationalist and evangelist was born in the building in early February 1745 (Stott 2003, 4-5).
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/54/1270).

Rookery Farm, Whitchurch. The farm was located some 80 metres to the south of Whitchurch Lane and was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500-scale County Series plan (Somerset  Sheet VI.15) published in 1885. At that date it comprised a farmhouse with a large building to the north-east. This building had been demolished by the beginning of the twentieth century and a smaller structure constructed to its east. The farm survived into the twentieth century but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped for housing. The site of the farm now lies largely beneath the houses and gardens of Nos.53-55 Rookery Way.

The remains of an eighteenth-century garden at Crew's Hole, recorded in c.1990 by James Russell of Bristol and Avon Archaeological Society. The garden measured 65 metres north-south by 75-85 metres east-west and had three terraces orientated east-west, each approximately 4 metres wide and descending in height southwards. Paths or ramps surviving from the original plan can be identified and the remains of an octagonal structure, interpreted as a bath house [SMR 20237] were identified on the north side of the of the garden. The remains of a small stone building and "a number of irregularly laid out terraced scarps with some stone revetting" lie at the west side of the site. These were extant by 1883 but probably post-date the original laying out of the garden (Russell 1990/91 51). Russell suggests that the garden may be attributable to William Reeves, builder of Arno's Court (ibid. 53).
The eastern and western boundaries of the garden could not be traced on the ground by the 1990s survey, and it was also noted that a nineteenth-century brickworks had encroached on its eastern end. The bath house is semi-derelict, and most of the rest of the garden has been allowed to become overgrown since the 1950s.

KNOWN_AS: Manor House, St. Mark's Road, Easton
MONUMENT_DESC:
Manor House, located on the northern side of St. Mark's Road. A plan of Kingswood of 1610 appears to show a building on the site but Manor House dated to later in the seventeenth century. It was a six-bay, three-storey house of random Pennant sandstone rubble bonded in a white lime mortar with red sandy inclusions. The house measured roughly 8.5 metres long by 6 metres wide and had a single-pile plan. On the northern side of the house there was a large projecting element containing the rear part of the main stair. The original internal plan comprised an entrance hall leading to a centrally-placed main stair with a drawing room on either side of the hall. The stair rose to a landing and appears to have divided into two half-turn stairs, one on either side, to serve first-floor landings (Brett et al. 1994).
The building was sited on a small promontory and appears to have stood within a large, south-facing garden plot. In an unpublished letter of 22 April 1937 F. C. Jones notes a large block of architectural stone, possibly a gate pier, bearing a crest and sundial with the date 1698 (BRO 33290(12)). The building was the garden house or summerhouse (ie. second residence) of a Bristol merchant dating to the seventeenth century (R. Leech pers. comm.). Drawings by Samuel Loxton produced in the early twentieth century record the St. Mark's Road frontage of the building and the entrance hall. The seventeenth-century central staircase was still extant at that date.
A plan of St. George of 1803 by William Maule indicates that the land parcel within which the house stood was then owned by L. B. Larwill. Manor House was recorded in the local street directories from 1878. In 1897 the building became the Manor House Christian Recreational Institute and later became the East Bristol YMCA. The site was acquired by the builders John Perkins and the fabric substantially altered by conversion into offices. The larger cellar was converted, probably immediately before or at the beginnning of the Second World War, into a works air raid shelter by the creation of an internal framework of rolled steel joists. John Perkins was liquidated in 1993 and the building was demolished in 1994. The remaining elements of the building were subject to archaeological recording before demolition (SMR 10504; Brett et al. 1994). The site was subsequently redeveloped for housing.

Redland House, located on the north side of Redland Hill. The house appears to have been in existence since the mid eighteenth century (Bryant 2000) and was first recorded cartographically by a map of the area produced by Sturges in 1817. In 1825 Redland House was owned by John Vivian and occupied by Arthur Foulks (BRO P/HTW/V2(a)) but by the time of the Westbury tithe survey it was owned by Sarah Nayler. Redland House was divided into two properties between the 1840s and 1855, the eastern half retaining the name Redland House and the western becoming Redland Bank. Both Redland Bank and Redland House had formal gardens according to the Ordnance Survey first edition plan surveyed in 1881, although that belonging to Redland Bank was the larger.
Construction of a terrace of housing at the foot of Redland Hill involved the removal of around 60% of Redland House. Redland Collegiate School moved to the building in 1915 from its original site in Clarendon Road but during the Second World War Redland House was requisitioned and the Collegiate School moved to Winterbourne. After the war the building became home to the Redland Training College.
Redland House were listed Grade III but it was removed from the statutory list in 1961 for the construction of new educational buildings.

Manilla Hall, located on the east side of Clifton Down Road. The building was erected in 1763 by Sir William Draper and named in honour of his capture of Manila in October 1762.
The house was a nine-bay, three-storey structure with a tetrastyle portico with ionic columns which extended to second storey level but had no pediment. The ground floor was rusticated with flat relieving arches above the windows and entrances arches with open pediments above at either end of the house, each adding half a bay to its width.
Draper erected a cenotaph to the 79th Regiment (SMR 20126) and an obelisk commemorating William Pitt the elder (SMR 20127) in front of the house (Dreaper 1998, 1).
Draper died in 1787 at Bath and the house was inherited by his surviving daughter. It was later bought by William Gordon, who lived at the property adjacent on the north side, and passed into the hands of the Miles family of Bristol bankers in the nineteenth-century. Sir Joseph Weston bought the property in 1892 and parcelled some of its grounds for building plots, while Manilla House itself was sold to the Dames de la Mere de Dieu and used as a Roman Catholic school. The obelisk and cenotaph were removed to their present position when the order wanted to dispose of them. The house was demolished in the early twentieth century Dreaper 1998, 23-24).

Gaunt's Ham Park, located on the north-western side of Lincoln Street. The need for a park in the area had been identified by the 1880s and a site known as Gaunt's Ham, lying behind terraced houses on Lincoln Street and adjacent to the Wain Brook, was approved for laying out by the Sanitary Committee on 18 August 1887. The land was owned by the Bristol Corporation and the Committee paid an annual rent of £40. On 21 August 1890 the purchase of a gateway at Highgrove, Totterdown (for £12 10s 0d) for the Elizabeth Street entrance to the park was authorised, and the park opened in the same year. Installation of a second gate for the Tenby Street entrance was agreed on 5 March 1891. The park layout appears to have been designed by the Bristol Corporation's Surveyor, George Ashmead and tenders for the undertaking the works were then invited. That by August Kruss of £653 was accepted on 12 May 1891. The Bristol Member of Parliament and former chairman of The Anchor Society Sir Joseph Dodge Weston donated a drinking fountain for the park which was erected by the Elizabeth Street entrance. This was manufactured by Macfarland and Co. and carried an inscription reading "Presented by Sir Joseph D. Weston M.P. February 1892".
The park originally covered an area of around 5300 square metres and had an adjacent recreation ground at its south-west end. Further planting of trees and shrubs by was agreed on 3 March 1892 at a cost of £72/12/0.
The park was extended along its south-east side when the site of the Lincoln Street terraced houses was incorporated into the park after their demolition. During the Second World War an air raid shelter (SMR 21889), an underground tunnel shelter approximately 9 metres square, was constructed at the south-west end of the site.
The layout of paths has not been substantially altered since the early twentieth century and the original gate piers at the Elizabeth Street and Tenby Street entrances are extant, although the gates have been removed from the Elizabeth Street piers. The drinking fountain has also been removed.

Redland Green. The green was in existence by the late-eighteenth century and is recorded by name in a series of plans of the area from 1817 onwards, including the Westbury-on-Trym tithe survey of 1841 (Land Parcel 490) and belonged to the Lords of the Manor of Westbury and Henbury. The Green appears to have been common land used for pasture and presumably for herbage.
A new Bishop's Palace was constructed in 1899 at the edge of the Green (within a field named Otward Brockridge). In 1902 seven and a half acres were given to Bristol Corporation and the Corporation bought out the remaining Commoners rights at a total cost of £200. The space was established as a public amenity and there appears to have been some planting, including the existing London Plane trees, and the setting up of park furniture at that date. One of the rustic cast-iron park benches, manufactured by T. P. Richards & Sons is extant. These are shown in a drawing of the Green by Samuel Loxton dating to the early twentieth century (Bristol Reference Library W1357). A further two and a half acres were given to the Corporation by the Trustees of Redland Chapel and this land was used as allotments until 1956. Between 1951 and 1953 tennis courts and a bowling green and pavilion were constructed.

KNOWN_AS: Iron Age occupation site, Hallen Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC:
An Iron Age occupation site at Hallen Marsh. The site was identified in 1990 during observation of a geotechnical pit by Mr P. Anderson of Soil Mechanics. A 0.3 metre thick layer of Iron Age occupation material, including quantities of pottery, bone, charcoal and stone was noted. In 1992 the site was archaeologically evaluated by Glamorgan-Gwent Archaeological Trust as part of the evaluation work for the English approaches to the Second Severn Crossing (Lawler et al. 1992). This work confirmed an Iron Age date for the site, which was subsequently archaeologically excavated by Wessex Archaeology between December 1992 and March 1993 (SMR 20131).
A palisaded enclosure of Middle to Late Iron Age date was recorded, with evidence for timber, post-built structures and considerable artefactual evidence. The site was noted to have undergone several modifications and it was suggested that "it was constructed during a period when the Avon Levels were relatively dry, probably drier at least than the periods immediately pre- or post-dating the settlement." It was also observed that the area of settlement continued beyond the western edge of the excavated area (Barnes et al. 1993, 8-13).

KNOWN_AS: The Fire Engine public house, Church Road
MONUMENT_DESC: The Fire Engine public house, located on the west side of the junction of Church Road and Blackswarth Road. The building is of possible eighteenth-century date and is a five bay rendered house, with a hipped double-Roman tiled roof at right angles to the road at the eastern end roof. The building has a double pile plan.

Cottage and garden on the west side of Birchwood Road, Brislington. The structure was first depicted on a plan of an estate in Brislington surveyed by Benjamin Price in 1791 (SRO DD/GLd/4) and was recorded as a cottage and garden in the ownership of James Goldstone. An earlier enclosure plan of 1780 depicts a similar enclosure and structure, although the building appears to occupy a different footprint to that in 1791. A building likely to be the same cottage as in 1791, is recorded on the 1846 Brislington Tithe map and recorded as being within the lands of James Ireland and occupied by William Pillinger. Later map evidence suggests that this building or elements of it survived until the existing house on the site was constructed in the second half of the twentieth century.

No.6 Denmark Street, located on the south side of Denmark Street. The building is a rendered house of three storeys, attic and basement with an M-shaped roof. It was constructed in the early 1720s as part of a terrace and No.6 itself was first recorded in the Land Tax assessment of 1728 under the name of a Captain Dunn (presumably a sailor), but was then unoccupied. A plan of c1743 recorded the property as being 20 feet [6.1 metres] wide and 40 feet [12.2 metres] deep (BRO 04479(1)).
The building is constructed of Brandon Hill grit bonded in a brown mortar.
The fireplace in the east wall is bonded in a red-orange mortar with white lime flecks. The fireplace is supported by two corbels in the east wall of the cellar. The building was substantially altered and the main elavation reconstructed in the nineteenth century. The main, north-facing, elevation is in an early nineteenth-century style and is of two bays with a small attic dormer window behind the parapet. At ground-floor the façade has a shopfront apparently of late-Victorian or Edwardian date and the main entrance is on its west side. A narrow pentice divides ground from first floor and the west side of the elevation is marked by a pilaster. The fenestration at first- and second-floor levels comprises sashes. The pitched roof is tiled and there is a rendered chimney stack at the east end of the roof.
The ground floor rooms have been knocked into one during the nineteenth or twentieth century. There are two rooms at first and second floor level. In both the northern, front, and the southern, rear, rooms late eighteenth- or early nineteenth-century chimneypieces survive in the east wall. Cornices which appeared to be contemporary also survived in the first-floor front room.
Access to the cellar is by a wooden stair on the west side of the building and its walls appeared to be constructed of stone. The front, north, wall appears to have been cut back in the centre to create a new and larger cellar entrance in the nineteenth century.
The building is listed as part of the terrace Nos.1-7 Denmark Street and has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/88). Photographs of the building are held in the SMR collection of Ground-based photographs (nos.1566-1596 inclusive).

Cromwell House, located some 140 metres to the west of St. Michael's Hill. The building was a three-storey house of mid-seventeenth century date, with a cross-gabled roof and chimney stacks at either end of the roof. The building was recorded in a drawing by James Stewart made on 10th April 1752 (BUAD 2757; Bodleian Library, Western MSS, Gough Somerset 2 fo.15) which shows the south-east facing elevation. An undated later Victorian photograph (BUAD 3982; BRO 41881/1) records the north-east and north-west facing elevations and indicates that a two-storey extension had been added to the north-west facing elevation (centred on ST 58255 75455).
The plot was leased to John Hicks, mercer, by the Corporation in 1665 and the lease itself notes that Hicks had "lately erected and built a house three storeys in height" there (BRO 04435(5)). The building seems to have belonged to members of the Hicks family until 1713, when it became the home of William Hopton. The property was leased to John Elbridge in 1727, though he did not occupy it, and this lease was renewed in 1738. The lease was assigned to Henry Woolnough and leased by John Broughton from 1788. Samuel Edwards of Cotham House had a lease from 1791 and Henry Hunt, chocolate manufacturer, from 1823. The building did not therefore form part of the Tyndall estate.
The building was demolished between 1885 and 1903 (Leech, 2000 57-59). Its site was subsequently redeveloped for the H. H. Wills Physics Building of the University of Bristol.

St. James Priory. The priory was locatoed in the area defined by modern Whitson Street, St. James Parade and Cannon Street. The monastery was a Benedictine site founded in the twelfth century, reputedly in 1129, by Robert of Gloucester (Robert Fitzroy). The nave of the church was in use for parochial purposes by 1374 and survived the Dissolution by virtue of its role as the church of the parish St. James (BUAD 143M). Part of the western claustral range, including 2 bays of the arcade of the cloister walk, survives incorporated into Church House (BUAD 144M). The brothers' burial ground was located immediately east of the conventual buildings, the parish burial ground to the south.
St. James Priory was dissolved in January 1540, and the buildings appear quickly to have become dilapidated. In 1544 Henry Brayne, a London merchant, bought the priory site and all its property, including the advowson of several Bristol rectories but specifically excluding the bells and the lead on the roofs of the priory buildings, for £667 7s. 6d. In January 1544 (Gairdner & Baird 1903, 37).
St. James Church has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/11/347) and the railings and attached walls also have a separate listing. Church House has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/11/348).

No.6 Peter Street, known as Simon Oliver's House. Parts of the monument were recorded by excavations directed by M. W. Ponsford and in 1975 directed by Eric Boore. The wooden corner post was drawn by the architect Thomas S. Pope c.1887. Gabled front; jettied to both elevations. Blitzed, 24/25 November 1940.

KNOWN_AS: St. Brendan's Roman Catholic Church, St. Andrew's Road, Avonmouth
MONUMENT_DESC:
St. Brendan's Roman Catholic Church, located on the north-eastern side of St. Andrew's Road, Avonmouth. The site was purchased by the Clifton diocese and a timber church dedicated to St. Brendan was established on the site in 1946, serving the local community but also seamen arriving at the port of Avonmouth and workers at nearby factories. In 1954 a scheme to construct a new church was granted planning permission and the timber church was dismantled in 1955. Father Norman Fisher of the Portsmouth diocese, whose family lived in Redland, had brought back a piece of rock from the shrine commemorating St. Brendan's voyage to America in County Kerry and this was set in the foundations of the new building. The new church was opened and blessed by the Bishop of the Clifton diocese, Joseph Rudderham, in late January 1956.
The church is a single-storey structure constructed of brick in a Romanesque style with a pitched roof. There is a campanile at the north-west corner of the building. Internally, the Stations of the Cross were donated by a local businessman, Jack Smith.
The last mass was held in the church on 1 February 2004.

Arno's Court Park, part of mid eighteenth century landscape park designed for William Reeve of Arno's Court now a municipal park since the 1960s. Originally a large designed landscape incorporating the Black Castle, bath house and triumphal arch. Some mature trees, boundary walls and the possible remains of a prospect mound survive in the public park that also contained a pond until it was infilled in the later twentieth century.

Wick Cottage constructed in the first half of the nineteenth century as outbuilings for Wick House. Wick Cottage and the associated stable buildings were in existance by the time of the Brislington Tithe survey in 1846 (BRO EP/A/32/9), but are not shown on an illustration by T. L. Rowbotham of Wick House dated 1826/7 (SMR 20592; Stoddard 1981, pl.18).
The cottage is of two storeys with a hipped roof with a three-widow bay. It is constructed of Pennant sandstone. The windows have brick reveals and there are two freestone arches on the ground floor north elevation one around the central entrance, now modern French doors and one around the present east window.
A stable block or coach house adjoins Wick Cottage at a slight offset. This is a two storey pennant sandstone building with a freestone circular window that lies in the centre of the north elevation. There are two other, probably later, circular windows at first floor and one on the ground floor all with brick reveals. One freestone archaed opening survives slightly west of centre in the north elevation, although the top of the arch has been replaced by an RSJ. Further openings are now obscured by a later nineteenth century stable block that stands perpendicular to the coach house abutting the east end of the north elevation. This later stable block is single storey pennant stone building with a pitched roof, semi hipped at the north end, and a single central dormer. The building is much altered, there are presently (03/12/04) seven openings in the east elevation on the ground floor all with brick reveals.
Boundary walls possibly relating to a kitchen garden partially survive to the rear of the propert enclosing the modern development of Nightingale Court.

Durdham Down Nursery to the west of Whiteladies Road consisting of Nursery Villa, and at the time of the first edition 1:2500 survey of 1883 (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.16) approximately 10 acres of grounds bounded by St John's Road to the west, Watley Road to the south and neighbouring properties along King's Parade and Apsley Road to the north and east. Within the grounds of the nursery the 1883 survey shows extensive terraced paths and numerous greenhouses. 
The nursery was in existance by 1827, an advertisement for John Miller, Nurseryman, Seedsman and Florist, shows the square outer bays of the Nursery Villa (listing description). Plumley and Ashmead's plan of Bristol, 1828, marks Nursery Villa and shows structures that are likely to be greenhouses in the extensive grounds to the rear. 
Nursery Villa is reported to be a late seventeenth century farmhouse and is shown on de Wilstar's survey of the Manor of Clifton undertaken for the Society of Merchant Venturers in 1746.
John Miller owned the nursery and lived at Nursery Villa until the late 1830s, during which time he proposed plans for a zoological gardens at Arnos Vale in 1835. These plans never came to fruition, although Miller became a member of the Bristol, Clifton and West of England Zoological Society that established the Zoological Gardens at Clifton in 1836. Richard Forrest, reportedly an employee at Miller's Nursery (Harding and Lambert 1994, 92), was appointed to design the layout of the zoological gardens and soon after the opening the management of the gardens was taken over by Miller's Nursery (Green-Armytage 1964, 40).
In the late 1830s the nursery was taken over by James Garaway who divided Nursery Villa into two dwellings occupied by other family members. 
The Garaway family retained the business until the nursery grounds were sold off for housing development and the creation of Chantry Road (formed from the entrance drive to the nersury), Hurle Road and Hurle Crescent in c.1900. 
Nursery Villa survived this development and lies on the north side of Chantry Road. Part of the boundary to the nursery is preserved as the rear property boundaries of 1-11 Hurle Crescent and the north boundary of No.62 St. John's Lane.
Nos.9-11 Chantry Road are listed Grade II (Listed Building number 901-1/34/10036).

Hengrove Farm. The farm does not appear to have been created until the land in which it stands was bought by the Smyth family of Ashton Court in 1873 (BRO AC/PL 131). A large quarry had been established in the field to the north of the farm by 1883 and two limekilns are shown to the north of the farm by the Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan of that year. The farm was tenanted by John Fitgerald in 1896 (BRO AC/E/32) but the Smyths had sold the land to Alfred Henry Fox by 1918 and his tenant between 1921 and 1931 was Arthur White.  A map, dated June 1917 (BRO DD/QK C/2984 47), details the farm, outbuildings and fields, in connection with the proposed sale of Hengrove Farm by the Ashton Court Estate. The farmhouse is constructed in the Tuscan style and is a two-storey, three-bay building with a hipped roof. Several of the farm buildings also remain, and there is a Pennant sandstone gatepost, typical of those found on farms around Bristol, at the south corner of the farmhouse yard (Bryant, 1995 4). A plan of the farm of 1917 shows the farmhouse and buildings were grouped together around a yard.

West Town House, Brislington.. The structure was of two storeys with, apparently symmetrical north-west and south-west facing elevations, five bays in each with a doorway at the centre. There were chimney stacks at the centre of the north-east and south-east sides of the building and the hipped roof had a shallow pitch. Each of the windows apparently comprised a three by four pane sash with glazing bars. The house was drawn by T. L. Rowbotham in 1826-27 (Stoddard 1981, 52).
Elizabeth Hurle owned the property in 1828 (Ireland Manuscript BRO St. LB/HM/1a & 1b). On the death of Elizabeth Hurle the estate and property passed to her nephew John Hurle. By 1828, he had settled West Town House on his niece Susannah and her husband Joseph Cooke. Their son Joseph Cooke assumed the surname of Hurle and succeeded to Brislington Hill House and the Cooke-Hurle estate in 1855. In the early nineteenth century a large pond was made which became known as Rylands Pond after the occupier of the house.
The house was subsequently let to a succession of wealthy families until it was purchased c.1923 by Joseph Corrigan, owner of a printing company. In 1938 some of the grounds were sold for housing development. Upon Corrigan's death in 1941, the house became a residential home for the elderly and was known as Uganda House. By 1962 the property had been converted into two dwellings.
The house is extant and is located on the east side of West Town Park. It has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/48/469). The site of the pond is now covered by development in West Town Grove.

Wick House, Brislington. The present house was constructed on the site of an earlier house which, by 1730 was in the ownership of William Reeve. On his bankruptcy the bulk of his estate was purchased by John Estridge. He also purchased additional land in the parish. His son, John, c1780 sold the estate which included Wick House and Broomwell House to Thomas Ireland. The present Wick House was constructed in the late-eighteenth century. The grounds had been landscaped in the Picturesque style. Neale (1823) describes the grounds as "the Pleasure Grounds, about sixty acres, in which natural advantages have been judiciously improved by art, present a bold inequality of surface, and an association of beauties rarely to be met wth in a similar compass. The little sequestered valley, in which a stream expands into a small lake, in animated by a Rookery, swans and other water fowl. Here the brilliant Kingfisher haunts the recesses of the babbling brook, or glances beneath the arch of the ivy-mantled bridge:- there the Hermitage in the midst of a shady grove, invites to musing and retirement."
 In 1792 Ireland sold the estate to Charles Hill, a wealthy merchant from Bristol and in 1820, Wick House was purchased by William Withering from Charles Hill. The Brislington Tithe Award of 1846 records Lydia Withering as the owner and occupier of Wick House. On her death in 1867, the estate was purchased by Daniel Collen (Ireland, 1870: BRO St.LB/HM/1a & 1b). After 1918 most of the grounds were built upon. In 1924 the house and two acres were sold to Walter James who presented the property to the Church of England Children's Society. The house remained a childrens' home until c.1980 when it became a nursing home for the elderly.
Wick House is extant and has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/56/471).

KNOWN_AS: Avenue of trees to Cotham's Lodge
MONUMENT_DESC: An avenue of trees leading from Cotham Brow to Cotham's Lodge. The avenue was in existence by 1742 when it was recorded by Jean Rocque's plan of Bristol. It was aligned from south-east to north-west, and measured 80 metres in length. The entrance to the avenue was flanked by two extant stone obelisks (SMR 21896 & SMR 21897). The avenue became the line of the highway of Cotham Grove when housing was developed in the later-nineteenth century.

KNOWN_AS: Sugar House or Burfield Pottery, Westbury Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
Sugar House or Burfield Pottery, located on the eastern side of Westbury Road. The pottery was in existence by the 1740s and the buildings appear to have survived into the mid-1820s. 
In 1742 the pottery was owned by Daniel Saunders, followed by George Hart in 1773 and then operated by Stephen Fricker in 1775. By 1788 the Yabbicom family were paying rates for the property until they moved the business to Avon Street in 1795-7 and closed the Sugar House Pottery (Jackson 2005, 129).
Adverts in the Felix Farley journal indicate that the pottery was producing sugar moulds, flower pots and chimney pots in 1775 (Jackson 2005, 127).
An early nineteenth century plan depicts a building called the 'Pot House' to the east of the road between Westbury and Bristol (BRO 32690(47), Jackson 2005, 123, fig 2). A lease of 1832 (BRO 21782, box 17, bundle 6) describes the various buildings of the former pottery that included a pothouse, coachhouse, stable, other buildings and yard. A plan dated 1829 attached to the lease indicates the location of the buildings (Jackson 2005, 123, fig.3) the boundary walls of which can be traced on the 1880s Ordnance Survey plan, although by this time the pottery had been demolished. This indicates that the main pothouse building lay on the site of the present nos.137-139 Westbury Road with the adjoining yard and outbuildings lying to the rear and beneath the existing nos.141-143.

KNOWN_AS: Swiss Cottage or Carysfoot Cottage, Brislington House
MONUMENT_DESC:
Swiss Cottage also known as Carysfoot Cottage, located in the grounds of Brislington House (SMR 1229). A private asylum was established in Brislington House by Dr. E. L. Fox in 1804 and Swiss Cottage was one of a number of cottages built in the grounds for wealthy patients. The cottage was constructed in the early nineteenth century (possibly by 1809 when the existence of separate cottages was mentioned in an advertisement) and was recorded by a watercolour drawing made by T. L. Rowbotham in 1827 (Stoddard 1981, 50-51). The building is of two storeys and attic with a basement. It has a T-shaped plan. The pitched roof has gables with scalloped barge-boards with quatrefoil-pierced rounded ends.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/49/465).

A building located in the area of what is now Elton Road, Redland. The building appears to have been constructed between the 1840s and the early 1880s, being first recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.12). Its function is currently unknown and it had been demolished by the beginning of the twentieth century, apparently to enable the construction of the housing of Elton Road. The site of the building is now beneath No.6b Elton Road.

KNOWN_AS: Round barrow 260m east of Badock's Wood Primary School sports ground
MONUMENT_DESC:
Southmead barrow, a Bronze Age round barrow located on the northern side of Bowness Gardens, Southmead, adjacent to the playing fields of Doncaster Road Primary School. The earliest reference to the monument is probably by the antiquarian Samuel Seyer (1821, 102). The monument was partially excavated, in December 1873, by Montgomery (SMR 20757) who excavated a section four feet (1.2 metres) wide "from the south side to the centre" (Anon. 1875). An archaeological evaluation trench was excavated on the east side of the monument by the University of Bristol Spelaeological Society in 1922 or 1923 (Tratman 1946, 169-171). Grinsell visited the monument on 9 May 1952 measuring it as 20 paces across and standing 7 feet [just over 2 metres] high (O'Neil & Grinsell 1960, 100).
The lack of a formal report either by Montgomery or by Tratman (the archive for the latter work reportedly having been destroyed by bombing during the Second World War) means that detailed interpretation of the monument is currently difficult. However, it appears to have consisted of a central earth mound, possibly of turf, with a surrounding outer ring of stone. Montgomery recovered human remains, including fragments of a skull, thereby confirming the funerary nature of the monument. No firm dating evidence has yet been recovered, although worked flint was recovered by both Montgomery and Tratman. Tratman suggested a Middle Bronze Age date for the monument by analogy with a similar barrow excavated in Glamorgan (Tratman 1946, 170-171). It has been suggested, apparently on the basis of the name of the field within which the monument lies - "Mill Tut field" - that the barrow was later reused as the mound for a windmill.
The monument is suffering some wear, with an erosion track probably formed by children's bicycles running from east to west across the top of the monument. The barrow is a Scheduled Ancient Monument (SAM No. AV 27).

Counterslip Baptist Chapel. The chapel was located on the south side of [the original] Counterslip, lying two properties to the east of Temple Street. It was set back from street frontage, with low wall with railings, two gates with stone gateposts. The chapel opened 22 March 1810. There were three galleries, and two vestries, one of the latter meeting with the pulpit. Inside the floor was inclined so as to afford a better view of the preacher. Interment within the building was ended by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852.
In 1908 the building became the Bio-pictureland, Bristol's first regular cinema, with 600 seats and a piano beside the projection box (Anderson 1983, 16; Winstone 1972, 8). The cinema was owned by Frank Ogden Smith until 1914 after which the building was demolished for a factory (Anderson 1983, 16).

Pembroke Villa, also known as Kelston View, built between 1826 and 1828 on the south side of Terrell Street. The building was a two storey rendered house with a double pitched roof and central chimney stack. There was a further chimney stack on the east end of the Terrell Street façade. The principle south front elevation featured two 8/8-pane sash windows and one central 4/4-pane sash window on the first floor. A central door on the ground floor was approached by stone steps and pathway from Alfred Hill. A survey of the building in 2005 revealed that the house retained many original features, although the stairs were a modern replacement.

"The Palace," located on the south side of the Pile Street, towards Temple Gate. The building was a lodge or garden house, probably extant by c.1660 but possibly a conversion of an earlier building, which stood at he north-east corner of a walled garden of approximately one acre.
The building was a single-bay gabled house of two storeys plus attic and was of stone rubble construction. There was a small window at ground floor in the centre of the elevation. A first-floor oriel took up about half of the total height of the wall. It was canted and the lower part had four wooden panels on the front, and one on each side. Above there was an eight-light transomed window, with two-lights on each side and the oriel had a pantile roof. There was also a small two-light window in immediately beneath the eaves of the gable end. The gabled roof was pantiled and there was a pendant at the apex of the eaves. On the east wall of the building there was an attached structure just over one storey in height with a lean-to pantile roof. The plot was bounded by a single-storey stone rubble wall attached to the north-west corner of the building, which ran parallel with Pile Street. There was a doorway in this wall immediately to the west of the building. 
The building was recorded as the lodge where Richard Novis lived. It was occupied by John Vittle and then by Charles Weekes , gardener, and the house and garden was granted by Henry Rich to Judith Rich in 1691.
G. W. Braikenridge noted in 1821 that the house possessed a small garden behind, implying that part of the had been taken into a different ownership by that date. Braikenridge also reported that the building belonged to Messrs. Henry Ricketts & Co. at the Glass House, and was due to be removed.

KNOWN_AS: New Dock Gates Inn, No.151 Hotwell Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
The New Dock Gates Inn, No.151 Hotwell Road, located on the southern side of Hotwell Road, on the east side of its junction with Dock Gate Lane. The building appears to be recorded by de Wilstar's map of Clifton of 1746 and Dock Gate Lane was also established by that date. By 1869 the building was a public house, the New Dock Gates Tavern, run by Mary Ann Wyatt. By 1874 street directories indicate that the ownership had changed and it was then run by Robert Jones. Mary Jones, presumably the wife of Robert Jones, had taken over as licensee by 1879 and she appears to have changed the name of the public house to the New Dock Gates Inn by 1884. Use of the building as a public house continued well into the twentieth century.
The building is a house of two storeys and attic with a pitched pantile roof. The building is constructed of Brandon Hill Grit in a random rubble construction bonded in a white lime mortar and is currently rendered with a sand-cement render. The original plan of the building is not clear but it may have been of two rooms at each floor off a central hall. The main, north-facing, elevation is of three bays with a central entrance at ground floor and single large sash windows on either side. The cellar has chimneybreasts at the eastern and western ends, with steps leading down, presumably from a cellar opening on to Dock Gate Lane, at the south-west corner. An extension had been added to the rear of the building by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.7) surveyed in 1883. Evidence within the building (BUAD 3851) also suggests that the main elevation was reconstructed in brick at first floor level during the nineteenth century and that the gables at either end of the building were also replaced. The pitch of the roof was probably also increased at this time.
By the late twentieth century the building was in use as an office and the interior walls were removed at ground floor to create an open plan office, probably in the 1980s. The floors are supported on inserted RSJs throughout the building. No original eighteenth-century features or fittings now appear to remain inside the building.

Anti-aircraft battery, Purdown. The site was a heavy anti-aircraft battery located on the crest of the south-west to north-east ridge of Purdown. The site was first occupied on November 11th 1939 by mobile anti-aircraft guns for the anti-aircraft defence of Bristol. In June 1940, it was converted into a permanent four-gun position with two more positions being added later in the war. During the Second World War Bristol was defended by about twenty anti-aircraft batteries. Purdown was one of eight which were fixed.
The battery consisted originally of four octagonal gun positions on the south-western side of the battery, each with three ammunition bays. At the centre of the position was a complex containing the command post and associated buildings, while the two magazines were sited on the north-west side of the site. Dobinson indicates that the battery armament of four 3.7in static guns remained the same between the summer of 1941 and January 1943 and that the battery did not have radar (Dobinson 1996, 330). Two additional square gun positions built of reinforced concrete blocks were added later (Roberts 1981). Early in the war the battery was also equipped with Lewis gun emplacements. An attack on the 2 December 1940 resulted in a high explosive bomb wounding of the crew of one of these emplacements, one member later dying of wounds (Penny 1997, 15-16). Immediately to the south-west of the battery was Purdown Camp (SMR 21027), ancillary buildings probably including sleeping quarters, canteen, sickbay etc.
The battery is a Scheduled Ancient Monument (SAM No. AV 184). There are photographs of the monument in the SMR collection of Ground-based Photographs, numbers 1604-1609 inclusive.

Limekiln at Southmead Quarry. The kiln is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.08) published in 1881 and lay at the southern end of the quarry close to Southmead Road. The kiln survived into the twentieth century and was still extant during the First World War. However, it had apparently been demolished by the mid-1930s. The southern part of the quarry was subsequently infilled redeveloped for housing. The site of the limekiln is now beneath the rear gardens of Nos.164-166 Southmead Road.

Speedwell Colliery. The colliery was in existence by the time of the St. George tithe survey of 1842 (BRO EP/A/32/32) when it was recorded as Starveall Coal Works. The colliery was acquired by Cossham and Wethered Ltd. In 1863 and was run by the Kingswood Coal and Iron Company Ltd. from 1867. It was reported by Warne that the shaft cut Doxall Seam, Upper Toad Seam, Hole Seam, Lower Five Coals Seam, Thurfer Seam, Great Vein Seam, Gillers Inn Seam and Lower Toad Seam. In the late 1920s another seam, the Two Foot Seam, was proved. Of these only Lower Five Coals Seam, the Great Vein Seam, Gllers Inn Seam and the Two Coals Seam were worked. According to Warne, the tip was "allowed to burn and the material turns a nice red colour and is removed for making paths etc." (Warne 1935-39, 308).
The colliery closed c1936 (Warne 1935-39, 306) and the site was subsequently redeveloped.

Druid Stoke burial chamber, on the south side of the garden of No.59 Druid Hill, Stoke Bishop. The monument is a neolithic long barrow (Tratman 1946, 165), probably with transeptal terminal chambers (Darvill & Grinsell 1989, 64), and now consists of a number of stones lying at the edge of the drive to the south of the house set in a small gravel garden. One large (cap?) stone leans against a stone set in the ground and on the north side there is another lying nearly flat. No evidence of any surrounding mound or cairn now survives above ground.
The monument was identified by Rev. John Skinner at the end of 1811, who noted "the Capstone of a demolished Cromlech", and made further visits to the site - one in 1818-1819 and another possibly in 1826 (British Library Add. Mss 33643, fo.79r & v fo.80 (sketch); Grinsell 1979, 119). The monument was also described by Seyer (1821, 103). The area around the stones was excavated in 1913 by Francis Were and Lewis Way of the Bristol and Gloucestershire Archaeological Society, though little information was recovered (Were 1913; SMR 20945).
Grinsell reviewed the evidence for the monument in 1979 (Grinsell 1979). It was subject to geophysical survey (SMR 20445) by the Ancient Monuments Laboratory (Clark in Smith 1989, 37) in December 1982 in advance of work to the surrounding garden, and this survey was followed by an archaeological evaluation (SMR 20444) by the Central Excavation Unit of English Heritage in the same year (Smith 1989). The 1983 evaluation, however, found a spread of limestone rubble around the stones which was thought to be the remains of the original mound. A human to bone was also found to the south of the stones and this produced a calibrated radiocarbon date of 2889 to 2460 BC at a 95% confidence. Analysis of a buried soil beneath the rubble produced molluscan evidence to suggest that the monument had been constructed in a woodland environment. It appears from finds evidence at one side of the monument that the mound which had surrounded the stones was likely to have been removed by Roman-British and later ploughing. However, Darvill and Grinsell (1989, 64) note that an "extensive" mound surrounded the monument until c1907 when it was reduced in height.
The burial chamber is a Scheduled Ancient Monument (SAM AV 28)

Westbury College, Westbury-on-Trym. A minster is thought to have stood on the site by the early eighth century. In c963AD a Benedictine monastery was established at the site by Oswald (Bishop of Worcester, 961-992). He appointed a monk named Germanus from the abbey of Fleury at Saint-Benoît-sur-Loire (where Oswald had spent a period earlier in his career) as prior and Westbury became a focus of a Benedictine revival in the region (Graham 1907, 107). In 968-970 the monastery was suppressed and the monks transferred to the Ramsey abbey in northern Cambridgeshire. The monastery was refounded by Bishop Wulfstan (1062-1096) as a cell of Worcester in about 1086. In 1093 it was endowed with lands in Westbury itself, Henbury, Charlton and elsewhere in Gloucesterhshire. The monastery was again suppressed, this time by Bishop Samson (1096-1113) and a college of secular canons was established. In 1286 this was enlarged from five to fourteen canonries by Bishop Giffard (1286-1301) in an attempt to have the churches within his patronage made prebendal to Westbury (Hoskin 2003, 439). Westbury College was reconstituted by Bishop Carpenter (1443-1476) with a grammar school and almshouse. The grammar school was founded in 1463 and the master was funded through the revenues of the Clifton parish church, St. Andrew. The first master was Roger Fabell and along with all of the subsequent masters he held the post together with another benefice. Carpenter also funded exhibitions for six scholars at Oriel College, Oxford and the dean of had the right to nominate at least one exhibitioner (Orme 1976, 182-184). Edward IV granted a number of manors and other privileges to Westbury in the 1460s (Graham 1907, 108). In 1535 the college comprised the Dean, the Sub-Dean, five prebendaries, Bishop Carpenter's chaplain, eight fellows, four clerks, six aged priests, twelve choristers and a schoolmaster (Graham 1907, 108).
The College was surrendered to the Crown in February 1544, the surrender document being signed by the Dean, John Barlo[w], the Sub-Dean John Lawrence and John Kerell and Thomas Barlo[w], prebendaries (Gairdner & Brodie 1903, 65). This also resulted in the loss of the grammar school. The College site and its property holdings were purchased by Sir Ralph Sadleir in March 1544 (Gairdner & Brodie 1903, 175-176).
During the Royalist attack on Bristol in July 1643 Prince Rupert was quartered at the College (Firth 1925, 183) and it was apparently one of the buildings fired by Royalist troops as the New Model Army arrived to attack Bristol in 1645. The College building was drawn by James Stewart in September 1747.
Archaeological excavation in 1968 directed by M. W. Ponsford of Bristol City Museum, revealed a boundary wall and stone jetty adjoining the River Trym, interpreted as a possible part of the college of 1194. Also recorded were buildings dating from the thirteenth- to the fifteenth-centuries with an L-shaped moat around the site. The oldest surviving elements of the Westbury College building include a four-storey gate tower and corner turrets, a spiral stair leading to the bell chamber.
The building has a Grade I listing (Listed Building Number 901-1/26/2056).

Pound located on the south side of Clifton Green. The pound was in existence by the mid-1740s and was recorded by the 1746 survey of the Manor of Clifton by de Wilstar. It was as a rectangular structure standing against the boundary wall to the land parcel on the south side of the  Lower Clifton Hill and measured approximately 8 metres from east to west and 7.3 metres north-south. The pound was still extant in 1828 but had been removed by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXI.16.22) surveyed in 1883.

KNOWN_AS: Garden of Clifton Wood House, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC:
Garden of Clifton Wood House. The 1746 plan of the manor of Clifton by de Wilstar records a geometrically laid out walled garden located immediately to the south of Clifton Wood House (SMR 21446). The garden measured 40 metres square and was laid out with parterres to form eight paths radiating from a central circular space. The entrance to the garden from Clifton Wood House was at the north-western corner of the garden via a, now blocked, arched gateway in the wall. A stone tunnel led from the west side of the house to the garden, probably for use by the servants.
The garden had apparently been separated from Clifton Wood House by 1828, Ashmead's plan of Bristol indicating that the plot had been developed for a new house and garden. This was subsequently demolished when Randall Road and its associated housing to the south were constructed in the 1880s.
Parts of the boundary walls to the garden possibly survive in the boundaries to several properties, including the south boundary wall to the present Clifton House driveway ( (ST 5754972698), the south boundary to the Randall Road properties along Clifton Lane, the east boundary wall to No.1 Randall Road and the west boundary wall to No.6 Randall Road (ST 57575 72695 to ST 5753872674).

KNOWN_AS: Infant School at Chapel Lane, Lawrence Weston
MONUMENT_DESC: Infant school located on the south-eastern side of the junction of Chapel Lane and Lawrence Weston Road. A building occupied the site at the time of the Henbury tithe survey of 1841 (BRO EP/A/32/22) and the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.03) published in 1881 records the infant school. The building was recorded as a Sunday School at the beginning of the twentieth century and was still extant during the First World War. The building was subsequently demolished and its site now lies in the verge in front of No.49 Chapel Lane and No.78 Lawrence Weston Road.

KNOWN_AS: The Mansion House, Royal Fort Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Mansion House, located on the northern side of Fort Lane [modern Royal Fort Road]. The house stood some 4.5 metres back from the road with a small, walled front garden and was accessed from a gateway on the lane flanked by two large gateposts with finials.
The building was a two-storey, five-bay house dating to the first half of the eighteenth century. It was extant by 1747 (BUAD 2766; Leech 2000, 46) and, given the location of the house within the plot for Elbridge's Charity School (BUAD 933M), is likely to have been built as the dwelling for the master of the school under the will of John Elbridge. The house was aligned from north-east to south-west, parallel with Fort Lane, and the main frontage measured 35 feet (10.7 metres) long and the building was 25 feet (7.6 metres) deep. The fenestration of the main elevation comprised sash windows set within openings with ashlar dressings which had segmental-arched pediments above. The central ground-floor bay contained the main doorway which was set in a segmental-arched opening which also had ashlar dressings. The upper part of the side, south-west facing, elevation appears to have been blank. The pitched roof was tiled and had tall chimney stacks at either end. The building also seems to have had a single-storey rear extension.
The building survived until c.1905 when it was removed to make way for the construction of new wards for the Bristol Children's Hospital. The site of the house now lies almost entirely beneath the Faculty Building.

Oldbury House, located on the west side of St. Michael's Hill. The building a late seventeenth-century  gabled house of three-storeys and attic and is of rendered stone rubble. The main, north-east facing, elevation is of six bays. The main entrance doorway is a the centre of the elevation and is surrounded by a rusticated ashlar moulding with an open-base pediment above. There is a pair of sash windows at either end of the elevation and six sashes at first floor. The three sashes at second floor are beneath the gables but those at the northern and southern ends of the elevation are not set exactly between the sashes below. The three gable ends are blind. The building is one room deep in plan and has a projecting stair at the rear. There is a chimney stack at the north and the south end of the roof.
The house was built between 1679 and 1689, apparently for Marmaduke Bowdler and was purchased from him in 1692 by Lady Phillipa Gore and occupied by her and Joseph Knight Esq., according to the ratebooks, until 1706. The building was occupied by Richard Haynes Esq. from 1709 and by Edward Bisdy (or Bisdee) and his widow from 1722 until the mid-1760s. From 1765 until 1773 Charles Horwood lived there (Leech, 2000 48-49).
The house is now in the ownership of the University of Bristol. It has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-/4/275).

KNOWN_AS: The Three Kings Inn, No.28 St. Thomas Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Three Kings Inn, located on the east side of St. Thomas Street. The date of construction of the inn is unclear. John Pritchard believed that it had been constructed in the fifteenth century and it was licensed in 1606. The main part of the inn was arranged along the south side of a large yard, known as Three Kings Yard, with the primary building standing on the St. Thomas Street frontage, and overailing the entrance to the yard of St. Thomas Street. This building was of two storeys and attic and was timber-framed. The ground floor of the main, west-facing, elevation was occupied by a shopfront. The interior had been much altered in the later nineteenth century, removing a good deal of its character. The inn was the headquarters of many country carriers serving towns such as Devizes, Warminster, Salisbury, Southampton and Portsmouth.
The building was in use as a public house in the 1880s and in 1882 was run by Malcolm Knee. It was acquired in 1903 by the Midland Railway Company with the intention of constructing a modern hotel, but the scheme was abandoned and the building remained empty for several years. It was demolished in December 1911 and John Pritchard observed the demolition (BUAD 679), noting that much of the original timberwork was exposed (Pritchard 1904, 337).

No. 6, Small Street. The building was of seventeenth century date. The first floor prinicipal room contained a finely-carved stone chimney-piece in a position corresponding to the principal room on the first-floor. This had a frieze "bearing Tudor roses within diamonds and circles alternating, surrounded by typical strap-work of the period; below which, upon small plain shields within the spandrels of the moulding over the opening, the initials "I. B." were found after the thick coats of colouring had been cleaned off" (Pritchard, 1908 297). A portion of another fireplace, and several fragments of "beautifully moulded" plaster work were found during demolition of the building.
The street elevation was rendered, with a short return wall to the front of the adjacent Post Office. Short plinth to front and side walls. Possible small window in side wall at ground-floor. The ground-floor had an entrance doorway on the left, with an arched vehicle entrance with double doors at the opposite end. In between were two sash windows under arches with visible voussoirs. Beneath the two windows were similarly arched openings to the basement. String course above ground-floor. Lesenes at edge of first and second floors, with cornice. Two sashes at first-floor above those on the ground-floor, with a larger window above the vehicle entrance. At second-floor, two pairs of sashes, again under arched voussoirs. The building removed in 1908 for the extension to the Post Office.

KNOWN_AS: Circular earthwork feature at Luckington Road, Southmead
MONUMENT_DESC: Circular earthwork feature located on the north-east side of Luckington Road, Southmead. The feature was recorded in a vertical air photograph taken by the Royal Air Force on 23 March 1946 (RAF/106G/UK/1288 Frame 5262) and was enclosed by an earth bank approximately 16 metres in diameter with a circular central depression with contiguous rectangular features surrounding it. The function of the feature is unknown but it appears likely to be a defensive feature dating to the Second World War. The feature had been destroyed by the end of March 1955 (RAF/540/1576 frames 94 and 170).

KNOWN_AS: Bronze Age occupation at Katherine Farm
MONUMENT_DESC: A Buried land surface recorded during evaluation and subsequent excavation at Katherine Farm, Avonmouth (21420 and 21421). The deposit was identified with an upper surface height of 5.07 - 5.28m aOD and a maximum thickness of 0.12m. Two radiocarbon dates were obtained from this layer; the first from a charcoal sample produced a date of 2778 +/- 55 BP (NZA-12725, 1070-810 cal BC) and a second from a cow tooth with a date of 2957 +/- 55 BP (NZA-12726, 1380-1010 cal BC) suggesting a Bronze Age date of deposition. Artefacts from the layer included 56 pottery fragments, imported stone fragments (mainly sandstone), five worked flints and animal bone. It was suggested that this evidence represented seasonal activity on the saltmarsh possibly hunting, grazing or salt-making, although conclusive interpretation was not possible from the available evidence.

A Buried land surface recorded during evaluation at the Somerset, Avon and Gloucestershire Fire Training Centre, Smoke Lane, Avonmouth (20955). The deposit was identified with an upper surface height of approximately 4.5m aOD and a maximum thickness of 0.05m. Organic material from the deposit was radiocarbon dated to a calibrated date range between 2580 BC and 2190 BC, with a 65.8% probability of dating between 2470 BC and 2280 BC. No artefactual remains were recovered from this deposit.

Gloucester House on the west side of Alfred Hill, built directly on the street frontage in the late eighteenth or early nineteenth century. This was a two storey rendered building with a single pitched roof and rectangular bay at the south end of west front. Assymetrical front façade with door slightly north of centre. When the property was surveyed in 2005 most of the internal fixtures and fittings were modern replacements with the exception of the single curving stairs that had original square spindles and a handrail that terminated with a scroll on the ground floor. The building was demolished for new hospital buildings in 2006.

KNOWN_AS: Scare Post, Mina Road, St Werburgh's
MONUMENT_DESC: Cast iron scare post on the east side of Mina Road set against the west wall of the Miners Arms Public House. The post is 'T' shaped, approximately 300mm high with the words 'Flood Level OCTR 1882' embossed across the top section. This is one of four surviving scare posts that record the floods in St Werburgh's in 1882.

KNOWN_AS: Roman Catholic Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul
MONUMENT_DESC:
Roman Catholic Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul, located on the western side of Pembroke Road, Clifton. The cathedral was commissioned in 1965 to replace the Pro-Cathedral in Park Place. The building was constructed between 1969 and 1973 to a design by Ronald Weeks, Frederick S. Jennett and Antoni Poremba of Percy Thomas Partnership by John Laing Construction Ltd. It was intended to accommodate 900 worshippers and adopted an elongated hexagonal plan with a series of lead-covered pitched roofs. It is constructed of pre-cast concrete panels and in-situ concrete with an imprinted finish from the timber shuttering. There are entrances at first-floor level off Pembroke Road (St. Peter's Door) and Clifton Park (St. Paul's Door and the West Door to its south). The entrance doors open on to an ambulatory space around the north, west and south sides of the building with the sanctuary and high altar located on the east side. The altar is of Portland stone with the lectern, designed by the architects and made by William Mitchell, on its north side. To the south of the sanctuary is the choir and the organ, by the Austrian company Rieger Orgelbau. The narthex on the north side of the building, adjacent to St. Peter's Door, is lit by two stained glass windows designed by Henry Haig, that on the north-west side being titled "Pentecost" and that on the north, "Jubilation". On its south-west side is the Blessed Sacrament Chapel while on the east is the Baptistery with a font by Simon Verity carved from Purbeck marble and supported on a base of Portland stone decorated with carved interlocking doves. The inscription "ONCE YOU WERE NO PEOPLE BUT NOW YOU ARE GOD'S PEOPLE" (First letter of St. Peter 2:10) runs around the rim of the font. On the north-west side of the West Door is the Lady Chapel. Relief panels in concrete designed and made by William Mitchell, depicting the Stations of the Cross are set in the wall of the ambulatory and run in an anti-clockwise direction from the south-east side. Two brass plaques setting out the history of the Mission to Bristol and the South-West which were brought from the Pro-Cathedral in Park Place are fixed to the west wall of the ambulatory. Beneath the building is a room for public use, the Apostle Room.
Some 16 metres to the south of the cathedral (at ST 57294 73547) is the presbtery, Cathedral House, a three-storey building with a plinth of concrete blocks and the upper storeys of roughcast concrete. There is an external stair tower at the centre of its south side.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/2/10054).

Roman Catholic Pro-Cathedral, located on the south-west side of Park Place. In 1830 Father Francis Edgeworth aquired land to build a large church. A substantial building in a Greek Revival style was designed by Henry E. Goodridge around 1834 (Crick 1975, 5) but the foundations partly subsided during construction and work was ceased in 1845. Edgeworth was bankrupted by the project and moved to Belgium in 1845. Bishop Ullathorne became Vicar Apostolic in 1846 and set out to finish the main church. He employed Charles Francis Hansom as architect who designed a lightweight timber structure to rest on the completed basement of Goodridge's building. The church, the Church of the Apostles, was opened in September 1848 by Bishop Hendren. The building became a pro-cathedral in 1850, taking on the function of a cathedral until a cathedral could be built.
Part of the site, including the small chapel, was sold to the order of St. Catherine of Siena to establish a community there. A school also operated in the buildings on the south-western side of the pro-cathedral (BRO Building Plan Books Vol.35 fo.18).
In the first half of the 1870s Hansom produced a scheme for the completion of the building (Crick, 1975 31). The west front was reconstructed in Penant sandstone.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed building number 901-1/9/905).

KNOWN_AS: Pound on the east side of Gloucester Road
MONUMENT_DESC: Pound located on the eastern side of Gloucester Road, Horfield.
