The pound was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.05) published in 1881 and was sited some 55 metres to the east of the road. It appears to have had an entrance on its south-west side and measured 12.4 metres along its north-west to south-east side and was 8.2 metres wide. The pound had been removed by the beginning of the twentieth century. Its site now lies beneath the houses and front gardens of Nos.13 and 15 Muller Road.

KNOWN_AS: Air raid shelter at Clifton College
MONUMENT_DESC:
Air raid shelter at Clifton College. The shelter was located on the southern side of Guthrie Road, between the road and School House and was a surface shelter, measuring 8 metres from south-west to north-east by 5 metres wide. The shelter was constructed of brick in alternate header and stretcher courses and had a flat concrete roof. The entrance was at the north-east corner, adjacent to Guthrie Road.
The shelter was built when Clifton College was taken over by the US Army during the Second World War 
After the Second World War the shelter was used by the College as a garage and an opening for a garage door was made in the west wall. The shelter was demolished in the early years of the twentieth century but was subject to archaeological recording in advance of demolition (SMR 21988; Heaton & Mordue 2004).

KNOWN_AS: Late Bronze Age circular timber structure at Barrow Hill Crescent, Shirehampton
MONUMENT_DESC:
Possible Late Bronze Age circular timber structure at Barrow Hill Crescent. The monument was identified during an archaeological evaluation in 1993 (SMR 20029). Four postholes cut into the underlying red sandy clay subsoil, each 0.33 metres in diameter and 0.25 metres deep, were excavated on the south-west quadrant of the circle. The timber circle  was approximately 7 metres in diameter. No stratification associated with contemporary human activity within or outside the monument was recorded and the postholes were sealed by a brown loamy clay containing ceramics of thirteenth- to fourteenth-century date. However, the fill of the postholes produced worked flint flakes and one lump of a material described by the excavator as a possible metallic ore.
The function of the monument was not established but the excavator suggested that it might be interpreted as a simple roundhouse.

No.25 St. Michael's Hill. The building is an early seventeenth-century jettied, gabled house of two storeys and attic. The ground floor has a single central sash window with the main entrance door on the southern side of the elevation. The first floor is jettied and at the centre of the elevation there is a projecting bay containing a sash. There is also a projecting bay in the centre of the attic gable.
It is not clear when the building was constructed but it was probably one of a pair with No.23 (BUAD 1413M). Nos.27-29 St. Michael's Hill (BUAD 1415M & 1416M) were built c.1637 and this house is probably roughly contemporary. The building was occupied by Henry Boucher in 1695 and by a sequence of other individuals through the eighteenth century (Leech 2000, 74-75).

Garden of Bishop's Knoll House, Stoke Bishop. It is a steep site, terraced and landscaped with retaining walls. There are ruinous garden buildings and pergolas.
The land lay within the Sneed Park deer park owned by the Bishops of Worcester. It was granted to Ralph Sadleir at the Reformation and passed into the hands of the Jackson family c.1650. The land was held together by terms of will until 1853 when an act of Parliament (the Martin's Estate Act) set aside the terms of the will. The house known as Bishop's Knoll (SMR 9891) was built in 1874. In the grounds of the villa were gardens and both fruit and vegetable gardens, greenhouses, orchards and a dairy.
In the Lower area surviving elements of the gardens, including the iron gateway and lower boundary wall, the walls of the lower, second, third and upper terraces and of the orchard, a "very fine" wrought iron pergola, a small "gothic" possibly a summerhouse. Also extant are an "L-shaped" range of buildings, assumed to be a stables, and the remains of the gardener's house.
In the middle area surviving parts of the garden layout were identified, while in the northern area there are signs of a small gatehouse.
Many different conifers were planted and several are protected by Tree Preservation Orders. The arboretum is in the care of Woodland Trust.

Council House, located on the north-west side of College Green. The building was constructed between 1935 and 1952 to a design in a Neo-Georgian style by the architect Vincent Harris and forms a crescent along the edge of the north-west side of the green. The building has a concrete frame and is of two storeys. It is clad with very wide, thin bricks. It has Portland stone dressings, including full-height porte cocheres at the middle, north-eastern and south-western ends of the building. There is also a large entrance porch at the rear entrance. The building has a leaded hipped roof with a gold unicorn at each end.
Internally the rooms are arranged off a corridor which runs the length of the building. The original fittings survive. There is an horological clock in entrance hall. The Council Room has painted ceilings by John Armstrong on the theme of Bristol and its history. Outside the building, in front of the main entrance, there is a scultpure of a medieval Bristol mariner by Sir Charles Thomas Wheeler R.A. On the parapet of the flanking towers there are sculptures by Jacob Epstein.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/72).

L Shed, Princes Wharf. At the end of the Second World War the Port of Bristol Authority decided to develop a general cargo handling facility at Prince's Wharf. This was completed in 1951 and L Shed was constructed as part of the scheme. The building is a two-storey transit shed with a steel frame attached to M Shed (BUAD 1579M). It was used as a general cargo shed until the dock use ended in the 1970s. In 1980 the ground floor was converted into the National Life Boat Museum while the upper floor became storage for the Bristol Industrial Museum. The National Life Boat Museum closed in 1988 and the remainder of the building became part of the Bristol Industrial Museum.

Nos.302-304 Hotwell Road, located in the northern side of Hotwell Road. The house was built as  a single lodging house for visitors to the Hotwell spa in c.1710. Both houses were known as Freeland Court in the early eighteenth century. It was of five-bay property with a single-depth plan. In the courtyard ot the rear there was a well.
By the latter part of the eighteenth century Nos.302-304 was known as The Stable Coach House with land stretching up Granby Hill, and had various out buildings including the tack room and store that now forms the ground floor of No.3 Granby Hill.
In about 1810-1811 the property was divided vertically to create two properties, No.302 retaining the original staircase, and No.304 the original main entrance doorway. A matching entrance and hallway for No.302 was created alongside. A floor was added at the same time, totally in the ownership of No.304, which oversails No.302 at the front. A wall beam preserved in the second floor landing of No.304 marks the position of the original wall before the property was divided. The well in the rear yard was the public water supply for the area until it was capped during the mid-nineteenth century following major cholera outbreaks.

No.18, Welsh Back, located on the north side of the junction of Crow Lane and Welsh Back. A building probably stood on the site by the end of the fourteenth century and in 1548 the tenement was owned by Spicer's Chantry and was occupied by Richard Cary. By 1572 the building was "now or late" of William Pytte, merchant (Leech, 1997 168). The front part of the building at least appears to have been substantially rebuilt in the seventeenth century. Watercolour paintings from the mid-1820s in the Braikenridge Collection of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery indicate that the building was a two-bay building of three storeys plus attic. The pantile roof was cross-gabled. The main, east-facing, elevation fronted on to Welsh Back. At ground floor this comprised a shopfront with a central doorway with large windows on either side. The first-floor was divided from the second by a projecting cornice, or possibly a narrow pentice. The board beneath the cornice carried a painted advertisement for "COWLEY & SON" (BRSMG M2238). The fenestration at first-floor comprised two pairs of three-by-four pane windows, apparently sashes. Another projecting cornice ran across the top of these windows and the second floor fenestration above was formed by two three-by-four pane sashes. There was a two-light casement at the centre of the gable. The south-facing elevation on Crow Lane was blank at ground-floor. At first-floor level there were three windows of different sizes, that on the east mullioned. There were four windows at second floor Beneath the eaves in the western half of the elevation there was a small cross-window at the west end, a larger window, possibly a sash and another small casement. Beneath the centre of the cross-gable was another, slightly larger window. There was also a small attic window in the gable end. Tall chimney stacks projected from the roof at the west end of the south wall of the building, from the base of the valley on the east side of the cross-gable and from the east end of the elevation. The Welsh Back elevation of the building appears to have been reconstructed in brick later in the nineteenth century. brick facade to Welsh Back. By the time of the Goad Fire Insurance plan of January 1887 the building was in use as a Hop and Malt warehouse.
The building was still extant in 1930 when it was photographed by P. E. W. Street but seems to have been demolished in the 1950s or 1960s.

KNOWN_AS: The Rose Alehouse, No.29, St. Michael's Hill
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Rose Alehouse, No.29 St. Michael's Hill. The building is an early seventeenth-century jettied, gabled house of two storeys and attic. It was originally one room deep and was constructed as part of a pair with No.27, St. Michael's Hill (BUAD 1415M) c.1637. The ground floor has a single central sash window with the main entrance door on the southern side of the elevation. The first floor is jettied and at the centre of the elevation there is a projecting bay containing a sash. There is also a projecting bay in the centre of the attic gable.
The house was demised to Philip Bowcher the younger by his cousin Humphrey Andrewes in 1637. During the 1660s it was occupied by Richard Cox and from 1695 until the beginning of the eighteenth century Nathaniel Milner occupied the property. The building was known as The Rose Alehouse in 1701 when it was leased to Solomon Edwards, sadler, by Edward Saunders of Axbridge. The house was occupied by Widow Tylee between 1703 and 1707 and by a sequence of other individuals through the eighteenth century (Leech 2000, 74-75).

No.145, Temple Street, alias the 'Rose' or 'Stone Kitchen'. Attached. 2 storeys and attic; gabled front; jettied. Central entrance. Cellar access below left-hand window. 2 sashes to first-floor, smaller sash to second; gable jettied immediately above attic window.
It had become the Rose alehouse by 1788-90 and Ann Sloper was the licensee at that date. The 'Rose', a noted alehouse kept by John Sloper and frequently known by the name of the 'Stone Kitchen', "in which the great Ale Drinkers of the City spend most of their evenings" (Braikenridge Notes).

A 'summerhouse' in the northwest corner of the garden of no.15 Marlborough Hill. A square, three-storey structure with a single room on each floor. The remains of the building were identified by Roger Leech in 1998 (4461) at which time three walls of the building survived. The partial remains of the south elevation was constructed of coursed white lias at ground floor level, the upper floors were constructed of Flemish bonded brickwork. The building was apparently constructed in the later eighteenth century and by 1828 had been extended to the east. All structures on the site were demolished in c.1975.

A large house on the north side of Upper Maudlin Street at the junction with Alfred Hill depicted on Plumley and Ashmead's 1828 plan of Bristol. It is possible that this structure is the same as that shown on Millerd's 1715 map of Bristol that depicts a large two storey building with end stacks within a large walled garden. The 1828 plan indicates that the frontage of the building consisted of three bow bays. The house is likely to have originated as a single dwelling, but by 1828 the building had been subdivided in two properties. The building was demolished for the construction of the King Edward VII Memorial Infirmary in the early 20th century.

KNOWN_AS: General offices at National Filling Factory No.23, Chittening
MONUMENT_DESC:
General offices at National Filling Factory No.23, Chittening., located at the eastern end of Smoke Lane. The building was constructed in 1918 and is recorded by a plan in the National Archives (MUN 4/1753) dated 27 November 1918. The building measured approximately 70 metres from north to south, was 10 metres wide and had small projecting wings at its north and south ends.
The building was extant in 1946 but was subsequently demolished.

KNOWN_AS: G. B. Britton and Sons Boot and Shoe Factory, Lodge Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
G. B. Britton and Sons boot and shoe factory located on the west side of Lodge Road. The factory was constructed at the end of the nineteenth century. The footprint of the original building measured 32 metres east-west by 66 metres north-south and is took the form of a six-bay, two-storey brick structure with the first floor and the timber trusses of the northlight roof supported by cast iron columns. The the detailing of the main, east-facing, elevation on Lodge Road comprises a two-storey arcade of segmental-headed arches supported by narrow pilasters, the pilasters and arches in red brick and the main plane and the cornice in black brick. The main entrance is at the centre of this elevation. The plans submitted to the Sanitary Athority in 1899 (BRO Building Plan Book 37 fo.10) suggest that the rear wall was blind. 
The works was expanded by the addition of a box store to the north end of the main building in 1900, other extensions in 1906 and 1907 and installation of a single-storey "Suction Gas Plant" in 1910 (BRO Building Plan Book 53 fo.4). A further extension was added to the west in 1913 and an office was constructed on the south part in 1915 (BRO Building Plan Book 63 fo.24). The architectural style of the Lodge Road elevations of these extension was matched to that of the original building, although the office element at the southern end of the building has a hipped pantile roof.
There were no further alterations until 1961 when a two-storey brick extension and ancillary structures were added to the west of the site. This work may have included alterations to the interior of the 1899 building.
The factory is extant, including the roof trusses and cast iron columns of the original building. It is not clear, however, what evidence for the production process survives internally. Inference from the date of construction of the factory suggests that the organisation of work, and hence the form of the building, may have been influenced by the concept of the production line but there is at present (26/04/2001) no evidence to support this. Similarly, the potential for archaeological evidence for process within the large extension constructed in the 1960s is unknown.

KNOWN_AS: Parish boundary marker stone at No.54 St. Matthew's Road
MONUMENT_DESC: A parish boundary marker stone set in the footway in front of the boundary wall of No.54 St. Matthew's Road, Cotham. The stone is of Pennant sandstone and stands to a height of approximately 50 centimetres. The stone was observed in May 2001 when no inscription could be seen on the surface of the stone and its surface was noted to be suffering from delamination.

KNOWN_AS: Scare Post, James Street (South side), St Werburgh's
MONUMENT_DESC: Cast iron scare post on the south side of James Street set against the north boundary wall of the former Cutler's Brook School. The post is 'T' shaped, approximately 300mm high with the words 'Flood Level OCTR 1882' embossed across the top section. The lettering and embossed detailing are currently (March 2010) painted white. This is one of four surviving scare posts that record the floods in St Werburgh's in 1882.

KNOWN_AS: All Saints Church, Pembroke Road, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC:
All Saints Church, located on the eastern side of Pembroke Road. The church was built between 1868 (being consecrated in 1868) and 1872 to a design by G. E. Street. It was constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble and cost around £40000 which was mainly collected through subscription. The Ordnance Survey 1:500 plan surveyed in 1881 indicates that the church had seating for 1200 people.
A narthex, designed by G. F. Bodley, was added in 1909 and a sacristy, by F. C. Eden, was built in 1928. The building was gutted by incendiary bombs on 2 December 1940, although the tower survived. The body of the church was rebuilt between 1963 and 1967 to a design initially by W. H. Randoll Blacking and then by Robert Potter.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/2/923).

Clifton Library on the sout side of Princess Victoria Street, Clifton. A two storey building with basement with a limestone ashlar façade.
Designed by Charles Underwood and built in 1852 as a school with a 'U'-shaped double-depth plan. The Listing description states that it was rebuilt in 1877 by Charles Hansom with further additions in 1891 by W T Bernard.
The building continued in use as a school until becoming a library in the 1960s.
The building is Listed Grade II (901-1/8/938).

Beaufort House on the east side of Terrell Street. Originally a pair of six-storey semi detached properties Beaufort House (east side) and Camden House constructed between 1800 and 1823. At some date between 1898 and 1924 the houses were knocked-through to form a single unit for nurses accomodation.

Both sides of the building were extended after construction. An extension was constructed on the south-west side of Camden House to the design of William Venn Gough in 1889 which was further extended (also designed by W.V. Gough) in 1898. A further extension was constructed in 1923 linking Beaufort House/Camden House and Gough's extensions to the houses in Bedford Row for further nurses accomodation.

A plan of property belonging to the Feoffees of Broadmead Baptist Meeting House (BRO 41045/J/PL/1) indicates that the original entrances in the west and east sides of each house appear to have been approached by steps from Bedford Place (since developed for hospital use). Other nineteenth century plans indicate a similar arrangement with extensive gardens for both properties.

When the building was recorded in 2010 the some of main significant surviving features were identified as being masonry wine-racking in the original cellars, winding cantilever staircases leading from the original ground floor to third floor, external metal window-guard and decorative rainwater-fittings.

Beaufort House is Listed Grade II, although consent for demolition was granted in 2005. The structure was recorded in 2010 (BHER 24870).

A conduit house within the cloister at Bristol Cathedral. This structure was first recorded in 1634 when three soldiers from Norwich wrote 'In the Clysters is a fayre Conduit of Freestone, and leads with many spouts, which continually runs, and waters all the Colledge with that sweet Rockwater' (Blockley 2010, 5).
The earliest cartograhic depiction of a structure on this site is on Rocque's plan of Bristol of 1742 that indicates a square building in the center of the cloister. Plumley and Ashmead's plan of Bristol (1828) indicates a similar structure that appears to measure approximately 9m square.
In the Chapter Minutes for 24 December 1853 it was agreed to remove the 'Reservoir and the water House in the Cloister,' (Blockley 2010, 5).
Part of the foundations of this building were recorded during an archaeological watching brief in 2010 (BHER 24898) where it was noted that the building was constructed of Brandon Hill stone bonded in pale red, clayey lime mortar with eighteenth and nineteenth century alterations, although no dating evidence was recovered the chronology being based on mortar types.

The Farriers Arms Public House on the east corner of Fishponds Road and Hockey's Lane, Fishponds.
The building is a two storey rendered, rubble stone structure with a pitched pan tiled roof with end and central brick stacks. The ground floor is likely to have been considerably altered, but the three front first floor sash windows are likely to be original.
The first cartograhic depiction of the building is on the Stapleton Tithe Map of 1839. The accompanying apportionment records that it was then a house, smith's shop and garden owned and occupied by William Daws.
The building was apparently first licenced for the sale of alcohol in the 1860s (John Penny, pers comm) and is stil in use as a public house (December, 2010).

A pair of houses, with ground-floor shops. Nos. 2 & 3, on the north side of Broadmead. Attached. 2 storeys and attics; gabled; jettied; each a 1-window range. The right-hand property (No.3) with a left-hand entrance. Shop windows to both. Pentice roof above ground-floor of at least No.3. Bay to upper storeys of each, all 6-light except attic of No.3, where an Ipswich window.

Churchyard for St. Michael on the Mount Without, St. Michael's Hill. The churchyard was in use from the medieval period, presumably from the later twelfth century when the church was founded, until it was closed by an Order in Council of 18 February 1854 made under the Burial Act of 1852. Part of the eastern side of the main churchyard was removed for road widening at the foot of St. Michael's Hill in the nineteenth century. The Ordnance Survey 1st edition map of the early 1880s indicates that there were a number of discrete smaller plots of land used for burial to the east of the church which have since been developed for other uses, although it is not known if they were cleared prior to reuse.
Some areas of the main churchyard are paved but it has not been cleared of burials. Archaeological work has been limited to a watching brief on part of the churchyard in 1996 (BUAD 539).

KNOWN_AS: Earthwork feature 125 metres east of Romney Avenue
MONUMENT_DESC: An earthwork feature located north-west of Pale Plantation, 125 metres to the east of Romney Avenue. Dr. H. Taylor observed the feature c.1946 and suggested that the feature was a barrow. However, an excavation by the Bristol Folk House Archaeological Club in 1954-1955 (SMR 21030) recorded sherds of medieval pottery "on or near the original ground surface" (O'Neil & Grinsell 1960, 68), and O'Neil and Grinsell suggest that it is therefore more probable that the feature is a post-medieval garden feature. When O'Neil and Grinsell visited the feature in the late 1950s it measured 60 feet long, 25 feet wide and survived to a height of 4 feet 6 inches (O'Neil & Grinsell 1960, 68). The feature currently measures approximately 26 metres from north-west to south-east and is 13 metres across.

No.146 Temple Street, located on the western side of Temple Street. The building was a jettied, timber-framed and gabled house of three storeys and attic. It dated to the seventeenth-century.
The main entrance was on the southern side and there was another entrance on the north side. The full width of the first-floor was glazed, with bays at the northern and southern ends of the elevation. At second-floor there was a single bay at the centre of the elevation, containing two eight-light mullion and transom windows at the front, with two-light windows at the sides. The attic storey was jettied and the eaves of the roof are supported by brackets. There was a six-light mullion and transom window in the gable end.
The building is reported to have been the residence of Sir John Knight, Mayor of Bristol in 1663. In the eighteenth-century the building was used as a Synagogue. This use continued until 1786. Features and plate from the Synagogue were retained and have been reused in the Synagogue in Lower Park Row [BUAD 1033M]. The building was painted by Hugh O'Neill in 1819 (BRSMG M2153) but appears to have been substantially altered later in the nineteenth century. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 scale Town plan surveyed in 1883 (Bristol Sheets LXXV.4.5 and LXXVI.1.1) suggests that the entire plot had been developed and the original building extended. The Goad fire insurance plan of January 1887 confirms that all of the internal walls had been demolished, although the party walls probably survived. At that date the building was part of the provision warehouse of W. Clark & Sons. The building was still in use as a provision warehouse in the late 1930s but was badly damaged by bombing during the Second World War and had been demolished by the late 1940s.

House. No.36 Temple Street. Attached to north. On the east side of Temple Street, immediately north of the lane leading to Temple Church, and attached to the gateway at the end of the lane. 3 storeys and attic; jettied. Shopfront built out at ground-floor; sign above reads "J STEVENS DRAPER TAILOR". Cross-windows to first and second floors; second-floor slightly jettied; window to attic. Side gable on south wall, set back about one room from street.

The "Three Horseshoes" public house, located on the north-east corner of Ellbridge Passage, facing that portion of the Frome leading to the Castle Ditch. Attached to east. Entrance at northern end of the west, or Passage, elevation. North elevation of 3 storeys and attic. Cross-gabled; 1-window range. Full-width pentice roofs over fronts of lower 3 storeys. 8-light transomed ground-floor window. Bay with Ipswich window to first-floor; bay with 8-light front to second-floor; 2-light attis window. Stack on western gable. Lamp attached to north-west corner of building. Photographed in June 1952 by Reece Winstone (Winstone, 1964), by which time it was boarded up and awaiting demolition. Now beneath the western side of Bond Street.

Bristol Bridge, re-constructed in 1768. In the eighteenth century the narrow highway of the medieval bridge was causing an impediment to the flow of the increasing volume of vehicular traffic through the city. In October 1758, as a reponse to public concern, the Corporation formed a committee to consider the options for improvements. Public disagreement over the various schemes prevented any final decision being reached. It was however resolved to construct a temporary wooden bridge alongside the medieval bridge which opened in early 1762 (Ison 1952, 115-117). In 1760 an Act of Parliament was obtained to allow works to be undertaken (Marcy 1968, 152).
The design ultimately used was produced by James Bridges. The bridge was built under the supervision of Thomas Paty between 1764 (the foundation stone being laid on 9 April) and 1768, reusing at least some of the piers of the medieval bridge (Barrett 1789, 77). The classical design is in limestone ashlar, the stone used being Courtfield stone from Monmouthshire (Ison 1952, 122) and comprises a central segmental arch flanked by two semi-circular arches, with rusticated voussoirs, soffits and pilaster strips. There were Portland stone balustrades, divided into three bays above each arch, with semi-circular iron lamp brackets above the apex of the central span. At either end of the bridge a pair of square, domed toll houses were built. The tolls imposed to cross the bridge were unpopular and ultimately provoked a serious riot in 1793 (Jones 1980; Manson 1997). When the practice of charging tolls was ended the four toll houses were converted to use as small shops.
The bridge was widened in 1873-74 by the addition of a cast-iron deck supported by paired cast-iron Doric columns on either side of the bridge. The toll houses were removed as part of this work. Steel pavement extensions and handrails were added in the 1930s.
Currently (01/02/2000) there is some damage to the ashlar, particularly the voussoirs and the Victorian elements of the bridge are badly corroded and unstable.
An archaeological analysis of the bridge was undertaken in early 2000 by Roger Leech. This identified the survival of ashlar foundations of three of the four eighteenth-century toll houses, as well as foundations of two shops and a blocked arch interpreted as the outlet for the necessary house associated with those shops (Leech 2000).
The bridge was a Scheduled Ancient Monument (SAM Number AV 158) but was descheduled in 2004. It has a Grade II listing (Listed Building Number 901-1/42/514).

Victory Arch, a First World War memorial gatehouse at Clifton College. The building was designed by Charles Holden and was erected in 1922. It is a two-storey structure of limestone ashlar and Brandon Hill Grit. The gatehouse has a central two-centred arch with a pair of open lattice timber gates with smaller pedestrian arches containing panelled doors on either side. At first floor, above each of the pedestrian gates, there is a Gothic tracery window containing a stained glass window.
Internally the arch has groined vaulting. Carved into the upper part of the arches in both the north and south walls is the legend "TO THE MEMORY OF / THE 853 CLIFTONIANS / WHO FELL IN THE WARS / 1914-1919 1939-1945 / From the great Marshal to the last recruit / These Clifton were thy Self thy Spirit in deed / Thy flower of Chivalry thy fallen fruit / And thine immortal Seed." The names of the fallen are inscribed on the walls.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/1/829).

War memorial, located at the centre of the traffic island at the junction of Canford Lane, High Street and Westbury Hill. The memorial was erected c.1920. The memorial is a limestone ashlar obelisk on a square plinth with swag. On each face of the first and second stages are marble plaques recording the names of the fallen. The south-east face of the monument bears the carved inscription from the memorial to the Battle of Kohima in Burma [Myanmar], which is attributed to Major John Etty-Leal and derives from John Maxwell Edmonds (1875-1958): "WHEN YOU / GO HOME / TELL THEM / OF US / AND SAY / FOR YOUR / TOMORROW / WE GAVE / OUR TODAY."
The memorial has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/26/2134).
[There are photographs of the memorial in the SMR collection of ground-based photographs, numbers 484 and 485].
[Public Monument and Sculpture Association reference number BR77].

KNOWN_AS: Quarry on the south side of Manor Road, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry located on the south side of Manor Road. The quarry was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.10) published in 1882 and measured, at that date, approximately 55 metres from east to west and 22 metres from north to south. The plan indicates that there was a spoil heap to the north of the quarry. All of the quarry appears now to have been infilled and the site lies mainly in the gardens of Nos.91-93 Snowdon Road.

White Cross Court. The building is located on the east side of Wells Road, and is set some 18 metres back from the road. The building is a rendered house constructed of coursed, squared Lias limestone rubble bonded in a soft pale yellow limestone mortar with white lime inclusions. The house consists of a three-storey range with a single depth plan parallel to Wells Road with two-storey ranges at right-angles to the main range on its north and south sides. These were probably constructed as an integral part of the original building since no indication of a change in the character of construction is evident at the junction between any of the ranges. The main, west-facing, elevation is symmetrical and has an open square porch with a moulded cornice and a parapet. A painted stone tablet above the central first-floor window is incised with a garland and the legend "1786 WHITE CROSS COURT". There are chimney stacks in the gable-ends. The fenestration originally comprised sash windows "with fine bars and exposed cases." Internally the original plan of the main range appears to have consisted at each floor of a single room on either side of a central stair and landing.
The house was converted to an accountants office in c.1975 and a maisonette was created within the building. It was converted into a hostel for families in c.1977 and as part of this work windows were inserted in the side elevations of the main range. Works to convert the building into flats was begun in 2004. No historic fixtures or fittings now survive within the building.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/58/1406).

Clifton Pool, located on the northern side of Oakfield Place, Clifton. The pool was created as a private swimming pool run on a subscription basis, and opened in 1850. The façade of the building is of three storeys with five bays, the entrance being set in the central bay. The pool was to the rear of this with a gallery on the eastern side. Between 1883 and 1885 the building was reorganised. The eastern two bays of the frontage were converted to The Victoria public house, the gallery building was removed and the pool enlarged into much of the space it had occupied. A small cottage was built where the southern end of the gallery had stood. The bath was shortened and a tepid bath was constructed across the width of the northern end of the site. The width of the pool was reduced in 1934 and the tepid bath was demolished in 1961. The pool itself was refurbished at around the same time.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/3/10039).

Broomwell House, Brislington. The house was built in the 1760s for Robert Bailey and was originally set in fifteen acres of land. In 1780 Rev. Thomas Ireland, formerly of Langton Lodge, purchased the property and moved there. He sold the estate in 1792 to Charles Hill, and John, Lord Colville of Culros, owned the property until his death in 1810. The house was eventually purchased by George Weare Braikenridge, the merchant and antiquarian, who moved there in 1823. The exterior and interior at the time of Braikenridge's occupation are recorded in a series of drawings by T. L. Rowbotham and other artists which he commissioned (see Stoddard 1981, 27-41).
The main part of the house was of three storeys with bay windows on either side of the entrance. Both bay windows had three, three-by-four pane sashes at ground and first floor levels and three-by-two pane sashes at second floor. The main door was at the centre of the elevation and was protected by a projecting canopy apparently supported on cast iron columns. At first floor there was a tripartite window with a central three by four pane sash and one by four pane windows on either side. Above this and spanning the full width of the window was a lunette. At second floor level there was another tripartite window with a central three by one pane window and single panes on either side. Above the fenestration a projecting, moulded cornice terminated abruptly on the south-facing elevation of the building. The roof was hipped and there were stacks at the north and south ends and another slightly to the north of the centre of the roof. On the both the north and south sides of the building there were a single-storey extension with pitched roofs. The northern was elaborately decorated by Braikenridge soon after he moved in. He inserted a gothic window with a drip-mould above in the centre of the west facing elevation, a crenellated parapet and a crocketed spirelet at its north end. At the centre of the west facing elevation was a coat of arms, although this had been removed by 1872 (Jones & Chown, 1977 pl.70: SMR 20597). On the apex of the parapet at the north end of the extension was a stone cross supported on a small arch. The decoration of the southern extension is unknown.
Braikenridge was still in residence at the time of the Brislington Tithe Award of 1846 (BRO EP/A/32/9). His son, Reverend George Weare Braikenridge, however put the house on the market in 1867. A sale prospectus describes the house as having ten bedrooms, extensive wine and beer cellars, warm air apparatus and a large courtyard with five-stall stable, coach house, brewhouse, and sheds for livestock (Ireland, 1870: Bristol Record Office: St. LB/HM/1a & 1b). It was bought in 1868 by William Procter Baker, a wealthy corn merchant and Alderman of Bristol. Between 1896 and 1915 George Johnson occupied the property.
The Brislington Tithe Map indicates that the house was reached by a long drive lined with trees, with its entrance being directly opposite the entrance to Wick House. By 1872 a path ran in front of the west-facing elevation (Jones & Chown 1977, pl.70).
The house was demolished in 1928 to make way for the development of new housing. Monitoring of subsequent redevelopment of the site in 2004 (SMR 21806) recorded the footprint of the building and the surviving basement which was infilled and left in situ beneath the front gardens of the new buildings.

Winash, Brislington. In 1740,  John Braikenridge is recorded as purchasing an estate that comprised the house now called Winash from the Hall family. On his death in 1764 the house and estate passed to his wife and eventually to their grandson, George Weare Braikenridge, who resided there for seven years until 1823 when he purchased and moved to Broomwell House. He is recorded as the owner in 1828 and although the house was let at various times, for most of its history it was inhabited by the Braikenridge family. The Brislington Tithe award of 1846, gives George Braikenridge as the owner with Thomas Kenn as the occupier. It remained in the Braikenridge family until 1907.
The house comprised three storeys.
In 1918 Thomas Ford was the owner and ran a market garden from the premises, but in 1920 Victor Marryat is recorded as the owner and following his death in 1927, his widow continued to live there. The house stood empty for many years and was demolished in the early 1960s. Dixon Road now covers the site of the house and garden..

Doncaster Farm, located on the west side of a lane which largely follows the line of modern Broomhill Road. The farm was in existence by the time of the Brislington tithe survey of 1846 and at the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition County Series 1:2500-scale plan of 1884 the farm comprised a farmhouse and several outbuildings. By 1961 the site had been redeveloped as a trading estate and the site of the farm now lies beneath the buildings of Birchills Trading Estate, on the east side of Emery Road.

Heath Farm, located on the northern side of Ironmould Lane. The farm is a two-storey gabled building constructed of stone rubble and dates to the seventeenth century. The original form appears to have been a single-depth plan with a room on either side of a central entrance and a projecting rear stair tower. The stone of the stair tower is bonded in an orange-red mortar. The internal organisation of the house has been substantially altered but major structural timbers with roughly-hewn stops survive. Some of the original roof timbers are also extant. A rear north-south range was added to the western side of the building in the late-eighteenth or the nineteenth century. Openings were made through the rear wall of the seventeenth-century building into this range and a lean-to extension on the east side of the stair tower.
The farmhouse has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/49/464).

KNOWN_AS: Quarry on the eastern side of Small Lane, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry located some 75 metres to the south of Manor Road, on the east side of Small Lane. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882 and measured at that date approximately 42 metres from north to south and 19 metres from east to west. The plan labels the feature "Old Quarry", suggesting that it had by that date been out of use for some time. The quarry has been infilled and the site now lies largely beneath the houses on the north and south sides of the western end of Lambrook Road.

KNOWN_AS: Medieval hermitage of St. Vincent, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC:
Hermitage chapel of St. Vincent at Ghyston Cliff (located at the top of the cliff in the vicinity of Clifton Down Camp) The site was visited by William Worcestre in 1480 who made a number of measurements there:
"latitudo aulo heremitagij est .7. virgas
longitudo vie ad Ecclesiam de aula in Rupe predicta [St. Vincent's Rock] fodiata .16. virgas.
longitudo Capelle sancti Vincencij 8. virgas
latitudo Capelle sancti Vincentij .3. virgas
longitudo domus Coquine .6. virge" (Neale 2000, 44-47).
Worcestre's reference to "the hermitage and chapel" suggests the existence of a discrete oratory. Similarly the mention of a kitchen may imply the existence of a kitchen detached from the hermitage. In 1492 an episcopal brief offered an indulgence to those who assisted the warden of the chapel of St. Mary and St. Vincent and contributed towards its preservation.
The precise location of the chapel is unknown, although a drawing of the 1780s by Grimm shows a ruined structure to the south of Clifton Down Camp. It is possible that all trace of the hermitage may have been removed by subsequent quarrying. A glazed encaustic tile, part of a small Gothic window and sherds of medieval pottery are reported to have been found in the Giant's Cave (Hall Warren 1907, 204-205).

The Hotwell. A spring was reported in the area below Ghyston cliff by William Worcester in 1480, who gave the location as "circa bowshott apud le blak Rok in parte de Ghystonclyff in fundo acque" (Neale 2000, 44-45). By 1661 the spring, described as "a certen Well of Water called the Hottwell", was owned by Joseph Whittington and William Hodges and that year they granted it to the Bristol Corporation on a one thousand year lease (Taylor 1884). The site seems to have consisted of a well (Exwood & Lehman 1993, 104-105) until 1695 when a pump-room was built and the place became a favourite resort (Hembry 1990). By the mid-eighteenth century a number of buildings had been constructed around the pump-room, including lodging houses and Angerstein reports that in 1754 visitors paid a subscription of 5 shillings to use the pump-room itself (Berg & Berg 2001, 132). The spa drew many visitors to the city, and allowed a number of other ventures to develop, notably providing audiences for the Playhouse at Jacobs Wells Road. A new pump-room was built in 1822 but this was demolished in 1867 to allow for the widening of the river.

KNOWN_AS: Georgian Church of St. Andrew, Clifton
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Georgian parish church of St. Andrew at Clifton, located on the north side of Clifton Green. The development of Clifton in the eighteenth century had increased the population of the parish to such an extent that the parish church could not accommodate all of the worshippers. It was also anticipated that the capacity of the existing churchyard would also be reached relatively quickly. An Act of Parliament to enable the rebuilding of the existing church (SMR 20285) and the acquisition of land to extend the churchyard was obtained in March 1816 (56 Geo.III Cap.vii). At that date the Rector of the parish was the Rev. James Vaughan of Wraxall and the vicar was the Rev. Stonhouse-Vigor.
The replacement church was constructed between 1819-1822 to a design by James Foster. It was an ashlar structure with a three-stage tower at the western end (Pevsner 1958, 446). The organ was built by John Smith senior of the Bristol organ builders John Smith and Sons and was completed by November 1822.
The church was gutted by bombing during the Second World War and the remains of the shell were demolished in 1958 (Anon. 1959, 155-156). The tower, which had also been gutted but was apparently in a better structural state, was demolished soon afterwards. The fabric of the church was pushed into the crypt, although the monuments in the crypt had apparently not been removed before this occurred (BRO 35709 Box 1).

Queen Square. The Bristol Corporation took the decision to develop an urban square on the marsh to the south of the city at the end of the seventeenth century. The ground surface was raised by dumping approximately 2.5 metres of material, mainly industrial waste (Insole 1999), and the first house was built by a Dr. Reade who apparently began construction in 1700. The leases issued by the Corporation were very specific about the materials to be used in the housing and in restricting the trades which could be carried on from them (Ison 1952, 142). Building was completed in 1732, the north-west corner of the square being the last to be completed, but the green space at the centre initially had no formal layout. It did however reuse the trees from the earlier ropewalks (which were removed after lobbying by residents in 1710) to provide shaded walks and Millerd's map of c.1715 shows railings set around it.
The square was intended as an exclusive residence, appropriating to the city's middle class what had formerly been a place of recreation and assembly for all. To form a centrepiece the Corporation commissioned an equestrian statue of William III by Michael Rysbrack (BUAD 308M) which was erected in September 1736. To enhance this formal paths on north-south and east-west axes were created, dividing the square into quadrants which were crossed diagonally by gravel paths. The Mansion House and the Custom House were built on the north side of the square. Illustrations in the Braikenridge Collection, Bristol Museum and Art Gallery suggest that in the early nineteenth century the trees on the square were being actively managed.
In October 1831 after the failure of the Reform Bill in the House of Lords the Square was the scne of rioting. This was highly destructive to the buildings of the Square. The Mansion House and Custom House were fired by the rioters and the fire spread to the adjoining dwellings, particularly on the north and west sides of the Square, which were gutted. Although the buildings were reconstructed in the following decade, the riots initiated a decline in the social status of the square; houses were divided into multiple tenancies and businesses took some over as premises.
Between 1937 and 1941 the dual carriageway of the inner circuit road was driven through the square. The Rysbrack statue was rotated from its original position facing north to face north-west, aligned with the road. A number of air raid shelters were constructed in the square in the years immediately before the Second World War. The road was closed in 1990 as a preliminary to a scheme to restore the square. This restoration project, carried out between September 1999 and 5th July 2000 when the square re-opened to the public, included the removal of the road surface, reorientation of the Rysbrack statue to its original position and the insertion of gravel walks.
Archaeological work in the square has focused on the buildings and several were surveyed by Dr Roger Leech and the Royal Commission on the Historical Monuments of England. An archaeological evaluation (BUAD 3369) was carried out in November 1998 in the south-western corner of the square to inform the restoration project and an archaeological watching brief (BUAD 3515) was maintained during the groundworks associated with the project (Etheridge 2000; Williams 1999, 104). There are also several photographs of the square and its buildings in the late nineteenth and twentieth centuries (Wells 1975: Winstone 1957; 1962; 1970; 1971; 1986).
A number of the buildings surrounding the square have listed status, including the Mansion House, the nineteenth-century Custom House and the equestrian statue of King William III by Michael Rysbrack (Grade I).

No.25 Victoria Street. The building is the northern of a terrace of four gabled houses on the west side of Victoria Street (having fronted on to St. Thomas Street until the 1870s when Victoria Street was cut through the existing street pattern). The plots were the property of St. Thomas's Church and four shops are known to have been present on the site by 1456 and a date plaque on the front of the building which gives a date of c.1456 is presumably a reference to the documentary evidence for the earlier tenements. The present building was constructed between 1673 and 1675 by Henry Gleson, linendraper (BRO P/StT/D/151).
The building is a single-bay timber-framed structure of three storeys plus attic with a pantile cross-gable roof of which only the northern ridge appears to survive. The ground floor is occupied by a shopfront and the first and second floors are bay windows. The attic has a small three over six pane sashes. There is a chimney stack on the southern side of the building. The original plan form consisted of a front and rear room at each floor with a winder stair against the south wall between the two.
Internally the building was heavily altered in the twentieth century. Stopped beams survive at various locations inside the building. Much of original timberwork of the stair, including turned balusters newels and pendants survives at first-floor level and above.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/325).

Church House, located on the southern side of East Street on the west side of its junction with Church Lane. The building was in existence by the time of John Plumley and George Ashmead's plan of Bristol of 1828. The frontage of the building measured 8.5 metres wide and it extended 13 metres back from the street according to the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.24) surveyed in 1883.
The building was occupied by Mrs. R. Phippen in 1871 and was still extant at the beginning of the twentieth century. However, by the time that the Ordnance Survey third edition plan was published in 1918 Church House had been demolished and the site redeveloped.

No.29 Victoria Street. The building is part of a terrace of four gabled houses on the west side of Victoria Street (having fronted on to St. Thomas Street until the 1870s when Victoria Street was cut through the existing street pattern). The plots were the property of St. Thomas's Church and four shops are known to have been present on the site by 1456 and a date plaque on the front of the building which gives a date of c.1456 is presumably a reference to the documentary evidence for the earlier tenements. The present building was constructed between 1673 and 1675 by Henry Gleson, linendraper (BRO P/StT/D/151). The building is a single-bay timber-framed structure of three storeys plus attic with a pantile gabled roof. The ground floor is occupied by a shopfront and the first and second floors are bay windows. The attic has a small 4 by 4 pane sash. There is a large brick chimney stack on the northern side of the building. The original plan form consisted of a front and rear room at each floor with a winder stair against the south wall between the two.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/325).

KNOWN_AS: Territorial Army Centre, Whitefield Road, Speedwell
MONUMENT_DESC:
Territorial Army Centre, located on the north side of Whitefield Road, Speedwell. The building was constructed in 1940 as a Territorial Army Centre for the Gloucestershire Regiment and the building remained largely unaltered after its construction. It is a three-storey brick structure designed in a Neo-Georgian style. The main, south-facing, elevation has a central entrance porch with pilasters topped by a sphinx (the emblem of the Gloucestershire Regiment) extending up to mid second-floor level set on either side. Between the entrance and the first-floor window of the central bay is a plaque bearing the Bristol City arms and the inscription "DANGER READY". Between the first and and second floor windows is the date "1940". Each of the ground-floor windows is set within a segmental-headed arched opening while the window openings on the upper storeys are flat-headed. On either side of the main block there were two wings and in the space enclosed by the front element of the building and the wings was a two-storey drill hall.
The Sergeants' Mess and the Junior Ranks' Mess were located at ground floor in the main block, the former on the west side of the entrance lobby and the latter on its east side. The armoury was located in the eastern wing with stores to its north. The ground-floor of the western wing was occupied by offices, including those for the Second-in-Command and Company Sergeant Major. Access to all of the ground-floor rooms in the wings was via the drill hall and at the north end of the drill hall there was a classroom. At first-floor level there was a conference room on the west side of the main stair and the Commanding Officer's office to its east. These offices were served by a corridor at the rear of the building and in the eastern wing there was a three-lane indoor firing range. The western half of the second floor comprised the caretaker's flat while the eastern was accommodation for military personnel.
The building was redeveloped for housing in 2001 and the majority of the wings and the drill hall were demolished at this tome. However, the main block was retained and the interior converted to apartments. The building was surveyed before this work (SMR 20927: Pilkington, 2001) and several of the original internal features, including fireplaces, remained, radiators and the main staircase were noted to survive from the 1940s. The original iron frame windows were also extant in the side and rear elevations, although they had been replaced with modern replacements in the main elevation. Several of these internal features were, however, removed during the conversion works.

KNOWN_AS: Hospital for Infectious Diseases, Holmes Hill Road, St. George
MONUMENT_DESC:
Hospital for Infectious Diseases, located on the east side of Holmes Hill Road. The hospital was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500-scale County series plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) published in 1904. The hospital appears to have been created by St. George's parish by converting two existing attached buildings in the late 1880s. The form of the building is not at present clear but it measured 10 metres square.
In 1897, when the county of Bristol was enlarged, the hospital was transferred to the authority of Bristol. A report by the Medical Officer of Health, dated 1898, reports that "the cottages in rear have been pulled down, the premises repaired and a bath room fitted. At present retained for use as a refuge under Sec. 15 of the Infectious Diseases Prevention Act, 1890, or for emergency use" (quoted in Erskine 2001). The hospital was latterly used as an out-patient centre and later was used as a "Sanitary Yard". The building was still extant at the end of the First World War.
The site of the hospital is now in the gardens to the rear of Nos.28-30a Holmes Hill Road.

Pottery Farm, Bishopsworth. The date of founding of the farm is at present uncertain but it was in existence by 1841 when it belonged to the Smyth family of Ashton Court. It was recorded by the Bedminster tithe survey as house, yard, gardens and buildings (BRO EP/A/32/8) and was then rented by Benjamin Britton. It apparently became known as Pottery Farm at a later date. The tenancy was taken on by Ernest Withers, the son of John Beard Withers of Pigeonhouse Farm (SMR 5165) later in the century.
Esme Smyth sold the farm at auction in May 1916 and it wasd purchased by William White of Church Farm, Clutton. White owned the farm until it was subject to Compulsory Purchase by Bristol City Council in 1949, along with his other property Pigeonhouse Farm. The farm buildings were subsequently demolished to allow development of housing estates at Hartcliffe after the Second World War.

Icehouse, Kings Weston House. The building was constructed after 1772 and replaced an earlier icehouse (Niall Phillips Associates, 1985) and is situated some metres to the north-east of the main house. It is of brick with a entrance tunnel 3 metres long by 2.1 metres high and 1.2 metres wide which had inner and outer doors. "The E[ast] side door post and top frame member are in the ice-house pit itself, they are oak and the butt hinge recesses can be seen" (Beamon & Road, 1990 188). This entrance tunnel leads into a domed circular chamber with an internal diameter of 5.5 metres. The icehouse has three walls, an outer stone wall 0.53 metres thick, separated from a brick wall 0.23 metres thick by a 4 inch gap (0.1 metres). Inside this wall is another brick wall 0.1 metres thick. Opposite the entrance the chamber has a rectangular hole 0.46 metres wide by 0.32 metres high which has been interpreted as a ventilation feature (Beamon & Roaf, 1990 188). The icehouse was surveyed by G. G. Locke in 1975 (SMR 20943).

Stoke House, now Trinity Theological College, located on the northern side of Stoke Hill. The house was constructed as the summerhouse or second residence of the Bristol merchant Robert Cann in the second half of the seventeenth century. The building was constructed as a single depth plan with rooms either side of a central staircase (R. Leech pers. comm.) and there was a stable block to the south-west of the main house (NGR ST 56413 75475) which has features of seventeenth-century date within it (J. Bryant pers. comm.).
The wing to the east was added and the road on the southern side of the plot was moved to its present course in the early eighteenth century. An engraving by Kip records the house at this time. The formal garden was on the west side of the main house while the icehouse lay to the north (at NGR ST 56415 75600 approx..), being now within the gardens of a modern house. There is an orangery of nineteenth-century date 20 metres to the north west of the main house (NGR ST 56356 75539). The building was partly refronted in 1872 by Foster and Wood.
The house has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/31/2012).

KNOWN_AS: Lion House at Bristol Zoological Gardens
MONUMENT_DESC:
A Lion House was in existance at Bristol Zoological Gardens by the time of Ashmead's survey of Clifton in 1849 and was probably on of the first structures built after the gardens opened in 1836. The original Lion House lay to the north of the centre point along the east-west terrace and measured approximately 40m east-west by 7 metres making it the largest and most prominent animal house in the gardens during the nineteenth century. The building had a rectangular plan with a large central bow bay. Photographs suggest that the building was neo-classical in style and that the bow bay formed a portico on the south elevation with pediment above. The guide book plan of 1886 indicates that the building contained eleven small cages for big cats set against the rear wall with a viewing area in front. The 1899 guide book shows that the internal space had been reconfigured with the number of cages increased to fourteen. An early twentieth century drawing by Samuel Loxton (Bristol Reference Library W1401) shows large cages for big cats in front of the building. These had been added after 1903 and are shown on the Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire sheets LXXI.15 and LXXI.16) surveyed in 1913.
The building was demolished in 1971 and replaced with an Ape House. The modern Lion House lies immediately to the west of the site of the original building.

KNOWN_AS: Elephant and Giraffe House at Bristol Zoological Gardens
MONUMENT_DESC:
An Elephant and Giraffe House at Bristol Zoological Gardens built in 1872 possibly to a design by Charles Hansom. The structure is a two storey, two window range building built in the Tudor Gothic Revival style with a square plan constructed of Brandon Hill Grit with limestone dressings and tiled cross-gabled roof. A Plan of the Zoological Gardens in the 1886 guide book to the Zoological Gardens indicates that the internal space was divided into three areas; two square areas for animals in the southern half of the building (the west area for an elephant and the east for camels) and a viewing area occupying the northern half of the building. To the south of the building was an open yard for the animals. An extension on the north side of the Elephant House was constructed in 1935 to a design by C.F.W. Dening (Green-Armytage 1964, 70) to provide a seperate Elephant House to the north while the former elephant and camel areas were given over to giraffes. In the mid 1990s the Elephant House extension was converted for use as a Gorilla House.
The building is extant and has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/1/748).

KNOWN_AS: Gazebo in the gardens of Southmead Manor House
MONUMENT_DESC:
Gazebo located in the north-west corner of the garden of Southmead Manor Gardens (SMR 20100). The structure was built in the late eighteenth-century. It is a two-storey structure with a two-window range and stands against the south-west and north-west boundary walls. It is constructed of coursed carboniferous limestone with occasional Dolomitic Conglomerate and has dressings probably of Dundry stone. There is a chimney breast and fireplace inside the building as well as a red brick bench along the east wall. The exterior of this wall was rendered with stucco, and traces of this survive. The structure was derelict, the interior strewn with rubble and the walls overgrown by foliage when it was visited in February 1995, in the course research for a desk-based assessment of the site (Boore 1995).
The gazebo is listed Grade II (Listed Building Number 901-1/53/1823).

KNOWN_AS: Barton Hill Nursery School, Queen Ann Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
Barton Hill Primary School. The school was built on the site of Tilly's Court (2293M) in 1893-1894 (BRO Building Plan Books Vol.30 fol.57b). The school is a two-storey brick structure with limestonr ashlar detailing and a slate roof. The core of the structure is a central range, orientated from south-west to north-east, with cross-wings with stepped gables at either end. On the south-east facing (Queen Ann Road) frontage these enclose two-storey square towers with a two-window range and parapet, and at the centre of the elevation is a paired single-storey element with a three-window range. There is a tall brick stack at the centre of the valley between the two ranges. On the north-west facing elevation there are a series of attached single-storey structures with flat roofs which house offices and ancillary spaces.
The entrances to the school consisted of separate doors for girls and boys, the girls entrance being on the western side of the central ranges and the boys on the eastern side.
The entrances lead into the main hall which is open to the roof. The hall has pairs of classrooms off the eastern and western ends, stairs leading to the first floor on the southern side and offices and ancillary rooms on the northern side. A seventeenth century stone chimneypiece, originally from Tilly's Court (SMR 20187), is fixed to the centre of the southern wall of the hall while the office on the opposite side has a plaster ceiling which was also resited from Tilly's Court. This was cut into sections for removal and reassembled in its new location. At first floor level the stairs lead out on to a timber gallery with a balustrade along the southern side, eastern and western sides of the hall, giving access to the classrooms, and is supported by moulded brackets.
Covered single-storey playsheds with single-pitch roofs stand along the full length of both the north-eastern and south-western sides of the site.

Greenway Farm, Westbury on Trym. The farm is recorded by the Westbury-on-Trym tithe map of 1841 and is shown on successive Ordnance Survey maps into the 1930s. The Ordnance Survey provisional edition of 1936 shows a rectangular farmyard with the farmhouse and outbuildings arranged around its sides. The farm now lies partly beneath the buildings of the Greenway Centre and partly beneath the gardens and driveway in front.

Pennywell Colliery. The colliery was in operation by 1854 when the owner was Chick, Keeling & Co. The main shaft (at ST 60199 73978) was 950 feet (290 metres) deep and several seams were worked, including the Kingswood Great seam at  280 feet (85.7 metres), the Kingswood Little seam at 396 feet (121 metres) and the Easton Red Ash at 945 feet (289 metres). Ownership of the colliery seems to have changed every few years in the 1860s and 1870s. By 1865 the pit was owned by Chick, Brown & Co. but it was owned by Thomas Brown in the following year, Brown and Harris in 1868, G. W. Harris in 1874 and the Pennywell Colliery Co. in 1877 (Southway 1971, 20). It was acquired by Leonard, Betts & Boult, which already owned the Easton and Hanham collieries, in 1888, though by 1889 the mine was reported as being used only for pumping and ventilation (Ramsey, 2003 24). The date of closure is unclear but Leonard Boult and Company was wound up in 1894. The site had been cleared of colliery buildings by the time of the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.13) published in 1903.
The site was redeveloped for housing in the twentieth century.

Whitelead Works, located on the eastern side of Avon Street. The factory was in existence by the time of Plumley and Ashmead's plan of Bristol in 1828 and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.2) surveyed in 1883. The works survived into the twentieth century but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped. The main railway line was expanded to the south, over the northern corner of the factory.

KNOWN_AS: United Free Methodist Chapel, Gas Lane, St Philips
MONUMENT_DESC: United Free Methodist Chapel, located on the northern side of Gas Lane. The chapel appears to have been built some time after 1828 but was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.2) surveyed in 1883. This indicates that the structure had seating for 500 people. The building fronts on to Gas Lane and in 1883 measured approximately 24 metres from north-east to south-east and was 18 metres wide. It is constructed of coursed Pennant sandstone rubble and the front and rear elevation have large segmental-headed arched windows. The chapel is now encased within a larger modern structure. The elevation fronting on to Gas Lane has been rendered with pebble dash and the original window openings have been blocked and smaller windows inserted. The original openings appear to survive on the internal face, however (SMR 21384).

KNOWN_AS: Malthouse on the south side of Silverthorne Lane
MONUMENT_DESC: Malthouse, located on the southern side of Silverthorne Lane. The malthouse was in existence by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXVI.1.3) surveyed in 1883. The building appears to have been extant at the beginning of the twentieth century but subsequently became part of the adjacent St. Vincent's Iron Works (SMR 21289).

KNOWN_AS: J. W. Bobbett & Sons Corn & Flour Warehouses, Waterloo Road
MONUMENT_DESC: J. W. Bobbett & Sons Corn & Flour Warehouses, located on the northern side of Waterloo Road, Old Market. A storehouse was recorded on the site by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.17) and the Goad fire insurance plan of 1896 indicates that the works was by then occupied by J. W. Bobbett and Sons and additional infill buildings had been constructed to provide extra accommodation. The use also extended into the rear parts of Nos.72-74 West Street.

KNOWN_AS: House on the south side of Waterloo Road
MONUMENT_DESC: House on the south side of Waterloo Road. The building lies on the eastern side of the junction of Waterloo Road with a lane from the south-west. It was probably constructed in the early eighteenth century and is recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 map which shows it as a rectangular structure, measuring approximately 9.5 metres from south-east to north-west by 5 metres wide. There was a rectangular formal garden on its eastern side. The structure had been extended on its eastern side by 1828, having been enlarged by one metre along the entire length of its eastern side. An extension, forming a south-west to north-east range 11.5 metres long on the Waterloo Road frontage, was built into the area of the garden. The Goad fire insurance plan of 1896 records that earliest element of the house was of three storeys in height while the extension was of two storeys. The building survived into the late 1960s but was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped.

The Synagogue, located on the northern side of Lower Park Row. The synagogue was designed by S. C. Fripp and Hyman Henry Collins of London and was built in 1874. The synagogue is a three-storey structure of coursed, rusticated Pennant sandstone with freestone ashlar detailing and a pitched roof. The interior of the synagogue was designed by Collins and is typical of his work. Most of the fittings are original. The Ark incorporates doors from the earlier synagogue at Temple Street [BUAD 291M]. The Bimah (central reading platform) is of unusual curved shape and the lamp stands are also from Temple Street. The Royal Family prayer boards came from the Montefiore Synagogue, Ramsgate (1831-1833) (Sharmian Kadish pers. comm.). The gallery was extended on the west side in the 1970s.
Collins was one of the earliest Jewish architects to practice in Britain and designed several synagogues in London and elsewhere. His only other surviving buildings are Chatham Memorial Synagogue (1865-1870) and London, St. John's Wood (1880-1882)

No.36 High Street, located on the western side of High Street. A building stood on the site from at least the mid-fifteenth century and in 1461 comprised two shops with a share of an inn. In 1473 the inn was named "le Cok in the Hope" and at this date it was leased to Clement Wiltshire, merchant, by John Shipward. In 1566 "inner" part (presumably the rear) of the inn was conveyed by Hugh Smyth to Walter Standfast and by 1607 this element had been acquired by John Pepwall. In 1648 the property was sold to Jeremy Holwey and by 1695 the inn had been renamed the Golden Cock (Leech, 1997 79).
In the late 1930s the building occupied a 3.7 metre wide frontage on High Street and the main, north-west facing, elevation was of four-storeys and two bays with a gabled roof. The ground floor was occupied by a shop front with large plate-glass windows. The fenestration at first and second floor levels comprised evenly spaced sash windows The second and third storeys were jettied out from the lower storeys and from one another. The windows of the fourth storey, however, formed a continuous band across the frontages of Nos.35 and 36, beginning two-thirds of the way along the frontage of No.35 and running to the north side of the frontage of No.36. The ends of the two parallel gables had plain bargeboards and there were now windows in the attic gables. A double chimney stack projected from the roof on the south side of the building.
The building survived into the twentieth century but was totally destroyed by bombing during the raid on 24 November 1940. The site was subsequently redeveloped and is now beneath No.35-38 High Street.

Holmses House, located on the north side of Manor Road, Stapleton. The date of construction of the house is currently (02/05/2006) unknown but it was in existence by the mid-eighteenth century and was recorded by a plan within a property terrier amongst the papers of the Smyth family of Ashton Court (BRO AC/WH 5 (86)). The house was still extant at the time of the Stapleton tithe survey of 1839 (BRO EP/A/32/35) but had been demolished by the early 1880s.

KNOWN_AS: South African War memorial, Clifton College
MONUMENT_DESC:
South African War memorial, Clifton College, located 17 metres to the south-west of the Guthrie Memorial Chapel. The memorial was designed by the Bristol architects W. S. Paul and R. C. James and the sculptor Alfred Drury (1856-1944) was invited to make the figure of St. George. The statue was unveiled by Lord Methuen in May 1905 (Merritt 2002, 32-33).
The memorial comprises a bronze figure of St. George in armour with a sword in the right hand and a shield in the left. The figure is set on a square carved limestone plinth in a Gothic Revival-style with angle buttresses which turn into pinnacles, linked by swept labels with crockets and finials. The top is panelled and there are bronze panels on each of the faces of the plinth. The bronze panel on the south-east face of the plinth carries a legend composed by the poet Sir Henry Newbolt (1862-1938), a Clifton College alumnus: "SOUTH AFRICAN WAR / 1899-1902 / CLIFTON / REMEMBER THESE / THY SONS WHO FELL / FIGHTING / FAR OVER SEA / FOR THEY / IN A DARK HOUR / REMEMBERED WELL / THEIR WARFARE / LEARNED OF THEE." The panels on the remaining faces bear the names of the fallen.
The memorial has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/2/831).

KNOWN_AS: Statue of Sir Douglas Haig, Clifton College
MONUMENT_DESC:
Statue of Sir Douglas Haig, Clifton College, located 22 metres east of the Victory Arch (SMR 20830) on College Road. The statue is a standing bronze figure of Earl Haig (1861-1928) in the uniform of an officer of the British Army, wearing a greatcoat and resting a map case, held in the left hand, on the left knee. The statue is set on a small rectangular plinth of Portland stone approximately 1 metre high with the legend "HAIG" carved into its south-east face. The figure was sculpted by W. McMillan (also responsible, with Charles Wheeler for mermen and mermaids on the Trafalgar Square fountains in London) and was cast by the A. B. Burton foundry at Thames Ditton in 1931 (Merritt 2002, 41-42). Haig had attended Clifton College between 1875 and 1879 and, pursuing a military career, succeeded Sir John French as Commander in Chief British Expeditionary Forces in December 1915. Haig retained that command until 1919. He became commander of Home Forces after the First World War, founded the Haig Fund and was subsequently created the first Earl Haig. The statue was unveiled on Saturday 15th July 1932 by Sir William Birdwood, former commander of the ANZAC forces and a Clifton College alumnus, in a ceremony also attended by Sir Francis Younghusband (1863-1942), another Clifton College alumnus.
The statue has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/832).

Two, two-storey semi detached dwellings on the south side of Tyndall Avenue. Origianlly these formed part of a group of five and a half pairs of villas built c.1906. These buildings were constructed of Brandon Hill Grit rubble with limestone dressings and brickwork to the side and rear elevations. The main roof was hipped and tiled, decorated with fretted bargeboard gables over two-storey canted front bays. The buildings were recorded by John Bryant of Bristol and Region Archaeological Services in 2010 prior to their demolition.

Parson Street Primary School on the east side of Parson Street to the south of Bedminster Road, built in 1908 and opened on 11th January 1909 with a proposed intake of 206 boys and 50 girls. Originally the school comprised two blocks, however, the western block was destroyed by an incendary bomb in 1940. The surviving eastern block is a single storey building constructed of squared Pennant sandstone rubble and limestone dressings. There is a central circular ventilation tower with copper roof. The original building has a rectangular plan, but was extended to the west in the later twentieth century.

KNOWN_AS: Former gardens of Southmead Manor House
MONUMENT_DESC: Former gardens of Southmead Manor House. The gardens lie to the north-west of the house and were planted by Dr. Stanley Badock who owned the Manor House and estate at the end of the nineteenth-century. The 1841 tithe map records the land as pasture. Badock created two gardens, upper and lower, the lower being a wild garden on the site of the kitchen garden. There is a gazebo (SMR 20099) of late eighteenth-century date in the north-west corner of the gardens. This has a Grade II listing. Badock also planted specimen trees, including rhododendron and giant Sequoia; several Tree Preservation Orders are in force on trees on the gardens. A sale document of 1926 mentions a swimming pool 70 feet long and space for two tennis lawns. The Manor House was owned by the Courtney family from the late 1930s and the gardens were maintained by them. During the years after the Second World War the gardens were regularly used to stage fetes and other public events. The house and its grounds were sold in the late 1980s and the grounds were divorced from the house then. Since the sale the gardens have been allowed to become overgrown. The gardens were listed in the Gazetteer of Historic Parks and Gardens compiled by Avon County Council. The gardens were visited by Eric Boore in February 1995 during the course of the research for an archaeological desk-based assessment of the site. It was noted that the gardens were overgrown but original garden features survived. The gazebo was derelict and the walls overgrown.

KNOWN_AS: Convent of the Sisters of Charity
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Convent of the Sisters of Charity. The building was designed by John Dando Sedding and was completed in 1894, after Sedding's death, by Henry Wilson. Its original function was as an industrial school run by the Sisters of Charity (an Anglican order) who were based in a building adjacent to the Church of St. Raphael in Cumberland Road. The building has a central courtyard. It is constructed of Lias rubble with limestone ashlar dressings. The main block has a two-storey, six-window range. The refectory building to the rear of the main group was designed by Henry Wilson and built in 1894. The grounds of the convent originally extended to the south-west of the main block, but the construction of St. Agnes Walk in the 1980s divided a large part of the original grounds from the convent. Within the former grounds on the western side of St. Agnes Walk is a stone shrine with the inscription "VIRGO IMMACULATA ORA PRO NOBIS 1917-1938 GRATIAS". The listing details for the convent note that within the building "many period details survive...".
A chapel to the south-west of the main block was built in 1900 and has a Grade II listing. The limestone rubble boundary wall of c.1891 surrounding the convent also has a Grade II listing.

KNOWN_AS: Cottage and garden at Red Splot Gout
MONUMENT_DESC:
A cottage and garden at Red Splot (Reed Splatt) Gout. The building was located to the south of Washingpool Lane (ST 53617 81366 approx.) and was extant by c.1810, being shown on a survey of that date. The building is recorded by the 1841 tithe assessment as a cottage and garden. The buildings are shown by the 1881 and 1915 Ordnance Survey maps.
The site (Area 1; Site 3) was visited by R. G. Jackson during the course of a desk-based assessment (SMR 20081) of areas of Bristol City Council owned land north of Avonmouth in December 1996. The plot of land was found to be extant but overgrown. No element of the building was observed above ground.
