Coal pits located some 25 metres to the north of Lodge Causeway. The pits are recorded Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.10) surveyed in 1881 as "Old Coal Pits". Two small rectangular structures were recorded, each measuring 6.5 metres by 3 metres, apparently covered each of the two pit heads. There was a large spoil or slag heap on the north-west side of the pits which was still extant by the time of the third edition plan published in 1918. The presumed pit head structres had however been removed by that date.
The site of the pit heads now lies beneath the gardens to the rear of No.295 Lodge Causeway and No.12 Woodcote Walk.

KNOWN_AS: Phoenix Chemical Works on the west side of Crews Hole Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
Phoenix Works, a chemical works located on the west side of Crew's Hole Road. The works is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.14) surveyed in 1880-81 which shows the buildings of the works grouped together on the west side of the site, on the bank of the River Avon, but no detailed indication of their functions is given.
The site of the works now lies beneath the Butler's Walk development.

A smithy on the corner of Fishponds Road and Hockey Lane was first recorded on the Stapleton Tithe Map of 1839. The accompanying apportionment lists the property as house, smith's shop and garden owned and occupied by William Daws.
A photograph of the property taken in 1973 indicates that the smithy was a single storey, rubble stone building with a pitched roof attached to the Farriers Arms (3266M). In 1973 the building was in use as Groce Garage Car Sales.
The building was subsequently demolished when Hockey's Lane was widened after 1973.

Millpond, serving Hooks Mills. The millpond appears to have been created by damming of a stream flowing down the hillside and across the line of Sevier Street. The pond may be medieval in origin but was certainly in existence by the seventeenth century. It was still in use around the end of the nineteenth century but had been filled in by the time the Blue Maids orphanage was auctioned in 1927.

KNOWN_AS: Prisoner of War Camp, Manor Road, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC:
Prisoner of War Camp, also known as the French Prison, located on the north side of Manor Road. The camp was built by the Admiralty in 1779 to hold those captured during the American War of Independence (Vintner 1956). The earliest record of the presence of the building, though not its form, is a plan, titled "Division 8th", which dates to c1779-1783 (BRO AC/PL59). The original form of the prison is recorded in an engraving by J. P. Malcolm published in May 1814 (SMR 20996). This indicates that the prison buildings were originally surrounded by high stone outer walls with four pairs of elevated sentry boxes at intervals along each side. These sentry boxes were set on a platform (probably wooden), immediately below the level of the parapet, supported by a narrow column at each corner and each was reached by a stair on its southern side. Those at the ends appear to have been exceptions since the stair runs along the adjoining wall rather than being freestanding, suggesting that the stairs were supported by cross-members set into the prison walls. There was a gate at the centre of the south wall.
The cell blocks were of three storeys with a pitched roof and were constructed of stone rubble with ashlar detailing. The blocks had an axial, E-shaped plan and a symmetrical front with a three-window central projecting block. Each main elevation had sixteen bays, each containing a plain barred window at first-floor level. There were small brick chimney stacks along the ridge of the roof and also a number of narrow rooflights.
The prison presumably stood empty until it was leased by the Bristol Guardians of the Poor as a workhouse c1831 and it was probably at this time that the outer walls were demolished. The western of the two prison blocks was demolished between 1861 and 1865 to make way for new workhouse buildings. The eastern block is extant but the interior is reported by the listing to have been remodelled in the twentieth century. It is not clear what other structures associated with the prison remain (Leech 2001).
The surviving building has a Grade II listing (901-1/30/1274). The listing details note that it is an early and important example. The only other known prison of this period and type is the Norman Cross camp at Yaxley in Cambridgeshire which operated between 1796 and 1816. The site is a Scheduled Ancient Monument survives mainly as earthworks, although the officer's quarters and part of the boundary wall are extant.

Conduit Head of Redcliffe Pipe, located to the north of Daventry Road. The conduit head encloses the spring which supplies the Redcliffe Pipe. The pipe was granted by Robert de Berkeley to the Church of St. Mary Redcliffe in the late-twelfth century and the deed of grant suggests that the conduit head was constructed around an earlier well, known as "Ruge Welle" (Hirst 1924, 359-361).
The present structure is constructed of stone rubble with an entrance door in the western side.

Bishopsworth Lodge or Bishport Lodge. Buildings on the site are first recorded by a survey of the parish of Bedminster in 1828 (BRO 32875/AC/PL/107/1). The date of the building of the lodge is unknown but the property is named as Bishport Lodge by 1832. The Lodge was located at the north side of the plot with an outbuilding to the south-west in 1841, according to the Bedminster tithe map, and one to the west by the late 1940s. A small pond lay to the east of the earliest outbuilding in the late 1940s. Air photographic evidence indicates that the Lodge had been demolished to make way for the surrounding housing development by c.1963 (BRO Picture Box 1/35 (1 & 2)). The site was subsequently landscaped to form the grounds of Elm Hays Elderly Persons Home.
A watching brief (SMR 20282) during redevelopment of the site for housing found little evidence for the Lodge and its outbuildings other than part of the foundation of a limestone rubble wall 0.6 metres wide and bonded in a white lime mortar. This was likely to have been part of the outbuilding indicated by the Bedminster tithe map. It was apparent that post-war building and landscaping had seriously affected the survival of archaeological stratification on the site and little of the lodge may be expected to survive (Brett 1995; Hume 1998).

Purdown Farm, located some 150 metres to the north-west of Sir John's Lane. The farm is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.05) published in 1881 when the farm appears to have comprised a farmhouse, measuring 17.5 metres from south-west to north-east by 8 metres wide, with a garden on its north-western side and two paddocks to the north. The farm was still extant in the late 1950s but it has since been demolished and the site redeveloped for housing. The site of the farmhouse now lies beneath the rear part of Nos.4-8 Fairacre Close.

No.21 Portland Square, located at the north-eastern corner of Portland Square. Portland Square was laid out in the late 1780s and building plots were advertised for sale from March 1790. Construction stalled, however, when the building boom collapsed in 1792 and was completed by the architect Daniel Hague in 1811 (Ison 1952, 221). No.21 is the northern house of a terrace on the eastern side of the square, Nos.18-21 Portland Square, and is a house with a double-depth plan of three storeys and attic with a slate mansard roof. The main, north-west facing elevation is of limestone ashlar. The ground floor is rusticated and the upper two floors plain. The fenestration consists of sashes. Cellars extend beneath the house and there is a basement lightwell at the front of the house and on the northern side of this smaller cellars extend under the road. During the 1860s the architect E. W. Godwin made his home at the building, and between 1863 and 1865 it also provided the office for his architectural practice (in partnership with Henry Crisp). Godwin developed an interest in interior design and was strongly influenced by Japanese domestic design. He removed many of the Georgian features of the building and implemented his own decorative scheme comprising an austere interior with oriental accessories (Soros 1999, 186). The actress Ellen Terry, who visited Godwin in the building, published a short description of this interior in her memoirs (BUAD 3937; Craig & St. John 1933, 37-38). This appears to have been the first occasion on which Godwin put his views on interior design into practice. By 1896 the building was in use as a boot factory. In the mid-twentieth century the building was entirely rebuilt behind the retained façade.
The building has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/6/1903).

No.29 Queen Square, located at the south-eastern corner of Queen Square. A lease for building was granted in 1709 and the house had been constructed by 1720 when rates were first collected on it. It is a house of three-storeys and attic with a cellar and a pantile roof. It is constructed of brick with limestone dressings.
The main, north-facing, elevation is of five bays with a central entrance door. The ground- and first-floor windows comprise sashes with alternate segmental and triangular pediments above the openings linked by a string course. Internally the entrance hall is divided by an elliptical arch leading to an open dogleg stair. The house has extensive surviving early eighteenth-century features, including panelling in the ground- and first-floor rooms. The structure which is now the Bristol Sailors Home (BUAD 1464M), to the south of the main house, formed the stables for the house, although at least some of the upper floors were probably used as warehouse space.
Between c1720 and 1750 a kitchen block was added on the west side of the courtyard and another, smaller, structure on its east side. A lean-to structure, interpreted as a "necessary" or former pantry, against exterior of the north wall built as part of the kitchen contained an oculus doorframe with an oval light above. The smaller structure on the east of the courtyard was interpreted as a possible pentice giving covered access to the stables/warehouse.
In the mid-eighteenth century, the closet wing at the south-west corner of the house was partly demolished and the line of the wall extended. A service room with a counting house to the north were built on the east side of the courtyard. On the east wall of ground-floor room of the counting house there was a fireplace with a moulded stone chimneypiece dating to the later-eighteenth century and this had a separate boiling hearth on its south side. The counting house itself was probably on the first floor and in this room panelling to dado height survives along with a contemporary cupboard in the south-west corner. There is also a chimneypiece with a moulded overmantel and shelf. The fenestration of the west-facing elevation of this block consisted of segmental-arched window openings.
During the 1850s the stable/warehouse was converted into the Bristol Sailors Home and the elevation to The Grove was reconstructed at that time (BRO 40311/B/1 fol.17; Leech 2002).
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/204).

KNOWN_AS: Three Cups and Salmon, Redcliff Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
Three Cups and Salmon Public house, No.84 Redcliff Street, located on the south side of the junction of Pile Street and Redcliff Hill. The primary elevation of the building seems to have been that fronting on to Redcliff Hill. Two tenements stood on the site in 1591 and by 1659 the "Blue Boar" tavern had been constructed. At this time it was leased to and occupied by John Birdcombe, baker.
The building dated to the seventeenth century and was a gabled house of two storeys and attic. First-floor jettied, with one bracket; full-width pentice roofs above ground and first floors. Two right-hand entrances, windows to left. One bay each to upper storeys, the lower with an Ipswich window. Signs on front to left and right of first-floor window, below which reads another: "The Three Cups & Salmon Inn & Tavern by James Fuller Dealer in Foreign Spirits".
The building was demolished in 1843 to make way for the widening of Pile Street. The site is now beneath the footway in front of St. Mary Redcliff and southern side of the Redcliffe Way.

Stokecliff Mews, Park Road, Stapleton, a former coach house for Soke Cliffe House built between c. 1800 and 1839. The earliest catographic depiction of the coach house is on the Stapleton Tithe Survey of 1839.
The coach house and stables comprises a two-storey gable fronted central section with two symmetrical single-storey flanking wings. The building is constructed in Pennant sandstone rubble with Bath stone details. Although the basic layout of the building appears to have had few alterations, all of the external doors and windows are late 19th or 20th century additions; the internal floors of the stables have also been resurfaced with concrete.

George Inn, a public house located on the southern side of East Street, Bedminster, on the west side of its junction with George's Barton. The building was a jettied, gabled single-bay house of two-storeys and attic of later seventeenth- or early eighteenth-century date. The building appears to have been constructed of coursed stone rubble, likely to have been Pennnant sandstone, and was rendered. By the early 1870s the main, north-west facing elevation of this building had a single bay and the ground floor consisted of a shopfront with a canted bay at the centre which contained a 6 by 4 pane central sash window and 3 by 4 pane sashes in the sides. On the western side of this bay was the main doorway. A pantiled pentice roof divided first- from ground-floor and there was a single bay window containing sashes at the centre of the elevation. This in turn had a pentice above it and there was another central bay window in the gable. This contained casement windows with an Ipswich window in the middle. The eaves were supported by carved wooden brackets resting on the pentice. At the northern end of the side, north-east facing, elevation there was a substantial chimney stack which projected above the level of the eaves and appears to have had an upper stage of brick. The roof was covered with clay pantiles and the rear element was probably cross-gabled (Winstone 1966, pl.78).
The building was occupied by William Northcott in 1871 but had been demolished and the site redeveloped by 1883 to enable the creation of Church Road. The site of the building now lies entirely beneath the western side of Church Road.

Woodland House, Church Parade, Brislington. The house is located on the corner of Church Hill and Church Parade on the northern side of the historic village square. The house dates from the Georgian period and is built in the classic Georgian style. It has five bays with a central front door with a pediment over supported by two columns. The fenestration comprises six over six sash windows. A two storey coach house previously adjoined the main house on the western side but was demolished in the early nineteenth century when Church Hill was widened.
In 1751, Woodland  House was recorded as the George Inn. It was sold in 1796 when a Charles Hill is recorded as living there. By c.1800 a Mr. Hare was the owner and may have added the extant Georgian façade. The Brislington Tithe Survey of 1846 records John Tompkins as the owner and Mary Evans as the occupier. Following the death of Walter Butt, the owner from 1920s, the property was taken over by the Army and a tank regiment was stationed there during the early part of World War II. In 1943, Alfred Parry purchased the house and lived there until his death in 1983. The house was subsequently converted into flats.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building no. 901-1/49/460).

Grove House,  also known as The Grove, located on the east side of Grove Road, Brislington. Grove House and garden occupied an area that was bounded by Bristol Hill, Grove Park and Montrose Park. The house is extant but the grounds have been built on and are now covered by housing on the southern side of Montrose Park, on the northern side of Bristol Hill and Grove Park Avenue.
The house was purchased by Richard Ricketts in 1799 from William Fry after Fry became bankrupt. On his death in 1818, the estate passed to his nephew Henry Ricketts, head of the Flint Glass Works at Temple Gate, and he was recorded as being the owner by the Brislington Tithe Survey of 1846. He died there in 1859, and the house remained in the Ricketts family until 1865 when it was sold to Mr. Cripps who died in 1899.
The estate was broken up and the grounds were subsequently developed for housing. The house became a children's home until it was purchased in 1909 by Brislington Congregational Church who had built their church nearby at the corner of Grove Park and Montrose Park. The Ordnance Survey County Series plan published in 1916 indicates that the grounds had been completely built over and the coach house had been converted into a laundry. The house itself became a private school until 1929. In 1978, the United Reform Church sold the property and there were plans to convert the property into flats.
The carriage entrance to the house was in Wick Lane, with smaller gates on Bristol Hill for tradespeople. The walls, gates and railings are constructed of ashlar and pennant rubble with wrought-iron railings and date to the early-nineteenth century. They have a Grade II listed (Listed Building no. 901-1/48/462).

KNOWN_AS: Picture house at Stapleton Road, Easton
MONUMENT_DESC:
Picture house located on the north-west side of Stapleton Road, Easton. The cinema was opened in 1911 as His Majesty's with seating for 800 (Anderson, 1983, 22). First recorded by the Ordnance Survey third edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.09). The cinema was rebuilt in 1934 by Hyatt and Neale, Bristol to designs by W.H. Watkins at the request of George Allen of the Eastville Hippodrome Company (Ewins 1984, 29). The building was converted to half bingo hall/half cinema and renamed the Concorde in 1969 (Ewins 1984, 29).
The building is extant.

No.79 Sea Mills Lane was in existence by the early 1770s and was recorded by a plan of the Southwell estate of 1772.
It was recorded in a painting by Joseph Walter of 1844 as a three-storey, two-bay house with a pitched roof and double-flue chimney stacks at either end of the roof. The northern bay of the main, north-west facing, elevation had a two-storey projecting bay with sash windows in each of its three faces. The remainder of the fenestration consisted of sashes. A wall projected from the north corner of the elevation to mark off the north-east side of the front garden. The side, north-east facing, elevation was plain except for a projecting feature on its eastern end which had a single sash window at second floor.

A garden house on the plot of No.19 Kingsdown Parade. The house was in existence by the early 1740s and stood at the south-eastern corner of a walled garden extending from Kingsdown Parade to the road to the north. It was recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 map of Bristol and was probably a merchant's garden house or lodge (ie. second residence). The building measured 8.5 metres from south-east to north-west and was 7 metres wide. It had been apparently been demolished by 1828.

A Smithy on the south side of Kennel Lodge Road was constructed in the early nineteenth century and the first cartographic depiction of the structure is on an estate plan of 1826 (BRO AC/PL/105) and an accompanying set of record cards lists the plot as (413) "Smiths Shop & Yard".
The building was a single storey rubble construction with gable ends. Archaeological building recording in 2009 (Bryant and Ducker, 2009) identified that the smithy had been built against the roadside of an earlier boundary wall constructed of Brandon Hill grit bonded with a brownish mortar. The gable end walls of the smithy abutted this boundary wall.
The smithy contained a gabled internal cross wall that also abutted the earlier boundary wall.
The walls of the smithy were constructed with Carboniferous Limestone with some Brandon Hil Grit and, Pennant sandstone.

Milking Parlour on the south side of Kennel Lodge Road. Built in the mid nineteenth century the building was first cartographically depicted on an estate plan dated 1865 (BRO AC/PL/126), although the term Milking Parlour was not in use until the twentieth century and the building may have originally been a 'cowhouse' (Bryant and Ducker, 2009, 4).
The building is a long and narrow structure (23.5m by 5m) that utilised an existing Brandon Hill Grit rubble wall for its northern wall. The remaining three walls were constructed in squared pennant sandstone rubble with freestone dressings bonded with off-white mortar. The south facing façade was built in a neo-Tudor style with 4-bays, each bay comprising a central doorway with a square-headed window to each side. Internal walls created four connected rooms. These internal walls were constructed in red brick with bullnose bricks to all openings. The flooring was bunched Pennant flagstones. At each end of the building was a gable containing a ventilation slit and the roof was originally slate.
At some point a small room at the east end of the structure was partitioned off, possibly to create a dairy, and a small single room extension with pan-tiled pitched roof added to the west end of the building. The small extension was constructed with squared Pennant sandstone with brick dressings bonded with black mortar.
The building was recorded in 2009 prior to conversion for accomodation.

KNOWN_AS: Boundary stone at Lockleaze School, Hogarth Walk, Lockleaze
MONUMENT_DESC:
A boundary stone located on the north side of Lockleaze School. The precise position of the stone is not clear, but it is recorded by the Ordnance Survey third edition County Series 1:2500-scale plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.05) published in 1916 and this suggests it was sited on the field boundary at the north-west corner of a field named Lockleaze, adjacent to a footpath which followed the east side of the field.
The stone was carved from a single block of Pennant Sandstone with an angled top. It stood 2.03 metres high, although the lowest 0.6 metres was set in the ground and had a rectangular section measuring 0.32 by 0.21 metres. On one side there was a narrow recess 0.67 metres long, 0.1 metres wide and 0.05 metres deep. The function of this feature was not certain, however.
The stone was pulled out of its position, probably when Lockleaze School was built, and is now lying approximately South-east to north-west along the line of ditch metres to the (Andrew Buchan pers. comm.).

Seamills Farm, located some 230 metres to the west of the River Trym. The date of the farmhouse is currently unknown but it was extant in 1772 when it was part of the Southwell estate. By the time of the Henbury tithe survey of 1840 it was owned by Philip Miles and occupied by George Webb Hall. The Ordnance Survey first edition County Series 1:2500-scale plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.07) published in 1885 also records the farm and shows a number of outbuildings surrounding the farmhouse. The farmhouse itself appears to survive as Sea Mills House, although the sites of the yard and ancillary buildings have been redeveoloped for housing.

Manor House, located on the south side of York Place. The building had been constructed by 1738 when a lease to Jane Phippen, widow of Whitchurch Phippen the younger, recorded it as newly erected by Whitchurch Phippen. Some of the original internal features survive at first and second floor level.
The house was occupied by the anthropologist John Beddoe until 1891. The building then became a school for preparing gentlemen for the colonial civil service examination and was substantially altered in 1891. Most of the present internal woodwork dates to that phase of works.
In the 1890s the house became an establishment preparing young gentlemen for colonial civil service, army and navy entrance. The school closed in 1915, and for the remainder of the Fisrst World War the building provided temporary accomodation for Red Maids' School while the school buildings were used as a Red Cross Hospital.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/9/887).

KNOWN_AS: Shirehampton National Schools, Station Road, Shirehampton
MONUMENT_DESC: Shirehampton National Schools, located on the eastern side of Station Road, Shirehampton. The site was granted by Philip John Miles of the Kingsweston Estate in the mid-1840s for the establishment of a "National School" (BRO 11054(32)). The school seems to have been built in the mid-1840s, apparently to a design by the architect Henry Rumley. Rumley's initial scheme of 1847 (BRO 222638(36)) does not appear to have been implemented but a school was probably in existence on the site soon afterwards. As built the school was a single-storey structure of coursed sandstone rubble, with Perpendicular Gothic ashlar details and a pitched roof. There was apparently a lantern at the northern end of the roof and a projecting chimneypiece at the centre of the roof. By January 1861 a new schoolroom had been added to the building (BRO P/St.MS/Sch/2(3)). The internal plan consisted of classrooms for the mixed school on the northern and southern sides of the entrance of Station Road, the southern being a large L-shaped space. There was an infants classroom behind these rooms and two pairs of toilets attached to the exterior of the north and east sides of the building. A new extension, designed by P. J. Byrne, was constructed at the southern end of the building in 1892 (BRO P/St.MS/Sch/2(6)). This matched the scale, style and materials of the original school. The school was apparently badly damaged by the explosion of a bomb close by on 29 March 1941 (Etheridge 2006, 13). The school was closed in the second half of the twentieth century and by 1972 was listed in local street directories as the Shirehampton Social Club. A café was added to the northern end of the building and the remainder had become a snooker hall by the end of the twentieth century.

Hospital of St. Katherine or Catherine, located on the western side of East Street, Bedminster. The hospital was founded by Robert de Berkeley (d.1219) "for a master and several brethren who should tend the sick and infirm and the needy traveller." The hospital was not monastic and the wardenship could be held with another benefice. The bretheren wore the same clothing as secular priests with the wheel of St. Katherine on the left breast (Scott Holmes 1914, lvi-lvii).
There would appear to have been some problem with the administration of the hospital in 1324-1325 when the register of Bishop Drokensford records that a visitand was commissioned to audit the accounts of the, then master, remove him, and appoint a brother from St. John's Hospital at Redcliff Hill as guardian (Hobhouse 1887, 239).
The form of the hospital is currently uncertain. Currently direct evidence comes mainly from William Worcestre who, in 1480, recorded the nave of the chapel as measuring approximately 16 yards long by 7 1/2 yards wide. The chancel was roughly 9 yards long by 5 1/2 yards wide" (Neale 2000, 280-281). Worcester also indicates that there was a cross associated with the hospital (Neale 2000, 94-97).
The churchwardens accounts of All Saints parish for 1525-1526 record 4d. paid "to the lazar house at Bright Bowe in bread" (Burgess 2000, 325) but it is not clear whether the hospital had by then essentially become a leper hospital. By 1548 there were no inmates in the hospital (Green 1888). The hospital survived into the middle of the reign of Elizabeth I, the last recorded master, F. Nevil, being appointed in 1573.
By 1791 the buildings had been converted to dwellings and the only surviving element was the east end of the chapel where there was a blocked Gothic window (Collinson 1791, 282). These features were apparently demolished in 1887 to make way for construction of a new tobacco factory for W. O. & H. D. Wills (SMR 5494), although Scott Holmes seems to state that at least part of the east end of the chapel was extant when he was writing on the history of the hospital at the beginning of the twentieth century (Scott Holmes in Page 1911, 153).

Bishop's Knoll House. The land was granted to Ralph Sadleir at the Reformation and passed into the hands of the Jackson family c.1650. The estate was held together by terms of will until 1853 when an act of Parliament (the Martin's Estate Act) set aside the terms of the will. Large villas were built in the following thirty years, including the house known as Bishop's Knoll in 1874 for Peter D. Prankerd.  In the villa had extensive gardens, including fruit and vegetable gardens, greenhouses, orchards and a dairy. The building had passed into the hands of the Bush family by the beginning of the twentieth-century. Robert Bush converted the building into a 100-bed hospital for wounded Australian during the First World War. The house was used to house evacuated industrial concerns during the Second World War and was taken over by Bristol Royal Infirmary as a hostel and training school for nurses. The building was demolished in 1972.
There are photographs of the building in the SMR collection of ground-based photographs. The surrounding gardens (2200M) survive.

Hill Cottage, 47 Brislington Hill, Brislington.  In 1660 the owner was recorded as William Newman, a blacksmith, who owned the property now called Hill Cottage as well as lands around the house on either side of the main road.  Parts of the house probably date from this period.  By 1751, the estate had had several different owners, including Jeremiah Pearce, a Bristol sea-captain.  His son, sold the estate in 1751 to John Newman which also comprised the present Church Hill House. The house eventually became part of the Clayfield-Ireland estate, and in 1837 a school was being run from the premises (Ireland, 1870: BRO St.LB/HM/1a & 1b). In the mid-19th century the house was enlarged. In 1884 David Cox Sherwell was recorded as the tenant, and in 1924, when the Clayfield-Ireland estate was being broken up, he purchased Hill Cottage and the next door property of Keeper's Cottage. In 1984, Avon County Council purchased the property which was resold in 1985 to a private purchaser.
The two-storey cottage is of rendered rubble with a pantile roof with brick end and ridge stacks. It has three window bays with pane sash windows. The cottage is grade II listed (Listed Building no. 901-1/49/447).

The Metropole Cinema on the north side of Ashley Road. The cinema opened in 1913. It was extensively remodelled by Hyatt and Neale, Bristol to a design by W.H. Watkins for George Allen of the Eastville Hippodrome Company in 1938 (Ewins 1984, 29) and reopened as the Metropole de Luxe with 1460 seats (Anderson 1983, 36). The Metropole de Luxe had shops either side of the brick tower entrance and made extensive use of coloured lights as the Bristol Evening Post of 7th October 1935 reported, "Another notable piece of equipment is the electrical arrangement for diffusing lights of all the colours of the rainbow. Alluring light effects are obtainable by the infinite variety of colours which the equipment can present. They are particularly charming in the contrast or harmony with the decorative scheme of the cinema itself," (Ewins 1984, 22).
The building was converted into a bingo hall in 1968 and then became a cinema again showing Indian films (Ewins 1984, 29).
The building was demolished in 1990 and is now the site of Ashley Court flats.

The Portview Picture Theatre located on the south west side of Portview Road, Avonmouth. The cinema opened in 1912 as The Words Picture Theatre which is recorded at ST 51808 77859 by the second edition 1:2500 Ordnance Survey plan (Gloucestershire sheet LXXI.01) published in 1916. The cinema closed in 1940 (Anderson 1983, 57).

Park Farm, located on the north side of Parklands Road. The farmhouse is of early nineteenth century date and is a two-storey building with an "L-shaped", double-depth plan. The building is rendered with limestone dressings and has a pantile roof. It building has been converted to two attached buildings and the listing description reports that the interior of the building has largely been remodelled.
The farmhouse has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/44/418).

No.52 Redcliff Street, located on the south side of the junction of Three Queens Lane and Redcliff Street. 
The building was constructed in the seventeenth century, apparently as one of a pair with No.53 Redcliff Street (BUAD 1445M). The entrance to the building was on the north-facing elevation in Three Queens Lane.
The land parcel, defined by Redcliff Street, Three Queens Lane and the lawditch on the west side, belonged to the Dean and Chapter of Bristol Cathedral in 1661 and an inn or tavern known as "the signe of the George" leased to a tailor named Henry Hitchens then stood on the site (BRO DC/E/40/37/52064). Hitchens's lease was surrendered in 1672 and a new lease taken for 40 years by John Jones, sergeant-at-mace who was contractually bound to spend £100 on building works (BRO DC/E/40/37/52070). By 1714 the building had been converted to three tenements. A malthouse with three cellars beneath had also been built to the rear by 1746 along with a new dwelling, with an associated pigsty, behind the malthouse (BRO DC/E/40/37/52101). By 1798 the building had become The Plume of Feathers public house, kept by Charles Selby. A lease of 1775 indicates that the number of tenements had by then been reduced to two, and that the malthouse was occupied by Thomas Cole, victualler, while the three cellars were leased by Arthur Moreton, carpenter. The dwelling belonged to David Barron (BRO DC/E/40/37/52108). The tenant of The Plume of Feathers was John Box by 1826 when the building was recorded in a watercolour drawing by T. L. Rowbotham (BUAD 967; BRSMG M2042). This view shows the structure as a single-bay jettied, gabled house of three storeys and attic which is likely to have been the structure built by John Jones in the 1670s. The building was still apparently extant in the mid-1850s, but it had been demolished by the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.5) surveyed in 1882 and the site redeveloped. The site of the building now lies partly beneath the highway in Three Queens Lane and Redcliff Street, but the south-east part of the footprint is on the site of modern No.54 Redcliff Street.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: Bristol Royal Infirmary, Upper Maudlin Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
New Jerusalem Church, located on the northern side of Terrell Street. The Bristol Society of the Swedenborgian or New Church was founded in 1792. The earliest church established by the Society in Bristol was never licensed, and was replaced by a new building in Silver Street in 1819. This was adjacent to the Bridewell Police Station and closed due to falling numbers in the congregation in the late 1820s. It was destroyed by fire during the Bristol Riots of 1831. In 1845, the Bristol Society was revived, meeting close to what is now the Colston Hall, maybe at Lodge Street Chapel (built by the Countess of Huntingdon Connexion), and later at premises close to The Triangle, Clifton, and the Odd Fellows Hall in Rupert Street.
The Terrell Street church opened on 7th April 1878. It was built of iron, with small gothic windows. After some years a stone façade was added. The building was recorded by the first edition Ordnance Survey 1:500 Town plan surveyed in 1883 which notes that it had seating for 120 worshippers. The Bristol Royal Infirmary purchased the building in 1898 but allowed services to continue there for a time until a new church was built elsewhere in the city. The church had been demolished by the beginning of the twentieth century.

Brandon Hill, reputed to be the oldest public park in Bristol being originally granted to the Bristol Corporation by Robert, Earl of Gloucester in 1174. Four acres at the summit of the hill were granted to the Abbey of Tewkesbury and a small chapel dedicated to St Brandon was built there so time prior to 1193 (1028M).
In 1581 the Corporation paid the Crown £30 for these remaining four acres at the summit of the hill.
Brandon Hill became known for the traditional rights for people to dry their clothes there and beat out their rugs (only between the hours of 6am and 9pm).
During the Civil War (1642-46) substantial defences were erected on the hill and where these earthworks and fortifications survive these are protected as Scheduled Monuments.
Following the continual encroachment of residential developments around the hill a subscription fund was started to pay for landscaping works in the park including walks and walls to enable the preservation of the landscape. Eight hundred pounds were raised for these works.
In 1857 some captured Russian guns were placed at the top of the hill before being replaced in 1897-8 by the erection of Cabot Tower, designed by W.V. Gough.
In 1936-7 further landscaping was undertaken to create water gardens with pools and cascades on the slopes below the tower.
In 1949-50 a heather garden was created at the base of the tower.

Passage Leaze Garden Suburb, Shirehampton. This was the first attempt to introduce garden suburb principles for a new development in Bristol. By the time of the 1:2500 Ordnance Survey plan published in 1915 the roads Passage Leaze, Grove Leaze, North Grove Leaze and South Grove Leaze had been laid out and several semi detached and short terraced properties had been constructed, however, the property developer went bust before the scheme was completed and following the First World War North Grove Leaze and South Grove Leaze were amalgamated to a single extension of Grove Leaze.
The original semi detached properties on the north and south west side of the junction of Passage Leaze and Grove Leaze are extant as are nos.2-18 and 1-19 Passage Leaze and 1-3 and 48-50 Church Leaze.

Kingsweston Roman Villa, now located on the southern side of Long Cross. The villa was discovered in November 1947 during the construction of a housing estate at Lawrence Weston, at the foot of the northern slope of Pen Pole, on the dryland margin of the North Avon levels. When identified the northern part of the villa had already been removed by the construction of the new road. The surviving part was excavated in 1948 under the direction of George Boon and John Clevedon Brown for the City of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery (SMR 20179; Anon 1949, 108).
The villa was probably constructed towards the end of the Third century in c270AD, a date inferred from a coin of Claudius II (268-270AD) found within one of the original walls. It was constructed using locally quarried stone in a rubble construction and the external walls were covered with white or pink stucco or render. Fragments of window glass were recovered during excaavtion, implying that the building had glazed windows. The villa was orientated from east-north-east to west-south-west and in plan it a had an enclosed rectangular gravel court at the centre. On the south side of the court there was a porticus, an open flagstone walkway with a roof supported on free-standing columns, and on either side a wing of rooms. Those on the west side appear to have been living accommodation, the two surviving rooms both having mosaic floors. The eastern wing consisted of a bath suite with a hypocaust.
The villa appears to have been in use until the mid-Fourth century and may have been abandoned as a result of raiding along the Severn as Roman power declined. A number of local villas seem to have been attacked in period, especially around 367-368 AD.
Finds from the excavation included a hoard of six coins dating between 330AD and 337AD, discovered in Room IV. An Iron Age Dobunnic silver quarter stater was also found in the south wall of Room VIII. (Boon 1950). Two inhumations were excavated within the building, one with two sword cuts on the skull (Boon 1993).
The villa was conserved and is now one of the museums of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery. It is a Scheduled Ancient Monument (AV87).

Whitwood Mill, Stapleton, also known as Snuff Mills Park and Stapleton Mill, located on the northern bank of the river Frome, some 300 metres to the east of Frome Bridge. The mill was in existence by the early-seventeenth century and is recorded by a map of Kingswood of 1610. By the 1770s the mill was owned by Thomas Bridgman and was known as Bridgman's Mill. It remained in the hands of the family until c1823 when it was taken over by Charles Hopkins. Hopkins had been declared bankrupt by 1843. In 1846 the mill became the property of Thomas Jones junior. Jones died in 1848 and the mill was subsequently leased to Josiah Bell, who ran it until the early twentieth century. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucester Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882 names the mill as Stapleton Mill and indicates that it was a flour mill at that date but by 1902 the mill was disused.
The mill was a single storey structure with an undershot wheel, boiler and chimney. In 1899 the machinery comprised "a 12 Horse-Power Water Wheel, three pairs of stones, Oat, Malt and Bean crusher and Dressing Mill" (quoted in Ward 1969, 24). The dwelling house was extant by the time of the tithe survey in 1839, and lay immediately to the west of the mill.
Elements of the mill survive. The mill has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/30/1971).

KNOWN_AS: Clift House or Redcliffe House, Ashton
MONUMENT_DESC: Clift House, also known as Redcliffe House. The house was constructed sometime before 1828 when it formed an L-shaped block with a series of outbuildings and a large kitchen garden with a tree lined entrance (this line is preserved in the present Frayne Road) with lodges at either end (built between 1828 and 1886). It was initially known as redcliffe House but had become known as Clift House by the 1880s. The house was similar at this stage but the grounds had been considerably altered with much tree planting. It had become the Clift Hill Diptheria Hospital by 1904. The building had been demolished by 1919 when the Warehouse Tobacco Bond C was constructed on part of the site.

Southmead Quarries, located on the north side of Southmead Road. The complex of quarries was aligned from south-west to north-east was approximately 700 metres long in 1881 when it was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.08). At that date limekilns stood at the southern end of the quarry (SMR 3932) and the middle. Another kiln had been constructed at the south end of the quarry (at ST 57966 77257), some 36 metres to the east of the earlier structure. The southern part of the quarry has been infilled and the site redeveloped for housing while the northern end is used as Henleaze Bathing Lake.

H. M. Factory, Avonmouth, located on the eastern side of St. Andrew's Road. The factory seems initially to have been established to manufacture the high explosive picric acid. In October 1917 a factory, National Filling Factory No.23 (SMR 21403), had been opened at Chittening to manufacture the blister agent mustard gas (sulphur mustard - 1,1-thiobis(2-chloroethane)) in response to German use of the weapon in the early stages of the Third Battle of Ypres (Passchendaele). Work ceased at Chittening in April 1918 and production was moved to the Avonmouth factory which was converted and extended between May and early June 1918, using equipment originally made for Chittening.
Initially the factory used the Guthrie high temperature process and the first batch was produced on 15 June. By the end of June 3.5 tonnes of the gas had been manufactured but this production yield was too low. French scientists were approached for advice and recommended adoption of the Levinstein low temperature method. The reaction temperature was reduced to 40 degrees Centigrade in the first half of July and this resulted in improved yields. However, the ethylene unit required complete overhaul in the second half of the month and this resulted in the shutting down of the entire plant. The first acceptable batch of the chemical was produced on 15 August 1918 (Haber 1986, 165-166; Hartcup 1988, 109) but production levels remained low until September 1918.
The factory was operational for around six months and had a workforce of 1100. An existing short section of railway was brought into passenger use and the St. Andrew's Road station (SMR 5042) was opened in May 1917 to bring workers to the site. The dangers inherent with the handling of the chemical coupled with the use of porous materials, such as wood and brick, in the construction of the plant led to a high rate of injury amongst the workforce. This was exacerbated by the fact that the factory was still under construction when manufacture began, resulting in "trying conditions for the workers" (Anon. 1919, 81). Between 15 June and 15 December 1400 gas casualties were recorded at the Avonmouth factory (Haber 1986, 249) including three fatalities. Around 700 workers were affected, "some of whom had three or four attacks," and the sickness resulting included "blisters on every part of the body (except the palms of the hands), conjunctivitis, bronchitis, etc., and chronic effects of debility, cough, gastric pain and breathlessness" (Anon. 1919, 81). The Avonmouth factory ceased production at 8:00pm on 11 November 1918. In all, the factory produced 560 tons of mustard gas, and 416 tons of this were deemed acceptable for shell filling (Haber 1986, 166).
The layout of the factory is currently uncertain but most of the original factory buildings appear to have been demolished. However, the administration building of the factory is extant. This is a two-storey brick structure with ashlar quoins. The building is orientated north south and has an H-shaped plan. The main element of the building has a central porch with a single doorway with ashlar detailing, including a pediment. It has a hipped roof with tall square projecting brick chimneystacks. There are a number of other surviving structures, including sheds, which may have been associated with the factory. There are also known to have been several reactors and the site was served by an internal electric railway. Three of the battery-powered locomotives were acquired by the Hythe Pier Railway (one being used for spares) where they still operate.

Rock Cottage, located on the west side of West Street, Bedminster. The building is a rendered three-storey house with a pitched pantile roof and was probably constructed in the late-eighteenth or early-nineteenth century. The building was recorded by the Bedminster tithe survey of 1841 (BRO EP/A/32/8). The building was refurbished in 1991.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/55/391). There is a photograph of the building in the SMR Collection of Ground-based photographs, number 1862.

Obelisk at Bowness Gardens, Southmead. In June 2002 Michael Fairfax was commissioned by the Bristol City Archaeologist, R. H. Jones, to produce an artwork to mark the site of the Bronze Age round barrow on the northern side of Bowness Gardens. Fairfax designed an obelisk, a pyramid of brushed stainless steel which tapered to a rounded point. The piece was 2.0 metres tall, 0.64 metres wide and 0.25 metres thick. The upper 0.25 metres of the obelisk is mirror-polished and beneath, on the south-east face, there is a circle comprising 23 mirror-polished lines which radiate from an indented central hole 30 millimetres in diameter. A text written by Fairfax laser-cut into the surface runs downwards from the circle and furls into a spiral towards the base. The text reads "At Badocks wood ghostly windmill sails turn and like a rewound film spin through history to remote times when this was a burial place for a bronze age warrior. In that past landscape wolves prowled and nervy deer grazed while wild hog rooted among trees."
The obelisk was installed on 19 February 2003, the commissioning and installation process costing £8000 in all. It was unveiled by Peter Hammond, the one of the Councillors for the Southmead Ward, on 20 February 2003.

Ashley Cottage, located on the northern side of Ashley Road. The building is a house of late seventeenth- or early eighteenth-century date and was in existence by 1759 when it is recorded by a plan of the Ashley Road area made in 1759 by William Lewellin (BRO 4964(25)). This indicates the building was on the eastern side of a large garden plot and was of irregular plan. By the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.1) surveyed in 1883 the building was known as Elm Villa. It had a probable glass conservatory on its western end. The garden plot had a formal layout, including a pond some nine metres to the north-west of the house (now beneath the rear part of No.73 Ashley Road at ST 59376 74217).
The building is of Pennant sandstone rubble construction and has undergone a complex history of change, including internal alterations in 1999. The listing description notes that some original roof timbers are reported to survive in the roof.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/36/1867).

KNOWN_AS: Church of St. John the Baptist, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC:
The Church of St. John the Baptist at Bedminster. The church was probably founded before 1066, although the exact date is unknown, and it is commonly assumed, on the basis of the placename evidence, to have an origin as a minster church. It may perhaps also have been the centre of a large estate (Costen 1992, 71). The church lay at the northern boundary of the diocese of Salisbury (and later Bath and Wells) and consequently was the mother church to Abbots Leigh and to St. Mary Redcliffe and St. Thomas the Martyr in Redcliffe.
St. John is reported, along with other buildings in Bedminster, to have been burnt by Prince Rupert's troops as they retreated from Bristol in 1645. In January 1651/2 the parish entered a plea at the Quarter Sessions for assistance in raising the estimated £3500 pounds which repair of the church would cost (SMR 20351; Bates Harbin 1912, 202). The rebuilt church is recorded in watercolours in the Braikenridge Collection, Bristol Museum and Art Gallery and in a watercolour executed by John Chessell Buckler in 1827 in The Piggott Collection. It was also described in February 1849 by Sir Stephen Glynne (SMR 882) as a "plain church, comprising a nave with north aisle, chancel, west tower and north porch" which had Early English, Decorated and Perpendicular Gothic features (McGarvie 1994, 34-35).
St. John was demolished again in 1853 to allow the building of a new church. This was designed by John Norton and was completed in 1855 (Dawson 1981, 21).
The church was gutted as a result of bombing in 1941. The rebuilding was delayed and a decision not to rebuild the church was taken in 1954. The remains of the church were cleared in 1966 and Bristol City Council bought the churchyard in 1973 (Crossley-Evans 2000, 80).
The churchyard was surveyed in 1980 by the Action Group for Bristol Archaeology in advance of clearance of the memorials for the creation of a public open space from the cemetery (Dawson in Thomas 1979), with additional information being recorded subsequently by Williams (1981). The state of the archaeological stratification on the site is unknown but deposits of high quality are very likely to survive. Dawson (1981) suggested that the site was worthy of designation as a Scheduled Ancient Monument.

Harley Lodge, located on the north side of Clifton Lodge. The date at which the buildign was consructed is unknowbn but it was in existence by the mid-1740s and is recorded by de Wilstar's survey of the Manor of Clifton of 1746. The form of the building is unclear but there is evidence for an eighteenth-century detached kitchen to the rear.
The house was heavily altered in the early-nineteenth century.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/7/805).

Rock House, built c.1881 for Isaac Britton and first depicted on the 1888 Ordnance Survey plan. The building was a two storey, single-pile, Pennant sandstone building with limestone reveals including moulded details on the front elevation, round headed openings on north and south elevations and a hipped pan tile roof. 
Originally the buildign had an 'L' shape plan with the main element of the house aligned north south a main entrance facing a large formal garden to the east and a rear east-west wing.
The building was inspected during the course of an archaeological desk-based assessment when it was noted that it was in a very "dilapidated state". The building was subsequently demolished for redevelopment of the site.

Mortimer House on the east side of Clifton Down Road. The house was built in c.1750 and consists of three storeys and a basement. It is a 9 window range constructed of Limestone ashlar with gable chimney stacks.
The house was part of the development, along with the neighbouring Rodney Lodge and Duncan House, of 'Holly Lands' first recorded in a survey of the smaller manor of Clifton dated 1625 (BRO 32835) and depicted on Jacob de Wilstar's survey of the Manor of Clifton, 1746, at which time the land was in the ownership of Francis Freeman (Leech, 2008, 15). By 1750 the land appears to have been sold to Isaac Elton for the purpose of constructing a new dwelling probably in accordance with a covenant with Francis Freeman drawn up to ensure that all the properties built along Clifton Down Road were of similar proportion and style (ibid., 16). Sketchley's Directory of 1775 records Elton, Isaac, Esq., alderman as the occupier. Ashmead's map of 1828 records that the building had been extended to the south by the addition of a small house abutting the main building. This plan also shows a carriage way at the front of the house and a long garden to the rear with terrace walk.
The house was sold at auction by the Elton family in 1876. The Ordnance Survey plan of 1884 depicts the house with outbuildings to the rear. The property was further extended in 1895 with the addition of a 'Refectory' at which time the house appears to have been used as a school (BRO Building Plans, vol.31, fol.45) and extended again in 1900 (BRO Building Plans, vol.38, fol.63) and 1906 (BRO Building Plans, vol.38, fol.63).

Nurses's Home to the rear of the St Michaels Hill Hospital for Sick Children. Four storey brick building with ashlar door surround on main entrance in east elevation and ashlar string courses and slate tiled mansard roof with dormer windows. Windows on ground, first and second floor have twelve pane sashes. South elevation has arched crittal french doors and fan light with ashlar arch over. The building was constructed c.1933 with a lecture room added in 1948 to the north side of the building (Townsend, 2007, 5), this latter being removed prior to the creation of new University buildings on Tyndall Avenue in 2002.

Henbury Station. The station opened on 9 May 1910 and consisted of an eastbound and westbound platform with a single-storey brick waiting room on each. To the east of the passenger station there was a goods yard which included a small number of cattle pens (at ST 5691679733). The station was closed to passenger use on 22 March 1915 and a second track was added to create a double line. On 10 July 1922 the station reopened for passenger traffic and it continued to operate as a passenger station into the early 1960s. The station was closed to passengers on 23 November 1964 and was closed completely on 5 July 1965 (Mitchell & Smith 2004; Oakley 1983).
The northern platform and waiting room were subsequently demolished but the platform and waiting room on the southern side was still extant in 2004.

A Pennant sandstone quarry at Rock, Brislington first depicted on the Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire sheet LXXVI.02) published in 1889. Subsequent Ordnance Survey plans do not mark the quarry suggesting that it went out of use in the 1890s or early in the twentieth century. The 1889 plan shows several trees in and around the quarry suggesting that it was already disused or going out of use.
The quarry is still extant partially within the garden of No.13 Millbank Close and to the rear of modern garages. Several structures possibly associated with the quarry are also shown on the 1889 plan and the earlier tithe map suggesting that the quarry was in use for at least the majority of the nineteenth century. Some of these structures are also still extant, although their original functions are unknown.

KNOWN_AS: Anti-Aircraft Battery, west of Rockingham Farm
MONUMENT_DESC:
A heavy anti-aircraft battery to the west of Rockingham Farm. The battery lay a short distance inland from the coast and occupied a roughly rectangular site of just over 4.8 hectares, between the north-west side of St. Andrews Road and the railway. The site was operational from February 1940 until the end of the Second World War and formed part of the Bristol Gun-Defended Area (GDA). The site was initially manned by 206th Heavy Anti Aircraft Regiment, Royal Artillery which had been replaced by 98th Heavy Anti Aircraft Regiment (Territorial) by November 1939.
The battery was laid out with four octagonal gun emplacements arranged around a central command post, which was unusual in comprising three separate structures. The magazine was sited on the north-west side and stands roughly 2.5 metres high. It is partially sunken and is protected by earth banks. Internally there are five rooms served by a corridor. The ancillary buildings - barracks, sick bay, stores etc. - lay just to the south-east, on the north-east and south-west sides of the access road which led into the site from St. Andrews Road to the east. The 98 HAA Regiment war diary for 9 November indicates flooding problems from heavy rain, recording that the mud on the site was nine inches deep. "Drainage ditches are full to overflowing as the drainage system connecting with the sea sluices has fallen into bad repair."
The battery was initially equipped with four 3.7 inch Mark I static guns. However it had been re-equipped with four 4.5 inch guns by May 1941 (John Hellis pers. comm.) and had GL Mark II radar (which came into service in Spring 1941 and could detect approaching aircraft at a distance of around 30 miles) by June 1942. A short account together with a photograph of the emplacement in action was published in 1943 (Anon 1943, 44). The latter enhancement may have been the result of a Prime Ministerial directive of 27 February 1941 which gave priority to the defence of shipping during the Battle of the Atlantic (Dobinson 2001, 292). The radar mat appears to have been circular rather than octagonal and smaller than the usual diameter of 130 yards (Dobinson 2001). An earthwork visible on a 1946 vertical air photograph (CPE-UK-1869 3016) which probably represents the location of the mat (at ST 52342 80707) measured only 46 yards (42.2 metres) across. By May 1944 the 4.5 inch guns had been replaced with 3.7 inch Mark II guns. The latest reference found to the site found by Dobinson dates to January 1946, suggesting that the battery was decommissioned later in that year (Dobinson 1996, 329).
Most of the ancillary buildings appear to have been demolished by the beginning of December 1946 but the gun emplacements, the command post and the magazine are extant. The site is overgrown and there is some damage to the emplacements and the magazine (SMR 21552). The site is a Scheduled Ancient Monument (SAM number AV 28885).

KNOWN_AS: Shirehampton Camp at Shirehampton Road, Shirehampton
MONUMENT_DESC:
Shirehampton camp. The camp was probably established in late 1942 or early 1943 and covered the eastern half of Shirehampton golf course and the site of Portway Community School. The camp appears to have consisted of a a series of timber barracks huts and other storage buildings set on raised piles.
The U. S. Army was racially-segregated through much of the Second World War with African-American troops organised into separate units before late 1944. Most of these, including the units stationed at Shirehampton, were employed in logistical or support roles until manpower shortages during the Battle of the Bulge in December 1944 pushed commanders to start the process of integration. The 517th Port Battalion, Transportation Corps (now 14th Transportation Battalion) was activated at Shirehampton on 4 June 1943. By August 1944 542 Port Company and 543 Port Company (Transportation Corps), United States Army were stationed there and by December 1944 had been replaced by 648 Port Company.  The eastern half of the camp was re-incorporated into the golf course after the war and the remaining half of the camp was demolished in the 1950s to enable the construction of Portway School.
Some elements of the camp were recorded during archaeological fieldwork at Grumwell Close in 1993 (SMR 20065) and the Portway School playing fields in 2004 (SMR 22020) including the recording of possible barracks huts (Webster 2005).

No.39 Cooperage Road, located on the north side of Cooperage Road, just to the west of Netham Road. The building was in existence by the time of the St. George tithe survey of 1842 (BRO EP/A/32/32) when it lay at the southern end of a long narrow plot. The buildings shown by Maule against Blackswarth Road were no longer present and a house (No.39 Cooperage Road) with a number of outbuildings on the rear, north, side had been constructed. The tithe apportionment records that the land parcel was a house and garden owned by George Bartley and occupied by Thomas Davis.
The building is a two-storey rendered house. The phasing of the structure is currently unclear but the house now has a double-depth plan. The rear element is both narrower and slightly taller than the front element, suggesting that the present building is of two main phases, with the rear element perhaps being the earliest. Both elements of the house have pitched pantile roofs, although only the front, southern, element has chimneystacks at the eastern and western gables.
Street directories record No.39 as being occupied by William Frederick Roberts. Between 1958 and 1963 no occupant was recorded but from 1964 the building was occupied by Leonard Bracey.

KNOWN_AS: Wesleyan Methodist Church, Collins Street, Avonmouth
MONUMENT_DESC: Wesleyan Methodist church on the west side of Collins Street, Avonmouth. The building was constructed in the early decades of the twentieth century and was recorded by the Ordnance Survey third edition 1:2500-scale County Series plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.01) published in 1916. It is a two-storey structure Gothic structure of squared Pennant sandstone rubble with limestone ashlar detailing.

Masonic Hall located on the south-western side of Portview Road, Avonmouth. The building was constructed in the early decades of the twentieth century and is recorded by the Ordnance Survey third edition 1:2500-scale County Series plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.01) published in 1916. The building is a two-storey red brick structure with limestone ashlar detailing. The main, north-east facing, elevation on to Portview road has a five-window range. The windows at ground-floor level are set in semi-circular arched windows with alternate limestone ashlar and brick voussoirs. At first-floor level the windows were set in shouldered rectangular moulded ashlar openings. The openings were subsequently infilled with brick.

KNOWN_AS: Mason's Madhouse, Fishponds Private Lunatic Asylum, Oldbury Court Road, Fishponds
MONUMENT_DESC:
"Mason's madhouse," also known as the Fishponds Private Lunatic Asylum. The building was located on the east side of Oldbury Court Road. It was founded by Dr. Joseph Mason in 1740. Mason died in 1779 but the hospital continued to operate until the mid-nineteenth century.
Relatively little is currently known about the form and operation of the hospital in the eighteenth century. However, an inquiry for the Gloucestershire Court or Quarter Sessions into the hospital in November and December 1848 recorded some evidence about its methods at that date. The superintendent of the hospital was then Dr. Joseph Carpenter Bompas who had taken over the licence for the institution after his father's death in 1847. The building had three departments, apparently single rooms. The first department was "the middle department of the house, where the gentlemen are" (Anon. 1848, 97). The second department was known as the "Farmer's Department" and was where middle-class patients were housed, while the third department was for the "sick and noisy" (Anon. 1848, 97). There were other restraint rooms, including a secure room known as the strong room, and an exercise yard surrounded by high walls (Anon 1848, 98).
The asylum closed in 1852 and the building was demolished in the 1880s.

Penpole Lodge, Penpole Wood. The lodge lay approximately 15 metres north of Penpole Point and measured roughly 13 metres by 7 metres. The building was a square, two-storey ashlar tower with narrow wings on either side. The primary feature of the main ground-floor elevation was a wide segmental-headed arched gateway with iron gates. There was a plat band on either side of the arch at the level of the springing and a projecting keystone in the arch. The first-floor was separated from the ground-floor by a plain string course. There was a tall opening with plain mouldings at first floor. The top of the tower had a narrow cornice supported by dentils and at each corner there were projecting square turrets capped by moulded stone finials in the form of urns. On either side of the central element the elevation was plain and there were no openings.
The architect of the building is currently unknown but it was part of the Kingsweston Estate and may therefore have been designed by Sir John Vanbrugh as part of the overall scheme for the house. The lodge was separated from the remainder of the estate and was acquired by Bristol Corporation as part of the land bought for the Lawrence Weston housing development. The building was derelict and being vandalised by the late 1940s and it was demolished in 1950 (Anon. 1959, 154-155).
The condition of any surviving below ground archaeological remains of the lodge is unknown.

Brook's Dye Works and Laundry. Brooks Dyers and Cleaners purchased land in Ashley Vale in 1870 and shortly afterwards constructed buildings on a site north of Morley Street. These buildings are shown on a plan by George Ashmead in 1874. These buildings housed the dye works, the dye cleaning plant and later the laundry. At least two of the watercourses running through the site had either been removed or culverted by this time. However, a brook, Cutlers Mills brook, ran immediately to the north of the works.

A print of c1900 shows two long laundry buildings, with the sign 'Brooks Dye Works' arranged parallel to each other, with a separate building on the other side of the road (probably Ashley Grove Road) with a sign 'Dry Cleaning Dept'. By 1918, the works had expanded to include the whole of the south side of Brooklyn Street. On the east side of Ashley Grove Road, the former Dry Cleaning Dept had been expanded into a much larger building. By the 1970s, the works had expanded considerably, with further buildings on the east side of Ashley Grove Road and further buildings between Brooklyn Street and Morley Street.

Sayer's Mill, located approximately 125 metres to the east of East Street, at the southern end of Mill Lane. This may be the Royal mill in Bedminster referred to in a grant of permission for the construction of Trin Mills in the second half of the twelfth-century (Walker 1998, 6). However, the mill was in existence by the late-eighteenth century and was recorded by the 1828 survey of Bristol by John Plumley and George Ashmead as a complex of buildings standing on Mill Lane, with a narrow mill leat orientated from south-west to north-east to the south of the mill buildings. The mill was still extant at the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.24) surveyed in 1883 and this plan indicated that the mill was a corn mill. The mill had been demolished by the time the second edition plan was published in 1903.

KNOWN_AS: Raja Rammohun Roy statue, Deanery Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
Raja Rammohun Roy statue, located in Deanery Road. The statue is by the Indian sculptor Niranjan Pradhan and comprises a figure of the Raja Rammohun Roy which faces west, and stands on a stone plinth.
Ram Mohum Roy Badahoor was born in Radhanagar, Bengal on 22 May 1772. He worked for the East India Company between 1804 and 1814 and learned Persian and English, which were the official languages of the Company's administrative structure. Roy had a strong interest in religious matters and learned Arabic, Sanskrit, Greek, Latin, and Hebrew to further his studies of the fundamental texts of the great world religions. He held strongly to a monotheistic religious viewpoint, arguing against both Hindu worship of gods and goddesses and the Christian doctrine of the Holy Trinity. In 1828 Roy founded the religious movement Brahmo Samaj (the Society of Brahma), the aim of which was to establish the worship of the Supreme Being. He also sought reform of the caste system and an improvement of the social status of women and children. In particular, with William Carey, he helped to persuade the Governor General of India, William Bentinck, to abolish suttee (the practice of burning a widow on her husband's funeral pyre) in 1829. In 1830, Roy became the envoy of the Emperor of Delhi to England. In April 1831 Roy arrived in England, primarily to witness the renewal of the East India Company charter, but he also attended the coronation of William IV. Roy travelled to Bristol in 1833 to visit Dr. Lant Carpenter, the Minister of the Unitarian Chapel at Lewin's Mead and father of the educational reformer Mary Carpenter. He stayed with other members of the Unitarian congregation at Stapleton but developed symptoms of meningitis and died there on 27 September 1833. His remains were initially interred in Stapleton but were moved to Arno's Vale cemetery in 1843.
The statue was unveiled on 20 December 1997 by the Indian High Commissioner (Merritt 2002, 59). A bronze plaque on the plint bears the legend "RAJAH RAMMOHUN ROY / BORN ON 22 MAY 1772 IN RADHANAGAR BENGAL / DIED ON 27 SEPTEMBER 1833 IN BRISTOL / PHILOSOPHER, REFORMER, PATRIOT, SCHOLAR / A FOUNDING FATHER OF INDIAN RENAISSANCE / UNVEILED BY HIS EXCELLENCY DR. L. M. SINGHVI / THE HIGH COMMISSIONER FOR INDIA IN THE UK, / IN THE PRESENCE OF THE RIGHT HONORABLE / THE LORD MAYOR OF BRISTOL, COUNCILLOR JACK FISK, / TO MARK THE GLODEN JUBILEE OF INDIA'S INDEPENDENCE / ON 20 NOVEMBER 1997. / SCULPTED BY MR. NIRANJAN PRADHAN / GIFT OF RPG ENTERPRISE."
Inscribed in the top of the statue's base, close to the left foot, is the legend "SCULPTOR / NIRANJAN PRADHAN / CALCUTTA / 1997 / INDIA."
[Public Monument and Sculpture Association reference number BR233].

KNOWN_AS: Bridge and ford in St Anne's Wood
MONUMENT_DESC: A crossing over Brislington Brook in St Anne's Wood was in existance by the time of the Brislington tithe survey in 1846 (BRO EP/A/32/9). It is not clear from this intial depiction of the crossing whether this was purely a bridge or ford, but by the first edition Ordnance Survey plan (Somerset Sheet VI.08) published in 1886 there does appear to be a bridge and ford in existance. The present bridge is constructed of pennant sandstone with a brick arch. The stone work has been repointed with modern cement and the path over the bridge has been relain with gravel cement. The ford lies immediately to the north of the bridge and partially survives as a series of squared blocks lain on the river bed. Longer blocks create a formalised kerbed edge to the ford on its north side. The original approach to the ford partially survives on the east bank, but has been covered on the west bank. It appears that the ford has been truncated by the construction of the present bridge suggesting that the ford went out of use by the late nineteenth century.

Curtis Mill on the south bank of the river Frome. The mill, also known as Broom Mill or Watts or Wyatts Mill, is located on the east side of the bridge at Broom Hill, Stapleton by the entrance to Snuff Mills Park. The mill was in existence by 1606 when it was referred to in a lease as a grist mill, known as Wyatt's Mill, and remained in use as such until 1890. The mill is shown by the 1839 tithe survey of Stapleton to consist of the dwelling with an attached building on the north side. It was destroyed when the bridge over the river Frome was widened at the end of the nineteenth century.

KNOWN_AS: Brickworks north of Two Mile Hill Road, St. George
MONUMENT_DESC:
A brickworks located some 120 metres to the north of Two Mile Hill Road, St. George. The works was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucester Sheet LXXII.15) published in 1882 and comprised a single "L-shaped" building some 20 metres long and orientated north-south at the centre of the site with a large clay pit (SMR 5044) immediately to the south-west. By the time the second edition plan was published in 1903 the brickworks had fallen into disuse, although the buildings were extant.
The main building now lies largely beneath Nos.72-80 Victoria Park while the clay pit is beneath Nos.82-84 Victoria Park and the gardens to the rear of the terrace.

Windmill, located on the west side of Pennywell Road (opposite the former junction with Bean Street). The windmill was a tower mill measuring 6 metres in diameter and stood over 7 metres high. It was apparently constructed in the eighteenth century. The structure is likely to have been built of stone rubble and originally had at least two small sash windows in its eastern side, at first and second storey level.
Winstone (1971 pl.134) reports that the sails and other superstructure was removed in 1850 by Mr S. Plenty who converted the mill to a dwelling. It was recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500 plan (Bristol Sheet LXXII.13.2) surveyed in 1883 which shows the structure at the northern end of Old Albion Court. By that date it was attached on the south to a rectangular building. A photograph from the 1920s (Winstone, 1971 pl.134) shows the tower and a single-storey rendered building with a lean-to pantile roof, presumably built by Plenty, attached to the south.
The remaining element of the mill was demolished in the later 1930s (Winstone, 1971 pl.134) and its site subsequently redeveloped. The site of the mill now lies on the western side of a shed on the west side of the junction of Pennywell Road and Easton Way.

A Romano-British settlement at Filwood Park. The site was discovered during levelling of the ground in Filwood Park in 1982 and the exposed remains were subject to archaeological excavation that year by R. G. J. Williams (Williams 1983) of Bristol and Avon Archaeological Research Group (BAARG) (SMR 20253). The excavation recorded a rectangular enclosure bounded on two sides by ditches. A two-room rectangular building, with a probable hearth, stood at the north end of the enclosure and a gully ran north-south through the enclosure, which was apparently cobbled. To the east of the enclosed area was a small metalled area adjacent to a ditch aligned north-south. Iron and lead ores, coal, and "the waste products of metal working" (Williams 1983, 14) were recorded here. Parallel ditches ran south from the southern side of the enclosure towards a small stone building with "substantial faced stone walls" (ibid. 15) and an area of cobbling and flagstones roughly 75 metres from the main enclosure. It was suggested by the excavator that the cobbling and flagstones may have served as the base for a further building. To the west of this was "an area of hardpacked burnt clay floor" with "a line of laid stones on the south side indicating a furnace, possibly a corn dryer" (Williams 1983). A dump of pottery was found some 50 metres to the east of the enclosure. On the available evidence the excavator concluded that the site was probably a farmstead, occupied from the 1st-century A.D. until possibly the latter part of the 4th-century A.D., where some metalworking was also taking place (Williams 1983, 19).
Subsequent evaluation and excavation in advance of development in the area of the park (SMR 20254; 20349) and at Inns Court Community Centre (SMR 20054; 20348) indicated that the settlement was more extensive than had been previously thought. Work at Inns Court in particular suggested that there was a substantial stone building of at least two ranges immediately west of the community centre. This building was apparently of higher status than those previously recorded in the area and surviving areas of internal stone flooring were found. A wide ditch separated this building from another stone building to the south, and this too had stone floors (Williams 1997, 77-79). The finds evidence may also indicate that the site may have had an origin in the Late Iron Age.
The areal extent of the settlement is currently undefined, although the features so far identified extend for a distance of over 400 metres from east to west.

Blaise Castle Iron Age hillfort.
An excavation was directed to the east of Blaise Castle by Bartlett in 1918 (SMR 20457) which recorded the foundations of a buttressed building, interpreted as the Chapel of St. Blaise (Bartlett 1919). Several evaluation trenches were dug across the monument in late 1956/early 1957 (SMR 20458) under the direction of Philip Rahtz (Rahtz & Clevedon Brown 1956-59).
By the later eighteenth century Blaise estate, including the hillfort, was owned by the Bristol merchant Thomas Farr, and Farr commisisioned the construction of Blaise Castle, a Gothick sham castle (SMR 780), within the hillfort. When Farr became bankrupt in the late 1770s he sold the Henbury manor to Dr. Denham Skeet, a Bath lawyer. The Castle and its setting were recorded in a number of drawings by Samuel Hieronymus Grimm made in the late 1780s (British Library Add. Mss. 15540 f.112-f.115). In 1789 Skeet sold Blaise to John Scandrett Harford, a Bristol banker. The landscape architect Humphry Repton was commissioned by Harford to landscape the Blaise estate, but is has not been established how much alteration to the hilfort was undertaken as part of these works. The site became a popular destination for day-trips by visitors to Bath at around this time and Blaise Castle is mentioned in Jane Austen's novella Northanger Abbey (written in 1798).
The hillfort is a Scheduled Ancient Monument (AV183).

A tree-lined avenue running from Cotham Road to Redland Court. The avenue was in existence by 1742 when it was recorded by Jean Rocque's plan of Bristol as the "Avenue to Mr Coffin's House" at Redland Court. As such it was part of the landscaping of the grounds of Redland Court and was approximately 600 metres in length and 12 metres wide. It ran from a crenellated stone arch (SMR 21902) in the area of Cotham Grove north-west towards Redland Court.
