The south-eastern end of the avenue was developed as Cotham Grove in the later-nineteenth century but part survives, including the planting, as the western side of Redland Park in Redland Grove.

KNOWN_AS: Quarry on the northern side of Leinster Avenue
MONUMENT_DESC: Quarry, located approximately 500 metres to the east of Novers Hill. The quarry is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.11) published in 1884. At that date it measured 25 metres from south-west to north-east and the working face was on the south-east side. The quarry was still extant in 1916, but had been infilled by 1931. The site was subsequently developed for housing and the site of the quary now lies in the gardens to the rear of Nos.56-62 Leinster Avenue.

KNOWN_AS: Netham Lock or Feeder Lock, St. Philip's Marsh
MONUMENT_DESC:
Netham Lock or Feeder Lock, Feeder Road, St. Philip's Marsh. The lock and the associated bridge were constructed as part of the creation of the Floating Harbour by William Jessop between 1804 and 1809. The lock was the eastern end of the Floating Harbour and gave access to the River Avon from the Feeder Canal.
The lock is of coursed rubble stone with wooden lock gates, a small single-span stone bridge with parapets and associated lock-keepers cottage (SMR 8459).
The Lock has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/43/1624).

KNOWN_AS: WWII air raid shelter at Fairfield School, Montpelier
MONUMENT_DESC:
Air raid shelter located in the playground of Fairfield School, Montpelier. The shelter was a trench shelter, square in plan, with four galleries (each 2 metres wide and 1.8 metres deep) and was built in 1940. The walls and roof were constructed of interlocking pre-cast reinforced concrete slabs. The shelter was constructed by excavation of a trench through the subsoil which was then lined and capped with the slabs. The whole was braced by a sectional steel frame fixed to plates in a cast concrete floor. Drains ran beneath the floor which contained small square drainage grilles.
The entrance was located on the west side of the shelter and was reached by a flight of steps down from the level of the playground. There were two square escape hatches in the roof and toilet enclosures, each measuring 1 metre square, at each end of the galleries. The shelter was supplied with electricity.
The shelter was stripped of its internal fittings after the Second World War and remained unused within the playground. The roof of the shelter was been damaged by the passage of earthmoving equipment during groundworks associated with the construction of temporary classrooms in the summer of 2002 and a decision was taken to infill it with hard core. A survey was undertaken as a result (SMR 21476; Longman & Stevens 2002; Wills 2003, 272).

KNOWN_AS: Quarries at Leopold Road, St. Andrews
MONUMENT_DESC: A group of quarries located in the area of modern Leopold Road. The quarries are recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.09) surveyed in 1880-81. The plan also indicates that there was a pair of associated limekilns (SMR 21340 & SMR 21341) to the south of the quarries. The quarries had been infilled and housing developed over the site by the beginning of the twentieth century. The site of the quarries now lies largely beneath houses and gardens of Nos.12-46 Leopold Road.

Hebron Chapel, located on the western side of Hebron Road, Bedminster. The chapel was built in 1853 on land which had previously been used for agricultural purposes and was designed by the architect Henry Crisp. It is first recorded by George Ashmead's survey of Bristol made in 1855 and then comprised the chapel, an attached building to the rear and the plot for the burial ground on the north side of the chapel. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.23) surveyed in 1883 indicates that the chapel was a United Free Methodist chapel with seats for 640. The structure attached to the rear of the chapel was marked as a Sunday school.
The building was the subject of archaeological survey in 2000 (SMR 20265; Pilkington 2001).
The chapel has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/45/380).

The 'French Chapel', a Huguenot Chapel located on corner of Orchard Street and Orchard Lane. The chapel was built in 1727. The building had a long elevation to Orchard Street, but its entrance was on Orchard Lane. Rendered walls, each with a plinth. A gabled roof, gable end to the Lane, parapet to the Street. To Orchard Street, an 8-window range, arranged at high level as 1+1+6, with a single ground-floor window beneath the left-hand example. A segmental-arched cellar access in plinth to right of centre. To Orchard Lane, probably a 3-window range, 3 at upper level, and 1 either side of a central entrance at lower level. The interior (in c.1930) a relatively plain rectangle with a wagon roof, and a balcony at the western end, above an inner porch. The building was replaced in the 1930s by the offices of the Bristol Municipal Charities (Winstone 1979, pl.94).

The Gallery of Arts. An art gallery in a former house. C18. 4 storeys; 4-window range; full-width pediment. Now with ground-floor shop windows. Braikenridge (Notes,G.32) gives the following information:-
1826 ".. the Gallery of Arts, now so called being the late Shiercliff Library & now the Property of a Mr.Walker, the Nephew of Mr.Shiercliff who has new fronted the house the several rooms of which are let out as occasions offer for travelling exhibitions of Pictures or other works of art. [In a later hand] Theses Premises have been called in succession the Gallery of Arts, The Bazaar & the New Exchange & was burnt down on 19 Feby 1827. Mr.Walker had expended upwards of £4000 on these premises & they were only insured at £1500". 
He also states (Notes L26) that it was let out as an occasional sale room. 
In 1828 (Rowbotham's drawing, BRSMG M2915) there was, at the apex of the pediment, a plinth, atop which appears to have been a statue. There was also a circular feature, probably a window, within the pediment.

Free Chapel of Knowle. The chapel was probably constructed in the medieval period, although its origin, form and date of construction are currently (13/02/2002) unknown, as is its precise location. The chapel is consistently stated to be a quarter of a mile from Bedminster and may therefore have been in the area of Lower Knowle, around the area of the junciton of Bedminster Road and St. John's Lane. This, however, remains to be established.
The main evidence for the chapel comes from the documents associated with its sale at Dissolution in the mid-sixteenth century. The survey for its dissolution made in 1548-49 records that the incumbent was then John Bradley and that the plate comprised a single chalice. The chapel did have a set of bells, implying that it also had a tower or campanile (SMR 20690; SMR 20693; Green 1888, 91). It was also endowed with lands in the area. The chapel was granted to London gentleman, Richard Roberts, in December 1549 when it was valued at £73 6s. 8d. (SMR 21112; Woodward 1982, 64) and passed from Roberts to Sir William Sharington, a Wiltshire J. P. who was also master of the Bristol mint, on 11 January 1550 (Woodward 1982, 64n).
The date of demolition of the chapel is unknown.

Deep Pit Colliery. The pit was initially called Tylers Pit but had become known as Deep Pit by the later nineteenth century. By then the pit seems to have been functioning as part of a larger operation and used, with Speedwell Colliery, for winding. The shaft was served by a twin double-acting winding engine which had a headstock standing 10 metres high with two wheels each nearly 4 metres in diameter. In 1899 77000 tons of coal were raised from Deep Pit (Southway, 1971 16-17). The colliery belonged to Handel Cossham by the end of the nineteenth century and was auctioned on 24 May 1900 following his death. The sale particulars noted that the colliery had contracts to supply the Midland Railway, Somerset and Dorset Railway, the Bristol Guardians and Christopher Thomas Bros. Ltd. soapworks at Broad Plain. There was also a coke works with twenty-four ovens (Ramsey, 2003 22).
The pit was closed in 1936 and the remains of some buildings were still visible circa 1953. However, only the shaft remained by the 1970s. The site was subsequently redeveloped.

The grounds of Brentry House, Brentry Hill. William Payne commissioned Humphry Repton to create a landscape park for his new house at Brentry Hill in 1802. The work was one of Repton's later commissions, relatively small in scale and taking the main house as the focus for the landscape. The Reptons placed the house carefully to exploit the topography of the site, emphasising the views of the Bristol Channel to the west and screening those of Westbury-on-Trym to the south by planting evergreen trees (Daniels 1999, 236). Repton created a grotto which is now lost, a view of the house from inside the grotto being published in 1803 (reproduced in Harding and Lambert 1994, 64). A mound with evergreen planting close to the drive has been suggested as its likely site (Land Use Consultants 1999, 7). When the work had been completed Repton wrote that "few houses have been built with more attention to the situation and circumstances of the place than the villa at Brentry" (Harding and Lambert, 1994 64). Repton's son John Adey Repton designed Brentry House at the same time, one of only two occasions where father and son produced complimentary designs. The house had passed into the hands of John Cave, a member of the Bristol banking family, by the early 1820s and Cave expanded both the house (by adding new ranges) and its grounds. This work took land from the fields on the south side of the original line of Charlton Road (part of which survives as a lane within the hospital) and created the new, existing, line to the south. An entry in the Gloucestershire Quarter Sessions records for 1825 confirms authorisation of this work and another, in the same year, its subsequent inspection and acceptance (Brett 1999). It has been argued that the sinuous carriage drive was created during the 1825 (Land Use Consultants 1999, 7) and the 1825 work appears to have cut the grotto off from the house, both physically and in terms of the landscape design. It may be for this reason that it was taken down. On the north side of the site is a quarried edge. The origin, date and purpose of this is uncertain but the suggestion has been made that it may represents diversion of a public path to enhance the privacy of the house and was undertaken either by Repton or by Cave (Land Use Consultants 1999, 7).
The landscape is included in the English Heritage Register of Historic Parks and Gardens where it has a Grade II listing although it has subsequently been altered by planting, building for the retreat and subsequently the hospital which occupied the site and the widening of Passage Road and the junction with Charlton Road which removed land from the park after the Second World War. Generally "the early 19th century landscape has been respected. Demand for built space has clearly impinged on the landscape and the land use, but it is fortunate that the essential elements of the designed landscape have been relatively unaffected" (Land Use Consultants 1999, 9).
Relatively little of the pre-Repton landscape can be identified, but a possible trackway of unknown purpose runs north-east from the drive leading to Charlton Road (Brett 1999). In the area now occupied by St. Peter's Hospice an area of ridge and furrow was identified by Bryant (Bryant 1995).

Blaise Castle, a Gothick sham castle located at Blaise Hill which stands wthin the Iron Age hillfort (SMR 777). The structure was commissioned by the Bristol merchant Thomas Farr, who then owned the manor of Henbury, and was designed by the Scottish architect Robert Mylne (1734-1811) who was employed between 1763 and 1772 to remodel the interior of Kings Weston House (SMR 755). The design has a wide, two-storey crenellated central tower with a flat roof, and three narrower but slightly taller towers attached at equal intervals around its circumference. The windows and other detailing is in a Gothick style, and each of the towers has window openings with shallow arched cinquefoil heads set in rectangular frames. There are blind cross arrow slits at the ground- and second-floor levels. The main entrance is at the centre of the south-east facing elevation. The building is constructed of Lias limestone rubble with limestone ashlar dressings. The three-tower form of the Castle was apparently inspired by Fort Belvedere, built in the early 1750s for Prince William Augustus, the Duke of Cumberland, at Shrubs Hill in Windsor Great Park (Pevsner 1958, 468). Unusually for such structures, the Castle was habitable and had a kitchen and drawing room. It was used as a summer house for entertaining.
When Farr became bankrupt in the late 1770s he sold the Henbury manor to Dr. Denham Skeet, a Bath lawyer. The Castle and its setting were recorded in a number of drawings by Samuel Hieronymus Grimm made in the late 1780s (British Library Add. Mss. 15540 f.112-f.115), and Grimm's 1788 drawing of the building from south-west records a fence enclosing the immediate area around the building. In 1789 Skeet sold Blaise to John Scandrett Harford, a Bristol banker. Humphry Repton was commissioned by Harford to landscape the Blaise estate and in his Red Book of 1798 recommended raising one turret in order to "give it more the character of a real castle at a distance" (Red Book). The proposal was not, however, carried out. The site became a popular destination for day-trips by visitors to Bath at around this time (Daniel 1999, 230) and Blaise Castle is mentioned in Jane Austen's novella Northanger Abbey (written in 1798).
The Castle suffered neglect in the twentieth century and the structure deteriorated. Remedial works were undertaken in 1957 and the interior was largely removed at this time. In 2006 a new internal timber floor was inserted into the building.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/20/1361).

Kings Weston Down Camp, a univallate hillfort, defended on the north and east sides by steep slopes, on the south by a low rampart and ditch, and on the west, the most vulnerable side, by a larger bank and ditch. Entrances cross the levelled ditch through the main rampart at the NW and SW corners, but neither need be ancient. Excavations by Rahtz in 1957 revealed an occupation layer within the south rampart of the fort and showed the ditch of the west rampart to have been 5 feet 5 inches deep and over 15 feet wide. Pottery indicates primary occupation in a late phase of the IA "A" period (but 13 sling stones in secondary fill of the circle's ditch (SMR 782, a circular earthwork within the fort) suggest IA "B" occupation. The main destruction of the upper rampart of the fort seems to have occurred in the mid-C2, while some Roman occupation is indicated by the quantity of pottery found here. Further west at ST55307805-ST55357797 is a cross-ridge dyke similar in size and character to main rampart of the hillfort, of N. The outer defence or cross ridge dyke was found to have a ditch similar to that of the inner work, but it was only 2 metres wide and 1.5 - 2 metres deep. It contained rubble from the rampart deposited in the mid-C2 or later. A probable hut site was also noted close to the east end of the main enclosure,  around 7 metres in diameter. Another F4339-42, and in reserve collection.<3> On the eastern extremity of King's Weston Hill, 3 1/2 miles NW of Bristol, near Blaise Castle Camp there is a small but clearly defined earthwork across the E end of the hill in half moon shape with a trackway running up to a west entrance, then ends of the banks resting on the escarpment of the hill at either side. Area enclosed c 5 acres. Further along the hilltop to the west there is another slight ditch & mound running across the hill from N-S. The hill overlooks Roman town of Abona and whole of lower Severn estuary, particularly the Roman road marked on Ordnance Survey map as extending in a direct line from Lawrence Weston to the Severn. Immediately opposite this road are the remains of a beacon tower which tradition allots to the Roman period.<7> Site is reasonably well looked after, but used by a large number of the public who cause some erosion of the banks. The west bank is 3 metres above the bottom of ditch and c 1 metre above the interior of the enclosures. The interior of the enclosure is covered with short grass, as is the west bank and ditch, which are constructed across the flat top of hill. The other sides of the enclosure are bounded by steep wooded slopes, in which a bank is visible on the south side.
The hillfort is a Scheduled Ancient Monument (AV 53).

Mere Bank, Avonmouth. The monument is a straight linear earth bank with flanking ditches which ran north-west from Lawrence Weston towards the river Severn as least as far as Hoar Gout (at ST 52468017). The bank is approximately 2.6 metres wide and stands around 0.25 metres high. Mere Bank Rhine forms the ditch along the north-east side of the Mere Bank while that on its south-west side is a smaller field boundary ditch. In 1992 an archaeological field evaluation trench was excavated across the monument to establish its nature and date as part of the evaluation programme preceding development of the Second Severn Crossing (SMR 20130). The bank was was found to have been formed from a series of clay loam and silty clay layers. No palaeosol was observed beneath the bank but it sealed an earlier ditch and a layer of very silty clay which produced a sherd of Cotswold Tripod Pitcher ware dating to the twelfth- or early thirteenth-century.
The Mere Bank is likely to be part of a late-Saxon or medieval scheme of reclamation of the Henbury salt marsh, which formed part of the estates of the Bishops of Worcester from the eleventh century. It enclosed the open fields of Great Madam and Little Madam, common land until the early-nineteenth century.
A section of the Mere Bank approximately 800 metres long (between ST 5307179491 and  ST 5359578915) is a Scheduled Ancient Monument (SAM No. AV27988).

Holy Cross Church, Inns Court. The church was located at the centre of Inns Court Green and was established in 1949-1950 in a converted farm outbuilding. A new church was built in 1959 to a design by Thomas H. B. Burrough and F. L. Hannam (Harwood & Foster, 1998 108). It was demolished in the late 1990s and a new church was built a short distance to the north-west.

KNOWN_AS: Earthworks, natural and leadworkings, Clifton Down
MONUMENT_DESC: Across the top of Clifton Down, running from north-west to south-east (ST565744-ST568741) is a series of shallow excavations, possibly "an advanced line of defence intended to protect the camp on Observatory Hill (SMR883). At the ends of the rows of pits (at ST56557428 and ST56777519) are the remains of two tumuli. South of the Pembroke Road quarry and opposite the entrance to the Zoological Gardens (at ST569743 and ST567741) are the remains of two pounds or village enclosures {1} "Dr Prowse...thinks that the mounds and hollows on the downs at Clifton are indications of ancient settlements. It is impossible to say that none of these mounds are ancient but on the other hand it appears certain that many of them are the natural outcrop of limestone ridges, and that others are caused by excavations made to discover lead... I can see no evidence of the existence of the two tumuli...or the two pounds or village enclosures?. {2}running shafts {3}

Chittening Platform, located to the south of Smoke Lane, Chittening. The station was created in 1917 for the use of munitions workers at the adjacent shell-filling factory (SMR 21403) but the eastbound and westbound platforms do not appear to have been contructed until 13 November 1918 and these continued in use until 11 October 1923. The station was reused in the Second World War when new shelters for passengers were provided. It continued in use after the war and reopened to passenger use on 31 May 1948. The station was closed on 23 November 1964 and the platforms were subsequently demolished (Mitchell & Smith 2004).

Home Farm, Kings Weston Lane, Henbury. The farm was probably part of the Kings Weston Estate and was in existence by the time of the Henbury tithe survey of 1841. The majority of the farm buildings The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.02) published in 188 suggests that the farm straddled Kings Weston Lane, with most of the farm buildings, including the farmhouse, lying on the western side of the lane but with other large outbuildings on the eastern side. The farm survived into the twentieth century, but most of the farm buildings were demolished atter the Second World War. However, the farmhouse survives as the Home Farm Family Centre and has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/24/1568).

War memorial located on the southern side of Stoke Hill. The memorial is a stone cross supported on a pillar with a square base. This is set on a stepped octagonal plinth. On the north-west face of the column there is a sword carved in relief. The north-west face of the base bears the inscription "IN GRATEFUL MEMORY/OF/STOKE BISHOP MEN WHO GAVE/THEIR LIVES IN THE GREAT WAR/1914-1918/"HE THAT DOETH THE WILL/OF GOD ABIDETH FOR EVER"[a quotation from the oratorio The Prodigal Son by Sir Arthur Sullivan]/"WHO STANDS IF FREEDOM FALL/WHO DIES IF ENGLAND LIVE" [a quotation from the poem "For All We Have and Are" by Rudyard Kipling]." The same face of the upper step of the plinth has the inscription "ALSO IN GRATEFUL MEMORY OF/THOSE WHO GAVE THEIR LIVES/IN THE SECOND WORLD WAR/1939-45." The names of the fallen are inscribed on the other faces of the plinth. A stone was added to the north-east face of the plinth to commemorate a soldier killed in Palestine in 1947 and Lieutenant Terence Edward Waters of The West Yorkshire Regiment (The Prince of Wales's Own), attached to The Gloucestershire Regiment, who died in Korea in 1951 and was posthumously awarded the George Cross.
[Public Monument and Sculpture Association reference number BR274]

Lower Knowle Court, located some 170 metres to the south of St. John's Lane. The date of construction is currently unknown but a drawing of the house shows architectural details of likely sixteenth century date (Hooper, 1996 11). The building may, however, have an earlier origin. It comprised a range of structures of between two and three storeys and these were orientated from north-east to south-west. There was a large tower, probably a stair tower, at the northern end. A large pond with a central island (SMR 3327) lay to the south-west. The house was owned by a William Bullock in 1674 but formed part of the estate of the Smyths of Ashton Court at the time of the Bedminster tithe survey of 1841. The building was described by the tithe apportionment as a "Farm house, gardens, yards and buildings" (Parcel 849) and was rented by Richard Hunt. It had been demolished by 1886 (Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan, Somerset Sheet VI.07). Its site lies mainly to the north-west of the buildings of Blagdon Close. The pond to the south-west of the house survived into the 1960s but was infilled to allow development of Blagdon Close.

KNOWN_AS: H. J. Packer and Co. Chocolate Factory, Greenbank Road, Easton
MONUMENT_DESC:
H. J. Packer and Co. Chocolate Factory, located on the southern side of Greenbank Road, Easton. The factory was constructed as a chocolate factory for H. J. Packer and Co. H. J. Packer was a former employee of J. S. Fry, and Packer and Co. was founded as a family business in 1881 at No.46 Armoury Square. H. J. Burrows joined the business as a partner in 1884 and became its sole owner in 1885. Burrows sold the business to Bruce Cole the following year. In the second half of the 1890s the business began to expand and acquired adjacent houses in the terrace.
Expansion necessitated the construction of a new factory and a site was acquired in Easton. In 1901 plans for a new factory were approved for construction along Co-operation Road.
The factory comprised three discrete ranges of brick buildings, each of three storeys and attic with hipped double-Roman tiled roofs, a dormer in the centre of the hip and further small dormers along the length of the roofs. The north-west facing, Co-operation Road, elevations of the eastern and central ranges have five bays while the western range is of three bays. The centre bay of each range consists of large openings for loading doors and the fenestration comprises arched openings containing metal windows. The space between the ranges is covered by ridge lantern lights with steel trusses. Internally the ranges have timber floors with cross-braced joints supported on steel columns. They have king post roofs with tusk tenons, with central steel columns and squared timber posts on either side to support the span.
To the east, at the junction of Co-operation Road with Thurley Road, an office building was constructed in c.1918. This is a two-storey, four-bay brick building with a limestone ashlar façade. The ground floor is rusticated and the fenestration consists of large metal windows set in recessed openings. Three bays face south-west on to Thurley Road while the fourth, narrower, bay at the south end, turning the corner into Co-operation Road, contains the main semi-circular arched door opening with an similar arched window above. There is a dentillated cornice with a balustraded parapet above. To the south of the factory was a recreation ground for the workers.
A fifth range of buildings was added to the eastern side of the factory in the 1950s. The company was acquired by James Goldsmith in 1964 and renamed Cavendish Confectionery. The firm purchased the Camberley-based firm Elizabeth Shaw in 1968 and moved its production to the Greenbank site where it continued until 2006.

KNOWN_AS: Gabled house on the southern side of East Street, Bedminster
MONUMENT_DESC:
Gabled house of likely later seventeenth-century date, located on the southern side of East Street, Bedminster. The building was a single-bay, gabled structure with a pantile roof, which the similarities of form suggest was probably constructed as the central house of a terrace of three. A photograph of the early 1870s (Winstone 1966, pl.78) indicates that the ground-floor had a bay window on the eastern side with a single doorway to its west. A pantiled pentice roof divided ground- and first-floor and resting on this there was a central bay which continued up to second-floor level. There was a single sash window at both first- and second-floor and a pentice roof divided the two levels. The bay had a sloping pantile roof.
The building was occupied by James Tutton, butcher in 1871 but it had been demolished and the site redeveloped by 1883. The site of the building now lies beneath Nos.135 and 137 East Street.

Royal Oak, a public house located on the southern side of East Street, Bedminster. The building was a rendered, jettied house of a single storey plus attic and was probably of late-medieval or sixteenth-century date. A photograph of the early 1870s (Winstone 1966, pl.78) indicates that the ground-floor level probably contained a shopfront at that date. There was a single sash window at the centre of the upper storey. The pantiled roof was steeply pitched.
The building was occupied by Benjamin Bird in 1871 but it had been demolished and the site redeveloped by 1883. The site of the building now lies largely beneath No.139 East Street.

Icehouse located on the western side of Westbury Road. The date of construction of the icehouse is currently (06/12/2006) unknown but it appears to have been associated with Cote House, but lay around 190 metres to the south-east of the main house. The icehouse was a circular structure measuring 6.3 metres in diameter with a short entrance passage on the northern side. The icehouse was extant in c.1916 but was subsequently demolished and its site was absorbed into the grounds of St. Monica's Home of Rest in the mid 1930s.

No.143 East Street, located on the southern side of East Street, Bedminster. The building is a rendered two-storey building, probably of stone rubble, with a pitched pantile roof. The date of construction is unknown but the building was extant by the time of the survey of Bristol by John Plumley and George Ashmead of 1828. In 1871 the building was occupied by Emma Palmer, grocer. It is currently still used for retail purposes.
The original form of the building is currently unknown. By the early 1870s (Winstone 1966, pl.77) the main, north-west facing, elevation was rendered and was of three bays. The main entrance door was at the centre of the elevation. The eastern bay had a bay window with canted sides at ground floor. This contained a central 4 by 4 pane sash and a 1 by 4 pane sash in its western side. The western bay had a larger bay at ground-floor level which appears to have be a shop window. The bays were subsequently removed and a new shopfront, comprising three large plate glass windows above a stall riser with an entrance door close to the western end, was inserted. At the western end of the elevation is the entrance to a passageway (leading into Allen Square, to the south of the building). The first floor of the building oversails this, supported by a lintel rather than an arch. At first floor the fenestration comprises two single sashes, one above each of the bays. The parapet has an ashlar coping and projects above the eaves of the roof, obscuring the lower part. The ridge of the roof is aligned parallel to East Street and a tall, double-flue chimneystack projects from its eastern end.

KNOWN_AS: Brislington Regional War Room, Flowers Hill, Brislington
MONUMENT_DESC:
Brislington Regional War Room, located at the southern end of the Flowers Hill trading Estate, Flowers Hill, Brislington. The Civil Defence Act 1948, enacted in the context of the developing Cold War, divided the UK into twelve mainland regional and four London sub-regional areas, each to have its own war room. These were often sited in government estates (Cocroft & Thomas 2003, 197) and were built between the spring of 1953 and 1956 to a standard design (McCamley 2002, 152-155). Flowers Hill was the war room for the south-west region, Region No.7.
The building is a two-storey structure, apparently constructed of brick (though presumably with an internal structure of reinforced concrete) and measuring 23 metres square. The exterior of the building is largely covered by foliage trained over it, obscuring detail of its construction but it has three large ventilation towers at the east end of the roof, probably serving the toilets, standby generator and air conditioning plant. The lower level is below ground.
The original internal layout survives. Internally the building has a "ring" corridor on each level circling around a central map room. Access to each of the rooms is off this corridor and each major area of civil administration (eg. Medical Officer of Health, Port of Bristol Authority etc.) was allocated a room.
The policy under which the war rooms were built was reviewed soon after the construction programme was completed. In 1962 The Flowers Hill war room was replaced by two new sub-regional command bunkers in Devon and Gloucestershire and was thereafter relegated to a minor civil defence role. The war room was abandoned in 1981 after the Home Office increased the rent required from Avon County Council from £400 to £4000 per annum (McCamley 2002, 207).
The war room is extant and the original internal layout survives. The fittings and furniture associated with several functions are apparently also still in situ (McCamley 2002, 157-158). The building was surveyed by Nick Catford in the late-1990s (SMR 21436) and photographs from the survey are held by the National Monuments Record under the file number AA98/18033-18034. There are also photographs of the exterior in the building in the SMR Collection of Ground-based Photographs.

An enclosure to the north-east of Redbourn Gout. The feature is a square ditched enclosure located on the southern side of Stuppill rhine (centred on ST 53912 80998). The enclosure measures approximately 32 metres long on the south-east side, 48 metres long on the north-west side and 70 metres long on the north-east side. A ditch runs from the northern corner of the rectangle toward Stuppill. The centre of the enclosure forms a circular platform higher than the surrounding fields. The feature does not appear on any historic maps of the area but can be identified on a vertical air photograph of the area taken in 1946. It is possible that the feature is a moated site, perhaps the site of a medieval farm.
The enclosure was surveyed by Wessex Archaeology during archaeological work associated with the construction of the English approaches to the Second Severn Crossing.
The site (Area 1; Site 8) was visited by R. G. Jackson during the course of a desk-based assessment (SMR 20081) of areas of Bristol City Council owned land north of Avonmouth in December 1996. The site was found to be overgrown on its south-west side.

KNOWN_AS: Two enclosures south of Rodbourn Gout
MONUMENT_DESC:
Two enclosures south of Rodbourn Gout. The sites are located adjacent to one another on the south side of Stuppill Rhine (centred on ST 53912 80998). The site was recorded by the 1841 tithe map which records "House, Homestead & Orchard" and "Potato Patch". The farm seems to have disappeared by the end of the nineteenth-century. The enclosures are shown on a 1946 vertical air photograph. One building is currently extant, a stone cow shed.
The earthworks at the site were surveyed by Wessex Archaeology during archaeological work in advance of the construction of the English approaches to the Second Severn Crossing. 
The site (Area 1; Site 9) was visited by R. G. Jackson during the course of a desk-based assessment (SMR 20081) of areas of Bristol City Council owned land north of Avonmouth in December 1996. It was noted that the earthworks have been disturbed by ploughing.

Brentry Farm Cottage, located on the eastern side of Wigton Crescent, Southmead. The cottage was constructed between the early 1880s and 1903, apparently to provide ancillary accommodation for Brentry Farm (SMR 20355), and is first recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500-scale plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXI.04) published in 1903.
It was a two-storey rendered structure with a central entrance door and a two-window range. The house had a pitched pantile roof with a brick chimneystack at the centre.

Kings Weston House. Sir Robert Southwell bought the Kingsweston estate in 1679 and it was inherited by Sir Edward Southwell at his father's death in 1702. Southwell undertook some changes to the garden in 1709 and decided to rebuild the gabled house, commissioning Sir John Vanbrugh to design the new building c.1710. Many of Vanbrugh's original drawings are contained within the Kingsweston Book of Drawings, held by Bristol Record Office (and also published (Downes, 1967)). The foundations of the earlier house were apparently reused and Downes suggests, from the evidence of letters from Vanbrugh, that Vanbrugh was very willing to accommodate Southwell's opinions on the design (Downes 1987, 342-345). Building was completed in 1725, after Sir Edward Southwell's death.
The house is of limestone ashlar with a seven-window range. It has a U-shaped double-depth plan and is of two-storeys with attic and basement.. At the centre of the building, above the three central bays, is a chimney arcade comprising six square stacks linked by semi-circular arches on each side. Robert Mylne carried out alterations to the building between 1764 and 1775, changing the east and north elevations and reworking the decoration of the interior (Gomme et al. 1979, 107-111). Vanbrugh also designed a number of the service buildings close to the house including the brewhouse, Loggia - probably an extension to an earlier but now demolished garden building - archaeologically recorded by Bryant (Bryant, 1997), a banqueting house known as The Echo, now surviving only as a shell and the Penpole Gate which was demolished in 1952. The ice house (SMR 3163) lies some 150 metres to the north-east of the main house.
The interior of the house was remodelled for Edward Southwell by the architect Robert Mylne between 1763 and 1772.
The stable block was designed by Mylne in the 1760s (Gomme et al. 1979, 181).The landscape park and gardens designed for Edward Southwell are presumably recorded by a view of Kingsweston of 1712 by Kip but it is not clear to what extent these were redesigned for the new house or subsequently, nor what the quality of the archaeological preservation of these buildings is likely to be.
The house has a Grade I listing (Listed Building Number 901-1/24/1742). The Loggia has a Grade I listing (Listed Building Number 901-1/24/1746), The Brewhouse has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/24/1743), The Echo has a Grade I listing (Listed Building number 901-1/24/1744) and the gatepost close to the north-east of the main house has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/24/1745).

KNOWN_AS: Barrow east of Evergreens Wood, Kingsweston Hill
MONUMENT_DESC: A round barrow on Kings Weston Hill. The barrrow was 7 paces in diameter, one foot high, with slight traces of a surrounding ditch on the south. It was excavated by E. K Tratman in about 1924 when a probable primary cremation was found, with sherds of a bipartite urn about 12 inches high. Finds in the University of Bristol Spelaeological Society Museum. Tratman believed this barrow, and others on the hill (SMR 783, 784, 785), to be of an Iron age date, though C. W. Phillips (1947) considered it Late Bronze Age. Green briefly reviewed the dating evidence available for the barrows at Kingsweston Hill in considering a cairn he had excavated at Tickenham. On the basis of a re-examination of Tratman's pottery finds, which appeared to be from collared urns, Green concluded that "in the absence of any structural grounds for considering the Kings Weston Hill barrows to be of Iron Age date" the Kingsweston barrows were of Early Bronze Age origin (Green 1972-73, 43-44). Tratman replied to Green's reinterpretation, arguing that the interpretation of the pottery as Iron Age was questionable, the monuments had not necessarily been disturbed to any great extent in antiquity and that the argument that absence of structural grounds for an Iron Age date leads to the inference of a date in the Early Bronze Age was "highly specious". Tratman concluded that there was no good reason to redate the Kingsweston barrows until fresh evidence became available (Tratman 1975, 56-57).

KNOWN_AS: Quarry on the west side of Small Lane, Stapleton
MONUMENT_DESC: A quarry located on the west side of the junction of Blackberry Hill and Small Lane, Stapleton. The quarry, roughly triangular, occupied the corner of the defined by the roads. It was recorded by the first edition Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.06) published in 1882. At that date the quarry measured 40 metres from east to west by 28 metres north-south and there were working faces on its northern, eastern and southern sides. The entrance was a via a short cutting at the north-west corner on to Blackberry Hill. The 1:2500 plan records a building of unknown function, presumably a shed or office, by the south face. This measured 6.7 metres from south-west to north-east by 8.1 metres north-west to south-east. The site of the quarry has been infilled.

Bedminster. Place-name evidence suggests that the settlement at Bedminster was founded in the Late-Saxon period. Archaeological evaluation trenches at Sheene Road in 1998 (SMR 9637) recorded a feature cut into the underlying rock which was interpreted as the trench for a cill beam. Pottery of eleventh- and twelfth-century date was also recovered (Anon. 1988, 33). Subsequent work at Sheene Road (SMR 20082) did not, however, record any further evidence for the early phases of the settlement and the form and extent of the pre-conquest settlement is therefore uncertain.
In September 1645 when Parliamentarian troops halted at Hanham as a preliminary to an assault on Bristol, the Royalists occupying the city under the command of Prince Rupert are reported to have fired Bedminster "and burnt it down to the ground" (Sprigg 1854, 99). The extent of the damage to the settlement is unknown but in 1652 the parish estimated the cost of the necessary repairs to St. John's Church at £3500 (Bates Harbin 1912, 202).

Twyford House, located on the western side of High Street, Shirehampton. The building appears to have been constructed in the first half of the eighteenth century as a three-storey, three-bay stone rubble house with pitched roof. There are chimneystacks at the apex of the gables at either end of the roof. The main entrance door is at the centre of the north--west facing elevation. There is a single sash window at first and second floor above the door.
At ground floor the internal plan of the building appears originally to have comprised a narrow central hall with large rooms to the north and south. The stair appears to date to the first half of the eighteenth century and the door and doorcase to the northern room are of similar date. At first- and second-floor the plan was similar and the doors and doorframes to the principal rooms are also of early-eighteenth century date, although at second-floor the openings are smaller than those of the floors below.
The house was first recorded by Taylor's plan of the area of 1777. In the early-nineteenth century the building was refronted with ashlar stone. As part of this work full-height bow windows were added, the northern and southern bays each containing three sash windows on each floor. At the same time sash windows were inserted into the south wall of the southern room of the first- and second-floors in a similar position to that on the floor below, and presumably at the same date. A large kitchen was added to the north-west corner of the original building. Single-storey outbuildings of stone rubble bonded in a white lime mortar also appear to have been constructed to the west of the house at this date. In the late nineteenth century the chimneypiece, cornice and skirting of the northern room were replaced.
In the 1908 a larger, two-storey extension, a "smoke room," was added to the south-west corner of the house (BRO Building Plans Vol.55 fo.11). Part of the rear wall of the original house had been removed to double the size of the southern room.
By 1935 the building was occupied by the Christian Science movement. In the later 1970s or the 1980s it passed into the ownership of Avon County Council which appears to have made a number of alterations, including the insertion of steel girders to support the floors. The pitched slate roof was also covered with bitumen.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building 901-1/52/1751).

A square 2-stage chimney of early nineteenth century date constructed of Pennant rubble with copper-slag block dressings. The chimney is the only structural remains of an engine house for the Crews Hole or Troopers Hill coal mine that was first recorded on the 1842 St George's Tithe Map. This shows a square building and adjoining rounded end enclosure to the north-west that may have been the location of a horse gin for hoisting within the shaft (Bryant 2008, 5). The accompanying apportionment lists the parcel (536) containing the site as 'Troopers Hill' in use as pasture owned and occupied by Dr Benjamin Somers.
The closure date of the mine is unknown, but it has been suggested that it was in disuse by 1845 (Cornwell, 2003, 40).
The structures are depicted on later nineteenth and twentieth century plans and an aerial view of the site taken in c.1930 (BRO PicBox/1/Avu/142) shows the engine house ruined and roofless with surviving gables to north-west and south-east and several window openings. By the time of the 1948 survey only the chimney and short sections of the abutting walls survived.
The structure is Listed Grade II (Listed Building number 901-1/56/1237) and has been repointed and stabilised (Bryant 2008, 5).

KNOWN_AS: Iron Age and Romano-British settlement at Henbury School
MONUMENT_DESC:
An Iron Age and Romano-British settlement at Henbury School. The settlement was identified through the discovery of six or more inhumations during groundworks on the south side of the school grounds in 1982 (SMR 5470; Russell 1983). Geophysical survey in 2002 (SMR 21560) and more extensive excavation in 2004 (SMR 21855) identified a system of ditches at the south-western corner of the playing fields although the landscaping of the playing fields in the 1980s had truncated the features.
The ditches formed part of a rural settlement which had begun during the Iron Age and continued well into the Roman period. A large enclosure had been subdivided into smaller enclosures on the same orientation during the Roman period. Margary (1957) suggests that the Roman road between Sea Mills and Gloucester (Margary 541) passed through the school grounds a short distance to the east of the site and the fieldwork also identified a section of its line close to Avonmouth Way.

Bridewell Gate, located at the northern end of Bridewell, now beneath Bridewell Street. Bridewell Gate was sited at the southern end of Bridewell Bridge (now beneath Bridewell Street) and was associated with the post-medieval Bridewell. The gateway consisted of a round-arched opening with a projecting keystone on the north side, with a segmental-arch at the rear. Within the opening there was a pair of studded gates standing about one and a half storeys in height, the eastern with a knocker. The gate was recorded in a watercolour drawing executed in 1824 by Edward Cashin (Bristol Museum and Art Gallery BRSMG M2829).

KNOWN_AS: Inclined plane between Ironmould Lane and the River Avon
MONUMENT_DESC: Inclined plane, believed to have been constructed in about 1800 initially to carry building materials and latterly supplies to Brislington House which was then a lunatic asylum, probably powered by a horse engine at the top. At the point where the incline passes under the Bath to Bristol railway line a number of stone sleeper blocks remain in situ, followed by a number of plate rails still in situ, the rails on the middle pair of rails are quite different from those on the two outside line of rails which are shorter and have interlocking ends, an incline roller remains in situ. Remarkable survival - the plate rails have very small cross-section suggesting light or very slow moving loads. Most of the incline is used as a footpath, the part where the rails remain in situ is being damaged by the overflow of water from an adjacent stream and partly by ballast thrown down from the railway above.

Ashley Court or Ashley Barnes, located on the western side of Ashley Hill. The date of origin of the building is currently unknown but it was apparently in existence by the seventeenth century since a drawing of the main, south-east facing, elevation of April 1746 by James Stewart (Bodleian Library, MS Gough Somerset 2 & 8) shows the northern part of the building with a gabled roof typical of local houses at that date. The house was apparently part of the Ashley estate which was purchased by Andrew Hooke, a Bristol brewer, in the 1660s and remained in the Hooke family until November 1731 when Hooke's grandson, also named Andrew, sold the whole estate to the distiller George Bridges. Bridges apparently lived in the house and at his death in 1733 he bequeathed the estate to his son William. William Bridges died in 1741 and the estate passed to his sisters Ann, married to William Champion and Mary. George Bridges widow Mary remarried (to Jacob Elton) in the year of his death but continued to live at Ashley Court until her death in 1775.
The house was refronted in a Classical style in the first half of the eighteenth century. It was recorded on a plan of Ashley by William Lewellin of 1759 (BRO 4964(25)). This indicated that there were ranges at the northern and southern corners of the house which extended north-west to create an enclosed rear courtyard. There was a formal parterre garden in front of the house, enclosed by a stone wall with tall central piers. The plot behind was an orchard. To the east of the house was an orchard known as "Lower Rookery" with a building towards its northern end. A tree-lined avenue (now part of Ashley Hill) ran north-east from the house.
The house had been bought by Edward Ash in the early years of the nineteenth century and his son Richard sold it to John Evans Lunell, a West India Merchant, in 1825 (BRO 4964(66-67)). William Player lived at Ashley Court from 1852 and continued to occupy the house until 1877 when it was sold to James Derham, a property developer. The house was demolished soon afterwards and much of the area of the formal gardens was developed for housing, including the rectory of St. Werburgh's.
The large rusticated limestone ashlar piers on the north side of Ashley Court Road are extant and have a Grade II listing.

Northview Cottage, located some 30 metres back from the south-west side of Diamond Street, behind Nos.1-5 Diamond Street. The building is a two storey house which measures 12.2 metres from north-west to south-east by 7.5 metres wide and is constructed of lias limestone in a random rubble construction. It was in existence by the time of the tithe survey of Bedminster made in 1841 (BRO EP/A/32/7) and lay at the north-west corner of a garden enclosed by a rubble wall. Ashmead's 1855 survey of Bristol names the building as North House. By the time of the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:500-scale Town plan (Bristol Sheet LXXV.4.23) surveyed in 1883, the eastern side of the garden had been set back a short distance to enable the widening of the southern leg of Back Lane (modern Diamond Street), although this had not yet occurred in the adjacent properties. By 1903, when the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 County Series plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXV.04) was published Nos.1-5 Diamond Street had been developed in the eastern half of the garden.

KNOWN_AS: Ashley Farm, or Ashley Grange, Ashley Hill
MONUMENT_DESC:
Ashley Farm, located immediately to the north of Ashley Hill. The date of the farm is not currently known but it formed part of the Ashley estate, owned by the priory of St. James until its Dissolution in January 1540, and may therefore have a medieval origin. The farm was certainly in existence by 1722 when it was mortgaged by Andrew Hooke, then owner of the Ashley estate (BRO 4964(3)). It was purchased by Edward Ash in the early nineteenth century and his son Richard sold it to John Evans Lunell, a West India merchant, in 1825 (BRO 4964(66-67)). Lunell mortgaged the property to Jacob Wilcox Ricketts in September 1829 (BRO 4964(71)).
John Plumley and George Ashmead's 1828 survey of Bristol indicates that the farm was reached by a lane from the top of Ashley Hill. The main building was a three-storey, five-bay rendered house orientated from north-west to south-east with a pitched slate roof. The majority of the south-west facing elevation was covered by ivy when it was photographed in the 1930s (Winstone 1977, pl.83) but the ground-floor wndows had ashlar dripmoulds. There was a two-storey extension with similar dripmoulds at second-floor level, apparently contemporary, at the north-west end end of the building and a conservatory at the south-east end. There was also a group of outbuildings to the north-west.
By 1881 the farm was known as Ashley Grange. It survived into the twentieth century but was demolished in around 1936 and the site subsequently developed for housing (Winstone 1977, pl.83). The site of the farmhouse now lies beneath the house and garden of No.25 Wathen Road and the garages to the rear.

KNOWN_AS: Reverend Urijah Rees Thomas Memorial Drinking Fountain, Blackboy Hill
MONUMENT_DESC:
Reverend Urijah Rees Thomas Memorial Drinking Fountain, located in a triangular parcel of land between Westbury Road and Stoke Road. The fountain was built in 1904. It is an octagonal structure of red and white granite and red sandstone ashlar, with a tiled, hipped roof surmounted by a square, copper-clad cupola with a clock on each face and a weather vane. Eight polished red granite Roman Doric columns and a central Old Red sandstone column support the roof, and there are four polished red granite basins with lion-head taps on the central column. A polished granite panel on the south side of the fountain carries an inscription commemorating the Reverend Thomas:
"THIS FOUNTAIN / WAS SET UP IN MEMORY OF / THE REV URIJAH REES THOMAS / BY HIS FELLOW CITIZENS OF ALL BELIEFS / IN GRATEFUL RECOGNITION / OF THE CATHOLIC SPIRIT AND GENEROUS ARDOUR / WITH WHICH HE GAVE HIMSELF TO THE PUBLIC SERVICE / AND ESPECIALLY OF HIS WISE AND TENDER CARE / FOR THE CHILDREN OF THE CITY / AND FOR ALL THE FRIENDLESS AND UNHAPPY, / THE DEFENCELESS AND THE POOR. / "THIS COMMANDMENT HAVE WE FROM HIM, THAT HE WHO / LOVETH GOD, LOVE HIS BROTHER ALSO." I JOHN IV 21 / BORN 16TH FEBRUARY 1839 / DIED 8TH MARCH 1901." 
The fountain has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/24/1134).

KNOWN_AS: War memorial at Arno's Vale Cemetery
MONUMENT_DESC:
The war memorial for the First World War, Arno's Vale Cemetery. The memorial was constructed c.1920 and is a central flat-roofed loggia of Bath stone ashlar with five semicircular headed arches with moulded keystones and a plat band. On the internal face of the rear wall of the loggia, there is an arcade of five blind arches with copper panels bearing the names of the fallen. The central arch has an inscription carved into the stone. There are flanking walls on the northern and southern sides of the memorial. The legend "THE GLORIOUS DEAD/A. D. 1914 - 1918" is carved into east face of the southern wall while the northern carries the legend "PROCLAIM THROUGHOUT THIS REALM/YE WHO PASS THIS MONUMENT/THAT WE WHO DIED SERVING HER/REST HERE CONTENT."
The war memorial has a Grade II Listing (Listed Building number 901-1/47/2133).

KNOWN_AS: The tomb of Raja Ram Mohun Roy Bahadoor, Arno's Vale Cemetery
MONUMENT_DESC:
The tomb of Raja Ram Mohun Roy Bahadoor, Arno's Vale Cemetery. Ram Mohum Roy Badahoor was born in Radhanagar, Bengal on 22 May 1772. He worked for the East India Company between 1804 and 1814 and learned Persian and English, which were the official languages of the Company's administrative structure. Roy had a strong interest in religious matters and learned Arabic, Sanskrit, Greek, Latin, and Hebrew to further his studies of the fundamental texts of the great world religions. He held strongly to a monotheistic religious viewpoint, arguing against both Hindu worship of gods and goddesses and the Christian doctrine of the Holy Trinity. In 1828 Roy founded the religious movement Brahmo Samaj (the Society of Brahma), the aim of which was to establish the worship of the Supreme Being. He also sought reform of the caste system and an improvement of the social status of women and children. In particular, with William Carey, he helped to persuade the Governor General of India, William Bentinck, to abolish suttee (the practice of burning a widow on her husband's funeral pyre) in 1829. In 1830, Roy became the envoy of the Emperor of Delhi to England. In April 1831 Roy arrived in England, primarily to witness the renewal of the East India Company charter, but he also attended the coronation of William IV. Roy travelled to Bristol in 1833 to visit Dr. Lant Carpenter, the Minister of the Unitarian Chapel at Lewin's Mead and father of the educational reformer Mary Carpenter. He stayed with other members of the Unitarian congregation at Stapleton but developed symptoms of meningitis and died there on 27 September 1833. His remains were initially interred at Stapleton but were moved to Arno's Vale cemetery in 1843.
The tomb for Ram Muhum Roy at Arno's Vale was commissioned by Dwarkanath Tagore (1794-1846), grandfather of the poet Rabindranath Tagore who had become wealthy through joint business ventures with British traders. It was designed in 1842 by William Prinsep (1794-1874) who had travelled to India as a merchant in 1817 and studied painting there under the artist George Chinnery.
The tomb is designed as an open temple in a Romantic Indian style with a cruciform plan. It is constructed of Limestone ashlar and comprises a high plinth with twelve decorated columns in groups of three at each corner supporting a flat roof. At the centre of the roof there is a tall, square-based, pointed dome with pinnacles at the top and the corners, and stone leaves on the sides. Within the monument there is a rectangular ashlar limestone block with a carved inscription on its south-east face. The inscription reads:
"BENEATH THIS STONE REST THE REMAINS OF / RAJA RAMMOHUN ROY BAHADOOR, / A CONSCIENTIOUS AND STEADFAST BELIEVER IN THE UNITY OF THE GODHEAD, / HE CONSECRATED HIS LIFE WITH ENTIRE DEVOTION TO THE WORSHIP OF THE DIVINE SPIRIT ALONE, / TO GREAT NATURAL TALENTS, HE UNITED THROUGH MASTERY OF SEVERAL LANGUAGES / AND EARLY DISTINGUISHED HIMSELF AS ONE OF THE GREATEST SCHOLARS OF HIS DAY. / HIS UNWEARIED LABOURS TO PROMOTE THE SOCIAL, MORAL AND PHYSICAL CONDITION OF THE / PEOPLE OF INDIA, HIS EARNEST ENDEAVOURS TO SUPPRESS IDOLATRY, AND THE RITE OF SUTTEE / AND HIS CONSTANT ZEALOUS ADVOCACY OF WHATEVER TENDED TO ADVANCE THE GLORY OF / GOD AND THE WELFARE OF MAN LIVE IN THE GREATFUL REMEMBRANCE OF HIS COUNTRYMEN. / THIS TABLET / RECORDS THE SORROW AND PRIDE WITH WHICH HIS MEMORY IS CHERISHED BY HIS DESCENDANTS. / HE WAS BORN AT RADHANAGARE IN BENGAL IN 1774, [sic] / AND DIED AT BRISTOL SEPTEMBER 27TH 1833."
A ceremony is held annually on 27 September at the tomb to commemorate Roy's life.
The tomb has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building No.901-1/47/438).

Earthworks and building remains, Hallen Marsh. The features suggest a deserted farm site at the south-west end of a trackway on Hallen Marsh. A survey of the area of 1773 shows a small enclosure, while the tithe survey of 1841 records a "House, Homestead & Orchard". The farm is shown on the Ordnance Survey maps of 1881 and 1915, and a pond lies to the south-east.
Trial excavation by Glamorgan-Gwent Archaeological Trust in 1991 revealed that the farm buildings were arranged around three sides of a yard. Mortared walls, largely of stone but with later brick additions, were revealed. Floor surfaces were found variously of flags, cobbles or beaten earth. Unstratified post-medieval pottery was found with one medieval sherd. The pond was surveyed. It may have served as part of a fishponds complex. It was partly backfilled but was originally much more substantial. A trial trench was also cut through the shallow bank which enclosed the farm on the south-east. No evidence was found for features associated with the construction of the bank. Pollen preservation was shown to be poor.
The site (Area 1; Site 12) was visited by R. G. Jackson during the course of a desk-based assessment (SMR 20081) of areas of Bristol City Council owned land north of Avonmouth in December 1996. The site is covered by debris, some derived from the farm itself. The pond is extant. A platform measuring approximately 25 metres by 50 metres was observed to the west of the house site.

Royal Edward Pier Station, located on the southern side of the entrance lock to Royal Edward Dock. The station was built to serve the passenger shipping operating from Royal Edward Dock and was opened during the royal visit on 8 July 1908. Regular passenger traffic started on 20 April 1910. The station was a single-storey, four-bay timber structure with a platform enclosed by a shed on the south-west side and connecting waiting rooms. A narrow shed led north to the dock.
The station was bombed during the Second World War and partly destroyed.

Horfield Prison, located to the west of Gloucester Road. Construction of the prison began in 1875 but work was suspended in 1877 after the boundary wall had been completed in anticipation of the passage of the Prisons Act which transferred the administration of all prisons to a new central authority, the Prison Commission. Construction was resumed in 1882, apparently to a new design by the Surveyor of Prisons, Alexander McHardy. The prison is thought to have opened in 1883 although building continued until 1889 (Brodie et al., 2002 150).
The prison held both male and female prisoners until 1921 and had accommodation for 188 men and 60 women. The sexes were separated and the women's access to the chapel, for example, was via a covered passage. There was a four-storey women's wing (now F Wing) and the female hospital and reception block and the laundry (now the "Time" workshop) were attached to this. The male wing (now A/G Wing) was a four-storey brick structure with the administration block and chapel at its east end. This is a two-storey structure in an Italianate style with a central arched entrance reached by steps and a square tower at the south-eastern corner (Brodie et al., 2002 150-157). The prison appears to have been extended at its eastern end at some time after the First World War. The National Monuments Record holds a file on Horfield Prison (NMR File No. 93741).

Richmond House, located on the northern side of Lower Clifton Hill. The house was constructed around the end of seventeenth centuy and is a three storey, five-bay rendered building of Brandon Hill Grit in a random rubble construction with limestone dressings. It has a pitched pantile roof with large chimney stacks at either end.
The house was likely to have been constructed as a lodge or summerhouse (ie a merchant's second residence). A lease of 1701 to Whitchurch Phippen calls the house the "Old Castle" and required Phippen to spend £350 on the building within three years. The Freeman family owned the property in eighteenth century and were required to make the house and kitchen available for two days each year for the manorial court. In the 1790s William Sewell ran a boarding school for young gentlemen in the house. Mr J. K. Bragge (one of the honorary secretaries of the Merchant Seamen's Bible Society for the Port of Bristol) also had a boarding school for boys in the building in the 1840s.
Survey of the north-east facing elevation (SMR 21074) recorded three blocked window openings and found that the wall was constructed in Brandon Hill Grit (Pilkington 2002).
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/14/791).

Lockleaze Farm, located on the east side of Lockleaze Lane. The farm was created in the second half of the nineteenth century. It is not shown by the tithe survey of Horfield but is recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.05) published in 1881. At that date the farm comprised a single building, presumably the farmhouse, on the south side of the plot and a range 65 metres long to the north. The farm survived into the mid-1930s but it was subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped for housing.
The site of the farmhouse now lies in the gardens to the rear of Nos.76-80 Bonnington Walk. The other buildings of the farm extend from No.74 Bonnington Walk, across the road to No.79 Bonnington Walk.

Hope Chapel, Hope Chapel Hill, Hotwells. Lady Glenorchy laid plans for the construction of a Calvinist evangelical chapel which was to be a memorial to Lady Henrietta Hope. The chapel was built by her executors between 1786 and 1788, and was possibly designed by Daniel Hague. The first minister described the chapel as "a plain structure with small doors, small windows and plastered walls" (Stell 1986, 63). An organ was installed by John Smith junior of the Brisotl organ builders John Smith and Sons in 1838, and this was refurbished by the the local firm of W. G. Vowles in 1886.
Attendance declined as a result of the founding of a new congregation at the Pembroke Chapel although services were still being held in the 1970s. The chapel is of stone rubble construction with ashlar dressings. In 1838 the chapel was extended at the rear, the windows were replaced and the roof apparently reconstructed (Stell 1986, 63-64). The seating was replaced in the late-nineteenth century (Stell 1986, 63).
The chapel has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/13/1437).

Horfield Rectory, located on the southern side of Wellington Hill. The plot within which the rectory stands was removed from Horfield Common between 1823 and 1825. Construction of the building was agreed on 19 March 1825, with the necessary funds being met by the imcumbent of the parish, the Rev. Samuel Seyer (£50), Bishop Newton's Fund (£350), the Governors of Queen Anne's Bounty (£600). The leaseholder of the manor Mr Shadwell gave an additional £50 on the condition that the roof of the building was slate. The rectory was completed on 25 August 1825.
The building is a rendered two-storey, five bay house with a hipped slate roof. The main entrance is at the centre of the main, north-west facing, elevation. The fenestration consists of sashes. There are large chimneystacks at either end of the roof. On the north-western side of the rectory there are two single-storey stone rubble outbuildings.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/53/1414).

Limekilns at Redcatch Road. Two limekilns were located on the southern side of Redcatch Lane. The limekilns are recorded by the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.07) published in 1886 as part of an L-shaped structure measuring roughly 10 metres from north to south by 12 metres east-west. The kilns were still extant in the early twentieth century but were subsequently demolished and the site redeveloped.

Greenbank cemetery. The cemetery was established by the Burial Board for the parish of St. Philip and Jacob and was opened 1871. The entrance gates were on Rose Green Road and Greenbank Road, with a lodge adjacent to the Greenbank Road entrance. A pair of mortuary chapels (SMR 20112), designed in a Gothic style by Henry Masters, was built at the centre of the site. The mortuary chapels and are constructed of squared Pennant sandstone rubble with polychrome limestone ashlar details and have pitched slate roofs.
The cemetery was expanded in 1881 and the Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500-scale County Series plan indicates that the cemetery then covered an area of 8.2 hectares The cemetery was transferred to the Bristol Corporation under the Bristol Corporation Act of 1895. It was expanded again in c.1900.
There are several war graves within the cemetery and a Cross of Sacrifice, or Great War cross, (SMR 20113) was erected immediately to the south-west of the mortuary chapels after the First World War.
The mortuary chapels have a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/38/1258). The entrance gates and piers to the cemetery on Greenbank Road have a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/38/1257).

Memorial walls at Greenbank Cemetery (centred on ST 61624 74560). The memorial is located to the north-west of the lodge at the entrance of the cemetery. It consists of a paved area sloping from north-west to south-east which is reached from the road to the chapel by a flight of four steps. On the paved surface are four brick walls with Portland stone bases and coping, each carrying three consecutively numbered inscribed marble panel on either side (1-23 in all). The panels record the names of those killed during the Second World War who are buried in the cemetery and are orientated to face south-south-west towards the lodge at the entrance of the cemetery.
The central (unnumbered) panel on the easternmost wall carries the inscription "1914-1918 1939-1945 THOSE HONOURED HERE DIED IN THE SERVICE OF THEIR COUNTRY AND LIE BURIED ELSEWHERE IN THIS CEMETERY". Panel 19 on the south-south-west face of the easternmost wall records the names of service personnel buried elsewhere in Bristol; panels 20-23 are blank.

POSTAL_ADDRESS: The Old Council House, Corn Street
MONUMENT_DESC:
Old Council House, located on the north-western side of Corn Street. The building was constructed as a Council chamber and treasurer's office between 1824 and 1827 to a design by Sir Robert Smirke. The sculpture on the building was by E. H. Baily. Extended 1828 by R. S. Pope and G. Dymock. Limestone ashlar with Pennant ashlar plinth, roof not visible. Neoclassical style. 2 storeys, attic and basement; 5-window range, with a 2-storey, 3-window left-hand extension. 
The Council House is symmetrical with a plinth to a moulded band, articulated above by giant pilasters to an entablature, the end window sections set back, and the centre recessed between giant fluted Ionic columns; a mid C20 attic storey behind outer balustrades, tall panelled parapets and recessed centre with a statue of Justice. 
Steps up to a large doorway, 2-leaf doors with 6 flush panels with roundels; windows with 6/6-pane sashes. Parapet sections flanking the centre have raised heraldic panels, and 2 attic windows flank the statue. The right return has a symmetrical 5-window range with end sections set forward between pilasters, 4 low basement windows have 8/8-pane sashes. 
To the left in Corn Street, the former Treasurer's Office is symmetrical with a plinth and cornice. Distyle Greek Doric columns to the entrance, with an entablature with triglyphs and cornice to a recessed doorway, now a window with ashlar panel beneath the cill; windows have 6/6-pane sashes. Low basement windows have grilles. 
Inside, wide entrance and stair hall with dogleg stair; first-floor rear former Council Chamber; basement with semicircular-arched tunnel vaults. 
Housed the Council House and offices until relocation to College Green after the Second World War, and after used as crown courts. The Treasurer's Office was added when the House was found to provide insufficient space.

Odeon Theatre, a cinema located on the western side of Union Street. The building was designed by T. Cecil Howitt and opened on 16 July 1938, having cost £57,600 to construct. It had 1945 seats, 1051 in the stalls and another 894 in the balcony. The cinema had a corner entrance with a circular tower above which contained five recessed windows. The entrance foyer was circular and there was an octagonal double-height foyer which was apparently unique amongst Odeon cinemas. A promenade at first-floor level led to the balcony (Eyles 2002, 186-189). The cinema was damaged by bombing on 3 December 1940 and closed briefly, re-opening on 17 December 1940. In 1967 the building was modernised and it was converted to three screens in May 1974, with 844 seats in the former balcony and 108 and 103 in the former stalls. The cinema was closed again in October 1983 for redevelopment of the interior to a design by the architect Donald Armstrong of Downton & Hurst. A new shop was created in the ground floor and the entrance moved to the side. The cinema reopened on 13 June 1985 with three screens seating 400, 225 and 215 respectively (Eyles 2002, 249-250). The building is currently (23/04/2002) still in use as a cinema.

Bush Warehouse, located at the south end of Narrow Quay. The building was a tea warehouse, apparently replacing part of a terrace of early-Georgian houses, which was constructed in c.1832 for Acraman, Bush, Castle and Co. to a design by R. S. Pope. The warehouse was a five-storey structure of coursed Pennant sandstone rubble. The ground-floor was vermiculated Pennant sandstone with a limestone ashlar plat band separating ground- from the upper-floors, and an ashlar cornice. The original structure was of six bays but the warehouse was extended in 1835-1837 when another three bays were added. The building was occupied by James and Robert Bush in the 1880s and by c.1900 a grain elevator had been added to the roof on the west side of the building, with several pipes running from it downwards into the roof to distribute the grain. After the First World War the grain elevator was removed and the building was used to store tobacco in bond.
By the early 1970s the building was empty and in 1972 it was acquired jointly by the Arnolfini art gallery and JT Building Group. Between 1973 and 1975 the building was gutted, a new steel frame inserted and offices and gallery space created in the building. A new glazed roof was also added. A substantial refurbishment and reorganisation of the internal space was undertaken between September 2003 and 10 September 2005 when the building reopened.
In 1973 a small archaeological excavation inside the building was directed by Roger Price (BUAD 473) and works to the basement in 2004 were also subject to archaeological monitoring (BUAD 4074). Both fieldwork exercises recorded evidence for the shipyard which previously occupied the site.
The building has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building number 901-1/42/190).

KNOWN_AS: Possible eighteenth-century bath house, Crew's Hole Road
MONUMENT_DESC:
The extant remains of an octagonal structure, possibly a bath house, of eighteenth-century date located on the north side of an eighteenth-century garden [SMR 8447] at Crew's Hole. The structure, recorded c.1990 by James Russell of Bristol and Avon Archaeological Society, and was terraced into the slope of the hill running south to Crew's Hole Road. It measures approximately 5 metres across and stands approximately 5 metres high. The building has a tall single-storey facade with a lancet doorway flanked by pilasters and rusticated with slag blocks. Above the doorway is a round panel and a ramped parapet. Inside, a small porch with niches to the sides leads to an octagonal chamber with a domed roof. There are shallow niches in the sides and a deeper niche with a blocked roof at the back. The ceiling is pierced by 4 brick-lined round openings. The structure is built of Pennant sandstone in a rubble construction. The remains of an "oval stone-revetted tank measuring 4.3 m[etres] from east to west and 2.8m from north to south" were recorded on the hillside to the north-west of the bath house, and this was interpreted as a cistern to feed the bath (Russell 1990/91, 52). Russell suggests that the structure and its associated garden may be attributable to William Reeve, the builder of Arno's Court (ibid., 53).
The structure was overgrown at the time of Russell's survey; the structure has a Grade II listing and was identified as at risk in the 1991 English Heritage Survey. Its current condition is not known.

Engine House, also known as the Old Fire Engine House, located on the eastern side of Hollywood Road, Brislington. The structure was built as a colliery engine house in c.1790 and is of three storeys with a steeply pitched roof and a single chimneystack. The bob or beam opening was at the Hollywood Road end of the building, implying that the shaft was located between the building and the road.
The coal industry in Brislington was in decline and the building was out of use by 1820. The Brislington Tithe Survey of 1846 records the site as a house, yard and carpenter's shop leased jointly from the owner, William Gore-Langton, by Thomas Portch and Hester Phillips. The tenant was Thomas Hillier. In 1881, John Jeffries carried on a carpentry and wheelwright business from the building.  By 1890, Alfred Sims was the occupier and ran a dairy from the premises. In 1904 the property was purchased by Edward Richards who farmed at Emery Farm, Brislington, and he continued to operate a dairy from the the premises until 1909 when he sold the property. The property is a private house.

Upper Pen Park also known as Pen Park Manor House. The building was recorded by a plan of the parish of Westbury-on-Trym by Sturges in 1817 (Northampton Record Office Plan 616) and was still extant in the 1930s according to the 1935 edition of the Ordnance Survey plan of the area (Gloucestershire Sheet LXVII.16). The site of the house is now within Filton golf course, some 150 metres to the north of Pen Park School.

Southmead Manor House, Southmead. The manor of Southmead was owned by the Nunnery of St. Mary Magdalene, located at the foot of St. Michael's Hill, in Bristol. The manor was possibly part of the property endowed on the monastery by its founder Eva Fitzhardinge in 1173. The manor house was extant by the early fourteenth-century. At dissolution in 1536 the manor was acquired by the Haynes family and then passed through several hands (Boore 1995, 5). It was acquired by Joshua James, a Bristol distiller, who made "great improvements" to the building according to Samuel Rudder in his history of Gloucestershire (Rudder 1779, 803). The Westbury tithe map of 1841 shows the manor house as an extensive range of buildings surrounded by outbuildings and with a large pond (possibly a former millpond) to the south-east.
The manor house and estate was bought by Dr. Stanley Badock in the late nineteenth-century. Badock laid out the gardens (SMR 20100). Southmead Road was created c.1903, dividing the Manor House from its outbuildings and the site of the pond; these now lie beneath, and on the south side of, the road. The manor house was sold again a few years later and rebuilt in 1912, although it is reported that several features were retained during the work (Boore 1995, 6). A sale document of 1926 refers to lawns, kitchen gardens, orchards, outbuildings, and a 70 foot long swimming pool (Boore 1995, 9). Boore reports that a "wet" cellar or possible ice-house lies beneath the entrance to the building, with access below the nursery doorway. The property was owned by the Courtney family from the late 1930s until the 1980s. The plot was then broken up and the gardens divorced from the main house. The present building is in use as a children's nursery (February 1995). It appears from the modern Ordnance Survey 1:1250 Landline plan that the northern buildings of the (?eighteenth-century) manor house were sited to the north of the present building, the site of No.149 Southmead Road.

Horfield Barracks, located on the eastern side of modern Filton Road. A field in Horfield named "West Bartholomew Leaze" was bought by the War Office in 1843 to construct a new barracks in response to the rioting in Queen Square in 1831 and more generally to a perceived threat to civil order from Chartism (Douet, 1988 112).
The foundation stone of Horfield barracks was laid on 3 June 1845. Construction was completed and the site brought into commission on 26 April 1847, at a cost of £57000. The barracks occupied a large rectangular parcel of land measuring some 260 metres from north-west to south-east by 170 metres. It was enclosed by a massive exterior wall of sandstone ashlar which, following the design principles of trace italienne, had bastions at the ends and the centre of the southern side. The barracks could accommodate four companies of infantry and two cavalry troops. Internally, the buildings were arranged around a central parade ground and included quarters for the infantry soldiers and cavalry troopers, quarters for officers together with ancillary buildings.
A garrison church (SMR 3209), designed by the architect William Butterfield (who also worked on Horfield Church and designed Highbury Chapel), was constructed immediately to the south.
