New buildings were constructed inside the barracks in 1873 and the field on the opposite side of Filton Road was acquired as a camping area for the Gloucestershire militia.
From 1881 until 1940 the barracks was the main training depot for the Gloucestershire Regiment. The Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucestershire Sheet LXXII.05) published in 1903 suggests that an infant school for the barracks had been built to the north-west of the garrison church by the end of the nineteenth century.
The barracks was taken out of use after the Second World War and the barracks was demolished in 1966. Office buildings were constructed within the site and there was some associated reduction of the ground level. Most of the original buildings associated with the barracks appear to have been demolished at this time. However, the barracks wall which surrounded the site is largely extant, particularly in the north-west corner and on the south side of the site where it appeared to be intact. In other locations, particularly on the north side of the barracks, the wall has been significantly reduced in height. Two War Department boundary stones recorded by the Ordnance Survey second edition 1:2500 plan survive on the Filton Road frontage.
The barracks chapel is also extant and has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/53/1411).

A round barrow on Kingsweston Hill. The monument was excavated in 1924 by E. K. Tratman. Round barrow was 10 feet in diameter by 1 foot high. Finds in University of Bristol Spelaeological Society Museum include a single fragment of burnt human bone from near the centre of the barrow, a possible quartzite hammer-stone and a portion of a Roman mortarium. Tratman says the barrows (SMR 784, 785, 786) on Kingsweston Hill are Iron Age although in a later volume he describes this barrow as probably Roman. Green briefly reviewed the dating evidence available for the barrows at Kingsweston Hill in considering a cairn he had excavated at Tickenham. On the basis of a re-examination of Tratman's pottery finds, which appeared to be from collared urns, Green concluded that "in the absence of any structural grounds for considering the Kings Weston Hill barrows to be of Iron Age date" the Kingsweston barrows were of Early Bronze Age origin (Green 1972-73, 43-44). Tratman replied to Green's reinterpretation, arguing that the interpretation of the pottery as Iron Age was questionable, the monuments had not necessarily been disturbed to any great extent in antiquity and that the argument that absence of structural grounds for an Iron Age date leads to the inference of a date in the Early Bronze Age was "highly specious". Tratman concluded that there was no good reason to redate the Kingsweston barrows until fresh evidence became available (Tratman 1975, 56-57).

KNOWN_AS: Church of St. Mary the Virgin, Henbury
MONUMENT_DESC:
Church of St. Mary the Virgin, Henbury located at the south end of Church Close, off Henbury Road. A church is believed to have been built on the site in the Saxon period. No fabric pre-dating the Norman Conquest of 1066 is believed to remain within the structure, and it was apparently substantially rebuilt in the second half of the twelfth century when a new nave was created. The chancel was rebuilt in the 1280s. The nave retains wome evidence for fire damage but this is undated and it is not clear if it was related to the late-thirteenth century building. The fabric of the tower has been dated to the sixteenth- and seventeenth centuries and it contains a peal of eight bells, the bells having been cast between 1717 and 1897.
The church was altered by the architectural practice of Thomas Rickman (1776-1841) and Henry Hutchinson (1800-1831) in the 1830s (who had designed several churches nationally and also St. John's College, Cambridge). Their changes were not considered successful, however, and the architect George E. Street (1824-1881) carried out further restoration work between 1874 and 1877. Several of the windows were reglazed with stained glass in the later nineteenth century, though John Harford donated some Flemish glazing dating to the sixteenth century, which is now in the vestry. A new organ was built between 1876 and 1878 by the Bristol-based firm of W. G. Vowles. Within the church there is a brass plaque commemorating the parishioners who were killed during the Second World War (1939-1945).
The church had chapels-at-ease within the parish at Northwick, Aust and Compton Greenfield.
The church has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building Number 901-1/17/1323).

Holy Trinity Church, Westbury-on-Trym. Dawson suggests that it is likely that the church stands on the site of a Saxon minster. He also notes that the plan of the nave and chancel are irregular and therefore "may reflect the survival of part of the pre-conquest building in the present structure" (Dawson 1981, 20). The south aisle dates to the thirteenth century.
The majority of the church was rebuilt in the fifteenth century, changes including the reconstruction of the tower and the insertion of a clerestorey with "unusually small windows" in the nave (Gomme et. al. 1979, 68).
An organ was built by John Smith senior of the Bristol organ builders John Smith and Sons in 1824. Under the then incumbent, Revd. William Cartwright, the church was restored in 1851 and heating ducts inserted, the boiler house being located in Bishop Carpenter's crypt beneath the chancel. In 1852-53 the architect John Norton was commissioned to design a new vestry at the north-east corner of the building and galleries for children within the tower and on its north side. The galleries were served by stairs against the north wall of the tower. With the alterations the church could accommodate 979 worshippers. There were 389 appropriated settings, 350 free sittings on the ground floor and the galleries and 199 seats for children in the galleries.
The building has a Grade I listing (Listed Building Number 901-1/26/2047).

KNOWN_AS: Mission Church of St. John the Divine, Lodge Causeway
MONUMENT_DESC:
Mission Church of St. John the Divine, also known as the "Old Hall", located on the south-western side of Lodge Causeway. The church was purchased by the Chester Park mission in 1894 from Peasedown St. John in Somerset, where it had originally been erected in 1874. The church stood on Lodge Causeway frontage, adjacent to the junction with Mayfield Park, and was orientated at right-angles to the street. It was a structure of timber and iron which measured 28 metres from north to south and was 8 metres wide. The church had a six-bay nave with a transept at its south-western end. There was an entrance porch at the east end with a rose window in the gable of the east wall above. There was an elaborate fleche near the centre of the roof. Internally the pews occupied the full width of the nave and a highly-decorated Gothic rood screen stood in front of the high altar.
A new church (SMR 22451) was built on the adjacent site in 1910-1911 to provide a parish church and the mission church become the parish hall and retained that function until 1930 when a new hall was built. The building was then leased to the local Education Committee to serve as a dining hall for children. During the Second World War it became a "British Restaurant" and after the war reverted to use as a school dining hall and classrooms until 1957. The building retained a community use until it was demolished in c1970.

Hillcrest, located on the northern side of Bell Hill, Stapleton. The building is a two-storey rendered house with a steeply-pitched clay pantile roof and a stair tower at the centre of the rear, north-west facing, elevation. It is constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble with a rendered finish and appears to date to at least the seventeenth century.
Works were undertaken to the main, south-east facing, elevation to Bell Hill in the eighteenth century. This elevation is now of three bays with the main entrance door sited at the west end of the elevation. Above the door opening is a flat canopy supported on scrolled brackets the opening itself contains a four-panel door with an overlight. The fenestration consists of six-over-six pane sash windows.
A further phase of alteration was undertaken in the mid-1990s when internal alterations were made and the first-floor windows were replaced. Structural repairs were made to the roof in 1999 and the attic was altered at the same time.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/33/1942).

A sub-rectangular ditched enclosure to the south of Severn Road, Chittening (NGR ST 53299 81787). The site was identified by R. G. Jackson during the course of a desk-based assessment (SMR 20081) of areas of Bristol City Council owned land north of Avonmouth in December 1996. It was first recorded by the tithe survey in 1841 and is shown by the 1881 and 1915 Ordnance Survey maps as being occupied by an orchard. The enclosure itself measures approximately 51 metres by 53 metres by 50 metres by 23 metres. The site was visited and it was found that water-filled ditches surround the enclosure (those to the north-west and south-east having been partially filled in to allow access by a trackway). The enclosed area is considerably higher than the surrounding farmland, and there is evidence there of both banks and a brick structure.

No.49/50 Broad Street, latterly known as Hort's. Attached house of c.1770. Ground floor of c.1854, possibly by Foster and Wood. Brick above with limestone dressings, lateral stacks and a double Roman hipped mansard roof. Double-depth plan. 3 storeys, attic and cellars; 4-window range. A ground-floor arcade of 3 segmental arches with granite columns and responds with foliate capitals. Pilasters above to a cornice and parapet; 2 dormers. Extensive cellars; at the front are two probably 15th.century cellars (1020A), with, at their rear, a four-centred arched doorway. In 1821 the ground-floor lacked the arcade, but had a plat band above it; sashes to first and second floors (BRSMG M2434).
An eighteenth-century house constituted on the first floor of a full width parlour backed by a stair opening onto a landing facing a blind arch with stucco work ornament. Back rooms include two using borrowed light gained through transom lit doorways (now removed) and a passage leading back to two second floor service building chambers. Of note are the surviving finishes related to service uses on the second floor and in the garret. The dwelling also includes evidence for a shedded piazza linking main block to kitchen on the ground floor and a compact open yard between the house proper and the back service building.

No.90 Redcliff Street, located on the western side of Redcliff Street. The building was a terraced house of medieval date.
The north wall of was recorded during the excavation of No.91 Redcliff Street by R. H. Jones in 1983 (BUAD 447). This section of wall aligned east-west with plain walling at the east end, beyond which was an arcade of three arches (1000A). At least the westernmost two were visible on both sides of the wall. The arches consisted of Pennant Sandstone voussoirs only - there was no decorative stonework. On the northern face, between the springings for the second and third arches, was a carved head, interpreted as a corbel. Excavation down the north side of the arcade was carried out, showing that the pier between the first two arches continued for more than a metre below the modern ground level.

No.44, Mary-le-Port Street. A house of seventeenth-century date located on the southern side of Mary-le-Port Street. In the principal room on the first-floor were some fragments of a plaster ceiling (sketched by Samuel Loxton) which was, according to Pritchard "The semi-figure of an angel within a scroll was used at one of the four corners of the principal ceiling and fleur de lys mouldings were freely introduced into the design of another ceiling on the same level" (Pritchard 1922, 88). There was an ornately carved stone chimney-piece (BUAD 1002A) reported to be of Ham Hill stone. It measured approximately 8 feet by 6 feet and carried the arms of the Cordwainers Company of London (Pritchard 1922, 90-92).
John Pritchard visited the building before its demolition and recorded some features of the building (BUAD 674), describing the exterior as "plain and unattractive" (Pritchard 1922, 88). Pritchard also noted that the ground-floor had been subject to much alteration, although a short element of the original staircase survived "on the upper floor".
The building was demolished, along with No.45 St. Mary-le-Port Street on it western side, between April and August 1920, to make way for the construction of new premises for Messrs. Stevens Bros. Ltd., Provision Merchants. The chimneypiece was recovered and sold by the contractor to a local dealer, then to London, and finally making its way to New York.

No.19a Orchard Street, also known as Orchard Villa and Orchard Chambers. The building is located at the north-eastern end of Orchard Street and is a two-storey house with a cellar of early nineteenth-century date. The building stands in an elevated position with its own railed yard reached by steps from Orchard Street to the front. The main, north-west facing, elevation is rendered and has a central entrance surrounded by an ashlar moulding with a single bay on either side, reflecting a simple plan with a room on either side of the entrance hall. There is a full-height bay window to the south of the doorway with an ashlar base and sills. It contains a central three-by-four pane sash and narrow two-by-four pane sashes in the sides. The window to the north of the door is also a three-by-four pane sash. Ground is divided from first-floor by an ashlar string course and there was a parapet above an ashlar cornice. Internally several early nineteenth-century features survive including chimneypieces in most of the ground- and first-floor rooms, although the main ground-floor room was redecorated around the end of the nineteenth century and the cornice and chimneypiece are of that date. The newel posts of the stair, which is located at the northern corner of the building, also appears to date to the early nineteenth century. Extensions have been added to the rear of the building by knocking through the rear wall of the building. At the south corner of the building there was a strongroom constructed of brick with a steel door made by Gardiners and possibly dating to the same time as the decoration of the main ground-floor room. Access to the cellar is by steps from a door adjacent to the stair. The cellar walls are of stone rubble with a brick vault in the eastern part.
In 1875 the building known as Orchard Villa and was recorded in the street directory as being occupied by Henry M. Morrish.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/15/154). Photographs of the building are held in the SMR collection of Ground-based photographs (nos.1612-1634 inclusive).

KNOWN_AS: Memorial to the 79th Regiment, Clifton Down
MONUMENT_DESC:
The memorial to the 79th Regiment, Clifton Down. The war memorial, built of Portland stone, was erected in 1766 by Lieutenant-General Sir William Draper (1721-1787) in the garden of Manilla Hall, Draper's home, to commemorate the role of the regiment he commanded in the campaigns of the Seven Years War (1759-1762), including an expedition which captured Manila from the Spanish in October 1762 (Dreaper 1998, 1; 8-9).
The monument is a sarcophagus with scrolled brackets at the corners surmounted by an urn with a flame and set on a rectangular plinth with angle buttresses. It is constructed of Portland stone with purple slate plaque set in the south-east face. A Latin inscription on the monument was drafted by the poet Christopher Anstey (1724-1805), a friend of Draper (Dreaper 1998, 11). The memorial was removed to its present position in 1882, after the intervention of Dr. John Beddoe (1826-1911), former President of the Anthropological Institute and a local antiquary, when the construction of Manilla Road threatened its destruction (Merritt 2002, 18-19; Parker 1914, 8).
The memorial has a Grade II* listing (Listed Building No. 901-1/7/755) and is described in the listing as "a very early war memorial."

Oakenhill Farm, Brislington. A seventeenth-century gabled farmhouse and surrounding grounds. The farm is recorded by the tithe survey of Brislington parish of 1846. Outbuildings are shown to the west of the farmhouse, apparently forming a D-shaped complex, only part of which now survives. An outbuilding is also shown in the area of an orchard to the east of the farmhouse.
The exterior of the house is currently (11/7/97) rendered, so the construction technique is not certain, but it is probably stone-built. Inside the house is panelling, door and hinges of seventeenth-century date. The farmhouse has a Grade II listing (Listed Building No. 901-1/41/445).
In the grounds surrounding the farmhouse are traditional stone-built outbuildings (possibly dating to the same period as the farmhouse) and the remains of an orchard lying to the east of the house. The building shown by the tithe map is no longer extant. There are also (unlisted) cottages (SMR 20150) to the south, which may be of eighteenth-century date.
The site was visited by L. Bingle of the City Centre Projects and Urban Design Team, Directorate of Planning, Transport and Development Services, Bristol City Council on the 9th July 1997 and the extant panelling and door observed.
The Farm became part of the Clayfield-Ireland estate around 1790 when the farm and associated cottages were known as "Oakenhills". George Vowles is recorded as the tenant from 1866 to 1879 followed by a Mr. Adams.  From 1910 the farm was run by Ted Brean of "Woodbine Farm", Water Lane although the farmhouse remained unoccupied.  When the Clayfield-Ireland estate was broken up in 1925, the farm was run by Gordon and Harry Carey with the farmhouse being  let separately to a succession of tenants.

T Farm, located some 380 metres to the north of Avonmouth Road. The farm was part of the Kings Weston Estate, owned in the mid-nineteenth cenutry by Philip W. S. Miles and it was in existence by the time of the tithe survey of the Shirehampton tithing of the parish of Westbury-on-Trym in 1840. The Ordnance Survey first edition 1:2500 plan (Gloucester Sheet LXXI.02) published in 1881 records the farm as "T Farm". The farm survived into the second half of the twentieth century and was acquired, along with seven surrounding fields, from the then owners, W. H. Goodwin and D. H. N. Squires by the City of Bristol at the beginning of April 1962 (BRO 16859(7-8)). It was subsequently demolished. The site of the farm now lies beneath a warehouse on the east side of First Way, immediately to the north of the M5 motorway.

KNOWN_AS: Bank Stores and Rose Cottage, Wick Road, Brislington
MONUMENT_DESC:
The properties now known as Bank Stores and Rose Cottage, Wick Road, Brislington were in existance by the time of the Ordnance Survey 1:2500 plan (Somerset Sheet VI.04) published in 1890. The properties appear as semi-detached buildings within a large triangular plot of land fronting Wick Road. 
The buildings largely survive though much altered and are constructed of Pennant sandstone rubble.
The front of the original triangular plot has largely been lost due to widening of Wick Road and the construction of the twentieth century properties to the east. The west boundary has probably been set back when the modern Langton Road was created, although the northern boundary wall along the back lane to the rear of the properties appears to be original.

A round barrow on Kingsweston Hill. The monument is 36 feet in diameter by 18 inches high with no ditch. It was excavated in 1924 by Tratman. A child's tooth was the only human remains. Two small bronze flakes, possibly part of a blade-like implement was taken by Tratman to indicate a Bronze age date for the original interment, but in his general conclusions he states that this and other barrows (SMR 761; 783; 784) are Iron Age in date. A few potsherds found in the barrow were dated by the British Museum as transitional Bronze Age/Iron Age. Other finds include a Roman blue glass bead, part of a Saxon bronze fitting, dated to about 600 AD. All finds are in the University of Bristol Spelaeological Society Museum. Though inconclusive, the excavations suggest a late Bronze Age date for the barrow, with other material in a secondary position. Green briefly reviewed the dating evidence available for the barrows at Kingsweston Hill in considering a cairn he had excavated at Tickenham. On the basis of a re-examination of Tratman's pottery finds, which appeared to be from collared urns, Green concluded that "in the absence of any structural grounds for considering the Kings Weston Hill barrows to be of Iron Age date" the Kingsweston barrows were of Early Bronze Age origin (Green 1972-73, 43-44). Tratman replied to Green's reinterpretation, arguing that the interpretation of the pottery as Iron Age was questionable, the monuments had not necessarily been disturbed to any great extent in antiquity and that the argument that absence of structural grounds for an Iron Age date leads to the inference of a date in the Early Bronze Age was "highly specious". Tratman concluded that there was no good reason to redate the Kingsweston barrows until fresh evidence became available (Tratman 1975, 56-57).

Crenellated arch at Cotham Grove. The arch was constructed in the early-eighteenth century as part of an avenue of trees (SMR 21899) leading from Cotham Road to Redland Court (SMR 3973) and framed the house from Cotham Road while terminating the view from the house to the south-east. It is not currently (23/03/2004) clear whether the arch is of the same date as Redland Court or was constructed as part of Thomas Paty's scheme for the addition of pavilions to the house. It was not recorded by Jean Rocque's 1742 plan of Bristol but was, however, in existence by April 1746 when it was drawn by James Stewart (SMR 21901). The arch consisted of a central segmental arch with ashlar voussoirs and a cornice with crenellations above. On the north-east and south-west sides were flanking walls (without crenellation) reaching to the height of the springing of the central arch. These were terminated with two rusticated square columns with pyramidal heads. Between the rusticated bands there were narrow slits. The arch was orientated from south-west to north-east and was approximately 20 metres long and appears to have been around four metres high. It was still in existence in the late 1820s and was recorded by John Plumley and George Ashmead's 1828 plan of Bristol as a "castellated arch" (SMR 21900). The arch had been demolished by the early 1880s and its site now lies mainly beneath the highway of Cotham Grove.

Eastville Park. A large late nineteenth-century municipal park. The main area of land for the park was bought by the Corporation from Sir Greville Smyth in February 1889, although further land purchases took place from 1893 to 1963 (Hillary Taylor Landscape Associates, 2008, 27). The design for the park was carried out by Frederick Ashmead, the Sanitary Authority Surveyor (ibid, 28). Between 1889 and 1892 paths were laid out and a bandstand erected.

There is a large lake on the north side of the park (centred on ST 61597 75451). This was created in 1908-9 and was excavated by unemployed men contracted by the Distress Committee's Labour Bureau (Hillary Taylor Landscape Associates, 2008, 30).

During the Second World War a barrage balloon was tethered in the park necessitating the removal of the bandstand and a searchlight cluster (3228M) was created close to the site of the existing play area.

The park is of some importance as the largest of Bristol's nineteenth-century municipal parks (Avon Gardens Trust 1991, 18; Lambert 2000, 40-44).

St. George's Park. The creation of a public park in St. George was suggested in 1890, and by 1894 the Urban District Council had acquired Fire Engine Farm as a site. Later a parcel of land was bought from Whitehall Colliery. There was an informal opening on 18 July 1894 after which designs for the layout of the park were invited. The winning design was that submitted by T. Lawrence Lewis. This had as its main feature a lake around which paths were set, with straight walks focusing on a central bandstand. Originally this was planted with Chestnut trees but these failed to establish themselves and within a few years were replaced with London Planes. A wrought iron fence 5 feet 6 inches high surrounded the park. In 1897 the Bristol Corporation took over the park and completed the laying out, which was apparently progressing slowly because of financial restrictions. The bowling green was completed in 1907-08. A cannon was positioned immediately inside the main entrance. The cannon was probably removed during the Second World War and the bandstand in 1958 (Lambert 2000, 54-60).

The Cottage, lcoated on the western side of Penpole Place, Shirehampton. The building is a two-storey, five-bay house with a pitched pantile roof. It is constructed of random stone rubble. The main entrance doorway is at the centre of the elevation and above it there is a large sash window in an arched opening. The remaining fenestration comprises sashes. There are two small dormers with flat roofs above the eaves of the roof and chimneystacks at either end of the ridge.
The building has a Grade II listing (Listed Building number 901-1/18/1775).
